title: 6 Czechoslovak Catholics Sentenced to Prison
description: A Czechoslovak court yesterday sentenced six Catholics to prison terms of up to three years on charges of illegally publishing and distributing religious literature for profit, dissident sources said today.

title: Market Place; Picking Out The Bargains
description: ONE result of the prolonged bear market: The battered shares of many exceptionally profitable companies are now selling at levels well below those of the average company.

title: Chairman to Retire At Union Carbide
description: William S. Sneath, 55 years old, who joined the Union Carbide Corporation 31 years ago as an accountant, said yesterday that he will retire as chairman and chief executive officer on Jan.1.

title: STEEP LOAN RATES CITED
description: High interest rates and purchase prices have slowed the sales of cooperative and condominium apartments in New York City, particularly among the middle class, according to real estate industry officials.

title: REDS DEFEAT ASTROS, ARE HALF-GAME OUT
description: Mario Soto scattered five hits over eight innings, then got relief help from Tom Hume as the Reds defeated Houston, 5-2, last night in Cincinnati and moved to a half-game back of the first-place Astros in the National League's Western Divison.

title: Japan Gold Imports Off
description: Japan's gold imports, excluding coins, fell sharply to 5.46 tons in August from a monthly record 22.30 tons in July, according to custom-cleared trade figures released today. The low imports last month were attributed to the fact importers bought a large amount of gold in July when the price fell below $400 an ounce briefly.

title: Article 033884 -- No Title
description: A $5 million pavilion, the first major construction at the Huntington Library, Art Gallery and Botanical Gardens in more than 60 years, will be opened to the public tomorrow.

title: FINDING STEREO COMPONENTS TO FIT NARROW SHELVING
description: IN small apartments, with space at a premium, listeners are often at a loss where to stash their stereos. Standard-size components rarely fit standard-size bookshelves.

title: FRASER MORTGAGE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $181,000 for the qr and $515,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss and includes a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $68,000 for the qr

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Central Maine Power Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission two million common shares and $45 million of general and refunding mor tgage bonds, Series E, due 1991, to be underwritten by Kidder, Peabo dy & Co. and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: PAPAL SECURITY INCREASED
description: PAPAL SECURITY INCREASED: Pope John II waving to crowds yesterday from the balcony of his residence at Castel Gandolfo, Italy. He leans on a bulletproof glass shield that was recently installed on the balcony.

title: U.N. Official, an Iraqi, To Snub Israel and Iran
description: The president of the General Assembly, Ismat Kittani of Iraq, said today that the Israeli and Iranian delegations could not expect him to accord them ''the usual courtesies'' of the presidency because of the harsh criticisms leveled by both nations after his election two weeks ago.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: KORCHNOI BIDS FOR CHESS TITLE KARPOV HOLDS
description: Two angry men, Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland and Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, will face each other in the world chess championship match beginning here tomorrow.

title: QUEBEC SUMMONS LEGISLATORS TO RENEW FIGHT WITH OTTAWA
description: The Quebec Government called the provincial Assembly into emergency debate today to fire the first shot of a renewed battle by eight of 10 provinces to defeat Ottawa's plans for a new constitution that would limit the power of the provinces.

title: Hiram Walker Hires Lockhart & Pettus
description: Lockhart & Pettus, specialists in advertising for the black consumer market, has just been appointed by Hiram Walker & Sons to do just such advertising for its Canadian Club brand.

title: South Africa Orders Reporter To Leave Country in 14 Days
description: The South African Government today ordered an Associated Press correspondent, Cynthia Stevens, to leave the country within 14 days.

title: MARRIOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
F.T.C. DROPS CONSIDERATION OF RULE ON CHILDREN'S TV ADS
description: The Federal Trade Co mmission today halted its rule-making proceedings on the issue of w hether advertising on television programs for children was unfair o r deceptive. The commission said it could not ''justify sacrif icing other important enforcement priorities'' in continuing its in quiry.

title: MITTERRAND'S BUDGET STRESSES NEW JOBS
description: President Francois Mitterrand's Socialist Government today introduced a proposed 1982 budget aimed at cutting unemployment by increasing Government expenditures.

title: Coach Bryant Denies Report of Bias
description: Coach Bear Bryant of the University of Alabama denied today a published report that a racial double standard was being applied in the disciplining of his football players.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.00-19.50** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues.

title: THE NEW FRIEND OF BELIZE'S FOE
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ PIANO: DOROTHY DONEGAN
description: THE legendary jazz pianist Dorothy Donegan on Tuesday brought her virtuosic skills to Michael's Pub, where she will be appearing through Oct. 24, along with the lounge pianist, Page Cavanaugh, as part of the club's ''Piano Playoffs'' evenings. Although the two keyboardists offered some playful duets on twin pianos, it was Miss Donegan's solo set that was the main attraction at Tuesday's late show.

title: CONGRESS APPROVES A BIGGER TAX BREAK FOR ITSELF
description: Meeting into the early morning hours, Congress today rejected an immediate pay increase for itself and high-level Government employees but voted to allow senators and representatives unlimited deductions from taxable income to cover living expenses in Washington.

title: Suspect Sought In Killing of Child
description: The police yesterday issued an alarm for a 25-year-old man after an autopsy showed that a 5-year-old Bronx girl in his care died last Friday of injuries sustained in a ''homicidal assault.'' The police described him as the boyfriend of the dead girl's mother.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Here you have the most controversial area of discussion in what is probably t he most controversial nuclear plant in the country.

title: Agronomics Unit Head
description: The American Agronomics Corporation, a citrus products company based in Tampa, Fla., has named its president, B. Mack DeVine, chairman and chief executive of a subsidiary it is forming to own, buy and sell orange groves.

title: RONSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $15,849,000 for the qr and $18,030,000 for the 6 mos...C-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,982,000 for the qr and $6,036,000 for the 6 mos

title: WHO TAKES CARE OF THEM
description: There is no point in having luxury linens unless you plan to take care of them. Some of the linen shops recommend the following laundries and dry cleaners, noting that they are expensive but capable of caring for fragile lace, pure silk sheets or down-filled comforters.

title: ERRORS IN USE OF DYE LINKED TO FRUIT FLY OUTBREAK
description: Despite the extent and sophist ication of California's program of trapping and differentiating inten tionally released, harmless and sterile Mediterranean fruit flies f rom the wild, destructive and fertile ones, some scientists now be lieve errors in the program may have allowed the present infesta tion to go undetected and spread out of control.

title: Western Air's Chief Officer Steps Down
description: Western Airlines, the object of a possible takeover by Air Florida, announced yesterday that its president and chief executive officer, Dominic P. Renda, 67 years old, had asked to be relieved of his duties. Mr Renda becomes chairman of the board today, replacing Arthur F. Kelly, 68, who will be chairman of the executive committee.

title: GRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Issues New Rules On Medicaid for States
description: Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, today issued new Medicaid rules that he said would give states more discretion on what health services to provide the poor and on how to pay for them.

title: Not Bad Company
description: He still has a quite a way to go before threatening their victory totals, but Laffit Pincay yesterday joined Bill Shoemaker and John Longden in one of thoroughbred racing's select groups. With a surprise victory in the seventh on Wander, a 5-1 shot, at Santa Anita's Oak Tree meeting, Pincay became the t hird jockey to score 5,000 career victories.

title: UNESCO'S 'ORDER'
description: For a decade, critics and defenders of Western journalism have fought about defining some ''new world information order.'' It would be more constructive to separate the real communications needs of moderate developing countries from the ideological exploitation of those needs by many in Unesco. That would mean improving international journalism, not creating some ''new order.''

title: De La Rose Wins in Rally
description: De La Rose, squeezed at the start and stuck on the rail, overcame early trouble and rallied from next to last to win the $56,900 Lamb Chop Handicap for 3-year-old fillies on the grass at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: THEATER: 'PARTICULAR FRIENDSHIPS,' A FIRST PLAY
description: AVERY (Luke Reilly) is a handsome, homosexual New York waiter who burns to be the art world's next Ben Shahn. Brooke (Julie Kavner), his closest friend and neighbor, works part-time at Gimbel's East while waiting for her big break as an actress. Brooke loves Avery so much she wants to go to bed with him - but Avery, quite understandably, isn't interested. So what's a girl to do? According to Bill Elverman, the author of the new play at the Astor Place, Brooke plunks herself down in Avery's apartment and talks. And talks and talks and talks.

title: CALGARY AND SEOUL TO STAGE '88 GAMES
description: BADEN, West Germany, Sept. 30 (AP) - The International Olympic Committee today made Seoul, South Korea, the host of the 1988 Summer Games, and Calgary, Alberta, the host of the Winter Games.

title: PANEL ADOPTS TRANSIT ECONOMIES, GIVING WORKERS 36
description: AN HOUR MORE By DAMON STETSON

title: Technology; Saving Energy - And Dollars
description: THE truth is that for most of us, most of the time, the energy problem has little to do with OPEC's solidarity, nuclear power plants or the intricacies of the coal export market. Pure and simple, the real energy crisis often seems to be the cost of heating a house.

title: News Analysis
description: For President Reagan, tomorrow marks the effective beginning for the central policies of an Administration that he has dedicated to achieving a historic turnaround in the role of the Federal Government in

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: THIS is a tale of two cultures, and it has a running theme. That theme is ''By their knickknacks shall ye know them'' (or words to that effect). An age defines itself as much in what it leaves around, that is to sa y, as in the grand design of its interiors.

title: BYRNE URGES JERSEY TO OPEN FILES IN KIDNAPPING OF LINDBERG BABY
description: Governor Byrne urged New Jersey's Attorney General yesterday to let the widow of Bruno Richard Hauptmann gain access to state police files in the investigation and conviction of her husband in the kidnapping and murder of the infant son of Charles A. Lindbergh. Mr. Hauptmann was electrocuted in 1936.

title: WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH
description: Watering Strategies If rains are sparse use recycled household water to continue nourishing shrubs, trees and vines. Rooftop plants are particularly vulnerable to wind and sun and can rapidly dehydrate, so water thoroughly. Until freezing weather arrives, help prepare for dormancy by gradually reducing frequency. Evergreen and deciduous plants need moisture during the winter. Late Tomatoes Tomatoes are best when vine ripened, but with cold weather approaching time is short. To direct the plants' energy into developing the immature fruit, cut off the stem growing tips and the new flower buds. Full-sized green tomatoes can also be hurried into ripening indoors by sealing them in a paper bag with an apple for several days. Keeping them together at room temperature will cause the apple to give off ethylene gas and turn green tomatoes red.

title: General Portland Backs Bid; Plans Canada Cement Merger
description: General Portland Inc., which had gone to court to block a takeover, said today that it had agreed to a new tender offer by Canada Cement Lafarge Ltd. for all of General Portland's shares at $47 (United States) each, or a total of about $326 million.

title: Marriott's Net Rises by 11.5%
description: The Marriott Corporation, the big hotel chain based in Washington, reported yesterday that earnings in the third fiscal quarter ended Sept. 11 rose by 11.5 percent on an increase in sales of 15.3 percent.

title: Treasure for Czech Jews
description: Jewish prayer books have not been printed in Czechoslovakia since before War II. But now, thanks to a New York rabbi, 2,000 copies of a rare Hebrew-Czech prayer book have been sent to Prague for distribution to the country's Jewish community during this year's Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur observances.

title: Cosmos Back Weisweiler
description: The Cosmos announced yesterday that Coach Hennes Weisweiler would lead the team on a three-week international tour beginning this weekend, even if this meant leaving without Giorgio Chinaglia, the star forward. And Chinaglia said, ''You will find me at home in Englewood.''

title: Popular Computing Has Premiere Issue
description: McGraw-Hill Publications' latest magazine, Popular Computing, has just arrived and the premiere issue of 116 pages includes 57 pages of advertising.

title: WHERE TO FIND THOSE LUXERY LINENS
description: MOST people no longer just make their beds. They dress their entire bedrooms, much as they do themselves, coordinating from top to bottom. But for those for whom pure luxury is the esthetic, and price is no object, there are shops that specialize in the nearly lost art of luxury linens, such as hand-embroidered or lavishly monogrammed sheets, cashmere blankets and silk-satin down-filled comforters.

title: TOP MAKERS FORGO RISE ON ALUMINUM
description: The nation's two largest producers of aluminum said yesterday that they had no plans to follow the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation's decision Tuesday to raise prices on common alloy aluminum products by 7 percent to 9 percent.

title: Official Named for Hearing
description: Daniel H. Hamscom, a retired administrativ e law judge, was appointed yesterday to make recommendatio ns on a proposed joint operating agreement b e tween The Seattle Post-Intelligencer and The Seattle Times. The 64-y ear-old official, who was the chief administrative law judge for t he Federal Trade Commission until he retired last year, will hold a h earing to consider the proposed joint operating agreement between th e two newspapers under the Newspaper Preservation Act of 1970.

title: SADAT URGES U.S. TO SELL AWACS TO SAUDIS, DESPITE THEIR 'CONNIVING'
description: President Anwar el-Sadat tonight strongly urged the United States to sell Airborne Warning and Control System aircraft to Saudi Arabia, despite the fact that the Saudis ''are still conniving against us.''

title: I.B.M. REPORTED TO PLAN MAJOR SHIFTS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer c ompany, is reported to be o n the verge of a major reorganization, spurred in part by heated com petition and internal conflicts within its sales groups.

title: CONTEMPORARY SWEDISH SILVER
description: TWO styles of silver sculpture on exhibit a t the American Scandinavian Foundation aptly reflect the con trasting personalities of two of Sweden's leading silversmiths, Kris tian Nilsson and Jan Lundgren.

title: BRIEFING
description: J USTICE Sandra Day O'Connor, on her third day at the Supreme Court, sent a notice yesterday to all women employed there. Mrs. O'Connor is sponsoring an exercise class, five mornings a week from 8 to 8:30, in the Supreme Court gym. The monthly fee, $35, will largely go to the exercise instructor hired from the Y.W.C.A. The regimen features ''conditioning in slimnastics with some aerobic dance.''

title: PRESIDENT IS PUT TO TEST BY START OF '82 FISCAL YEAR
description: President Reagan's economic and social policies will finally be put to the test as most of his budget and tax reductions go into effect tomorrow, marking a historic contraction in the role of the Federal Government.

title: A Male 'Feminist' Claims a Reverse Bias
description: Howard Goldberg, a Santa Monica, Calif., marketing consultant, considers himself a feminist. So much of a feminist, in fact, that he wants to serve on the city's new Commission on the Status of Women.

title: Judge Eases Restrictions On Presley Trial News
description: Judge Bernie Weinman today relaxed his restrictions on television and radio coverage of the trial of Elvis Presley's doctor, accused of prescribing thousands of pills for the rock star.

title: A SHOT ACROSS THE BOW
description: Americans who think our NATO allies can be taken for granted - and that seems to include Ronald Reagan - had better note what happened in Brighton, England, this week. Tony Benn came within a hair's breadth of election as deputy leader of the Labor Party.

title: REAGAN WOULD DOOM THE SYNFUELS EFFORT
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AND HAITI PLAN TO END FLOW OF MIGRANTS
description: The United States and Haiti announced an agreement of cooperation today to stop the flow of illegal Haitian migrants to this country.

title: STOCKS UP A BIT IN CALMER DAY
description: Following a dramatic two-day rally, stock prices edged higher yesterday as relative calm settled over Wall Street in the final session of the third quarter. Some analysts expressed the belief that prices probably would move higher in October before entering a period of testing recent lows.

title: Wood Signs With Jazz
description: Howard Wood, who last month filed a Federal suit against the National Basketball Association so that he could negotiate with teams other than the Utah Jazz, yesterday signed a four-year contract with the Jazz. Wood, a former University of Tennessee star and the club's second-round draft choice, had been unhappy with the Jazz' original offer of a five-year contract with a starting salary of $50,000 .... Marques Johnson, the Bucks' star forward, will probably remain in Milwaukee, said his agent, Willie Naulls.

title: B.P. Rejects Kuwait Offer
description: The British Petroleum Company today confirmed that Kuwait, trying to increase its exports of crude oil, had offered easier credit terms that would reduce the effective price by $1 a barrel, to $34.50.

title: AINGE AND BLUE JAYS DIFFER IN TESTIMONY
description: Danny Ainge testified yesterday he believed that the Toronto Blue Jays had released him from his baseball contract so that he could play basketball with the Boston Celtics.

title: RUSSIAN NEWSPAPER DENIES SPY CHARGE FACING U.S. OFFICER
description: A Soviet newspaper denied today that an American Air Force officer accused of unauthorized contacts with the Soviet Embassy in Washington ever entered the embassy or passed any ''strategic military secrets.''

title: Reagan News Session Will Be on TV Today
description: President Reagan's news conference, scheduled for 2 o'clock this afternoon, will be televised live by the CBS, NBC and ABC networks, which correspond to channels 2, 4 and 7 in New York.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE OBSESSION. Reflections on the Tyr- anny of Slenderness. By Kim Chernin. 206 pages. Harper & Row. $12.50.

title: OFFER BY GROMYKO TO HAIG REPORTED
description: The Soviet Union has asked the United States to agree to a new set of principles governing their relations, with each side pledging not to seek military advantage over the other, a senior State Department official said today.

title: British Airways
description: British Airways introduced a $100-a-year membership package for frequent travelers that includes free travel insurance, personal check cashing, hotel and car hire discounts, use of lounges at airports, hot-line telephone arrangement, free use of message centers and other privileges. The ''anytime you travel'' free insurance package is for members traveling outside the United States, whether or not they use British Airways, the carrier said. The package includes $50,000 in medical coverage, $2,000 for baggage loss, $1,000 for credit card or cash loss, $20,000 personal accident and $500,000 in liability coverage.

title: Reagan Stand On Thrift Units
description: The Reagan Administration is backing legislation to permit interstate acquisition of ailing savings and loan associations by bank holding companies, Representative J. William Stanton, Republican of Ohio, said today.

title: Alleghany to Sell Block of Securities
description: The Alleghany Corporation and its subsidiary, Investors Diversified Services Inc., said that they will sell off a block of portfolio securities carried on the books at $244 million but having a market value of only $165 million as of Aug.31.

title: Connecticut's Deficit I s Put at $230 Million
description: The state's deficit in the current fiscal year may exceed $230 million, the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities estimated today.

title: LEADING INDICATORS DROP 0.5%
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators, designed to forecast economic trends, declined fivetenths of 1 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the third decline in the past four months.

title: French Senate Votes To End Death Penalty
description: The Government bill to abolish the death penalty cleared its last hurdle today when the oppositiondominated Senate passed the measure by a vote of 161 to 126.

title: Bell Printing Job To City Investing
description: The City Investing Company said that its World Color Press Inc. unit has been awarded a new contract to produce subscriber telephone directories for the Western Electric Company, a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The 1980 figures were adjusted to reflect a pooling of interests

title: Penn to Play in Tokyo
description: Three American college basketball teams will play regular-season games against one another here in December, officials said today. They are Pennsylvania, Louisville and Oregon State.

title: Thrift Unit Flexibility
description: The Government today gave federally insured savings and loan associations more flexibility in the way they account for sales of old, low-paying mortgages as a means of helping them out of their financial troubles. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which supervises the nation's approximately 4,000 federally insured savings and loan associations, also proposed new rules that would let them lease personal property to consumers.

title: Williams Suit Charges Civil Rights Violations
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., the New Jersey Democrat convicted of Abscam bribery charges, filed a $6 million lawsuit yesterday against current and former Justice Department officials, charging they violated his civil rights.

title: KINGSTON BANK CALLS IN 50 MORTGAGES AT 8.5%
description: The Ulster Savings Bank of Kingston, N.Y., has called in 50 mortgage loans made five years ago at 8.5 percent and informed the homeowners that they must pay off the loans. The bank has offered to refinance the loans at 15 percent for one year.

title: Reagan Signs Increase In Federal Debt Ceiling
description: President Reagan tonight signed legislation raising the Government's borrowing authority above $1 trillion for the first time.

title: 7 VIETNAMESE DIE ON SHIP
description: Seven out of 69 Vietnamese refugees aboard a small boat died of thirst and exposure in the South China Sea before the survivors were rescued by a United States Navy ship, refugee officials said today. Fifteen other refugees had to be treated in hospitals when the Southern Cross landed them in Singapore on Monday.

title: The Islam Bomb
description: You are Indira Gandhi, Prime Minister of India, a ''nonaligned'' country that is tightly aligned with the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. TAX LOSSES ON SAVER NOTES COULD BE HIGH
description: The new, eagerly promoted tax-exempt savings certificates go on sale today amid predictions that they will attract far more funds than originally expected. This would mean a substantially higher tax loss to the Government than it initially believed.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
PRESIDIO OIL reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: The figures are adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split in Dec 1980 and a public offering of 946,000 shrs in Mar 1981

title: Lendl in Quarterfinals Of Tennis in Madrid
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia coasted into the quarterfinals of the $75,000 Madrid Grand Prix tennis tournament today with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Gabriel Urpi of Spain.

title: HERS
description: NOW that I have reached 50, I find myself, more and more, stepping outside myself to see what is becoming of me. As my body thickens and my face seems to thumb its nose at the kindness of cosmetics, I select from the trick-or-treat bag of memory a feature here, a character trait there. I notice that I place my thumb on my chin, my fingers on my temple when I listen, just the way my father did, twist my Bobeh Stollman's skinny brown hair into a knot at the back of my head. Some matches are obvious, but it has taken me years to realize that one of the women I have been becoming all along is an incarnation of the Pushke Lady.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ANEW multipurpose bench-mounted power tool should interest home craftsmen, workshop enthusiasts and do-it-yourselfers. It combines the usefulness of a bench grinder with the accuracy of a power-driven sanding disk machine. Called the Finishing Machine, it is made by Black & Decker's Consumer Power Tool Division, 3012 Highwoods Boulevard, Raleigh, N.C. 27625.

title: Lauda to Race Again
description: Two years and a day after he had announced his retirement, Niki Lauda of Austria, the two-time world driving champion, said yesterday that he would return to Formula One competition next year. Lauda will apparently have a choice between the Brabham and McLaren teams.

title: Husky Oil Shifts Plans To Conserve Its Cash
description: Husky Oil Ltd. of Calgary today announced a shift in corporate direction that would conserve cash over the next two years in order to spend up to $1.5 billion (Canad ian) by 1986 on a massive dev elopment of heavy oil in the Lloydminster area of western Saska tchewan. (The Canadian dollar is worth about 83 United States cents. )

title: Topics Youthful Indiscretions;  Bent Twigs
description: When Andy Hardy was 10 years old he probably had a paper route, listened to ''Jack Armstrong'' and, in response to an ad in a comic book, sold seeds for the American Seed Company. ''For more than 60 years,'' its catalogue says, ''selling our garden-tested seeds has become a part of the American way of growing up.''

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday as the credit markets sought to cope with a flood of Treasury bill and bond auctions.

title: HAITIAN PRESIDENT EXPECTING U.S. AID
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 30 -President Jean-Claude Duvalier said tonight that he expected that the United States would provide new economic and social aid soon to this poverty-stricken country.

title: DANCE: MISS DE GROOT'S 'YELLOW WHALE'
description: minute piece ''Yellow Whale.''

title: NEW TABLES ON WITHHOLDING READY
description: New withholding tax tables were mailed early in September to 5.4 million employers. An Internal Revenue Service spokesman said they were expected to make "a good faith effort" to reduce withholding as of the first payday after today.

title: DANCE: STREAM INC. PRESENTS A DOUBLE MATINEE
description: THE Dance on the Lower East Side series of performances presented by Stream Dance Inc. concluded with two Sunday matinees - the second following immediately upon the first - at La Mama Annex. The result was a long, crowded but, fortunately, often fascinating, afternoon of dance.

title: BRITISH LABORITES URGE DISARMAMENT
description: The Labor Party voted by a large majority today in favor of a policy of unilateral nuclear disarmament, including the shutdown of all American nuclear bases on British soil or in British waters.

title: ENGLISH, BY LAW
description: One point that Americans often boast about to foreign guests is how our country has assimilated different ethnic groups that at first glance seem irreconcilable. Fleeing political repression and religious persecution, these individuals have endured the most difficult of hardships to enjoy the freedom we have to offer.

title: Oct. 1, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M. Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. adn 3 P.M. Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 3 P.M. Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M.

title: PAKISTANIS END SIKH HIJACKING
description: Indian officials extended their thanks today to the Government of Pakistan for the raid this morning in which commandos dressed as cleaning men stormed a hijacked Indian plane at Lahore and rescued 44 hostages while arresting the five Sikh separatists who had commandeered the domestic flight yesterday.

title: IPM TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reagan Picks 2 Army Aides
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate James R. Ambrose, a retired vice president of the Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation, to be Under Secretary of the Army. The President also said he would nominate Jay Raymond Sculley, head of the department of civil engineering at the Virginia Military Institute, to be Assistant Secretary of the Army for research, development and acquisition.

title: JAMES MADISON WRITES AGAIN
description: WHEN he was a backup defensive end on Notre Dame's 1966 national championship football team, Allen Sack was walking to practice one day with a few teammates.

title: NEW DRUG THERAPY MAY UNCLOG ARTERIES AFTER HEART ATTACKS
description: Researchers have found that a clotdissolving medicine appears to protect people from the damage that usually follows heart attacks.

title: CALENDER: A FAIR ABOUT BROWNSTONES
description: ''Beyond Tradition'': 25th Anniver- sary Exhibition, American Craft Museum, 44 West 53d Street.

title: PENSION CHECKS GO TO DEAD PEOPLE IN SOCIAL SECURITY'S 15-YEAR ERROR
description: In a $60 million bungle, Social Security checks have been routinely mailed, for as long as 15 years in some cases, to about 8,000 dead people, Government officials said today.

title: CITY PLANS TO CURB TAX AID FOR MANHATTAN DEVELOPERS
description: The Koch administration will put forth today a plan to prohibit developers in much of Manhattan below 96th Street from taking advantage of a variety of New York City tax abatements geared toward encouraging the construction or rehabilitation of commercial buildings.

title: NATO OFFICIAL CHIDES REAGAN
description: A top NATO official said today that the Reagan Administration gave the appearance of being more interested in achieving military supremacy than in controlling the nuclear arms race and was insensitive to European concerns about the arms buildup.

title: Abraham Hurwitz Dead at 76; New York's Official Magician
description: Abraham B. Hurwitz, who entertained more than a million young people as New York City's official magician and who taught thousands more as a professor at Yeshiva University for 47 years, died Tuesday night at Doctors Hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He was 76 years old and had lived in Hallandale, Fla., for seven years.

title: Sohio Buys Coal From U.S. Steel
description: The United States Steel Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of Ohio announced that they have completed the sale of 700 million tons of the steel concern's coal reserves to the oil company for about $600 million.

title: MX PLAN PRECEDED BY DENUNCIATIONS
description: Opposition to President Reagan's reported but unconfirmed plan to deploy MX intercontinental missiles in Nevada mounted here today, even though the President was not scheduled to announce his decisions on a comprehensive new package of strategic weapons until Friday.

title: Diocese Acts On Idle Funds
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn has established a computerbased cash management program so that parishes may invest idle checking account funds on a short-term basis.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Advertising; Eastern Air Picks Campbell
description: EASTERN AIR LINES INC. made the expected announcement yesterday. Campbell-Ewald, Detroit, will become its new ad agency on Jan. 1, replacing Young & Rubicam of New York, the largest American agency, which served the account for 17 years.

title: FIRST CLASS STAMP TO INCREASE TO 20
description: The Postal Service, overruling the independent Postal Rate Commission for the first time, announced today that it would raise the price of a first-class domestic stamp by 2 cents, to 20 cents. The new rate will be effective Nov. 1.

title: TAIWAN REJECTS AS PROPAGANDA PEKING'S OFFER OF TALKS
description: The Chinese Nationalists in Taiwan said today that a Communist offer to begin talks on reunification aimed at sharing power in China was a propaganda ploy. A spokesman for the Nationalist Government said the offer contained not hing new and was intended to subjugate the people on Taiwan.

title: ROADWAY EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: B-After extraordinary gain of $12.3 million from a tax benefit attributable to the writeoff of Motor Carrier operating rights in qr and 9 mos...C-Net loss for the qr and after an extraordinary charge of $26.8 million from a similar writeoff as in the 1981 qr and 9 mos for the qr and 9 mos

title: Euronote Issue
description: Northern Indiana Public Service Finance, a subsidiary of the Northern Indiana Public Service Company, is offering a $50 million issue of Euronotes, the lead manager, Merrill Lynch International & Company, said today. The seven-year notes, which are fully guaranteed by the parent company, carry a fixed 17 1/4 percent coupon, but the issue will not be priced until Oct.6. A Merrill Lynch official said that pricing is ''very flexible in light of the prevailing market conditions.''

title: News Analysis
description: There is a mournful mood among Roman Catholics in Chicago, who are more laden with sadness than anger in response to the recent allegations of fiscal wrongdoing against John Cardinal Cody, their Archbishop. c A grand jury is looking into reports that the Cardinal mishandle d church funds. The accusations remain the central issue, but the discomfort of Catholics has been heightened by accusations that th e Rev. Andrew M. Greeley, a diocesan priest who is a bitter critic o f the Cardinal, helped prompt the inquiry.

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1981
description: INTERNATIONAL FOUR IRANIAN MILITARY LEADERS DIED in an air crash near Teheran. Details were not disclosed. The four, who included the Defense Minister and acting Chief of Staff, played key roles in the prosecution of Iran's year-old war with Iraq. (Page A1, Column 1). TAIWAN REJECT ED A PEKING OFFER of talks aimed at sharing power in a unified China . The Nationalists asserted that the Communists' proposal was a propaganda ploy. (A6:1-4.)

title: Korean Contracts Up
description: The value of overseas construction contracts awarded to South Korean companies rose to $6.98 billion during the first nine months of 1981, from $5.4 billion in the comparable 1980 period, Construction Ministry sources said today. They said that total contracts were expected to top $10 billion by the end of 1981, as against $8.26 billion obtained last year, mainly in the Middle East.

title: Conoco Now Part of Du Pont
description: Conoco Inc. and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company completed the largest corporate takeover in American history when Conoco shareholders overwhelmingly approved a $7.6 billion merger of the two giants.

title: BIRD KEEPS ABOVE THE LAW
description: The bird perched on a ledge above Judge Francis X. Egitto's head made arraignments in Manhattan Criminal Court more than just a little interesting yesterday. Spectators and defendants alike wondered where it had come from, what kind it was and whether it would fly to freedom.

title: 4 FOUND SLAIN AT HOME OF VOODOO PRACTITONER
description: Four persons were shot to death and two others wounded yesterday in what the authorities called a ''vicious massacre'' in a home equipped with an altar for the practice of black magic. The police said they were seeking at least two suspects.

title: Scali, McCabe Expands Mrs. Paul's Account
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, which knows its way around Frank Perdue's chicken pluckers, is now becoming expert also on the brimming nets that service Mrs. Paul's Kitchens.

title: BIG MARKET FOR JUICE FROM ORANGE PULP ATT RACTS TROPICANA
description: No longer content with its substantial share of the market for pasteurized orange juice, Tropicana Products Inc. is trying to use its well-known brand name and profitable marketing techniques to break into the already crowded business of reconstituted juice.

title: Madison Studies Suit on AM Stock
description: The Madison Fund, a publicly traded closed-end investment company, said that it has retained legal counsel to investigate the possibility of filing damage claims against unnamed parties in connection with its earlier purchase of AM International stock. Madison Fund owns 16 percent of 10.2 million common shares outstanding.

title: POLL FINDS VOTER APATHY IN JERSEY GOVERNOR'S RACE
description: A poll released today by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University found that, of 840 registered voters interviewed, only half could name the two major candidates for Governor of New Jersey in the November election.

title: Toyo in Nigeria Talks
description: The Toyo Kogyo Company Ltd., Japan's third-largest car manufacturer, said today that it will start talks with the Nigerian Government on its plan to produce commerical vehicles there. A spokesman for the maker of Mazda cars said that the company is one of five candidates chosen by Nigeria. He said that Toyo Kogyo exp orted only 3,000 vehicles to Ni geria last year.

title: PRICES SET RECORDS
description: Sales of new single-family houses, which have been depressed by high interest rates, fell 14.2 percent in August from July, to an annual rate of 362,000 units, the Government reported today.

title: A DEMOCRACY IN ANY LANGUAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Carpenter T o Report, G iants Say
description: Rob Carpenter will report to the Giants tomorrow afternoon, Coach Ray Perkins said today, after two phone conversations with Carpenter, the running back acquired yesterday from the Houston Oilers. ''We are making arrangements for him right now,'' Perkins said.

title: Sunbeam Protects Its Top Executives
description: The Sunbeam Corporation, battling a $45l million takeover bid by IC Industries, disclosed that its senior executives have awarded themselves the option of collecting lucrative severance pay if IC succeeds in its bid and then dismisses or demotes them. The plan also protects executives who decide to quit even if their status is unchanged.

title: GREEKS SEEM READY TO VEER LEFTWARD THIS MONTH
description: Public opinion polls suggest that Greece will turn left in the general elections of Oct. 18 and install the Socialist lead er Andreas Papandreou in power. But Prime Minister George Rallis insists that his conservative camp is an ''awakening giant'' that will prevail.

title: COMMONWEALTH TALKS LOOK TO AFRICA
description: The problems of southern Africa and the gap between rich and poor nations quickly emerged as the dominant issues as 41 member nations of the Commonwealth opened a meeting of heads of government here today.

title: Officer's Dismissal In Theft Is Upheld
description: The Police Department's dismissal of an officer who had been arrested for shoplifting $30 in merchandise was upheld in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: AWACS FOR SAUDI ARABIA: IN THE NATIONAL INTEREST
description: A weeklong effort by the Reagan Administration to renegotiate some terms of its proposed sale to Saudi Arabia of five Boeing Airborne Warning and Control System planes and other equipment has underlined how heated and important the dispute aroused by the plan has become.

title: Arizona Asks F.B.I Aid On Grade Disclosures
description: A University of Arizona official said yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been asked to look into the disclosure of grade information cited in published accounts this week concerning football and basketball players.

title: Modern Art to Screen Five Chinese Movies
description: China Film Week - arranged under the 1979 cultural agreement between the United States and China - will feature five Chinese movies at the Museum of Modern Art from Oct. 22 to 29. The New York showing will follow an opening on Oct. 15 in the American Film Institute's auditorium at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: RAINOUT SPURS YANK PLANNING
description: The outfield in Cleveland Stadium was swampy tonight after a day of rain, the path from the dugout to home plate was very muddy and the stands were nearly empty. The game was meaningless, and perhaps hazardous, to both teams, and it started 48 minutes late. Seven minutes later, it was halted, and then called off.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Agronomics Corp. said that it completed its previously announced acquisition of Juice Tree Inc. for 950,000 American Agronomics shares.

title: E.T. MCCAFFREY, RETIRED JUDGE
description: Edward T. McCaffrey, a retired justice of the New York State Supreme Court who, as a New York City Commissioner of Licenses campaigned against an Italian movie, ''The Miracle,'' as ''blasphemous,'' died Tuesday in Norwalk, Conn. He was 82 years old and lived in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Oil Statistics Delayed
description: The weekly American Petroleum Institute figures do not appear today because the A.P.I. was delayed in gathering the statistics. The figures will be published on Friday.

title: MIME: DANIEL STEIN'S 'SCENES'
description: MIME can be an exasperating art because mimes often appear to delight in squandering their gestural skills on trivial themes. Fortunately, one mime who doesn't do so is Daniel Stein, who offered his new hourlong ''Apparent Scenes'' last Friday night at the playhouse that used to be known as the American Theater Laboratory but which has been renamed the Bessie Schonberg Theater in honor of a distinguished teacher of modern dance.

title: Senate Unit Votes Oil Control Power
description: The Senate Energy Committee tonight approved legislation that would restore the President's authority to reimpose price and allocation controls on crude oil. Those powers are due to expire at midnight tonight,

title: This is the third of a number of articles that will appear from time to time examining how changing economic conditions affect Americans in one small city.
description: The early autumn weather has been glorious here in the Corn Belt, but the economic climate in this tidy little city is turning distinctly chilly.

title: HOWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $565,000 from life insurance...C-Net loss

title: MAZZILLI'S HIT IN 9TH DEFEATS CUBS BY 2-1
description: It probably came a couple of weeks too late, but the Mets scored one of their more professional victories of the season last night when Lee Mazzilli pinch-hit a single in the ninth inning to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 2-1.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $59,000 and a tax credit of $281,000...C-Includes reduction of deferred income taxes of $760,000 income from reversal of balance of insurance reserves of $832,000 and tax credit of $1,260,000

title: Harvester Survival P lan Given
description: The International Harvester Company's plan to save $20 million a month on its interest payments was the focal point of controversy today as the company explained its latest survival plans to representatives of the 225 banks to which it owes $3.4 billion.

title: The Clouded Missile 'Window'
description: President Reagan is said to have decided to build at least some MX missiles and B-1 bombers and to announce it only after he meets the press today. He would be wiser to heed John Kennedy's example and ditch the ''missile gap'' oratory that helped elect him. But if he means to deploy these weapons he ought to field the serious questions they raise.

title: 1982 FESTIVAL TO HONOR CAGE
description: ONE way to define ''experimental music'' is to think of it as marginal and defiant, set apart from establishment culture. But now such music has elicited major, big-city financial support on its behalf. The city is Chicago, and the funds will be for the 1982 installment of the New Music America festival.

title: BLUEPRINT SWITCH AT COAST A-PLANT WIDENS U.S. INQUIRY ON ITS SAFETY
description: A Federal inquiry into design errors at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant, which focused at first on improper placement of supports protecting a cooling system against earthquakes, was broadened today to include five key safety systems.

title: DESIGN SCOUTING AROUND PARIS
description: ''WE'RE in a radical chic socialist period,'' said Jean-Charles Dedieu, a stylist who is now in the process of occupying a tiny shop front called Details at 56 Rue de l'Universite in Paris.

title: LUXURY HOUSING, BUT AT A PRICE
description: ''If living in the most prestigious and expensive apartment building in the United States appeals to you, see RiverTower and be convinced,'' says an advertisement running in newspapers and magazines.

title: THE GREAT DIVIDE, 1981: TAKING SIDES ON AWACS
description: It is an issue that has divided Jimmy Carter and Walter F. Mondale, Senator Henry M. Jackson and the Boeing Company, Israel and the Reagan Administration.

title: Salvadoran Leader Meets With Kin of Slain Women
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador, calling four American churchwomen who were murdered last year in his country ''martyrs'' who died helping the poor, met with a group of their relatives today and promised to help them in their search for justice.

title: THOMAS PAINE'S UNLIKELY DISCIPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1981; The Economy
description: The new tax-exempt savings certificates go on sale today. Experts predict they will attract far more funds than originally expected, adding up to a substantially higher loss to the Government in forgone tax revenues than it initially believed. (Page A1.)

title: FAMILIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-AFter an extraordinary charge of $117,000 from cumulative effects of an accounting change...C-Net loss...D-Includes a gain of $63,000 from discontinued operations

title: NAVY DROPS BRUTALIT COUNTS AGAINST THREE PETTY OFFICERS
description: The Navy has dropped charges against three petty officers scheduled for courts-martial on assault, violating orders and maltreating men aboard the carrier Ranger.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Some time ago I received a crystal chandelier that was about 25 years old. While cleaning and rewiring it, one of the crystal glass arms was accidentally broken and we have been unable to find anyone that can repair this or that can tell us where to find a replacement. Do you have any suggestion as to how this can be repaired? -G.A.C., Southwick, Mass.

title: Country Living Becomes a Monthly
description: Country Liv ing magazine, which following the Hearst Magazines mode has gone from an annual to a monthly (as of February), has increased its rate base by 50,000, to 600,000 in anticipation of demand.

title: ON BEAUTY CONTESTS AND 40TH BIRTHDAYS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Carol Eisen Rinzler, a lawyer, is the author of ''Your Adolescent: An Owner's Manual'' (Atheneum, 1981). By CAROL EISEN RINZLER

title: Labor Rift Threatens
description: Labor Ministry officials, racing organizers and union leaders will meet tomorrow to try to settle a dispute that threatens Sunday's $357,000 Prix de L'Arc de Triomphe, the richest all-age horse race in Europe, a union official said today.

title: Marcos Threatens To Reinstate Martial Law
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos threatened today to reimpose martial law to stop subversives from infiltrating labor and student groups. It was the first such threat by Mr. Marcos since he ended eight years of martial law on Jan. 17.

title: Duguay Agrees to Terms; Rangers Win
description: Ron Duguay, the Rangers' only holdout this season, agreed to the terms on a new contract yesterday, according to Craig Patrick, the general manager.

title: Belanger on the Bench
description: Mark Belanger, the eight-time Gold Glove shortstop, may no longer have a future with the Baltimore Orioles. He has been on the bench the last two weeks while the Orioles have struggled for a playoff spot, and now has spoken out against Manager Earl Weaver, blaming him for the team's relatively poor showing this year .... Wes Stock, the 47-year-old pitching coach of the Seattle Mariners, has decided to retire after 26 years in baseball, 19 in the major leagues.

title: BOY, 16, SEIZED IN KNIFE SLAYING OF AN ATTORNEY
description: A 16-year-old youth was charged yesterday with the robbery and murder of a Wall Street lawyer last Saturday evening in a Lower East Side park.

title: MRS. ONASSIS' HIDEAWAY IS NEARING COMPLETION
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., Sept. 30 (UPI) - Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, one of the world's most famous women, has a new, $3.1 million island hideaway nearing completion here .

title: 10 China Fishermen Defect
description: Ten Chinese fishermen said today that they had escaped to Taiwan with the help of stolen arms and had decided to stay. The fishermen, ranging in age from 18 to 22, said at a news conference that they got the arms from a military depot.

title: NEW YORK DELAYS U.S. WELFARE CUTS
description: More than 40,000 families receiving welfare, food stamps and Medicaid in New York State will get at least a temporary reprieve from federally ordered cutbacks scheduled to go into effect today.

title: A TOP POLICE TEAM TELLS HOW TO CATCH A THIEF
description: Gene Kraese and Joe Modica have seen all kinds of thieves, from the very crafty to the incredibly inept. And what common thieves have in common, the two police officers say, is a kind of street paranoia.

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRITISH SUIT ON ART AUCTIONS SETTLED
description: A dark cloud that had been hanging over the London art world was removed today, with the out-of-court settlement of a lawsuit between the dealers and the auctioneers.

title: GREENHOUSE WINDOWS
description: AGREENHOUSE window provides a manageable environment for growing plants that is ideal for apartment and house dwellers alike. Greenhouse windows have a frame of extruded aluminum with a brown or white finish that is attached to the outside frame of a window.

title: DR. GEORGE CORNER, BIRTH-PILL PIONEER, 91, DIES
description: Dr. George Washington Corner, whose research in human reproduction and sexuality led to the development of the contraceptive pill, died Monday at the home of his son, Dr. George W. Corner Jr., in Huntsville, Ala., where he lived. He was 91 years old.

title: LABOR'S LOVE IS LOST; DONOVAN CARRIES ON
description: Raymond J. Donovan, once a wealthy New Jersey building contractor and fund-raiser for Ronald Reagan, now fills one of Washington's more anomalous jobs: Secretary of Labor in a Republican Administration that is determined to revise or terminate the many health, safety, fair employment, and job training programs that organized labor prizes so highly.

title: M.I.T. FACULTY BACKS RESEARCH INSTITUTE OFFER
description: Faculty members generally agreed today that the Massachusetts Institute of Technology should accept an industrialist's offer of $7.5 million, and with it a new $120 million independent institute for biomedical research, whose scientists would become professors at M.I.T.

title: Talks Planned in Strike Of Philadelphia Teachers
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh and Mayor William Green announced new negotiations today to settle a three-week-old teachers' strike. The Governor offered up to $36 million in state funds as an incentive for a settlement.

title: Pemex-Britain Oil Pact Set
description: Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, Mexico's state oil monopoly, said today that it has signed two contracts to export 70,000 barrels a day of oil to Britain until the end of the ye ar.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes loss on investment options of $2,368,000 for the qr and 9 mos and tax credits of $300,000 for the qr and $2,200,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes an extraordinary loss of $600,000 for the qr and a gain of $700,000 for the 9 mos

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks
description: A United States Government delegation began talks in Moscow today on the sale of millions of tons of grain to the Soviet Union, now facing its third poor harvest in a row.

title: Bridge: A Scottish Writer Suggests When to Forget a Finesse
description: The rapid flow from Britain of small bridge books with large price tags continues unabated. Almost all of them are of high quality, and the two most recent are no exception: ''Test Your Finessing'' and ''Test Your Trump Control,'' both by the Scottish writer Hugh Kelsey. Each has 80 pagesand is paperbound, and is available for $5.95 from Barclay Bridge Supplies, 8 Bush Avenue, Port Chester, N.Y. 1 0573.

title: CROP PRICES PAID TO FARMERS FALL
description: Prices paid to farmers for their crops fell 2.2 percent in September, cutting the buying power of the income received to its lowest point in nearly half a century, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Misguided Mall
description: The idea of a pedestrian mall north of Times Square has bloomed perennially over the last decade; a modified version has now won hearty endorsement and a $4.5 million subsidy from the Federal Government. At the risk of sounding ungrateful, we still think the project is a poor idea.

title: Buyer-Selected Note Maturities
description: A new type of tax-exempt security is scheduled for sale next week by the state of Washington, which plans to issue $400 million of oneyear notes through underwriters led by Citibank and Salomon Brothers.

title: LONDON PRINTERS REJECT PACT AT THE SUNDAY TIMES
description: Workers at The Sunday Times tonight rejected a proposed settlement of their dispute with management, throwing into doubt the future of the paper and its sister publication, The Times of London.

title: ADMINISTRATION POSTPONES ACTION ON SAUDI PLANES
description: The Reagan Administration today postponed by a day formal notification to Congress of a plan to sell radar planes to Saudi Arabia. There were reports that the Saudis had agreed to adjustments in the deal.

title: News An alysis
description: The New York State Board of Regents, which moved last week to require high schools throughout the state to keep their dropout rate to less than 10 percent, is trying anew to force the schools to become responsible for the achievement of their students rather than shrug the problem off as a social ill.

title: NEW YORK JUDGE PICKED FOR U.S. COURT
description: Richard J. Cardamone, a New York State Supreme Court justice, was nominated yesterday by President Reagan to the Second Circuit of the United States Court of Appeals, which covers New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

title: IF WE SHACKLE THE DOLLAR TO THE PRICE OF GOLD
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN CRAFT MUSEUM TO OPEN A BRANCH IN MAY
description: The American Craft Museum will open a second facility, in May, in the lobby of the International Paper Company's headquarters at 77 West 45th Street.

title: School Busing Debated A t a Hearing of Senate
description: Legislation to curb court-ordered busing was assailed as a distraction and an assault on the Federal judiciaryas Senate hea rings began today but was defended as a way out of an ''educational nightmare.''

title: NEW HOPE FOR A JOURNEYMAN
description: In coaching and playing college basketball and football, achieving the top 10 has always been a standard of success. College coaches whose teams are in the top 10 at the end of a season usually keep their jobs at least another year. And players chosen among the first 10 usually get the big money, guaranteed contracts and happiness.

title: POLAND'S COAL MINE STRUGGLE
description: Andrezej Szoltysik, a 28-year-old miner, walked out of the shower room dressed in blue jeans and a tartan shirt, passing the statue of the Virgin Mary and a banner saying ''God Bless You.''

title: Only for the Best
description: It must make Aundra Thompson, a fifth-year journeyman wide receiver, feel worthy, if a bit unsettled. Yesterday, for the second time in two weeks, Thompson was traded for one of the best receivers in the National Football League. Two weeks ago he was included in the package that the Green Bay Packers sent to the San Diego Chargers for John Jefferson. Yesterday the Chargers replaced Jefferson with another all-pro receiver, New Orleans's Wes Chandler.

title: WASHINGTON GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for 12 mos to Aug 31
Sharja Gas Fi eld Described
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said that its natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas find in the United Arab Emirate of Sharja appears to be ''one of the largest discoveries ever made by the company.''

title: Transit Delays
description: The Transit Authority said passengers on a Manhattan-bound B train were discharged at the New Utrecht Avenue station in Brooklyn about 3:40 P.M. after a minor fire broke out under the train.

title: CITY OPERA: 'LA BOHEME' IS LED BY JUDITH SOMOGI
description: IT'S wintry through three acts of Puccini's ''La Boheme,'' but as Bohemians know, the ardor of love and the passions of art are fiery enough to provide warmth. The first ''Boheme'' of the season at the New York City Opera on Friday night, directed by Cynthia Auerbach, let in a few too many cool drafts, but there were quite enough embers to counteract them.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has named Michael Strauss executive vice president, card marketing, of the company's newly formed Consumer Financial Services Group.

title: FOREIGN AID DONORS SET CUTBACKS
description: Foreign aid donors s erved notice today that they would scale back their contributions to the poorest countries in proportion to any reductions made by the U nited States.

title: Curb Eased On Futures
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today approved a rule to expand limits on the size of speculative positions in commodity futures and options.

title: MORMONS ALTERING INDIAN PROPHECY
description: The Mormon Church has altered the wording of a prophecy about Indians so that it no longer says native Americans will develop ''white'' skin if they join the religion.

title: Thanks for Calling
description: The collected calls of Woody Hayes and Bo Schembechler, Part II. The first time was after Schembechler's Michigan football team had been upset in its opener this season by Wisconsin.

title: U.S.-Japan Tariff Cut
description: The United States and Japan are reducing their tariffs on semiconductors, the Special Trade Office said today. The two governments agreed that such duties should be reduced to 4.2 percent in both countries. The United States now collects 5.6 percent on imports of semiconductors, while Japan collects 10.1 percent.

title: Jet Production Altered at Lear
description: Plans for an acceleration in the production schedules of two types of executive aircraft produced by the Gates Learjet Corporation have been postponed because of lagging orders, a company spokesman said.

title: 4 MILITARY CHIEFS IN IRAN ARE KILLED IN A PLANE CRASH
description: Iran announced today that its Defense Minister, its acting Chief of Staff and two other top military leaders were killed last night in an air crash near Teheran.

title: AMERICAN WELDING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July 1981

title: DELAY OF FARM BILL IN HOUSE EXPECTED TO LIFT MILK PRICES
description: The Reagan Administration failed today in a last-minute effort to prevent a temporary rise in milk price supports that could cost Americans $1 million more each day in Government payments to farmers and far more at the grocery store.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 5-Year Lottery Report Lists 51 Big Winners
description: More than $1.1 billion in state lottery tickets have been sold in the last five years, but only 51 persons were million-dollar winners, state officials said today.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY PEKING
description: Following is the text of the official English translation of China's reunification proposal to Taiwan, which was made public here today by the Foreign Ministry:

title: SAME-DAY SETTLEMENT BEGINS TODAY FOR BANKS
description: Little noticed in the world at large, a major event in banking is quietly taking place today that will require a far higher degree of dexterity from money managers across the world.

title: Tenneco Foam
description: Tenneco Chemicals Inc., a unit of Tenneco Inc., said that it has sold its foam division to G.F.C. Foam Corporation, a subsidiary of the Plastic Management Corporation of Sun Valley, C alif., for an undisclosed amount.

title: BENNETT: HIS 'CHORUS LINE' 'CHANGED EVERYBODY'S LIFE'
description: FOR a brittle moment, all was still and sil ent. Thirty-two performers stood along the walls of the brigh tly lit rehearsal hall, their eyes fixed on Michael Bennett. Finally, Mr. Bennett took a longpuff on his cigarette and nodded to the three -piece band in the corner. In a flash, the room erupted with har d-driving rock-and-roll music and a swirl of lean, young black bodies dancing across the floor.

title: Richard Harris, Ill, Misses 'Camelot'
description: Because of illness, Richard Harris has left his role as King Arthur in ''Camelot'' in Detroit.

title: DO N'T 'LIGHTEN THE BURDEN' OF PESTICIDE CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvard on Notice to Pay Heed to Its Names
description: If Harvard doesn't mind its nomenclature, it may find its address renamed John F. Kennedy Square. That's the threat, at least, from Alfred Velucci, a member of the Cambridge City Council, who says he fears that Harvard may be preparing to change the name of its John F. Kennedy School of Government to the Harvard School of Government.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
GOVERNORS' MANSIONS: BRINGING THEM BACK ALIVE
description: IOWA is doing it cookbook by cookbook. Texas is doing it millionaire by millionaire. In Mississippi, the schoolchildren gave. The Kentucky Governor's wife launched a ''Save the Mansion'' campaign, after the official residence was condemned as a firetrap. New Jersey has gone about it by planning to move its governor's residence from one grand old house to another down the road.

title: TRUCK INDUSTRY IN TRANSITION
description: Like cars, trucks are getting lighter and more efficient to cope with the high cost of fuel and, like the domestic auto makers, truck manufacturers are finding it difficult to extract themselves from a persistent slump. Along with a stagnant market, American truck makers are facing increased com petition from overseas. As a result of these troubles, each segment of the American truck market -light, medium and heavyduty - i s in a state of transition.

title: ROYALS CLINCH A PLAYOFF SPOT
description: The Kansas City Royals clinched a playoff berth in the American League's Western Division playoff series yesterday with a 5-2 victory over the Twins at Bloomington, Minn.

title: Hambletonian for Fillies Goes on Separate Card
description: The Hambletonian, the most prestigious race in trotting, will be separated from the companion Hambletonian Filly Stake next year because of complaints that this year's one-day program was too long.

title: Riot by Prison Gangs Kills 2 in Puerto Rico
description: Rival gangs of prisoners fought each other today at Puerto Rico's main penitentiary.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HARBORSCAPE

title: SENATE VOTES TO END BAN ON AID TO ANGOLAN REBELS
description: The Senate voted today to repeal an amendment that bars the United States from aiding rebels fighting the Marxist regime in Angola.

title: NEEDED: MORE VARIETY IN OUR CONCERT HALLS
description: IN case anyone is wondering why a lot of what goes on in the concert halls of New York has a deja vu or, perhaps, deja entendu, aspect about it, Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall and the 92d Street Y -to mention only the biggies - may have the answer. They ought to, anyway, since they are major contributors to the problem.

title: ITI CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
ANTICIPATING NEW UNIT, BELL SHIFTS TOP OFFICERS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is shifting executive responsibilities as it prepares to enter new and unregulated lines of business through a separate subsidiary.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $95,000... C-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $54,000 for the qr and $1,147,000 for the 9 mos plus a loss of disposit of $724,000 for the 9 mos

title: FOR A CONCERNED EFFORT
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; O.&M. Public Relations Moves Into the Arts
description: There is nothing new about the concept of spreading corporate messages through sponsorship of the arts.

title: FACTORY ORDERS FELL IN AUGUST
description: The Government reported today that factory orders in August fell 1.9 percent, the largest monthly decline in more than a year and a sign that the current economic sluggishness may get worse.

title: A VELAZQUEZ IS BOUGHT FOR $6 MILLION
description: An outstanding portrait by the 17th-century Spanish painter Diego Velazquez has been acquired for a reported $6 million by the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth. The purchase adds to the museum's reputation as one of the dominant purchasers - at top prices - in the art market.

title: Holiday Inn Payments Noted in Jersey Report
description: Holiday Ins Inc. made payments of more than $700,000 to foreign government officials between 1969 and 1980 to obtain favorable treatment for its business operations, the New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Saudi Arabia, we will not permit to be an Iran.'' - President Reagan. (A1:6.)

title: Chase Planning Appeal
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it would appeal a decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit that would enable 11 Vietnamese to recover about $450,000, plus 26.5 percent interest, that had been on deposit at its Saigon branch.

title: The Senate Is Lifting Itself
description: Senators, used to riding automatic elevators run by paid operators, began pushing their own buttons today.

title: MERGER ISSUES RISE
description: Merger situations provided some of yesterda y's larger price swings as the stock market over all moved moderately higher on the strength of a late recovery. Energy issues also showed sizable gains.

title: Reprieve for Willowbrook
description: Back in 1975, a Federal judge found conditions so appalling at Willowbrook Hospital, a New York State facility for the mentally retarded on Staten Island, that he ordered the removal of more than 5,000 patients to community residences. But the deadline for placing them passed last April with 900 still at Willowbrook. Lawyers for the patients sued the state again. But before the case reached court last week, the two sides agreed on a settlement. Though some consider the agreement retrogressive, we think it deserves support.

title: Arabs to Meet in Morocco
description: The Arab League will hold its 12th conference of chiefs of state in Fez Nov. 25-28, with the Middle East situation again the main topic of discussion, Government officials said today.

title: AGNES VARDA'S MURALS
description: THE wall paintings shown in Agnes Varda's ''Mur Murs'' are lively and energetic, and they can't help but give the film some measure of vitality even when Miss Varda's own methods do not. Miss Varda has photographed dozens of Los Angeles murals of varying style and quality, from simply decorative works to representative ones, and interviewed many of the artists responsible for them. The artists are not shy about their accomplishments. ''Even if they've only seen it for three seconds, they've been exposed to art and beauty,'' one woman says of her mural with a forest motif.

title: LABOR PARTY IN BRITAIN VOTES TO QUIT THE COMMON MARKET
description: The Labor Party's annual conference voted overwhelmingly today in favor of British withdrawal from the European Economic Community without a referendum.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan pledged to veto any appropriations bill that violates his plan to reduce Federal outlays. He called at a news conference for public patience with his economic program. (Page A1.) The President, in an effort to show Wall Street support, cited a Securities Industry Association letter. (A22.) Meanwhile, his budget chief, David A. Stockman, told Congress it would have to cast painful budget-cutting votes ''again and again and again.'' (A29.)

title: Agreement Announced in Football Death Suit
description: An out-of-court settlement that was announced today by Virginia Tech has ended an attempt by the parents of a football player, Bob Vorhies of Irvington, N.J., to prove that the Tech football program was responsible for the death of their son.

title: SADAT SENDS DEPUTY TO U.S. WITH PLEA FOR ARMS FOR SUDAN
description: President Anwar el-Sadat today sent his Vice President on a hurried mission to Washington to deliver a ''very urgent message'' to President Reagan. Egypt's Defense Minister said the message contained an appeal for American arms for the Sudan because it is being threatened by Libya. Vice President Hosni Mubarak left for the U nited States this morning and is scheduled to meet with Mr. Rea gan tomorrow, officials here said. Mr. Sadat told reporters that Mr. Mubarak was carrying ''avery urgent message that I want to deliver to President Reagan.'' He said he also wanted Mr. Mubarak to have talks with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SALES FORCE REALIGNED BY I.B.M.
description: The International Bu siness Machines Corporation yesterday confirmedreports that it was planning to abandon its product-group marketing in favor of a n approach that would enable customers to buy a wide range of I.B. M. products from a single sales representative.

title: Abortion Rights Action Unit Changes Staff and Advisers
description: The National Abortion Rights Action League has announced several staff and advisory board changes, including the resignation of Karen Mulhauser, who served as executive director for six years. Judith Widdicome, a long-time abortion rights leader, will assume the role of acting director.

title: SOME YANKEES UNEASY
description: The man with the glowering expression and the menacing fastball says he is scared, and so do some of his Yankee teammates. ''I think momentum has a lot to do with how you play in the playoffs,'' Goose Gossage said yesterday as he contemplated the prospect of the team's beginning postseason play next week, after having coasted through the last weeks of the regular season. ''It's unfortunate for us, but it's very important to have that edge mentally. I just don't think we're capable of turning it off and turning it on. I might be wrong and I hope I'm wrong, but it's not that easy to walk in and say, 'We're going to win today,' after messing around for a month. I don't think it's going to work, and I'm kind of scared.''

title: Article 035403 -- No Title
description: President Reagan today defended his wife's recent purchase of $209,508 worth of formal c hina for the White House, saying that, as a result of breakage a t state dinners, ''we can't set the table with dishes that match.''

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $214,000 for the qr and $538,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes a gain on payment of bank debt of $1,561,000 for both periods and tax credits of $876,000 for the qr and $1,330,000 for the 9 mos

title: OPPENHEIMER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Notes on People; Playboy in Braille
description: When a stopgap money bill for the Library of Congress was being considered by members of a House-Senate conference this week, Senator Mack Mattingly, a Republican of Georgia, saw a chance to do something about a magazine of which he disapproves.

title: CITY OPERA: PATRICIA MILLER AS CARMEN
description: REALLY, isn't it a wonder that ''Carmen'' has not long since dropped right out of the standard repertory? Not only do successful portrayers of the title role happen along about as often as Halley's comet but most productions barely dare to stick a tentative toe into the dark undercurrents of sex and death in this opera. ''Carmen'' audiences often accept whatever dramatic shallowness is offered them simply because the score is crammed with memorable melodies and virtually indestructible.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.00-19.50** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Judy Garland's Shoes Auctioned for $12,000
description: A pair of ruby red silk shoes worn by Judy Garland as Dorothy in the ''Wizard of Oz'' were auctioned yesterday for $12,000 at Christie's East, the annex of Christie's at 219 East 67th Street. The California collector who bought the shoes was not identified.

title: PRESS DISPUTE IN LONDON ENDS
description: Workers at The Sunday Times voted tonight to end a dispute that had threatened the future of the paper and that of its sister publication, The Times.

title: 'TAXIZUM KLO'
description: FRANK RIPPLOH emerges from ''Taxi zum Klo'' (''Taxi to the John'') as a funny, cheerful, sympathetic fellow. In view of the fact that Mr. Ripploh, who directed the film while also starring in it, has graphically filmed himself doing such things as undergoing a rectal examination at a VD clinic, this is no small accomplishment.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1981
description: International A firm pledge to protect Saudi Arabia was given by President Reagan. He said the United States would not allow the Saudi Government to fall into the hands of any internal or external forces threatening to cut off oil supplies for the West. He left unspecified the means that would be used to carry out the pledge. (Page A1, Column 6.) The sale of Awacs planes to the Saudis was pressed before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. He asserted that new ''understandings'' had been reached with Saudi Arabia to increase and extend American control over Saudi missions, but he faced renewed skepticism and opposition to the proposed sale from most members of the committee. (A28:1-2.)

title: Joint Venture In U.S. Coal Set
description: The American Natural Resources Company and Petrofina S.A. of Brussels said they had agreed in principle to form an equally owned joint venture to mine and market Eastern United States coal, including those reserves now owned by a subsidiary of American Natural. The agreement provides that affiliated comp anies of the two groups will form a partnership to which American Nat ural's subsidiary, the ANR Coal Company, will contribute its assets, including 500 million tons of clean recoverable coal reserves and r elated mining, processing and loading facilities.

title: Credit Markets; ONE-YEAR U.S. BILL RATE DROPS
description: The Treasury sold new one-year Treasury bills yesterday at an average discount rate of 14.58 percent, which means banks and savings institutions may pay a 12.14 percent yield on the new tax-exempt savings certificates, starting Monday.
To the Editor:

title: Dr. Henry Brodie, 68, Headed U .S. Delegation at Trade Talks
description: Dr. Henry Brodie, a retired Foreign Service officer who headed the United States delegation at tariff and trade negotiations in Geneva for five years, died Saturday night at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington after a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived in Washington.

title: COST-OF-LIVING RAISE FOR TRANSIT WORKERS IS ATTACKED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch and the Transit Authority yesterday criticized a costof-living award that will give the city's 35,000 bus and subway employees a 36-cent-an-hour wage increase beginning next week.

title: PUBLISHING: LUCKY HARE
description: TOMORROW marks the first anniversary of the publication in America of ''Masquerade'' by Kit Williams. The British author's book has been a best seller in the United States for much of the year, it boasts 360,000 copies in print here and it has been both the No. 1 adult and No. 1 children's best seller in Britain, where it has sold 400,000 copies. More importantly, the 32-page illustrated fantasy about the misadventures of a rabbit named Jack Hare has bolstered the publishing fortunes of Schocken Books, the small New York publisher that took a huge gamble and won.

title: 13 Die in Philippines Crash
