description: A bus skidded off a winding mountain road and landed in a river, killing 13 people, the Philippine News Agency said today. An American among the victims was identified as Joseph Burch, a retired United States Air Force serviceman living in Baguio, 120 miles north of Manila.

title: Free Walking Tour Of Melville's New York
description: The streets of lower Manhattan that Herman Melville knew will be explored in a free walking tour on Sunday at 2:30 P.M. During the tour, sponsored by the Academy of American Poets, the influences on the writer's works, including the architecture and social history of the early 1800's and mid-1800's, will be discussed by four tour leaders - James Dillon of the New York Landmarks Preservation Commission; Kenneth Jackson, an urban historian and history professor at Columbia University; George Held, a literary historian, and Galway Kinnell, a poet and novelist. Mr. Kinnell will also read from works by Melville, including a passage from ''Moby-Dick.'' Melville was born on Pearl Street and lived in the city at various times in his life. The tour, which goes on rain or shine, begins at the James Watson House, 7 State Street, between Pearl and Whitehall Streets. Information: 427-5665

title: SOVIET IS TARGET AT THE COMMONWEALTH TALKS
description: The Soviet Union was made the principal target of strong denunciations by four Prime Ministers of the Commonwealth here today during a debate on the international situation.

title: MAN IN QUEENS ACCUSED OF PLOT TO ARM I.R.A.
description: A 78-year-old director of the Irish Northern Aid Committee was arrested by Federal agents on a street in Queens yesterday morning on charges of conspiring to ship guns to the Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland.

title: 3 Bach Cantatas
description: A free concert of Bach cantatas will be given by the Cathedral Singers on Sunday at 4 P.M. in the St. James Chapel of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and West 112th Street. The singers will perform Cantatas Nos. 33, 38 and 49 under the direction of Richard Westenburg; an eight-piece ensemble will accompany the singers. Information: 662-2133.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Included a charge of $1 million for liquidation of subsidiary

title: Rare firearms at Christie's.
description: AN auction of rare firearms, billed by Christie's as the first major sale of its kind in the country, will take place Wednesday at 2 P.M. at its galleries at Park Avenue and East 59th Street. It is considered the first public sale of guns in New York in decades, and it is being held with assistance with the firearms division of Colt Industries.

title: Chess; KARPOV BEATS KORCHNOI IN FIRST GAME
description: When the game began, the two antagonists looked away from each other and refused to shake hands. Korchnoi donned a pair of reflecting spectacles shortly thereafter, but Karpov paid no attention, never taking his eyes from the boa rd in front of him.

title: CALNY FOOD SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
CUT & CURL INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
WALESA FACES CONTEST IN ELECTION
description: Three leaders of Solidarity challenged Lech Walesa today in a bid for the chairmanship of the independent labor union.

title: MISPLACED BLAME FOR A SPLIT AMONG SOUTH KOREAN DISSIDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Giving Wingo Tryout
description: The once happy cry of Knick fans for ''Win-GO, Win-GO'' was revived yesterday at Madison Square Garden. The shouts, heard in the mid-1970's, were for Harthorne Nathaniel Wingo Jr., a 6-foot-8-inch forward. Now, at the age of 33 and after five years of playing in Italy and Switzerland, Wingo will be trying for a spot on the Knick roster when training camp opens today at Monmouth College in West Long Branch, N.J.

title: Stadler's 63 Leads by 1
description: Craig Stadler carded four straight birdies on the back nine, shot a seven-under-par 63 and took a one-shot lead over Bruce Lietzke after the first round of the Texas Open.

title: Bridge: A Good Play by Defender Loses Impact by Slowness
description: A defender who makes an unusual play may lose a lot of the impact if he makes it slowly. On the diagramed deal, from the Summer Nationals in Boston, East made his play so quickly that the declarer was completely deceived.

title: THEATER: JANE ALEXANDER PLAYS 'HEDDA GABLER'
description: the sensual Lovborg as well as her submissive husband Tesman - at arm's distance.

title: KOOP PROMISES JOB WON'T BE A 'PULPIT'
description: President Reagan's nominee for Surgeon General, Dr. C. Everett Koop, said at his confirmation hearing today that although he strongly opposed abortion he would not use his job ''as a pulpit for ideology.''

title: HOROWITZ TO PLAY MET BENEFIT NOV. 1
description: Yesterday was the 77th birthday of Vladimir Horowitz. ''I'm an old man and I don't know if I can play any more,'' he dolefully said, looking out at an interviewer at the corner of his eyes. He wandered over to the piano. ''But perhaps.'' The Horowitz hands began to play pearly Scarlatti, crashing Liszt, songful Rachmaninoff, the coda of Chopin's F minor Ballade. ''Maybe,'' he admitted, ''the reflexes are not so bad, after all.''

title: FLEMING LIFTED BY DAVIS CUP
description: Peter Fleming says the worst is behind him. But the ride from No. 8 to No. 103 in the world rankings was longer and more frustrating than he had imagined.

title: HOUSE KILLS MEASURE OF CAPITAL'S COUNCIL TO ERASE SEX CURBS
description: The House, reacting to pressure from fundamentalist religious groups, today killed a District of Columbia bill that would have legalized most sexual acts between consenting adults.

title: How to Figure Certificate's Yield
description: Here is how to figure the yield on a tax-exempt savings certificate, starting with the discount rate for one-year Treasury bills.

title: STOCKMAN TELLS CONGRESS IT FACES VOTES ON CUTS 'AGAIN AND AGAIN'
description: President Reagan's budget chief, David A. Stockman, told Congress today that it would have to cast politically painful budget-cutting votes ''again and again and again.''

title: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After a tax loss carryforward credit for Canadian subsidiary of $9,000...C-After tax credits of $17,000 in latest 9 mos and $39,000 for the earlier period; the 1980 tax credit amounts reclassified for comparative purposes

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adage Inc., Billerica, Mass., has elected to its board William N. Mitchell, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Unitrode, a semiconductor manufacturer.

title: Steelmakers Set Cuts
description: Steel producers, faced with a decline in orders and the prospect of a stagnant fourth-quarter market, are temporarily furloughing workers and suspending some operations.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $59,000 for the qr and $145,000 for the yr and tax credits of $281,000 for the qr and $2,875,000 for the yr...C-1980 figures included income of $760,000 for qr and $1,144,000 for yr from reduction of deferred Federal income taxes and income representing revers of balance of issuance reserves of $832,000 and $841,000 for th qr and yr, plus tax credits of $1,260,000 for the qr and $2,621 for the yr

title: GRUMMAN LOBBIES AGAINST LTV BID
description: The chairman and chief executive officer of the Grumman Corporation, John C. Bierwirth, sought Congressional support today for his efforts to block a $450 million takeover of Grumman, Long Island's biggest employer, by the LTV Corporation of Dallas.

title: MORE TAXES, PLEASE
description: 2WASHINGTON - The Reagan team has finally awakened to the reality that they simply don't have enough revenue to balance the Federal budget in the foreseeable future. They slashed tax receipts by $150 billion in fiscal 1984 (and $270 billion in 1986) without nailing down expenditure cuts that would bring the budget even close to balance. They forgot that the tight monetary policy of the Federal Reserve - which they avidly support - would collide with continued high deficits to generate high interest rates that are retarding and will retard economic growth.

title: BURT REYNOLDS SEEKS HEIR IN 'PATERNITY'
description: ''PATERNITY,'' which opens today at Loews State 2 and other theaters, is a frail comedy about Buddy Evans (Burt Reynolds), a single fellow who, on his 44th birthday, decides he wants a son to give him some sort of immortality, someone who, as he puts it, will say, ''Buddy Evans was here.''

title: Fiat to Lay Off 70,000
description: Fiat, the Italian state-owned auto maker, said today that it would temporarily lay off 70,000 workers for varying periods in October, November and December. Fiat blamed the weakness of the overseas export market and high stocks for the layoffs. A Fiat spokesman said the workers would be laid off for 10 days beginning next Monday, for 10 days in November and for 12 days in December.

title: LISZT JURY WITHOLDS TOP PRIZE
description: Muza Rubackitye of the Soviet Union and Hortense Cartier-Bresson, a French-born, American-trained pianist, won second and third prize, respectively, in the Liszt-Bartok Piano Competition that ended here last night. No first prize was awarded because the jury of 19 pianists and educators decided that none of the entrants - a total of 66 from 20 countries - had merited it.

title: PBS'S 'ENTERPRISE' AIMS AT REPORTING HOW BUSINESS RUNS
description: Even before its premiere tonight, ''Enterprise,'' a weekly series of 13 half-hour television documentaries that details the strivings of various American business people, has attracted attention. It comes at a time when television's economic coverage has increased and, some business partisans say, is more balanced.

title: SINGLE ISSUES' WORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Ainge's Trial Goes to the Jury
description: Peter Bavasi, the president of the Toronto Blue Jays, testified yesterday that he had been ''shocked and stunned'' by Danny Ainge's decision to quit baseball so he could play basketball for the Boston Celtics.

title: STAR SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
British Banks Set 16% Rate
description: British banks lifted their interest rates to 16 percent from 14 percent today, the second sharp rise in two weeks encouraged by the authorities to tighten monetary policy and bolster the British pound.

title: Notes on People; After a Long Fight, Mrs. Mailer Is Evicted
description: She had won one reprieve after another, but time and legal recourse finally ran out for Beverly Mailer, a former wife of the novelist Norman Mailer.

title: REAGAN REASSERTS VOW TO VETO BILLS THAT 'BUST BUDGET'
description: President Reagan, marking the first day of the new fiscal year, today reiterated a vow that he would veto any appropriation bill that violated his plan to reduce Government spending.

title: Advertising; Eisaman's 20 Years With G.M.
description: SHADES of Dinah Shore. Eisaman, Johns & Laws, a 25-year-old Los Angeles ad agency, is seeing the U.S.A. with its Chevrolet. That's about the size of it. You see, about 20 years ago the first of the General Motors' division's dealer advertising associations, which was in southern California, appointed the agency.

title: Tenants of Hotels May Get Leases
description: Tenants of single-room-occupancy hotels, many of whom have complained of harassment and illegal evictions, will soon have the right to demand written leases.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE ISLANDS. America's Imperial Adven- ture in the Philippines. By Emily Hahn. Illustrated. 258 pages. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $14.95.

title: WILLIAM COLBY'S UNGRATEFUL NATION
description: uf913To the Editor:

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; ORGAN MUSIC AT MIDNIGHT
description: Calvin Hampton, who has been playing the organ at midnight on Fridays at Calvary Church, Park Avenue South and 21st Street, for the last seven years, will begin his eighth season tonight with the premiere of a work he wrote for the occasion. Also on the program will be Bach's Fantasy and Fugue in G minor, which makes Mr. Hampton feel like ''a mad Teutonic organist,'' and Mozart's Fantasy in F minor, which was written for a mechanical organ but transcribed. There's no admission fee to the concerts, which he says draw a mixed crowd - ''old and young, rich and poor, weird and ordinary.'' Mr.Hampton chats a little about the pieces he plays and, when he is finished, joins the audience for cider and cookies.

title: NO. 1 SPOT IS CAPTURED BY DOLPHINS
description: The Miami Dolphins are the top team in professional football, according to The New York Times's first computer ranking of the season. After the Dolphins come the Philadelphia Eagles and the Dallas Cowboys, the league's two other undefeated teams.

title: SAVER CERTIFICATES MAKE THEIR DEBUT
description: They came in packs, and they came in steady dribbles. Some came with new money being shifted from other investments. But most came with old money, already in one savings account or another. Some came with clear conviction and some came with confusion. But they came, and most banks seemed content, if not overwhelmed, by the showing.

title: Money Funds I n Small Gain
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds climbed $732 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday, the 18th consecutive weekly increase, but the smallest since June 3.

title: Around the Nation; Marine Guard Cleared Of Cruelty on Brig Duty
description: A court-martial today acquitted a young marine of jabbing a nightstick into the ribs of sailors and poking them in the eyes while guarding the brig aboard the aircraft carrier Ranger.

title: CLIBURN WINNER SCHUB OPENS CARNEGIE SEASON
description: IN Texas, at the Van Cliburn Competition, Andre-Michel Schub impressed some observers as a brilliant, dedicated but rather cold pianist. He went on to win the competition, which means two years of steady playing here, in Europe and the Far East. The Van Cliburn Competition t reats its winners well. Since his emergence as a winner,Mr. Schub fro m all accounts has been a different kind of pianist. New Yorkers c an check out the new Schub this Sunday afternoon, when he launches t he Carnegie Hall season playing the Beethoven ''Emperor'' C oncerto with the American Symphony under Sergiu Comissiona.

title: BREZHNEV PROMISING 'CONSTRUCTIVE' SPIRIT IN TALKS ON MISSILES
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, said today that the Soviet Union was prepared to enter in a fair and constructive spirit into talks with the United States on medium-range nuclear forces in Europe. He was allu ding to the decision reached last week by Secretary of State Alexand er M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko toresume the ta lks in November in Geneva. Mr. Brezhnev's comment, made in a meeting with President Didier Ratsiraka of Madagascar, was reported by t he Government press agency Tass.

title: Sports of The Times; A Big Week for Sports in the Big City
description: FIFTH AVENUE was a busy place last weekend. On Saturday Sydney Maree, an emigre from South Africa, ran the second-fastest mile in history over the manhole covers and the depressions of that fabled avenue. And on Sunday, Leonard Nitz, an emigre from California and an Olympic cyclist, won the 75-mile Apple Lap with a finishing spurt to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: U.S. WILL PERMIT RUSSIANS TO TRIPLE IMPORTS OF GRAIN
description: The United States has agreed to nearly triple - to 23 million metric tons - the amount of American wheat and corn that the Soviet Union will be allowed to purchase in the next 12 months, American officials announced here today.

title: PIPING, FROM THE PALACE TO THE GARDEN
description: TRUMPETS will blare and bagpipes will skirl this weekend as two of Britain's most celebrated ceremonial troops begin a 63-city tour of North America.

title: China Meets Oil-Flow Goal
description: China produced 553.8 million barrels of crude oil in t he first nine months of the year, the Government's New China News Agency reported today. If the pace is ma intained, China will reach its goal of producing 733 million barre ls for 1981, the agency said.

title: Bird Escapes F rom Courtroom
description: The bird that spent about 36 hours trying to find its way out of Criminal Court at 100 Centre Street in Manhattan flew to freedom yesterday morning.

title: JERSEY ECONOMY DOMINATES SECOND FLORIO-KEAN DEBATE
description: The two major candidates for Governor in the November elections flailed at one another's economic proposals and positions on the appropriate role of government as they met in their second debate of the campaign.

title: Around the Nation; Bomb Accidentally Made Is Safely Detonated
description: The bomb squad today removed and safely detonated a toxic explosive substance from a University of Massachusetts building where the substance had accidentally formed in a chemistry experiment.

title: Around the Nation;  zg State's Case Detailed In Newport Poisoning
description: Claus von Bulow, accused of trying to kill his wife with insulin, obtained drugs from a New York prostitute, according to the state's evidence against him.

title: Keith Meyers Can Winter Be Far Behind?
description: As custodians shoveled up potting soil that supported arrangements of summer flowers, the rink at Rockefeller Center was readied for its most famous activity. If work is completed on schedule, ice skating begins Saturday.

title: BID PUT OFF
description: Newmont Mining stock surged nearly $6 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $58.125, after Consolidated Gold Fields announced that it would delay further purchases of Newmont stock until Oct. 15 - nine days after it would have been free under Federal law to resume buying. Gold Fields already owns 8.1 percent of the Newmont Mining Corporation.

title: Around the World; Pope Is Pronounced Fit; Resumes Normal Work
description: Pope John Paul II today resumed normal activity after a long period of convalescence following an attack on his life on May 13, Vatican officials said.

title: Oil Concerns' Link To Soviet Project
description: Five Western oil companies, three of them American, are part owners of a consortium negotiating to bring Soviet natural gas to Western Europe through a pipeline opposed by the United States Government as a threat to NATO, records show. Both President Reagan and the State Department have expressed concern about the deal, which is estimated to cost between $12 billion and $15 billion.

title: POLLUTION CONTROL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SWAN'S ARM DOESN'T HURT
description: Through no particular misdeed of their own, the Mets were eliminated from the second-half pennant race last night when the Montreal Expos defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates 300 miles from Shea Stadium.

title: Notes on People; Any Resemblance Is Not Coincidental, Suit Argues
description: It was not billed as a roman a clef, but June E. Pritchard says that Stephen King's novel, ''The Shining,'' was just that and, what is more, that she was the key.

title: ELATED SHIRLEY WILLIAMS PLOTS CHANGE OF COURSE FOR BRITAIN
description: Shirley Williams, who could be Britain's next Prime Minister, radiates nonstop confidence over the nation's newest political phenomenon, her infant Social Democratic Party and its alliance with the Liberals.

title: Captured Coast Shark Dies
description: A year-old female great white shark, captured last week, died today at the Marineland aquatic park. Marineland officials had hoped it would be the first great white to survive more than 16 days in captivity.

title: MUSIC: RARE 'L'HISTOIRE'
description: COMPOSERS' SHOWCASE is celebrating its 25th anniversary this season by doing what it has always done - focusing attention on the works of 20th-century composers. But Charles Schwartz, founder and director of the series, decided that something a little special was in order this season, and so he planned a three-day mini-festival that got under way at the Whitney Museum on Wednesday night.

title: Briefing
description: W HAT is described as an emotionally painful shakeup is being prepared by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig at the State Department, according to well-placed officials who say it represents a break of sorts in the Long Gray Line.

title: THRATER: CLAUDETTE COLBERT IN 'TALENT FOR MURDER'
description: before we get to the sorry heart of the matter -let's pause for a fond salute to Claudette Colbert. In ''A Talent for Murder,'' the Jerome Chodorov-Norman Panama play that arrived at the Biltmore last night, this star is quite a surprise.

title: TIGERS FALL TO 2D PLACE AFTER 5-4 LOSS TO ORIOLES
description: Gary Roenicke hit a tiebreaking sacrifice fly with one out in the 10th inning yesterday to give the Baltimore Orioles a 5-4 victory over the Tigers at Detroit.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC
description: MATTERS

title: DALTON PLANNING A CHAIN TO SELL DISCOUNT BOOKS
description: B. Dalton Booksellers, which has grown from a single bookstore to a 600-store industry giant in the last 15 years, is preparing to open a nationwide chain of discount bookstores. The new discount chain, Pickwick Books, plans to open three stores this year in Columbus, Ohio, and to have 150 stores operating by the end of 1986, by which time Dalton also expects to have 1,000 bookstores under its own name.

title: Business People; BEGELMAN NAMED UNITED ARTISTS CHIEF
description: David Begelman, the 59-year-old president and chief operating officer of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company, has been named chief executive officer of the United Artists Corporation. He was also appointed to the vacant post of chairman.

title: PROPOSAL FOR A $500 MILLION BOND ISSUE FOR PRISON CONSTRUCTION
description: For the first time in a half-century, people in New York State will have an opportunity Nov. 3 to vote for or against a bond issue for the state's prisons: Proposition 1, the $500 million Secure Correctional Facilities Bond Issue.

title: Loan in Peru Delayed
description: The Southern Peru Copper Corporation said today that it had postponed its proposed $100 million 9 3/4 percent refinancing because the necessary steps for putting it into effect could not be completed by the Oct. 15 closing date. It said the loan would refinance some existing secured long-term debt. Southern Peru is majority-owned by Asarco Inc. Other owners are the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the Newmont Mining Corporation and the Marmon Group Inc.

title: ADDISON-WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes an additional income tax provision for prior yrs of $600,000 or 24 cents a shr

title: ANATOMY OF A SUCCESSFUL PARTY
description: After Zubin Mehta warmed up the New York Philharmonic orchestra with the overture to ''Die Fledermaus'' at Lincoln Center last week, Danny Kaye and bedlam took over. He led the orchestra through Beethoven, Sousa and a safety razor commercial and was granted a standing ovation. Still holding their sides, 820 members of the glittering black-tie audience moved to a tent in nearby Damrosch Park for a supper dance that lasted into the night.

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After an extraordinary item of tax benefit carryforward the company announced that a 100 percent stock distribution to its shareholders of record Oct 1, 1981 will be paid Oct 16

title: Harvester Order
description: The International Harvester Company, its traditional business for farm implements battered by the nation's economic slowdown, said it had secured a multimillion-dollar order from the Army for 769 rough terrain forklifts. Harvester said the contract is worth $53 million over four years and could reach a value of $128 million if the Army exercises an option for another 769 units. Production is set to begin at Harvester's Libertyville plant next August, the company said.

title: Canada Bill Rate Off
description: The average yield on this week's issue of 90-day Treasury bills fell slightly, to 19.35 percent, from 19.38 percent last week, the Bank of Canada said today. The new rate means that the official bank rate, Canada's benchmark lending rate, will fall to 19.60 percent next week from the 19.6 3 percent posted last week.

title: TELECOMMUNICATION NETWORKS SPLIT FROM BRITISH POST OFFICE
description: Britain's unitary approach of keeping telephone, telecommunications and postal services in one organization - the British Post Office - ended today when British Telecom, which operates Britain's telephone and telecommunications system, was formally split from the Post Office.

title: Polish Concert Follows Pulaski Day Parade
description: After watching the Pulaski Day Parade proceed up Fifth Avenue on Sunday, spectators will be able to listen to a free outdoor concert by the Polish pianist Wladimir Kochanski at 5:30 P.M. at the Damrosch Park Bandshell in Lincoln Center. On the program are Ballades by Chopin and Polish folk tunes.

title: ART: LEGENDARY MASTER OF EARLY PHOTOGRAPHY
description: FEW photography exhibitions have been as eagerly awaited as the show devoted to the work of the French photographer Eugene Atget opening tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art. Atget, who died in 1927 at the age of 70, is clearly one of the great figures in the history of photography, a master whose work has acquired a legendary status for connoisseurs of the medium.

title: HYATT HOTEL, WHERE 113 DIED, IS TERMED SAFE ON REOPENING
description: The 40-story Hyatt Regency Hotel reopened this afternoon, without fanfare, when a group of jewelers pushed throug h the hotel's revolving doors and made their way across the refurbish ed lobby to the registration desk.

title: BUILDING DOWN 1.6% IN AUGUST
description: American builders, still hampered by high interest rates, put up new construction in August at the lowest rate since last fall, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: BOMB AT P.L.O. OFFICE KILLS AT LEAST 50
description: A car packed with more than a hundred pounds of explosives blew up today outside Palestinian guerrilla offices in a crowded street, killing at least 50 people and wounding more than 250, according to officials.

title: THE U.S. AND SALVADOR
description: .8,2WASHINGTON - The Senate was at its best when on Sept. 24 it refused to drop an amendment proposed by Christopher J. Dodd, Connecticut Democrat, requiring President Reagan, in advance of any further United States assistance, to certify twice a year that El Salvador is working to put an end to the ''indiscriminate torture and murder'' practiced by its armed forces. This amendment points the way toward a common-sense resolution of the Salvadoran crisis.

title: A Tight Squeeze
description: Tom Burleson, who some time ago told the Atlanta Hawks that his long-ailing knee would keep him sidelined this season, will keep active by squeezing his 7-foot-3-inch frame into the cockpit of a hydroplane racing boat.

title: Argentina Gets Loan
description: The Bank of America said today that 77 international banks had signed a seven-year, $600 million loan agreement with Argentina.

title: PANEL URGES A LIMIT ON PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARIES
description: A group of 20 politicians and other public figures, led by former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina, today released a report proposing that Presidential primaries be held on only four days, each a month apart, but said that no delegates should be picked in those primaries.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
EVELYN CRONSON LUBIN, BENEFACTOR OF SEVERAL NEW YORK UNIVERSITIES
description: Evelyn Cronson Lubin, who with her husband was a major benefactor to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and other educational institutions, died Wednesday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: THE MILITARY FAIRNESS FACTOR
description: To the Editor:

title: About Real Estate; HOW SHARP CUTS IN FEDERAL HELP WILL AFFECT HOUSING
description: The not surprising news from Washington is that subsidies for housing are dropping sharply. Public housing has been particularly hard hit as its operating subsidies shrink.

title: OVAL OFFICE-SPEAK
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan And Crime
description: President Reagan went for and got the headlines in his New Orleans speech on crime. But he left almost unmentioned the most serious plans of his Justice Department for doing something useful about crime and violence in American streets.

title: KUWAIT SAYS IRAN RAIDED OIL SITE
description: Kuwait said today that Iranian jets attacked and set fire to one of its oil installations last night in the third such air attack since the start of the Iran-Iraq war more than a year ago.

title: Advertising; Agency Wins Account F or 3-D Camera Photos
description: Completely unrelated but involving the advertising side of Ogilvy & Mather is the report that the Nimslo Corporation of Atlanta, developers of a camera that it says produces three-dimensional photographs, has assigned the agency its account.

title: U.N. SESSION PUTS ENVOYS ON DISPLAY AROUND CITY
description: As certain as the return of chilly mornings, autumn brings to New York a frenetic fortnight of diplomatic activity. More than 120 foreign ministers, with a sprinkling of heads of state and government, have descended on the city for the ''general debate'' of the 36th General Assembly - two weeks of speeches, at times winding late into the evening, when envoys from each of the 156 member states address the United Nations.

title: Ouch! That Tackle Hurt
description: There was no penalty on the play, but Odis McKinney, the Oakland Raider safety , was fined $500 by the league for what Commissioner Pete Rozelle called a ''flagrant'' tackle on Steve Dils, the Minnesota Vik ing quarterback, in a game two weeks ago. Coach Bud Grant of the Vikings had complained that the hit by McKinney, a former Giant, was unnecessarily violent, as were two tackles made against the V ikings the following week by the Detroit Lions.

title: CSX Corp. Net Soars by 87.5%
description: The CSX Corporation, a diversified railroad holding company formed through the November 1980 merger of the Chessie System and Seaboard Coast Line industries, reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter ended Sept. 30 soared 87.5 percent while revenues increased 16.7 percent.

title: How sense of humor saves Walter Hill.
description: ''IT'S a bit of a bandit's profession, being a film director,'' Walter Hill says blithely. ''Like being a congressman, or a journalist, instead of working for a living.'' Fortunately, Mr. Hill is a bandit with a sense of humor, or he might think he'd gone crazy, after reading conflicting reviews of his latest effort, ''Southern Comfort,'' which opened in New York a week ago.

title: HOPE IN FED'S LONG BATTLE
description: The Federal Reserve Board, after years of failure, is now showing that it can control the money supply and thus put the squeeze on inflation. The Fed's success so far this year puts hard numbers behind the rhetoric of monetary restraint voiced over the past two years by its chairman, Paul A. Volcker.

title: House, 328-58, Votes to Keep Milk Supports at Lower Level
description: The House voted today, 328 to 58, to roll back a 3 percent increase in dairy price supports that would cost the Government mo re than $1 million a day and probably result in consumerprice increas es.

title: Despair In Guatemala
description: Nobody seems excited. Nobody sounds emotional. There is an eerie quiet in Guatemala. Day after day the newspapers print items like one the day I came: ''Unknowns killed 31 peasants in Rabinal,'' a small county. ''Unknowns'' has become a code for armed men on the Government side. The item also said that ''none of the victims has been identified so far, since the residents who remained alive preferred to flee their (four different) villages and nobody knows where to find them.''

title: Crab and Beer Buffet
description: An all-you-can-eat crab and beer festival sponsored by the Village Visiting Neighbors will be held tonight from 6 to 9 o'clock at Our Lady of Pompei Church, the Avenue of the Americas and Bleecker Street.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON NEW FOOD STAMP CUTS
description: On the day that President Reagan's first round of budget cuts went into effect, a compromise was reached on Capitol Hill that would slice food stamp benefits by $138 more a year for an average family of four. But the bipartisan agreement also provides enough extra money to forestall even deeper cuts that had been threatened for the fiscal year that began today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ago International B.V. said about 2 million shares of Life Investors Inc. common stock was tendered as of midnight Wednesday, the proration date under its offer to purchase Life Investors' stock.

title: HART SCHAFFNER & MARX reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
News An alysis
description: In assuming office in January, the Reagan Administration said President Jimmy Carter had been ''clumsy and illadvised'' to pledge protection of the Persian Gulf because the United States lacked the military forces to sustain the commitment.

title: NEW AWACS PROVISIONS CITED BY HAIG IN SENATE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. informed a Senate committee today of what he called new ''understandings'' with the Government of Saudi Arabia about the terms of a proposed sale of Awacs aircraft to that nation. But he encountered continued skepticism and hostility toward the sale from important members of the committee.

title: DECISION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GIANTS ARE FAVORED TO DEFEAT PACKERS
description: The Giants take on a team their size - the Green Bay Packers, who have lost three straight times - at home Sunday. The Jets have a less appetizing assignment, facing the unbeaten Dolphins in Miami. The Giants are favored; the Jets are not.

title: Delayed U.S. Blast Set Off
description: A twice-delayed underground nuclear test was detonated today by American scientists. It was scheduled for 8 A.M., but scientists ordered a two-hour delay to 10 A.M. to wait for more favorable winds. As a precaution aga inst accidental release of radioactivity, tests are not conducted whe n winds are blowing toward Las Vegas.

title: HOW SENATOR PROXMIRE SERVES HIS STATISTICS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SENATOR WHO SPEAKS FOR PRESIDENT REAGAN
description: When Paul Laxalt talks, like the man from E.F. Hutton, everyone listens. Late Tuesday evening, for example, his working style was on display on the Senate floor, which was in disarray. The President had asked Congress to raise the debt limit to the politically perilous sum of more than $1 trillion, and the Republicans were wary of being tagged as big spenders.

title: ASTROS WIDEN LEAD BY BEATING REDS, 8-1
description: Nolan Ryan, who pitched the fifth no-hitter of his career in his previous start, pitched a seven-hitter yesterday, and the Houston Astros took advantage of 11 walks to widen their lead in the National League West to one and one-half games with an 8-1 victory yesterday over the second-place Cincinnati Reds.

title: The Evening Hours
description: A T some parties, the main attraction is the guests. At others it's the setting. At still others, the quantity or quality of the beverages served. But at three parties this week, while all of those elements played a part, the star was definitely the food.

title: Rockies Get 2 Islanders
description: The Islanders traded Bob Lorimer and Dave Cameron to the Colorado Rockies yesterday for future considerations. Lorimer, a defenseman, was to start his third full season with the Islanders, who are the defending Stanley Cup champions; Cameron, a center, has yet to appear in a National Hockey League game.

title: Marilynn K. Yee Legal Aid Society Lawyers Vote to Stay on the Job
description: Members of the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys counting ballots after a stormy two-hour session yesterday at their headquarters at 13 Astor Place. The lawyers voted 281 to 189 to accept a one-year contract that would give them a 5.5 percent increase in salary. The dominant opinion expressed during the debate was that a strike at this time could mean the end of the organization, which represents the city's poor in civil and criminal cases.

title: WHEELCHAIR BUS SERVICE GETS OFF TO A ROUGH START
description: The Transit Authority began issuing keys to bus drivers to enable them to operate special wheelchair lifts on new General Motors buses yesterday. Several handicapped people were unable to board buses Wednesday because of a dispute between the drivers' union and the Transit Authority.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC BUYING 3 SOFTWARE COMPANIES
description: The General Electric Company, in a move intended to strengthen its computer services business, said it would acquire three private computer software companies for a price totaling between $35 million and $68 million, based on performance measurements over the next few years.

title: CITY EMPLOYEES CITED IN INQUIRY ON FOOD STAMPS
description: Federal officials believe tens of millions of dollars have been stolen from New York City's food-stamp program by organized groups with the cooperation of city employees, check-cashing offices and wholesale food companies.

title: COAST A-PLANT CONSTRUCTION ERROR TIED TO MISSING GUIDE TO BLUEPRINT
description: The mix-up that caused the improper placement of supports designed to protect the cooling systems of the two Diablo Canyon nuclear reactors from earthquakes occurred because a single, transparent blueprint was prepared for both, and someone failed to attach instructions to flip it over.

title: NEW FACES
description: WAHT MAKES TWO OLYMPIC HEROES RUN IN THE BRITISH 'CHARIOTS OF FIRE'

title: Borodin Trio to Play Shostakovich Program
description: The Borodin Trio will present a Shostakovich program Sunday at 8 P.M. in the Reisinger Concert Hall of Sarah Lawrence College, Glen Washington Road and Kimball Avenue in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Baroness A. de la Grange, 93; Related to Sloane's Founder
description: Baroness Amaury de la Grange, the granddaughter of the founder of the W & J Sloane Company, died in an accident Sunday while in her chauffeur-driven automobile in Monaco. She was 93 years old.

title: Poetry at Poe's Cottage
description: The 132d anniversary of the death of Edgar Allan Poe will be marked on Sunday at 2 P.M. with a free outdoor poetr y reading sponsored by the Bronx County Historical Society at Poe Co ttage, Grand Concourse and East Kingsbridge Road.

title: Zoe Caldwell and Judith Anderson p lan to do 'Medea.'
description: ZOE CALDWELL, who has rarely appeared on the stage in recent years, plans to play Medea this winter. She will go into rehearsal in January, open at the University of Tennessee on Feb. 12 for a threeweek run, and movethe second week of April into the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. If all goes well, the Robinson Jeffers adaptation of Euripides's ''Medea'' is likely to turn up on Broadway later in the season.

title: OCTOBER HARVEST IN DUTCHESS COUNTY
description: THE grapes hang heavy on the bough, the turkeys are fattening, the pumpkins are splitting, the foxes are running, the geese are flying and the apples are as red as the evening sun.

title: LETTER BY WALL ST. TO REAGAN NOTES MARKET INDEPENDENCE
description: President Reagan, in an effort to show that Wall Street supports his economic program, read at his news conference today a two-week-old letter from the Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's leading trade group.

title: Around the World; China Presses Plan To Reunify With Taiwan
description: The Chinese Communist Party insisted today that its new proposals for reunification with Taiwan were reasonable and had been made after taking full account of the interests of the Taiwan authorities.

title: Around the World; U.S. General Meets Worried Nicaraguans
description: A United States Army general has opened talks with Nicaraguan officials to calm their fears about joint Honduran-United States naval maneuvers scheduled for next week, Government spokesmen in Managua said.

title: Sharpening the Ax
description: It doesn't sound good for Manager Bobby Cox's future with the Atlanta Braves: Ted Turner, the usually loquacious owner, refused to talk about reports that Cox would not be back next year. ''I'm just not saying nothing,'' said Turner. ... An Atlanta newspaper report said the Braves would also drop Gaylord Perry, the 43-year-old pitcher who is just four victories shy of 300. ... Ferguson Jenkins, 36 victories from 300 and 38 strikeouts from 3,000, will not be a Texas Ranger next season.

title: EX-DEAN OF SCHOOL OF MUSIC IN TORONTO
description: Boyd Neel, former dean of the Royal Conservatory of Music in Toronto and conductor of the Boyd Neel Orchestra in the 30's , died ofcancer Wednesday in Toronto. He was 76 years old.

title: A Fake Stick for School Dropouts
description: Give the New York Board of Regents an ''A'' for the initiative but an ''F'' for the way it proposes to solve the problem of high school dropouts. The board threatens to withdraw accreditation from schools that fail to hang onto their students.

title: MORT SAHL, INTRACTABLE AS EVER, BACK IN TOWN
description: It was as if he had never been away. Wearing an oxford blue shirt peeping out from the V-neck of his blue wool sweater and poplin trousers and a cou ple of newspapers tucked under his arm, Mort Sahl walked onto a New York stage for the first time in seven years and began to chat .

title: 8-WEEK FILM SERIES CASTS ASTORIA AS A MOVIE CAPITAL
description: THE MARX BROTHERS' ''Animal Crackers'' is a classic Hollywood comedy, correct? Not quite. It is a classic comedy, all right, but it was made in Queens, and Dr. Richard Koszarski, a film historian at the Astoria Foundation, would like you to remember that.

title: Index; International
description: Labor Party i n B ritain votes to quit Common Market A2 Shirley Williams plots Britain's future course A2 Khomeini names military com- mander to replace crash victim A3 Pressmen at The Sunday Times approve pact A4 Around the World A5 Soviet is target at Commonwealth talks A7 Sadat sends envoy with plea for U.S. arms for Sudan A8 Plusses and pitfalls in new U.S.- Israel links A8 Brezhnev says Soviet plans con- structive missile talks A9 West Germans free Brandt case spy A9 Government/Politics Court that shaped Southern his- tory comes to an end A14 Surgeon General nominee vows not to use job as a ''pulpit'' A16 House kills capital measure eas- ing sex curbs A16 General Assembly session ushers in whirlwind of activity B1 Florio and Kean clash over their economic proposals B2 DelBello links sheriff to charges in anonymous letter B2 Wheelchair service for handi- capped is begun on city buses B3 Washington Talk Briefing A24 Working profile of Senator Paul Laxalt A24 Booklet offers insights of former No. 2 man at State Department A24 General First food stamp recipients com- ment as rules tighten A12 Around the Nation A14 Detroit's baseball team has a city by the tail A14 Hyatt Regency, where 113 died, reopens without fanfare A20 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 October harvest in Dutchess County C1 Mort Sahl returns to New York scene after 7 years C14 Theater: Broadway C2

title: Matthew Forelli, 73, Founder Of a Manufacturer in Queens
description: Matthew A. Forelli, founder and retired president of the Precision Manufacturing Company in Corona, Queens, died Tuesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Old Greenwich.

title: BONN RELEASED SPY IN '74 BRANDT CASE
description: West Germany, in an exchange with East Germany, today released the master spy whose activities led to the 1974 resignation of Willy Brandt as Chancellor.

title: Olive Oil Kills 3 More in Spain
description: The health authorities said three more people died today from contaminated cooking oil that has already been blamed for 140 deaths since May. The olive oil, adulterated with rapeseed oil that is used for industrial purposes, has caused 15,000 people to be hospitalized.

title: REAGAN SAYS U.S. WOULD BAR A TAKEOVER IN SAUDI ARABIA THAT IMPERILED FLOW OF OIL
description: President Reagan broadened the American commitment in the Persian Gulf today by saying that the United States would not allow Saudi Arabia to fall into the hands of any internal or external forces threatening to cut off oil supplies for the West.

title: ETHIOPIA'S BLACK JEWS, A PERILED COMMUNITY
description: .8,2TORONTO - Once again, Jews are victims. T his time, the Falashas, the black Jews of Ethiopia, face possible ext inction. What is more, few Jews, in Israel and elsewhere, seem to ca re or will take action.

title: 2 More Olympic Games
description: BADEN, West Germany, Oct. 1 (AP) - Te nnis and table tennis were taken into the Olympics today, starting in 1988, bringing to 23 the number of sports in the Summer Games.

title: JAZZY COLLAGES BY ROMARE BEARDEN AT THE BROOKLYN
description: AS retrospectives go, ''Romare Bearden, 1970-1980'' at the Brooklyn Museum is selective to the point of austerity. A listing of works in the catalogue reveals that during the 10 years in question, Mr. Bearden produced 342 collages, 128 oils on paper, 122 watercolors, 24 drawings, 25 prints, 5 tapestries, 4 murals and mosaics, and a number of illustrations, designs for film and theater, magazine covers, record covers, book jackets, banners and quilts. Every one of these is carefully listed in the catalogue, which also includes a lengthy and fascinating essay by Albert Murray on Mr. Bearden's general development and a brief art-historical summary by Dore Ashton.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. 'BABBLE' AT GDANDK
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Citrus Company Debenture Offer
description: CO., the Florida citrus company whose efforts to buy in its shares with a 15 1/2 percent, 20-year debenture have been unavailing, has raised its offer.

title: NETS ANXIOUS ON ALBERT KING
description: While the Nets were delighted to announce that they had agreed to negotiate a contract with Henry Bibby, a free-agent guard, they were on edge about Albert King.

title: Xerox Increasing Prices on Rentals
description: The Xerox Corporation said it was increasing rental prices on its entire line of copiers and duplicators sold in the United States, a move the company said reflected increased labor and material costs.

title: TETRA TECH INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 2
description: B-After a gain on sale of land of $465,000

title: 'MASTERPIECE'S 'ALICE,' MUSICIANS AND NAZISM
description: ''MASTERPIE CE Theater'' is going to Australian television for six weeks, abando ning productions of the British Isles for the first timein the 10 yea rs the series has been on public television. This Sundayat 9 P.M. on WNET-TV, the new offering will be ''A Town Like Alice,''based on a Ne vil Shute novel that was published in the United States as ''The Lega cy.'' (There is also a 1956 movie version of the story starring the late Peter Finch and Virginia McKenna.)

title: AFTER 3 YEARS, 'ANNIE'S' STAR RETURNS IN BERLIN REVUE
description: BACK in the spring of 1977, Andrea McArdle was the 13-year-old star of ''Annie,'' and through radio, newspapers and television her face and voice became as familiar as a friend's. She posed numberless times with the striking, bald munitions magnate Daddy Warbucks and the friendly mongrel Sandy. Most unforgettably, she belted out the show-stopper ''Tomorrow'' in a husky voice that charmed audiences and helped win her a Tony award nomination. She was the youngest person to receive the honor.

title: U.S.- ISRAEL STRATEGIC LINK: BOTH SIDES TAKE STOCK
description: For years, Israel has tried to sell itself as a ''strategic asset'' to the United States. Boasting a crucial location, sophisticated military power and a singular stability in the Middle East as a pro-American activist, Israel has wanted very much to be treated by Washington as an ally.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: 1980 figures include a gain from sale of property of $146,430 for the qr and $536,750 for the yr

title: IRAN NAMES MILITARY CHIEF TO REPLACE AIR CRASH VICTIM
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini appointed a new military commander for Iran today to repl ace the general who diedwith three other military leaders in a plane crash near Teheran on Tuesday.

title: ARTHUR MILLER PLAY SET TO STANLEY SILVERMAN MUSIC RESURFACES
description: Never underestimate the resilience of an Arthur Miller play. When ''The Creation of the World and Other Business'' appeared on Broadway in the 1972-73 season, the public showed no particular interest in it. Mr. Miller's sly reworking of Genesis ran briefly and then dropped into the playwright's purgatory of short runs and unfulfilled hopes.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's proposal last month to cut the revenue-sharing program by 12 percent in 1982 threatens to shatter the uneasy alliance he has established with state and local officials.

title: COURT THAT SHAPED SOUTHERN HISTORY ENDS LONG AND BUSY LIFE
description: Accompanied by an assortment of unjudicial sounds, the clicking of cameras, reminiscing, occasional laughter and a few tears, the 90-year-old United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, whose judges desegregated the Deep South, went out of existence here today.

title: SHIRLEY BASSEY SINGS AT CARNEGIE
description: night engagement at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, is a singer so addicted to the grand gesture that she leaves no room for subtlety. Miss Bassey, whose signature song, ''This Is My Life,'' sounds like a parody of Paul Anka's ''My Way,'' has an imposing pop alto that she hurls recklessly, with little regard for the niceties of pitch and phrasing.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Around the Nation; Georgetown Chief Likens Moral Majority to Klan
description: The Rev. Dr. Timothy S. Healy, president of Georgetown University, compared Moral Majority today with the Ku Klux Klan, saying, ''Whether hatred comes wrapped in white sheets or the Scripture, it is still a denial of man and his works.''

title: BALLOTS IN JERSEY BLOCKED AS A COURT DISCERNS BIAS
description: A state appeals court today barred the printing of ballots for the November election, which it said carried an intentionally biased explanation by Byrne administration officials of a constitutional question.

title: PENN CENTRAL LINK TO COLT IS FOUGHT
description: A group of the Penn Central Corporation stockholders, including members of the Hunt family of Texas, asked a Federal court today to halt the company's proposed merger with Colt Industries unless a majority of shareholders approve it.

title: VAST 'HOLE' IN SPACE APPEARS TO DEFY THEORIES
description: Using telescopes at three major observatories, astronomers have found what appears to be an almost total void so large it would make up about 1 percent of the observable universe. It is by far the largest departure from a uniform distribution of galaxies yet detected, and the discovery is said to demand revision of current theories on how the universe evolved.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan's Aims On Poor Lands
description: WASHINGTON JUST about the only piece of hard news to emerge from this year's annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund has been the admission to membership of the Republic of Vanuatu and the Kingdom of Bhutan.

title: CARTIER IS VICTOR ON TRADEMARK
description: After a 10-year legal battle, Les Must de Cartier, one of France's best-known makers of luxury goods, has persuaded a Mexican businessman to halt a multimillion-dollar operation counterfeiting Cartier products and has appointed him to sell the genuine articles.

title: Pakistan's Choice: Aid or a Bomb
description: In one vital respect, Pakistan is a deserving customer in the Reagan Administration's thriving arms bazaar. Its security is plainly threatened by the Soviet thrust into Afghanistan. More than two million Afghans have fled into its territory and Soviet MIG's recently pursued them over the frontier, strafing a Pakistani border post.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 2, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3:00 P.M.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Notes on Fashion column on Sept. 1 incorrectly reported plans of Anderson & Sheppard, the SavileRow men's tailor in London. The company is planning a sales trip to New York, not the opening of a branch.

title: Business People; TROPICANA PRODUCTS SELECTS NEW CHAIRMAN
description: A new head of Tropicana Products Inc. has been appointed by the Beatrice Foods Company, its parent company. The announcement follows reports that the profit growth of the nation's largest citrus juice processor had slowed.

title: 22-1 Rectory Tops Amber Pass
description: The Paterson Handicap, named for a New Jersey track that shut down 85 years ago, had been run only four times before tonight but had already established a tradition: The favorite always lost. Tonight, the tradition continued.

title: Mr. Reagan's War on Poverty
description: Who speaks for the Reagan Administration on policy toward the poor? Is it the President? In his news conference yesterday he focused on the dependent poor, who can't work. ''People that are totally dependent on Government,'' he said, are ''our obligation, and nothing is going to happen to them.''

title: THRIFTIMART INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 13
Man Surrenders In Death of Girl, 5
description: A 25-year-old Queens man sought in connection with the death of a 5-year-old Bronx girl last Friday appeared at the 46th Precinct station house along with his lawyer and a police officer last night and surrendered, the police said.

title: ART: CHEEKY SCULPTURES BY RICHARD STANKIEWICZ
description: HUMOR of one kind or another can be found in the high art of the past - Breughel and Goya, for example. But in no era has the quality been so prevalent or so consistently ironic as in the 20th century, thanks to the license that was issued by Dada to mock art as well as humanity.

title: TRANSNET CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Restaurants; New Texas, old English.
description: IN the beginning, there was Texas music, progressive country Western sounds as represented by Willie Nelson, David Allen Coe and Waylon Jennings. Then came the television soap opera ''Dallas,'' closely followed by the popularity of Texas clothing - studded jeans, embossed leather boots and J.R. Ewing Stetsons. Inevitably, Texas food has come north, in all of its earthy, countrified simplicity.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GUARD DOG PUTS SOME MEANING INTO PRODUCTION
description: Just days after Mayor Koch announced the use of German shepherds at the Corona subway yard in Queens, one of the guard dogs gave birth to four puppies.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NOT SO VITAL STATISTICS
description: For President Reagan watchers - and trivia collectors - a few essentials about the man in the White House: Height and weight - 6 feet, 1 inch; 184 pounds. Waist - 36 inches; shirt collar, 16 inches; sleeve, 33 inches. Eyesight - Contact lenses to correct near-sightedness, half glasses for reading. Overcoat size - 44; shoe size, 10 1/2 B; hat size, 7. Allergies - Rhinitis (hay fever) for which he takes shots. Hobbies - Collecting Western art and trappings: spurs, belts, saddles, saddle-buckles, blankets, old prints. Nighttime snacks - Very few, but when he does indulge, he likes fresh fruits. He's also a popcorn freak. Favorite food - Macaroni and cheese. Sweet tooth? - He'll always go for vanilla ice cream, in addition to his favorite jelly beans. He's also fond of carrot cake. Favorite wine - California Cabernet Sauvignon. Favorite television show - ''Little House on the Prairie.'' Current reading - ''The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt'' by Edmund Morris, ''Peter the Great'' by Robert Massie. Favorite magazine - National Review. Favorite time of day - Early morning. Favorite sport - Horseback riding; as he says, ''There's nothing better for the inside of a man than the outside of a horse.'' Pajamas? - Yes.

title: NEW CANCER TREATMENT HAILED
description: A new combination of drug and radiation treatment appears to be doubling the survival rates of patients with an arm or leg cancer while sparing many arms and legs, the National Cancer Institute reported today.

title: DEMAND FOR HOME-CARE WORKERS IS RISING IN CITY
description: Ethel Hunter, who is 80 years old, waits each morning for a Haitian woman the city sends to help her survive. Miss Hunter said she was doing all right after a stroke a few years ago until she fell and fractured a hip. ''I would be out of luck,'' she said, if her home-care aide, Maryse Williams, did not help her bathe and dress, cook the broiled chicken that she likes, clean her house and take her outside in a wheelchair. This relati vely new city service, called home care, is New York's fastest growi ng Medicaid program. But its popularity is threatening the amount of money available for other social services.

title: KELLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CHATTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes income of $53,000 from discontinued operations

title: Washington Dinner Collects $950,000 for the Democrats
description: Democrats held a $1,000-a-plate fundraising dinner today, coinciding with the beginning of the Reagan Administration's austerity program, and Mayor Henry W. Maier of Milwaukee described the Administration's budget cuts as ''the sacking of urban America.''

title: FOCUSING ON THE CHILDREN OF THE WORLD
description: During most of the year, Justice Bentley Kassal focuses his attention on the cases that come before him at the New York State Supreme Court, at 60 Centre Street. But during his vacations, his focus switches to the children of the world.

title: ECONOMISTS SEE SLUMP TILL MID-'82
description: The economy will remain slow during this quarter and for the first half of 1982 before picking up speed. That was the message from many of the economists speaking yesterday at the ''Business Outlook 1982,'' a symposium sponsored by the Conference Board, a nonprofit research organization. It was also a view echoed by many of the several hundred business executives in the audience, some of whom are experiencing first-hand the crushing effects of continued high interest rates.

title: 20 YEARS LATER, FOOD STAMPS CHANGE
description: In May 1961, Alderson and Chloe Muncy were driven the 25 miles from here to the county seat at Welch, W.@Va., and were ceremoniously given the first $95 worth of food stamp coupons in a program that grew to cost $12.1 billion nationally in the last fiscal year.

title: Notes on People; Reagan's Forebears in the O'Reagan Clan
description: His great-grandfather was born near the village of Ballyporeen, and that makes Ronald Reagan Irish enough for the American Irish Historical Association.

title: Business People; PROFESSOR TAKES LEAVE FOR YEAR TO RUN BIOGEN
description: Walter Gilbert, a Harvard University professor associated with Biogen N.V., a genetic engineering company, since it was established in 1978, has taken a leave of absence to become chief executive officer of the concern. The title was not formally used before.

title: Around the World; President of Brazil Leaves the Hospital
description: President Joao Baptista Figueiredo of Brazil left the hospital today , 13 days after suffering a heart attack.

title: Polish Debt Effect Cited
description: Polan d's problems in r epaying an estimated $23billion of loans to the West have chilled int ernational bank lending,according to delegates attending the 36th ann ual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

title: Notes on People; President of U.D.C. to Step Down Next Year
description: Richard A. Kahan, president and chief executive officer of New York State's Urban Development Corporation, said yesterday that he planned to resign next year and return to the private sector. In the interim, he said, he will leave key U.D.C. decisions to others, to avoid the appearance of impropriety.

title: A FORMER DIPLOMAT'S THOUGHTS ON DIPLOMACY
description: In his four years as the No. 2 man at the State Department in the Carter Administration, Warren M. Christopher was the epitome of the self-effacing bureaucrat. Even after his highly publicized, successful diplomatic mission to free the American hostages in Iran, Mr. Christopher gave few interviews and turned down offers to write a memoir because, as he said, ''there would be too many vertical pronouns.''

title: Fighters and Snakes
description: The featured 10-round fight between Ruby Ortiz and Alfredo Escalera, former junior-lightweight champion of the World Boxing Council, may attract herpetologists and snake charmers to ringside Oct. 16 at the Felt Forum. Escalera, now a junior welterweight, was famous for his pet snakes, which in his native Puerto Rico he was allowed to take into the ring.

title: LAWMEN TIED TO KLAN IN COMMUNISTS' PROTEST
description: After a six-month investigation, the Institute for Southern Studies has determined that there was an ''intimate alliance'' among the district attorney's office and police officials in Greensboro, N.@C., and Ku Klux Klan and American Nazi gunmen who killed fiv e m embers of the Communist Workers Party in a street demonstration two years ago.

title: DETROIT'S TIGERS HAVE A CITY BY THE TAIL
description: In front of Tiger Stadium the other day, the following exchange took place: ''So are the Tigers gonna make the playoffs this year?'' ''Sure.'' ''Really?'' ''Well, probably not. But it's fun while it lasts.'' Detroit may be skirting municipal bankruptcy and industrial decline, a lot of people are out of work and the rest of the country feels sorry for it, but the Tigers are flirting with first place in the American League East, and a town that hardly dares to believe good news anymore is having a lot of fun while it lasts.

title: SHERIFF TIED BY DELBELLO TO AN ACCUSATORY LETTER
description: County Executive Alfred B. DelBello said today he believed that the former County Sheriff, Thomas J. Delaney, ''or somebody close to him'' was the author of an anonymous letter last year that accused Mr. DelBello of political interference in police matters.

title: G.M. to Restore Loan Discounts
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would restore loan rate discounts on two small car lines in an apparent bid to counter price undercutting by its two biggest competitors. G.M. said it would offer car loans from its financing subsidiary at13.8 percent through Nov. 11, compared with p revailing average rates above 16 percent.

title: REAGAN CITES ISLAMIC SCHOLAR
description: President Reagan, in his news conference yesterday, cited a 14thcentury Islamic scholar as an early exponent of the ''supply-side'' economic theory on which his Administration bases many of its policies. An authority on the scholar later said that the reference seemed accurate.

title: All Not Lost in 2d Season
description: The loss column in the baseball standings has become another victim of the split season . All four division races could be won by teams with no advantage in that heretofore sacrosan ct statistic because thecontenders are playing an unequal number of g ames, just as they did in the first half of the season.

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-After extraordinary credits of $301,000 for the qr and $436,000 for the yr...C-Net loss which includes a gain from extraordinary credit of $165,000

title: energywatch
description: SEPT. 25, 1981 Crude oil stocks fell to 369.9 million barrels, in a sharp drawdown.

title: U.S. ASSERTS SAUDIS NEED 'ASSISTANCE' ON AWACS INTO 90'S
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met in New York today with Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, and a State Department spokesman said later that United States ''assistance'' would be necessary well into the 1990's for what was called ''the support'' of five Saudi Awacs aircraft.

title: Posts Change At Texas Air
description: Texas International Airlines Inc. reported late yesterday that Robert J. Carney, 41 years old, the company's chairman, had assumed the additional responsibilities of president from Harry T. Chandis, 47.

title: PROPOSES
description: 1 BOMBER By RICHARD HALLORAN Speci al to the New York Times

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE B-1 AT A GLANCE
description: OVERALL DESCRIPTION The B-1 is a four-engine, swept-wing, subsonic bomber that, advocates say, could penetrate Soviet air defenses 200 feet above the ground and drop conventional or nuclear bombs or stand off and launch cruise missiles, torpedo-like pilotless aircraft guided to targets by remote control. About 100 bombers would be deployed in the 1980's, two this year and most of the rest by 1986.

title: French L'Arc to Be Run
description: The staging of Sunday's $357,000 Prix de L'Arc de Triomphe, which had been threatened by a labor dispute, was assured today when the labor union Confederation du Travail reached a collective bargaining agreement with the owners of the Longchamp course.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's decision today on modernizing the American strategic nuclear arsenal is based on an apparent contradiction: There is a continued belief that land-based missiles are vulnerable to a surprise Soviet attack, yet the programs it proposes to set in motion will do virtually nothing to reduce that theoretical vulnerability. According t o Pentagon experts, the President's p lan to build MX missiles, place them in existing silos and pour more concrete to harden them against blast represents a giant step aw ay from a solution. To them, safety can come only from mobility, and Mr. Reagan has scrapped that approach for now.

title: Associated Press
description: SCHOOL BUS AND TRUCK COLLIDE: The wreckage of a school bus in Coppersburg, Pa., after it was hit by a tank truck that had run a red light. The bus driver, Anna Miller, was killed and 52 children were injured, most of them not seriously. The truck driver, who was not hurt, was charged with homicide by vehicle.

title: by Leo Cherne
description: As the Admi nistration and Congress proceed with consultations on the number of Indochinese refugees to be admitted tothe United St ates starting this month, I deplore the growing tendencyhere and abro ad to identify the refugees as ''economic migrants.'' Wemust be deepl y concerned that refugees so identified may be subject to mass repat riation without steps to ensure their safety.

title: U.S. Steel to Shut Furnace in Gary
description: The United States Steel Corporation said that it was taking out of operation a blast furnace at its Gary, Ind., works, leaving only two of the mill's six furnaces there in operation.

title: Roadway Express Net
description: Roadway Express Inc. said today that it had a profit of $30.1 million, or $1.52 a sha re, in the third quarter, compared with a $10.4 million loss a year earlier. Revenues rose to $261.1 million from $255.5 million. L ast year's loss included a one-time $26.8 million writeoff in operating rights resulting from Federal deregulation of the tr ucking industry.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; yr-ago revs have been restated

title: Court Finds for Jays On Ainge's Contract
description: The Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Boston Celtics in a Federal courtroom yesterday in a contest for the services of Danny Ainge. As a result of the decision, which ended the trial of a lawsuit between the teams, Ainge still has a valid baseball contract with the Blue Jays, preventing him from negotiating a contract to play basketball for Boston.

title: WINN-DIXIE STORES INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Sept 16
AMID HEAVY SECURITY, IRANIANS ELECT 2D PRESIDENT IN THREE MONTHS
description: Iranians voted amid heavy security today to elect their second president in less than three months, and the expected winner went on the radio even before the polls closed to promise that he would retain the present Government.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Oct. 1 incorrectly translated a sign shown above Polish coal miners. It ac- tually said, ''Food Distribution.''

title: Notes On People; Winning Recognition
description: Unlike the late novelist Thomas Wolfe, the violinist Jaime Laredo believes that ''indeed you can go home again.'' In his case, home is Bolivia, where he has been something of a national hero since 1959, when he won the prestigious Queen Elisabeth of Belgium music competition.

title: Letter: On Corrupt Practices Abroad; Make Foreign Bribery Limits Clear
description: To the Editor:

title: HAZEL SCOTT, 61, JAZZ PIANIST, ACTED IN FILMS, ON BROADWAY
description: Hazel Scott, the pianist and singer who was once married to the late Adam Clayton Powell Jr., died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 61 years old.

title: UNPROTECTED WOMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: Bay State Nurses End S trike
description: Registered nurses reported for work today at the Berkshire Medical Center, ending a 69-day walkout.

title: POLISH 'CONTRACT,' BY ZANUSSI
description: Krzysztof Zanussi, who made last year's New York Film Festival selection ''The Constant Factor'' while also working on ''Contract,'' a current festival entry, is clearly now working at the top of his form. Mr. Zanussi, the Polish director of such earlier films as ''Illumination'' (1973) and ''Camouflage'' (1976), has this time constructed a comedy of manners and morals revolving around a wedding party, and a very playful comedy it is. Things go so steadily awry on this festive occasion that nothing works out properly, nothing at all. The bride and groom don't even finish getting married.

title: No Headline
description: To The Editor:

title: COMMONWEALTH TALKS DEBATE GAP BETWEEN RICH AND POOR
description: The Commonwealth Conference, which every two years brings together leaders of some of the most industrialized nations as well as some of the least developed, was turned into a forum today for an exchange of views between the world's rich and poor nations.

title: Sambo's Is Late On Loan Payment
description: Sambo's Restaurants Inc., which has about 1,100 units nationwide, disclosed that it had failed to pay $4.8 million it owed as the first installment of a $100 million restructured loan arrangement critical to the survival of the chain.

title: The Talk of Mayersville
description: It boasted that it was the largest settlement between Memphis and New Orleans in the 1830's, successfully fought the coming of the railroad because it thought the Mississippi River steamboat traffic would abandon it, and saw the river move two miles west of town and take commerce with it. It shrank right off the map, got reincorporated in 1976, was the first community in the state to elect a black woman as Mayor, voted overwhelmingly for Jimmy Carter twice, and now feels, what with President Reagan's budget cuts, that if it were not for bad luck Mayersville would have no luck at all.

title: Grounding the Air Travel Market
description: Air travel is almost back to normal - or so it seems. Most travelers are getting where they want to go in spite of the air controllers' absence. Most airlines are in the black, making up for fewer flights by using bigger planes. There is even a price war of sorts on some routes.

title: COLORADO LODGES INVEST IN SNOW-MAKERS
description: The first snows of the season are due any day now in Colorado's high country. But just in case the weather won't cooperate, anxious Rocky Mountain ski resort operators have bought themselves a bit of snow insurance during the summer.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: James W. Johnson, 84, Former I.R.S. Collector
description: James William Johnson, a former Collector of Internal Revenue and a lawyer in Manhattan for decades, died Sept. 23 while on vacation in Florence, Italy. He was 84 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Notes On People; For 'Camelot,' a Shield Against Losses
description: The illness that forced Richard Harris out of the touring company of the musical ''Camelot'' until the end of October may cost Lloyd's of London a quarter of a million dollars, according to the broker who arranged insurance for the production.

title: COMMUNIST PARTY OUSTS 30 IN FRANCE
description: In the biggest purge it has conducted since World War II, the French Communist Party announced the ouster today of 30 prominent dissidents.

title: PORTUGAL DEFENDS ANGOLA ON CUBANS
description: Many Angolans consider the Cubans a costly and sometimes disruptive presence in their country, the Foreign Minister of Portugal asserted today, but he said it would be ''suicide'' for Angola to ask the Cubans to leave until its southern border was secure against invasion from South Africa.

title: 5 ACQUITTED OF BEATING CUBANS
description: Five Federal officers accused of mistreating Cuban refugees were found not guilty of 13 assault charges today, and a mistrial was declared on conspiracy and other assault counts.

title: EGYPT URGES REAGAN TO BOLSTER SUDAN FORCES
description: Vice President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt conveyed to President Reagan today an urgent request that the United States take immediate steps to bolster the Sudan's military forces in the face of growing clashes between Sudanese and Libyan forces along the Sudan's border with Chad.

title: Q&A: MAYOR ON THE CAPITAL'S PLIGHT
description: Marion S. Barry Jr., Mayor of the District of Columbia, has more than the usual urban problems to contend with. Besides facing the customary budget restrictions and overburdened city services, he is also fighting what he calls the ''tyranny'' of Congressional control over Washington's municipal Government.

title: FAIRFIELD NOBLE CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Includes a gain of $794,000 from the sale of a building

title: News Analysis
description: As the second stage of Solidarity's national convention in Gdansk nears an end, Soviet news outlets have fallen into a pattern of almost daily attacks on the independent Polish union's actions and resolutions.

title: FUTURE STEPS FOR PROGRAM
description: President Reagan's program for modernizing and expanding United States strategic forces now goes to Congress for authorization and financing.

title: Gromyko Back in Moscow
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, returned today from New York, where he attended the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Stamps and Small Change
description: Increasing the price of stamps twice in one year is a nuisance. But is it unreasonable? Not at all, says Robert Hardesty, chairman of the Postal Service board.

title: ROCKWELL'S SHARE: $10 BILLION
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, the aerospace and electronics conglomerate, estimated yesterday that the resumption of the B-1 bomber program would increase its sales $10 billion to $12 billion through 1988 and result in the hiring of 11,000 new employees.

title: BACKGROUND STATEMENT FROM WHITE HOUSE ON MX MISSILE AND B-1 BOMBER
description: Following is the text of the background statement distributed today by the White House in support of President Reagan's decision on basing the MX missile and building the B-1 bomber: Overview Introduction

title: SAVERS' CERTIFICATE SALES BRISK
description: Banks and thrift institutions reported much heavier sales of ''All Savers'' certificates yesterday, as consumers clamored to make their purchases before the yield drops on Monday.

title: AIR FORCE GENERAL GETS SHUTTLE POS T
description: An Air Force general was named yesterday to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's shuttle project. He is Maj. Gen. James A. Abrahamson, a former test pilot and manager of the F-16 fighter development program.

title: F.B.I. Inquiry Is Barred In Salvadoran Killings
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation will provide the maximum possible assistance to help the Government of El Salvador solve the killings of four American missionaries but cannot conduct an independent investigation, the Reagan Administration said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.00-19.50** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MARYLAND REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-AFter an extraordinary gain of $7,000 on the partial utilization of the company's operating loss carryforward... C-After extraordinary gain of $32,000 or 2 cents a shr... D-Net loss

title: Sports People; Murphy Still a Rocket
description: Calvin Murphy, the 5-foot-8-inch guard, re-signed for three years with the Houston Rockets, putting an end to a squabble that had sparked ill feelings. Murphy, a free agent, was asked by the Rockets last week to get offer sheets from other teams so that Houston would have some idea of his worth on the open market.

title: CITY SETS PLANS FOR AN OVERHAUL OF TWO DRIVES
description: Plans for a complete overhaul of the Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harlem River Drives - long plagued by flooding and washboard surfaces and more recently by a cave-in - were announced yesterday by the Koch administration.

title: CONSERVATIVE SECTS FIND HOME IN NEW YORK
description: As society moves faster and more frenetically, New York State is becoming a magnet for conservative religious groups, such as the Amish and the Mennonites, whose members believe that the rewards and duties of the world are to be lived more slowly and calmly.

title: Reagan Fails to Stay Judges' Pay Increases
description: The fiscal year 1982, which began Thursday, brought pay increases for the nation's Federal j udges, including the United States Supreme Court.

title: Righetti, Gossage Halt Orioles
description: The Yankees began preparing seriously for the division playoffs tonight. They powered their way to a 9-0 victory over the Baltimore Orioles, and Rich Gossage reclaimed his role as the team's premier relief pitcher.

title: IC'S OFFER FOR SUNBEAM HEAVILY OVERSUBSCRIBED
description: Shareholders of the Sunbeam Corporation, ignoring strong company opposition to an unwelcome $451 million takeover offer, have overwhelmingly accepted a bid by IC Industries to buy a controlling interest in the appliance manufacturer for $32 a share.

title: LAWYER SAYS NIXON FALSIFIED TAPES ACCOUNT
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon was accused today of filing in court a ''false and misleading'' description of a tape-recorded conversation he had with an aide in the White House on May 5, 1971, concerning measures to harass antiwar demonstrators gathered here.

title: Kaufman Sees Easing by Fed
