description: Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers and one of Wall Street's most prominent interest rate forecasters, is predicting that the Federal Reserve will probably decide on a more accommodative monetary policy at next week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.

title: Your Money; The Pitfalls Of 'Call' Loans
description: THE recent decision by two upstate banks to demand payment on lowrate mortgages whose short terms had expired points up some of the consumer dangers in the new breed of mortgage loans.

title: Colbert, Stadler Tied For Lead in Texas Open
description: Jim Colbert shot a 6-under-par 64 today and tied the first-round leader, Craig Stadler, for the lead after two rounds of the $250,000 Texas Open golf tournament.

title: OIL DRILLER GETS STOCK SUSPENSION
description: The stock of the Santa Fe International Cor poration, one of the world's largest oil drilling companies, did n ot trade yesterday afterthe company asked that trading be suspended o n the New York Stock Exchange pending an announcement to be made o n Monday.

title: Chinaglia to Go on Tour
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, the star forward who said earlier in the week that he would not go on tour with the Cosmos today if Hennes Weisweiler remained as coach, has decided to accompany the team after all.

title: 6 College Students Killed in Collision
description: Six Houghton College students were killed when their car and a tractor-trailer collided in South Wales, N.Y., authorities said.

title: HARRY GOLDEN, AN EDITOR AND HUMORIST, 79, DEAD
description: Harry Golden, the editor and publisher who fought bigotry with humor in books, lectures and especially through the pages of his oneman newspaper, The Carolina Israelite, died yesterday after a long illness at his home in Charlotte, N.C. He was 79 years old.

title: Canada Budget Deficit
description: Canada's budget deficit rose to $1.29 billion in July from $955 million a year earlier, the Finance Department said today.

title: Fuqua Details R epurchase Bid
description: Fuqua Industries announced the terms of its tender offer for its own stock, saying it would repurchase up to 2.5 million share s at $20 a share, or about $50 million.

title: Sports People; Dean Goes to Chargers
description: Fred Dean, a defensive end who has played in the Pro Bowl seven times, yesterday became the second star holdout in recent weeks to be traded by the San Diego Chargers. Following in the path of John Jefferson, who was sent to the Green Bay Packers late last month, Dean was dealt to the San Francisco 49ers for a second-round choice in the 1983 draft.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: The front page of the Sept. 23 Times was interrupted by a picture of Richard Serra's ''Tilted Arc,'' a steel sculpture installed in front of 26 Federal Plaza and described as being 12 feet high and 120 feet long.

title: IN NEW YORK, WILDLIFE'S NOW A NUISANCE
description: New York State's populations of deer, geese, beaver, wild turkey and several other species are growing so fast that some have become nuisances, wildlife officials say. Even coyotes and moose have been spotted for the first time in many years.

title: Porsche Prices Up
description: Volkswagen of America is increasing prices on its 1982 Porsche and Audi models an average of 3.2 percent, or about $516 a car, from 1981 levels, the auto maker said. Prices on optional equipment for the imported models are also going up an average of 6.8 percent, VW said. Base prices for the Porsche-Audi models range from $9,755 for the Audi 4000 to $39,500 for the Porsche 928.

title: 'TRANSES,' MOROCCAN MUSICAL
description: Ahmed el-Maanouni's ''Transes,'' a French-Moroccan documentary that will be shown at the New York Film Festival today at 7 P.M., is about an immensely popular Moroccan musical group called Nass el-Ghiwane. The five-man combo, we are told, has had the same kind of electrifying effect on popular North African music in the 1970's that the Beatles had on the popular music of England, Europe and America in the 60's.

title: THE LEANING SCULPTURE OF FEDERAL PLAZA
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; Data to Aid Unaffiliated Inventors
description: WASHINGTON THE Patent and Trademark Office has arranged for the transmission to its 37 depository libraries of information that should be advantageous to independent inventors. A contract was awarded this week to the ABA Corporation, Arlington, Va., to conduct a classification and search support information system.

title: Union Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corp. said that its Carbon Products division would close one of its three Niagara Falls plants with a loss of about 300 jobs, but would invest several million dollars to modernize the other two facilities.

title: THE ROAD TO EUPHORIA: THE 'BODY SHOPS'
description: There once was a woman who got so exhausted thinking about all she had to do that she went to bed and took a nap. Actually, it was a good idea. Breaking up a busy routine with a rest gives one renewed energy, so that chores get done better and in less time. These days, when a woman is juggling job, home and social life, she may need more than half an hour on the chaise longue. Just about the most restful escape available is to take an hour off - or better half a day or a day - to have a soothing facial or massage by an expert in hushed surroundings.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
MORE DISCLOSURES ON DIABLO A-PLANT
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company has notified the Federal authorities that construction errors in supports designed to protect the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant from earthquakes extended to the trays holding the two reactors' electrical cabling system.

title: Books of The Times
description: Thinking in Space By ANATOLE BROYARD THE MEANINGS OF MODERN ART. By John Russell. Illustrated. 429 pages. The Museum of Modern Art/Harper & Row. $35 hardcover. $16.95 paperback.

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1981; The Economy
description: The nation's unemployment rate rose to 7.5 percent in September, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. It said the rate was pushed upward by the loss of many jobs held by adults, including more layoffs of construction workers and school teachers. (Page 1.) The September jobless rate fell in New York State and New Jersey, but rose in New York City, to 8.4 percent from 8.1 percent. (15.)

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.9 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday a larger-than-expected $1.9 billion decline in the nation's money supply, which strengthened the conviction of some analysts that short-term interest rates would drop soon.

title: Court Backs Monsanto
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Monsanto Company, while it may have a near-monopoly on the production and sale of artificial athletic surfaces, had not abused its power.

title: R.T. ROSS, EX-CONGRESSMAN
description: Robert Tripp Ross, a former member of the House of Representatives from Queens and Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Eisenhower Administration, died on Thursday. He was 78 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Energy Issues Lead Stock Gain
description: Rise Broad as Dow Adds 8.47 By VARTANIG G. VARTAN

title: Relatives of 3 Killed in Blast At Nuclear Plant Lose Suit
description: Relatives of three men killed in a 1977 explosion at the Pantex nuclear weapons assembly plant have lost their suit against the Federal Government, but say they will appeal.

title: NEW LEAK SHUTS CON ED A-PLANT AT INDIAN POINT
description: A new leak has been discovered in the tubing of a steam generator at the Indian Point 3 nuclear plant - one of 17 in the country where such tubing has been affected by rust.

title: Asbestos Corp.  Shares Climb
description: The shares of the Asbestos Corporation jumped $5.875, to close at $41 (Canadian), or about $34 in United States funds, on the the Toronto Stock Exchange today, after Premier Rene Levesque of Quebec hinted publicly that the province may soon purchase the company. The General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis holds 54.6 percent of the company's shares.

title: The City; 2 Officers Cleared in a Bronx Killing
description: A Bronx grand jury cleared two police officers in the killing of a Bronx bank robbery suspect who held a hostage at gunpoint, the Bronx District Attorney's office reported.

title: POLITICAL LEADERS IN UTAH AND NEVADA APPLAUD DECISION ON THE MX
description: President Reagan appeared to have scored a major political victo ry in the West today as offici als in the region reacted with relief and enthusiasm to his dec ision to scrap a plan tobase the MX missile in the Great Basin of Uta h and Nevada. Instead, Mr. Reagan said the missiles would be scatter ed in Titan 2 and Minuteman 3 missile silos in several states.

title: LOUIS GOLDENBERG, ART DEALER
description: Louis Goldenberg, an accountant who became president of Wildenstein & Company, one of the foremost art galleries, died Wednesday. He was 68 years old.

title: DODGERS PREVENT ASTROS FROM CLINCHING
description: Steve Garvey and Dusty Baker each collected three hits to support the four-hit pitching of Jerry Reuss last night as the Dodgers prevented Houston from clinching the second-half title in the National League West with a 6-1 victory over the Astros in Los Angeles.

title: PARDON DRIVE GAINS IN '64 SHOOTINGS
description: It was about dusk when George R. Senn, looking through his apartment window in nearby Upper Darby Township, saw a crowd of about 20 youths gathering and called the police, asking them to investigate. A little later he saw the youths surrounding a car in his parking lot.

title: I.O.C. Yields Power O n Eligibility Rules
description: BADEN, West Germany, Oct. 2 (AP) - The International Olympic Committee ended its four-day meeting today by revising its Rule 26, the eligibility regulation that has caused controversy over the years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's my hope that this program will prevent our adversaries from making the mistake others have made and deeply regretted in the past: the mistake of underestimating the resolve and the will of the American people to keep their freedom and protect their homeland and their allies.'' - President Reagan, announcing military plans. (12:5.)

title: Consumer Saturday; OLD-TIME RADIO EMPORIUM
description: IT is a remnant of an older New York, a shop that would have been at home along a part of Cortlandt Street that no longer exists, among the collection of tiny, cluttered shops that once constituted what was often called ''Radio Row.'' It is, however, on Chambers Street, just west of West Broadway, it is called Court Radio and it is a place that can produce in minutes from the thousands of cardboard boxes stacked on its sheet-metal shelves just about every tube, diode or knob that ever graced a wireless, radio or television.

title: MASSACHUSETTS WARNS ON GASSING CARS WITH D EFECT, BUT FUEL FLOWS
description: For Massachusetts owners of some Ford Escorts and Mercury Lynxes, filling the tank this week made the gas lines of 1978 seem easy.

title: JUSTICE AIDES IN DISPUTE OVER LAG IN SENTENCING
description: With New York City's jails at a point of dangerous overcrowding, city officials and judges are disputing who is responsible for delays in sentencing that are contributing to the problem.

title: BREWERS WITHIN 1 OF TITLE
description: Ben Oglivie cracked a two-run homer, and Paul Molitor and Robin Yount drove in two runs each last night to carry the Brewers within one victory of the American League East second-half title with an 8-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers in Milwaukee.

title: Patents; M.I.T. Devises Methods For Fusion Reactors
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass., received two patents this week that are believed to mark an advance toward the development of fusion reactors. Most nuclear reactors in operation today use a fission process.

title: Notes On People; Music to His Ears
description: A follow-up: Last July it was reported from Kuhmo, Finland, that Peter Cropper, first violinist with the Lindsay Quartet from London, had tripped and fallen on his Stradivarius, breaking off the neck of the rare instrument.

title: A.M.C. Offering New 1 0% Rebates
description: The American Motors Corporation said that it was offering 10 percent rebates on the base prices of certain A.M.C., Renault and Jeep vehicles.

title: In a Shift, John Henry to Run in Gold Cup
description: Sam Rubin, who says that horse owners should always reserve the right to change their minds, has done so for the second time in three weeks and will send John Henry to New York for the Jockey Club Gold Cup next Saturday.

title: John Spivak, Reporter And Political Crusader
description: John L. Spivak, a foreign correspondent and author in the decades before World War II, died Wednesday at Temple University Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 84 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Joseph Van Gelder, Former Court Reporter
description: Joseph Van Gelder, a shorthand reporter in the New York State courts for 30 years, died Thursday at the Miami Heart Institute in Miami. Mr. Van Gelder, who had lived in Miami Beach after retiring, was 82 years old.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Whether you believe Mr. Serra's work to be ''art'' or not is a question of f ashion. However, the comment by Donald W. Thalacker reported in y our Sept. 25 news article ''Serra Work Stirs Downtown Protest'' is misinformed.

title: WORLD BANK, I.M.F. SOUND SOMBER NOTE
description: The World Bank and International Monetary Fund concluded their 36th annual meeting today on the twin notes that world economic conditions would get worse before they got better and that there was a strong need to coordinate anti-inflationary policies to avoid a world depression.

title: WRITING PARKING TICKETS THAT STICK
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; 11 Ex-Hostages Suing For More Compensation
description: Eleven persons who were held as hostages in Iran filed suit in Federal District Court yesterday saying that $12.50 a day was not enough compensation for their 444 days of captivity.

title: Around the World; Taiwan Calls Overtures, By China a Smokescreen
description: The Prime Minister of Taiwan, Sun Yun-suan, told legislators today that Peking's latest overture on reunification was a smokescreen to hide discontent on the mainland and promote discord among the Chinese Nationlists.

title: by Edward A. Baker
description: Ed Koch and I served together as riflemen in the combat zones of northern Europe in World War II. Many details have faded from memory, others were indelibly etched. Remembering has very little, if anything, to do with being able to write about such incidents as flushing snipers out from steeples, taking turns at point scout (the first man advancing), or flank scout (left or right), and probing haystacks with bayonets, searching for the German rear guards left behind to do as much damage as possible to our advancing troops.

title: Patents; Missile, Secret Since '65, Is Patented for Navy
description: A ramjet supersonic missile, designed in 1965 and kept secret since, has been patented for the Navy. When built, it should be able to travel at from five to 10 times the speed of sound.

title: Sports People; Craig Back From Injury
description: Jim Craig, the former Olympic hero who is now a backup goalie with the Boston Bruins and who had been sidelined since August with a broken right index finger, got permission to return to play. Craig broke his finger at the training camp of the American team that competed in the Canada Cup tournament .... Steve Ovett, the British track star, underwent treatment for a hip injury yesterday, on the eve of an 800-meter race that he is still scheduled to run in Brisbane, Australia.

title: GAMEX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OCCIDENTAL SAYS LIBYA EASES OIL-SALE TERMS
description: The Libyan Government has ''sweetened'' its oil sales arrangement with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, the company said yesterday. Other oil companies and analysts sugested that Tripoli wanted to keep Occidental as a customer at a time when many companies were refusing to buy Libyan crude.

title: THE FRENCH AND THEIR GOLD
description: The cloak of anonymity has been lifted from the Paris gold market, and the French are upset. Starting yesterday, France's Socialist Government closed a possible loophole in its new plan to tax wealth by requiring that buyers of gold disclose their names and addresses, the prices they paid and the quantities exchanged. All this information must be recorded and preserved for inspection by the Fisc, as France's tax collectors are known.

title: New York; PULLING THE WINGS OFF PEOPLE; by Sydney H. Schanberg
description: There may be no new words or phrases to describe the awesome crime in this city or the frightening fact that more and more of it is being committed by children, but it is fairly obvious that if we do not address it with at least as much energy as we devote to acquiring a new television set, things are going to get worse.

title: Jeter's Return Puts Giants in Quandary
description: Gary Jeter is back. The Giants' fifth-year defensive end, who missed the first four games of the season after undergoing arthroscopic knee surgery, was reactivated today and will play Sunday against the Green Bay Packers at Giants Stadium.

title: Around the Nation; Patient Seeking Relatives Is Denied Court Hearing
description: The Missouri Supreme Court refused today to hear the case of a man who has cancer who is seeking relatives who might be able to provide medical help.

title: Crocker Off 7 1/8 After Bid Ends
description: The common stock of the Crocker National Corporation fell 7 1/8 points, to 34 1/8, yesterday to register the largest percentage decline of any issue on the New York Stock Exchange after a purchase offer was heavily oversubscribed.

title: NCR Cites Electronic Shopping
description: Shoppers at Dahl's Food Market in southwest Des Moines now have a new way to pay for their groceries. Instead of writing a check or paying cash, they can electronically transfer money from their bank account to the store's bank account using a plastic card at the checkout counter.

title: ISRAEL TRIES TO WEAN WEST BANK ARABS FROM P.L.O.
description: Occupied West Bank, Sept. 29 - Israel has begun carrying out a revised policy of occupation designed to build up moderate Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank and curtail the radical political influence of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: De Gustibus; THE FORTUNE IN THE COOKIE CRUMBLES
description: Although much has been written about the death of the novel, little has been said about the near demise of the Chinese fortune cookie - to many a far more dire and depressing prospect. At the risk of infringing on the territory of a literary critic, I feel that it is high time to point out that these messages are not what they used to be, becoming so dull and preachy that many former devotees are ignoring them.

title: WALESA WINS UNION VOTE WITH EASE
description: Lech Walesa was re-elected easily today asthe chairman of Solidarity, but the margin of victory showed that hishold over the union was not as unshakeable as it once was.

title: Asbestos Insurers Held Liable
description: A ruling by a Federal appeals court here imposes broad liability upon insurance companies to pay potentially huge amounts of damages awarded in thousands of lawsuits brought against manufacturers by workers exposed to asbestos.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. Many of the people who impersonate characters at Disney World in Orlando, Fla., say they are overworked, underpaid and must wear unclean costumes.

title: Notes On People; Divorce on the Hill
description: After 23 years of marriage, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and his wife, Lee Ludwig Hart, plan to divorce.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF ARMS PROPOSALS
description: Deployment of a limited number of MX missiles, starting in 1986, in existing Titan or Minuteman missile silos, which would be ''hardened'' to withstand the effects of a nuclear attack. At least 100 missiles to be deployed by the end of the decade in one or more of the following modes: aboard aircraft in continuous flight, in deep underground silos or in bases protected by missile defense systems.

title: The; 30-Year Nemesis
description: IT happened 30 years ago today, but remains curiously alive. And every single day in those 30 years someone has mentioned it to Ralph Branca, or he has expected someone to.

title: Mayor of Hiroshima Protests Nuclear Tests
description: Hiroshima, the target of an atomic bomb in World War II, sent telegrams to the United States and the Soviet Union today protesting nuclear tests carried out by both nations yesterday.

title: Index; International
description: Israel trying to wean West Bank Arabs from the P.L.O. 2 Egypt urges U.S. to bolster Suda- nese forces 2 Kuwait offered aid after air at- tack on oil complex 2 Iranians elect second president in three months 3 Most Quebec Liberals join move opposing Trudeau plan 4 Trudeau and Nyerere debate rich-poor issue at parley 4 Around the World 5 French Communist Party ousts 30dissidents 5 Portuguese aide says Angola can't ask Cubans to leave now 6 Government/Politics Future steps in Reagan's strate- gic forces plan 13 Utah and Nevada politicians praise the MX decision 14 City officials dispute reason for overcrowding in jails 29 50% of voters in Jersey poll back Kean economic plan 30 Dinkins vows ''serious'' effort against Stein as candidate 31 Washington Talk Briefing 15 Washin gton's Mayor Barry speaks out on government 15 Religion New York State is a magnet for conservative religious groups 29 Health/Science Air Force general to head space shuttle project 15 PARADE TODAY The second annual Korean Parade begins today at 11 A.M. Floats and cos- tumed Korean-A merican marchers move down Broadway from 41st Street to 23d Street. General Around the Nation 8 Pennsylvanian seeks pardon in shooting of marauders 8 Mississippi town faces hard times under Reagan's budget 8 Members of a religious sect are linked to 19 Jersey robberies 30 Arts/Entertainment Alf Sjoberg films on festival's double bill 16 Krzysztof Zanussi's ''Contract'' screened at Film Festival 17 Arms and armor specialists con- vene at Metropolitan Museum 17 ''Transes,'' a film about French- Moroccan rock band 17 Fundamentalist minister criti- cizes nudity in dance festival 18 ''The Meanings of Modern Art'' by John Russell reviewed 21 ''Saturday Night Live'' back in third incarnation 55 Style Consumer Saturday 32 The road to euphoria: The 'body shops' 32 Party at craft museum honors ar- tisans 32 De Gustibus: The fortune in the cookie crumbles 32 Obituaries Louis Goldenberg, headed Wil- denstein art gallery 33 Sports Nets' King may not need knee surgery 22 Expos retain lead as Rogers's 2-hitter stops Mets 23 Red Sox lose and are eliminated from playoff contention 23 Rangers trade 3 for Whalers' Rogers; Islanders deal Howatt 23 Blue Jays win suit against Celtics over Ainge 23 Ira Berkow on Ralph Branca's 30- year nemesis 23 McEnroe, Tanner give U.S. 2-0 lead in Davis Cup 24 Yankees down Orioles, 9-0 24 Jeter's return gives Giants a small problem 24 I.O.C. gives 26 units power over key rule 24 Owner changes mind, John Henry will run in Gold Cup 25 Features/Notes Saturday News Quiz 18 Notes on People 20 Going Out Guide 21 Sports People 24 About New York 31 News Analysis Leslie H. Gelb on Reagan's plan for silo-based MX missiles 1 Serge Schmemann on the cam- paign against Solidarity 3 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 26

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REMARKS BY THE PRESIDENT ON WEAPONS PROGRAM
description: Following is a transcript of a statement by President Reagan and his responses to questions in the East Room of the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: The Region; Fire After Blast Dispels Pollution
description: A blaze that followed an explosion at the Solvents Recovery Inc. plant here burned off potential air contaminants before they could spread over re sidential areas, officials said.

title: MAYOR KOCH TRIUMPHS OVER THE PARTY SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: On the stretch of Eighth Avenue where sex is sold, the street at night is light and dark, dark and light, like the dim interior of a fish tank. The people move, merge, disappear: couples on their way to the Port Authority Bus Terminal, men leaving theaters that show movies rated XXX, the police, in uniform and undercover.

title: Irving Chernev Is Dead; Wrote Books on Chess
description: Irving Chernev, a chess master who wrote 18 books on the game, died Tuesday at his home in San Francisco after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: WESTERN MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Net income...C-After gains of $184,200 on sales of real estate

title: LABOR CONFERENCE ENDS IN ENGLAND
description: Leaders of Britain's Labor Party singing ''Auld Lang Syne'' at the end of their annual conference in Brighton. In a closing statement, they urged nationalization of British industry, withdrawal from the European Economic Community and unilateral nuclear disarmament. However, proposals that Britain pull out of NATO and that banks be taken over by the state were defeated.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP TO 7.5% IN U.S. FOR LAST MONTH
description: An extensive loss of jobs among adults, including more layoffs of construction workers and schoolteachers, pushed the nation's unemployment rate up to 7.5 percent in September, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: TRUDEAU PARTY IN QUEBEC JOINING OPPOSITION TO HIS PLAN FOR CHARTER
description: The Parti Quebecois majority, which wants to make Quebec independent, and the Liberal Party minority, which wants to keep Quebec in Canada, joined today in a vote to defend the largely French-speaking province's rights against encroachment by the federal Government.

title: Nets' King May Not Need Knee Surgery
description: As their regular training camp opened at Ramapo College here, the New Jersey Nets learned today that Albert King, their second first-round draft choice last spring, may not need surgery for his injured right knee.

title: Patents; A New Microorganism Aids Alcohol Output
description: Discovery of a new microorganism promises increased production of alcohol. Two patents were granted this week to a professor and a former research associate at the University of Georgia, Athens, Ga., for inventions made under a Department of Energy contract.

title: MCENROE, TANNER GIVE U.S. 2-0 LEAD
description: Courtside advice from his captain helped lift Roscoe Tanner to a five-set victory over Peter McNamara today and give the United States a 2-0 lead over Australia in the semifinals of the Davis Cup.

title: Briefing
description: I F Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. thought negotiations with the Russians were delicate, he was obviously unprepared for CBS. Several weeks ago Mr. Haig ate lunch at the State Department with Dan Rather and Bob Pierpoint, the television reporters; Bill Leonard, the head of CBS News, and Dean Fischer, the agency's spokesman. The food was tasty, the mood warm, and by the end of lunch Mr. Haig had agreed to appear on ''60 Minutes'' for the kind of n o-nonsense interrogation that viewers expect of the tele vision program.

title: Canada Bank Cuts U.S. Tie
description: The Mercantile Bank of Canada, whose control by Citibank N.A. has been a sore spot with Canadian politicians and banking officials for 18 years, yesterday symbolically cut most of the ties with its parent.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in the method of accounting for compensated absences

title: 2 AT FESTIVAL GIVE SAMPLING OF SJOBERG
description: The New York Film Festival's double bill of films by Alf Sjoberg makes a fine retrospective program, illuminating the talents of a Swedish director whose simple, heartfelt, visually breathtaking style at times has a resonance like John Ford's. ''Only a Mother'' (1948) and ''Karin Mandsdotter'' (1954) present the late Mr. Sjoberg as a largely overlooked figure whose films have their moments of astonishing beauty.

title: AMCOLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for 12 weeks to Sept 12
description: B-Including $975,000 benefit from the sale of German operations; yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on Nov 5, 1980

title: Wing of I.R.A. Terms Hunger Strike Pointless
description: The Provisional Sinn Fein, a political wing of the outlawed Irish Republican Army, said today that the seven-month-old hunger strike of guerrilla prisoners in Northern Ireland had become pointless.

title: Transcanada Gas
description: Transcanada Pipelines Ltd. said that it was concluding contracts with about 100 Alberta producers to buy additional gas supplies in order to fill contracts for export sales totaling a billion cubic feet a day that it signed earlier this year. The company said that gas deliveries from the new contracts would begin when its current contracted supply can no longer satisfy markets.

title: EMPLOYMENT RISES IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Unemployment in New York State and New Jersey fell last month, but the jobless rate in New York City rose slightly, the regional office of the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: J. P. Remensnyder, 83; A Collector of Antiques
description: John Paul Remensnyder, retired chemical industry executive and a collector of early American stoneware and antique metal crafts, died Wednesday at his home in Saugerties, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: THE MX AT A GLANCE
description: Overall Description: The MX is a proposed four-stage rocket carrying 10 nuclear warheads, each a re-entry vehicle that would separate from the missile in space and drop o n a different Soviet target. At least 100 missiles planned for dep loyment in the mid-1980's would be launched from silos in th e United States or perhaps from aircraft aloft.

title: NEED 1 TO CLINCH
description: The Montreal Expos took a giant stride toward winning the secondhalf race in the National League's East last night when Steve Rogers pitched them to a two-hit, 3-0 victory over the Mets in a nearly flawless performance in cold Shea Stadium.

title: AND WITH MAILED FIST RAISE A TOAST
description: The baronial hall housing the armor collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art echoed last night with lute music, jesters' bells, the tinkle of glasses of mulled wine and intense discussions of such curatorial arcana as gorgets and mangonels.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: The conventional explanation for Edward I. Koch's similar majorities in both the Democratic and the Republican primary is that he is an unusually popular Mayor. A less generous interpretation could be that the voters of one of those parties don't know what Mr. Koch stands for. LARRY SHERMAN Bronx, Sept. 28, 1981

title: 3 Title Bouts on Agenda
description: A World Boxing Association title, a World Boxing Council title and an overall world boxing title will be at stake today. Mike Weaver, the W.B.A. heavyweight champion, will defend against James (Quick) Tillis in Rosemont, Ill., tonight.

title: Around the World; Italian Parliament Backs U.S. Missile Proposal
description: The Italian Parliament today narrowly endorsed a plan to deploy 110 United States cruise missiles in Sicily in 1983 if Soviet-American negotiations on reducing the number of nuclear missiles in Europe should fail.

title: NUCLEAR PHARMACY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Around the World; Toll Up to 83 in Bombing At P.L.O. Beirut Office
description: The death toll in yesterday's car bomb explosion outside the offices of the Palestine Liberation Organization rose to 83 today, P.L.O. spokesmen said.

title: DISCOUNT CORP OF NY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Newlin Gets Longer Pact
description: Mike Newlin's contract was extended and Harthorne Wingo's comeback was ended today when the Knicks opened their training camp at Monmouth College.

title: MX DECISION WINS PRAISE BUT B-1 PLAN FACES TEST
description: Congress reacted with broad approval and considerable relief today to President Reagan's plan to deploy MX missiles in existing silos and to scrap costly plans for a new basing system in Western desert regions.

title: Going Out Guide
description: MILESTONE

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 1 incorrectly identified the ownership of Fiat S.p.A., the Italian auto maker. The company is privately held.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: DINKINS VOWS SERIOUS RUN AS LIBERAL
description: David N. Dinkins, who narrowly lost the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Manhattan to Andrew J. Stein in the primary last month, vowed yesterday to wage a ''serious'' effort for the office as the Liberal Party candidate.

title: Japan Maps Import Rise To Avert Curbs Abroad
description: The Japanese Government announced today the broad outlines of its plan to stimulate its economy and increase imports. The program is Japan's strategy for defusing the threat that Europe and the Unite d States, facing huge trade deficits with this merchant nation, will erect protectionist barriers against Japanese exports.

title: SURVEY FINDS 50% OF VOTERS FAVOR KEAN ECONOMIC PLAN
description: TRENTON Oct. 2 - The plan advanced by Thomas H. Kean, the Republican candidate for Governor, to stimulate New Jersey's economy by cutting taxes, appeals to about half of the state's voters, according to a poll taken by the Eagleton In stitute of Politics at Rutgers Unive rsity.

title: Bridge: Swiss Team Play Can Call For Tactics of Desperation
description: It is usually wrong to strain for good results, and players often turn victory into defeat by doing so. But there is one situation in which desperate tactics are certainly called for. In the final round of a Swiss team event scored by victory points, members of one squad may know that only a big winning margin will bring them victory in the contest. With only seven deals available, steady bridge may offer little hope.

title: 2 ISSUES RAISED BY COMPTROLLER IN FIRST DEBATE
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday raised two new issues - involving President Reagan and the residence of one of his opponents - in the first debate of the general election campaign for Comptroller.

title: STRUGGLE FOR CENCO EXPANDING
description: The bidding war for Cenco Inc., one of the nation's largest nursing home operators, expanded today as a Canadian company appeared as a possible suitor.

title: RANGERS ACQUIRE ROGERS, WHALER CENTER
description: The Rangers, worried that they were weak at center, yesterday acquired one of the highest scorers in the National Hockey League, Mike Rogers of the Hartford Whalers. In return, they gave up Doug Sulliman, a forward, and Chris Kotsopoulos and Gerry McDonald, both defensemen.

title: Saab Holds Prices
description: The Swedish auto maker Saab said it was holding prices of 1982 model cars exported to the United States at 1981 levels, taking advantage of a rise in the value of the American dollar against the Swedish crown. The 1982 Saab prices will range from $10,400 for the three-door hatchback Saab 900 to $16,610 for the four-door Saab 900 Turbo sedan.

title: Winn-Dixie Net Rises
description: Winn-Dixie Stores Inc. announced yesterday that net income in the 12 weeks ended Sept. 16 increased 13.7 percent, to $19.1 million, or 77 cents a share, from $16.8 million, or 64 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales climbed 8.1 percent, to $1.47 billion, from $1.36 billion.

title: The Region; PATH Union Ratifies Pact
description: JERSEY CITY (UPI) - Motormen and switchmen who operate the PATH commuter line have ratified a 45-month contract with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, it was announced.

title: The City; Suspect Indicted In Death of Boy, 5
description: A Queens grand jury has indicted a South Ozone Park man on a charge of murder in the beating death of a 5-year-old boy. The indictment also charged the man, Philip Ross, 27, of 142-46 Bascom Avenue, with endangering the welfare of the child, Emanuel Myers.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective in June 1981

title: WESTERN TIMBER AREA CAUGHT IN DEEP SLUMP
description: Battered by high interest rates that have devastated the housing industry, a sharp upward swing in imports from Canada and diversion of domestic timber to foreign mills, the lumber and wood products industry in the Pacific Northwest is in a slump.

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1981
description: International American assistance with the Awacs is necessary, a State Department spokesman said after a meeting in New York between Saudi Arabia'a Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. American aid for ''the support'' of the five surveillance planes that the Administration proposes to sell to the Saudis would be necessary well into the 1990's, the spokesman said. But Defense Department estimates of the time needed to train Saudi crews are much less than 10 years. (Page 1, Column 2.) National MX missiles will be housed in silos being vacated by Titan missiles rather than shuttled among shelters in the Western deserts, as had been proposed, President Reagan told newsmen, ending several days of speculation about the basing of the intercontinental nuclear missiles. Their deployment will be part of what the President called a comprehensive plan to revive the nation's strategic nuclear deterrent. He also revived plans for the long-range B-1 bomber, which had been canceled by the Carter Administration and proposed the construction of 100 of them. ''This is the strategic program America can afford,'' the President said. Defense Department officials said the program would cost $180.3 billion over the next six fiscal years, starting with the year that began Wednesday. (1:6.))

title: Donation to Add Library Hours
description: Two branches of the New York Public Library will have longer hours for at least a year because of a bookstore ch ain's donation of $90,550.

title: ECONOMIC PLAN'S GAP
description: To the Editor:

title: Observer; THE WELL-BRED MUMMY; by Russell Baker
description: A s always when ''The Mummy'' is shown on te levision, I was riveted to my armchair the other night when the rotti ng casket containing theScroll of Thoth was excavated from the sands of Egypt, along with a linen-wrapped object that looked suspiciously like Boris Karloff.

title: Notes On People; A New Glint for an Old Pair of Sunglasses
description: People who go to political conventions are prone to picking up strange souvenirs when caught up in the euphoria of the moment, and often regret their impulse-buying acquisitions.

title: Albert Granovsky, 85; Ex-Publisher in Croton
description: Albert A. Granovsky, retired editor and publisher of Croton-Cortlandt News in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., died yesterday at White Plains Hospital. He was 85 years old and a resident of Ossining, N.Y.

title: 'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE' IS BACK IN THIRD INCARNATION
description: Last season, NBC-TV's ''Saturday Night Live'' was nearly left for dead. A groundbreaking comedy show when it began under the producer Lorne Michaels in 1975, its flinty irreverence gave way a year ago to cheap shocks and worn-out formulas under the guidance of a new producer working with new writers and a new cast.

title: RACKETEERING CASE FOCUSES ON JERSEY MUSLIM SECT
description: On Aug. 28, 1980, four men robbed the University Savings and Loan Association in North Brunswick of $7,000. As they were fleeing, they got into a gun battle with an off-duty police lieutenant. One holdup man was wounded and all four were arrested after their car crashed into a tree.

title: A Torpedo for Public Education
description: The idea of tuition tax credits, though stalled on Capitol Hill, is headed for a showdown in Washington. A citizens group affiliated with the National Taxpayers Union has mustered enough support to get an initiative on the November ballot to authorize this pernicious idea. The outcome will send waves across the country.

title: Around the World; Spanish Ship Bombed; Basque Rebels Suspected
description: A bomb tore a six-foot hole in the hull of a docked Spanish destroyer and wrecked the engine room today. An anonymous telephone caller told a radio station that the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. was responsible and that a ship on the high seas would be the next target.

title: MINISTER SCRUTINIZES DANCE FESTIVAL
description: A local minister, head of a group called Concerned Christians for Good Government, has begun an organized questioning of prospective candidates for Mayor and City Council, requesting their positions on municipal subsidy to the American Dance Festival. Among other complaints, he has criticized instances of nudity during performances over the last three years.

title: by James F. Bere
description: Well over 100 years ago, John Wanamaker, one of the world's great merchandisers, declared: "I know half my advertising is being wasted, but I don't know which half." Today I hear more and more business executives saying the same thing - about corporate philanthropy.

title: Saturday News Quiz; by Linda Amster
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 34.

title: Sports People; Montefusco Suspended
description: The Atlanta Braves suspended John Montefusco, their unhappy pitcher, after he had failed to make the plane for a season-ending series in Cincinnati. Montefusco had earlier expressed his displeasure with Atlanta management, asking to be traded and then demanding his release so that he could become a free agent .... John Castino, 26, the Minnesota Twins third baseman, underwent an operation yesterday to correct a lower back problem, with prospects that he will miss most or all of next season.

title: K-TEL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Arkansans Who Heard Titan Blast Accept MX
description: Some Arkansas residents who heard a Titan 2 missile blow up a year ago said today that they would feel safer with the solid-fuel MX missiles proposed by President Reagan.

title: PARTY AT CRAFT MUSEUM HONORS ARTISANS
description: No one can accuse the American Craft Museum of being stodgy. While it is a serious institution devoted to fostering both crafts and craftsmen, it does so partly by mounting exhibitions on such subjects as ''Homage to the Bag'' and ''The Great American Foot.''

title: KUWAITIS OFFERED AID AFTER RAID
description: Jordan and Qatar have offered their support to Kuwait if it is attacked again, and other Arab countries today strongly condemned yesterday's air strike on a Kuwaiti oil installation.

title: KAISER BEGINS TALKS ON BUY-OUT OF ITS STOCK
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it had begun discussions with a group of venture capitalists who want to acquire all the shares outstanding of the nation's 10th-largest steel producer.

title: Art; 'PEEP S HOWS' OF CATASTROPHE
description: STONY BROOK THE eruptions at Mount St. Helens, the devastating earthquakes in Iran and Italy and the seemingly endless string of natural disasters that disrupt the good life in California continually remind us that the earth is a fragile and often hostile environment. No matter how secure and solid our fortresses, nature can reduce them to rubble at her whim.

title: The Missile and the Bomber
description: President Reagan's solution to the MX problem resembles Churchill's comment about democracy: it's the worst system there is, except for all the others. After years of studying dozens of ways to make ground-based missiles invulnerable, Washington finally has admitted the sad truth: none works well. Other methods must be studied. More important, the Reagan proposals acknowledge indirectly that the danger lies in the future; there is time to reduce it and no need to panic over the ''window of vulnerability'' exploited in the 1980 campaign.

title: HARVARD DRAFTS RULES ON CONFLICTS OF INTEREST
description: Harvard University's faculty council has approved a broad set of guidelines regulating the activities of faculty members outside the academic community, especially those involved in profit-making business ventures.

title: FLIGHTS OF A POLYMATH'S FANCY
description: FIRES By Marguerite Yourcenar. Translated from the French by Dori Katz, in collaboration with the author. 129 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $12.95.

title: U.S. STUDY ON SOVIET POWER WELCOMED BY NATO
description: The European allies of the United States have generally welcomed the publication this week of the Defense Department's comprehensive study of Soviet military power.

title: Health Officials Report Drop in Measles Cases
description: Cases of measles reached the lowest level in over 50 years last month, although an outbreak in Florida indicates that the disease has not faded completely, a Federal health agency has reported.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Lucrative Monster
description: Repeated reports by residents that they had spotted a sea monster in Bulwagga Bay convinced officials of Port Henry, N.Y., that they were on to a good thing. By official resolution in October 1980, they forbade the harassing of sea monsters.

title: Edith Noble, Artist, Bride Of a Lawyer
description: Edith Jackson Noble, daughter of Mrs. Roger Haydock Hallowell of Manchester, Mass., and the late John Noble of New York, was married yesterday to Carter S. Bacon Jr., son of Karen L. Bacon of Wellington, Fla., and Hyannis Port, Mass., and Mr. Bacon of Coopersville, Mich. The Rev. William H. Brittain performed the ceremony in the First Parish Congregational Church in Manchester.

title: Television Week; Disappearing Dollars
description: Magic is the crucial element in a new half-hour comedy series, ''Mr. Merlin,'' which will have its premiere on CBS Wednesday at 8 P.M. Max Merlin is played by Barnard Hughes, who won the Tony, Drama Desk and Outer Critics Circle awards for his performance in the Broadway play ''Da.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Reagan on Crime: Let's Not Crowd Police Officers
description: ''Law and order'' was again the order of the day as President Reagan last week added his own chapter to the hardliner's textbook written by the Nixon Administration. He told the International Association of Chiefs of Police meeting in New Orleans that the legal system has failed in ''the protection of the innocent and the punishment of the guilty.''

title: Mailbox; Welcome To Toronto
description: To the Sports Editor: After reading Paul Gardella's article on the decline of the hockey spectator from fan to barbarian (The New York Times, Sept. 27), I feel compelled to comment.

title: IT'S TIME TO THINK BULBS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Susan Gilbert is a writer whose special topic is hardy spring bulbs. By SUSAN GILBERT

title: Essay; THE REAGAN COROLLARY
description: In the acronym-ridden lingo of the national security types, a Special National Intelligence Estimate - SNIE - is pronounced ''snee.''

title: Environews; by Leo H. Carney
description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency last week defended its enforcement of the Federal Clean Water Act, saying that criticism by a statewide consumer organization ''totally misinterpreted and distorted the facts.''

title: A VERY SPECIAL GUITARIST
description: James Blood Ulmer plays the electric guitar. So do countless professional, semiprofessional and amateur musicians the world over, but none of them sounds like Mr. Ulmer. He has shared concert stages with Ornette Coleman and other jazz artists and with forward-looking rock performers like Public Image Ltd. and Captain Beefheart, and he has been enthusiastically reviewed by jazz and rock critics. But his few recordings have been for independent labels, and he has been little heard outside New York City, where he lives, and a few European cities. That situation will change later this month when Columbia Records releases Mr. Ulmer's new album ''Free Lancing.'' Although it is actually his fourth LP, it will probably be the first of his recordings to penetrate beyond the small circle of new-music devotees that has been aware of his work all along. And it confirms what these devotees have been saying for several years now - that Mr. Ulmer is the most original electric guitarist to emerge since the late Jimi Hendrix, who made his most influential recordings between 1967 and 1970.

title: Escalator Phobia
description: To the Business Editor: We can see the advantages of an escalator, but what about the poor souls who are afraid of escalators? How will they be able to manage? More and more places are becoming out of bounds.

title: ORIOLES' MCGREGOR BEATS YANKEES, 3-0
description: The Yankees, who appeared as if they had begun preparing seriously for the divisional playoff when they scored nine runs last night, reverted to a more typical recent performance tonight and were shut out by Scott McGregor o f the Baltimore Orioles for the second time in nine days.

title: DO AS I SAY, NOT AS I DO
description: A WOMAN I know is opposed to the Equal Rights Amendment because she is afraid that it will force her to share her bathroom with any unemployed lesbian who voted for Jimmy Carter or Gus Hall.

title: WILL AUSTRALIA'S TV MATCH ITS FILMS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jill Sykes is a Australian freelance journalist specializing in the arts. By JILL SYKES SIDNEY, Australia Americans have responded enthusiastically to a number of recently released Australian films, particularly ''Breaker M orant'' and ''Gallipoli.'' Now it may be Australian telev ision's turn. Tonight at9, the first episode from the Australian dram a series ''A Town Like Alice'' will be shown as the season premiere presentation of ''Masterpiece Theater'' on Channel 13. The si x-part dramatization is derived from a novel by Nevil Shute, who borr owed from reality in hisstory that begins during World War II with a group of English women being trapped by the fall of Singapore, taken prisoner by the Japanese but left to wander Malaya under guar d because no one is willing to take responsibility for them. Joe Harmon, an Australian soldier they meet on the road, helps them out with a few ''luxuries''such as soap , but the chickens he steals for them lead to a hideous punishment by the Japanese.

title: PARIS MAY SWAP SPY FOR KEY SOVIET DISSIDENTS
description: French Government sources indicat ed today that France was pr epared to exchange a former East German Air Force General arres ted on espionage charges in Lille last year for Andrei D. Sakharov, Anatoly B. Shcharansky and Yuri F. Orlov, three of the most famous i mprisoned Soviet dissidents.

title: OFF TO THE CITY...
description: PANTING up five flights of stairs, the cartons of books and records increased in weight at every landing. Over the rim of the boxes, my husband and I looked at each other, asking the same question - ''Why did she move?''

title: Home Clinic; PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE KEEPS THE BUGABOOS AWAY
description: ALTHOUGH many light-duty outdoor power tools have electric motors, most outdoor power tools and powered yard equipment use a gasoline engine as their source of power - not only because the engines are generally more powerful than an electric motor, but also because they eliminate having to drag an awkward extension cord.

title: A TALE OF 2 CAPITALISMS
description: Because he is a declared enemy of social welfare and Federal regulation, Ronald Reagan is regarded by many Americans as a true friend of big business. But in fact his vision of capitalism bears only the slightest resemblance to big business's, and neither his remedies to the present economic crisis nor his vision of the American future find much resonance in corporate board rooms.

title: LED THE DEMOCRATIC SOCIALISTS
description: Suehiro Nishio, founder and former chairman of Japan's center-left Democratic Socialist Party, died here today of a kidney ailment, his family reported. He was 90 years old.

title: U.S. WEAPONS SALES EXPECTED TO DIP
description: The Reagan Administration, which has pledged to promote the sale of American weapons abroad, is not likely this year to sell as many arms as did the Carter Administration, which espoused a policy of restraint, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: New Continental: Sleek and Jazzy
description: FIRST there was the 1980 Cadillac Seville, a head-turner whose classic trunk reminded everybody of an old Rolls-Royce. Then, last year, came Chrysler's bulge-backed Imperial, a trinket out of the same mold. And now there is the new Continental. It is the smallest Lincoln in history and it makes the bustle-brigade complete.

title: YUGOSLAVS ALARMED BY SHARP RISE IN DRUG USE
description: A 17-year-old youth has become the seventh heroin addict in Yugoslavia to die of a drug overdose in less than two months. The authorities say that drug use, virtually unknown in this Communist country 10 years ago, has become a national epidemic.

title: Practical Traveler; TIMELY WARNING ON TROUBLE SPOTS
description: Shortly after 2 P.M. last April 30, Telex machines began to clatter in about a dozen major newspaper offices around the country. They transmitted a 45-word message: an official ''travel advisory'' from Washington. ''In view of the current labor dispute in Bermuda,'' it said, ''which now involves strikes by hotel workers, bus operators, taxi drivers and airport services, the Department of State recommends that U.S. citizens planning to vacation in Bermuda defer plans to visit there until the situati on improves.''

title: THE HUNGARIAN EPISODE
description: THE POLITICS OF GENOCIDE The Holocaust in Hungary, Volumes I and II. By Randolph L. Braham. 1269 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $60.

title: MORALITY PLAY, OF SORTS
description: When a partnership bids six no-trump missing two aces after using Blackwood, the players generally prefer to keep this disgraceful episode from reaching the ears of the general public. And in such cases, the play is most unlikely to be of interest. Neither of these generalizations was true on the diagramed deal, played in the first round of the 1980 World Team Championships.

title: Theater; 'MAME' AT THE COACHLIGHT
description: FIRST there was the best-selling novel, ''Auntie Mame'' by Patrick Dennis that the playwriting team of Lawrence and Lee turned into the smash hit play of the same name in 1956. Then 10 years later, the same playwrights in collaboration with Jerry Herman adapted the play into the musical ''Mame'' that took the Tony Award for the best musical of the season.

title: Music; TOP CONCERT SERIES BEGIN THIS MONTY
description: OCTOBER in the county will see increasing cultural bounty, with a number of major series about to begin and dozens of eminent artists preparing to visit the county this season.

title: Critics' Choices; POP MUSIC
description: Chrissie Hynde, who is from Akron, Ohio, wrote rock criticism until she decided she would rather write and sing rock 'n' roll songs. After several false starts, she put together a band with three musicians from Hereford, England.

title: Seton Daly Is Married To Brian T.  B eckwith
description: Seton Daly, daughter of Charles P. Daly of Short Hills, N.J., and Barbara Daly of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian T. Beckwith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Beckwith of Fairfield, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Tewell performed the ceremony.

title: Prospects; The Market's Still Nervous
description: Although the stock market's 37-point advance last week suggests that an end to the six-month slide in prices may be at hand, some analysts say that the gains constitute little more than a correction, and they doubt that stocks will move appreciably higher in coming months.

title: Pitt Weighs Conference Shift
description: Dave Gavitt, commissioner of the Big East Conference, has met with officials of the University of Pittsburgh to explore the possibility of Pittsburgh's becoming the ninth member of that two-year-old basketball league. This could change Pitt's thinking about forming a new Eastern conference wi th Penn State and others that would base its strength onfootball.

title: THE RUGGED, QUICKSILVER BEAUTY OF YEAT'S SLIGO
description: We were moving slowly up the sharp slope of Knocknarea, a flattopped mountain on the west coast of Ireland that sits between Sligo town and the sea. Shin-deep in heather, we had wandered away from the trail, eager to slip out of the mainstream of Sunday morning hikers. The hearty local folk - children skipping, singing and giggling, women dressed for church rather than for the trail, grandparents carrying walking sticks - seemed to charge up the steep incline, while the two of us inched along, red-faced and gasping.

title: Miss Sweigart Captures Avon Half-Marathon
description: Kiki Sweigart of the Warren Street Social and Athletic Club, a 30-year-old school teacher, led from start to finish in winning the Avon Women's Half-Marathon yesterday at Central Park.

title: Headliners
description: A WIDOW'S CAUSE Her husband has been dead for 45 years, but Anna Hauptmann, widow of the man the state of New Jersey executed for the kidnapping and murder of Charles A. Lindbergh's infant son countinues, at 83, to "live for the day that he is posthumously exonerated and vindicated."

title: REPORT CITES A SURGEON IN HIGH MORTALITY RATE
description: The chief heart surgeon at an Air Force hospital had a patient mortality rate of 43 percent, about eight times higher than average, and only a rebellion by aneesthesiologists halted his work, it was was reported Thursday.

title: POST'S NEW CONCERT HALL IS TEST FOR ARTS
description: BROOKVILLE CAN a university concert hall be all things to all people: a focal point for the cultural life of a community as diverse and dispersed as the Island, and a teaching tool for the education and training of young adults?

title: Connecticut Guide; by Eleanor Charles; JAZZ COMBO
description: Although the Galvanized Jazz Band, originated at Yale University in the 60's, was once made up of Yale alumni, none of its members were music students and none of the current members is a full-time musician.

title: Antiques; LAFAYETTE: A SURPRISE OR TWO OFF INTERSTATE 80
description: LAFAYETTE FOR antiquers, the main purpose of a superhighway like Interstate 80 is to deliver them as quickly as possible to those back-country roads where the antiques are. Route 15, and the Sussex County community of Lafayette in particular, have more than their share of shops that seem to fit so well into old village buildings without rippling the country atmosphere.

title: Bill on Disclosing Police Files Is Vetoed by Governor Brown
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. yesterday vetoed a bill that would have given reporters and the public access to some police files.

title: THE NEED TO RECOVER LOST VALUES
description: JUST last year Arthur Levine, senior fellow at the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, sketched a portrait of today's college student in a book that he entitled ''When Dreams and Heroes Died.'' It is not a pretty portrait. None of the reasons he cites for students having neither dreams nor heroes should come as any surprise: current economic pressures, disillusionment with national leadership, the threat of nuclear war, a breakdown of family life, the overpowering realism of television programming.

title: Egg on the Face
description: As a child, I was taught an expression to cover the ''wog'' situation.

title: GIANTS MAY SEND CARPENTER INTO ACTION
description: The Giants, with a new running back in Rob Carpenter, play the Green Bay Packers, with a new wide receiver in John Jefferson, tomorrow at Giants Stadium.

title: No Headline
description: Dan Suhr starred on offense and defense as Madison defeated Erasmus, 19-0, in a Division B game. Suhr had one touchdown, an extra point, two interceptions, eight tackles and blocked a kick. Suhr, a 6-1, 215-pound senior, scored in the third quarter after returning an interception 21 yards. He plays tight end on offense and is a linebacker on defense.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error in last week's Economic Affairs column, the statement, ''Market failure is exceeded by Government failure in controlling the business cycle,'' was wrongly attributed to Norman B. Ture, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Tax and Economic Policy. It was a comment by the columnist, Paul W. MacAvoy.

title: TAIWAN IN SISTS, NO DEAL
description: Chiang Ching-kuo, the President of the Republic of China on Taiwan, is 75 years old and suffering from diabetes. He intensely dislikes the Soviet Union. He is a Chinese patriot who dearly wants to see Taiwan and the mainland reunited. Deng Xiaoping, the most powerful figure in the People's Republic of China on the mainland, is 77 years old. Hearing in one of his ears is deteriorating and his lungs have been ravaged by constant smoking. He, too, intensely dislikes the Soviet Union and is a Chinese patriot who dearly wants to see Taiwan and the mainland reunited.

title: Suspect Held in 4 Killings
description: The police arrested 32-year-old Charles Livingston today for killing a ''root doctor'' and three other persons Tuesday at a house whose residents, the police said, practiced voodoo. The police speculated that several gunmen had killed Edward (Doc) Harkless, 62, ''the top root doctor in South Carolina''; his wife, Frankie, 39, and two other persons. They said withcraft and voodoo artifacts had been found in the house.

title: Bay Shore Wins, 44-6
description: Dennis Maloney scored two touchdowns and passed for two more to lead Bay Shore to a 44-6 League III victory over Centereach. Maloney rushed for 140 yards on 12 carries and completed 7 of 11 passes for 84 yards. Brian Williams who scored one touchdown for Bay Shore on a 3-yard run, carried the ball 29 times and picked up 207 yards.

title: INSIDE HIMMLER
description: INFILTRATION By Albert Speer. Translated by Joachim Neugroschel. 384 pp. New York: Macmillan. $15.95.

title: Comment; G.M. ON CLEAN AIR
description: T HE fight over Government regulation of the auto industry is gaining new importance and timeliness today over the issue of the Clean Air Act. This act is now 11 years old, and it is up before the Congress for reauthorization.

title: Hackensack Is Winner by 10-6
description: Tim Bajraktari hit Bill Darley with a 30-yard scoring pass in the second quarter to lift Hackensack to a 10-6 victory over Ridgewood yesterday in Hackensack.

title: AN AMERICAN REFUSAL TO PRECLUDE STARTING NUCLEAR WARFARE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. IN CUP FINAL ON STORMY VICTORY
description: The United States advanced to the Davis Cup tennis final today, but only after John McEnroe and Peter Fleming had come within one warning of being defaulted in their doubles match with Peter McNamara and Phil Dent of Australia.

title: ORTHODOX-ROMAN CATHOLIC UNITY TALKS HAILED
description: Bishops of the Eastern Orthodox and Roman Catholic Churches in the United States have completed a first r ound of talks aimed at helping to clear the way for a reunion of the two bra nches of Christianity, which split in the 11th century.

title: GOODMAN WARNS OF A SUBWAY 'SAFETY EMERGENCY'
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman said yesterday that there was a grave danger an accident in New York City's subway system ''killing and injuring hundreds or thousands'' of riders would result in the near future from what he called a ''substantial safety emergency'' in the system.

title: The World in Summary; Voting and Dying In Iran as the Crisis Continues
description: In a continuing climate of violence, Iranians voted last week for a president who seemed destined to be a candidate for martyrdom. The Government claimed a heavy voter turnout and Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, head of the Islamic Revolutionary Party, who was still recovering from wounds suffered in a bomb attack in June, seemed certain to win. More than 100 Islamic and Government leaders, including President Mohammed Ali Rajai, have been assassinated since the mullahs replaced Abolhassan Bani-Sadr with Mr. Rajai in June.

title: City Hall Notes
description: There seems to be no end to the obstacles confronting the Westway, the superhighway that, it is said, will one day run along the Hudson River. Given the pledge of considerable Federal aid made by President Reagan, Westway supporters had thought it was safe to go near the water. Then Congress came forth with a new twist.

title: The Lively Arts; PAF: NEW NAME, NEW START
description: HUNTINGTON STATION THEY'LL be rolling out a brand-new carpet donated by a well-wisher for the occasion, and the ushers will be done up as doctors with robes and stethoscopes.

title: Long Island Guide; by Barbara Delatiner; ASTRONOMY JAMBOREE
description: The stars will be big and bright deep in the heart of Southold today as the Custer Institute brings its third annual Eastern Long Island Astronomy Jamboree to a rousing conclusion. From a sunrise watch at Orient Point (4-6 A.M.) to a cosmic walk along the shores of Peconic Bay (7-9 A.M.) to a NASA workshop on ''Remote Sensing or Living in Space'' or an observer's clinic (both 10:30 A.M.) to afternoon sessions on ''Star Atlases'' or ''50 Ways to Leave Your Planet,'' the day will be loaded with enough star-gazing activities to keep amateur astronomers busy. Registration is $6. The institute, which boasts a 6-inch Eichner refractor, a 5-inch Alvan Clark refractor and a 12 1/2-inch Newtonian, is on Main Bayview Road. For information, call 765-2626. BOUDOIRS AND BARNYARDS

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Gregory Fulkerson, Vi olinist of Wide Range
description: The Second Violin Sonata by Charles Ives and Aaron Copland's ''Duo'' for Violin and Piano combine expansive lyrical sprituality with down-home earth-stomping eclecticism. Gregory Fulkerson, in his violin recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday night, gave those extravagantly American expressions performances that demonstrated his own brand of American musicality - sincere, pensive, energetic, emphatic and stringently committed.

title: Around the Nation; More in Oklahoma Quit In Inquiry on Kickbacks
description: Four more county commissioners have resigned their posts in what United States Attorney David Russell called ''a very significant week'' for a statewide kickback investigation involving county commissioners.

title: THE TIME OF YEAR TO STOP AND STARE
description: THROUGH many years, ever since I can remember, autumn is always a celebration, a reassurance and a promise. I do not find it sad as many people do who mourn the end of carefree summer, dread cold colorless winter, ache for spring's youth. Jan. 1 is never the beginning of my New Year, but when the first red leaf falls, I step into the new year that has begun for me. It is then that I am armed with a list of shining resolutions, tempered by the reminder that surely this is the time ''to stop and stare.''

title: Stage View; HIGH MARKS FOR 'SEA MARKS' AND A FIZZLE AT THE PHOENIX; by Walter Kerr
description: Time was when a reviewer had to keep his wits about him trying to remember the proper names of all the characters in a play. In all probability, there would be a Nora and a Tom and a Victor plus a Danielle and a Selma and maybe a policeman to be kept track of as a playwright's plotting zigged this way and zagged that, and - to speak for myself - I found it useful to keep a separate little corner of my program or a separate half-sheet of notepaper available on which to list not only the name but the acting habits of each newcomer to bolt on stage. Over a long theatrical season it's perfectly possible to get your Toms and your Victors, and possibly even your Toms and your Selmas, mixed up. And reviewers, like Caesar's wife, are not supposed to get mixed up. The more identifying notes, the better.

title: CHOICE OF JUDGES SPLITS MANHATTAN DEMOCRATS
description: The Manhattan Democratic organization and Harlem leaders within the organization have split over the choice of blacks and women as nominees for three State Supreme Court judgeships.

title: Table of Contents
description: October 4, 1981 NONFICTION ALL THE STARS IN HEAVEN: Louis B. Mayer's M-G-M. By Gary Carey. 18 INFILTRATION. By Albert Speer. 14 MONTY: THE MAKING OF A GENERAL 1887-1942.

title: KUROSAWA ON HIS INNOVATIVE CINEMA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Audie Bock, author of ''Japanese Film Directors,'' was assistant producer of the international film version of Akira Kurosawa's ''Kagemusha,'' and has translated Mr. Kurosawa's autobiography, scheduled for publication in 1982. By AUDIE BOCK

title: TROOPS IN HAWAII PLAN ENVIRONMENTAL BATTLE
description: National Guardsmen and Army reservists in Hawaii are about to join in a new kind of battle that will take them to state and national parks throughout the islands.

title: by Parton Keese
description: When Bryan Trottier arrived at the Islander training camp last month, the first thing that caught his eye was a training-camp brochure. Pictured on the cover under the Islander logo were three Stanley Cups, one for the first cup the Islanders won in 1980; the second for last season's cup triumph, and the third one, in the shadows, representing the Islander goal for this season: a third consecutive Stanley Cup. Someone asked Trottier: "Can the Islanders win it again?" "Yes," replies the Islander's all-star center.

title: WARY OF FUEL PRICES, VERMONTERS HEADING FOR THE WOODSHEDS
description: The costs of oil and gas and fears about their scarcity and environmental effects have turned Vermonters to look to their backyards for wood, which has become the state's most popular heating fuel.

title: FLORIDA CURB ON HOMOSEXUALS SURVIVES A TEST
description: State Representative Tom Bush was not surprised that a Florida law barring state aid to any university that gives funds, meeting space or recognition to any group advocating ''sexual relations between persons not married to each other'' survived its first judicial test, in a state circuit court last week.

title: Florida Interference Barred In the Salvaging of Galleon
description: A Federal judge yesterday temporarily barred Florida from interfering with the salvaging of a galleon that sank in a hurricane 266 years ago.

title: Jordan Builds Nuclear Plant
description: Jordan, with East German technical aid, is building its first nuclear accelerator, a nuclear physicist said today. The accelerator, at the University of Jordan, will be used for research purposes, Dr. Issa Khbeis, a professor at the university, said.

title: CRANBERRIES: SIGN OF STABILITY
description: WHITESBOG AS THE first light of morning filters through the thin mists above Union Reservoir in the central pinelands, herons stalk the shallow water in search of frogs and fish, ducks glide across the still surface and sparrows and warblers move in and out of the woods and tangled bushes along the shore.

title: On Language By William Safire; Winged Words Kimble Mead
description: A miss used to be as good as a mile. Under the pressure of airline euphemism (which turned ''safety belts'' to ''seat belts,'' and ''Life Savers?'' to ''Mints?''), a moment of danger to two aircraft was dubbed a ''near miss.''

title: AS BIG DAIRY SURPLUS GROWS, SO DO U.S. WISHES TO SHED IT
description: America's biggest dairy case is deep inside the cold, dark limestone tunnels under Kansas City. There, in the refrigerator-freezer that is the Agriculture Department's Inland Storage and Distribution Center, are 200 million pounds of surplus products, barrels of cheese and boxes of butter, stacked like frozen pillars and stretching over acres of gray stone floor.

title: ALLEN SETS RECORDS AS U.S.C. ROMPS
description: Marcus Allen rushed for 233 yards to break two National Collegiate Athletic Association records today as top-ranked Southern California routed Oregon State, 56-22.

title: A WORLD OF BAFFLED LOVE
description: THE COUNTRY By David Plante. 159 pp. New York: Atheneum. $9.95.

title: PUERTO RICO SCHOOL HALTS CLASSES AFTER MELEE
description: University authorities have indefinitely suspended classes at the largest branch of the state-operated University of Puerto Rico in the wake of student uprisings over the first tuition increase in 31 years.

title: THE NEW KEYS TO HOME LENDING
description: The costs and complications involved in financing a home in today's world of 19 percent mortgages have become so great that they are supplanting the house itself as the most important aspect of any purchase. People in America no longer shop for homes; they shop for financing.

title: PIECES OF SKYLAB MAY LAND IN COLLECTORS' POCKETS
description: ''Where will Skylab land?'' That was one of the world's burning questions 27 months ago when the 77-ton American space station teetered on the brink of its fiery descent to earth. The question was answered July 12, 1979, when the vessel crashed near Perth in Western Australia - but now it appears that tiny bits of Skylab may soon be ''landing'' again, this time in the pockets of collectors.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1981
description: International The I.R.A. hunger strike has ended. The strike begun last March by imprisoned members of the Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland, who were seeking status as political prisoners rather than as criminals, was called off, the prisoners said, because they had "reluctantly" concluded that the families of the strikers would keep on refusing to let them die. Ten men died during the strike. Further deaths were prevented by the intervention of families, who succeed in removing five other men from the strike. Page 1, Column 1. Lech Walesa was combative but wary after his re-election as leader of Poland's Solidarity union. He said in an interview in Gdandsk, where the union convention is being held, that Solidarity faced " a difficult, very hard period," and warned the Polish Government not to exploit apparent weaknessess within the union. 1:2.

title: COMPANIES OFFER EXPANDED HOUSING BENEFITS
description: Like many young people facing today's high-cost residential market, Stephen Koval, a 28-year-old statistician, is not yet in a position to buy a home. So when he applied for a job with the pharmaceutical manufacturing firm of Boehringer Ingelheim at its new corporate headquarters in Danbury this year, he was pleasantly surprised to find that the company had a program to help pay part of his rent each month.

title: The Region; USING HYDROPOWER TO QUENCH NEW YORK'S ENERGY THIRST
description: The joys of producing energy from the sun, the wind and the rivers have long been evident to those who asserted these ''renewable'' sources were cleaner and safer than nuclear fuel and coal. Lately, some politicians have discovered another virtue - they are relatively cheap.

title: DEBATE RA ISED ON WHEN VOTERS GET TO CHOOSE ON PUBLIC UTLITIY
description: THE proposal by the county to create a public power agency, a once fiercely controversial issue that now seems to enjoy broad political support, last week became the focus of a new dispute, this time over how and when to present the issue to Westchester's voters.

title: 'FAT, DUMB, HAPPY'
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige (right) likes to use plain English. One of his first acts in office was to ban bureaucratic language in favor of short words and sentences.

title: DOES MOM NOT CARE?
description: MOTHER LOVE: MYTH AND REALITY Motherhood in Modern History. By Elisabeth Badinter. Foreword by Francine du Plessix Gray. 360 pp. New York: Macmillan. $13.95.

title: 'UP TO THE MINUTE'--TOO SLICK
description: Television's ''reality boom'' is usually defined in terms of entertainment programs such as ''Real People'' or ''That's Incredible!'' But the medium's true reality roots can be found in the presumably more lofty area of news, and it's here where the boom is expanding into a phenomenon with far-reaching reverberations. Local stations have discovered that news sells and that their newscasts can be quite profitable. On a network level, the CBS News presentation of ''60 Minutes'' has won a top-10 ratings prominence that is the envy of every entertainment studio in Los Angeles. ABC News is usually not too far behind with ''20/20.'' Then, floating somewhere between news and entertainment are a wide assortment of magazine shows with varying degrees of local coverage. Westinghouse's Group W was a pioneer on this level with its ''PM'' series, now in syndication. In brief, news, once the public-service obligation of disgruntled broadcasters, has become a hot item.

title: NIXON SUPPORTING THE SALE OF AWACS
description: Former Pres ident Richard M. Nixon, in a bluntly worded statement insupport of th e sale of Airborne Warning and Control System planes to Saudi Arabia, said that ''if it were not for the intense opposition''of Prime Mini ster Menachem Begin of Israel and ''parts of the American Jewi sh community, the Awacs sale would go through.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN LIECHTENSTEIN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PAUL HOFMANN, a former Times correspondent, lives in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN AFFLUENCE O N THE RHINE -''Long live Liechtenstein, flourishing on the young Rhi ne,'' the subjects of Prince Francis Joseph II sing in their nationa l anthem. Flourishing is rather an understatement. An independent e nclave between Austria and Switzerland, only 61 square miles in tota l area, the principality has a population of 26,000 and is the legal home of twice as many corporations and holding companies. Li echtenstein is a tax haven, a magnet for international money. It ask s almost no questions, offers generous fiscal privilegesand assures i ronclad anonymity. Its vineyard-girded capital, Vaduz, may look like a one-horse town, but millions of dollars are routinelyhandled every business day in its modern offices.

title: Dining Out; THE JAPANESE INFLUENCE IN BERGEN
description: ALARGE community of Japanese businessmen and their families have settled in Fort Lee and with them, fortunately for the rest of us, have come a number of Japanese restaurants. Sushi bars are becoming almost as common as fast-food spots in this Bergen County community.

title: Notes; ALTERNATIVES TO HOTELS AND MOTELS
description: The alternatives to traditional hotel and motel accommodations continue to proliferate. Families or groups taking skiing vacations in the Swiss Alps this winter can choose from among more than 4,000 chalets and apartments listed by Interchange, a New York agency that arranges vacation dwelling and automobile rentals. Among resort areas represented in their 1981-82 listings are Zermatt, Davos, St. Moritz, Gstaad, Silvaplana, Villars, Saas Fee, Tasch and Wengen.

title: Critics' Choices; DANCE
