description: In recent years, the influence of African dance and music has been increasingly felt among American composers and dancers, including those who work in both the avant-garde and pop-music fields. For many American audiences, an introduction to the different cultures of Africa often came through the varied dances that were performed by the numerous African dance troupes that have performed here since the 1950's.

title: T-SHIRTS SHOW NIMITZ PRIDE: U.S. 2, LIBYA 0
description: The predawn darkness on the flight deck is a scene of controlled confusion. Guided by sailors brandishing luminous batons, the fighters, attack bombers, antisubmarine planes and helicopters move slowly to takeoff positions.

title: Sally S. Bunting, Teacher, Is Bride
description: Sally Sayen Bunting, daughter of Mrs. Reeves Bunting of Haverford, Pa., and the late Mr. Bunting, was married yesterday to Eric Sutton Kaufmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Bowman Kaufmann of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. J. Cameron Yorkston, a Presbyterian minister of the Tatnall School in Wilmington, performed the ceremony in a barn at the Paper Mill Farm in Newtown Square, Pa.

title: A NATIONAL SALES TAX TO THE RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: BURMESE TEMPLES RISE FROM RUBBLE OF QUAKE
description: On July 8, 1975, an earthquake toppled the spires of Pagan's pagodas, cracked the walls of its monasteries and reduced the glorious ruins of Burma's golden age to rubble. Six years later the devastation that once seemed impossible to repair is no longer visible.

title: Miss Wood Wed To Julian Younger
description: Deborah Ann Wood, daughter of Kathleen V. Wood and Homer J. Wood both of Los Angeles, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Julian W. Younger. The Rev. Andrew J. Mullins performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: THE DOMESTIC POLICY STAFF IS DIFFERENT UNDER REAGAN
description: WASHINGTON IF President Reagan has adhered more closely to his campaign promises than other chief executives, the credit goes at least in part to the White House's intellectual-in-residence, Martin C. Anderson. As chief domestic policy adviser, Mr. Anderson keeps an eye on emerging policies to insure that they conform with Mr. Reagan's views.

title: Jennifer L. Blackburn Wed to S.M. Walker
description: Jennifer Logan Blackburn and Steven Michael Walker, both of Frisco, Colo., were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. DeLoss Blackburn, parents of the bride, in Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Loring Ensign, minister of the Southport (Conn.)

title: G.M. on Gas
description: To the Business Editor: I'd like to clear up the misunderstanding that has resulted from the way the General Motors' position on natural gas deregulation was set forth in the table accompanying ''The New Battle Over Natural Gas'' (Sept. 6).

title: GOLD IN THE YEAR OF THE QUACK
description: H OW will 1981 be entered in the annals of the history of economic thought? Will it be recorded as a year of intense intellectual turmoil, of struggles to cast aside the discredited consensus of the 1960's and 1970's? More likely, I think, 1981 will be viewed as a period in which eccentric voices temporarily won the ear of political leaders, the year of the economic quack.

title: Travel With Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Defamation Suit Is Dropped Against Indira Gandhi Relative
description: A defamation suit was dropped today against M aneka Gandhi, the daughter-in-law of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, after she apologized for describing 2 6 Indian journalists as members of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: CAN CHAMPIONS GO FROM FIRST TO SECOND
description: Are former world champions too proud to be listed as official match seconds? Mikhail Tal came to the 1978 championship match in the Philippines ostensibly as correspondent for the Moscow magazine ''64,'' but when asked about the chance of his moonlighting as an additional second for Anatoly Karpov, he said,''If Anatoly should ask me whether one move is better than another, I cannot keep silent.''

title: Susan Stroetzel Married
description: Susan Ann Stroetzel, daughter of Donald S. Stroetzel of West Redding, Conn., and the late Dorothy Gow Stroetzel, was married yesterday to Lawrence Pace Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pace of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Charles Stubbs performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: New Jersey Guide; by Martha G. Wilson; A WINNING BALLERINA
description: Amanda McKerrow, who last June became the first American to win a gold medal in the 12-year-old Moscow International Ballet Competition, will perform with the Washington Ballet at Trenton State College on Oct. 16. The petite 17-year-old won out over 130 dancers from more than 20 countries in Russia.

title: Crafts; by Patricia Malarcher
description: TO WHET appetites for the Morristown CraftMarket next weekend, the Nabisco Gallery in nearby East Hanover once again has served up a sampling of the fare for that event. The works of 100 craftspeople - they represent the majority of those who will converge at the Morristown National Guard Armory Friday night - are currently on view at Nabisco.

title: DONALD KENT BROOKS
description: Donald Kent Brooks, a retired real-estate investment banker, died Friday at hi s home in Pelham, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

title: DRAMA SHINES IN 'RIGOLETTO'
description: COMMACK EIGHT months ago, Carl Olsen, a former tenor with the New York City Opera, took charge of the problem-plagued Opera on the Sound. On opening night of the company's new season, Mr. Olsen, who is a voice teacher, rounded up his past and present students to assist him. They were transporting the singers, selling and taking tickets, answering phones and greeting the audience. Amid the tumult, it was a small wonder that some semblance of ''Rigoletto'' made it onto the stage of the Commack South High School auditorium last Saturday.

title: The Nation in Summary; The Clock for Reagan Program Starts to Tick
description: Relaxed and well-rehearsed, Ronald Reagan started the first year of his revolution with a news conference, a demur and a threat.

title: Cogeneration Option Should Be Used
description: It is as something of a flash in the pan that I see the project of Otis Elevator and another company in Westchester looking into cogeneration for more economic energy (''Study Rejects Joint Energy Plan,'' Sept. 20). United Technologies Corporation, its parent company, has had an engineering project looking into cogeneration technology near Washington, D.C., under a contract with the Department of Energy. It also has an energy group on the West Coast, looking into windmill power.

title: THE DANCE: MARTA RENZA AND COMPANY
description: Choreographically speaking, Marta Renzi likes to change her mind. Favoring sudden transitions and unexpected contrasts, she makes a virtue of abruptness and an art of ungainliness.

title: Observations
description: In Russia I arrived home from my first trip to Russia on a Saturday evening recently to find the Sunday New York Times waiting for me.

title: The Nation in Summary; More With Less At the E.P.A.?
description: In Federal bureaucracies, one person's trimmable fat can be another's lean meat, as Anne M. Gorsuch, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, is discovering. In-house documents revealed last week that she is seeking to cut her staff and budget almost in half over the next two fiscal years, pitting Mrs. Gorsuch and her aides against the agency's career employees.

title: Bird Calls: Not Always Music to One's Ear
description: The recent Long Island Opinion article ''When Birds Come Home to Roost'' omitted the most objectionable of all bird noises, in my opinion - the loud, raucous noise of the crow.

title: JAIL FUGITIVES TURN UP ON MICHIGAN WELFARE
description: Escaped convicts in Michigan have traded their prison stripes for welfare checks, and many are getting away with it, an investigation has disclosed.

title: Carole Ann Zeuschel Married to Douglas S. Grover
description: The marriage of Carole Ann Zeuschel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Zeuschel of Town and Country, Mo., to Douglas Senior Grover of Tarrytown, N.Y., took place in St. Louis yesterday. The Rev. Timothy Fortner performed the ceremony at the Covenant Presbyterian Church.

title: The Guillotine
description: There were machines for ''decollation'' well before a doctor named Joseph Ignace Guillotin put his hand to redesigning them, but none that approached his in speed, efficiency and - comparatively speaking - painlessness. The guillotine was modern in another way as well: it made decapitation, once reserved for noble criminals, available to the masses. A highwayman was, in fact, the first to partake of this new privilege, in 1792, but he was soon joined by a king and a queen. When the queen, Marie Antoinette, stepped on her execut ioner's foot, she said: ''I ask your pardon. I did not mean to do it.''

title: Healthy Traveling
description: To the Editor:

title: PERU ACTS TO STEM TRADE IN STOLEN ARTWORKS
description: The Peruvian Government is waging an urgent campa ign to halt a billion-dollar trade in st olen art treasures that is ravaging the country's cultural heritage.

title: by S.J. Horner
description: JAMES J. FLORIO, the Democratic candidate for Governor, and his Republican opponent, Thomas H. Kean, are ''wasting their television money,'' insists Lee Weinblatt, an advertising research consultant, ''unless they skip the rhetoric about issues and concentrate on getting the voters to remember their names.''

title: Food; SALT-FREE SPLENDORS
description: One of the best cooks we know is a fellow named Joseph Luppi 3d, who is the ''right hand'' in our East Hampton kitchen. Not long ago, he told us that he had created a menu made without a grain of salt and tailored to a low-sodium diet. Because this is a subject of keen interest to us, we accepted with alacrity his invitation to share this meal with him and his wife, Melissa, a model, on the following evening.

title: COLLEGE AIMS TO BE FUNDAMENTALISM'S NOTRE DAME
description: Students at Liberty Baptist College need the written permission of a dean to go out on dates. The film series features G-rated movies such as Walt Disney's ''101 Dalmatians,'' and being caught at a disco or with a copy of Playboy magazine would be grounds for suspension.

title: Susan Chadwell, Teacher, Is Wed
description: Susan Summeril Chadwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Tyree Chadwell Jr. of San Marino, Calif., was married in the Community Church there yesterday to Seth Walworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Walworth Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Michael Roffina, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Marshlow, David Mooney
description: Melinda Susan Marshlow and David Walton Mooney were married yesterday at the Huguenot Memorial Church in Pelham, N.Y., by the Rev. Donald R. Kocher.

title: Halfway House Plan Is Cut
description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons is trimming $13 million scheduled to be used for 400 halfway houses to help inmates adjust to life outside prisons. The bureau said yesterday that it would shorten the average stay of ex-convicts from about 80 to 45 days, as part of an effort to reduce its $383.8 million budget by $24.5 million. Last year, about 9,000 former inmates were sent to the halfway houses.

title: RUTHERFORD, AT 100, LOOKS BOTH FORWARD AND BACK
description: ''Welcome to Rutherford on our 100th anniversary,'' reads the banner hanging between the Station Square Market and the National Community Bank.

title: A Copy of Great Seal Of California Is Back
description: The earliest known reproduction of the Great Seal of California has been returned to its home in the State Capitol after an absence of 127 years.

title: Frank Church on Foreign Policy
description: Frank Church's analogy between Afghanistan and Iran is totally false. Afghanistan bears no resemblance to Khomeini's Iran, nor has its population ''proven susceptible to the fundamentalist ferment sweeping the Moslem world.''

title: U.S., SAUDIS SHARE HISTORY OF BUILT-IN CONTRADICTIONS
description: President Reagan's pledge last week that he would not permit Saudi Arabia's oil to be ''shut off'' underscored the longstanding, if contradictory, relationship between the world's largest oil consumer and the world's biggest exporter. While the President was affirming the importance of the defense of Saudi Arabia, key members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee were expressing grave doubts about a $8.5 billion arms package which is supposed to to help Saudi Arabia protect its oil fields from sudden attack.

title: MASTER DIARIST MAX FRISCH
description: Stephen Singular is a freelance writer. By Stephen Singular Max Frisch gave up writing almost 45 years ago. He was 26 at the time and had already published one novel, one novella (which he now calls very bad), some short stories and two or three plays. His writing was nicely done, he says, but superficial, lyrical in the tradition of earlier Swiss and German romantics. One afternoon, he tied all of his published work and his notebooks into several bundles and carried them into the woods outside his hometown of Zurich. It was a rainy afternoon in Switzerland and Frisch used up a whole box of matches before he succeeded in turning the bundles into ashes.

title: Critics' Choices; by Hilton Kramer
description: ART Small galleries specializing in ''big'' art - big in names, in quality and in promise for the future, if not always in the physical dimensions of the objects shown - used to be one of the most delightful features of the New York art scene. Over the years they have been largely superceded by the big galleries that specialize in small art (which is often very large indeed in its physical dimensions). One fine gallery that has not significantly changed either in its scale of operation or in its dedication to quality, however, is Robert Elkon's, which is currently observing its 20th anniversary. To mark this event, the gallery has mounted an exhibition that brings together a representative selection of the modern master works and the art of contemporary painters and sculptors for which it has become renowned.

title: Around the Nation; Court Upholds Searches At 3 Scientology Offices
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the legality of Federal Bureau of Investigation searches of three Church of Scientology offices in July 1977.

title: THE UTILITY THAT GLOWS IN BROOKLYN
description: The Dodgers are gone. So are the Schaeffer and Rheingold breweries, the United States Navy and, over the last decade, 400,000 people. More than 1,000 business enterprises have al so left New York City's biggest borou gh.

title: AIR BAGS: COSTLY POTENTIAL KILLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE TO TURN FOR INFORMATION
description: New Jersey has nine group homes for autistic children and one for autistic adul ts, along with about a dozen private and public dayschool pro grams. Still, the facilities have not come close to meeting the n eed of the state's autistic youngsters.

title: A TEST CASE ON STABILIZED RENTS
description: When the 10-year tax abatement on the building at 400 East 54th Street expires next June, the owners plan to remove the building from rent stabilization. They say they are entitled to collect free-market rents once the city starts collecting full taxes.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: PLAYING THE GAME OF POLITICS
description: Government officials do what they do in ways that are sometimes puzzling, sometimes predictable and often shrouded in just enough mystery to make them seem more important than they are. It is, then , reassuring when events serve to remind us that those in positions of reputed power often react the way the rest of us do. Consider, f or example, the case of the Port Authority bridges. For months now, two government agencies have been tangling over plans to buil d two bridges between the proposed commercial complex at Battery Pa rk City and the World Trade Center. Officials of the Urban Develop ment Corporation had charged officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey with foot-dragging.

title: SOLIDARITY DISCOVERS THAT ITS DEMOCRACY ISN'T PERFECT
description: When the delegates at Solidarity's national convention voted last week, they held up their beige-colored convention cards to be counted. And when they wanted to razz a speaker who was rambling off the point, they waved the cards high in the air like fans.

title: RUTGER M. SMITH
description: Rutger M. Smith, president of H. J. Baker and Brother Inc., an international trading company, died of cancer Friday at Roosevelt Hospital.

title: GALAXY LIBRA WINS MAN O'WAR ON TURF
description: Charlie Whittingham makes such a good living training horses in California that he does not bother running his horses in New York unless he sees a spot where the money is good and the competition looks soft. He found one yesterday and he brought Bill Shoemaker with him from California.

title: UPDATE FROM CHINA
description: To the Editor:

title: KARPOV ADJOURNS SEALING 42D MOVE
description: Is the age difference - Viktor Korchnoi is 50 years old and Anatoly Karpov 30 - becoming a factor in the world championship chess match here in the Kurzentrum? Tonight Korchnoi blundered away a pawn in a position difficult to defend and stands to lose his second game in a row when play is resumed tomorrow at 5 P.M.

title: FORMALDEHYDE: A WORKHORSE CHEMICAL FACES BANS
description: Formaldehyde Might smell foul. But with its odor controlled, formaldehyde is one of chemistry's most versatile compounds - it's found in everything from embalming fluid to toothpaste. Formaldehyde maintains the ''press'' in permanent-press fabric, bonds the fibers in paper towels and, when used as a fertilizer additive, helps the garden grow.

title: U.S. AND IRELAND HONOR WHITEHOUSE ARCHITECT
description: The United States and Ireland have just issued companion commemoratives for James Hoban, the Irish immigrant who became the architect of the White House and one of the builders of the new capital established by the fledgling republic on the banks of the Potomac.

title: Indian Guesthouse
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard Fischbeck Weds Amy Halsted
description: Amy Mari lla Halsted, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Halsted Jr.of New Canaan , Conn., was married there yesterday to Richard David Fischbeck, so n of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Fischbeck of Middletown, N.Y. The Rev. Alfred H. Whisler, rector of St. Mark's Episcopal Church, perfo rmed the ceremony at the Halsted home. Msgr. Francis X. McGuire, past or of St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church, gave the blessing.

title: BROOKLYN ARMY TERMINAL STUDY ASKED
description: With Harry B. Helmsley's announced withdrawal as the redeveloper of the Brooklyn Army Terminal, two civic associations that have long questioned the Helmsley approach called upon the Koch Administration anew to review the issue of how the property should be redeveloped.

title: OHIO ST. UPSET BY FLA. ST.
description: The opposing quarterbacks, Rick Stockstill of Florida State and Art Schlichter of Ohio State, passed for a total of more than 700 yards today, with Stockstill engineering the Seminoles to a 36-27 upset of the Buckeyes.

title: REDS ELIMINATED IN LOSS TO BRAVES
description: Bob Horner hit two home runs, batted in three runs and scored three today as the Atlanta Braves defeated Cincinnati, 4-3, and eliminated the Reds from the race in the National League West. The Reds' loss gave the Houston Astros the West title in the second half of the split season.

title: FOOTBALL THAT IMPROVES WITH AGE
description: DARIEN WERE he a football player, John McEnroe, the volatile tennis star, might enjoy the special freedom of Inter-City Touch Football League, whose games are played without interruption by officials. And Dave Jennings, the Giants' punter from Woodbridge, no doubt would be happy to take advantage of the league's rule barring defensive players from blocking punts.

title: The World in Summary; Touchy Trade-Off On Foreign Aid
description: There are those supporters of foreign aid in Washington who have painfully learned one rule: You're damned if you do and you're damned if you don't.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: OUTDOOR wall murals are nothing new, particularly the recent spate of brightly colored primitives done by local amateurs to spruce up a neighborhood. But something new has been added in Stamford, where an outdoor mural by one of Connecticut's leading artists, Gunther Riess, has been painted on the wall of the Stamford Art Association building at 39 Franklin Street. The work is 30 feet long and two stories high.

title: U.S. to Ease Standard On Bumpers for Cars
description: The Transportation Department plans to ease standards requiring automobile bumpers to be built to withstand damage in a 5-mile-an-hour crash on the ground that the rule may not be cost-effective.

title: Stage View; WHERE CORRUPTION IS A WAY OF LIFE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Billington is London theater critic for The Guardian. By MICHAEL BILLINGTON LONDON The Royal Shakespeare Company is obsessed by Russian drama. In recent seasons it has given us a posse of plays by Chekhov, Gorki, Bulgakov and Erdman. Now, possibly smarting from accusations of bein ga Soviet company in exile, it has come up wit h the British premiere of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's ''The Love-Girl a nd the Innocent,'' a vast, panoramic study of life in a Stalinist labor camp in 1945. The result is one of those rare theatrical evenin gs that make the usual esthetic niggles look puny. What matters is t he savage honesty with which Solzhenitsyn sets before us the seamles s web of corruption thatruns through the corrective camps. The play b ecomes a momentous experience because of its momentous theme.

title: ENGLISH FURNITURE FACES A TEST
description: The market for English furniture has changed dramatically in recent seasons, attracting for the finest offerings new collectors, higher prices and serious scholars. Whether or not this strong response will continue this season will be seen in the weeks and months ahead with the sale of moderate-priced to expensive designs at auctions and in shops.

title: Fireman Saves Brooklyn Girl
description: A firefighter who heard a 7-year-old girl's screams raced through a smoke-filled hall and rescued her just as flames engulfed her family's fourth-floor apartment in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn yesterday, Fire Department officials said. Neither the girl, Rosa Canzel, nor the fireman, John Kwiatkowski, of East Meadow, L.I., was seriously hurt. Fire marshals said the blaze, at 5622 Fourth Avenue, was suspicious.

title: Editor's Note
description: Despite the headline on the review of Tracy Kidder's ''The Soul of a New Machine'' (Aug. 23), the new work is not related to ''The Hardy Boys'' juvenile book series of the Stratemeyer Syndicate.

title: THE NEW BLACK CONSERVATIVES
description: Lee A. Daniels is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times. By Lee A. Daniels Nathan Wright Jr., educator, author and chairman of the National Assault on Illiteracy Program, is convinced that racism no longer has ''a damn thing'' to do with the still-perilous predicament of black America and that Ronald Reagan, a man of ''principle and pragmatism,'' is committed to helping blacks advance.

title: Pamela Friant Is Bride Of John Anthony Foley
description: The marriage of Pamela Rae Friant and John Anthony Foley, who received master's degrees in technical writing last year from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, took place at the West Side Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J., yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Steven Geckler, assisted by the Rev. Russell Holmes, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: FINLAND EXPECTING A LEADERSHIP SHIFT
description: For the first time in more than 25 years, Finland is facing a change in presidents, and political leaders say they are confident that the transition will be an orderly one without interference or adverse comment from the Soviet Union.

title: Long Islanders; A FAMILY MEMBER ON HIS OWN TRACK
description: BY now, everybody knows about Carmine Coppola, the composer and conductor. And everybody knows about Francis Coppola, the director of such films as ''The Godfather'' and ''Apocalypse Now.'' So it seems appropriate to move farther along the branches of the family tree and introduce Marc Coppola, who is Carmine's grandson, Francis's nephew and a newly anointed nighttime disk jockey at New York radio's leading bastion of rock, WPLJ-FM.

title: MONMOUTH: ON WITH THE DANCE
description: WEEK dance residency program that began on Sept. 21 will be highlighted by performances by the Eglevsky Ballet of Long Island next Saturday and again on Oct. 24. Both will be presented at the Monmouth Arts Center, 99 Monmouth Street.

title: 2 STATES AT ODDS ON DRINKING HOURS
description: An interstate dispute has broken out along the New York-Massachusetts border about the problems caused by differing drinking hours in the two states.

title: EXP OS, ASTROS, BREWERS CLINCH IN DIVISIONAL RACES
description: After 13 years in the big leagues, Canada received its first baseball prize yesterday when the Montreal Expos rallied to defeat the Mets, 5-4, and clinched the second-half race in the National League's Eastern Division.

title: Miss Hamel Wed To K.M. Houston
description: At St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Portsmouth, R.I., yesterday, Cecily Charlyn Hamel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Rogers Hamel of Francestown, N.H., was married to Kenneth Mapes Houston, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Mapes Houston of Schenectady, N.Y. The Rev. Peter A. Maguire performed the ceremony.

title: 36 Food Outlets Called Health Code Violators
description: Thirty-six food establishments were found i n violation of the health code, the New York City Health Departm ent reported last week. One establishment reopened after correcting earlier violations and three were closed for failing to do so.

title: Keith Meyers
description: SWIMMING OUT, ICE SKATING IN: Joanne and Jeff Alderman and their daughters Merri, left, and Liz yesterday on the skating rink at Rockefeller Center. The weather cooperated for the opening of the rink by contributing a blustery high of 57 degrees. Today should be a little warmer, up to about 65 degrees, with less wind.

title: COLUMBIA REPORTS A 27% RISE IN DONATIONS IN 1980-81 YEAR
description: Columbia University received $48.4 million in donations for the 1980-81 academic year, an increase of more than $10.3 million over the previous year, the university has announced.

title: Other Business; ALL SAVERS: THE BIG WINNERS ARE NEWSPAPERS
description: Who were the biggest beneficiaries of the Oct. 1 launch of ''All Savers'' certificates? Not the savers. They'll have to wait a year to realize the tax-free benefits. And it wasn't the banks, at least not yet. It was the nation's newspapers.

title: VULNERABILITY ASSUMES THE SOVIETS WILL STRIKE FIRST
description: WASHINGTON THE Carter Administration defined the strategic nuclear options facing America in a cautious and restrained way; yet it proposed what could have been a $100 billion solution of shuttling 200 new MX missiles among 4,600 underground shelters. Last week, the Reagan Administration painted the strategic challenges in far more dire terms, but went on to recommend the much less expensive solution of building 100 MX missiles and simply putting many of them in existing ICBM silos protected by extra concrete.

title: HE JUGGLES A HOT, NEW COMMODITY IN WORLD TRADE
description: P IETER L.M. VISMANS looked in exasperation at the Telex message from the Port of New Orleans. It notified him that the coal carrier Royal Lynx, which had arrived there to pick up coal that day, would not be loaded right away.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Void Where Banned by Law
description: Some regions of space are emptier than others, the result of gravity drawing galaxies together into clusters and clusters into superclusters, leaving ''voids'' in between. Now astronomers using telescopes at three major observatories have found what appears to be the largest void yet, where the average density of material is one tenth that of the universe as a whole. It is an aberration in the generally uniform distribution of galaxies in space that, if confirmed, may mean revising current theories of the universe's evolution.

title: Kate Oliver Barry Is Wed to Richard H. Robinson
description: Kate Oliver Barry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Barry of Hillsborough, Calif., was married in San Mateo, Calif., yesterday to Richard Hutchinson Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Robinson of Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Jack C. Graves performed the cereZony in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: 43d Motion in Atlanta Case
description: Mary Welcome and Tony Axam, attorneys for Wayne B. Williams, who is accused of two of 28 slayings of Atlanta blacks, asked Friday in their 43d pretrial motion yesterday that the case be dismissed because publicity in the news media had made a fair trial impossible.

title: GRASS MAY GIVE LEMMINGS REPRODUCTIVE CUE
description: Scientists have discovered a substance appearing each spring in new shoots of grass that they believe performs like a super hormone, abruptly turning on reproductive activity in some mammals.

title: BREWERS FINISH FIRST BY TOPPING TIGERS
description: Gorman Thomas drove in the go-ahead run wi th a bases- loaded sacrifice fly in a two-run Milwaukee eighth inning today, and the Brewers defeated the Detroit Tigers, 2-1, to clinch the Am erican League East second-half championship.

title: THE POWER OF POSITIVE PASSAGE
description: PATHFINDERS By Gail Sheeh y. 494 pp. New Y ork: William Morro w & Co. $15.95.

title: ELIZABETH WINS, 29-7
description: Elizabeth rallied in the second half and stunned highly regarded Westfield, 29-7, before 6,000 fans yesterday in Elizabeth. Westfield lost by the widest margin since Gary Kehler became coach 21 years ago. Westfield (1-1) opened the scoring when Kevin Morris hit Dave Jackson with a 23-yard pass to cap an 88-yard drive in the second period. But Elizabeth (2-0) struck back when Barry Hunter scored on a 3-yard run to complete a 58-yard drive in the same period. Hunter scored Elizabeth's final touchdown on a 1-yard run in the fourth period after Jerome Baker's 20-yard touchdo wn pass to Ted Porter and Rodney Carter 's 59-yard scoring sprint in the third. Carter carried nine times fo r 101 yards.

title: Footnotes
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. FOOTNOTES The first five titles on the hardcover fiction list remain the same as last week's.

title: Around the World; European Finance Aides Open Parley in Brussels
description: Common Market finance officials began talks today amid reports of changes in Western Europe's monetary system.

title: WARDE RALLIES TO TOP DARIEN
description: It took a dramatic ending in Darien, but Andrew Warde of Fairfield is now 3-0, its best start in more than a decade. A 12-7 victory over Darien kept Warde in a first place tie in the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference's Eastern Division with Trumbull and Staples, which also posted victories.

title: FRANK FAZZINI PACES BELLEVILLE
description: Frank Fazzini, Essex County's premier fullback, ran for 66 yards and two touchdowns to lead Belleville over Barringer, 39-14, yesterday in Belleville.

title: by Andree Brooks
description: STAMFORD WITH conventional apartment buildings becoming almost extinct in lower Fairfield County, accessory apartments permitted inside the many underused single-family houses in the area are becoming the most cost-effective and visually acceptable way of creating a new source of inexpensive rentals.

title: Around the World; Prince Charles Grants Himself a 50% Raise
description: Prince Charles has granted himself a $4,816-a-week raise to offset the costs of married life, Buckingham Palace announced last night.

title: INDIAN GUESTHOUSE
description: To the Edit or: The stateme nt in Barbara Crossette's article that although you do not need a vi sa to enter India by air at Delhi you must have a visa to cross the Pakistani-Indian border by land reminded me of my unsuccessful attempt to reach Amristar, India, from Lahore, Pakistan,in 1977.

title: Westchester Housing; A CAMPAIGN TO KEEP RACIAL BALANCE
description: ACAMPAIGN to attract corporate transferees to two integrated White Plains neighborhoods, Battle Hill and Fisher Hill, is being waged by the White Plains Housing Information Service.

title: HIGH LEVEL OF PCB'S FOUND IN WATERFOWL IN UPSTATE NEW YORK
description: A three-year study shows that ducks and other waterfowl in upstate New York are contaminated with high levels of PCB's, a known cause of cancer in laboratory animals, according to state officials.

title: The Region in Summary; The City and the Great Outdoors
description: Some of the first steps in the revitalization of Times Square could be taken by pedestrians along a traffic-free Broadway mall. That was the prospect last week as city planners, who have pressed for such a mall for a decade, received a $4.5 million Federal subsidy for its construction.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstan ds, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as i n bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed report s from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40, 000 outlets across the United States.

title: Six Die in Italian Rainstorms
description: Two days of rainstorms that struck Italy's west coast have left at least six people dead and scores injured, the authorities said today. Hardest hit were the summer resort of Santa Marinella, north of Rome, and the city of Civitavecchia.

title: Clare Price Botta Becomes a Bride
description: Clare Price Botta, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Robert Botta of Allendale, N.J., and Stratton, Vt., was married in New York yesterday to Sterling Brownlee Brinkley Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Brinkley of Washington. The Rev. Charles Quinn performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour.

title: The Nation in Summary; Red Ink Mail May Turn Black
description: Just in time for the Christmas rush, the Postal Service overruled the independent Postal Rate Commission last week and announced that it would raise the cost of a first-class domestic stamp by 2 cents.

title: FIRE RANKS LACKING YOUNG VOLUNTEERS
description: IT'S a familiar scenario. The alarm sounds, and the fireman stops whatever he's doing and races to the firehouse in his car, at lifeendangering speed, with its warning lights flashing.

title: THE PHILHARMONIC: PERLMAN
description: When Itzhak Perlman played Beethoven's Violin Concerto with the New York Philharmonic on Friday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall, he seemed on intimate terms with the music - an intimacy based on fresh experience rather than rote recitation.

title: Egg on The Face
description: Russell Baker's ''Egg on the Face'' (Sunday Observer, Aug. 30) discusses the dining calamities of misplaced food - wog particles - attached only to cleanshaven faces.

title: Bess Truman Fights Fever
description: Bess Truman is improving steadily from a mild stroke suffered last week but is still fighting a slight fever, her physician said today. She managed to eat a little food, but she still was receiving most of her nutrients through a nasal tube, the doctor said.

title: Headliners
description: WELCOME TO City HALL The Vatican's bank suffered heavy losses under his stewardship in 1974, but Bishop Paul C. Marcinkus has an employer who is, if anything, forgiving.

title: The Nation in Summary; Watch at Sea For Haitians
description: The Bahamas channel is the sea lane sailed by most of the 60,000 Haitians who since 1972 have fled the Western Hemisphere's poorest country for the American dream. Starting this week, the Reagan Administration announced, more than tropical storms or the refugees' leaky boats will turn the voyage perilous.

title: Catholics Get Appeal To Bar Nuclear Arms
description: Archbishop John R. Quinn, immediate past president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, urged Roman Catholics today to take concerted polit ical action to stop development and deployment of nuclear weapons .

title: FUTURE OF INDEPENDENT BELIZE IS FULL OF QUESTIONS
description: For over 30 years, the tiny British colony of Belize slowly gathered the recognized attributes of nationhood, including its own government, army, flag, currency and national anthem.

title: Film View; THIRD QUARTER REPORT: MOVIE MAGIC IS BACK
description: Just as you become convinced that movies have reached the point of no return, when you feel they are being made for tiny-brained creatures from outer space, and when a bland inoffensiveness appears to be the sea into which we're all sinking helplessly, something magical happens. First one, then another and then still a nother good film opens, and moviegoing, which has been a definite chore, once again becomes a matter of excitement and legi timate interest.

title: JOSEPH P. BRENNAN
description: Joseph P. Brennan Jr., a former city sheriff who retired in 1976, died yesterday at the Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Egyptian Confers With Haig; ' Close Convergence' Is Cited
description: Vice President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. discussed Middle East peace today during a two-hour lunch at the State Department.

title: A RANGER LOOKS AT HOCKEY FIGHTS
description: Barry Beck of the Rangers will miss the first three games of the National Hockey League season. He was suspended for his part in a fight at Madison Square Friday night.

title: Food; FULFILLING ANY TASTE, AT ANY HOUR
description: OCEANSIDE THE red and yellow striped exterior and colorful banners flapping outside the Big Banana Farmers Market create a carnival-like impression and belie the serious shopping that occurs 24 hours a day inside this well-stocked store.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Loyalty's Reward
description: After 55 years of service to the Federal Government, Zhao Wenjin appeared eligible for a pension. But as of last May, he had not yet received one.

title: Westchester Guide; COMBATING ILLITERACY
description: Statistics indicate there are 23 million illiterate Americans. Authorities contend that that figure will double when results of the 1980 census, due in 1982, are disclosed.

title: John Goeke Weds Anne de la Bouillerie
description: Anne Elizabeth de la Bouillerie, daughter of Mrs. Walter A.L. Gruber of New York, London and Water Mill, L.I., and Baron Henri de la Bouillerie of Paris, was married yesterday to John Howard Goeke of San Francisco. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: KREMLIN PLEDGING RESPONSE ON ARMS
description: The Soviet Government's press agency, Tass, said today that the Soviet Union would have ''an appropriate counterbalance'' to Presi dent Reagan's decision to deploy the MX missile in fi xed sites, revive the B-1 bomber and develop an improvedsubmarine-bas ed Trident missile.

title: Art; SUPERB CRAFTSMANSHIP STANDS OUT IN JAPANESE ART
description: GREAT NECK ALTHOUGH Japanese culture is extraordinarily rich in its diversity and depth, most Westerners have a painfully poor awareness of it. We may have a smattering of knowledge about tea ceremonies, shoguns, banyan trees, flower arrangements, Sony and the samurai warriors, but our exploration of Japanese civilization has not extended much beyond that.

title: STUDENTS ABROAD: EXPERIENCE AS VAST AS GLOBE
description: ''MY semester was very exciting and without a doubt a fantastic experience. L ondon is a great place to be for a semester, and I consider myse lf lucky to have gone to school there.''

title: Ideas & Trends; ENVIRONMENTAL LAISSEZ-FAIRE KEPT WELL IN CHECK
description: He that hath land hath quarrels. So wrote the English poet George Herbert more than 300 years ago. James Watt would no doubt agree. As Interior Secretary, Mr. Watt has land aplenty. The Federal Government owns over 750 million acres, about a third of the nation's total land mass, most of that controlled or supervised by the Interior Department. In some Western states and Alaska the Government owns more than half of the total acreage in the form of National Parks, wildlife refuges, national forests and rangeland operated by the Bureau of Land Management. Because of his approach to managing those lands, an approach that diverges radi cally from the practices of his recent predecessors, Mr.Watt also has many quarrels on his hands. The Interior Secretary has the responsib ility of conserving the lands entrusted to his care but also of super vising the orderly use of the lands and their resources. Mr . Watt, proclaiming that the ''pendulum'' had swung too far toward co nservation, has taken a swift series of policy measures to open the p ublic lands to exploitation by energy, mining, timber and ranching interests.

title: U.S. REOPENS CASE ON COLLABORATOR
description: Erna Alley has been granted a military hearing on her effort to obtain an honorable discharge for her late husband, Ronald K. Alley, a former Army major who was convicted of collaborating with the enemy in his 33 months as a prisoner of war in North Korea in 1951 and 1952.

title: 85 JOIN AND SHARE IN A NONPRIVATE PROSPERITY
description: They had heard, outside their circle, ''Friendship and business don't mix.'' They had heard, ''Everyone needs privacy.'' They had heard many things, they ignored all of them, and today 85 friends here are business partners living togetherin what they call ''The Environment.''

title: Observations in Russia
description: In stating his proposition that no Russian Governments have ''received the consent of the governed,'' Mr. Austin asserts that czarist rule was ''never underwritten by parliaments, assemblies of notables or Magna Cartas.''

title: MANHATTAN CO-OPS: PRICES ARE LEVELING OFF
description: There's a man living in the Dakota who is distraught because he has not been able to sell his 5 1/2 room cooperative apartment in one of the most prestigious buildings on the West Side. He wanted $850,000, but has reduced his price to $800,000.

title: PRINCETON EDGES BROWN, 21-17
description: With a 93-yard scoring drive in the closing minutes, Prin ceton achieved a 20-to-17 Ivy League triumph over Brown today in a ga me that saw the lead change hands four times.

title: Television Week; Class Experiment
description: Fourteen years ago, during a world history class at Cubberly High School in Palo Alto, Calif., Ron Jones, the teacher, was asked by a student: ''How could the German populace claim ignorance to the slaughter of Jewish people?'' Mr. Jones later wrote: ''I didn't know the answer.'' So, he embarked on an experiment that came to be known as the ''Third Wave.''

title: REAGAN CUTS MAY ADD UP TO $2 BILLION IN STATE
description: President Reagan's latest budget-cutting plan could increase New York State's losses of congressionally approved funds to ''well over'' $2 billion in the Federal fiscal year that began Thursday, the head of Governor Carey's Washington office warned yesterday.

title: Business Conditions; A BRIGHT SPOT FOR STEEL
description: Although sales to such traditional customers as automobile companies remain weak and have prevented domestic steel producers from breaking out of their long slump, rising demand for seamless pipe has kept a bad situation from getting worse.

title: OVERFISHING AND PIRACY ARE PLAGUING
description: LOBSTERMEN By JUDI CULBERTSON

title: Long Island Journal
description: ANOTHER round in the long-running battle over dev elopment of 21.5 acres of Glen Head Country Club land is about to begin, according to Celia Swing, president of the Glen Head-Glenwood Civic Council.

title: Craig Morton and Dan Reeves Are Back on Top
description: Craig Morton amd Dan Reeves, whose paths first crossed 16 years ago when both were rookies in the Dallas Cowboys' training camp, are going through a euphoric period, much different than the life they've known in the National Football League.

title: Around the Nation; American Airlines Plane In Near Crash in Illinois
description: An American Airlines jet carrying 52 persons flew within 300 feet of a small state-owned plane carrying three members of the Illinois General Assembly, officials said yesterday.

title: ARE HOUSE CALLS PASSE? NOT FOR VETERINARIANS
description: UNION THE doctor rang the doorbell, and the patient took off like a frightened cat. Literally. ''Come back,'' Meryl Marias shouted, rushing up the stairs of her home here to retrieve the patient, which was, indeed, a frightened cat named Melissa. As Dr. Saul A. Zucker, a veterinarian who limits his practice to house calls, prepared a syringe, Mrs. Marias looked under the bed. ''We're com ing,'' she called, running into the kitchen bearing an orange cat dr aped in a white towel. Melissa, wh o has been declawed, has been known to scratch. Althoughshe did not s eem to notice the needle going in, she was off like a flash again w hen the ordeal was over.

title: A TENDERFOOT TAKES TO THE ADIRONDACKS
description: It sounded like a trip out of James Dickey's ''Deliverance'' - or maybe middle-aged madness - when my friend Ray Morrissey first suggested spending six days canoeing and camping in the Adirondacks. But it also sounded very appealing to a middle-aged political reporter whose idea of a hike, until then, was the 10-block walk from Pennsylvania Station to Times Square and back five days a week. If ever there was a chance to get away from it all, this was it. The price was right: $50 for the instant oatmeal flavored with apple and cinnamon and other such delicacies we existed on for the week. (Among us we already had the canoes and gear we needed, and no fees were required on the waterways or at the state campsites.)

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 3 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with the Berrys, an eccentric family that sets up house in unlikely hotels, here and abroad. 2 2 8 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 3 3 22 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and C hinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 4 4 10 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Chief of Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York.

title: INDIAN GUESTHOUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Remembering Hofstra's Tiny 20
description: SOME players never showed up for camp that September and others started disappearing in the middle of the night. ''Captain Midnights'' - that's what the surviving players called the defectors.

title: Mailbox; Steinbrenner's Loyalty Askew
description: To the Sports Editor: I find it ironic that George Steinbrenner (The New York Times, Sept. 20) regards loyalty as a requirement for all his employees when he consistently fails to show them the same courtesy. Steinbrenner publicly berates and embarrasses his ballplayers and then doesn't have the se nsitivity to realize that his outb ursts act as the catalysts for a player's rebuttle.

title: NEWSPAPER OFFICE IN NEW LIFE
description: HARTFORD A FORGOTTEN downtown corner here has sprung back to life as The Hartford Times building - silent and empty for nearly five years - has reopened for the first time since the demise of the afternoon daily on Oct. 20, 1976.

title: IS SOUTH AFRICA HELPING MUGABE TO FAIL?
description: A year ago, it was a favorite boast of South African diplomats that when neighboring black states got into economic straits, they would send out a quiet S.O.S. for Kobus Loubser, a high official of South African Railways, who would then slip discreetly into their capitals and, working his white magic, set things right. The boast - by no means unfounded - emphasized the extreme dependence of eight members of the Organization of African Unity on South Africa's transport system and ports.

title: Fidel La Barba Dead; Ex-Boxing Champion
description: Fidel La Barba, a onetime flyweight boxing champion of the world and a 1924 Olympic gold medalist, died of heart failure late yesterday at Veterans Administration Hospital, friends reported. He was 76 years old.

title: SEARCHING FOR SPACE TO DANCE IN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lois Draegin is dance editor of the Soho News. By LOIS DRAEGIN

title: New Jersey Journal; by Anthony DePalma
description: MOST of the 35,000 railroad commuters who arrive in Hoboken each morning never get to see much of the old Erie-Lackawanna terminal as they rush for a seat on the next PATH train to Manhattan. However, if they have a minute or two to spare on the return trip some afternoon, they might use the time to view some of the extensive renovations that have taken place over the last three years.

title: NORTHWEST TOWNS RESIST RIVER PROJECT
description: HARTFORD IN a little-publicized move, but one that was preceded by almost 30 years of planning, the Metropolitan District Commission has taken the first step in a project to divert water from the Farmington River, in the northwest part of the state, to 11 towns in the Hartford area.

title: NORWAY MAY TIGHTEN ITS RULES ON FOREIGN AID
description: The outgoing Labor Government has suggested new rules that would deny Norwegian development aid for projects that could harm the recipient country's environment.

title: DON SHULA AND THE DOLPHINS ARE SIZZLING ONCE MORE
description: MIAMI D ON SHULA doesn't have dirty fingernails and his Miami Dolphins are 4-0. Does this make sense? It makes as much sense as the Jets, who face the Dolphins today, coming in with a 1-3 record.

title: EAST END UPZONING WEIGHED
description: THE East Hampton Town Board is considering a plan to upzone more than 2,500 acres of mostly contiguous land from one-acre to two-acre residential use in another effort to slow development. The town has had a record number of housing starts this year, mostly for luxury vacation homes.

title: Pamela Walker, Engineer, Is Wed
description: Pamela Maria Walker, daughter of Regina Ricca Walker of Southbury, Conn., and Graham Woodward Walker of San Carlos, Calif., was married yesterday to George Christopher McNamara, son of Mrs. George F. McNamara of Somerset, Mass., and the late Mr. McNamara.

title: PANEL SEEKS TO BAR A LEASE OF ST. BART'S LAND
description: Organizations of preservationists and architects have formed a committee that seeks to prevent the prop osed lease of land next to St. Bartholom ew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue for construction ofan office bui lding.

title: ALONG ZIMBABWE'S BORDER, A WAR IS STILL GOING ON
description: Although the war ended last year between the forces of the former Rhodesia and the insurgents who now govern Zimbabwe, the sound of firing has never been stilled in the rich farming country here along the Mozambique border.

title: Italian Chief to Visit Portugal
description: President Sandro Pertini, the 85-year-old chief of state, will pay an official visit to Portugal Oct. 23-25, a spokesman for the presidential palace said today.

title: Abortion Is More Than Political Issue
description: Susan Schneider's article on the horrors of illegal abortion (''Antiabortion Plan: Where Is Justice?'' Sept. 20) should be required reading for every politician who thinks abortion is merely a political issue.

title: Miss Smith Is Married
description: At St. Thomas's Episcopal Church in New Hav en yesterday, Elizabeth Chatfield Smith, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. How ard Willis Smith of New Haven and Lake Placid, N.Y., was married to R ichard Howe Stukey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Stukey of Teaneck, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rev. Lansing Hicks, associate pr ofessor of Old Testament and director of studies at the Yale University Divinity School. He was assisted by the Rev. William R .

title: Giving Credit Where It's Due
description: On Sept. 20, there appeared an article on the formation of a bus service by Saddle Rock residents. Unfortunately, the article neglected to credit two people who have worked an extraordinary number of hours and have overcome what appeared to be insurmountable obstacles.

title: PARENTS INITIATE DRUG-ABUSE PROGRAMS
description: THE beginning of the school year is marked by students carrying new school supplies - clean notebooks, sharp pencils and pocket calculators with fully charged batteries. But some high school students of the 1980's may also bring reefers, rolling papers and roach clips - the three newest R's of the school experience.

title: Dance View; TWYLA THARP'S GROWING PAINS
description: When she is good, she is very good. And when she is bad, she's justplain bad. Twyla Tharp is inconsistent. She has to be judged piece by piece. As her Winter Garden season currently proves, she is still working things out. In ''The Catherine Wheel,'' she fails grandly with an 80-minute production that is two-thirds bad and one-third terrific. Yet she works to total perfection in an intricate little plotless dance she calls, for no discernible reason, ''Uncle Edgar Dyed His Hair Red.'' In ''Short Stories,'' another premiere, she does more powerfully what she attempts on an elaborate theatrical scale in''The Catherine Wheel.'' And for dessert, she has come up with a bland new version of ''Deuce Coupe'' that is bound to leave unhappy those who remember the 1973 original, but which takes on a strange life of its own.

title: RELIGIOUS REVIVAL IS GRIPPING CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: Despite curbs on church activists, a religious revival is under way in Czechoslovakia. Even Dr. Karel Hruza, head of the Government's Secretariat for Religious Affairs, says that there is a back-to-church trend among young people.

title: A MAYOR ACCUSES D.E.P. OF IGNORING ILLEGAL DUMPING
description: FLORENCE TOWNSHIP THE Mayor of this Burlington County community has accused the state's Department of Environmental Protection of ignoring evidence that the Hooker Chemical Company of Burlington Township had illegally dumped hazardous wastes at a landfill here with the permission of the landfill's owners.

title: Television Week; Randall Returns
description: ''Sidney Shorr,'' a television movie starring Tony Randall as a middle-aged N ew York homosexual who shares his apartment with a young actress (Lorn a Patterson) and her daughter, will have its premiere on NBC Monday night from 9 to 11. As the pilot for a forthcom ing series,''Love, Sidney,'' which will also star Mr. Randall and is scheduled to begin on Oct. 28, the program represents something of a first for television: the beginning of a series in which the central character is a homosexual.

title: 'Peculiar' Irony
description: To the Editor:

title: Antiques; RARE COLT FIREARMS AT AUCTION
description: AN auction of rare and historic firearms, many with a Co nnecticut history, will be held Wednesday at 2 P.M. at Christie's Ga lleries, 502 Park Avenue, New York City. Included will be numerous early Colt firearms made at the famous Hartford factory. Other lots w ill includelithographs of hunting scenes commissioned by Col. Samuel Colt, powder horns, officers' swords, Revolutionary War and early-19thcentury flintlock pistols, a 1790 blunderbuss an d early Kentucky rifles.

title: The Region in Summary; New Court Case For Willowbrook
description: As a heartbreaking combination of human need and legal complexity, few cases can match the lengthy struggle to reform conditions for the mentally retarded at Willowbrook, on Staten Island. Last week, lawyers for New York State and two public interest groups representing residents of Willowbrook drafted a settlement which outlined new ways to achieve improvements first sought in 1972 and ordered by a Federal judge in 1975.

title: COURT TO RULE ON USE OF CASINO FUND INTEREST
description: A state appeals court will decide whether the Byrne administration may use interest from the casino revenue fund for general state expenditures.

title: MARINO SETS RECORD
description: Dan Marino threw six touchdown passes, a Pittsburgh single-game record, as he led the undefeated Panthers to a 42-28 victory over South Carolina today.

title: SCOUTING FOR RECESSION-PROOF STOCKS
description: I T'S no secret that the stock market likes to anticipate events by a matter of months. Prices have been plummeting since mid-1981. So what is the basic message of the market?

title: INDUSTRY BACKS REAGAN EDICTS
description: WASHINGTON SOME of New Jersey's largest corporations are feeling the pinch of inflation and high interest rates. Even so, they strongly support President Reagan's tax and budget policies, maintaining that they will help to revitalize the economy.

title: BUDGET CUTS PERIL CONSUMER AGENCY
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission, which is making the deepest budget cuts of any Federal regulatory agency, has shed so many of its programs, dismissed so many of its employees and closed so many of its offices that even some business quarters are concerned about its viability.

title: THE STUFF OF MARVELS
description: GEMINI By Michel Tournier. Translated by Anne Carter. 452 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95.

title: YIELDING TO U.S., THAIS TARGET OPIUM FIELDS
description: Under pressure from the United States, Thailand is planning the first major destruction of opium poppy fields cultivated by hill tribesmen in the Thai section of the socalled Golden Triangle, according to Thai and Western officials.

title: E. Erica Malarek Is Wed
description: The marriage of E. Erica Malarek, research coordinator for Robert Gersin Associates, design consultants in New York, to Dr. Charles Michael Miller, a senior resident in surgery at Mount Sinai Hospital, took place at the Tower Suite yesterday. William Lawton, leader of the Westchester Ethical Humanist Society, performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Michael Malarek of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and Cecile Miller of New York and the late Dr. Alvin Miller of Seattle.

title: FARM BOND ISSUE SEEN AS SYMBOL OF COMMITMENT
description: CONCERNED over the continuing loss of about 7,000 acres of farmland a year, agricultural and legislative leaders have taken a number of steps to preserve the state's remaining farmland and open spaces.

title: YALE HANDS NAVY A 23-19 LOSS
description: Faced with both an early deficit and a Navy defense that slowed its best player, Yale rallied to defeat the Middies, 23-19, today for its most significant victory outside the Ivy League since the league was formalized 25 years ago.

title: Mailbox; Sorry Sound Of Success
description: To the Sports Editor: In the article describing the Giants' victory over the Saints (The New York Times, Sept. 21), Coach Ray Perkins was quoted as saying: ''That may have been the all-time hit. I almost went on the field and picked up Curtis McGriff myself.

title: ANDOVER STOPS WORCESTER
description: Time ran out on Worcester Academy yesterday, and the result was a 29-24 defeat by Andover that snapped Worcester's 10-game winning streak. The home team was undefeated in nine contests in 1981 and won its opener last week.

title: LANDLORDS TO FIX 1,900 VIOLATIONS IN BROOKLYN
description: The owners of several Brooklyn-based real-estate companies under investigation by state and city officials have pledged to correct 1,900 housing code violations in 34 buildings they own or manage.

title: Yachting's New Wave: No Handicaps
description: As yacht racing shifts into the fall season, the signs and portents evidenced during the summer signify changes on the horizon, not only in the nature of the game but also in who can play it.

title: THE SAVING OF THE DALLAS SYMPHONY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- John Ardoin is music critic of The Dallas Morning News. By JOHN ARDOIN

title: Prince of Wales Conference; Patrick Division
description: Islanders - The team to beat. The No. 1 favorite in nearly everyone's book, with a near-perfect blend of explosive scoring, maneuverable defense, superior goaltending, clever playmaking, rugged checkers, experience and youth. Not to mention excellent coaching by Al Arbour and fine depth. Gone are Bob Lorimer, a defenseman, who was traded to Colorado, and Garry Howatt, a left wing, to Hartford. A last-minute situation that was resolved was the signing of Bob Bourne, an all-star left wing last season. Among the few new faces with a chance to make the team were two Swedes, Tomas Jonsson on defense and Mats Hallin at left wing, as well as two others of junior age, Brent Sutter at center and Monty Trottier at right wing.

title: CECILE LICAD--FIRST WINNER OF THE 'NEW' LEVENTRITT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Glenn Plaskin is the author of the forthcoming biography of Vladimir Horowitz to be published by William Morrow. By GLENN PLASKIN

title: Agency Expects to Kill 'Orphan' Wild Horses
description: The Federal Government's fees for adopting wild horses have been increased, and that probably means a death sentence for some of the West's free-roaming mustangs, the Bureau of Land Management says.

title: Susan Dunn Bride Of Richard Hill Jr.
description: At St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley, Mass., yesterday, Susan Louise Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Joseph Dunn of North Conway, N.H., was married to Richard Devereux Hill Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hill of Marblehead, Mass. Msgr. Russell Davis performed the ceremony.

title: Music View; IS THE RIGHT TO BOO LEGITIMATE?
description: The opera season is never officially open until the first booing incident has been recorded at the Metropolitan. This year the season arrived especially early, at the opening-night ''Norma,'' when Renata Scotto was given an ill-mannered vote of no-confidence by an impatient few of her detractors even before she had opened her mouth for the recitative leading into the fierce test that is ''Casta diva.'' As it happens, Norma's first words were apt enough: ''Sediziose voci!'' (''Traitorous voices!''). But they did not put down the jeering, which went on intermittently in one form or another all evening. The final curtain apparently developed into a noisy competition between those who had come prepared to boo and less contentious first-nighters who either liked what they had heard from the Italian soprano and the conductor, James Levine, or simply felt that famous artists should not have to hear unpleasant sounds on such an occasion. In fact, Miss Scotto did not measure up in any way to this most dem anding of bel canto roles, but that is not the point here. The iss ue is to what extent booing or otherwise disturbing an opera perform ance can be condoned.

title: Fashion; A SPIRITED SPRING IN MILAN; by Mary Russell
description: The story from Milan for spring 1982 is told in shades of pimento red, sunflower yellow, emerald green, turquoise, hot pink and a spectrum of purples. These colors are often mixed with darker shades, combined in flower or Dec o prints, in stripes or insertions. They areso vibrant an d so boldly mixed that they virtually dictate the shape of the clothe s. And in this season, that means separates, pieces to mix and switc h at whim, a break away from the ''total-look'' concept that dominate d previous seasons.

title: The World in Summary; Troubles Pile Up For Bonn Leader
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's troubles these days seem not to come singly but in pairs: Economic recession coupled with the highest unemployment in 29 years, and dangerous dissension within his own party stemming from the West German leader's commitment to new medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe. Largely as a result of these twin troubles the Chancellor's Social Democratic Party took another drubbing in West German local elections last week.

title: Politics; AN ISSUE EMERGES: THE BYRNE ARENA
description: TRENTON THE Brendan T. Byrne Arena is on the minds and lips of a large number of people these days, and the controversy surrounding the naming of the Meadowlands sports emporium is threatening to become a cutting issue in the gubernatorial campaign.

title: Around the World; Car Bomb Is Defused In West Beirut Street
description: A 110-pound car bomb was defused today minutes before it was set to explode in a crowded Palestinian quarter in West Beirut, the leftist Arab Lebanon radio said.

title: Business Conditions; APPLE CROP CUT BY BAD WEATHER
description: After three consecutive years of record harvests, poor weather has cut the size of this year's apple crop, which is now being harvested. The dropoff, which could be as much as 15 percent from year-earlier levels, is putting upward pressure on prices.

title: SEEKING TRANSIT PRODUCTIVITY AMID THE 'SMOKE AND MIRRORS'
description: To improve the efficiency and productivity of an organization, managment experts say again and again, get everyone pulling together in a spirit of enthusiasm and cooperation.

title: REVIVING 'BAIL REFORM': A PROTECTION OR PERIL?
description: ''Bail reform'' used to be a rallying cry of liberals, who moved successfully to let more criminal defendants out of jail so that they would not be punished until their guilt or innocence had been determined by a jury.

title: The World in Summary; No Respite For Beirut
description: Despite a shaky cease-fire in southern Lebanon between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, which brought a halt to deadly air and rocket attacks, Beirut remains a 24-hour battleground, torn by factions (including some within the P.L.O. itself) which have brought bombings of another kind. Last week, a car packed with more than 100 pounds of explosives blew up in a narrow, crowded street of Moslem West Beirut, tearing through buildings and cars on either side and leaving more than 90 persons dead and more than 300 wounded.

title: BEYOND DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Clarkstown North Victorious
description: Clarkstown North, unbeaten so far in Rockland County P.S.A.L. games, defeated Nyack, 13-0. Ed Ruppert passed 14 yards to Mike Ingram, a halfback, to open the scoring.

title: HOW 42 ACTORS AND 2 DIRECTORS ASSEMBLED 'NICHOLAS NICKLEBY'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Benedict Nightingale writes about theater for The New Statesman. By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE LONDON It all ended with the most un-English scenes: cheers, tears, flowers piled up to the cast's knees, banners unfurled in the dress circle reading ''We love you, we'll miss you.'' ''Nicholas Nickleby,'' the Royal Shakespeare Company's greatest success since the Peter Brook staging of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' had completed its third and final season in London; and its ex-officio fan club, some of whom had sat through its eight and a half hours three, five, even ten times, were not going to let it leave for New York without showing their feelings. The wilder groupies, it's said, were even vow ing to attend the Broadway opening - today at the Plymouth - un deterred by plane fares and $100 seats. Anything for oldNick.

title: PUBLIC AUTHORITY SHOULD FINANCE UTILITY CAPITAL
description: WE HEAR much these days about the cost of oil and its impact on our electric bills. We should. The cost of oil hurts. But there is another big contributor to the high cost of energy that we hardly ever hear about. That is the cost of capital, the dollars that a utility pays to its owners and creditors for the use of their money. In the case of Public Service Electric and Gas, the cost of capital will rise to nearly $1 billion a year, or $1 of every $3 in our monthly utility bill, if the company receives a rate increase it has requested. The cost of money is skyrocketing. The charge for borrowed money has risen fro m 10 percent in 1979 to 13 percent in 1980 and 16 percent this year. The profits demanded by shareholders are, at leastaccording to P.S.E.& G., also sharply higher, being up 25 percent from what the state's Board of Public Utilities found to be the case only 14 month s ago.

title: Headliners
description: I SPY The army may have been the only family Joseph G. Helmich Jr. had ever known, as the 44-year-old former warrant officer has attested, but it apparently inspired little in the way of filial devotion. Last week Mr. Helmich pleased guilty to peddling military secrets to the Soviet Union over a period of 17 years, beginning in 1963, when he "got into some financial problems" and passed some bad checks.

title: The Region in Summary; Voters Have a Lot To Learn About N.J. Campaign
description: If ignorance is bliss, the New Jersey electorate evidently is ecstatic about the state's upcoming gubernato rial election. A poll bythe Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University last week reported that only half the registered voters could name the two major candidates and only a quarter of them f elt they would be able to cast an informed vote.

title: PASSERS-BY AND PUMPKINS ON W. 87TH
description: It wasn't the biggest celebration ever held in the city, or the warmest, but the West 87th Street One Hundred Block Association liked its annual pumpkin street fair just fine yesterday.

title: HIGH PRICES MAKE $100 BILLS COMMON CURRENCY
description: Inflation is reaching so deep into the American pocket that it has begun pulling $100 bills out of overalls as well as from silver money clips.

title: Behind the Best Sellers
description: Unlike some of the other books predicting economic doom that have achieved best sellerdom during the past year or two - ''The Coming Currency Collapse,'' for example, or ''The Alpha Strategy: Financial Survival in an Economically Unstable World'' - Paul Erdman's ''The Last Days of America'' is unabashed fiction. Set in an inflationravaged 1985, at a time when West Germany is trying to acquire the technology to produce missiles, it's a story of trans-oceanic bribery involving industrialists, financiers and politicians, and its hero is American spaceman Frank Rogers, who is seeking to discover why his company lost a lucrative NATO contract.

title: Art View; MOMA PRESENTS A NEGLECTED ABSTRACTIONIST; by Hilton Kramer
description: In the history of the European avant-garde in the years 1910-20, the decade in which abstract art first emerged to challenge so many traditional beliefs about art and its meaning, one of the names that tends to get lost is that of the Swiss artist Sophie Taeuber-Arp (1889-1943). By all accounts, she was a remarkable figure, much beloved by her contemporaries and recognized by them as having achieved something very distinctive in her work. Yet the exhibition that Carolyn Lanchner has now organized at the Museum of Modern Art (t hrough Nov. 29) is the first retrospective to be devoted to her artin this count ry. In addition to giving us our first coherent view of Miss Taeuber- Arp's oeuvre, it is a show that casts an interesting light both on the early history of abstraction and on its subsequent development i n Paris in the 20's and 30's.

title: WEINBERGER'S SPECTER
description: Remember the days when Soviet submarines were suddenly seen lurking off our coasts just as the naval appropriation bills were coming before Congress? Well, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has found a 1981 equivalent. With his department's budget under increasing scrutiny by members of Congress, Mr. Weinberger has again raised the specter of a Soviet move to grab Persian Gulf oil.

title: Sallie Fraenkel Becomes a Bride
description: Sallie Fraenkel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Levy Fraenkel of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael Zuch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Zuch of Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Robert A. Rothman performed the ceremony in the Community Synagogue.

title: BITING 'ENTERTAINER'
description: MADISON THE recent marriage of Prince Charles may have given England's sagging spirits a temporary lift, but one doubts if John Osborne was comforted by the royal wedding.

title: MUSICAL: MILLER'S 'UP FROM PARADISE'
description: ''What could have possessed me to create Lucifer?'' is the way God puts the Q uestion in Arthur Miller's ''Up fro m Paradise.'' It's a question that still has no answer at the end of that musical concert version of Mr. Miller's play ''The Creation o f the World and Other Business.''

title: Other Business; RUBIK'S CUBE: IDEAL TOY TAKES ON THE KNOCK-OFFS; by Mark Roman
description: The obfuscating little puzzle, Rubik's Cube, is sold by the Ideal Toy Corporation - and only the Ideal Toy Corporation. That's what Ideal says, anyway. Spokesmen for the company are worried that amid the influx of myriad duplicates, people will forget that.

title: WORKING LIKE A STAND-UP COMIC
description: SIXTY STORIES By Donald Bar thelme. 457 pp. New Y ork: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95.

title: Patricia Ann Devlin Wed
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn Harbor, L.I., yesterday, Patricia Ann Devlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Devlin of East Hills, L.I., became the bride of Nicola A. Zanghi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Zanghi of Glen Head, L.I. The Rev. Laurence Costello performed the ceremony.

title: Excavations in Saudi Arabia
description: Robert Reinhold is to be commended for chronicling the hard work of Saudi Arabian specialists as they struggle to understand and protect their antiquities. Please allow me to clarify a statement attributed to me in words which seem sweepingly to condemn as prejudiced the attitude of all my colleagues in the United States: Some Western archeologists eager to resume the traditional practice of individual major excavations have indeed felt frustrated by the insistence of overseas officials on a coordinated national policy (of regional surveys, with selective small-scale probes, in order to determine priorities and map out coherent long-range plans).

title: THE WARS AT HOME
description: WASHINGTON DESPATCHES, 1941-1945 Weekly Political Reports from the British Embassy. Edited by H.G. Nicholas. Introduction by Isaiah Berlin. 700 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $40.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Defeat on Awacs would be a serious embarrassment to Reagan, both at home and abroad. Israel's friends should not be under any illusion that they help Israel's cause by embarrassing and undermining the authority of their indispensable friend in the White House.'' - Former President Richard M. Nixon (1:5.)

title: CLERGYMAN TAKES HUGE LED IN IRAN'S PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION
description: Although official results are not expected until next week, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei has taken an overwhelming lead over three other candidates as the votes are being counted from Iran's presidential election, the Teheran Radio said tonight.

title: R.L. Doran Weds Carolyn Cranis
description: The marriage of Carolyn Cranis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David O'D. Kennedy of Centre Island, Oyster Bay, L.I., to R. Lawrence Doran, son of Mrs. Robert F. Doran of Old Brookville, L.I., and the late Mr. Doran, took place yesterday.

title: HOW THE NEW JERSEY SYMPHONY ENDED ITS LONG SILENCE
description: NEWARK SOME call it a rebirth; others, a period of transition. However it is characterized, the New Jersey Symphony is back after more than a year of silence and now plans to open its 1981-82 season at Symphony Hall here on Nov. 1.

title: The Careful Shopper; Additional Discounts At Childrenswear
description: The expansion of Childrenswear House will be celebrated all this week at both the Eastchester Mall outlet, which was established two years ago, and at the new Loehmann's Plaza store in White Plains, which opened yesterday.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: STOVE BY A WHALE Owen Chase and the Essex. By Thomas Farel Heffernan. Illustrated. 273 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. $19.95.

title: Gardening; FOR GALAXY OF SPRING BULBS, PLANT NOW
description: FLOWERING bulbs, next to the robin, are the most widely recognized harbinger of spring. After struggling all winter with frigid temperatures, icy roads and endless snowdrifts, it is reassuring to one's spirit to catch a glimpse of the first promise of spring in the form of a golden-yellow eranthus emerging from a waning late-winter snowdrift.

title: PAUL SCULLY
description: Paul Scully, suburban single-copy sales manager for The New York Times, died of a heart attack Friday en route to Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 64 years old and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

title: About Long Island
description: IF some Horrible Crime occurred in this house, it would not take Sherlock Holmes, Dr. Watson or even Inspector Lestrade long to figure out who had been living here or to conclude that this was one case in which there was no need to cherchez la femme. Just the opposite, my dear fellow. There is no femme to cherchez!

title: A Bigger Triad But Without MX Mobility
description: President Reagan last week unveiled a $180.3 billion program for getting more mega-bang for the buck -and for showing Moscow that Washington isn't to be trifled with. ''It is my hope this plan will prevent our adversaries from making the mistake others have made and deeply regretted in the past,'' he said.

title: C.I.A. Plans a New Building
description: The Central Intelligence Agency wants to double the size of its headquarters by adding a $100 million, sevenstory building to its 18-year-old complex in McLean, Va. James McDonald, a logistics officer for the agency, went before the National Capital Planning Commission Thursday to explain the project, which would house about 3,000 C.I.A. employees.

title: Paperback Talk; by Ray Walters
description: Calendars '82. The leave s may have just beg un to turn where you live, but many of the residents of Publishers Row dearly hope you'll realize that the new year is only 90 days awa y, and soon stop in at a bookstore to buy the calendars and diaries they've created to help you find your way through 1982. Some 125 publ ishers have 575 of them ready, designed to appeal to every taste - fr om admirers of Judy Blume to those of Virginia Woolf, from youngs ters anxious to learn one new $10 word each day to oldsters hoping to stir fond memories with ''Winnie-the-Pooh.'' The calendars that we're told are likely tohave the largest sales are tied to currently popular fancies:

title: Art; ORIGINALITY AND FRESHNESS IN ALDRICH SHOW
description: RIDGEFIELD AN exhibition of new paintings and sculptures at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art here tends to suggest that the whole, contrary to Euclid, may occasionally be more than the sum of its parts. By that I mean that over all the show is interesting and provocative, but when one looks seriously at the individual works, disappointment often ensues.

title: The Nation in Summary; Autopsy on the Greensboro Case
description: Two years ago, five members of the Communist Workers Party were gunned down in a street demonstration in Greensboro, N.C.
