Last week, a private civil rights group said that the killings had taken place and that the accused gunmen - members of the American Nazi Party and the Ku Klux Klan - subsequently were acquitted because local law officers and prosecutors had an ''intimate alliance.''

title: ONE-ACT PLAYS: TWO BY MISS BARLOW
description: Note to playwright: when adulterous lovers meet for a picnic in a lonely, isolated part of a forest, and a crowbar happens to be on the blanket along with plastic glasses and a can of smoked oysters, there is no doubt that only one of the pair will be alive at the end of the play.

title: The Poet Himself
description: W.H.AUDEN A Biography By Humphrey Carpenter. Illustrated. 495 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $15.95.

title: THROUGH NEW ZEALAND'S RUGGED LAND OF FJORDS
description: R. V. DENENBERG is a frequent contributor to the Travel Section. By R.V.DENENBERG

title: Charges Filed in Bus Death
description: The driver of a tank truck that collided with a school bus, killing the bus driver and injuring the 52 kindergarten and elementary pupils aboard, has been charged with homicide. Leroy Warner, 27 years old, of Saylorsburg, Pa., was charged with homicide by motor vehicle, reckless driving, running a red light and speeding. He was released on $10,000 bail.

title: 7 FINGERS REATTACHED BY SURGICAL TEAM OF 44
description: Seven fingers severed from the hands of a 21-yearold man were successfully reattached in a two-day surgical procedure that involved 44 doctors, nurses and technicians, doctors at Massachusetts General Hospital said Thursday.

title: EX-CHAUFFEUR FOR JAPANESE PREMIERS RECALLS WAR AND INTRIGUE
description: An 80-year-old retired chauffeur, who can usually be found in his garden in a Tokyo suburb, has become a celebrity through a recent television program, and his memoirs are due to be published soon.

title: AFTER 15 YEARS AFFIRMATIVE ACTION DEBATE STILL HEATED
description: AS President Reagan's war on Federal regulations intensifies, rulesgoverning min ority hiring have become prime targets for revision. The President has proposed changes reducing obligations of contractors o n federally-funded projects to hire minority workers. The Administr ation is considering trying to reduce the minimum wage to stimulate hiring of black teenagers. Last week, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republ ican of Utah and chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Com mittee, continued to hold oversight hearings on the Equal Employm ent Opportunity Commission. Senator Hatch and William T.Coleman, a pr ominent black Republican lawyer, a former Secretary of Transportatio n and current chairman of the Legal Defense Fund of the National Asso ciation for the Advancement of Colored People, were asked to disc uss these issues with reporters Robert Pear and Seth S. King of The N ew York Times. Excerpts follow. *

title: U.N. DEFICIT CASTS SHADOW ON PALESTINIAN SCHOOLS
description: Occupied West Bank, Sept. 28 -The classrooms are in a building that was scheduled for demolition. They are dimly lit. Some have no windows. Jammed into the rows of hard, scarred wooden desks and benches are 40 to 50 girls per class. They wear neat school uniforms and ribbons in their hair. This is education in a Palestinian refugee camp. Most schools are on double session, some on triple. The teachers, with huge classes, have no time to give individual attention to those who lag behind. There are not enough books. The rooms are barren, devoid of the murals and bulletin boards of childhood.

title: Connecticut Housing; FIREWOOD SALES BRING COMPLAINTS
description: FINDING a good, safe buy on wood for fuel, it appears, is not as easy as it once was. An increase in the numbe r of households that have installed wood-burning stoves to cut the cost of home heating has crowded what had once been a relatively l ight firewood market. And with the increase in demand have come a w ide range in price - in Connecticut this year the cost of a cord has ranged from $65 to $150 - and an increase in the number of consumers complaining that they have been shortchanged by unscrupulous suppli ers.

title: Aruba Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Base Defends Shooting Of Goats for Training
description: Live goats are being shot and used as surgical patients in Green Beret medical training, according to officials at Fort Bragg.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: minded, but it allows Michael Crichton to present a bounty of interesting ideas.

title: VIGILS HAIL 800TH BIRTHDAY OF PATRON SAINT OF PEACE
description: In the peaceful, modest sanctuary of St. James' Roman Catholic Cathedral in Brooklyn, nuns, priests and laymen Friday night paid homage to St. Francis of Assisi, whose gentle, guileless nature reflected a picture of a world in loving harmony.

title: New Jersey Housing; IS SMOKE-DETECTOR LAW WORKING?
description: ''SO MANY buildings are time bombs that it would take your breath away if you walked through them,'' said Dennis Fulton, owner of the Northern State Alarm Company in Bergenfield. ''The law was definitely overdue.''

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL MILITARY PROGRAM
description: President Reagan's proposal to build 100 B-1 bombers and place 100 MX land-based missiles in existing silos was assailed by Senate Democrats today as ''political'' and a ''nondecision.''

title: Editor's Choice
description: seven by the Irish master. THE GEOGRAPHY OF THE IMAGINATION. By Guy Davenport.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: FLEXIBLE BUSES WIN PRAISE IN NASSAU
description: ALTHOUGH New York City has twice withdrawn its new Grumman-built buses from service, Nassau County's new Grumman fleet, despite some problems described as minor, is winning praise from bus drivers and riders.

title: Cathy Card, Sc ott Sterling Are Married
description: Cathy Lee Card, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Annon Melton Card of Houston, formerly of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Scott Evans Sterling, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Sterling of Pelham Manor. The Rev. Donald R. Kocher and the Rev. Steven Sibson performed the ceremony at the Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church in Pelham Manor.

title: Sunday ObserverBy Russell Baker; Ringing Up the Past Patrick McDonnell
description: The more ad vanced technology becomes, the more it baffles me. Take the telephone company's latest electronic miracle, which I recently had installed in a moment of weakness.

title: TAKEOVER BID UNDERSCORES DEFENSE ROLE IN L.I. ECONOMY
description: THE headlines of the last 10 days have underlined the importance of the defense industry in Long Island's economy and raised questions about the future of the smaller companies that deal with the Island's military contractors.

title: A Sportsman's Reading List
description: CONTRARY to a notion held by some, hunters and fishermen are not all insensitive, inarticulate, beer-drinking clods who revel in the sight of blood and who confine their reading to books and articles that only tell them how to catch or kill more.

title: St. John Baptist Prevails
description: St. John the Baptist of West Islip, L.I., the defending Catholic High Schools Football League champion, rebounded from its stunning 1-point loss to St. Francis Prep last Sunday with a 26-12 victory over St. Anthony's of Smithtown, L.I., yesterday at West Islip. St. John took the lead for good in the third period on a 45-yard pass from Joe Gagliardi to Tom Corcoran.

title: Philadelphia Lawyer Receives 6 Years on Abscam Conviction
description: A Federal judge yesterday sentenced Howard L. Criden, convicted in the Government's Abscam investigation, to six years in prison and a $40,000 fine.

title: THE JOB IS TO POUR OUT YOUR HEARY
description: From time to time The Book Review invites both new and established writers to comment on their craft. These essays are intended to provide an opportunity for writers to explain themselves to their readers.

title: SHIFT IS PREDICTED FOR KEY RESEARCH
description: Northeastern states, including New York, must increase support of scientific facilities and personnel at their colleges and universities or ''there will almost certainly be a further shift of key research from the campus to the corporate research center,'' according to Michael I. Sovern, Columbia University's president.

title: Toby Knight Starts a Long Road Back to Knicks
description: There was a look of satisfaction on Toby Knight's face today as Mike Saunders, the Knick trainer, placed a knee wrap round his left knee that fastened two ice bags to it. Knight, a 6-foot-8-inch forward, had just completed his longest and most strenuous workout at the opening day of the Knicks' training camp at Monmouth College.

title: WALESA ASSERTS SOLIDARITY FACES A 'HARD PERIOD'
description: A combative Lech Walesa, newly re-elected as chairman of Solidarity, said today that the union faced ''a very hard period'' over the coming months, and he warned the authorities not to exploit apparent weaknesses within Solidarity.

title: WITH FALL'S FUEL BOUNTY THE FORECAST IS 'PLEASANT'
description: Nietzsche once characterized winter as a ''bad guest.'' Since the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries turned the world upside down in 1973, few Americans would disagree. Autumn winds sharpen energy worries. And why not? Last year, in the throes of the coldest winter in a century, Boston had a severe natural gas shortage, recalling the gas shortages of the 1970's, as well as oil embargoes, coal strikes and enormous price increases for all forms of energy.

title: ASBURY PARK IS VICTOR
description: Dan Moore sprinted 70 yards for a touchdown, and Kent Taylor kicked the extra point that started Asbury Park on a 20-6 victory over Manasquan yesterday in Manasquan.

title: Television Week; More 'Hillbillies'
description: Paul Henning created and produced ''The Beverly Hillbillies,'' which ran on CBS from September 1962 through September 1971. Watched by up to 60 million viewers weekly during its first two seasons, it ranked as the number-one program on television.

title: About Westchester
description: "It's unusual," Bert Kent was saying, "to see people dancing right away. Normally coctail time is slow, but this went off like a bang."

title: New York Times Magazine October 4, 1981
description: William Safire 10 On Language Winged Words Russell Baker 17 Sunday Observer Ringing Up the Past Lee A. Daniels 20 The New Black Conservatives Richard J. Meislin 24 The Careys of Albany Jo Thomas 34 Cuba's School for Exporting Marxism Since 1977, some 26,000 children from Cuba, Africa and Central America have been brought to a Cuban island for a controversial work-and-study program that is a mixture of general education and Marxist indoctrination. William F. Buckley Jr. 38 God and Boys at Millbrook Mary Russell 82 Fashion Preview A Spirited Spring in Milan Craig Claiborne 88 Food with Pierre Franey Salt-Free Splendors Stephen Singular 94 Master Diarist Max Frisch 108 Puzzles Answers, Page 92 110 Letters Cover:Photograph by Neil Selkirk Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: Dr. Loewinger Is Bride Of Howard W. Gutman
description: Dr. Michelle Phyllis Loewinger and Howard William Gutman were married yesterday at the Great Neck (L.I.) Jewish Center by Rabbi E. Yechiel Simon.

title: CAN MRS. KAISER, THE 'NEWCOMER,' UNSEAT VERGARI, THE 'INSTITUTION'?
description: CAN Barbara L. Kaiser, the Democratic candidate for District Attorney of Westchester County, unseat Carl A. Vergari, the Republican-Conservative who has held the job since 1968 and is seeking a fifth term?

title: Children's Books
description: MOTHER CROCODILE ''Maman-Caiman'' By Birago Diop. Translated and Adapted By Rosa Guy. Illustrated by John Steptoe.Unpaged. New York: Delacorte Press. $10.95. (Ages 4 to 7) By MARGUERITE FEITLOWITZ

title: Gail L. Manyan, W. A. Henry 3d, Editor, Married
description: Gail Louisa Manyan, a writer, was married yesterday to William A. Henry 3d, an associate editor of Time magazine. New Hampshire State Representative Eugene S. Daniell Jr., who is a also Justice of the Peace, performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. V. George Manyan, mother of the bride, in Salisbury, N.H.

title: No Headline
description: Taking the Train; To the Editor:

title: Topics; SENDING A MESSAGE; Information Again
description: Rebirths are as rare in bureaucracy as in cemeteries; a nominal but welcome one is imminent in Washington. In 1978, the Carter Administration finally succeeded in doing something about the overlapping activities of the United States Information Agency and the Cultural Affairs Bureau of the State Department: it combined the agencies.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Judith Nicosia, Soprano, Sings a Brahms Series
description: In a week marked by soprano debuts, Judith Nicosia's at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday evening left by far the most lasting impression. Miss Nicosia probably invested more concentration, intelligence and sensitivity into her two hours of singing than one ordinarily experiences in a week's concertgoing.

title: CUBA'S SCHOOL FOR EXPORTING MARXISM
description: For reasons best known to themselves, the Cuban revolutionaries who took over the Colony Hotel in 1959 did not disturb the mural on the wall of the lobby that had welcomed American gamblers to the island hideaway. The painting shows Long John Silver watching his fellow pirates bury treasure while cabin boy Jim Hawkins looks on. Scholars disagree over whether the island where the hotel stands is the ''Treasure Island'' immortalized by Robert Louis Stevenson, but during the 16th and 17th centuries this piranha-shaped island 30 miles off the southwest coast of Cuba was the hiding place for Sir Francis Drake, Henry Morgan, Calico Jack Rackham and other pirates of the Spanish Main. Since then, it has been a penal colony, a haven for American expatriates during the early 1900's and a tourist resort. It has had many names; Christopher Columbus christened it Evangelista, and it was subsequently known as Santiago, Reina Amalia and the Isle of Pines. Three years ago, Fidel Castro renamed it Isla de la Juventu d, the Isle of Youth.

title: HANDING OVER THE REINS
description: It is all too common a scenario. Sam and Harry are partners in a small but thriving business in New York's garment center. Then Sam dies of a heart attack at the age of 46, leaving all his stock in the company to his wife, Marion.

title: A HARVEST OF ENTERTAINMENT IS AT HAND FOR THE SEASON
description: THE days when autumn in Westchester was merely a time for admiring the foliage seem to have passed, now that growing numbers of actors, musicians, artists and lecturers are reversing the travel pattern by commuting from the city to entertain or inform in the lucrative and culture-oriented suburbs.

title: PENN IS DEFEATED BY COLUMBIA, 20-9
description: Columb ia de feated Pennsylvania, 20-9, yesterday at Baker field, andthe Lions did so with dispatch and style. The victory ended a 10-gamelosing streak and gave the Lions their first Ivy League triumph after13 losses, th e last league victory coming over Penn two years ago.

title: Sports of the Times; THE EXPO'S TORCH
description: HE'S 54 years old now and he's never been married. But no, say people close to Jim Fanning, he really is married. ''He's married,'' one friend says, ''to baseball.'' Now that the Montreal Expos have clinched the second half championship in the National League East, his marriage is glowing more than ever. After two decades of desk work and tank-town travel in player development and scouting, silver-haired Jim Fanning is right there in the dugout where everybody can see him as the Expos manager, the surprise successor to Dick Williams, who was suddenly dismissed on Sept. 8 with the Expos only one and a half games out of first place.

title: TIGHT SECURITY IS SET FOR TRIAL OF SUSPECT IN SLAYING OF BLACKS
description: When Pvt. Joseph Christopher goes on trial next week in the slaying of three black males, he will be screened from public view while traveling between the courthouse and jail.

title: NEW QUARTERLY ON BIRD STUDY
description: ''HERONS were down. The American bittern was more common. There were seven Cooper's hawks compared to four last year.'' Those are records of birds seen in Connecticut last year in the 80th annual Christmas bird count as reported in a new bulletin ''The Connecticut Warbler.''

title: by Leo H. Carney
description: The complai nt by Mayor Sharon Worrell of Florence Township that thestate's Depar tment of Environmental Protection was lax in providing her with test results on hazardous chemicals dumped in that community app arently is not an uncommon one.

title: COLUMBIA STUDENT IS ARRESTED IN $2 MILLION RARE BOOK THEFT
description: A cache of antique books stolen in London was recovered and a Columbia University graduate student was arrested by customs agents who enlisted a New York rare-book seller for an undercover drama played out over lunch Friday at the Princeton Club.

title: Children's Books
description: SONG OF SEDNA By Robert D. San Souci. Illustrated by Daniel San Souci. Doubleday & Co. $8.95. (Ages 7 to 10) By CAROLE PAIKIN

title: Gregory Ferguson Still Marries Jean L. Sinica
description: Jean Lee Sinica, daughter of Mrs. John Sinica of Wellesley, Mass., and John Sinica of Valley Forge, Pa., was married yesterday to Gregory Ferguson Still, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Douglas Still of Cottage Grove, Ore. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: INSURERS PROMISE TO HELP JOBLESS
description: Leaders of more than 100 insurance companies have promised President Reagan that as a ''public responsibility'' they will direct a share of their resources nationwide toward grappling with unemployment, particularly among minority youths.

title: AT STRIKE'S END, NURSES GAIN, HOSPITAL SEES DEFICIT
description: A 69-day strike of registered nurses at the Berkshire Medical Center here has ended with a settlement that provides substantial salary and benefit increases and a challenge to the hospital to avert an operating deficit.

title: NEW YORK LIBERTIES UNION LAUDS LEGISLATURE
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union this year gave the State Legislature the highest rating it has ever accorded the body in the 11 years it has been issuing legislative ''score cards.''

title: CONRAIL MUST LEARN TO STAND ON ITS OWN
description: NEARLY everyone is familiar with some aspect of Conrail's economic horror story. Just ask any of the thousands of riders who recently were saddled with fare increases of as much as 79 percent or any one of New Jersey's taxpayers, who collectively pay more than $90 million a year to keep the state's trains and buses limping along.

title: Renaissance at Chaminade
description: George Toop, in his seventh season as head coach at Chaminade, has seen good times, such as 1977 and '78, when his team went undefeated in 18 games. He has also seen seasons of little success, such as the last two, when Chaminade won four of 16 games. But signs o f a revival are beginning to show as the Flyers are off to a 2-0 star t this season, including Friday night's 26-3 victory over St. Domi nic's. Ask Toop about the team's start, and he will say the standard things about being optimistic and playing one game at a time. But the re is no hiding the effectiveness of Chaminade in its two games so far in which the Flyers have outscored the opposition by46-19.

title: WESTPORT TRANSIT, ONCE A LEADER, TRYING TO KEEP UP
description: WESTPORT THE seven-year-old Westport Transit District, once in the vanguard of public transportation in the state, has recently suffered a series of financial and organizational setbacks, reduced ridership and increased fares.

title: New Zealand Premier I s Critical of Mugabe
description: Prime Minister Robert D. Muldoon of New Zealand assailed Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe today over criticism of New Zealand's sporting ties with South Africa.

title: LABOR PARTY FLIRTS WITH DEATH WISH
description: Alan Fisher, the acerbic, left-wing leader of the hospital workers' union, had a message last week for the 1,300 delegates to the 80th annual conference of the British Labor Party. It was delivered, as is Mr. Fisher's habit, in a roundabout way, concluding with the observation that he believed now more than ever in the maxim that he had learned 42 years ago as a trainee typist: ''Now is the time for all good men to come to the aid of the party.''

title: No Headline
description: Observations in Russia Having recently spent three months in the U.S.S.R. on an academic exchange, I find myself wrestling with many of the same questions raised in Mr. Austin's article. It seems to me that Mr. Austin has done an excellent job of identifying some of the basic problems of Russian life and has suggested ways of understanding this complex, often contradictory society.

title: Architecture View; AN INGENIOUS ADVANCE IN HOUSING DESIGN; by Ada Louise Huxtable
description: Conside r a building that has to be vandal-proof, constructed of maintenance-f ree materials, with every surface resistant to neglect and abuse, wh ere violation of design and function must be an anticipated f act, along with defacement and petty thievery - a place where surveil lance is a necessity and the population is transient. A description o f a maximum security prison? Not at all. This is a dormitory at Columbia University.

title: 50TH ANNIVERSARY FOR 4 VILLAGES
description: ROSLYN MONTHS of research and discussion have gone into the planning of a celebration of the 50th anniversary of four incorporated villages. A historical exhibition, which is to open on Saturday with a wine and chee se party from 3 to 5 P.M. at the Bryant L ibrary in Roslyn, will be on view all month.

title: PRESERVING TREASURED COLOR PRINTS AND SLIDES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Martin Hershenson is a freelance writer and photographic consultant. Color prints and slides start to fade from the moment the materials are processed, and in order to alert users to this photographic fact of life, film manufacturers have been printing an exculpatory statement on their packages for years explaining this possibility. However, there are some steps every photographer can and should take to preserve those once-in-a-lifetime events that he or she has photographed in color.

title: Prison Disturbance Quelled
description: Guards used tear gas and riot sticks yesterday to force 190 inmates to return to their cells in the second disturbance in two days at a Texas Department of Corrections unit near here. A spokesman said a guard and 15 inmates were hurt.

title: Business Conditions; SOVIET TRADE WEAKENS
description: A sharp cut in Western demand for Soviet oil, coupled with a rise in grain imports, weakened Moscow's trade position with industrialized countries during the first half of the year.

title: ALIENS' RIGHTS AND CURBS ON FEDERAL POWER AMONG CASES FACING HIGH COURT
description: With the ceremony of a new Justice's arrival behind it, the Supreme Court returns to business Monday to grapple with such issues as the rights of illegal aliens, the limits of Federal authority over the states, and the ability of ordinary citizens to sue high Government officials.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Phyllis Kirian, Soprano, In Demanding Program
description: Phyllis Kirian, a young soprano, gave a musically rich and professionally impractical program last Sunday evening at the Abraham Goodman House. The music was consistently interesting and ranged from Mozart and Messaien to Granados and Mahler.

title: Youth World Cup Growing
description: The Youth World Cup tournament, the counterpart to the World Cup for players 20 years of age and younger, started in Australia yesterday with 16 countries, including the United States, taking part in what is quickly becoming one of the two major international soccer events in the world.

title: Paul Evans Weds Gay Huey
description: Gay Jeanette Huey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Calvin Huey of Marienville, Pa., was married yesterday in the Drew United Methodist Church in Carmel, N.Y., to Paul David Evans, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul V. Evans of Indianapolis. The Rev. Albert Miller performed the ceremony. The bride, who will use her name professionally, is a vice president of the New York investment banking firm of Ehrlich-Bober & Company Inc., of which her husband is a senior vice president.

title: Dining Out; ELEGANCE IN ITALIAN-FRENCH CUISINE
description: LA PACE in Glen Cove offers one of the more elegantly beautiful settings for dining on the Island. A polished copper doorway opens into the bar area with dark green walls, bare floors and brick archways leading to the dining room. The bar is spacious enough to accommodate the crowds waiting for tables on weekends.

title: ...AND BACK TO THE SUBUR BS
description: We have arrived. That's what I concluded this-summer while sitting in the fourth row of the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York in Purchase. Lights were lowered. The fanfare heralding the second selection of the Joffery Ballet flooded the huge theater. The curtain rose to reveal a solitary dancer in black. All was silent. He clicked his castanets, then chatted them, then brought them to a clattering crescendo. And with his perfect body, he executed perfect pirouettes and leaps and jumps. And we were one; the audience, the dance at its impeccable best. Over and over, I just kept thinking, "Westchester, you've made it.We have arrived."

title: Jane Tracy I s Betrothed
description: The engagement of Jane Mackintosh Tracy to Andrew Ramsay Ahrens has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James J. Tracy Jr. of Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ahrens of Tucson, Ariz.

title: Black Heritage Trail
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region in Summary; Guess Who Steals Food Stamps?
description: Critics have long insisted that fraud and waste in New York City's food stamp program could be traced to liars, cheaters and thieves among the recipients. Federal officials said last week that stealing was indeed rampant, but they accused city employees, check-cashing companies and grocery wholesalers of scheming for years to turn millions of dollars a month in illegally issued food stamps into cash.

title: Around the World; Peking Presses Detente With the Taiwan Regime
description: Despite denunciations by the Chinese Nationalists in Taiwan, the Communist Government today pressed its proposal for detente, offering sanctuary to Nationalist planes and ships and urging air, sea and mail links.

title: Chemist Marsha Pilat Wed To Gary S. Davis
description: Marsha Dale Pilat, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Pilat of Dallas, was married yesterday to Gary Stuart Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Davis of Denver. Rabbi Allen Secher performed the ceremony at the Tavern-on -the-Green.

title: GOD AND BOYS AT MILLBRO OK
description: William F. Buckley Jr., editor of National Review, graduated from the Millbrook School in 1943. By William F. Buckley Jr.

title: Art; NAIVE ART IN MONTCLAIR
description: MONTCLAIR MUCH art is called naive these days, but it is by no means that. It is often produced by sophisticated painters who are simulating a naive style, disallowing their own refined palette for a simpler, down-home one.

title: Samuel Abate Jr., Lawyer, Weds Ann Marie Hammel
description: The marriage of Ann Marie Hammel, daughter of Mary Sutter Hammel of Rowayton, Conn., and John Elliott Hammel of Darien, Conn., to Samuel Joseph Abate Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Abate of Sloatsburg, N.Y., took place yesterd ay.

title: More on Lunch
description: To the Business Editor: Waiter! It's time to check the facts.

title: When Calling for Cab, The Right Booth Helps
description: When Richard Kiernan called for a taxi to take him to his home here early today, he placed the call from the wrong kind of booth, the Nassau County police said.

title: politics; CANDIDATES SEEK ADVANTAGE OF THEIR PASTS
description: HARTFORD IF the past is a plus in election campaigns, Barbara B. Kennelly and John T. Downey have a sizable advantage. Mrs. Kennelly and Mr. Downey, both Democrats, are running, or preparing to run, for separate Federal offices next year. While their pasts may not have much in common, they are not being neglected.

title: A RUN ALL THE WAY TO SELF PRIDE
description: IT all started for me when my friend Ben began to run. He's the son of a famous writer, and not an unsuccessful writer and editor himself, but he's a pretty insecure guy, and I always figured things were O.K. as long as I felt better than he did. But then he started running, and suddenly he was coming around to my desk at work and bragging, ''Well, I went eight miles yesterday - it felt pretty good.''

title: ASSEMBLY SPEAKER TRYING TO SAVE PLAIN-LANGUAGE ACT
description: WEST NEW YORK IN A move designed to stop sabotaging of the Plain Language Act by state agencies, the Assembly Speaker plans to introduce an amendment to the controversial measure. The act was signed into law recently by Governor Byrne.

title: UTILITY CLOSING EYE
description: THE Greenport Utility Company has struggled on a s a municipal utility since the invention of the incandescent lightbulb made it possible to p ut away the oil lamps in this sea coast village, which was one of th e first communities on the Island to be electrified.

title: Art; MUSEUM INCLUDES WORKS JUDGES REJECTED FOR SHOW
description: YONKERS SUCH is the star system in art that a juried exhibition tends to attract notic e in proportion to the fame of those who selected it. Intentionally or not, the Hudson River Museum has challenged this state of affa irs while acting as host to the annual show sponsored by the Hudson River Contemporary Artists, formerly the Yonkers Art Association, which continues through Oct. 18.

title: Kathleen Moriarty Is a Bride
description: The marriage of K athleen Hill Moriarty and Robert John Keefe, graduates of the University of Notre Dame Law School, took place at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the ceremony.

title: Business Forum; THOSE TAX CUTS COULD MISS THE TARGET
description: A DVOCATES of supply-side economics have argued that the tax cuts in the 1981 tax legislation are a crucial component of the Administration's plan to restore economic vitality and reduce infla tion.

title: Montclair Triumphs, Remains Unbeaten
description: Bob Vannoy ran for 122 yards and one touchdown yesterday as undefeated Montclair State defeated Ramapo, 20-0, in Mahwah, N.J. Montclair State, in winning four games this season, has allowed only 3 points. Its defense forced Ramapo (2-2) into seven turnovers, four fumbles and three interceptions.

title: Reading and Writing; GOOD SKATES
description: ''One afternoon Mr. Emerson and Mr. Thoreau went with (Hawthorne) down the river. Henry Thoreau is an experienced skater, and was figuring dithyrambic dances and Bacchic leaps on the ice - very remarkable, but very ugly, me thought. Next to him followed Mr. Hawthorne, wrapped in his cloak, moving like a self-impelled Greek statue, stately and grave. Mr. Emerson closed the line, evidently too weary to hold himself erect, pitching headforemost, half lying on the air.''

title: Frances Buchheit Wed to Neil Goodzeit
description: Frances Elizabeth Buchheit and Neil Evan Goodzeit were married yesterday at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. A. Orley Swartzentruber performed the ceremony.

title: More Fights as Rangers Win
description: Seven players were ejected tonight and 166 minutes in penalties were levied as the Islanders and Rangers continued to turn their rivalry into a contest of fists and sticks.

title: SURVEY SPURS EMERGENCY PLAN FOR COMMUTERS
description: WHAT would Connecticut commuters on the New Haven line do if they awoke one morning to find that the Cos Cob power plant had generated its last, or some other power failure had knocked out the trains?

title: OFF AND RUNNING IN A FATEFUL FISCAL YEAR
description: The fiscal year began Thursday with the kind of notice usually reserved for the start of the calendar year. Oct. 1 marked the beginning of a historic contraction of the Government's role and sent the nation into unknown economic territory. Among President Reagan's policies, a 5 percent reduction in personal income taxes went into effect, All Savers certificates to spur saving and aid banks went on sale and measures to curb social spending began.

title: CITY REPORTS 18% DECREASE IN FAMILY RELIEF ROLLS
description: A rapid decline in the number of children in each case and an ''aggressive'' enforcement of rules have combined to reduce New York City's welfare family rolls 18 percent from a peak of 894,289 individuals in September 1972 to the current 731,699, according to the city's Human Resources Administration.

title: A MUSICAL MIRRORS A STRUGGLE
description: LISA, a girl in a wheelchair, sings, ''Someday, I'm gonna dance with you.'' ''You don't have to,'' Scottie, her boyfriend, assures her. ''But I will,'' she answers with determination.

title: FANS STILL PREFER FOOTBALL
description: Football 48, Baseball 31. Those are the percentages of the American public preferring to watch one sport or the other, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken as the pennant races wound to an end and the football season was beginning.

title: YALE DISPLAYS VIENNA PIANOS OF 1750-1850
description: NEW HAVEN ''KLAVIERLAND,'' a German word meaning ''piano land'' was Mozart's nickname for Vienna, where the piano came of age, and it might aptly describe the exhibition of Viennese pianos, 1750-1850, opening this month at the Yale University Collection of Antique Instruments.

title: INVENTOR TRIES FOR BETTER TIRE SHREDDER
description: BRISTOL THE city of clocks and watches, home of the Eastern Baseball League champion Red Sox -Bristol may now be bidding for another kind of fame. It could also become known as the place where a solution was found on how to dispose of dead tires.

title: 'PENULTIMATE WILLS' GUARD THE ELDERLY
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Awacs in A Bigger Picture
description: The White House last week formally submitted to Congress its statement of intent to sell five Awacs planes and accompanying air war weaponry to Saudi Arabia. On the same day, President Reagan also defended considerably more than the $8.5 billion deal.

title: FEASTING ON THE BAROQUE IN GERMANY
description: It takes re al work to find Bruchsal on the map of Europe. And when at last you g et it in focus, it looks like Nothingsville - a little town in Germa ny that lies not too far from Karlsruhe, Stuttgart and Baden-Baden a nd was mostly destroyed during World War II. It has a very fine chu rch by Balthasar Neumann, but in all other respects it could well be a creepy, disinherited sort of place, and best avoided.

title: POLL FINDS STRONG SUPPORT FOR ENVIRONMENTAL CODE
description: A large majority of the American public supports continued strong protection of the environment even if it requires economic sacrifice, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: JAZZ
description: Michael's Pub, which has been building shows around the work of individual songwriters for several years, tried a new tack three months ago - a program of piano duets by Dick Hyman and Roger Kellaway. That worked so well that they were followed in August by a second duo -Blossom Dearie and Dave Frishberg, who sang as well as played two pianos.

title: TECHNICIANS INSPECT A LEAK IN INDIAN POINT 3 PLANT
description: Technicians at the Indian Point 3 nuclear plant were working around the clock today in their inspection of the tubing inside a steam generator. The discovery of a leak in the tubing has forced the plant to shut indefinitely.

title: PLEASING BOTH SIDES, COURT JUST SHARPENS CANADA CRISIS
description: According to a routine by the Royal Canadian Air Farce, a popular comedy troupe, ''Some nationalities look at things as they are and say, 'Why?' A Canadian looks at things as they might be and says, 'No way!' '' And so it seemed last week as Canada experienced another of its periodic constitutional convulsions.

title: MOTHER, LAWYER, POLITICIAN, ENVOY
description: For Faith Ryan Whittlesey, who is often described here as the most powerful woman in Pennsylvania politics, life has become a little more hectic than usual since her nomination early last month as Ambassador to Switzerland.

title: ARGUELLO STOPS MANCINI IN 14
description: A masterful performance by Alexis Arguello gave the inevitable end to boxing's version of ''Love Story'' today when Ray Mancini, fighting for the lightweight title his father never had a chance for, was stopped at 1 minute 46 seconds of the 14th round.

title: Topics; Sending a Message; Sharing of the Green
description: A lovable Irish worker of our acquaintance is thrilled that a ''lovable Irish worker,'' as a Republican news release describes him, is the star of a new Republican Party television commercial.

title: WHY ARMSTRONG RUBER STILL SELLS TIRES
description: I F there's one industry that has been hurting even more than cars, it's tires. The industry has been clobbered by the three-year slowdown in new-car sales and by the success of the long-wearing radial tire. Even there, foreign-based corporations, notably Michelin, have run off with chunks of the business. As a result, the industry has atrophied, marginal producers have gone out of business and many plants have closed. But in tire making, as in other businesses, sometimes a protected niche safegua rds companies that occupy it. For tires, the niche was the replaceme nt market and it has helped reverse the fortunes of one company - Arm strong Rubber. Armstrong, though smaller than industry giants, owns about 9 percent of that market and derives 70 percent ofits sales fro m it.

title: INDIAN CULTURE CENTER TO OPEN
description: The Institute of Indian Culture, a 43-year-old organization dedicated to educating foreigners and the people of India about that country's vast cultural heritage, has announced that it will soon open its first center in the United States.

title: Around the Nation; Inmates Win Settlement In Suit on Jail Conditions
description: A Federal jury yesterday said that 2,000 current and former inmates of the Worcester County jail were entitled to nearly $2 million in damages for enduring unsanitary and overcrowded conditions.

title: Crime; by Newgate Callendar
description: Two books that deal with the more unsavory aspects of the police and the connection between venal cops and organized crime are ROOFTOPS by Tom Lewis (Evans, $11.95) and THE SANTA CLAUS KILLER by A.H. Garnet (Ticknor & Fields, $12.95). ''Rooftops,'' Mr. Lewis's first novel, looks into the New York Police Department. The Garnet book concerns itself with a crooked mayor, a crooked police department and the Mob in a town near Detroit.

title: GERHARD HUSCH DISKS SHED LIGHT ON LIEDER STYLES
description: Arabesque's release of a three-LP package of Schubert song recordings by Gerhard Husch (8107-3L), along with the same company's single-disk compilation of operatic arias also recorded by Mr. Husch in the 1930's (8022), serves three almost equally valuable functions.

title: CLARK R. PACE
description: Clark R. Pace, who worked at Business Week for 32 years and was editor of the magazine's Business Outlook column, died Thursday in Peekskill (N.Y.) Community Hospital. Mr. Pace, who lived in Garrison, N.Y., was 77 years old.

title: Elizabeth Jane Bremer Bride of John R. Liegey
description: Elizabeth Jane Bremer, daughter of Richard George Bremer of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Elizabeth Knight Bremer, was married yesterday to John Richard Liegey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Richard Liegey of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Timothy Curtain performed the ceremony in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Region in Summary; Jet Lag Hits Conn. Workers
description: It still may be the best of times for the United Technologies Corporation, but it seems like the worst of them for many who work for Connecticut's largest private employer. With orders for commercial jet engines declining, layoff notices went up last week at four plants in the state run by its Pratt & Whitney subsidiary, leaving 1,415 workers without jobs.

title: Jeff Sparks, Radio-TV Official With the U.N., Is Dead at 76
description: Jeff Sparks, a p ioneer broadcaster and a ra dio and television official of the United Nations from 1947 unti l his retirement in 1968, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home.

title: The World in Summary; 'Magic of the Market Place'
description: President Reagan took supply-side on the road last week, before the 141 nations at the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, and found - not surprisingly - that it plays better in Peoria.

title: BELFAST PRISONERS END HUNGER STRIKE THAT LEFT 10 DEAD
description: The hunger strike by Irish nationalist prisoners in Northern Ireland, in which 10 men have died since May, was called off tonight. The prisoners said they had ''reluctantly'' concluded that the families of the men now on the fast would refuse to let them die.

title: FOR BETTER OR WORSE, REAGANOMICS NOW BEGINS
description: WASHINGTON WITH the start of fiscal year 1982, the preparations were over, the trip under way. Thursday, the Reagan Administration set sail on a voyage of fiscal experimentation, and under cloudy skies. For weeks after passage of the Reagan tax cut early in August, the stock and bond markets sank. (Early Monday, a new crisis seemed to be building, as share prices tumbled on major exchanges abroad. But the New York Stock Exchange - unaccountably - decided it was time to rally; Big Board prices climbed.)

title: Frank Church On Foreign Policy
description: Frank Church's excellent article, ''America's New Foreign Policy'' (Aug. 23), was noteworthy for its admission that a concerted attempt to see the policies of the Reagan Administrat ion as a logical whole simply fails. The Administration's holding of rearmament, tax cuts and a balanced budget as simultaneous goals, its perceptions of the U.S.S.R. as simultaneously crumbling and on t he road to world domination, and the search for a nuclear supe riority that only means multiplying ''how many times the rubble bounc es'' all bespeak a profound irrationality. G.C. RAMSAY, Palo Alto, Calif.

title: by Anthony DePalma
description: PRINCETON LIKE the youngsters it treats, the Princeton Child Development Institute has created a world of its own. Inside an old building on the outskirts of Princeton, colorful hand-drawn posters and scaleddown tables and desks are unmistakable signs that children are around. As cl asses change on the half-hour, the youngsters, books in hand or slung over a shoulder in a knapsack, walk quietly from one room to anoth er. Teachers bring along stragglers as the classroom doors shut an d another class begins.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Dunce Cap for Diablo Experts
description: Where protests failed at the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant, simple blunder was effective. Two weeks ago, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission granted the Pacific Gas and Electric Company a license to begin low-power testing on one of its twin reactors, situated near an offshore earthquake fault at San Luis Obispo, Calif. Last week, the opening was postponed and a commission inquiry begun into design errors, after Pacific Gas disclosed that blueprints for the completed reactor were inadvertently confused with those for a second.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN NEVER ADVOCATED CARTER'S MX PLAN
description: Senior White House officials said today that in their view, the vast ''shell game'' proposed by President Carter in 1979 to shuttle missiles among bases in the Western deserts had never been an option considered seriously by President Reagan.

title: DIRECTING AT 81, GEORGE CUKOR SPANS THE HISTORY OF THE TALKIES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. By STEPHEN FARBER LOS ANGELES

title: Mitchell Karlan And Carey Moler To Marry Dec. 19
description: Mr. and Mrs. John C. Moler of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carey Loraine Moler, to Mitchell Alan Karlan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Karlan of Nutley, N.J.

title: STATE TESTS USE OF BATTERIES ON SUBWAY TRAINS
description: An experimental project to determine whether New York City's subway system can be run on storage batteries has been initiated by the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority.

title: COURT SAYS COMMUNIST PARTY MAY SHIELD NAMES OF DONORS
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan has ruled that the Communist Party of the United States does not have to disclose its campaign contributors because they could be exposed to harassment.

title: Union Figures Are Arraigned
description: Pleas of not guilty have been entered for four men accused of conspiracy in dealings with union trust funds. Arraigned yesterday were Arthur E. Coia, an official of the Laborers International Union of North America; his son, Arthur A. Coia; Albert J. Lepore, counsel to the Rhode Island Laborers Health and Welfare Trust Fund, and Joseph J. Vaccaro Jr., a trustee of the New England Laborers Training and Trust Fund. A fifth defendant, Raymond L.S. Patriarca, a reported crime figure, did not appear.

title: Mr. Reagan Blames Mr. Begin
description: The President did not quite say ''Choose Begin or Reagan,'' or accuse the opponents of his Awacs deal of putting Israel's interests ahead of America's. But those are the repugnant implications of his prepared statement Thursday that ''It is not the business of other nations to make American foreign policy.''

title: Sound; SEEKING POWER WITH CLARITY; by Hans Fantel
description: Proverbially, figures don't lie. But as most accountants and some engineers know, they can be nudged, fudged, coaxed and cooked. When it comes to power rating in audio, the figures are clearly manipulable, and certain ambiguities should be taken into account.

title: DUTCH ATTITUDES SHIFT ON POLITICS
description: The Dutch are running out of patience with politics and politicians, and an uncharacteristic cynicism is creeping into their attitudes. On Sept. 10, after three and a half months of negotiations after a ge neral election, a new Government was formed. The election produced a swing to the left, and the new Government, appropriately enough, isa center-left coalition. But it is headed by the same man, Andries va n Agt, who headed the outgoing center-right coalition.

title: WAR HERO SEIZED AS DESERTER
description: For almost seven years Roque Vela gave his best to the United States Army. He fought in one of Vietnam's most difficult battle zones until a hand grenade knocked him out of the war.

title: Missouri Upsets Mississippi St.
description: Bobby Meyer ran for one touchdown and caught a pass for another as the Missouri Tigers upset Mississippi State, 14-3.

title: FLORIDA HOSPITAL TRIES TO COPE WITH REFUGEES
description: Doctors and nurses at Jackson Memorial, Florida's largest public hospital, are learning voodoo, along with new languages and new cultures, as part of adjusting to care for refugees pouring into the state.

title: U.S. REPORTS AIRLINE FLIGHT DELAYS AT 3 TIMES THE RATE BEFORE STRIKE
description: Air travelers in the United States are encountering flight delays at about three times the rate that existed before the walkout by air traffic controllers, and the Government is ordering trims in schedules to avoid aggravating the delays.

title: Pitt Fans Irked By TV Switch
description: A spokesman for ABC Sports said ''a considerable number of calls from viewers who wanted to watch Pittsburgh'' were received by seven telephone operators in New York yesterday afternoon when the network switched from its coverage of the Pittsburgh-South Carolina game in the second quarter.

title: Washington; SQUABBLE AND WOBBLE
description: Since World War II, the United States has had Presidents who have personally dominated the foreign policy of the nation - John Kennedy, Richard Nixon and Jimmy Carter, for example - and other Presidents such as Harry Truman, who delegated this responsibility to Secretary of State Acheson, and Dwight Eisenhower, who left the burden primarily to Secretary of State Dulles.

title: No Headline
description: The chart accompanying last week's story on All Saver certificates was misleading. The after-tax yields for money funds and passbook accounts should have been compared with a 12.61 percent yield on All Savers.

title: by Julian Auerbach
description: So successful have the New York Yankees been throughout their history that fans of other, less successful, teams have never voiced even the slightest pity for the disasters that at times have diverted the great pin stripe power from its path of shampionship achievement.

title: WHAT HAPPENED TO GRIN AND BEAR IT?
description: I AM a Long Islander. I grew up in Massapequa Park. I now rent a garden apartment with my wife in Queens. Over the last three years, I have commuted to my job in the city via the Long Island Rail Road and two M.T.A. subway systems, the IRT and the IND. I have hopped from stoplight to stoplight on Sunrise Highway and crawled along the old faithful Long Island Expressway.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Cynthia Madison Sings With Correct Gestures
description: Cynthia Madison, who made her New York debut Wednesday in Carnegie Recital Hall, showed a pleasant and attractive personality somewhat inhibited by a tenuous and incomplete vocal technique. ''Caro Nome'' from Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' was her most impressive moment.

title: KENYON'S KICKING LEADS MASSAPEQUA PAST EAST MEADOW
description: Floyd (Flip) Kenyon added to his laurels as Long Island's premier placekicker as the Massapequa High senior led the Chiefs to a 10-0 Conference I-A victory over East Meadow yesterday. The triumph was the 14th straight for Coach Bill Cutillo's squad.

title: The Broker's Fee
description: To the Editor:

title: Vivid Imagination Brings Enjoyment
description: While vacationing in the Hamptons, I had the opportunity to read your Sunday edition, and I particularly enjoyed an article by Roberta Graff, ''Why I Won't Have an Affair'' (Opinion Page).

title: Follow-Up on the News; Golf in Moscow
description: It was a grand blueprint for a multimillion-dollar East-West trade center in Moscow, and on the site there was to be an 18-hole golf course - the first in the Soviet Union.

title: LOOSER CONTROLS MAY SOUR THE MARKET FOR NEW JERSEY RENTERS
description: Traditionally, New Jersey has been a renters' market. Apartments abounded, and so did rent control laws, which were enacted by more than 100 towns and cover nearly half of the state's estimated 2.9 million renters.

title: THE CAREY'S OF ALBANY
description: Richard J. Meislin is chief of The Times's Albany bureau. By Richard J. Meislin There is a First Lady of New York State that Evangeline Gouletas-Carey would like you to meet. She is, she will inform you right off, intelligent, a woman of ''ex traordinary good judgment,'' agoaloriented dynamo who emigrated to the United States from Greece 35years ago and , through good old-fashioned hard work and persistence, captured her share of what she calls ''the American dream.''

title: FLORIO AND KEAN MAKING A HEAVY PITCH ON TV
description: AS THE state's gubernatorial race enters its final month, the candidates have committed $1.2 million each - more than half the legal campaign budget -in an effort to establish winning television images.

title: PIUS XII, THE NAZIS AND 110 POUNDS OF GOLD
description: To the Editor:

title: AMSTERDAM'S NEW FOODS
description: It's not too soon to start talking about Amsterdam Avenue in the low 80's. The renaissance is beginning along this stretch that seemed to be the stepchild of West Side renewal. Several new food shops have opened recently.

title: Kathryn Marie Adorney Wed to Neil B. Rindlaub
description: Kathryn Marie Adorney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Adorney of Greenwich, Conn., was married in the First Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Neil Beyer Rindlaub, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Rindlaub of Saddle River, N.J. The Rev. David A. Norris performed the ceremony.

title: IRVINGTON BOWS, 14-12
description: Revenge was sweet for Dobbs Ferry. The Eagles nipped Irvington, 14-12, avenging their only losses over the pas t two years.

title: Spending Reform, Not Tax Reform
description: In her article, ''Pressures for Tax Change'' (Aug. 23), State Senator Marcella Fahey considered the three ''painful'' alternatives for state government in Connecticut. Mrs. Fahey said those alternatives were: Live with small tax increases, massively cut state services, initiate tax reform.

title: A COACH UNCERTIFIED IS A COACH DENIED
description: I HAVE coached soccer since 1975. I have worked with age groups from 8 to 18. I have produced, at the club level, five outdoor and two indoo r state championship teams, two New England champs and one Eastern United States runner-upsquad. I have organized and chaperoned soccer trips in the United States, Canada and Europe.

title: MALPRACTICE INSURER'S RATE REQUEST ASSAILED
description: The biggest malpractice insurer for physicians in New York State has built up an ''inordinate'' war chest of premiums to fight future court battles, according to a trial lawyers' association spokesman.

title: SOMERVILLE SUCCEEDS
description: Thomas Gray, a senior running back, ran for three touchdowns to lead Somerville to a 21-15 victory over Bridgewater East yesterday in Bridgewater.

title: Dining Out; 2 THAT WON'T STRAIN THE BUDGET
description: ''ISN'T there any place a family with kids can go for dinner without taking out a bank loan?'' That's a question frequently asked of this column, and one ''yes'' answer may be found at Post Corner Pizza in Darien. Another is Pickles in Ridgefield.

title: PRESIDENT'S PROGRESS
description: THE REAGAN REVOLUTION By Rowland Evans and Robert Novak.257 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $12.75.

title: St. Bernard's Runners Excel
description: Connecticut schools competed in cross-country for the first time on Long Island yesterday and were winners in three of four boys' varsity races in the 10th St. Anthony's Invitational held at Sunken Meadow State Park in King's Park.

title: ELDERLY OF YONKERS JOIN TOGETHER TO FIGHT CRIME
description: year-old Yonkers resident, has been mugged twice. After the second incident, she said, ''I got mad. I told myself, this is getting to be too much.'' So with the help of the Yonkers Office for the Aging and one of its project directors, Deborah Matystik, Mrs. Battcock organized the Community Advocacy Resource for the Elderly, or C.A.R.E.

title: WINE CROP SMALL BUT STOCKS AMPLE
description: THOUGH severely damaged by a deep freeze la st winter, Connecticut's fledgling wine industry is taki ng its losses in stride. This year's crops will be smaller, bu t reliance by the state's wineries on grapes imported from New York State and western Pennsylvania or on well-stocked wine cellars will mean little loss of momentum, vintners say.

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'New' Lighthouse
description: Under a Coast Guard efficiency plan begun in 1966, yet another romantic figure of time - the lighthouse keeper - was marked for displacement by automation. The plan called for human-less lighthouses everywhere in the country by the mid-1980's.

title: Dining Out; OKTOBERFEST FROM AN OLD CELEBRANT
description: OF all festivals, the jolliest, to our mind, is the celebration of autumn's harvest. The rite is at once a tribute to the fertile spirits of earth and sun for the year's crop and an appeal for future abundance. The grain harvested bears bread and beer and a moment of leisure to enjoy the bacchanal. It has been noted that myth changes while custom remains constant, and so the Bavarian version of the October festival is now being commemorated at most restaurants in the county that offer German specialties.

title: 'Test Disclosure' Bill Enacted in California
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has signed into law a ''test disclosure'' bill, the second in the nation, similar to New York State's truth in testing law.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary
description: Money-Splicing Gift for M.I.T. For many universities, financial necessity has recently been the mother of commercial - and sometimes controversial - invention. The University of California founded Genentech, Inc., a lucrative company based on its faculty's work in ge ne-splicing; Harvard University's faculty r efused participation in a similar company.

title: HOSPITAL WING TO USE 70TH STREET AIR RIGHTS
description: The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center will begin construction this week on a nine-story building over East 70th Street between York Avenue and the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive.

title: Excavations In Saudi Arabia
description: I was intrigued by the cover of The New York Times Magazine depicting the tomb of Madain Salih in Saudi Arabia, and turned to Robert Reinhold's article, ''Cities Beneath the Sands'' (Aug. 23), with great anticipation. Good reporting, but he might have mentioned that these archeological discoveries were recorded, in fact, by Charles M. Doughty in his book ''Travels in Arabia Deserta'' in 1888.

title: A MOMENT OF REALIZATION IN A PLACE CLOSE TO HOME
description: I LEARNED that my apple tree was officially dead on the same day that I heard my neighbor Carol was moving to the city. Now, although I know that neither of these bits of news will cause the United Nations to convene in emergency session, in the small world that borders my home they are thought-provoking.

title: Christopher Goff, Lawyer, Weds Janet E. Bridgwater
description: Janet Elaine Bridgwater, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald N. Bridgwater of West Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Christopher Lee Goff. The Rev. Eugene Laubach performed the ceremony at the Riverside Church in New York.

title: Westchester Journal
description: ABILL that would extend daylight-saving time from six months to eight months is expected to be reported out of the Rules Committee of the United States House of Representatives later this week and sent to the floor shortly thereafter for consideration, according to a spokesman for Representative Richard L. Ottinger, Democrat of Mamaroneck and sponsor of the legislation.

title: Your Own Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: COAST CANDIDATE ASSAILS REPORTER
description: Lieut. Gov. Mike Curb's verbal attack on a Los Angeles newspaper reporter erupted in a news conference at the California Republican Convention here today in a way that may affect next year's race for Governor of California.

title: ALEXANDRA CUMMINGS IS WED
description: Alexandra Ellis Cummings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cummings of Providence, R.I., was married there yesterday to John Hincks Duke, son of Betsy Trippe Wainwright of New York and Old Black Point, Conn., and William Hincks Duke of New York. The Rev. Normand J. Demers performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: WEAVER, HAGLER RETAIN TITLES
description: Marvin Hagler defended his undisputed world middleweight boxing championship by stopping Mustafa Hamsho, the top challenger, at 2 minutes 9 seconds of the 11th round of their bout tonight at the Horizon Arena.

title: House Backs Medical Status For 'Agent Orange' Veterans
description: The House has passed a bill giving priority medical care in Veterans Administration clinics to Vietnam veterans who believe their health has been affected by exposure to Agent Orange or other defoliants.

title: 'Bed and Breakfast' And Zoning Ordinances
description: The recent article on the ''bed and breakfast'' idea taking hold on Long Island omits any reference to the zoning implications of this practice.

title: Illinois to Issue Bonds for Tuition Loan Fund
description: Illinois has become the first state to authorize iss uance of tax-exempt revenue bonds to provide loan money for students attending private colleges and universities.

title: Politics; FOR NEW LEADER, G.O.P. IS 'ENEMY'
description: MARTIN L. MELLMAN, the new Nassau Democratic Party chairman and one of the most liberal county leaders in the state, gave a lukewarm endorsement to Governor Carey shortly after assuming his new post recently.

title: Other Business; LOTTERY: TOUGH ODDS ON OIL AND GAS LEASES
description: After a four-month shutdown for an investigation of fraud, the Federal Government's lottery is back in business. The Bureau of Land Management conducts a lottery every other month for oil and gas leases. A player can get in the action for as little as $25 and m ightwin land wort h hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: Completion of I-287 Is Called Misguided
description: The Federal Department of Transportation, together with the New Jersey Depart ment of Transportation, have decided to make a ''final effort'' to c omplete Interstate 287 through parts of Morris, Passaic and Bergen Co unties, apparently an embarrassing missing link in a highway of in creasingly questionable value.

title: Colbert and Stadler Tied For Lead in Texas Open
description: Jim Colbert and Craig Stadler turned in rounds of 69 today to remain tied for the lead after three rounds of the $250,000 Texas Open golf tournament.

title: Speaking Personally; 2 STATES WITH AN IMAGE PROBLEM
description: WHEN I decided to move to New Jersey, I wondered whether I would have much difficulty in adjusting. I'm from Kansas and, coming from a largely rural background, I wasn't sure that I could become an urban sophisticate overnight - or at all.

title: Colette Monetti Bride of Christopher McKown
description: At St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Port Washington, L.I., yesterday, Colette Monetti, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Earl Monetti of Tampa, Fla., was married to Christopher John McKown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. McKown of Sandy Creek, N.Y. The Rev. Kurt Von Roeschlaub performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday incorrectly identified the owner of the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant, which is shut because of a leak in the steam generator. The plant is owned and operated by the Power Authority of the State of New York.

title: A DIFFICULT GENERAL
description: MONTY The Making of a General 1887-1942. By Nigel Hamilton. Illustrated. 871 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $22.95.

title: Index; International
description: On Zimbabwe-Mozambique bor- der, guns have not been stilled 3 Finnish lineup of forces if Kekko- nen resigns 4 Norway may tighten rules on for- eign aid projects 5 Dutch attitude toward politics and politicians turning cynical 11 Religious revival under way in Czechoslovakia 12 Yugoslavs alarmed by sharp rise in drug use 13 Japanese history recalled by ex- chauffeur for prime ministers 14 Burmese are restoring temples devastated by earthquake 15 In Palestinian refugee camps, education prized 18 On the aircraft carrier Nimitz, long days and corporate pride 19 Under U.S. pressure, Thais plan to destroy opium fields 21 Soviet says it will match Rea- gan's arms program 41 Government/Politics Budget cuts hurting Consumer Product Safety Commission 33 Cases in Supreme Court's term range from familiar to novel 34 Reporter's Notebook: playing the game of politics 54 General Around the Nation 26 Troops in Hawaii plan environ- mental rescue mission 27 Puerto Rico university suspends classes after uprisings 35 Rutherford, at 100, looks both for- ward and backward 50 U.S. reopens case on Korean War collaborator 68 Florida hospital tries to cope with refugees 71 Industry/Labor Massachusetts nurses gain after strike, hospital sees deficit 32 Education/Welfare Harvard prepares to adopt new faculty ethics code 29 Religion Vigils mark 800th birthday of St. Francis of Assisi 45 Eastern Orthodox-Roman Catho- lic unity talks progress 55 Arts/Entertainment Korchnoi's loss to Karpov laid to changed strategy 22 Perlman plays Beethoven's Vio- lin Concerto with Philharmonic 76 Two one-act plays by Miss Barlow are reviewed 77 Marta Renzi and troupe give a dance concert 77 Style Amsterdam's new food 78 Mother, lawyer, politican and envoy 78 Obituaries Suehiro Nishio, former leader of Japan's Democratic Socialists 44

title: STUYVESANT SENIORS UPSET BY COLLEGE-REFERENCE BAN
description: Getting into the country's best colleges has not been a problem for graduates of Manhattan's Stuyvesant High School, but this year's seniors have run into an obstacle: as part of a union boycott, their teachers are refusing to write them letters of recommendation.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: PAUL SCULLY
description: Paul Scully, suburban single-copy sales manager for The New York Times, died of a heart attack Friday en route to Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 64 years old and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

title: DANCE: WEEK'S FESTIVAL OF NEW DANCE BEGINS
description: What promises to be the nation's largest and most concentr ated pow-wow of avant-garde dancers and choreographers got under way here last night with splendid performances and a highlyenthusiastic response at the opening of the New Dance USA Festival, sponsored by Minneapolis's Walker Art Center.

title: 'BRACERO PROGRAM NO. 3
description: President Reagan's new immigration proposal is certain to be a topic of conversation for the 10 United States and Mexican border-state governors who meet in El Paso, Tex. today and tomorrow,

title: Advertising; Overseas Marketing Choices
description: THERE have been two ways for an American company to get advertising support for an overseas marketing effort, according to Edward D. Brown, former international specialist for Doyle Dane Bernbach. One was taking your business to a multinational agency with a network of offices, and the other was retaining an international media consultant, who from an office in this country would arrange for placing existing ads abroad.

title: Armenian Group Says It Set Two Bombs in Central Geneva
description: Two bombs went off in the center of Geneva yesterday, and today Armenian extremists claimed responsibility.

title: WARREN N. RIKER
description: Warren N. Riker, a retired engineer associated with many overseas projects for the Walsh Construction Company of New York City, died Saturday in Myrtle Beach, S. C., where he lived.

title: Van Pelt's Purgatory
description: OVER near the sideline Mark Haynes and Bill Currier appeared to have John Jefferson surrounded at the 9-yard line. But suddenly the Green Bay Packer wide receiver whirled away into the end zone yesterday for the touchdown that would seal t he Giants' 27-14 loss. Not far away Brad Van Pelt, squatting on his haunches, stared at whathad happened and then dropped his head in des pair. Another agonizing moment to add to all the others that the pere nnial Pro Bowl linebacker has endured in his nine seasons of suffering with the Giants.

title: Benton & Bowles Takes A Tobacco Account
description: Benton & Bowles, which has had a policy against taking cigarette assignments, has just got a tobacco account from the Liggett Group.

title: Israelis Imprison a Guerrilla Who Tried to Fly Over Border
description: A 17-year-old Palestinian guerrilla who tried to fly a hang glider across the Lebanese border into Israel was sentenced today to seven years in prison, the Israeli Army radio reported.

title: Clerc, Vilas Win
description: Guillermo Vilas and Jose-Luis Clerc won their singles matches today to give Argentina a 5-0 victory over Britain in their Davis Cup semifinal.

title: REAGAN'S PLANS ON MISSILE STIR GROWING DEBATE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Senator John Tower, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, fueled a potentially tumultuous national debate over President Reagan's new plan for nuclear weapons today by disagreeing over the capability of the plan to make the nation safe from Soviet attack.

title: HARRIS PROMOTED BY CROWN
description: Bruce S. Harris, who joined the Crown Publishing Group in 1960 as an assistant in the juvenile publishing division, has been named director of the group's trade-publishing divisions. They are Crown Publishers, Harmony Books and Clarkson N. Potter.

title: Orr on Offense
description: Bobby Orr changed hockey. But not enough, he says now. As a defenseman for the Boston Bruins from 1966 through 1976 and for a few games in two following seasons with the Chicago Black Hawks, Orr redefined the position. Although no defenseman before him had ever scored more than 20 goals in a season, he led the National Hockey League in total points twice, in assists four times and was judged the most valuable player in the league three times.

title: KNEE SURGERY PUTS BRYANT OUT FOR SEASON
description: Kelvin Bryant, North Carolina's junior tailback who had scored 15 touchdowns in the season's first three games, will be out for the remainder of the regular season after undergoing knee surgery yesterday in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: PURCHASING MANAGERS PESSIMISTIC
description: Purchasing managers at 225 leading industrial companies across the United States are increasingly pessimistic about the future of the American economy, according to a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: CAL IFORNIA G.O.P. ENDS MEETING IN UPBEAT MOOD
description: California's Republican activists today came away from a weekend convention at this desert resort confident their political star was rising.

title: FOOD AND HUNGER STATISTICS QUESTIONED
description: As the first World Food Day nears, on Oct. 16, the sponsoring agency, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, is disseminating statistics purporting to show the dimensions of the world hunger program. ''In 1981 at least 420 million people do not have enough to eat,'' the agency's literature says. Increasingly, however, the unqualified assertion of such statistics is being challenged. Indeed, a vocal minority of critics maintain that the world hunger problem has been vastly exaggerated. Problem of Tragic Scope

title: ASHE STICKING WITH MCENROE
description: John McEnroe will represent the United States in the Davis Cup final against Argentina, Arthur Ashe, the captain, said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Landmark Nacshares Corp. amended a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, proposing a public offering of $7 million principal amount of convertible subordinated debentures, instead of 300,000 shares of common stock, to be sold through a Drexel Burnham Lambert group.

title: HANNAH ARENDT: THE ANIMUS FADES
description: More than 500 people - as many as could fit into Schimmel Auditorium at New York University - gathered over the weekend to hear one scholarly talk after another on the work of Hannah Arendt, the German-born political thinker who died of a heart attack in her Riverside Drive apartment in 1975. Political philosophers from France, Britain, Israel and the United States did most of the talking.

title: MAYORAL PRIMARY IN ATALNTA CONTAINS SYMBOLS FOR CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT
description: When Mayor Maynard Jackson took to the pulpit at the Salem Baptist Church a couple of Sundays ago to endorse Andrew Young in this Tuesday's mayoral election, it was not so much an indication that politics is a religion here as that religion often is politics.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: GIANTS DOMINATED BY PACKERS, 27-14
description: The Green Bay Packers, hardly the team that dominated pro football in the 1960's, overwhelmed the Giants today, 27-14.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: NEW SUBWAY TO RESCUE OF OLD PRAGUE
description: Rows of scaffolding mar the monumental stone buildings in the heart of this splendid medieval city. But Prague is not falling into ruins, the city's chief architect, Jiri Hruza, says. ''The health of the city is technically safe and sound.''

title: VOICE OF AMERICA FINDS ITS WORDS ARE WEIGHED
description: At the Voice of America, the Government radio that beams news and commentary to foreign lands in 39 languages, reporters and editors are choosing their stories - and words - with greater care.

title: KARPOV DEFEATS KORCHNOI IN SECOND CHESS GAME
description: After blundering away a pawn yesterday, Viktor Korchnoi could not offer much resistance against the smooth technique of the world champion, Anatoly Karpov, when the second title chess match game resumed today. The challenger resigned tonight on his 57th move here in the Kurzentrum.

title: TORRE IS DISMISSED BY METS
description: Joe Torre was dismissed as manager of the Mets yesterday after four and a half years of trying to rebuild one of the most persistently losing teams in baseball.

title: FINAL ACT BEGINS FOR STRANGEST SEASON
description: Baltimore DESPITE their conspicuous presence, the American League division playoffs will feature elements other than George Steinbrenner's former and present managers. True, Billy Martin and Dick Howser will match tactical skills in the Western Division playoff that begins tomorrow in Kansas City, and Bob Lemon will exercise his quiet managerial moves in the Eastern encounter starting Wednesday night in Milwaukee. However, it is the players who play for those managers, as well as for Bob Rodgers of Milwaukee, who will, in the end, determine which two teams will play for the league pennant next week and the American's spot in the World Series.

title: BANKERS SAY RATES MAY EASE
description: Many of the nation's bankers believe that interest rates will decline one or two percentage points from current levels but that they will remain relatively high at least through early next year.

title: New Orleans Inmates Shifted After an Ultimatum by Judge
description: The sheriff of Orleans Parish has reshuffled prisoners to comply with a Federal judge's ultimatum that he ease chronic overcrowding in the local prison system or face charges of criminal contempt.

title: Bridge: Swiss Te am Breaks Allow Fun Views of Contestants
description: Every hour or so in a Swiss team event players meet their teammates to compare scores. An observer can have a certain amount of fun in watching their demeanor, which may be confident, calm, nervous, sheepish or guilt-ridden.

title: Accounts
description: * Hearst/ABC Video Services to TLK Direct Marketing, the New York division of Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago.

title: LOOKING AT THE PREMISES
description: Theory has rarely had so strange an encounter with reality as in President Reagan's decision on the MX missile. Theoretical arguments long made by nuclear hawks yielded in significant ways to reality: scientific, political, financial reality. Yet the theories survived in the President's rhetoric, seemingl y unt ouched and quite likely to affect future decisions.

title: TV ROLE CITED IN CANDIDATES' LOW VISIBILITY
description: Representative James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, said yesterday it was understandable that only half the registered voters in the state could name the two major contenders in the race.

title: Federal Offense
description: If the men who knocked Linda Reel down in a Miami alley near the F.B.I. headquarters and fled with her purse are wondering why the authorities are making a Federal case of the mugging, there is an explanation.

title: News Analysis
description: If the 93 nations professing nonalignment are to be taken literally, the United States is the only threat to world peace and prosperity.

title: Jersey Rail Line S hut for Inspection
description: TRENTON (UPI) - A 50-mile section of a railroad line between Lindenwold, N.J., and Cape May will be closed while crews inspect the track for deficiencies, the state's mass-transit agency announced.

title: Landslides Kill 240 in China
description: Some 240 people have died in landslides after storms and flooding in the southwestern province of Sichuan, Peking Radio reported tonight. The broadcast said 100,000 people were homeless after heavy rain in mountain areas.

title: Haydn and Broadway, Bingham and Rosenbaum
description: In New York, it's getting hard to tell where politics ends and show business begins. Next Sunday, for example, Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, a Bronx Democrat, will be listed as composer when the Bronx Arts Ensemble presents his violin sonatina, at the Riverdale-Yonkers Ethical Culture Society.

title: LABOR CHIEF RECALLS FUTILE EFFORT TO SUPPORT CONTROLLER STRIKE
description: ''My idea was to shut the air carriers down,'' said William W. Winpisinger, head of the 800,000-member International Association of Machinists. But he needed support, he said, from other unions, particularly the Air Line Pilots Association.

title: Soviet Is Said to Dismiss An Official in Oil Scandal
description: A Deputy Oil Minister has been dismissed for falsifying petroleum production figures, misusing state funds and holding a second job illegally, the newspaper Sotsialisticheskaya Industriya said today.

title: GRUMMAN'S LOYAL WORKERS
description: After 21 years as a Grumman engineer, Ray Lokkenberg wasted no time when he heard that a Texas conglomerate wanted to take control of the company that he says is more like a family member than an employer. He called a stockbroker and bought 300 shares of Grumman.

title: FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF THE GENERATION GAP
description: Contrary to the impression that grandmothers are delighted to help their grown daughters and care for their grandchildren, a study of multigenerational families indicates that many older women resent the frequent impositions of the younger generations on their time and energy.

title: Patriots Defeat Chiefs for First Victory
description: The best laid plans in the National Football League often do not last through a game's first quarter. Buttoday they di d for the New England Patriots, who also had a modicum of luck come their way at last.

title: Guidry Will Start In Playoff Opener
description: Ron Guidry, who could be in his final days as a Yankee, will pitch the opening game of the American League Eastern Division playoff in Milwaukee Wednesday night, Manager Bob Lemon announced today before the Yankees concluded their regular-season schedule with a 5-2 loss to Baltimore.

title: Asbestosis Found in Tests
description: More than half of the 1,018 shipyard workers tested earlier this year for asbestosis were found to have the disease, which is caused by exposure to asbestos, the American Lung Association says.

title: EMBASSY ROW; THE PRESS OF THE PRESS AND A DELICACY ISSUE
description: For the city's foreign embassies, there is no busier season than the fall, when it seems that whole governments descend en route to or from the United Nations General Assembly or the meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. But for the small Salvadoran Embassy, the last two weeks have been more than busy; they have been a nightmare.

title: Pakistan Says Outpost Is Strafed by Afghan Jets
description: Pakistan said two Afghan MIG-17 jets strafed a Pakistani border o utpost today in the third violation of Pakistani territory by Afghan forces in a month.

title: AN AUTOPSY AFFIRMS IDENTITY
description: The body resting in Lee Harvey Oswald's coffin was removed from its grave today, and a team of examining pathologists said that the remains were indeed Oswald's.
