The finding appeared to end speculation that the corpse might have been that of a Russian agent sent here to kill President Kennedy in 1963.

title: CEASE-FIRE IN SALVADOR
description: Whatever you have heard about the troubles in El Salvador is doubtless part of the truth. There is an extreme gap between poor and rich, who made a deal with the army to rule and get richer. The army canceled the election of Jose Napoleon Duarte in 1972, and many date intense repression from that time.

title: 3 Policemen Suspended After Sex Accusations
description: Three policemen were ordered suspended because of accusations by a woman that they regularly released her from her cell for sexual relations and parties to relieve her boredom, the Detroit News reported today.

title: Helpers in Nisei Camps Described as Informers
description: Some social scientists assigned to improve conditions at United States internment camps for Japanese-Americans during World War II served as Government informers, a University of Nebraska researcher has charged. Peter T. Suzuki, 52 years old, a former cam p resident, said that the information he collected from the Nationa l Archives on 20 anthropologists and seven sociologists assign ed to the camps was ''overwhelming'' proof.

title: A. JOHNSON'S NEW CHIEF
description: John W. Priesing, 51, has been named President and chief executive officer of A. Johnson & Company, a shipping, oil, steel and engineered products copany based in New York. He succeeded Robert W. Lynch, 62, who was appointed to the vacant post of vice chairman.

title: MAKE-BELIEVE SAVING
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN WILL PRESS SOVIET ON DISPUTED ISLANDS IN FIRST TALKS SINCE '79
description: Japan and the Soviet Union, by agreeing to hold talks on ''various pending questions'' by the end of 1981, have opened the way for the Japanese to raise once again the issue of the Soviet occupation since 1945 of what Tokyo calls its northern territories.

title: BIG BAD 'SOVIETS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Set On DeLorean
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher tonight ordered a police investigation into allegations of financial irregularities involving an automobile plant in Northern Ireland established by John DeLorean, an American entrepreneur.

title: Export Curb O n Fuel Ends
description: The Administration has lifted export controls on g asoline and jet fuel imposed after the 1973 Arab oil embargo, sayi ng they were no longer needed ''to insure adequate supplies'' fo r American consumers. The controls sharply limited the amount of oil products that could be sold abroad.

title: POPE GOES BACK TO ST. PETER'S SQUARE
description: Protected by the strictest security in modern times in St. Peter's Square, Pope John Paul II beatified two women and three men from France and Italy today and celebrated mass in front of a crowd of tens of thousands.

title: LIMITS OF EXEMPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. GERHARD FANKHAUSER DIES
description: Dr. Gerhard Fankhauser, professor emeritus of biology at Princeton University a nd an expert on embryology and cell biology, died yesterday a t his home in Princeton.He was 80 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Saturday incorrectly attributed a quotation about hiring Teamsters to "go in and knock their heads off" in a White House discussion in 1971 on how to deal with antiwar protesters. The speaker, according to a White House tape recording, was former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MONDAY'S CHILD

title: INVESTORS ANGRY OVER MUIR CLAIMS
description: A group of investors, many of them wealthy, who had accounts at John Muir & Company, the brokerage house that was liquidated in August, complain that they are not being adequately protected by the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.

title: BORROWING COSTS FORCING NEW YORK TO CURB BUILDING
description: Governor Carey and State Comptroller Edward V. Regan plan to ask the state's department heads at a meeting today to delay the building of some new hospital wings, highways and state buildings already approved for construction. The delay is required to reduce the state's need to borrow at current high interest rates.

title: More TV Game Shifts Likely
description: When ABC Sports cut off television coverage of the Pittsburgh-South Carolina game Saturday and replaced it with the Mississippi State-Missouri game for the remainder of the regional telecast in the Northeast, it marked the first time in 16 years of ABC college football telecasts that the network had cut off a game because it appeared to be an unattractive rout. But it probably will not be the last time. Donn Bernstein, a spokesman for ABC Sports, said yesterday: ''Underthe ground rules of the new contract with the N.C.A.A., it will be possible to change to another game if one tea m is leading by 18 or more points at halftime.''

title: Britain's Reserves Fall
description: Britain's gold and foreign currency reserves fell $815 million in September to $23.7 billion, the lowest level since December 1979, the Treasury said Friday. The underlying fall, net of repayments and new borrowing, was $677 million, well below the record of $2.11 billion in April 1978.

title: FRENCH ORCHESTRA SETS U.S.-CANADIAN TOUR
description: Under the direction of Leonard Bernstein and Lorin Maazel, the Orchestre National de France will begin a 24-day, 17-concert tour of the United States and Canada in Boston on Nov. 27.

title: MOVIE: DIVERSE STUDIES OF LENGTHY MARRIGES
description: THE theme that unites Brian O'Doherty's ''Hopper's Silence'' and Michael Blackwood's ''We Were German Jews'' is that of long-term union, because both of these films on seemingly unrelated subjects study lengthy marriages. ''Hopper's Silence'' is a portrait of the artist Edward Hopper and his wife, Jo, with particular attention to the wife's presence in the husband's work, and to the husband's overshadowing effect on his spouse. ''I al ways thought of him as a kind of rock, and I always thought of her as a kind of mosquito,'' says one frie nd of the late couple.

title: Fewer Jews Leaving Soviet
description: Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union is running at its lowest level in many years, Israeli immigration officials said today. Yehuda Domonitz, the director of the Jewish Agency's immigration department, said there had been a decline in the number of exit visas issued in the last few months.

title: BRANDT SEES NO ANTI-U.S. DRIFT
description: Recent anti-American demonstrations in West Germany ''do not reflect the general mood of our people,'' in the view of Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor.

title: IMPACT OF CHECKOUT SCANNERS
description: The age of the high-technology supermarket has arrived. At the checkout counter, a cashier rotates cans and boxes over a small window, through which a concealed scanner emits laser beams. As the beams ''read'' the Universal Price Code - that postage stamp-size set of bars now printed on most packaged goods - the scanner beeps to indicate that the message has been received. A few more turns, a few more beeps, the sale is recorded and the shopper is out the door. But more is at stake here than efficient checkouts. What the scanners First of two articles on scanners and marketing. record is not only price but also information about products and profits that could have a far-reaching impact on the marketing of packaged goods.

title: Market Place; Holder of APL Relates a Saga
description: paper company that also produces plastics and vitamins, recently added to shareholder disappointment with the abandonment of its second plan to merge with the NVF Company.

title: Peking Leader Meets N ationalist Defector
description: A Chinese Nationalist Air Force major who defectec to China in an F-5F jet trainer in August met today with Deputy Prime Minister Deng Xiaoping, the official New China News Agency reported.

title: AMID THE LAWLESSNESS IN LEBANON, HASHISH TRADE FLOURISHES
description: The harvest is on in the Bekaa Valley, some of the most fertile land in the Middle East, and workers in the broad fields are bringing in another record crop of Lebanon's biggest cash export - hashish.

title: Cardinal Cody Hospitalized
description: John Cardinal Cody of Chicago was admitted to Columbus Hospital tonight for ''routine tests,'' a spokesman for the archdiocese said. He said the 73-year-old Cardinal had driven himself to the hospital on his doctor's orders and was expected to leave the hospital Tuesday evening.

title: CRUDELY HIDDEN AID FOR AMERICA'S RICH
description: To the Edit or: William Coy ne's analysis of tax expenditures on your Sept. 8 Op-Ed page (''Wealt hfare? No.'') focuses attention on one of the least defensible as pects of this Administration's economic programs.

title: SAVINGS AND LOAN UNITS MERGE AT ST. LOUIS
description: The Government has announced the merger of two savings and loan associations in the St. Louis area, bringing to 15 the number of Federally approved thrift unit mergers so far this year. Eleven were approved in all of 1980.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With a runner on second, the batter hits a single to center field. The runner dashes for home and is called safe in a close play. The catcher disagrees, starts arguing while still holding the ball in his hand. The player who singled advances to second but is waved back by the umpire, who says the defensive team called time out. Is it legal for time out to be called while a runner is still advancing?

title: BRIEFING
description: G T HIS is a wonderful city for contrived secrets, and in the hours before the Reagan Administration's official release of its new strategic weapons policy, White House officials vehemently insisted that the press corps observe the thick black ''EMBARGO'' instructions stamped on advance copies.

title: PUBLIC HEALTH HOSPITAL ON S.I. ORDERED TO CLOSE
description: The United States Public Health Service Hospital on Staten Island, which opened 150 years ago to treat merchant seamen and has since become a community facility, has been ordered by the Reagan Administration to stop admitting patients and to close by the end of this month.

title: BRITONS DISTURBED BY UNLISTED TRADING
description: When shares of Business Computer (Systems) started trading on the Unlisted Stock Market here, the money the company raised through its public sale of stock was distributed to the original shareholders.

title: POLAND ANNOUNCES PRICE RISES, AND UNION PROTESTS
description: The Government disclosed plans last night to increase sharply the prices of tobacco products and certain foodstuffs. The action drew protests today from the independent union Solidarity, which complained that it had not been consulted. The new prices will go into effect tomorrow.

title: Unfinished Voting Rights
description: The House o f Representatives will decide today whether to extend the Voting Ri ghts Act until that landmark 1965 law has done its job. A bill well c alculated to secure the hard-won rights of blacks and Hispanics is the main order of business - and the target of weakeningamendments. I t is imperative that the most effective provisions of the law be re tained beyond its expiration next August. The strongest possible bill is needed from the House for next year's uphill battle in the Senate .

title: Maryland's Yacht Saves 4
description: Gov. Harry R. Hughes pulled four wet boaters from their capsized sailboat in the choppy waters of the Severn River yesterday, the Governor's press secretary said today.

title: Association Head Asks Better Training for All
description: Leonard S. Matthews, president of the Ameri can Association of Advertising Agencies, last week got into the continuing feud between supporters of advertising copy research and i ts detractors - usually copywriters.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bethlehem S teel Corp., Bethlehem, Pa., has elected to its board Silas S. Cath cart, chairman of Illinois Tool Works Inc. * Business International Corp. has appointed Frank X. White senior vice president in charge of worldwide client programs. *Callahan Mining Corp., Phoenix has named Charles D. Snead Jr., president and chief executive officer, to the additional post of chairman.

title: NEW EFFORT IS URGED BY COMMONWEALTH ON RICH-POOR ISSUE
description: The 42 Commonwealth heads of government issued a declaration today calling for a new effort to end inequality between developed and developing countries.

title: Nicaragua Threatens To Shut a Leading Paper
description: The Government has threatened to shut Nicaragua's leading opposition newspaper permanently unless its editors stop criticizing the leftist Government.

title: Bettors at Belmont Get Touch of Paris
description: The croissants were rubbery and there wasn't a glass of even vin ordinaire to be found, but a touch of Paris seeped into Belmont Park yesterday morning.

title: Sedco Purchases
description: Sedco Inc., an offshore drilling contractor, said that it had raised its stake in the Marathon Oil Company to 5.5 percent through the aquisition of an additional 407,900 shares at a price of $22 million. The company also disclosed last week that it had acquired a 4.8 percent interest in Marathon and that it intended to make future open-market purchases of Marathon shares, depending on the availability of funds and other factors.

title: Coal-Tar Cleanup Is Begun Upstate
description: ALBANY (AP) - The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation has begun a $1 million project to contain coal-tar deposits that have been leaking into the Saranac River at Plattsburgh, Robert F. Flacke, the State Environmental Conservation Commissioner, announced.

title: British Laborite Warns U.S. Over Soviet Talks
description: Michael Foot, leader of Britain's opposition Labor Party, warned the Reagan Administration today against doing anything that might jeopardize the coming Soviet-American negotiations on limiting medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: OFF BASE ON CAPITAL GAINS AND ESTATE TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: JOSEPH P. BRENNAN
description: Joseph P. Brennan Jr., a former sheriff in New York City who retired in 1976, died Saturday at the Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Berlin Squatters Evicted
description: The police evicted squatters from three West Berlin buildings yesterday soon after they were occupied. A police spokesman said today that 186 people were detained for identity checks but that only one person was arrested. Squatters protesting the shortage of housing in West Berlin occupy about 150 vacant buildings here in defiance of owners and city authorities.

title: Fred R. Conrad More Than 100,000 Turn Out for Pulaski Parade
description: Youngsters dressed in traditional Polish costumes watching the 45th annual Pulaski Day parade yesterday on Fifth Avenue. The parade honors Casimir Pulaski, a Polish gen eral who fought in the American Revolution.

title: Chevron Oil Find
description: Chevron Petroleum (U.K.) Ltd. said a well 25 kilometers southwest of the Ninian Field in the North Sea encountered an ''encouraging'' amount of oil. The company announcement Friday said a total depth of 5,781 feet was reached and production tests yielded 3,066 barrels a day through a two-inch pipe, with a gas-to-oil ratio of about 230 cubic feet a barrel. Chevron is operator for a group including Dawsea, Dow Chemical International Energy, ICI Petroleum, Sovereign Oil and Gas and Westburne Drilling and Exploration.

title: TRACY AUSTIN HALTED
description: Martina Navratilova brought Tracy Austin's 28-match winning streak to a halt tonight by winning the final of the $125,000 United States Women's Indoor tennis championship, 6-0, 6-2, at the Met Sports Center.

title: MUSIC: MORE OF KURT WEI LL
description: A SIZABLE crowd attended the Whitney Museum's ''A Kurt Weill Encore,'' the second of three events in the festival celebrating the 25th anniversary of the Composer's Showcase series. Many people had been lured by the promise of a rare appearance by Lotte Lenya, so that when it was announced that the composer's widow was too ill to appear, there was disappointment. But after hearing this poorly conceived potpourri of Weill's piano music, art songs and show tunes Thursday night, one wondered if perhaps Miss Lenya had foreseen problems and decided to keep her distance. For the performances were so underrehearsed and perfunctory as to do the composer a real disservice.

title: Experts Divided Over Fed Policy
description: Monetary policy makers of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee will meet this week, and analysts do not agree about whether the Fed will continue to pump money into the banking system - a move that would cause short-term interes rates to fall.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Sweethearts Are Reunited After 40 Years When his manager introduced John Raitt to Rosemary Yorba Lokey earlier this year, there was more than a spark of recognition between the singer and the socialite. More than 40 years before, when he was in college and she was in high school, they had been sweethearts, and at one time, even engaged.

title: 66 LEFTIST REBELS EXECUTED IN IRAN
description: Sixty-six leftist guerrillas were executed over the weekend as counting continued in Iran's presidential election, the Teheran newspaper Kayhan reported today.

title: Cards Defeat Cowboys, 20-17
description: The score was 17-17, only 23 seconds remained in the game between the Dallas Cowboys and St. Louis, and the Cardinals had the ball at the Dallas 20.

title: A New Generation of Politician in Tennessee
description: The district is brand new, and the two leading contenders are political unknowns, but in Tennessee, where the campaign for next year's House election from the Fourth Congressional District is already under way, the names couldn't be more familiar.

title: MURRAY A. GOLDBERG
description: Murray A. Goldberg, retired principal of Public School 11 in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, died of a heart attack Saturday while walking near his home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

title: I.R.A. VOWS TO PRESS STRUGGLE DESPITE ENDING OF PRISON FAST
description: The Irish nationalist guerrillas fighting the British here said today that their struggle would continue undiminished, despite the collapse yesterday of their seven-month-old prison hunger strike.

title: Lidocaine Overdose Blamed In One of 27 Hospital Deaths
description: An investigation into 27 deaths at three hospitals has shown that at least one patient, a 62-year-old woman, died of an overdose of the drug lidocaine, it was revealed Saturday.

title: MUSIC: SCHUB'S 'EMPEROR' CONCERTO
description: BEETHOVEN'S ''Emperor'' Concerto would seem to be a felicitous choice for a program that was at the same time opening the season of an orchestra - the American Symphony - and marking the first major New York appearance of Andre-Michel Schub since he was crowned winner of the prestigious Van Cliburn International Piano Competition. And it was that work, placed at the end of the program, that much of the audience was awaiting yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall; Mr. Schub was even welcomed with an introduction by Mr. Cliburn himself.

title: Polaroid's Suit Reaches Court
description: After five years of legal skirmishing, the giants of the photography industry - the Polaroid Corporation and the Eastman Kodak Company - square off in Federal court Monday in a battle over the booming market in ''instant'' photography.

title: STUDENT FACING EXTRADITION BID IN BOOKS THEFT
description: Scotland Yard said yesterday that it would seek to extradite the Columbia University graduate student arrested in Manhattan on Friday in connection with the theft of $2 million worth of rare books from a London library.

title: Mother Earth News Gets Grit's Advertising
description: Mother Earth News, a six-a-year publication that caters to rural America, is taking over every one of the advertising sales chores of Grit, the weekly newspaper that is celebrating its centennial next year.

title: ROYALS-A'S HOME FIELD EDGE STILL UNDETERMINED
description: Forty-five minutes after the Royals lost to the Oakland A's, 4-3, yesterday at Kansas City, they left on a chartered flight for Cleveland.

title: Now Tackle Inflation Directly
description: The Reagan Administration's ''incomes policy''? The very words sound odd. If there is one thing this Administration has made perfectly clear, it is its view that Government has no business restraining wages and prices. No jawboning, no guidelines, no badgering business and labor to write anti-inflation compacts.

title: FOR CREDIT CONTROLS
description: To control inflation, the Federal Reserve, with the Reagan Administration's blessing but the occasional balking of its chief executive, has been trying to reduce the money supply by driving up interest rates. But by narrowing policy to this one option - with the consequence of limiting public discourse on the problem - the Administration forgoes alternative strategies, even those that promise to be more efficacious. Selective credit controls provide a case in point.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "we're going to ask them to slow it down just as much as possible.

title: Iowa Man Gets New Heart
description: The heart of an 18-year-old South African youth was flown 500 miles from the coastal city of Port Elizabeth last night and transplanted today into 29-year-old Rick Anderson of Iowa City, Iowa. The transplant team was led by Dr. Christiaan Barnard, who performed the world's first heart transplant operation in the 1960's. Mr. Anderson was reported in excellent condition after the five-hour operation.

title: Randolph on Defense
description: Willie Randolph, the Yankee second baseman who was fined $500 for missing a special team practice on Aug. 20, has been named the honorary chairman of the Mental Health Association of New Jersey. Randolph failed to attend the practice, called by George Steinbrenner after the Yankees had lost five of six games, because he had made a previous commitment during the 50-day players' strike to appear at a function for the Mental Health Association on Aug. 20.

title: SCOLA'S 'PASSIONE D'AMORE,' A COMEDY
description: THE time is 1862 and the place is Italy during one of the infrequent periods of peace between wars of unification. The Romantic Movement, so closely identified with the Risorgimento, defines everything in terms of the ideal -ideal courage, ideal loyalty, ideal love, ideal beauty.

title: PEACEFUL MARCH ENDS IN VIOLENCE
description: Paris policemen and leftist extremists clash at the end of an antinuclear demonstration. The leftists had joined the march to demand freedom for ''political prisoners.''

title: Washington Watch; Oil Import Fee Stirring Again
description: WASHINGTON QUIETLY simmering as a possible way to raise copious revenues is a rehash of the oil import fees concocted in both the Ford and Carter Administrations but never actually served up. Up to $10 billion a year could flow into the Treasury, giving the President a big boost toward his goal of a balanced budget by 1984.

title: FREE HEALTH AID IN HARLEM FAILS TO ATTRACT POOR
description: A year after starting an experimental program to provide free health care for the poor of East Harlem, city officials say they are having trouble persuading families to enroll.

title: Social Democrats Open F irst Parley in Britain
description: Britain's new Social Democratic Party opened its first conference today with Roy Jenkins, one of its founders and a former Labor Party Cabinet minister, telling delegates that they had astonished the world and could form the next government.

title: Iranians Charged in Manila
description: Criminal charges have been filed against 68 Iranian students arrested after clashing with the authorities during demonstrations by supporters and opponents of the Teheran regime, the police said today. Six Iranians and two policemen were reported injured in the incident on Friday.

title: RUTHERFORD IS NEXT
description: Rick Mears took the lead four laps from the end for his fifth victory of the season and second in a row in a race for Indianapolis-style cars by winning the Watkins Glen 200 today.

title: A BITTERSWEET OPENING FOR DANBURY STATE FAIR
description: ''This is the beginning of the end,'' said Fred G. Fearn as he snipped a red ribbon to symbolize the opening of the 112th - and last - Great Danbury State Fair.

title: REAGAN TO NAME PANEL OF 36 TO LEAD SHIFT TO VOLUNTARISM
description: President Reagan, who is moving to shift the burden of many community-aid programs from the Federal budget to private sources, is about to name a high-level panel to recommend a course of action.

title: Smith Shows His Speed in Knicks' Drill
description: DeWayne Scales had just grabbed an offensive rebound and was dribbling toward the basket when Randy Smith flashed across the court and took the ball from him. Minutes later, Smith did the same to two other big men during a scrimmage yesterday at Monmouth College, where the Knicks are training.

title: A U.S. BROKER SPEAKS, AND THE JAPANESE LISTEN
description: ''Frankly, I was never very good at foreign languages,'' Christopher C. Lapp said the other day. ''It's true.'' Coming from Mr. Lapp, a 26-year-old securities salesman in the Osaka office of Merrill Lynch, it seems an odd confession. Last month the husky young broker, a native of Sterling Heights, Mich., became one of a handful of Westerners ever to pass the salesman's test given by the Securities Dealers Association of Japan.

title: STAGE: 'NICHOLAS NICKLEBY' ARRIVES AS A TWO-PART, 8 1 2 HOUR DRAMA
description: AND so, after eight-and-a-half hours of ''The Life & Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' we go home with an indelible final image. The time is Christmas, and a grand Victorian happy ending is in full swing. Carolers are strewn three stories high about the stage, singing ''God Rest Ye Merry Gentlemen.'' Families have been reunited, couples joined together, plot ends neatly tied. And our young picaresque hero, Nicholas, has vanquished the two enemies who have stalked him for five acts - his usurious uncle, Ralph, and the cruel Yorkshire schoolmaster, Wackford Squeers.

title: Geer, DuBois Has A New Almay Task
description: Over at Geer, DuBois the happiness is over a new assignment from Almay Inc., a client of only four months.

title: Dr. Jeffrey Parsonnet Weds Kathy A. Cadow
description: Kathy Ann Cadow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Cadow of North Smithfield, R.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Jeffrey Parsonnet, son of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Parsonett of Millburn, N.J. Rabbi Arnold Belzer performed the ceremony in the Marquand Chapel of the Yale Divinity School in New Haven.

title: Sports World Specials; Football, Italian Style
description: A week from today, Americans will get their first look at a game that had its origins on a February day in 1530 in Florence, Italy, when the city was under seige. To show their indifference to the invaders, two teams of soldiers in full-dress regalia played a match of ''football in livery'' in full view of the enemy.

title: Coast Market Shortens Hours
description: Starting today, the Pacific Stock Exchange will close an hour earlier, at 1:30 P.M. Pacific time, or 4:30 P.M. Eastern. The exchange currently closes an hour and a half later than the major New York exchanges.

title: Soviet Naval Vessels Found in Gulf of Mexico
description: Soviet naval combat vessels have entered the Gulf of Mexico 10 times since 1969, once approaching within 20 nautical miles of the United States coastline, The Corpus Christi Caller-Times said today. A nautical mile is 15 percent longer than a statute mile.

title: Waiver Draft Set By Hockey Today
description: If a National Hockey League team is willing to gamble that there is life left in several veteran players, then that team will be busy tomorrow as the league holds its waiver draft.

title: ILLINOIS BELL TELEPHONE NAMES LONGTIME EMPLOYEE AS HEAD
description: William L. Weiss, 52, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company, an operating subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company based in Chicago. Mr. Weiss succeeded Charles Marshall, 52, who was elected a vice president of A.T.&T.

title: Burmese Voting Starts In Single-Party Election
description: The Burmese went to the polls today to elect 475 Members of Parliament and more than 187,000 officials of local bodies at various levels in a single-party election.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1981
description: International Adjustment of four currencies in Western Europe was agreed to in Brussels by the region's finance ministers, who are attempting to lower speculative pressure on foreign-exchange markets that has severely depressed the French franc and the Italian lira. At their special meeting, the ministers decided to raise the West German mark and the Dutch guilder by 5.5 percent and lower the value of the French and Italian currencies by 3 percent in relation to the currencies of other member countries of the European Monetary System. (Page A1, Col. 1.) The end of the I.R.A. hunger strike in an Ulster prison announced over the weekend will not diminish the Irish nationalist guerrillas' fight to force Britain from Northern Ireland, they said. During the strike, 10 prisoners starved themselves to death in attempt to get political status. The strike was called off when it became clear that the families of the surviving participants in the strike would not let them die. (A1:2-3.)

title: IN BURMA, NINE VILLAGES FLOAT WITH THE TIDE
description: The name of this village means ''Freeing the rabbit.'' No one knows why, but the name has stuck for generations, on whatever soil the village has stood. So has the population, which has followed Yon Hlut wherever the Irrawaddy River moved it.

title: DONALD KENT BROOKS
description: Donald Kent Brooks, a retired real-estate investment banker, died Friday at his home in Pelham, N.Y. He was 68 years old. He was a partner from 1952 to 1969 in Brooks, Harvey & Company, a concern that arranged financing for major buildings in New York City.

title: CONTRAST IN HIS TWO CAREERS
description: The playing career of Joe Torre was in sharp contrast to his record as manager of the Mets. Torre, the son of a baseball scout and the brother of Frank Torre, who played in the 1950's with the Milwaukee Braves and Philadelphia Phillies, seemed unlikely as a teen-ager to become a major leaguer, much less a star. ''Too fat, too slow, absolutely no future,'' read one scouting report on the youth from Brooklyn who weighed 240 pounds and stood 5 feet 9 inches tall at 16.

title: THE WESTERN-SANCTIONED SHACKLES ON POLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: FATIGUED ISLANDERS TIE WITH BRUINS
description: The Islanders, playing their fourth exhibition game in four days tonight, were looking forward to getting some rest on their flight to Los Angeles, where they will open the season Wednesday.

title: Both Pepsi and Avis Start New Campaigns
description: It was a big week at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn last week as two major clients, Pepsi-Cola and Avis Rent A Car announced new campaigns.

title: PRISONER TOTAL IN U.S. RISES 20,000 IN SIX MONTHS
description: The number of inmates in prisons in the United States rose more than 20,000 in the first half of 1981. This growth rate, if continued for six months, would produce the highest annual rate in 56 years, the Bureau of Justice Statistics announced today.

title: Border Governors Meet On Illeg al Alien Proble m
description: An aide to Gov. Bill Clements of Texas says the Government of Mexico is concerned about how illegal aliens are being treated in this country and that the subject will be the main focus of the second international meeting of the border governors of the United States and Mexico, which begins tomorrow.

title: HAGLER IS SEEKING BOUT WITH LEONARD
description: Marvin Hagler, the undisputed middleweight champion, has set his sights on boxing's only other holder of a unified title.

title: TO UPGRADE TEACHING OF SCIENCE AND MATH
description: To the Editor:

title: Dancer's Mother Aids Joffrey's 25th Season
description: As First Lady, Nancy Reagan, as a matter of course, accepts the honorary chairmanship of several committees and drives every year. But she has a special reason for serving as honorary chairman of the national committee fo r the 25th anniversary season of the Joffrey Ballet.

title: Pittsburgh Pedestrian Killed
description: A woman was crushed and five people were injured when a car went out of control last night, jumped a curb and plowed into a crowd outside Heinz Hall. A pedestrian, Mary Guehl of Pittsburgh, 55 years old, was dead on arrival at Mercy Hospital. A spokesman for the Allegheny County Morgue said the gas pedal had stuck in a car driven by Sarah Langer of Washington, Pa., as she was leaving a parking lot.

title: Helaine Newstead, 75, Expert On Early Arthurian Romances
description: Dr. Helaine Newstead, an expert on Arthurian legends and other medieval subjects, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 75 years old.

title: BOYCOTT OF SPONSERS ON TV IS CALLED OFF BY FUNDAMENTALISTS
description: The new television season is on, but aplanned boyco tt by the fundamentalist Coalition for Better Televisionis off.

title: TWO L.I. MEN FOUND IN FLAMES NEAR BURNING DINER IN NASSAU
description: Two men were engulfed in flames and suffered burns over 80 percent of their bodies during a suspicious fire in an empty diner early today, the police said.

title: 2 Former Diplomats Take Up Consulting
description: Having trouble with a Middle Eastern country? Is a South American nation giving you a hard time? Need someone to smooth your way in Europe, Asia or Africa? Donald F. McHenry and William J. vanden Heuvel may be just the men to see.

title: L.I. Man Killed in Cras h
description: A Smithtown man celebrating his 21st birthday lost control of his car in a chase with the police and crashed into a telephone pole today, killing his 19-year-old passenger instantly, the police said.

title: E.P.A. CHIEF DRAWS FIRE IN HARD JOB
description: The nation's capital, notoriously quick to leap to judgment and embrace caricature, has already found a title for Anne M. Gorsuch, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency for four months. She is called ''The Ice Queen.''

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1981; International
description: West European currencies are being realigned to damp rising trading speculation that has depressed the French franc and Italian lira. The West German mark and Dutch guilder were raised in value by 5.5 percent, while the value of the French and Italian currencies were lowered 3 percent against currencies of other European Monetary System members. (Page A1.)

title: EUROPEANS ADJUST CURRENCY VALUES IN FOUR COUNTRIES
description: West European finance ministers agreed today to realign the values of four major currencies in an effort to reduce speculative pressure on foreign exchange markets that has severely depressed the French franc and the Italian lira.

title: How Bad Is Crime? No One Knows
description: Each fall, the Federal Bureau of Investigation publishes a hefty best seller called ''Crime in the United States,'' which invariably causes alarmed comment: Crime up 9 percent in 1980, was the typical headline this year. And in his recent speech outlining crime policy, President Reagan picked up the tune: ''In the past decade, violent crime reported to police has increased by 59 percent.''

title: Feminist's Speech Canceled
description: Carlow College's faculty has narrowly approved the cancellation of a speech by a feminist who wants women to be free to decide whether to have abortions. Sister Jane Scully, president of the Roman Catholic college for 800 women, had canceled the talk by Sarah R. Weddington, a Texas lawyer who had served as President Carter's adviser on women.

title: German Aide to Visit China
description: The West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, left for China today to sound out the views of Chinese leaders on world problems. Mr. Genscher will stop over in Qatar, in the Persian Gulf, for a few hours.

title: TREASURY BORROWING DOMINATE NEW OFFERINGS
description: The Treasury is again a prominent borrower in the credit markets this week. It has scheduled auctions of three- and six-month bills on Monday and Friday, with a $3 billion sale of seven-year notes on Wednesday. The Friday bill auction will replace the regular Monday auction on Oct. 12, which is a public holiday.

title: Outdoors: Bit of Optimism for Waterfowler Hunters
description: WATERFOWL hunters in New York and other Atlantic Flyway states have a better chance for success this year than those in other areas of the country. That isn't promising much, however, because the outlook nationwide is that duck hunting will be worse than last year, and last year was poor.

title: Commodities; Markets An d Soviet Gr ain Pact
description: THAT the grain markets shrugged off the Administration's agreement to sell huge amounts of wheat and corn to the Soviet Union was no surprise. The news caused hardly a ripple, as reflected by the spot December corn and wheat futures prices, which rose a cent or two during the week,

title: Military Analysis
description: The strategic center of gravity of NATO is shifting to the south, the largest of the four military regions in the alliance. For most of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's 32 years, Central Europe has been considered the area of greatest risk. But now Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., the southern area commander, and other allied leaders believe that this has changed.

title: TV: 'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE' BACK WITH NEW CAST
description: TRAILING a reputation wildly exceeding its actual accomplishments, NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' returned last weekend with a new cast and personality. Rabid fans of the old shows may not be overly enthusiastic. The program is more slick, less adolescent, not as smugly ''clubby'' as in the giddy days of yore. On the other hand, the overall content was far funnier, on a sustained basis, than it has been for the last few years.

title: HEALTH CENTERS START STUDY TO DETERMINE BIRTH DEFECTS' CAUSE
description: Federal health officials have begun a $1.5 million study, involving 10,000 infants and their parents, to determine the cause of birth defects.

title: Volkswagen Plans
description: Volkswagen of America will move most of its Englewood Cliffs operation to Detroit in what corporate officials call an economy move. A Volkswagen spokesman, Tom McDonald, has confirmed that the company wants to relocate most of its 500 local employees but he said the move probably would take two to six years.

title: AIR TRAVELERS LEARN DELAY HAS BECOME PART OF ITINERARY
description: It is the start of a clear and sunny day, a good day for flying, and the taxiways of O'Hare International Airport are clear and uncluttered at 7:30 A.M. as planes move smartly to their takeoff positions and roar skyward. But by 8 o'clock, status screens in the O'Hare terminals are already beginning to tell a different story.

title: News Analysis
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 1 - It was damned if you do, damned if you don't. The veiled ultimatum put to Haiti was: Stop the illegal migration of Haitians to America or risk further economic distress by being bypassed by

title: U.S. ASKS CURB ON RECORDS RELEASE
description: The Reagan Administration plans to ask Congress to narrow the Freedom of Information Act by establishing new restrictions on the release of intelligence and law enforcement records and business information.

title: CURBING WINNING MANIA
description: I T happened last fall during a Pee Wee hockey game in Boston, when a spectator named Bobby Orr was appalled at what he saw. A middle-aged father was screaming from the sidelines at his 10-year-old son, who had missed a shot on goal. ''The boy came off the ice and, suddenly, he was crying his eyes out,'' said Mr. Orr, ''and I thought, 'Somehow, we have just got to stop this kind of thing.' ''

title: MOUNT ST. MICHAEL WINS, 12-7
description: Mickey Buddington scored two touchdowns and led Mount St. Michael to a 12-7 Catholic High Schools Football League triumph over Cardinal Spellman yesterday at McGovern Field in the Bronx. It was the first victory of the season for the Mount against one loss; Spellman dropped its second straight game.

title: Kansas City Demonstrators Protest at Reopened Hotel
description: A small group of demonstrators including relatives of victims of the Hyatt Regency Hotel disaster marched yesterday in front of the newly reopened hotel to protest the city's inspection procedures.

title: THE HARTFORD STAGE: 'ANTONY AND CLEOPATRA'
description: HARTFORD IN ''Antony and Cleopatra,'' which recently opened Mark Lamos's second season as artistic director of the Hartford Stage Company, Keith Baxter offers an Antony who is simultaneously seduced and liberated. He abandons his duties for sensual passion, but finds with Cleopatra a harmony and a purpose unknown to his world in Rome. He has a flair for self-dramatization, a characteristic that he shares with Cleopatra, but he is not one to delude himself. Mr. Baxter is an ironic Antony, and the anchor of a production that in other respects has a tendency to drift.

title: Jane Kramer Is Married to Dr. Daniel Joseph Carr; Jane Kramer Married To Dr. Daniel J. Carr
description: Jane Bookstaver Kramer, daughter of Louise Bookstaver of New York and the late Burton J. Bookstaver, was married yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel to Dr. Daniel Joseph Carr, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Carr Jr. of Indianapolis. The Rev. Dr. Peter Samson of the Community Unitarian Church in White Plains performed the ceremony.

title: U .S. SOPRANO WINS IN BRIT AIN
description: Jo-Ann Pickens, a 31-year-old soprano, became the first American to win the Benson and Hedges Gold Award for concert singers yesterday at the Maltings Concert Hall, 100 miles northeast of London.

title: NEW COURT OFFICE SEEKS TO CONSOLIDATE SERVICES
description: New York State's Office of Court Administration yesterday announced the creation of a new Office of Court Operational Services to consolidate a number of services, including the payrolls for more than 1,000 judges and 10,000 nonjudicial employees that have been spread among several offices.

title: HELPING WOMEN FACE LIFE AFTER A MASTECTOMY
description: At first, the new women come in slightly hunched over, one arm held against their side as if they were protecting something. They have had one of the most devastating kinds of surgery a woman can have -a mastectomy, the removal of a breast. The aftershock is emotional as well as physical.

title: NIXON'S AWACS VIEW ASSAILED
description: Israel's Cabinet today approved a proposal by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon for a modest reorganization of the military governments in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.

title: SHORTLY after 11 o'clock yesterday morning, Joe Torre received a message that Frank Cashen wanted to see him. Torre, cigar in hand, rose from behind his desk in the manager's office in Shea Stadium and went upstairs to see Cashen, the Mets' general manager.
description: ''Joe,'' said Cashen, ''this is never easy.'' ''I know,'' Torre said, ''don't worry about it.'' ''We've just decided to go in another direction. ...'' ''Would it be all right to manage this game?'' Torre referred to the last game of the season, against Montreal. ''Certainly. We don't have to announce this until later. You can leave the ball park in the seventh inning - and we'll hold conference tomorrow morning. ...''

title: Screening of Evidence Sought in Nazi Case
description: Federal prosecutors have asked a judge to screen for government secrets any evidence submitted by Otto von Bolschwing, 71 years old, who is accused of serving as an adviser to Adolf Eichmann in persecuting Jews.

title: KENNETH LOACH'S 'LOOKS AND SMILES'
description: KENNETH LOACH, the English director (''Kes'' and ''The Gamekeeper''), is not a fashionable film maker at the moment, but he is an exceedingly good one whose movies may one day provide a more accurate record of a nation's collective unconscious than the work of any other single director.

title: Burlington Talks
description: Burlington Industries said that it and Gulf and Western Indu stries were negotiating the sale of Burlington In dustries' hosiery division. The division has two plants,one in Burlin gton and another in Harriman, Tenn. G.& W., based in New York, is one of the nation's largest corporations, with interestsin oil, motio n pictures and textile products. Burlington Industries is the one of the nation's largest and most diversified manufacturer of textiles a nd related products.

title: BRONCOS SET BACK RAIDERS BY 17-0
description: Fred Steinfort kicked a 31-yard field goal, and Rick Parros ran 20 yards for a touchdown as the Denver Broncos posted a 17-0 victory over the Oakland Raiders today. It was the second straight shutout for Oakland, last season's Super Bowl winner.

title: 8 PUBLIC QUESTIONS ON BALLOT IN JERSEY
description: In addition to electing a governor and all 120 members of the State Legislat ure, voters in N ew Jersey will decide eight public questions, a record, when they g o to the polls on Nov. 3.

title: MET OPERA: 'RHEINGOLD'
description: SATURDAY evening's ''Das Rheingold'' at the Metropolitan Opera tookon a sudden vividness in Scene II with the ap pearance of Heinz Zednikas Loge. Mr. Zednik was busy and inventive wi thout boiling over into hyperactivity; and his clear, agile tenor cut through much of the murky vocalism around him. He along with Joce lyne Taillon as Erda were the most communicative voices on stage.

title: SENATE'S DEMOCRATS DEBATE STRATEGY
description: In search of a consensus, 40 of the Senate's 46 Democrats spent the weekend at a conference in the Monongahela National Forest debating whether to develop a grand strategy of legislative alternatives to the programs of the Reagan Administration.

title: JETS AND DOLPHINS PLAY TO A 28-28 TIE
description: The clock showed no time remaining in sudden-death overtime when Pat Leahy's 48-yard field-goal attempt headed toward the Orange Bowl goalpost tonight. The kick was short and wide, the game was over and so was the strange mastery the New York Jets had held over the Dolphins.

title: Ally & Gargano
description: Ally & Gargano has been assigned the corporate advertising account of the Bank of New York, the country's 18th largest bank with 191 branches in this state and overseas. The assignment was previously at Doremus & Company. Retail advertising for the bank will continue to be done by Cunningham & Walsh.

title: WEEKLY PAPER IN MISSISSIPPI IS PRAISED BUT SHUTS ANYWAY
description: A small but muscular 50-cent-a-week newspaper, The Capital Reporter, slipped out of existence here last week, and its editor, Wilson F. Minor, slipped out of Jackson this weekend for a vacation on the Alabama Gulf coast, taking with him a pocket full of condolences from Southern politicians, journalism professors and nationally known writers.

title: WALTRIP WINS 400
description: Darrell Waltrip won the Holly Farms 400 at North Wilkesboro Speedway today and moved closer to his first Winston Cup Grand National stock car driving championship. Waltrip finished a lap ahead of his nearest competitor.

title: QUEBEC MEETS DEFIANCE IN ENFORCING LANGUAGE LAW
description: A defiant 68-year-old war veteran who runs a shop in the western part of the Montreal region appeared in court recently to answer criminal charges that he refused to change his English sign to a French one.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan and the Republican Party are facing a subtle yet serious political problem illuminated by a jarring confluence of statistics reported last week.

title: NEW JERSEY ZINC APPOINTS PRESIDENT
description: The New Jersey Zinc Company, founded in Newark in 1848 and acquired by Gulf and Western Industries in 1966, is again an independent company. Following a leveraged buy-out of most of the zinc concern's assests by its management team and others, William E. Flaherty has been named president and chief executive officer of New Jersy Zinc, based in Palmerston, Pa. Mr. Flaherty, 48 years old, had been executive vice president of Gulf and Western's natural resources group.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE MAN IN THE CROWD. Confessions of a Sports Add ict. By Stanley Cohen. 266 pages. Random House. $13.50.

title: U.S. WEIGHS SUITS CHARGING UNEQUAL MINORITY EDUCATION
description: The Justice Department is considering filing suits that would charge some school boards with providing inferior education in schools where most of the students are black or members of other minorities, the Reagan Administration's top civil rights enforcement officer said tonight.

title: WOMEN SPONSORING TORAH
description: Thousands of Hasidic Jews watched yesterday as a scribe began his work on a new Torah at the Congregation Lubavitch in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: PAKISTAN RAIDS DRUG FACTORY
description: The police raided a large hashish packing factory in the basement of a house here and seized about $30 million worth of drugs, police sources said today. The officers reportedly confiscated 5,900 pounds of hashish, 44 pounds of hashish oil and 4.4 pounds of heroin.

title: Ladies' Home Journal To Cut Its Rate Base
description: With its February issue, Ladies' Home Journal will cut its circulation rate base, which was as high as seven million in 1970, by 500,000, to five million, and although its page rate will be dropped its cost per thousand will be increased for both four color and black and white.

title: Polaroid Expects Drop in Earnings
description: The Polaroid Corporation said that its third-quarter earnings are likely to be down sharply from the $13.4 million, or 31 cents a share, that it earned in the second quarter and the $20.6 million, or 63 cents a share, that it earned in the third quarter a year ago.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A LITTLE BIT INDEPENDENT

title: NEW MEDICAL PROGRAMS OFFER ROUNDED EDUCATION
description: Gregory Irvine was admitted to medical school directly from high school. By joining an experimental program at the University of Michigan he escaped the competitive scramble for admission to medical school.

title: Manager to Leave At Electric Boat
description: P. Takis Veliotis, 55 years old, will soon leave as vice president and general manager of the Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation, a major submarine builder for the Navy with headquarters in Groton, Conn., the company said yesterday.

title: Browns Drop Kicker
description: The Cleveland Browns released Dave Jacobs, the former Jet who beat out the veteran Don Cockroft for the place-kicking job at training camp but who converted only four of 12 field-goal attempts during the regular season. Coach Sam Rutigliano said he had not yet made a decision on Jacobs's replacement, but he seemed to be leaning toward the rookie Steve Cox, who already punts and kicks off for the Browns.

title: ROYAL TRUSTCO BID FOR FLAGSHIP ENDED
description: Royal Trustco Ltd., the Toronto-based parent of Canada's largest trust company group, announced today that it had broken off negotiations for the $305 million (in United States currency) acquisition of Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami because of ''significant adverse changes in capital markets'' since agreement in principle for the acquisition was announced July 20.

title: Firestone Facing Huge Tire Loss
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said it was facing a potential ''multimillion-dollar loss'' because it produced up to 250,000 defective tires last mont h.

title: BRANDT CAUTIONS THIRD WORLD
description: Former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany urged developing countries yesterday not to reject out of hand the insistence of the Reagan Administration that future international aid to them be linked with their own economic reforms and austerity.

title: Japan Studies Coal Sources
description: Japan is considering increasing coal imports from the United States and other coal-producing countries, an official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Saudis Said to Permit Israelis to Rescue Ship
description: Israel, using the United States as a gobetween to gain Saudi cooperation, rescued a grounded Israeli missile ship from a sandbar off the coast of Saudi Arabia, Israeli military sources said today.

title: Yeager Inducted Into Space Hall of Fame
description: His ''Aw, shucks'' drawl with its resonance of calm in the face of disaster has been echoed, it is said, by a generation of admiring airline pilots. So it came as no surprise that Charles Yeager did not sound excited on Saturday when he was inducted into the International Space Hall of Fame in Alamogordo, N.M.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: FOR nearly two full days, 21-year-old Michael Bates, who had eight fingers severed by an iron press in a factory accident, lived under general anesthesia in a ''surgical marathon.'' It lasted 46 1/2 hours while a team of 44 doctors, nurses and technicians at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston reattached his fingers.

title: Texas Oil Note Offering
description: The Texas Oil and Gas Corporation said today th at it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission fo r an offering of $75 million of 10-year notes, underwritten by the First Boston Corporation, Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. and Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. The company said proceeds woul d be used to reduce short-term debt.

title: CONTROL OF AWACS RULED OUT BY HAIG
description: Secretary of Stat e Ale xander M. Haig Jr. told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that United States-SaudiArabian joint command of five Airborne Warnin g and Control System planes that President Reagan is trying to sel l to the Saudis ''is simply not possible at this time.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.00-19.50** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Topics Longer, Cleaner; Marathon Theater
description: ''Nicholas Nickleby'' is compelling theater. But it also asks a lot of its audiences - $100 for a ticket and eight and a half hours of persistence in two sittings.

title: Linn J. Boyd, 86, Researcher And a Professor of Medicine
description: Dr. Linn John Boyd, a researcher and professor of medicine at New York Medical College for more than 30 years, died on Sunday at Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Princeton to Curb Use of Its Library
description: Princeton University's extensive Firestone Me morial Library will be declared off limits to all but students and fa culty members next year because of thefts, vandalism and a shortageof space, university officials say. After 33 ye ars of unlimited access, the library plans restrictions starting in S eptember 1982.

title: N.F.L. FAVORING THE RUN
description: A move away from frequent passing and back to the running game, as a means of controlling the ball and perhaps hiding a dubious defense, has begun to show in pro football. That is understandable as the delicate balance between offense and defense continues to take on different shadings in the National Football League's keen competition.

title: FRESNO MAYOR IN RACE FOR SENATE-AND TV TIME
description: Mayor Daniel K. Whitehurst of Fresno today made the obligatory dawn-to-dusk state tour to announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page on Saturday gave an incorrect price for a massage at Elizabeth Arden. The cor- rect price is $30.

title: 'NICKLEBY' CAST SAYS OF NEW YORK: 'LOVE THE AUDIENCES! HATE THE RENT!'
description: WHEN the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of ''The Life & Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' began previews for New York audiences a week and a half ago, it became instantly clear that something was amiss: American audiences were responding differently from London audiences. Changes were needed and time was short, so Trevor Nunn and John Caird, the co-directors, had to work fast.

title: AIR FORCE PLANNING RESPONSE TO JUDGES ON SPYING CHARGES
description: The Air Force will respond ''in due course'' to a Court of Military Appeals demand to show cause why spying charges against a young nuclear missile officer should not be dismissed, a spokesman said today.

title: Professor's Trial On Drugs Upheld
description: The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to hear an appeal by Dr. John Buettner-Janusch, a former chairman of the anthropology department at New York University, who was convicted of manufacturing drugs in the department's laboratory.

title: Forms Available For Brownstones
description: Applications for the city's lottery for 12 brownstones in Harlem were picked up at a brisk pace, according to the community boards involved. More than 9 0 people picked up applications at Community Board 9, 530 West 133d Street, during the first four hours they were available.

title: Stepping Out for a 102d Birthday Celebration
description: She has already received some sheets and pillow cases and a pair of ''beautiful bedroom slippers,'' not to mention birthday greetings from such admirers as President Reagan, Vice President Bush, Governor Carey and Mayor Koch. But the real celebration will not come until tonight when her son, Norman, takes her to dinner at the ''21'' Club.

title: Court Stops Knoetze
description: The Supreme Court upheld the State Department's revoc ation of Kallie Knoetze's visa. Knoetze is the white h eavyweight boxer from South Africa whose presence in the United Sta tes was opposed by civilrights groups, partly because as a policeman he once shot a black youth during a racial disturbance in Soweto.

title: POLAND ENFORCES PRICE INCREASES
description: The Government today brushed aside protests by the independent union Solidarity and put into effect increases in tobacco prices that raised the cost of a pack of high-quality cigare ttes to the equivalent of nearly $2. The action drew angry sp eeches from delegates at the union congress here.

title: DON'T BLAME POLICE FOR A CLEARLY OBSCURE RULE
description: To the Editor:

title: MONTH-END AUTO SALES DOWN 0.9%
description: With some rebates and incentive programs expiring, sales of new cars by the Big Three auto makers for the last 10 days in September fell by nine-tenths of 1 percent, the companies reported today.

title: IONS CREATED BY WINDS MAY PROMPT CHANGES IN EMOTIONAL STATES
description: FOR many years it has been suspected that certain weather conditions, notably such hot, dry winds as the foehn in Europe, the sharav in Israel and the Santa Ana in southern California, affect people's mood and health, even precipitating suicides, crimes and accidents.

title: Leadership Magazine Campaign Scheduled
description: The first ad campaign from NH&S/ Issues and Answers division at Ne edham, Harper & Steers for the Leadership Network is scheduled to ru n next Monday. The theme, straight from the typewriter of Barry Bi ederman, president of the unit, is ''If you want to reach brainy pe ople, make a brainy buy.''

title: Lloyds Stock Purchase
description: Lloyds Bank Ltd. said today that it held 71.6 million, or 60.3 percent, of the ordinary issued shares of Lloyds and Scottish Ltd. following the close of its offer for the finance and leasing group. Acceptances totaled 11.99 million shares, or 10.09 percent, of the issued shares, Lloyds said, adding that it already held 59.64 million shares before the posting of the offer.

title: Advertising; Merger Lasts With 2 Leaders
description: CONSIDERING the strong-willed people involved, it is quite surprising to some that the merger that formed Jordan, Case & McGrath on Jan. 1 has not only lasted but also appears to be prospering. And that's with two guys running the place and no chief executive.

title: KOCH CALLED 'STOOGE' BY IZVESTIA BUT HE TAKES IT AS 'COMPLIMENT'
description: Edward I. Koch may have secured both the Democratic and Republican nominations for re-election next month as Mayor of New York City, but he ran into a blast of opposition today from one of the world's most powerful newspapers, Izvestia.

title: CAROLE BARON SET AS DELL PUBLISHER
description: Carole Baron, editor in chief of Crown Publishers since 1979, has been named publisher of the Dell Publishing Company.

title: 2 Men Go on Trial In Dominica Coup Plot
description: The trial of two men accused of financing a plot to take over the Caribbean island nation of Dominica began today in Federal District Court here.

title: COURT TO HEAR STATE-COMPANY TAX CASES
description: The Supreme Court, opening its 1981-82 term, today placed on its agenda two cases with tax consequences for most sizable companies. The Court agreed to decide whether states may tax the income from dividends, interest and capital gains earned by companies that do business locally but that have their headquarters in other states.

title: TORRE'S CAST REGROUPING
description: The Mets pursued the search for a successor to Joe Torre yesterday while Torre and his deposed coaches scattered, with hints that they might appear as a unit next season on some other team.

title: Kuwait Giving Oil Discount
description: Kuwait is mainta ining its official oil price at $35. 50 a barrel but is giving customers a discount of more than $1 a bar rel, Sheik Ali Khalifi al-Sabah, the oil minister, said in interviews published today.

title: Deadly Colors
description: Tree swallows stick a white feather upright at the back of their nests, in a dark cozy hole high in a tree, to help them navigate as they swoop in to land at dusk. Possibly it also gives a cheerful cast to the coming of the night - much as bright fall colors ease us into accepting the winter's short, cold days and indoor life. Whole hills of sugar maples turn rose-colored, and three weeks later, as if to wind things up, the larches go all gold.

title: A HARD LOOK AT COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: JUSTICES TO STUDY DENIAL OF BAIL ON SEX VIOLENCE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Constitution allows courts to deny bail on the basis of the crime of which a defendant is accused.

title: Woman of the Year
description: Chris Evert Lloyd was named the professional sportswoman of the year by the Women's Sports Foundation yesterday, and the honor did not include her 1981 victory at Wimbledon. Mrs. Lloyd, honored in New York last night at the foundation's annual dinner, was judged on her performances from June 1980 to June 1981. During that time, she won the 1980 United States Open and was runner-up in the 1980 Wimbledon.

title: Officials Seek Support For N ew Port Facilities
description: Officials of New York City, its harbor and the surrounding region began a campaign yesterday to seek support for a $520 million plan to build three terminals on Staten Island and in New Jersey for ships carrying coal and oil.

title: Construction Workers Protest Foreign Labor
description: Six boats carrying disgruntled construction workers sailed into the Santa Barbara Channel yesterday to protest Texaco's use of foreign labor to install an offshore natural gas platform.

title: Disaster Aid Ruled Out
description: Federal officials said today that as many as 155 Michigan communities could be ineligible for disaster aid after last week's torrential rain because local officials never signed the required flood insurance agreements.

title: 9 PERCENT OF EVERYONE WHO EVER LIVED IS ALIVE NOW
description: BARRY GOLDENSOHN, a poet on the faculty of Hampshire College, was reading a poem early this year and came across lines that jarred his credulity. ''. .. there are now more of us/Alive than ever have been dead,'' William Matthews had written in a poem published in the periodical, ''Vegetable Box 4.''

title: German Oil Use Down
description: West German consumption of major oil products fell an average of 13.7 percent in the first eight months of 1981 compared with the 1980 period, the Office for Trade and Industry said today.

title: U.S. WON'T BACK A KEY CITY PLAN FOR SOUTH BRONX
description: A city-backed plan that has long been regarded as a key feature in the protracted efforts to revitalize the South Bronx has been rejected by the Reagan Administration.

title: Canadian Controllers Suspended 1 to 3 Days
description: More than 150 Canadian air traffic controllers are being suspended for refusing to handle planes from the United States in August, Dave Austin, a spokesman for Transport Canada, said today.

title: DR. FRANK E.  FIERRO
description: Dr. Frank E. Fierro, former professor and chairman of the department of anesthesiology at New York Medical College and Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital, died yesterday at Mercy Hospital in Scranton, Pa.

title: JOB GROWTH SINCE 1976 IS MOSTLY IN MANHATTAN
description: New York City has added about 135,000 jobs in the private sector since the economic crisis of the 1970's, almost all of them in Manhattan, according to new figures by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: MILAN: STARRING ARMANI
description: Giorgio Armani is clearly the hero of the first days of the Italian ready-to-wear showings for spring and summer 1982, which began here over the weekend. Like a Renaissance man, he dominated the day's activities, showing his own collection to small groups in his offices on the Via Durini. He favors loose shirts and bright colors, giving a distinctive look to contemporary clothes.

title: WEAK ECONOMY WOULD LIMIT BUDGET CUTS, STOCKMAN SAYS
description: David A. Stockman, the budget director, said today that if a weak economy caused Federal revenues to fall short of forecasts, he would not seek additional spending cuts just to prevent the budget deficit from growing.

title: 'MASSACHUSETTS' 'OTHER SENATOR' URGING A REALISTIC LIBERALISM
description: At first he called it the new liberalism. Then he tried humanistic realism. Finally, though he concedes the term does not especially please him, he settled on compassionate realism.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 6, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: EAGLES (5-0) BEAT FALCONS BY 16-13
description: The Philadelphia Eagles, pro football's only undefeated and untied team, won their fifth game of the season tonight by defeating the Atlanta Falcons, 16-13, in a tense struggle before a record crowd of 71,488 at Veterans Stadium. It is Philadelphia's best start since it joined the National Football League in 1933.

title: BYELORUSSIAN BISHOP WORKED WITH EXILES
description: Bishop Caslau Sipovich, the Apostolic Visitator for the Byelorussians in exile since his appointment by Pope John XXIII in 1960, collapsed and died in London Sunday while celebrating the 10th anniversary of the Francis Skaryna Byelorussian Library and Museum, which he founded. He was 66 years old.

title: Steel Output Off 3.4%
description: Steel production fell to 2.1 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, down 3.4 percent from the previous week's 2.2 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Efforts to Save a Child Help 6 Other Patients
description: Six patients have received organ transplants because donors who wanted to help a dying 2 1/2-year-old girl did not meet the criteria, but hospital officials said today that no suitable liver donor had been found for the child.

title: ROYALS BEAT INDIANS TO CLINCH WEST TITLE
description: The Kansas City Royals, who finished fifth in the American League West during the first half of the season, clinched the second-half title today with a 9-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: W.R. Grace Sets P lant in Germany
description: W.R. Grace & Company said it would start construction immediately of a multimillion-dollar plant in Worms, West Germany, to manufacture fluid cracking catalysts used to refine crude oil into light-grade petroleum products.

title: RETREATING IN THE BRONX
description: The South Bronx is now a household synonym for abandonment, hellish crime, devastation, terminal urban disease and, in the visual i mageryof some of it s quarters, saturation bombing. For some time, however, the synonyms have been spreading north and west through the rest of the Bronx - a governmental unit whose population, 1.17 million, is larger than t hose of Dallas, Milwaukee or Boston.

title: Cleanup Scheduled In Garment Area
description: The Sanitation Department will send a force with brooms to Manhattan's garment district to help rid the area of trash, Commissioner Norman Steisel announced.

title: Gold Idea Is Attacked
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, yesterday attacked the idea that the United States should return to a gold standard.

title: Campbell-Mithun Appointment Canceled
description: William D. Dunlap, 43-year-old president of MCA Advertising, who was scheduled to become president of Campbell-Mithun Advertising, a Ted Bates/Worldwide subsidiary in his native Minneapolis, has called off the move because of a ''sudden illness'' in his family.

title: Appliance Park Recall by G.E.
description: About 10,000 workers at General Electric Company's giant Appliance Park here have been recalled from two-week furloughs, but 900 G.E. employees with the least seniority face indefinite layoffs beginning Nov. 9.

title: News Analysis
description: As part of its effort to salvage the Awacs sale to Saudi Arabia, the Reagan Administrati on has become involved in a confrontation with Israel and its Americ an supporters that could have serious implications for future Un ited States policy in the Middle East.

title: SIERRA CLUB SUIT TERMS WESTWAY PERILOUS TO FISH
description: An environmental group is pressing its efforts to block construction of the Westway, contending that the landfill part of the project could seriously harm striped bass and other fish in the Hudson River.

title: Jack Dolph, 53, Former Head Of Basketball League, Dead
description: Jack Dolph, commissioner of the American Basketball Association from 1969 to 1972, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Riverside, Conn. He was 53 years old.

title: Salvadoran Army Opens Drive Against Rebels
description: The army has begun a new offensive against guerrilla forces in the northern province of Chalatenango near the Honduran border, the military authorities said today.

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The yr-ago shr earnings have been restated

title: Index; International
description: Mexico's '82 election: All over but the shouting A2 Sudanese, dispersing power, disband parliaments A3 Britain seems to succeed in gaining support on Namibia plan A3 Poland enforces price increases A4 Around the World A5 Brandt cautions third world on aid A6 Text of Haig statement to Senate panel on sale of Awacs A8 Excerpts from New York speech by Israel's Foreign Minister A10 Government/Politics Fresno Mayor joins race for Sen- ate in California A19 Curb on identification of covert agencies faces vote A22 Supreme Court Roundup A23 Congressional veto power faces High Court review A23 Reagan said budget is not ba- rometer of social concern A28 Puerto Rico coming to grips with deep cuts in Federal aid A29 Koch is sharply criticized in Soviet newspaper article B1 Minorities prevail in five New York court choices B4 Washington Talk Briefing A24 Sen. Packwood opposes Awacs and his party's President A24 Royal box at Redskins games is considered a seat of power A24 Presidential stands on crime, 1905-1981 A24 General Around the Nation A14 Biologist in key role in battle against fruit fly A14 Death in ship 's brig has resulted in two courts-martial A18 Life in some New York suburbs includes a little farming B2 Environmental group pressing efforts to block Westway B7 Science Times Ions on the wind may cause emotional changes C1 Maya ingenuity is shown again, this time by their agriculture C1 How many humans have ever lived? 9% are still alive C1 About Education C1 Science Watch C2 Science Q&A C3 The Doctor's World: Importance of the anesthesiologist C3 New medical programs for a better-rounded physician C4 Science Library C5 Religion Cody case reported followed closely by Vatican A19 Industry/Labor Newspaper strike in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., enters fourth year A14 New York City's job growth has been largely in Manhattan B3 Arts/Entertainment ''Nickleby'' cast adopted last-minute accent changes C7 Marx Brothers heirs win suit on ''Day in Hollywood'' C7 Two books on recollections of Russia are reviewed C9 Montserrat Caballe sings with the Philharmonic C9 Three postmodern choreographers at Minneapolis festival C18 Barbara Cook's cabaret act packs the Savoy C18 Gary Coleman loses round in TV salary battle C19 Style Notes on Fashion B8 Milan: starring Armani B8 Affirmative action is backed B8 Obituaries Fred Lindstrom, ex-New York Giant, baseball hall of famer D31 Sports Royals beat Indians and clinch second-half title C11 Questions raised about Jets' last-minute strategy C11 Torre's coaching crew and Mets regroup C11 Rangers expect Rogers, new center, to be big asset C11 New opponent named for Joe Frazier C12 Canadiens lose Lambert to Buffalo in waiver draft C12 Dave Anderson on the Mets C13 Yankees head into playof fs in buoyant mov e C13 Giants plan to run with Carpenter at fullback C14 Features/Notes Man in the News: Ali Khameini, Iran's new President A12 Notes on People B11 Going Out Guide C6 Sports People C14 News Analysis Bernard Gwertzman on the tension between U.S. and Israel A1 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A30

title: POWER, IF NOT GLORY, FILLS BOX AT REDSKINS' GAME
description: The San Francisco 49ers led the Redskins, 14-0, in the early stages of the football game that would produce Washington's fifth defeat in five starts this season. Brainard Warner 3d, a Washington lawyer, brought a message to Jack Kent Cooke, the Skins' principal owner, from R. Sargent Shriver. ''Sarge says don't forget Yale was down, 12-0, in the first quarter yesterday, and we won.''

title: POWER OF CONGRESS TO VETO ACTION OF EXECUTIVE BRANCH FACES STUDY
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to settle a dispute that has hurt relations between the White House and Congress for nearly 50 years: whether Congress has the constitutional authority to block executive branch action by exercising the socalled legislative veto.

title: Walter Mehring, 85, Writer; His Sarcasm Enraged Nazis
description: Walter Mehring, a German-born American writer whose biting ballads infuriated the Nazis, died Saturday. He was 85 years old.

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1981
description: International Israel assailed Saudi Arabia, accusing it of being a ''major obstacle'' to peace in the Middle East and of ''a fanatic hatred of Jews and Israel.'' Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir made the charges in a 2,000-word address to the Foreign Policy Association in Manhattan four days after President Reagan suggested at a news conference that Israel might be interfering in American foreign policy by opposing the proposed sale of Awacs aircraft to Saudi Arabia. (Page A1, Column 5.) France will freeze some prices and take other steps to try to reduce its annual inflation rate to 10 percent from 14 percent, thus enabling French industry to take full advantage of the franc's devaluation. Besides the price freeze, Finance Minister Jacques Delors announced plans to defer some public spending increases and to seek wage guidelines with unions. (A1:2-3.)

title: THE SAVOY: BARBARA COOK
description: oriented role of pop chanteuse, for she exudes a dignified regality th at seems neithe r stuffy nor flamboyant.And of course, there is the voice, a magnific ent, reedy soprano that she wields with tremendous dynamic control.

title: IMPERIAL HARVEST
description: IMPERIAL HARVEST: Emperor Hirohito of Japan using a sickle to reap a rice crop in a field near the Imperial Palace in Tokyo. The new rice is to be donated to the Ise Grand Shrine for the annual harvest festival.

title: SUDANESE, DISPERSING POWER, DISBAND PARLIAMENTS
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan dissolved his country's two parliaments today in a move that Sudanese officials described as a further step in Mr. Nimeiry's plan to decentralize power in the vast and troubled nation.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
REFORGING U.S. HULLS
description: No industry in the United States is more threatened by misunderstanding and neglect than the maritime industry, which has seen its workforce cut in half over the last 20 years and its foreign trade reduced by more than 10 times since World War II, and which, under recent calls in Washington to eliminate Government subsidies to the shipping business, would be even more severely whittled away.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MEXICO'S 1982 ELECTION: ALL OVER BUT THE SHOUTING
description: ''Be ready, peasants of Mexico!'' a young politician shouted as he struggled to excite the 400 or so people bused in that morning from the nearby state of Morelos. ''He will soon be with you, your candidate, the man who will advance the Mexican revolution!''

title: QUESTIONS RAISED ON TIE
description: Sixteen Jets, more than a third of the players in action yesterday at Miami, received medical treatment today for aches and pains that were suffered in vain.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including net realized capital gains of $5,607,000 for the qr and $8,002,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including net realized capital gains of $376,000 for the qr and $1,017,000 for the 6mo

title: WHY BUILD THE MX AT ALL?
description: Building 100 MX missiles and hardening existing silos for basing them obviously is less costly and more sensible than building 200 of these huge (10 warheads) weapons and scattering them among 4,600 shelters across most of Nevada and Utah.

title: KUWAIT SET TO BUY A U.S. OIL DRILLER
description: The Kuwaiti Government has agreed to buy a big American oil drilling and production company for $2.5 billion in cash. The purchase of the Santa Fe International Corporation of Alhambra, Calif., announced yesterday, would apparently constitute the largest single Arab investment in the United States.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Retain Road Safety Programs
description: Representatives of more than two dozen state agencies and community groups urged the Federal Government today not to eliminate their individual highway safety programs.

title: TEXT OF HAIG STATEMENT ON AWACS TO SENATE PANEL
description: Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today on the Reagan Administration's proposal to sell five Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia: Special to the New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I found out a long time ago that it was more important for me to convince the Commander in Chief than for the Commander in Chief to convince me.'' - Gen. David C. Jones, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. (A1:4.)

title: Korean Ship Contracts
