description: The value of foreign shipbuilding contracts won by South Korean concerns totaled $1.58 billion for 55 ships in the first eight months of this year, more than twice the $748 million for 44 vessels in the comparable 1980 period, officials of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry said today. Korean companies are also negotiating contracts for 47 ships worth $741 million, they said, adding that the ministry expects the 1981 target of $2 billion of ship construction to be surpassed.

title: British Gas Ends Deal
description: British Gas Ltd., the state-owned utility, said today that it had stopped buying Algerian liquefied natural gas for the time being after failing to settle on a new price when a nine-month interim agreement expired on Sept. 30. Industry sources said British Gas had thus joined a growing number of gas importers that are waiting for a lead on pricing to emerge from current negotiations between the Algerians and their biggest buyers, the French. British Gas has been buying a modest volume of about 100 million cubic feet daily of Algerian liquefied natural gas for an average $4.60 per million British thermal units.

title: Swedish Hero Is Declared Honorary U.S. Citizen
description: President Reagan signed a resolution today making the Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg an honorary American citizen.

title: Polaroid Says Kodak's Entry In to Instant Photos Injured It
description: In a court battle over the invention of the instant camera, the Polaroid Corporation today accused its rival, the Eastman Kodak Company, of violating its patents in a way that ''strikes at the very heart of Polaroid's business.''

title: Italy 4-1 Cup Winner
description: Italy completed a 4-1 victory over South Korea in the 1982 Davis Cup tournament today.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: SHOCK and anger linger at Pittsburgh's Carnegie-Mellon University over the mysterious death of one of its junior faculty members on July 3 during a visit to his native Taiwan. Since his death, other students from Taiwan have written from a number of American campuses to complain about alleged spying on them by agents of their governments.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard RUSSIAN JOURNAL. By Andrea Lee. 239 pages. Random House. $13.50. FROM THE YAROSLAVSKY STATION: Russia Perceived. By Elizabeth Pond. 296 pages. Universe Books. $12.95.

title: REAGAN DRAFT ORDER SAID TO ALLOW WIDER INTELLIGENCE ACTIVITY IN U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration, after months of internal debate, has drafted a proposal that would grant American intelligence agencies broad authority to infiltrate domestic organizations and to review bank, medical, telephone and other private records, according to Congressional sources.

title: GETTING FIT IS NOT EASY FOR POLICE IN TRAINING
description: Judging by the Police Academy's newest class of recruits, New York's finest, surprisingly, are not necessarily New York's fittest. The 1,100 men and women in the class are eager and, typically, more than half have some college education and a quarter have college degrees. But the academy's commander, Deputy Chief Michael J. McNulty, said, ''A substantial number can't run - or do sit-ups or push-ups.''

title: WHERE THEY STOOD ON CRIME (1905-1981)
description: ''It's time for honest talk, for plain talk. There has been a breakdown in the criminal justice system in America. It just plain isn't working.

title: KHAMENEI IS PROCLAIMED WINNER OF IRANIAN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION
description: A 42-year-old Iranian clergyman, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, was proclaimed President of Iran today, the third chief of state in 21 months. He is the first clergyman to hold the post.

title: GASOLINE FUTURES GO ON SALE
description: The first market in leaded regular gasoline futures opened yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with 305 contracts of 42,000 gallons each changing hands during the session at prices ranging from a high of 99.75 cents a gallon to a low of 99 cents at the close.

title: DANCE: 'BREAKING' INDOORS
description: GOOD dance can come from anywhere, even from the streets themselves. As proof, there was Saturday night's ''Graffiti Rock'' concert at the Kitchen, a program devoted to breaking, a dance form that has flourished in recent years quite literally on the sidewalks of New York.

title: Q. Why is toothpaste sweet and what is it sweetened with?
description: A. In order for toothpaste to be effective, it must be used regularly. Research has indicated that a sweet taste encourages the regular use of toothpaste.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
European Oil Costs Rising
description: European importers are paying the equivalent of up to $11 a barrel more for their oil than they were in January because of the increase in strength of the United States dollar since then, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said today.

title: TENANTS' GROUP ASSAILS END OF LOFT MORATORIUM
description: The end of the one-year moratorium on evictions and sizable rent increases for lofts in New York City have created hardship for many loft tenants in Brooklyn and Manhattan, a State Assemblyman and officials of a tenants' lobbying group said yesterday.

title: MARCUS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 20
description: The shr earnings and the shrs outstndg have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock divd declared Aug 14, 1981 and paid on Sept 21

title: zf PLAYBOY IN LONDON LOSES CASINO FIGHT
description: A court ruling today lifted the gambling licenses of Playboy's two most profitable London casinos, charging that they had engaged in gambling improprieties.

title: UNDER PRESSURE, U.S. PANEL AVOIDS TAKING STAND ON REVENUE SHARING
description: An influential Federal study group that monitors Federal-state policies and programs bowed today to intense White House pressure and sidestepped taking a stand on President Reagan's proposal to slash revenue-sharing funds.

title: Cubs Interested in Green
description: Dallas Green, manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, is one of several candidates for the job of president and general manager of the Chicago Cubs, according to Andrew McKenna, the Cubs' new chairman.

title: BRIEFING
description: THE White House is plainly delighted at former President Richard M. Nixon's strong support for the proposed sale of Airborne Warning and Control Systems planes to Saudi Arabia. Although White House officials denied that they prompted Mr. Nixon, President Reagan's security adviser, Richard V. Allen, knew that the former President's statement was about to be disclosed over the weekend. Mr. Allen, in fact, holds private briefings for Mr. Nixon on security matters once every month or so, and their most recent session was last week.

title: Scott Acquisition
description: The Scott Paper Company said it had acquired Amer ican Convenience Products Inc. of Milwaukee, a producer of paper prod ucts for the food service market.

title: GARY COLEMAN SET BACK IN PAY FIGHT
description: Gary Coleman, the diminutive 13-year-old star of NBC's ''Diff'rent Strokes,'' lost a round in court last week. Mr. Coleman is seeking a renegotiation of his contract with Tandem Productions, producers of the series. He earns $30,000 an episode, and his lawyers are seeking a raise and a share of the show's future profits from syndication.

title: HOUSE VOTE BACKS KEEPING KEY PARTS OF 1965 VOTING ACT
description: The House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved renewal of the Voting Rights Act tonight after defeating a series of amendments aimed at weakening the legislation that has governed the nation's electoral process since 1965. The vote was 389 to 24.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ISRAELI FOREIGN MINISTER'S SPEECH
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a speech delivered yesterday by Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to the Foreign Policy Association at the Hilton Hotel in New York:

title: 2 OF 28 CASES TRIED AFTER DEATH IN SHIP'S BRIG
description: With 19 of 28 cases dispatched, only two members of th e U.S.S. Ranger's crew have been court-martialed as a result of an investigation into the death of a sailor in the carrier's bri g.

title: DESPITE SLUMP, ACQUISITIONS SOUGHT BY DAYTON MALLEABLE
description: At a glance, Dayton Malleable Inc. seems like just another troubled smokestack in the Middle West's foundry industry. The company's biggest plants are operating in the red, its main market is the struggling domestic auto industry and its over-thecounter stock is virtually ignored by Wall Street.

title: Grand Street in Debut As Literary Quarterly
description: Grand Street, a new literary quarterly, makes its debut this month with a portion of the pre-World War II Paris diary of the novelist Glenway Wescott as a highlight of the first issue. There are also articles, stories and poems by Alice Munro, Ted Hughes, James Salter, Penelope Gilliatt, John Hollander, James Michie, Northrop Frye, W.S. Merwin and others.

title: John C. Korn, Ex-Aide For the Stock Exchange
description: John C. Korn, a former secretary of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday at his home in Rutherford, N.J. He was 84 years old. Mr. Korn, who spent more than 50 years working on Wall Street as an employee and member of the stock exchange, was born in New York City an d went to work for the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company in 1914.

title: VACU-DRY CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Delhi Oil Flow Report
description: Delhi Petroleum Proprietary Ltd., the Australian unit of Delhi International Oil, said today that an appraisal well in the Cooper Basin had flowed oil at the rate of about 2,860 barrels a day. The flow is the second best ever recorded from an onshore Australian well, the company said.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: The Nobel Duel: Two Scientists' 21-Year Race to Win the World's Most Coveted Research Prize. By Nicholas Wade. 321 pages. Illustrated. Anchor Press/Doubleday. New York. $15.95.

title: Transamerica Interway Appoints a New Chief
description: Transamerica Interway, a container and trailer leasing company owned by the Transamerica Corporation since 1979, has appointed Richard M. Finn, 46, president, to the additional position of chief executive officer. He succeeds James P. Thrasher, 49, who resigned ''to pursue other interests.''

title: YANKS ARE IN A BUOYANT MOOD
description: The chatter at the batting cage in County Stadium was brash and loose today as the Yankees, a team that had drifted lethargically through the second half of the season, began serious preparation for the division playoffs that begin here Wednesday.

title: A LAW FIRM REJECTS A 'SPOOF'
description: (The following is a response to an Op-Ed column of Sept. 29, ''New Math Explained,'' in which Sydney H. Schanberg presented the ''transcript'' of an imaginary interview concerning election districting for New York's City Council.) To the Editor:

title: PAPERS' FEUD ROOTED IN 3-YEAR STRIKE
description: A newspaper strike here enters its fourth year tomorrow and no one talks anymore about a settlement. Rather, most of the talk centers on whether the struck newspaper or its counterpart, a newspaper started by the strikers, will survive.

title: Italy Allowed to Confiscate the Pontis' Art
description: The Italian Supreme Court has ordered the confiscation of an estimated $6.7 million worth of art owned by Sophia Loren and her film-producer husband, Carlo Ponti, in the latest move of a legal skirmish with Mr. Ponti.

title: ALCOA, REYNOLDS RAISE PRICES
description: The Aluminum Company of America and Reynolds Metals Company yesterday rai sed their prices of common alloy aluminum products by 7 percent to 9 percent.

title: Stuyvesant's Teachers Delay Letter Decision
description: Teachers at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan voted yesterday to wait until Fr iday to decide whether they would resume writing lettersof recommenda tion to colleges for seniors.

title: Study by CBS Counters 'Superstation' Proposal
description: Ted Bates/New York did not need to get its clients to put money into Ted Turner's superstation, WTBS, Atlanta, in order to get the kind of people the networks were losing to pay cable, according to the CBS Television Network. The network contends that commercial TV itself can supply the desired audiences.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: I T goes something like this. For six months, Women's Wear Daily works retailers and consumers into a fashion lather over the latest trend in clothes. But sometimes, when those trendy styles hit the stores, they don't sell. It happened with midis@kirts, and it seems to be happening again with a similar length. The current no-go is the new Long and Strong look - long skirts, shawls, wrap coats and lots of layers. Now that the trend has hit the stores, almost no one's buying it.

title: PRESIDENT IS FIRM ON WELFARE CUTS
description: President Reagan, defending his decision to cut spending for social welfare, said today that the new Federal budget was not a fair ''barometer'' of his Administration's social concern.

title: MONTE MASTERS, 24, TO FACE JOE FRAZIER
description: Joe Frazier, saying ''I don't play around - fighting is still my business,'' will mark his comeback to boxing with a 10-round bout against Monte Masters, it was announced yesterday. According to William Cooley, one of the promoters, Frazier will dust off his left hook sometime late next month in Atlantic City or Masters's home base, Oklahoma City.

title: SCANNERS A RESEARCH TOOL
description: When Arlene Flaherty turns on the television, the commercials she sees often differ from those seen by her nextdoor neighbor. And when Mrs. Flaherty goes to her local Stop & Shop each week, the $85 worth of groceries she buys are scrupulously recorded by the supermarket scanner against her personal identity code. The Flaherty family along with more than 2,000 other households here are subjects in a series of experiments that, increasingly, will Second of two articles on scanners and marketing. help decide which products will be sold to the rest of the nation, as well as how they will be sold.

title: ROGERS GIVES RANGERS A LIFT FOR OPENER
description: As they open their 56th season in the National Hockey League at Madison Square Garden tonight against the Detroit Red Wings, the Rangers have expectations that Mike Rogers, the high-scoring center they acquired from the Hartford Whalers Friday, may make them winners.

title: A PARTIAL BREAKDOWN OF HOUSE VOTE ON ACT
description: Following are the names of the 44 members of the House of Representatives who voted against extension of the 1965 Voting Rights Act, or who did not vote. The 24 votes against were cast by: Archer, R-Tex.; Billey, R-Va.; Brinkley, R-Ga.; Butler, R-Va.; Collins, R-Tex.; Daniel Crane, R-Ill.; Dan Daniel, D-Va.; Robert Daniel, R-Ill.; Dan Daniel, D-Va.; Robert Daniel, R-Va.; Dickenson, R-Ala.; Hansen, R-Idaho.

title: by Adam Raphael
description: The emergence of a new center party, the Social Democrats, whose inaugural conference is being held this week, is unquestionably the most serious challenge yet to the cozy two-party system of alternating Conservative and Labor Governments that have ruled Britain for half a century.

title: BOGUS $2.5 MILLION AND FOUR SUSPECTS SEIZED ON STATEN I.
description: Secret Service agents seized $2.5 million in counterfeit money Saturday night on Staten Island after they caught four men printing bogus $50 bills, the agency announced yesterday.

title: Police in India Arrest 70 Suspects in Sikh Case
description: A police crackdown in Punjab state has led to the arrest of more than 70 people who are believed to be involved in a movement that is demanding an independent Sikh state, the Times of India reported today.

title: Crime Unit Backs Prison Bond Issue
description: A proposed $500 million New York State bond issue for prison construction has been endorsed by the Citizens Crime Commission, a nonprofit group financed by business.

title: Mt. Etna Crater Spews Ash
description: A recently opened crater on the western slope of Mount Etna resumed spewing black smoke and ashes today after being dormant for several days. The Seismological Institute at the University of Catania said there appeared to be no danger of a violent explosion soon.

title: MEXICAN FAULTS I.M.F.
description: Gustavo Rom ero Kolbeck, the head of Mexico's central bank, yesterday des cribed the recently completed annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank as a ''tremendous disappointmen t'' for the growth prospects of developing countries.

title: Marini Banned For Brawl
description: The National Hockey League today suspended Hector Marini, the Islander forward, for the first three games of the season for being the first man to leave the bench during a brawl Saturday night in a game with the Rangers.

title: CALIFORNIA STATE BIOLOGISTS HOLD KEY POSITIONS IN LINGERING FRUIT FLY BATTLE
description: Karen Corwin had no reason to expect anything unusual on a warm June day more than a year ago when she received a vial containing two small insects. They had been taken from an insect trap in the populous South Bay area almost two weeks earlier.

title: Schayes Signed by Jazz
description: The Utah Jazz signed their No.1 draft selection, Dan Schayes of Syracuse, to a multiyear contract.

title: New Haven Riders Pick Cars in Survey
description: An overwhelming majority of New Haven line commuters would try to get to New York City in automobiles if the rail line had to shut down in an emergency, such as another breakdown of the generating station at Cos Cob, Conn., according to a survey.

title: Natural Selection in Finches
description: There has long been debate over the fine points of Charles Darwin's theory that the evolution and adaptation of species came about primarily as a result of the process of natural selection.

title: 8 Runners Barred for Accepting Money
description: The Athletics Congress has suspended eight long-distance runners and cleared four others, including Bill Rodgers, the four-time Boston Marathon champion, on charges of accepting prize money at a race last June in Portland, Ore.

title: THE AYATOLLAH'S FAITHFUL FOLLOWER
description: Each Friday for more than a year, a slim, intense Islamic clergyman delivered a fiery sermon before large crowds at Teheran University or one of the major mosques in Iran's capital.

title: Executive Loses A Bid for Freedom
description: A judge has rejected the argument of the president of a parachute company who said that he was too ill to be jailed for not turning over his stock to an amusement park.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 19
DOWN ON THE FARM
description: In their suburban backyard, once the habitat of polyethylene flamingos and badminton birdies, Gregory and Nancy Mehl are raising chickens, turkeys, geese and pigs. ''Food at the store is too expensive,'' Mrs. Mehl explains.

title: Fred Lindstrom Dies at 75; Ex-Giant Was Hall of Famer
description: Fred Lindstrom, a third baseman and outfielder for nine seasons with the New York Giants and a member of the Baseball Hall of Fame, died Sunday at Mercy Hospital in Chicago after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: PUERTO RICO COMES TO GRIPS WITH CUTS
description: The people of this Caribbean island pride themselves on their ability to survive tropical storms, job shortages and strikes by groups ranging from utility workers to students. Now they are bending their minds to surviving 'El Barbero.'

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-Including $1,624,000 gain from the settlement of litigation on the sale of Tyco's investment in Cutter-Hammer Inc

title: Plea Withdrawn I n Slashings Case
description: A suspect in a series of throat-slashing attacks that left two men dead and 13 wounded in Manhattan withdrew his guilty plea in State Supreme Court.

title: PAN AM CUT FARES TO LONDON
description: Pan American World Airways, in an effort to attract more overseas business, announced yesterday fare cuts of up to 59 percent on some of its London routes, including a one-way unrestricted economy fare between New York and London of $261.

title: IS RAELI ATTACKS SAUDIS' LEADERS AS FOES OF JEWS
description: The Israeli Government accused Saudi Arabia yesterday of ''a fanatic hatred of Jews and Israel,'' of keeping the Palestine Liberation Organization alive with oil money, of pressuring countries to break relations with Israel and of supporting a scheme to dismember the country.

title: Hijacking Foiled At Buffalo Airport
description: A man who said he had a bomb and wanted to fly to the Soviet Union tried to hijack a domestic flight yesterday but was captured as he tried to leave the aircraft, authorities said. No injuries were reported.

title: U.S. COURT RULES FOR MARX BROTHERS' HEIRS ON 'DAY IN HOLLYWOOD'
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the recent Broadway show ''A Day in Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine'' was an ''unauthorized appropriation'' of characters created by the Marx Brothers.

title: VATICAN WATCHING CODY CASE CLOSELY
description: Vatican prelates ''at the highest level'' are deeply aware of the controversy surrounding the Archbishop of Chicago, John Cardinal Cody, and Pope John Paul II is following the case closely, well-informed church sources say.

title: U.S. BACKS USE OF EVIDENCE FROM ILLEGAL POLICE SEARCHES
description: The Justice Department today endorsed a proposal to allow use of illegally seized evidence in some Federal criminal cases, and said it was considering an effort to require admission of such evidence in all cases.

title: All Savers - and All Payers
description: ''Join the great tax revolution .... Make us your tax savings headquarters in your war against income tax.'' So urge the champions of free enterprise at one big savings and loan association. ''Ours is five ways better,'' exclaims a competitor, borrowing imagery from an old bread commercial.

title: Foreign Aid, Under the Formal Dress
description: One of the better kept secrets in Washington is that the Reagan Administration approves of foreign aid. You'd never guess it from the President's speech last week before the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, or from Secretary of State Haig's earlier address to the General Assembly. Both advise the world's poor to seek salvation in what Mr. Reagan calls ''the magic of the marketplace.'' He praises development aid with faint damns.

title: SWAMP FARMS ARE NEW EVIDENCE OF MAYA INGENUITY
description: TWELVE HUNDRED years ago, whe n the Roman em pire had already faded and Viking longships were raiding the British Isles, a complex civilization was near its peak in regions of Central America.

title: JAPAN'S PLANS FOR AIDING ITS NEIGHBORS
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE MAY USE PENSION MONEY TO BUILD
description: Governor Carey has asked Comptroller Edward V. Regan to consider using New York State employee pension funds to finance some of the state's building needs as an alternative to raising money in the troubled municipal bond market.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.M. International Inc. announced it had completed the sale of its Documentor division in Santa Ana, Calif., to Computerized Systems Inc. of Anaheim, Calif. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

title: PHILHARMONIC: MONTSERRAT CABALLE, INSTRUMENTALIST
description: GREAT singing is such a complex weave of pure sound and profound emotional communication that we should not be surprised to find so little of it at any moment in history. Every singer - in fact, every musician - leans at least somewhat in one direction or the other, but it is safe to say that the desire to make beautiful sounds comes first, and is perhaps the truest indication of musical talent. For that reason, the program of arias that Montserrat Caballe offered last night with the New York Philharmonic raised quite a storm of applause and cheers, and rightly so. The Spanish soprano is one of the virtuoso instrumentalists of our day, no less so because her instrument is the voice.

title: AWACS CHILLS A SENATOR'S WHITE HOUSE WELCOME
description: When Ronald Reagan invited Senator Bob Packwood to the White House for a chat recently, the President was not handing out cuff links or warm expressions of gratitude. The Oregon Republican is the leading Congressional opponent of the Administration's plan to sell Awacs reconnaissance planes to Saudi Arabia, and the President had a blunt message to deliver: ''You're cutting me off at the knees.''

title: SABRES DRAFT YVON LAMBERT
description: Yvon Lambert, a le ft wing who was a key member of Montreal Canadien teams that won fo ur Stanley Cup championships, was selected by the Buffalo Sa bres in the first round of the National Hockey League's waiver draft today. His selection gives him an opportunity to rejoin Coach Scot ty Bowman, under whom Lambert played at Montreal.

title: Talking Business with Moore of Lang, Fisher & Stashower; For TV Ads, A New Era
description: As vice president and account supervisor at Lang, Fisher & Stashower, a Cleveland advertising agency, Thomas A. Moore handles advertising for a wide variety of products, ranging from soap to hardware to baby bottles, among the 49-year-old agency's $22 million a year in billings.

title: FRANCE PLANS RESTRICTIVE MEASURES TO CUT INFLATION AND HELP EXPORTS
description: France's Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, announced plans today to reinforce the devaluation of the franc by freezing a wide range of retail prices, deferring some public spending increases and working out wage guidelines with labor.

title: JOINT CHIEFS' HEAD SAY HE PREFERRED CARTER'S MX PLAN
description: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. David C. Jones, testified before Congress today that he personally preferred President Carter's ''shell game'' plan for deploying MX intercontinental missiles to the ''superhardened'' silos chosen by President Reagan.

title: STATES ARE RATED IN ACID RAIN STUDY
description: Fifteen states east of the Mississippi River are ''extremely vulnerable'' to the harmful effects of acid rain, according to a study released today by the National Wildlife Federation.

title: 4 MOVIE UNITS JOIN VENTURE
description: Four major movie companies - Universal, Paramount, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, and United Artists - have joined together to form one organization to distribute their films abroad.

title: Fidrych Waived Again
description: Mark Fidrych, beset by tendinitis in his pitching arm every season since he was named the American League's rookie of the year in 1976, was placed on waivers yesterday by the Detroit Tigers. Fidrych, whose antics on the mound endeared him to fans not only in Detroit but also around the league, had been struggling to make a comeback with the Tigers, twice in recent seasons going to the minor leagues. ''It was one of the most difficult decisions I've ever had to make,'' Jim Campbell, the Tiger general manager, said yesterday. ''But we reached that decision after reviewing the promising young players we have to protect on our 40-man roster this winter.'' Fidrych, a 27-year-old right-hander, said he had no bitterness. ''The Tigers,'' he said, ''have done everything they possibly could do.'' ... Frank Robinson will be back as manager of the San Francisco Giants next season, his c ontract extended two years, but his leading pitcher, Doyle Alexand er, may not. Alexander, who was 11-7 this year, said thefinal day of the season was his deadline for the team to extend his contract, wit h a substantial raise. Alexander, 31, acknowledged that he was not el igible to become a free agent but added that ''I have the option to stop playing.'' ... Rick Sutcliffe, left off the Los Angeles Dodge rs' 25-man roster for the playoffs, responded by throwing a ch air in the office of Tom Lasorda, the manager, and asking the te am to trade him.

title: BRITAIN ADVANCING PLAN ON NAMIBIA
description: In a Commonwealth Conference characterized by harsh oratory directed against South Africa, Britain appears to be succeeding in a largely behind-the-scenes effort to shore up African support for the continuing endeavor by five Western nations to obtain South African agreement on a plan for independence for South-West Africa.

title: GIANTS TO RUN WITH CARPENTER
description: The Giants' running game, the least productive in pro football and almost catatonic in yesterday's 27-14 rout by the Green Bay Packers, is about to be shaken up.

title: Jumbo Jet Skids Into Mud
description: A Delta Airlines jumbo jet was mired in mud off the edge of a Tampa International Airport runway today after skidding off a wet runway while landing yesterday, the authorities said. The tower chief, Richard Allen, said that the plane, a Lockheed L-1011, which had originated a flight in Los Angeles and stopped in Atlanta, was up to its nose gear in mud while the rear section of the plane hung over the end of the runway.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest Rates Are Off Slightly By MICHAEL QUINT

title: Deere to Extend Plant Shutdowns
description: Deere & Company announced that it will extend by one month its Christmas shutdown at two plants making construction equipment because of the continued slump in the housing market.

title: Musical Teams Remembered at Symphony Space
description: Among those who made contributions to the ''Save a Seat'' fund at the Symphony Space, the Upper West Side community-sponsored cultural center th at was once a skating rink and then a movie house, was Mary Rodgers Guettel. She is the daughter of the late composer Richard Rodgers and is herself the composer of the Br oadway musical hit, ''Once Upon a Mattress.''

title: Cleveland Parents Halt Half the School Buses
description: Parents protesting the use of public transit to move some pupils prevented about half of the Cleveland school system's 460 buses from leaving their yards today, stranding up to 15,000 children.

title: Market Place; Comsat's New Satellite
description: OCCASIONALLY a major company event is overlooked for a time. Some years ago, for example, a pressed-wood company's new plant blew up and dimmed an otherwise rosy future.

title: Houston's Population Passes Philadelphia's
description: If the last decade's population trends have continue d since the last census count, today is the day when Philadelphia unofficially to becomes the nation's fifth largest city,relinquishing the No. 4 spot to Houston.

title: TO KEEP THE BIBLE'S SONG AND SUBSTANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After $58,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Top Executives View Economy
description: Top-level business executives are slightly more pessimistic about the economy, but their outlook for six months from now continues to hold up, the Conference Board said yesterday.

title: MINORITIES PREVAIL IN 5 COURT CHOICES
description: Manhattan and Bronx Democratic leaders agreed last night on five nominees for State Supreme Court, including two women and two blacks. Race and sex were major considerations in the selection of Judges Eve M. Preminger of Criminal Court, Edith Miller of Family Court and Kenneth L. Shorter of Civil Court, all of Manhattan, and Judges David Levy and Joseph Cerbone of Bronx Civil Court.

title: Concern Told to Stop Using Shredded Cash
description: The United States Treasury Department, acting on a tip from a woman who was upset to find her new lamp packed in shredded money, told a Brooklyn lamp manufacturer yesterday to find new packaging material.

title: CITY CONCERNED OVER CRIME RISE AGAINST CABBIES
description: The number of reported crimes against taxicab drivers is sharply increasing, after having reached its lowest point in many years in 1979, police officials said yesterday.

title: London Transit Fares Are Decreased by 25%
description: Subway and bus fares here were cut an average of 25 percent today, fulfilling a campaign promise by the new Socialist-controlled city government to the six million daily riders. It is the first reduction in London's mass transit fares in 152 years, when the system was started with horse-drawn buses.

title: Car Emission Rule Relief
description: Domestic auto makers should receive some regulatory relief from Federal emission standards by the end of the year, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: Indians Protest Diablo Plant
description: A group of California Indians led a daylong prayer vigil yesterday at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant to protest construction of the facility atop a Chumash burial ground. About 80 people participated in the vigil, and an executive from Pacific Gas and Electric, operators of the nuclear plant, was on hand to support what he called ''a sincere protest.''

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION IS BACKED
description: Leaders of women's and civil rights groups criticized the Reagan Administration today for its proposals to ease Federal affirmative-action guidelines in hiring and promotion. The groups also charged that the enforcement of some regulations had been modified prematurely.

title: Stocks Advance, Even as Dow Slips 0.86
description: The stock market overall moved slightly higher yesterday amid profit-taking pressures after last week's strong recovery. Takeover situations once again produced large price swings. Railroad stocks were strong.

title: MESA TO SELL OIL ROYALTIES IN ALBERTA
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company, a leading independent developer and producer, announced yesterday that it would sell its Canadian oil and gas royalty interests in Alberta.

title: Sports of The Times; DID STRIKE COST THE METS HOWSER?
description: UNDERSTANDABLY, baseball fans blame the seven week strike for the fraud of the miniplayoffs that begin today, the joke of the split season, the d isenchantment with the game itself. Now it develops thateven the Met fans have a legitimate beef.

title: No Headline
description: Major League Leaders; FINAL; AMERICAN LEAGUE; Based on 275 or more times at bat. G AB R H Pct. Lansfrd, Bos. 102 399 61 134 .336 Gibson, Det. 83 290 41 95 .328 Paciorek, Sea. 104 405 50 132 .326 Cooper, Mil. 106 416 70 133 .320 R.Hdrsn, Oak. 108 423 89 135 .319 Hargrve, Clev. 94 322 44 102 .317 G.Brett, K.C. 89 347 42 109 .314 Zisk, Sea. 94 357 42 111 .311 Oliver, Tex. 102 421 53 130 .309 Remy, Bos. 88 358 55 110 .307 Mmphry,Ynks 80 319 44 98 .307; HOME RUNS

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arizona Chemical Company, Wayne, N.J., has elected Don Stiling executive vice president.

title: SEARS SET REAL EATATE EXPANSION
description: In a major expansion of its real estate operations, Sears, Roebuck & Company, the big retailer, said yesterday that it would buy Coldwell, Banker & Company, the nation's largest independent broker of commercial and residential real estate, for $179 million in cash and stock.

title: Shuttle's Progress
description: Technicians are well ahead of schedule in replacing tiles loosened wh en a caustic propellant spilled on the spac e shuttle Columbia last month, officials at the Kennedy Space Center said today. As of this morning, 215 tiles had been cleaned and repla ced, leaving 154 to go.

title: CURB ON IDENTIFYING SECRET AGENTS FACING SENATE PANEL VOTE TODAY
description: Press and civil liberties groups have been marshaling support for a last-ditch effort tomorrow to amend a Housepassed bill that would make it a crime to identify intelligence operatives working under secret cover overseas, even in an article exposing illegal activities by those operatives.

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1981; Companies
description: Santa Fe International will be acquired by Kuwait for $2.5 billion in cash, the big contract-drilling and oil producing company said. The surprise move came as OPEC investments in the U.S. were put at $200 billion. The purchase is expected to touch off Government inquiries. (Page A1.) Pan Am cut fares to London by up to 59 percent. One of the new rates - $360 for a one-way unrestricted New York to London flight - undercuts Lak er Airways by $57. The cuts are due to go into effect Nov. 1. (D1.)

title: DON'T BLAME POLICE FOR A CLEARLY OBSCURE RULE
description: To the Editor:

title: President Adds Post At Johnson & Higgins
description: Robert V. Hatcher Jr., the 51-year-old president of Johnson & Higgins, a major insurance brokerage firm, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Richard I. Purcell, 63, who will continue as chairman until he retires at the end of this year.

title: DANCE: A TRIO OF WORKS FROM THE AVANT-GARDE
description: After an exhilarating start, the Walker Art Center's weeklong New Dance USA Festival settled down into the kind of uneven fare inevitable to any such ambitious survey of an experimental field.

title: THE COMMUTER AIRLINES COPE
description: In August, when the nation's commuter airlines suffered a sharp drop in flights and passenger traffic because of the air controllers' strike, there were widespread fears that many of these small and cash-hungry carriers would not fly much longer.

title: 3D KARPOV-KORCHNOI GAME IS DRAWN
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland ended his two-game losing streak by drawing the third game of the world chess championship match with Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union here tonight.

title: Victor Borge Knighted for Fourth Time
description: Some people collect things like stamps and baseball cards; Victor Borge is a minor collector of knighthoods. The pianist who mixes broad comedy with his music was invited last night to the home of the Finnish Consul General in New York, Erik Heinrichs, to be knighted for the fourth time.

title: AIRLINE LUGGAGE IN NEWARK 'DELIVERED' EARLY (TO ROOFS)
description: Three suitcases fell from a New York Air passenger plane today onto the roofs of two buildings at the Sherwin-Williams Company industrial complex and in a nearby backyard.

title: Bridge: Players Can Be in 2 Places
description: Bridge players are not exactly ubiquitous, but they have been known to be in two places at the same time. An example occurred in the recent Triathlon individual in New York, where one young player played double-dummy, not technically but literally.

title: CITY URGED TO ASK THE PUBLIC'S HELP IN COMBATING CHILD ABUSE
description: The chairman of the Mayor's Task Force on Child Abuse and Neglect called yesterday for the city to begin a ''public awareness'' campaign to combat abuse and said he would resign unless certain measures were taken.

title: O. Beyond Scrabble
description: Board game fans who have become real cutthroats at a Scrabble Word Game now have a new challenge. Instead of using letters as one does in the regular game, the new game has cubes bearing complete words. Each of two players draws 30 cubes to start, each with a different word on each side. One player begins by forming a seven-word sentence, on which the opponent builds further sentences. Like the regular Scrabble Word Game, the board is marked with bonus squares that enable the player to build up his score. The Scrabble Quip Qubes game is in Macy's adult game department on the seventh floor for $16.

title: Hawks' Eddie Johnson Is Admitted to Hospital
description: Eddie Johnson of the Atlanta Hawks was admitted to the psychiatric unit at Grady Hospital today, escorted by three officers from the Cobb County sheriff's department.

title: WORLD OIL MARKETS UNEASY
description: The assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt unsettled world oil markets and dispelled optimism over prices and supplies that had prevailed for nearly a year.

title: No Headline
description: PENNSYLVANIA LABOR GROUPS LOBBY: Members of labor organizations from across Pennsylvania met yesterday in the State Capitol, Harrisburg. The groups were there to lobby against bills they feel would have a detrimental effect on the state's workers.

title: U.S. ACADEMIC EXPERTS PREDICT POWER STRUGGLE
description: The death of President Anwar el-Sadat, at a time of internal unrest, is expected to ignite a power struggle, according to interviews with American analysts of Egyptian affairs.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BEST BUYS
description: VEGETABLES are inexpensive and plentiful th is week as fall produce arrives to augment summer supplies. This is a good time to make economical soups, both to eat now and freeze for later.

title: One Down, Two to Go
description: The Cincinnati Reds yesterday signed Dave Concepcion, their shortstop, one of three key Cincinnati players who had threatened to choose free agency. To do so, the Reds had to come up with the largest salary and the first guaranteed contract in the club's history.

title: NETS SOUGHT PACT WITH RAY WILLIAMS
description: The vision for Nets Coach Larry Brown became clear a few weeks ago when Ray Williams, the free-agent Knick guard, joined a few basketball players for a friendly game at a high-school gym in northern New Jersey. Brown was in the stands, and each time Williams drove the lane, maneuvered inside several big men for a rebound, or jumped a few feet to block an opponent's shot, Brown fidgeted just enough to show that he noticed.

title: Sentenced in Priest's Death
description: The 19-year-old son of Russell Means, the In dian activist, was sentenced today to 20 years in prisonfor the death of a Roman Catholic priest who interrupted a church robbery and s uffered a heart attack. Walter Dale Means pleaded guiltyto first-degr ee manslaughter charges and was sentenced by Circuit Judge Merton Tice Jr.

title: Inmate Indicted In Guard's Slaying
description: A twice-convicted murderer already serving three 25-year-to-life sentences was indicted yesterday on first-degree murder charges in the May 15 slaying of a prison guard.

title: UNITED REALTY INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Celanese to End Textured Yarn
description: The Celanese Corporation said that it plans to terminate the production and sale of textured polyester yar n by the end of next year.

title: Burton in Hospital
description: Richard Burton was reported in satisfactory condition at a Santa Monica, Calif., hospital yesterday, four days after undergoing emergency surgery to repair a duodenal ulcer.

title: A Brand New Shot For Hollis Copeland
description: The muscular, square shoulders, the springin his legs and the ability to run the fast break have not changed. Only Hollis Copeland's method of shooting, developed and perfected in Spain last season, is different.

title: Leak Shuts Down 2d Nuclear Plant
description: Consolidated Edison announced that its Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant in Buchanan had been taken out of service to repair a leak in a pressurizer spray valve. The shutdown means that both active nuclear plants in Westchester County are out of service.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Working

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 7, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: DOCTORS call it ''the cancer nobody talks about.'' Yet, it is second only to lung cancer in the number of new cases that occur each year and it claims more lives than breast cancer. It is cancer of the lower bowel - the colon and rectum, a part of the body generally not mentioned in ''polite company'' and a part many of us find embarrassing to discuss even with our spouses and physicians.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a provision of $45,000 in connection with the settlement of a lawsuit

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THIS has been, in my own case, a banner year for growing tomatoes and, of all the things that come from my garden, it is one of the only vegetables of which I never tire. My enthusiasm for an overabundance of zucchini or green beans may have waned as the summer progressed, but for tomatoes, never, whether in salads, sandwiches, sauces or casseroles.

title: STRONG BILL LIKELY ON VOTING RIGHTS
description: The overwhelming approval of the Voting Rights Act by the House of Representatives yesterday increases the likelihood that the Senate will produce a strong bill, analysts on Capitol Hill agreed today.

title: 4 Schools Scrutinized On Coast
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is investigating the athletic programs of three schools that were penalized by the Pacific-10 Conference last year, along with Arizona.

title: A Dull Blade for College Loans
description: In political budget-cutting, some knives slice deeper than others. But who ever thought that the cutters-in-chief would slyly turn the blade and merely pretend to cut with the dull edge?

title: Cosmos Get Moyers, Top California Scorer
description: The Cosmos purchased the contract of Steve Moyers of the defunct California Surf yesterday, hours before a dispersal draft for the players of the four North American Soccer League franchises that folded last month.

title: EGYPT AFTER SADAT
description: The assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt created a new series of problems for future American policy in the Middle East at a time when the Reagan Administration was already worried about the spread of disorder in the region.

title: ACCOUNTANTS FIND GOVERNMENT FAVOR
description: The nation's accountants, blamed by Federal officials for some of the corporate scandals of the 1970's, are enjoying better days.

title: UNDAUNTED CELTICS
description: ''We never give up,'' said Red Auerbach, general manager of the Boston Celtics, who plans to talk to the Toronto Blue Jays about signing Danny Ainge, the two-sport star who has a baseball contract until 1983 that precludes his playing basketball. The Celtics have to sign Ainge by next June's draft, or they lose the rights to him within the National Basketball Association. A Federal Court jury in Manhattan decided last week that Ainge was bound to his Toronto contract, which means the Celtics will have to reach a compensation agreement with the Blue Jays if they still want to sign him .... Franco Thomas, the heavyweight boxing champion of West Virginia and Alaska, will oppose Jimmy Young in a 10-round preliminary on the heavyweight title card pitting Larry Holmes against Renaldo Snipes on Nov. 6 in Pittsburgh.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Sept. 10 on the Mediterra- nean fruit fly incorrectly identified the manufacturer of the bait used in ef- forts to poison the flies. It is the A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company of Decatur, Ill.

title: ULSTER'S 'RIGGED' SYSTEM OF JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: ANWAR EL-SADAT, THE DARING ARAB PIONEER OF PEACE WITH ISRAEL SADAT'S INNOVATIONS SPRANG FROM HIS COURAGE AND FLEXIBILITY
description: ''Sadat! Sadat!'' tens of thousands of Cairenes chanted at the grinning figure in the open limousine. ''Sadat! The man of peace!'' It was the night of Nov. 21, 1977. President Anwar el-Sadat had just returned from his epochal journey to Jerusalem. Egypt's people were giving their frenzied approval to what his trip had achieved - an Egyptian-Israeli thaw that set the stage for the peace treaty of 1979.

title: FED POLICY TOO TIGHT FOR REGAN
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, in his strongest statement to date, said today that the Federal Reserve Board's monetary policy was too tight and that the nation's central bank would have to increase the growth rate of the money supply to avoid prolonging a recession.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BankAmerica Corp. said that it and Japan's Zen-Noh Grain Corp. had signed an $88 million agreement for the leveraged lease financing of a grain terminal in Louisiana.

title: City Investing Plans To Sell Two Units
description: The City Investing Company, a holding company with major interests in insurance, housing, manufacturing, consumer services and finance, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell two of its wholly owned subsidiaries - the City Petroleum Company and the City Exploration Company - to a group of international investors.

title: Simpson-Sears Bond
description: Simpson-Sears, Canada's biggest retailer, is planning a $40 million Eurobond offering through its subsidiary, the Simpson-Sears Acceptance Company, bond market sources said today. The bond will run for seven years, and has a coupon indicated at 17 1/2 percent, with a likely pricing at par, they said. Lead manager for the issue will be Wood Gundy Ltd., the sources added.

title: Spanish Study NATO Plan
description: A Spanish parliamentary committee, preparing for a debate on the issue next week in the lower house, today began examining the Government's plan to take Spain into NATO by early next year. The centrist administration, with support from small conservative and regional parties, is expected to win a comfortable parliamentary majority in favor of the plan.

title: ANY HUMANS THERE?
description: A machine purporting to be the Rev. Jerry Falwell had written a strident letter asking me to send it $5, $10 or $25 immediately, and signed itself breezily as ''Jerry.''

title: Careers; Engineers For Solar Energy
description: RETAIL stores for solar and other forms of energy equipment? James L. Darrington, manager of business development and planning in the advanced energy programs department at the General Electric Company foresees outlets not unlike the Computerland stores today. ''It will be an alternate energy supermarket,'' he said.

title: DISSIDENTS ROUTED, K.G.B. OFFICER SAYS
description: The top career officer of the K.G.B., the Soviet security and intelligence organization, declared today that his organization had succeeded in crushing the political dissent movement in the Soviet Union.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citibank said an average rate of 15.351 percent was set yesterday at the weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp commercial paper, compared with a 16.211 percent average rate last week.

title: PARENTS OF MISSING CHILDREN URGE SENATE TO FORM REPORTING SYSTEM
description: With breaking voices and tears in their eyes, parents of three missing children urged a Senate subcommittee today to approve a bill establishing a national center to help find children who have disappeared.

title: 5,000 Evacuated as Train Derails With Gas Tanks
description: Some 5,000 people were evacuated from their homes early today after a freight train derailed, overturning five tanks of liquid chlorine and two of butane gas, officials said.

title: NASA LOFTS A SATELLITE TO STUDY OZONE LAYER
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration yesterday launched a satellite designed to study reactions between sunlight and molecules in the atmosphere and to give scientists a better understanding of the ozone layer that protects the earth from solar ultraviolet radiation.

title: Reactor Cooperation
description: West Germany's Kraftwerk Union A.G., a Siemens A.G. subsidiary, has signed a cooperation agreement with three Japanese companies to jointly study a new type of pressurized water reactor for use in Japan, a Hitachi Ltd. spokesman said today. The spokesman said that the Toshiba Corporation and the Fuji Electric Company were also involved in the deal. Japan has 22 operational nuclear power stations, 11 of which are boiling water types, 10 pressurised water and one gas cooled.

title: OWNERS REPORT 'NO DEALS' ON NEWS AGENCY SALE
description: The owners of United Press International said yesterday that they expected to reach ''a satisfactory ownership conclusion'' but that ''no deals have been made'' yet on the sale of the money-losing news service.

title: Mineral Stockpile Needs
description: The United States does not have enough strategic minerals stockpiled to last through a three-year war, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology researcher said here today. Dr. Daniel I. Fine told the St. Louis Council on World Affairs that it would cost about $7 billion to bring stockpiles up to required levels. Congress defines a strategic mineral as one needed for national defense, such as chromium and manganese.

title: PIANO RECITAL: MARK ZELTSER PLAYS BACH AND CHOPIN
description: ONE of the characteristic features of the Russian school of pianists - perhaps its trademark - has always been a heavy reliance on starkly defined contrasts, a chiaroscuro manner of playing that in the right hands can be potently dramatic. Sviatoslav Richter and Emil Gilels come to mind, of course, and further back in history we hear about such prophets of the style as Anton Rubinstein. On less exalted levels today we find the same approach being perpetuated so consistently by recent products of Soviet teaching that we might conclude, even without having read Dostoyevsky and Solzhenitsyn, that sudden shifts in emotion and kaleidoscopic shifts in mood somehow satisfy deep needs in the Russian soul.

title: Group Formed to Fight Changes in Food Laws
description: A new coalition led by consumer activist groups announced yesterday that it would fight a proposal to change Federal food safety laws, including one that bans any food additives implicated as cancer-causing in tests with laboratory animals.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
INTEGRATED APPOINTS EX-HOUSING OFFICIAL
description: Integrated Resources Inc., a diversified financial services companyin New York, has established a mortgage banking subsidiary, Integrated Fu nding Inc., and has named Lee Goodwin, a former New York State Co mmissioner of Housing and Community Renewal, as its first preside nt.

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for compensated absences

title: Last of the 9th For Reggie Bar
description: The Reggie candy bar, named for the Yankee slugger Reggie Jackson, may be in its last inning. Wayne Candies, which makes the Reggie bar, announced yesterday thatit would close its plant here on Oct. 16. Off icials did not say whether the Reggie would be produced by anoth er subsidiary of the company.

title: WHO MURDERED PRESIDENT SADAT
description: In the confusion swirling around the assassination of Egypt's President, Anwar el-Sadat, little information was made public in Cairo about the killers. Egyptian authorities were known to have several uniformed men in custody last night, but the Egyptians gave no details about the number or identity of the attackers or the reasons for the attack.

title: Cody Released by Hospital
description: John Cardinal Cody was released from a hospital today after spending two days undergoing routine medical tests, a church spokesman said. The 73-year-old Cardinal, who is the subject of a Federal investigation into his use of church funds, has a history of heart disease and diabetes. The spokesman declined to comment on the nature of the tests.

title: Son of Police Captain Is Held
description: In Paterson Tavern Stabbing

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER AT THE Y
description: CHAMBER Music at the Y Monday evening offered an intriguing mixture of sameness and difference. All three pieces were of the Romantic era, and all were in minor keys.

title: Dutch Joblessness Up
description: Unemployment in the Netherlands rose to a postwar record of 404,200 in September, more than one and one-half times the 267,000 reported in September 1980, and 2.9 percent above the 392,700 in August this year, according to provisional, seasonally adjusted figures released today by the Ministry of Social Affairs.

title: Heizer Announces Decline in Value
description: The Heizer Corporation announced that its total assets have declined about 20 percent since June 30 because of the decline in the stock market. The company, a business development concern, said that its total assets from June 30 to Sept.30 dropped to $259.6 million, or $15.25 a share, from $325.6 million, or $19.14 a share.

title: DU PONT AND SEAGRAM REACH DIRECTOR ACCORD
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and the Seagram Company, which were intense rivals in the bidding war for Conoco Inc. last summer, said yesterday that they had signed an agreement whereby the chairman of each company will become a director of the other.

title: BLUEPRINT FOR CHAOS IN SOUTHERN AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKER AT IMPERIAL ADDS JOB IN LEASE-PURCHASE FINANCING
description: A fast-growing field these days is large-scale municipal leasepurchase financings as an alternative to bonds and other forms of municipal financing. Industry sources predict that lease-purchase deals, involving at least $3 million apiece, will total about $12 billion this year, up from $3 billion in 1980.

title: Lukens Charges Steel Dumping
description: The Lukens Steel Company, the nation's leading producer of clad steel plate, filed a complaint with the Commerce Department charging the Japan Steel Works with dumping.

title: Federated Set To Buy Chain
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's fifth-largest retailer, reached agreement today with The Children's Place Inc., a regional chain of children's specialty apparel stores, to merge the two companies in a $45 million transaction.

title: Trade Secret Thief Gets Jail
description: A county judge here has sentenced a business executive to two years and eight months in prison for conspiring to steal electronic secrets worth an estimated $10 million.

title: Air Travel to Egypt Reported Normal After Assassination
description: Air travel to Egypt was reported to be normal yesterday after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat, and the State Department said there was no reason for tourists to cancel planned visits.

title: DANCE: PAUL TAYLOR'S 'HOUSE OF CARDS'
description: THE Paul Taylor Dance Company returned to one of its old haunts last night. It has not performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for some years and the word was that Mr. Taylor returned for old time's sake to the friendly sponsor that had presented him in New York when few or no one else did.

title: HIS AND STATE'S
description: Governor Carey swept through this upstate community today to stump for two bond proposals on the November ballot, to address a business group and to raise money for his debt-ridden campaign fund.

title: Federal Judge Blocks Utah Abortion Law
description: A Federal judge issued a prelimary injunction today ordering Utah to stop enforcing a new law that requires a 24-hour waiting period before an abortion can be performed.

title: West Indies Isle Protests Plan for Independence
description: Barbuda, a tiny British territory in the West Indies, is protesting plans for joint government with Antigua on the ground that Antiguans will dominate when the islands become independent Nov. 1.

title: RANGERS LOSE OPENER TO RED WINGS, 5-2
description: Herb Brooks, the rookie coach, presented the 1981-82 New York Rangers and his new system of swirl-around hockey to 17,401 critical fans at Madison Square Garden last night in the opening game of the National Hockey League season.

title: Index; International
description: Hungary feels that it's on the right path; Poland proves it A2 British Army reduces its role in Ulster A3 Iranian executions protested in takeover of Ankara consulate A4 Israel discloses rescue mission on Saudi reef A6 Israel says it regrets that Arafat was invited to visit Japan A13 Trudeau makes bid for consensus on constitutional reform A16 Dissident movement crushed, K.G.B. chief declares A17 Mrs. Thatcher facing attacks from Tory ranks A18 British Social Democrats get a lift at conference A19 Government/Politics Governor Carey raises funds and stumps upstate for bond issue B2 Anderson, a possible rival to Carey in '82, assails him B2 Jersey high court upholds ballot bias ruling B5 White House halts letter chiding Republicans on donations B12 Parents of missing children urge national reporting system B12 Senate panel approves bill out- lawing identification of agents B13 Washington Talk Briefing A24 Two compete for podium at White House press briefings A24 Lawyer works to untangle the mazes of Government A24 General Around the Nation A20 Old department store building stirs Philadelphia struggle A20 Owners report ''no deals'' yet on sale of UPI A22 Obituaries Sherman R. Knapp, retired utility executive D23 Living Section Food A strategy for quick, easy meals C1

title: Dylan Thomas Plaque A t Westminster Abbey
description: Dylan Thomas, who died in New York in 1953 at the age of 39, has won a place in Westminster Abbey's hallowed Poets Corner, regarded as the greatest honor for Britain's poets.

title: WHITE HOUSE STOPS DONATIONS LETTER
description: The White House has ordered a halt to the mailing of a Republican fund-raising letter that scolded reluctant contributors for ''causing the President grave concern.''

title: STAGE: 'DEXTER CREED,' MORIARTY'S SATIRE A CLEF
description: A FEW years ago an actress, stung by a review, dumped a plate of pasta on the head of a drama critic - a public act of drama-critic criticism. Michael Moriarty has taken a more imaginative approach. He has written an entire play about an actor's war with a drama critic, and he is appearing in it at the Public Theater. This is, as one might gather, a satire a clef, about a certain well-known - in Mr. Moriarty's eyes, infamous - critic who specializes in argumentum ad hominem.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Later this month on network and spot TV Alberto-Culver is going to introduce its first room deodorizer product.

title: VICE PRESIDENT AFFIRMS 'ALL TREATIES'
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was shot and killed today by a group of men in military uniforms who hurled hand grenades and fired rifles at him as he watched a military parade commemorating the 1973 war against Israel.

title: 2 Governors Criticize 'Guest Worker' Plan
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California and Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona today criticized President Reagan's plan for allowing 50,000 Mexican nationals to work as ''guests'' in the United States.

title: Afghan Guerrillas Said to Yield a Town
description: Afghan insurgents recently gave up their hold on Paghman, a town near Kabul, and allowed a Soviet-Afghan force to occupy it without a fight, a Western diplomatic source said today.

title: ENDOWMENTS EXPECTED TO STAY AS THEY ARE
description: A Presidential task force is expected to recommend that the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities remain separate entities instead of being merged and that the Federal Government continue providing funds for the arts and humanities.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are accustomed to these wounds and we believe in God's will and we will continue, in the name of the spirit and soul of our leader and our Constitution, to abide by all treaties and commitments made.'' - Vice President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. (A8:1.)

title: Market Place; The Benefits Of a Spinoff
description: WALL STREET won't bet on a mystery. As a result, shares of conglomerates usually sell at discounts relative to underlying values. Their financial reporting is often exemplary, but these multi-industry companies are so complex that investors cannot grasp what they read.

title: Connecticut Man Dies in Jail
description: A 39-year-old Connecticut man held since May in the San Diego County Jail was found hanged in his cell early today. Authorities said the man, Andrew F. Ferola of Farmington, Conn., was hanging by his own trousers, which had been wrapped around bars in the cell. Mr. Ferola was serving two consecutive 90-day sentences for petty theft, malicious mischief and failure to appear in court.

title: Moscow Issues Warning To U.S. on Arms Talks
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda warned today that the Soviet Union would have to take steps to guarantee a balance between East and West in nuclear weapons in Europe if arms talks with the United States next month were marked by bad faith.

title: TORIES ATTACK MRS. THATCHER'S ECONOMIC POLICIES
description: Just three weeks after shuffling her Cabinet to quell unrest within the Conservative Party, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is facing an even fiercer barrage of attacks from Tory ranks over her economic policies.

title: New Movement on Northern Ireland
description: What is happening in Northern Ireland isn't a new dawn, but it is a break in the clouds. Irish Republican Army prisoners have abandoned the hunger strikes that brought 10 deaths without wringing any concessions from Prime Minister Thatcher. Wisely, her Government has yielded to some demands for prison reform, even at the risk of angering the province's Protestant majority. And in the south, where Catholics predominate, the Dublin Government has proposed constitutional changes that could eventually lead to peaceful unification. Some welcome news on a bad day.

title: The Nixons Register For Voting in Jersey
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon has registered to vote in the state's Nov. 3 gubernatorial election. Mimi Sarthou, Bergen County Commissioner of Registration and Election Superintendent, said today that both Mr. Nixon and his wife, Pat, had registered by mail on a form signed Sept. 14.

title: BROOKS FASHION STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After $504,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: REAGAN CALLS SADAT 'CHAMPION OF PEACE'
description: President Reagan said today that the United States had lost ''a close friend'' and ''a champion of peace'' with the death of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt. But the Administration refrained from any public assessment of the possible repercussions of the assassination.

title: AUXILIARY REFRIGERATOR
description: THE piece of kitchen equipment in my home that is perhaps least practical for the nonprofessional kitchen is my auxiliary refrigerator. It has, sitting on top of it, a permanently chilled slab of marble. Yet whenever I describe this refrigerator and whenever visiting journalists write about it, there is an extraordinary amount of interest in it. I do think that for any very serious cook, professional or not, who does a great deal of baking, this small refrigerator of mine is at least worth knowing about.

title: ON THE FRONT LINES
description: For some lawyers, it seems, litigation is not enough. Jack Smith, for example, a 36-year-old Pittsburgh lawyer, is giving up his practice to join the Venice (Fla.)

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
zf U.S. Opens Reserve To Grain, Corn Crops
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, trying to remove some of the price-depressing bumper grain crop from the market, today opened the farmer-owned grain reserve to this year's corn and other feed grain crops.

title: USED MARINE BIOLOGY IN MEDICAL RESEARCH
description: Dr. Frederik Barry Bang, a pioneer in applying marine biology to medical research, has died at the age of 64, Johns Hopkins University said yesterday.

title: One Extraordinary Man
description: America is shocked, bereft and, quite properly, worried. Was it only one extraordinary man they gunned down in Cairo yesterday - or did a whole structure of foreign policies collapse with him? Will any Arab now dare to follow him to Jerusalem? Was there truth in his recent premonitions of a Soviet plot? Is alliance with America a pact of doom for Arabs?

title: Bridge: Some Quirks Are Involved In Mammoth Double Fits
description: There is a very rare situation in which 13 + 11 is worth much more than 12 + 12. If both partnerships have a mammoth double fit, the two 12-card fits are both exposed to a possible opening ruff. The 13-card fit and the 11-card fit are safe, as can be seen by studying the deal in the diagram.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: About 24 years ago, just a few months after her first birthday, a little girl with tight brown curls named Mari a Ruiz became the responsibility of the State of New York.

title: SEALABLE SEWAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: Results for the latest periods are for 14 weeks and 53 weeks ended Aug 1, 1981; results for the previous periods are for 13 weeks and 52 weeks ended July 26, 1980

title: WALKER COLOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ABANDONING THE SEARCH FOR THE 'EXTRA MAN'
description: IT is now acceptable in some circles to have an uneven table at a dinner party. We are not talking about the sort of uneveness that may be rectified by propping up the short leg of the table with a matchbook. Rather, we are talking about dinner parties at which the ratio of male to female guests is less than equal and even dinner parties at which the men are so precious the hostess has studded them around the table like truffles on a pate. This is what is now acceptable in some, not all, circles.

title: Reagan Halts Oil Rule Bid
description: The Reagan Administration, faced with a potential embarrassment in Congress, withdrew a regulation yesterday that critics said would have cut state governments out of decisions on oil drilling off their coasts.

title: RECALLING YOM KIPPURS PAST
description: ALTHOUGH holiday reminiscences usually include memories of great meals prepared and eaten in celebration, Yom Kippur, which begins this evening, is something of an exception to the rule. Though the Jewish Day of Atonement, observed by a sundown-to-sundown fast, is preceded and followed by huge meals, the 24 hours in between hang heavy and hungrily, at least for a child.

title: Youth Sentenced In Girl's Slaying
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn youth was sentenced to three to nine years in prison in the fatal shooting of a 13-year-old girl. He had claimed the shooting was accidental.

title: De Lorean's Finances
description: Britain's Solicitor General today denied reports that the Prime Minister's office had ordered a police investigation into the financial affairs of the De Lorean Motor Company, which is based in the United States.

title: VICE PRESIDENT AFFIRMS 'ALL TREATIES'
description: Israel, which had such a high stake in the survival of President Anwar el-Sadat, reacted with stunned anxiety today to news of his assassination in Cairo.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OLD WORDS

title: Q & A
description: Q. I have a quantity of achiote or annatto seeds on my pantry shelf. If I wanted to use these to color paella, how would I go about it?

title: APPROVAL OF B-1 CALLED UNCER TAIN
description: Representative Melvin Price, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, warned Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today that Congressional approval of the Reagan Administration's proposal to build the B-1 long-range bomber ''is by no means certain.''

title: SADAT'S JOURNEY
description: The journey that began in the army was ended by the army. Anwar el-Sadat, once a conspirator, a plotter, had become king of the land. From humble origins in the delta, he had climbed to the summit; the world had become his theater. He would be what every Egyptian boy playing on the banks of the Nile would dream of being; he would go places for them.

title: TV: 'MR. MERLIN' AND KENNY ROGERS
description: TV'S ''Mr. Merlin,'' a weekly series beginning tonight at 8 o'clock, takes the gifted actor Barnard Hughes and dumps him into a prime-time situation comedy that could just as easily have been scheduled as part of the network's Saturday-morning cartoon lineup. Mr. Hughes plays Max Merlin, who is not only the owner of a dilapidated San Francisco garage but also the very same Merlin who served as sorcerer for the court of King Arthur. Students of the form might refer to ''Mork & Mindy,'' ''The Greatest American Hero'' and other current dabblings in the supernatural.

title: LAYER CLEARS PATHS THROUGH THE FEDERAL JUDGE
description: Robert D. Wallick is a lawyer reputed to know more about the inner workings of the Federal Government than anyone in it. His bulging forehead seems to house an oversize brain, and a first impression is that the slight frown he wears in public appearances comes from having such irritants as ''Attachment 'O' to OMB Circular A-102'' or the ''UMTA external operating manual IIIC-17'' constantly rubbing his cranial nerves.

title: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1981; The Sadat Assassination
description: The death of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt unsettled world oil markets and dampened recent optimism over prices and supplies. At the New York Mercantile Exchange, more barrels of oil were sold for future delivery than ever be fore. In Rotterda m, trade on the spot market halted as investors awaited signs of a price surge. (Page D1.)

title: FORTUNE SMILES ON EAGLES AS FALCONS SQUANDER OPPORTUNITIES
description: Those teams consistently successful in the National Football League often develop a habit of winning games they otherwise deserve to lose.

title: IRANIANS STAGE ANKARA PROTEST
description: Revolutionary guards reportedly executed 61 more leftist Mujahedeen dissidents in Teheran today, and anti-Khomeini forces shot up and ransacked the Iranian consulate in Istanbul to protest the mounting toll of executions.

title: FEDERAL TAX LAWS: THE FIRST PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: IN MASSACHUSETTS, IT'S 'KENNEDY OIL'
description: Over the weekend, an oceangoing barge slipped into Boston harbor and then out again, leaving at dockside 125,000 barrels of heating oil, a deposit against the winter whose gray early chill is already in the air.

title: Islanders Face Kings Tonight
description: The Islanders, winners of the Stanley Cup the last two seasons, open their 10th National Hockey League season tonight against the Los Angeles Kings at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif. The game will be televised in New York on Channel 9 at 10:30 o'clock.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HERE is an agency besides the Defense Department where the budget is actually being increased. And there is joy at the Patent Office at the modest 4.8 percent gain, for the money will eventually help to cut into a backlog of applications from inventors who now wait for two years for their Federal patents.

title: Chicago Jury Gives $208,000 To Couple Bumped by Delta
description: A Circuit Court jury has awarded a retired couple $208,000 for being bumped from a Delta Air Lines flight.

title: ZUMWALT CRITICIZES LTV GRUMMAN BID
description: Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, the former Chief of Naval Operations, testified today that if the LTV Corporation was allowed to take over the Grumman Corporation, the resulting reduction in competition for military contracts would be ''very negative from the viewpoint of the Government and national defense.''

title: SELF-MANAGEMENT: CURE FOR POLISH WOES?
description: An eerie silence pervades the halls at the new Ursus state tractor plant, built some eight years ago with the help of Massey-Ferguson on the outskirts of the Polish capital.

title: VW PURSUES ROLE IN CANADA
description: Volkswagen's decision to build an auto-parts plant in Canada, announced yesterday, reflects a growing interest among West Germany's automotive manufacturers in using Canada as a back door to sales in the United States. The plant's value is estimated at $82 million (American funds).

title: Brewer Ends Soft Drink Test
description: The second attempt of Anheuser-Busch Inc., the nation's largest brewer, to gain a foothold in the soft-drink business has ended unsuccessfully.

title: Change Barred At Troubled FSC
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge declined to appoint a trustee to oversee the operations of the FSC Corporation and said a senior vice president should continue running the diversified leasing and manufacturing company.

title: 13 ARE ACCUSED IN TAXI PAYOFFS FOR INSPECTIONS
description: Thirteen people, including eight present or former New York City taxi inspectors, were arrested yesterday and charged with accepting payoffs from cabdrivers to certify that vehicles met government safety and pollution-control standards.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt SEXTET. T.S. Eliot & Truman Capote & Others. By John Malcolm Brinnin. 278 pages. Illustrated with Photographs. Delacorte/Seymour Law- rence. $15.95. NO one could possibly fault the liveliness and intimacy of these six literary portraits by the poet, teacher a nd social historian JohnMalcolm Brinnin, based on a journal he has ke pt for more than 40 years. Whether he is showing us someone's les s austere view of T.S. Eliot - ''On the day Time magazine came out w ith his face on the cover,'' reports Eliot's longtime roommate Jo hn Hayward to Mr. Brinnin, ''he walked for hours looking for wh erever he might find it,shamelessly taking peeks at himself'' - or re producing a somewhat bizarre picture of Montgomery Clift and Marle ne Dietrich kissing at aparty while ''holding one another like prayin g mantises,'' Mr. Brinnin continually astonishes the reader of ''Sextet'' with the sharpness of his focus and the precision of h is characterizations.

title: RIVETT'S 'LE PONT DU NORD'
description: THE first day: Marie (Bulle Ogier), newly released from prison, arrives in Paris in the back of an open truck. It has to be open. Marie cannot stand being in enclosed spaces. She meets Baptiste (Pascale Ogier), a severely pretty young woman who wears jeans, a leather jacket and a resolutely humorless expression. Baptiste trails Marie's heels, like a mean puppy.

title: Electric Chain Saws Recalled After Problems of a 2d Brand
description: The McCulloch Corporation of Los Angeles began yesterday to recall 8,000 electric chain saws that might be capable of restarting when set down after use.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
VICE PRESIDENT AFFIRMS "ALL TREATIES"
description: There was no mourning in most of the Arab world today for President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, whose separate peace with Israel had led to his isolation.

title: Actors' Fund to Mark Centennial With Benefit
description: The Actors' Fund of America will observe its 100th anniversary in February with a celebration at Radio City Music Hall, ''Night of 10 0 Stars.''

title: CANADIAN, U.S. WITNESSES DIFFER ON ACID RAIN
description: The United States and Canadian governments differed sharply today over whether it was necessary to take immediate action to deal with the problem of acid rain.

title: 4 SOLIDARITY LEADERS FAIL TO GAIN SEATS ON NATIONAL PANEL
description: Four top Solidarity officials, including one involved in the controversy over cigarette price increases, failed today to win seats on the national leadership commission.

title: A TAILGATE PICNIC FOR GRIDIRON DEVOTEES
description: IT is a uniquely American ritual, combining two national passions: football and automobiles. The fall tailgate party season is under way again, and station wagons have never smelled so good.

title: United Cuts Fares
description: United Airlines announced sharp fare reductions Tuesday for coast-to-coast flights and on flights from the Midwest to the West Coast.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
YANKS AND BREWERS LOOK TO BULLPENS
description: Last weekend at County Stadium, Rollie Fingers participated in a pennant-clinching celebration that reminded him of the rowdy years in Oakland when the A's won five division titles and three World Series.
