After securing a playoff berth by beating the Tigers last Saturday, the Brewer players spent nearly three hours behind the closed door of their clubhouse, consuming 10 cases of champagne and dunking everyone from the team's president to its equipment manager in the whirlpool.

title: EXPERT WITNESS IN TWO TRIALS ACCUSED OF LYING ON TRAINING
description: A man who had been retained as a psychologist for the defense in two celebrated criminal cases was charged yesterday with having lied under oath about his professional credentials.

title: Cities Service
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. said that it had received a contract from the Cities Service Company to provide detailed engineering and procurement for a $100 million, 30,000 barrel-a-day hydrocracking unit for Cities Service's Lake Charles, La., refinery. The company said that process technology would be supplied by the Union Oil Company of California.

title: SCHRADER, ABE, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
'TIFELAND,' WITH LENI RIEFENSTAHL AS STAR AND DIRECTOR
description: LENI RIEFENSTAHL filmed ''Tiefland'' between 1942 and 1945 against a historical backdrop that becomes the only reason for not regarding this effort as utter foolishness. Unlike ''Olympia'' and ''Triumph of the Will,'' Miss Riefenstahl's legendary works of pro-Nazi propaganda, ''Tiefland'' makes no attempt to address the politics of the day. Instead, it casts Miss Riefenstahl as a saintly, castanetwielding Spanish peasant, loved equally well by a handsome mountain lad and the brutal, powerful ruler of the village.

title: Real Estate; Converting Loft Space To Offices
description: THE year 1978 was a turning point for William H. Nickerson. ''I rolled the dice in 1978,'' he says. He decided that year to vacate the tenants at the family-owned, turn-of-the-century building at 1100 Avenue of the Americas, on the northeast corner of 42d Street, all on short-term leases, and rebuild it as first-class, modern office space.

title: ANDERSON ASSAILS CAREY, CALLING HIM 'INDIFFERENT'
description: Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader of the State Senate, criticized Governor Carey yesterday for what he called the Governor's ''indifference, indecision and invisibility.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE VICE PRESIDENT'S STATEMENT
description: Following are excerpts from Vice President Hosni Mubarak's statement today announcing President Anwar el-Sadat's death, as translated by The Associated Press:

title: SADAT: THE U.S. REFLECTS
description: The murder of President Sadat of Egypt has stunned this city into silence, and forced in the executive and in Congress a pause for reflection on United States policy in the Middle East. This may be one consolation of the tragedy.

title: Baseball's Dishonest Season
description: QUESTION: When Bowie Kuhn and his court jesters decided to split the 1981 baseball season like a walnut, they dreamed up a playoff in which the winners of the first-half season - the Yankees, Oakland, Philadelphia and Los Angeles - would meet the second-half winners for the divisional championships. In the American League West, the end of the irregular season found Kansas City on top by a half-game over Oakland. Why did the Royals then have to play a postseason game with Cleveland?

title: Senate Alters Cable TV Bill
description: The Senate struck from a pending communications bill provisions that mayors across the country say would threaten their cities' authority to regulate cable television franchises.

title: PLAYED SULKING-BLONDE ROLES
description: Gloria Grahame, the actress best known for her screen portrayals of sulking and occasionally wisecracking blondes, died on Monday night of cancer at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 55 years old.

title: U.A.W. Stages C ornell Strike
description: Some 950 service and maintenance workers seeking thei r first contract struck Cornell University, setting up picket lines at entrances to the campus.

title: Fighting for His Job
description: Kenneth Milano is the high school football coach in the Denver suburb of Aurora, Colo., who was suspended last month after a practice session aimed at disciplining a player had developed into what several witnesses termed a severe beating. Now Milano has filed suit to prevent the school district from dismissing him.

title: ANDREW YOUNG LEADS MAYORAL VOTE IN ATLANTA, GAINING SPOT IN A RUNOFF
description: Former United States Representative Andrew Young and State Representative Sidney Marcus were headed for a mayoral runoff contest after winning the top two spots yesterday in this city's hotly contested nonpartisan primary. Both are Democrats.

title: ISRAEL TELLS JAPAN IT REGRETS ARAFAT WILL VISIT
description: In an unusual diplomatic move, Israel publicly expressed regret today through its Ambassador here that Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, had been invited to visit Tokyo next week and ''will be received by political leaders.''

title: FINANCIAL TIMES ENDS WEEKLY
description: World Business Weekly, the three-year-old digest of international business and financial news aimed at the American business executive, is ceasing publication after its current issue, the Financial Times Group announced yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: SHUTTLE TANK ARRIVES AT SPACE CENTER: The external fuel tank for the third space shuttle flight as it arrived yesterday at the center in Cape Canaver-al, Fla., after a five-day journey by barge. It will later be attached to the command craft Columbia, which is, however, still weeks away from its second voyage.

title: Leader in Dominica Plot D epicts Rastafarian Plan
description: The leader of a plot to overthrow the Government of Dominica testified today he had persuaded members of a religious cult not to stage a bloodbath on the tiny Caribbean island.

title: Sawdon Wins Lees Carpets
description: Sawdon & Bess, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, is the new agency for Lees Carpets, the leader in the wall-to-wall category and a division of Burlington Industries.

title: Noranda Unit Buys Carol Cable
description: Canada Wire and Cable Ltd., a subsidiary of Noranda Mines Ltd., of Toronto, said that it had acquired the Carol Cable Company from Avnet Inc., a New York-based electronics distibution concern, for $140 million.

title: HOUSE BACKS SOCIAL PROGRAMS FUNDS
description: With Republicans divided, the Democratic-controlled House of Representatives approved an $87.3 billion financing bill for social programs tonight despite a threatened Presidential veto.

title: '... Any Gun You Want'
description: In his recent speech on crime, President Reagan quoted approvingly from an Esquire magazine article by a man who decided to defend again st neigh borhood crime by buying guns for himself and his wife. As the Presid ent was giving this implicit support to the proliferation of private firearms, Administration officials were preparing to dismantle the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and F irearms, the Federal agency that controls illegal possession an d trafficking in guns.

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TRUDEAU MAKING FINAL BID FOR ACCORD ON NEW CHARTER
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today invited Canada's 10 provincial premiers to Ottawa for a last attempt to reach a national consensus on constitutional reform.

title: Woman Pleads Guilty I n Lottery on a House
description: A woman who tried to raffle off her $60,000 house pleaded guilty today to a charge of unlawful promotion of gambling.

title: Honored Philadelphian Becomes Subject of Debate
description: The City Council President in Philadelphia, Joseph E. Coleman, has reluctantly returned a $9,850 18-karat gold watch presented to him at a dinner in his honor because of ''vicious and baseless attacks upon my character and integrity.''

title: Noncommercial Flights Face New Curbs Today
description: New restrictions on noncommercial flights will take effect tomorrow in the Chicago, New York and Cleveland tra ffic control center areas.

title: HOUSE UNIT DELAYS A KEY AWACS VOTE
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee postponed from today until tomorrow morning a vote on a resolution of disapproval of President Reagan's plan to sell $8.5 billion in air defense equipment, including five Airborne Warning and Control System planes, to Saudi Arabia.

title: BYRNE TO RELEASE LINDBERGH FILES, 49 YEARS AFTER THE KIDNAPPING
description: Governor Byrne said today that he would issue an executive order making 90,000 documents and pieces of evidence in the kidnapping-murder of the infant son of Charles A. Lindbergh available to scholars and other ''interested parties.''

title: MARGARET MEAD FILM FESTIVAL OCT. 17-18
description: Forty-one anthropological films, including 19 premieres, will be offered Oct. 17 and 18 at the American Museum of Natural History during the fifth Margaret Mead Festival. They will run continuously from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. at five sites without charge other than the museum's pay-what-you-wish admission fee.

title: PERILS OF MUSHROOM HUNTING IN GERMANY
description: This is the time of year when Germans, as if seized by a communal tropism, are drawn into the woods to gather wild mushrooms. Again and again, they are told to be careful.

title: A REAPPRAISAL OF 'SOMALIA'S DIF FICULTIES'
description: To the Editor:

title: LONDON IS EASING RULES IN ULSTER PRISONS
description: The British Government, making a conciliatory gesture to prisoners in Northern Ireland, granted them the right today to wear their own clothes all the time, instead of requiring any kind of prison-issued clothing.

title: PARTY DRAWS A COLLECTION OF ROCKEFELLERS
description: ''THIS is the first time I've se en them all together,'' said David Rockefeller, smiling and gesturing with his h and at the collection ofblue and white Ming porcelains, the Japanese Haniwa figures, the bronzes and delicately painted wood carvings from Japan. ''It would have pleased my brother very much.''

title: Newspaper Plans Layoffs
description: The Baltimore News-American will lay off an undetermined number of employees this month, according to a newspaper union official and the afternoon newspaper. Charles Coyle, a spokesman for The News-American, said the decision came ''as a result of the sluggish Baltimore economy.'' The newspaper, a publication of the Hearst Company, has a staff of about 1,000, including 155 editorial employees.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Yom Kippur to Begin At Sundown Tonight
description: Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, begins at sundown this evening.

title: BRITISH ARMY REDUCING ROLE IN NORTHERN IRELAND
description: The British Army's role in maintaining order in Northern Ireland has decreased significantly both in the numbers involved and in the missions assigned, while the Royal Ulster Constabulary has assumed increased responsibility for security.

title: South African Tour of New York Courts Canceled
description: A three-day escorted tour of New York City's court system for a group of South African jurists did not take place this week because two local judges refused to participate.

title: Blackjack Tourney Wins Ad Approval
description: ATLANTIC CITY (AP) - The New Jersey Casino Control Commission voted to allow a Boardwalk casino hotel to advertise Atlantic City's first blackjack tournament, but it withheld permission on the holding of the contest.

title: WINE TALK
description: central France. Winter in the valley of the Marne is a long period of chill fogs, gray days and long nights, and Champagne people know that the few days of bright fall weather are only harbingers of the somber months ahead. This year i s worse than ever for the Champagne makers. Not only is the long wint er about to set in; they have no wine to tide them through it. I f ever a group of wine men had counted on a decent harvest it wa s the Champag ne growers in the year 1981. The ir prayers were not heard. It was a summer of rain, hail and mold. An d then morerain.

title: Hynes Asks U.S.  T o Help on Arson
description: Fire Commissioner Charles J. Hynes urged the Federal Government to finance an arson-prevention plan that he said could save lives, neighborhoods and millions of tax dollars.

title: 20-Cent 'C' Stamp in a Week
description: The Postal Service said today it would put a 20-cent ''C'' stamp on sale Oct. 13 to meet the demand created by the increase in first-class postage that will take effect Nov. 1.Like the ''A'' and the ''B'' stamps, the ''C'' was printed in anticipation of a postal rate rise. It will eventually be dropped when large quantities of 20-cent stamps are available.

title: JERSEY HIGH COURT UPHOLDS BALLOT BIAS RULING
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld a lower court's ruling t hat a statement on the November ballot explaining a proposed constitutional amendment on riparian land was biased and wo uld discourage passage. State officials immediately agreed to use a statement recommended by the court.

title: BUYING MIDEAST ALLIES
description: The assassination of Anwar el-Sadat not onl y throws the whole Camp David settlement up for grabs but also dramat izes the failure of a Middle East policy based on muscle-flexing an d allies who are for sale. Egypt may be Iran all over again, and s o may Saudi Arabia. In its eagerness to sign up military surrogates, the Reagan Administration has failed to consider the Uni ted States' long-term interests in the area.

title: EGYPT'S ACTING LEADERS
description: The man most likely to succeed Anwar el-Sadat as President of Egypt is Vice President Hosni Mubarak, Mr. Sadat's protege and closest adviser.

title: SHERMAN K. KNAPP, UTILITIES OFFICIAL
description: Sherman R. Knapp, retired chairman of the board of Northeast Utilities and a leader in the commercial development of nuclear power in New England, died Monday at his home on St. Simon's Island, Ga., after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Shopping Game Is Set For Cable TV Users
description: Soon, thanks to the wonders of cable TV, ''800'' phone numbers and credit cards, certain Americans will be able to participate in a game show from their very own homes. No, not play the game.

title: G.E. NET UP 13% IN 3D QUARTER WITH AN 11% RISE IN REVENUES
description: The General Electric Company yesterday reported a 13 percent increase in third-quarter earnings on a revenue gain of 11 percent. The diversified electrical equipment company earned $405 million, or $1.78 a share, in the third quarter, compared with $358 million, or $1.58 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenues rose to $6.64 billion from $5.96 billion.

title: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Promotes Executive
description: Burton Blum, 41-year-old senior vice president and recent arrival at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson, has been promoted to executive vice president-associate creative director and member of the management committee.

title: POSTSEASON BASEBALL IN CANADIAN DEBUT
description: Half a title or not, Canadians reacted with fervor today to their postseason baseball debut, which will take place tomorrow when the Montreal Expos open the National League's Eastern Division playoff against the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Elude Government Trap
description: A rebel force that the Salvadoran Army thought it had trapped in the northern province of Chalatenango apparently slipped away four days ago, military sources said today.

title: ISRAEL DISCLOSES RESCUE MISSION ON SAUDI REEF
description: Israel's Defense Ministry said today than an Israeli missile boat had run aground on a Saudi Arabian reef 12 days ago and had been extricated by an Israeli force without hostile action from the Saudis.

title: CBS/Records
description: CBS Inc. said that its CBS/Records Group would phase out its manufacturing and distribution facilities in Santa Maria, Calif., in order to increase manufacturing efficiency. Production at the plant will continue at least until the end of the year. The Santa Maria plant and a related distribution facility operated by CBS's Columbia House division employ 588 workers.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: WHEN a rock group creates a distinctive new sound that takes it to the top of the best-seller charts, the last thing anyone wants the group to do is change. But the Police, the English trio whose third and most recent album was a million-seller in the United States and a worldwide hit as well, have never had much faith in the conventional wisdom of the music business. In l978 they promoted their first album, ''Outlandos d'Amour,'' by touring America on a shoestring budget, riding with all their equipment in a single van. Instead of accepting the usual advance against royalties from their record company, A&M, the Police negotiated a contract guaranteeing them a higher royalty rate than is customary. If their records had been unsuccessful, they would have received little or no money. But their unusual decision proved extremely profitable for them: their second album went gold and their third went platinum.

title: U.S. FINES AN AIRLINE $4,000 FOR VIOLATING TRADE CURBS ON CUBA
description: A Florida charter airline has been fined $4,000 for violating United States customs rules on taking American newspapers and magazines to Havana.

title: FOUNDATION TO AID WOMEN OVER 40
description: Wonder Woman, the comic book heroine, marked her 40th year of daring exploits this year. In celebration, the people at Warner Communications have started the Wonder Woman Foundatio n, which will provide finan cial grants for women 40 and older.

title: DINKINS ENDORSED BY MANHATTAN'S DEMOCRATIC LEADER
description: The Democratic leader of Manhattan yesterday rejected Andrew J. Stein, his party's nominee for Manhattan Borough Pr esident, and came out instead for the Liberal Party candidate, David N. Dinkins, a personal friend and a Harlem political ally.

title: Edmondo Zacchini, Inventor Of Human Cannonball Act, 87
description: Edmondo Zacchini, credited with inventing the ''Human Cannonball'' circus act by firing himself out of an spring-powered cannon, died here in a hospital Saturday. He was 87 years old.

title: THE TWENTY-CENT STAMP
description: The twenty-cent stamp Could be made most merry By mixing the glue With brandy and sherry. JULIUS GRODENCHIK

title: TO HUNGARIANS, THE POLES ARE ON THE WRONG TRACK
description: There is a growing sense of confidence here that the Hungarian model of gradually loosening controls is ''the right way'' and that the crisis in Poland proves it.

title: Mortgage Rate R ises to 17.71%
description: The average interest rate charged Americans for new home loans rose to a record 17.71 percent in September for long-term, fixed-rate mortgages, the Government said today. It was the seventh consecutive monthly increase in interest rates for home loans.

title: REAL POLICEWOMEN VIEW THE TV VARIETY
description: WHEN Loretta Swit and Tyne Daly are promoted to New York City police detectives in the CBS-TV movie ''Cagney and Lacey,'' the male detectives give them a desk - in the hallway outside the squad room.

title: NEW BRITISH PARTY GETS TWOFOLD LIFT AT PARLEY
description: The Social Democratic Party, which hopes to fill the underpopulated middle ground of British politics, got two pieces of good news today as its first annual conference reached the halfway point.

title: ENERGY, METALS UP
description: Energy and precious-metal issues moved briskly higher yesterday, while the stock market over all posted a modest decline as investors sought to evaluate the assassination of President Sadat of Egypt.

title: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Advertising; Corporate Ads Show Growth
description: DESPITE all the talk about issue or advocacy advertising, the use of that communications form seems to have reached a plateau, according to the Association of National Advertisers. Corporate advertising generally, however, has had a real growth of 5 to 6 percent, it said.

title: ASTROS WIN, 3-1, ON HOMER IN 9TH
description: Alan Ashby hit a two-run homer with two out in the bottom of the ninth inning tonight to lift the Houston Astros to a 3-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers in the opening game of the National League's Western Division playoff series.

title: Israeli Wounded in Stands
description: Israeli television said today that a security officer attached to the Israeli Embassy in Cairo was among those wounded in the attack on President Anwar el-Sadat. The man, who was not identified, was guarding Ambassador Moshe Sasson in the reviewing stand at the parade.

title: Ecuadorean Ore Lode Found
description: A deposit of copper and other strategic metals worth $2 billion or more has been found on the Pacific Ocean floor west of Ecuador, and similiar lodes probably exist off Oregon and Washington, the Government announced today.

title: 3 U.S. OFFICERS HURT IN THE ATTACK
description: Three United States military officers were wounded in the attack on President Anwar el-Sadat, but they are out of medical danger and are remaining in Egypt for the present time, officials said today.

title: SEARS ACQUISITION HAS TASTE FOR GROWTH
description: In 1906, Colbert Coldwell, a 23-year-old real estate broker, decided to form his own business in San Francisco. It proved to be just the right move, for the great earthquake and fire had leveled the city, and the services of a reliable real estate broker were much in demand.

title: Turkey Seizes a Politician
description: Necmettin Erbakan, the chairman of the Islamic fundamentalist National Salvation Party, was taken into custody by the Ankara military court today after he delivered a speech that apparently displeased the authorities. Mr. Erbakan, who is being tried on charges of conspiring to establish an Islamic state, was released from prison July 24 while his trial continued.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BILLY TAYLOR IS CUT
description: The up-and-down Giant career of Billy Taylor, the club's leading running back the last two seasons, ended yesterday when he was placed on waivers.

title: CRENSHAW: A BUDDY HOLLY REBORN?
description: and-roll rhythms, the way Mr. Holly used to do.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation has elected Thomas J. Whitaker president of Alstrip Inc., a newly acquired subsidiary.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tire Recall Described
description: John J. Nevin, chairman and chief executive officer of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, said today that the company should have voluntarily recalled its Firestone 500 tires months before the Government required it in 1978.

title: Economic Scene; Sadat Death: No Panic Seen
description: ALTHOUGH the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt inevitably raises fears in some quarters of wider conflict in the Middle East, such fears seem wrong-headed.

title: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1981
description: Assassination in Egypt Egypt's President was assassinated by a group of men in uniform as he watched a military parade in Cairo. The assassins broke rank as the parade passed by and threw grenades and fired rifles at the reviewing stand, fatally wounding Anwar el-Sadat. Others in the crowded reviewing stand area were killed or wounded. The parade was commemorating Mr. Sadat's 1973 war against Israel. For the time being, Egypt's affairs are expected to be run by Vice President Hosni Mubarek, President Sadat's long-time associate. The interim president, for the next 60 days, pending elections, will be Sufi Abu Taleb, Speaker of Parliament. (Page A1, Colum n 6.) The assassination stunned Israel, which had such a high stake in Mr. Sadat's friendship. Fear for the Eyptian-Israeli peace treaty dominated all emotions. (A1:1.)

title: RUSSIANS PLAN TO LAUNCH MODULES TO DOCK WITH AN ORBITING STATION
description: The Soviet Union, unveiling additional details on the next phase of its orbital space program, says that it plans to launch a series of specialized modules that would link up with a permanent orbiting station of the Salyut type.

title: Argentine Gas Find
description: A company formed by concerns from West Germany, France and Argentina said it had discovered an offshore hydrocarbons deposit off the southern tip of Argentina. The Argentine state oil company, Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales Sociedad del Estasdo, said today that the well, sunk to a depth of 5,685 feet, initially yielded 21.2 million cubic feet of natural gas and 1,412 cubic feet of a light mixture of gas and crude oil a day,

title: Youth, 16, Indicted In Lawyer's Death
description: A 16-year-o ld youth has been indicted on charges of murder in connection wi th the fatal stabbing of a Manhattan lawyer last month in Roosevelt Park on the Lower East Side.

title: PORTMAN, THINKING BIG, IS UNFAZED BY NEW YORK
description: John C. Portman Jr. well remembers his first visit to New York City. He was 18 years old, lonely, homesick for Georgia, on leave from the Navy and thoroughly intimidated by what he saw.

title: ASSASSINS PORTRAYED AS 'ISLAMIC FUNDAMENTALISTS'
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat appeared to be the work of ''Islamic fundamentalists'' within the Egyptian Army, Congressional sources reported.

title: A STRATEGY FOR QUICK, EASY MEALS
description: Around 5 o'clock each weekday afternoon, a chorus of weary voices echoes the same complaint throughout the city: ''I'm too tired to cook.'' As the chorus reaches a crescendo about 6 o'clock, it gladdens the hearts of pizza parlor entrepreneurs, haute carry-out proprietors and fast-food franchises.

title: 'AVAITOR'S WIFE' OF ROHMER
description: EARLY one Parisian morning, two men arrive within minutes of each other to leave notes beneath the same woman's door. The first man, 20-year-old Francois (the late Philippe Marlaud), is so much in love with 25-year-old Anne (Marie Riviere) that he has arranged for a plumber to come fix her leaky faucet; that's what his note says. The second man, considerably older, is Anne's long-absent lover, Christian. He has arrived to tell Anne that he has had a reconciliation with his wife, who is now pregnant, and that their affair must end. Christian is a pilot, which is more or less how Eric Rohmer's latest film, ''The Aviator's Wife,'' gets its title.

title: Soviet Oil Output Up
description: Soviet oil production in the first nine months of this year totaled 455 million tons, or about 3.5 billion barrels, an increase of 1 percent over the comparable period last year, Moscow radio said today.

title: SANTA FE TRADING REVIEWED
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday, following informal charges from traders that they had been bilked out of millions of dollars, that it was conducting ''a review'' into the trading of stock options in Santa Fe International.

title: STAGE: A PAIR OF ONE-ACTERS AT FRANKEL THEATER
description: THE scene is a children's playroom and the floor is covered with toys, dolls, papers, a baseball bat and other signs of disorder. The mother, played by Lorey Hayes, enters and as a reflex action immediately begins to clean up. She is servant, drudge and sex object. As she tells us, ''All these words I'm speaking are written by him.'' The ''him'' refers to the playwright, Oyamo, and she questions his veracity. What does he know about the plight of women?

title: BILLING CHANGES SOUGHT BY NEW YORK TELEPHONE
description: New York Telephone has proposed a new billing system throughout the state that would increase the cost of some calls to nearby areas and reduce the cost of calls to more distant points.

title: Sherwin-Williams Gets Most of Gray
description: The Sherwin-Williams Company said that approximately 93.2 percent of the outstanding common stock of the Gray Drug Company had been tendered by the deadline in its $54.8 million takeover of the drug company.

title: HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Denver Concert to Aid St. John the Divine
description: John Denver will give a benefit concert at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at West 112th Street, on Oct. 15 at 8 P.M.

title: 2 HELD IN ABDUCTION OF WEST SIDE JEWELER AND THIRD IS SOUGHT
description: Two men were arrested yesterday and charged with kidnapping an 86-year-old jeweler Sept. 15 as he was on his way to a synagogue near his home on the Upper West Side. A third man whose identity is known to the police was still being sought.

title: POLL DISCOUNTS INFLUENCE OF REAGAN IN JERSEY VOTE
description: Neither President Reagan nor Governor Byrne will have a great impact on the election of a New Jersey Governor, according to a poll released yesterday by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: WEST, HEARING OF SADAT'S DEATH, MOURNS THE LOSS OF A FRIEND
description: President Anwar el-Sadat was mourned through much of the West yesterday as a man of vision and courage who had brought a frail hope of peace to the Middle East.

title: HANDLED BY CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 NORWALK OFFICIALS ARE GUILTY OF THEFTS FROM UTILITY AGENCY
description: Two commissioners of the South Norwalk Electric Company in Connecticut pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing more than $10,000 from the company, and a vendor admitted taking more than $37,000 through bogus contracts.

title: 'THE STREETS ARE GETTING CLEANER'
description: To the Editor:

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
description: Short-and long-term interest rates fell yesterday in extremely light trading volume, with price changes rapid but based on very few trades, securities dealers said.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES CURB ON IDENTIFYING AGENTS
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today overwhelmingly approved a bill that makes it a crime in some cases to publish lists or otherwise identify undercover United States intelligence operatives.

title: CONCEPT INC. FILLS POST
description: James T. Treace, 35, has joined Concept Inc., a manufacturer of surgical and medical equipment for hospitals and physicians, as president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Terry F. Tanner, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer of the company, based in Clearwater, Fla.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Swiss Raise Rates
description: Major Swiss banks will raise their time deposit rates by one-quarter to one-half percentage point effective today, banking sources said.

title: Polaroid Founder Testifies
description: Edwin H. Land, the inventor of instant photography and the founder of the giant Polaroid Corporation, testified in Federal court today that he had discussed a color film development with an Eastman Kodak Company researcher 14 years before Kodak is accused of copying the innovation.

title: NEW MIDEAST UNCERTAINTY FELT
description: American business and economic leaders expressed fears yesterday that the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat could further shake the Middle East's fragile stability. Concern over the shooting of the Egyptian President drove up the price of gold, the dollar and domestic oil stocks.

title: OLD PHILADELPHIA STORE STIRS REALTY-PRESERVATION DISPUTE
description: The largest piece of Victorian architecture remaining in the city's commercial district is caught between the booming downtown real estate market and an equally resurgent interest in preserving Philadelphia's rapidly disappearing architectural landmarks.

title: MIKLOS SCHWALB
description: Miklos Schwalb, a Hungarian pianist who gave several New York recitals after his debut in the city in 1942, died F riday at the University Ho spital in Boston.

title: SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CBS TO CUT CONVENTION NEWS
description: Thomas H. Wyman, the president of CBS Inc., said yesterday that CBS would not cover the 1984 Presidential conventions gavel-to-gavel. Instead, he said, CBS will broadcast live only the major developments, saving other proceedings for summaries.

title: Savings-Loan Merger Backed
description: The Government today approved the merger of two savings and loans associations in the Chicago area, bringing to 16 the number of federally approved mergers so far this year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * CBS Inc. has appointed Donald D. Wear Jr. vice president, Washington affairs, and J. Roger Moody vice president, development.

title: Oil Data Delayed
description: Because of a delay in gathering statistics, the weekly American Petroleum Institute figures do not appear today. The figures are expected to appear tomorrow.

title: Boston Exchange Selects First Chief
description: Following the pattern established by the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and other regional stock exchanges, the Boston Stock Exchange has created a full-time salaried position of chairman and chief executive officer. And the first person to occupy it, beginning on Oct. 26, will be Charles J. Mohr, 34 years old, who is now a vice president of the Big Board.

title: The View From Yovimpa Point
description: Utah's Bryce Canyon National Park is a wonderland of salmon-colored limestone spires, sculptured by centuries of wind erosion. Stunning views abound; from Yovimpa Point a vista of canyons, mesas and cliffs spreads out for 90 miles. About 600,000 visitors a year come to contemplate this natural beauty, which is enhanced by the remarkable silence.

title: TELEVISION TIED TO COMPLACENCY ON HEALTH
description: Americans who watch a lot of television ''are more likely to be complacent about eating, drinking and exercise'' than other Americans, according to a preliminary report issued today.

title: Advertising Appealing To a Sense Of Shame Philip H. Doughert
description: ONE can think of many emotions that Madison Avenue tries to play on to make a sale - greed, lust, pride, anger - but shame does not come readily to mind, except perhaps in deodorant advertising.

title: Philharmonic to Open New Hall at C. W. Post
description: The New York Philharmonic will play a benefit concert Saturday to mark the opening of the new Concert Theater of the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University in Greenvale.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PROMPT home removal of spots and stains on upholstered furniture, curtains and other fabrics is not only less expensive than having the job done professionally, it is also sometimes the only way to insure that stains will come out completely.

title: HERS
description: FAR ahead of us, past the sign that reads ''Emergency Entrance'' and through the double doors, an orderly in sea-green coat lounges behind a wheelchair and observes our slow progress. My mother-in-law is 80 years old. When she walks, her body lists f rom side to side like a wobbly table. I match my steps to her slow steps and wonder why the young man doesn't bring the wheelchair to help us. Struck by a whiplash of paranoia, I decide it has something to do wi th malpractice suits. After a while, I realize he probably do esn't see us at all.

title: ISRAELIS SAY THEY WILL ABIDE BY PEACE TREATY WITH EGYPT
description: The Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin gave assurances today that Israel intended to abide by the peace treaty with Egypt, despite the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat, as long as Egypt kept to the provisions of the accords.

title: HAIG PLEDGES ACTIVE SUPPORT
description: Egyptian leaders moved quickly today to seek an orderly transition a nd to stress continuity a day after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat.

title: WNYC-TV TO ALTER FORMAT
description: New York City's television station, Channel 31, will make a radical change in its format beginning Oct. 19 with emphasis on prime-time programming for black viewers. In addition, beginning Oct. 29, the city's most heavily populated borough, Brooklyn, will get its own weekly television magazine series.

title: The Region; Honesty Put First In Poll on Governor
description: New Jersey residents rank ''honesty'' as the quality they most want in a Governor.

title: House of Worship Tour
description: A free walking tour of historic houses of worship in Lower Manhattan is being held on Sunday by the Yorkville Catholic-Jewish Council.

title: Doctors Report a Gain In Treating Leukemia
description: Children who have suffered a relapse of leukemia have a better chance of recovering from the disease if they receive bone marrow transplants at the time of a second remission rather than as a last resort, doctors reported today.

title: HE'S STRIVING TO MAKE AMERICANS PAY AS THEY GO
description: At 7:30 one recent morning, Drew Lewis started his day at the Transportation Department, as is his custom, with a brandy snifter full of iced tea that he sipped at his desk as two aides, Mark Knouse and Judy Swantak, outlined his schedule and reviewed the important mail.

title: Around the Nation; Governor of Vermont Won't Seek Re-election
description: Gov. Richard A. Snelling, a Republican, announced today that he would not seek election to a fourth term next year.

title: ABBOTT INDICTED IN KNIFE KILLING OF CAFE WAITER
description: Jack Henry Abbott, who has spent most of his life in prison and whose book, ''In the Belly of the Beast,'' has received critical acclaim, was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on charges of murdering a waiter here in July.

title: No Headline
description: The New England Patriots, the Jets' opponents on Sunday, have been having trouble finding a punter. Today they waived Mike Hubach and signed Ken Hartley, a free agent, to take over the kicking.

title: OFFICER WOUNDED IN SHOOTOUT WITH 4 GUNMEN
description: A polic e of ficer was shot and wounded yesterday as he and his partner excha nged fire with four gunmen along the Sara D. Roosevelt Parkway on th e Lower East Side, the police said.

title: Citibank Executive Emerges From Busy 'All Savers' Week
description: For Richard M. Kovacavich, the 37-year-old senior vice president of Citibank's New York banking division, the past week has been one of the busiest of his career. Mr. Kovacavich was responsible for the huge bank's efforts to develop and market its ''All Savers'' certificates - the tax-free savings certificates instituted last Thursday by banks all over the country with great fanfare.

title: SENATE PASSES A.T.&T. DECO NTROL
description: The Senate approved today, by a vote of 90 to 4, a telephone deregulation bill that would free the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to expand into new data -processing and information services.

title: KEY SUSPECT: MOSLEM GANG OF TERRORISTS
description: A small, violent Moslem fundamentalist group has become the main target of the investigation into the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat.

title: Film Box Offices Set 8-Month Record
description: Sparked by the biggest summer movie boxoffice returns in history, a record $1.956 billion was taken in at United States theaters in the first eight months this year, the Motion Picture Association of America reported yesterday.

title: SENATE BILL ASKS BANK DECONTROL
description: Senator Jake Garn, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee , citing the ''revolution th at is taking place in the financial services industry,'' introduced legislation today designed to help banks and thrift institution s compete more effectively against other institutions offeri ng financial services.

title: Around the World; Two More Labor M.P.'s J oin New British Party
description: Two Labor Members of Parliament, one of them a political adviser to James Callaghan when he was Prime Minister, defected to the Social Democratic Party today at the new British political party's first congress.

title: Around the Nation; Priests Campaigning Against United Way
description: Priests in Berks County have advised Roman Catholics to refuse to donate to the United Way because the organization provides funds to the county's Planned Parenthood Center, which has an abortion counseling program.

title: U.S. BACKS PIPELINE WAIVERS
description: The Reagan Administration today threw its weight behind efforts to build a 4,800-mile pipeline to bring natural gas from Alaska to the lower 48 states, an enormous project that has bogged down because of problems in raising the money.

title: MALLE'S PROVOCATIVE TABLE TALK IN 'MY DINNER WITH ANDRE'
description: WALLY (Wallace Shawn), wearing an oversize raincoat, mushes morosely along a street in SoHo in a chilly evening light. Wally, a playwright who takes acting job s when he can get them to make ends meet, is on his way to a posh restaurant to h ave dinner with Andre (Andre Gregory), the innovative theater direc tor (Off Off Broadway's ''Alice in Wonderland'' at his Manhattan Thea ter Project) who was Wally's first mentor.

title: Sharon Seeks City Shares
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation said it had filed an application with the insurance d epartment of New Hampshire for approval to acquire up to 25 percent of the City Investing Company's stock outstanding.

title: REVLON'S HEALTH-CARE PUSH
description: For millions of women around the world, the name Revlon is synonymous with the beauty business. But the company, which the late Charles Revson founded in 1932 as a nail polish business and built into the largest manufacturer of retail cosmetics in the United States, is now deeply involved in such unglamorous products as plasma derivatives, diagnostic reagents, Tums antacid tablets and lens-grinding equipment.

title: MOSCOW SENDS PERFUNCTORY CONDOLENCES TO CAIRO
description: The Soviet Union sent a chilly message of condolence today on the death of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and voiced the hope that his successors would abandon the good relations with Israel and the United States.

title: LUNG DISABILITY PAYMENTS ARE CUT FOR REGULAR SMOKER
description: The North Carolina Supreme Court has ruled that disability payments to a textile worker could be reduced because the worker regularly smoked cigarettes.

title: 2 MILLION MOSLEMS CONVERGING ON HOLY SITES
description: About 2.2 million Moslems from 64 countries streamed from Mecca to the plain of Arafat today for the climax of their annual pilgrimage.

title: FIRST STRIKE
description: McLEAN, Va. - President Reagan's decision on the MX missile signals t hat the United States is now firmly and publicly embarked on a f irst-strike strategic nuclear policy. This is a prescription for n uclear castastrophe, a disaster unparalleled in the history of m ankind.

title: CHRISTIE'S HOLDS A MAJOR AUCTION FOR SMALL ARMS
description: Gun collectors, dealers, manufacturers and onlookers gathered yesterday afternoon at Christie's, Park Avenue and 59th Street, to bid at and watch what the auction house described as the first major auction of rifles, revolvers, shotguns and pistols in this country.

title: Addenda
description: * Money magazine increasing its circu lation rate base 8.6 percent, to 950,000 fr om 875,000, and its advertising rates 18.4 percent, effective wit h the January issue.

title: Financier's Trial Scheduled
description: Jury selection will begin Nov. 16 in Superior Court in the trial of Claus C. von Bulow, a New York City financier charged with trying to murder his wife.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $293,000 in qr and $3,637,000 in the 9 mos and after losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $12 million in qr and 9 mos...C-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $880,000 in qr and $2,545,000 in the 9 mos

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WINDOWS ON THEIR WORLD

title: Notes on People; Thompson Suspended as Lawyer in Jersey
description: Frank Thompson Jr., a former United States Representative who was convicted of bribery in the Abscam case earlier this year, was suspended from the practice of law yesterday by the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: HOMEOWNERS' TAX QUESTIONS
description: IT was christened Christmas in July for investors - and the Reagan tax act does bestow a host of benefits on the millions of Americans whose biggest investment is their house.

title: A Realignment At Conde Nast
description: There were a number of executive changes announced in the Conde Nast family yesterday.

title: Jets Claim Taylor on Waivers
description: ''It's all over,'' a despondent Billy Taylor said yesterday morning. ''I'm not in pro football now. Who wants an ex-running back from the Giants?''

title: SALVADORAN URGES FOREIGN MEDIATION
description: A Salvadoran opposition leader said Tuesday that the alliance of political groups and guerrilla forces opposed to the ruling junta was ready to discuss ''a political solution'' to the civil war if the Government removed its conditions for a cease-fire.

title: Notes on People; A Vegetable Garden Grew in Shea Stadium
description: It was back in 1969, Joe Pignatano recalled yesterday, that a stray tomato plant pushed its way up through the dirt beyond the right field fence in Shea Stadium. That was also the year the Mets won the World Series, and to Mr. Pignatano, a Mets pitching coach and amateur gardener, the plant was a good omen.

title: RANGERS BACK SWIRLING ST YLE
description: In the wake of their opening-night loss to the Detroit Red Wings Tuesday at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers and their rookie coach, Herb Brooks, refused to blame the swirling hockey system that failed for their 5-2 defeat. The system Brooks is insisting his players use is basically European: to form an attack in their own zone, the Ranger forwards are to circle and criss-cross until a defenseman passes to one of them. No more are the Rangers, like most of the other teams in the league, suppo sed to churn up and down the ice in fixed lanes.

title: Colombia Closes a University Because of Violent Incidents
description: The National University here has been closed because of violence, Education Minister Carlos Alban said in reports published today.

title: Around the Nation; Reporters Fined $50 In Nuclear Site Trespass
description: Seven reporters who followed a group of demonstrators across a barricade at a nuclear waste site Sept. 7 were found guilty of criminal trespass today and fined $50 each.

title: A'S BEAT ROYALS, 2-1
description: Tony Armas drilled a grounder through the legs of George Brett, the Kansas City third baseman, for a double that scored Dwayne Murphy from second base in the eighth inning and helped the Oakland A's beat the Royals today, 2-1. The victory gave the A's a 2-0 lead in the American League Western Division playoff.

title: LOYALTY AND INVISIBILITY TOOK MUBARAK TO TOP
description: ''If I'm not present at a Cabinet meeting and Vice President Mubarak is,'' Anwar el-Sadat announced in a television broadcast in May 1979, ''he is automatically the chairman.''

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $275,307 foreign currency exchange gain... C-After $10,397 foreign currency exchange loss

title: Without Sadat
description: The tribute that Americans now owe to Anwar Sadat, and to themselves, is to let him pass into history. There can be no ''Sadatism without Sadat,'' as some in Washington would have it. No successor, however able, will soon acquire his stature in Egypt, as warrior or statesman. No Egyptian can replace him in the Camp David scheme, in the hearts of Israelis or on American television screens. The policies that he made possible can be revalidated, but they cannot be merely reasserted.

title: Arab Is Reported to Confess To Killing Vienna Aide in May
description: An Arab detained after an attack on a synagogue here in August has confessed to the killing in May of a Vienna city councilor with close ties to Israel, Interior Minister Erwin Lanc said today.

title: Briefing
description: I SRAELI Ambassador Ephraim Evron has told friends that he's planning to leave his current job and return home. Mr. Evron and Prime Minister Menachem Begin have maintained a delicate - some say, strained - relationship that worsened when the Israeli leader visited the United States last month.

title: PROBLEMS OF AGING: A COURSE FOR OFFSPRING
description: GINGER BROOKWELL of Bayside, Queens, who is 28 years old, and Lorraine Howard of Richmond Hill, Queens, who is 53, have two things in common: Each has an aging parent and each spent part of the summer back in school learning how to cope with the situation.

title: Banks Cut Broker Rate
description: Two of the nation's leading 10 banks, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and New York's Chemical Bank, lowered their broker loan rates to 16 percent today from 16 1/2 percent, effective immediately.

title: DEXTER M. BULLARD, A PIONEER IN PSYCHOANALYSIS TREATMENT
description: Dr. Dexter M. Bullard, retired medical director of the Chestnut Lodge mental hospital in Rockville, Md., died of cancer Monday at his home. He was 83 years old.

title: Arms Impact On Inflation
description: The Reagan Administration's military buildup could contribute to inflation ''in the very short run,'' but it was not expected to have a major effect on consumer prices, Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today.

title: Bail Is Set at $350,000 In Gang-Warfare Case
description: Bail of $350,000 was set in Manhattan yesterday for a man accused of participating in three murders in a struggle between rival factions of what court papers described as ''the Bonanno organizedcrime family.''

title: 3 EX-PRESIDENTS IN DELEGATION TO FUNERAL BUT REAGAN IS NOT
description: President Reagan will not attend the funeral of Egypt's President, Anwar el-Sadat, on Saturday because of widespread concern for his safety, the White House announced. The United States will be represented by a delegation including Mr. Reagan's three immediate predecessors in office.

title: NEWARK CONNECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: HARRIS TRIAL FAIR, VERGARI SAYS, REBUTTING APPEAL
description: The Westchester County District Attorney, contending that the jury had found that Jean S. Harris ''was a liar and that the roots of her hatred for Dr. Herman Tarnower ran to the marrow,'' argued in legal papers released today that she should be denied a reversal of her conviction for the murder of the Scarsdale physician.

title: U.S. HAD ADVISED SADAT SINCE '74 ON SECURITY
description: United States concern about the personal safety of President Anwar el-Sadat goes back to the Nixon Administration.

title: TOP GRUMMAN JOBS UNCERTAIN
description: Paul Thayer, chairman and chief executive officer of the LTV Corporation, said today that he could no longer guarantee that top officials the Grumman Corporation would keep their jobs if LTV succeeded in its $450 million bid to take over Grumman.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: B-Including tax credit of $5,635,000 and loss of $8,354,000 on the sale of Margo's La Mode Inc...C-Including tax credit of $1,030,000

title: WARDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WESTPORT LAWYER NOMINATED AS U.S. ATTORNEY FOR CONNECTICUT
description: President Reagan today nominated Alan H. Nevas, a 53-year-old Westport lawyer active in state Republican politics, to be the United States Attorney for Connecticut.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard ELIZABETH TAYLOR. The Last Star. By Kitty Kelley. Illustrated. 448 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.95. EDDIE. My Life, My Loves. By Eddie Fish- er. Illustrated. 360 pages. Harper & Row. $14.95. RICHARD BURTON. By Paul Ferris. Illus- trated. 328 pages. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $15.95.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON U.S. POLICY AFTER SADAT'S DEATH
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a news conference by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. yesterday at the State Department, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Spot Oil Price Stable Despite Fears Over Mideast
description: The price of oil on the spot market remained stable yesterday despite fears in some quarters that the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt would touch off an upward price spiral.

title: RCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a tax benefit of $67.7 million...C-Net income

title: 5 I NGENIOUS SOLUTIONS FOR COPING WITH TINY SPACES
description: AT the time, most people probably didn't appreciate the farsighted import of Sid Caesar's remark, when the comedian - in the role of an astrophysicist on the 1950's ''Show of Shows'' -was asked what was the greatest problem in space; he replied, ''Closet space.''

title: RULES FOR VETERANS' RADIATION BENEFITS VOIDED
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that the Government violated the law in adopting rules that were then used to deny medical benefits to former servicemen who had been exposed to nuclear tests in Nevada and assigned to cleanup operations at Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

title: FENDI, MISSONI SHINE IN MILAN
description: Some Italian fashion houses are having difficulty maintaining the high level of excitement established at the fall and winter openings six months ago. But not Fendi and Missoni, the twin pillars of the Italian industry. Both are family enterprises, with the younger members applying new energy and a fresh outlook.

title: Letter: On Treating the Mentally Ill Community Help for the Homeless
description: o the Editor:

title: Around the World; Scores Hurt as Students Clash With Manila Police
description: Police firing guns and swinging riot sticks battled students denouncing the ''U.S.-Marcos dictatorship'' today.

title: CONSUMER DEBT UP AT 10.5% RATE
description: Americans took on $2.9 billion more in installment d ebt than they paid off in August, the biggest jump in short-term de bt since March, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: The Region; 4th Cable Concern Sues for Franchise
description: HARTFORD (AP) - A fourth cable television company started legal action against the State of Connecticut to try to reverse a decision giving the lucrative Fairfield County franchise to Cablevision of Connecticut.

title: ISLAMIC MILITANTS: RELIGION IS A FOCUS FOR OPPOSITION TO MIDEAST
description: REGIMES By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN News Analysis

title: Carpenter Scores in His Debut
description: Bobby Carpenter, the 18-year-old American who went directly to the National Hockey League without having played junior hockey, scored a goal and was credited with an assist in his first game tonight. But his team, the Washington Capitals, lost by 5-3 to the Buffalo Sabres.

title: PRESIDENT REAGAN VS. THE IMPROVABILITY OF MAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Oilers 7, Rockies 4
description: Gary Unger scored consecutive goals in the second period to lead Edmonton.

title: INTEL ADDS FOUNDRY TO FABRICATE CHIPS DESIGNED BY BUYERS
description: The Intel Corporation, looking for ways to ride out the slump in the semiconductor industry, is using its assembly lines to make chips designed by its customers themselves.

title: Mattick Steps Up
description: Saying that ''the biggest factor was my age,'' 65-year-old Bobby Mattick announced yesterday that he had decided to step aside as manager of the Toronto Blue Jays and accept a post in the club's front office. ''I loved managing,'' said Mattick, who directed the team on the field the last two years, ''but i f I managed again it would only have been for one more year.'' One of his first duties as the Blue Jays' executive coordinator of baseb all activities will be to help choose a successor, and Peter Bavasi, the team's president, was planning to meet with Ted Turner, the own er of the Atlanta Braves, about the availability of Bobby Cox.

title: SENATE REPUBLICANS IN RIFT WITH REAGAN OVER SPENDING CUTS
description: In the first open rift between the White House and Republican Congressional leaders over the budget, three Republican Senate chairmen have begun major revisions in President Reagan's proposal for $13 billion in new cuts.

title: A TEST FOR DAVE WINFIELD
description: MILWAUKEE PERHAPS someday Dave Winfield won't have to continue justifying his 10-year contract, which could be worth more than $20 million. Perhaps someday the Yankees' left fielder will be accepted simply for what he showed himself to be this season -a steady and occasionally sensational baseball player who can hit, run, throw and make spectacular catches. Perhaps someday. But not yet, because Dave Winfield is under the microscope again in the American League Eastern Division playoff.

title: 2 Hospitals in Staten Island And Seattle May Be Spared
description: Two of the nation's Public Health Service hospitals threatened with closing Oct. 31 may be kept open a little longer while local officials try to find a way to take them over, officials said today.

title: Around the World; Honduran-U.S. Exercise Starts Despite Protest
description: Honduran and United States military forces began a three-day air and sea exercise in the Caribbean today despite a last-minute attempt by neighboring Nicaragua to force its cancellation.

title: LET THE REGENTS ADVANCE HONEST STUDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Brunei Oil Reserves
description: Brunei's total recoverable oil reserves are not far short of the total 1.5 billion barrels produced so far and will last 20 years at present production rates, John Wybrew, technical director of the Brunei Shell Oil Company, said today. But recovering much of the remaining reserves, he said, will be expensive and technically difficult. In the first half of 1981, production averaged 167,000 barrels a day.

title: WHEN NEW YORK BECAME THE MODERN-ART CAPITAL
description: WHY have there been so few memoirs of the New York art scene in the early 40's, the World War II period when many European artists and writers came to the city as exiles and played a sometimes decisive role in the formation of the New York School? Everyone agrees that the war years marked a turning point in the fortunes of American art, for it was in that period that the Abstract Expressionist movement had its beginnings and, with Paris occupied by the Nazis, New York emerged for the first time as the modern-art capital of the Western world. Yet there have been very few first-hand accounts of that period.

title: '80 TRANSIT STRIKE DEPRIVES 3 UNIONS OF DUES CHECKOFF
description: A state labor board yesterday suspended for 18 months the right of three New York City transit unions to the automatic deduction of dues from salary checks. It cited the heavy costs and the hazards to the public of the illegal 11-day transit strike last year,

title: POLISH UNION ADOPTS ECONOMIC PROGRAM
description: Solidarity union delegates approved a two-year national program today to solve Poland's economic ills, issued a call for a cut in military spending and threatened a national strike over price incre ases.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We would like to lighten some wood paneling that is now stained a medium oak color. Is it possible to take it down a shade or two, or to bleach it and then restain it, by using some commercial preparation? -D.P., New York City.

title: Technology; Kodak's Fight With Polaroid
description: UNLESS Polaroid and Eastman Kodak have second thoughts - and settle their five-year-old dispute over whether Kodak has infringed Polaroid's instant-photography patents - almost everything there is to know about the development of instant photography technology is going to become public over the next couple of months.

title: Randolph Appeals Fine
description: Willie Randolph, the Yankee second baseman, formally appealed Wednesday the $500 fine that the team had assessed him after he had missed an off-day workout Aug. 20.

title: Brascade Raises Noranda Stake
description: Brascade Resources Inc. said it had succeeded in raising its 28 percent interest in Noranda Mines Ltd. of Toronto to 39 percent through a tender offer and through purchases from the Noranda treasury that totaled about $1.06 billion (Canadian currency).

title: DEAN WITTER CHANGES ITS PACE
description: Dean Witter Reynolds, the pride of San Francisco's Montgomery Street, is in the midst of a decade-long transformation. Long associated with the more conservative pace of Montgomery Street, where it makes its headquarters, the Dean Witter Reynolds Organization Inc. is moving from being a traditional, closely held family-based firm to a broad and diversified financial services company, capable of competing head to head with Wall Street's largest financial conglomerates.

title: Hanover Unit To Issue Notes
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Financial Corporation, an affiliate of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, announced plans yesterday to sell up to $200 million of investment notes with maturities ranging from one day to 10 years.

title: EXILE BIDS EGYPT END TIES TO ISRAEL
description: An exiled Egyptian general whose supporters have said they were responsible for the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat said in a radio broadcast today that he would cooperate with the new Egyptian Government if the peace accords with Israel were scrapped.

title: ATLANTA'S PRIMARY GIVES YOUNG 40.9%
description: Two popular Democrats in a vigorous contest for Mayor found themselves facing a runoff election after final results today showed that both had failed to win a majority of votes in a nonpartisan primary.

title: CONGRESS VOTES MILITARY RAISE
description: A compromise plan to provide increases of 10.7 percent to 17 percent in the pay of enlisted military personnel was approved by Congress today and sent to the White House.

title: COMMONWEALTH REPORT HAS THIRD-WORLD VIEW
description: The Commonwealth ended its heads-ofgovernment meeting today with a long communique that strongly reflected the views of its majority of third-world members.

title: How to Use Building Subsidies
description: Since 1977 New York City has encouraged business construction by excusing much of it from some of the tax burden, sometimes for more than 10 years. As the demand for Manhattan office space has grown, so has the clamor to end these concessions.

title: JOURNALISTS URGE TRUDEAU TO SHUN PRESS LAW
description: The Commonwealth Press Union appealed to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada today not to introduce a law that it said could encourage third-world governments to control the press.

title: Cox Reportedly Says He's Out
description: The Atlanta Braves' manager, Bobby Cox, said the club's owner, Ted Turner, had informed him in a meeting today that he had been dismissed, The Atlanta Constitution reported.

title: Winning by Design
description: A 26-year-old artist will have a special thrill when the Chicago White Sox take the field for opening day next year. The team will be adorned in uniforms designed by Richard Launius, a softball player who won a popular contest conducted by the White Sox' front office.

title: FORD OFFERS REBATES ON 1982 AUTOS
description: With the new model year barely under way, the Ford Motor Company said today that it would offer rebates of $400 to $700 to increase sales of its small cars.

title: Imagic Account
description: Into the highly competitive field of video games has come Imagic of Saratoga, Calif.

title: Belgian Mail to Use Bicycles
description: Postal vans will be replaced by bicycles in an effort to conserve fuel, the Ministry of Post, Telegraph and Telephone said today.

title: FINDING AUTHENTIC TOUCHES WHEN RESTORING OLD HOUSES
description: HOMEOWNERS interested in restoring or reconstructing old houses can find a wealth of information in a number of publications. Reconstructing 18th-century houses generally requires consulting the period's construction guides, primarily those imported from Europe by American builders. Restoring interiors is difficult since there are few pictorial records.

title: ZIMBABWE STRIVES TO CUT ITS FORCES
description: Zimbabwe, w hich had three distinct, sometimes war ring armies at the start of the year, has now nearly finished the task of getting them all under a single chain of commandin a regular national army.

title: E.E.C. Output Down
description: Industrial production in the European Economic Community was down 4.4 percent in the first half of 1981, compared with the first half of 1980, the Common Market headquarters said today.

title: PACT ON TRADE SUBSIDIES SAID TO BE NEAR
description: An agreement ending the subsidy war that has broken out among the world's major industrial exporters seems likely within the next few days, an official in the Reagan Administration predicted today.

title: Public Evenly Divided On Reagan and Budget
description: Public opinion on President Reagan's proposal to cut an additional $13 billion from the 1982 Federal budget is about evenly divided, 43 percent in favor and 46 percent opposed, the Gallup Poll reported.

title: GAMBLING CASINOS ARE A TEEN-AGE DRAW
description: To the Editor:

title: MERCHANTS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISLANDERS STOP KINGS, 4-1, TO START SEASON
description: With the temperature outside hovering in the 80's, the New York Islanders opened the defense of their National Hockey League championship tonight in the Forum with a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Prayers

title: E.P. DUTTON IS STILL FOR SALE, DESPITE COLLAPSE OF VOLT DEAL
description: Although officers of Volt Information Sciences agreed in principle three months ago to purchase E.P. Dutton from its Dutch parent company, Volt's board of directors recently turned down the proposed purchase. Meanwhile, a reliable source said that Dutton ''is in the process of concluding a new deal that will be announced next week.''

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Abroad at Home; WHEN A STAR FALLS
description: President Sadat's greatness lay in vision and daring. His fate was sealed by the failure of politicians elsewhere to match those qualities.

title: The City; Legal Aid Workers Strike Over Wages
description: More than 400 clerical, paralegal and social workers for the Legal Aid Society walked off their jobs in a dispute over wages. A spokesman for Local 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees said members voted to approve the strike follow ing two weeks of unsuccessful negotiati ons.

title: HOME BEAT
description: SOME chicken wire and ribbons happened to be left over from the floral arrangements John Oppido usually designs - and that gave him the idea of doing something with them on a larger scale. The first constructions held flowers at parties, for example.

title: HOUSE REINS IN MILK PRICE SUPPORTS
description: The House of Representatives voted today to hold milk price supports at the level President Reagan wants for the next 12 months but to raise them by about 2.5 percent a year from now.

title: 'MAKE IT IN N.Y.C.' IS MADE IN JERSEY
description: ''Make It in New York City,'' they call it. It's an exhibition composed of slides and a sample of products from letter-openers to the ubiquitous Rubik's Cube puzzle -all manufactured in the five boroughs.

title: IRANIAN PARLIAMENT IN AN UPROAR AS BAZARGAN CRITICIZES EXECUTIONS
description: Iran's Parliament was thrown into an uproar today as the Islamic Republic's first Prime Minister condemned the daily execution of Moslem lefti sts on charges of anti-Government activities.

title: CLOWNS: THE ART OF NUTTINESS
description: ''MY Heart Is in Your Shoes,'' a clown show playing at the Theater fo r the New City on weekends through Oct. 18, begins nuttily and soonge ts nuttier. It could well be a conspiracy of clowns.

title: President for Donelcor
description: James A. Hill, 42, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of Donelcor Inc., a manufacturer of computer hardware and software. He succeeds David R. Miller, 55, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer of the corporation, which has its headquarters in Aurora, Colo.

title: Arizona Racing Case Spurs Internal Inquiry; Arizona Racing Case Spurs Internal Inquiry
description: An internal affairs inquiry is under way in the State Department of Public Safety into ac tions of officers who investigated the drugging of race horses the last two years, The Phoenix Gazet te reported today.

title: CITY'S FEMALE BUS DRIVERS WIN RIGHT TO PROMOTION
description: The 30 or so women who drive buses in New York City won an antidiscrimination case against the Transit Authority yesterday when a Brooklyn judge ruled that the authority had to make promotions based on merit rather than seniority.

title: U.S. AGREES TO MODIFY OFFSHORE DRILLING PLAN
description: The Interior Department said today that it would modify its offshore oil and gas drilling program to provide greater consideration of environmental risks.

title: A GERMAN CITY'S FIGHT TO SAVE A STEEL PLANT
description: A conflict between labor and management ov er the future of an aging steel plant has unified this working-class city, which is putting pressure on one of West Germany's lar gest industrial companies to consider people before profits.

title: CAIRO STREETS ODDLY QUIET
description: An old man wearing pajamas sat in front of a tiny ramshackle restaurant on Ramses Street, a main Cairo throughfare, and keened over and over again: ''Oh, who could do such a thing! They are filth, infidels. Long live Egypt! Long live Egypt!''

title: WALDHEIM TO OFFER NO-GROWTH BUDGET
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim will formally present to the 156 member countries tomorrow his two-year, $1.54 billion zero-growth budget for the United Nations. It will be the first time since 1954 that a Secretary General has submitted a budget that does not provide for the expansion of the world body.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bibby Dropped by Nets
description: Henry Bibby, whose career in the National Basketball Association began with the Knicks' championship team of 1972-73, faced the possibility of an end to that career yesterday when he was cut by the Nets at their training camp in Mahwah, N.J.

title: Japan-Soviet Oil Find
description: The Sakhalin Oil Development Company said today that it had struck oil and gas at two of five test drilling sites in the Sea of Okhotsk off the Soviet island of Sakhalin. Sakhalin Oil, the Japanese partner in a joint oil and gas developmentproject with the Soviet Union, said one well flowed at a rate of 1,918 barrels of oil and 1.3 million cubic meters of gas a day. A second well f lowed at a rate of 3,773 barrels of oil and 600,000 cubic meters of gas a day, it said.

title: HOSPITAL GROUP ON WARDS I. SUES TO CLOSE MEN'S SHELTER
description: An advocacy group for state mental patients in a hospital on Wards Island sued New York City yesterday, seeking to close a shelter for homeless men there and, in the meantime, to force the men off public buses on the island.

title: Notes on People; University Hits Gusher
description: Bill Saxon has apparently done pretty well for himself since he graduated from the University of Oklahoma in 1951. Mr. Saxon, the president of the Dallas-based Saxon Oil Company, has just given $30 million to help build a new energy center and endow energy programs at the university's campus in Norman.

title: Theater Seminars Set for Next Week
description: The chief executive officers of the Shubert Organization will discuss their producing corporation and its procedures and answer questions at a seminar on Oct. 16 at the CUNY Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street.

title: A 2D LIFE FOR VACANT PARK SLOPE SHOPS
description: Even while surveying the dilapidated and vandalized four-story brownstone in Brooklyn they plan to turn i nto an art studio and gallery, the optimism of Miharu and Edward Lane could not be dampened.

title: Chrysler-Perkins Talks on Engines
description: Chrysler Canada Ltd. confirmed earlier reports that it was negotiating with the Perkins Group, a unit of Massey-Ferguson Ltd., about the possible joint production of lightduty diesel engines for cars and trucks at Chrysler's inactive plant in Windsor, Ontario.

title: No Headline
description: PALESTINIAN LEADER IN CHINA: Yasir Arafat being greeted yesterday in Peking by Foreign Minister Huang Hua, at center, at start of four-day official visit. Interpreter is at left. In a speech to Chinese leaders, Mr. Arafat said the collapse of the Camp David accords had begun with the killing of President Sadat of Egypt.

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1981; The Economy
description: A bill deregulating the telephone industry was approved by the Senate. The legislation, the most comprehensive of its kind since 1934, would free A.T.& T. to expand into new data processing and information services. (Page A1.)

title: GLORIA GRAHAME, 55, MOTION PICTURE ACTRESS, DIES
description: Gloria Grahame, the actress best known for her screen portrayals of sulking and occasionally wisecracking blondes, died Monday night of cancer at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 55 years old.

title: People
description: * Susan Gillette elected a senior vice president of Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago.

title: WITTER GETS OFFER TO MERGE
description: Dean Witter Reynolds Organization Inc., owner of the nation's fifth-largest securities firm, announced yesterday that it had received a takeover offer from an unidentified company.

title: g PLANTS THAT CAN LIVE WITH LITTLE WATER
description: ALTHOUGH this past summer was not as dry for gardens as that of 1980, weather scientists said this year may have been a reprieve before a prolonged drought descends on the Northeast. This could mean serious problems for gardeners.

title: SPECIAL DOOR LATCHES
description: AS hardware buffs know, there are door latches that perform very specific functions. A Dutch door, for instance, must have a latch that will allow the top and bottom of the door to operate separately or together.

title: Essay; THE PERCEPTION PITCH
description: Missing from the reaction to the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat is the element of outrage.

title: WELFARE CUTBACKS PROPOSED FOR 2-PARENT FAMILIES
description: Reagan Administration officials have devised a proposal that would sharply reduce Federal welfare payments for poor families when both parents live at home.

title: Bridge: Becker Team Gets Double By Capturing All 26 Tricks
description: One of the rarest results in a team game is for the same team to take all 26 tricks, 13 at one table and 13 at the other. Divided opinions on whether to open pre-emptively led to this result in the recent Spingold knockout team championship in Boston.

title: THE SCREEN: 'VERNON, FLORIDA' LOOKS AT TOWN'S ECCENTRICS
description: A SERMON in Vernon, Fla.: the minister tells his flock that he began to wonder about the frequent use of ''therefore'' in the Bible. So, he reports, he looked in the dictionary, ''and I found the word to be a conjunction.'' ''Now I had long since forgotten what a conjunction was.'' He looked that up and found that a conjunction connects one thing to another. This led him, in trying to discover what connections Paul used ''therefore'' to make, to find 119 separate uses of the words in Paul's writings. He ends by telling the parish that they have lost peace, ''and you won't gain it back until you have another therefore experience.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on acid rain in- correctly described testimony to the House Subcommittee on Health and Environment by Kathleen M. Bennett, assistant administrator of the Envi- ronmental Protection Agency. It was presented in writing.

title: Bombs at Jewish Sites Hurt at Least 6 in Italy
description: Bomb attacks on two Jewish targets injured at least six people today, the police said. A bomb exploded at a tourist information office of Israel's El Al national airlines on Rome's Via Veneto.

title: INTERNATIONAL COMPUTER-FUJITSU PACT
description: International Computers Ltd., the troubled British company, said today that it would join Fujitsu, Japan's largest computer maker, in what is being billed as an attack on I.B.M.

title: Elephant Steps
description: Pat Summerall, the former Giant tight end and place-kicker who is now a CBS broadcaster, is thinking about running for the Senate next year as a Republican in Florida. He said that the race ''has been suggested to me and it interested me'' but that first he said he would have to study government and politics.

title: ILLINOIS REAPPORTIONMENT MAP FAVORS DEMOCRATS
description: The Illinois Legislative Redistricting Commission has adopted a reapportionment plan that is expected to give Democrats control of both houses of the Legislature and greatly enhance Chicago's ebbing influence there.

title: EXPOS TRIUPMH
description: The Yankees, with nearly perfect relief pitching by Ron Davis and Rich Gossage, and revived hitting by Oscar Gamble, Rick Cerone and Bob Watson, scored a 5-3 victory over Milwaukee in the first game of the American League East playoffs tonight and spoiled the Brewers' first postseason appearance.

title: LIBERALS OPEN PURSES TO FUND-RAISER
description: All around Washington, the old liberal issues have fallen from fashion. In Congress, the White House and the thousand offices that watch them both, the themes of the left are seldom heard, and then only in subdued tones.

title: The Region; Wording of Ballot Approved in Jersey
description: The office of the New Jersey Secretary of State gave official approval yesterday to an explanatory statement that will appear on the Nov. 3 ballot with a referendum aimed at limiting state claims to riparian land - land washed by tidal waters.

title: BL's New Automobile
description: Britain's state-owned auto maker, the BL Motor Company, introduced a new Japanese-designed car it hopes will help reverse losses running at nearly $18 million a week. The car, the Triumph Acclaim, a British-built version of a Honda car introduced in Japan, has a Japanese engine and gearbox.

title: LUIGI PETROSELLI, ROME MAYOR
description: Luigi Petroselli, the Mayor of Rome and a Communist, died of a heart attack here today. He was 49 years old.

title: KNICKS' CARTWRIGHT LOST FOR 4-6 WEEKS
description: Bill Cartwright, the 7-foot-1-inch center and forward who led the Knicks in scoring and rebounding during his first two National Basketball Association seasons, is expected to be sidelined from four to six weeks as the result of a knee injury he suffered Tuesday night at the team's training camp at Monmouth College in West Long Branch, N.J.

title: I.R.A. PRISONERS IN ULSTER CALL NEW BRITISH RULES INADEQUATE
description: Irish Republican Army prisoners in Maze Prison outside Belfast reacted critically today to the British Government's new prison rules for Northern Ireland.

title: GRANT TO AID ORCHESTRA COMMISSIONS
description: THE American Composers Orchestra has received a grant of $19,200 from the National Endowment for the Arts to coordinate a consortium of four orchestras for the commissioning and performance of new music. Additional funds, which have already been raised, will enable the Composers Orchestra and the participating orchestras each to offer $7,000 to a composer. Each composer's work will then be performed by the specific orchestra that commissioned it as well as by the other three orchestras, with the round robin taking place in the 1982-83 and 1983-84 seasons. The whole procedure is on the same model as the Bicentennial orchestral commissions for the ''big six'' American orchestras a few years ago.

title: TRUST PRESERVING PRAIRIE AS THE PIONEERS KNEW IT
