description: This is how the land must have looked to the pioneers as they plodded westward over a century ago. From a bluff high above the Niobrara River, the prairie seems to stretch on forever in an endless succession of grass-vcovered sandhills. Sunlight drenches every small draw and canyon, and the wind rushing in from the north is clean and fragrant.

title: RECORD YIELD FOR NEW ISSUE
description: The Treasury sold $3 billion of new 15 3/8 percent seven-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 15.40 percent. This is a record yield for a new issue of that maturity, and it shows continued weak investor demand for new debt issues due in more than two years.

title: Market Place; Saving Taxes For College
description: MANY investors have accumulated substantial assets over a lifetime only to see them disappear in a few years of paying college tuition. But under a little noticed Federal case, some taxpayers have managed to hang onto capital while at the same time funding college tuition costs. They are doing so through interest-free loans to their children.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surchages on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The City; Bronxite Cleared On Killing Robber
description: The 58-year-old owner of a Bronx dry-cleaning store held up six times in recent years was cleared by a grand jury of criminal responsibility for fatally shooting an armed robber.

title: William C. Bullock, 77, Served As a Bankers Trust Executive
description: William C. Bullock, a retired vice president of Bankers Trust Company, died Tuesday at Lawrence Memorial Hospital in New London, Conn. Mr. Bullock, who was a resident of Old Lyme, Conn., was 77 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AMF Inc. said it would write off an additional $23.3 million, or $1.03 a share, against its third-quarter profits in connection with discontinued operations.

title: IRT THIRD-RAIL FIRE IN BROOKLYN DISRUPTS MORNING RUSH HOUR
description: Thousands of Manhattan-bound commuters from Brooklyn were delayed during yesterday's morning rush when a third-rail fire on the IRT subway line between Atlantic Avenue and Nevins Street forced the suspension of northbound service for nearly an hour.

title: GRAY COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Florida Transfers Land Of Miccosukees to U.S.
description: Gov. Bob Graham and the Florida Cabinet voted yesterday to transfer 76,000 acres of Miccosukee Indian land to Federal jurisdiction, ending months of negotiations over state tax rights in the area.

title: Rain Breaks Seattle Record
description: A downpour broke nearly 30-year-old rainfall records in Seattle and Olympia and caused scattered power failures, officials said. The storm snarled traffic throughout western Washington last night. The National Weather Service said 3.55 inches of rain fell Seattle and 3.35 inches fell in Olympia in a 24-hour period.

title: GUILTY CONSCIENCE SCORES IN BOOJUM
description: Guilty Conscience, who had finished second in five sprint stakes this year, pulled away in midstretch to post a five-length victory in the $55,800 Boojum Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: PLAN TO EASE FIGHT ON JOBS CRITICIZED
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed easing of Federal efforts against job discrimination drew sharp criticism today from the acting chairman of the Equal Employment Opp ortunity Commission.

title: Colombia Oil Find Cited
description: A new oilfield with potential reserves of a billion barrels was discovered in the southern territory of Caqueta, according to reports published here today.

title: Belgians Seize an Embassy
description: A dozen young Belgians briefly occupied El Salvador's Embassy here today to protest that country's junta and American influence in Central America. The police removed them.

title: JOHN HEMMER
description: John Hemmer, an award-winning press photographer, died here yesterday. He was 89 years old and had lived at the Pinehurst Nursing Center since 1971.

title: EXPOS TRIUMPH
description: Canada's first playoff game in major league baseball became a rousing success today when the Montreal Expos defeated Steve Carlton and the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-1.

title: IRAQI ASSERTS HE WANTS PEACE
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said today that his country would press for a peaceful solution to the war with Iran as it has repeatedly done since shortly after the conflict began more than a year ago.

title: Notes On People; Here's a Politician Who Wants His Pay Cut
description: He has been a Ronald Reagan supporter since 1968 and he thinks that cost-cutting should not stop with the President, so Earl C. Henwood, clerk of the Union County Board of Freeholders in New Jersey, has asked for a 22 percent pay cut.

title: REPUBLICANS PRESS VIRGINIA CAMPAIGN
description: Amid unexpected indications that their candidate for Governor may be in trouble, Virginia's powerful and conservative Republican organization opened a belated drive here today to salvage the campaign of Marshall Coleman.

title: HIGH COURT URGED TO UPHOLD CAMPAIGN CONTRIBUTION LIMIT
description: Large sums of money raised by special interest groups outside regular political channels have a ''corrosive effect'' on Presidential campaigns, Archibald Cox told the Supreme Court today.

title: Notes on People; More Milestones Ahead for a Producer at 77
description: Spending the day in a dentist's chair and keeping a doctor's appointment may not be the most festive way for a Broadway producer to celebrate a birthday, but Alfred Gustav Etienne de Liagre Jr., who did just that when he turned 77 on Tuesday, says he does not pay as much attention to birthdays as he used to.

title: Question on Women Has Haig 'Overawed'
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. fielded tough and diplomatically sensitive questions at a news conference today but became involved in a lengthy exchange about women.

title: A.M.C. Canada Offer
description: American Motors Canada Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the American Motors Corporation, said today that it would begin a ''cash-back'' program on its cars and jeeps, effective immediately.

title: TOSCO USES OIL UNIT AS LOAN COLLATERAL
description: The Tosco Corporation, a diversified energy company with interests in refining and marketing petroleum products, agreed yesterday to pledge the stock of its principal subsidiary in exchange for $1.1 billion in Government loan guarantees for a project to produce oil from oil shale in Garfield County, Colo.

title: WALCO NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Including securities gains of $1,73,000 in the latest yr and $5,438,000 in the previous yr; the yr-ago shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been restated to reflect a 20 percent stock divd declared in May 1981

title: STOCKS STAGE ROBUST GAINS
description: Wall Street's takeover fever spread to brokerage issues yesterday as the general stock market staged a robust advance. Analysts said they were impressed by the market's remarkably steady tone in the wake of political and economic uncertainties created by Tuesday's assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt.

title: ROOM DESIGNERS WOULD LOVE TO LIVE IN
description: IT'S become standard practice for stores to dedicate model rooms to celebrities. Sometimes they're movie stars, sometimes Broadway stars, occasionally politicians or writers. But right now at Lord & Taylor, the spotlight is on fashion designers.

title: Astros Win for 2-0 Series Lead
description: Denny Walling, a pinch-hitter, lined a single into right-center field with the bases loaded and two out in the bottom of the 11th inning today to give the Houston Astros a 1-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Government in Ireland Moves To Abolish the Death Penalty
description: The Government yesterday approved a bill to abolish the death penalty, and official sources said it was expected to be passed by Parliament within a month.

title: HUNTERS WHO EAT DUCKS WARNED ON PCB HAZARD
description: On the opening day of the duck hunting season in New York, the State Health Department today warned hunters not to eat too many of the ducks they shoot because of contamination of the birds by polychlorinated biphenyls.

title: Boy, 14, Is Stabbed to Death And Brother, 16, Gravely Hurt
description: A 14-year-o ld boy was stabbed to death last night and his 16-yearold br other was critically wounded by the same assailant in the Crown Hei ghts section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: TAIWAN SAYS IT WILL NEVER NEGOTIATE WITH CHINA
description: President Chiang Ching-kuo said todaythat Taiwan w ould never negotiate with the Chinese Communists. Mr. Chiang made the remarks at a Central Standing Committee meetingof the ruling Kuomintang. It was the first top-level affirmation of Taiwan's longstanding policy since Peking began its reunification drive last week and the first public statement from the President on the offer to share powerwith the Nati onalists in ruling a reunified nation.

title: Smith's Day in Court
description: Floyd Smith, a former coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs, who is now a scout for the team, testified in Ontario that he drank only two or three bottles of beer on the day he was involved in a traffic accident that killed two persons. Smith has been charged with criminal negligence causing death and impaired driving .... George Rogers, last season's Heisman Trophy winner, underwent medical tests to find out why he has been getting leg cramps during games with the New Oreleans Saints.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: ASTATE china service, which usually bears a national or royal crest, is reserved for official entertaining. Like the best china in any household, the design is calculated to make a splendid display on the table for important guests.

title: The Region; Plea of Not Guilty In Guard's Slaying
description: Lemuel Smith pleaded not guilty to a charge of first-degree murder in the death on May 15 of a Green Haven state prison guard. Mr. Smith, who was a Green Haven trusty, made his plea shortly after his attorney charged that material had been improperly withheld from a grand jury.

title: 4 ARE CHARGED WITH ENSLAVING, CAUSING DEATH
description: A crew leader for migrant laborers and three of his assistants were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of kidnapping and enslaving workers at a North Carolina camp where one potato digger collapsed and died.

title: STUYVESANT TEACHERS END LETTERS BOYCOTT AFTER AN ULTIMATUM
description: Under orders from the Schools Chancellor, teachers at Stuyvesant High School yesterday ended a 24-day refusal to write college recommendations.

title: Ainge Finds a Way
description: A Federal Court jury decided last week that Danny Ainge's contract with the Blue Jays prevented him from becoming a pro basketball player. But the case had nothing to do with his taking a job as a basketball coach, so Ainge has accepted a part-time position at his old school, Brigham Young University .... Harvey Catchings, a reserve forward and center for the Milwaukee Bucks, broke his right thumb in practice and will miss workouts for four or five days .... The Kansas City Kings have signed their first-round draft choice, Steve Johnson, a 6-foot-10-inch center from Oregon State.

title: OPERA: GAIL GILMORE DEBUT
description: SOMEWHERE in the midst of the New York City Opera's cast changes in ''Carmen'' on Tuesday night, an opera was struggling to be heard. But much of the performance looked and sounded like a dress rehearsal, with ragged choral and orchestral playing (conducted by Smeyon Bychkov), awkward staging and inaccurate singing.

title: Spinks to Risk Title
description: Undefeated Michael Spinks will make the first defense of his World Boxing Association light-heavyweight championship Nov. 7 against Vonzell Johnson, a former sparring partner of Spinks's brother Leon.

title: CHINA TAIWAN'S SUITOR
description: Behind Peking's new offensive to reunify China is a desperate desire to co-opt Taiwan's economy, for there is a growing realization that without an injection of some new economic force, the 10-year, $250-billion modernization program announced by Deng Xiaoping in 1979 is doomed. Bluntly put, China's political leaders need Taiwan's economic success. Although China has repeatedly called for re unification in the last 18 months, there has been a recent crescendo of such proposals. Peking has upped the ante by offering to shar e leadership with the Kuomintang Party, as well as to permit Taiwan to keep its political, military, and economic structures. Left unsta ted is how Taiwan's successful economy would be integrated into t he mainland's troubled one.

title: 2 Hanna Plants Close for 6 Weeks
description: The Hanna Mining Company said it would suspend production at two iron ore facilities near Hibbing, Minn., for six weeks from Oct. 18 because of ''stagnant steel demand.''

title: Haim Landau Is Dead; Was a Leader of Irgun
description: Haim Landau, a leader of the Irgun underground and a minister in Prime Minister Menachem Begin's previous Government, died last night after a long illness. He was 65.

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 13
uf1Land Knew of Kodak's Film
description: Edwin H. Land, founder of the Polaroid Corporation and creator of instant photography, testified today that he heard about a new Eastman Kodak Company film while serving on a Presidential panel but avoided learning much about it to guard against conflict of interest.

title: FED REJECTS REQUESTS BY REGAN
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, indicated today that he would not increase the speed at which money was pumped into the economy, despite requests that he do so from the Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL YANKEES (A.L.) - S igned a new five- year working agreem ent with Columbus of the Internationa l League.  MONTREAL (N.L.) - Replaced Rod- ney Scott, second b aseman, on the roster with Wallace Johnso n.  TORONTO (A.L.) - A nnounced that Manager Bobby Matti ck is stepping down to become executive coordinator of opera- tions for the club. ; BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (N.B.A.) - Released three rookie guards: Russell Bowers, Ethan Martin and Ken Page.  DETROIT (N.B.A.
description: PORTLAND (N.B.A.) - Released Herb A ndrew, rookie guard. COLLEGES BIG EAST CONFERENCE - Signed a three-year contract to stage its postseason tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1981
description: Egypt After Sadat Egypitian leaders vowed to continue the policies of slain president Anwar el-Sadat in an effort to assure an orderly transition of power. In a nearly unanimous move, Parliament named Vice President Hosni Mubarak to succeed the assassinated president. For the past six years Mr. Mubarak had been a close associate of Mr. Sadat. The nomination is subject to a popular vote in an election in which Mr. Mubarak will be the only candidate. No official announcement was made but sources said the leader of the assassins was an army officer with ties to a fundalmentalist Moslem group involved in terroirism in the past. Meanwhile, Mr. Sadat's funeral was set for Saturday. (Page A1, Column 6.) The United States assured Egypt of continued strong support and promised to play an active role in the Egyptian-Israel negotiations for Palestinian autonomy. In the Reagan Administration's first policy statement since the assassinsation of President Sadat, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig also warned other countries against trying ''to manipulate the tragic events of the last 24 hours.'' At the same time the White House announced that Mr. Haig would head the delegation to Mr. Sadat's funeral. Neither the President nor Vice President Bush would will attend for security reasons. (A1:3.)

title: Big East Tourney Set For Garden for 3 Years
description: The Big East Conference will hold its postseason basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden for three years, starting in 1983.

title: NEW ENGLAND MERCHANTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 mos results includes an after-tax gain of $5.3 million from the sale of aircraft formerly under lease; the 1980 9 mos results include an after-tax gain of $900,000 from sale of real estate; all figures restated to reflect the acquisition of TNB Financial Corp on a pooling of interest basis

title: STAGE: KLEIST'S 'THE BROKEN PITCHER'
description: Despite the failure of Heinrich von Kleist's ''The Broken Pitcher''in its first production in 1808 under Goethe's direction, the play ha s come to be regarded as one of the most popular of German co medies. Still, it is largely unknown in America, and Carl Weber's pr oduction, which opened last night at the Martinique Theater, is th erefore an event of some cultural and academic significance. Ho wever, the evening's theatrical interest is limited, and the re asons, I think, have as much to do with von Kleist as with the cu rrent production.

title: Article 042810 -- No Title
description: IF you think $3.95 is a lot for a best-selling paperback novel, wait until you reach for James Clavell's ''Noble House'' after it is published in paperback next spring. It will carry a list price of $5.95, far and away a record for a mass-market paperback. James Michener's ''The Covenant,'' scheduled to come out about the same time, will carry a cover price of $4.95. So will ''Best Evidence'' by David Lifton, a 1980 nonfiction best seller that is also due out in the spring.

title: Reagan Fills U.N. Post
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Geoffrey Swaebe to be the new United States representative at the European office of the United Nations with the rank of ambassador. Mr. Swaebe, 70 years old, is a California businessman.

title: BYRNE SIGNS BILL CREATING AGENCY TO BOLSTER JERSEY'S WATER SUPPLY
description: A powerful new state agency designed to protect New Jersey from future water shortages was created yesterday by Governor Byrne at a bill-signing ceremony in Trenton.

title: FLEXIBLE RETIREMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Barber-Greene placed with a private investor $10 million of 13 1/2 percent subordinated convertible debentures, due in 1994 and convertible into 454,545 shares, about 16.6 percent of the company's common stock.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's great consternation that the President's mix won't work. There's an evolving conse nsus that we need bi g cuts, but made up differently than the President has proposed.'

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Filled, Alternates Needed For Trial of Presley's Doctor
description: A jury of seven women and five men was seated today for the trial of Elvis Presley's personal physician on drug charges, but selection of four alternates was put off until Monday.

title: THRIFT UNIT 'ALL SAVERS' ESTIMATED AT $ 15 BILLION
description: The United States League of Savings Associations estimated yesterday that consumers bought more than $15 billion worth of ''All Savers'' certificates at the nation's savings and loan institutions through Monday, which it said exceeded its expectations.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
KOTAR SCHEDULED TO START
description: On the day after the Giants had placed Billy Taylor on waivers, from which he was picked up by the Jets today, Coach Ray Perkins said that he planned to start Doug Kotar at halfback and Leon Perry at fullback Sunday against the St. Louis Cardinals at Giants Stadium if they had recovered sufficiently from their injuries.

title: CHILDREN'S EXHIBITS STRESS PARTICIPATION
description: SINCE the 1960's children have been caroming through museums with hands outstretched - absorbing new sciences and old cultures by touch.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES TO BLOCK U.S. SALE OF PLANES TO SAUDIS
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted 28 to 8 today for a resolution that would prevent President Reagan from selling $8.5 billion in air defense equipment, including five Awacs planes, to Saudi Arabia.

title: Around the World; East Berlin Parade Marks Communist Anniversary
description: Tanks, missiles and artillery were paraded in East Berlin today in an annual show of military strength to mark the 32d anniversary of the foundation of Communist East Germany.

title: THERE ARE NO EASY SOLUTIONS FOR MARKETING MILK IN NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: RCA REPORTS LOSS OF $109.3 MILLION
description: RCA reported yesterday that it had a third-quarter loss of $109.3 million on sales of $1.99 billion. It was the first earnings report since Thornton F. Bradshaw became RCA chairman and chief executive on July 1 and includes a $230 million pretax charge to cover anticipated losses.

title: LIFE EXPECTANCY FALLS FOR FIRST TIME SINCE '68
description: A 14 percent increase in deaths from flu and pneumonia in 1980 caused the life expectancy of newborn Americans to fall last year for the first time since 1968, the Federal Government reported today.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 8, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Heekin Leaves Canter, A chenbaum
description: James R. Heekin Jr. has resigned from Canter, Achenbaum, Heekin, the marketing consulting firm run by former agency people. Mr. Heekin, who has been president of four different ad agencies, could not be reached either at his New York apartment or his country home, but Alvin A. Achenbaum, his former partner, said he had got the feeling that Mr. Heekin would prefer working as a consultant to ad agencies instead of to advertisers, as the firm was doing.

title: U.S. AIDES FEAR SADAT'S DEATH IS ISOLATING SUDAN
description: The death of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt is regarded by American officials as having increased the isolation and the vulnerability of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan.

title: Amax Will Ask Mining Approval
description: Amax Inc., a diversified natural resources concern based in Old Greenwich, Conn., said it would seek permissi on to mine tungsten and tin at Hemerdon, England, in a joint venture with Hemerdon Mining andSmelting Ltd.

title: WD-40 CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NORPAC EXPLORATION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Taylor Reports To Jets
description: Billy Taylor, the halfback the Jets claimed on waivers from the Giants yesterday, was at work ear ly this morning. He r eported to Coach Walt Michaels at 8:40 and immediately immersed hims elf in the playbook.

title: G.M. Unit's Eurobond
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation's Overseas Finance Corporation is raising a $150 million, threeyear Eurobond, guaranteed by the parent General Motors Acceptance Corporation, bond market sources said here today. The bond is noncallable, with a 16 1/2 percent coupon, and will be priced at 99 3/4 percent, they said. Lead manager of the issue is Morgan Stanley International.

title: Case to Extend Plant Shutdowns
description: J I Case, a unit of Tenneco Inc., said it will close manufacturing plants in six states for four weeks b eginning Jan . 4 because of ''sluggish'' demand for farm and construction equipment.

title: Health Fair in Village
description: If you don't know what's good for your health, one place to find out is the Health Fair III, to be held at the Greenwich Village School, Sixth Avenue and 11th Street, tonight through Monday. Among the 80 exhibitors, will be specialists on subjects ranging from vitamins to holistic dentistry.

title: N.F.L. Computer Rating; Computer ranking based on games through Oct. 5.; Average Opponents (Last Margin of Cumulative Rank Team Week) Record Victory Rating Record* 1 Denver (5) 4-1-0 10.4 1.000 9-11-0 2 Philadelphia (2) 5-0-0 11.2 .950 9-11-0 3 San Diego (4) 4-1-0 8.4 .917 11-9-0 4 Atlanta (7) 3-2-0 10.8 .909 11-9-0 5 Miami (1) 4-0-1 8.4 .900 9-11-0 6 Buffalo (6) 3-2-0 12.0 .782 9-10-1 7 Dallas (3) 4-1-0 9.6 .769 6-14-0 8 Pittsburgh (9) 3-2-0 4.8 .763 8-10-2 9 Houston (14) 3-2-0 -0.4 .705 11-7-2 10 Tampa Bay (19) 3-2-0 3.2 .697 9-11-0 11 Los Angeles (15) 3-2-0 5.4
description: The New York Times's pro football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won a game, by what margin and against what qu ality of opposition. Distinctions are also made as to the success of the offensive and defensive units.

title: DATA LINKED TO EARTHQUAKES STUDIED ON COAST
description: Scientists said today that they had recently measured puzzling geophysical phenomena in southern California that were very similar to events that have preceded major earthquakes in the past.

title: Surrealism at La Mama
description: ''Why Hanna's Skirt Won't Stay Down,'' a Surrealistic play focusing on two characters who spend their free time in a Coney Island funhouse, is being shown Wednesdays through Sundays at 9:30 at La Mama E.T.C., 74 East Fourth Street, through Oct. 18.

title: Crenshaw Beats Faldo In Match Play Tourney
description: Ben Crenshaw of the United States defeated Nick Faldo of Britain, 5 and 3, today in a firstround match of the $185,000 36-hole World Match Play Golf Championship.

title: Biology Text Censored
description: Two pages of an advanced biology textbook used in Bellevue East and West High Schools have been glued together because they describe specific birth control methods, a school administrator says. Jim Davis, assistant superintendent of sch ools, said that the pages were glued together because a 10-yearold ad ministrative policy specifies that ''schools will not advise or pre scribe specific methods of birth control.''

title: LDB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $955,000 for the qr and $3,378,000 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $699,000 for the qr and $2,481,000 for the yr

title: CHASE CUTS PRIME RATE TO 18 1 2%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank cut its prime lending rate yesterday for the second time this week, lowering it one-half percentage point, to 18 1/2 percent, but no other major banks followed its lead. Last Monday, when Chase reduced its rate to 19 percent, most of the nation's banks followed.

title: MUSIC: CHOPIN CONCERTO BY CECILE LICAD
description: BOTH of Chopin's piano concertos, as the New York Philharmonic program boo k reminded us last night, were wri tten before he was 20 years old. And, despite the dark-of-the-moon treatment that they often receive at the hands of fully matured v irtuosos, they bear up extremely well when played as the youthful, innocent outpo urings of song that they are. At this concert, the Concerto No. 2 in F minor received just such a performance by Cecile Licad, a Manila -born pianist who is, aptly enough, just 20 years old. This year , Miss Licad won the Gold Medal of the Levintritt Foundation, whi ch had not awarded the prize for 10 years.

title: MULTI-FAITH OPPOSITION
description: To the Editor:

title: DESPITE KILLINGS, IRANIAN SEES A 'KIND OF STABILITY'
description: Despite waves of assassinations and executions, Iran's revolution has achieved a ''kind of stability,'' according to the country's Foreign Minister.

title: WALESA SUPPORTERS ON UNION'S BOARD
description: Lech Walesa won his first test as the Solidarity union's re-elected leader today when all but one of the 12 candidates he had proposed were elected to the union's governing presidium.

title: U.N. PRINCIPLE (SO-CALLED)
description: When the United Nations General Assembly met recently to consider South Africa's refusal to grant Namibia (South-West Africa) independence, it voted overwhelmingly to eject from the session the one country without whose cooperation a peaceful settlement in Namibia is improbable. Not only was South Africa not allowed to speak, but also the credentials of its delegates were rejected on the grounds that the delegates did not represent the people of that country. Then, a few weeks lat er, the credentials of the Pol Pot ''regime'' of Cambodia were accep ted by the same credentials committee. Many countries that de nied South Africa the right to speak vote routinely to seat the Pal estine Liberation Organization on the grounds that a Middle Eas t settlement is impossible without its participation. Why doe sn't the same logic apply to Southern Africa?

title: THEODORE W. LIBBEY Jr.
description: STENDHAL considered it the perfect opera, but to achieve perfection ''Don Giovanni'' must be performed with an awareness by both the director and the singers of the musical characterization Mozart put in the score. When that awareness is only fitfully present, as in the New York City Opera's first performance of the work this season Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, the focus of the drama begins to dissolve and the animation that Mozart's music should impart weakens.

title: CORRECTION
description: A movie review yesterday incorrectly named the theater where ''My Dinner With Andre'' will open. The film begins Sunday at the Lincoln Plaza I.

title: Pop Jazz; ICONOCLAST LETS THE PIANO DO SINGING AT MICHAEL'S
description: IT is doubtful that the jazz world has a more colorful and outspoken iconoclast than Dorothy Donegan, the Chicago-born pianist, vaudevillian and feminist, who is appearing at Michael's Pub this month. Miss Donegan, who is sharing the bill with another jazz legend, Page Cavanaugh, as part of ''Piano Playoffs'' - the two play together briefly on twin pianos - has been performing professionally for more than 40 years. From the outset, she has been recognized as one of the most technically accomplished pianists in the world, mastering styles from a thunderous, two-fisted boogie-woogie to a flamboyant romanticism that parodies Scriabin and Rachmaninoff.

title: LOUIS JOSEPH FISHER
description: Louis Joseph Fisher, a member of the United States Olympic Committee for 29 years and a leader in international amateur athletics, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at the age of 80.

title: G.O.P. MONEY DOESN'T BUT HARMONY
description: The Republican Party is raising more money than ever these days, but the dollars aren't buying pure happiness. They seem to be bringing a mixture of satisfaction and edginess. In July and August, usually poor fund-raisi ng months, a net of justunder $11 million, according to the Federal E lection Commission, wasraised by the party's three major organs: the Republican National Committee, the National Republican Congressio nal Committee, and the National Republican Senatorial Committee.

title: Around the World; French Parliament Backs Cut in Nuclear Building
description: The National Assembly today overwhelmingly approved the Socialist Government's plans to cut back on nuclear power plant construction.

title: U.S. BARS A LIBYAN FROM CAPITAL
description: The State Department t oday denied a Libyan diplomat's request to address a meeting of Ar ab-Americans here. A department spokesman said the request was de nied because Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, had '' cheered and applauded'' the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt.

title: By Peter Passell
description: The Editorial Notebook Some Taxes That Can Be Raised

title: PUBLISHING: WRITERS CONGRESS OPENS
description: THE first American Writers Congress convenes this afternoon at the Roosevelt Hotel with keynote addresses this evening by the authors Meridel LeSueur and Toni Morrison, followed by what is being billed as New York's largest literary cocktail party. Tomorrow and Sunday many of the more than 2,500 registrants for the congress, which is now completely sold out, will participate in some 50 panels, workshops, causes, plenary sessions and roundtables, debating and discussing the impact of economic, cultural and political trends on publishing.

title: GARMENT AREA TO GET TRAFFIC AID
description: Twenty-five additional traffic-enforcement agents will begin work in the garment center on Tuesday in an effort to reduce congestion, the Department of Transportation announced yesterday.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CO (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Muir Cornelius Starts Unit for Medical Ads
description: Muir Cornelius Moore, with billings of some $32 million, has formed the MCM Medical division to do advertising for companies in the health care field. John S. Friedberg, who has been a vice president of the agency, has been designated president of the division.

title: 'All Savers' Suit Is Filed
description: Iowa's Attorney General, Tom Miller, filed a lawsuit today against 14 out-of-state banks and brokerage houses, charg ing that their sale of the new t ax-exempt savings certificates violated state law.

title: Egypt's Parliament Approves A Pension for Sadat's Widow
description: Parliament has approved a law to give President Anwar el-Sadat's widow, Jihan, a pension as well as his residences in Cairo and Alexandria.

title: SHUTTLE'S 2D FLIGHT SCHEDULED BY NASA FOR A NOV. 4 LIFTOFF
description: The space agency announced yesterday that Nov. 4 would be the new scheduled launching date for the accident-delayed second flight of the space shuttle Columbia. If there are no further problems, Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force and Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy will lift off from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida at 7:30 A.M. on that date. They are scheduled to orbit the earth five days and fo ur hours, returning to a touchdown Nov. 9 on the desert at Edwards A ir Force Base in California.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Castro and Palestinian Meet
description: President Fidel Castro had talks here with Farouk Kaddoumi, the Palestinian leader, the Communist Party newspaper Granma said today.

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The figures for both years reflect the acquisition of First Melville Bancorp Inc on a pooling-of-interest basis effective Sept 30, 1981

title: MATAGORDA DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Broadway; A musical about E thel Waters due in the spring.
description: THE popularity of Broadway musicals built around the works and lives of black composers and performers has been too unflagging these several years to be shrugged off as a trend; it has become more of a tradition. Now a new musical built around the life of Ethel Waters, the Broadway singer of jazz and blues who died in 1977 at the age of 81, promises to lengthen the roster. This new venture, scheduled for next March, is called ''Stringbean'' and will star Lynnie Godfrey, who received enthusiastic notices for her work in ''Eubie,'' the revue of Eubie Blake songs.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISRAELIS PRESS MILITARY ACCORD WITH U.S.
description: Israeli leaders hope that the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt will impel the United States to speed agreement on the broad military cooperation Israel has proposed.

title: TV Weekend; VIEWS OF AMERICA AND HOLLYWOOD
description: THE season of reruns dribbles to an end this weekend as most of the schedules established series begin offering ''brand new'' episodes. Among other things, a special two-hour edition of ''The Love Boat,'' on ABC-TV tomorrow at 8 o'clock, will have Julie (Lauren Tewes) getting married in Australia. Tonight at 10 on CBS, devotees of ''Dallas'' will finally find out who killed the woman in the pool. That kind of thing.

title: Ban on a Pesticide Upheld by Court
description: ALBANY (AP) - A state appeals court refused to ease New York's ban on the use of the toxic pesticide Endrin.

title: Decision on Gas Is Postponed
description: Despite the fact that his Cabinet advisers unanimously favor accelerating the decontrol of natural gas, President Reagan today once again postponed making a decision on the matter, Energy Secretary James B. Edwards reported.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $4.7 million or 11 cents a shr for the qr and $18.5 million or 43 cents a shr for the 9 mos from foreign currency translations...C-After losses of $2.1 million for the qr and $4.4 million for the 9mos from foreign currency translations; yr-ago results have been restated for consolidation of Kaiser Aluminum Europe Inc as of Jan 1, 1981

title: CUKOR'S 'RICH AND FAMOUS'
description: SOMEWHERE inside ''Rich and Famous,'' George Cukor's splashy, elongated new comedy, there is the material for a possibly brilliant two-character one-act play. This film, which opens today at the Cinerama II and other theaters, covers too much ground too superifically, being about the friendship of two women, from their days as Smith College undergraduates in 1959, through their separate careers, one husband and a number of lovers, up to the present.

title: PIZZA TIME THEATRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
AN ENCIRCLED NATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Flxible Presents Its New 'Metro' Bus
description: The Grumman Flxible Corporation, which has spent millions of dollars repairing structural flaws in its so-called advanced design buses over the past two years, today presented a new city bus here modeled on more traditional lines.

title: Auto Output Off in U.S.
description: American auto makers built 452,257 cars in September, 15 percent fewer than in the same month last year and the lowest production figure for any September since 1961, when 355,202 cars were made, an industry journal reported today.

title: POLICEMAN SHOT DURING A CHASE IN EAST FLATBUSH
description: A New York City police officer was shot at least five times yesterday after being ambushed from behind a parked car by a suspected drug dealer in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: IF OUR OIL IMPORTS ARE INTERRUPTED
description: To the Editor:

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: the 1980 shr earnings figures restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split June 24, 1981

title: Bridge: Reese Will Not Make Trip To Port Chester Tourney
description: The international furor concerning the captaincy of the British team in the forthcoming world championship beginning Oct. 20 in Port Chester, N.Y., took another twist last week. Terence Reese of London, who had been barred from his designated position as captain by the credentials committee of the World Bridge Federation, announced that he would not make the trip even if the appeal against the committee decision scheduled to be heard Oct. 18 was successful. He will be replaced by the team coach, Gus Calderwood.

title: Foreign Affairs; NICARAGUA ON A TIGHTROPE
description: The revolution here remains a peculiar combination of closed minds and open possibilities. The impact has already been intense throughout Central America, and it will take a sage U.S. policy to help the queasy region emerge with reasonable stability.

title: NUCLEAR REAGANOMICS
description: Nuclear power is the only major program the Reagan Administration has completely spared during its campaign to reduce Federal spending. And yesterday the President made clear his intention to bail out the ailing nuclear power industry. No energy program less deserves such favoritism.

title: Court Bars Offer by Armco
description: A Federal judge barred Armco Inc., a diversified company with a large interest in steel, from pursuing its takeover of the Ladish Company, a specialized metals foundry and forging concern based in Cudahy, Wis.

title: Jury Picked in Texas Trial
description: With jury selection complete, defense lawyers prepared motions to be heard Monday in the trial of Vickie Daniel, accused of killing her estranged husband, Price Daniel Jr., the former Speaker of the Texas House. Prosecutors say that Mrs. Daniel shot her husband in a quarrel over an impending divorce. Mrs. Daniel, 34 years old, has pleaded not guilty to a charge of murder.

title: ENERGY WATCH
description: Crude Oil Inventories Despite an increase in crude oil imports and a dropoff in refinery outp ut, crude oil stocks fell to 365.7 millio n barrels, down 4.9 million.

title: ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CBS AND BELL PLAN VIDEO-TEXT TEST
description: CBS Inc. and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that they would jointly test a home information system with consumers in Ridgewood, N.J., beginning next autumn.

title: Hobbies and Games I n Uniondale, L.I.
description: A four-day exposition of hobbies, toys and games - from stuntflying paper planes to Russian needlepoint to a Rubik's Cubeathon - opens this evening at the Nassau Coliseum. Bruce Pandolfini, chess master and author of ''Let's Play Chess,'' will take on as many as 30 opponents at a time tomorrow and Monday.

title: DOW GAINS 9.42 AS STOCKS CLIMB BROADLY
description: Stock prices continued their broad advance yesterday, aided by favorable earnings reports and the Chase Manhattan Bank's decision to cut its prime rate by half a percentage point.

title: U.S. Investigation Of Kodak Is Ended
description: A four-year Federal investigation of the Eastman Kodak Company under the Sherman Antitrust Act has been closed with no action being taken, company officials said today.

title: FUNDAMENTALISTS AND POLICE SKIRMISH IN EGYPTIAN TOWN
description: Several people were killed yesterday in clashes between the police and Moslem fundamentalists in a city in Upper Egypt after policemen sought to stop the Moslems from marching in prayer in the streets in defiance of a Government ban on public gatherings.

title: Pennsylvania Sheriff Cleared
description: A Federal jury today acquitted Sheriff John Dinger of Jefferson County of charges that he concealed the identity of a man wanted in a $7 million bank robbery in California. Mr. Dinger had been charged with harboring Harry James Barber, who lived in the sheriff's hometown of Brookville, Pa., for seven years, under the name of John Baker.

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Index; Egypt After Sadat
description: World leaders to gather for Sadat funeral A10 Egyptian warns of more blood- shed A10 U.S. bars Libyan U.N. delegate from Washington A11 International Foreign Minister sees ''kind of stability'' in Iran A2 Walesa supporters elected to Pol- ish union's board A3 Iranians prepares bill to expel Bazargan from Parliament A3 Around the World A5 Antimissile demonstration is readied in Bonn A6 Israelis hope for accord soon on military cooperation with U.S. A8 Canada says half of acid rain there is from polluters A9 Government/Politics Washington leaders upset over Congressional interference A17 Pentagon plan new warhead to in- crease MX missile power A18 U.S. panel asks lie tests to broaden access to secret data A23 Washington Talk Briefing A24 Justice O'Connor brings a differ- ence to the Supreme Court A24 The Republican Party's money isn't bringing it pure happiness A24 General Around the Nation A12 Chapels of Cal ifornia youth cor- rection sch ools bugged A22 China legal scholar leaves ivory tower and enters fray B3 Health/Science Scientists studying data linked to occurrence of earthquakes A15 Features/Notes Notes on People B9 Sports People B16 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Where to view the fall foliage close to home C1 Metropolitan Baedeker: New London and Groton C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: News Analysis
description: Significant changes are taking place in the financing of research at the country's major universities, pointed up by the debate over an industrialist's offer of a biomedical research institute whose scientists would become professors at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Article 044129 -- No Title
description: The Long Island Lighting Company is seeking $2 million in damages in a suit against members of an antinuclear group that tried to halt work on the nuclear power plant at Shoreham, L.I., last fall.

title: MILAN FINALE: TOUCHES OF WHIMSY
description: Some madcap elements turned up in the last days of the spring and summer showings here to provide the sense of abandon that can make Italian fashions amusing and attractive.

title: DISCOVERING CONNECTICUT'S OLD PORT CITIES
description: IF you like whales and submarines, you'll love New London and Groton. The two old port cities in southeastern Connecticut still cling to the sea that has shaped their history and has brought them good times as well as bad.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
IS THE END IN SIGHT?
description: ''Reports which appeared in the media recently regarding a final specific Administration proposal to eliminate the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and F irearms were incorrect. While a number of possible options to re organize and possibly eliminate a number of activities are being con sidered, no final decision has been made by the department to dismantle or abolish A.T.F.''

title: News Analysis; MUBARAK'S EGYPT: JUST A CARBON COPY OF SADAT'S, OR WILL IT BE AN ORIGINAL?
description: Egypt's new leader, Hosni Mubarak, faces a bewildering array of foreign and domestic issues at a time when he will be under intense scrutiny at home and abroad.

title: SADAT'S SUCCESSOR INVITED BY REAGAN TO VISIT U.S. IN '82
description: President Reagan today invited Egypt's new leader, Hosni Mubarak, to visit the United States next year, and the three living former American Presidents departed to attend the funeral of Anwar el-Sadat.

title: Consumer Caution Seen
description: American consumers expect business conditions to worsen this winter and are delaying plans to buy cars, homes and major appliances - suggesting problems ahead for the United States economy, the Conference Board, an independent business research group, said yesterday.

title: Otis Signs Accord On Chinese Trade
description: HARTFORD (UPI) - The Otis Elevator Company, the world's largest manufacturer of elevators and escalators, announced yesterday that it had signed a business agreement with the largest elevator company in China.

title: Article 044033 -- No Title
description: Two robbers stole jewels worth $3 million from a Mexican couple staying at the Ritz Hotel, the police said today. The armed men forced their way into the room of Hugo Salinas y Rocha, 74-year-old businessman, and his wife, Maria Isabella, 42, bound and gagged the couple and then searched the room and discovered the jewels. The jewels included a ring containing a 45-carat diamond, whose value was given as more than $2 million.

title: SUN BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CBT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in July 1981

title: Lawyer Reports 12-Year-Old No Longer Wants Abortion
description: A 12-year-old girl who was raped by three youths has decided against an abortion because doctors assure her that giving birth will not endanger her life, her mother's attorney said yesterday.

title: Around the Nation; Court Bars Fund Cutoff To University Over Sex
description: A Federal judge temporarily barred the state today from enforcing a law that would cut off funds to the University of South Florida because a student group there advocates sex between unmarried adults.

title: Baltimore Paper Cuts Staff
description: The Baltimore News-American, one of two afternoon dailies in the city and one of the oldest in the nation, today cut 24 employees from its 150-member editorial staff as part of a reorganization effort, the newspaper said.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Luchow Art for Sale Most people think of Luchow's for what it is - a huge German restaurant that, since 1882, has served hearty dishes such as pigs knuckles, boiled beef with horseradish sauce, roast goose, and sauerbraten to generations of New Yorkers.

title: Cartwright Passes Test
description: An arthroscopic examination of Bill Cartwright's right knee at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan yesterday confirmed that the Knicks' center has suffered no damage other than a bad sprain.

title: GRUMMAN UNIT REBUFFS LTV
description: The trustees of the Grumman Corporation's pension fund, which controls 5.2 percent of the company's stock, said yesterday that they had decided to reject the LTV Corporation's offer to purchase those shares as part of the Texas conglomerate's $450 million bid to acquire Grumman.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 6 incorrectly reported Laker Airways' unrestricted one-way economy fare between New York and London effec- tive Nov. 1. It will be $261, matching the fare anno unced by Pan American World Airways also effective Nov. 1.

title: Market Place; Gas Pipeline In Turnaround
description: TEN years ago, Arkansas Louisiana Gas was being squeezed by customer and regulator alike. The pipeline company's long-term industrial contracts, dictated by unsympathetic state officials, offered gas at unrealistic prices.

title: COLUMBIA CHASE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: The company is listed on the Boston and Philadelphia stock exchanges

title: Briefing
description: A S Congress skittishly prepares for the next round of budget cutting, the idea of slowing or altering the personal tax-cutting program enacted this summer continues to be included in the potpourri of alternatives being concocted by lawmakers who find President Rea gan's proposals too drastic. Delaying or reducing the 10percent tax c ut due to take effect next October would be an instant way of findin g revenue and reducing the deficit and requisite spending cuts , lawmakers note.

title: CALIFORNIA CORRECTION AGENCY BUGS 3 YOUTH FACILITY CHAPELS
description: The California Youth Authority has installed electronic eavesdropping devices at chapels in three of its correctional facilities in the Stockton area. The Rev. C. E. Curtis, head of the 150-member Greater Stockton Ministry Asso ciation, said that the youth authority began installing the bugs in A ugust while chaplains were on vacation.

title: Study by V.D. Hotline Challenges Stereotypes
description: The stereotype of venereal disease victims as young, poor and nonwhite is not reflected in the experience of the Venereal Disease National Hotline, officials of the Hotline say.

title: Firefighters Warn Town on Apparel
description: Three volunteer fire companies in this South Jersey community, citing a lack of protective clothing and insurance, say they will no longer enter burning buildings unless there is a ''life or death situation.''

title: French Aerobatic Pilot Killed
description: Lieut. Col. Guy Charvet, the 44-year-old commander of the French Air Force's ''Patrol of France'' aerobatic flight team, was killed when his jet crashed in training, the air force announced today. The colonel's plane crashed yesterday near Artigues on the French Riviera for undetermined reasons, officials said.

title: Around the World; Mother of Shcharansky Says Visits Are Barred
description: The mother of the imprisoned Jewish dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky said today that she had been barred from visiting him until the end of 1982.

title: FRAILTY OF NEW ENGLAND UNDERWORLD CHIEF LEADS TO FEAR OF BATTLE FOR REALM
description: For over a quarter of a century he has been the head of organized crime in New England, Federal law-enforcement officials say.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Nuclear power has become entangled in a morass of regulations that do not enhance safety but that do cause extensive licensing delays and economic uncertainty.''

title: Massachusetts' Police Seek Lieutenant in Marijuana Theft
description: The Massachusetts state police issued a nationwide alert today for a suspended lieutenant accused in connection with the theft of more than a ton and a half of marijuana from a state police barracks.

title: ON FIRST FAMILY AFFAIRS
description: .6,0SANTA FE, N.M. - A President of the United States who cannot curb his family and kinfolk can expect to see the result in the polls and at election time. It only remains for historians to calculate the precise share of the 1980 vote that Billy Carter's uncontrolled capers lost for his brother. Richard M. Nixon's brother, Don, probably cost Dick the close 1960 election because of Howard Hughes's loan to the Nixon family to bail out Don's failing restaurants (featuring the Nixonburger). Lyndon B. Johnson's brother Sam was a constant political embarrassment to his presidential sibling.

title: Antiques at the Armory
description: An armoire of Duncan Phyfe design, a double-spouted ceramic vessel and many oriental artifacts are among the items to be offered at the 19th National Arts and Antiques Festival that opens tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: Bristol-Myers Names Phillips to Clairol Unit
description: Robert M. Phillips, who has been president of the health and beauty products division of Chesebrough-Ponds, is joining Bristol-Myers's Clairol Products division as executive vice president ''with primary responsibility for marketing and sales of retail hair color and toiletries.''

title: F OR 'NICKLEBY' PATRONS, SPECIAL DINNERS, TOO
description: Feeding the patrons of ''The Life & Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' particularly on Saturdays, Sundays and Wednesdays, when attendance is a nine-and-a-half-hour two-part exercise in endurance, has become a challenge in logistics and imagination for restaurateurs near the Plymouth Theater on West 45th Street.

title: 40 Arrested in Raid At Brooklyn Clubs
description: Forty persons were arrested and five ounces of heroin and cocaine seized when narcotices detectives raided two Brooklyn social clubs. Acting after complaints from neighbors, the police raided the two clubs -at 742 Nostrand Avenue and 534 Sterling Place - shortly after 6 A.M. All 40 of those arrested were charged with narcotics possession, the police said. Four weapons were seized, the police said. (AP)

title: WARNER ELECTRIC BRAKE & CLUTCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After unrealized foreign currency translation losses of 11 cents a shr for the qr and 24 cents a shr for the 9 mos

title: Take a Message
description: It was 25 years ago yesterday that he pitched the only perfect game in World Series history, but Don Larsen, to be perfectly frank, is a bit bored by it all now, and so he has his son Scott field some of the interminable telephone calls seeking interviews.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: W ITH the onset of fall, parties around town tend to concern themselves with the worlds of art and fashion. And so it was this week.

title: PAN AMERICAN BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANCE: TAYLOR REVIVES HIS '69 'DOMAIN'
description: THE revival of ''Private Domain'' by the Paul Taylor Dance Company this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music is one of the high points of the entire dance season.

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $205,000 for the qr and $143,000 for the 6 mos

title: U.S. STEEL PLANS MOVE ON IMPORTS
description: The United States Steel Corporation, signaling the end of a truce over imports, has told the Congressional steel caucus that it is about to file a huge complaint alleging unfair trade practices against foreign steel producers.

title: CRED IT MARKETS
description: Interest Rates Decline Slightly By MICHAEL QUINT

title: Around the Nation; Judge in Murder Case I n Hawaii Found Beaten
description: Circuit Judge Harold Shintaku, who aroused a protest by 300 people by overturning a jury's murder verdict, was hospitalized today after emergency brain surgery for an apparent beating, officials said.

title: ART: NEW GALLERY FOR OLD MASTERS
description: NEW YORK is notoriously sho rt of first-rate dealers' gal leries that put on exhibitions of European Old Master paintings f or sale. Ofcourse, we can see paintings of that sort any day at the M etropolitanMuseum of Art, and very fine most of them are. But even if we can't afford them, there is a particular curiosity and a special bite aboutpaintings that are for sale. And although we glimpse Old M aster paintings from time to time in the auction rooms, there is also a particular savor about a gallery that lays its reputation on the lineevery day of the working year.

title: Pricing Hurts A .&P., Safeway
description: Safeway Stores and the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company reported yesterday that grocery store price wars hurt earnings during the latest reporting quarters.

title: MORE U.S. LIE TESTS ASKED TO WIDEN DATA ACCESS
description: The Reagan Administration is weighing yet another proposal that would broaden the use of so-called lie detectors to provide thousands of Federal officials with access to highly classified intelligence information, according to Administration officials.

title: Phone Antitrust Bill Is Criticized
description: William F. Baxter, the Justice Department's chief antitrust enforcer, said today that the telephone deregulation bill passed by the Senate yesterday ''falls short'' of providing adequate safeguards to prevent the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from using its monopoly power to take unfair advantage of competitors in unregulated markets. Mr. Baxter told a press conference here that the Justice Department's huge antitrust case against A.T.& T. ''will continue'' unless two '' deficiencies'' in the Senate bill are corrected, or the case is settl ed.

title: SANDRA DAY O'CONNOR: A DIFFERENT KIND OF JUSTICE
description: This much is known so far about Sandra Day O'- Connor: She is cool under pressure; she suffers fools gracefully; she has a sense of humor.

title: No Headline
description: THE one known as Goose usually gets the saves and the adulation and the headlines. But the one known as R.D. enables the Goose to honk his fastball in the late innings.

title: THIRD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago per shr earnings adjusted for a 20 percent stock divd paid Feb 1981

title: IRANIANS, FURIOUS AT CRITICISM, MAY OUST BAZARGAN FROM PARLIMENT
description: Iran's Parliament was reportedly preparing a bill today to expel former Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan from membership because of his cricitism yesterday of the executions of leftist opponents of the Islamic Government. Mr. Bazargan, who was shouted down when he said the Government's acts of revenge had started a ''terrifying fi re, threatening the revolution,'' paid a brief visit to the Parli ament building today. But, according to an aide reached by telephon e, he left before today's session began.

title: KRUEGER, W A, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TOP CHRYSLER EXECUTIVE LEAVES FOR GATX CORP.
description: Paul A. Hei nen, the vice president, general counsel and secretary of the Chrysl er Corportion, resigned from his post to accept a job with another company, Chrysler said yesterday. Chrysler also announced tha t Richard Goodyear was elected to those posts.

title: CONVERTING A POLITICAL CLUB IN PARK SLOPE INTO CO-OPS
description: It is no ordinary building that the Kossak brothers, Jeffrey and Steven, have found in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn for their first venture in housing development. It is the landmark Weber house, built in 1909 for the president of a brewery and after 1944, when it became the home of the Unity Club, the favored hideaway of leading Brooklyn Demo crats. It is at 101 Eighth Avenue, on the corner of President Str eet.

title: ADVANCED PATENT TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After $3,017,137 loss from the settlement of disputes with a former president of the company

title: Tape Shows Private Side of F.C.C.
description: By the time they went behind closed doors last April, members of the Federal Communications Commission were unanimous in their view that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was entitled to a significantly higher profit margin than that approved by an administrative law judge or recommended by its staff, a videotape of that meeting shows.

title: YANKEES WIN, 3-0, AND LEAD BREWERS BY 2-0 IN SERIES
description: Rich Gossage saved the Yankees for the second time in a row as New York beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 3-0, today on homers by Lou Piniella and Reggie Jackson.

title: Ford Is Recalling 2,400 Cars To Alter Fuel-Intake System
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it was recalling 2,400 Escort and Lynx automobiles of the 1982 model year to modify their fuel-intake grounding systems.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Apr 1981

title: THE LURE OF A DOLLAR IN POLAND
description: At the best Warsaw restaurants, the sort that foreigners frequent, the check always arrives covered by a snowy white napkin. A good meal of sour herring, roast venison, apple strudel and Hungarian red wine costs about 1,000 zlotys, or $30, using the official exchange rate of 34 zlotys to the dollar.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * European Investment Bank is floating a $100 million, 10-year Eurobond at 99.75 percent, yielding 16.79 percent at maturity and bearing 16.75 percent interest annually, through an underwriting syndicate led by Hambros Bank.

title: A Mozart Immersion
description: In Philadelphia this week to rehearse with Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra for their concert next Tuesday in New York's Carnegie Hall, James Galway, the flutist, decided it was time to see the play ''Amadeus'' again.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Walter V. Shipley, 46 years old, has been named president of the Chemical Bank, the nation's seventh largest, effective Jan.1. Mr. Shipley, who has been senior executive vice president in charge of Chemical's wholesale banking activities worldwide, will succeed Norborne Berkeley Jr., 59.

title: DUBLIN HOPING TO EASE ULSTER'S FEARS ABOUT ROLE OF CHURCH
description: In an attempt to make the Irish Republic more appealing to Northern Ireland's Protestants, the Government here is considering steps to lessen the official status of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: MILLER, HERMAN, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: The shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable Oct 31, 1981

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $146,000 C-After income from discontinued operations of $55,929,000 in latest period and $756,000 for the yr-ago 9 mos

title: Nicholas Rethymnis, 95, Dies; Founded Steamship Concern
description: Nicholas B. Rethymnis, who founded a steams hip company in Greece after World War I and was the founder and pre sident of the Rethymnis Steamship Agency in New York City, died Tuesd ay at his residence at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y. Mr. Rethymnis, who also hadan apartment at the St. Moritz Hotel in Manha ttan, was 95 years old.

title: Funds' Assets U p $2.5 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds climbed $2.5 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the 20th consecutive weekly increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The total has risen $88.6 billion since the start of the year, to $163.2 billion.

title: BRITONS RECOVER $76 MILLION IN GOLD
description: Deep-sea divers have recovered 95 percent of the gold bullion from the sunken British cruiser Edinburgh, netting bounty worth some $76 million.

title: Rise in Alcohol Tax Urged
description: The Federal excise tax on alcohol, unchanged for 30 years, should be increased and applied equally so beer and wine would be assessed at the same rate as liquor for drinkers, a group urged today.

title: WHERE TO VIEW THE AUTUMN FOLIAGE CLOSE TO THE CITY
description: FROM the deep purple of the low-lying sumacs t o the brilliant orange and reds of the sugar maples to the go ld and yellow of the swamp maples, the countryside north of New Yo rk City is ablaze with color this weekend. But the annual spectacle of the fall foliage has arrived in the rural areas not too far from m etropolitan New York a little earlier and a little less intense than normal because of a variety of stresses on trees earlier in the y ear.

title: U.S. EASES BAN ON KNITTING BY WORKERS IN THEIR HOMES
description: The Labor Department announced today that it would eliminate a long-standing ban on the manufacture of knitted outerwear by workers in their own homes, saying there was no evidence that such a ban was needed.

title: Bridge Traffic Being Curtailed
description: The Brooklyn-bound outer roadway of the Williamsburg Bridge will be closed for nine months beginning next Monday because of rehabilitation work, the city's Department of Transportation said.

title: VICTORIA STATION INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Sept 13
PHOTO ID CARDS TO BE REQUIRED FOR FO OD STAMPS
description: The Federal Government, in an effort to combat fraud, will require food stamp recipients in 17 of the nation's largest cities to obtain photographic identification cards.

title: Giants and Jets Face Divisional Foes
description: Both New York teams play divisional opponents Sunday, and both are at home, the Giants against the St. Louis Cardinals and the Jets against the New England Patriots.

title: U. S. ISSUES DATA ON RACE OF HISPANIC POLULATION
description: The Census Bureau has released figures on the racial makeup of New York City's Hispanic population that opponents of the City Council's proposed redistricting plan said yesterday undermined the Council's defense of its new lines.

title: Czyz Stops Snyde r in 2d For 15th Victory in Row
description: Bobby Czyz of nearby Wanaque, N.J., raised his unbeaten pro record to 15 victories tonight as he stopped Dan Snyder of Darby, Pa., at 2:22 of the second round. It was the 12th knockout for Czyz.

title: SEARS WILL PURCHASE DEAN WITTER IN PLAN TO OFFER FINANCIAL SERVICES
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's biggest retail store chain, announced yesterday that it would buy Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., the fifth-largest brokerage house, for about $607 million in cash and stock.

title: Israelis Add Delegates For the Sadat Funeral
description: Israel said today that three Cabinet ministers would accompany Prime Minister Menachem Begin to the funeral of Anwar el-Sadat.

title: Upshaw Steps Aside
description: The Oakland Raiders, defending Super Bowl champions, have lost three of their first five games this season and have been shut out their last two games. Part of the problem has been the offensive line, which has allowed 19 quarterback sacks. So Gene Upshaw, the seven-time all-pro left guard, who has started all 207 Raider games since he joined the team in 1967, will be replaced in the starting lineup for Sunday's game against the Kansas City Chiefs by Curt Marsh, Oakland's first-round draft choice, who had been on the injured-reserve list. Upshaw, who is 36 years old, admitted to Coach Tom Flores on Monday that he felt the pressure of the belief in some quarters that he should be benched, and that he didn't know how much longer he could handle it. ''Mentally is where I've been having my problems,'' Upshaw said yesterday. ''That's where it's gotten to me. My mind hasn't always been in the game,'' Upshaw, the captain and the oldest player on the team, said he would try to get his job back. ... Fred Dean, the all-pro defensive end who walked out on the San Diego Chargers in a demand for contract renegotiation and then was traded a week ago to San Francisco, has signed a series of four one-year contracts with the 49ers. ... Walter Payton, who has been taking his lumps this season with the Chicago Bears and has been unable to gain 100 yards in a game so far, can't blame his offensive line for this one: He suffered a slight thigh bruise when, believing that his 10-month-old son, Jarrett, was about to fall, he slipped grabbing the infant.

title: Marsteller Obtains USA Cable Account
description: Marsteller, one of Young & Rubicam's many subsidiaries, has picked up a new client, the USA Cable Network, Glen Rock, N.J., which could spend anywhere from $1 million to $5 million on advertising.

title: Texaco Reports North Sea Yields
description: Texaco Inc. said that its 3-4A-8 wildcat well in the British sector of the North Sea tested highquality crude oil at the rate of 7,239 barrels a day and natural gas at 8.98 million cubic feet daily.

title: A Freud-Jung Reading
description: The exchange of letters between Sigmund Freud and C.C. Jung has attracted interest not only for their psychological insights but also for their dramatic content. To demonstrate both, three part-time performers will give a dramatic reading of selected segments from the book ''Freud-Jung Letters,'' edited by William McGuire and published by Princeton University Press, at the Sargent Auditorium, 310 E. 67th St, tomorrow at 8 P.M. Dr. Robert Breen, of the Northwestern University Sc hool of Speech will read Freud's letters; Dr. Roland Rude, teacher of speech and psychology at the C. G. Jung Center in Chicago, will read Jung's letters and Mary-Lou Rude, teacher of English and s peech at the Jung Center, will depict Emma Jung.

title: WASHINGTON SEEKS TRUE HOME RULE
description: The ''Last Colony'' bumper stickers are beginning to reappear on District of Columbia automobiles. Not since before 1974, when Congress granted the capital a measure of home rule, have leaders of the municipal government here been so annoyed at an action by what they consider the city's real rulers, Congress.

title: KEY TO THE PREVENTION OF CHILD ABUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICAL DIRECTOR OF TIME INC.
description: Frederic Theodore Kirkham Jr., medical director of Time Inc., died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old. Dr. Kirkham, a member of the staff of New York Hospital for the last 34 years, was appointed medical director of Time Inc. in 1966.

title: Thomson Subsidiary Purchases Ward's
description: International Thomson Business Press, the Radnor, Pa., subsidiary of the International Thomson Organization of Toronto, has struck again.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 9, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: E.E.C. Tax Plan
description: The European Common Market Commission has dropped plans for a controversial tax on fats and vegetable oils, averting a possible trade confrontation with the United States, sources in the European Economic Community said today. A tax had been considered as a way of coping with a huge surplus of olive oil expected after Spain and Portugal join the Common Market.

title: Canadiens Tied, 5-5
description: Blaine Stoughton scored twice, and Rick Meagher got a goal with 2 minutes 11 seconds remaining tonight as the Hartford Whalers rallied for three third-period scores to earn a 5-5 tie with the Montreal Canadiens.

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $5,325,000 loss for the qr and $2,482,000 gain for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-After $108,891 loss from discontinued operations

title: Auction; Notable gems at 2 houses.
description: SOME spectacular diamonds, sapphires, rubies and emeralds with impressive pedigrees will star next week in the first important jewelry auctions of the season at New York's two leading auction houses. The sales are bound to be viewed as a barometer of the international jewelry market after a softening in sales of gems earlier this year. The highlights of the auction next Tuesday and Wednesday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet's Madison Avenue galleries (at 76th Street) are a signed Winston ring with an 8.67 carat ruby framed by 18 diamonds and a pair of diamond earrings with leaf-shaped tops suspending pear-shaped stones, one of which weighs about 8 carats, the other 9 carats. They are expected to sell for up to $500,000 each

title: Around the Nation; Nuclear Foes Sentenced For Waste Plant Protest
description: A news photographer and 20 demonstrators against nuclear power were sentenced today to 30 days in jail and were fined $250 each for criminal trespass in a Labor Day protest at a nuclear waste repository site.

title: Lewis Named Captain
description: Dave Lewis, traded by the Islanders to Los Angeles a year and a half ago, has been named the Kings' captain. He replaces Mike Murphy, who remains the player representative. ... Bill Rodgers, who has been feuding with Fred Lebow, president of the New York Road Runners Club, said that, despite published reports, he might still run Oct. 25 in the New York City Marathon, an event he has won four times.

title: Around the World
description: The United Nations agency dealing with economic relations between rich and poor nations decided today not to hold its next assembly in Havana because of a United States threat to boycott the session.

title: KORCHNOI ERRS BEFORE GAME AGAINST KARPOV IS ADJOURNED
description: Shockingly bad play in what should have been an easy position threw Viktor Korchnoi i nto desperate straits when the fourth game of his world championshi p chess match with Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union was adjour ned tonight at the 41st move.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 19
FIRST CONNECTICUT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HULL FAILS TO MAKE RANGERS
description: For the first time in his life, Bobby Hull couldn't make the team. General Manager Craig Patrick announced yesterda y that the Rangers and Hull had ''mutually agreed'' that the 42- year-old left wing, one of the most prolific scorers in hockey histor y, had failed in his attempt to make a comeback.

title: Scott Gains Credit
description: The Scott Paper Company, which is undertaking a major expansion and modernization program, said that it had arranged a $100 million revolving credit with three banks led by the Royal Bank of Canada. Scott said the 10-year agreement was part of the financing program for its previously announced plans involving five capital investments of more than $1.6 billion.

title: CAROLINA BOY IS CAIRO-BOUND, AGAIN
description: Sam Brown says he never dreamed he would have a chance to go to the funeral of his hero and pen pal, Anwar el-Sadat.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NET FALLS AT KAISER ALUMINUM
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, the nation's thirdlargest producer of aluminum, reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter plunged 74.8 percent as sales dropped 5.5 percent.

title: Janice Elwood, Lawyer Who Helped Homeless
description: Janice Elwood, a lawyer and a founder of Toward Community, a charitable organization dealing with the problems of the homeless, died Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital after a long illness. She was 51 years old.

title: Bundesbank Cuts Rate
description: The Deutsche Bundesbank, the West German central bank, announced today that it was cutting its special Lombard lending rate to 11 percent from 12 percent effective tomorrow, a move that effectively eases the nation's tight money policy.

title: REAGAN APPROVES NEW SETUP TO RADIO MISSILE SUBMARINES
description: The Defense Department announced today that President Reagan had approved the construction of an advanced communications system in Michigan and Wisconsin to transmit orders to submarines armed with nuclear ballistics missiles.

title: Mental Patient in Philippines Kills 5 in Stabbing Rampage
description: A patient about to be discharged from the National Mental Hospital sud denly attacked other patients with a knife today, killing 5 and wounding 14 before giving the knife up to a fellow inma te, authorities said.

title: EXPLAINING CHINA
description: The granddaughter of the man who set up the foundation that gave the White House $209,508 for a new set of fine china said yesterday she was sorry that Nancy Reagan had been criticized for ordering the dishes.

title: TRUFFAUT OFFERS 'WOMAN NEXT DOOR'
description: MUCH in the way that a writer of precise, clean, seemingly effortlessly flowing prose can capture one's attention in an opening paragraph of essential but banal information, Francois Truffaut can draw us immediately into the everyday world of his films, which look familiar but are as foreign to most of us as life among a tribe of aborigines.

title: REXHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: B-Including $170,000 net income for the qr and 9 mos from discontinued operations and $175,000 extraordinary charge for the 9 mos

title: Around the World; Czech Court Reduces A Dissident's Sentence
description: An appeals court in Prague today cut two years from a seven-and-a-half-year prison sentence imposed on Rudolf Battek, a Czechoslovak human rights activist who had been convicted of subversion and assaulting a public official, according to emigre sources.

title: A MISSILE PROTEST PREPARED IN BONN
description: One of the organizers of a demonstration ''for peace'' that will take place here on Saturday says the West must renounce all its plans to station Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adage Inc., Billerica, Mass., has elected Edward B. O'Brien vice president, manufacturing.

title: JAZZ SWINGS THROUGH NIGHT AT ST. PETER'S MARATHON
description: STAYING up all night listening to jazz is not the sort of thing one exp ects to fi nd many faithful churchgoers doing. But on Sunday, plenty of chu rchgoers and lots of others as well will be staying up all night to listen to jazz - in church. The church is St. Peter's Lutheran, at Lexington Avenue and East 54th Street, and the event is ''All Night S oul.'' From 5 P.M. until 5 A.M. or later, the church will present enough jazz performers to stock a full-scale festival. Visitors can stay all night, or a shorter period, for a $6 donation.

title: CRONKITE QUITS BOARD OF PAN AM
description: Walter Cronki te has resigned from the board of directors of Pan American Worl d Airways in order to remain free to cover aerospace stories for C BS News.

title: WEAPONRY WINDFALL? MAYBE
description: On paper, President Reagan's proposal to spend $180 billion to revitalize the nation's strategic nuclear deterrent should provide a torrent of profits for thousands of military contractors and subcontractors over the next six years.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1981
description: Egypt After Sadat Three former Presidents met with President Reagan at the White House, shortly before the three - Jimmy Carter, Gerald R. Ford, and Richard M. Nixon - departed for Egypt as part of the American delegation to the funeral of Anwar el-Sadat. Earlier in the day Mr. Reagan extended an invitation to Mr. Sadat's designated successor, Hosni Mubarak, to visit the United States in 1982.(Page A1, Column 6.) The assassination investigation in Cairo continued as Egyptian leaders tried to determine how four men evaded security measures at the military parade where President Sadat was killed. The investigation focuses on how the men were able to insinuate themselves into the parade, leap from a truck at precisely the right moment and shoot the President despite the presence of guards. (A1:5.)

title: Change of Command At Crown Zellerbach
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, which has had its share of troubles lately, elected William T. Creson, 52, yesterday to the positions of chairman, president and chief executive officer. He will replace C. Raymond Dahl, 60, who retired after 31 years with Crown Zellerbach.

title: News Analysis
