description: Both major candidates for Governor of New Jersey are limited to spending $2.1 million each. But a portion of the campaign falls outside the expenditure limits and, in a close contest, could significantly affect the results of the voting on Nov. 3.

title: The Talk of Heights-Inwood
description: North of 155th Street in Manhattan is an area that its residents like to call the real Upper West Side. Unlike the lower Upper West Side, it is a section where people do not roller-skate plugged into a tape-cassette, there are no hanging plants in the bars and the perils of gentrification are still a few years off. The miracle is that gentrification is even in sight for Heights-Inwood.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXILED EGYPTIAN WARNS OF FURTHER BLOODSHED
description: Egypt's exiled army chief of staff, Lieut. Gen. Saadeddin Shazli, said in Libya today that Egyptians faced more bloodshed unless opposition demands were met.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
Baker Is Urged to Reconsider Support for 2 Large Projects
description: Twenty-five members of Congress, most of them Republicans, have asked Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, to sacrifice two controversial and costly Federal projects to help achieve President Reagan's new round of budget cuts.

title: JUILLIARD QUARTET MARKS 35TH YEAR OF SHARING
description: The players of the Juilliard Quartet have only been together for nine years, but they are celebrating the quartet's 35th anniversary in a concert at 8 tomorrow night at the Juilliard School. To mark the occasion, they have chosen a program that will repeat the works the quartet presented in its first appearance - on Oct. 10, 1946.

title: 3 NEW MAXIM'S PLANNED FOR THE U.S.
description: After giving such American chain restaurant s as McDonald's and Burger King royal welcomes, France will soon return the favor by sending a chain of its own to the United Stat es.

title: Economic Scene; Signs of Slump Remold Policy
description: GROWING evidence that the United States economy is slipping into recession has called forth a striking change in the Reagan Administration's monetary and fiscal policies. The most recent indication came from Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, who made known his conviction that the Federal Reserve Board ought to start loosening up the money supply if the nation is to grow and create more jobs next year.

title: RESTAURANT EXPANSION BACKED BY PARKS PANEL
description: A special panel that reviewed seven proposed restaurant concessions for New York City parks has approved plans to expand the restaurant facilities at Battery Park, build a new restaurant in the rotunda in Riverside Park at 79th Street and set up a cafe on Fifth Avenue in front of the New York Public Library.

title: STAGE: 'DOUBLE FEATURE,' JEFFREY MOSS MUSICAL
description: YOU know a musical is in trouble when Act II opens with a song asking ''How's It Gonna End?'' and you're still waiting for the show to begin. You also know a musical is in trouble when the only moment that raises either the cast or audience out of a stupor is a mistake. At a critics' preview of ''Double Feature'' at the Theater at St. Peter's Church, that mistake came in the top-hat finale, during which Carole Shelley dropped her cane. Miss Shelley giggled. Her fellow cast members giggled. The audience giggled. It was as if someone had suddenly opened the door of a tomb and flooded it with light.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Aug
Polish Debt Eased
description: The West German Government announced today that it had rescheduled a portion of Poland's foreign debt. The Finance Ministry said $289 million in Government-backed credits that were due in 1981 would now be due by 1989, after a four-year grace period. The announcement followed the signing of the German-Polish portion of t he rescheduling agreement negotia ted in April by Western lender nations and Poland, the ministry said.

title: ART: POUSETTE-DART'S ABSTRACT EXPRESSIONISM
description: IT is now 40 years since the American painter Richard Pousette-Dart had his first solo exhibition at the Artists Gallery in New York. He was then 25 years old, and in the years immediately following that early debut - in a steady succession of exhibitions at the Willard Gallery, at Peggy Guggenheim's Art of This Century and at the Betty Parsons Gallery - Mr. Pousette-Dart emerged as the youngest as well as one of the most gifted members of the first generation of Abstract Expressionist painters.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Sept 12
Around the Nation; 3 in Navy Held in Thefts From Norfolk Bases
description: Three Navy petty officers have been arrested in the theft of millions of dollars worth of tractors, helicopter engines, pumps and generators, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

title: DETROIT PLANS ITS BEST SHOT IN SUPER BOWL
description: Automobile sales are down, unemployment is up and the first cold drafts of the blustery gray Michigan winter are blowing down Lake Huron. What an excuse for a party!

title: CHEMICAL AND MARINE MIDLAND UP
description: The Chemical New York Corporation reported yesterday that it had a 12.5 percent increase in third-quarter after-tax operating income, while Marine Midland Banks Inc. reported a gain of 79.2 percent, compared with the same period last year. Both banks attributed the gain to better yields on earning assets, increases in fee income and greater trading profits.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt FROM BAUHAUS TO OUR HOUSE. By Tom Wolfe. 143 pages. Illustrated. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95.

title: Pleasant Colony Hurt, to Miss Gold Cup
description: The race of the year lost a leading contender for horse-of-theyear yesterday when Pleasant Colony was not entered for tomorrow's $500,000 Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park after the colt reportedly suffered a minor injury in a training mishap.

title: RAY PROHASKA
description: Ray Prohaska, a painter and illustrator, died Wednesday at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 80 years old. Mr. Prohaska was a past president of the Society of Illustrators and a member of the Illustrators Hall of Fame. He is survived by his wife, the former Carolyn Pierson; two sons, Raymond of Locust Valley, L.I., and Anton of East Hampton, and a daughter, Elena Glinn of Manhattan.

title: NIXON, ISRAEL AND THE U.S.-SAUDI AWACS DEAL
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD LEADERS EXPECTED TO ASSEMBLE FOR FUNERAL
description: The funeral of Anwar el-Sadat, scheduled to be held on Saturday, will be the largest gathering of world leaders in the Middle East in many years. But Egyptian officials insist there will be no security problems.

title: Before the Ballot
description: Election Day comes on Nov. 3, but that won' t mean much to anyone who has not registered to vote. The last chan ce to do that is tomorrow, and the easy thing to do is call th e borough office of the Board of Elections. People there will tell yo u where to register; thehours will be from 1 to 9 P.M.

title: LEGAL SCHOLAR LEAVES IVORY TOWER AND JOINS FRAY
description: Jerome Cohen's new office at the midtown law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison still lacks what he calls ''an East Asian ambiance.'' Even so, the premises already seem well suited to the man just about everyone, including Jerome Cohen himself, considers the foremost authority on the Chinese legal system and the trailblazing American lawyer in China.

title: Chrysler to Shut Instrument Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it will close its Scio Township plant near Ann Arbor, Mich., by July 1982 as part of the company's continued cost-cutting efforts.

title: Goodbye, Bobby Cox
description: ''A fresh face, that's all it was,'' said Ted Turner, owner of the Atlanta Braves, in announcing yesterday that Bobby Cox had been dismissed as manager and giving the reason why. ''I think he's a terrific manager and a terrific person,'' said Tur ner, ''but, becauseof the record, sometimes you have to make a c hange.''

title: Michelle Marvin Loses Bid To Regain $104,0 00 Award
description: The California Supreme Court refused yesterday to reinstate a $104,000 award to the former companion of the actor Lee Marvin.

title: Canada Defeats Cosmos By 4-0 in an Exhibition
description: Gordon Sweetzer scored two goals in the first half last night to lea d the Canadian national team to a 4-0 victory over the Cosmos in an e xhibition match.

title: State U. Rolls Set a Record
description: ALBANY (AP) - Enrollment at the 64 campuses in the State Universitysystem reached 380,522 this fall, a record, C hancellor Clifton R. Wharton Jr. announced.

title: PROVIGO INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Aug 15
Canadian Aide in Yugoslavia
description: Defense Minister Gilles Lamontagne of Canada met today with his Yugoslav counterpart, Nikola Ljubicic, officials said. Mr. Lamontagne, who arrived yesterday from Prague, is here in his capacity as acting Minister of Veterans Affairs to pay respects at the graves of Canadian soldiers killed in Yugoslavia in World War II. He has also visited Italy and Poland.

title: Bear Mountain Fair
description: More than 130 craftsmen from the West Hudson Highlands will display their wares at the 11th annual crafts fair at Bear Mountain State Park starting tonight. Costumes that are throwbacks to medieval times and wall hangings made from velvet and suede will be among the crafts on display through next Sunday.

title: VOTER REGISTRATION TAKES PLACE TODAY
description: Polling places throughout the city will be open tomorrow from 1 to 9 P.M. for the final registration to qualify to vote in the Nov. 3 municipal elections.

title: Judge Overturns Ban On Abortion Coverage
description: A Federal judge r uled today that the Government did not have the authority to elim inate abortion coverage from all 1982 health care plans for its emplo yees.

title: Money Manager, 16, Weeding Out the 'Deadbeats'
description: Some high school students earn money after school with newspaper routes, by offering yard care or baby-sitting services, by bagging groceries at supermarkets and workin g as delivery boys. Not Kenn Bloom, a 16-y ear-old pupil in a suburban Chicago high school.

title: EGYPTIAN MYSTERY: THE GUARDS ' ROLE
description: Egypt's leaders are trying to determine how four men were able to insinuate themselves into a military parade, leap from a truck at precisely the right moment and, apparently with almost no opposition from security guards, shoot President Anwar el-Sadat to death.

title: THE CITY
description: A 2-year-old boy who was playing with his grandmother's rifle pulled the trigger and grazed his 3-year-old cousin's ear with a bullet.

title: CARTERS THREATEN TO SUE FOR LIBEL
description: Former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, p la n to sue The Washington Post for libel over a gossip column item a sserting that they had eavesdropped on some of Nancy Reagan's conv ersations during her pre-inaugural residence at Blair House, an att orney for the Carters said today.

title: Crafts From 20 States At Morristown Show
description: Work by 135 craftsmen from 20 states will be featured today through Sunday at the fifth annual Morristown Craft Market, at the Morristown National Grand Armory. Items for sale will include ceramic wind bells, gold jewelry, leather crafts and porcelain pottery, at prices ranging from $2 to $2,500.

title: Sears Strategy: B eating the Banks
description: The country's largest retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Company, has announced a bold series of acquisitions and new ventures in a race to become a financial services department store before banks are freed to offer competing services. ''The banks are going to become unfettered, '' Edward R. Telling, the chairman of Sears, noted recently. ''They should be allowed to compete,'' he said. ''Hopefully we'll be a fe w miles down the road when that happens.''

title: Advertising; Puerto Rico Seeks Out Business
description: ONE of the oldest and most vicious advertising wars is being waged by the economic development departments of our various states, territories and regions, who are trying to woo, cajole and kidnap businesses from other areas.

title: 'BEAU PERE,' BY BERTRAND BLIER
description: MOMENTS after she declares to her lover that her career is failing because ''they want younger ones,'' a photographer's model is killed in an automobile accident. The dead woman's 29-year-old lover and her 14-year-old daughter barely bother to shed a tear before embarking on the lengthy flirtation that Bertrand Blier's new movie, ''Beau Pere,'' is about. The lover resists the daughter's advances for a while, protesting, ''I'm not old quite old enough to go for little girls.'' But he turns out to be wrong.

title: LEAVE EXTENDED FOR KEKKONEN
description: The medical leave of Finland's President, 81-year-old Urho Kekkonen, has been extended for a second month, and reports from Helsinki say one of the reasons is to give more time for political parties to prepare for special elections to replace him.

title: U.S. Team Ousted
description: Dariusz Dziekanowski scored two goals inside one minute of the second half tonight to lead Poland to a 4-0 triumph over the United States, eliminating eliminate the Americans from the 16-nation FIFA world youth soccer championships. The Americans totaled only five shots on goal. With only a tie in two previous matches, the Americans needed to defeat Poland by three goals to reach the quarterfinals.

title: No Offers Yet for Torre
description: Tom Seaver of NBC-TV, formerly of the Mets, walked up to Joe Torre of CBS-Radio, formerly of the Mets, and asked:''Any job off ers yet?''

title: CANADA BLAMES ITSELF FOR HALF OF ITS ACID RAIN
description: A parliamentary subcommittee said today that half of the acid rain falling on Canada ''comes from domestic sources of air pollution.'' It recommended a number of actions within Canada to solve the problem.

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1981; Companies
description: Sears will buy Dean Witter, the fifth-largest brokerage firm, for $607 million in cash and stock. The acquisition is a major step in the big retailer's effort to become the ''largest consumer-oriented financial service entity.'' Its goal is for a shopper to be able to handle financial, insurance and real estate transactions at one store. (Page A1.)

title: Restaurants; Russian fare near Lincoln Center.
description: BECAUSE Russian food seems especially appropriate before or after concerts and the ballet, it seems equally appropriate to have it represented near Lincoln Center. Opened about two months ago on 62d Street, Tovarisch is already good enough to indicate that with time and practice it may become even better.

title: ASTROS TRY FOR CLINCHER
description: The Houston Astros remember last year all too well to come to Dodger Stadium claiming anything this year. The Astros have a 2-0 lead in the National League Western Division playoff and need only one victory in three games here to advance to the league championship series for the second straight year. They will send Bob Knepper to pitch against Burt Hooton tomorrow afternoon. But they are aware of how quickly three games vanished last year at this time.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; ALL OF KUROSAWA
description: Akira Kurosawa, the acclaimed Japanese film director who came into prominence when ''Rashomon'' won the grand prize at the Venice International Film Festival in 1951, will appear at Japan House, 333 East 47th Street, tonight to open the first complete American retrospective of his works. With an interpreter, Mr. Kurosawa will introduce two screenings, at 7:30 and 10 P.M., of ''Yojimbo'' (1961), the tale of a samurai who offers his services to both sides in a feud. The series will continue through Dec. 20 and will include at least two showings of all 26 Kurosawa films, with English subtitles. Admission is $7.50 on opening night, $4 for subsequent screenings - Saturdays and Sundays at 2 and 7:30 P.M. and Wednesdays and Fridays at 7:30. For information, call 832-1155.

title: PANEL, ON APPEAL, DECLARES UNSER INDY 500 WINNER
description: Bobby Unser, who last May became the first driver in the 65-year history of the Indianapolis 500 to lose a first-place finish by an official ruling, yesterday was declared the winner.

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS PLANS FOR REVIVAL OF NUCLEAR POWER
description: The Reagan Administration today formally specified the steps it will take to revive commercial nuclear power, an industry whose current problems the Administration regards as largely due to overregulation by the Government.

title: The B-1 Is a Bomb
description: President Reagan's proposal to revive a modified version of the B-1 strategic bomber, at a cost of $20 to $30 billion for 100 planes, is in trouble in Congress. It deserves to be.

title: PITTSBURGH NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earrings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Oct 1, 1981

title: In the Nation; A NEW SECURITY MANIA
description: The foul murder of Anwar el-Sadat obviously will have great consequences in the Middle East. At home, it might well feed a panicky new political reaction against ''terrorism'' - although the actual threat of terrorism in the United States is downgraded by William Webster, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 18.50-19.00 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers e stimates for bellwether issues

title: MRS. THATCHER VISITS AFGHANS ON THE FRONTIER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain shook hands across the border with an Afghan Government militiaman today, gingerly touched a Soviet machine gun and told a gathering of Afghan refugees that her Government would continue to press Moscow to withdraw its troops from their homeland.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp. said production will be suspended for one week at its passenger car plant in Kenosha, Wis., beginning next week, in an attempt to balance inventories with slow sales, idling 5,000 workers.

title: TO PROTECT AMERICA'S INTELLIGENCE EFFORTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIBYA AND EGYPT SAID TO BE ON ALERT
description: Administration officials said today that Libyan and Egyptian forces have been placed on ''high alert'' along their common border in the aftermath of the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt.

title: ART: RICHES OF ADDISON
description: THIS year marks the 50th anniversary of the founding of the Addison Gallery on the campus of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., and to celebrate this event an exhibition of major works drawn from its permanent collection, which is entirely devoted to American art, has come to New York for the first time. Called ''Masterworks of American Art From the Addison Gallery Collection,'' the exhibition opened this week at the Hirschl & Adler Galleries, 21 East 70th Street, where it remains on view through Oct. 31. It is an exhibition that everyone with an interest in the history of American art will want to see.

title: At the Movies; Maud Adams finally taken seriously.
description: YOU probably think if you were tall and gorgeous, you'd be happy, right? Well, not so fast. Take the case of Maud Adams, the Swedishborn, international model turned movie star. ''Tattoo,'' opening today, is her 11th feature film, but until recently, nobody took her seriously as an actress. ''I'd studied, I felt I was ready, but I kept being offered roles without dimensions.''

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Sept 27
Posner Buys Crown Stock
description: Victor Posner, the Miami Beach financier, announced that he has purchased an additional 390,000 shares of the Royal Crown Companies, the producer of soft-drinks and fast foods, for $16 a share, or a total of $6.2 million.

title: FIRST UNITED BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW, MORE POTENT WARHEADS MAY BE USED ON MX MISSILES
description: The Pentagon leadership has tentatively decided to develop a new warhead for the MX missile with ''significantly greater'' explosive power than the most advanced United States warheads in existence, a senior military official said today.

title: Shamrock Net Rises
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter increased 17 percent, to $51.8 million, or 83 cents a share, from $44.3 million, or 71 cents, in the corresponding 1980 period. Sales rose 6.4 percent, to $823.4 million from $774 million.

title: MIRED COAST FREEWAY GETS GO-AHEAD
description: In the nest of freeway interchanges known as downtown Los Angeles, an office supply store has put up a window display to honor the city's bicentennial. The centerpiece is a miniature green and white freeway sign poking fun at the municipal image. ''Los Angeles, next 200 exits,'' it says.

title: Jersey Officials Search For Dangerous Wastes
description: State authorities cut off electricity, gas and phone service to a Paterson, N.J., warehouse today to try to prevent an explosion while they take samples from drums believed to contain toxic wastes.

title: Football Aide Resigns After Assault on Player
description: An assistant football coach at Quincy High School who hit a player and broke the player's jaw after the team lost a game resigned today.

title: An Oil 'Glut' That Raises Prices
description: Most people know that a worldwide oil ''glut'' has provided a welcome pause in rising prices. But few know that a very different kind of glut is, paradoxically, increasing the cost of oil from Alaska's Prudhoe Bay. There is an easy legal remedy for the problem, but only vigorous lobbying by the White House can bring it about.

title: Venezuela Budget Approved
description: The Cabinet has approved a national budget of $20.33 billion for the 1982 fiscal year, the Ministry of Information has announced. Seventy percent of the income is expected to come from the country's oil exports, the ministry said.

title: LANIER BUSINESS PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: B-After equity in losses of AES Data Ltd of $591,000 for the latest period and $594,000 for the previous period

title: Notes on People; Bess Truman Home
description: Bess Truman, the 96-year-old widow of President Harry S. Truman, was released yesterday from the Kansas City Research Medical Center and sent to her home in nearby Independence, Mo., to recover from a stroke she suffered Sept 26.

title: PEASANTS VS. STATE IN POLAND
description: Josef Broniszewski, a young farmer who owns 20 acres of land outside this town near Warsaw, has just sold 40 percentof his grain harvest to the state for 1,000 zlotys a quintal. He willsell the rest in the private market for 2,000 zlotys a quintal.

title: TIMES FIBER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-1 stock split in Jan 1981

title: HARVEST OUTLOOK: SMALL FOR SOVIET, BIG FOR U.S.
description: Poor growing weather and the smallest acreage in a decade are expected to reduce this year's Soviet grain harvest to 175 million metric tons, the third smallest since 1972, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Br oyard BACHELORHOOD: Tales of the Metrop- olis. By Phillip Lopate. 286 pages. Little, Brown. $13.95.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN GEORGIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Brainy Quarterback Leading W. Virginia
description: One year after West Virginia Universitywon a publici zed recruiting battle for Robert Alexander, a native sonrunning back in 1977, hardly anyone noticed when Oliver Luck of Cleveland dec ided to attend West Virginia instead of an Ivy League school.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Urges Talks On Conflict in Cambodia
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, whose Government has recognized the Vietnamese-backed regime in Cambodia, said here today that India would welcome any conference that would seek a resolution of the conflict there.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 18.50-19.00** Rates are before any surchages on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Roger Wolcott Sperry
description: When Roger Wolcott Sperry entered Oberlin College in the early 1930's, he had not decided on what would be his career. He majored in English literature and was captain of the varsity basketball team. Influenced by courses in psychology, he switched from humanities to psychology for his master's degree at Oberlin, then went on to earn his doctorate in zoology at the University of Chicago in 1941.

title: REAGANS BUY MORE CHINA
description: Nancy Reagan has ordered another set of china, this one to be paid for out of her own pocket and to be for the Reagan family's personal use in the White House. Copies of the set will be made available to the public, according to the maker, Edward Marshall Boehm Inc. The 24-place set will be handmade by Boehm, of Trenton and Malverne, E ngland, according to Helen Boehm, owner of the porcelain studio, w hich is best known for for its limited editions of naturalistic bird s. Mrs. Boehm, widow of the sculptor who founded the enterprise, said today that she had known Mrs. Reagan for 18 years.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CLOSE TO HOME

title: U.N. OFFICER SHOT IN LEBANON
description: The chief of staff of the United Nations forces in southern Lebanon was wounded yesterday when his vehicle was ambushed by Palestinian guerrillas, a United Nations spokesman reported.

title: Brotherly Losers Are Safe at Home
description: PHILADELPHIA THE cover of the press guide reads, ''World Champion Phillies,'' but that was last year, when the Phils were winning the National League pennant for the first time in 30 years, on their way to the first World Series victory in the club's long and sometimes comical history. This year they are losing the playoff in the National League East to the Montreal Expos. They are losing their owner, Ruly Carpenter, who has put the franchise up for sale. They may be losing their manager; Dallas Green is reported leaving for the Chicago Cubs.

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: DUTCH SQUATTERS AND POLICE CLASH: Demonstrators in Amsterdam pelting police with stones during confrontation near a former office building occupied by squatters. After repulsing the attack, policemen broke down the building's doors and ejected the squatters. Three protesters were arrested.

title: PHILARMONIA OPENING SIXTH COMMUNITY SERIES
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia will open its sixth season of community concerts at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, 304 West 47th Street, tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: LARGE AND SMALL PRODUCERS CLASH ON FUTURE OF CABLE TV
description: Clashing views about the opportunities and content of cable television emerged yesterday at Alice Tully Hall. It was the first time in the 19-year history of the Lincoln Center Film Festival that television had come under scrutiny. The program was presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and New Medium, a communications concern that links artists with the electronic marketplace.

title: OFFICIALS FROM AROUND THE WORLD ATTENDING SADAT'S FUNERAL
description: Following is a list of foreign dignitaries and other mourners planning to attend the funeral of President Anwar el-Sadat tomorrow, as compiled by The Associated Press: AUSTRALIA Deputy Prime Minister J. Douglas Anthony AUSTRIA Vice Chancellor Fred Sinowatz Foreign Minister Willibald Pahr BELGIUM King Baudouin BRITAIN Prince Charles Foreign Secretary Lord Carrington Former Prime Minister James Callaghan CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC Minister of Public Works Sylvestre Yangongo CHINA Deputy Prime Minister Ji Pengfei DENMARK Prince Henrik Foreign Minister Kjeld Olesen FRANCE President Francois Mitterrand Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson Former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing GREECE Former President Constantine Tsatsos Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister Evangelos Averoff INDIA Speaker of Parliament Ravindra Varma IRELAND President Patrick J. Gen. Emmanuel A. Erskine of Ghana Aly I. Teymour of Egypt, protocol chief

title: LAKER FIGHTING PAN AM FARE CUT
description: The fare war on trans-Atlantic routes between London and the United States heated up yesterday as Sir Freddie Laker, the pioneer of cheap no-frills trans Atlantic fares, said that he would complain to the British Department of Trade over recent fare cuts by Pan American World Airways.

title: THANKS, MR. NIXON
description: Richard M. Nixon bought me a couch, so to speak. And through me, he also, you might say, contributed money to the American Civil Liberties Union and to other organizations that are staunch supporters of the First Amendment.

title: LAWYER IS HELD IN SCHEME TO BRIBE U.S. JUDGE
description: The former president of a lawyers' organization was arrested here today on charges that he attempted to bribe a Federal District judge in Miami to re duce the sentences of two men.

title: A World to Feed 11th article of a series ap-; pearing periodically.
description: The two farmers faced real dangers on opposite sides of the war that turned Rhodesia into Zimbabwe. Both have now had a piece of the first big postwar harvest, which has made this the only black-ruled country in Africa that has to worry about overproduction of food. Yet, although they are separated by only 25 miles and a range of hills, the two farmers - Nichodamas Manomano and Hermanus Conradie Jr. - exist in different worlds. One of these worlds knows bumper crops as a matter of course; the other still shares in the crisis of rural Africa, where population pressure and ruinous cultivation practices are part of a cycle that ends in malnutrition and the depletion of the soil itself.

title: EGYPT BLAMES OFFICER WITH GRUDGE FOR ASSASSINATION
description: The Egyptian Government said today that an army lieutenant had organized the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat ''out of a black grudge'' because his brother, a Moslem extremist, was arrested in the mass crackdown on Sept. 5.

title: COSEKA RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-After $138,000 special loss on the sale of shrs of affiliated company

title: WATT SSOFTENING ATTACKS ON CRITICS OF HIS POLICIES
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, probably the most visible and vilified Cabinet member of the first year of the Reagan administration, is growing somewhat circumspect, if not chastened, after eight months in office.

title: PARIBAS SUISSE ACCEPTS BID
description: A group of investors announced a bid today for the Swiss branch of one of the major French banks threatened by nationalization under the new Socialist Government of France.

title: EAST AND WEST GERMANS, IN OPEN LETTER, SEEK END TO 'OCCUPATION'
description: A letter signed by 27 public figures from East Germany and about 150 from West Germany has been sent to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, calling for a withdrawal of Soviet and American troops and weapons from both Germanys.

title: Notes on People; Reagan Gives Posthumous Award to Mrs. Grasso
description: In White House ceremonies yesterday, President Reagan presented the Medal of Freedom to six persons, including the late Governer of Connecticut, Ella T. Grasso. Her husband, Dr. Thomas A. Grasso, accepted the award.

title: TASTY BAKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-AFter losses from discontinued operations of $1,561,963 for the qr and $1,810,717 for the 9 mos both of which include a $781,266 loss from sale of the company's Larant Toy subsidiar C-After losses from discontinued operations of $69,152 for the qr and $67,023 for the 9 mos...D-Net income

title: The Region; Poll Finds Jersey Wants a Change
description: Three of four New Jersey residents believe that things have been getting worse rather in the state over the la st few years and would lik e a change, according to a poll by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: The City; Suspect Is Sought In Shooting Case
description: A warrant was issued yesterday for a suspected drug dealer, Kenneth A. Douglas, 26 years old, of Brooklyn, in the shooting Thursday of a New York City police officer.

title: About New York; A NIGHT IN THE TEMPLE OF THE ANIMALS
description: It is night. Outside the hospital windows, the Queensboro Bridge glitters above the black of the East River. Inside, in the recovery room, the dogs snore, slack and sleepy on Valium. The cats look darkly out of their cages in the wards, apparently angry at the indignity of adhesive tape and gauze on their glossy fur. The waiting room is filled with people. Their animals are in pain.

title: IC REPORTS 7.2% RISE IN QUARTER
description: IC Industries, a diversified international corporation with major interests in consumer and commercial products, railroads and foods, reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter rose 7.2 percent on an increase in revenues of 4.2 percent.

title: Jets Get a Big Lift as Todd Passes Way to No. 3 in the League
description: The name, the team and the numbers just did not belong. On the statistical sheet tacked to the Jets' bulletin board today, there was Richard Todd's name and it showed that he was pro football's third-leading passer.

title: Apparatus for Checking Rail Scanner Systems
description: Automatic identification systems can be used by railroads to scan passing cars.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
David Hunter Hubel
description: Dr. David Hunter Hubel knew he had been proposed for the Nobel Prize in past years, but was still surprised and thrilled at the award yesterday.

title: Reputed Crime Figure Is Cleared of Charges
description: James V. Montemarano, a reputed figure in organized crime on the Jersey shore, was ruled not guilty of helping to skim profits from a casino in Nevada.

title: FERROFLUIDICS CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Including $16,582 foreign tax credit

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Golfing the Hard Way
description: The police in Alameda, Calif., say they have broken up a hot golfball ring by arresting three men in wetsuits. They said the three had donned the suits to raid water hazards throughout the state to steal wayward golf balls.

title: 'DEAD AND BURIED'
description: Something's amiss in the seaside town of Potters Bluff: its good citizens - or those, at least, who hang out in the town's steamy diner exchanging knowing looks - have taken to random murder, recorded with blinding bursts of flashbulbs. Who are they and why are they doing it? James Farentino, as Dan Gillis, a handsome sheriff with an advanced degree in criminology, finds out in ''Dead and Buried,'' which opened yesterday at the Guild Embassy and other theaters.

title: INVESTIGATORS ASSERT CITY AIDES HINDERED FOOD-STAMP INQUIRY
description: A group of present and former New York City investigators has charged that city officials consistently hindered their efforts to investigate large-sca le fraud in the city's f ood-stamp program.

title: FIRST & MERCHANTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Colt Can't Cite Cause of Gain
description: A spokesman for Colt Industries said yesterday that the company knew of no reason for a sharp rise in its stock. The shares rose $3.25 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $80, on volume of 111,900 shares.

title: TIMBER CONCERNS FAIL TO DRAW BIDS
description: In the heat of today's acquisition fever, companies are often snapped up even before the sale notice is properly displayed. But this enthusiasm apparently does not extend to companies that grow trees: The American Can Company and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation are both trying to sell their forest-products divisions, so far unsuccessfully.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a pooling of interests acquisition in July 1981

title: GIRARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AWACS AIRCRAFT IS SENT TO EGYPT-LIBYA BORDER
description: Administration officials said today that an Awacs surveillance plane had been sent to the Egyptian-Libyan border area to detect any hostile moves by Libya and that the aircraft carrier, Nimitz, had been moved closer to the region.

title: Salvadoran Says U.S.  Took Her for Terrorist
description: Ana Estela Flores Guevara, a Salvadoran refugee who says she has been mistaken for a terrorist leader, has sought political asylum in the United States.

title: Roberts Leaves 'Appeal'
description: Because of medical problems resulting from injuries suffered in an automobile accident in June, Eric Roberts has withdrawn from Bill C. Davis's comedy ''Mass Appeal,'' which is in previews in Boston. The play's scheduled opening in New York at the Booth Theater on Oct. 29 has been postponed.

title: AKZONA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 23
TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
SENATE BACKS 'VETO' OF WATT'S MOVE
description: The Republican-controlled Senate today filed court papers opposing the Reagan Administration's argument that a directive issued by the Democratic-controlled House Interior Committee to Interior Secretary James G. Watt was an unconstitutional ''legislative veto.''

title: Health Unit Issues Model Law To Help Families Who Adopt
description: The Department of Health and Human Services has published a model adoption law that provides for financial assistance to families who adopt children with ''special needs.''

title: Bridge: The Search for Knowledge Begins Early on Occasion
description: One of the most difficult arts in the game - deliberate maneuvering to collect information about the defenders' hands - is virtually unknown to the average player. It is sometimes necessary to begin the information-collecting process before it is clear that the information will be valuable.

title: CAROLINE BUNTING KLESH
description: Caroline Bunting Klesh, former editor and publisher of two weekly newspapers on Long Island, died Thursday at a nursing home in Snydersville, Pa. Mrs. Klesh, who lived in Buck Hills Falls, Pa., was 58 years old.

title: 2 PLUS 2 EQUALS WHITE
description: In 1977 the United States Supreme Court, in a decision involving New York City, ruled that election districts could be drawn in a racially aware fashion so as to produce a reasonable relationship betwen minority population and minority representation in legislative bodies. The principal opinion was written by Justice Byron White, no leftist radical. The vote was 7 to 1. Nothing has happened since in case law to alter this important ruling.

title: HOUSTON ARCHITECTURE TYPIFIES CHANGING ATTITUDE
description: It is 10 years since the completion of One Shell Plaza, the 50-story tower of travertine marble that was the tallest building west of the Mississippi and the first major sign to all the world that Houston meant its skyline to be taken seriously. An Appraisal

title: TAX BREAKS ON HOUSING STUDIED
description: Tax breaks for homeowners have had a mixed effect on the housing market and the United States economy as a whole, according to a new study by the Congressional Budget Office.

title: FLORIDA POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cuban Arrested by F.B.I.  On a Passport Charge
description: Armando Cesar Santana Alvarez, reportedly a follower of the anti-Castro terrorist organization Omega 7, was held in $150,000 bail in Newark last night on Federal charges of obtaining a passport under a false name.

title: BRUCE DERN STARS IN 'TATTOO'
description: Some men think flowers will do, and others try jewelry or a nightie or a nice box of chocolates. Not Karl Kinski, the hero of ''Tattoo.''Karl is the l atest of those movie males who stalk the women they love with a f ondness bordering on sadism, and he also happens to be atattoo artist par excellence. So when it comes time for Karl to tell the hapless M addy that he thinks she's that special someone, he says it with needl es. And dye.

title: Your Money
description: SEVERAL years ago, when banks first started offering bill payment by telephone, the service was widely viewed as the first step in the inevitable and imminent transition to a totally electronic banking system. But pay-by-phone, as it is sometimes known, has failed to live up to expectations.

title: ZOE CALDWELL HELPING ON 'OTHELLO' PRODUCTION
description: Zoe Caldwell, the actress turned director in recent years, has been called upon to help with the staging of one of the most eagerly awaited Broadway productions of the season. She is quietly working on ''Othello,'' starring James Earl Jones and Christopher Plummer.

title: Carey Orders an Investigation Of Disclosures in Attica Case
description: Governor Carey ordered an investigation today into how a Rochester television station obtained secret grand jury testimony about the 1971 Attica state prison uprising.

title: STUDIES ADVANCE WORK ON BRAIN, EYE DISORDERS
description: Important new research on problems such as reading and writing difficulties, as well as a better understanding of how to treat two visual birth defects, are growing out of the brain research that won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine yesterday.

title: The City; Officer Injured I n Hotel Robbery
description: A police officer was slightly injured last night when he interrupted the armed robbery of a guest at the New York Statler Hotel, the police said.

title: SEARS EARNINGS WEAKER
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, which announced agreements this week to acquire a major securities firm and a nationwide real estate brokerage for more than $780 million, said yesterday that thirdquarter earnings ''will not exceed and may be slightly lower'' than in the comparable 1980 quarter.

title: The Region; Jersey Takes Over Foundation Life
description: New Jersey's Department of Insurance seized control of the financially troubled Foundation Life Insurance Company of Chatham.

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about a visit to New London, Conn., gave an incorrect starting point for the Amtrak train from New York City. It starts from Pennsylvania Station.

title: RANGERS FALL AGAIN IN 8-3 ROUT BY JETS
description: Before their game tonight with the Winnipeg Jets, the Rangers were reminded by Coach Herb Brooks that the last time they were here, in January, they gave up four goals in the third period and lost to the team with the worst record in the National Hockey League, the Jets.

title: VESSEL BEGINS VIGIL FOR ALIENS TODAY ,
description: The Coast Guard cutter Hamilton tomorrow will begin intercepting boats suspected of transporting il legal aliens, officials here announced today.

title: Letter: On Tax-Exempt Investments The Case for 'All Savers'
description: To the Editor:

title: New Home for 'Annie'
description: ''Annie,'' which was on the verge of becoming an orphaned Broadway musical, has found a new home - albeit a temporary one. It is going to move into the Eugene O'Neill Theater on Oct. 28. The show is currently playing at the ANTA Theater, but must move out of there by Oct. 25 to make way for another new musical, ''Oh, Brother!'', due to open Nov. 10.

title: POET CONVICTED A SECOND TIME IN HIS WIFE'S SHOOTING DEATH
description: James E. Lewisohn, a poet and former English profe ssor at the University of Maine, today was found guilty a second time of the 1974 shooting death of his wife, Roslyn, in CapeElizabeth, Me .

title: 7 Injured by Bomb Blast In Salvador's High Court
description: A bomb exploded today in El Salvador's Supreme Court building, injuring the court president and six other officials.

title: 3 EX-PRESIDENTS CALL ON MUBARAK AND MRS. SADAT
description: Three former American Presidents arrived here today bearing their sorrow in the name of the American people at the death of President Anwar el-Sadat.

title: Union Electric Ends Expansion
description: The Union Electric Company, echoing similar announcements from a growing number of electric utilities, said it had canceled plans to build a second unit at its Callaway nuclear power plant because of the ''financial risks and uncertainties inherent in its construction.''

title: News An alysis
description: Mayor Koch has been critical of benefits won by the Transport Workers Union, but his tough rhetoric does not always jibe with his flexibility in dealing with municipal unions, according to a number of participants in municipal labor affairs.

title: ARIZONA BANK (PHOENIX) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results include operations of Applewhite Mortgage Co acquired in Dec 1980

title: Notes on People
description: Lincoln MemorialTypo In the nearly 60 years since the dedication of the Lincoln Memorial in 1922, tens of thousands of Ohioans must have visited the Washington landmark. Only one, however, seems to have noticed something wrong.

title: ADMINISTRATION PLANS, ON ITS OWN, TO REDUCE MOST OUTLAYS BY 12%
description: Faced with stiffening resistance in Congress to further budget cuts, the Reagan Administration is planning immediate reductions on its own, averaging 12 percent in most areas outside the military, by seeking to have spending deferred.

title: REPORTER 55 YEARS
description: Emma Bugbee, a reporter whose colorful career on The New York Herald Tribune spanned 55 years, died on Tuesday in a Rhode Island nursing home at the age of 93. She retired two days before the newspaper ceased publication in 1966.

title: Root-Canal Kit Devised As an Aid to Dentists
description: A kit to provide a general dentist all the instruments and supplies he needs for root canal work was patented this week by Dr. Joel L. Dunsky of Boston.

title: Business Digest; The Economy
description: The Producer Price Index for finished goods rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in September, the smallest monthly rise in over three years, the Government reported. It cited lower prices for some foods and price-cutting on the last of the 1981 mod el cars. The report was seen as another sign that inflation is recedi ng. (Page 1.)

title: Polls Are Open Today For Registering Voters
description: Polling places throughout New York City will be open today from 1 to 9 P.M. for the final registration to qualify to vote in the Nov. 3 municipal elections.

title: ASKING TOO MUCH OF THE 'SPIRIT OF VOLUNTEERISM'
description: T o the Editor: President Reagan expects too much from American philanthropy. In his address to the nation (Sept. 24) on the need for additional cuts in domestic spending, the President invoked the American ''spirit of volunteerism'' and our ''proud tradition of generosity.''

title: '33 GERSHWIN SHOW REVIVED
description: ''Let 'Em Eat Cake,'' the ill-fated sequel that George Gershwin wrote to his Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Of Thee I Sing'' in the early 1930's, will be presented in concert tomorrow night in Gusman Hall, at the University of Miami.

title: INDUSTRIAL-AMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Oh, no, I was afraid of that! Maybe I sho uld go and hide.'' - Dr.Torsten N. Wiesel, winner of the Nobel Prize. (1:1.)

title: A 50-YEAR VIEW OF THE GEORGE WASHINGTON BRIDGE
description: Fifty years ago, when workmen finished building a still nameless bridge across the Hudson River between the sliced-off cliffs of the Palisa des and the rocky ledges of Washington Heights, it was hailed as a major en gineering accomplishment. The new bridge not only exceeded the length of the longest existing suspension bridge, it doubled it.

title: P.L.O. AIDE KILLED BY BOMB IN ROME
description: A member of the Palestine Liberation Organization's Central Council and of Al Fatah's Executive Committee was killed today in an explosion in his Rome hotel room.

title: 'TASTING' MENU: A GOOD IDEA SOURS
description: One byproduct of the nouvelle cuisine is the menu de degustation, or tasting menu, that is offered in many restaurants here - including the Quilted Giraffe, Chanterelle, Claude's and Lutece - and in France and that is perhaps being overworked. The reasons for its development are easy to grasp. As this new cuisine became highly publicized, diners were eager to sample all of the dishes they had read about, and so each person in a group ordered a different appetizer, main course and dessert. Then all would taste everything.

title: 10/10: The Broken Pieces of China
description: Today, for the first time, Peking's Communists will celebrate ''double ten,'' which marks China's rebirth as a republic on Oct. 10, 1911. The event emphasizes Peking's new interest in reuniting with the Nationalists, a move it proposes on terms that recognize the differences between the mainland and Taiwan.

title: Process For Creating A Feline Disease
description: One of the week's patents related to forms of life concerns a process of promoting a disease in cats. Two Dutch inventors, Marian C. Horzinek of Bilthoven and Albertus D.M.E. Osterhaus of Bunnik, were granted patent 4,293,653 for a method of propagating feline infectious peritonitis virus.

title: Comeback at 73
description: The king and queen at this weekend's homecoming festivities at Humboldt State University in Arcata, Calif., were born five years before the school was founded in 1913.

title: BUSH SIGHTS DANGER AHEAD IF AWACS SALE IS BLOCKED
description: Vice President Bush said today that Congressional approval of the sale of air defense equipment, including five Awacs aircraft, to Saudi Arabia was essential to tell the world that the United States was not ''a confused, contradictory, often helpless, sometimes clumsy giant.''

title: LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HEINZ KOHUT, WHOSE THEORY OPPOSED FREUD'S, DEAD AT 68
description: Heinz Kohut, a leading psychoanalyst who developed a new theory of the self in opposition to the ideas of Sigmund Freud, died Thursday of congestive heart failure at Billing Hospital in Chicago. He was 68 years old.

title: STAGE: 'DEAD GIVEAWAY'
description: While Claudette Colbert is ensnared on Broadway in the nonmysterious "A Talent for Murder," Off Off Broadway Mary Orr and Reginald Denh am are offering "Dead Giveaway," a thriller with at least a glimm er of suspense. Playing at the Apple Corps Theater, a comfortable l ittle theater far west on 51st Street, "Dead Giveaway" is not withou t its banalities and contrivances, but it is clearly thework of profe ssionals in the craft of crime writing.

title: PRICE CO reports earnings for Yr to Aug 30
DANCE: ANONYMITY AND VIRTUOSITY
description: Douglas Dunn, Dana Reitz and Karole Armitage were the choreographers presented on the third program of avantgaard dance in the New Dance USA Festival organized here by the Walker Art Center.

title: OPTIONS FOR EXPECTANT MOTHERS
description: A GUIDE to alternatives to the traditional childbirth services offered by hospitals in New York City is available to pregnant women who prefer intimacy to technology when they give birth. The options include midwifery programs in hospitals and at childbirth centers outside hospitals and delivery at home.

title: INSILCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle in Metropolitan Report yesterday gave incorrect detour plans for trucks using the Williamsburg Bridge.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $3.2 million approximate net credit for the qr from changes in accounting estimates and commodity book-to-physical inventory adjustments and $7.9 million approximate net gain for the yr from the sale of river barges...C-Including $10.4 million approximate net gain for the qr and yr from the sale of seven grain elevators $1.3 million credit for the qr from a reduction in the provision for the estimated loss from discontinuance of a product line, $2.9 million loss for the yr related to the discontinuance of that line and $1.6 million approximate investment tax credit for the qr

title: CAREY AND KOCH BACK BOND ISSUE ON STATE PRISONS
description: With a group of prosecutors standing behind them, Governor Carey and Mayor Koch called yesterday for passage of a $500 million prison bond issue that will appear on the ballot in the Nov. 3 general election.

title: DON SUTTON UNDERGOES OPERATION ON KNEECAP
description: Don Sutton, the Houston Astros pitcher, underwent surgery on his right kneecap this morning at Centinela Hos pital, the team announced.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $347,438 or 15 cents a shr gain on the sale of securities; shr earnings reflect a 25 percent stock distribution paid Aug 31

title: PHILS AND DODGERS AVOID ELIMINATION
description: The Philadelphia Phillies stayed alive in the National League East playoff today when they rallied after two straight losses and defeated the Montreal Expos, 6-2.

title: William E. Sauro Kean Visits Morris County Map Exhibition
description: Thomas H. Kean, Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, speaking with members of the Morris County Heritage Commission yesterday in Morristown. Mr. Kean took time out from his campaign schedule to view a collection of historic maps on display in the Freeholders Meeting Room at the Morris County Courthouse.

title: Walesa Holds First Talks With a Key Foreign Aide
description: The leader of Solidarity, Lech Walesa, conferred with Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France today in his first meeting with a ranking official of a foreign Government.

title: A'S SWEEP
description: After going scoreless for 19 consecutive innings, the Milwaukee Brewers came to life last night long enough to gain a 5-3 victory over the Yankees and remain alive in the playoff for the American League East championship.

title: ASBESTOS TAKEOVER DATE SET
description: The Quebec government, seeking to make good a long-standing but much-delayed pledge, announced today that the Asbestos Corporation would be expropriated Nov. 30 unless its American owner, the General Dynamics Corporation, accepted terms for its sale before then.

title: 3 SCIENTISTS SHARE NOBEL PRIZE FOR STUDIES OF THE BRAIN
description: The Nobel Prize for medicine was awarded yesterday to one scientist at the California Institue of Technology and two at Harvard University for research that has proved vital to understanding the organization of the brain.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1981
description: International Israeli and Egyptian leaders met in Cairo and vowed to press for peace in the Middle East. Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel talked for 40 miniutes with Hosni Mubarak, the new Egyptian leader. Mr. Mubarak is virtually certain to be approved to replace Mr. Sadat in a referendum Tuesday. Mr. Begin was among the host of world leaders who began assembling in Cairo for the funeral of President Anwar el-Sadat, who was assassinated during a military parade this week. Mr. Sadat will be honored with a state funeral. (Page 1, Column 6.) Calm returned in Egypt after more that 24 hours of fighting between policemen and Moslem fundamentalists in Asyut. Soldiers brought in to restore calm hunted for remaining snipers. According to officials, 20 persons were killed. But witnesses said at least 40 people were killed. Asyut is a center of Moslem fundamentalists critical of Mr. Sadat's pro-Western policies. (1:3-5.)

title: Drug Overdose Kills 2 Sailors on the Midway
description: Two sailors aboard the carrier Midway died of a drug overdose and 19 others have been detained as suspects in the seizure of 17.6 pounds of marijuana, the Navy announced today.

title: Tropical Storm Kills 65 In Northern Mexico
description: A tropical storm, designated Lydia, swept into the north Pacific coast of Mexico, killing at least 65 people, the authorities said today. The region is one of Mexico's major agricultural areas and a key exporter of tomatoes and other produce to the United States.

title: POLITICS AND MUSIC
description: In recent years, music seems to have lost its subversive edge. Glitter and punk rock have dulled audiences' appetites for outrage: ''There is no future in Rock and Roll,'' said Mick Jagger recently. Instead of topical songs of the 60's, the classic hits of the 30's and 40's are coming back into fashion; piano bars flourish in place of coffeehouses.

title: A Treatment For Cancer Of Cervix and Uterus
description: A method of treating cancer of the cervix and uterus with both radioactive and microwave energy has been invented by scientists at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J. Patent 4,292,960 was obtained this week by Robert W. Paglione for the process and instrument.

title: WRITERS CONGRESS OPENS WITH CALLS FOR SOLIDARITY
description: The American Writers Congress, whose organizational meeting in a Manhattan loft in March drew 40 writers, opened to a sellout audience yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel. The only discordant notes were sounded when, after the grand ballroom filled with spectators well in advance of the 7:30 P.M. keynote addresses, members of The Nation Institute, the sponsor, finally linked arms to bar further entry.

title: INVESTIGATION OF 5 YEAR OLD IN FATAL SHOOTING STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: Neighborhood children were playing around a plastic swimming pool in the August heat of Fort Jackson, in the on-post ghetto for military dependents.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 27.

title: PESSIMISTIC OUTLOOK AT BUSINESS COUNCIL
description: Economists for top corporations in the Business Council see moderate growth next year, with a decline in inflation but continued high unemployment. The forecast, which is more pessimistic than that of the Reagan Administration, sees no recession now or in 1982.

title: AAV COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MONEY SUPPLY OFF $2.1 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's money supply fell $2.1 billion in the week ended Sept. 30 and remained well below target despite the Fed's continuing efforts to stimulate faster growth.

title: AIDE SAYS REAGAN DIFFERS WITH FED
description: Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to President Reagan, said today that the President endorsed the urgings of his Treasury Secretary for a slight increase in the current growth rate of the nation's money supply.

title: STUDIED MOTIVATION AND EFFECTS OF COLOR
description: Louis Cheskin, a pioneer in the field of motivation research and marketing techniques, died last Saturday at Stanford University Hospital after suffering a heart attack. Mr. Cheskin, who lived in Menlo Park, Calif., was 72 years old.

title: G.M. Selling Houses; Can't Give Away Cars
description: It is no secret that the nation's automobile companies are having trouble selling cars. Now, it seems, General Motors can't even give them away.

title: WINTER, JACK, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-Net loss after $1,315,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: J.& L. Steel Increases Layoffs
description: The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation announced that it had laid off another 185 steelworkers at local operations because of a lack of orders. The layoffs, one of several announced by the steel industry in recent weeks, bring the number of workers furloughed this year to 350 at J.& L.'s Pittsburgh Works and 55 at the Aliquippa Works.

title: WING OF DUTCH PLANE FELL OFF
description: A storm exerting six times the force of gravity tore off the wing of a Dutch airliner and caused it to crash Tuesday, killing all 17 people aboard, investigators sa id today.

title: The City; Queens Teachers Ratify Contract
description: Striking lay teachers at St. John's Roman Catholic Preparatory School in Queens unanimously ratified a three-year contract and said they would return to work Tuesday.

title: Rich Purses Lure Filly, Mare
description: A 5-year-old mare and a 2-year-old filly will try to turn the richest program in New York racing history into Ladies Day at Belmont this afternoon against the best older horses and younger colts in the country.

title: Reagan Nuclear Policy Is Called Irresponsible
description: President Reagan's decision to revitalize the nuclear power industry was assailed today as an irresponsible safety and economic policy that could lead to the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

title: SATURN CLOUD FOUND TO CONTAIN A REGION HOTTER THAN THE SUN
description: The Voyager 2 spacecraft discovered a cloud of electrified gases circling Saturn that is 300 times hotter than the Sun's outer regions and the hottest spot ever detected in the solar system, a team of space scientists reported yesterday.

title: BYE BYE BEETHOVEN
description: One day a giant who lived in a castle in the sky dropped some magic seeds out the window. Upon waking next morning, he was astonished to see a huge beanstalk outside his window and, upon looking down, he saw that the beanstalk was rooted far below in the earth.

title: Affirmative Action vs. None at All
description: The Reagan Administration is backing away from affirmative action, the concept under which the Government has insisted that hiring and promotion reflect the ethnic and sexual makeup of the available labor force.

title: Confessed Spy Seeks to Tell H is Story on Television Show
description: A former United States Army officer who pleaded guilty last week to espionage charges has asked to appear on national television as a ''public service'' to describe his dealings with Russian intelligence agents 18 years ago.

title: KIKKOMAN SOY SAUCE EVEN ON CATFISH?
description: As far as George Horis hige is concerned, soy sauce goes just as well with Ame rican food as it does with oriental cuisine. ''I use soysauce on catf ish and I think it's real good,'' he says.

title: MASONITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EGYPT'S CHIEF SENDS MESSAGE TO REASSURE ISRAELIS ON PEACE
description: Hosni Mubarak, the new Egyptian leader, today sent a message of reassurance about peace to the Israeli people. Interviewed in Cairo by the Israeli newspaper Maariv, Mr. Mubarak was quoted as saying the assassins of President Anwar el-Sadat who were captured alive had not mentioned the peace settlement with Israel as a motive but had apparently acted out of their Islamic extremism.

title: O'Neill Birthday Party At Circle in the Square
description: The Theater Committee for Eugene O'Neill will observe the playwright's birthday Oct. 19 at 8 P.M. in the Circle in the Square Theater, on West 50th Street. The program will consist of readings and reminiscences and the presentation of the Eugene O'Neill Birthday Medal.

title: Fan Runs After Umpire
description: A fan entered the field last night at Yankee Stadium and was arrested on charges of criminal trespassing and disorderly conduct after he charged the third-base umpire, Mike Reilly.

title: The City; School Fire Forces 500 Pupils Outside
description: More than 500 pupils were sent home from an elementary school evacuated in Jamaica, Queens during a fire in a duct that damaged several rooms on the building's fourth floor, according to the Fire Department and the Board of Education.

title: Royals Lose, 4-1
description: Billy Martin's Oakland A's, who had the best overall record in the American League in the split season, ended the Royals' suffering tonight with a 4-1 victory and a sweep of the Western Division playoff.

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May 1981

title: ASKING TOO MUCH OF THE 'SPIRIT OF VOLUNTEERISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: Moroccan to Visit Canada
description: Foreign Minister Mohammed Boucetta will sign a cooperation agreement here and open a consulate general in Montreal on a five-day official visit to Canada next week, it was announced today.

title: GENERAL FOODS PRESIDENT
description: Philip L. Smith, 48 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the General Foods Corporation, succeeding Ross Barzelay, 59, who will become vice chairman and retire at the end of the company's fiscal year on April 2, 1982.

title: F.T.C. SEEKS MORE LTV DATA ON BID TO ACQUIRE GRUMMAN
description: The Federal Trade Commission has asked the LTV Corporation to file additional documents to answer antitrust allegations arising from the Dallas-based company's $450 million bid to acquire the Grumman Corporation, both companies said yesterday.

title: U.S. COURT BACKS CALIFORNIA CURB ON BUILDING NUCLEAR POWER PLANT
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld a state-imposed moratorium on construction of nuclear power plants in California. The decision, which will almost certainly be applealed to the United States Supreme Court, is expected to influence other states in deciding whether to slow nuclear development.

title: CHINA INVITES TAIWAN LEADERS TO VISIT
description: China pressed its new campaign for reconciliation with Taiwan today by inviting the leaders of the island's Nationalist party to return to the mainland to visit their ancestral homes. (The invitation was rejected within hours in a statement by a Nationalist Government spokesman, who denounced the move as a ''big show'' and part of the Communist leadership's ''smiling offensive'' that the Nationalists had previously rebuffed.)

title: E.R.A. - YES, BUT...
description: With the Democrats worrying about losing control of the House of Representati ves in 1982, the shortsightedness of the ''E.R.A.-orelse'' rule adopted at the Democra tic National Convention last year becomes more evident.

title: CULLEN-FROST BANKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid Feb 24, 1981

title: MITSUI MANUFACTURERS BANK (LOS ANGELES) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: Mitsui Bank of California and Manufacturers Bank of Los Angeles merged on June 30; results prior to that date represent the combined totals of the individual banks

title: Torsten Nils Wiesel
description: It was not an altogether joyous day for Torsten Nils Wiesel. When a reporter called to inform him that he had won a share of the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, Dr. Wiesel said, ''Oh, no, I was afraid of that!''

title: ILLNESS FROM TICKS MAY BE SPREADING
description: A mysterious illness called Lyme Disease may be more widespread than was previously believed, a report issued today by the national Centers for Disease Control indicates.

title: Dow Slips By 5.14; Volume Up; Dean Witter Surges by 13 1/2
description: Stock prices retreated slightly yesterday amid profit taking after the market's strong advance in the first four days of the week. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had advanced 54 points in less than two weeks through Thursday, slipped 5.14 points, to end the week at 873. For the overall market, however, issues that advanced in price slightly outnumbered those that declined.

title: A Paean for Martin
description: JoAnne Carner, the leading money-winner this year on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, credits Billy Martin, manager of the Oakland A's, with having made her a more aggressive player.

title: 'MINOR' CHANGES FORSEEN AS RESULT OF MIXUP AT COAST NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Officials of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company said today the company's Diablo Canyon nuclear plant in California required only ''minor'' modifications to remedy a construction error discovered last week and that those were expected to be completed by the end of this month.

title: WHAT DECONTROL CAN DO FOR NATURAL GAS
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleveland May Appeal Verdict in Utilities' Duel
description: A Federal jury has ruled that the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company broke no laws when it competed with the city-owned Municipal Light Plant.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DASH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
REBATES TAKE WORK BUT GAIN POPULARITY
description: When Barbara Greenwald went out to buy a food processor last January, she noticed that the manufacturer, Moulinex, was offering a $7 refund with proof of purchase.

title: Massachusetts Ruling In Rape Case Overturned
description: A State Supreme Court justice today blocked a lower court's ruling that revoked suspended sentences for five men accused of raping the onetime winner of a beauty contest.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Per shr figures are after capital gain distributions of 98 cents a shr in Feb 1981 and 67 cents a shr in Feb 1980; asset figures represent net assets

title: The Region; Impostor Seized Posing as Doctor
description: A man who opened a doctor's office and treated hundreds of people even though he never attended medical school has been arrested for practicing medicine without a license, authorities here said.

title: U.S. ACCUSES SOVIET OF 'DISINFORMATION'
description: The State Department accused the Soviet Union today of using forgery, ''disinformation'' and blackmail ''to discredit and weaken the United States and other nations.''

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income figures represent net investment income

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said it had purchased 550,000 ordinary shares of Alexander Howden Ltd. at $2.58 each. Alexander & Alexander previously announced an offer to aquire 100 percent of the Alexander Howden shares pursuant to an exchange offer.

title: BRIEFING
description: A LTHOUGH some ranking Cabinet and sub-Cabinet officials strongly urged President Reagan to fly to Cairo for the funeral of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, the figure who argued most forcefully against the trip was Nancy Reagan. At the Israeli Embassy, Nachman Shai, a spokesman, said very qu ietly: ''Suddenly it happened. Something many Israelis have been ve ry much afraid of for a long time. Always in the back of our minds.Wh at happens when he dies. ...''

title: In Plain English
description: The Department of Education is analyzing new evidence that expensive bilingual education programs don't work. It's too early to judge the methodology of these new studies, but it sounds as though they accord both with every known pedagogical theory and with common sense. The modern theory of bilingualism is that u ntil they learn enough English to keep up, non-English-speaking chil dren should be taught other subjects in their native language. It i s an appealing idea, butthe practice rarely stops there.

title: GRUMMAN FINDS PERFECTLY AGED POTHOLES FOR TESTING BUSES ON A STREET IN
description: BROOKLYN By DAVID W. DUNLAP

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.E., Pratt Seek Jet Engine Role
description: The General Electric Company and the United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney Company unit, the two biggest manufacturers of jet engines in the United States, have separately approached the English-Japanese consortium, Rolls-Royce and Japan Aero Engines Ltd., with proposals to join its jet engine development project, industry sources said in London.

title: HEAT'S OFF,' A MOSCOW WATCHER SAYS
description: There is a small fraternity of military intellectuals in this town who operate out of the public eye but who exert considerable influence on national policy through their writing, speaking and consulting. Generally described as ''strategic thinkers,'' they become especially active in a national debate on strategy such as the one that was activated by the Reagan Administration with its announcement last week of plans to build the B-1 bomber and deploy the MX missile.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES U.S. ON AN INDIAN POINT PLAN
description: A lawsuit seeking to correct what it called ''deficiencies'' in a plan for the removal of residents from the Indian Point area in nuclear-plant emergencies was announced here today.

title: CUSTOMS AGENT LINKS STOLEN BOOKS TO SUSPECT
description: A Customs agent testified in Federal court yesterday that 95 apparently rare and valuable books, including 19 missing from a university library in London, had been found in the Manhattan apartment of a Columbia University graduate student who was arrested last week.

title: The City;
description: The biggest slot-machine jackpot ever won in Atlantic City - more than $192,000 - has been won by a freelance illustrator and children's book author from New York, officials of Harrah's Marina Hotel-Casino said.

title: ORANGE-CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

title: Jersey's Commuter Tax I s Ruled Const itutional
description: About 94,000 New York residents must continue paying a special commuter tax levied against them by New Jersey, a judge ruled today.

title: 2 Abandon Everest Climb
description: Fierce winds forced two New Zealanders to abandon their attempt to conquer Mount Everest, the Nepalese Tourism Ministry reported today. Russel Brice, 29 years old, and Paddy Freany, 42, reached 24,600 feet before giving up on Tuesday, the ministry reported.

title: EGYPTIAN CITY IS QUIET AFTER CLASHES
description: After 24 hours of clashes between policemen and Moslem fundamentalists, quiet returned today to this southern city. Policemen reinforced by soldiers brought in yesterday and today were hunting remaining snipers.

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLTS FIND A LEADER
description: The Baltimore Colts, loser of four of their first five games, will waste no time in making use of Joe Federspiel, a linebacker who was acquired yesterday. He not only will play tomorrow but also will call the defensive signals against the Cincinnati Bengals. ''He has the intelligence and knowledge to make the calls we want him to make,'' Coach Mike McCormack said of Federspiel, who was waived by New Orleans in the exhibition season.

title: Does Reagan Know Pe ople Need Shelter?
description: To the Editor:

title: EGYPTIAN REPORT ON SLAYING
description: Following are excerpts from the Egyptian Government report on the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat, as translated from the Arabic by The Associated Press:

title: USAC on the Spot
description: Bobby Unser said he was thrilled to be restored as the Indianapolis 500 winner, but he angrily criticized the decision to fine him $40,000 for having passed cars under the yellow caution flag. Unser, saying the fine was a way for the United States Auto Club to save face, said: ''I still believe I didn't break any rules.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Italian Leaves for Cuba
description: Enrico Berlinguer, the head of Italy's Communist Party, left today for Cuba at the start of a 12-day tour of the Central American region.

title: Ex-Defense Chief of Austria Found Dead South of Vienna
description: Former Defense Minister Karl Luetgendorf was found dead with a pistol next to him in his Jeep near a hunting lodge 50 miles south of Vienna today.

title: A MILLION-DOLLAR GIFT'S FORBIDDING PROVISO
description: To the Editor:

title: BASSETT FURNITURE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEWARK LAWYER NAMED FOR U.S. ATTORNEY'S POST
description: W. Hunt Dumont, a 40-year-old Newark lawyer, was nominated yesterday by President Reagan to be the United States Attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Dumont said that if he were confirmed, one of his goals would be to repair relations with other Federal law enforcement offices.

title: New Panel For Solar Heating; WASHINGTON An inventor of solar energy devices believes that his fiberglass panel, when incorporated in a greenhouse roof or wall, will for the first time heat water sufficiently for domestic use.  Kurt J.  Wasserman, president of Insolar Inc., Port Jervis, N.Y., was granted patent 4,292,956 this week for the collector apparatus.
description: The panel has pairs of corrugated plates with cavities that collect the solar energy.

title: CALLS ON MUBARAK AND PLEDGES PEACE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel met for 40 minutes today with Hosni Mubarak, the new Egyptian leader, and promised that the search for peace in the Middle East would go on.

title: Ulster Explosions Cause Damage but No Injuries
description: Three bombs exploded in Northern Ireland today, causing extensive damage, but warnings were given in each case and no one was injured.

title: SCIENTISTS SAY COMET COLLIDED WITH THE SUN 2 YEARS AGO
description: A comet collided violently with the Sun two years ago, generating tremendous energy and scattering debris millions of miles across the solar system, scientists at the Naval Research Laboratory reported today.

title: WITNESSES SAW SLAYING LAID TO CONVICT-AUTHOR, LAWYERS IN CASE SAY
description: As Jack Henry Abbott, the convict-author, pleaded not guilty yesterday, lawyers for both sides said they had witnesses to the July 18 murder he is accused of committing.

title: California Judge Rules Holocaust Did Happen
description: A Superior Court judge, acting on a suit filed against a group that contends the Holocaust was a myth, ruled today that ''Jews were gassed to death in Auschwitz in Poland in the summer of 1944.''

title: No Spoils for Victor
description: Johan Kriek showed yesterday that he does not like to be ignored, especially after defeating the world's top-ranked tennis player.

title: PRODUCERS' PRICES RISE BY ONLY 0.2%
description: The Government's Producer Price Index for finished goods, an important indicator of inflationary trends, crept up by two-tenths of 1 percent in September, the smallest rise in more than three years.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. Hashish. 2. The Nature Conservancy; in Nebraska. The land, in northern Nebraska and southern South Dakota, brings together startingly diverse ecological systems in an area that has never been plowed, where the trees have never been cut, and the air and water have never been polluted.

title: NOW GETS READY FOR RIGHTS BATTLE
description: The National Organization for Women opened its national convention here tonight. When it adjourns on Monday morning, Colette Roberts says she intends to fly home to Houston for a brief reunion with her husband and ''to get my winter clothes.''

title: Notes on People; Decentralized Park
description: In an effort to decentralize authority in the city's Department of Parks, Gordon J. Davis, the Parks Commissioner, announced yesterday that he had appointed separate commissioners for four of the city's five boroughs and would name one for Manhattan in about 30 days.

title: Top Rate Cut By F.H.A.-V.A.
description: The Government, going against a yearlong trend in which home loan rates have hit record levels, will lower the ceiling on federally insured mortgage rates Monday, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., said today.

title: KARPOV BOLSTERS CHESS MATCH LEAD
