description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland could put up no real resistance when the fourth game of his world championship chess match with Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union was resumed here today and he resigned after 53 moves.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets

title: Antiques; OLD BOOKS, RARE TITLES AT FAIR
description: NEW HAVEN OLD books, rare titles, books with handsome custom-made bindings; early maps, broadsides and other souvenirs of history will be on exhibit and for sale at the second Antiquarian Book Fair to be held next weekend at the New Haven Colony Historial Society Museum, 114 Whitney Avenue.

title: FANS OF OLD-TIME RADIO TO MEET IN BRIDGEPORT
description: THE co-chairman of Friends of Old Time Radio, Joseph Webb, 25 years old, is too young ever to have heard a radio broadcast from the ''golden age,'' yet he's made a hobby of collecting tapes of mystery and adventure shows from that period, roughly 1938 to 1948. At last count, his collection consisted of 20,000 recordings. The other cochairman, Jay Allen Hickerson, 46, of Orange, Conn., was only a child when the flow of advertising revenue to television turned radio into a musical broadcast medium.

title: THE MARKETPLACE IN FOUR MAJOR FIELDS ENGINEERING
description: S OME say the inevitable downturn in the cyclical demand for engineers may begin soon. Others say there is no sign of it. However, by all accounts, the estimated 60,000 engineering graduates who entered the job market in the last year have benefited from a clear gap between supply and demand, and next year's crop is likely to do just as well.

title: ART
description: CAPTURING THE TRAITS OF PERSONALITY BEFORE THE PRIMACY OF PHOTOGRAPHY By DAVID L. SHIREY HUNTINGTON THERE is good reason why portrait painting is not one of the most popular genres in art. It can be self-conscious in its exaggerated importance, not a little artificial in its manners and poses and stagy to the point of inexcusable boredom.

title: Joseph Michael Roberts 3d Weds Mary Schratwieser
description: Mary Louise Schratwieser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Schratwieser of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Joseph Michael Roberts 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roberts of Mountain Lakes, N.J. Msgr.

title: JIHAN SADAT LOOKS ON CALMLY AT RITES FOR HER HUSBAND
description: Jihan Sadat appeared in public today for the first time since her husband was killed. Sitting only a few feet from the site where Anwar el-Sadat was shot, Mrs. Sadat, dressed in black and wearing no hat or veil, appeared calm. Several women with her were sobbing, their white handkerchiefs contrasting with the mourning black they were wearing.

title: YONKERS MAYORAL RACE RESTS ON LAURELS
description: YONKERS TWO years ago, a brash young Democratic City Councilman, Gerald E. Loehr, succeeded in ousting the incumbent Mayor, Angelo R. Martinelli, with a campaign promise of restoring fiscal integrity to the city and of eliminating the political divisiveness that he said had often characterized Yonker's politics under Mr. Martinelli's administration.

title: OIL CONSUMPTION RISES
description: While the drive toward greater conservation continues, figures compiled by Townsend-Greenspan & Company, the economic consulting firm, show some shifts in United States oil consumption over the last few months.

title: BUSLESS STUDENTS IN OREGON LEARNING THROUGH THE MAILS
description: Two dozen students in the remote mountain hamlet of Granite are being schooled by correspondence course because there is no money for a bus.

title: PORTRAYING D.H. LAWRENCE'S WIFE AS 'THE FIRST HIPPIE'
description: ''I shall always be a priest of love and a glad one. Once you've known what love can do, there's no disappointment and no despair.'' -D.H. Lawrence By LESLIE BENNETTS

title: Article 047482 -- No Title
description: Damages of $1.7 million have been awarded to a 7-year-old girl who was severely burned as a toddler by boiling shortening from an overturned deep-fat fryer. The settlement in the case of Angela Buford of Holland, Mich., was approved yesterday in Federal District Court.

title: Betsy L. Bliss Is Engaged to a Minister
description: Betsy L. Bliss, a vice president of Oppenheimer & Company, and the Rev. James Phillip Nicholls Jr., plan to be married Nov. 22 at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, where Mr. Nicholls is an assistant minister.

title: CRAFTS AND ART: DO THEY DIFFER?
description: ''THERE is no essential difference between the artist and the craftsman. The artist is an exalted craftsman.'' With this proclamation, Walter Gropius opened the Weimar Bauhaus in 1919 and dedicated it to breaking down the ''arrogant barrier between craftsman and artist.''

title: FRANCE BY ALLOSTOP
description: T ravelers in France who are willing to trade the scheduled certainties of rail or air transportation for a more adventuresome way to go may find an organization called Allostop fits their requirements. Allostop is a service that puts prospective passengers in touch with drivers of automobiles who are planning to go the same direction.

title: Miss Simmonds, D.C. Riegler Wed
description: Levinia Simmonds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey R. Simmonds of Greenwich, Conn., and London, and David Carl Riegler, son of Mrs. David F. Deming of Hollywood, Fla., and the late H.G. Riegler, were married yesterday in Greenwich. The Rev. Edward A.M. Cobden Jr. performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: AUDIT COMPARES CITY AND PRIVATE X-RAY UNITS
description: A comparison of productivity and efficiency in the radiology departments of two New York City hospitals has found that the private voluntary hospital operates more economically and productively than the other, a municipal hospital.

title: New Jersey Journal; by Martin Gansberg
description: AFTER 20 years of debate in the legal community about the rigidity of the bar examination, the State Supreme Court has adopted changes th at it hopes will make winning admission to practice more realistic.Th e major one calls for simplifying the essay portion of the exam.

title: ISLANDERS-ROCKIES A REUNION
description: If the New York Islanders tho ught they saw a mirror image of themselves tonight in taking on the Colorado Rockies,it would be no surprise.

title: RX FOR A MISSTEP ABROAD
description: WHILE in Italy last June, I broke both elbows in the kind of accident that could happen to any traveler anywhere. I recovered fully, but it was an awkward and sometimes painful experience, and it taught me some lessons about accidents and illnesses away from home that may be useful to others.

title: AT THE U.N., SPEAKERS' LIST IS A BIG ISSUE
description: Two years ago fistfights nearly erupted outside the General Assembly hall among delegates who had staked out spots in line for more than 12 hours to insure that their country was given a place high on the list of speakers for the general debate.

title: THE OFFICE OF THE FUTURE: IS IT A NEW LAND OF OPPORTUNITY?
description: People who instinctively resist the idea of working around word processors, computer terminals and other paraphernalia of what has come to be known as the office of the future may be sharply narrowing their job opportunities.

title: Jill Susan Stern Is Wed
description: Jill Susan Stern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Stern of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Richard Tyler Kaufman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Kaufman of Middletown, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin Sirner, assisted by Cantor Lawrence Avery, pe rformed the ceremony at the Beth El Synagogue-Center.

title: U.S. INTENSIFIES DRIVE AGAINST WORLD PRESS CURBS
description: Bolstered by the Government's warning to Unesco against supporting moves to regulate journalists, American and international press groups believe they are now in a better position to deflect a campaign for what has become known as a new world information order.

title: JOURNEYS OF D.H. LAWRENCE
description: Christopher Miles's ''Priest of Love'' is a foolish film about the tumultuous marriage of Frieda and D.H. Lawren ce, the English writer who, beginning in 1913 with ''Sons and Lovers ,'' scandalized the public and the censors for decades with such novels as ''Women in Love,'' ''The Rainbow'' and, especially, ''La dy Chatterley's Lover,''which, among other things, promoted new uses for wildflowers. The movie opens today at the Cinema 2.

title: SOUTHWEST
description: The lure of the Sun Belt, particularly the Southwest, as a growing labor market remains strong, and there are many jobs available - but not for everybody. The focal point is still Texas, where employment in mining - including petroleum extraction - continues. The outlook is strongest in Oklahoma, but overall the Texas picture is brighter. Employment in mining rose 16.8 percent last year in Oklahoma City and 11 percent in Tulsa.

title: DUKE 14, VIRGINIA TECH 7
description: Dennis Tabron, a defensive back for Duke, intercepted a pass from Steve Casey, Virginia Tech's quarterback, and ran 10 yards for a touchdown with 56 seconds to play.

title: CROSS COUNTRY; CHRIS CURTIN TAKES GIRLS' EASTERN CROSS-COUNTRY
description: Chris Curtin and Pearl River were winners yesterday in the Girl's Eastern States Championships at Van Cortland Park in the Bronx, held as part of the Manhattan College Invitational, the nation's largest schoolboy cross-country meet.

title: REAGAN TO SEEK $100 MILLION FOR 3 MILE ISLAND
description: A top Reagan Administration budget official disclosed today that the White House had changed its mind and would support Federal aid for the crippled reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant. The aid, he said, will be in the form of a request to Congress for $100 million to hasten the slow-moving decontamination work.

title: Truly Bound Captures $108,800 Bowie Feature
description: Truly Bound, the only filly in a field of six 3-year-olds, won the $108,800 Governor's Cup Handicap today in the richest race of the 36-day fall meeting at Bowie Race Course.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: TRIAL SET FOR POLICE BIAS CASE IN NEW ORLEANS
description: Trial of a lawsuit charging pervasive racial discrimination in the New Orleans Police Department is scheduled to begin here Tuesday, eight years after it was filed.

title: RIVAL SUITORS FOR GRUMMAN ON THE HORIZON IN TAKEOVER BID
description: THE Grumman Corporation's case against the proposed takeover by a Dallas-based conglomerate went to United States District Court last week at the same time that Wall Street analysts were speculating that rival bidders might join the fight to buy Grumman's stock by offering more than the $45 a share that the LTV Corporation wants to pay.

title: HEAVY SECURITY AT FUNERAL BARS EGYPTIAN PUBLIC
description: Haunted by the memory of the assassination four days ago of President Anwar el-Sadat while he was surrounded by aides and bodyguard s, Egyptian officials turn ed his funeral today into an intense exercise in security control.

title: LONDON BOMB KILLS O NE, HURTS UP TO 50
description: An antipersonnel bomb, apparently planted by the Irish Republican Army, exploded in central London this morning, killing a woman bystander and injuring as many as 50 people.

title: The Carbohydrate Question
description: Our findings do not support ''the growing conviction among nutritionists that the carbohydrate ratio of the diet should be increased,'' as reported by Jane Ogle (''New Thoughts on Diet,'' Sept. 20). In fact, I believe that our observations have no immediate relevance whatsoever to the question of what people should eat.

title: THE DETECTIVE VS. THE FUGITIVE: HOW JACK ABBOTT WAS FOUND
description: Two men, both 5-foot, 10-inch, mustachioed figures in their mid-30's,-studied each other across a rear corridor of the United States Courthouse on Foley Squ are on the afternoon of Sept. 25. They had never met or spoken.

title: J. S. Getty Weds Miss Whitehead
description: Katherine Gaynor Whitehead, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Whitehead of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Schuyler Getty, son of Mrs. Gorman E. Getty Jr. of Cumberland, Md., and the late Mr. Getty. The ceremony was performed in the Dahlgren Chapel of Georgetown University in Washington by the Rev. Robert J. Rokusek, a Roman Catholic priest who is acting director of campus ministry.

title: THE VOICE OF THE CHICANO
description: ON a cool, breezy New Mexico evening early last summer a crowd of over 300 people converged on the auditorium of the University of Albuquerque for an evening of fiction readings and classical guitar music. On most campuses in the East you'd have to hunt to find even three people who recognized the name of Rudolfo Anaya, the novelist who was the main attraction that night.

title: HE LEARNED TO LIKE AUTHOR HE HATED
description: ''I HATED Camus when I was in college,'' said Anthony Rizzuto. But life is strange, and today Anthony Rizzuto of Miller Place, an associate professor of French at the State University at Stony Brook, is the author of a new book on the existentialist French author.

title: NEW COURSES ON ENVIRONMENT
description: ''I AM worried about the quality of life,'' a woman was saying. ''I think people in my community feel that home rule is not playing any part, that developers are coming in and rattling their sabers. I'm on a conservation board in northern Westchester, and through this course I hope to learn how to help local government, instead of being negative all the time - how to have a more positive input.''

title: Dining Out; TAKING SOME SOLID FIRST STEPS
description: IN the middle of busy Mamaroneck, Enzo's restaurant has for three months occupied the corner that once held Rimini Riviera. Completely remodeled, Enzo's pretty, semiformal dining room offers a seriously Italian menu of the northern persuasion, but the kitchen seems as young as the restaurant, unused to grave matters, and has still to find itself. On the whole, the food is pleasant, fresh, but undistinguished. Conspicuous care seems to be taken in order not to offend the tastes of all diners; thus the kitchen errs mostly through omission rather than commission, and the culinary efforts tend to the jejune. However, Enzo's, still in its fledgling stage, has definite possibilities - and character develops with growth. Dishes list ed on the blackboard menu deserve consideration; quite afew successes appeared here. Enzo's offered so many pasta dishes that they app eared to be a specialty, raising diners' hopes above wisdom, becau se the timid hand in the kitchen could not, for the most part, gi ve the pastas their distinctive due.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: SEXTET T.S. Eliot & Truman Capote & Others. By John Malcolm Brinnin. 278 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $15.95.

title: FOR THE LOVE OF LAMB
description: We have always found it odd that lamb has never achieved the universal appeal in this country that it enjoys in countries such as France, Italy, Spain, Greece, Turkey and those in the Middle East.

title: MOUNTAIN
description: Inflation and recession have caused Western economists to revise downward their projections of regional labor growth, but the general belief is that the Rocky Mountain area, in the words of Walter R. Siebert of the Rocky Mountain States Employers Council, ''will continue to experience steady growth, with energy development playing a key role.''

title: WORD PROCESSORS SPELL OUT A NEW ROLE FOR CLERICAL STAFF
description: T HE growing business reliance on word processors, those small computers with typewriterlike keyboards designed to complete routine reports and other rote clerical chores, has barely begun, but it already is having a profound effect on the office of the present as well as the future.

title: New York Political Notes; A COSTLY RACE IS INVESTMENT FOR BRONXITE; New York Political Notes
description: Politics has become an expensive avocation for Ismael Betancourt, the Liberal Party contender for Bronx Borough President. Mr. Betancourt, who operates a food catering concern, spent $60,000 of his own money preparing for the Democratic primary only to be ousted from the ballot by legal challenges to his petitions by the Bronx Democratic organization, which is supporting the incumbent, Stanley Simon.

title: John Rau, 73, a Leader In Contract-Bridge Play
description: John Rau, a leading figure in the early days of contract bridge, died in Walnut Creek, Calif., Friday night.

title: No Headline
description: The pictures used in the Delaware Water Gap article were an outrageous misrepresentation of the homes of the seasonal dwellers. My family has been on the New Jersey side for more than 40 years. Our little cabin and the 30-odd nearby are nothing like that awful picture. ELAINE BONIFACE, Chatham

title: BERTINO, THE PATRIARCH OF RIVERDALE
description: When Frank Bertino became head coach at the Riverdale Country Day School in 1944, the football team had not won a game in two years. He knew he couldn't do any worse.

title: DEEP-SEA DIVER IS HONORED
description: FOR centuries, adventurous young men have turned to the sea to seek their fortunes where others have feared to go. Such was the case for Andre Galerne, who, as a young Frenchman living in the turmoil of Europe after World War II, saw an opportunity for men willing to risk the dangers of undersea exploration and construction.

title: N.J. Jumps Into Water Business
description: The severe drought that struck New Jersey this year was compounded by human error in the state's water storage and distribution system. Last week, a new agency was created to try to cope with dry spells.

title: Nobel Winner Urges Schools To Teach More Civil Defense
description: A Nobel Prize-winning physicist is urging civil defense officials and supporters to prod state and local educators to set up high school courses on how to prepare for nuclear war.

title: CHINA- WHERE FILM EXTRAS ARE A DIME A MILLION
description: PEKING In the depths of the Forbidden City a few weeks ago, the actress June Lockhart deputized herself as assistant commissar for crowd control and waded into a group of 500 quizzical Chinese, who were innocently interrupting her scene. She gave them her rendition of the football cheer, ''Push 'em back! Push 'em back! Wwwaaaaay back!''

title: NORTHWEST
description: For the last several years, the Seattle and Washington economy has been healthier than the nation as a whole, so many employment agency managers expected 1981 to be a boom year for jobs. However, because of the high cost of money, just the opposite occurred. Unemployment is at 9 percent, two points higher than the national average. ''Much of this is attributable to the housing slump because our economy is highly dependent on forestry products,'' said Paul Chalmers, manager of Houser, Martin, Morris & Associates, executive recruiters.

title: STRIP MINING OF COAL IS PRESSED IN SOVIET ASIA
description: The Soviet Union, indicating concern over a stagnant coal industry at a time of tightening energy supplies, has ordered an accelerated program of strip-mine development in its Asian regions.

title: TEMPTING FARE IN A STEAKHOUSE
description: AL STEINER'S, a fixture in Cedarhurst across from the railroad station for the last 20 years, changed management this year. Since this is the first time it is being reviewed, comparisons with the past cannot be made. But as it is, it seems to be doing a commendable job.

title: THE BEST PLAYER IN THE LEAGUE
description: PHILADELPHIA ANDRE DAWSON was shagging flies in the outfield before the fourth game for the half-championship of the National League. Then he lay down on the ersatz grass of sunny left field and took stretching exercises, loosening muscles accustomed to the gentler climes of Florida, where he grew up.

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: Eating In Boston To the Editor: "What's Doing in Boston" (Travel Section, Aug. 30) describes a number of dining places and says, "You can literally eat your way through Faneuil Hall Marketplace," yet fails to mention the city's most famous and distinctive restaurant, Durgin-Park, which - next to Faneuil Hall, itself - is the very anchor of the Quincy Market and the embodiment of old Boston.

title: New York Times Magazine October 11, 1981
description: William Safire 16 On Language Goodbye, ''Mr. Justice'' Russell Baker 29 Sunday Observer Getting There First Eugene Kennedy 33 John Glenn's Presidential Countdown Kim Chernin 38 How Women's Diets Reflect Fear of Power Hilton Kramer 52 Russia's Lost Revolution In Modern Art Reviled and suppressed by the revolutionary movement it helped nourish, the work of R ussia's avant-garde, which flourished from 1908 to 1922, had been all but lost. Now, a remarkable show at the Guggenheim Museum reveals its innovative force. Ted Barry 76 The Great Onshore Oil Lottery William Borders 94 Britain's New Look at the Irish Question Nina Darnton 113 Poland's Man of Films Craig Claiborne 119 Food with Pierre Franey For the Love of Lamb Enid Nemy 120 Fashion What to Wear When the Invitation Says ''Informal'' Terry Robards 124 Wine A Home Port in California Marilyn Bethany 126 Design The Carpentry Connection 133 Puzzles Answers, Page 141 142 Letters Cover:Costume design by L.S. Popova for the play ''The Magnanimous Cuckold,'' courtesy of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: EYE INJURIES ALARM SCHOOLS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ABOUT 500 serious eye injuries have occurred in New Jersey vocational classrooms in the last three and a half years, almost all which could have been avoided, according to the state's Division of Vocational Education.

title: MORE JUDGES ARE URGED TO EASE JAIL CROWDING
description: A 53-member panel of experts in criminal justice has concluded that the best way to relieve overcrowding at the Westchester County Jail is to spend money on the judicial system.

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: Buenos Aires To the Editor: I saw your article "What's Doing in Buenos Aires" by Edward Schumacher (Travel Section, Aug. 23) just as I finished reading "Prisoner Without a Name, Cell Without a Number" by Jacobo Timerman, a former editor of a newspaper in Buenos Aires. Mr. Timerman was arrested, tortured and held without due process of Argentine law for two and one-half years. He was finally freed afterworldwide pressure. He was arrested because he had exposed the torture and murders of thousands of his count rymen. He describes theparanoid anti-Semitism of his torturers in hi s moving book.

title: Unloaded; Signals to Cuba
description: Question: Is it now a Federal offense to fly to Cuba such publications as The Times, The Washington Post, The Miami Herald and U.S. News and World Report?

title: PUBLIC BUILDING DECLINES
description: Public construction expenditures have been tumbling since the beginning of the year. Such spending normally amounts to about 20 percent of overall construction spending.

title: ENERGY PLAN ASSUMPTIONS QUESTIONED
description: NEWARK SOME of the conclusions reached in the revised Energy Master Plan of the state's Department of Energy may be less than electrifyingly clear, according to one state official.

title: 'OTHERS' (AMONG OTHERS) PLAY HAVOC WITH CENSUS
description: Probably none of the numbers emerging from the 1980 census over the next few years will get more public attention than those concerning race and ethnicity in America. And probably none will be less reliable.

title: STUDENTS' PARENTS RUSH TO GET LOANS
description: Parents of college students borrowed more than $27 million under a relatively new federally subsidized education loan program in the 1981 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, nearl y four times more than Federal officials projected as recently as mi d-August.

title: IN THE LAND OF LONDON, EUROPEAN PREPPY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JOHN VINOCUR is chief of The Times bureau in Bonn. By JOHN VINOCUR

title: BUGGING EACH OTHER
description: That liberal Democratic cultural force known as the Georgetown Set was devastated last week by The Wall Street Journal's publication of ''the Harriman tapes.''

title: Bruce Harper Ready to Go to Extremes for the Jets
description: Tomorrow could be one of those days that Bruce Harper, the littlest Jet, calls ''an extreme game.'' He has had two in his career: last Sunday, in the late afternoon heat and humidity of Miami, and last year, against the New England Patriots -the team he faces tomorrow at Shea Stadium.

title: Realty News; LUXURY CONDOMINIUM PLANNED ON 96TH ST. SIT E
description: Plans for the 31-story residential tower on the northwest corner of Broadway and 96th Street have been changed from a rental project with 20 percent low-income tenants to a luxury condominium.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Alcohol as Fuel
description: Gasohol. Its future seemed promising in 1979 as the nation's retail gasoline supplies dropped and lines at the pumps grew. Composed of nine parts gasoline and one part ethanol, an alcoholic product derived from starches like corn, gasohol was welcomed by motorists.

title: Future Events Art, Brunch and Chanel
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Antidrug Campaign Oct. 14 - B. Altman & Company throws a dinner dance at its Charleston Garden restaurant to raise funds for Phoenix House's new afterschool program to combat the spread of drug abuse among adolescents. Jane Pauley of NBC's ''Today'' show and Joan Tisch, wife of Pres ton Robert Tish, president of the Lo ews Corporation, are chairmen for the event at which Bobby Short, the singer-pianist, will entertain in his inimitable style and danci ng will be to the music of Peter Duchin, a former board member of t he beneficiary, and his orchestra. Tickets, $250.

title: Connecticut Guide; ONE-ACTERS FOR LUNCH
description: The variety of amusements usually offered to the lunchtime crowd, such as concerts, poetry readings, lectures and physical fitness programs, has broadened to include fully staged one-act plays produced by none other than the Hartford Stage Company.

title: MIDDLE ATLANTIC
description: ''Stagnant'' is the favorite word of stock-market analysts describing prospects in the Middle Atlantic states. High interest rates are joining the cost of energy as a preferred whipping boy.

title: Nixon Flies to Jidda After Sadat Funeral
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon flew to Saudi Arabia today after attending the funeral in Cairo of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, the Saudi press agency said.

title: 'March of the Falsettos' Moves to Westside Arts
description: On Tuesday evening, ''March of the Falsettos,'' the musical by William Finn, will move to the Westside Arts Theater, 407 West 43d Street.

title: PERC's Services Will Still Be Offered
description: I couldn't help notice the paragraph on our environmental organization in the Long Island Journal (Sept. 27). It appears to be an obit without a corpse.

title: Giving Everyone A Chance to Work
description: I'm sure that most people who read the recent article ''Work and Play: Not Just Opposites'' (Opinion Page) must have found it interesting and enjoyable. However, it meant even more to me as the mother of a mentally retarded son.

title: NEW ENGLAND
description: In the last two years, Massachusetts and New Hampshire have boasted unemployment rates among the lowest in the nation. New Hampshire is now in high technology, and the absence of income or sales taxes has made it a job hunter's paradise. Computer and electronics companies have been lured northward from Boston's Route 128 belt.

title: YALE BEATS HOLY CROSS, 29-28
description: A 32-yard field goal by Tony Jones with 35 seconds to play gave unbeaten and untied Yale a 29-28 victory over Holy Cross.

title: Trouble Lands Jet at Boston
description: A British Airways Concorde bound for New York made an unscheduled landing at Logan International Airport today after t he supersonic jet's pilot reported trouble with an engine. ''The y had to shut down one of the engines because of a computer fail ure,'' said an airport spokeswoman Jo Ryan. ''When they do that they use about 30 percent more fuel.''

title: OCTOBER AUTOFEST NOW TUNING UP
description: The accent will be on safety, skill and careful car maintenance next Sunday when the county's October Autofest wheels into action at Playland Park and automobile buffs with three distinctly different interests engage in competition.

title: Around the Nation; Executive and 2 Others Found Slain in Houston
description: The bodies of a nuclear energy firm executive, hi s wife and father have been found in their suburban homehere, and pol ice officers were speculating that the three had been shot by a pro fessional killer.

title: WHY WE OUGHT TO GO SLOW
description: T HE appointment of a Federal commission to re-examine the role of gold in Government has done more than redeem a Republican platform plank and one of Ronald Reagan's campaign promises. It has touched off a new debate on gold that is tinged at times with more theological fervor than market wisdom.

title: Can Food Stamps Be Cleaned Up
description: Food stamps, used by 22 million Americans to bring food costs down an average 45 cents a meal, are a source of millions in illicit revenue for others, New York City investigators contended last week. The accusations were made as the White House was announcing a plan to crack down on cheating in the program.

title: GAINS CITED FOR HEMOPHILIACS
description: ALTHOUGH it might seem that hemophiliacs would not be considered for any surgery, procedures for those who have the hereditary bloodclotting deficiency are becoming ''relatively safe,'' according to Dr. Marvin Gilbert of Scarsdale, an orthopedic surgeon at the Mount Sinai Hemophilia Treatment Center and medical co-director of the National Hemophilia Foundation. ''We still use surgery when all nonsurgical methods fail,'' he explained, ''but injections of the clotting factor can provide normal clotting for hemophiliacs before and after surgery. At the treatment center we have a team of doctors and other medical personnel who carefully study and monitor the patient's clotting. The operation is done only after an extensive individual assessment of the patient.''

title: Around the World; Drive to Oust Bazargan Said to Expand in Iran
description: A drive by Islamic hard-liners to oust former Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan from Parliament includes a petition drive for the ouster for Mr. Barzargan's parliamentary supporters, a former Bazargan aide said today.

title: ANYTHING FOR LOVE, ALMOST
description: BACHELORHOOD Tales of the Metropolis. By Phillip Lopate. 286 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $13.95.

title: REFLECTIONS ON THE CROTON AQUEDUCT
description: FOR some, the Croton Aqueduct, built between 1837 and 1842 to carry water from the Croton basin in central Westchester to New York City, was one of the engineering marvels of the 19th century. The aqueduct provided the city with its first adequate water supply, made indoor plumbing possible and contributed to the rapid growth of the city.

title: MAYER WINS
description: John McEnroe, the world's No. 1 player, was ousted by Eliot Teltscher in the semifinals of the $457,000 Mazda Superchallenge round-round tennis tournament today, 6-7, 6-1, 6-3. It was McEnroe's second defeat in two days.

title: Leisure; ODD PLANTS THAT GO BLOOM IN THE NIGHT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Tovah Martin is a professional horticulturist specializing in house plants. By TOVAH MARTIN

title: COUPONS AND OTHER BONUSES FOR THE AIRBORNE
description: Airline marketing is taking some startling twists as the major carriers struggle to recover business lost in the early days of the traffic controllers' strike. A major accent is on programs aimed at getting people to fly not just occasionally, but again and again and again.

title: WORLD HUNGER IS REAL DESPITE A LACK OF DATA
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Observen By Russel Baker Getting There First Patrick McDonnell
description: Have you ever thought how weird it must have been to be standing on the beach when Columbus discovered America? Fellow rows ashore while you're standing there gaping - he's going to be dressed very oddly, isn't he? - and says, ''Is this old Cathay, Japan, India, Vietnam or Indonesia?''

title: POLAND'S MAN OF FILMS
description: Nina Darnton is a freelance writer currently living in Warsaw. By Nina Darnton At a meeting of film makers in Kiev recently, a young Soviet director approached Krzysztof Teplitz, a film critic visiting from Warsaw, and said, ''Please, I am a great admirer of Andrzej Wajda, but I haven't seen anything by him for a long time. What is his latest film about?''

title: Union Congress Speaks Its Minds
description: Solidarity ended the second stage of its first convention last week with some fancy parliamentary footwork. Rank-and-file delegates to the Polish union congress, after reelecting Lech Walesa to a two-year term, showed their dissatisfaction with his leadership by electing many radicals to a new 107-member, policymaking National Commission.

title: Moral Development
description: To the Editor:

title: SPIRIT OF FREEDOM FILLS A DESERT PRISON CAMP
description: Inmates at the Federal Prison Camp near this small town are surrounded by coyotes, rattlesnakes and the trackless expanse of the Mojave Desert.

title: Louise Leona Demers Married to Robert C. Noble
description: Louise Leona Demers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Adelard A. Demers of Fall River, Mass., was married there yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Name to Robert Catto Noble, son of Mrs. James C. Noble of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Noble. The Rev. John Mahoney, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Stamps; ARTIST OF THE OLD WEST
description: Of all the artists who depicted the Old West, Frederic Remington, American painter, illustrator and sculptor, did more than any other to shape the image that the frontier evokes in Americans. No other artist has provided Americans with such a wide ranging documentation of the Old West. The frontier was in its last phase when Rem ington went west - in time to see the last resistance of the Indian s, the barbed wire and the homesteader closing in on the ranges, the last of the buffalo herds, the gold rushes and the railroad towns springing up overnight.He sensed what he saw and spent much of his s hort life recording the passing of a vanishing era.

title: TRUFFAUT AND THE ENIGMATIC WOMAN
description: For Francois Truffaut, a movie is almost like an anniversary. They come regularly, as if he were observing them rather than making them. Twenty films in 22 years. Some of them - ''The 400 Blows,'' ''Small Change,'' ''The Last Metro'' - are open and exploratory. Others - ''Adele H.,'' ''The Green Room'' and his latest, ''The Woman Next Door'' -seem concentrated and closed in. Does he classify them that way?

title: FLORIDA 15, MARYLAND 10
description: A Forida defensive back, Kyle Knight, tackled Maryland's quarterback in the end zone fro a safety, and James Jones, a halfback, threw an option pass to his own quarterback for a touchdown.

title: EXPOS DEFEATED ON PINCH HOMER
description: The Philadelphia Phillies survived the last-chance odds for the second straight time today when they defeated the Montreal Expos, 6-5, on a pinch-hit home run by George Vukovich in the 10th inning.

title: HAUPTMANN WIDOW NOT SURE SHE'LL LOOK AT FILES
description: year-old Anna Hauptmann asked softly. Standing in the doorway of her neat, brick two-story home, the widow of Richard Bruno Hauptmann politely but firmly brushed aside questions about the suit she has filed in an effort to prove that her husband did not kidnap and murder Charles A. Lindbergh's son almost 50 years ago.

title: Women's Unit Sues N.C.A.A.
description: The Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women said today it had filed an antitrust suit that seeks to bar the National Collegiate Athletic Association from holding intercollegiate championships in women's sports.

title: Politics; FLORIO STRATEGY: AVOID SPECIFICS
description: American Club, waited in a restaurant in Garwood the other night to hear the Democratic candidate for Governor, James J. Florio, for the first time.

title: THE HOUSE THAT FILMORE BUILT
description: If you go Check the Weather In good weather the home is open 2:30 to 4:30 P.M. Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays, but visits at other times can be arranged by calling 716-652-5362; ask for Virginia. Where It Is East Aurora is 25 minutes southeast of Buffalo via the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and State Route 400. For Dining The Roycroft Inn (Grove Street, 716-659-9030) is recommended for its roast beef specialties. Further Information Write Millard Fillmore Home, 24 Shearer Avenue, East Aurora, N.Y. 14052.A.H.M.

title: 'GYPSY MOTH' GROUP PLANS ITS STRATEGY
description: WASHINGTON FOUR moderate Republican Representatives from New Jersey and some two dozen of their House colleagues may play a more prominent role in White House plans to guarantee legislative victories than the y did in the last session of Congress.

title: Art; TRANSPLANTED ROMANTICIST AT KEAN
description: UNION LAST year, Kean College presented an art s h ow that reconstructed the extraordinary partnership of Bernard Rabi n and Nathan Krueger. Founders of the Cooperative Gallery in Newa rk in 1935, these enterprising dealers established a marketplac e and rallying point forNew Jersey artists, especially those concerne d with the American scene, and their reputation extended well bey ond New Jersey.

title: COLOMBIA TRYING TO WIPE OUT DRUG INDUSTRY
description: Three helicopters thundered over the tree-tops, a loudspeaker blaring orders for anyone on the ground to come into the open with hands up.

title: Boar That Attacked Farms Slain by a Hunter in Georgia
description: A 300-pound wild boar that had gored and slashed horses and a mule over a two-week period was found today by a pack of hunting dogs and shot to death when it stopped to fight in a creek.

title: Stage View; WHY 'NICKLEBY' IS POTENT BUT FLAWED
description: After seeing the Royal Shakespeare Company's ''The Life & Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' you're going to feel tremendous admiration for the many people who have had the talent and stamina to create such a marathon theatrical event. Having lasted for eight and a half hours, you're also going to be pretty pleased with your own stamina. Yet, in the end, your greatest admiration may be for this production's unseen host, Charles Dickens. ''Nicholas Nickleby'' honors this writer by bringing much of his third novel to the stage - and it may honor him even more when it fails. It takes an artist of genius to escape a great theatrical troupe's most Herculean attempts to pin him down.

title: Theater; ACTRESS JAN MINER: ON- AND OFFSTAGE
description: JAN MINER is one of those rare actresses who on a stage never bears the slightest resemblance to the offstage Jan Miner. In Morton DaCosta's Broadway revival of ''The Women,'' she was a scatterbrained romantic as the much married, much divorced Countess DeLage. As Mrs. Lord in the Long Wharf's ''The Philadelphia Story,'' she was very much the society matron and mother. At the same theater, as Fanny Farrelly in ''Watch on the Rhine,'' she was very proper and very naive politically. At the Darien Dinner Theater, where she played the medium, Madame Arcati, in the musical ''High Spirits,'' she was a dotty eccentric. And then there's always Madge, the television manicurist of Palmolive commercials. Madge is open, goodhearted and tough.

title: A POTTER'S CRAFT THAT'S ALSO AN ART
description: CHESTER ''MOST people still think of pottery as brown glazed mugs and hanging planters; so much more is involved,'' said Lois Cassen Nadel, a potter whose works in porcelain have been reaching a larger audience each year.

title: Planted Gossip?
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL ENTERS THE ICE AGE
description: D O spitballs freeze up in cold weather? ''If they did,'' said Jeff Torborg, a Yankee coach, ''guys would just go to grease. That never freezes.''

title: Sadat Is Slain; Egypt Moves Fast On a Successor
description: The memory of Anwar el-Sadat descending from an Egyptian plane onto Israeli soil will now be indelibly linked with that of a blood-soaked grandstand in Cairo. As his journey to Jerusalem four years ago raised hopes of an end to war in the Middle East, his assassination last week raised fears that the limited peace he achieved with Israel would not long outlast him.

title: A HUGE ARAB INVESTMENT IN THE UNITED STATES
description: Santa Fe International, a major oil-drilling company, received a bid of $2.5 billion from Kuwait's national petroleum company. The proposal apparently would constitute the largest single Arab investment in the United States. Santa Fe approved the offer.

title: INSTITUTE DISPLAYS WILDLIFE ART
description: STONE HARBOR FIELD guides for every imaginable form of flora and fauna are very much in evidence these days, reflecting the enormous growth of interest in nature.

title: The 'On' Switch For Atom Power
description: The Reagan Administration last week announced its plans to revive the nuclear industry by easing regulation, despite many warnings that the patient may be economically incurable and dangerous besides.

title: EAST HARTFORD SEEKS WIDER RULES ON OBSCENITY
description: EAST HARTFORD THE Town Council here is considering an ordinance that its proponents say is designed to rid the town of adult bookstores and bars that feature exotic dancing. The ordinance, on which there is to be a public hearing a week from tomorrow, would add a layer of local restrictions to existing state statutes and Liquor Control Authority regulations.

title: MARITIME SCHOOL TO USE SIMULATOR FOR TRAINING
description: A $4.5 million computerized simulator that imitates a ship's engine room and bridge may be used to train officers for Great Lakes vessels by 1983.

title: Antiques; ENGLISHTOWN: SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE
description: ENGLISHTOWN PEOPLE start trickling in about 1 A.M. By 3:30, there is a steady flow, and by 4:30 the cars and trucks are waiting in line to be waved into place by flashlight.

title: THE HERRINGS OF SCANDINAVIA
description: For the peoples who live around the Baltic and the North seas, preserved fish have always been a staple. Scots, Englishmen, Dutchmen, Germans, Danes, Finns, Norwegians and Swedes have devised dozens of ways of salting, smoking and pickling the catch taken off their shores. Salt cod, smoked salmon and mackerel and eel, pickled shrimp, the elegant cured salmon called gravlax -all have their honored place on the tables of northern Europe. But the hum ble herring (Clupea harengus) reigns supreme in Scandinavia. Herring bones have been discovered in Scandi n avian mounds dating from Neolithic times; in the Middle Ages it was the herring trade that brought the merchants of Lubeck into th e region, giving birth to the Hanseatic League. No visitor should mi ss the chance to explore the astounding number of changes that ta lented Scandinavian cooks can ring on this ancient regional theme .

title: URUGUAY HITS SNAGS IN PLANNING 1984 ELECTION
description: Early problems have arisen in Uruguay's effort to restore representative government, with military leaders and politicians accusing each other of obstructing discussions.

title: Harvard 27, Cornell 10
description: Scott Murrer had a key interception during Harvard's 14-point scoring spree in a span of 1:26 seconds in the third quarter.

title: Realty News; EQUITABLE BUYS BUILDING...
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has acquired for its pension fund clients the site on the southwest corner of Park Avenue and 59th Street. The site includes the former Olivetti office building at 500 Park Avenue and the Nassau Hotel on the 59th Street midblock.

title: Westchester Housing; WAYS TO CUT DOWN ON FUEL COSTS
description: THE price of home-heating oil has leveled off at about $1.25 a gallon, 10 cents below the price last January, and will probably cost the same all winter, according to several Westchester fuel oil dealers.

title: ACTRESS FINDS ROLE IN 'PLAYING SICK'
description: MARTINSVILLE MARGARET McGOVERN, a resident of this Somerset County community, and all the people she employs have been ''examined'' for a variety of disabling illnesses and severe psychological problems, sometimes, by some of the top rheumatologists and psychiatrists in the country.

title: DUTCH REGION TO MARK A 200-YEAR LINK TO U.S.
description: The anxious young man made polite conversation for awhile, then blurted out the question that was obviously on his mind: ''Do they know anything about us in the United States? Anything at all?''

title: Susan R. Norton, John H. Allen 2d, Banker, Married
description: Susan Roberta Norton, daughter of Mrs. J. Wright Barry of Glen Cove, L.I., and Robert D. Norton of Packanack Lake, N.J., was married yesterday to John Hall Allen 2d, son of Mr. Allen of Glen Cove and the late Mrs. Allen. The Rev. Bruce Rogers performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: RAFFLE OF A CO-OP IS PLANNED
description: On Halloween night, American Landmark Festivals, a nonprofit organization affiliated with the National Parks Service, will hold a fund-raising gala with an unusual door-prize: a $165,000, four-and-a half room cooperative apartment on Central Park West.

title: RUTGERS CONQUERS ARMY, 17-0
description: Two long, first-half scoring drives helped Rutgers to a 17-0 victory over Army today before a crowd of 40,567 at Michie Stadium.

title: STATE SEEKS TO SHED LIGHT ON INCEST, A LONG-DARK ISSUE
description: IN AN effort designed to shed new light on a long-buried social problem - incest - legislators, educators and social service and lawenforcement experts will meet this month and next in a series of conferences throughout the state.

title: SUFFOLK; WEST ISLIP TRIUMPHS
description: West Islip and East Islip, League II contenders, remained unbeaten with their third victories yesterday. They are 2-0 in conference play.

title: West Point Orders Princeton To Keep Ba nd Off Its Gridiron
description: Princeton University's marching band has been banned from performing at the United States Military Academy and urged to clean up its football halftime act, school officials say.

title: Politics; FLORIO CAMPAIGN FOCUSING ON ETHNIC GROUPS
description: AT A recent Democratic gathering in Teaneck, Senator Matthew Feldman mixed in some Yiddish with his remarks, and then turned to Representative James J. Florio to explain what he had said. Mr. Florio, the party's candidate for Governor, was the next speaker.

title: A Matter of Good Intentions on Bad Evidence
description: Tip-toeing through the intricacies of the Fourth Amendment, which prohibits ''unreasonable searches and seizures,'' and the ''exclusionary rule,'' the court doctrine barring use of illegally seized evidence at trial, can be perilous for law enforcement officers. Federal courts, for example, require that officers have warrants to search and seize luggage; warrants aren't needed to search and seize anything in the passenger section of a car whose occupants are being arrested.

title: Auburn 19, L.S.U. 7
description: Joe Sullivan, one of four quarterbacks used by Auburn, passed for one touchdown and scored another. Sullivan capped an 80-yard opening drive by firing a 10-yard scoring pass to Mike Edwards and came back with a 3-yard run for the other Auburn touchdown in the third quarter after L.S.U. (2-4) had cut the Auburn lead to 13-7. It was Auburn's first victory over L.S.U. since 1942.

title: HOW TO PLAY YOUR HAND FOR A SALARY
description: ''I T didn't occur to me to question the salary,'' a data-processing supervisor in New York City commented during a question-and-answer session after a speech I made recently about salary negotiation. ''I took it for granted the company would be fair. Not until I was on the job did I discover that others with similar responsibilities were earning as much as $10,000 a year more than I.''

title: Denise Anne Valente Wed
description: Denise Anne Valente, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Corrado G. Valente of College Point, Queens, was married there yesterday to Dr. Joseph A. Mariglio Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mariglio of Niagara Falls, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas L. McNamara performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Fidelis Roman Catholic Church. The bride is a nurse in the medical intensive-care unit at the Cornell-North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Dr. Mariglio is a pulmonary fellow at the University of Rochester-Strong Memorial Hospital.

title: MARATHON YACHTS STRUGGLING
description: By today, roughly one-third of the 29-boat fleet in the Whitbread Round-the-World Race were expected to have arrived in Cape Town, the mandatory first stop in the 27,000-mile global marathon. But it was a bedraggled fleet, with 21 yachts having reported structural, rigging or equipment failures.

title: Franc Falls, and Some Hopes Too
description: With the franc under pressure, President Francois Mitterrand last week swallowed hard, devalued the currency and shifted his emphasis a bit from economic expansion to a fight against inflation. He deferred $3 billion in public spending but seemed to be relying more on a sixmonth freeze in prices of basic foods and services and labor's willingness to lower wage demands to reduce 14 percent inflation.

title: Miss Spencer Has Bridal
description: Linda Spencer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edson W. Spencer of Long Lake, Minn., was married yesterday in Wayzata, Minn., to John Reid Murchison 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Murchison of Wilmington, N.C. The Rev. Edwin Eilertsen performed the ceremony in St. Martin's Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Paul Zahl of Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: MARINE SAYS 95% IN MILITARY ARE DOING WELL
description: The marines had landed on Cape Teulada in southern Sardinia, one of the few exercise areas remaining in NATO's southern region where live ammunition can be used.

title: THE PLEASING HABITS OF AMERICA'S RICH
description: To the Editor:

title: B y PATRICIA PFEIFFER
description: POMONA EVER since Nancy Reagan, the First Lady, announced that Lenox China Inc. would be creating a dinner service of 220 place settings for the White House, Robert Sullivan, the concern's vice president for advertising and promotion, has been conducting tours of the plant here almost daily.

title: VIEWS OF SPORT
description: IN April 1980, Kevin McHale went from a projected middle-round pick to No. 3 on the first round of the National Basketball Association draft, which was held a few weeks later. Now he is wearing a Boston Celtics world championship ring. Roosevelt Bouie went from a projected mid-first-round pick to No. 33 over all, and now he is playing in Europe. All in just six days.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: BREWERS DEFEAT YANKEES, 2-1, TO FORCE A FIFTH GAME
description: The Yankees, who committed a series of base-running blunders, lost to the Milwaukee Brewers, 2-1, yesterday at Yankee Stadium, forcing a fifth and deciding game of the American League East playoff and prompting another tirade from George Steinbrenner.

title: Centrists Are All Over the Lot
description: The first annual convention of Britain's new Social Democratic Party covered a lot of ground last week, literally and figuratively. The party staged the week-long gathering in three cities - Perth, Scotland, Bradford, England and London - avoiding Brighton, where the Labor Party had met earlier, and Blackpool, where the Conservatives gather this week.

title: TEXAS SEEKS NEW PLAN FOR MEXICAN OFFENDERS
description: To Texas officials, the problem of Mexican youths who cross the border and commit crimes in El Paso seemed to have an easy solution: Ship them back to a detention center in Ciudad Juarez.

title: ROCKLAND; NORTH ROCKLAND WINS, 28-7
description: Undefeated North Rockland topped Spring Valley, 28-7, yesterday in P.S.A.L. action. Spring Valley scored on a 4-yard touchdown run by Seth Joiner early in the game, but North Rockland dominated thereafter.

title: Clemson 27, Virginia 0
description: Cliff Austin ran for two touchdowns, and Donald Igwebuike kicked two field goals as Clemson rolled.

title: UKRAINIAN DIOCESE IN CELEBRATION
description: FOR Ukrainian Catholics in the United States, milestones in the long, tumultuous history of their church are marked with a degree of thankfulness and significance less often foun d in churches not so fraught over the years by uphill struggles.

title: Other Business; NOW, INSURANCE AGAINST MUGGERS
description: The idea originated in the reports showing soaring statistics in nearly every form of violent crime. ''There used to be a time where you could just leave your doors open, now we realize that that is impossible,'' said Robert Romanik, a vice president of the American Banker's ((Are we sure an apostrophe goes there?))Insurance Company of Miami. So American Banker's has launched a new type of coverage - anti-mugging insurance.

title: JOHN GLENN'S PRESIDENTIAL COUNTDOWN
description: Lightning flashes outside the french doors of the elegant Georgetown dining room. A gust of wind billows the curtains inward and the guttering candles distort the dinner-party guests' shadows on the walls and ceiling. They have been contemplating lost and gone Democratic Administrations. Looking ahead - and assuming that Ronald Reagan does not make such a success of his Presidency that a second term is guaranteed - a visiting Episcopal bishop lights a cigar and asks, ''Well, whom will you chaps run for President next time round?''

title: 5 ASIAN NATIONS JOIN IN THE SEARCH FOR ENERGY
description: The five member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations have agreed to cooperate in searching for alternative energy sources in view of the high cost of oil.

title: A HIGHER GRADE OF CAMPUS DRESS
description: STUDENTS are dressing up more than they have in years. At Connecticut's private colleges, though there are plenty of students who are oblivious to what they wear or who deliberately ''dress down,'' more and more - particularly women - are sprucing up their wardrobes with such items as pastel Indian-print dresses, Westernstyle ti ered skirts, denim jumpers and neatly tailored pants.

title: by Joan Davidson
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Journal
description: IN Cambridge, Mass., the graphic designs on the garbage trucks and street-cleaning trucks are so attractive that passers-by often break into applause, according to truck drivers. New Haven, trying for the same effect, last spring staged a competition to pick a new graphic symbol for the city. A winner was to be announced in April.

title: MOONLIGHT ON THE FARM
description: By almost any measure, these are tough times for farmers. Estimates of net farm income last year and in 1981 were recently revised downward by the Agriculture Department.

title: Sniper Faces Oklahoma Trial
description: An Oklahoma court will be the next to try Joseph Paul Franklin, an avowed racist and convicted sniper who has already been given four life sentences, the Oklahoma County prosecutor, Bob Macy, said yesterday. Mr. Franklin has been charged here with the 1979 sniper killings of a black man, Jesse Eugene Taylor, 42 y ears old, and a white woman, Marian Vira Brese tte, 31. Hewas convicted Sept. 19 of the sniper slayings of two black joggers inSalt Lake City and also is charged with the slayings of tw o black menin Indianapolis.

title: THE PROPHET WHO FAILED TO SEE SOME FATEFUL SIGNS
description: CAIRO FEW who watched him over the years ever thought Anwar el-Sadat would become a tragic figure. There were moments when strain and loneliness broke through his usual expression of bonhomie. But most of the time, the descriptions of him that came to mind were slightly dismissive - intelligent, cunning, mercurial, debonair, welltailored, vain, vindictive. There were times when it was difficult to take him entirely seriously. But last week, the tragedy of the man wa s there for all to see.

title: BRIDGEHAMPTON HAS BOOSTER GROUP
description: As a young airman stationed on Long Island in 1957, Guy Frost watched the first sportscar race held at the Bridgehampton Road Racing Circuit. Now an architect in Roslyn, L.I., he doesn't want to see the racing stop at the track.

title: MCCARTER THEATER OFFERING IS GLIB AND UNFOCUSED
description: PRINCETON NAGLE JACKSON, the McCarter Theater's artistic director, has polished venerable comic relics such as ''Hay Fever'' and ''The Play's the Thing'' with so much elan that one wonders what moved him to stage Alan Ayckbourn's ''Just Between Ourselves,'' which will be at the McCarter through next Sunday.

title: Jersey Court to Decide On Arena-Name Vote
description: The State Supreme Court agreed yesterday to decide whether Bergen County voters can consider renaming the Brendan Byrne Arena at the Meadowlands Sports Complex.

title: PROVO, Utah, Oct. 10 (UPI) - Sam King's 20-yard touchdown pass to Jim Sandusky with 19 seconds left gave Nevada-Las Vegas a 45-41 upset of Brigham Young today. The loss ended Brigham Young's 17-game winning streak, the longest among major-college teams.
description: King completed 31 passes for 473 yards and two touchdowns, including a 52-yard pass to Mike Morton. He also scored a third touchdown on a 1-yard run.

title: THE MARKETPLACE IN FOUR MAJOR FIELDS THE LAW
description: L AST year Boalt Hall, the University of California's law school at the Berkeley campus, began asking law firms to contribute $150 a day for the privilege of interviewing prospective employees. So eager were firms to hire students from Boalt that more than 500 signed up, producing well over $30,000 for the school's placement center. And this year Columbia University's School of Law, among others, is asking for contributions for on-campus interview privileges. But for most law school graduates job prospects are not nearly so hopeful. By many estimates the United States is already ''overlawyered.'' There are now some 522,000 lawyers in the United States, and by 1985 there will be more than 600,000, although the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics projects that fewer than 500,000 law jobs will be available then. The predictions are that 30 percent of next June's crop of prospective lawyers will be unable to find jobs in their profession.

title: CONNECTICUT; Greenwich Romps, 34-0
description: The elite of the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference continued to roll yesterday as each of the league's five unbeaten teams won again.

title: HIGH HOPES FOR HIGH SCHOOLERS
description: DAVID P. dropped out of school a few months before graduation. "Academic pursuits," a counselor at David's school said, "were just not for him, but he had the best attitude about work I've ever seen in a young person." David worked as a groundskeeper at his high school until he had earned enough to get an apartment in an area of New Jersey where he wanted to live. He moved and, through persistence, got a job as a plumber's apprentice.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Skilled jobs in high-technology industry appear to hold the most promise for development and growth in New Jersey, state economists and personnel experts say. To spur this growth, they say the state would be wise to join with the private sector and colleges in inducing high-technology industry to locate in the Garden State.

title: Chess; WINNING IN THE END
description: Yasser Seirawan of Seattle, now one of Viktor Korchnoi's seconds in the world championship match being played in Italy; Raymond Keene of Britain, a former second to Korchnoi; and Anthony Miles of Britain all tied for first place in the Lloyds Bank International Tournament in London. Each grandmaster scored 7-2 in the nine-round, 112-player, Swiss-system event.

title: DECISION NEARS ON LILCO COAL PALNT
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company is looking for more partners among the state's utilities to help finance the construction of a large coal-powered electrical generator at Jamesport .

title: S.I. PRISON IS CITED IN AUDIT BY STATE
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has criticized the security arrangements and financial management of the Arthur Kill Correctional Facility on Staten Island.

title: DANCE: ZAIRIANS RELATE STORIES OF THEIR HERITAGE
description: Given a large country with a number of old, distinctive cultural traditions, five official languages and 250 ethnic groups, how does one go about preserving that cultural heritage in any organized way? The National Dance Theater of Zaire made its American debut Thursday at La Mama Experimental Theater Club in an ingenious solution to that problem.

title: Paperbacks: New and Notewo rthy
description: 1974) - scion of a well-to-do New York German-Jewish family and a brilliant student of William James's and George Santayana's at Harvard - exerted, during a 60-year career as an editor and a syndicated newspaper columnist, enormous power over public opinion, Presidents, politicians and policy makers. This biography - winner of the National Book Critics Circle Award and the Bancroft Prize in history - was described by our reviewer Joseph P. Lash as ''marvelously researched and readable.'' MAN IN THE HOLOCENE, by Max Frisch. (HBJ/ Harvest, $3.95.) Herr Geiser, a sep tuagenarian retired engineer and a widower, lives alone in a Swiss mo untain valley that has a long history of avalanches, quakes and fl oods. As the forces of nature begin to gather portentously, he obsessively takes steps to identify himself with theprehistoric h olocene period in a novella that George Stade called ''aluminous para ble ... a masterpiece.''

title: FOR FANS OF VIDEO GAMES, FAST FIN GERS ARE BIG HEL P
description: Frank Cretella, a 10th-grader from New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, spent a half-hour hunched over an Asteroids video game yesterday afternoon, blasting away at U.F.O.'s, shifting into hyper space and hoping for the $5,000 grand prize.

title: EX-MANAGER OF CUNARD LINE
description: Charles J. Moran, who retired in 1966 as joint general manager of the Cunard Line in the United States, died Friday at his doctor's office in New York City. Mr. Moran, who was a resident of Middletown, N.J., was 74 years old.

title: RUTGERS DRAFTING GUIDELINES FOR USE OF ALCOHOL ON CAMPUS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK A COMPREHENSIVE policy encouraging the responsible use of alcohol has been drafted by Rutgers University, and will be reviewed this semester by students and faculty groups representing the state un iversity's various campuses.

title: BANKERS DANCE TO A SOMBER SONG
description: SAN FRANCISCO I T seemed like any other annual convention of the American Bankers Association. Some 11,000 bankers and their wives (bankers are still overwhelmingly male) took over San Francisco most of last week, all wearing blue-and-white identity cards, all monopolizing the city's taxis, cable cars and best hotels and restaurants.

title: 12 Thai Children Saved
description: Thai policemen rescued 12 childrenfrom the operator of an illegal candy factory who forced t hem to work18 hours a day in slavelike conditions, authorities said t oday. The employer was arrested. The police said the children -11 gi rls and a boy between the ages of 11 and 15 - were paid $6.50 to $11 a month.

title: STRIFE AMONG CRITICS
description: FEROCIOUS ALPHABETS By Denis Donoghue. 211 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $14.95.

title: ART MUSEUM A SYMBOL OF TURNABOUT IN JAPAN
description: With the end of World War II, the art patron disappeared in Japan. The new business concerns that leaped into existence after 1945, the giant old industrial groups that stemmed from the 19th century and the Government were all unwilling to sponsor avant-garde work.

title: A LARGER ROLE FOR WOMEN AND MINORITIES
description: By 1995 children now in nursery school or perhaps first grade will be reaching another important moment in their lives: the moment when they enter the working world, or try. Already some people, demographers and economists, have ideas about what the labor force will look like then, and what that will mean for the nation's future.

title: Doing Business As
description: To the Business Editor: I must make one comment about what you said concerning a sole proprietorship in ''How to Structure Your Own Business'' (Sept. 20). I refer to the staement that ''no legal forms or agreements need to be drawn up.''

title: IN THE SILICON VALLEY, A COMPUTER TIES THE KNOT
description: With this console I thee wed, or so it goes in California's Silicon Valley, where for $6 the Rev. Apple, the electronic pastor, will join a young couple in programmed matrimony.

title: RACIAL PROBLEMS POLARIZE A TOWN
description: The late Asa A. Allen, a radio and television evangelist, founded Miracle Valley in 1958 at the base of the Huachuca Mountains in southeastern Arizona, three miles north of the Mexican border. He gave Miracle Valley streets names such as ''Loaves and Fishes Drive'' and ''Healing Way,'' and made it the home of his Bible school, telephone prayer service and publishing concern.

title: Deborah Cooper, Lawyer, Married
description: Deborah Ellen Cooper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman E. Cooper of New York, was married last evening to Daniel Steven Sternberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Sternberg of Bellerose, Queens. Surrogate Millard L. Midonick performed the ceremony at the Cooper home.

title: Plane Drops Turkeys, D efying the Authorities
description: Someone in a small airplane, defying the Federal Aviation Administration and the Arkansas Humane Association, flew low over the Marion County courthouse today and tossed several flapping turkeys to a cheering crowd at the annual Turkey Trot Festival.

title: AT 'A MINIMUM $200 MILLION A BIRD,' B-1 BOMBER DEBATE BEGINS
description: THE Administration's plan for upgrading the United States's nuclear arsenal came under heavy attack last week. Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger testified that the $180.3 billion program would create a ''stable and secure'' deterrent, but Capitol Hill wasn't so sure. Some members of Congress set their sights on the proposal to install new MX missiles in superhardened Titan siloes. Others claimed that a resurrected B-1 would be a bomber without a future.

title: THE WORLD IN SUMMARY
description: The hunger strike that became a metap hor fo r Ulster's tragedy has ended but the dying goes on. The remaining si x strikers at Maze prison gave up their fast when it became clea r that their families would not allow them to die; three days later , Britain acceded to several of their demands, including the right to wear their own clothes.

title: Teachers' Skills Useful In Other Types of Work
description: Janel Handlin Halpern, in her article, ''A Teacher Reflects on Classrooms Past'' (Sept. 27), informs us that she and her teacher friends, sensing a ''burn-out'' situation, moved into other careers. This should be heard by those people, many of whom are learned, who claim that teachers are not ''marketable.''

title: Helen Hollerith, 52, Is Dead; Kips Bay Boys Club Trustee
description: Helen McVey Hollerith, trustee and vice president of the Kips Bay Boys Club, died Friday of cancer at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bold Words in Iran Parliament
description: In a country seemingly partial to acts of martyrdom, Mehdi Bazargan, the first Prime Minister in Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic Repub lic, may have invited one.

title: Bridge; 'ROBERT'S RULES'
description: Ever since the world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl was inaugurated in 1950, North American teams have been in contention. On every occasion but one they have finished first or second.

title: Micaela Degan Is a Bride
description: Micaela Degan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Degan of Goshen, N.Y., was married there yesterday in St. John's Roman Catholic Church to Eric Jan Wilson of Paris.

title: RIGHT TO LIFE CANDIDATE IN LIMITED CAMPAIGN
description: Dr. Jeronimo Dominguez, the mayoral candidate of the Right to Life Party, is offering proposals that he says would improve life in the city, but his chief goal, he asserts, is to sound an alarm against abortion.

title: THE SECRETARY: STILL A NOWHERE WOMAN
description: I N the theme song from the recent movie ''9 to 5,'' Dolly Parton laments the hours of ''service and devotion'' given a boss who then denies her both the opportunity for a promotion and credit for using her ideas. Whether this scenario represents the real world of the secretary has become the subject of controversy as the perils and potential of that job undergo scrutiny in light of the women's movement and changing technology. The more traditional service magazines, secretarial schools and th e older generation of women executives continue to insist that the se cretarial job is the ideal first rung on the ladder to success for an yone with hardly more than a high-school diploma. But career co unselors, feminist organizations and secretaries themselves have la tely become far more ambivalent and cautious. They suggest that an yone with board-room ambitions has to be extremely careful not to be ''type-cast' ' in the job.

title: MUSIC: LINDSAY STRING QUARTET
description: The New York debut of the Lindsay String Quartet on Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall served to introduce the New York audience - or at least one tiny fraction of that audience - to both a fine ensemble and a major new score.

title: NEW ARTS CENTER IN OLD TOWN HALL
description: GREENWICH AN arts center where local painters, writers, musicians, sculptors, dancers and actors may rent exhibition and performance space is to open here a week from tomorrow in the upper two floors of the former Town Hall. It is believed to be the only such facility in the region to be housed in a municipally owned building.

title: CITY SUED ON WATERFRONT PLAN
description: A real-estate developer who lost a bid to rehabilitate a prime piece of Manhattan waterfront property has sued the city, charging that it made a commitment to award him the development contract and should, therefore, pay him more than $100 million in damages.

title: HAIG MEETS WITH FIVE FOREIGN GUESTS IN CAIRO
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. conferred today with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and the leaders of the Sudan, Somalia, Oman and Liberia. The State Department said the parties had agreed on the need to defend the Middle East against all forms of intervention.

title: KHALDUN WAS NOWHERE NEAR THE SUPPLY SIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Moody Is the Bride Of a Lawyer
description: Caroline Leisenring Moody, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Elliott Moody of Haddonfield, N.J., was married yesterday in Philadelphia to Roy Bertram Simpson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Simpson of Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed at Ch rist Ep iscopal Church by the rector, the Rev. James A. Trimble.

title: IN DEFENSE OF NEW BRUNSWICK TOMORROW
description: PICTURE this scenario for New Brunswick, the seat of Middlesex County and the home of Rutgers, the State University: Suppose that New Brunswick Tomorrow had not been created in 1975 as a unique coalition of public, private and community representatives to spearhead the revitalization of a declining city.

title: New Jersey Housing; SELLING YOUR HOME? TRY A RAFFLE
description: WE ALL know that these are tough times for many Americans, but the good old ''can do'' spirit has not vanished from the housing scene, as some recent news stories attest.

title: ALTERNATIVE TO AWACS: BRITISH NIMROD
description: One of the arguments of the Reagan Administration for its proposal to sell Awacs radar planes to Saudi Arabia is that, if the United States does not furnish such early warning aircraft, the Saudis will purchase a fleet of similar British planes called Nimrod.

title: 24 Food Places Called Health Code Violators
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 24 food establishments for violations of the Health Code. In addition, one establishment was closed after a final inspection and another was reopened.

title: GEORGIA 37, MISSISSIPI 7
description: The tailback Herschel Walker carried the ball 41 times and gained 265 yards, his highest total this season, to lead Georgia.

title: No Headline
description: With all due respect to Sir Francis Chichester, it should be mentioned that the first person to sail around the world alone in the modern era was Capt. Joshua Slocum, Master Mariner, a Nova Scotian by birth and a Yankee by adoption, who had sailed the seven seas as mariner and trader for 20 years. His book, ''Sailing Alone Around the World,'' published in 1899, describes wonderfully how, upon being ''beached'' (an old nautical word for unemployed), he found an old foundered 36-foot cabin sloop, and for love of the sea, decided to sail her around the world.

title: A'S, WITH A SWEEP, REVELING IN THEIR TURNAROUND
description: Betsy Eisenhardt was up early this morning, taking her husband's champagne-soaked clothes to the dry cleaner. The chore was pleasant for the wife of Roy Eisenhardt, the Oakland A's first-year president, because it symbolized in some ways a remarkable turnaround.

title: NOTEBOOK: POLITICAL RIPPLES OVER DELANEY
description: THE disciplinary hearings against former Sheriff Thomas J. Delaney limped into their fourth month last week, with no end in sight. Not even the presence of County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, the accuser, on the witness stand has been enough to fill one full row in the courtroom.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Judy Geist, Violist With Elegant Sound
description: Judy Geist created a sweet, dark sound on the viola when she made her debut last Sunday at the Merkin Concert Hall. She used that sound with a great deal of elegant musical sensitivity and technical control as well.

title: Wisconsin Defeats Ohio State
description: Jess Cole threw two touchdown passes and Wendell Gladem scored the go-ahead points with a 50-yard field goal on the last play of the first half, to lead Wisconsin to a 24-21 victory over Ohio State today.

title: PEKING SEEKS BANKING BUSINESS WITH TAIPEI
description: The Communist Government's Bank of China said today that it was ready to establish business relations with Chinese Nationalist banks in Taiwan under Peking's reunification proposal. The Nationalists have rejected the overtures.

title: FLYERS' BARBER FULFILLING ROLE
description: Coach Pat Quinn named Bill Barber captain of the Flyers before the season, and Barber responded by scoring two goals that gave Philadelphia a 2-2 tie against the Detroit Red Wings Friday night.

title: Auto Accidents Killed 52,600 People in 1980
description: Fewer Americans died in traffic accidents in 1980 than the year before, but vehicular deaths still were most common type of fatal accident, the National Safety Council said.

title: BERGEN-PASSAIC; Clifton Tops Hackensack, 13-0
description: Clifton remained undefeated in three games by scoring a 13-0 victory over previously unbeaten Hackensack yesterday in Clifton. Clifton took a punt in the second quarter and drove 52 yards in five plays for a touchdown. Rich Noon's 12-yard run, and Jim Kral's extra-point kick produced a 7-0 lead. Clifton took a 13-0 lead in the third quarter when Chris Joyce scored on a 23-yard interception return. Hackensack (2-1) reached the Clifton 1-yard line in the third period but lost the ball on downs. Clifton rushed for 150 yards and held Hackensack to 19.

title: Westchester Guide; MARKETING STRATEGY
description: Tom Carvel, the man who franchises ice cream and delivers his own commercials on television or radio, will discuss his marketing strategies at noon Friday in the Scarsdale Golf Club, Hartsdale.

title: IT AIN'T FAIR
description: The airlines these days fly pretty much the same planes, so they have to go some lengths to differentiate one from another in soliciting customers. They've been doing it by cutting fares and then probing their Thesauruses for the words to make one fare sound cheaper than another. Trouble is, who's fare is which? Below, try to match each airline with its fare. (Answers on page 26)

title: CAN A MILITARY ALLIANCE HELP SPAIN FIND CIVIL BLISS?
description: Spanish entry to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is expected soon and could well prove to be as momentous for Madrid as it was for Bonn. Twenty-six years ago, the young Federal Republic of Germany joined NATO and thereby set the fundamental definitions of its politics and international personality.

title: NEW YORK CITY; UNBEATEN CANARSIE'S RON MCLAUGHLIN SLIPS AND SLIDES FOR 191
description: Thanks to Ron (The Snake) McLaughlin, who scored two touchdowns, undefeated Canarsie won its fourth game of the season yesterday by handing Midwood its first defeat, 22-0, in the Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn B division.

title: Carpenter, Jackson Rush to Giants' Aid
description: The New York Gian ts' running game,the most anem ic in pro football, could get a major lift tomorrow fromRob Carpenter and Louis Jackson, the two newest members of its cast. Carpenter and Jackson probably will play most of the way in a 4 P.M. game against the St. Louis Cardinals at Giants Stadium.

title: A's Itinerary Is Shaken Up
description: The Milwaukee Brewers' comeback against the Yankees in the last two days has forced the Oakland A's, Western Division winners, to make some unusual travel plans.

title: Thomas V. diLustro, 63, Dies; Served as A.P. Photo Editor
description: Thomas V. diLustro, photo editor of The Associated Press, died Friday of cancer at the Westchester County Medical Center. Mr. diLustro, who was a resident of Irvington-on-Hudson, was 63 years old.

title: MORRIS-SOMERSET; MADISON BOROUGH FALLS
description: Clarkstown South of New York scored two touchdowns in the final quarter to hold off Madison Borough, 30-21, yesterday in Madison Borough.

title: PINTER'S 'BETRAYAL' FAILS TO UPHOLD END
description: LINDENHURST HAROLD PINTER'S ''Betrayal'' begins after the end of a relationship. It ends just at the precise moment when that relationship is about to start. When the play is over, we should want to see it again - to reinforce retrospective revelations or to pinpoint new ones. At least, we should be somewhat curious about what we already know. When the Studio Theater production is over, we are just plain relieved.

title: Aroundt the World; Moscow and Pretoria Sai d to Discuss Captives
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that talks were under way between the Soviet Union and South Africa for an exchange of prisoners.

title: Patricia M. Cardi, Lawyer, Wed to Michael Calabrese
description: Patricia Marie Cardi, daughter Dr. and Mrs. Alphonse R. Cardi of Cranston, R.I., and Michael Calabrese, son of Mildred Calabrese of Buffalo and the late Michael Calabrese, were married in Manhattan yesterday. The Rev. Michael Trianor performed the ceremony in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Dining Out; A MERGER OF QUANTITY AND QUALITY
