description: RESTAURANTS are frequently recommended on the basis of the quantity of food served. Unfortunately, quantity and quality are not usually synonomous. Thus , it's all the more pleasant to come across a restaurant li ke Francesco's in Passaic; here, the portions are large, but th e quality of the basic ingredients is good and, for the most part, th e food is carefully prepared.

title: Speaking of Being Bugged
description: Did The Ear hear it right last week? She re ported that Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter had bugged Blair House, where Ronald and Nancy Reagan stayed before the Inauguaration, and t aped Mrs. Reagan saying she wanted the former First Family to vacate the White House early soshe could get a jump on redecorating it. Dian a McLellan, who writes The Ear gossip column for The Washington Post , insisted that the Carters ''know perfectly well it is true.'' B ut former press secretary Jody Powell called the item a ''rec kless, hurtful lie'' andsaid the Carters were planning a ''seven-figu re'' lawsuit.

title: Whither E.P.A.?
description: To the Business Editor: Professor MacAvoy's ''Deregulation: A Letter to George Bush,'' (Aug. 30), suggests dismantling the Environmental Protection Agency because it ''stands in the way of progress and efficiency.'' I find the use of the terms efficiency and progress not only shortsighted and narrow, but also out of step with the feelings of a majority of Americans.

title: EXPERTS GATHERED AT NEWARK ORGANIZE U.N. CRIME SURVEY
description: Crime experts from a dozen countries, meeting here at the Rutgers University School of Criminal Justice under the auspices of the United Nations, announced yesterday the development of a questionnaire designed to gather worldwide statistics on crime.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the name of Allah All Merciful: ''Do not consider those killed for the sake of Allah as dead but alive with the Almighty.

title: TENNESSEE 10, GEORGIA TECH 7
description: Steve Alatorre, the quarterback, threw a 42-yard touchdown pass to Anthony Hancock in the fourth quarter to give Tennessee the victory.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH PETUNIAS
description: GREEN THOUGHTS A Writer in the Garden. By Eleanor Perenyi. 289 pp. New York: Random House. $15.50. By BROOKE ASTOR

title: 2 MINSTRELS TREK AUTUMN'S LEAF TRAIL
description: LIKE westward-bound jet travelers flying at sunset, Bill Lauf Jr. and Horace Williams Jr., by traveling in a different direction at a much slower pace, are seeing an extended version of ephemeral earthly beauty. For them, the direction is south, their speed is walking and the sunset they see is through the trees.

title: Center to Resume Use Of Corpses in Car Tests
description: Reseachers at Battelle Memorial Institute will soon clothe corpses, put them in sitting and standing positions and run over them with cars.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Thalia Moore, Cellist, Offers Couperin 'Pieces'
description: When Thalia Moore played Couperin's ''Cinq Pieces en Concert'' at the opening of her cello recital Oct. 3 at Carnegie Recital Hall, she displayed many of the musical gifts that were evident throughout her debut.

title: DOINGS OF A HERO HEROINE
description: HERMA By MacDonald Harris. 431 pp. New York: Atheneum. $16.95.

title: REALITY ANEMIA
description: WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF NO CONTEXT By George W.S. Trow. 230 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $12.95.

title: Elaine K. Garofalo, Nurse, Wed to Stephen R. Greene
description: Elaine Kathryn Garofalo and Stephen Richard Greene were married yesterday at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Park Ridge, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Revs. Thomas A. Kleissler, James Bouffard and George Clyde.

title: Chorus of 'Ayes' On Voting Rights
description: Though President Reagan has been slowly backing away from his opposition to the Voting Rights Act, his views on extending the law without change remain unknown. Not so those of the House of Representatives.

title: California City Hit by Quake
description: A slight earthquake shook this northern Sacramento Valley city before dawn today. There were no reports of damage or injuries. The quake measured 3.1 on the Richter scale and was centered a few miles west of Redding, said the state Office of Emergency Services.

title: SHARING THE BURDEN
description: Willard C. Butcher, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, was quoted recently as saying: ''It's no longer a question of the Reagan policy working. The question is whether Congress has the courage to enact the Reagan program. It's Congress, not Reagan, which has the responsibility for failure.''

title: Women In Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: THE INS AND OUTS OF HOUSE-SITTING
description: For the last 16 years, John Tarangelo, a freeland writer, has been living in luxury homes in California and Long Island and spending a penny on rent or on mortgage payments.

title: Dr.  Zehnbauer And a Physician Will Be Married
description: Dr. Barbara Ann Zehnbauer, daughter of Fay Reilly Zehnbauer and Richard John Zehnbauer of Cahokia, Ill., and Dr. Timothy George Buchman, son of Barbara Adler Katzander and Dr. Myron I. Buchman of New York, plan to be married in early March.

title: Holmesiana
description: Was Sherlock Holmes an American? So Christopher Morley wondered in one of his Saturday Review columns in 1934. After a lengthy exegesis of the Holmes corpus, he concluded, ''That Holmes was reared in the States, or had some schooling here before going up to Cambridge, seems ... at least arguable.''

title: CO-OP CONFERENCE PLANNED SATURDAY
description: The Council of New York Cooperatives and the Real Estate Institute of New York University are sponsoring a day-long conference, Saturday, Oct. 17 to examine common problems facing cooperative board members, managers, and shareholders.

title: Orchids and Brickbats On the Delaware Gap
description: We are not fighting eviction from the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area. Vandals and the National Park Service's inability (or unwillingness) to provide even routine patrols have driven us out of the place we love so much.

title: HUSBANDS, KINGS AND BUMS
description: Thurber lives, in Kansas City under the name of Charles Barsotti, and has been drawing cartoons for The New Yorker for the last 12 years. '' 'What is art,' Harry? Why do you ask? You're an accountant,'' says a wife to a husband.

title: Sound; BETTER RECEIVER VALUES
description: The autumn nip in the air calls the imagination indoors.Domesticity revives. Yet in this era of high-rise urbanism, the archetypical images of hearth and fireside have been supplanted, at least in some quarters, by a newer emblem of shelter and its cozy joys: music and stereo. At any rate, seasonal receptiveness toward the pleasures and promises of audio varies inversely to the outside temperature, which may be why most new audio equipment is introduced at summer's end.

title: Environews
description: IN A year or two, New Jersey residents probably will be able to know whether living near a specific abandoned dump, or downwind from an industrial smokestack, increases their risks of contracting cancer or other diseases.

title: William & Mary 12 Dartmouth 7
description: Jeff Powell, a freshman tailback, faked a reverse handoff and sprinted 54 yards for a fourth-quarter touchdown for William & Mary.

title: Locking 'em Up Faster Than Ever
description: Serving time has become one of the fastest-growing occupations in the United States, to judge by a Federal report issued last week. The Bureau of Justice Standards said the nation's inmate population rose from 328,695 to 349,118 during the first half of this year - a growth rate that would produce a 12.8 percent annual increase for 1981, the largest increase in the last 56 years.

title: BANKS HELP PUPILS WITH MATH STUDIES
description: NEW HAVEN THE field trip, that traditional walk-through tour of some local business or government office by elementary school pupils, has been raised to new heights for Sammolene Patton's fifth-grade class at Helene Grant School here.

title: Crime
description: In 1976, Theodore Wilden wrote an espionage novel, ''To Die Elsewhere''; his new EXCHANGE OF CLOWNS (Little, Brown, $11.95), which is also a spy story, carries out the promise of the first novel. It is complicated (and pessimistic), but Mr. Wi lden, who is interested in more than mere action, manages to keep his plot lines clear. Toward the end there is a sort of set piece in which a Russianspy, trying to swing an American to his side, discusses the weaknesses of contemporary capitalism; his in dictment is damning, andthe Russian's subsequent action is ironic. Mr . Wilden takes a sour view of what he considers the West's limp res ponse to Communism.

title: Music View; THE DEARTH OF GREAT OPERA SINGERS
description: Many years ago, in the dawn of the Stereo Age, some farsighted impresario in the record business put out a series called ''Opera Without Words.'' An orchestra and a conductor whose names escape me at the moment performed voiceless versions of ''La Traviata,'' ''La Bo h@eme'' and other popular favorites, presumably for the audience that liked operatic music but could not bear to hear it sung. At the time, some of us were already so sophisticated that we could not only listen to whole operas, voices and all, but detect the difference between Hans Hotter and Russell Oberlin. We whooped in derision at the oafs who bought and presumably played these wordless operas, which stood in connoisseur esteem just one level below records bearing such titles as ''The Heart of the Concerto.''

title: BRIDGE ENDS NASHVILLE'S RAILROAD BLUES
description: For years this city has tried to persuade outsiders that it is just a country town. But even the most inveterate city slickers who pose as good ol' boys and girls would have to admit that the Music City has outgrown the days of making much ado about the opening of a small bridge in town.

title: PARADISE IN THE ALPS
description: S WITZERLAND is a paradise for tourists and conservatives. A conservative tourist can have a particularly good time there. The Federal Assembly is not activist to say the least and few outside of Switzerland know the name of the country's president. Indeed, many Swiss have to think a while before remembering his name - Kurt Furgler.

title: Anita Roberts Fiancee Of Alan Steven Korosy
description: The engagement of Anita Ellen Roberts to Alan Steven Korosy, both of Newton, Mass., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Alfred B. Roberts of Livingston, N.J., parents of the future bride.

title: HOW WOMEN'S DIETS REFLECT FEAR OF POWER
description: Kim Chernin is the author of ''The Obsession: Reflections on the Tyranny of Slenderness,'' which will be published this month by Harper & Row. This article is adapted from the book. By Kim Chernin

title: Children's Books
description: THE INDIAN IN THE CUPBOARD By Lynne Reid Banks. Illustrated by Brock Cole. 181 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $9.95. (Ages 10 and Up) By ANNE TYLER

title: COLLEGES SEEK TO REPLACE LOAN FUNDS CUT BY U.S.
description: Columbia University persuaded a foundation to cover $200,000 of reductions in Federal grants to disadvantaged students. Williams College has a new loan program for parents, and Vanderbilt University is suggesting to parents that they consider taking out a second mortgage.

title: ALABAMA IS HELD TO A 13-13 TIE
description: Steve Clark kicked a 40-yard field goal with 8 seconds left to give Southern Mississippi a 13-13 tie with Alabama today.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Major on the Spot
description: As Maj. Stanley Daugherty marched his 200-member Army company past the general's quarters at Fort Riley, Kan., a dozen soldiers added an unflattering coda to a marching cadence that ended: ''We like it here.'' The general heard the barnyard epithet.

title: THE CHANGING COURSE OF ADULT EDUCATION
description: ADULT Education, now more fashionably known as Continuing Education, has come a long way since Hyman Kaplan was a student at the American Night Preparatory School for Adults in New York City. Readers of Leonard Q. Ross's delightful 1937 classic, ''The Education of Hyman Kaplan,'' may remember Hyman's great rendering of the speech from ''Macbeth'' (which he thought came from ''Julius Scissor'') and his declaration that the plural of cat is Katz.

title: TV View; SALVAGING 'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE'
description: Back in 1975, Lorne Michaels, an independent producer, had the novel idea of taking an under-used and seldom-noticed television slot, Saturday from ll:30 to 1 A.M., and filling it with comedy material that would never get past the censors protecting the sanctity of family in prime time. In creating ''Saturday Night Live'' for NBC, Mr. Michaels was primarily interested in writers - veterans such as Herb Sargent, brash new arrivals such as the National Lampoon's Michael O'Donoghue, and all sorts of aspiring youngsters. He wanted to give them as long a creative leash as possible and, with the nervous but steady support of NBC executives, he quickly began to succeed.

title: DOUBLE FEATURE
SADAT IS INTERRED AT RITES ATTENDED BY WORLD LEADERS
description: In a stark ceremony that was attended by leaders from more than 80 nations, President Anwar el-Sadat was buried today across from the reviewing stand where he was assassinated Tuesday.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Cosmos Win, 6-2
description: Giorgio Chinaglia scored three goals and Vladislav Bogicevic two in leading the New York Cosmos to a 6-2 victory over the Valur Football Club today.

title: 'NAPOLEON'- A TRIUMPHAL RETURN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Kevin Brownlow is an English critic, film historian and producer. By KEVIN BROWNLOW

title: Home Clinic; SCREWDRIVERS FOR THE TOUGH JOBS
description: ALTHOUGH everyone probably knows how to use a screwdriver, many do-it-yourselfers soon realize they need more than one size and more than one style. Besides the conventional flat-blade models that fit ordinary slotted screw heads, they will also need one or more crossslot drivers to fit Phillips-head screws.

title: Wife Confesses, but Husband Is Convicted in Murder Case
description: A man who told the police that he killed his mother-in-law when he mistook her for a raccoon was convicted of second-degree murder yesterday.

title: FALL FLOWER SHOW
description: When it comes to continuity, the Planting Fields Arboretum has the longest-running Fall Flower Show and Plant Sale around. For 77 years now, the event has taken over the 409-acre estate of majestic gardens, fields and greenhouses in Oyster Bay. This year's theme is ''Reflections,'' and all the displays and plant society, educational institution and commercial programs will, well, reflect that. The show will run through next Sunday (through Tuesday, events will be geared to amateur horticultural competition; the last two days will be given over to the Long Island Chrysanthemum Society Show) from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., and admission is $2 or $1 for under 12. The arboretum is on Planting Fields Road. FAMILY PHOTOS

title: VALENZUELA TOPS ASTROS, 2-1, TIES SERIES
description: Fernando Valenzuela won the most important game of his life, so far, with a four-hit, 2-1 victory over the Houston Astros tonight that tied the National League's Western Division playoffs at two games each.

title: ARABS FIND THE SOUTH OF SPAIN TO THEIR LIKING
description: Evicted five centuries ago by crusading Christians, the Arabs are back in Spain, using their oil dollars to buy land that was seized from their ancestors by the sword.

title: Washington 27 California 26
description: Chuck Nelson's last-second, 21-yard field goal lifted Washington. Nelson's kick, set up by the running of the tailback Ron Jackson, highlighted a dramatic 27-point second half by the Huskies (4-1).

title: Tennis Players Need an Outlet
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MORE JOINING JUNIOR R.O.T.C.
description: IT is drill time for students enrolled in the Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps at Riverhead High School, and a soccer field is busy with cadets parading.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Prospects Oil and Sadat

title: Jockey Breaks Collarbone
description: Mario Verge, an 18-year-old apprentice jockey, will be sidelined for six weeks as a result of a broken collarbone he incurred in a three-horse spill during the first race at the Meadowlands last night. Verge, the meet's leading rider with 18 victories, was thrown heavily to the track just before the finish line after his mount, Valentia, broke his right foreleg.

title: Who Owns Sadat?
description: No less than when he was alive, the world struggles to possess Anwar Sadat. Wise Egyptians want to preserve his rough passage from hostility to peace with Israel. Wise Israelis seek to enshrine the legitimacy he finally conferred upon their state. Arabs in many places interpret his murder as divine retribution for betrayal. The Soviet Union cites his fate as the destiny of those who would oppose it. And Americans, though they admired him more than any foreign figure of the last decade, now quarrel about how to read his life and death.

title: A TROUBLED UPSTATE CITY SOLVING ITS LABOR UNREST
description: In the 1960's, when this western New York city of 37,000 was losing business as a result of labor unrest, its leaders developed an unusual committee system to try to resolve the disputes.

title: Children's Books
description: OVERHEARD IN A BUBBLE CHAMBER And Other Sciencepoems. By Lillian Morrison. Illustrated by Eyre de Lanux. 64 pp. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $7.95. (Ages 12 and Up) By ARLENE M.PILLAR

title: UNION-MIDDLESEX; UNION WINS ON DEFENSE
description: Tony DeFede, a senior running back and linebacker, blocked two punts that le d to touchdowns, including the decisive score with 2 minutes 23 se conds to play, as Union beat Elizabeth, 19-4, before a crowd of 8,35 0 yesterday in Union.

title: Dance View; PAUL TAYLOR'S ADVICE TO YOUNG DANCERS
description: At at a time when dance is reaching a broader public and many young people are impelled to become dancers, the realists are offering a cautionary note. Dancing is serious business. Among these realists - it turns out - is Paul Taylor. One had always considered him more of a visionary, but a recent open letter from the choreographer that arrived at t his desk puts him, after all, in the two-feet-on-theground camp. Mr. Taylor, whose company ends a week at the Brookly Academy of Music today, has lectu red his own dancers in the past on the need for ''Zunch,'' his name for a certain spiritual ''oomph'' in their dancing.

title: Children's Books
description: TURTLE By Betty Sue Cummings. Illustrated by Susan Dodge. 42 pp. New York: Atheneum. $8.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By ELAINE EDELMAN

title: Politics; FAULISO 'SATISFIED' WITH HIS NO.2 ROLE
description: HARTFORD FOR Joseph J. Fauliso, the worst moments in his 11-day tenure as Acting Governor of Connecticut came on the night of Sept. 30 when a state trooper informed him of a major fire in a former textile dye and print factory in Derby. There was concern that the huge clouds of s moke from the factory contained polychlorinated byphenyl, or PCB, a nd could force the evacuation of hundreds of residents in the De rby area.

title: NEW PLANS IN THE WORKS TO SAVE THE GOOD EARTH
description: Since the 1930's, the Federal Government's Soil Conservation Service has spent more than $15 billion either financing contour terracing, small dams, farm ponds and shelter belts or persuading farmers to share in the cost of protecting their own land against erosion.

title: SCHOOLS TEACH HOME-BUILDING
description: On a steaming day laced with periods of rain, Carl and Dotty Albright worked against time to finish building their house. Camped out in a tent on their 21-acre property with their four children, they were trying to get in before winter. But they were behind schedule, still at the most discouraging stage, the foundation level.

title: 'SESAME STREET' BOY HELPS THE DISABLED
description: WHEN the county observes the International Year of Disabled Persons on Wednesday, awards will be given to several organizations that have helped the handicapped, but only one individual award is scheduled.

title: WESTCHESTER; SCARSDALE BOWS, 42-12
description: White Plains, spurred by Wayne Anderson's game-breaking play, overpowered Scarsdale, 42-12, yesterday for its second victory in three games.

title: STRONGER GUN LAW SOUGHT IN CHICAGO
description: Owners and prospective owners of pistols would be required to undergo background checks and in some cases be fingerprinted to qualify for licenses to own the weapons under an ordinance proposed by the administration of Mayor Jane E. Byrne.

title: CITY SEIZURE BARRED IN PROPERTY-TAX DISPUTE
description: A Federal judge has barred New York City from taking possession of several buildings owned by a company that is delinquent in paying disputed taxes on the properties.

title: Hawks Bid for Glenn
description: Mike Glenn, one of the Knicks' two free-agent guards, signed an offer sheet yesterday with the Atlanta Hawks for a guaranteed threeyear contract worth a reported $650,000.

title: TRENTON HOTEL: TRYING AGAIN
description: TRENTON DURING its 12-year history, the state capital's last remaining hotel has seen its owners come and go like tenants. And, like many tenants, they painted and hung a few pictures before leaving the place generally the worse for wear.

title: by Judith Hoopes
description: PRINCETON GROUND was broken here last week for a project that its designers said used ancient ideas to create the building of the future: Two structures that will need about one-third the energy that most new, but conventional, buildings require.

title: Recordings; ARETHA FRANKLIN: GOSPEL AND GLAMOUR
description: It has been nine years since Aretha Franklin, the greatest soul singer of her generation, made an album as strong and as emotionally compelling as ''Love All the Hurt Away'' (Arista AL9522). When Miss Franklin left Atlantic Records two years ago, severing a historic 14-year association with the label, to sign with Arista Records, her future seemed shaky.

title: Brooklyn Philharmonia Opens Season Oct. 23
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia, conducted by Lukas Foss, will begin its season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Oct. 23, 24 and 25.

title: Numismatics; WHAT WILL BECOME OF THOSE ANTHONY DOLLARS?
description: Now that the United States Treasury has virtually written off the Susan B. Anthony dollar, one small problem remains: What's to become of the half-billion ''mini-dollar'' coins still on the government's shelves?

title: Rear Adm. James Sykes, 86; Held World War II Commands
description: Rear Adm. James Bennett Sykes, retired, who in World War II was captain of the aircraft carrier Card and was in command of the U.S.S. Bennington, died Friday at his home in Willis, Tex.

title: The Crime of Mugging the Umpire
description: IN the sociological structure of baseball, if not all spectator sports, the most significant moment of the Yankees-Brewers playoffs has not involved runs, hits errors or a George Steinbrenner oration. Instead, it concerned a 24-year-old man at Friday night's game at Yankee Stadium who jumped the third-base rail and then jumped an umpire.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SCHOOL nights. One for the fourth grader in Center Street, one for the eighth grader at the Herricks Middle School. It is easy, of course, to find Michael's desk. It's the one you can't find because of everything on top of it. He has written us a note left on top of the desk: ''Dear Parents,'' it begins, ''I know. This desk is a mess ...'' We sit in teeny chairs and face the center of the room, our eyes on Mrs. Shapiro and her colleague, Mrs. Lauria, who is perhaps the only teacher in America who refers to her husband as ''Big Al.''

title: ESSEX-HUDSON; Montclair Shuts Down Linden, 26-7
description: Darryl Giles, a senior quarterback, passed for a touchdown and ran for another to lead Montclair to a 26-7 victory over previously unbeaten Linden yesterday in Montclair.

title: Stage View; THE ONLY MYSTERY IS WHY
description: The fact that Claudette Colbert's wickedly warm smile is as ravishing as ever it was, the fact that the lady looks a good quarter of a century younger than the age she admits to and even brags about, and the further fact that she remains in total control of a transparently keen intelligence and a wittily challenging voice must all be matters of some pride to the entrancing actress. Certainly they are sources of comfort and a kind of stunned awe to the rest of us.

title: For Love of The Sea
description: Joanne Fishman's article ''The Ultimate Nautical Marathon'' (Sept. 6) gave me great pleasure.

title: TWO POETS
Follow-Up on the News; Rail Harassment
description: In an age when railroads are disappearing in the United States, Littleton, Colo., had an unusual complaint last May: Too many trains were disrupting city life.

title: EXECUTIVE OPPORTUNITIES SHOW DECLINE
description: T HE market for executive jobs experienced a sharp drop in the third quarter of this year, but prominent corporate recruiters look forward to a strong year in 1982. The Executive Demand Index, a survey of hiring advertisements in major American business publications, showed a 18 percent decline in the third quarter compared with the same period last year, with the Northeast, Middle West and Southeast especially hard hit. The survey, conducted by Arthur Young Executive Resource Consultants, had indicated only a 2 percent decrease in the first six months of this year.

title: TO DALLAS'S DISMAY, FOOTBALL RALLY IS NOW RIOTOUS CUSTOM
description: This city has once again survived what the police call its regularly scheduled October riot. But that is only modest consolation to officials trying to find a way to eliminate a traditional evening of drunken excess that almost everyone agrees has outstayed its welcome.

title: COHALAN, IN BUDGET MOVE, WEIGHS PRIVATE OPERATION OF PARK FACILITIES
description: HAUPPAUGE MUCH of Suffolk County's extensive park system may soon be operated not by the county, but by the highest bidder. In keeping with what he sees as a nationwide trend toward reduced government spending and involvement, the County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, has unveiled a proposed 1982 budget that dramatically curtails services. One area affected is the county's elaborate network of nearly 18,000 acres of parklands and wetlands, which include facilities ranging from undeveloped nature preserves to shuffleboard.

title: THE GREEKS DIDN'T HAVE A WORD FOR IT
description: ALPHA TO OMEGA The Life and Times of the Greek Alphabet.By Alexander and Nicholas Humez. 224 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $13.95 By ERICH SEGAL

title: Critics' Choices
description: FILM

title: Browns vs. Steelers In a Key Matchup
description: Two games on the National Football League's schedule today, Cleveland at Pittsburgh and Los Angeles at Atlanta, would seem to have much at stake. But do they deserve to be called critical or crucial? The Cleveland coach, Sam Rutigliano, thinks not.

title: LOCAL COLLEGES; WAGNER BEATS HOFSTRA AS PATTERSON EXCELS
description: Alonzo Patterson made touchdown runs of 41 and 78 yards, both in the first quarter, and set two records as Wagner COllege defeated Hofstra, 35-14, yesterday in Hempstead, L.I.

title: Realty Man Weds Miss McCormack
description: Judith McCormack, stepdaughter of Mrs. Buren H. McCormack of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Edward Carroll Culhane, son of Mrs. M. Carroll Culhane of Waterbury, Conn., and the late Dr. Culhane. Msgr. William B. Delaney performed the ceremony at St. Aidan's Roman Catholic Church in Brookline, Mass.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN KYOTO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- HENRY SCOTT STOKES is head of the Tokyo bureau of The Times. By HENRY SCOTT STOKES Autumn Splendor

title: WEST COAST
description: The West is faring well comparatively, according to economists. They point out that California, for instance, accounts for a quarter of the nation's job increase, though it represents only 10 to 11 percent of the nation's total wage and salary employment.

title: SERVICE IS DISRUPTED
description: Rail traffic between New York City and New Jersey and points south was disrupted yesterday morning after a Manhattan-bound commuter train crashed into a 30-foot length of rail that was suspended from a crane near the entrance to the Hudson River tunnels in New Jersey.

title: IT'S MORE THAN A SPACE BETWEEN 4 TIRES
description: AS a profes sional woman in my middle years, I was hardly prepared for the big s urprise that awaited me when I set out to purchase a carby myself.

title: FLORIDA'S REFUGEES CHALLENGING PLAN TO USE WEST INDIANS IN CANE HARVEST
description: The great green sea of sugar cane that covers 359,000 acres of Florida farmland southeast of Lake Okeechobee is almost ready for harvest, and once again West Indian workers are expected to spend six months bringing it in, as they have for 37 years.

title: But Can She Cook?
description: For exactly 40 years, Wonder Woman has been inspiring young fans with her exploits.

title: Television Week
description: Portrait of a First Lady ''Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy'' is a made-for-television movie that Stephen Gethers, who wrote and directed it, calls a ''romantic comedy.'' The three-hour film, which traces the former First Lady's life from age five through her arrival with her husband in Dallas in November, 1963, will be shown on ABC, Wednesday from 8 to 11 P.M. Jaclyn Smith, one of ''Charlie's Angels,'' plays the title role; Rod Taylor as her father, ''Blackjack'' Bouvier; James Franciscus plays John F. Kennedy.

title: SOUTHEAST
description: Employment figures in most of the Southeast, which had shone brightly in an otherwise gloomy national scene last year, are showing a decidedly darker picture this year. ''If it weren't for Florida, we would be worse off than the rest of the country,'' said Lewis R. Jones, associate economist for the Trust Company of Georgia.

title: LONDON: AN EYE FOR ART... AND HISTORIC NEIGHBORHOODS
News Summary; SUNDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1981
description: International Anwar el-Sadat was buried in the presence of leaders from more than 80 nations. The 62-year-old President received full military honors at Egypt's Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, where four days ago he had placed a wreath just before the parade at which he was killed. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: HOW INDUSTRY LEADERS VIEW THE CRITICAL ISSUES
description: O NE benefit of the economic problems of the 1980's, for job hunters at least, is that they offer several clues to where positions might be found. The energy crisis, the growing emphasis on military might and the developing shortages of skilled technicians, among other issues, can apply in the most personal way to those seeking a new career or a change.

title: THE BIG APPLE SHOWS SOME BRUISED SPOTS
description: I F one word could describe the situation in New York City's work force, that word would be mixed. For the first half of the year, employment in the city declined while it went up in the nation as a whole - the first time that has happened in two years. But though the job market has been bleak for semi-skilled bluecollar workers, it has been quite the opposite for the skilled, educated, white-collar worker.

title: AN ARMS BUILDUP TAILORED FOR ARMS CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: Alice Feder Is Married
description: Alice Feder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Feder of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married in Rye, N.Y., yesterday to Stephen R. Krawitz.

title: FRENCH HORN: DAVID JOLLEY
description: When the French Horn is played as David Jolley did it Tuesday night in the Merkin Concert Hall, one regrets keenly the paucity of recital literature for the instrument. Mr. Jolley - familiar here through his performance with the Dorian Quintet, the Orpheus Ensemble and the Chamber Music Society, among others - has brought his command of the tricky instrument to an uncommonly high level. He can execute difficult music so reliably and so smoothly that it no longer sounds difficult.

title: RECITAL: EARLY MUSIC GROUP
description: Harald Vogel, a North German keyboard specialist, is a known quantity on today's early-music performance circuit. But his assisting ensemble, called the Musicalische Compagney, was making its local debut Monday night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: GIRLS GAIN PROMINENCE IN PREP SCHOOL SPORTS
description: WALLINGFORD IN earlier years, when Choate was an all-boys' school, its football, soccer and cross-country squads would report a few days before classes to begin training for the fall athletic season.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: China: Its History and Culture By W. Scott Morton. 276 pages. Lippincott & Crowell. $16.95.

title: DePaul University President Reinstates the Student Paper
description: DePaul University's student newspaper is back in business, one day after being shut down by school officials for running an article about a campus rape.

title: CAN THE 'MUSICAL AUTHENTICITY' QUEST GO TOO FAR?
description: Authenticity is on the verge of becoming a fetish. That one word, labeling record jackets and concert performances, is almost more important than the music it describes. And an accompanying phrase - ''on original instruments'' or more likely, ''auf authentischen Instrumenten'' -has become an assertion of musical Truth. Authenticity, according to Webster's, promises something ''having a genuine authority.'' In the more elite segments of musical life today, that authority has been enthroned.

title: THE THINGS A FELLOW DON'T DO
description: THE RETURN TO CAMELOT Chivalry and the English Gentleman. By Mark Girouard. Illustrated. 312 pp. New Haven, Conn.: Yale University Press. $29.95 until Jan. 1, 1982; $35 thereafter.

title: Freeman McNeil Lost to the Jets for at Least 4 Games; Team Cautious About Injury
description: The key runner on the Jets, Freeman McNeil, their marvelous rookie, will be lost to the club for at least the next four games after being placed on the injured-reserve list today following afoot injury suffered last week at Miami.

title: Around the Nation; Trial Starts Nov. 30 For Reagan's Attacker
description: The trial of John W. Hinckley Jr., who plans an insanity defense against charges that he tried to kill President Reagan, will open Nov. 30.

title: Ellen S. Oran Wed to Lewis B. Kaden
description: The marriage of Ellen S. Oran, daughter of Acting Justice Howard E. Goldfluss of State Supreme Court and Mrs. Goldfluss of Riverdale, the Bronx, to Lewis B. Kaden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Kaden of Red Bank, N.J., took place yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony.

title: A NEW PLAY IN COMMODITIES FUTURES
description: T HE sages of commodities trading warn investors against dabbling in things they know little about. Well, a new futures game opened last week that should prove far less of a mystery than most others. The commodity is gasoline - leaded regular.

title: Watt Is Slowed On Oil Leasing
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, who has already had to abandon or defer similar plans, suffered another reversal last week, on the leasing of a billion acres of the Pacific continental shelf to oil and gas companies.

title: ALL IS WELL AT THE MAUNA KEA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ROBERT LINDSEY is chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The New York Times. By ROBERT LINDSEY

title: T. J. Reckford Fiance of Jane Edgerton
description: Jane Edgerton, public-information specialist in the division of public affairs of the American Psychiatric Association in Washington, and Thomas Joseph Reckford, a specialist in country assessment for multinational corporations, plan to be married Nov. 28.

title: SEWER DISTRICT ISSUE RAISED IN D.A. RACE
description: SUFFOLK's Republican District Attorney, Patrick Henry, is considered a strong favorite to win re-election over his Democratic challenger, Paul Gianelli, a former chief assistant district attorney, in a campaign that is considerably more low-keyed than the 1977 district attorney election. ''I fear I have a very slim chance, but I don't think he should run unopposed ,'' Mr. Gianelli said. Indeed, Dom inic J. Baranello, the county Democratic chairman, acknowledged Mr. Gianelli's problems when he said that he was tellingparty leaders and workers to get out and work for the Democratic candidate.

title: HEATING OIL SUPPLY AND PRICES 'STABLE'
description: BARRING any unforeseen events that would upset the world oil market, oil-industry officials on the Island predict that the supply and price of home heating oil should remain ''very stable'' over the next few years.

title: HERE, YOU CAN SPEND $325 FOR A TOOTHBRUSH
description: A ROSEWOOD standing humidor that holds 400 cigars fetches $2,500 and a set of two root briar pipes is about $600. A crocodile attache case with gold-plate fittings is $5,000 and a malachite and gold-plate toothbrush commands $325. Men's suits are $650 to $800, trousers, $150 to $165.

title: Stanford 26, U.C.L.A. 23
description: The running back Darrin Nelson capped a brilliant performance with a 2-yard touchdown dive with 46 seconds left as Stanford upset U.C.L.A. It was the first victory of the year for the Cardinals after four losses and dropped U.C.L.A. to 3-2.

title: Rumania Says Food Hoarders Will Face Stiff Prison Terms
description: In an effort to overcome growing food-supply problems, Rumania's Communist Government announced yesterday that hoarders would face stiff prison terms.

title: ALBUQUERQUE MAYOR'S STAR FADES IN ELECTION LOSS
description: Among the casualties of local elections held this week was the Mayor of this city, David Rusk, who finished third in a field of 10.

title: BIRGIT NILSSON, THE SOPRANO WHO DEFIES THE ODDS
description: The skies have been relatively calm so far this young autumn, but a major force of nature will be blowing through New York's opera world for the rest of the month. It is Birgit Nilsson - and although 63 years old and a survivor of 35 years in the world's most demanding dramatic soprano repertory, she can still summon an instrument of stunning power and clarity. As recently as last season, Donal Henahan declared that ''the famous shining trumpet of a voice is still far from sounding like a cornet.''

title: AN OLD TRADITION IS MODERNIZED IN SOUTH JERSEY
description: VINELAND IN FRONTIER days, it was a custom among farmers - and still is among the Amish and Mennonites of Pennsylvania and Ohio - to pitch in and build a barn when a neighbor needed one. A Vineland organization has now revived the tradition in a modern version. So far this year, the Farmworkers Corporation, the largest nonprofit group devoted to serving New Jersey's farm workers, has used the barn-raising method to add solar greenhouses to the homes of two low-income agricultural workers.

title: 'From Bauhaus to Our House'
description: There is almost no one who is not bewildered by the events of the last two decades in architecture. Sleek modern buildings go up, covering more and more of the landscape with glass and aluminum and steel and concrete, as ornate buildings of stone go down to make way for them. And while some of the new buildings excite the public imagination, as a group they are not nearly so popular as the old ones. This public disaffection may be due to the great size of the new buildings as much as to anything else. But they continue to rise, lately taking stranger and stranger shapes.

title: Critics' Choices
description: PHOTOGRAPHY ''This must be a mistake,'' many viewers feel, when they first encounter a Mark Cohen photograph. In his large, grainy black and white prints, figures are often blurred or out of focus, and the edge of the picture often cuts off heads or feet of people as if the photographer could not even aim his camera correctly.

title: Critics' Choices
description: MUSIC With the coming of October, the city warms to the business of a new music season. Two major orchestras visit New York this week.

title: A TOAST TO BEAUNE
description: Beaune is a wine town. It is inhabited by wine shippers and wine growers, and it is invaded regularly by wine buyers and wine tourists. It stands on millions of gallons of wine in its cellars and is surrounded by thousands of acres of wine grapes. It would be possible to visit Beaune and ignore the wine, but it would not be easy. It would be like visiting Las Vegas and ignoring the casinos.

title: A NEW NPR SERIES TUNES IN NEW MUSIC
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Anthony is a music critic with The Minneapolis Tribune. By MICHAEL ANTHONY

title: THE MARKETPLACE IN FOUR MAJOR FIELDS STOCKBROKERAGE
description: C AREER opportunities in the brokerage business today are more plentiful than ever. This mirrors a transformation in the securities industry, which has emerged from the harrowing bear market of the early and mid -1970's to a boom period in recent years.

title: Brainwork Is Rewarding Work
description: The brain - the body's Mission Control - monitors, controls and coordinates a host of physiological, emotional and intellectual activities in ways yet to understood. Last week, the Nobel Prize for physiology or medicine was awarded to three pioneers in the new frontier of b rain research. Dr. Roger W. Sperry, of California Institute of Technology, delineated the separate functions of the brain's left and right hemispheres. Drs.

title: HOW TO UNSTOP A JOB BOTTLENECK
description: ''I EXPECTED to get the jobs no one else wanted when I started working,'' said Paul Waggoner, a college graduate who was employed in the corporate-communications office of a large bank for eight months. ''But even though I've been given good raises, I've been assigned more and more secretarial work than writing jobs, which I was promised when they hired me.''

title: T.W.U. Gets Hit In the Farebox
description: It cost the public more than $1.5 million a day in lost city tax revenue and perhaps 70 times that in lost business production last year when transit workers illegally struck the city for 11 days. Last week, the public struck back.

title: FESTIVALS AND OTHER CELEBRATIONS
description: The romance of masked balls and swirling carnivals in Luxembourg, the drama of bullfights and the world soccer championship in Spain, the hoopla of fireworks and thumping parades in Germany, the serenity of a candlelit town square or a thatched cottage in the Irish country side:

title: EARLY FURNITURE IN COUNTY REFLECTS CARPENTRY SKILLS
description: SCARSDALE ''ACCORDING to the 1850 census, there were 96 cabinetmakers in Westchester and 26 were located in Greenburgh, Hastings, Dobbs Ferry, Irvington and Tarrytown,'' said Jacqueline Calder, curator of the Scarsdale Historical Society. As she spoke, she strolled among the 14 examples of Westchester furniture that make up the society's second of four sh ows celebrating the county's 300th anniversary.

title: Kevin King Weds Susan B. Squires
description: The marriage of Susan Barstow Squires and Kevin Nelson King took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Sparta, N.J. The Rev. Dr. David R. Aaronson performed the ceremony.

title: Hooligan, Russian Style
description: In reference to William Safire's column ''Boll Weevils Whomp Gypsy Moths'' (On Language, Aug. 16), Mr. Safire is in error when he states that the word ''hooligan'' is pronounced in the U.S.S.R. as it is in the United States. I know because, while sitting next to a woman on a bench in Moscow, I saw an irate seller of watermelons grab a young man who had apparently taken a melon without paying.

title: No Headline
description: FROM BAUHAUS TO OUR HOUSE By Tom Wolfe. Illustrated. 143 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95.

title: Miss Barrett Married
description: Elizabeth Barrett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hunter L. Barrett of Wellsville, Pa., was married there yesterday to David Foster Pendergast, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Pendergast of Westwood, Mass. Canon George A. Kemp performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Old Methodist Church.

title: IS THE 'MONA LISA' IN A NEW JERSEY BANK?
description: SOMEWHERE IN NEW JERSEY WITHOUT doubt, the most famous work of art in the world is Leonardo da Vinci's ''Mona Lisa.'' A recent book on the painting has put forward the fascinating idea that an early version of the work is currently housed in a New Jersey bank vault, a possibility that seemed well worth investigating.

title: Coming Down On The C.I.A.'s Side
description: Fresh from the drawing boards of the Central Intelligence Agency last week came the outline of the latest proposals to give intelligence agencies more rein. The sketch was too freely drawn, said the critics.

title: New Jersey Guide; by Martha G. Wilson; CAPE MAY CELEBRATES
description: The Columbus Day weekend - this weekend, that is - has been a tradition in Cape May since the early 1970's. It's when the city celebrates its Victorian heritage and archite cture.

title: WHAT TO WEAR WHEN THE INVITATION SAYS 'INFORMAL'
description: When an invitation spells out "informal" in the lower left hand corner, it is quite clear to men that it's dark-suit time, not black-tie. But what is clear to men is considerably more misty for women. Any woman who takes informal literally, and sh ows up in jeans or gray flannel pants, will spend the rest of the evening praying forthe floor to open up, or trading in mineral w ater for straight gin.

title: Orchids and Brickbats On the Delaware Gap
description: Anthony DePalma's article about seasonal dwellers along the Delaware River (Sept. 27) was well researched and well written, but the eye-catching accompanying photograph was offensive.

title: Bumping Back
description: Many have suffered ''humiliation, indignity and outrage'' at the hands of the nation's airlines, but few stand to profit as handsomely from the experience as Thomas E. Kluczynski, a retired Illinois judge, and his wife, Melanie.

title: HEAD OF SOLAR ENERGY UNIT AVOIDING ACTIVISM
description: With its budget slashed by more than half, its staff cut almost a third and its activist director dismissed, the Solar Energy Research Institute would seem just a shadow of its former self.

title: TOXIC DUMPING IN NIAGARA RIVER IS REPORTED
description: More than 500 million gallons of water contaminated with hazardous chemicals are being discharged into the Niagara River daily, according to the findings of a three-year investigation by the New York Public Interest Research Group.

title: CONNECTICUT
description: The job market in Connecticut is relatively strong, with unemployment hovering around 6 percent, more than one point below the national average. Employers report a persistent shortage of engineers, technicians, computer programmers and operators, clerical workers, and skilled workers of many kinds.

title: Photography View; TWO PRACTITIONERS IN AND OUT OF FASHION
description: George Platt Lynes and Deborah Turberville have something in common. They both made names as fashion photographers while doing other kinds of photography as well, and now they are both subjects of shows and books featuring work that is different from, but not unrelated to, their fashion work.

title: A NOVEL BURDEN
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN DISSIPATES HEAT BY DELEGATING AUTHORITY
description: President Reagan looked decidedly uncomfortable the other day when a reporter asked him why he thought the proposed B-1 bomber could penetrate Soviet air defenses. ''I think my few minutes are up, and I am going to turn that question over to Cap,'' Mr. Reagan said w ith an apologetic grin, as he beckoned Defense SecretaryCaspar W. Wei nberger to his side.

title: SEVENTH-DAY ADVENTISTS ACCUSED OF SEX BIAS
description: The Seventh-day Adventist Church, already embroiled in internal and external controversy, has a new problem: a discrimination suit filed by a magna cum laude graduate of its top school.

title: Theater; ON- AND OFFSTAGE JAN MINER
description: JAN MINER is one of those rare actresses who on a stage never bears the slightest resemblance to the offstage Jan Miner. In Morton DaCosta's Broadway revival of ''The Women,'' she was a scatterbrained romantic as the much married, much divorced Countess DeLage. As Mrs. Lord in the Long Wharf's ''The Philadelphia Story,'' she was very much the society matron and mother. At the same theater, as Fanny Farrelly in ''Watch on the Rhine,'' she was very proper and very naive politically. At the Darien Dinner Theater, where she played the medium, Madame Arcati, in the musical ''High Spirits,'' she was a dotty eccentric. And then there's always Madge, the television manicurist of Palmolive commercials. Madge is open, good-hearted and tough. But none of these ladies is the offstage Jan Miner -warm, fun, fairly soft-spoken and continuously bubbling with laughter.

title: Defense Attorney Dismissed
description: One of the two attorneys representing Wayne B. Williams, who is charged with killing two young blacks here, says he has been dismissed from the case. Tony Axam said he received a letter of dismissal Thursday from Mary Welcome, who is Mr. Williams's other attorney. In a letter to the Fulton County Sheriff, Miss Welcome indicated that she would appoint another attorney to take Mr. Axam's place.

title: RECITAL: VIOLIN AND PIANO
description: For some reason there have been relatively few pianist-composers who did not try their hand at writing a violin sonata. In many cases, once was enough; in others, it was not.

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: Canadian Guide To the Editor: "Through Canada's North by Dogsled" (Travel Section, Sept. 13) was interesting to this reader who has neither expectation nor yearning for such a trip.

title: STATE PUSHING PRISON RELIEF
description: TRENTON STATE officials took two significant steps last week in an effort designed to alleviate prison overcrowding. On Thursday, Governor Byrne's office announced the members of a blue-ribbon task force that will study the prison system and propose immediate solutions. Earlier in the week, officials of the Department of Corrections confirmed that the state had applied for part of $500,000 in grant money to pay for the task force's efforts.

title: PRODUCTIVITY: THE SEARCH FOR THE OLD MAGIC
description: W HEN complex ideas make that big leap from the textbook to the political theater, something is often lost in the translation. So it seems to be with the lagging growth in American productivity, a problem that in some circles has become a symbol of the decline of all our basic virtues.

title: ROBERT ALTMAN TURNS TO THE STAGE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Leticia Kent is a freelance writer who frequently reports on the cultural scene. By LETICIA KENT

title: STUDY FINDS STATES IN FISCAL DECLINE
description: The fiscal condition of most state governments has deteriorated since 1979 and they are unable with existing revenue sources to increase spending to make up for the lossof Federal aid this year, according to a stud y by the National Governors Association.

title: Art; PORTRAITS BY THE ARTIST AS A YOUNG WOMAN
description: KATONAH THE Katonah Gallery's presentation, ''Eudora Welty: The Creative Process,'' is an excerpt from a much larger show that was organized in 1977 at the Mississippi State Historical Museum in Jackson by its director, Patti Carr Black. It consists of 34 black-and-white photographs taken by the author for herself when she toured Mississippi in the early 1930's as a publicity agent for the state office of the Federal Work Projects Administration.

title: Julia E. Hopkins Married
description: Julia Elizabeth Hopkins, administrative editor of G.P Putnam's Sons, the publishing house, was married yesterday to James Renaud McConnon, a vice president of the Elms Commodities Corporation and Elms Management Services. The Rev. Bettye A. Doty, a Unitarian minister of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Dobbs Ferry (N.Y.) Women's Club. The bride is a daughter of Barbara Hopkins of Hastings-on-Hudson and Chester Hopkins of New York. Mr. McConnon's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. McConnon, live in Lakewood, N.Y.

title: COMPOSER'S KEYNOTE IS TENACITY; HUNTINGTON One way a musician or composer is supposed to get t o Carnegie Hall - or any other prestigious concert theater - is to pr actice. Another way, according to Marga Richter, the composer, is "to meet Zubin Mehta at a party and talk him into playing your work. "
description: A third approach is to rent the hall yourself, which is what Miss Richter has done, and why "The Music of Marga Richter" will be performed at the Merkin Concert Hall in Manhattan next Sunday.

title: APARTMENTS STRIVE TO BREAK THE MOLD
description: A new crop of luxury apartment projects coming on the market in the metropolitan area is offering design features that are bold, if not eccentric, by the standards of past residential construction.

title: No Headline
description: Paul Hoeffel notes that the oligarchs have taken out an estimated $5 billion from their country since 1978.

title: BRITIAN'S NEW LOOK AT THE IRISH QUESTION
description: William Borders is a London correspondent of The New York Times. By William Borders

title: Do Nothingism
description: To the Business Editor: In ''When Nothing Works, Do Nothing'' (Sept. 27), Mr. MacAvoy ends with a testimonial from ''a distinguished French civil servant'' who resignedly concludes that ''Reagan economics is right because all else seems to be wrong.''

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: After The Trip To the Editor: The cartoon "Welcome to the Flickertail State" on the Letters page (Travel Section, Aug. 16) brought back some delightful memories of a long-ago trip to Europe.

title: BRAZIL BLOCKS 13 ADOPTIONS BY AMERICANS
description: Brazilian authorities have abruptly and without explanation barred a group of legally adopted children from leaving the country with their American parents.

title: Margaret Anne Gray Is Bride
description: Margaret Anne Gray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Steele Gray Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Cameron Colthup, son of Mrs. James F. Colthup of Englewood, N.J., and the late Mr. Colthup. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church.

title: TEXAS, AFTER TRAILING BY 14-3, OVERCOMES OKLAHOMA 34-14
description: The battering runs of A.J. Jones softened Oklahoma's de fense, and Rick McIvor threw for two touchdowns today tospark Texas t o a 34-14 victory over Oklahoma.

title: Dance; NEW DIRECTOR RECALLS LESSONS OF MENTOR
description: ''I HAVE a feeling of being part of a great progression, and I'm very proud of the place Sarah Lawrence's dance program has had in dance education,'' said Jennifer Donohue, the new director of the dance program at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville.

title: THE REGION IN SUMMARY
description: Surveying the blighted landscape of the South Bronx on a campaign trip a year ago, Ronald Reagan declared himself ''impressed with the spirit'' of its people. Mr. Reagan's Administration is not impressed with the neighborhood's credit rating, however; last week, it was reported to have refused to guarantee a $12.4 million loan city officials considered crucial to their plans to rebuild the neighborhood.

title: QUICK RECOVERY FOR BEATEN JUDGE IS DOUBTED
description: A State Circuit Court judge was in satisfactory condition in a hospital today after a week in which he was criticized by the Governor for overturning a verdict of guilty in a murder case, arrested for drunken driving and attacked and beaten at his beach cottage.

title: Music; 3 SYMPHONY SERIES POISED FOR THE DOWNBEAT
description: IF you like orchestral music, circle next Saturday on your calendar. No fewer than three symphonies have selected Oct. 17 as opening night.

title: Miss Holbritter and Joel Moser, Law Students, Wed
description: The marriage of Margaret Forrest Holbritter and Joel H. Moser, students at the Albany Law School of Union University, took place yesterday at the Fort Orange Club in Albany. Judge Nicholas Greisler of the Town Court of Colonie, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: THE COURAGE OF ANWAR SADAT
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 4 INTERVIEWER BREEDS: HOW TO TAME THEM
description: Y OU want the job. You've learned that the company is growing. The work promises to be challenging. It's now time for the interview. Within minutes, you should be able to recognize a clear and perceptible communications style in the interviewer. By learning about the four basic style types (we all conform to one particular style) and how each manifests itself, it's possible to literally psych out the interviewer.

title: Leslie A. Wyman Married to John Byrnes Cooper
description: Leslie Andrea Wyman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Wyman of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church to John Byrnes Cooper, son of Edward J. Cooper of Cos Cob, Conn., and the late Rosemary Cooper.

title: ELECTION OFFICIAL WARY OF RULES IN TUESDAY'S CAPITAL PRIMARY
description: HARTFORD LIKE players in a stickball game who cannot agree on whether the ball landed in foul or fair territory, the parties in the Democratic mayoral p rimary held here on Sept. 8 have dec ided to do it over. But some election officials are concerned that in the new election Tuesday the counting of the ballots might sti ll be less than perfect.

title: June Dalton Is a Bride
description: The marriage of June Dalton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Dalton of White Plains, to Peter Campbell Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Port Chester, N.Y., took place yesterday in White Plains. The Rev. Eugene J. O'Brien performed the ceremony in the chapel of Good Counsel Academy. Mr. Dalton is head of Michael Dalton Associates, consulting engineers, in White Plains. Mr. Brown, a lawyer, is an assistant vice president of Sellon Associates Inc., a reinsurance brokerage concern in White Plains. His father is a New York lawyer.

title: YOUTHFUL YUKS
description: Delia Ephron, who remembered youthful yuks in ''How to Eat Like a Child,'' recalls adolescent agonies in TEENAGE ROMANCE, or How to Die of Embarrassment (Viking, $9.95). Edward Koren's drawings capture the more unforgettable moments: If both of you like cheeseburgers medium rare with everything, how come you're sitting there in absolute silence? Burgeoning adolescents are let in on all the important secrets, from how to have a crush to how to die of embarrassment.

title: No Headline
description: Although Mrs. Fishman does not exaggerate the treachery of the Roaring Forties to sailors, it is not entirely true that ''no land interrupts the passage of the wind around the circumference of the earth.'' Tasmania is the first of three lands south of the 40th parallel, in a direct path of the Roaring Forties, as they blow from west to east. In fact, Tasmania owes its discovery to the Roaring Forties, which swept Abel Tasman, the Dutch navigator, to its shores in 1642. MARGARET PERKINS, Hobart, Tasmania

title: Storm Kills a Briton
description: Gale-force winds and heavy rain overnight and early today killed one man, injured 10 other people and caused widespread damage, officials said.

title: Purdue 44, Illinois 20
description: Scott Campbell passed for 290 yards and three touchdowns and ran 20 yards for another score to lead Purdue.

title: Man Killed in Bombay Clash
description: A man was killed and 48 other people were wounded in clashes during a three-day disruption in water supplies, a police spokesman said today. The spokesman said the man was killed and six others were wounded yesterday when policemen fired on protesters demanding a resumption of water supplies.

title: ULTIMATE VERDICT ON THE SOVIET HEALTH SYSTEM: SHORTER LIVES
description: One distinguishing feature of an advanced society has traditionally been a high and rising level of public health. By this criterion, the Soviet Union was rapidly progressing for the first 50 years of its existence. However, recent studies by Western scholars indicate that the quality of Soviet health care has deteriorated dramatically in the past 15 years. Indeed, many believe its lapses may now have reached epidemic proportions.

title: DANCE: LISBETH DAVIDOW AND DEBORAH GLADSTEIN
description: Although there was very little music to be heard Thursday night at the Merce Cunningham Stu dio, ''Chord'' proved a good name for the concert of solos and duets that Lisbeth David ow and Deborah Gladsteinpresented there. As performers and choreograp hers, they were so beautifully attuned to each other that their duets were studies in sweet harmony and their solos could have been danced songs from the same book of lieder.

title: A CENTER TO HELP PREVENT CHILD ABUSE
description: GREAT NECK AT the Open Door parent-child care center, the key word is ''prevention.'' The center opened in Augu st a s a service to mothers under stress who need a few hours of respite from the demands of child care in order to diffuse emotions that may lead to abuse or neglect of their children.

title: N.H.L. Needs Suspensions
description: To the Sports Editor: Barry Beck calls for changes in National Hockey League rules, at the same time insisting that fighting is ''part of my job'' (''A Ranger Looks at Hockey Fights.'' The New York Times, Oct. 4).

title: Camera; CAPTURING THOSE FALL LANDSCAPES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- George Schaub and Fred W. Rosen are freelance writers and photographers.

title: RADICAL ARABS ASSAIL MOSLEM LEADERS IN CAIRO
description: Most Arab nations boycotted the funeral of President Anwar el-Sadat today and the more radical regimes condemned Islamic leaders who went to Cairo to pay their respects as traitors.

title: First at Last
description: The problem with sports, it sometimes seems, is that it takes a lawyer to figure out who has won.

title: AMBITIOUS SENEGAL RIVER PROJECT TO START SOON
description: O ne of Africa's most ambitious development projects, the harnessin g of the Senegal River, is finally due to begin this month after deca des of study and years of wrangling over money.

title: Anne F. Germain Wed To David A. Teeter 2d
description: At Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J., yesterday, Anne Fullerton Germain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerry G. Germain of Rumson, was married to David Alexander Teeter 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John O. Teeter of Middletown, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Rooney performed the ceremony.

title: HISTORICAL ROUNDUP AT THE SQUARE HOUSE
description: RYE ''GEORGE WASHINGTON slept here - twice,'' Elizabeth Witt boasted. But it remains pure conjecture whether the then newly elected first President spent his nights in the master bedroom or in a lessconspicuous back room in the Square House, now the museum of the Rye Historical Society.

title: 2 ARE CLEARED OF ROLES IN PLOT TO TAKE OVER CARIBBEAN ISLE
description: A Federal jury acquitted two men last night of charges that they helped to finance a group that was planning to invade and take over the Caribbean island nation of Dominica.

title: SYMPHONIC LIFE IN THE SUBURBS
description: Christopher Keene - music director of the Syracuse Symphony, a regular for several years at the Spoleto Fetival of Two Worlds in Italy and a guest conductor of the New York City Opera who will lead two new productions there this season - will drive out from Manhattan to the suburbs tonight for the conducting assignment he says he enjoys the most of all: leading the Long Island Philharmonic. ''We're reaching thousands of listeners for the first time,'' he says. ''It's a real thrill.''

title: TEACHING ADULTS TO TEACH OTHERS
description: AS adult-education courses proliferate on the Island, potential instructors are being sought after to share their expertise in a classroom situation. But teaching adults auto maintenance can be a lot different from running a gas station.

title: Spying on Ourselves
description: The Reagan Administration wants the Congressional intelligence committees to bless, or at least tolerate, the Central Intelligence Agency's re-entry into the business of spying on Americans. The idea is just as intolerable now as it was last spring.

title: MAINE'S BUSINESSMEN-LOBSTERMEN
description: including inventory management - are becoming as characteristic of the trade as the cozy fishing villages that h ave clutched the Maine coast for hundreds of year s.

title: BRADLEY AIR MUSEUM REOPENS
description: WINDSOR LOCKS TWO years ago at the Bradley Air Museum, one of the largest collections of vintage aircraft in the country was turned into a mass of twisted wreckage in less than five minutes. ''There was a lot of weeping,'' recalled Robert F. Pope, a member of the museum's volunteer service crew, who viewed the havoc caused by a tornado that hit the area on Oct. 3, 1979.

title: A DECADE OF TURMOIL IN THE ARAB WORLD
description: IRAN Once seemingly the most stable American all y in the region, Iran has been in a state of revolu- tionary chaos since the overthrow of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi in January 1979. The taking - and freeing - of American hostages exacerbated a fight between dominant hard- line Islamic fundamentalists and secular revo- lutionaries which continues, with assassinations and executions almost daily. IRAQ Iraq skirmished with Kurds and with Iran until it cut a deal with the Shah in 1975. After his over- throw, President Saddam Hussein sought to take advantage of Iran's seeming weakness and to punish Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini for stirring up Shiite Moslem opposition to his Sunni regime. Iraq invaded a year ago, but Ira- nian resistance has been surprisingly strong.

title: D'ANNA FORTUNATO IN A MEZZO PROGRAM
description: When D'Anna Fortunato sang Debussy's ''Chansons de Bilitis'' on Monday night in her debut recital at the Merkin Concert Hall, her voice recreated the sensations of the dreamy texts. The tone color in ''Le Tombeau des Naides'' suggested a bleak chill; ''La Flute de Pan'' was fluid, half-sp oken, and ''La Chevel ure'' was an unsettled evocation of sensual tension.

title: WESTCHESTER
description: Westchester County continues to grow at a steady rate, according to local planners and government experts, with the unemployment rate still the lowest in the state, at 4.4 percent last month, and the prospects quite good for qualified job seekers, especially in whitecollar fields.

title: NEW DELAY ON A LEASE FOR CASINO ON GLEN ISLAND
description: THE county's effort to find someone who will restore the glitter to the Glen Island Casino in New Rochelle is nearing an end, but very slowly. Last week, the Board of Legislators asked the administration to make a final effort to renegotiate a proposed long-term lease it had completed last April.

title: Walter Hamilton, 59; Held a Commerce Post
description: Walter Hamilton, a vice president of the Conference Board, a business research organization, died at his New York home Thursday night. He was 59 years old.

title: Gardening; SWEET AND SOUR GUMS FOR AUTUMN COLOR
description: WHEN someone refers to the sweet and sour gums, he is not referring to a Chinese dish. Instead, these are two of the finest trees native to this region. While both are near their northern limits here, they may be seen growing in the natural environment through central New Jersey, with the sour gum extending even farther north into Long Island.

title: L. L. Knox Weds Mary E. Lambert
description: Mary Ellen Lambert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Lambert of Port Chester, N.Y., and Ponte Vedra, Fla., was married yesterday to Lance L. Knox, son of Robert C. Knox Jr. and the late Leonice Merrels Knox. The Rev. Joan B. Malick performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Jeanne Vail Chapel of Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill.

title: HARTFORD RUNOFF MAY DECIDE IF THE MAYOR RULES OR GOVERNS
description: Summer reruns may have ended everywhere else, but on Tuesday Hartford is to play last month's Democratic mayoral primary again. The four candidates disagree not only on both of the city's biggest issues - rotting neighborhoods and tax breaks for a booming downtown - but even on whether the winner will be able to run the city anyway.

title: MONMOUTH-OCEAN; BRICK STAYS UNDEFEATED
description: Brick twonship scored tow touchdowns in the second quarter and stopped a long Southern Regional drive midway through the fourth to achieve a 14-6 victory in Manahawkin. Southern Regional took its first loss after two victories; Brick remained unbeaten in three games.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: COLLECTED STORIES, by Frank O'Connor. (Alfred A. Knopf, $20.) Sixtyseven by the Irish master.

title: Poor Alligator Season Tied to Bad Weather
description: Wildlife officials say that they are optimistic about the future of alligator hunts in Louisiana and that this year's poor showing was a result of the weather and gators that did not mate.

title: Follow-Up on the News; The Big Sink
description: The sinkhole opened last May 9, and when it stopped expanding several days later, it had swallowed a three-bedroom bungalow, half a municipal swimming pool and six cars in Winter Park, Fla. It was, authorities said, the biggest known sinkhole, measuring 350 feet wide and more than 100 feet deep.

title: B-1 VOTE COULD SPUR L.I. JOBS
description: CONGRESSIONAL approval of President Reagan's proposal to build 100 B-1 bombers - a ''most likely'' event, according to Representative Thomas J. Downey, a leading critic of the program -could generate up to $1 billion in revenue and create hundreds of jobs in Long Island's military electronics industry.

title: INSTITUTE SEES CHANGES FOR HOMES IN AMERICA
description: The American home is going the way of the automobile. It will be smaller, built with less costly materials and more energy efficient than its predecessor of a decade ago, according to a report issued recently by the Worldwatch Institute.

title: INVESTING IN PEOPLE
description: T HE Reagan Administration's drastic reduction in funds for education, job training, day care, student loans and a host of seemingly expendable social services are the worst sorts of false economies.

title: Dining Out; WESTPORT SICHUAN: SPICY, FRIENLY
description: size cheerful dining room in front, with additional separate dining alcoves in the rear and a smaller room at the very back. Decor is an unlikely but unobtrusive mix of Chinese parasols overhead and modern wood-and-stainless steel chairs.

title: FIRST BLACK TO HEAD V.F.W. SEEKS NEW MEMBERS
description: FOR Melvin Garrett of New Rochelle, the first black to be elected Commander of the 109,500-member New York State contingent of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, the task facing him is two-fold: to increase the membership rolls of the V.F.W. and to improve its image.

title: BUSING STUDY FINDS GAIN, BUT NOT IN ATTITUDE
description: A new study indicates that education improved after two years of court-ordered busing in a Delaware school district but racial attitudes did not. Results of the $600,000 study, conducted by Michigan State University's Urban Affairs Program under a grant from the RockefellerFoundation, a re to be presented at the foundation's National Conference on Education in New York next week.

title: REAGAN PLAN AIMS TO SAVE $1 BILLION THROUGH NOV. 20
description: A high-ranking White House official, providing new details of the Reagan Administration's unusual plan to defer some Federal spending, said today that the administrative deferrals might save an estimated $1 billion through Nov. 20.

title: AN AMERICAN DREAM, SOUTHERN-STYLE
description: THE HAMMONDS OF REDCLIFFE Edited by Carol Bleser. Illustrated. 421 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: Brooks Berates Rangers
description: After having watched his team lose, 8-3, to the Winnipeg Jets, one of the weaker clubs in the National Hockey League, the Rangers' rookie coach, Herb Brooks, sat outside the dressing room in Winnipeg last night, hung his head and muttered.

title: EX-AGENT TIED TO PLAN TO GIVE DATA TO SOVIET
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent charged with illegally shipping explosives to Libya, attempted to divert American technology used in electronic intelligence gathering and reconnaissance to the Soviet Union, according to two former associates familiar with the scheme.

title: National Recruitment - Survey; The Changing Market
description: Many Questions in Year Ahead By William Serrin Cover Industry C hiefs Explore Issues By Elizabeth M. Fowler5 In Sea rch of Productivity Magic By Michael Oreskes6 New York Has Job Tr ouble Spots By Joyce Purnick 7 Some Occupational Outlooks Engineering Forges New Horizons By Barnaby J. Feder 17 New Style: Overlawyered Look By Kenneth B. Noble17 Transportation Has Its Ups and Downs By Ari Goldman17 Stockbrokerage Trends Upward By Vartanig G. Vartan 17 Executive Suite Overcrowded By Christopher Fitzgerald 22 Fields of the Future A Look at Office of the Future By Thomas C. Hayes29 Word Processors Spread the Word By Sharon Johnson30 Secretary Still a Nowhere Woman By Andree Brooks 31 Electronic Specialists in Clover By Andrew Pollack32 Computer Experts Can Call Shots By Alix M. Freedman 32 Metropolitan Area Roundup of Job Opportunities36 Aspects of Uncertainty What 90's Work Force Will Look Like By Linda Charlton 43 College Grads Face Hard Knocks By Christopher Wellisz 44 How to Unstop Promotion Bottlenecks By Peggy Schmidt44 Things L ook Up for High Schoolers By Anne R. Noble45 New Market for the Old Work Skills By Damon Stetson 46 Workers Learning How to Retire By Rhoda M. Gilinsky48 The Job Search The 4 Breeds of Interviewer By William J. Morin59 Making Liberal Arts a Plus By William N. Yeomans59 Playing Your Cards in Salary Talks By Sherry Chastain 60 Those Little White Lies in the Resume By Sheila Rule61 Regional Roundup of Job Opportunities70

title: Eleanor Prescott Bride of Lawyer
description: The marriage of Eleanor Prescott, a producer with the ABC News program ''20/20,'' to Nicholas G. Garaufis, a former assistant New York State Attorney General, took place at the Park Lane Hotel yesterday . Surrogate Millard L. Midonick perf ormed the ceremony.

title: Arafat Visits North Korea
description: Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived today in Pyo ngyang, the North Koreancapital, on the second leg of his Asian tour. He is to begin a three-day visit to Japan on Monday.

title: BRONX NATIVE LEADING FIGHT ON ATOM WASTE
description: Al Giordano, a Bronx native, has abandoned a silk-screen printing career in the hill towns of western Massachusetts to lead a fight against legislative plans to dump nuclear waste west of Worcester.

title: Missouri 58, Kansas St. 13
description: Bobby Meyer ran 1, 4 and 11 yards for touchdowns, and Mike Hyde flipped passes for 202 yards and another score, pacing Missouri. Mistakes marred the performance for Kansas State.

title: ROCK: MARTY BALIN SINGS
description: As the lead male singer of the Jefferson Airplane-Jefferson Starship in the 60's and 70's, Marty Balin provided crucial humanizing elements of sex and soulfulness to an aggregation more concerned with science fiction and Orientalia than with pop music basics. It was Mr. Balin's return to the fold in the mid 70's that was largely responsible for the Jefferson Starship's commercial comeback.

title: El Salvador's Exiled Oligarchs
description: Paul Hoeffel's thoughtful analysis of El Salvador's oligarchy is really about the main tragedy of the country: the rich don't give a damn about the poor (''The Eclipse of the Oligarchs,'' Sept. 6).

title: U.S. Youth Soccer Struggling
description: American soccer experienced another nasty kick last week when the United States National Youth team was eliminated in the first round of the Youth World Cup tournament in Australia.

title: KORCHNOI GRANTED A RESPITE IN CHESS
description: The fifth game of the world title chess match, scheduled for today, was postponed until Monday at the request of Viktor Korchnoi, the challenger.

title: October 11, 1981
description: NONFICTION ALPHA TO OMEGA: The Life and Times of the Greek Alphabet. By Alexander and Nicholas Humez. ............................... 13 BACHELORHOOD: Tales of the Metropolis.By Phillip Lopate. ...... 7 FEROCIOUS ALPHABETS. By Denis Donoghue. ......................... 11 FRIEDA LAWRENCE AND HER CIRCLE: Letters From, To and About Frieda Lawrence. Edited by Harry T. Moore and Dale B. Montague. 18 FROM BAUHAUS TO OUR HOUSE. By Tom Wolfe. ........................ 1 GREEN THOUGHTS: A Writer in the Garden. By Eleanor Perenyi. ..... 12 THE HAMMONDS OF REDCLIFFE.
