By Marion Margery Layne. .................... 41 THE BOOK OF LIGHTS. By Chaim Potok. .............................. 14 CONFESSIONS OF A HOMING PIGEON.

title: Design; THE CARPENTRY CONNECTION
description: The educati on of a designer is a various thing: Some are schooled, others skip t he formalities and learn on the job in design firms. In any case, by the time a young designer is ready to hang out a shingleof his own, h e is usually well versed in the received wisdom of his trade. For th e most part, this is good, except for one drawback: At atime in life when designers ought to be doing their most adventurous work, these a colytes tend to be mired in mainstream thought.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART Max Beckmann (1884-1950) had as brilliant a beginning to his career as any painter could wish for. In no time at all he was admired, sought out and made much of.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 4 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with the Berrys, an eccentric family that sets up house in unlikely hotels, here and abroad. 2 2 9 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 3 3 23 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 4 4 11 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Chief of Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York. 5 6 16 THE CARDINAL SINS, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Bernard Geis, $12.95.) The triumphs and tragedies of two Chicago boys as priests in the Catholic Church. 6 5 27 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents.

title: QUEENS PLANT OPENS JOB MARKET TO 9 DROPOUTS
description: The graduation took place without pomp in the most modest of circumstances. But to the nine high school dropouts receiving technical diplomas last week - certification they were trained to operate machinery that makes leather goods - it was a moment of pride. And for the owners of the Queens factory in which the ceremony took place, it was proof that unemployed and untrained youths could be given a trade and a jobwithout a pen ny of government money. ''I agree with Ronald Reagan -everyone goes to Uncle Sam as if he were a cow who would never run out of milk,'' said Barry B. Schiller,a partner at the Campbell Bosworth Machinery Company in Long Island City, which volunteered the time and faciliti es for the training program. ''It is the private sector's respons ibility to train the unemployed and link them up with companies wh o need workers.''

title: Around the World; Nicaragua Says It Killed 14 Pro-Somoza Rebels
description: Fourteen people were killed in the last week in clashes between Government soldiers and ''counterrevolutionary'' groups in northern Nicaragua, the Interior Ministry announced yesterday. The Ministry said no Government soldiers had been killed.

title: RUSSIA'S LOST REVOLUTION IN MODERN ART
description: Hilton Kramer is the senior art critic of The Times. By Hilton Kramer No chapter in the entire history of modern art now commands the degree of curiosity and wonder that greets each successive revelation of the accomplishments of the avant-garde that flourished in Russia in the years just before and after the Revolution of 1917. No other aspect of the modern movement seems at once so close to recent developments in our own art and yet so remote in the spirit and circumsta nces of its creation. None has more clearly won the right to be c onsidered ''advanced.'' Ideas that were thought to be wildly innova tive and even shocking as recently as the 1960's - ideasabout the for ms and materials of art, and about its meaning and social functi ons - turn out to have been fully developed in Russia inthe second an d third decades of this century.

title: FENDING OFF A 'BEAR CALLED LTV
description: BETHPAGE, L.I. I N his fight to block the LTV Corporation's proposed $450 million takeover of the Grumman Corporation, John C. Bierwirth, the target company's chairman, can't promise much.

title: ELECTRONICS EXPERTS HAVE SYSTEM WIRED
description: A YOUNG electronics engineer looking for a job in the San Francisco Bay area might be offered a host of unusual inducements. While still in school he might be provided with lucrative summer jobs by companies hoping to lure him back when he graduates. Upon graduation he might be given a bonus to sign with a company, or stock options, profit-sharing plans, sabbaticals and other fringe benefits.

title: LONG ISLAND
description: The increased Federal defense budget is expected to create jobs on Long Island in the aerospace and electronics industries, especially with large defense contractors and smaller subcontractors that manufacture parts. This will mean a more certain future for hightechnology companies that Long Island officials have been wooing in an effort to render the region's economy recession-proof.

title: ASIAN REFUGEES: STARTING LIFE AGAIN
description: LAWRENCE AFTER a year of living on Long Island, a group of Indochinese refugees sponsored by the Community Bible Church here are finding that their major problems are not related to employment but in adjusting to a culture that to them is fast-paced and achievementoriented.

title: PITTSBURGH STOPS WEST VIRGINIA, 17-0
description: While their star quarterback, Dan Marino, stood on the sideline nursing an injured arm, the undefeated Pittsburgh Panthers relied on defense and ball control today to beat West Virginia, 17-0.

title: A NEW BONUS: COMPANY AID ON RETIREMENT
description: T HROUGHOUT the country, large corporations and smaller businesses are thinking less about what kind of gold watch to give their prospective retirees and more about what kind of preretirement program to offer them. Rough estimates are that 500 companies now have some kind of retirement program, ranging from one-hour meetings with a local bank officer to several days of carefully structured seminars.

title: TRANSIT OFFICIALS TO RESIST U.S. CUTS
description: Leaders of the nation's mass transit industry are vowing to fight strenuously against plans by the Reagan Administration for a new 12 percent cut in Federal assistance.

title: NEW DANGERS ADDED TO THE MIDDLE EAST'S OLD RIVALRIES
description: Sadat of Egypt has plunged the always volatile Middle East into a new period of uncertainty. The questions start, of course, with the future direction of Egypt itself and ripple outward to encompass the region's shifting alliances, the struggle for Arab leadership, the future of the Camp David accords and the American policy which depends upon them, the Palestinian issue and, ultimately, the questions of peace and war.

title: A Decent Burial
description: Forty-nine years after Bruno Richard Hauptmann was executed for the kidnap and murder of the Lindbergh baby, the case files are to be opened; New Jersey's Governor Byrne hopes that as a result, questions about the case ''will not be kicked around for years and years to come.''

title: Crafts
description: THE emergence of ''wearable art'' as a serious contender for attention in the fashion world has insp ired, during this wardrobeswitc hing season, two overlapping exhibitions in Bergen County.

title: Hospital and Parents In Pact on Baby Defect
description: The University Medical Center agreed yesterday to pay $900,000 in settlement of a suit filed on behalf of a severely retarded baby who might have been aborted if his parents had been told of a prenatal test that might have detected the fetus's condition.

title: Pick Your Victim: Pupil or Teacher?
description: When Stuyvesant High School teachers began refusing a month ago to write college recommendation letters, their students trembled, some with rage. Even mightier than the teachers' pens, however, is the Schools Chancellor's sword, and last week, amid hints he might use it, the educators called off their boycott.

title: WINNING THE WAR ON ENERGY
description: THE United States appears to be on the brink of winning the war it began in the 1970's for control of its energy destiny. The evidence is everywhere : Supplies are abundant, prices have flattened, a sharp decline in oi l imports has helped put OPEC in disarray, the crisisconceiv ed Department of Energy is scheduled to be dismantled and analysts of every stripe are busy trying to figure out why their pessimistic p rojections of the past eight years were so off.

title: DENUCLEARIZATION
description: The Reagan Administration i is now committed to entering into talks with the Soviet Union, at the end of next month, on the question of the so-called theater nuclear weapons in and around Central Europe. Let us hope that in preparing its negotiating position, the Administration will consider that alternative which, precisely because it is the simplest, may also appear the most radical - namely, total denuclearization of the region.

title: CORNWALLIS'S LAST STAND TO BE RELIVED
description: Two centuries after the gunfire ended here at the mouth of the Chesapeake Bay, the green fields on which a crack British Army under Lieut. Gen. Charles Cornwallis surrendered its earthworks and its flintlocks to Gen. George Washington's ragtag Continentals are aswarm again this weekend with communications and public address system technicians.

title: PROGRAM ON YOUTH AND LAW EXPANDS
description: IN 1978, shortly after the New York State Juvenile Offender Law was enacted, three women interested in juvenile justice felt there was a need to inform young people about its provisions. What began as a simple booklet-writing project has grown into the Juvenile Law Education Project, a nonprofit organization that informs thousands of young people in the county about their legal rights and responsibilities. It is now training volunteers to assist in the programs it conducts at Westchester schools.

title: Bonn's Mayor Assails A Communist Tactic
description: City officials said today that the Communist Party had urged storekeepers here to paste placards in their windows supporting today's antiwar demonstration to avoid having them smashed.

title: KNOWING YOURSELF ON THE DEER HUNT
description: NONE of the 16 deer hunting books I have accumulated deals with knowing thyself, a relevant element of the endeavor.When contemplating a hunt, you must decide whether you truly want to slay a deer, but even if you don't, there is no reason to forego part of the experience.

title: APPALACHIAN TRAIL OPENS NEW SECTION
description: The first major relocated section of the Appalachian Trail in New York State has been opened to hikers in this hilly area of southern Dutchess County.

title: Around the Nation; Hyatt Walkways' Maker Cites Designers' Change
description: A change in the suspension design for the Hyatt Regency Hotel's walkways, which collapsed and killed 113 persons July 17, was ordered by a St. Louis engineering firm, according to documents on file in court here.

title: THE MARKETPLACE IN FOUR MAJOR FIELDS TRANSPORTATION
description: A T a time when there are dark clouds over the airline industry, those interested in working for the big air carriers might have to lower their sights and look instead to smaller airlines or opportunities in ground transportation. The change might mean more down-to-earth salaries, but the jobs are there, the experts say.

hand 80 Obituaries Charles J. Moran, former official of the Cunard Line 44

title: 'THE TROUPE,' LIFE IN ISRAELI MILITARY
description: According to the production notes, Avi Nesher's ''The Troupe'' has been a big success in Israel, where its blend of saccharine music and cute comedy undoubtedly went over better than they will here. Mr. Nesher's film, a kind of ''Chorus Line'' in army boots, presents life in a military unit that specializes in song and dance.

title: FLA. STATE TOPPLES IRISH
description: Bobby Bowden, the football coach at Florida State University, had made jokes while all of Tallahassee looked at the schedule and cringed. They were looking at a five-game stretch that had the Seminoles at Nebraska, at Ohio State, at Notre Dame, at Pittsburgh, and at Louisiana State.

title: Creative What?
description: To the Business Editor: In your story, ''The New Keys to Home Lending'' (Oct. 4), the term ''creative finance'' in the present housing market should mean mutual benefits to both lender and borrower. There is little or no benefit to the average American home buyer when the cost of mortgage financing is simply unaffordable. ALLAN HAYMES Allan Haymes Associates New York, N.Y., Oct. 6, 1981

title: ACCORD IS REPORTED ON SOCIAL SECURITY PANEL
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House of Representatives, has reportedly reached a compromise with the White House on the composition of a panel that President Reagan has proposed for a bipartisan study of Social Security.

title: Richard Tucker Gala Nov. 1 at Carnegie Hall
description: The fifth Richard Tucker Memorial Gala honoring the late Metropolitan Opera tenor will be Nov. 1 at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. Marilyn Horne will be the hostess.

title: TELEVISION TAKES VILLAGE TO THE FUNERAL
description: At Hajj Ahmed Eissa's house in this village, 15 men crowded into his small parlor today to watch President Anwar el-Sadat's funeral on the color television set.

title: History's Paths Cross in Atlanta
description: For more than 100 years, Atlanta has been the center of black civil rights leadership; for the past 20, it has been a symbol of Sunbelt splendor. Last week, in the city's mayoral election, lines between the movement and the New South blurred in a close contest between Andrew Young, the black United Nations ambassador, Congressman and rights activist and Sidney Marcus, a white moderate-to-liberal State Representative.

title: Miss Aronson Has Bridal
description: Alison Carol Aronson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar D. Aronson of New York and South Gouldsboro, Me., was married yesterday to Thomas Edward Sherman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee A. Sherman of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Emeritus Nathan Perilman of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony at the St. Regis Hotel.

title: LANDSCAPE PHOTOS DOT SUMMIT CENTER
description: SUMMIT AT TIMES, art might imitate nature, but it does not always emulate it. For example, many artists who have attempted to convey the splendid majesty and vast grandeur of the American landscape have not succeeded; one need only compare their canvases and the nature that inspired them to realize who comes out on top in the comparison.

title: AFRICAN LEADER ARGUES CASE FOR THIRD WORLD
description: His country is one of Africa's smallest and poorest, and so the Foreign Minister of Burundi speaks with both alarm and conviction when he argues the third world's case against the Reagan Administration's belief that a free-market economy and private enterprise can solve the problems of the developing nations.

title: PREPS; PHILLIPS ANDOVER HALTS CHOATE'S 10-GAME STREAK
description: Choate's 10-game winning streak over two years was halted yesterday when Phillips Andover scored twice in the first half and then hung on for a 13-7 victory over its long-time rival. Both teams were 2-0 coming into the game.

title: Realty News; ...AND ITS NEIGHBOR IS SOLD; by Diane Henry
description: Delmonico's hotel on Park Avenue at 59th Street, for decades one of New York's most fashionable establishments, was sold last month for $33 million to Sarah Korein and Philip Sills.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: In the chorus of comments on President Reagan's decision to put aside all versions of the Multiple Aim Point (MAP) basing mode for the MX missile, one point seems to have been overlooked: its relationship with the SALT II treaty.

title: Report Says Lax Accounting Of Checks Costs U.S. Millions
description: The Treasury has lost millions of dollars through lax controls over the duplicate payment of lost, stolen or forged Government checks, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: Savannah's Charms To the Editor: As a transplanted Southerner living in New York, I salute your article on Savannah, "Enduring Charm of a Southern Belle" (Travel Section, Sept. 13). Having been a lifelong Savannahian until moving to New York with my family 10 months ago, I still miss and long for my home place. David W. Dunlap's article was a breath of warm Southern air filled with emotional ties that will always endure.

title: Reading and Writing; THE RIGHT VOICE CAN'T LIE
description: ''His voice is his own,'' the critics say, or, plumping for the tautology, ''uniquely his own.'' We talk about voice more than we talk about style or structure. We tend to think of literature as one person speaking to another, an intimate transaction.

title: A WASHINGTON FABLE
description: Sitting in President Reagan's ''window of vulnerability'' the other night, idly watching the Awacs float by, I imagined in my fabled mind that I could see the whole world and all the people in it, and listen in on their quarrels and even hear their prayers.

title: Westchester Journal
description: NORTH CASTLE'S controversial burglar-alarm law, which requires residents of the town to register their alarm systems with the police and makes them liable for fines of $10 for each false alarm, went into effect July 1. But the false alarms continue and no one has been fined, according to the police chief, Albert L. Stipo.

title: ON BUDGETS, PRESIDENT'S WORD MAY BE THE LAW
description: In his heyday, the late John J. Rooney, the Democrat from Brooklyn, was one of the most feared men in Washington. Embassies were cowed by his visits, Attorneys General danced attendance and the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation provided confidential data on campaign opponents.

title: Wine; A HOME PORT IN CALIFORNIA
description: ith the onset of autumn and cool weather, the thoughts of many oenophiles turn to Port, the robust, intensely flavorful fortified wine made in the rugged Douro River region of northern Portugal. is a wine to be drunk after a meal, perhaps with stilton or some other sharp cheese. It is a wine to be talked over, to be savored, and it is said that there is no such thing as a half-empty bottle of Port, for somehow the bottle is always finished.

title: BAKING BREAD WITH DEVOTION
description: THREE years ago, Judy Silz donated clothing to the Attic Door, a thift shop run by the First United Methodist Church. The fragrant smell of baking enticed Mrs. Silz up the stairs and into the church's large kitchen.

title: DARKER DAYS FOR COLLEGE GRADS
description: A S an undergraduate at Boston College, Susan Stoller had to tailor her goals to suit a precarious job market. She switched her major from elementary education to special education, where there is a higher demand, and she resigned herself to moving out of Massachusetts because tax cuts had resulted in a freeze in the demand for teachers. She arranged her job interviews through the Massachusetts Educational Recruiting Consortium, a group of colleges that invites representatives from out-of-state school systems. ''Every time a school system was coming to recruit, I would take the interview regardless of whether I wanted to go there,'' said Miss Stoller, who graduated this year.

title: MIDDLE WEST
description: The early 1980 recession hit hardest the Middle Western states that have heavy industrial bases. Affected most were manufacturing and construction in Michigan, Illinois, Ohio and Indiana, especially auto-related manufacturing jobs.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Due in Rumania
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India will pay a three-day visit to Rumania from Oct. 18 on her way to the conference of developing and industrial nations in Cancun, Mexico, the Government said today. Mrs. Gandhi returned to New Delhi last night after a 17-day foreign tour during which she attended the Commonwealth conference in Melbourne, Australia.

title: FASHION REVEALS A FINE ITALIAN HAND
description: Italian clothes are supposed to be light and amusing for summer. Sometimes, as in next year's clothes that were shown here during the past week, they seemed sober and heavy.

title: THE GREAT ONSHORE OIL LOTTERY
description: Ted Barry, a reporter and writer in the Washington bureau of ABC-TV News, is writing a book about the oil-and-gas lottery. By Ted Barry ''There's a fever; there's an oil fever like there was a gold fever and a uranium fever.'' Dale E. Zimmerman, the top career Interior Department official in charge of onshore minerals, was talking about the ambitious plans of Secretary of the Interior James Watt plans to accelerate the leasing of oil-and-gas rights on Federal lands. What Zimmerman, whose title is Assistant to the Deputy Director for Energy and Mineral Resources, did not say, but what has been implicit in everything that he and Secretary Watt have been advocating for months, is that this fever should be exploited to spur domestic oil-and-gas production by opening up an additional 100,000,000 acres of Federal lands, mostly in Alaska and the Rocky Mountain states, for leasing. Their insistence on retaining the present methods of allocating onshore leases - a lottery for previously leased lands and a first-come, first-served (called, ''over-the-counter'') system for lands never before leased - has escalated an already heated controversy. The lottery system, which many critics both in and out of Government, contend is highly susceptible to manipulation and may, in fact, be illegal, has come under particular attack.

title: Kentucky 28 South Carolina 14
description: Gordon Beckham of Kentucky ran 5 yards for one touchdown and passed 9 yards to Horace Smith for another. The defensive tackle Andrew Provence set up Beckham's scoring pass with an interception at the Kentucky 30 and ended the Wildcats' final comeback bid with an 11-yard sack of Randy Jenkins late in the fourth quarter.

title: Count Is Fiance Of Miss Lichine
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. C. Robert Devine and Alexis Lichine, both of New York, of the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Lichine, to Etienne, Count de Damas, son of Count and Countess Rene de Damas of Paris and Chateau Le Ply, Songeons, France.

title: OUSTED BURMESE CHIEF FORGIVES HIS USURPER
description: U Nu, who served as Prime Minister from before independence in 1948 until his overthrow in a military coup has forgiven the man who directed it, the current President, U Ne Win.

title: H.G. Mueller, Jane Hewson Are Married
description: The marriage of Jane Mabbett Hewson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Beresford Hewson of Princeton, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., to Henry Gregor Mueller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Muth Mueller of New York and Nantucket, took place in Nantucket yesterday. The Rev. Dr. J. Everett Bodge performed the ceremony in the Old North Vestry of the First Congregational Church.

title: HORSES IN BETHANY SERVED BY COUNSEL
description: BETHANY LACKING a defined business district, a major industry or even a traditional village green, this pastoral community of 4,500 could easily be mistaken for what is colloquially known as a ''one-horse town.''

title: CRENSHAW IN FINAL MATCH OF PLAY
description: Ben Crenshaw edged a fellow Texan, Bill Rogers, on the last hole and reached the final of the Suntory world match-play golf tournament today.

title: Princeton Subdues Columbia
description: Princeton moved 70 yards and scored with just under two minutes remaining today to break a 14-14 tie and defeat Columbia, 21-14.

title: On LanguageBy William Safire Goodbye, 'Mr. Justice' Kimble Mead
description: Until a year ago, the way to address Justices of the Supreme Court was ''Mr. Justice Soandso.'' Then, mysteriously, without explanation, the ''Mr.'' was dropped from the printed publication of opinions: The Justices were called, simply, ''Justice Soandso.''

title: BOCCE MAY BE BEAUTIFUL, BUT...
description: FEDERAZIONE ITALIANE BOCCE, VIA CRISTOFORO COLOMBO, GENOA, ITALY GENTLEMEN:

title: Washington State 23 Oregon State0
description: Ricky Turner's 49-yard touchdown runearly in the third quarter broke a scoreless tie.

title: MAKING THE LIBERAL ARTS A PLUS
description: A LAN LUCAS stared dejectedly at the letter from Midwest Microprocessor. It was a nice enough letter, sprinkled with phrases like ''I enjoyed meeting you ... you have a fine background ... I wish you every success ....'' But the message was clear. Midwest had no job for Alan Lucas. That rejection letter was particularly discouraging to Mr. Lucas because his roommate, Bob Abrams, had just received a job offer from Midwest, even though his grade-point average was lower than Mr. Lucas's and his campus activities were not as impressive.

title: MANY QUESTION MARKS AHEAD
description: T HE nation's outlook on job availability is highly unpredictable and will remain so for some time, most experts believe, because of the Reagan Administration's rewriting of the nation's budget and tax policies, continued high interest rates and an economy that has been unsettled for several years.

title: THROUGH RED-COLORED GLASSES
description: POLITICAL PILGRIMS Travels of Western Intellectuals to the Soviet Union, China and Cuba 1928-1978. By Paul Hollander. 524 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: WHY IT IS MORE EXPENSIVE TO EDUCATE FEWER STUDENTS
description: MANY taxpayers today are asking the very legitimate question: why do school expenses increase at the same time that the number of students is decreasing.

title: No Headline
description: Bjorn Borg advanced to the semifinals of the $300,000 Edmonton Tennis Challenge today with a 6-4, 6-4 victory over Vijay Amritraj of India.

title: Spare the Rod, Spoil the Child?
description: In a major deregulation victory for the Reagan Administration, the Senate last week played midwife to a Ma Bell offspring, hoping the progeny wouldn't grow up to be a big bully.

title: U.S. HAS TWO OBLIGATIONS: TO GRIEVE AND PERSEVERE
description: The sudden aching shock and sense of forboding Americans felt last week at the news that President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt had been assassinated have forcefully brought home the risks of pinning American policy and American hopes so heavily on a single foreign leader in so vital a region.

title: SEEDLINGS AS DEFOLIATION CURE
description: THE office of the State Forester at the Department of Environmental Protection has announced that Connecticut landowners can purchase tree and shrub seedlings for reforestation, wildlife habitat improvement, erosion control and other conservation purposes.

title: WESTPORT LAWYER PREPARES FOR U.S. ROLE
description: WESTPORT IT was last Wednesday afternoon that the White House put an end to weeks of waiting for Alan H. Nevas and announced that President Reagan had nominated him to be the next United States Attorney for Connecticut.

title: BUS DRIVER IN BROOKLYN KILLED BY A RIDER REFUSED A TRANSFER
description: A New York City bus dr iver was shot and fatally wounded aboard his bus in Broo klyn yesterday afternoon by an angry passenger in a dispute over free transfers, the transit police said. The gunman, accompanied by a woman, escaped after the slaying.

title: Woman Accused of Helping A Fugitive Spy Denies Guilt
description: Gloria White p leaded not guilty yesterday to a charge of harboring Christophe r Boyce, a convicted spy, in a mountain cabin after he escaped fro m prison.

title: POP: ELECTRIC LIGHT ORCHESTRA
description: Since the mid-70's, the Electric Light Orchestra has been turning out a mass-market brand of English art rock that shamelessly borrows tunes from Little Richard, the Beatles and Rimsky-Korsakov, among innumerable sources, and fuses them into a glitzy ''space age'' style of pop.

title: NEW GATEWAY IN FLORIDA
description: Except for its 12,000-foot runways, originally built for military flights, everything at Orlando International Airport is brand new. On its first day of operation, Sept. 20, I flew in to look at the $300 million complex. Through clear skies, I got a glimpse of Walt Disney World as Air Florida's Flight 7 from Gainesville prepared to land.

title: Records Include Monday's Gameloss ended Brigham Young's 17-game winning streak, the longest among m; American League 275 or more turns at ba t; AB R H HR RBI Pct Lansford Bos 399 61 134 4 52 .336 Gibson Det 29 0 41 95 9 40 .328 Paciorek Sea 405 50 132 14 66 .326 CCooper Mil 4 16 70 133 12 60 .320 RHendrsn Oak 423 89 135 6 35 .319 Hargrove Cle 322 44 102 2 49 .317 GBrett KC 347 42 109 6 43 .314 Zisk Sea 357 42 111 16 43 .311 Oliver Tex 42 1 53 130 4 55 .309
Antiques; VINTAGE CLOTHING
description: When outstanding period clothing appears on the market, enthusiastic collectors and dealers willing to pay extraordinary prices vie eagerly for the chance to buy. This occurred twice in recent auctions in New York, sales that attracted two quite different types of collectors. In one case a 1920's tea gown by Mariano Fortuny, the Venetian artist-designer, sold for $7,000, a record for the designer and the highest price ever paid at public sale for a period gown. In the other auction, a pair of ruby red silk slippers worn by Judy Garland as Dorothy in ''The Wiza rd of Oz'' sold for $12,000.Both prices are astounding considerin g the fact that the market for vintage clothing and other collect ibles is, according to many observors, now undergoing a mild recessi on.

title: About Westchester
description: IT is 6 A.M. and Sue Wood is about to report to work. When she left her house in Briarcliff this morning, the sky was deep blue, the moon, still silver. Now, the light in the east is pale pink, and the cliffs across the Hudson seem to change from black to green in the early sunlight.

title: JOANNE ZISSON IS MARRIED
description: Joanne Esther Zisson, daughter of Miles M. Zisson of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Norma Stern Zisson, was married yesterday to George Elliot Reed, Jr., son of Dr. Reed of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Thelma Bilik Reed. Rabbi Jacob Shankman performed the ceremony at the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck.

title: Making a Pitch for a More Realistic World Series
description: AS every broken-hearted Red Sox fan (and my heart is the most broken) knows, the World Series is not a true test of baseball depth. I still have nightmares remembering Harry Brecheen of the St. Louis Cardinals trudging in from the bul lpen in the seventh game in 1946 (when Enos Slaughter made his famous dash) an d stopping the Sox' eighth-inning rally cold.

title: Children's Books
description: THE MISSING P IECE MEETS THE BIG O By Shel Silve rstein.Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row. $8.95. (All Ages) By JOYCE MILTON

title: MUSINGS OF A DOCTOR: URCHINS AND ABORTIONS
description: F or nearly 100 summers, biologists at Woods Hole, Mass., have performed the classic experiment of the Marine Biological Laboratory: They have fertilized urchin eggs with sperm in a small dish. Persuaded that urchin eggs holds lessons for human disease, I have spent a dozen seasons watching this ritual. This summer, while waiting for the eggs to divide, my attention was repaid by another lesson. I turned to Science magazine, to discover that a Senate committee was engaged in defining the beginning of human life: the junction of sperm with egg. What coincidence! On my left, urchin life was stirring in the dish; on my right, Science informed me that the Government was legislating biology, with the stated intent of supporting the ''Right to Life'' movement. The urchins tell another story.

title: Patricia O'D. Whelpley, Textile Artist, Is Married to William Gordon Brittain
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday, Patricia O'Donnell Whelpley, daughter of Mrs. Rollin H. Wiggin Jr. of Darien and the late Gordon Brittain Whelpley, was married to William Gilbert Barton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Barton of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Frederick B. Stimson Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Deal With Unru ly Fans, Too
description: To the Sports Editor: The recent incidents involving the baseball players Cesar Cedeno and Reggie Sm ith, each of whom went into the stands to confront heckling spec tators, raises an important question concerning just what should b e done with abusive fans.

title: FOR JULIUS ERVING OF THE 76ERS, IT'S ALL A PHILADELPHIA STORY
description: not as a New Yorker who grew up on Long Island, but as a Philadelphian. This is a new feeling for him and he is here, where his 76ers train, reminiscing a bout that short part of his life when he was a New York Net.

title: CALIFORNIA TO HALT FRUIT FLY DRIVE FOR WINTER
description: California began winding down its aerial assault on the Mediterranean fruit fly for the winter this weekend, but scientists involved in the eradication effort say that the war is far from over and the hardy little insect is almost certain to reappear in early summer.

title: Michigan 38 Mic higan State 20
description: Steve Smith of Michigan scored two touchdowns and Butch Woolfolk became the first Michigan player to rush for 200 yards in a game since 1975.

title: Film View; MIDTERM FESTIVAL REPOR T
description: Although at this writing the 19th New York Film Festival has still one more week to go, some random observations are in order at the midpoint. Item: Autobiographical cinema - the kind that has its origins in the camera-mad 1960's and early 70's, is back with a vengeance. The two most notorious films at this year's festival have unquestionably been ''Lightning Over Water,'' an almost unbearably painful recording of the last, agonizing months in the life of Nicholas Ray (''They Live by Night,'' ''Rebel without a Cause,'' etc.), co-directed by Mr. Ray and Wim Wenders, and ''Taxi zum Klo'' (''Taxi to the John''), a breezy, frequently funny, aggressively candid ''reconstructed'' autobiography.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; ALEXANDRA PENNEY
description: Once upon a time, mothers used to counsel their daughters that the way to a man's heart was through his stomach. In her book ''How to Make Love to a Man,'' which appears on the best seller list this week for the eighth time, Alexandra Penney makes a case for replacingman's culinar y preferences with man's sexual preferences. The information i n my book is ages old,'' Miss Penney concedes. ''What isnew is the po int of view.''

title: NATION CONTENDS WITH NEED FOR THE OLD SKILLS
description: T HE president of the International Association of Machinists recently voiced fears that ''the most highly industrialized nation is in danger of becoming a nation of industrial illiterates.'' In his crystal ball, the union's leader, William M. Winpisinger, saw vast numbers of people in the nation ''who do not know how to stop a running toilet, replace a burnt-out fuse or identify anything on a car more complicated than a gas tank.''

title: Connecticut Housing; SOLAR DEVICES ADVANCE WITH USE
description: WHEN Carolyn and James Russell purchased a $130,000 colonial-style home on two acres of exposed hilltop in Weston a year ago, they gave scant attention to the fact that the southside of the house was completely shaded by a garage. They also attached little importance to the fact that the large windows on either side of the living room were not airtight.

title: STAR OF 'MARLOWE' IS A MARLOWE FAN
description: WHEN ''Marlowe,'' a new rock musical, opens tomorrow at the Rialto Theater on Broadway, Patrick Jude of Hoboken will be in the limelight largely because he had the nerve to try a trick or two when his career seemed blocked.

title: PERSONAL FINANCE
description: M OST plans to accumulate a fund for a child's college education assume that a parent has a lot of foresight or a lot of money - or both. But there's one approach that's tailor-made for people who don't get around to doing something until their child is in high school, and it even allows them to borrow the money that's needed to put the plan into action.

title: UNLOADED; Rare Guns
description: Guns, for once, brought pleasure and commerce to New York City last week.

title: COUNTY ANGLERS TURN OUT FOR FALL FISHING
description: NEW CASTLE VICTORIA PIGIET of Yonkers had just landed a whopping 36-inch, 20-pound carp from the north end of the Kensico Reservoir and seemed disappointed.

title: Gallery View; A SPLENDID NEW HOME FOR ROCKEFELLER' S TREASURES
description: As of this coming week New York will have a new museum building at 725 Park Avenue, on the same cross street as the Frick Collection at 74th Street. Designed by Edward Larrabee Barnes, it is the relocated headquarters of the Asia Society. The Asia Society was founded by John D. Rockefeller 3d just 25 years ago. It was not meant to be primarily an exhibiting society, and indeed the display of works of Asian art is only one of the activities that are already going forward in the new building. The word ''multi-purpose'' applies as much to the society itself as to the enfilade of conference rooms with which Mr. Barnes has endowed one of the upper floors of the building. The nuances of Indian Buddhist sculpture in the 6th century A.D. are important to the Asia Society, but so are the latest breakthroughs in Japanese technology and the population problems of Bangladesh.

title: V.S. PRITCHETT'S MINORCA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- V.S. PRITCHETT'S latest book is a collection of short stories, ''On the Edge of the Cliff.'' By V.S.PRITCHETT

title: Around the World; 4 Acquitted in Jamaica On Charge of Treason
description: Four men charged with plotting to overthrow the Government of former Prime Minister Michael Manley in June 1980 were acquitted yesterday after a key witness was judged to be unreliable.

title: AIR FORCE REPORTS RECRUITING REACHED GOAL FOR FISCAL YEAR
description: The United States Air Force says that in the fiscal year 1981 it achieved 100 percent of its quota for recruits who have no previous military service.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Has the Auto-Train between Lorton, Va. and Sanford, Fla. been discontinued? And is there any similar operation on the East Coast? - R.M.P., Manchester, N.H. Answer:The Auto-Train Corporation filed a bankruptcy petition in 1980 and ceased operation April 30, 1981. A New York City company called Auto-Rail has announced that it will begin transporting cars by specially equipped railroad cars between Newark and Miami this Friday. Cars 162 inches or less in length will cos t $249 to ship, longer cars $ 379 and up. Auto-Rail is a subsidiary of Aaac on, an automobile transporting company. Some of these companies s hip your car on a highway automobile carrier and some hire individu als to drive your car to the destination. Such companies are list ed in the Yellow Pages under ''Automobile Transporters and Drive-Awa y Companies.''

title: FINDING VILLAINS FOR SOCIETY'S ILLS IS NOT SIMPLE
description: SEEMINGLY overwhelmed by the towering mounds of effluent that it generates daily -much of it hazardous - society is doing what it usually does when it is frightened or feels threatened: It looks for villains.

title: Paperback Talk
description: The revolution. ''OUT TODAY! THE NEW POCKET BOOKS THAT MAY REVOLUTIONIZE NEW YORK'S READING HABITS!'' Within a decade of its appearance in an advertisement in this newspaper in June 1939, that exclamatory prediction had been more than fulfilled. The kind of books it heralded -low-priced, 4 1/4-by-7-inch paper-covered volumes -revolutionized reading habits not just in New York, but in towns and neighborhoods where books had never been sold before. A dozen publishers, with the help of 600 magazine wholesalers, kept racks filled with them in 100,000 newsstands and drugstores. In 1950, sales totaled 200 million copies. In 1960, nearly 300 million copies. With some roller-coaster fluctuations, the revolution kept rolling along until 1973, when the total reached 520 million.

title: Careful Shopper; Elmsford Warehouse A Weekend Store
description: The word is out among shoppers: an Elmsford warehouse devoted to wholesale shipping during the week turns into The Factory Warehouse Store each weekend and offers 30 to 50 percent discounts on junior and misses' nationally advertised sportswear, a few men's trousers (at $19.99) and children's jeans, corduroys and skirts. This weekend will be extended for Columbus Day shoppers - the hours are 8 A.M. until 5 P.M. Monday.

title: THOSE LITTLE WHITE LIES IN RESUMES
description: John Jones was seeking a job in public relations and, in an attempt to stand out among the applicants, stated in his resume that he had earned a graduate degree from an Ivy League school. ''I felt I wouldn't get the job without it,'' said Mr. Jones, which is not his real name. But the employer checked with the school, discovered that the degree had been fabricated and confronted Mr. Jones indignantly about the deception.

title: ALL AT ONCE, THE BLACK VOTE LOOMS LARGER
description: The importance of race in New York politics has never been a secret to those who select the city's candidates. But in recent weeks it has become conspicuous even to those who merely vote for them.

title: CURRENCY: THE POWER OF A PENNY
description: This is what a penny will buy in 1981: Not much. ''I can't think of a whole lot of things that sell for a penny,'' said United States Treasurer Angela Marie ''Babe'' Buchanan.

title: FLIGHTS OF DREAMS, REALITY'S DEBRIS
description: THE boxcar has been gone longer than usual. I look for it often now, worried that it's been demolished in a freight yard or prairie train wreck. Little seems to change during its periodic absences in this gritty part of town, past the red gingerbread railroad station, below the shaded streets and flower-fringed lawns, where lame cars are parked on both sides of the street.

title: Unwanted Pregnancies: Support Is Needed
description: The incident described in Susan Schneider's recent critique of the antiabortion amendment (''Antiabortion Plan: Where Is Justice,'' Sept, 20) was, indeed, tragic. Too many women have been victimized by back alley abortionists, rapists and communities that offer no alternatives to self-induced abortions. An unexpected, unwanted pregnancy, especially one that is the result of a violent, sexual assault, is a frightening personal burden. Women who seek abortion are not murderers, as some overzealous antiabortionists would have us believe. They are, rather, the women with whom we work and socialize, the women we marry and with whom we raise our children. They are burdened with the unexpected and unwanted responsibility for another life and are offered little support to help manage this responsibility within the context of their careers, relationships, financial constraints, etc. Their's is an unenviable situation, one that too often involves their suffering severe psychological or physical trauma.

title: BUILDER OF THE B-1 BOMBER
description: NO one has yet raised a flag proclaiming ''Reagan Country'' over the Rockwell International Corporation's plant complex here. But theymight just as well have. No company has benefited more so far from the policies of the Reagan Administration than Rockwell, the diversified c onglomerate based in Pittsburgh.

title: ONE WHO BROKE THE MOLD
description: WHEN Anne Tolstoy Wallach graduated from Radcliffe 30 years ago, having majored in English, she was advised that the only way to get a job in the business world was to become a secretary. "So I learned to type but was never terribly good at shorthand," she recalls. For that reason she grabbed the opportunity to work for a man at J. Walter Thompson, the advertising agency, "who hated to dictate, preferring to type out all his letters in rough."

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Three Solisti, Troupe From Yugoslavia
description: Some chamber groups behave more like loose confederations than ensembles. As an example, Three Solisti from Yugoslavia made their American debut Monday night at Carnegie Recit al Hall with a program that kept Ljupco Samardziski, double bassist; Jovan Kolundzija, violinist, and Vladimir Krpan, pianist, from actually playing together until the final selection.

title: Robert Braddock Simpson Weds Deirdre Blair Brady
description: Deirdre Blair Brady, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wright Brady of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Braddock Simpson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Holmes Simpson, also of New Canaan. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church.

title: THE REGION'S LEADERS AT A GLANCE
description: LIBYA President Sadat's assassination has removed Colonel Qaddafi's main adversary from the scen e and fortified his determination to spread his is lamic radicalism through North Africa and the Middle East. SUDAN A survivor of many coup and assassin ation a ttempts, President Nimiery is embroiled in a critical struggle w ith Libya and has asked Egypt to intercede with Washington for milita ry aid.

title: 'From Bauhaus to Our House'
description: There is almost no one who is not bewildered by the events of the last two decades in architecture. Sleek modern buildings go up, covering more and more of the landscape with glass and aluminum and steel and concrete, as ornate buildings of stone go down to make way for them. And while some of the new buildings excite the public imagination, as a group they are not nearly so popular as the old ones. This public disaffection may be due to the great size of the new buildings as much as to anything else. But they continue to rise, lately taking stranger and stranger shapes.

title: A GROWTH IN ACTIVISM IS CITED BY FEMINISTS
description: AROUND the state in recent weeks, a Hartford conference for women drew 5,000 enthusiasts, a political action committee was formed to support legislative candidates sympathetic to women's issues, a study was released that indicates women are strong candidates for public office, and a monthly newspaper geared towards working women was inaugurated.

title: HANNAH ARENDT - INSPIRATION, PROVOCATEUR, RESPECTED FOE
description: HANNAH Arendt, the German-born political philosopher, writer and teacher, died in New York in 1975, but her thinking on such subjects as totalitarianism, democracy, modern revolutions, the ''banality'' of evil and even the nature of thinking continue to stimulate serious and feisty debate. A week ago, a conference based on her work, sponsored by several universities and other institutions, attracted several hundred people to Schimmel Auditorium of New York University. During three days of sessions, scholars from France, Britain, Israel and the United States gave their responses to Hannah Arendt's ideas on philosophy, politics, history and ethics. Excerpts from some of the presentations follow. On Living in America

title: PROGRAMMERS: WRITING THEIR OWN TICKET
description: J UST over a decade ago Joseph Salomon, a high school teacher, became a programmer in the fledgling computer industry. ''It looked like the profession was going places,'' he recalled. ''I entered the market because of the financial lure.''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: DESPITE opposition from some residents, the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation has granted the Community Synagogue in Port Washington a permit that will allow it to sell seven acres of property near Hoffstots Lane in Sands Point for development.

title: Mistakes Have Steinbrenner Seething
description: When the Yankees filed into their clubhouse after a 2-1 loss to the Milwaukee Brewers yesterday, George Steinbrenner was waiting to address them. In no uncertain terms. ''Stupid, stupid, stupid base running,'' St einbrenner, the Yankees'principal owner, had growled on the elevator down from his office following the fourth game of the American Lea gue East playoff. ''Now we're down to the last game. Now we'll see wh o the players are who deserve to be in the playoffs, No. 1, and No. 2, which of these players don't deserve to be Yankees.''

title: NASSAU; KENYON'S TOE SPARKS MASSAPEQUA
description: Once again the talented kicking foot of Floyd (Flip) Kenyon proved the difference, as the Massapequa High School senior booted a field goal and an extra point to lead the Chiefs to a 10-7 Conference I-A victory yesterday over neighborhood rival Berner. The Triumph was the 15th straight for Massapequa, including three this season. Berner dropped its first game in three starts.

title: Samuel Vincent to Wed Miss Hawes
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Keene Hawes of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Lynn Hawes, to Samuel Allen Darlington Vincent, son of Mrs. Edwin Serre Murphy of Fairfield, Conn., and Leigh, Surrey, England, and the late Samuel Mitchell Vincent.

title: TWO WAYS OF LIFE
description: THE BOOK OF LIGHTS By Chaim Potok. 370 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.50. YESTERDAY'S STREETS By Silvia Tennenbaum. 528 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: Speaking Personally; NEIGHBORS, FAR AND NEAR, BUILD A CHURCH
description: COLTS NECK, a quiet, picturesque Monmouth County community long known for its horse farms and expensive homes, is the site of a project common many years ago but unusual today: People building a new church with their own hands.

title: PENN STATE TRIUMPHS BY 38-7
description: Curt Warner rushed for 105 yards and two touchdowns, and Mike Meade went 107 yards and scored a touchdown today to power Penn State over Boston College, 38-7.

title: THE NATION IN SUMMARY
description: They, the Reagan political economists said, were going to be different. But last week, they did what politicians with economic ills often do. With the going getting tough, they got going on the Fed.

title: States News Service
description: WASHINGTON DURING the recent Congressional debate over offshore drilling, Representativ e William J. Hughes, Democrat of Ocean City, seemed unable to mak e up his mind.

title: W.D. Parker, Flier, Dies at 82; Developed First Aviation Fuel
description: W.D. (Billy) Parker, an aviation pioneer who built his first plane before he was 15 and helped develop the first fuel exclusively for airplanes, died Thursday at Presbyterian Medical Center here. He was 82 years old.

title: GREEK VOTERS JUST MIGHT END AN ERA OF CONSERVATIVE RULE
description: For a generation Greece has been held firmly on a Western course by a coalition of conservatives and moderates. That could change with next Sunday's general elections and the repercussions would be felt far beyond Athens.

title: Press Notes
description: The editor of President Reagan's newspaper, worried about deadline problems, is concocting plans to go electronic so that more news can be delivered on time to the Oval Office.

title: JOHN HENRY AND 8-1 TIMELY WRITER WIN
description: Two former claiming horses took home the biggest prizes at Belmont Park yesterday on the richest afternoon in New York racing history. John Henry won the $568,400 Jockey Club Gold Cup and became racing's leading money-earner and probable horse of the year. Timely Writer won the $150,800 Champagne Stakes and became the early favorite for next year's Kentucky Derby.

title: NASSAU COUNTY SHOULD CONSIDER A LEGISLATURE
description: NASSAU County residents are being governed by an illegally constituted County Board of Supervisors, according to the ''one man, one vote'' decision handed down by the Supreme Court almost 20 years ago. Practical as well as legal considerations dictate the need to abolish the board and to replace it with a representative county legislature.

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: Fried Ice Cream To the Editor: Respondents to the letter of Donald M. Kirschenbaum (Travel Section, July 5) have pointed out that your readers could travel to Tokyo, Kowloon and Scottsdale, Ariz., t o enjoy Japanese fried ice cre am. For those living in or visiting New York, ice creamtempura is av ailable at Dan Japanese restaurant near Lincoln Center at 2018 Broad way. I topped off a recent meal there with the desert, and it is bot h unusual and delicious. THOMAS F. HOAR Queens

title: Carol Blazejowski Seeks Free Agency, Sues Gems
description: Carol Blazejowski, one of the stars of the financially ailing Women's Basketball League, is suing the New Jersey Gems for more than $110,000 in back pay and bonuses and is seeking free agent status.

title: HOTEL FACES FIGHT ON ITS LOGO
description: TRENTON THE letters ''CP'' no longer will be associated with this city's only hotel, if one of Canada's largest corporations has its way. More than 125 feet from the ground, the nine-foot-high letters adorning the Capitol Plaza Hotel infringe upon a trademark, Canadian Pacific Ltd., according to a civil lawsuit pending in Federal District Court here. The trademark was registered almost 11 years ago.

title: Dana Ann Poris Married to Robert Matthew Slater
description: Dana Ann Po ris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Poris of Haworthand Loveladie s, N.J., was married in Haworth yesterday to Robert Matthew Slate r, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Slater of New York and Nantucket, Ma ss. Mayor Elias Eliasoff of Closter, N.J., performed theceremony at t he Poris home.

title: NEW CENSUS DATA ADDRESS RACIAL DIVISION IN CITY
description: Black and Hispanic people and other racial or ethnic minorities now make up 48.1 percent of New York City's population, according to new data released by the Census Bureau.

title: 250,000 AT BONN RALLY ASSAIL U.S. ARMS POLICY
description: About 250,000 demonstrators staged a meeting here today to denounce plans by the Atlantic alliance to modernize its nuclear arsenal in Europe. The meeting was marked by accents of German nationalism and attacks on the United States.

title: I regret the need to correct facts, but I don't own a yacht, not even a canoe. I don't own an apartment, much less a $500,000 one. And I am here not to plot my way back to a power and privilege which I never had; I am here because I lost my job to Communism and to Christian-Democratic communitarianism. It is my desire to return, not to the old status quo, but to a new status of peace, freedom and justice.
description: It was in this effort that I accompanied Maj. Roberto D'Aubuisson to Washington, where he was invited, not by me, as Mr. Hoeffel claims, but by the American Legion and the American Security Council.

title: STATE TO TEST 479 ON TOXIC EXPOSURE
description: The State Health Department announced yesterday that it would begin a series of tests this month on people who might have been exposed to toxic chemicals following a fire last Feb. 5 in a state office building in Binghamton.

title: Dr. James LeClair Weds Anne Hall
description: Anne Kerin Hall, daughter of Harry D. Hall of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Mrs. Hall, and Dr. James Michael LeClair, son of Mrs. James Moran of New Glouchest er, Me., and Roger LeCl air of Auburn, Me., weremarried yesterday in Washington. The Rev. Tho mas Dwyer performed the ceremony in the Great Choir of the Washington Cathedral.

title: XAVIER POSTS 27-0 VICTORY
description: Dennis Tobin, a sophomore, passed for three touchdowns, and Samuel Galloway scored twice to lead Xavier of Manhattan to a 27-0 victory over Mount St. Michael yesterday in a Catholic High Schools' Football League interconference game in the Bronx. It was the second victory against one loss for Xavier; Mount St. Michael fell to 1-2.

title: MARTIN'S OAKLAND: HOME SWEET HOME
description: chested and grinning, still sat behind his desk at the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum dispensing wine in paper cups and coffee mugs.

title: No Headline
description: An article Saturday incorrectly identified th e Human Resources Ad- ministrator w ho assigned an inv esti- gation into a suspicious fire to the In- spector General's office rather than to the Bureau of Client Fraud Investigation. It was the former administrator, Stanley Brezenoff.

title: ALCO KEEPS ADDING FAMILY BUSINESSES TO ITS COLLECTION
description: It has been a busy three months for the Alco Standard Corporation. In that time, the $2.2 billion conglomerate, which has built a formidable reputation on its acquisition policy, has added four more companies to its stable, raising the number of its takeovers to 143.

title: Resch Frustrates Ex-Teammates
description: Chico Resch did it. That is what the Islanders were saying following last night's 2-2 tie with the Colorado Rockies in a game that made almost everybody happy.

title: OKLAHOMA INQUIRY: CHANCES IN DOUBT
description: There is an old story in Oklahoma politics about a county commissioner running for re-election who got angry when his opponent promised to end ''the 20 percent kickbacks.''

title: 197 FAMILIES FIGHT TO END WOES OF EVERGLADES LIFE
description: All of them moved a little west when Miami started getting a little crowded, then farther west when the city got more crowded, then over the levee and along the sloughs of the eastern Everglades. Today they are up to their shins in water and rattlesnakes, and the National Guard ferries their children to school in troop transport trucks while flood control authorities contend it serves them right for building in a swamp.

title: SCHOLARS MEET TO LAUD EISENHOWER AS LEADER
description: It surprised no one here during a scholarly three-day conference on Dwight D. Eisenhower that he seems in retrospect a more skillful and attractive statesman than he appeared to many intellectuals during the 1950's and early 60's.

title: RIDER BOARDS BUS WITH LIFT BY PERSISTING
description: There was an standoff on a Manhattan street yesterday between a sparkling new blue and white Transit Authority bus and a handicapped man in a wheelchair who demanded to get aboard. The driver of the General Motors bus, with a flashing sign saying ''wheelchair route,'' insisted that he did not have a key to operate the lift.

title: Miami Scofflaws Get 'Boot' From a Judge
description: Dade County's parking ticket revenues have increased 20 percent, to $350,000 a month, an increase that began after a judge warned scofflaws to pay up or get ''the boot.''

title: Steelers Win, 13-7, Continue Mastery Over Browns
description: The Cleveland Browns made their 12th visit to Pittsburgh's Three Rivers Stadium yesterday and came away with their 12th loss, a 13-7 defeat by the Steelers.

title: No Headline
description: President Reagan's plans to cut funds for the law agency that fights cigarette smuggling and the illegal making of liquor could help organized crime, Federal officials said today.

title: Beth Israel Buys Infirmary Building
description: Beth Israel Medical Center has purchased the former New York Infirmary building next to it at Stuyvesant Square East and East 15th Street and plans to use it for inpatient services.

title: GREEK SOCIALIST PREDICTS A VICTORY FOR HIS PARTY IN NEXT WEEK'S VOTE
description: After the largest rally of a heated campaign, the Socialist leader Andreas Papandreou confiden tly predicted her e today that his party would win ''a big majority'' in next Sunday's general election.

title: ARAFAT CAUSES JAPAN SOME DISCOMFITURE
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, is scheduled to arrive here today to meet with Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki, politicans of all parties and leading Japanese businessmen.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Haitian Patrol Spends Quiet First Day at Sea
description: A Coast Guard cutter patrolling the Windward Passage for boats smuggling illegal Haitians into the United States spent its first full day watching tankers go by without spotting any suspicious vessels, the Coast Guard reported tonight.

title: OPERA: 'PURITANI'S' NEW ELVIRA
description: JUNE ANDERSON made an impressive debut Friday night as Elvira in the New York City Opera's fourth performance this season of Bellini's ''I Puritani,'' galvanizing the scenes in which she took part with her effortless coloratura and touching vocal expressiveness. The intensity of her singing was matched by fine acting, a combination that conveyed quite potently the sentiment Elvira's derangement should possess.

title: Penney, Citicorp
description: The J.C. Penney Company and Citicorp Industrial Credit Inc., a subsidiary of Citicorp, said that they had reached an agreement under which Penney has repurchased its customers' accounts receivables from the Citicorp unit for about $260 million. The retail store chain said that it does not anticipate selling additional receivables in the foreseeable future other than to its wholly-owned finance subsidiary.

title: HOLIDAY TRIMS OFFERINGS
description: Only a handful of ne w debt issues are scheduled for sale in this holiday-short ened week, although investment bankers note that some borrowers mig ht appear quickly if conditions are favorable.

title: U.S.C. LOSS: ANOTHER NO.1 TEAM FALLS
description: As a result of Arizona's 13-10 upset of Southern California, there will undoubtedly be another team ranked No.1 in the nation by the wire service polls this week - either Penn State, which was No. 2 last week and beat Boston College, 38-7, or Texas, which was No.3 last week and beat Oklahoma, 34-14. This will be the fourth team to hold the top spot in the weekly rankings in the six weeks of the season.

title: Going Out Guide
description: SEASONAL

title: Bo oks of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE GATE OF HEAVENLY PEACE: The Chinese and Their Revolution, 1895-1980. By Jonathan D. Spence. Illustrated. 465 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Full Sports Day Around the Area
description: Sports fans in the metropolitan area had a variety of events to choose from yesterday as baseball, football, basketball and horse racing offered attractions.

title: HOWARD F. KOONS
description: Howard F. Koons, retired postmaster of Perth Amboy, N. J., and a former civil engineer with the New Jersey Highway Department, died Saturday at Perth Amboy General Hospital. Mr. Koons, who was a resident of Perth Amboy, was 87 years old.

title: POWER OF TRANSIT UNIONS OVER RULES TO BE CURBED
description: Arthur E. Teele Jr., head of the Federal Urban Mass Transit Administration, told transit operators in Chicago this weekend that he planned to ease a restriction that allows labor unions to impose work rules on local transit systems.

title: CUTBACKS' EFFECT ON MOVE TO END FRAUD DEPLORED
description: President Reagan, who pledged to ''follow every lead, root out every incompetent'' in fighting waste and fraud in government, is calling for a $30 million cut for his chief watchdogs, the inspectors general.

title: HANDS OFF THE MET AND RENATA SCOTTO!
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: 'MAN OF IRON' TELLS OF POLISH UNION'S STRUGGLE
description: ANDRZEJ WAJDA'S ''Man of Iron'' is such an up-to-date report on political events in Poland that one attends to it less as a piece of fiction than as a prime-time television news special. It's not criticism but a statement of fact to describe it as more notable as a political than an artistic achievement. Another fact is that it's an unexpected disappointment, because it is both a continuation and an explanation of Mr. Wajda's extraordinarily fine ''Man of Marble,'' which was made in 1977, but not shown in New York until 1979.

title: CAIRO ABOUNDS WITH RUMORS OF NEW VIOLENCE
description: Reports of continued scatt ered violence following the funeral of President Anwar el-Sadat swept Cairo today, including one that said gunmen sprayed the home of Egyp t's Interior Minister with machine-gun fire, killing a number of hi s bodyguards.

title: CONCERT: SHOSTAKOVICH BY CANADIANS
description: IT is a mystery why the National Arts Center Orchestra of Canada chose to play the Shostakovich Symphony No. 14 at its Carnegie Hall concert Friday night. The Canadians were clean, competent and always on their best musical behavior.

title: Jackson Lives Up To His Nickname
description: Reggie Jackson: ham, egotist, Mr. October, the straw that stirs the drink or whatever one wishes to call him -and he has been called those names and many more in his pyrotechnical 15-year major league career - the man produces, and he produces under pressure.

title: And Rick Cerone Is Still on Trial
description: UP on the Grand Concourse, the thick, gray Bronx County Courthouse towers above the facade of the Yankee Stadium bleachers. But for Rick Cerone, the two landmarks are interchangeable. Even though the 27-year-old catcher hit a home run last night as the Yankees advanced to the American League championship series against the Oakland A's, he remains on trial in George Steinbrenner's courtroom, where the principal owner is both the judge in a powdered wig and the executioner in a hangman's hood.

title: CHRISTIANS DEBATE NEW RIGHT'S VIEWS
description: A meeting of more than 50 clergy, lay people and theological professors here has drawn attention to the difficulty moderate and liberal Christians have in defining their opposition to what they call the ethical absolutism of groups such as the Moral Majority.

title: THEATER: 'FORTY-DEUCE' REWORKED AND RECAST
description: DESPITE the services of a skillful director, Sheldon Larry, and a generally solid cast, Alan Bowne's ''Forty-Deuce'' didn't exactly soar when it first appeared at the Perry Street Theater last March. Though the characters - young 42d Street homosexual hustlers - were capable of odd turns of streetwise wit, the play was imprisoned by its tiresome melodramatic plot and the substitution of sociological platitudes for insight. Now ''Forty-Deuce'' is back again at the Perry Street - somewhat rewritten and entirely recast, under the revamped direction of the talented Tony Tanner, currently represented on Broadway by ''A Taste of Honey.'' The results? Different, but not good.

title: MUSIC: MATA LEADS DALLAS SYMPHONY
description: THE resurrection of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra out of bankruptcy some five years ago now just seems part of the steady economic growth of its native region. But more than money is needed to give a large orchestra life or justify its concert hall, on which construction will begin next year.

title: 5 Dead and 1 Hurt In Jersey Collision
description: A fiery head-on collision killed five young New Jersey residents, including a brother and a sister, and critically injured a sixth person.

title: Briefing
description: R EAGAN aides are furious with former President Jimmy Carter, saying that, unlike Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford, Mr. Carter ignored his place carefully marked by taped X's close to President Reagan, thus disturbing what was planned for photographers as a shoulder-toshoulder ''Mount Rushmore scene'' of solidarity last week as the American mission left for the funeral of Anwar el-Sadat. As the four men gathered outside the White House, Mr. Carter moved off slightly from the group, summoning for an instant in the minds of politically minded viewers the moment at the 1980 Democratic convention when Senator Edward M. Kennedy came forward for a scene of podium harmony with Mr. Carter, but then drew back. Reagan aides insist that each tableau of the regrouping of the Pr esidents had been planned to the inch, and they refuse to believe Mr . Carter's moving slightly apart was anything but deliberate. Th eir rage was compounded at the close of the ceremony when Mr. Ca rter cut across the foreground - in Mr. Reagan's old profession, th at's stealing the spotlight - and went over to the press corps andbe gan shaking hands and saying ''Hi.'' Reporters were surprised, si nce the last they had heard, they were not particular favorites of Mr . Carter. But photographers quickly turned their lenses from the ot her three Presidents to catch Mr. Carter in a smiling scene re miniscent of his working an airport fence at campaign time.

title: BACCALARIUS STEINEM
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN BEATS NO RETREAT IN WAR ON BUREAUCRACY
description: Recently, Edwin Meese 3d came to a Cabinet meeting carrying a small effigy that he identified as a ''bureaucrat doll.''

title: Around the Nation; Vietnam Veteran Cleared In Murder of an In-Law
description: A former marine who blamed delayed combat stress for the shooting of his brother-in-law was found not guilty by reason of insanity last night.

title: Turner Sets Mark In Sydney Hurdles
description: Sam Turner of the United States stole the limelight from such world track and field stars as Henry Rono of Kenya and Steve Ovett of Britain today at the rain-soaked Seiko-Tiger Games by shattering a 25-year-old national record.

title: 3 Killed and 14 Are Wounded In 3 Incidents in Guatemala
description: Gunmen driving past the United States Embassy killed a Guatemalan policeman and bombings and a gun fight left two others dead and 14 wounded, the authorities reported today. The securit y force spokesmen said that assailants firing automatic weapons from several vehicles sped past the embassy last night and killed the 23 -year-old national policeman guarding the building.

title: FOCUS ON KUWAITI INVESTMENTS
description: Thirty years ago Abdullah al-Salim al-Sabah, the Emir of the British Prot e ctorate of Kuwait, signed a new royalty agreement with the Kuwait Oi l Company, the British- and American-owned enterprise that dominate d the Kuwaiti oil scene. Soon he was receiving more than$2.5 million a week.

title: IC Is in Accord
description: IC Industries Inc. announced that it had entered into an agreement with the staff of the Bureau of Competition of the Federal Trade Commission in connection with its offer to acquire the Sunbeam Corporation.

title: NEW SPOT FOR ARAMIS ON TV
description: YOU say you just love romantic films, the kind featuring beautiful, affluent people using bright, contemporary dialogue in rich settings? Well, we have a new flick for you. It is called ''Meetings,'' and it is making its debut this very day.

title: VW to Raise Prices
description: Prices for Volkswagen of America's 1982 vehicles will be an average of 3.4 percent higher than prices for comparable 1981 models, the auto maker said. The increases of $250 per vehicle, reflect ''rising costs of materials, production and distribution'' as well as upgraded equipment on some models, VW said. Base prices for the 1982 models include $5,99 0 for the Rabbit, $6,775for the VW pi ckup, $8,375 for the two-door Jetta and $11,360 for the Vanagan L. Th e 1982 vehicles are to be introduced late this month.

title: HISPANIC PARADE HONORS COLUMBUS EARLY
description: ''Viva la Espana! Viva la Hispanidad! Viva, viva! Arriba!'' Pepita Marcos exhorted the spectators along Fifth Avenue for yesterday's Hispanic Day parade. Clapping her hands, stamping her feet and blowing kisses, the singer-dancer in a troupe from Madrid was working the crowd in a ruffled black flamenco dress, her lace mantilla draped over a comb that seemed a foot high.

title: EXPOS OUST PHILLIES, 3-0
description: Steve Rogers outpitched Steve Carlton today for the second time in a week as the Montreal Expos defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-0, and won the National League's Eastern championship.

title: Seoul's Foreign Debt
description: South Korea's total outstanding foreign debt amounted to $30.3 billion at the end of last August, but it is well within the manageable level, Prime Minister Nam Du ck Woo told Parliament Fr iday. The total breaks down to $18.6 billion in longterm, $60 0 million in medium-term, $8.2 billion in short-term and$2.9 billion in other forms of debt, he said.

title: WRITERS BACK PROPOSAL TO FORM NATIONAL UNION
description: Participants in the first American Writers Congress last night approved a resolution endorsing the principle of a national union of writers.

title: Hamilton Winner At Skate America
description: Scott Hamilton and Vikki de Vries, both of Colorado, took individual gold medals as the Skate America competitio n ended yesterday.

title: Bedding Change: From Sealy to Serta
description: Roy B. Unger, a 60-year-old bedding industry executive, has joined Serta Inc., one of the nation's largest bedding manufacturers, as president. He succeeds Alan Goff, who resigned.

title: Rangers Puzzled by Stumbling Start
description: The Rangers seem confident that since nothing human lasts forever, even on ice, neither will their losing streak.

title: Francine Stern and Michael W. Millican Married
description: Francine Stern, an editor with the network news division of the ABC, was married yesterday to Michael W. Millican, business-news editor of The Associated Press. Rabbi Bonni e Steinberg, who is with the chaplain's office at H ofstra University, performed the ceremony at Once Upon A Stove, a Manhanttan restaurant.

title: ANDREW SILK WEDS NANCY JO PERLMAN
description: The marriage of Nancy Jo Perlman, an editor at G.P. Putnam's Sons, to Andrew David Silk, editor of the editorial page of Greenwich (Conn.) Time, took place at Temple Sholom of West Essex in Cedar Grove, N.J., yesterday.

title: RAIDERS SUFFER 3D STRAIGHT SHUTOUT,27-0
description: The situation in Oakland is getting serious. The Raiders were shut out yesterday for the third consecutive week, a club record. This time the loss was by 27-0 to the Chiefs in Kansas City. And nobody seems to know what is wrong with the defending National Football League champions

title: HAIG SAYS THE U.S. IS READY TO SPEED ARMS AID TO EGYPT
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States was ready to speed up the delivery of arms to Egypt and would take part in a ''very extensive joint exercise'' with Egyptian forces next month.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: EXECUTIVES SEE STRONG ECONOMY
description: Executives of the nation's biggest companies spoke of brighter days for the United States economy at a meeting here of the Business Council, but underlying their sunny disposition was pessimism about the near term.

title: Priest, 64, Injured In Church Robbery
description: A 64-year-old priest was knocked unconscious in the rectory of an East Harlem church and robbed of $1,500, the receipts of a church bingo game, the police said.

title: Around the Nation; California Renews Drive To Eradicate Fruit Flies
description: Crews set up Mediterranean fruit fly traps today and stripped trees in residential areas in a renewed eradication campaign sparked by the finding of a sixth fruit fly in the La Puente area.

title: Around the World; Bush's Arrival Ignites Santo Domingo Protest
description: Dominican troops fired tear gas and warning shots to disperse demonstrators protesting the presence in the Dominican Republic of Vice President Bush, who arrived today on a 24-hour official visit.

title: Saucy Susan Plans West Coast Campaign
description: Saucy Susan Products of Briarcliff, N.Y., has decided to end the advertising fast, which has kept it without that form of communication for two years. It has enlisted one of the big names in the agency business, Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver (they do not come much bigger), to help it introduce its sauces on the West Coast as part of a three-year plan to go national.

title: UNION YIELDING 'GIVEBACKS' TO EMPLOYERS AT RISING RATES
description: Confronted with management assertions that jobs, plants and perhaps the viability of industries are at stake, labor unions are agreeing at what appears to be a record rate to reopen contracts and to accept reduced wages and benefits for their members.

title: AN OIL TAX CAN BAIL OUT REAGAN'S BUDGET
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets and Williams Seem at Impasse
description: It was billed as the return of Julius Erving to the Nassau Coliseum, where he spent three seasons with the New York Nets in the American Basketball Association. But what was most intriguing about the New Jersey Nets' 107-93 exhibition victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight was what was happening off the court.

title: DR. CHARLES SAFRAN, INTERNIST, MARRIES DONNA JEAN BROWN
description: Donna Jean Brown, an administrator of outpatient services at St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Boston, was married yesterday to Dr. Charles Safran, a resident in internal medicine at the Boston Veterans Administration Medical Center.

title: LIFE AFTER THE LOSS OF WEIGHT
description: O BESE people who lose large amounts of weight often find themselves facing new problems, the least of which is buying new clothes. One of the thornier problems, according to the formerly fat and the doctors who work with them, is coping with changing relationships with their spouses, children and co-workers.

title: White Hits Homer
description: Roy White, the former New York Yankee outfielder, hit his 13th home run of the season, a two-run shot, as his team, the Yomiuri Giants, and the Chunichi Dragons played to a 3-3, 12-inning tie in a Japanese League game today.

title: 18 From Council of Churches Plan November Visit to China
description: An 18-member delegation from the National Council of Churches will visit China next month, the first group of United States church leaders to be officially invited by China's two major Christian organizations.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1981
description: International Arms deliveries to Egypt will be stepped up, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said in Cairo, adding that the United States will take part in a ''very extensive'' joint security exercise with Egyptian forces next month. Mr. Haig expressed confidence in President-designate Hosni Mubarak but said that American officials felt that Egypt and the neighboring Sudan would be vulnerable to outside interference in the coming months. (Page A1, Column 6.) A U.S.-P.L.O. dialogue is critical to a lasting peace in the Middle East, former Presidents Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter said during an interview aboard an Air Force jet returning from Cairo. But both former Presidents stressed that the Palestine Liberation Organization would have to agree to accommodations with Israel. The former Presidents, together with former President Richard M. Nixon, were part of the American delegation to the funeral of President Anwar el-Sadat. (A1:4.)

title: CHAMBER: 35TH ANNIVERSARY AT JUILLIARD
description: THE Juilliard String Quartet has reach ed an age at which most individuals begin to show style and maturity, but these qualities appeared long ago in the ensemble's playing. Appropriately, the quartet, led by Robert Mann, founding first v iolinist, celebrated its 35th anniversary Saturday night with a pe rformance of exceptionalbrilliance.

title: MOSCOW ASSERTS U.S. IS MEDDLING IN CAIRO AFFAIRS
description: The Soviet Union, in an unusual ''statement to the Government of the United States,'' said today that events in Egypt affect Soviet security and accused Washington of applying ''gross'' and ''unlawful'' pressures on that country. The strongl y worded communique was the first official Soviet statement on Egyptian affairs since the assassination of President Anwar el-Sada t last Tuesday. However, it did not mention the assassination .

title: DISASTER PLAN FOR NINE MILE POINT IS CRITICIZED
description: The ability of New York State and local governments to respond to a nuclear accident at the Nine Mile Point plant near Oswego has numerous deficiencies, according to the regional office of the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

title: An Oil Tax Can Bail Out Reagan's Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Hotline Involves Family Violence
