description: ALBANY (AP) - Victims of domestic violence can get help from a statewide 24-hour toll-free hotline now in service. The opening of the hotline coincides with the state's observance of Domestic Violence Awareness Week.

title: Shooting Suspect Linked to Sect
description: A Jamaican man su spected of shooting a police officer fi ve times has a criminal record and links to the Rastafarian religio us sect, detectives said.

title: U.S. MIDEAST POLICY
description: When Jimmy Carter in January 1980 committed us to defense of the Persian Gulf region, many people who were to join the Reagan Administration criticized him for giving an unspecific commitment without the military forces necessary to carry it out. The guarantee given Oct. 1 by President Reagan to Saudi Arabia, which, he said, we would ''not permit to be an Iran,'' can be criticized on the same grounds, with greater justification.

title: Girl, 15, Is Killed In L.I. Accident
description: An off-duty New York City firefighter was charged with drunken driving in the death of a 15-year-old girl, the police said.

title: SLAIN DRIVER'S CO-WORKERS RARELY DENY TRANSFERS
description: Bus drivers on the Brooklyn route where a fellow worker was shot dead Saturday by a passenger whose request for a transfer he had refused said yesterday that they were often threatened and harassed in such disputes.

title: BEVERLY BULLOCK WED TO DR. MITCHELL KAHN
description: Beverly Campbell Bullock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Woods Bullock of Glen Head, L.I., and Wolfeboro, N.H., was married in New York yesterday to Dr. Mitchell Kahn, son of Mrs. Irving Simon Kahn of Chicago and the late Mr. Kahn. Walter Lawton, leader of the Westchester Ethical Humanist Society, performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion.

title: HOLLYWOOD MOVES 2,400 MILES TO THE WEST
description: HOLLYWOOD THE Hollywood beach colony has moved 2,400 miles farther west. Or, at least, the first wave of movie-industry immigrants is splashing against Hawaii's dazzling white shores.

title: News Analysis
description: Although Egypt's new leader, Hosni Mubarak, has made every effort since the death of President Anwar el-Sadat to convey a sense of continuity and calm in Egypt, the nation is nevertheless experiencing unease and foreboding.

title: OLD CHARLESTON MAKES ROOM FOR NEW CITY CENTER
description: On a block of historic Meeting Street, businesses that had been in the same families for generations are vacant and 19th-century warehouses are soon to be demolished, making way for the proposed Charleston Center, a $60 million complex with 424 hotel rooms, 500 parking spaces, 72,000 square feet of retail space and conference facilities for 800 people.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL CLEARED ON ROLE IN $230,000 CONTRACT AWARD
description: The Treasury Department said today that Norman B. Ture, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Tax and Economic Affairs, did not profit from a Treasury contract for an economic forecasting model that Mr. Ture had developed and partly owned.

title: GIANTS OVERPOWER CARDINALS, 34-14
description: The Giants, who looked so uninspired, so uninvolved and so untalented in last Sunday's 27-14 loss to the G reen Bay Packers, rebounded today with a game teams dream about. They thrashed the St. Louis Cardinals, 34-14, and in theprocess unvei led a folk hero in their new fullback, Rob Carpenter.

title: Bell Defense Is Restricted
description: Current and former Federal officials may provide only limited testimony if called as defense witnesses in the trial of the Government's antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, a Federal judge said Friday.

title: Officer Saves Man on Bridge
description: A police officer narrowly avoided being pulled from a Mississippi River bridge after he handcuffed himself to a man who was threatening to jump, the police said. Officer John Gillespie was credited with saving Orlando Peterson, 29 years old, of Gretna.

title: Mann First on L.I.
description: Charlie Mann of the West Point Track Club registered a 240-yard victory over his teammate, Bill Estes, today in The Athletics Congress national 25-kilometer road-racing championship at Eisenhower Park.

title: In Search of a Not-So-Literary Antecedent
description: A comic book collector out there could be sitting on a sleeper. The comic book tells the story of Napoleon's kidnapping of Pope Pius VII in 1809, and somebody wants a copy pretty ''I'd pay $10,000 for that comic book - if I had the mon ey,'' said Edward Sheehan, who just may be getting the cash to back u p his offer.

title: Webster Is Getting A New Opportunity
description: Before the start of the Maurice Stokes Memorial Game last August, Red Auerbach, the president and general manager of the Boston Celtics and the coach of one of the teams, told his players, ''Get the ball down low to Marvin Webster and take it from there.''

title: INMATES' DEATHS IN TEXAS LINKED TO INFERIOR CARE
description: A hospital for Texas prison inmates is staffed by untrained personnel amid inadequate sanitary conditions, and some prisoners have died as a result of shortcomings in the care, according to a doctor's report.

title: RAMS TOP FALCONS IN LAST MINUTE,37-35
description: Frank Corral, LeRoy Irvin and Jeff Rutledge werethe key playe rs today for the Los Angeles Rams, who beat the Atlanta Falcons, 37-3 5. The winning points came on a 25-yard field goal by Corral in the last minute.

title: FOR MAYOR'S OPPONENTS, FUNDS ARE ALMOST GONE
description: As the New York City mayoral campaign enters its final three weeks, Mayor Koch's four major opponents are severely short of campaign funds. Among them, they have raised about $30,000 for the Nov. 3 election, according to their latest campaign statements, while the Mayor has more than $400,000.

title: ELSIE MEYER BRIDE OF HENRY FEUERSTEIN
description: At the Fift h Avenue Synagogue yesterday Elise A. Meyer, daughter ofArlene Meyer Cohen of Greensboro, N.C., and New York and the late John H. Meyer of Norwich, Conn., was married to Henry I. Feuerstein, son of Dr. an d Mrs. Sidney S. Feuerstein of New York and Palm Be ach, Fla. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Nissan Schulman, assisted by Cantor Joseph Malovany.

title: Question BoxS.
description: QUESTION: In a National Hockey League game, Player A is serving a minor penalty when the referee raises his arm to signal a delayed penalty on a teammate. However, the opposition scores before the shorthanded team can gain control of the puck. What is the standing of the two penalties?

title: MIDEAST REALITIES
description: Anwar el-Sadat provided an alibi for Palestinians and other Arabs who opposed the peace process that he initiated. He gave Israel and America an excuse for their reluctance to build on that agreement, and irritated many Egyptians who believed in peace with Israel but rejected the autocratic way i t was implemente d. Now, they have no alibis or excuses for failing to make pe ace.

title: A Need for Faith at Hunt's Point
description: Washington's decision not to guarantee a $12.4 million loan stymies, possibly forever, New York City's efforts to expand the Hunt's Point regional produce market. The Federal Economic Development Administration defends its action reasonably: there is no assurance that the loan can be paid back. But of course if there were such assurance, no guarantee would be needed.

title: TRADE STORMS ARE BREWING
description: WASHINGTON THE dollar's rise over the past year, already pinching exports and sucking in more imports, is adding to th e woes of agriculture, steel,autos, chemic als, textiles and other foreign trade sectors as furtherweakness deve lops in the domestic economy.

title: BERGDORF IS PLANNING RENOVATION
description: Bergdorf Goodman will begin a major renovation of its Fifth Avenue store next year that is expected to increase se lling space by 50 percent and s ales between 15 percent and 20 percent in the first fullyear followin g its completion.

title: AN INDIAN CHIEF GOES TO RIO TO BATTLE FOR HIS PEOPLE
description: In recent years he would not talk to white people without f irst turning on the tape recorder that he always carrie d to capture what he said were their inevitable lies.

title: News An alysis
description: For Britain's Social Democratic Party, last week provided a few bracing brushes with reality, in the form of questions and conflicts, that the new party will have to face as it moves closer to contesting its first general election.

title: Needham Creates Post Of Agency Media Head
description: Richard C. Anderson, 50 years old, who has been executive vice president and director of media resources at Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, is returning to New York, where he will fill the newly created position of corporate director of media and programming for the agency. He continues with the proud title of executive vice president and also moves on to the board.

title: MISDIRECTED CANDOR OF THE SOVIET EMBASSY'S SCIENCE ATTACHE
description: To the Editor : As a partic ipant in the meeting at the National Institutes of Health addres sed by the Soviet Embassy's science attache, Dr. Igor Makarov, I wo uld like to comment on the nature of the ''candor'' attributed to him (news story Sept. 26).

title: Dodgers Win, 4-0, Take Western Crown
description: This year, three was enough. After coming close to overwhelming the Astros last October, the Dodgers did it today as Jerry Reuss outpitched Nolan Ryan in a 4-0 victory.

title: A New Chief for I.M.S.
description: Lars H. Ericson, 46 years old, has been named chairman, president and chief executive officer of I.M.S. International, which provides publishing, market research, direct mail, preclinical testing and other services to the medical field.

title: The Morning After the Tax Revolt
description: The great American tax revolt hasn't died, but it is sputtering - done in by hard times, and also by its own success. Already there are signs of counterrevolution in the form of tax increases at the state and local level.

title: OLD POLICE HEADQUARTERS DUE FOR REBIRTH AS HOTEL
description: New York City and a major Canadian developer have reached a tentative agreement to convert the vacant, vandal-scarred former Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan into a 125-room lu x ury hotel with a restaurant, theater and other community facilities.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Way Down South in Jersey
description: A separate state for the southern counties of New Jersey? An odd idea, yet last November, six of eight South Jersey counties placed a nonbinding referendum on the ballot declaring that they wanted to secede.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 12, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Reagan Library Is Proposed
description: Stanford University is interested in housing Ronald Reagan's Presidential papers at its Hoover Institution, university officials said Friday. The institution already houses papers from Mr. Reagan's two terms as Governor of California and from his 1976 and 1980 Presidential campaigns. Richard Burress, deputy director of the institute, has informally met with Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to the President, to discuss the university's offer.

title: More Pretrial Releases Recommended by U.S.
description: A new Government study on the pretrial activities of criminal defendants found that 84 percent of those surveyed were not arrested a second time while awaiting trial.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Soviet Government resolutely condemns the U.S. attempts at interfering in any way in the internal affairs of the Arab Republic of Egypt.

title: Charles Shapiro Weds Lois A. Smith, Lawyer
description: Lois A. Smith, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David J. Smith of Upper Nyack, N.Y., was married yesterday to Charles Alexander Shapiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul A. Shapiro of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Isaak performed the ceremony at the Shapiro home.

title: Former G.E.  Aide to Head Spun-Off Uni- t
description: In 1971, two researchers at the General Electric Company took its superconductive products operation, which the giant corporation wanted to spin off, and founded the Intermagnetics General Corporation. Now one of them, Paul S. Swartz, 47 years old, is succeeding the other, Carl H. Rosner, 52, as chief executive officer of the compan y, the headquarters of which are in Guiderland, N.Y., near Albany.

title: A DEMOCRAT'S SWITCH TO G.O.P. SETS OFF TREMORS
description: Representative Bob Stump is hardly a household name, even in the House. Since his election to Congress in 1974, the Arizona Democrat has seldom sponsored a bill or spoken on the floor. By his own account, he has held precisely one news conference, and that was two weeks ago.

title: Bridge: Experts Split on Meaning Of a 2 No-Trump Overcall
description: Tournament players are virtually unanimous in their treatment of a two no-trump overcall after a major-suit opening. They use it as ''unusual'' to show length in the minor suits, an idea proposed by Alvin Roth of New York a quarter of a century ago.

title: AMANDA SWINNERTON KIRKPATRICK WED
description: Amanda Swinnerton Kirkpatrick and Willard Dwight Dickerson Jr. were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Reading, Pa. The Rev. Walter Krieger performed the ceremony.

title: 49ers Rout Cowboys
description: Joe Montana's passes to Freddie Solomon propelled San Francisco to an early 24-0 lead over Dallas, and the 49ers romped to a 45-14 victory today, handing the Cowboys their worst defeat in 11 years.

title: U.S. SALE OF SILVER; USERS SET
description: CHRISTMAS will arrive this Wednesday for silver users, hoarders and speculators. Oct. 14 is when the General Services Administration, complying with a Congressional mandate, will begin selling most of the nation's remaining hoard of silver in mimimum lots of 8,000 ounces. It will be the first such Federal sale since 1970.

title: Ballesteros Takes Golf From Crenshaw, 1 Up
description: Severiano Ballesteros of Spain, after trailing most of the day, edged Ben Crenshaw of the United States by 1 up in a 36-hole duel today to win the Suntory World Match Play Golf Championship.

title: Around the World; Iranian Radio Announces Execution of 82 Leftists
description: The Teheran radio announced today that 82 people whom it identified as leftists were executed last night in Iran.

title: Foreign Affairs; GOOD NEWS FROM PERU
description: In depressing days, Peru is a place of encouraging news and enthusiasm. President Fernando Belaunde Terry, fairly elected with a whopping vote after 12 years of military dictatorship, puts his goal tersely.

title: Sports World Specials; Rage Review
description: Sonny Jurge nsen was statistically one of the great passers in the history of th e National Football League. In 18 years with the Philadelphia Eagles and Washington Redskins, he completed 2,433 passes for 32 ,224 yards and 255 touchdowns. In the alltime rankings, Jurgensen is listed third behind Otto Graham and Roger Staubach.

title: AIR TRAVEL DELAYS TOOK JUMP OCT. 1-8
description: Significant air travel delays in the United States, which late in September occurred at triple the rate that existed before the strike by air traffic controllers, jumped to more than five times the prestrik e rate for the first week of October.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Flagler System Inc., Palm Beach, Fla., has appointed Stayton Addison president.

title: A's Keep Eye on Yanks
description: The Oakland A's players and their wives spent the afternoon today clustered around four television sets at a restaurant near the airport, watching the fifth game of the Yankees-Brewers playoff and waiting to learn who their opponent would be in the American League championship series.

title: Packers Shuffle Top Management
description: Judge Robert J. Parins, vice president of the Green Bay Packers, was given significant additional duties today in the first major change in the National Football League club's corporate structure i n nearly 2 5 years.

title: Around the World; Soviet Mechanic Invades U.S. Embassy in Moscow
description: A shotgun-carrying 42-year-old Soviet mechanic, driving his car wildly past Soviet security guards, entered the United States Embassy compound today, where he surrendered to marine guards.

title: NOW MEETING TURNS TO RAISING FUNDS FOR RIGHTS PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 11 - The National Organization for Women, at its annual conference here where the atmosphere reflects part political campaign and part revival meeting, is launching a last-ditch drive to salvage the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: Magazine Survey Finds Earnings Measure Falls
description: A Magazine Publishers Association earnings survey of 114 publications showed lower pretax operating profit as a percentage of revenues in 1980 than in the two previous years.

title: UNIONS FIGHT TAKEOVER OF A CONRAIL COMMUTER LINE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Two groups of rail employees are fighting a move by the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority to assume control of one of its commuter rail lines that is now run by Conrail.

title: CHEAP FIREWOOD BECOMING SCARCE
description: Bargain firewood, for heating a home or for just an occasional cheery blaze in the drawing room, is increasingly difficult to come by this year as access to traditional sources on public lands in the New York metropolitan area is being limited.

title: Around the World; Paper Links Saboteurs To Raid on Iraqi A-Plant
description: Israel's bombing attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor in Baghdad in June may have been a cover for explosives set inside the plant by undercover Israeli agents, The Sunday Times reported today. Quoting uni dentified Italian technicians who it said were employed at the reacto r when it was attacked by Israeli jets June 7, the papersaid the air attack may have been nothing more than a cover for an operation by saboteurs inside the complex.

title: PHILADELPHIA TEACHERS ARE URGED TO DEFY COURT ORDER TO END STRIKE
description: Union leaders today urged the Philadelphia School District's 22,000 striking teachers and aides to disobey a back-to-work order, even though they could be found in contempt of court and could lose their jobs.

title: ANALYSTS DIFFER OVER OUTLOOK
description: IN describing a bull that is sensed but not seen, Wall Street analysts are sketching outlines of a hoped-for rising market that differ in several important respects.

title: BENEFIT CUTS TO HURT SOUTH'S POOR, STUDY SAYS
description: The Reagan Administration's ''new federalism '' and its attendant cuts in social and welfare programs will force the South's poor, even those who are employed, deeper into poverty, acording to a prominent Southern research organization.

title: Conservatism, Privacy and Abortion
description: Pity the New Right. It finally gets its man in the White House and he appoints a Supreme Court Justice with moderate views on abortion. Even worse, he seems to care more about the economy and Awacs than a constitutional ban on abortion.

title: NORTH JERSEY'S A BATTLEGROUND FOR FLORIO AND KEAN
description: Both major candidates for Governor of New Jersey concentrated their campaign efforts today on the main battleground of the election - the northern part of the state and two of its most populous counties, Essex and Hudson. But they had somewhat different ends in mind.

title: Output Up, China Says
description: The value of China's industrial output in September climbed 5.7 percent from September 1980, the labor union newspaper, Worker's Daily, reported Friday.

title: Waltrip Captures 5 00-Miler in Buick
description: Darrell Waltrip won the National 500 stock car race today at Charlotte Motor Speedway for his third straight Grand National victory.

title: EMPLOYERS SEEK TO STEM ABUSE IN USE OF PHONES
description: A legal researcher's friends phone her ''free'' on her employer's WATS line. A bookkeeper starts each workday by dialing for his horoscope. An accountant calls Florida during his lunch hour.

title: TV: MILLER DIRECTS 'OTHELLO'
description: BEGINNING the fourth season of a six-year project, the BBC's mammoth undertaking, ''The Shakespeare Plays,'' settles comfortably into one of the most prominent chestnuts in the repertory. Tonight at 8 o'clock, on WNET-TV, and running for three and a half hours, the offering is ''Othello,'' directed by Jonathan Miller, starting his second season as executive producer, and starring Anthony Hopkins in the title role, Bob Hoskins as Iago and Penelope Wilton as Desdemona.

title: CENTERPIECE OF ENERGY FAIR
description: This five-level, steel-framed globe tops the Sunsphere, under construction in Knoxville, Tenn., for Energy Expo '82. This edition of a world's fair, the first since 1974, will open May 1, 1982.

title: YANKS RALLY TO BEAT BREWERS, 7-3, FOR DIVISION TITLE
description: Perhaps the Yankees were only teasing their boss. Perhaps they knew all along that they would win. Whatever, after squandering a two-game lead and prompting an angry clubhouse visit from the owner, George Steinbrenner, they advanced to the American League pennant playoff last night.

title: REAGAN ARMS POLICY SAID TO RELY HEAVILY ON COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Reagan Administration's plan to spend $18 billion on strategic military communications over the next five years is intended to provide the United States with a far more effective and flexible capacity to wage nuclear war, according to senior Administration officials.

title: SHOEMAKER SCORES WITH 2-1 LOVE SIGN
description: Bill Shoemaker, who displayed his skill at coming from behind to win Saturday's Jockey Club Gold Cup on John Henry, gave an exhibition of how to win on the lead yesterday by riding Love Sign to victory in the $218,500 Beldame Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: PROTECTING THE SAUDIS FROM DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Newly Hired Purolator Driver Missing With $700,000 Cash
description: The Scottsdale police were searching today for the driver of an armored van who they said disappeared with at least $700,000 yesterday, less than two weeks after going to work for Purolator Armored Inc.

title: CARTER AND FORD SAY U.S. AND P.L.O. WILL HAVE TO TALK
description: Former Presidents Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter, in an interview aboard an Air Force jet returning from Egypt, said that the United States would eventually have to negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Around the Nation; Pinta Wreckage Believed Discovered in Bahamas
description: The Pinta, one of three small ships Christopher Columbus guided to the New World, may have been found in the Bahamas, a Washington-based group says.

title: 43 Hurt as Stands Collapse
description: Forty-three members of a high school band were injured yesterday when a set of makeshift bleachers collapsed during a marching band competition. Thirty-three members of the New Philadelphia High School band were treated at local hospitals for minor abrasions, possible fractures and back injuries, according to Richard Mueller, acting Division Four fire chief. About 10 other band members were injured but did not require hospital treatment.

title: IN THE LAND OF HORSES AND FOXES, MONEY AND PRIVACY
description: Amid spacious green lawns dressed with flowers and hedges, the Richard M. Nixons have moved into a community of prosperous executives, bankers, lawyers and brokers -mostly Republicans. It is a peaceful town - a town with no sidewalks, no street lights, no water mains, no sewers and not many children.

title: VISA'S MOVE WORRIES GERMAN BANKS
description: West German banks are regrouping to fend off a wave of American-style credit cards after a marketing coup by the last of the big consumer cards to penetrate this closely guarded market.

title: LAS VEGAS IS BETTING ON ITS SPORTS FUTURE
description: owner of an advertising agency. The first big sporting event he can remember in the city was an exhibition baseball game in the spring of 1955 between the American League champion Cleveland Indians and the National League champion New York Giants.

title: BRONCOS 27, LIONS 21
description: Craig Morton passed for three Denver (5-1) touchdowns to offset Billy Sims's 185-yard, two-touchdown performance.

title: Expos Ignore Fans' Salute
description: PHILADELPHIA BEFORE the game, citizens of the City of Brotherly Love gathered behind the vi sitors' dugout in Veterans Stadium and saluted the Montreal Expo s in brotherly and loving tones: ''Choke! Choke!'' This was a comrade ly reference to the Expos' two defeats here Friday and Saturday afte r having taken a lead of two victories to none in Montreal.

title: LAND BOOM FADES AFTER MX DECISION
description: In the small town of Milford, one of the capitals of the Western Utah desert, many of the 1,500 residents were crestfallen last week when President Reagan eliminated the region from Administration plans for basing the MX missile system.

title: JETS HOLD OFF PATRIOTS, 28-24
description: With their players jumping and cheering on the sideline as excitedly as their fans at Shea Stadium, the Jets escaped yesterday with a 28-24 victory over the New England Patriots.

title: Reluctant Artist Ventures Back Into Public Eye
description: Sam Glankoff is a retiring sort, so retiring, in fact, that when an exhibition of the 87-year-old artist's ''print paintings'' opened at the Graham gallery on Madison Avenue the other night, there were plenty of Glankoff relatives on hand, but no Sam.

title: PACIFIC ISLES NEAR AUTONOMY
description: Negotiations on the fut ure political status of the American-administered trust territory of Micronesia appear to be close to an end following the Reagan Administ ration's acceptance of plans to make the three strategic Pacific Isl and groups autonomous.

title: EXCERPTS FROM AN INTERVIEW WITH FORD AND CARTER ON THE FUTURE OF EGYPT
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a news conference held last night by former Presidents Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter on their flight from Cairo to Washington, as made public by the White House:

title: DEBORAH COHEN IS BRIDE
description: Deborah Lynn Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Cohen of York, Pa., was married there yesterday to Jeremy Davis Spingarn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Spingaran of Washington.

title: THE STATE OF KIM
description: A visitor to the Democatic People's Republic of Korea quickly learns that North Koreans are proud of their ''workers' paradise'' and its economic accomplishments. It was also clear, however, that they want a new relationship with their old archenemy, the United States. North Korea is thus a pasticcio of anomalies, made more obscure by the regime's secrecy about basic facts and by the standard guided tours.

title: FLOATING FACTORY IN ARGENTINA
description: The world's first floating petrochemical plant has successfully docked here after an e ight-week ocean voyage from its construction cradle in Japan.

title: Kevin Porter Hurt
description: Kevin Porter, a guard for the Washington Bullets, tore the Achilles tendon in his left leg during practice today and may miss the full season, a team spokesman said. Mark Pray, the spokesman, said the 30-year-old Porter would have to undergo surgery at George Washington Hospital in nearby Washington.

title: DROP SEEN IN SHORT-TERM RATE
description: Lower short-term interest rates are widely expected in the credit markets, though participants disagree about the extent of the decline or how much it will help reduce long-term interest rates.

title: INMATE SHOOTS INMATE IN CITY JAIL
description: An inmate in the Brooklyn House of Detention was seriously wounded last night when another inmate shot him in the side with a pistol that had somehow been smuggled into the jail, the Correction Department said.

title: Soviet Ships Visit Vietnam
description: A Soviet flotilla arrived at Da Nang in central Vietnam and was greeted by thousands of Vietnamese, the Hanoi radio said yesterday. The broadcast, monitored here, said several Vietnamese naval officers and nearly 3,000 civilians welcomed the fleet in driving rain. No other details were provided.

title: Chemical Waste Shifted After Fire
description: Crews working in a factory damaged by fire are expected to finish removing 500 to 800 barrels of chemical waste to a safe area by this week, authorities say.

title: I.R.A. ADMITS PART IN AMBUSH BOMBING
description: At a London hospital, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain visits army bandsmen wounded Saturday when a booby-trapped van exploded near their bus. Yesterday the Irish Republican Army too k responsibility . A bystander died and more than 50 people were injured.

title: CAN THE NIGHT OF GOBLINS AND GHOSTS BE FAR AWAY?
description: With Halloween only weeks away, this 4-year-old youngster got into the ''spirit'' of the season by drawing a pumpkin yesterday in the sand at a playground in Washington Square Park in Manhattan. The weekend's glorious autumn weather should continue today, with more sunshine and temperatures ranging up to 60 degrees.

title: Losing Is Strange for Faust
description: Before this season, Gerry Faust could take the list of plays out of his back pocket and go home in his sweater and w indbreaker. There was never a need to dress up after a game. Of cour se, all that has changed. As he sat in a television studio last n ight, his dark blue suit and tie were appropriate for a wake. An Iris h wake.

title: Hospital Panel to Investigate 2d Death After Minor Surgery
description: A second Philadelphia woman who lapsed into a coma after a minor operation has died, and the hospital said yesterday it would form a committee to investigate.

title: Index; International
description: Indian chief goes to Rio to battle for his people A2 Arafat's visit is causing the Japa- nese some embarrassment A3 Greek Socialist predicts victory A4 Around the World A5 Talk of Warsaw: Dread winter approaches A6 Pacific islands near autonomy A18 Government/Politics Welfare cuts will push Southern poor deeper in poverty A15 A udit critici zes bookkeeping of Emergency Medical Service B8 Washington Talk Briefing A14 Democrat's defection to G.O.P. sents tremor through capital A14 Reagan continues his war against the bureaucrats A14 The Calendar A14 SportsMonday Baseball: Yankees beat Brewer- sto win American East playoff C1

title: ELIZABETH KLEIN MARRIED
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Anne Klein, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lester Klein of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Joel Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Baker of Worcester, Mass., took place yesterday at Temple Israel Center in White Plains. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony. The bride's father is a dermatoligist in Yonkers. Mr. Baker is a vice president of Norman Baker Auto Sales in Worcester, of which his father is president.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1981; The Economy
description: Corporate leaders are talking about brighter days under the Reagan Administration's economic plan, but they are somewhat pessimistic about the near term. They said at a meeting of the Business Council that they were also not yet ready to commit larger amounts of money for capital investment. (Page D1.)

title: Wedding Plans for Robert Kennedy Jr.
description: They haven't set the date or picked the place, but Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Emily Black have settled on each other. The couple, who met as students at the University of Virginia law school, plan to marry next year.

title: Miss Stacy Wins
description: Hollis Stacy made a seven-foot birdie putt on the first extra hole of a four-way playoff and won the $150,000 Inamori Classic today at the Almaden Golf and Country Club.

title: OPEC Sees Price Stability
description: Subroto, president of OPEC, said that the group did not anticipate any increase in the price of its oil during 1982, which would mean a decline in real terms.

title: CBS CABLE STARTS CULTURAL TV SERVICE TONIGHT
description: The opening night for CBS Cable includes a one-hour musical created by Elizabeth Swados based on the poetry of William Blake and starring an ensemble of eight children; an interview with Isaac Stern; a report on unusual tax shelters, in which Mike Nichols talks about his investment in Arabian horses, and a drama written for television by John Osborne starring Alec Guinness.

title: COLUMBUS DAY
description: Today is Columbus Day. Following are holiday schedules: Parade - Columbus Day Parade will begin at noon.

title: BARYSHNIKOV AND FRIENDS IN WASHINGTON GALA
description: If the Washington Ballet was interested in making a splash this weekend, it certainly succeeded. The headliner was the guest appearance of Mikhail Baryshnikov and a contingent of American Ballet Theater members in the first public showing of a new ballet by Choo San Goh, the Washington Ballet's assistant director.

title: SLOPPY RECORDS IN HOSPITAL UNIT CITED BY GOLDIN
description: The New York City Comptroller has warned the Emergency Medical Service that its sloppy record-keeping could jeopardize the agency's continued receipt of Federal and state grants.

title: FAMILIES DEAL WITH CHRONIC ILLNESS
description: The problem for Iris and Howard Meadow, as they look back on it now, wasn't so much that their infant son, Ian, had acute hemophilia. Of course, this had been devastating to them at first. But then they found ways to cope with the baby's episodes of bleeding, and they were learning more every day. What seemed much more disturbing was that they were fighting so frequently.

title: The Talk of Warsaw
description: The days are getting shorter and the skies are already a forbidding gray. There is a bite in the wind as it sweeps through the trees, blowing orange and yellow leaves into gutters and pinning them against the fences of empty fields. The horse-drawn wooden carts a re piled high with hay.

title: Abroad at Home; BACK TO NIXONISM
description: Imagine it: Richard Nixon among those representing the United States at a solemn international occasion, and everyone acting as if he were respectable. We really have come to accept anything. Or perhaps it was a sense of delicacy about the Sadat funeral that led Americans to mute what many felt at Mr. Nixon's presence: revulsion.

title: GIANTS WILL PLACE PRIORITY ON PASSING
description: Having run for 198 yards against the St. Louis Cardinals, what will the Giants do against their next opponents, the Seattle Seahawks, who have dropped to 27th in rushing defense among the league's 28 teams?

title: Ohio Workers, in Light Vote, Reject Concessions on Plant
description: Steelworkers narrowly rejected concessions sought by a steel company as a condition for building a plant in a depressed industrial area of Ohio. This encouraged officials in Kentucky and Tennessee seeking the Timken Company mill.

title: FIRST LADY TELLS CRITICS: 'I AM JUST BEING MYSELF'
description: The gold crown is studded with costly jewels. The dress is of finest brocade. The cape is snowy ermine. But the majestic woman on what may be Washington's best-selling post card is not, on second glance, Queen Elizabeth II of Britain.

title: EXILED SALVADORAN CALLS FOR PEACE TALKS
description: A former member of El Salvador's ruling junta, Col. Adolfo Arnoldo Majano, called yesterday for political negotiations between the country's warring factions.

title: BILLS BEAT DOLPHINS BY 31-21
description: The game tonight between the Buffalo Bills and the Miami Dolphins might easily have ended by halftime. The Bills led, 31-7, behind the passing of their quarterback, Joe Ferguson, and went on to win, 31-21, sending the Dolphins to their first defeat.

title: IC RAISES SUNBEAM BID BY $4
description: IC Industries, a diversified railroading company most widely known for its Pet foods and Midas mufflers, yesterday sweetened its offer for nearly 50 percent of the Sunbeam Corporation to $36 a share.

title: GET CONTROL OF TAX EXEMPTIONS
description: Letter: On Development Incentives Get Control of Tax Exemptions To the Editor: While I support The Times's call for better targeting of the Industrial and Commercial Incentives Board's tax exemption program, I believe your (Oct. 8) editorial, ''How to Use Building Subsidies,'' overlooks several crucial problems.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Alcohol

title: TAX LOSS IN NORTH FEARED AS U.S. ENDS FIGHT ON BOOTLEG CIGARETTES
description: Federal officials disclosed yesterday that the Treasury Department had ended a two-year effort to prevent smuggling of cigarettes from the South to Northeastern states, including New York and New Jersey.

title: No Headline
description: G.O.P. WOMEN ASSAIL STAND OF REAGAN ON EQUAL RIGHTS

title: 2 CITIES STUDY GETTING OUT OF NUCLEAR PLANT PROJECT
description: Two partners in a nuclear power plant being built by four utilities on the Texas Gulf Coast are considering withdrawing from the project because of increasing costs and delays in construction.

title: MORTGAGE ASSN, FEDERAL NATIONAL (FNMA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes credits of $522,000 or 8 cents a shr for the qr and $1,240,000 or 19 cents a shr for the 9 mos to reflect accounting adjustment

title: STRIKING TEACHERS DEFY COURT ORDER
description: Most of the city's striking public school teachers defied a back-to-work order today as an increasingly bitter school strike entered its 35th day.

title: REAGAN VS. WOMEN
description: During his Presidential campaign, Ronald Reagan promised to appoint a woman to the Supreme Court. He has kept that promise, but many other promises made to women have not been kept. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's appointment cannot abscure the fact that this Administration discriminates against women and that women will bear the brunt of budget cuts.

title: BIRDSONG INJURY A BRUISE
description: The Nets learned yesterday that a bone scan on Otis Birdsong's injured right foot was negative and that the all-star guard had not suffered a stress fracture, as the club earlier feared. Later Birdsong was examined by the team podiatrist, Dr. John McNerny, who diagnosed the pain as a bruise.

title: CLOTHES FOR NIGHT OWLS
description: East 60th Street between Second and Third Avenues is one of those fashionable shopping streets that always seem to have room for one more boutique. The newest one is called Madeleine, and it's special for two reasons: It sells only evening clothes, and it spotlights offbeat designers.

title: No Headline
description: De La Rose continued her drive toward the grass championship for fillies and mares with an impressive victory in the $85,200 Athenia Handicap on the final card of Belmont's fall program yesterday.

title: FRENCH GOVERNMENT TO FIGHT PARIBAS BID
description: France's Socialist Government said today that it would contest the first major attempt from abroad to resist the Government's plans to nationalize French banks.

title: Autolog Plans Rail Service
description: The Autolog Corporation, a nationwide transporter, will inaugurate a rail service tomorrow providing express delivery of personal automobiles to Florida.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Rights Group Is Seeking To Send Team to Iran

title: A JOURNEY UP 5TH AVENUE CELEBRATES 1492 VOYAGE
description: This year, for the first time in memory, Columbus Day actually fell on Columbus Day. In an age of floating holidays created for the sake of three-day weekends, that alone seemed reason enough for a parade.

title: Corning Glass Up 69.1%
description: Corning Glass Works reported yesterday that net income in the 16 weeks ended Oct. 4, increased 69.1 percent, to $50.4 million, or $2.75 a share, from $29.8 million, or $1.62 a share, in the 16 weeks ended Oct. 5, 1980. Sales advanced 5 percent, to $475.1 million, from $452.3 million.

title: TAILORING 'RACHMONES'
description: The blinding speed at which our fashion tastemakers change, from season to season, the style of the clothes we are supposed to wear has now been approximated by the speed with which their relatives, the political image-makers, change the going system of values, or at least our application of them. Their tools are the same - television, newspapers, magazines and more television.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Nobody could have prevented it. The incident occurred in one or two seconds.

title: Robert D. Herring Dies at 60; Headed Houston Natural Gas
description: Robert R. Herring, chairman of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. He was 60 years old.

title: PROVIDENT NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Audrey Wood Winner Of Coe Theater Award
description: Audrey Wood, a theatrical agent, has been named winner of the annual Richard L. Coe Award by the New Playwrights Theater of Washington.

title: CONSERVATIVE PAPER STIRS DARTMOUTH
description: Beginning at Dartmouth College in the north woods of New England, and fed by a small group of foundations in Manhattan and a clutch of conservative writers and political figures, a fresh conservative wind is beginning to blow through the campuses of the Ivy League and beyond.

title: TECHNOLOGY STOCKS LEAD MARKET LOWER
description: The stock market ended slightly lower yesterday in very slow trading, with some technology issues that reported lower thirdquarter earnings registering the largest losses.

title: EGYPT DISCHARGES 18 ARMY OFFICERS IT CALLS FANATICS
description: The Egyptian Government said today that it had dismissed 18 army officers whom it described as Moslem religious fanatics since President Anwar el-Sadat's assassination last Tuesday.

title: Joe Carr, Tennessee Official In 'One Man, One Vote' Case
description: Joe C. Carr, a former Tennessee Secretary of State, died of cancer today at the age of 74. Mr. Carr, who retired in 1977 after serving 26 years, died at Baptist Hospital.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $300,000 for the qr and $2.4 million for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary gains of $500,000 for the qr and $1.6 million for the 9 mos

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 18.50-19.00Markets closed for the Columbus Day holiday.** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. PROSECUTES FEWER THAN 12% OF FRAUD CASES
description: Fewer than 12 percent of the tens of thousands of people suspected of defrauding the Federal Government are criminally prosecuted, a report to Congress showed today.

title: PHILLIES DUE FOR SPLIT-UP
description: The Philadelphia Phillies, who came up short in defense of their first World Series championship, are breaking up.

title: FOR TEEN-AGERS, TRAVEL BRINGS FEAR AND CHALLENGE
description: Teen-agers will tell you the rules of traveling in the city. ''The key is to look like you don't have any money,'' said Theresa O'Neill, 17, of Staten Island. ''We always travel in a crowd,'' said Matthew Ahern, 14, of Brooklyn. ''I try not to take the train if it's after 11 P.M.,'' said Mathieu Wiepert, 15, of Queens. The teen-age world of dating and discos, of track meets and drama club, of hanging out with friends at favorite stores is haunted in New York City by the problem of how to get there safely. Teen-agers, despite the discomfort of their parents, still make frequent use of the city's public transportation, but their travels are hardly carefree. Wary but Stubborn

title: Crocker Cuts Prime to 18 1/2%
description: The Crocker National Bank, the nation's 12th largest, cut its primerate yesterda y to 18 1/2 percent from 19 percent. The move followed Friday's Fede ral Reserve report that the nation's money supply plunged by $2 .1 billion in the latest reporting week.

title: Two Mormon Church Leaders Undergo Surgery
description: The Mormon Church's two top leaders underwent surgery in Salt Lake City yesterday. Spencer W. Kimball, the 86-year-old president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, had a minor operation at Latterday Saints Hospital, to correct a urinary tract problem.

title: Is She or Isn't She?
description: Can an animal be pregnant and not know it or show it? The Virginia opossum apparently can. Zoologists at Ohio State University have looked and thus far found no physical or hormonal difference between a pregnant and a nonpregnant female opossum, save for the presence of a fetus in the former.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COPPERWELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No New Injury for Brady
description: A George Washington University Hospital spokesman today dismissed concern that James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, who was shot in the head, had suffered another injury. A photograph of Mr. Brady over the weekend showed him wearing a cast on his left arm. Dr. Dennis O'Leary said that Mr. Brady's cast was removable, ''assists in the physical therapy program and controls muscle spasms.'' Mr. Brady was shot in the March 30 attempted assassination of President Reagan.

title: BOMB DAMAGES ULSTER CHURCH
description: A new Roman Catholic church was seriously damaged by a 100-pound bomb during the night. Hours later, gunmen burst into a home and shot to death a Roman Catholic father of three as he watched television.

title: Zimbabwe Leader Ousts His Health Minister
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe has dismissed his Health Minister, Dr. Herbert Ushewokunze, a spokesman said tonight. He said the minister would be replaced by his deputy, Dr. Simon Mazorodze.

title: U.S. SHIPS SHOULD LOOK TO COSTS, NOT SUBSIDIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Armored Van Driver Charged in $400,000 Loss
description: A missing driver of an armored van was charged today with stealing about $400,000, the authorities said.

title: Jets Are Atop N.F.L. in Sacks
description: Although they rank near the bottom of the National Football League in pass defense, the Jets have taken the league lead in sacks. They have dumped the quarterback 25 times in six games.

title: Gail Smith Rejoins D'Arcy-MacManus
description: Gail Smith, at 63 one of the better-known people in advertising circles, having been general director of advertising and merchandising for General Motors, is now working for his former agency, D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, in his home town of Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: WILLOWBROOK PACT FAILS ON OBJECTIONS OF PARENTS
description: A draft settlement of disputes over the care of mentally retarded patients at Willowbrook state hospital on Staten Island has fallen through after opposition by parents of many of the patients.

title: FUJI READY TO SELL ITS INSTANT CAMERAS IN JAPANESE MARKET
description: The Fuji Photo Film Company of Japan said yesterday in Tokyo that it will introduce its first instant camera and film next week. The introduction was scheduled for Japan only, according to wire service reports of the news conference, but analysts who follow photographic companies called the move a prelude to worldwide competition with the Polaroid Corporation and the Eastman Kodak Company, the only ones currently in the market.

title: STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fannie Mae's Loss Extended
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association today reported a net loss of $79.5 million for the third quarter of this year, blaming the high cost of borrowing money during the period.

title: Juan Carlos in Capital For a 2-Day State Visit
description: King Juan Carlos of Spain arrived here today for a two-day state visit that will include talks with President Reagan on Spain's prospective entry into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Boston School Official Is Cleared in Kickback
description: A Federal jury on today acquitted John J. McDonough, a Boston School Committee member, of charges that he took a $5,000 kickback from a Philadelphia school bus company.

title: Oil Rig Collapse Kills Worker
description: The superstructure of a portable oil drilling rig collapsed today, burying the crew's living quarters under tons of steel and killing a sleeping worker, the authorities said. The victim's identity was being withheld until relatives could be notified. Three other workers were injured.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
REAGAN HAS A WEEK LEFT TO SWAY CONGRESS ON AWACS
description: The Reagan Administration has about a week left in which to try to win a struggle in Congress over the proposed sale of $8.5 billion in air defense equipment to Saudi Arabia, including five Awacs planes for radar surveillance.

title: MEETS SAUDI LEADER
description: After attending President Sadat's funeral last Saturday in Cairo, former President Richard M. Nixon met in Jidda with

title: P.L.O. OBSERVER AT U.N. PRAISES CARTER-FORD STAND
description: Zehdi Labib Terzi, the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer here, today hailed as ''positive, constructive, significant'' the call by two former American Presidents for talks with the P.L.O.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt MRS. HARRIS. The Death of the Scarsdale Diet Doctor. By Diana Trilling. 341 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: Index; International

title: ANTHEM ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dutch Retailer Seeks Giant Food
description: Giant Food Stores Inc. said that it had entered final negotiations for the sale of the company to Ahold, the Netherlands' largest food retailer.

title: BANK OF DELAWARE (WILMINGTON, DEL) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place; New Tax Law And Oil Funds
description: THERE is concern among independent oil drillers that the Reagan tax cuts will seriously temper the incentive to invest in oil and gasdrilling prog rams. Should that happen - it is by no means clear that it will - the re could be a significant effect on domestic explorationactivity.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SUDAN'S LEADER PREDICTS AN INVASION BY LIBYANS
description: Maj. Gen. Gaafar al-Nimeiry, President of the Sudan, said today that he expected Libya to invade the Sudan through Chad in the near future and that such an invasion was ''going to be pushed by the Soviet Union and its bloc.''

title: WHITE HOUSE FEARS A LAG IN ECONOMY WILL DAMAGE G.O.P.
description: White House officials are increasingly resigned to the likelihood of slow economic growth, possibly even a recession extending through the spring of 1982. They are seeking to prevent the economic downturn from damaging Republican chances in the election next year.

title: CONTROL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Sept 30

title: CZECH TRADE WITH WEST LAGS
description: Czechoslovakia is seeking to import advanced electronics technology from the West, senior Government officials emphasize, seemingly at every possible occasion. But at last month's Brno Engineering Fair, many businessmen from France, Britain, West Germany and elsewhere in the West complained of a slump in contracts from Czechoslovakia.

title: Wide Use Seen for Transplant Drugs
description: The success of antirejection drugs in four heart-lung transplants at Stanford University Hospital could open the way for more such surgery, a University of Toronto surgeon said today.

title: Lag in Shifts To Gas Seen
description: Residential heating conversions to natural gas from oil and other fuel sources are expected to taper off to 395,000 this year from a record 583,000 in 1980, American Gas Association officials said yesterday.

title: CHURCH SCHOOL, SHUT BY JUDGE, MEETS SECRETLY
description: Students at Faith Christian School went to class today at undisclosed locations, avoiding another confrontation with the authorities who have ordered their school closed because its teachers are not accredited by the state.

title: Poor Harvest In Soviet Seen
description: This year's Soviet grain harvest, hit by dry hot weather, could be less than 170 million metric tons, Soviet agricultural sources said today.

title: AUDIT CRITICIZES PROJECT TO AVERT CITY FOSTER CARE
description: A New York City program to keep children out of the foster care system is inadequately evaluated and monitored by the government agency responsible for it, according to an audit by the City Comptroller's office.

title: THEATER: JANGO EDWARD'S 'GARBAGE'
description: JANGO EDWARDS is a fearless, tasteless, ferociously comic clown. He unveiled his act Wednesday at the Entermedia Theater under the title ''Garb-age,'' a one-man explosion of comedy talent, drawing inspiration from such sources as burlesque, Berlin in the 20's and Lenny Bruce, filtering everything through his own manic sensibility. If he were a restaurant, he would not win a seal from the Board of Health.

title: Q&A
description: Q. From what did the oil found in frozen and barren areas of northern Alaska form?

title: Venet to Be Turned Into Holding Company
description: Zal Venet, chief of Venet Advertising, home of such advertising clients as Pathmark supermarkets and Prince spaghetti, has decided to turn his agency into a holding company called the Venet Company.

title: Borg Defeats Clerc
description: Bjorn Borg defeated Jose-Luis Clerc, 6-2, 6-2, 7-5, tonight to win the Edmonton Tennis Challenge. Borg, who will shortly be taking a five-month layoff from professional tennis, earned $80,000. Clerc, a 23-year-old Argentine who was erratic throughout the match, earned $60,000.

title: Atlanta Suspect Called Task Force a Year Ago
description: Wayne B. Williams, accused of killing two young black men, says he notified the police that he was auditioning children for a musical act, so ''there wouldn't be any problems later.''

title: TEXAS AIR BID CLEARED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan said today that he would not block Texas International Airlines' bid to acquire Continental Air Lines, clearing the way for the takeover.

title: HOOTEN TO FACE EXPOS
description: The National League will open baseball's first international playoff for the pennant today when the Montreal Expos meet the Dodgers in Los Angeles, with Bill Gullickson pitching for Montreal against Burt Hooton of the Dodgers.

title: GRUMMAN SETS LTV OBSTACLE
description: In another obstacle to the LTV Corporation' s takeover attempt, trustees of the Grumman Corporation's pension plan said yesterday that they had increased their holding of Grum man stock and voted the larger block held by the employee investment plan against the merger.

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a net gain from the sale of property of $1,684,000; all 1980 figures have been restated to include the operations of General Semiconductor Industries as a pooling of interests since its acquisition on Jan 20, 1981

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Court Blocks State's Ban On Abortion Referrals
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that a state may not cut off funds to an agency because it advises women on abortions.

title: ASHLAND OIL REALIGNS U.S. FILTER MANAGEMENT
description: Four months after Ashland Oil Inc. completed the acquisition of all the voting stock of the United States Filter Corporation, Edwin T. Veith, 50, has been named president and chief operating officer of U.S. Filter. He succeeds Raymond A. Rich, 64, who will become a consultant to the company, a diversified energy and environmental products company based in New York.

title: Nissan Predicts U.S. Sales Rise
description: Officials of Nissan Motors U.S.A. predicted that the company's sales in the 1982 model year would improve to 500,000 cars and 130,000 trucks, equal to its record 1980 performance.

title: Fire Kills TwinsIn Connecticut
description: Twin girls were killed and three members of their family injured in a weekend fire that destroyed their ranchstyle home.

title: INGOTS OF GOLD ARE DIVIDED IN MURMANSK
description: A team of British divers left the Soviet port of Murmansk for home Friday night after Soviet and British officials divided the more than $80 million in gold ingots that the divers recovered from a sunken British warship beneath the Arctic waters of the Barents Sea.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 13, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M.

title: POLISH UNION WILL DECIDE IN 10 DAYS HOW TO PROTEST THE PRICE RISES
description: The Solidarity union said today that it would decide in 10 days whether to call some sort of strike or national protest unless there were talks with the Government over fixing prices and improving the food supply in Poland.

title: WEINBERGER 'STATISTICS'
description: The glossy Pentagon booklet ''Soviet Military Power'' unveiled by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger recently is obviously intended to reinforce a recurrent theme of the Reagan Administration: The Russians are engaged in an enormous and indeed unprecedented buildup in defense production and deployment, the better to project their power and influence around the world. Unfortunately, the report is seriously misleading on two key points.

title: FIRST BANKERS CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SANTA FE'S VIEW OF SALE TO KUWAIT
description: Since the announcement last week that the Kuwaiti Government, through its Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, had agreed to acquire the Santa Fe International Corporation for $2.5 billion in cash, attention has focused on the motives of Edfred L. Shannon Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of Santa Fe, and his management team. But the 55-year-old Mr. Shannon says that his reasons for agreeing to the proposed sale of his oil drilling and production company are simple.

title: Bellevue Restores Severed Hand
description: A 19-year-old New Jersey man was in satisfactory condition at Bellevue Hospital in New York after surgeons reattached his severed hand in a 10-hour operation.

title: Transplant Recipient Stable
description: Barry Davis, the fourth heart-lung transplant recipient this year, was in critical but stable condition today at Stanford University Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said. The 40-year-old Redwood City man, who was born with a hole in his heart, was given the heart and lungs of a 20-year-old suicide victim in an operation yesterday.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for 16 weeks to Oct 4
description: B-Including $14.8 million gain for the qr and 9 mos on the sale of assets...C-Including gains on the sale of assets of $9.6 million for the qr and $19.3 million for the 9 mos

title: Why Halas Growls
description: George Halas, owner of the Chicago Bears, unhappy that the team has produced only 89 points in six games, brought back Jim Dooley as a ''consultant'' to Ted Marchibroda, the offensive coordinator. Dooley was Halas's hand-picked successor as head coach in 1969 and had a 20-36 record in four seasons.

title: No Headline
description: The baseball divison playoffs attracted more than three-quarters of a million fans to ball parks, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's office said yesterday.

title: A TALE OF TWO FORD PLANTS
description: To the casual visitor, the sleek gray Ford Motor Company plant here appears to be exactly like its cousin at Halewood, England, outside Liverpool. At each, shiny Escorts, Ford's hot new car, roll off bustling production lines dominated by robot welders and vast automated presses punching out steel as if it were aluminum foil.

title: Emergency Is Declared After Attack in Peru
description: The Government declared a state of emergency tonight and suspended constitutional guarantees in five Andean towns after an attack on a police station in which three people were killed.

title: BL Ltd. Closing Three Plants
description: BL Ltd. will close three of its 34 plants by the end of next year with a loss o f nearly 2,000 jobs, the company said. The state-o wned automobile company, formerly known as British Leyland, whic h lost $428 million in the first half of this year and has eliminate d 65,000 jobs over the past four years, said that the closings woul d save $21 million.

title: Wesleyan Students Protest Racism
description: Spurred by reports of increased Ku Klux Klan activity in Connecticut, about 200 Wesleyan University students yesterday staged a rally against racism.

title: Further Fare Cuts Made by Airlines
description: Several of the the nation's major airlines again cut fares to attract passengers as they struggle through one of the worst years in aviation history.

title: ART: ASIA SOCIETY OPENS NEW GALLERY
description: AS of 10 o'clock this morning the new Asia Society Gallery will be open to the public at 725 Park Avenue. Like its predecessor at 112 East 64th Street, it is intimate in scale. Designed by Edward Larrabee Barnes, the gallery serves as an island of tranquillity and meditation in a building that elsewhere is devoted to East-West relations in all their multifarious complexity.

title: Andretti Makes Appeal on Indy
description: Mario Andretti said today he was appealing the United States Auto Club's ruling last week that made Bobby Unser the winner of the Indian-apolis 500-mile race.

title: New Ad Sales Director At CBS Magazines
description: Peter Veronis, formerly of Book Digest, Psychology Today and Saturday Review, and always a space salesman, will begin work today at CBS Publications as director of a newly created advertising sales unit called the CBS Special Interest Magazine Network.

title: U.N. Agency for Palestinians Says It Is in Financial Trouble
description: In the bleakest report since its formation 32 years ago, the United Nations relief agency for Palestinian refugees reported today that it was in ''a perilously critical state'' and might face bankruptcy.

title: No Headline
description: Talking Businesswith Feiner of Merrill Lynch Has Sears Hit A Ceiling?

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: W ORLDS collided with increasing frequency last week, with results at once odd and edifying. A Broadway dress house named Aria/Argent offered $5,000 to anyone who could create the all-American royal wedding dress. One designer entered a cowgirl concoction, another a dress that doubles as a honeymoon nightgown. The winning design, by John McIlwee, was pure Victorian, with white lace train and puffed sleeves.

title: Why Modell Fumes
description: Art Modell, the Cleveland Browns' owner, virtually invited a fine by Commissioner Pete Rozelle when, after Sunday's 13-7 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers, he accused the officials of a ''very badly called game.'' Referring to the league's policy of automatically imposing a $5,000 for public criticism of game officials, Modell said: ''If the commissioner wants to fine me $5,000, he can.

title: Stanford Scholar Dies In a Fall in Philippines
description: Michelle Z. Rosaldo, an associate professor of anthropology and a feminist scholar at Stanford University, died on Sunday in a hiking accident in the Philippines, where she was working on a research project, the university said. She was 37 years old.

title: LOSS ON SHOTS FOR PUPILS PUT AT $2 MILLION FOR CITY
description: Strict enforcement of the state law barring public school students who have not been immunized against childhood diseases has already cost New York City more than $2.1 million in state education aid, City Council President Carol Bellamy said yesterday.

title: The Education of Alien Children
description: To hear the moanings of Mark White, the Texas Attorney General, you would think that rich state, awash in oil severance taxes, was bound for bankruptcy. If public schools are obliged to admit the children of illegal aliens, he said in Federal court last year, as many as 100,000 would pour in, costing the state and local school districts a staggering $200 million annually, busting the state's budget and jeopardizing the education of American children.

title: Ivy Strick Is Married To L. Stan Stokowski
description: Ivy Strick and L. Stan Stokowski were married at the couple's farm in Saugerties, N.Y., on June 18. Town Justice Richard I. Ryan performed the ceremony.

title: W.D. Parker, Pioneer Pilot, Pursued Pancho Villa in 1916
description: W.D. (Billy) Parker, whose colorful aviation career included the unsuccessful pursuit of Pancho Villa into Mexico in 1916, will be buried Wednesday in Sedona, Ariz.

title: GROUP DESCRIBES SMUGGLING OF A MILLION BIBLES INTO CHINA
description: The smuggling of more than a million Chinese-language Bibles to China has been disclosed by an evangelical missionary organization and a company in Nashville that says it is the world's largest Bible publisher.

title: WORLDWIDE USE OF VALIUM DRAWS NEW SCRUTINY
description: VALIUM, one of the most intensely scrutinized drugs in recent years, is about to be scrutinized again. Is it as dangerous to unsuspecting users as critics contend? Or has the drug been criticized too much, its faults magnified out of all proportion to its virtues? These and other issues will be debated by scientific advisers to the World Health Organization next month as they review the misuse and abuse of the minor tranquilizers known as benzodiazepines.

title: LANDSCAPE AS DESIGN: 2 SHOWS FOCUS ON OLMSTED
description: THEIR deteriorated condition often blinds us to the fact that most of New York's parks are remarkable works of design -truly extraordinary syntheses of art, engineering and social ideas. Such places as Central, Prospect, Riverside and Carl Schurz Parks and the Brooklyn Heights Promenade create an image of a city that is not only coherent, but also civilized and even graceful, a city in which a respect for natural landscape is blended perfectly with an expression of the democratic ideal.

title: Sommers Finds Signs of a Recession Now
description: The United States appears to be in a recess ion, but it may not lastlong or be severe, the Conference Board said yesterday in a newsletter.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: AMONG the actions that get college presidents into trouble are: locking horns with powerful politicians; speaking out on controversial issues; risking students' wrath by setting limits to campus protests; frequently leaving the campus on national and international missions; upsetting the traditional management of the university; serving an unpopular President and then publicly attacking that President's policies.

title: MANY BILLIONS NECESSARY TO RESTORE PUBLIC WORKS, ALBANY AIDES SAY
description: New York State and local governments will have to spend $8 billion to $10 billion annually to keep their deteriorating bridges, roads, water mains, sewers, highways and other public facilities from worsening, according to estimates by analysts in the State Legislature.

title: PREWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gain equal to 17 cents a shr from the disposition of a European fuel fabrication operation

title: News Analysis
description: The Federal Government, which pays for nearly two-thirds of the nation's hospital costs, is beginning to challenge some of the ways hospitals and physicians bill Government-financed hospital-insurance programs for their care.

title: FIFTH KARPOV-KORCHNOI CHESS GAME IS ADJOURNED
description: The fifth game of the world chess championship match was adjourned here tonight with the titleholder, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, confident that he would draw with Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland when play resumed tomorrow.

title: COLLUSION REQUEST LAID TO LAW FIRM
description: A lawyer representing two environmental groups has filed a legal brief accusing the Pacific Legal Foundation of making a ''highly irregular request for direct collusion'' to the Justice Department in connection with Pacific's lawsuit against Interior Secretary James G. Watt.

title: DISTRICT IN MICHIGAN PLANS SCHOOL CLOSING OVER LACK OF FUNDS
description: The 2,000 students at Alpena High School are wearing black armbands this week, and some are making plans to get their diplomas elsewhere because the school system is closing until it gets new tax money.

title: JUDGE UNDER AN INQUIRY ASKS CASELOAD REMOVAL
description: Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings, told over the weekend by the Federal Bureau of Investigation that a grand jury would soon begin an inquiry into whether he solicited bribes from criminal defendants, has asked the chief judge of the district to remove him from making judicial decisions until ''a final resolution of this matter is achieved.''

title: Japanese-British Trade
description: The leader of the Japanese economic mission said today that Japan and Britain must cooperate to strengthen trade between the two countries.

title: DOMINICANS ADMONISH BUSH ON SUGAR
description: Vice President Bush, on a three-day visit to the Dominican Republic, went before a joint session of the Dominican National Assembly today with a speech castigating President Fidel Castro of Cuba and warning of the dangers of Cuban and Soviet expansionism.

title: JAPAN SEES ARAFAT VISIT AS CHANCE TO SEEK WIDER ACCORD IN MIDEAST
description: Japan regards the visit to Tokyo by Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, as a ''valuable opportunity'' to work for a broader peace settlement in the Middle East, Foreign Ministry officials said today.

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE DEATH PENALTY 'IS INDEED HUMANE'
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS MANDRELL, GEORGE JONES WIN COUNTRY MUSIC AWARDS
description: Barbara Mandrell was named ''Entertainer of the Year'' by the Country Music Association last night in a 90-minute ceremony held at the Grand Ole Opry House in Nashville, Tenn.

title: GUN-TOTING TOTS
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN'S TRADE SURPLUS WITH U.S. AT A RECORD
description: The Japanese Government reported today that its trade surplus with the United States climbed to a record $1.76 billion in September, surpassing the previous monthly record of $1.35 billion set in July.

title: CARTER TO LOBBY SENATE ON AWACS
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, saying the Reagan Administration should play a stronger role in the Middle East, told reporters today that he would lobby senators to support the sale of Awacs radar surveillance aircraft to Saudi Arabia.

title: Post Office Beginning 20-Cent Stamp Sales
description: The Postal Service is putting 5.3 billion 20-cent stamps on sale tomorrow, although first-class postal rates do not go up to that level until Nov. 1.

title: YANKS, A'S STIR SPITBALL DISPUTE
description: The American League pennant playoff, which begins tonight at Yankee Stadium, is supposed to be a three-of-five series between the players of the Yankees and the Oakland A's. But it more likely will become a three-of-five-act revival of the George and Billy Show.

title: SENATOR, DISPUTING BUSH, SAYS IDI AMIN IS A GUEST OF SAUDIS
description: Senator Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota, challenging a recent statement by Vice President Bush, said today that Saudi Arabia, and not Libya, was harboring Idi Amin, the former Ugandan dictator.

title: Excerpts of debate are on page B6.
description: The two major-party candidates for Governor of New Jersey disagreed sharply yesterday on the causes and scope of the state's economic problems and on how to solve them.

title: MR. SADAT'S EXAMPLE
description: In his remarkable conversation with former President Ford on their way home from Anwar el-Sadat's funeral, Jimmy Carter pointed to a truth about the Middle East that Mr. Sadat learned the hard way, but which now seems in danger of being forgotten.

title: DeLorean Is Cleared
description: John Z. DeLorean was cleared today of any financial wrongdoing in setting up an assembly line with heavy British Government subsidies to build a stainless steel sports car in Northern Ireland. Britain's Director of Public Prosecutions said after a police inquiry that there was no evidence to support accusations against Mr. DeLorean by a former employee, Marian Gibson. Miss Gibson said that Mr. DeLorean, a former General Motors vice president, put in only a small fraction of the $7.2 million he was required to invest in return for the $125 million he secured in Government grants and loans.

title: 2 CHILDREN MISSING
description: Two brothers, 2 and 7 years old, were reported missing last night after a fire swept through two tenements in Hoboken, N.J., injuring 12 persons, five of them critically.

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
CASTS CHANGING IN REHEARSAL
description: It is a sign that the new theater season has started in earnest: casts are changing suddenly in rehearsal. There were two major changes yesterday, both involving stars of new productions.

title: Braniff Account Goes To Bloom Agency
description: The Bloom Agency, Dallas, having resigned the Southwest Airlines account, billing about $3 million, has been assigned Braniff International, billing almost $15 million. It is thus following Howard D. Putnam, the former head man at Southwest, who took over the lead at Braniff two weeks ago.

title: No Headline
description: * Berol Corporation, Danbury, Conn., has appointed S. Denis Thomas corporate vice president and general manager of the Berol USA division.

title: DOROTHY SAYERS' POISON IS A TREAT FOR CHEMISTS
description: DOROTHY SAYERS was a Latin scholar; a student of Medieval history; an expert translator of Dante; a poet; a playwright; a feminist before most people knew about feminism; an authority on Christian philosophy; one of the first women to ever receive a degree from Oxford, and, when the demands of scholarship permitted, a sophisticated writer with an formidable knack of writing novels and short stories about absolutely horrid people who go around plotting murder.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KAUFMAN SEES NEW HIGHS FOR RATES
description: Interest rates will rise to new highs in the next six months, Henry Kaufman, a prominent Wall Street economist, warned financial executives here yesterday.

title: VASS: A KNACK FOR KNITS
description: Reaching her is half the battle. She lives, to begin with, on 25th Street, in a part of Chelsea dominated by a housing project and teenagers hanging out on the sidewalk playing radios at full blast. She has the top floor of a building that houses a bindery, and the elevator, which goes only part of the way up, smells like glue.

title: BRENCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $1,755,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: POP: 'GRAN FIESTA,' GALAXY OF SPANISH-SPEAKING STARS
description: ''GRAN FIESTA EN EL MADISON,'' a three-hour Latin American variety show Saturday and Sunday in Madison Square Garden, brought together a multinational cast of Spanish-speaking pop stars in an unprecedented display of Spanish-speaking talent. Sunday's concert was also televised live via satellite along with New York's Hispanic Day parade as part of the ceremonies launching an international television network, Univision, linking Latin America, Spain and the United States.

title: ANOTHER G.I. BILL IS COMING, BUT ITS FORM IS UNCLEAR; WASHINGTON
description: AT a largely unnoticed Congressional hearing a month ago, Lawrence J. Korb, the Assistant Secretary of Defense in charge of manpower, succinctly laid out the Reagan Administration's position on proposals for a new G.I. Bill.

title: Krugerrand Sales Increase
description: Krugerrand sales rose 35 percent in the first eight months of the year compared with the same period in 1980, according to South Africa's Chamber of Mines.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WHY NOT JUST SUPERHARDEN MINUTEMAN?
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: Since President Anwar el-Sadat's assassination, the Reagan Administration has widened its security umbrella in the Middle East to include not only Saudi Arabia but also Egypt, the Sudan, and, in the words of Richard V. Allen, the White House national security adviser, ''any of the other states in the region'' that are friendly to the United States.

title: THEATER: 'MARLOWE,' A ROCK MUSICAL
description: WHEN everything goes right in a musical, the audience feels a rush of exhilaration that is the quintessence of Broadway. And what happens when everything goes wrong? Well, when everything goes wrong, another kind of giddiness sets in - that same slaphappy feeling that comes when Laurel and Hardy send a grand piano crashing down a flight of stairs.

title: AFTER 2 YEARS, ABC MOVIE DIVISION TO MAKE 3 FEATURES
description: A National Lampoon comedy, a parody of doctor movies and a film about Karen Silkwood starring Meryl Streep and directed by Mike Nichols are the first three movies firmly set for production by ABC Motion Pictures.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE DEBATE BETWEEN CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR OF NEW JERSEY
description: Following are excerpts from a debate yesterday at The New York Times between Representative James J. Florio and Thomas H. Kean, candidates for Governor of New Jersey:

title: Handler Gets Top U.S. Science Award
description: Dr. Philip Handler, president of the National Academy of Sciences for 12 years, was given the National Medal of Science, the nation's highest scientific award, on Sunday.

title: BENIGN IGNORANCE OF THE LAW IS NO PROTECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTINGHOUSE NET UP 14.4% IN THIRD QUARTER
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's second-largest maker of electrical equipment after the General Electric Company, reported yesterday that gains by all three of its component groups caused earnings in the third quarter to rise 14.4 percent as sales increased 10.1 percent.

title: Advertising; McDonald's Switching To Burnett
description: THE Chicago advertising community was shocked yesterday to learn that the $75 million McDonald's Corporation account for national advertising will be going to the Leo Burnett Company, leaving behind the Chicago office of Needham, Harper & Steers and years of awardwinning advertising.

title: FINGERPRINT ID'S CUT BACK BY F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has stopped making fingerprint checks for banks and state and local licensing agencies that must make sure applicants for jobs as tellers, teachers and casino workers do not have criminal records.

title: HOW HUGE ANTENNA CAN BROADCAST INTO THE SILENCE OF THE SEA
description: PERHAPS no element in American deterrence against nuclear attack is more vital than the ability of the Navy to communicate with its missile-carrying submarines, considered by many to be the least vulnerable leg of the military triad, the other two being land-based missiles and bombers.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Babcock & Wilcox, an operating unit of McDermott Inc., received two solar power contracts valued at $1.2 million from Sandia National Laboratories in Livermore, Calif.

title: 4 Fail in Escape Attempt
description: Four prisoners made an abortive attempt to escape from the Marion Federal Penitentiary, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. The four sawed through cell bars, battered down a door and broke a window in making their way to the prison roof, an bureau spokesman said. Three were apprehended on the roof and the fourth received a superficial gunshot wound as he attempted to climb a fence.

title: Broten Scores 2 Goals As North Stars Win, 4-2
