description: Neil Broten scored the go-ahead goal late in the second period and another in the third to help the Minnesota North Stars to a 4-2 victory over the Quebec Nordiques tonight. The victory extended the North Stars' unbeaten streak to four games.

title: Hartford Reruns A Primary Today
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Hartford Democrats will go to the polls today for a second time this fall in an attempt to select a mayoral candidate to represent their party in November's election. The results of the first primary on Sept. 8 were discarded after they were challenged in court.

title: SHE PROGRAMS A SUCCESS STORY
description: When Sandra L. Kurtzig and her husband decided it was time to start a family, Mrs. Kurtzig quit her job at General Electric and began writing computer programs at home as a part-time job.

title: China's Oil Import Needs
description: The World Bank has concluded that China, which exported 265,000 barrels of oil a day in 1980, could be forced to import oil by 1985 because of declining crude output and rising internal demand, an oil newsletter reported yesterday.

title: LIVE FISH USED TO WARN SCIENTISTS WHEN WATER IS TOXIC
description: DOWNRIVER from the chemical factory the morning mist rises slowly to reveal hundreds of dead fish floating on the water's surface. The event is reported to the authorities. Questions are asked. Were the fish killed by a toxic discharge from the factory upstream? If so, what was the chemical? And how long had it been in the river before it became fatal?

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1981; The Economy
description: The White House is resigned to slow economic growth and possibly a recession through the spring of next year, according to Presidential aides. They said they were concerned that unemployment would replace inflation as the leading issue among voters and were seeking to prevent the economic downturn from damaging Republican chances in the election next year. (Page A1.)

title: 7 Admit Vote Buying In South Carolina
description: Seven persons, including a Democratic county chairman and a former sheriff, pleaded guilty today to vote buying, ending a year of investigation by the Federal authorities.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NATO Agrees to End Talks by Christmas
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today on the need to conclude the European security review conference in Madrid by Christmas, a senior United States diplomat said.

title: Luzinski Coming Back
description: Another baseball star who had been thought likely to become a free agent was taken off this winter's market yesterday. One week after the Cincinnati Reds had re-signed Dave Concepcion for five years, the Chicago White Sox signed Greg Luzinski, their designated hitter, to a three-year guaranteed contract.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SCAPES

title: Jones & Laughlin Sets More Layoffs
description: The LTV Corporation said that slack demand from most markets had led to further shutdowns and layoffs at its Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation facilities.

title: TV: 3 HOURS OF A MOTHER AND HER SON
description: NOT too long ago, the giving of a full three hours of prime time to a television movie used to signify something special, something along the ambitious lines of, say, ''Friendly Fire.'' In no time at all, however, the three-hour production has become nothing more than a convenient way to fill a schedule desperate for fresh material. There is certainly nothing even remotely special about ''Callie & Son,'' the peculiar melodrama that CBS-TV has chosen to show from 8 to 11 this evening.

title: SOLID STATE SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-Includes tax credits of $35,000 for the qr and $151,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes tax credits of $225,000 for the qr and $523,000 for the 9 mos

title: Walter B. Alexander, Ex-Official of Antioch
description: Walter Boyd Alexander, retired vice president of Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio, and a founding editor of the quarterly Antioch Review, died on Sunday at his home in Tucson, Ariz.

title: STONES SET DATES FOR AREA CONCERTS
description: The Rolling Stones announced yesterday that they woulde performing at Byrne Arena in New Jersey's Meadowlands on Nov. 5, 6 and 7 and at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 12 and 13. These will be the only scheduled appearances in the New York area by the Stones, although they have promised to throw in a New York nightclub performance as well.

title: AUSTRIA ANGERED BY STAND OF P.L.O.
description: A spokesman for Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria said today that Austria might suspend its contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization or even close the P.L.O.'s office in Vienna because of the organization's outbursts of joy at the slaying of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt.

title: Sun Cuts Prices
description: The Sun Company has cut the wholesale price of its unleaded gasoline by as much as 1.8 cents a gallon in Pennsylvania, Delaware and New Jersey, and a subsidiary, Sunmark Industries, reduced wholesale heating oil prices by two-tenths of a cent to 1.6 cents a gallon on the Eastern Seaboard and in parts of Tennessee, Kentucky, Ohio and Michigan. The Sun Company is the 11th-largest gasoline marketer in the United States. A Sun spokesman said the company was ''adjusting to a competitive market.''

title: A JOB-HUNTING RUSE HELPS GUNMEN STEAL $250,000 IN JEWELS
description: A young man who answered a help-wanted advertisement for an experienced diamond setter yesterday did not get the job. Instead, he and his accomplices stole more than $250,000 worth of diamonds, other gems and metals from the Manhattan concern that had placed the ad.

title: NEVADA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $1,773,000 or 55 cents a shr gain from the sale of land held for investment purposes; 1980 shr earnings were restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in Dec 1981

title: EGYPTIANS VOTING TODAY ON MUBARAK PRESIDENCY
description: About 12 million Egyptians will vote in a national referendum tomorrow that is expected to elect Vice President Hosni Mubarak as Egypt's next President by an overwhelming margin.

title: Weightlessness Aids Glassmaking
description: Scientists at Westinghouse Electric Corporation and Clarkson College say they demonstrated a technique for making ultrapure glass in the weightlessness of space.

title: A VOICE OF MODERATION IS GOING BACK TO IRELAND
description: Last spring, when the Irish Republican Army's hunger strike was just getting under way in the H-Block of Maze Prison, Sean Donlon brought the Lords Mayor of Dublin and Belfast together for a quiet lunch in his home here.

title: 3 Pupils Die and 25 Hurt As School Bus Hits Log
description: Three children were killed and 25 were injured today when a 77-foot log protruding from a truck pierced the windshield and door of a school bus, the police said.

title: Chester Cable Stake Acquired
description: Compagnie Generale D'Electricite, France's third-largest company, said that its Cables de Lyon subsidiary had acquired a substantial equity interest in the Chester Cable Corporation in Chester, N.Y.

title: METROPOLITAN OPERA: 'DIE FRAU OHNE SCHATTEN'
description: If officials of the Metropolitan Opera have been sitting up nights worrying about how to keep this season's slight booing infection from spreading, they had the answer readily at hand last night. Exciting singing will provide the remedy every time. Birgit Nilsson's return to the company to sing the Dyer's Wife in ''Die Frau ohne Schatten'' was the most obvious reason, though far from the only one, why nothing but cheering could be heard.

title: Polish Prelate Due in Rome
description: Archbishop Jozef Glemp, Poland's new Roman Catholic primate, is expected in Rome Saturday for talks with Pope John Paul II and other Vatican officials, Polish church sources said today. The primate's visit is part of the regular contacts between the Polish church and the Holy See, the sources said.

title: 85th Birthday Celebrant Plans $5 Million Gift
description: If there is one thing Nathan Cummings likes, it is a big party. To Mr. Cummings, the founder of the Consolidated Foods Corporation, that means something like the one he gave for his 80th birthday five years ago - 635 people at the grand ballroom of the @Waldorf-Astoria and Bob Hope popping out of a giant cake.

title: News Analysis
description: The current inquiry into the finances of John Cardinal Cody and the Archdiocese of Chicago may raise one of the most delicate First Amendment disputes ever litigated.

title: Trial Begins in Reno Deaths
description: A trial began in Washoe District Court today for Priscilla Ford, who is accused of killing six people and injuring 23 others as her automobile sped down a crowded sidewalk on Reno's Casino Row last Thanksgiving. Mrs. Ford was charged with six counts of murder, 23 of attempted murder and 23 of battery. Her attorney, Lew Carnahan, entered a plea of not guilty by reason of insanity for his client. District Attorney Cal Dunlap said that he will seek the death penalty if Mrs. Ford is found guilty.

title: Pleasant Colony Is Retired
description: Pleasant Colony, the 3-year-old standout whose injury left him unable to compete in last Saturday's Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park, has been retired.

title: Defense for Presley's Doctor May Assert Prior Drug Use
description: Elvis Presley was a ''terribly sick person,'' his physician's attorney said today, with a drug problem he may have picked up while in the Army.

title: PHOTOS SHOW CAIRO SECURITY BREAKDOWN, EXPERTS SAY
description: A seeming breakdown in security and the element of surprise at the Cairo parade grounds last week turned what should have been a suicide mission for the assassins into a successful attack on the life of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, in the view of three American security experts.

title: 40 Poets and Artists Depict New York State
description: Forty artists and poets from 23 facilities of the State University of New York will participate in ''The New York Landscape,'' an exhibition that will feature 20 poems about places or scenes in the state and the visual responses of 20 artists.

title: Jail Is Searched After Shooting
description: The Brooklyn House of Detention was searched floor by floor after an inmate was shot in the back while lying on his bed, a spokesman at the jail said. However, the search did not yield any evidence in the shooting.

title: Free Flu Shots Available Today
description: Free influenza vaccinations for the elderly and infirm will be available at nine New York City Health Department clinics in all five boroughs beginning today, Acting Health Commissioner Margaret T. Grossi announced.

title: Ill Winds
description: Cyclones have names as violent as their blasts: hurricane, typhoon, tornado. But there is another kind of wind whose many names lull and soothe: sharav, chinook, sirocco, for example, and Santa Ana.

title: Combustion Engineering
description: Combustion Engineering Inc., one of the city's largest private employers, said today that a depressed market is forcing the company's third employee layoff within two months.

title: Strike Delays Italian Trains
description: Italian trains were delayed up to 10 hours today when thousands of railroad workers went on strike for 24 hours. It was the first of a series of rail strikes planned this month by unions protesting the Government's decision to delay negotiations on new contracts.

title: GASOLINE PRICES DOWN AGAIN, SURVEY FINDS
description: Gasoline prices fell nearly another half-cent a gallon across the country during the past two weeks, and Dan Lundberg, the oil industry analyst, cited intense competition among retailers.

title: Craig Sent Down
description: The Boston Bruins sent Jim Craig, the goalie of the United States team that won the Olympic gold medal in Lake Placid last year, to the Erie (Pa.) Blades, their farm club, for ''conditioning purposes.''

title: Hiding From Social Security
description: Adroit politicians don't ignore issues too hot to handle. They appoint commissions to study them. And after an initial burn or two, that is just what President Reagan has chosen to do with Social Security. In this case, though, adroit politics doesn't make for good public policy. The longer Washington puts off a remedy for Social Security's financial woes, the harder it will be to find one.

title: Goodrich to Raise Mexican Output
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said that its Mexican associate, Compania Hulera Euzkadi, planned a $105 million expansion that would increase its annual tire production by 60 percent.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
EX-YANKEES ON A'S IN A VENGEFUL SPIRIT
description: At dawn yesterday, as the Oakland A's bus pulled out of the Lincoln Tunnel and onto the deserted streets of Manhattan, Cliff Johnson peered through the window with half-closed eyes and advised his teammates to ''get out your surgical masks.''

title: GERMAN CONSERVATIVE PAYS CALL ON FRIENDS IN U.S.
description: Helmut Kohl, the leader of West Germany's opposition Christian Democrats, left today for the United States, where his party is often seen as a constant friend in a time of strengthened currents here of neutralism, pacifism and anti-Americanism.

title: 27 Hurt on Budapest Train
description: Twenty-seven people were injured, none seriously, when the Polonia Express from Warsaw crashed into a retaining wall at the Eastern Station here today, the Hungarian press agency said. The police said that, except for one Hungarian, all the injured passengers were Poles.

title: Hilton Net Up 1.9%
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation, the largest operator of hotels in the United States, announced yesterday that net income in the third quarter edged 1.9 percent higher, on a gain in revenues of 7.4 percent. Hilton said that net income in the most-recen t three months rose to $26.4 million, or 99 cents a share, f rom $25.9 million, or 97cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues advan ced to $455.6 million from $424.4 million.

title: Captain Phillips Balks at Horse's Name
description: What's in a name? Plenty, if it is one that can deprive a would-be Olympic equestrian of his amateur standing, Capt. Mark Phillips has decided.

title: SOVIET PAPER ASSERTS SOLIDARITY IS TRYING TO END COMMUNISM
description: The Soviet Union today accused Solidarity, the Polish trade union, of plotting to destroy the Communist community, starting with Poland.

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1981
description: International Egypt has dismissed 18 army officers, described as Moslem religious fanatics, since the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat. A close friend of his also disclosed that Mr. Sadat had said that Islamic extremists, including an Egyptian intelligence officer, plotted to kill him during a public appearance on Sept. 26 but that the plot was discovered and thwarted by the police. (Page A1, Column 6.) A seeming breakdown in security and the element of surprise transformed what should have been a suicide mission for the assassins into the swift murder of President Sadat, in the opinion of three American experts. The experts, former Secret Service agents who have guarded Presidents, examined a series of photographs of the assassination and agreed that Egyptian security forces appeared confused, outgunned, poorly stationed and slow to respond to the assault. (A1:5.)

title: EX-C.I.A. MEN JOINED U.S. COMPANY TO SELL TECHNOLOGY OVERSEAS
description: Two former agents of the Central Intelligence Agency joined forces with a small California electronics company in the 1970's in an effort to market sensitive American technology abroad, according to current and former company executives and company documents.

title: EX-REP. BROOKS HAYS, AIDE TO PRESIDENT, 83, DIES
description: Brooks Hays, a voice of Southern moderation in his 16 years in Congress, died in his sleep last night at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 83 years old.

title: AIC PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Flying Tiger Line Plans Saudi Route
description: The Flying Tiger Line, the air cargo carrier, has agreed with Saudi Arabian Airlines to start a direct 747 freight service, described as the only one of its kind so far, between the United States and Saudi Arabia.

title: Big Sky Resort Interest Sold
description: Mid-Texas Oil and Gas Inc. announced that it had acquired controlling interest in the Big Sky Ski Resort. The resort, formerly a wholly owned subsidiary of Boyne USA Resorts of Boyne Falls, Mic h., is northwest of Yellow stone National Park.

title: A Bit of Broadway Collapses Uptown
description: A broken steam pipe caused a section of Broadway to cave in between 59th and 60th Streets at the beginning of the rush hour last evening, the police said.

title: A FAMILY REUNION
description: FROM the tape player on the floor of Reggie Jackson's locker at Yankee Stadium yesterday, the voices of the O'Jays were singing, ''It's been a long time since we had a chance to get together. ... family reunion.'' Hearing those words, Reggie Jackson smiled.

title: Debt Securities Little Changed
description: Prices of corporate and tax-exempt debt securities were firm but little changed in very light trading yesterday, dealers said. ''It really was not much of a trading day,'' one analyst said, ''since many potential buyers were on vacation and nobody wants to trade actively without some feedback from the government securities market.''

title: BRISTOL-MEYERS NAMES 3 GROUP P RESIDENTS
description: The Bristol-Myers Company, the diversified consumer products corporation based in New York, has named three group presidents to head its three major operating groups. The management appointments came as the company announced the retirement of Herman Sokol as president, effective Oct. 31.

title: Pulitzer Prize-Winning Weekly Sold
description: They knew enough about journalism to gain national recognition for The Point Reyes Light, but David and Cathy Mitchell decided they lacked the business acumen to keep it shining. And so the husbandand-wife publishers have sold the tiny Marin County, Calif., weekly that won a Pulitzer Prize in 1979 for its investigation of the Synanon drug and alcohol center.

title: JOUSTING OVER NAME OF BYRNE ARENA
description: It was not a main topic of yesterday's debate at The New York Times, but the question, which has been on the minds of many voters, raised some smiles and hackles in the confrontation between the two men who want to succeed the Democratic Governor.

title: U.S. SHIPS SHOULD LOOK TO COSTS, NOT SUBSIDIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefing
description: A LTHOUGH Ronald Reagan retains personal and ideological rapport with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the President looks askance at Britain's high unemployment and inflation rates. At recent White House meetings, Mr. Reagan rejected tax increases to balance his budget. ''That's what Margaret Thatcher did and I'm not going to do it,'' the President said.

title: Woolworth Unit
description: -F.W. Woolworth & Company said that its British subsidiary, B and Q (Retail) Ltd., had agreed to buy Dodge City Ltd., a privately owned chain of do-it-yourself stores, for $38.1 million. The purchase, subject to Government approval, should become effective in a few weeks, it added. The deal will add 32 Dodge City stores to the 49 stores run by B and Q. Combined sales of the two companies last year were $151.7 million, excluding value-added tax.

title: Mother Charged In Neglect of Sons
description: A 20-year-old mother who, the police said, left her three infant sons alone and apparently unfed over the weekend, turned herself in to the police yesterday and was charged with endangering their welfare.

title: Oil Refining Is Sluggish
description: Domestic refineries operated at only two-thirds total capacity in the week ending Oct. 2, matching last April's two-and-a-half-year low point caused by sluggish demand and a growing oil glut, the Government reported.

title: GEORGE C. DICKEL JR.
description: George C. Dickel Jr., retired head of construction and fuel-oil supply companies in Queens and on Long Island, died Sunday.

title: CEY RETURNS AFTER ARM INJURY
description: The pitch was soaring toward Ron Cey's face on the night of Sept. 9. He threw his left hand out and felt a pain where the ball hit on the outside of the forearm. But the pain on the inside was 10 times worse, he said, and Ron Cey knew he was in deep trouble.

title: TORIES ATTACK MRS. THATCHER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, insisting ''all is well'' as she arrived for a crucial Conservative Party conference, came under renewed attack today from fellow Conservatives opposed to her tight-money policies.

title: Bridge: Contracts Seem 'Hopeless' Only in Eyes of Beholders
description: Some contracts that appear hopeless to the inexperienced player offer quite good prospects if an expert is in charge of the proceedings. Readers who wish to test their ability should cover the East-West hands in the diagram and plan the play in six no-trump after an opening spade lead. What is South's percentage chance of success?

title: A CLASH AT THE CLUB
description: ''I'll tell you what the Japanese are,'' said a disgruntled member of the Haworth Country Club. ''The Japanese are too ... too successful.''

title: Diana Trilling Encounters a New World
description: As an essayist, editor and author of a biography of D. H. Lawrence, Diana Trilling has a reputation for dealing in matters literary and her books have appealed mostly to intellectuals.

title: FOREIGN CURRENCY TRANSLATION HURTS NCR AND HONEYWELL
description: Unfavorable currency exchange translations helped to depress third-quarter earnings of two major computer makers. The NCR Corporation announced yesterday that its net income plunged 29.9 percent, compared with the third quarter of 1980, while Honeywell Inc. said that its earnings dropped 30.8 percent. The Control Data Corporation, however, aided by a strong revenue g ain anda lower tax rate, managed a 9.7 percent advan ce in net income.

title: PANEL CHALLENGES BREADTH OF C.I.A. GUIDELINES
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed guidelines for the Central Intelligence Agency appear to be a ''sweeping grant of authority to intelligence agencies to collect information on purely domestic matters,'' according to an analysis by the staff of the Senate Intelligence Committee.

title: Rider on IRT Shot
description: A subway rider was shot in the Times Square IRT station Monday night when he attempted to flee from a gunman who robbed him on a northbound train as it entered the station.

title: HOUSE VOTES CURB ON FOREIGN BIDS
description: The House today approved by voice vote a measure that would make it more difficult for foreigners to finance acquisition of American companies.

title: GRUMMAN SEEKS A MILLION SHARES
description: Continuing its efforts to block a proposed takeover by the LTV Corporation, the Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it intended to purchase up to a million shares of its own stock, which would give it control of approximately 42 percent of the 13.8 million outstanding shares.

title: SUPER-GOAL
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET 'STRENGTH' PLACED IN PERSPECTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDE DEFENDS THE CARE OF PRISONERS IN TEXAS
description: Texas convicts get adequate medical care, a state spokesman says in response to a doctor's report that inmates were being treated by untrained personnel under poor sanitary conditions.

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Wreckage on Iceland Glacier Identified as U.S. Navy Plane
description: The Navy confirmed today that the wreckage found on a glacier in Iceland was that of a Navy plane that crashed with nine men aboard 28 years ago.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Revs for the yr-ago first qr include $264,000 from a division that was sold at the end of that qr

title: SAUDIS REPORTED TO PLAN A HUGE STOCKPILE OF OIL
description: Saudi Arabia is planning to build the world's largest oil stockpile as a hedge against possible disruptions in the Persian Gulf region that might affect its oil production, according to Petroleum Information International, a weekly newsletter.

title: U.S. Troops of 7th Fleet Join Military Exercises in Thailand
description: Combat troops of the United States Seventh Fleet stormed ashore at a lonely beach in southern Thailand today in the first joint military exercise of the United States and Thailand in 18 months, officials said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can make a good case either way, but once a President makes a commitment it's important that it be fulfilled.'' - Former President Jimmy Carter, on Awacs sale. (A27:2.)

title: Flat U.S. Growth Seen
description: United States economic growth is expected to be flat in the fourth quarter, with little growth in the first half of next year, Charles Dumans, an economist and vice president at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, said at an economic seminar here today. ''Only from July 1 next year, with the secondround tax cuts, do we expect a return to significant growth in the United States economy of 2 1/2 to 3 percent,'' he added.

title: Stress Syndrome Held Handicap in Suit on Job
description: A Federal appeals board has established delayed stress syndrome as a handicap for which a person may not be dismissed.

title: CURBS OF TECHNOLOGY EXPORTS HURT BY GAPS IN ENFORCEMENT
description: Despite the growing concern of Government officials that sophisticated American technology and arms are being illegally shipped to unfriendly nations, including the Soviet Union, the Federal agencies charged with administering the export control laws remain understaffed and their enforcement efforts are spotty.

title: DODGERS OVERCOME EXPOS, 5-1
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers continued their postseason flair today when they defeated the Montreal Expos, 5-1, in the opening game of the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: CUTS IN AID TO YOUNG MOTHERS DEPLORED
description: REDUCTIONS in Federal assistance to pregnant teen-agers and adolescent mothers, as called for in the Reagan Administration's budget, which went into effect Oct. 1, will ultimately cost the Government more than they will save, according to a study released yesterday.

title: RODGERS PRIZE IS AWARDED TO A MUSICAL
description: ''Child of the Sun,'' a new musical by Damien Leake, has won the first annual Richard Rodgers Production Award. The $60,000 grant, which comes from income on Mr. Rodgers's $1 million gift and is administered by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, will be used to mount the work at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, 466 Grand Street.

title: U.S. SEEMS UNSURE ABOUT SPEEDING ARMS FLOW TO THE SUDAN
description: The Administration said today that it hoped to speed deliveries of military equipment to the Sudan but was uncertain how much faster deliveries could be made.

title: CLERIC SWORN IN AS IRAN'S PRESIDENT AMID CRIES OF 'DEATH TO AMERICA!'
description: Amid cries of ''Death to America!'' Iran's first clergyman-President took the oath of office before Parliament today and vowed to stamp out ''deviation, liberalism and American-influenced leftists.''

title: NEW ORLEANS SETTLES A SUIT CHARGING POLICE HIRING BIAS
description: An eight-year-old lawsuit charging the New Orleans Police Department with racial discrimination in hiring and promotions was settled here this morning, the day the suit was scheduled to reach trial.

title: Padres Drop Howard
description: The San Diego Padres, who finished last in the National League West in both halves of baseball's split season, dismissed Manager Frank Howard today after one year on the job. Jack McKeon, the club's general manager, made the announcement.

title: TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After net losses from discontinued operations of $19,194,000 for the qr and $35,747,000 for the 9 mos...C-After net losses from discontinued operations of $5,679,000 for the qr and $13,094,000 for the 9mos

title: REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes foreign currency gains of $16.7 million for the qr and $42.2 million for the 9 mos...C-After $6 million foreign currency loss for the qr and $4.7 million foreign currency gain for the 9 mos

title: Appeals End for Tose
description: The Supreme Court, without comment, refused to review the claims of Leonard Tose, majority owner of the Philadelphia Eagles, that five banks conspired to deny loans to him and his team in 1977 in an effort to deprive him of controlling interest in the club.

title: TEXAN WAS GIANT AMONG OILMEN
description: John Whitfield Mecom Sr., for many years one of the world's largest independent oil operators, died Monday night at his home in the River Oaks section of Houston. He was 70 years old and had suffered from a heart ailment for almost a year.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S a nice idea - small towels especially for guests. They're pretty and practical, they dress up the bathroom and they have only one flaw. At the end of the evening, after 10 people have paid that room a visit, the little devils are often as crisp and fresh as they were when they came out of the linen closet.

title: JUKE JOINTS: WHERE STYLES MATE AND NEW MUSIC IS BORN
description: call them what you will, these disreputable and often dangerous establishments are the bedrock of American popular music. Tomorrow's rock stars often start out in juke joints. In fact, rock-and-roll was born in them. Living in New York, one tends to forget that such places exist. Musicians who perform in New York nightclubs tend to perform with one eye on their audience and the other on a favorable review or a recording contract -lucky breaks that only an urban media center can bestow.

title: 10-YEAR RESTORATION PLANNED FOR CENTRAL PARK
description: An extensive 10-year restoration of Central Park will be announced today and will include the refurbishing of Bethesda Terrace, the formal center of the park and a symbol of its disrepair.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard CAMERA LUCIDA. Reflections on Photog- raphy. By Roland Barthes. Translated by Richard Howard. Illustrated. 119 pages. Hill & Wang/Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $10.95.

title: OPEC Talks Foreseen
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will hold an emergency meeting before the end of October, seeking an end to oil-pricing chaos before the group's December meeting in Abu Dhabi, a leading Kuwaiti newspaper said today.

title: Warner to Expand Office of President
description: Warner Communications Inc., like a growing number of corporations these days, has no president. Instead, the big New York-based entertainment company is run by chairman and chief executive officer, Steven J. Ross, 53 years old, and a group of executives known collectively as the office of the president, established in 1976.

title: A MUSICIAN CONNECTS WITH BASEBALL
description: ''Babe Ruth once lived here,'' said the violinist Itzhak Perlman. ''That's what people told me when I moved into this apartment. I believe it. There were a lot of broken windows. Babe must have practiced a lot.''

title: AFTER A SLOW START, NEW YORK 'CITYCAID' IS BEING DISCOVERED
description: To the Editor:

title: FALL TIED TO DOLLAR GAIN
description: The third-quarter earnings of the International Business Machines Corporation tumbled 21.6 percent, the company reported yesterday. Analysts said that the decline was worse than had been expected and made it likely that 1981 would be the second year in the last three in which I.B.M.'s earnings have declined from the year before.

title: VTN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
WOMETCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DIS-(MIS-?)INFORMATION
description: Three years ago, I went to the Soviet Union on a reporting trip for Mother Jones magazine. At the Leningrad airport, a customs official spotted an issue of the magazine in my wife's suitcase. Consternation ensued. For more than an hour, she was surrounded by a plainclothesman and three officials in different kinds of uniforms. One of the latter, a stony-faced security-police officer, shook his head somberly and muttered as he read, page by page, a long critical article about Soviet treatment of Jews and dissidents. Finally, he confiscated the magazine.

title: REPUBLICANS COOL TO WHITE HOUSE BUDGET DEFERRALS
description: Republican Congressional leaders were cool today to President Reagan's proposal to defer some Government spending, and Democratic leaders assailed the approach as an attempt to circumvent the budget process.

title: THATCHER POLICIES INVITE CATASTROPHE, TORIES TOLD
description: A former Conservative Cabinet minister warned his party today that it faced electoral catastrophe unless it turned away from rigid monetarism and ''demonstrated more outrage at our unacceptable level of unemployment.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 18.00-18.50 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DEMOCRAT, WOOED BY REAGAN, IS SET TO SWITCH
description: Representative Eugene V. Atkinson, a conservative Democrat who has been intensively wooed by the White House, plans to tell President Reagan tomorrow that he is switching to the Republican Party.

title: Post Studying Sunday Edition
description: The New York Post has set up an editorial task force to study publication of a Sunday edition, according to Roger Wood, The Post's executive editor.

title: CARTER IS CRITICAL OF REAGAN POLICIES
description: A few hours before his first private meeting with President Reagan at the White House, Jimmy Carter dismissed his successor's Administration today as an ''aberration on the political scene.'' He said its ''false and erroneous promises are now being realized.''

title: An Appraisal
description: When President Kennedy called James Tobin to ask him to be a member of his Council of Economic Advisers in 1961, the Yale professor asked whether he wasn't making a mistake, saying, ''I'm an ivory tower economist.'' Mr. Kennedy replied, ''That's all right, I'm an ivory tower President.''

title: THERE'S NO 'BETTY CROCKER' BUT SHE'S A REALITY TO MANY
description: ''Betty Crocker'' is one of the most famous names in cooking, and hundreds of men have written over the years proposing marriage. Yet Betty Crocker is not a person but a 60-year-old corporate trade character created by General Mills, the Minneapolis-based food giant, and used to provide a homey touch to everything from cake mixes to pudding - and to adorn the company's 50 or so cookbook titles, which have sold more than 45 million copies.

title: AN OFFBEAT SUCCESS
description: Alice Antreassian spent two years putting together "Armenian Cooking Today" but she devoted 20 or more years to collecting the 200 or so recipes reproduced.

title: SEPTEMBER STORE SALES UP BY 0.4%
description: Sales by the nation's retailers crept up four-tenths of 1 percent in September, continuing a pattern of very sluggish growth since last spring, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: TAYLOR DEVICES CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-Including $20,264 extraordinary gain...C-Net loss

title: SCHMIDT IS GIVEN PACEMAKER
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany had an operation today to install a pacemaker for his heart, a Government spokesman reported.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $369,000 for the qr and $1.1 million for the 9 mos

title: Prosecutor Tells Jury Of Presley Addiction
description: Elvis Presley was a drug addict and received ''staggering amounts'' of drugs from Dr. George Nichopoulos, a state prosecutor charged today.

title: MERRILL LYNCH PROFIT OFF, REVENUES UP
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, corporate parent of the nation's largest securities firm, reported yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell 29.2 percent despite a sharp increase in revenues.

title: A Tale of Great Expectorations
description: AFTER George M. Steinbrenner III had instructed Lee MacPhail on how to do his job as president of the American League, Billy Martin commented on the accusation by George III that Martin's Oakland pitchers throw the illegal spitball. The first pitch, kosher or trayf, had not yet been thrown in the Yankees' playoff with the A's for the American League pennant, but the latest episode of the popular series, The Bill and George Story, was off and running.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE; NOFZIGER EXIT TO ALLOW SHAKE-UP OF POLITICAL TEAM
description: At a recent White House meeting, James A. Baker 3d, the chief of staff, announced a crackdown on the rule requiring President Reagan's senior aides to wear the distinctive lapel badges that identify them to the Secret Service.

title: Coast Judge Found Guilty
description: A San Diego Municipal Court judge, Lewis Wenzell, has been sentenced to two months in jail on his conviction on five misdemeanor counts of soliciting prostitution. The lawyer for Mr. Wenzell said he would appeal.

title: THE EXILE'S RETURN
description: Long before the stylish people took up Nantucket and sent real estate prices into space we bought an old house there for a song. Well, an aria. Anyhow, as the summer people became more and more beautiful with each passing year we began to feel like unsightly embarrassments, frogs at a peacocks' ball as it were.

title: FIFTH GAME IS DRAWN IN CHESS MATCH
description: ''Viktor Korchnoi is a crazy man,'' said Lev Polugayevsky, one of Anatoly Karpov's seconds, after Korchnoi played on to the 68th move before agreeing to a draw in the fifth game of the world chess championship match here.

title: AQUEDUCT'S EYE ON THE AFFLUENT
description: Sunday night, at the preview opening of Aqueduct's $7 million Equestris restaurant complex, the Duke Ellington Orchestra provided dinner music for the 1,000 or so guests at a black-tie gala. When Mercer Ellington, the Duke's trumpet-playing son, began a set with the band's signature tune, ''Take the A Train,'' he was also unwittingly sounding an appropriate theme for the seven months of racing at Aqueduct that begin this afternoon.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cargill Inc., Minneapolis, has elected the following as group vice presidents: John P. Cole, Trading group; James A. Howard, Commodity Marketing group; Cary H. Hum@phries, Industrial group; Donald L. Leavenworth, U.S. Oilseed Processing group, and Gerald M. Mitchell, Milling group.

title: BRIEFING
description: D ESPITE a court finding that ideology has been placed in the way of due process, the Reagan Administration persists in its attempt to deny Federal workers coverage for therapeutic abortion in their health care programs. Last week, a Federal district judge found that the Administration's director of personnel management, Donald J. Devine, had exceeded his authority in ordering abortion benefits to be cut back in Federal workers' health plans.

title: RIGHTS GROUP SAYS F.B.I. MADE UP DATA PRESENTED IN 2 TRIALS
description: Amnesty International asserts that the Federal Bureau of Investigation fabricated evidence and used other means to put leaders of black, Indian and other American minority groups behind bars. The human rights organization made public its report today.

title: KOCH AND STEIN BACK EACH OTHER BUT DISAGREE ON PARTY CHIEF
description: Mayor Koch and Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan, both of whom are seeking re-election, endorsed each other yesterday on the steps of City Hall. The event evolved into a rough-and-tumble news conference over the role of race in city politics.

title: ISRAELIS, IN SHIFT, REPORTED BACKING A WEST BANK PLAN
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel has reportedly expressed readiness to accept the principles for Palestinian self-rule proposed a year ago by the Carter Administration.

title: U.S. PROSECUTERS LOSE APPEAL OF CURB ON EVIDENCE AT MARGIOTTA TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors lost an appeal yesterday to overturn rulings on evidence for a second trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman. He was charged with arranging insurance kickbacks for political allies.

title: Germany's Outlook
description: A trend of gradually rising West German economic indicators was reported today by the Economics Minister, Count Otto Lambsdorff. In a speech prepared for delivery at the opening of the Frankfurt Book Fair, Count Lambsdorff said this trend should continue into 1982, barring unforeseen external factors. He warned that, although figures for incoming orders, industrial production and the current account balance of payments are favorable, unemployment is expected to continue to worsen during the decade.

title: Economic Scene; Timing the Ups And Downs
description: A FUNDAMENTAL principle of political economy is that an incumbent President should have any recession in an odd-numbered year and a recovery in an even-numbered year - in time for the Congressional or Presidential election.

title: 'Sugar Babies' Turns 2
description: It was a party celebrating the second anniversary of ''Sugar Babies,'' but it was not the second anniversary of ''Sugar Babies.'' ''That was on Oct. 4,'' said Mickey Rooney, who explained that the party at Astor's on Monday night had been postponed until Ann Miller returned to the cast after some time off.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE;
description: A new apartment for Governor Carey and his wife, on the second floor of the Executive Mansion in Albany, has been completed at a cost to the state of $84,428.

title: 2d Death From I.R.A. Bomb
description: An 18-year-old civilian died today of wounds suffered Saturday when the Irish Republican Army set off a nail bomb here, police said. It brought the casualty toll to two dead and 38 wounded. The latest victim, John Patrick Breslin, received severe head injuries when the bomb, hidden in a parked laundry van, was detonated by remote control as a busload of British troops passed by.

title: Amin Aide Goes on Trial
description: Bob Astles, a British-born former aide of the ousted Ugandan dictator Idi Amin, pleaded not guilty at the start of his murder trial in Kampala today. Mr. Astles, who amassed considerable wealth and power during Mr. Amin's brutal rule, is charged with murdering a fisherman, Henry Musisi, near Lake Victoria in an antismuggling operation four years ago.

title: Labor Party in Norway Resigns Its Posts
description: Ten years of Labor Party rule in Norway ended today when King Olav V approved the resignation of the Labor Prime Minister, Gro Harlem Brundtland, and her Government.

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARTHRITIS: THE MOST COMMON CRIPPLER First of two articles.
description: Arthritis is truly a universal illness. Virtually all of us, if we live long enough, will develop arthritis in one or more of our joints. The disease has been around at least as long as Neanderthal man - the one nearly complete specimen of a Neanderthal spine is deformed by arthritis, which has created the misimpression that all such early humans walked in a bent posture. Today, arthritis in one of its myriad forms afflicts some 31 million Americans seriously enough to require medical treatment. More than one in 10 arthritis victims are severely affected and unable to carry out normal activities. In one form, arthritis is the most common cause of pain and stiffness in people over 50; in another, it afflicts a quarter of a million children under age 16.

title: STAGE: LA MAMA RESTAGES 3 CLASSICS
description: TWENTY years ago, Ellen Stewart opened her first Off Off Broadway theater, and it became La Mama, the mother of the American experimental theater movement. La Mama continues to be a valuable and prolific playhouse, performing two primary functions - discovering new plays and playwrights and welcoming distinguished foreign companies. In celebration of her anniversary, Miss Stewart is having a festival of revivals of plays, many of them with the original cast and director.

title: Stephen Y.  Hord, a Partner In Brown Brothers Harriman
description: Stephen Y. Hord, a partner in Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., and former manager of the bankers' Chicago office, died Monday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 84 years old and lived in Lake Forest, Ill.

title: TOBIN OF YALE WINS NOBEL IN ECONOMICS
description: James Tobin of Yale University was awarded the 1981 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science today for his analyses of financial markets and their effect on how businesses and families spend and save money.

title: Cooling System Test At Reactor Is Hailed
description: An experiment designed to test the emergency cooling systems in an experimental breeder reactor has been termed successful.

title: TV: 'JACQUELINE BOUVIER KENNEDY'
description: TONIGHT'S three-hour saga, on ABC-TV at 8 o'clock, is a biography of Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy. Some idea of the tone can be gleaned from a comment said to be made by Stephen Gethers, the scriptwriter, recalling when he was first approached for the project by Louis Rudolph, the producer:

title: YOUNG SUPPORTED FOR MAYOR BY LOSER IN ATLANTA PRIMARY
description: Former Representative Andrew Young, the leading vote-getter in the first phase of the campaign for Mayor of this city, today received the endorsement of A. Reginald Eaves, whose strong third-place showing in the nonpartisan primary last week forced the Oct. 27 runoff.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH BACKING SOMALIA TO THE HILT
description: To the Editor:

title: BAR ASSOCIATION DIVIDED ON WHY AN OFFICER QUIT
description: The City Bar Association, traditionally a staid collegial body, is divided on the reason for the abrupt resignation of its executive secretary, even as the search for his successor continues.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: EDWIN NEWMAN notes that on the southwest corner of 54th Street and Madison Avenue, ''where a relatively modest 42-story building is going up for 'POSSESSION SUMMER 1982,' the owners have placed, at second-floor level, four window boxes filled with flowers.'' He adds, ''They have also posted a sign decorated with representations of a pumpkin, an apple, a pear and an orange.'' It bears these words:

title: Two Bodies Found After Fire in Jersey
description: The bodies of two young brothers were removed from the charred remains of a tenement after police officers and firefighters tore down what was left of the building and sifted through the rubble.

title: SUDAN ASKS HELP OF U.S. IN COMBATING SUBVERSION
description: The Government has asked the United States for urgent help to strengthen internal security in the face of what it says is increasing subversive activity sponsored by Libya.

title: Yachting Unit Sued Over Suspension
description: Seymore Sinett, whose yacht Williwaw was accused of handicap irregularities during last winter's competition in the Southern Ocean Racing Conference, sued for damages yesterday against the United States Yacht Racing Union, the sport's national authority.

title: YANKS TOP A'S, 3-1, IN FIRST GAME OF PENNANT PLAYOFF
description: George Steinbrenner seemed to be more upset than Billy Martin about developments in the first game of the American League pennant playoff last night, but Steinbrenner's team won and Martin's team lost.

title: AFTER A SLOW START, NEW YORK 'CITYCAID' IS BEING DISCOVERED
description: To the Editor:

title: NETS EXPECTED TODAY TO OFFER PACT TO KNICKS' RAY WILLIAMS
description: The Nets expect to offer Ray Williams, the Knicks' free-agent guard, $500,000 a year for three years today, according to Alan Cohen, the New Jersey club's chairman.

title: WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WESTERN CO OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in the second qr this yr

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK ASKS 40 NATIONS TO EXPLAIN THEIR ANTI-U.S. STAND
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American delegate, has privately asked 40 nations to explain their support for a document of ''base lies and malicious attacks upon the good name of the United States.''

title: LOWENSTEIN, M, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-Net loss...C-Including $449,000 or 13 cents a shr net gain for the qr and 9 mos resulting from the sale of the company's Wambel plant in Union, S.C. and the closing of its Aleo plant in Rockingham, N.C. and also a $623,000 or 19 cents a shr net gain for the 9 mos on the sale of part of the company's chemical division

title: A NUN, 30, IS RAPED AND CUT REPEATEDLY IN 116TH ST. CONVENT
description: A 30-year-old nun was raped and robbed in a South Bronx convent on Saturday by a man who scratched a series of crosses on her body with a sharp implement, the police said yesterday.

title: FREDDIE FIELDS MAY HEAD M-G-M FILM UNIT
description: According to film-industry sources, Freddie Fields, an independent producer since 1975, has been offered the newly created position of president of the motion-picture division of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Corporation.

title: Bush Arrives in Bogota Amid Heavy Security
description: Vice President Bush landed in Bogota today for a 22-hour visit to the Andean city where Nelson A. Rockefeller's arrival led to serious rioting in 1969.

title: Expos' Spaceman Still Traveling Alone
description: Where was Bill Lee? Yesterday, as the Montreal Expos took their workout in Dodger Stadium, the club president, John McHale, anxiously scanned the blue skies.

title: REAGAN GETS A LIFT
description: The bet in this corner is that President Reagan is going to squeak through the Senate with his military program for Saudi Arabia. For the moment, the votes for and against him are about even, but in the end the issue is likely to be decided by about 10 senators who will switch to the President's side despite their doubts about the merits of his case.

title: U.S. DIET GUIDELINE WILL BE ASSAYED
description: Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block surprised and delighted a recent meeting of the American Dietetic Association when he said that Dietary Guidelines, the official Government recommendations for sound eating, would ''remain the basis in our nutrition information and education programs'' and would be reissued by the Government Printing Office.

title: SPAIN A 'PARTNER,' REAGAN TELLS KING
description: President Reagan welcomed King Juan Carlos of Spain to the White House today and assured him of United States support for the ''complete integration'' of Spain into both the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Economic Community.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four went down by 59 cents, to $105.68, during the two-week period that ended Friday. According to the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, shoppers paid $6.71 less during this time last year.

title: JUSTICES TO REVIEW STATES' CURBS ON SCHOOL BUSING
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the constitutionality of efforts by the States of Washington and California to restrict the use of busing as a tool for racial integration of local schools.

title: REVUE: 'PUMP BOYS' BY JIM WANN
description: ''PUMP BOYS and Dinettes,'' the delightful revue that opened last night at the Colonnades, offers three ways of dealing with the energy crisis. You can eat and get gas. Or you can eat. Or you can just get gas.

title: British Airways To Cut Pensions
description: British Airways, which last month announced it was planning to eliminate 9,000 jobs in a bid to stay in business, gave its employees another financial shock with proposals to cut staff pensions.

title: REAGAN OFFICIALS WOULD LET STATES LIMIT FOOD STAMPS
description: Reagan Administration officials want to give states the power to tighten eligibility standards and reduce benefits in the food stamp program, which has been governed by uniform national standards for 10 years.

title: STOCKS FALL DESPITE PRIME CUT
description: The stock market, despite a reduction in the prime interest rate by a number of major banks, ended slightly lower yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: MORTON-NORWICH PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge: Passive Play Not Immune To Post-mortem Criticism
description: It sometimes happens that a defender sits through a deal, following suit and making routine plays, apparently uninvolved. But when play is over, he is assailed by his partner for missing an unusual defensive stroke.

title: STEINBRENNER ASSAILS UMPIRES
description: Annoyed at an eighth-inning stall by Cliff Johnson of the Oakland A's that led to the removal of his relief pitcher, Ron Davis, only three balls later, George Steinbrenner last night loudly criticized the umpiring crew assigned to the American League championship series, which opened with a 3-1 victory for the Yankees.

title: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1981; The Economy
description: Prof. James Tobin of Yale was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for his analyses of the financial markets and their impact on the way businesses and families spend and save. The 63-year-old economist's work was described as a breakthrough in a ''classic'' problem. (Page A1.) Mr. Tobin is known for his roles in both ''ivory tower'' and national economics. (D22.)

title: Cosmos Defeated, 4-2; Chinaglia, Davis Score
description: Borussia Dortumud of the German First Division defeated the New York Cosmos today, 4-2.

title: Theotis Brown Dealt
description: Beating yesterday's trading deadline in the National Football League, the St. Louis Cardinals sent Theotis Brown, who began the season as their starting fullback, to the Seattle Seahawks for draft choices. Brown, a second-round draft pick from U.C.L.A. three years ago, had only 15 carries for 52 yards and two touchdowns this season. The Cardinals were unhappy with his blocking for Ottis Anderson and his fumbling (he lost the ball once Sunday against the Giants), and Brown had lost his starting job to Wayne Morris. ... The Dallas Cowboys, who have lost two straight, announced that Tony Hill would replace Butch Johnson at wide receiver for Sunday's game against the Rams. ... Ted McKnight, halfback for the Kansas City Chiefs, underwent knee surgery and will be out the rest of the season.

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-The company did not report yr-ago net income; shr earnings reflect payment of divds on preferred stock issued in Feb to finance in part the acqusition of Idaho Timberland

title: WILDCAT STRIKES ERUPT IN POLAND IN PROTEST AGAINST FOOD SHORTAGES
description: At least 22,000 workers went on strike today in three central Polish towns to protest food shortages. The work stoppages came as the Government proposed new talks and asked the Solidarity union to accept its offer to join a commission to oversee prices, supplies and distribution of food.

title: TOBIN ALWAYS 'AHEAD OF FIELD'
description: It has been nearly 40 years since James Tobin went through naval officer training in the same class as Herman Wouk, who went on to write ''The Caine Mutiny.''

title: St. Paul Accord
description: St. Paul Companies, St. Paul, said that it had reached a definitive agreement with the Home Insurance Company of New York for the purchase, by St. Paul, of the Seaboard Surety Company for $84 million.

title: West German Held in East
description: East German security forces have arrested a Hamburg city government employee and charged him with spying, the East German press agency said today. The man, identifed only as Rudiger N., was arrested ''in the act'' of espionage and has been committed for trial, the press agency said.

title: Infant Is Thrown 5 Floors to Death
description: An 18-month-old infant boy was thrown to his death from a fifthfloor window of a Bronx apartment building yesterday by an uncle, the police said.

title: MEDICAL STUDENTS LEARNING TO BE AGED
description: Students age quickly here at the Medical College of Pennsylvania - in an instant, in fact. The consolation is that, unlike the patients they will treat one day, they recover their youth just as rapidly.

title: Who Profits From Tax-Exempt Bonds?
description: 13.5 percent on Hawaii Airport System bonds ... 15 percent on Washington State Power bonds ... 14.6 percent on Philadelphia Water and Sewage bonds ....

title: Dyson Company Buys E.P. Dutton
description: E.P. Dutton, the century-old publisher, has been acquired by John S. Dyson, chairman of the New York State Power Authority.

title: MICHAEL FLORINSKY, 86, AUTHOR AND EX-COLUMBIA PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Michael T. Florinsky, professor emeritus of economics at Columbia University and author of more than a dozen books on his native Russia and European problems, died last Saturday in Switzerland. He was 86 years old.

title: Advertising; Let Them Drink Brandy
description: IF all Americans behaved like those in Wisconsin, James R. McManus would be in heaven. Mr. McManus is president of the California Brandy Advisory Board, and for some unknown reason, the people of Wisconsin, along with those in Minnesota and northern Michigan, are unusually big brandy drinkers.

title: A MASTERY OF MOROCCAN CUISINE
description: I first met Suzy Larochette on a visit to Marrakech, Morocco, more than a dozen years ago. My visit had been spurred by an account I had read in which the Paris-based restaurant critics, Henri Gault and Christian Millau, had proposed that the Maison Arabe in Marrakech was the greatest restaurant in the world. The owners of the Maison Arabe were Suzy and her mother, Helene Sebillon.

title: 5 Killed in Explosion At Texas Chemical Plant
description: An explosion at a Dow Chemical plant tonight killed five workers and injured at least seven others, one critically, a company spokesman said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHARP

title: 379 Heat-Resisting Tiles On Shuttle Are Replaced
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today the repair and replacement of the 379 heat-shielding tiles that were damaged last month when a rocket propellent spilled down the side of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Persson of Islanders Is Lost for 10 Days
description: Stefan Persson, the Islander defenseman, will be out 10 days with two cracked ribs on his right side, the club said today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN planning the menus for this column, I have tried to offer a broad range of food while taking cost into consideration as well. We have probably stressed chicken more than any other meat or poultry because it is almost always one of the least expensive items on the market. At times, however, I like to propose foods that are slightly more expensive to prove that some of the most elegant of meats are not all that difficult and time-consuming to prepare.

title: New Head for Seligman
description: At one of Wall Street's old-line firms - J.W. Seligman & Company, founded in 1864 - Ronald T. Schroeder, 34, has been elected president. He succeeds Fred E. Brown, 67, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the investment advisory, brokerage and service concern with $3.7 billion worth of assets under management.

title: NEW LIFE ON THE WAY FOR SITE AT FIFTH AVE. AND 42ND ST.
description: Diagonally across the street from the New York Public Library, on the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, stands a rundown, mostly vacant six-story building with a long past and little future. Retailers on short-term leases do business at high rents on the ground floor, but the upper floors are used, if at all, for storage.

title: EGYPTIANS ARE TOLD WHY TO VOTE YES
description: On Monday night, the Government-controlled Egyptian television broadcast a special program entitled ''Why Say Yes?''

title: The Talk of Berkeley
description: It was a scene from an earlier age that would warm the heart of a traditionalist. Two lines of bright-faced freshmen at the University of California waited to be presented to the chancellor, I. Michael Heyman, and Mrs. Heyman. Men wearing suits and ties stood in one, and women wearing party dresses were in the other at the annual reception for new students.

title: Death Toll in Mexico Put at 74 After 2 Storms Strike Coast
description: Two storms that struck Mexico's Pacific coast five days apart caused at least 74 deaths and $84 million damage to crops and cattle, officials said today.

title: Nixon Meets With Hussein
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon met with King Hussein today and discussed the Middle East, including the Palestinian issue, Jordanian sources said. Mr. Nixon came here from Saudi Arabia, which he visited after attending the funeral of President Anwar el-Sadat in Egypt. Details of Mr. Nixon's talks with the King were not disclosed.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1981
description: International Israel is now ready to accept the principles for Palestinian selfrule that were proposed a year ago by the Carter Administration, according to two members of the American delegation to President Anwar el-Sadat's funeral in Cairo. Delegation members said that Israel's new position was disclosed by Prime Minister Menachem Begin. (Page A1, Column 6.) The election of Hosni Mubarak as President of Egypt was placed before the voters. The 53-year-old Vice President was the only candidate to succeed President Sadat in the balloting, which was held a week after he was assassinated. The count will be announced today when Parliament convenes to swear in Mr. Mubarak, who will then address the nation. (A1:3.)

title: Castro and Italian Communist Hold Talks on World Issues
description: Fidel Castro of Cuba and Enrico Berlinguer, the Italian Communist Party leader, held talks on international problems in Havana yesterday, Granma, the Communist Party daily, reported today.

title: LTV's Income Climbs Sharply
description: The LTV Corporation, which is currently attempting to take over a fiercely resisting Grumman Corporation, announced yesterday that it had a net income of $97.1 million, or $1.86 cents a share, in the third quarter, compared with earnings of $4.9 million, or 6 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales increased 46.6 percent, to $1.95 billion, from $1.33 billion.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings represent subshares

title: Soviet and Sweden Sign Pact To Eliminate Double Taxation
description: The Soviet Union and Sweden today signed an agreement to eliminate double taxation on income and property, the Soviet press agency Tass said.

title: ROBINTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MARTIN IN NEW DISPUTES
description: Billy Martin, unusually mild-mannered as his A's prepared to face the Yankees, was cool but controversial in the dugout last night as the Yankees beat Oakland, 3-1, in the first game of the American League championship series.

title: Continental Air Near Texas Tie
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board said that it will permit the takeover by Texas International Airlines of Continental Air Lines to become effective immediately. The action followed approval of the merger by President Reagan.

title: Nets' Gminski Is Savoring Even the Little Victories
description: A brush with death alters a man's priorities, changes his perspective and heightens his appreciation for the things around him. Last August, Mike Gminski, the No. 1 center for the Nets, suffered a rare staph infection in his lower back, which had earlier been bruised. Before it was detected, the infection had entered his bloodstream, and it could have killed him.

title: Jets Call Back Springs
description: The Jets brought their roster to full strength today by adding Kirk Springs, a defensive back from Miami of Ohio. Springs had failed to survive the final cut.He was picked up to replace Freeman McNeil, the rookie running back who was placed on the injured-reserve list Saturday.

title: SEAGRAM SETS OFFER FOR ITS OWN STOCK
description: The Seagram Company announced yesterday that it would make a tender offer to buy 5 million, or 14.25 percent, of its own shares at $60 a share.

title: Two Pieces of I.D.
description: Will the person who knows the real Reagan position on identification cards please stand up?

title: 1. Old Friends in Toyland
description: Toad, Mole, Badger and Rat, out of Kenneth Grahame's ''The Wind in the Willows,'' have been translated by David Hyman into endearing stuffed toys that sit up nicely to be read to. Mr. Hyman, a 24-yearold graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design, used the illustrations of Michael Hague in the Ariel Books edition of the Grahame classic as his models and has been faithful to costume details. The animals will be available for $10 each at the Manhattan Laboratory Museum, 314 West 54th Street, by next Tuesday. Do-ityourself kits for the characters will be $5.50. 2. Jewelry From the Past Cut-steel and marcasite jewelry is having a revival. If you weren't lucky enough to inherit your grandmother's antique pin or belt buckle, you might have a look at the collection of 19th-century ornaments at the James II Galleries. The buckles are especially interesting in this year of waistline emphasis. The shop has added black suede belts to some of the handsome cut-steel buckles (the ones shown are $375 and $435) and also sells pieces separately. The galleries are at 15 East 57th Street.

title: L.I. Couple Killed
description: An elderly couple from Islip Terrace, L.I., were killed when their car collided with a Long Island Rail Road train at a Central Islip grade crossing, the Suffolk County police reported.

title: G.M. SHIFT: OUTSIDE SUPPLIERS
description: The General Motors Corporation, historically the domestic automobile company most committed to producing its own components, is looking increasingly to outside suppliers as a means of lowering its labor costs, according to the company's chairman, Roger B. Smith.

title: Israeli Troops Allow Palestinian Protest
description: Israeli troops on the West Bank allowed Palestinian students to hold a symbolic funeral today for a slain leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: International Paper, Boise And Reynolds Metals Down
description: The International Paper Company, the world's largest paper company and a major producer of building materials, reported yesterday that the continuing housing slump caused earnings in the third quarter to plunge 23.6 percent, as sales edged eight-tenths of 1 percent higher.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 14.674 percent was set at yesterday's weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp commercial paper, compared with an average rate of 15.351 percent last week.

title: HARTFORD MAYOR LOSES IN RERUN OF CITY PRIMARY
description: Thirman L. Milner, a State Representative, took a major step toward becoming the first popularly elected black mayor in New England by winning the Democratic nomination for Mayor of Hartford in a primary rerun tonight. He defeated the five-term incumbent, George A. Athanson.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SUN TO SELL 25% OF UNIT TO ONTARIO
description: The Sun Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell 25 percent of its Canadian subsidiary to Ontario Energy Resources Ltd. for $650 million (Canadian), or about $543.4 million in United States funds. Sun eventually plans to turn over 51 percent control of the unit to Canadian interests.

title: THE OTHER REFUGEES
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in Dec 1980

title: NICOLET INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to include Nicolet Paratronic Corp acquired June 18, 1981 on a pooling of interests basis

title: Firestone Plans $91 Million Outlay
description: Officials of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced plans to invest $91 million in their North American tire operations as part of a companywide $234 million capital program for the fiscal year 1982.

title: Bags Taken in $400,000 Theft Found in a Canyon in Arizona
description: An informant directed police to a canyon 30 miles north of Prescott today, where they recovered 15 of the 40 bank bags stolen from an armored van in a $400,0000 robbery Saturday.

title: Ends and Means in the Middle East
description: When Presidents Reagan, Carter, Ford and Nixon more or less agree on how to proceed in the Middle East, you'd think the United States had achieved a solid consensus. And indeed, their comments have cumulatively defined America's deep interests in the region. But a worthy foreign policy requires a match between ends and means. Most Middle East actors do not share America's view of their interests or its plans for their protection.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: IN the days when I worked in restaurants I would return home each day to my own kitchen, feeling that something important was missing there. Actually, lots of important things were missing, but I had one thing in mind, one thing that would give my kitchen a sense of meaning business: a butcher block for pounding meat. Of course, I didn't need the butcher block at home in those days any more than I needed the other appurtenances of a terrific kitchen. Though I did almost all my important cooking on the job, I would have felt better, more secure, if the butcher bdock was there in my own home.

title: IT'S FIRST NIGHT IN JAIL FOR AN ACTOR
description: He has been arrested before, but his scrape with the law in Stowe, Vt., was the first to result in a night in jail, according to Oliver Reed, the British actor.

title: PRESS IN BUFFALO IS HONORING NEWS BAN BY CANADIAN COURT
description: A seemingly routine order by a Canadian court has created an unusual problem for journalists in Buffalo. The court ordered newspapers and broadcast stations not to report pretrial testimony in a murder case against a Toronto woman who dropped her 2-month-old son into Niagara Falls on Aug. 30, and the news organizations are honoring the order.

title: G.M. Plant Started
description: Construction workers began pouring concrete at the site of the General Motors Corporation's new $500 million assembly plant astride the Detroit-Hamtramck border. The plant, which will assemble front-wheel-drive luxury cars such as Cadillac's Eldorado and Seville models, is scheduled to be completed by early 1984.

title: TOPAZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Marijuana and Acid
description: For a time, Gordon Harris, the chief of police in Horry County, S.C., was having so much trouble disposing of 832 bales of contraband marijuana that, he says jokingly, he thought of sending it to New York to be smoked.

title: Market Place; Resorts Shares And Futures
description: RESORTS INTERNATIONAL is awash in casino profits, but the shares are being buffeted in the wake of even larger losses in Treasury futures contracts.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AGREEMENT INTENSIFIES SUNBEAM BIDDING BATTLE
description: Allegheny International and the Sunbeam Corporation announced a definitive merger agreement yesterday, firing the first volley in a bidding war for Sunbeam between Allegheny and IC Industries for one of the world's leading home appliance makers.

title: WINE TALK
description: IT'S been estimated that 100,000 people are taking wine appreciation courses in the United States. If this fascination with wine can be considered a healthy sign, Manhattan is in great condition. Wine courses continue to proliferate here so that this fall about 30 are being given, with more promised by early 1982. Every aspect of wine appreciation - from tasting techniques to investing - can now be studied in a Manhattan classroom.

title: WESTERN PACIFIC RAILROAD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Silver Disallowed
description: New York's Commodity Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, the two biggest silver futures markets, announced yesterday that the silver being offered by the General Services Administration at weekly auctions starting this morning would not be acceptable for delivery against contracts outstanding on their exchanges.

title: HISTORIAN AND NOVELIST; James Horan, 67, Dies; Historian and Novelist
description: James D. Horan, a historian of the Old West, novelist and newsman who was the author of 40 books, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan after open-heart surgery that was performed Oct. 2. A resident of Little Falls, N.J., he was 67 years old.

title: Legislator Asks for End To Strike by Controllers
description: Representative William D. Ford, Democrat of Michigan, head of the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee, urged the Reagan Administration today to settle the 10-week-old air traffic controllers' strike, contending ''the pressure is building out there.''

title: Gun Used to Kill Bus Driver Found
description: The gun a Brooklyn bus passenger used Saturday to kill the driver after being denied a transfer has been recovered. The gun, a .357 magnum, was found in a factory doorway in Brooklyn yesterday morning and later a ballistics check showed that it was used in the killing, the police said.

title: A REUNION FOR CARTER AND COLLEAGUES
description: The ''outs'' began arriving at 7:30 last night, driving their own cars. You could tell they were out of office now, because nobody was in a hurry.

title: SERVING THE U.S.
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has often objected to military conscription on grounds that he declares ''philosophical.'' This is, I suspect, his way of conceding that his objections are unimportant. But even if his call to get ''Government off our backs'' were more than a slogan, it is particularly misplaced here.

title: INTEREST RATES SLIGHTLY HIGHER
description: Interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday. Although the consensus forecast is for lower interest rates in the next few weeks, dealers said yesterday's move to lower prices and higher yields was not too surprising since it followed a week when prices rose rapidly.

title: RUMOR ABOUT CARTER UNBELIEVABLE, PAPER THAT CARRIED IT SAYS
description: The Washington Post said in an editorial today that it found ''utterly impossible to believe'' a rumor, reported in its gossip column, that President Carter bugged Blair House while Ronald and Nancy Reagan stayed there on preinaugural visits.

title: High Court Bars Question on Arena
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday rejected a proposed ballot question designed to test voter sentiment in Bergen County about the naming of the Meadowlands Sports Arena after Governor Byrne.

title: THE WORLD IS BURSTING WITH COOKBOOKS
description: PELICAN PUBLISHING has 26 cookbooks in its current catalogue, everything from Scottish recipes to cooking with herbs. Nevertheless the Gretna, La., house is surprised by the many advance orders it has received from as far away as New York and Los Angeles for its forthcoming kosher-Creole cookbook. ''There doesn't seem to be any limit to the kinds of books that cooks are interested in,'' said Kate Siegel Bandos, Pelican's marketing director.

title: Cornell Dechert, Economist And Former Knoll Chairman
description: W. Cornell Dechert, a retired economist, corporation executive and college administrator, died Sunday at his home in Hockessin, Del. He was 74 years old.

title: Badger Meter President
description: James L. Forbes, 49, has been appointed president of Badger Meter, Inc., a manufacturer of residential water meters and other products. He succeeds James O. Wright, 60, who remains as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: LYNCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $44,000 for the qr and $124,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $15,000 for the qr and $340,000 for the 9 mos

title: JAPANESE AGREE WITH P.L.O. ON BACKING SAUDI PEACE PLAN
description: The Japanese Government expressed support today for a Saudi Arabian proposal for peace in the Middle East, issuing its statement after Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization who is visiting here, described the plan as ''a positive first step.''

title: News Organizations Seeking Tapes of Teamster Wiretaps
description: A Federal appeals court has taken under advisement arguments by three news organizations that they have a right to look at sealed Government wiretap information involving major figures in the teamsters union.

title: Soviet Farm Import Rise Seen
description: American farmers will be getting lower prices for their huge 1981 harvests but a thriving export market may help soften the blow, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: GOLDEN NUGGET WINS ITS LICENSE AS CASINO IN A UNANIMOUS VOTE
description: The Casino Control Commission today granted licenses to the Golden Nugget and its chairman, Stephen A. Wynn, to operate a casino in Atlantic City.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Senatorial Courtesy

title: Dionne Scores 2 Goals As Kings Beat Flames
description: Marcel Dionne scored his first two goals of the season, including the deciding one with 6 minutes 36 seconds to play, to lead the Los Angeles Kings to a 4-3 victory tonight over the Calgary Flames.

title: Index; International
description: A French heir refights the Battle of Yorktown A2 Tories hear Thatcher's policy invites catastrophe A3 Schmidt has heart pacemaker installed A4 Wildcat strikes erupt in Poland over food shortages A6 Around the World A7 Two Moroccan planes shot down, Hassan says A8 Hojatolislam sworn in as President of Iran A10 U.S. not sending more troops to exercise in Egypt A12 U.S. says it may not be able to speed up arms for the Sudan A14 Government/Politics Young wins backing of third man in Atlanta mayoral race A18 Amnesty International accuses F.B.I. of fabricating evidence A20 Republicans question Reagan strategy on budget deferrals A22 Bill to ease requirements for naturalization passes House A22 Maneuvering heightens in House on farm bill A23 Democrat wooed by White House is set to switch parties A29 U.S. prosecutors lose appeal on Margiotta evidence B2 Koch and Stein endorse one another B3 Health/Science Medical students get new emphasis on geriatrics A16 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of the Jewish holiday of Succoth, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect. Living Section Food A mastery of Moroccan cuisine C1

title: PRIME CUT FULL POINT, TO 18%
description: Most of the country's major banks lowered their prime lending rates a full percentage point, to 18 percent, yesterday, providing businesses with a touch of relief from high interest rates.

title: FIRE ACADEMY TEACHES DISCIPLINE UNDER STRESS
description: It is a mad village - a tiny reproduction of New York City - aswarm with young men in black helmets and yellow slickers.
