They scale the sheer walls of skyscrapers, slide off the roofs of tenements, heave unwieldy hoses up fire escapes, crawl blindly through smokeclogged rooms and put out oil blazes at the edge of town.

title: EGYPTIANS SEIZE FIVE IN GUNFIGHT AT THE PYRAMIDS
description: A gunfight near the pyramids and two bomb explosions at Cairo airport that reportedly killed two people marred election day in Egypt today.

title: FARM BLOC FACING UNUSUAL COALITION
description: ''More so now than ever,'' mused Representative Peter A. Peyser, Democrat of Westchester, ''there's a lot of political maneuvering going on over the farm bill.''

title: U.S. ADDING TROOPS TO WAR GAMES IN EGYPT
description: Defense Department officials said today that there would be no increase in the number of American troops scheduled to take part in a military exercise in Egypt and the Sudan that was planned before the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat. They said, however, that the range of the maneuvers would be extended.

title: C. Hugh Holman, Professor; Humanities Center Founder
description: C. Hugh Holman, a University of North Carolina professor who helped found the National Humanities Center, died today at his home. He was 67 years old.

title: WHEELING-PITTSBURGH STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $24,500,000 gain from sublease of idle steam coal revs...C-Includes 428,516,000 or $7.25 cents a shr, gain from a change in accounting

title: First Chicago Up Sharply; Irving Posts A 13.1% Rise
description: The First Chicago Corporation, recovering from past troubles through rising loan demand and smaller losses from bad loans, reported yesterday that its net operating earnings tripled for the third quarter.

title: HIGH COURT TO DECIDE DRUG CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether manufacturers of brand-name drugs can prevent the makers and sellers of generic equivalents from copying the design of the brandname capsules and from using that name in comparative advertising.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Can you explain why some recipes specify three teaspoons rather than one tablespoon, which would be more logical?

title: SOVIET BIDS POLES ACT AGAINST UNION
description: The Soviet Union said today that the Solidarity labor union in Poland was threatening the vital interests of the Soviet bloc and that the Polish people had a special responsibility to give the union an ''effective rebuff.''

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 14, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.

title: Buffalo Philharmonic Extends Rudel's Pact
description: Julius Rudel, conductor of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra since 1979, has been given a three-year contract, according to Michael Bielski, the orchestra's co-executive director. He said the trustees had voted unanimously to extend the contract.

title: A FRENCH HEIR REFIGHTS THE BATTLE OF YORKTOWN
description: LA-ROCHETTE, France -The chateau of Rochambeau stands half a mile from the main road, down an alley of lime trees bordering the Loir River, and past cords of firewood and a sign warning snailgatherers that they are liable to a summons.

title: De Lorean Files Suit
description: John Z. De Lorean, the American automobile executive, today sued Nicholas Winterton, a Conservative Member of Parliament, and several news organizations for $250 million over allegations of financial irregularities against him at his Government-financed sports car company in Northern Ireland. Mr. De Lorean acted a day after the Attorney General, Sir Michael Havers, ended a police investigation of the company ordered by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher after Mr. Winterton wrote to her alleging ''irregularities'' in the De Lorean operation.

title: Bogus Policeman Robs Jeweler
description: A man wearing the uniform of a New York City police officer bluffed his way into a closed Madison Avenue jewelry store, handcuffed a clerk, and made off with antique jewelry valued at more than $1 million, the police reported. The robbery, at Ares Antiques Inc., 961 Madison Avenue, occurred shortly before the store was to open at 11 A.M.

title: A Big-Band Singer Carrying On Without the Band
description: ''I'm a big band singer,'' Helen O'Connell was singing the other night.

title: IVORY'S ORIGINAL 'WILD PARTY'
description: HOLLYWOOD. 1929. Sound is coming in and a lot of silent stars are going out. Among them is Jolly Grimm (James Coco), who is more than grim. He's jolly desperate. A once-popular fat-man comedian of slapstick, a fellow who has been on his way out even before sound, Jolly Grimm has just completed his first new film in five years, something about an 18th-century Los Angeles friar who goes to Africa, is attacked by cannibals and, at the end, oversees the miraculous cure of a lame girl.

title: SAGA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Board Acts on Beating
description: A school board in the Denver suburb of Aurora, Colo., has backed a recommendation of its superintendent and has begun proceedings to remove Kenneth Milano, Overland High School's football coach, for ''incompetency, neglect of duty, insubordination and other just and good causes.'' Milano was charged with shoving a player, forcing him to run a gantlet of teammates as a disciplinary measure and allowing the incident to degenerate into the player's severe beating. He has seven days to appeal to a hearing officer.

title: U.S. Jury Cites Five Railroads
description: A Federal grand jury accused five railroads today of conspiring to restrain trade in the movement of iron ore from Lake Erie to steel mills in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Kentucky and West Virginia.

title: JUDGE ASSAILS CITY AGENCY ON ITS PRESENTENCE REPORT
description: Justice Michael J. Dontzin of State Supreme Court charged yesterday that the presentencing reports prepared by New York City's Probation Department were ''wholly inadequate.''

title: TIGHT MONEY FORCES NEW LIFE INTO OLD CARS
description: ''Heaven is having 12 cars, one of which starts in the morning,'' said Betty Hoffman of Hartford, whose seven-year-old Plymouth Valiant does not. Her husband, Herbert, drives a 10-year-old Dodge Dart that does start, despite its 90,000 miles, but it has other troubles.

title: REAGAN TO SEND CONGRESS A NOTE ON AWACS
description: President Reagan plans to send Congress a letter promising not to deliver Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia until he has informed Congress in writing that several conditions have been met by the Saudis.

title: Long-Distance Bout
description: He is 49 years old and 50 pounds overweight, and he was once knocked out by Floyd Patterson. But Ingemar Johansson is in good enough shape to run Oct. 25 in the New York City Marathon.

title: On West Side, No One Is a Fence Straddler; by Anna Quindlen
description: On the inside of the fence were, naturally, the insiders. There were politicians and lawyers, developers and bankers, shaded from the autumn sun by a big green-and-white striped tent with a long refreshment table and a scale model inside. One or two elderly women sidled around them, wrapping miniature Danish pastries in handkerchiefs and slipping them into their purses.

title: BRIEFS
description: * After Six Inc. sold the operating assets of its Harry Fischer Corp. and Koko Bainwear Corp. outerwear subsidiaries to Abraham Zion Corp., for approximately $5.5 million.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
BILL AIMED AT EASING NATURALIZATION LAW APPROVED BY HOUSE
description: The House today approved a bill that would eliminate adultery and possession of marijuana as grounds for mandatory denial of naturalization for aliens.

title: Careers; Training For Jobs In the Arts
description: MOST young artists need extra income to survive, and some may be interested in full-time careers in arts management, education or promotion.

title: BY JAMES BEARD, A NEW VIEW
description: JUST how radically American cooking has changed in 20 years is ably demonstrated in James Beard's latest cookbook, called ''The New James Beard'' (Knopf $16.95). A hefty volume with 1,000 recipes, it was originally to be a simple revision of the ''James Beard Cookbook,'' which was published in 1959 and updated in 1970. But it turned into a completely different project.

title: Jersey Man Seized In Upstate Slaying
description: A New Jersey man was arrested in Maryland as the principal suspect in the fatal stabbing of his 94-year-old grandfather in Tallman.

title: VINTAGE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
OPERA: BIRGIT NILSSON IN 'FRAU'
description: IF officials of the Metropolitan Opera have been sitting up nights worrying about how to keep this season's slight booing infection from spreading, they had the answer readily at hand Monday night. Exciting singing will provide the remedy every time. Birgit Nilsson's return to the company to sing the Dyer's Wife in ''Die Frau ohne Schatten'' was the most obvious reason, though far from the only one, why nothing but cheering could be heard.

title: New Spraying for Fruit Flies Said to Mean a Long Battle
description: Expanded pesticide spraying of a 27-square-mile area of the San Gabriel Valley renewed the battle today against the Mediterranean fruit fly.

title: Yokohama Fire Extinguished
description: A fire at an oil storage center near here was extinguished tonight and 800 local residents who had been evacuated earlier returned to their homes. The blaze, which lasted four hours, began with an explosion that could be heard eight miles away. The cause was not immediately known.

title: British Rail Dispute
description: Leaders of the rail drivers union called for a one-day national rail strike on Oct. 21 to protest cuts proposed by British Rail in train services, the U.K. Domestic News Agency Press Association reported. Talks today between union and management failed to resolve the dispute.

title: LIBRARY BOOK DISPUTE FACES REVIEW
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a case that could become a test of a local school board's authority to control the contents of school libraries.

title: THEATER: ANNE SEXTON IS 'MY OWN STRANGER'
description: THE eyes are quick and a little sad in what may be the best-known photograph of the poet Anne Sexton. The mouth slants into a characteristic half-smirk, half self-deprecatory grin. A T-shirt as awkward as a straitjacket is visible, its printed message ''Live or Die.'' It is a photograph taken, possibly, at a party celebrating her Pulitzer Prize for the book of poems of the same name. It accompanies a newspaper announcement of her death, by suicide, at age 45.

title: India Delegation Cancels Visit to China
description: A delegation from India's Parliament has canceled a visit to China after a new dispute over disputed territory on the Indian-Chinese border.

title: LTV CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Yankee Series a Boon For Oakland Economy
description: The American League championship playoffs, which shift to Oakland Thursday, with additional games possible on Friday and Saturday, mean a financial lift for the city.

title: UNINVITED LIBERALIZERS OF THE LIBERAL ARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cost of Rooting
description: ''The live gate is not enough to survive,'' said Eddie Einhorn, the president of the White Sox, after his team had joined three other professional clubs in Chicago - the Black Hawks, the Bulls, and the Sting - in setting up Sportsvision, a pay television company that will charge fans about $260 a year for their games. ''Even if we are filling our stadiums in sports, the franchises are operating at a deficit,'' said Einhorn, whose theory is that fans have to be reconditioned to pay for games. ... The Atlanta Braves have received about 60 offers from fans who want to named as the replacement for Bobby Cox as manager.

title: PAT FASHIONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FIRST-CLASS FARE FOR A TANKER'S CREW
description: Food on merchant ships has come a long way since the days of hardtack biscuits and leathery strips of salted beef. Today's sailors, aided by strong maritime unions and modern technology, are sustained during long voyages on food that is a far cry from Conrad novels and probably closer to those of Nero Wolfe.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Profit Off 40.6% At Time Inc.
description: Time Inc., the diversified communications concern, reported yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell 40.6 percent. Losses associated with two discontinued units, The Washington Star and Time-Life Films, were cited.

title: MOROCCO REPORTS MAJOR BATTLE
description: King Hassan II said tonight that two Moroccan planes were shot down today by Soviet-made missiles in a major battle in the Western Sahara.

title: City Begins Push On Student Shots
description: The city began a push to complete immunization of 70,000 public school students, busing students to special centers to get their shots.

title: EGYPTIANS VOTING TO ELECT MUBARAK
description: A week after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat, Egyptians voted today in a referendum to elect Vice President Hosni Mubarak the country's new President.

title: U.S. ENVOY GIVES ACCOUNT OF SADAT'S SHOOTING
description: The United States Ambassador to Egypt, Alfred L. Atherton Jr., who was in the revewing stand, gave an account today of what he said, heard and did after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat eight days ago at a military parade.

title: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STANLEY WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $3.5 million net gain on the sale of the drapery hardware division...C-Including $2,920,000 net gain on the sale of the power tools division

title: PROGRESS IN SHORTCHANGED APPALACHIA
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR: WOMEN AS LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTS
description: American Women and Gardens 1915- 1945, a conference and exhibition sponsored by Wave Hill, 249th Street and Independence Avenue, the Bronx,

title: U.S. FOREIGN AID IS ANYTHING BUT A 'HANDOUT'
description: To the Editor:

title: West Germans, Scots Gain 1982 World Cup
description: Pierre Littbarski, making his international debut, scored two goals yesterday as West Germany advanced to next year's World Cup finals in Spain with a 3-1 victory over Austria in Vienna.

title: COMMERCE SOUTHWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After tax credits of $1,524,000 in qr and $3,867,000 for the 9 mos...C-After tax credits of $187,000 for the qr and $903,000 for the 9 mos

title: HERBERT DANA GREGGS
description: Herbert Dana Greggs, an actor and playwright who was administrative secretary of the United States Institute for Theater Technology, died on Tuesday in New York City after a long illness.

title: EXPOS WIN, TIE SERIES
description: The Montreal Expos, who beat Steve Carlton twice last week, added Fernando Valenzuela to their list of celebrity victims tonight as Ray Burris pitched them to a 3-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: TRUDEAU OFFERS COMPROMISE ON CONSTITUTION
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has offered what he calls a substantial compromise on his proposals for a new constitution for Canada, and he has proposed a meeting with the 10 provincial premiers on Tuesday for a final attempt to reach a consensus.

title: Bid for Zapata: How It Arose
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation's recent offer to acquire the Zapata Corporation was encouraged by David H. Murdock, Zapata's largest shareholder and a member of its board of directors.

title: HOUSE AGAIN REJECTS EFFORTS TO HOLD DOWN MILD SUPPORTS
description: The Reagan Administration was routed again today in the House of Representatives in its efforts to block a section of a new farm bill that would raise dairy price supports a year from now.

title: Former U.S. Officials Warned Memoirs Have to Be Cleared
description: Former Government officials who do not clear their memoirs with the Reagan Administration before publication could face Federal suits, a Justice Department official said today.

title: NEEDLESS SCREAMS
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Chiefs Outline New Budget Prospects
description: Republican Congressional leaders predicted today that any new revenue measures would be postponed until next year and that the Senate would drastically reduce the new round of budget cuts sought by the Reagan Administration.

title: KAUNDA'S 17-YEAR RULE MAKING ZAMBIA RESTLESS
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda's lieutenants like to rally support at public meetings with a litany that goes like this: The official will cry, ''One Zambia!'' The crowd, dutifully, responds, ''One nation!'' The official continues, knowing the answer in advance, ''One nation?'' ''One leader!'' say the faithful. ''That leader?'' ''Kaunda!'' comes the response, in a crescendo.

title: EDITORIAL BY WASHINGTON POST
description: Following is the text of an editorial that appeared in The Washington Post yesterday:

title: PASSIVE SOLAR DESIGNS ARE OLD, BUT BUILDERS DON'T LIKE THEM
description: THOUGH it is widely agreed that solar systems using largely nonmechanical, passive methods are effective, relatively few home builders are putting them in new construction. Although the concepts are not new -the pre-eminent Roman architect Vitruvius popularized the principles, already ancient then, in the first century B.C. - they are looked at askance by most builders.

title: TAXES BY ENERGY STATES CAUSING EAST-WEST SPLIT
description: ''Severance tax'' is a prosaic gray term, unlikely to excite anyone. But today the severance taxes levied by most energy-producing states on the value of their oil, natural gas and coal are rapidly becoming the focus of a struggle that pits much of the Eastern United States against much of the West.

title: ANIMAL EXPERIMENTS VITAL TO STROKE VICTIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO RADAR PLANES ARE SENT TO EGYPT
description: The United States said today that two Awacs radar surveillance planes had been sent to Egypt for ''an indeterminate period'' to demonstrate increased American support for Egyptian and Sudanese security.

title: Bridge: Picking the World Winner Might Prove Challenging
description: The world team championship beginning next Tuesday at the Rye Town Hilton, Port Chester, N.Y., poses more problems for the prophets than any previous such occasion. The American team includes one outstanding partnership, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, but no member of the team has international experience. Europe is sending two strong teams, from Poland and Britain, but neither seems good enough to be classified as a probable winner.

title: TORIES COME TO AID OF MRS. THATCHER
description: Former Prime Minister Edward Heath's assault on the economic policies of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was all but lost today in waves of applause for her defenders.

title: DISSIDENTS' BOOKS AT FRANKFURT FAIR
description: With the political struggle in Poland continuing and a trial imminent in Prague against 18 Czechoslovak dissidents, many of them writers, themes and personalities from among Eastern Europe's dissidents are widely evident at the International Book Fair, which opened today.

title: Chris-Craft Takeover
description: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the assumption of majority control of United Television Inc. by Chris-Craft Industries, giving Chris-Craft the maximum number of VHF telelvision stations - five - that a company may own. The F.C.C. said yesterday that it had approved the transfer of United Television and its three stations - KTVX-TV in Salt Lake City, KMOL-TV in San Antonio, Tex., and KMSP-TV in Minneapolis -from the stockholders of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Renault Head Reported To Be Next U.S. Envoy

title: Wometco Adds Office
description: Harold Brownstein, 39, has been named president of Wometco Home Theater, an over-the-air subscription television service transmitting on separate frequencies and operating in the metropolitan New York and Philadelphia areas. The corporation - a unit of Wometco Enterprises that offers motion pictures, professional sports and entertinment specials -had no president before and a spokesman said that Mr. Brownstein was hired because ''we needed the extra strength.''

title: REPUBLIC NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IS SILENT ON HUMANITIES
description: President Reagan put off naming a new chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities today, although he did formally announce the appointment of Francis S.M. Hodsoll as chairman of the companion National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Girl, 15, Is Raped by 5 Youths And Tossed Into the Hudson
description: Two youths were arrested last night and charged with repeatedly raping a 15-year-old girl under the George Washington Bridge at knifepoint and throwing her battered and unconscious into the Hudson River, leaving her for dead.

title: Record-Setting Inning
description: In the Yankees' seven-run fourth inning, several records for a league championship series were tied or broken. Among those tied were most hits by a team in an inning (7); most consecutive hits (5); and most runs (7). Among the records set were most hits by a player (2) by Graig Nettles; most consecutive batters to reach base safley (8), and most players to bat (10).

title: BATHROOM ACCESSORIES
description: MOUNTING frequently used bathroom accessories on walls can help eliminate the need to find extra storage space; it also puts these accessories in easy reach for immediate use.

title: Timely Honor, Timely Warning
description: President Reagan's economic policy received another challenge this week from an unlikely source: the selection committee of the Royal Swedish Academy of Science, which awarded this year's Nobel award in economics to James Tobin of Yale University. The honor, of course, was for Mr. Tobin's brilliant economic theories and not his current political attitudes.

title: 'Acis and Galatea' Saturday in the Capital
description: ''Acis and Galatea,'' Handel's first essay in dramatic music for the English stage, will be presented in Washington on Saturday at 8:30 P.M. in the opening of the sixth John F.Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts Festival in the Concert Hall.

title: WALTER REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-Includes $595,000 or 58 cents a shr extraordinary gain and $879,000 gain on the Oct sale of a mobil home park along with the income from operations of $383,000...C-Inlcludes $31,000 or 3 cents a shr extraordinary gain and $605,000 gain on the sale of properties

title: The City; Sheridan Sq. Gets New Traffic Flow
description: New York City's Transportation Department announced changes in traffic patterns at Sheridan Square that are intended to increase substantially the pedestrian crossing time at one of Manhattan's more confusing and congested intersections.

title: Fireman's Fund To Buy Insurer
description: Fireman's Fund Inc. of New York will acquire the Wisconsin Employers Group insurance company under an agreement in principle reached by the two companies, a Wisconsin Employers spokesman said.

title: CARTER INTENT ON SUING WASHINGTON POST ON RUMOR
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, asserting that he still intended to sue The Washington Post over a gossip column item saying that Blair House had been ''bugged'' in his Administration, said today that the newspaper's editorial explanation was as baffling to him as it was unsatisfactory.

title: THE POOR TRACK RECORD OF CREDIT CONTROLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Barney Ingoglia Autumn's Mantle Graces
description: Upstate Areas As the colors of autumn move closer to the metropolitan area, many seekers of beauty headed north for a preview of nature's annual art show.

title: FIRST SECURITY CORP
Marcos Drafts Program For Third-World Aid
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos consulted the four other members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations today on a program for third-world resource development that he plans to present at a meeting of developing and industrial nations in Cancun, Mexico, this month.

title: Index; International
description: Zambia's ills are laid at Kaunda's doorstep A2 Greek Premier counting on fear of left in election Sunday A3 Polish workers occupy textile mills for a second day A3 Tory delegates rally to Mrs. Thatcher A3 Helmut Schmidt reported in good condition after heart operation A4 Around the World A5 U.N. agency's work seems end- less A6 Trudeau offers a compromise on his constitutional proposals A9 Arafat meets with Japan's lead- ers A10 Government/Politics Reagan allies try anew to mold California politics A16 Panel is challenging the breadth of new C.I.A. guidelines A20 Ruling clears Connecticut town of housing bias charge B2 Liberal candidate assails Koch on minorities B6 Democrats bring out three alter- native economic plans B15 Washington Talk Briefing B10 Embassy Row B10 General Around the Nation A16 The volume of oil spilled into the world's oceans is reduced A17 Witness says Presley's doctor in- creased doses on prescriptions A22 Carter to press suit against Wash- ington Post B16 Health/Science New drug found to curb nausea of chemotherapy patients A24 Education/Welfare Summer school helped many city students pass reading test B4 Home Section Home Solar architecture: the good, the bad and the indifferent C1

title: U.S. BLOCKS DOCUMENTS ON ENERGY
description: The Reagan Administration today invoked executive privilege for the first time, and refused to hand over various documents to a House oversight subcommittee exploring ways to curb takeovers by Canadians of United States energy companies.

title: Charles L. Widney Jr. Is Dead Ex-State Department Officer
description: Charles L. Widney Jr., a former State Department officer and financial consultant, died Monday at New York Hospital. Mr. Widney, who lived in Manhattan and Charleston, S.C., was 53 years old.

title: DRUG STOPS CHEMOTHERAPY ILLS
description: An experimental drug called metoclopromide can eliminate the nausea and vomiting that accompany one of the most widely used and powerful treatments for cancer, according to a team of researchers.

title: MILITARY RAISE BILL SIGNED
description: President Reagan today signed a $4.5 billion bill providing pay increases of 10 to 17 percent for the 2.1 million men and women in the armed forces. For enlisted personnel, the increases will be 10 to 17 percent, with the higer amounts going to experienced personnel. Officers will receive a 14.3 percent increase.

title: Hauptmann's Widow Sues for $100 Million
description: The 83-year-old widow of Bruno Richard Hauptmann filed a $100 million damage suit in Federal Court in Newark yesterday, seeking to overturn the conviction of her husband for the kidnapping and murder of the 20-month-old son of Charles A. Lindbergh. Hauptmann was electrocuted in 1936.

title: HOUSE, 301 TO 111, REFUSES TO UPHOLD SAUDI PLANE DEAL
description: The House of Representatives voted 301 to 111 today not to approve President Reagan's proposed sale of radar planes and other air equipment to Saudi Arabia.

title: THEATER: 'BOY AND TARZAN'
description: AN over-the-hill middle-ged man, wearing a loincloth that reveals a burgeoning midsection, leaps awkwardly on stage. It is Tarzan, as pictured by Amiri Baraka in ''Boy and Tarzan Appear in a Clearing,'' at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater. This absurd ape man (Jack R. Marks) - a figure much closer to Buddy Hackett than to Buster Crabbe - is followed by his son, Boy, or Mr. Boy (Rod McLucas), as he is known to the servile black African middle class, and he is a jive-talking hipster of the jungle. ''Why you stop here, Tarzan?'' he asks his old man as if addressing a wino on a Manhattan street corner. ''Lost,'' says Tarzan tersely.

title: LAWRENCE LARIAR
description: Lawrence Lariar, a cartoonist, editor and author of mystery novels, died Monday in Waterbury, Conn.

title: SAFETY BOARD ASKS MEASURES TO EASE AIR CONTROLLER STRAIN
description: The National Transportation Safety Board recommended yesterday that a Government program be set up to detect the development of fatigue and stress among air traffic controllers and to alleviate such problems.

title: MIXED RESULTS ARE REPORTED FOR SUMMER READING CLASSES
description: An evaluation of the summer remedial program for poor readers at New York City's public schools shows that the more often a student attended classes, the more likely he was to pass the final test. But it also found to the surprise of educators that some youngsters, no matter how regularly they attended, apparently failed to improve at all.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My 10-year-old refrigerator sweats on the outside during humid weather and has started to rust. I assume this is due to a lack of adequate insulation. Would it be a good idea to put some type of contact paper on the outside as a form of added insulation? - W.M.K., Babylon, L.I.

title: No Headline
description: Israel Hints Firm Line On Palestinian Talks

title: I.C.C. Cuts Rail Rates on Some Scrap
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission, in an order issued late Tuesday and released yesterday, said that the nation's railroads must reduce rates charged on moving nonferrous, recycled materials and issue refunds to shippers retroactive to Jan. 1.

title: SAFETY GROUP SPLIT ON A MEDICINE CAP
description: As a result of a tie vote today, the Consumer Product Safety Commission will not take action to bar an innovative medicine bottle cap that its staff said was a potential threat to children's safety.

title: Montana: No. 1 and Sure of It
description: When he took over as a starting quarterback last season, Joe Montana of the San Francisco 49ers was jittery and unsure of himself. Despite a career as an all-American at Notre Dame, he admitted that he was in awe of the National Football League.

title: HOUSE TOURS FOR AN AUTUMN WEEKEND
description: Autumn is a season for falling leaves, hot cider, baseball playoffs and, it would seem, a multitude of educational house tours. And this weekend's crop of planned events is no exception. In fact, the tours scheduled for Saturday and Sunday will offer everything from real estate advice in Bedford-Stuyvesant to historic houses in Jersey City.

title: ANOTHER PENN HOLDER FIGHTS BID FOR COLT
description: A shareholder committee opposing the Penn Central Corporation's $1.4 billion proposal to purchase Colt Industries won substantial new support yesterday with an announcement by American Financial Enterprises of Cincinnati that it would vote its Penn Central shares against the plan.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
KING HASSAN WARNS RABAT WILL RESPOND TO ATTACK IN SAHARA
description: King Hassan II of Morocco has warned that a guerrilla attack on a Moroccan garrison in Western Sahara yesterday had restored to his country ''a total freedom of action'' in the territory where he had offered to hold a ''controlled referendum'' on the area's future.

title: Market Place; Future Growth Of McDonald's
description: ONE of the premier growth companies of the last 20 years, the McDonald's Corporation, has slowed down. Although McDonald's is expected by forecasters to earn $6.60 a share in 1981 - which would be a sparkling 20 percent gain over last year's $5.49 a share - that growth rate looks like a peak to some analysts and is decidedly below historic rates.

title: New York-Chicago Lawyers In International Venture
description: A joint venture, a common occurence among corporations but a relative rarity among law firms, has been established by two law concerns in Chicago and New York to work for American clients in Europe and European clients in the Middle West. The firms - Sonnenschein Carlin Nath & Rosenthal, a 75-year old Chicago firm, and Walter Conston Schurtman & Gumpel of New York, founded in 1954 by a West German lawyer with an American law degree - have created the new firm of Sonnenschein Walter & Conston.

title: Cyprus Chief Presses Turkey On Future of Divided Island
description: President Spyros Kyprianou of Cyprus said today that no progress had been made in talks on the future of the island and that none could be expected until Turkey decided to abandon what he called its ''philosophy of division.''

title: HERS
description: ICOULD afford to teach if I had a dollar for every person who has asked me if I really enjoy educating seventh and eighth graders. Adolescence is a 20th-century invention most parents approach with dread and look back on with the relief of survivors. Why then would anyone willingly surround herself for nine months of the year with a gaggle of teen-agers? I can only tell you that the year I took a sabbatical from the small independent school where I have taught since 1974, I arranged to be out of the country when classes started in the fall. The ineluctable loss of mellow, apple-scented September mornings and my children, like their newly sharpened pencils, ready for the months ahead, was too much for me to bear.

title: CONCERN ON AID FOR MENTAL HEALTH IS RAISED IN LIGHT OF LAW'S REPEAL
description: Rosalynn Carter lobbied for it. Congress approved it. And Jimmy Carter, in his last months as President, signed it into law.

title: DAVIDSON EXCELS AS RANGERS WIN BY 2-1
description: The Rangers huffed and puffed for nearly all 60 minutes, but they won their first game of the season last night, beating the Vancouver Canucks, 2-1, at Madison Square Garden.

title: CAREY TO SUGGEST NOT MAKING UP CUTS IN WELFARE
description: Governor Carey, who has been critical of Federal cuts in aid for the needy, will propose that New York State avoid making up for all the welfare assistance that many young adults will lose under new Federal regulations.

title: MERCANTILE TEXAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Detroit Cancels Race
description: Plans for a Formula One road race through the streets of Detroit were canceled today when organizers and the car owners association were unable to agree on the size of the purse.

title: Age for Childbearing
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: After reading Claudia Wright's lament on her fast disappearing fertility (''Hers,'' Sept. 17), I am torn between pity and anger.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Analysts International Corporation, Minneapolis, has named John T. Paprocki vice president-finance.

title: STEROTYPE TRUTH
description: ''Stereotype'' is a dirty word among some intellectuals and others who feel that, when used to describe members of a race, religion, or nationality, it indicates prejudices. Perhaps it is time we changed our thinking.

title: N.A.A.C.P. in South Carolina Suing to Force Redistricting
description: Attorneys for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed a suit today asking a Federal court to remap the state's Congressional districts or order the Legislature to do so.

title: ROBERT AHMED
description: Robert Ahmed, former Mayor of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., died of cancer yesterday at Albany Medical Center.

title: Technology; Freelance Software
description: JOHN P. IMLAY JR. calls it an I.B.M.-sponsored ''love-in.'' Later this month, the International Business Machines Corporation will play host to 100 representatives of independent software companies at a three-day conference in White Plains.

title: IRISH-AMERICANS ARE DEFENDED
description: A British newspaper accused five American politicians yesterday of moral responsibility for an Irish guerrilla attack in London that killed two people. Today, the Irish Foreign Minister, James Dooge, defended the five.

title: Military Analysis
description: On Sunday, Oct. 4, a full brigade of the Palestine Liberation Organization, armed with tanks and artillery, made a mock attack against a settlement in Lebanon's

title: News Analysis
description: The sharply rising trade surplus that Japan is running up, particularly with the United States and with members of the European Economic Community, is said to represent a politically volatile force -one that may well lead Japan's trading partners to erect protectionist barriers against the flow of exports from this merchant nation. That Japan's trade gap is growing at a startling pace is beyond dispute. Yesterday, for example, the Ministry of Finance reported a record $1.7 billion surplus with the United States in September, surpassing the previous record set just two months earlier.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 18.00-18.50** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Pan Am Cuts Overseas Fare
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it would cut fares on one-way trips from various East Coast cities to West Germany by 32 percent to 45 percent.

title: Caterpillar Layoffs
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the British subsidiary of the heavy construction equipment group based in the United States, plans to reduce the work force of 2,300 at its Scottish plant near Glasgow by about one-third. The announcement follows the parent company's decision to produce its new D-8l crawler tractor solely at its Peoria, Ill., headquarters. The Scottish plant now builds an earlier model of the tractor.

title: 'A MOTHER'S FAILURE'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Just a note of appreciation for your ''Hers'' column on the subject of venereal disease and the casualness with which it is treated by today's sexually active populaion.

title: Missouri Pacific Plans Repair Shop
description: The Missouri Pacific Railroad will build a $40 million complex at North Little Rock designed exclusively for the repair and rebuilding of diesel locomotives.

title: LATHROP S. HASKINS
description: Lathrop S. Haskins, retired senior vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died last Saturday at his retirement home in Point Manalapan, Fla.

title: OPERATING NET OFF BY 26.6% AT MORGAN
description: Third-quarter operating income fell 26.6 percent at J.P. Morgan & Company Inc., rose 17.5 percent at the Continental Illinois Corporation, and increased 11.6 percent at First Interstate Bancorp, the three banking companies reported yesterday.

title: TRANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $146,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: CANADIAN MINE CALLED POLLUTION PERIL TO U.S. PARK
description: A proposed open-pit coal mine in the Canadian province of British Columbia, 12 miles north of the Glacier National Park, could have a severe polluting effect on Glacier, the wildest of the United States national parks, according to officials.

title: YANKS ROUT A'S, 13-3, ON 7-RUN 4TH FOR 2-GAME LEAD
description: The biggest onslaught in pennant playoff history enabled the Yankees to defeat Oakland yesterday, 13-3, deflating the highspirited A's and sending them home two games down in the three-offive American League series. And the A's left Yankee Stadium with a message that wasn't comforting: a second-line member of the Yankee relief corps is better than the best of the A's bullpen.

title: Charles Visits Riot Area
description: Amid tight security, Prince Charles today visited the Toxteth area of Liverpool, which was devastated by riots in July. The Prince, who unveiled a commemorative plaque at a youth center, was greeted by about 300 local residents.

title: Belated Poetic Justice
description: It may seem a little overdue, but Sterling A. Brown has finally won Establishment recognition for the poetry he stopped writing decades ago. ''The Collected Poems of Sterling A. Brown,'' published last year, has won the 1980 Lenore Marshall/Saturday Review prize for poetry, a $5,000 award for the outstanding book of poems published in the United States during the year.

title: NEW CLASSICS AND JAZZ RADIO SHOW
description: THE cause of classical-music radio broadcasting in this country, which only a few years ago seemed threatened by a rising tide of top-40 rock stations, has been boosted immeasurably by National Public Radio - programs both from the national office and programs produced at the local level.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said it had purchased on the London Stock Exchange 450,000 shares of the Alexander Howden Group at $2.51 a share, pursuant to an exchange offer.

title: CITY'S SUBWAYS STILL DECLINING, A SURVEY FINDS
description: An independent survey of subway performance finds a sharp decline in service on all lines in New York City and shows trains were late about twice as often as in a similar survey conducted only a year ago.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PIANIST: ALAN MANDEL
description: THOSE who complain about hackneyed recital programs would have found relief Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, where Alan Mandel presented piano music by Fanny Hensel, Elie Siegmeister, Georges Enesco, Clara Schumann and Nicolas Roslavetz. And -oh, yes - Chopin.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Berry Industries announced that it had arranged bank lines of credit totaling $12 million with the Bank of America and the Bank of the Southwest.

title: MILNER DISCOUNTS RACE AS HARTFORD VICTORY FACTOR
description: Thirman L. Milner's first act this morning after his upset victory in the Democratic mayoral primary was to leave town.

title: No Headline
description: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS IN EGYPT BY MUBARAK

title: Briefing
description: T HE assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt has stirred uneasiness within the Secret Service about the scheduled appearance of Presidents Reagan and Mitterand this weekend in Yorktown to celebrate the decisive battle of the Revolutionary War. The two chiefs of state were scheduled to troop the line in an open jeep. But Mr. Reagan's security force has asked him to forgo the review. Instead, the Presidents of the United States and France will watch the troops march past from behind a bullet-proof shield.

title: Phoenix Coverage Rise
description: The Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company plans to give 350,000 customers increased coverage - with no rise in premiums - effective with the 1982 anniversary date of each policy. Changes in Federal laws have cut costs, the company said today, letting it pass the savings along.

title: Sports of The Times; The Professional Hitter
description: IN the years when Catfish Hunter was on the Yankees, he and Lou Piniella enjoyed insulting each other in the camaraderie of the clubhouse. Lou Piniella would snarl about all those home runs that Catfish Hunter had a tendency to allow. And then Catfish Hunter would sneer.

title: U.S. NUNS' DEATHS LAID TO SALVADOR
description: A captured Salvadoran national guardsman said in a broadcast over a guerrilla-run radio station that the four American missionaries killed last year were slain by guardsmen who suspected that two of them were running messages between leftists in Nicaragua and El Salvador.

title: Martin Is Aroused By Taunts, Umpires
description: The best thing that happened to the Oakland A's yesterday, according to their manager, was when the Yankee fans taunted them with a chorus of ''Goodbye Billy'' in the final inning of the 13-3 rout.

title: Necessary Distinctions About Evidence
description: In the current campaign against the exclusionary rule, which bars the use of illegally obtained evidence in criminal trials, its critics argue that the rule is so confusing it cannot possibly deter the police from improper searches and unjustified arrests. Since learned jurists disagree sharply about how to apply the rule, the critics maintain, what's a poor cop to do in a fast-moving, dangerous situation?

title: ROLL-CALL VOTE IN HOUSE ON RESOLUTION AGAINST THE AWACS SALE
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 301 to 111 by which the House of Representatives passed a resolution today that disapproves President Reagan's proposed sale of Awacs radar planes and other weaponry to Saudi Arabia. A ''yes'' vote was a vote against the sale. A ''no'' vote was a vote in favor of it. Voting ''yes'' were 193 Democrats and 108 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 33 Democrats and 78 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Flippo, no; Nichols, no; Shelby, yes. Republicans - Dickinson, no; Edwards, yes; Smith, yes.

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Texas Storm Toll Reaches 6
description: Two more persons, including a 15-month-old baby, died in flood waters today, bringing a slow-moving storm's two-day death toll to six. The infant, Brandon Gustavus, of Bryan, Tex., was drowned when rising waters swept him from his trailer home after a 2-year-old sister opened the door, the police said.

title: Mack Trucks
description: Mack Trucks Inc. may shut its Hagerstown plant for five days in January, according to an official of the United Automobile Workers union. Dave Smith, president of Hagerstown auto workers Local 171 said Mack Trucks officials had notified the union of the possible closing, which would affect most of the work force. A Mack spokesman at the truck maker's Allentown, Pa., headquarters declined to comment on the possibility of a shutdown in January.

title: North Stars 2, Maple Leafs 1
description: TORONTO (AP) - Bobby Smith scored with three minutes to play to give Minnesota its first regular-season victory here since Oct. 27, 1976.

title: Pilgrim Wins Air Route
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today picked Pilgrim Airlines of New London, Conn., a small commuter carrier, to fly nonstop between New York's Kennedy International Airport and Ottawa. The board instructed its staff to prepare an order for President Reagan, who must make the final decision because an international route is involved. He will have 60 days to consider the recommendation after it reaches his desk in about two weeks.

title: Topics; Righting Wrongs; Demolition Justice
description: Landmarks, like other forms of beauty, are in the eye of the beholder, and the contractor who recently reduced a historic manor house in Britain to a heap of rubble made a mistake. Either that, or he preferred a historic ruin.

title: OIL SPILLS' DANGER APPEARS REDUCED
description: The amount of oil spilled into the sea, one of the great environmental concerns of the last decade, has dropped sharply throughout the world, according to the Center for Short-Lived Phenomena in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Pope Says His Ordeal Was 'a Special Grace'
description: Pope John Paul II said today that his suffering after the May 13 attempt on his life ''has turned out to be a special grace for me and for the whole church.''

title: MORGAN, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Maine Potato Harvest
description: Potato growers have managed to harvest 85 percent of their fall crop despite recent delays in Maine caused by excessive rainfall, according to the Maine Potato Council. The council said northern Maine's weather has been favorable for the past few days and that some growers are in the final stages of gathering the crop. The average yield has been close to 250 pounds an acre and the quality of the potatoes going into storage is generally very good, the council said.

title: SAFETY A CONCERN AS NUN'S ATTACKER IS HUNTED
description: As church officials discussed security arrangements at religious centers, dozens of detectives joined uniformed police officers yesterday in a search for the man who raped, beat and robbed a 31-year-old nun in an East Harlem convent.

title: Bache to Use New Visa Card
description: Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. said yesterday that it had canceled plans to use the American Express gold card as part of its ''cash management-type'' account. Instead, the brokerage firm said it had reached an agreement in principle to offer the new Visa premium card.

title: A 'General Hospital' Benefit From Miss Taylor
description: A follow-up: Some of the money that Elizabeth Taylor will receive for guest apearances on her favorite soap opera, the top-rated ''General Hospital'' on ABC-TV, will be donated to two Virginia hospitals that helped her in emergencies.

title: Oil Data Delayed
description: Because of the Columbus Day holiday, the weekly American Petroleum Institute statistics were delayed and do not appear today. The figures are expected to appear tomorrow.

title: FLORIO: RESTLESS LONER IN RACE FOR JERSEY GOVERNOR
description: In a rare moment of relaxation between campaign stops, his athletic body stretched out in a motel chair, Representative James J. Florio reflected on how he had emerged from what he calls the "cesspool" of Camden County politics in South Jersey to become Democratic candidate for Governor.

title: Philadelphia Walkout Called
description: Labor leaders voted unanimously today to hold a one-day general strike in two weeks unless the 37-day-old teachers' strike is settled. The head of the Philadelphia Federation of Teachers, John Murray, also announced a demonstration at City Hall tomorrow, where President Reagan is to give a foreign policy speech. The strike began Sept. 8.

title: UNITED STATES INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $2,055,000 loss from discontinued operations and $800,000 pre-tax loss from foreign currency translation... C-After $102,255,000 loss from discontinued operations and $3.4 million pre-tax loss from foreign currency translation... D-Net income after $2,618,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Western Air Stock
description: Eli Timoner, chairman of Air Florida, said yesterday that Air Florida recently purchased about 130,000 shares of Western Air stock, less than 1 percent of the outstanding. He added that he was still interested in buying control of Western Airlines. For months, Air Florida held 11.6 percent of the Los Angeles-based carrier's stock but refrained from increasing this share.

title: The Right Help for the Sudan
description: The Sudan does need help. Economically stricken and politically unsteady, this vast African country is threatened by Libya's Colonel Qaddafi -the more so since President Sadat, the Sudan's protector, was slain. Speeding American arms to Khartoum might discourage an invasion by Libya's occupation troops in neighboring Chad. But the Sudan's overriding needs are economic, and here, surely, Saudi Arabia should be at least as forthcoming as the United States.

title: NEW FRENCH FURNITURE LINE REACHES BACK TO PRIMITIVE TIMES
description: THE postmodern movement -and its sometimes witty references to the classical past -has encouraged several European designers to reach even further back in time.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It so happened that this is my fate today, that I should stand here while he's absent.

title: KNICKS TOPPLE NETS IN BYRNE EXHIBITION
description: The lights went out early for the New Jersey Nets and the New York Knicks this season. With 4 minutes 30 seconds remaining in the first quarter of the first basketball game at the Brendan Byrne Arena, the Nets' new home, a power failure interrupted their exhibition game for 23 minutes. Officials said later that the trouble had been in a substation in the building.

title: KODAK, WARNER, PEPSICO AND TELEDYNE POST GAINS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest producer of photographic supplies and equipment, reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter increased 5.7 percent, while sales rose 18.9 percent.

title: VIOLIN RECITAL: NINA BEILINA AT Y
description: NINA BEILINA may not be the most elegant violinist before the public, but she has the ability to go beyond the mere playing of her instrument - she makes it speak. Her music has a big-boned roughness about it that is probably less a question of technical insufficiency than a matter of personality.

title: DAYS OF PROTEST, PARTIES AND PROPRIETY
description: The ranks are forming in something other than receiving lines in northwest Washington's diplomatic neighborhood, where residents are challenging the State Department on the sensitive issue of where a foreign nation can open its chancery, or business office.

title: Harvester Sets Layoffs in Illinois
description: Financial troubles plaguing the International Harvester Company will result in the temporary or indefinite layoff of about 2,500 workers at three Illinois plants, the company announced.

title: CITY SAYS COST OF WOODHULL MAY KEEP IT FROM OPENING
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that underestimated and unexpected costs of Woodhull Hospital, the empty ''municipal dream hospital'' in Brooklyn, could make it so expensive that the city might not open it.

title: DEMOCRATS PROPELLING 3 STRATEGIES ON ECONOMISTS INTO BATTLE OF IDEAS
description: The Democrats tried to reclaim, or re-enter, the battleground of ideas today with the well-advertised distribution of three occasionally conflicting studies on strategies for curbing inflation.

title: ROCK: JOURNEY FROM COAST
description: based quintet that headlined at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., on Saturday, is yet another teenoriented hard-rock band that has taken eight years and nine albums to build a mass following. In the same way that it happened for Styx and REO Speedwagon, Journey's chart-topping success only came with the softening of its sound.

title: USAir Profit Falls
description: USAir, the nation's sixth-largest domestic airline, reported today that its third-quarter profit fell sharply, mostly because of the strike by air traffic controllers. Earnings were $7.1 million, or 40 cents a share, down from $15.4 million, or $1.19 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose to $268.1 million, from $249.5 million.

title: Nuclear Emergency Test Is Almost Taken for Real
description: A police official who forgot to say ''this is an exercise'' sounded a false alarm in a test of the emergency response plan at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant, leading to some tense moments at an elementary school and prompting several more calls.

title: SILENCE: RARELY HEARD IN OUR CONCERT HALLS
description: WE seem to know more about music than we ever have, but less about how to listen to it. This ignorance centers on the musical quality of silence - the surrounding quiet on which every musical experience depends for its life.

title: ISLANDERS' NO. 1 LINE EXCELS IN A 4-1 TRIUMPH OVER PENGUINS
description: The Islanders, who are now in the same division as the Pittsburgh Penguins, made nearly everyone forget that they had won here only three times in nine years by soundly defeating the Penguins, 4-1, tonight.

title: STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for QTr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes $1,098,000 tax credit

title: DANCE: 3 CHOREOGRAPHERS DISPLAY WORKS AT RIVERSIDE
description: THREE authoritative performers with distinct but complementary choreographic points of view were the focus on Sunday evening in a ''choreographers' night'' program presented by the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: A SHAKEN BURMAH OIL NOW RISK-SHY
description: The once-aggressive Burmah Oil Company has emerged from an ordeal of failure in the mid-1970's as a slow-moving, risk-shy conglomerate with little remaining connection to the oil industry.

title: David Huddleston Cast As Rickey in 'The First'
description: David Huddleston has been chosen to replace Darren McGavin in ''The First,'' the new musical scheduled to begin previews Monday and to open Nov. 12 at the Martin Beck Theater.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CHARTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BIG 3 CAR SALES OFF 34.7% FOR OCT. 1-10
description: New-car sales by the three major American automobile makers fell 34.7 percent in the first 10 days of October, the beginning of the 1982 model year. Analysts said the various sales incentive programs had failed to attract buyers and had led them to await further price cuts.

title: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
3 Guilty in Film Fraud
description: Three men have been convicted of mail fraud in a film franchise scheme that prosecutors say cost 200 investors a total of $2 million. The three men operated the Barrett Industries Corporation, a photographic film franchise business in Chicago in which more than 200 distributorships were sold between December 1974 and June 1978, according to evidence presented in a bench trial in United States District Court here. The three found guilty are Howard Ginsburg, 52 years old, of suburban Northbrook; Curtis Norton, 51, of Narberth, Pa., and Lawrence Bender, 37, of Ithaca, N.Y.

title: In a Racquet's Defense
description: John McEnroe displayed his temper for fans in Sydney, Australia, on his way to an easy victory over Rod Frawley in a tennis tournament there. McEnroe yelled at the umpire over a line call and smashed his racquet, and as a result drew a $350 fine for ''racquet abuse.''

title: ONE-ACT DRAMAS: '2 BY SOUTH'
description: IN his best movies, such as ''M*A*S*H'' and ''Nashville,'' Robert Altman creates a sprawling, highly populated world that seems to spill right out of the frame. He does so by using overlapping dialogue, whirligig cutting and subjective camera movements - cinematic techniques that are often antithetical to those of the stage. Now, after 19 movies, Mr. Altman has turned to the theater, and, surprising as it sounds, he's made this unlikely transition with total ease. His staging of ''2 by South,'' a pair of one-act dramas at St. Clement's, is impeccable in its concern for precise details and imaginative in its overall conception. You'd never guess that Mr. Altman hasn't given his life to directing plays.

title: OPERA: 'MOSE' BY ROSSINI
description: Without much warning or even concerted planning, America seems to be awash this fall in revivals of serious operas by Rossini. There was ''Semiramide'' recently in San Francisco and ''La Donna del Lago'' on Thursday in Houston, and last night the Opera Company of Philadelphia opened its season with ''Mose'' - the first of what will apparently be an annual series of Rossini operas.

title: Allied Out Of Chapter 11
description: Allied Supermarkets Inc., Detroit, said yesterday that it had emerged from Chapter 11 proceedings under the Federal Bankruptcy Act after almost three years.

title: Playwright Puts His Words Into Action
description: Once again, when the producers of ''Mass Appeal,'' by Bill C. Davis, have needed an emergency replacement for one of the two actors in the play, they have called out, ''Author, author!''

title: ARGENTINE MOTHERS WON'T LET HOPE DIE
description: ''Please,'' the elderly woman with tinted glasses said, ''it is about my son.'' Her name is Sara Rumani de Goitea, she said, the 65-year-old mother of a disappeared son, one of a group of mothers who march every Thursday in the Plaza de Mayo on behalf of their missing sons and daughters. Now she had knocked on the correspondent's door.

title: TODD SHIPYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $1,750,000 for the qr and $4,275,000 for the 6 mos

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 15, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Jamaica to Pass the Tab
description: Amid an opening day marked by eight losing favorites, Pass The Tab restored some order to Aqueduct yesterday by scoring a 3 1/2-length victory as the 7-10 choice in the featured $55,500 Jamaica Handicap.

title: Cagney and Gable Films In Series at Regency
description: An eight-and-a-half week series of films featuring James Cagney and Clark Gable will begin Sunday at the Regency Theater, Broadway and West 67th Street.

title: INVENTORIES UP BY 0.7% IN AUGUST
description: Inventory stockpiles held by United States businesses climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent in August as sales fell 1 percent in a new sign of a flat or declining national economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: AMERICAN INDIAN CRAFTS AT TWO GALLERIES
description: American Indian art, from basketry to beadwork, has been steadily gaining in stature in recent years. As the audience and the collectors multiply, so, too, do the prices, particularly as older Indian works become rarer.

title: FIDELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN ALLIES TRY ANEW TO MOLD CALIFORNIA POLITICS
description: In 1965, a group of wealthy, politically conservative Republicans who were unhappy with the liberal drift of national affairs decided to groom their own man to become Governor of California, hoping that he might someday become a Presidential candidate.

title: U.S. Starts New Efforts To Return Haitians
description: Immigration officials today announced plans to speed up deportation proceedings and asked a Federal court to allow the repatriation of Haitians who want to return home.

title: Silhouette Books Names President
description: Silhouette Books, a combatant with Harlequin Books in the paperbacks' so-called romance wars, has named John C. Gfeller, 44 years old, as president. The position at the company, part of the Simon & Schuster subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, had been vacant.

title: INDUSTRIAL NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEXICO'S LATIN POLICY
description: The North-South meeting in Cancun, Mexico, next week provides an ideal opportunity to examine Mexico's foreign policy, particularly its relations with Cuba. Washington, to its detriment, tends to dismiss many aspects of that foreign policy.

title: POLE GOES TO TRIAL ON COAST AS A SPY
description: A spy trial that underscores the growing problem of espionage in California's military technology industry opened in Federal court here this week.

title: Error on Date For 'All Savers'
description: The Depository Institutions Deregulation Committee said today that a new and lower interest rate on the taxexempt savings certificates, known as ''All Savers'' certificates, began on Sunday, Oct. 4, not on the following day, as a news release issued by the committee staff had said earlier.

title: IC LIFTS CASH SHARE OF SUNBEAM OFFER
description: The bidding battle for the Sunbeam Corporation continued yesterday as IC Industries increased the number of shares it would buy for cash to 12 million, or 80 percent of the total shares outstanding, from 7.25 million, or 48 percent.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANCE: WINDHAM TROUPE
description: ACONCERT by Leslie Windham and Company on Friday at the Eden's Expressway loft theater provided yet another example of the eclecticism of today's modern dance. Miss Windham incorporated everything from the dangerous life of miners to social dancing and sibling rivalry in the five pieces presented.

title: TV: DOBSON IS NEW MIKE HAMMER
description: MICKEY SPILLANE'S Mike Hammer is being recycled again. The hardboiled, cynical private eye is now snarling his way through ''Margin for Murder,'' a television movie on CBS at 9 this evening. Years ago, the New York tough guy was portrayed by Darren McGavin in a syndicated series called ''Mike Hammer.'' In the movies, he has been depicted by Biff Elliott, Ralph Meeker and Mr. Spillane himself. This time around, Kevin Dobson does the head-bopping honors.

title: WORLDWIDE WORK OF U.N. AGENCY SEEMS ENDLESS
description: Each day dozens of weary women, children and men file across the Ethiopian border, walking 40 miles to a southeast corner of the Sudan in search of food, water, medicine and tents at a camp run by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugeees.

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1981; Companies
description: LTV was ordered by a Federal judge to delay its efforts to take over Grumman. Judge Jacob Mishler, in granting a preliminary injunction, said that ''substantial anticompetitive effects could be presumed'' from a merger of the two makers of aerospace and military products. An LTV spokesman said the company was ''shocked and disappointed'' and planned an immediate appeal. (Page A1.)

title: THE GAMES NEWSPAPERS PLAY
description: In hopes of holding or gaining circulation, newspapers across the country have been increasingly opening their pages to games, contests and other nonjournalistic features that seek to lure readers with thousands of dollars in cash prizes for everything from essays to crossword puzzles to variations on bingo.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $280,000 or 5 cents a shr gain from the liquidation of certain inventories vlued on a LIFO basis in the second qr...C-Includes $930,000 or 15 cents a shr gain from the liquidation of certain inventories valued on a LIFO basis in the second qr; shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid in Jan

title: Electric Auto Plant
description: An auto maker that will begin producing luxury-priced electric cars next year may establish a plant in St. Louis, a company official said today. John Shea, president of the Electric Auto Corporation of America, said, however, it would be at least two years before the company will be in a position to move into its own plant. City officials said they had hoped the company, based in Southfield, Mich., would move into the abandoned Corvette assembly plant.

title: Bush Visits Brazil To Strengthen Ties
description: Vice President Bush arrived in Brazil today for a three-day visit aimed at strengthening relations between the United States and an increasingly independent-minded Brazil.

title: Hutton Group Reports Drop
description: E.F. Hutton Group Inc. reported yesterday that its third-quarter profits fell 39 percent despite a 33 percent rise in revenues, to $345 million from $259.6 million. The investment banking and brokerage concern is the parent of E.F. Hutton & Company, one of the largest brokerage firms in the country.

title: HOUSE CHORES FOR CHILDREN, 1980'S STYLE
description: ON the balance sheet of demographers and population experts, children register as a high-priced luxury. They do not mine coal or milk cows; neither do they spin, weave nor always wash away the bathtub ring. At the same time, the cost of raising a child has soared above the $150,000 mark for middle-income families.

title: Walton Case Challenged
description: The defendants in Bill Walton's $5.4 million medical malpractice suit have moved for dismissal because Walton refused to answer some questions about cocaine use. Walton, the former basketball star whose foot injury ended his career, told a court in Portland, Ore., that he would answer some questions about cocaine use but none that he considered a violation of his constitutional rights. The defendants - Dr. Robert Cook, a team physician for the Portland Trail Blazers, and the Oregon City Orthopedic Clinic - want to know if drug use may have contributed to the foot fracture or impaired Walton's perception. ... The sentencing of Luther (Ticky) Burden, the former Knick who was convicted of a bank robbery on Long Island, has been postponed until Oct. 27.

title: The City; Borough Divisions Urged in Cable TV
description: Consultants recommended that the city divide cable television franchises among several companies in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, reasoning that each of those boroughs was too large for one company to service effectively.

title: MASTERING THE MEDIUM OF LEATHER IN MILAN
description: and, of course, there are leather shorts as well, along with leather miniskirts.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NOBEL PEACE AWARD GOES TO U.N. AGENCY FOR ITS REFUGEE WORK
description: The 1981 Nobel Peace Prize was awarded today to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for aiding the growing numbers of homeless and displaced people around the world.

title: Advertising; Explaining Business to Engineers
description: WHEN it comes to inspiration for new magazines, technology has become this year what science was last year. In Boston, Bernard Goldhirsh, the publisher who opened the eyes of the magazine industry with his highly successful Inc. magazine for small-business men, has just brought out two technology magazines and will be raising their circulation rate bases in January: Both High Technology and Technology Illustrated will go to 300,000 from 200,000. And next month will mark the appearance of Technology, a business publication for engineers.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $66.7 million gain from consolidated subsidiaries, $35.1 million gain from equity in net income of unconsolidated subsidiaries and $15.2 million gain from income of investments for the qr and $192.6 million gain from consolidated subsidiari $127.2 million gain from unconsolidated subsidiaries and $58.8 gain from equity in net income of investments for the 9 mos... C-Includes $44.7 gain from consolidated subsidiaries, $32.5 mil gain from equity in net income of unconsolidated subsidiaries a $13.2 gain from income of investments for the qr and $158.8 mil gain from consoldiated, $104.3 million of equity in net unconsolidated subsidiaries and $42.7 million gain from equity in net income of investments for the 9 mos

title: VICTORIAN DAIRY OPENS ONCE MORE IN THE PARK
description: The Central Park Dairy, probably the finest example of Victorian Gothic architecture in the park, was reopened to the public yesterday after extensive restoration.

title: Sears Opens Offer For Dean Witter
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced that it had begun a tender offer for Dean Witter Reynolds Organization Inc., the first step toward completing acquisition of that concern.

title: KEY ZAPATA STRATEGY: SHIFTING OF ASSETS
description: Back in 1952 George Bush, now Vice President of the United States, and J. Hugh Liedtke, now chairman of the Pennzoil Company, were sitting around their offices in the west Texas oil town of Midland, wondering what to name their fledgling drilling business.

title: 3 Mile Island Operators Queried on Statements
description: A member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that failure of the owners of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant to acknowledge wrongdoing in the 1979 accident had raised serious questions about allowing the plant to resume operations.

title: Proud Appeal Retired
description: Proud Appeal, who won five straight stakes and was the Kentucky Derby favorite, has been retired following the discovery of a broken sesamoid, a small bone, in his left front ankle. Proud Appeal, who finished 18th in the Derby, won eight of 14 races and earned $366,286.

title: FIRST UNION BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1980 figures were restated to reflect the acquisition of the Columbia Union National Bank and Trust Co in March 1981 accounted for as a pooling of interests

title: Giants' King, Healthy, Finally Fulfills Promise
description: The pressures on Gordon King have come from every direction. Because the Giants had made him their first choice in the 1978 draft, many people expected too much too soon. He is an offensive right tackle, a job much more difficult than it appears. And he has been bothered by injuries every year.

title: 5 Exceed 100 M.P.H.  In Las Vegas Practice
description: Five drivers surpassed average speeds of 100 miles an hour today in preparation for the Caesars Palace Grand Prix Saturday. All of the 30 Formula One drivers bettered averages of 90 miles an hour in best laps during the first practice rounds.

title: 'A Mother's Failure'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Claudia Wright's ''Hers'' column (Sept. 24) doesn't hesitate to inform her readers: ''I have told my daughter she should get a fresh medical examination with every change of sexual partner and send me the bill.''

title: Trosclair Convicted
description: Angelo Trosclair, a 24-year-old jockey whose mounts have won more than $1 million, was convicted in New Orleans of having bribed two riders to finish out of the money with their horses in a race at the Fair Grounds in February. After a non-jury trial, Judge Matthew Braniff found that Trosclair had paid $300 to L.J. Drousseau and $600 to Curtis Hale to hold back their mounts in a race won by a long shot, Bye Gem.

title: BOOKSHOP AT MET MUSEUM WON'T CARRY HOVING'S BOOK
description: The bookstore of the Metropolitan Museum of Art will not carry ''King of the Confessors,'' the controversial new book by Thomas Hoving, former director of the Met.

title: SALES ARE LAGGING AT CITY'S MAJOR STORES
description: New York City's major stores had an average 7.9 percent sales gain in September over the same month last year, the third consecutive month in which their increases in business fell below the 8 percent level, a spot-check found yesterday. In the four prior months, beginning with March, sales gains had maintained double-digit levels over 1980.

title: BURRIS GAINS FAME BY DEFEATING A STAR
description: Sometimes a gunslinger is measured by the opponent he knocks off. Who remembers the name of the man who shot Liberty Valance in the movie of the same name? But a few Expo and Dodger fans may remember that it was Ray Burris who thoroughly outclassed Fernando Valenzuela tonight.

title: Rams' Haden Healthy
description: rays showed no fracture, so Pat Haden, who suffered a leg injury in the Los Angeles Rams' victory over Atlanta last Sunday, will be ready to start at quarterback against the Dallas Cowboys. ... A man suspected of last weekend's shooting of Don Smerek, a defensive tackle for the Cowboys, was charged with attempted murder after having surrendered to the Dallas police. The accused, Kenneth Wayne Watson, was then released on $3,500 bond. ... His Oakland Raiders have been shut out in their last three games, and Coach Tom Flores said he will bench Jim Plunkett as the starting quarterback in favor of Marc Wilson, a second-year player, against Tampa Bay Sunday. ... Len Walterscheid, a defensive back for the Chicago Bears, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his knee and is expected to be idle at least six weeks. ... Bobby Joe Birden was sentenced to 34 years to life in prison for the 1980 murder of Bruce Rhodes, a former defensive back for the San Francisco 49ers, and for the attempted murder of Rhodes's wife. ... Dan Marino, the quarterback who missed Pitt's game against West Virginia last Saturday because of a shoulder sprain, is expected to return this weekend against Florida State.

title: No Headline
description: George Brodzki, 60, Is Dead; Was A.P. Reporter in Poland

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NAPOLEON'S RETURN

title: Memorex, Tandy Talks
description: The Tandy Corporation said yesterday that it is considering purchasing the consumer products division of the Memorex Corporation, which produces blank audio tapes and videotape cassettes.

title: Gannett's Net Rises by 12.9%
description: The Gannett Company, owner of the nation's largest newspaper group and a leader in other communications fields, said today that its net income totaled about $41.1 million in the third quarter, an increase of 12.9 percent over the $36.4 million earned in the comparable period in 1980.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FILES and rasps, which are suitable for shaping, smoothing, trimming and sharpening chores, may be among the oldest tools known to man.

title: MRS. CODD POINTS TO KOCH 'FAILURE' ON HIS RELATIONS WITH MINORITIES
description: City Councilwoman Mary T. Codd, the Liberal Party candidate for Mayor, charged last night that Mayor Koch's ''greatest failure'' has been his relationship with minority groups in the city.

title: POLICY BY GYRATION
description: If there is a shrewd professor somewhere writing a book on American foreign policy, he has the material at hand for a riveting chapter on What Not to Do. His case study would be the record of Middle East policy in the first nine months of the Reagan Administration.

title: U.S. FOREIGN AID IS ANYTHING BUT A 'HANDOUT'
description: To the Editor:

title: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per shr figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Aug

title: BIRDS OF WINTER CAN USE HELP IN THE CITY
description: THE casual observer may assume that no ''real'' birds (pigeons don't count) live in the city, but they do. As proof, consider the dozens of species observed in the area during the annual Christmas count of the National Audubon Society.

title: GOING BACK ON THE ROAD AGAIN
description: THE artist doesn't particularly like the mugs and is disgruntled about the colors. ''They were supposed to be richer and deeper,'' said John Baeder, who is known for his realistic paintings of diners, in referring to his new ceramics for Towle/Sigma Giftware.

title: Snap-On-Tools
description: Snap-On-Tools announced that it would suspend its United States manufacturing operations for the week of Oct. 26 ''to improve the balance between inventories and sales.'' The announcement was made by the company president, Edwin C. Schindler. Snap-On-Tools is the world's largest independent manufacturer and distributor of hand tools and related equipment for auto mechanics.

title: 5 POLICEMEN FACE CHARGES IN ARRESTED MAN'S DEATH
description: A coroner's inquest in Milwaukee into the death of Ernest Lacy while in police custody ended today with a recommendation from jurors that three policemen be prosecuted for ''homicide by reckless conduct'' and that two others be prosecuted for ''misconduct in public office and failure to aid a prisoner in their custody.''

title: N.Y.U. INSTALLS 13TH PRESIDENT AT FISHER HALL
description: At his formal installation as the 13th president of New York University, John Brademas called yesterday for renewal of the university's commitment to ''academic distinction.''

title: G.E. Antitrust Suit Dismissed
description: The Justice Department dismissed a nine-year-old civil antitrust suit charging the General Electric Company had engaged in anticompetitive practices.

title: VIRGINIA NATIONAL BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARAFAT ASKS JAPAN'S LEADERS TO BACK STATE FOR PALESTINIANS
description: Yasir Arafat met today with Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki and Foreign Minister Sunao Sonoda to seek Japan's backing for an independent Palestinian state.

title: SCHMIDT IS IN GOOD CONDITION
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt was described today as in good condition after an operation yesterday for the insertion of a heart pacemaker.

title: Examining McDonald's Dismissal of Needham
description: As the smoke begins to clear from Monday's explosive news that the McDonald's Corporation, the world's leading fast-food chain, is switching its $75 million national account from Needham, Harper & Steers to the Leo Burnett Company, we discover that this might have been a classic case of the old foot-in-the-door technique.

title: Ad Bureau Resolves 11 Challenged Claims
description: The National Advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus resolved 11 different cases in September involving challenged advertising claims.

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES PRESLEY'S DOCTOR, NOT PATIENTS, ALTERED PRESCRIPTIONS
description: Elvis Presley's doctor altered prescriptions to give his patients larger quantities of addictive drugs than he originally prescribed, a state witness testified today.

title: POLITICIANS SOUND OUT DELEGATES TO PARLEY ON AGING
