description: The White House Conference on Aging, in past decades a peaceable meeting of like-minded advocates, has suddenly taken on the appearance of a bitterly contested political nominating convention.

title: A Presidential Salute to One of New York's Finest
description: A New York City police officer who persuaded a distraught youth not to fling himself from a Bowery flophouse roof, then later took the youth into his home, has received a written pat on the back from President Reagan.

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS DELAY OF LTV BID TO BUY GRUMMAN
description: A Federal judge today ordered the LTV Corporation to halt at least temporarily its $450 million bid to take over the Grumman Corporation because ''substantial anticompetitive effects could be presumed from the proposed merger.''

title: An Appraisal
description: THERE is a house pictured on the September cover of Solar Age magazine that mixes green and maroon shingles, vertical wood siding and windows of varying sizes into a shape that looks like a cross between a barn and a spaceship. The passive solar structure in Vermont was designed by the architect Ted Montgomery of Circus Studios, who refers to it as ''solar funk.''

title: Olin Earnings Up 46.2%
description: The Olin Corporation said today that gains on chemical and brass operations enabled it to earn 74 cents a share in the third quarter, up from 51 cents a year ago. Net income was $17.7 million on sales of $489.9 million, compared with $12.2 million a year ago on sales of $432.1 million, an increase of 46.2 percent. For nine months, Olin earned $79.1 million, or $3.29 a share, on sales of $1.56 billion, compared with $61.4 million, or $2.56 a share, a year ago on sales of $1.4 billion.

title: Meat-Grading Fees Rise
description: The Department of Agriculture said today that it would raise the fee it charged meatpackers and processors that use the Federal grading and certification service by $3 to $6 an hour. The new rates, which depend on when the inspection takes place, range from $23.20 to $46.60 an hour and come into effect Nov. 29.

title: Khomeini Urges Export Of Iranian Revolution
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, said today that Iran had to work harder to enhance its image abroad so that it could export its revolution. He spoke in a broadcast as the Teheran radio reported the execution of 20 more dissidents.

title: TEXAS COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1980 figures restated to reflect pooling of interests transactions

title: FIRST KENTUCKY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
YARDSTICK FOR THE FEDERAL DEBT'S CURRENT IMPACT
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: POLISH WOMEN OCCUPY MILLS FOR A 2D DAY IN FOOD PROTEST

title: VYQUEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
'A MOTHER'S FAILURE'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: It is amazing that Ms. Wright is so taken with the horror of germs and so little concerned with her children's moral values and happiness. She and her army of ''think alikes'' are the problem, certainly not the solution. MRS. MATTHEW C. WALSH Manhasset, L.I.

title: CITY LIFE: SEEING HOW OTHER HALF SUFFERS
description: THE day can be cool and crisp, warm and sunny or even wet and miserable. It doesn't matter a fig. But it's usually on a weekend when the chores have been done and the feet begin to get restless. That's the time most city dwellers set out to do something healthy or entertaining, They jog, window shop, go to the movies or visit art galleries.

title: GREEK PREMIER COUNTING ON FEAR OF LEFT IN ELECTION
description: Prime Minister George Rallis is counting on the public's fear of the Socialist opposition's anti-Western policies to give his ruling conservative New Democracy Party a victory in Sunday's general election.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1981
description: International The House rebuffed the President, disapproving by 301 to 111 his plan to sell five radar planes and other advanced air equipment to Saudi Arabia. Senator Charles H. Percy, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, suggested that, if the Senate also rejected the sale, Mr. Reagan might invoke a 1977 law that might permit him to proceed despite Congressional disapproval. (Page A1, Column 6.) Two radar planes have been sent to Egypt for an indefinite period to demonstrate United States support for the security of Egypt and the Sudan, the State Department said. (A1:5.)

title: Topics; Righting Wrongs; Voices of the Deep
description: The voice said something like this: "Tension pasjers sistrain will make onlxpress stop huntwenfif necks." A friend heard the announcement on an IRT local during rush hour, and it was his frantic guess that for unfathomable reasons the train was turning into an IND express.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt LIARS IN LOVE. Stories by Richard Yates. 272 pages. Delacorte/Seymour Law- rence. $14.95.

title: TOWN CLEARED OF BIAS CHARGE
description: A Federal judge today rejected charges by the Department of Justice that a 1979 referendum in the suburban town of Manchester was motivated by racial discrimination.

title: The City; Restaurant Cashier Is Shot in Holdup
description: A 60-year-old cashier was shot and wounded when two men held up a Steak & Brew restaurant on Fifth Avenue and escaped with an undetermined amount of cash, the police said.

title: A STALWART'S LAMENT
description: I am a staunch supporter of Ronald Reagan's foreign posture. Although ''foreign policy'' has not yet been articulated, the Reagan foreign posture is unmistakable: a tough-minded approach to the Soviet Union on arms reduction and its sponsorship of terrorism, a rejection of third-world demands for psychological and material coddling, and the projection of the impression that the U.S. is again a reliable ally.

title: Bookkeeping Change Highlights Fiscal Gap
description: New York State plunged into a deficit of $2.33 billion yesterday, but no one got too excited.

title: THE 'BLONDIE' ARTIST MORE THAN 40 YEARS
description: James C. Raymond, the artist who worked on the ''Blondie'' comic strip for more than 40 years, died yesterday at his home in Boynton Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

title: WESTERN PACIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The net income figures reflect unrealized foreign exchange losses of $1,331,000 for the qr and $2,287,000 for the 9 mos of 1981; they also include an expense provision for the estimat cost of settlement rights under stock option agreements of $550 and $1,657,000 for the qr and 9 mos of 1980 respectively

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
MUBARAK, IN TEARS AT SWEARING-IN, TELLS EGYPTIANS, 'THIS IS MY FATE'
description: Hosni Mubarak, a 53-year-old former commander of the Egyptian Air Force, was sworn in as President today to succeed Anwar el-Sadat, who was assassinated eight days ago.

title: HORIZON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Everest Attempt Set Back
description: Three members of a North American medical research team gave up an attempt to reach the summit of Mount Everest today because of winds, the Tourism Ministry reported. Radio reports from the team said the climbers had returned to Camp 5 at 26,300 feet but would try again tomorrow. The three are Chris Pizzo of San Diego, Chris Kopczynski of Spokane, Wash., and David Jones of Vancouver, B.C.

title: STOCKS FALL AMID PROFIT GLOOMINESS
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday, reflecting investor apprehension over declining profits at a number of large corporations, the sluggish state of the economy and high interest rates.

title: Green May Join Cubs
description: The Chicago Cubs scheduled a news conference for today at which they are expected to announce that Philadelphia's manager, Dallas Green, is joining them as general manager and that Green is bringing along one of his coaches with the Phillies, Lee Elia, to replace Manager Joe Amalfitano. Green would succeed Herman Franks, who was hired by William Wrigley as interim general manager last May. A few weeks later, Wrigley sold the Cubs to the Tribune Company.

title: Nettles a Big Contributor
description: On an afternoon when the Yankees overwhelmed the Oakland A's and every member of the batting order contributed, Graig Nettles contributed the most. Nettles, the Yankee third baseman who at 36 began the season amid some predictions that his career was near an end, had four hits in four times at bat yesterday. One was a threerun homer in the seventh inning of the Yankees' 13-3 victory; two others were singles in the seven-run fourth inning, making Nettles the only player in a league championship series to get two hits in an inning.

title: ECOLOGY CHARGES FALL OFF SHARPLY
description: Since the Reagan Administration took office, the number of cases the Environmental Protection Agency has sent to the Justice Department for enforcement has slowed to a trickle, according to internal agency data.

title: SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SURPRISES AT SILVER AUCTION
description: The Government surprised the silver trade yesterday by accepting bids for only 160,000 troy ounces of the 1.25 million ounces of silver bullion it offered at its first auction of the metal since 1970. The accepted bids ranged from a high of $9.41 an ounce to a low of $9.331 and were well below silver prices in the New York cash and futures markets.

title: INTEREST RATES END UNCHANGED
description: The widely predicted drop in interest rates was put on hold again yesterday when rates moved higher early in the day but then closed about unchanged.

title: PACT IS NEAR ON ADDING 2-MAN GARBAGE CREWS
description: New York City and the sanitation workers' union are moving toward an agreement that could result in virtually every sanitation truck in the city carrying a crew of two men instead of three, negotiators for both sides said yesterday.

title: News Analysis
description: The disclosure that two former American intelligence agents attempted to divert military-related technology abroad has focused attention on a problem with serious national security implications: the Government's failure to assure that its advanced technology does not leave this country illegally.

title: HONEYMOON NEARS END FOR REAGAN AND CONGRESS
description: When President-elect Ronald Reagan paid courtesy calls on Congressional leaders last November, his aides said that he hoped to avoid the mistakes of his predecessor, Jimmy Carter, who had had a strained relationship with Capitol Hill.

title: CHAMBER: THE MUSIC PROJECT
description: THE chamber quintet doesn't have the intellectual reputation of the quartet or the intimacy of the trio; contrasts in color and tone are its forte. On Sunday afternoon at the Merkin Concert Hall, the Music Project, an expert group of ensemble players, presented three quintets, revealing most of the works' dramatic contrasts.

title: July Decision Goal Of A.T.&T. Judge
description: Judge Harold Greene, who is hearing the Justice Department's antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, says that he hopes to render a decision by July 1982.

title: DANCE: SKINNER ENSEMBLE FROM SEATTLE
description: THE success of improvisational dance rests largely on the empathetic response of the performers to one another. There's no technique, thematic development or single point of view to hold the observer's attention, only that highly charged space between the bodies. But the space was empty on Tuesday, when the Seattle-based Music and Dance Ensemble of Skinner Releasing made its New York debut at the Cunningham Dance Studio.

title: Big Apple Circus Will Open Dec. 4
description: Opening its fifth season in New York, the Big Apple Circus will play for the first time in a new 1,600-seat, fully heated tent set up in Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center. The one-ring show, including acts from Europe and performers trained by the New York School for Circus Arts, will be presented from Dec. 4 through Jan. 3.

title: BRIEFING
description: B EFORE the curtain went up on the Senate Budget Committee hearings yesterday, two principals of the cast met for a relaxed, revealing moment before taking their places as antagonists. Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat who does not miss a chance to press the Administration on its budget policy, bid a friendly good morning to David Stockman, the budget director, and asked about tax loopholes.

title: PRICE-FIXING RULES: TIMING IS THE KEY
description: It's just a one-sentence provision stuck on the end of Senate bill No. 995, a relatively obscure and broadly supported measure that would change the way damages are assessed in corporate price-fixing cases.

title: EGYPTIAN CHIEF EXPECTED TO BE TOUGHER ON FOES
description: The inauguration of President Hosni Mubarak completed an impressively quick, businesslike transition of power in Egypt. The expectation here is that the new administration will lack personal drama and flair but will be tougher on opponents and more steady in the conduct of day-to-day buisness than was that of Anwar el-Sadat.

title: Friday; TWO WORLDS OF ART IN MIDTOWN
description: Terra cotta treasures from the ancient West African civilizations of Mali and Ghana are on view at the African-American Institute, First Avenue at 47th Street, through Jan. 9. Most of the 59 sculptures date from the 12th to the 17th centuries and include Akan works from Ghana created solely by women. The oldest item is a ninthcentury snake head. On Second Avenue, at 56th Street, an exhibition of Japanese ceramics is on through Oct. 25 at the Old Horizons Gallery of the Manhattan Art & Antique Center. The 19 pieces, from the 15th to 20th centuries, include items used in the traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Both exhibitions are free. CANADIAN BRASS ON L.I.

title: ROWAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Another M.C. for the Miss America Show
description: There he is - yet another master of ceremonies for the Miss America Beauty Pageant at Atlantic City. Gary Collins, an actor and host of the ''Hour Magazine'' television talk show, will replace Ron Ely, a former movie Tarzan, who was hired two years ago to fill the shoes worn for 25 years by Bert Parks. Mr. Collins is married to the actress Mary Ann Mobley, Miss America of 1958.

title: SOME CHOICE SPOTS FOR A GALLERY-HOPPING TOUR OF SOHO
description: AS the art season goes into high gear, SoHo, alive with artists, galleries and those who come to look at both, is drawing its usual crowds. This year, expectations are high, generated not only by the prospect of a bustling art season, but also by the promise of new directions in it.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIN BROADCASTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books
description: The Lessons of McCarthyism By Herbert Mitgang JOE McCARTHY AND THE PRESS. By Edwin R. Bayley. 270 pages. University of Wisconsin Press. $16.50.

title: COLLOQUIM DEBATES MERITS OF PUZO
description: For a few moments Wednesday at Columbia's School of International Affairs, it looked like a street scene on the Via Roma in Naples: Everyone was talking animatedly, the Gucci scarves on some of the chic women in the audience were flying as they sought to be heard, nobody paid much attention to the moderator, and hardly anyone seemed to be in agreement -including, probably, about the above description of a slightly operatic literary roundtable.

title: CONTINENTAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-AFter $5.2 million loss for the qr and $30.5 million gain for the 9 mos from foreign currency translations and gains from debt retirement of $22.8 million for the qr and $24.8 million for the 9 mos...C-Including foreign currency translatio gains of $4.8 million for the qr and $4.6 million for the 9 mos

title: MAUL TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $110,000 for the qr and $855,000 for the 9 mos

title: Cleveland School Drivers Delay Strike Indefinitely
description: School bus drivers demanding higher pay agreed today to put off a strike indefinitely, but both sides said many issues remained.

title: MUSIC: AEOLIAN PLAYERS
description: SCHOENBERG once complained that his music was not modern, just played badly. The Aeolian Chamber Players added a positive footnote to this sad but accurate aphorism at the Abraham Goodman House Wednesday evening.

title: JOHNSON, E F, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $559,000 for the qr and $1,793,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary credits of $128,000 for the qr and $1,015,000 for the 9 mos

title: ALLIED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Included $91 million pretax nonrecurring gain from the sale of Canadian oil and gas properties

title: Shift Hinted On Money Policy
description: A top Administration official said today that the White House thinks the recent effort of publicly urging the Federal Reserve Board into easing its tight grip on the nation's money supply should stop.

title: A Sharp Curve for American Cities
description: Like other big cities in the older parts of the country, New York views with foreboding President Reagan's demand to cut the budget 12 percent more. Having already cut social programs they consider expendable, the cities are now offered an ominous choice: cut even more deeply into income maintenance and medical care for the needy or put off yet again the long-postponed repair of physical facilities necessary to survival.

title: POLAND'S UNION OBTAINS FREEZE IN RISE OF PRICES
description: The Polish Government and the independent Solidarity union agreed today on a temporary freeze on price increases until a system of compensation for the lowest paid workers could be put into effect.

title: Nancy Reagan Wins Support on China Issue
description: Margaret Truman Daniel, a former resident of the White House who is very much a Democrat, came to the defense of Nancy Reagan yesterday, in the seemingly never-ending debate over Mrs. Reagan's ordering $209,508 worth of china for state dinners.

title: Advertising; Magazine Food for Thought
description: Well, at least the weather was fairly nice. And after the gloomy talk about the economy, all of the magazine people could flee the convention site for the courts and links where their sparkling sports togs would be more in tune with the topic.

title: HOUSE CHANGES METHOD FOR PEANUT SUPPORTS
description: The peanut and sugar price support programs favored by the House Agriculture Committee were defeated today in the House of Representatives when the farm state coalition fell apart.

title: WRITER OF CENTRAL EUROPE WINS NOBEL PRIZE
description: Elias Canetti, a 76-year-old writer whose books stem from the vanished cosmopolitan traditions of Central Europe, was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature today.

title: BROWN & SHARPE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
MORE THAN ONE WAY TO GORE AN OX
description: In a hut atop the Sutton Place Synagogue festooned with fresh fruit, branches and tinsel in celebration of Succoth, a group of young lawyers spent an hour yesterday afternoon analyzing a nettling legal issue. It was one that has been debated longer than any amendment to the United States Constitution: the liability of someone whose ox has gored another animal.

title: BECKMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Military Analysis
description: On the night of Oct. 14, 1781, a column of Continental Light Infantry launched a violent attack on Redoubt No. 10 on the extreme left of the British positions around Yorktown. Led by Lieut. Col. Alexander Hamilton, the light infantry stormed the redoubt. At the same time, French infantry took a second British redoubt.

title: Ford Steel Cut
description: A lack of demand for steel has prompted the Ford Motor Company to reduce production by about 20 percent at its Dearborn steel plant until Jan. 1, idling about 200 hourly workers. Ford said yesterday that it shut down two electric furnaces used to melt and recycle scrap steel and iron early in September, when the layoffs occurred. Ford, the nation's ninth-largest steelmaker, is the only United States auto maker that manufactures some of its own steel.

title: Tate Stops Foe in 7th
description: John Tate, former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, survived a brief scare against Barry Funches, a 32-year-old Post Office employee nicknamed ''the fighting postman,'' and scored a seventh-round knockout tonight at the Sands Hotel. Tate weighed 240 pounds and Funches 200.

title: GERARD-CASE HORSE SCRATCHED
description: A horse that had been entered in tonight's second race at the Meadowlands was scratched last night after the track's stewards had learned that he was barred from racing in New York and New Jersey as a suspected ringer in an offshoot of the celebrated Mark Gerard case.

title: ARMS FOR CHINA AND TAIWAN: TWISTS IN DIPLOMACY
description: A week before President Reagan's private meeting with China's Prime Minister at the conference in Mexico on the developing world, the United States, China and Taiwan are enmeshed in an intricate game of arms sales diplomacy.

title: Blind Student Aided by Ex-Justice Stewart
description: For two hours yesterday, Potter Stewart, the recently retired Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, helped a blind second-year law student by reading parts of a law textbook at the Washington studios of Recordings for the Blind Inc.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard A FLAG FOR SUNRISE. By Robert Stone. 439 pages. Knopf. $13.95

title: GUGGENHEIM OFFERS SHOW OF THE RUSSIAN AVANT-GARDE
description: ''ART of the Avant-Garde in Russia: Selections From the George Costakis Collection'' at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is the latest in what is by now a long series of exhibitions devoted to one aspect or another of avant-garde art in Russia between 1910 and 1930. London, Paris, Los Angeles and Washington - in that chronological order - have all had substantial exhibitions of this kind. But if New York in this context has taken its time, the Guggenheim show is a remarkable affair and rich above all in small-scale lyrical work that comes across with a remarkable freshness.

title: DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
OMNICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Earnings are reported on a proforma basis to reflect costs of operating as a separate entity as a result of Omnicare's initial public offering in July 1981

title: REAGAN BIDS THIRD WORLD ADOPT FREE ENTERPRISE TO BATTLE POVERTY
description: President Reagan called on the third world today to develop free-market economies to break the grip of poverty. In a speech delivered a week before he flies to Cancun, Mexico, for a conference on world economic development, the President outlined a development strategy that emphasizes the advantages flowing from free enterprise, investment and trade.

title: Eddie Johnson Fit
description: A week after Eddie Johnson had entered an Atlanta psychiatric ward on his doctor's orders, he was released yesterday.

title: Kurosawa at 8th St.
description: New prints by Macmillan Theatrical Films of two films directed by Akira Kurosawa and starring Toshiro Mifune will be screened tonight through Sunday at the Eighth Street Playhouse, 52 West Eighth Street. ''Yojimbo'' (1961), a tale of two warring merchant families in feudal Japan, will be shown at 4 and 7:55 P.M. each night; ''Throne of Blood'' (1957), Shakespeare's ''Macbeth'' in gory Japanese style, will be shown at 6 and 9:55 P.M., with matinees tomorrow and Sunday at 2:10 P.M. Admission is $4.50; $2.50 for the elderly and children.

title: FLIGHT TRANSPORTATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GRAINGER, W W, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dave Maloney Ailing
description: The Rangers, whose 2-1 victory over the Vancouver Canucks Wednesday night was their first of the season after three defeats, incurred another setback yesterday.

title: 20% Interest On Tax Bills
description: Delinquent taxpayers will be charged 20 percent interest on their outstanding bills, and those who overpay will collect interest at the same rate starting Feb. 1, the Internal Revenue Service announced today.

title: TANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALCOA NET CLIMBS 8.8%
description: The Aluminum Company of America reported that profits for the third quarter rose 8.8 percent, to $81.3 million, or $1.09 a share, from $74.7 million, or $1.03 a share, for a comparable quarter last year.

title: Yanks Selling Series Tickets
description: The Yankees will put World Series tickets on sale this morning at the Yankee Stadium advance ticket windows, starting at 9 o'clock.

title: DETROITBANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago results have been adjusted for a stock split distributed Mar 5, 1981; 1981 results include $739,000 or 15 cents a shr credit from reversal of British income taxes on inventory

title: Honda Profits Decline 54.6%
description: The Honda Motor Company, citing the higher value of the Japanese yen against other currencies, said today that profits in the second quarter of the fiscal year 1981 fell 54.6 percent from the same quarter a year ago on an 11.1 percent revenue gain.

title: No Headline
description: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN SPEECH ON U.S. POLICY TOWARD DEVELOPING NATIONS

title: PENN CENTRAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRESSURE ON AWACS COMES WITH WINKS AND NODS
description: Some of the pressure is open and direct: One Senator is told that his nominee for United States Attorney might be sidetracked; a second hears that he could have an easy time in the next election; a third is threatened with right-wing primary opposition.

title: NILS ASTHER, 84, LEADING MAN IN HOLLYWOOD IN 20'S AND 30'S
description: Nils Asther, who was a leading man to such Hollywood film stars of the 20's and 30's as Greta Garbo, Joan Crawford, Barbara Stanwyck and Marion Davies, died Tuesday at a hospital near Stockholm. He was 84 years old.

title: WORK BEGINS IN WESTCHESTER ON A WASTE DISPOSAL PLANT
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP) - Westchester County broke ground at the site of the county's largest capital project, a $165 million solid-waste disposal plant on 25 acres in Peekskill.

title: Writer of Central Europe Wins Nobel Prize
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 15

title: Reviving The Emperor
description: Life is being breathed once again into the Imperial Presidency by a Nixon-Carter-Kissinger Doctrine that is simple, appealing and wrong. No matter how the President decides a foreign policy question, this doctrine holds, Congress and everyone else must accept it or his authority will be undermined.

title: A ROYAL HAND FOR DISABLED
description: Princess Benedikte of Denmark, the only one of the three Danish princesses who will probably never be a queen, came to New York this week in her role as one of the world's leading advocates of the disabled.

title: MONEY SUPPLY JUMP AWAITED
description: The credit markets exhibited growing apprehension yesterday as both traders and investors braced for a sharp increase in the weekly money supply figures that the Federal Reserve is to issue this afternoon. As a result, changes in values for most Treasury debt issues were minimal and trading remained light, according to dealers in Government securities.

title: East German Escapee Jailed
description: A West Berlin court sentenced a former East German border guard to six years in jail today for shooting and killing his colleague while escaping to the West. Egon Bunge, 21 years old, shot his superior officer on the East-West Berlin border last November before escaping over the Berlin wall.

title: ALDRICH'S '...ALL THE MARBLES'
description: ROBERT ALDRICH has made all kinds of movies, including some very good action films (''Vera Cruz,'' ''Ulzana's Raid'' and ''Emperor of the North Pole''), some that are high camp (''Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?'') and some, like ''The Dirty Dozen'' and ''The Grissom Gang,'' that are so violent that they come close to being selfparody. Each has been to some large degree comic. Now Mr. Aldrich has made an all-out comedy that is, to some small degree, violent.

title: CHANGES AT TEXASGULF
description: Now that France's state-controlled oil company, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, is the owner of about 65 percent of Texasgulf Inc., the American company has merged its minerals exploration division with the Elf Aquitaine Mining Corporation in the United States to form the Texasgulf Minerals Exploration Company.

title: News Analysis
description: Most of the population of Taiwan listens to the Government's ritual vows to ''recover the mainland'' with a jaded ear and little-disguised derision.

title: SUN MYUNG MOON INDICTED ON TAXES
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on charges that he had filed false tax returns omitting more than $150,000 of his income in a three-year period.

title: ALLIED CORP. GAINS 78.8%
description: W.R. Grace & Company, a diversified chemical concern with interests in natural resources and consumer businesses, reported yesterday that profits for the third quarter rose 40.7 percent, to $97.1 million, or $2.04 a share, from $69 million, or $1.47 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: Cave-In Kills Three Workers
description: Three city employees were crushed to death today when the wall of a sewer trench they were digging caved in, the authorities said. The police identified those killed as Ed Ferrell, Jerry Thompson and Moe Kuykendoll.

title: Director talks of 'difficult' Lawrences.
description: THE British director Christopher Miles describes D.H.Lawrence and his wife, Frieda, as ''difficult people.'' They were always questioning things,'' he said. ''And what they did when they were young was a scandal. In those days, a woman didn't leave her children and run away with a writer!''

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including $57 million extraordinary gain from payments from the U.S. government for property taken for a national park

title: New Job for Green
description: Only hours after the Blue Jays had appointed Cox, Dallas Green, as expected, was formally named general manager of the Cubs, and, at a news conference in Chicago, he likened their plight to that of the Philadelphia Philles a decade ago. Green, who was with the Philadelphia organization for 27 years and led the Phillies to the World Series championship in 1980, his second year as manager, said ''the similarities are striking,'' but he warned Chicago fans not to expect any miracles.

title: STEELMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
VARCO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SENATE, 95-0, ACTS TO SAVE SOLVENCY OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Senate today unanimously approved legislation designed to preserve the solvency of the Social Security System through the 1980's. The 95-to-0 vote also retained the minimum benefit for all those now receiving it, reversing an action taken last August.

title: GODFREY'S BREAKFAST: POLITICS AND EGGS
description: The early birds arrive in the Crystal Room of the Sheraton Carlton Hotel at 7:30, draw coffee from an urn, peruse the morning papers and gossip. At 7:45, Godfrey Sperling Jr., the chief Washington correspondent of The Christian Science Monitor, walks out to the lobby to await the guest of honor.

title: Burnett Relinquishes Steak & Ale Account
description: The Leo Burnett Company has resigned the $5 million account for Steak & Ale Restaurants of America. Burnett, which earlier this week acquired the $75 million dollar McDonald's account, has been the agency for Steak & Ale since 1977, the year it lost Kentucky Fried Chicken.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today; Oct. 16, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Ceremony for World Food Day - 10:30 A.M.

title: MOHAWK RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr ago shr earnings are restated for a 3-for-2 stock divd paid May 22, 1981

title: THE EARPHONED PEOPLE
description: Perhaps it all has to do with the movies. I mean the practice of walking down a sidewalk with a stereophonic radio hanging from the shoulder or cradled in the arm, its twin speakers blasting out disco beats. The movies always provide a musical background for people walking down city streets; is that why some people require a personal soundtrack?

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $376,000 tax credit...C-Including $459,000 tax credit

title: POLLUTION AGENCY HEAD SAYS JOB CAN BE DON DESPITE BUDGET CUTS
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, told the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee today that her agency would be able to improve protection of the nation's environment despite a reduced staff and budget.

title: SECURITY PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COSMOPOLITAN IN TRADITION OF GOETHE
description: ''IF, despite everything, I should survive,'' Elias Canetti wrote in his notebook as the Luftwaffe's bombs fell on London in World War II, where he had taken Man in The News refuge from the Nazis in 1939, ''then I owe it to Goethe.'' The great cultural tradition of Goethe strengthened Mr. Canetti's will to survive.

title: PENN CENTRAL CLIMBS BY 80.6%, TANDY UP BY 57.4% IN QUARTER
description: The Penn Central Corporation, a broadly diversified energy, industrial and leisure-products company, reported yesterday that the inclusion of the results of a recently acquired electronics company caused earnings in the third quarter of 1981 to soar 80.6 percent as sales widened by 72 percent.

title: TYLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $4.7 million tax credit...C-Net loss after $10.2 million writeoff...D-After $10.2 million writeoff

title: Bloodbath in Iran
description: The statistics are appalling: Iran has executed more than 1,800 persons since June. Amnesty International reckons this exceeds the known toll for the entire world in 1980, and brings to 3,350 the number of Iranians put to death since the Shah was deposed in 1979.

title: A FAMILY INVOLVED IN POLITICS HELPS MRS. CODD'S CAMPAIGN
description: Helped by her big, politically active family and hindered only slightly, she insists, by her small campaign treasury - all of it from the Liberal Party - Mary T. Codd is running for Mayor of New York City, Staten Island-style.

title: METHODICALLY, SMALL DEVELOPER EXPANDS IN MANHATTAN
description: Project by project, a small development company called Britton Development Ltd. has been growing since it was founded seven years ago by an accountant and an architect.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results reflect foreign currency exchange losses of 44 cents a shr and $1.25 a shr for the latest qr and 9 mos respectively, and 5 cents and 16 cents for the previous qr and 9 mos

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: RAMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
John Hayes, Ex-Envoy And a Radio Executive
description: John S. Hayes, former American ambassador to Switzerland and head of broadcasting stations at The New York Times and The Washington Post, died Wednesday at Baptist Memorial Hospital in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 71 and had lived in retirement in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla.

title: REAGAN SUBMITS A PLAN TO CURB INFORMATION ACT
description: The Reagan Administration submitted to Congress today a proposal that would restrict use of the Freedom of Information Act and permit the Attorney General to keep secret selected information about terrorism, organized crime and foreign counterintelligence investigations.

title: Rogers, Reuss Renew Rivalry
description: When they were in high school in Missouri 15 years ago, Steve Rogers and Jerry Reuss pitched against each other with the state championship at stake. They will renew the rivalry tomorrow night with another prize at stake: the lead in the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: Canada Hopes to Stem Influx Of Sikhs by Requiring Visas
description: Canada placed visa restrictions on Indian nationals today to stem an influx of Sikhs claiming refugee status.

title: KAISER CEMENT & GYPSUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 results includ net gain on the disposal of investments and other assets of $4,404,000; 1980 results include net gains of $2 million

title: AMERICAN CYANAMID CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONE MILLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Self-Defense Plea Likely for Abbott
description: The lawyer for Jack Henry Abbott said yesterday that his client would not deny having fatally stabbed Richard Adan, a 22-year-old waiter.

title: FIRST BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After net losses of $193,468 for the qr and $1,865,289 for the 9 mos from foreign currency translations... C-After net losses of $235,973 for the qr and $963,922 for the 9 mos from foreign currency translations

title: Talks in Teacher Strike Resume in Philadelphia
description: Secret talks resumed between striking teachers and the school board today, as labor leaders threatened a general strike and teachers joined with discharged air traffic controllers in protesting an appearance by President Reagan.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER APPOINTS NEW HEAD
description: The International Paper Company has returned to a more traditional organizational format and elected John A. Georges, 50 years old, as president and chief operating officer. The world's largest paper company has not formally had a president since February 1980, when it named two vice chairmen to serve under the chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Georges was named president following completion this month of the sale of International Paper's Canadian subsidiary to Canadian Pacific Enterprises for $910 million in cash.

title: Steel Imports Opposed
description: The Steel Service Center Institute has urged stronger protection against imported steel, which accounted for 25 percent of steel sold in the United States in August. The industry group said the trigger price mechanism, designed to protect domestic steel makers from foreign competition, had failed and must be replaced.

title: IN BRITAIN, A WEEK OF FASHION
description: The good news about British fashion for next spring and summer is that the two indisputable and singularly disparate leaders, Jean Muir and Zandra Rhodes, are working like masters in complete control of their craft. They have each reached the point where they are paring down their designs rather than embellishing them with odd decorative elements - a sure sign of maturity. It is a bit like the days when the late Norman Norell and James Galanos enjoyed separate-but-equal status in the United States and, even earlier, when Christian Dior shared the pinnacle with Balenciaga in Paris.

title: A Marionette Premiere
description: The Nuova Opera dei Burattini, the Italian marionette theater company, is presenting the first United States production of E. Gordon Craig's ''Gentlemen, the Marionette!'' at the University Theater of New York University, 30 West Fourth Street, tonight through Sunday. Performances are at 8 P.M., with a Sunday matinee at 3 P.M. Admission is $5, $2.50 for students. For information, call 598-7060.

title: THOUSANDS SEEK 126 VACANCIES IN APARTMENTS
description: A crowd of 2,000 people turned out yesterday to seek applications for 126 Manhattan apartments whose tenants will receive Federal rent subsidies.

title: News Analysis
description: The dispute between former President Jimmy Carter and The Washington Post over a gossip column item raises basic, intertwined questions of law and journalistic practice, according to press lawyers, editors and writers.

title: FUN AND FANCY WITH TRISHA BROWN
description: Trisha Brown has danced up museum walls and across the rooftops of SoHo. She has wound her dancers through choreography plotted with Einsteinian rigor and had them ease through games with poles and looping calisthenic gestures. Her mop of hair, unmadeup face and tumbled dancing clothes suggest a firmer purpose than mere entertainment, but there's more than a glint of humor to that inscrutable stare. Tonight Miss Brown and her company of six dancers will open ''The Next Wave: New Masters at the Brooklyn Academy of Music,'' a two-month festival of avant-garde dance and music.

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $349,000 loss for the qr and $6,315,000 or 88 cents a shr gain for the 9 mos from discontinued operations... C-After $1,630,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: ART PASSARELLA, EX-UMPIRE, LATER ACTED IN FILMS AND TV
description: Art Passarella, a former major league umpire who went on to have a role in the television series ''The Streets of San Francisco'' and appear in several films, died of a heart attack here earlier this week. He was 71 years old.

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1981; International
description: President Reagan outlined a third world development strategy, stressing the advantages that arise from free enterprise, investment and trade. In a speech before the World Affairs Council of Philadelphia, the President depicted economic and political freedom as the key to prosperity. (Page A1.)

title: Rail Freight Grows
description: Railroad freight hauled last week totaled about 18.9 billion ton-miles, up 7 percent from a year earlier, the Association of American Railroads estimated today.

title: THE PILL IS NOT A 'TRAP'
description: To the Editor:

title: SIGNAL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DUTCH CABINET IS SET TO RESIGN
description: Prime Minister Andries van Agt will offer the resignation of his month-old Cabinet to Queen Beatrix today after a failure by the coalition to agree on financial policy, a Government spokesman said.

title: ZENITH NATIONAL INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split declared Dec 3, 1980

title: CABARET: HINTON BATTLE IN SONGS AND DANCE
description: THE musical ''Sophisticated Ladies'' has become a significant launching ground for cabaret talent. Earlier this year, the dancer Gregg Burge gave a premiere of a flashy vaudevillian act that was strongly indebted to Ben Vereen.

title: RALLY BY FLORIO COUNTERS A VISIT BY THE PRESIDENT
description: The Democratic gubernatorial candidate, Representative James J. Florio, addressed a crowd of union workers, students and the elderly today at a rally. It was staged here as a counterpoint to President Reagan's visit tonight in support of the Republican candidate, Thomas H. Kean.

title: Common Market to Curb Baby Formula Ads
description: The Common Market will begin work soon on draft legislation to curb the promotion of breast-milk substitutes in the third world because they are a health risk, Commissioner Karl-Heinz Narjes said today.

title: Newmont Sues Gold Fields
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation, fighting a possible takeover by Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd. of London, said yesterday that it had filed an antitrust suit in Federal District Court against Gold Fields and the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa.

title: INJUNCTION WEAKENS GRUMMAN'S SHARES
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it was still buying its own stock and continuing its efforts to defeat the LTV Corporation's $450 million tender offer.

title: Simonini Healing
description: Ed Simonini, Baltimore's top linebacker, joined the Colts for practice for the first time since he broke his collarbone in an exhibition game against the Giants. The injury has not completely healed, but the Colts say that they hope he will be ready for the game at Cleveland Oct. 25.

title: Coal Port on S.I.  Proposed by City
description: New York City requested preliminary proposals from developers and others for construction of a coal port on Staten Island that, officials said, could make New York a major port for coal being shipped to Europe.

title: TRITON OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes $125,000 tax credit

title: Northern Exposure
description: MONTREAL A sticker on a pillar in the Yankees' clubhouse in New York reads: ''And on the fourth day, God made the Yankees.'' Nobody is sure why George M. Steinbrenner III hasn't ordered it removed, for George III does not share credit willingly. One theory is that George III confuses the Creator with himself.

title: BATTERY PARK CITY TAX PLAN ACCEPTED
description: The Koch administration has, after months of negotiations, reached agreement on a tax abatement plan with the developers of Battery Park City's commercial complex.

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Honduras to Relocate Salvadoran Refugees

title: WATSON LEADING AFTER A 64
description: Tom Watson, hoping to retain his money-winning and player-of-the-year titles, made an 80-foot birdie putt on the final hole to complete a 64 and take the first-round lead today in the $200,000 Pensacola Open.

title: BANKERS TRUST CO (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago qr results exclude $5.8 million gain on the sale of branches

title: AN AGENCY'S EFFORTS TO SAVE THE FALASHAS
description: To the Editor:

title: WEINBERGER ASSAILS NEUTRALISM
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger warned today against ''the dangers of neutralism'' in Europe posed by those who advocate ''unilateral disarmament.'' But he said he distinquished between such neutralism and the neutrality of Sweden, which is strongly armed.

title: MUSIC: LORIN MAAZEL LEADS LEONORE' AND MAHLER'S 9TH
description: IT is probably a sign of health, rather than confusion, when one emerges from a concert unsure as to whether the music or its performance was more superb. It is sometimes said that the greatest performances obliterate all thought of execution, permitting one to dwell unimpeded on the essence of the music. Yet without calling vulgar attention to itself, a great performance can serve the score and still let one admire the way it was brought to life.

title: BARD, C R, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $197,000 loss for the qr and $5,000 gain for the 9 mos from discontinued operations

title: YANKEES BEAT A'S, 4-0, AND GAIN WORLD SERIES
description: In the end, it wasn't the George and Billy Show at all. In the end, the American League pennant playoff belonged strictly to the Yankee players.

title: CANNON MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLICE ARREST ARSON SUSPECT
description: A 37-year-old man who lives a block from the burned-out building was arrested and charged with eight counts of homicide and one count of aggravated arson.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alberta Energy Co. said it had applied with Esso Chemical Canada, a subsidiary of Imperial Oil and Gas Company, for a permit to build an ethylene plant near Edmonton.

title: Mexico's Party Leader Resigns Unexpectedly
description: The head of Mexico's ruling party, Javier Garcia Paniagua, resigned unexpectedly last night, just hours after Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado began his campaign as official candidate in next July's presidential elections.

title: Cosmopolitan in Tradition of Goethe
description: ''IF, despite everything, I should survive,'' Elias Canetti wrote in his notebook as the Luftwaffe's bombs fell on London in World War II, where he had taken Man in The News refuge from the Nazis in 1939, ''then I owe it to Goethe.'' The great cultural tradition of Goethe strengthened Mr. Canetti's will to survive.

title: DORSEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-AFter $1.5 million extraordinary loss

title: MCGRAW-HILL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Standby U.S.  Cotton Plan
description: Because of the delay in getting a new farm law, the Agriculture Department said today that it was putting into effect standby legislation to provide a cotton program for 1982.

title: NOXELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ferragamo Benched
description: Vince Ferragamo, once hailed as the savior of professional football in Montreal, will not accompany the Alouettes of the Canadian Football League to Toronto for a game tomorrow with the Argonauts. Jim Eddy, Montreal's coach, said that Gerry Dattilio and Ken Johnson, acquired this week from Calgary, will be the quarterbacks.

title: CHILD'S VIEW OF DIVORCE
description: ''THE DAY the Loving Stopped,'' a movie on ABC-TV at 9 o'clock tonight, stars Dennis Weaver and Valerie Harper, but the picture belongs to Dominique Dunne, who plays their daughter Judy Danner. Liz Coe's script examines divorce from the point of view of the children.

title: AUCTIONS
description: SOME major American art and artifacts will be sold in three auctions next week at Sotheby Parke Bernet galleries and in one at Phillips, Son & Neale, Madison Avenue at 72d Street. In the first sale, at Sotheby's Madison Avenue galleries, at 76th Streeet, on Thursday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M., the most important art work up for bidding is Winslow Homer's ''East Hampton, Long Island.'' It is an 1870's beach scene showing three women garbed in billowing white dresses, an oil on canvas that was bought for $35 in the 1950's in a curio shop in Tulsa, Okla., by William Roehrick, a young actor.

title: BROADWAY
description: IS there life after divorce? For the couple in ''Special Occasions,'' Bernard Slade's new romantic comedy, the answer is an emphatic yes - and with each other. ''Special Occasions'' will open Jan. 31 at the Music Box Theater. ''Deathtrap,'' the Music Box's current tenant, plans to move to another theater.

title: Malthus and Marx, on Food Day
description: No better occasion than today, the first world Food Day, to exorcise the gloomy spirit of Malthus that clings to discussions of world hunger.

title: Prime Rate Cut in Canada
description: At least five of Canada's 11 nationally chartered banks lowered their prime lending rate today after the central bank dropped its key rate.

title: Coins Approved By Senate Panel
description: The Senate Banking Committee today approved a deal between the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee and a private venture for marketing of coins to raise money for the 1984 Summer Olympics.

title: PUROLATOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
P.L.O. Recalls Envoy in Rome
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization recalled its representative in Rome today. The move was said to be a protest against the Italian Government's handling of an investigation into the death of a high P.L.O. official, Abu Sharar, on Oct. 9.

title: PITT, RATED NO 1, EDGES MISSOURI
description: Pittsburgh, the nation's No.1 major-college football team in The New York Times's final computer ranking last season, is on top again in the first such weekly ranking this season.

title: KAISER STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $22,266,000 for the qr and $30,664,000 for the 9 mos

title: MARTIN: NO EXCUSES-'THEY BEAT US'
description: Matt Keough pushed his way through a crowd of reporters in Billy Martin's office and reached out his hand to the A's manager. ''I'm sorry,'' Keough said softly, looking into Martin's sad eyes and holding his hand for a long moment.

title: THE JAPANESE WAY AT QUASAR
description: The cinder-block walls are painted glossy white. Women work quietly with circuit boards and multicolored wires along the rolling assembly lines.

title: Illinois Town Cuts Back To Reimburse Chrysler
description: Police cars will no longer patrol this city of 17,000 people, and some street lights will be turned off, to save money so that the Chrysler Corporation can be reimbursed for apparent tax overcharges.

title: KORCHNOI HAS EDGE AS 6TH GAME ADJOURNS
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland adjourned the sixth game of the world chess championship match here tonight in a winning position against the titleholder, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union.

title: THE STRATEGIC BALANCE
description: As Congress begins to debate the wisdom of the Administration's new strategic-weapons package and continued reluctance to open SALT negotiations, it should recall why the Johnson and Nixon Administrations decided to open a serious dialogue with Moscow about limiting such weapons. This dramatic departure - often called a failure but, I think, an enormous success - was based on three conclusions that are as valid in the early 1980's as they were in the late 1960's.

title: Mortgage Rules Eased
description: Federally chartered savings and loan associations were given more leeway today in making balloon loans and reverse annuity mortgage loans.

title: Turkey Names Panel To Revive Democracy
description: Turkey's ruling junta named a 160-member ''advisory assembly'' today to prepare a new constitution and election law for Turkey's eventual return to democracy.

title: CONCERT: THE PHILADELPHIANS
description: THE Philadelphia Orchestra opened its 1981-82 New York season at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, and up there on the podium - looking as though he had commanded time to stand still and had gotten the obedience he has long been accustomed to - was its conductor laureate, Eugene Ormandy. On Nov. 18, Mr. Ormandy will be 82 years old, but he was making no visible concessions to age on this occasion.

title: Earnings Up 20.3% At Chase
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, in step with the emerging pattern of higher third-quarter bank profits, said yesterday that its operating earnings rose by 20.3 percent during the latest three months.

title: CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results reflect foreign currency translation losses of 2 cents and 4 cents a shr for the latest qr and 9 mos respectivel and foreign currency translation gains of 1 cent and 14 cents a shr for the previous qr and 9 mos respectively

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports of The Times column yes- terday incorrectly reported the where- abouts of the baseball player Jim Wohlford. He is with the San Francisco Giants.

title: STAGE: AYCKBOURN PLAY
description: Alan Ayckbourn has often been compared to Neil Simon, his equal in terms of popularity and productivity, but a closer American correlative may be John Cheever, at least as demonstrated by the English playwright's ''Just Between Ourselves'' at the McCarter Theater Company.

title: COLONIALS AND REDCOATS MUSTER ANEW FOR BATTLE
description: Authentically costumed ''camp followers'' joined thousands of volunteer ''troops'' assembling here today for this weekend's re-enactment of events leading up to the British surrender in 1781. Four thousand strong, the ''Continentals'' and ''Redcoats'' have come from 23 states and Canada to meet at a 1,000-tent re-creation of an 18th-century military encampment on the green banks of the wide York River.

title: Nets' King Agrees to Pact
description: Albert King, one of the Nets' three firstround draft choices, has agreed to contract terms and could begin practicing by Tuesday, Coach Larry Brown said today. King has been hampered by a sprained right knee and will be re-examined Monday morning.

title: FOR THE YANKEES, IT'S BOBBYBALL NOW
description: Then the Yankee manager talked about how ''we had more depth in our bullpen than he did.'' Goose Gossage finished the 4-0 victory after Dave Righetti had pitched six innings and Ron Davis two innings. Willie Randolph hit his first home run since April and Graig Nettles hit a three-run double in the ninth for a three-game total of nine runs batted in. But for the Yankees last night, perhaps the most significant moment occurred on the game's first pitch, when Jerry Mumphrey had to spin into the dirt from Matt Keough's high, inside fastball.

title: PARKER-HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split Sept 4

title: KOCH SAYS NEW REAGAN CUTBACKS WOULD COST THE CITY $68.6 MILLION
description: A Koch administration analysis of President Reagan's proposed new budget reductions suggests that New York City stands to lose $68.6 million in operating budget funds for the present fiscal year. The cuts could threaten day-care center and centers for the elderly, teachers' jobs and youth training programs, the study says.

title: BURROUGHS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PIONEER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
DEVASTATED VOLCANIC AREA TO BE PRESERVED BY U.S.
description: Almost 85,000 acres devastated by the eruption of Mount St. Helens will be preserved for public education, recreation and research, the United States Forest Service announced today.

title: Economic Scene; Philosophical Impact of Prize
description: WHETHER it meant to or not, the Royal Swedish Academy of Science, in awarding the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science this week to James Tobin of Yale University, a harsh critic of the economic policies of the Reagan Administration, has focused national and world attention on the claims that Reaganomics is an answer to the most serious and pervasive economic ailment of our times - stagflation, that mixture of stagnation and inflation that afflicts the entire industrial world.

title: THE IRANIAN CABINET STEPS DOWN
description: Iran's state radio said today that the Iranian Cabinet had resigned to give the new clergyman-President a free hand in choosing its members. It also said that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini had delegated his powers as Commander in Chief of the armed forces to the new military commander.

title: SOVIET BIDS EGYPT IMPROVE RELATIONS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, told President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in a message today that the Soviet Union would look favorably on Egyptian moves to improve relations.

title: TRW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $30.4 million gain from the sale of Datacom

title: TO PROTECT NEW YORK STATE'S WILDLIFE-OR ITS VICTIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: T HE big party news this week was that those two department storescum-catering halls - Bloomingdale's and B. Altman's - really outdid themselves with after-hours bashes.

title: Summing Is Retired
description: Summing, who was syndicated for $8 million after his surprise victory in the Belmont Stakes in June, has been retired.

title: PHILIP MORRIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HONDA MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SUIT TO OUST ESPOSITO AS COUNTY CHIEF REVIVED
description: The Court of Appeals, New York State's highest court, yesterday reinstated a suit that could remove Meade H. Esposito as the Brooklyn Democratic leader.

title: City Street Signs Get a New Look
description: Street signs along a 25-block stretch of Third Avenue in Manhattan changed colors last month. The city's Department of Transportation traded the familiar yellow-and-black color scheme for a luminescent green-and-white version of the street marker.

title: Market Place; Margin Calls: Market Threat
description: WITH the amount of stock in weak hands rising last month to levels approaching those of September 1974, the worst month on record, the stock market could be pushed into a painful fall. The most withering bear market in a generation ended in December 1974.

title: WHEN THE MILITARY MARCHES OUT OF BOUNDS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SEES DANGERS IN TENSE MIDEAST
description: The Reagan Administration expressed concern today that the rise in ''tensions and rhetoric'' since President Anwar el-Sadat's assassination could produce ''an outbreak of hostilities'' in the Middle East.

title: ALUMINUM CO OF AMERICA (ALCOA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Feb 1981

title: THE HOMECOMING
description: The Yankees remained here tonight for a victory celebration at the same restaurant where the A's ate and drank last Sunday while they were waiting to learn who their opponent in the American League championship series would be. Tomorrow afternoon, the Yankees will fly home,scheduled to arrive at Newark Airport between 8 and 10 P.M., New York time.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Reichhold Chemicals Inc. announced yesterday that Edward E. Shea, 49 years old, had resigned as chairman, member of the executive committee, vice president and general counsel and as a director, ''to pursue outside interests.''

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes $52,000 credit

title: SEAFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
5.61 RISE PUTS DOW AT 856.26
description: The stock market, battered this week by investor concern over lower third-quarter earnings reported by a number of large corporations, registered a modest advance yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 5.61 points, to 856.26.

title: 2 U.S. AWACS IMMEDIATELY BEGIN PATROLS IN EGYPT
description: Two United States airborne surveillance planes arrived over Egyptian airspace today and immediately began patrolling Egypt's vast western desert, which borders on Libya.

title: FILMWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $24,835,000 for the qr and $26,243,000 for the 6 mos and $17,074,000 extra- ordinary credit for the qr and 6 mos...C-Net loss including inc from discontinued operations $1,680,000 for the qr and $2,204,0 for the 6 mos

title: GENERAL COUNSEL IS NAMED BY TIMES
description: Katharine P. Darrow has been appointed general counsel of The New York Times Company, with responsibility for all of the company's legal affairs, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.

title: A VALUE-ADDED TAX IS 'POISON' FOR THE PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Boys Choir Uptown
description: The Boys Choir of Harlem, which isn't just a traditional church choir, mixing innovative, traditional and jazz styles in its music, will perform Sunday at 6 P.M. at the Church of the Intercession, 155th Street and Broadway.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UMC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $376,000 for the qr and $903,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes $70,000 gain from discontinued operations and $245,000 gain on a sale; 1980 results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interes with High Performance Machines Inc

title: EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Canadiens 7, Whalers 2
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Mario Tremblay had the second three-goal game of his career and added an assist for Montreal.

title: LEGISLATOR CALLS BOND FOR PRISONS UNNEEDED
description: State Assemblyman Arthur O. Eve, charging that state officials were lying to the public, said today that he was going to court to halt the use of state money to promote New York's $500 million prison bond issue proposal.

title: Reagan Approves 4.8% Raise For 1.4 Million U.S. Workers
description: President Reagan gave 1.4 million Federal workers a 4.8 percent raise today.

title: Thrace Oil Find Cited
description: The Turkish Petroleum Office has discovered petroleum deposits at a depth of 9,800 feet in the Hamitabat region of Thrace, the Turkish daily newspaper Cumhuriyet said today. It said that a quality test would be completed in a few days.

title: S.E.C. WARNS ON BUDGET CUT
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission contends it would have to drop 20 percent of its employees, close as many as six offices and reduce sharply its enforcement and documentreviewing capability if the Administration and Congress force it to make a 12 percent budget cut.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES, 9 TO 8, TO OPPOSE SAUDI AWACS SALE
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 9 to 8 today to recommend the disapproval of President Reagan's plan to sell Awacs radar surveillance planes and other air-combat equipment to Saudi Arabia.

title: NORTH AMERICAN COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ILLINOIS CHOO-CHOO BLUES
description: Galena, a lovely, historic place cradled in the hills of northwestern Illinois, is saddened that it has just lost its one and only Amtrak train, the Blackhawk. Big cities yawn when they lose a train. But Galena, calling itself ''a 3,900-person town,'' feels hurt. It struggled to make the Blackhawk work, and feels that government and other cities on the line didn't - Rockford (pop. 142,500), Freeport (25,000), and Dubuque, Iowa, (63,500).

title: ALIEN CHILDREN ENTITLED TO U.S. EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR THE BROWSER IN SOHO, RESTAURANT AND CAFE SUGGESTIONS
description: In SoHo, last year's garage is this year's fashionable nightspot. Meatball heroes are giving way to nouvelle cuisine, and limousines with darkened windows can now be seen waiting at the door to whisk their owners back to the Upper East Side.

title: ALBERT MAYER, 83, ARCHITECT AND HOUSING PLANNER, DIES
description: Albert Mayer, architect of some of Manhattan's best-known apartment buildings and a city planner, died of a coronary arrest Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: BEVERLY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FILMS IN THE SPIRIT OF MARGARET MEAD
description: The Margaret Mead Film Festival at the Museum of Natural History tomorrow and Sunday will once again take adventure-seeking New Yorkers on a vicarious journey to the few remaining societies on earth without cars, telephones, televisions or washing machines.

title: GIBSON, C R, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
16 MURDERS AND STARVATION REPORTED ON HAITIANS' BOAT
description: The Federal authorities are investigating reports that as many as 16 Haitians were murdered with machetes, knives and ropes and that dozens of others were deliberately starved to death on a voyage from Haiti to Florida last July.

title: ISLANDERS WIN HOME OPENER
description: Though it may have seemed like the middle of the season to some fans, the Islanders finally played thier home opener tonight, beating the Vancouver Canucks, 4-1. It was the Islanders' third victory without a loss - all by the same score. They have played one tie.

title: R.J. REYNOLDS AND PHILIP MORRIS UP
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter increased 9.3 percent on an 11.4 percent rise in sales. Reynolds, the nation's largest producer of cigarettes, accounts for about a third of the market.

title: 'CHANEL SOLITAIRE' AND WHAT WOMEN WANT
description: AT the end of many a long, talky scene in ''Chanel Solitaire,'' the sentimental piano score becomes extremely noticeable. The music isn't anything to get excited about, but it's livelier than the conversation, which has none of the dash one might expect from a movie about the first lady of haute couture.

title: REAGAN KITCHEN CABINET BACK HOME IN THE WEST
description: They had been with Ronald Reagan from the start. They urged him to run for Governor of California, they helped finance his campaign and they oversaw the selection of his advisers. Then, when Mr. Reagan ran and was elected President, they did it again.

title: NATIONAL HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $891,000 gain from discontinued operations; 1980 results restated for a change in accounting for compensated absences

title: PIANO: WORKS OF NORDICS
description: IF the drawing-room passions and wintry dramas of Henrik Ibsen, and the introspective island-bound angst of Ingmar Bergman were combined with an occasional touch of the detached bemusement of Victor Borge, and if this Nordic mixture were set to music, the result might be very like what was heard in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.

title: Garfield Granddaughter Dies
description: Ruth Stanley-Brown Feis, granddaughter of President Garfield, died Tuesday at the age of 89. Mrs. Feis was the wife of the late Dr. Herbert Feis, an author who won a Pulitzer Prize in history in 1961 for ''Between War and Peace: The Potsdam Conference.'' She is survived by a daughter, Felicia Gomes of Altamonte Springs, and two grandsons.

title: A PETER, PAUL & MARY REUNION
description: the opening concert of a four-night stand - offered no musical surprises. Their smooth, polite folk-pop style didn't significantly evolve after the mid-60's.

title: PRICE RIFT IN OPEC MAY CLOSE
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries appears to be moving toward an end to the bitter pricing battle that has preoccupied the 13 member nations for most of this year.

title: NEW DELAYS EXPECTED IN FLXIBLE BUS REPAIRS
description: The latest timetable for repairing the city's defective Grumman Flxible buses and returning them to the streets puts off full delivery of all 715 recalled buses until at least February.

title: French dining spot re-evaluated.
description: IT is not often that an ambitious French restaurant in New York deserves two stars, and such a rating attracts attention and optimistic diners. But if a four-star restaurant is reduced to a twostar ''very good'' rating, it does not seem quite good enough in relation to ''extraordinary.'' This came to mind after recent return visits to Le Cygne, on 54th Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, which indicate that while it is not the four-star restaurant it was a year or two ago, it continues to offer a number of dishes that make a visit worthwhile.

title: AMDAHL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A James Bond Expo
description: The first ''007 James Bond Collectors Expo,'' featuring books, records, models, toys and dolls related to Ian Fleming's famous fictional spy, will be held Sunday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. at the New York Statler Hilton, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Mr. Walinsky suggests capping the disasters of the President's tax cut and war-spending increase with the atrocity of a value-added tax.

title: MUSIC: VOCAL SOLOS BY ANDREA VON RAMM
description: TO hear Andrea von Ramm sing Italian Renaissance music as she did at the Mannes College of Music Wednesday night is to enter the solo vocal world as it probably existed around 1600 - when opera was born - and a wondrous world it is in her re-creation. Miss von Ramm's mezzo-soprano is not imposing of itself, but her singing was so acutely responsive to the meaning of the texts at hand that her performances took on a monumentality having nothing to do with vocal timbre or amplitude per se.

title: Blue Jays Name Cox
description: There was a spate of activity off the field in several major league baseball cities yesterday. First, Bobby Cox, dismissed last week by the Atlanta Braves, was named to manage the Blue Jays, replacing Bobby Mattick, who decided recently to step up to Toronto's front office.

title: TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid last month

title: Index; International
