title: 2 DEMOCRATS OBJECT TO REAGAN'S PLANS FOR C.I.A.
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed guidelines for the Central Intelligence Agency, which would expand its activities ''into domestic matters,'' create the appearance that the agency is being politicized, two senior Democrats on the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence said today.

title: Strong Quake Strikes Chile
description: A strong earthquake shook the Chilean capital early today, and unofficial reports said it was felt throughout the central part of the country. There were no immediate reports of casualties or damage. The University of California seismographic station in Berkeley estimated the magnitude of the quake at 7 on the open-ended Richter scale, which meant the earthquake was severe enough to cause widespread damage.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTENANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
UNITED BANK CORP OF NY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per shr figures are fully diluted

title: THE DANGER OF ABSOLUTES
description: A trip through Central America and further south highlights the problem of absolutes. In Salvador, Msgr. Ricardo Urioste said he dared not go to see if Communism, which he opposes as a Catholic, is gaining ground in Nicaragua because just making the trip would brand him as a Communist. In Guatemala, a conservative American businessman whispered that he had to be careful what he said or he'd be called a Communist.

title: CHEMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $4,455,000 gain for the qr and 9 mos from the sale of Omnicare stock in July and $881,000 gain for the 9 mos on the sale of an Australian licensee...C-Including $775,000 income for the qr and 9 mos from a favorable tax adjustment, $1,070,000 gain for the 9 mos on the sale of Quaker Chemical stock and $318,000 gain for the 9 mos from the sale of fixed assets

title: Runner Reinstated
description: Allison Roe, the New Zealand distance runner, has been cleared by The Athletics Congress to compete in the United States. She had been suspended for accepting prize money in a race at Portland, Ore. Her reinstatement followed her transfer of the money to the New Zealand Amateur Athletic Association.

title: Youth, 17, Seized In Attack on Cleric
description: A 17-year-old East Harlem youth was arrested shortly after he sprayed Chemical Mace on a Roman Catholic brother and a church employee and stole four canvas bags containing last Sunday's collection, the police said.

title: Heavenly Jazz Begins
description: Zoot Sims, the saxophonist, and Clark Terry, the trumpeter, get the fifth season of the ''Heavenly Jazz'' series off the ground Sunday at 5 P.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and 90th Street. Backing them up in the rhythm section will be Roger Kellaway, pianist; Major Holley, bassist, and Allen Dawson, drummer.

title: A TASTE OF THE 50'S IN 'STRANGE BEHAVIOR'
description: ''STRANGE BEHAVIOR'' belongs to two movie species, both of them nearly extinct. It's a 1950's mad-scientist movie, or at least a very fond and painstaking reincarnation of same. And it's a small, original, offbeat film of the sort that is out of fashion.

title: Money Fund Growth Slows
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $1.3 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $164.5 billion, the 20th consecutive weekly increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The rise in assets was significantly below the average weekly increase this year of $2.2 billion.

title: AT SEAPORT, A RESTORATION OF SPIRIT
description: The yellow-pine resin of fresh lumber is spicy in the brackish air. The buzz and whine of saws and drills down out the East River gulls and the Brooklyn Bridge traffic. Sawdust and splinters drift over Pier 15 at the South Street Seaport Museum.

title: Bucks Defeat Knicks In Exhibition, 121-101
description: The Milwaukee Bucks, Central Division champions in the National Basketball Association last season, defeated the Knicks, 121-101, in an exhibition game tonight.

title: PRESIDENT STOPS OFF IN JERSEY TO ASSIST KEAN'S CAMPAIGN
description: President Reagan campaigned here tonight for the Republican candidate for Governor, Thomas H. Kean, saying that "We couldn't ask for a better spokesman for our cause."

title: IC YIELDS AS ALLEGHENY WINS SUNBEAM CONTEST
description: IC Industries yesterday dropped its unwelcome takeover bid for the Sunbeam Corporation, a leading appliance maker, after Allegheny International, a Pittsburgh-based conglomerate, raised its competing offer to approximately $532 million in cash and stock.

title: BEGIN EASES STAND ON AUTONOMY UNIT
description: An aide to Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Israel had agreed to a slight enlargement of the proposed administrative council that would conduct the Palestinians' affairs in the West Bank and Gaza Strip under the Camp David accords.

title: LOUDON WAINWRIGHT 3D TAKES FOLK ROAD TO SATIRE
description: To characterize Loudon Wainwright 3d as a folk singer would be as insufficient as calling Richard Pryor a standup comic. For Mr. Wainwright, who will be appearing at the Bottom Line tonight and tomorrow, is also a pungent social satirist, a great natural clown and a promising rock-and-roller. The quintessential Wainwright performance is an emotional tour de force of writing, singing, acoustic guitar, acting and mugging in which the singer, alternately mischievous and shamefaced, ruthlessly cracks his own preppy exterior.

title: TRIANGLE PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALLAN RYAN, EX-STATE SENATOR
description: Allan A. Ryan, a retired board chairman of the Royal Typewriter Company and a former State Senator from Dutchess County, died Tuesday in New York Hospital. Mr. Ryan, who maintained homes in Palm Beach, Fla., and Manhattan, was 78 years old.

title: KNOGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $196,000 for the qr and $423,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net income

title: PUBLISHING: CYNTHIA FREEMAN'S TRIP TO THE JACKPOT
description: ARBOR HOUSE recently sold Cynthia Freeman's new novel, ''No Time for Tears,'' to Bantam for $1.86 million, a figure it believes to be the year's biggest paperback deal with the possible exception of the sale of John Irving's ''The Hotel New Hampshire.'' Equally significant, however, is the way in which the author's salability has increased with each of her six novels.

title: Giants And Jets Underdogs
description: The Giants and the Jets together have won five games so far, only three fewer than their total for last season. The Jets have a tough opponent at home Sunday in the Buffalo Bills, and the Giants face the Seahawks, who have lost 14 of their last 15 games, in Seattle.

title: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
COOPER TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
15 Are Contaminated In Plutonium Release
description: Fifteen workers at the Los Alamos National Laboratory were contaminated in an accidental release of highly radioactive plutonium, a spokesman for the laboratory said today.

title: A TOP PRIVATE COLLECTION OF OLD MASTERS COMES TO MET
description: THE ''Old Master Paintings From the Collection of Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza'' exhibition, opening tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an event guaranteed to be of exceptional interest to everyone who has a passion for great painting. What pictures these are! Outside the permanent collections of our greatest museums, we seldom see so many paintings of such remarkable quality brought together for our pleasure and instruction. This is the kind of show that many people will want to return to and feast their eyes on again and again before it closes Dec. 6.

title: Tour of Succoth Huts
description: As part of the tradition of the Jewish holiday Succoth, huts outside houses are decorated with fruits and other signs of the harvest. Sunday, at noon, the 92d Street Y will sponsor a tour of two such bowers on the Upper West Side, one at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, the Spanish-Portuguese Synagogue, and the other at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue. The tour costs $6.50, and advance registration is required. For information, call 427-6000, extension 179.

title: energywatch
description: OCT. 9, 1981 Crude oil supplies surged to 375.5 million barrels, as refining output dipped and imports increased.

title: SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE AT HENRY ST.
description: ''Everybody's a dancer! Come on!'' a woman in a purple leotard urged as a small troupe of 4- and 5-year-olds approximated her movements. They swung both arms, first to one side and then the other, fingers wiggling. In a nearby classroom, Stephanie Daley, 8, at her first piano lesson, stood shyly by the open lid of a grand and touched a vibrating string. Downstairs in a theater, Tarzan's Jane hurled dollar bills.

title: STAGE: SHAW'S 'CANDIDA' WITH MISS WOODWARD
description: IF any worthwhile purpose is served by Michael Cristofer's revival of Shaw's ''Candida'' at the Circle in the Square, it's an unintentional one. What this production mainly does is remind us of the glories of Stephen Porter's current ''Misalliance'' at the Roundabout. Mr. Cristofer's ''Candida'' is the sort of misguided affair that makes us fear that American actors are incapable of handling Shaw - and that they might as well not even try. But then we realize how lucky we are, for Mr. Porter's American company is on tap, right now, joyously giving such pessimistic thoughts the lie.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN BANK (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''To a remarkable degree, many nations of the world have now entered into an economic dialogue.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arizona Bank, Phoenix, has elected to its board Douglas J. Wall, a partner in the law firm of Magnum, Wall, Stoops and Warden.

title: TRANSCON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $8.4 million tax credit for the company's investment in operating rights...C-Net loss

title: Bridge: U.S. Women's Team Held Likely to Win World Title
description: In the women's division of the world team championship beginning Tuesday in Port Chester, N.Y., the United States team, with its wealth of experience, is expected to carry too many guns for its rivals from Britain, Australia, Brazil and Venezuela.

title: PRICES ABOVE $10,000 ARE DIMINISHING AMERICANS' DESIRE FOR NEW AUTOS
description: It now costs more than $10,000 to buy a fullsize car such as the Chevrolet Caprice or Ford LTD with the features most buyers prefer, and the advent of the five-figure family car appears to be changing the relationship Americans have with their automobiles.

title: TWILIGHT WORLD OF ZIMBABWE'S PRESS
description: Only a few voices were raised to warn of encroachments on press freedom when the Government engineered the creation of a semi-independent trust early this year to buy out the South African interests that had controlled nearly all the newspapers in the former Rhodesia.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TO PROTECT NEW YORK STATE'S WILDLIFE-OR ITS VICTIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1981
description: International President Reagan was rebuffed again by Congress on his plan to sell radar surveillance planes and other advanced air-combat equipment to Saudi Arabia. The Senate Foreign Relations Commitee disapproved the plan by a vote of 9 to 8, with all eight Democratic members opposed. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Fear of Middle East ''hostilities'' was expressed by the State Department, which warned about a rise in ''tensions and rhetoric'' that it said it was trying ''to defuse.'' (A1:6.)

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF SANTA BARBARA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIGHT OVER NAVY SIGNAL PLAN ABATES
description: They say that this is not the end of the world but that you can see it from here, and everyone seems to prefer it that way.

title: A Genuine Coincidence
description: It's one of those long-arm-of-coincidence stories, but both of the musicians concerned swear it's true. Kyung Wha Chung, the Korean violinist who will be soloist with the New York Philharmonic Oct. 22, 23, 24 and 27, playing the Stravinsky Concerto, was going through a preliminary run-through the other day with Rafael Kubelik, the Czech conductor who is a last-minute replacement for the ailing Andre Previn.

title: BUSH TELLS BRAZIL ATOM BAN IS EASED
description: Vice President Bush announced tonight that the United States had made a ''special-case exemption'' to allow Brazil, which has not signed the international treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, to purchase fuel for its nuclear reactor.

title: CBS AND TURNER DIFFER ON TALKS
description: This is how Ted Turner, the Atlanta cable entrepreneur and owner of the Cable News Network described the encounter in remarks before the Washington Press Club Wednesday evening:

title: ROGERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $397,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: POP JAZZ
description: ''DUKE ELLINGTON didn't follow any one line of religious thought,'' the late composer-bandleader's son, Mercer Ellington, remarked the other day. ''He told me he had the deepest respect for all religions and felt equally at home in any building where God might be.''

title: HARTE-HANKS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Volcker Reiterates His Policy
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said in a speech here today that a relatively tight monetary policy would be necessary for some time to fight inflation.

title: WAITING FOR A LOCAL
description: To the Editor:

title: PRINTRONIX (ORGN) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
4 Plead in Cattle Prod Case
description: Three policemen and a state agent pleaded not guilty before a Federal magistrate today to charges that they tried to force inmates to confess crimes by shocking them with cattle prods. The defendants are Lieut. Doug Acker, Sgt. Thomas Lamar Cruce and Patrolman Stephen D. Crump, all Bessemer policemen, and Robert E. Bassett, an agent of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

title: Notes On People; Ormandy in Hospital
description: The 81-year-old conductor laureate of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, was in stable condition at Pennsylvania Hospital yesterday in Philadelphia, where he was taken for observation after he developed a fever. Mr. Ormandy, who retired as conductor two years ago but remains active with the orchestra, was accompanied to the hospital by his wife, Gretel.

title: EXPOS LEAD 2-1
description: The Montreal Expos moved within one game of winning Canada's first National League pennant tonight when Steve Rogers pitched them to a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. Jerry White capped the Expos' four-run sixth inning with a three-run homer.

title: POOR INVESTMENT POLICY FOR SOCIAL SECURITY CHARGED
description: The chairman of the House Subcommittee on Social Security charged today that the Treasury Department had needlessly deprived the national retirement fund of as much as $1 billion a year in interest income through poor investment management.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: The City; Man Harassed Caroline Kennedy
description: A 35-year-old California man was found guilty yesterday of harassing Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of the late President, John F. Kennedy.

title: MONEY SUPPLY GROWS BY $5.9 BILLION IN WEEK
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a $5.9 billion increase in the nation's money supply for the reporting week ended Oct. 7, a sign that the Fed is at last succeeding in its months-long effort to stimulate faster growth in the money supply.

title: Notes On People; American Diplomat Goes to the Wrong Party
description: In her tenure as chief United States delegate to the United Nations for the Reagan Administration, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick has had her share of diplomatic imbroglios. Wednesday night on the party circuit, Mrs. Kirkpatrick became involved in another one.

title: NEW ENGLAND TOWN RISES UP TO BLOCK A TOXIC WASTE PLANT
description: This small town of apple orchards and maple forests has used its oldest weapon, the town meeting, to keep out the nation's largest toxic waste disposal plant.

title: 3 Philadelphia Homes Fall
description: Three row houses in South Philadelphia collapsed today, apparently because of a gas explosion in the middle home, sending one woman to the hospital, the authorities said.

title: Donald R. Heath, 87; Served as a U.S. Envoy
description: Donald R. Heath, whose 40-year career in the United States Foreign Service and as an Ambassador ended with his retirement in 1961, died on Thursday in Orinda, Calif. He was 87 years old.

title: CENTRAL BANKING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-Net income; shr earnings refllct 15 percent stock divd paid May 1

title: HOOVER UNIVERSAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The City; Innis Is Indicted In Beating Case
description: Roy Innis, executive director of the Congress of Racial Equality, was indicted yesterday on charges of assaulting a man he said was stealing a radio from a car used by the organization.

title: GATEWAY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
That Multiracial Gerrymander
description: Considering its task, New York's City Council has finally made a stronger case for its 1981 redistricting plan. Seeking the Justice Department's approval under the Voting Rights Act, the Council disputes the apparent injury to black and Hispanic voting strength. With sometimes bewildering new census data, it contends that previously uncounted minority members change the picture, permitting a finding that the plan is not discriminatory in purpose or effect.

title: AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHERWIN GAINS
description: The Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings plunged 32.4 percent, despite a 15.9 percent gain in sales, because of adverse currency exchange conditions.

title: Your Money; The 'Assumable' Mortgages Curb
description: IF the Treasury Department has its way, thousands of consumers who now have the right to transfer their old, low-rate mortgages to people who purchase their homes without big rate increases will no longer be able to do so. Such ''assumable'' mortgages have been a major selling point because of high interest rates in the current mortgage market. They are viewed as a big plus by home buyers, who are often as concerned about financing their purchase as they are about the actual house.

title: Bridge: The Kaplan Team Outlasts; Field to Win Von Zedtwitz
description: An event that lasted exactly a year concluded last week when the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship was won in New York City by Betty and Edgar Kaplan, Dick Kahn, Peter Leventritt, Ronald Blau and Martin Ginsberg.

title: Sports People; The Weight Factor
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday signed their third baseman, Bill Madlock, to a six-year contract that includes an unusual clause requiring him to keep his weight down. Without mentioning any figures, Harding Peterson, the club's executive vice president, said: ''There's a weight he'll report to spring training at, a weight he'll be at when he leaves spring training and a weight he will maintain throughout the season every year.''

title: MERCK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign exchange losses of 27,600,000 for the qr and $55,800,000 for the 9 mos; third qr earnings benefited by 11 cents a shr from a lower effective tax rate reflecting the impact of recent changes in the British tax law

title: SOUTHERN BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SKIRMISH IS RE-ENACTED AT YORKTOWN
description: Muzzle-loading muskets and cannon clattered and smoked as Colonial-uniformed troops with fixed bayonets led a wild charge against a 200-year-old earthen fortress here this afternoon.

title: BE BOLD, MR. BEGIN
description: There is only one man who, with some help from the United States, could lead the Middle East to peace: Prime Minister Menachem Begin. He stands alone as the only recognizable leader in the Middle East who has been visibly and centrally involved in the start-and-stop quest for a settlement in Sinai, Gaza, and on the West Bank.

title: Around the World; U.N. Group Proclaims World Food Day
description: The first World Food Day at the Rome headquarters of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization was opened today by former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany, who said that more than half a billion people were suffering from hunger and malnutrition

title: Sports People; Football-Gear Suit
description: William Crumby, who as a Memphis State football player suffered a paralyzing spinal injury in a 1977 game, has filed a $15 million damage suit, with the major defendant Riddell, a Chicago-based equipment concern.

title: De Gustibus; TIME AND PLACE CAN DECIDE FLAVOR
description: Certain foods, like certain wines, do not travel well either in time or in space. Once removed from a given season or locale, they lose their appeal no matter how beguiling they may have seemed in their original setting. This is as often true of simple products such as olive oil, salami and cheese as it is of prepared specialties such as pissaladiere, pasta and pumpkin pie.

title: ARBORETUM TO CELEBRATE 10 YEARS OF ACHIEVEMENT
description: On a sunny day in August 1971, Dr. Howard Irwin, then head of the New York Botanical Garden, and two members of his staff strode purposefully through wooded sections and fields of Queen Anne's lace on the Mary Flagler Cary estate in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: STRUTHERS WELLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Pre-tax income includes foreign currency losses of $177,747 for the third qr and $667,551 for the 9 mos

AMERICAN MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Trolio Paces Fordham
description: Art Trolio scored three touchdowns and rushed for 211 yards in 29 carries tonight to lead Fordham to a 28-14 victory over Marist College.

title: Alpena, Mich., Public Schools Are Closed for Lack of Funds
description: The Alpena school system shut its doors to 6,800 pupils today in the the state's first public school closing over money since the Depression.

title: FARM INTERESTS SEEK REASONS FOR SURPRISING DEFEAT
description: Members of the House of Representatives from sugar-@ and peanut-producing states, some of them still shocked at what happened to their favorite commodity programs yesterday, were searching today for ways to revive them.

title: TORIES CHEER FIRM THATCHER SPEECH
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher brought the Conservative Party's quarrelsome conference to a rousing conclusion today with a resolute rejection of what she called ''false hopes and spurious remedies'' for economic difficulties.

title: War, Peace and General Dayan
description: ''I set out to be a farmer,'' Moshe Dayan once said, ''and I think I made quite a good farmer. Yet I have spent most of my adult life as a soldier, under arms.''

title: SAKE-DRINKING SLIPS IN JAPAN
description: Where matters of the pocketbook are concerned, the Japanese are said to be fiercely nationalistic. Yet a consumption trend is evident here that has the whiff of heresy to it.

title: EGYPT'S ARMY EXPECTED TO RETAIN ITS SPECIAL ROLE
description: The assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt last week during an army parade was obviously a black mark against that brance of the service, but military analysts here say they believe that the army's special status in Egypt will not change as a consequence.

title: RURAL VOTE IN THE GREEK ELECTION EXPECTED TO BE CRUCIAL AND CLOSE
description: The parliamentary elections on Sunday are generally expected to be decided in the traditionally conservative countryside. A tour of this northwestern farming region indicates that the race may be close.

title: 'Nickleby' Tickets at $60 for Students
description: The producers of the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of ''Nicholas Nickleby,'' who had said there would be no discounted tickets for the play, disclosed yesterday that they were trying to sell cut-rate tickets on a group basis to students in the New York area. Tickets for the eight-and-a-half-hour play cost $100 for all seats - the highest in Broadway history -are being offered to students for $60.

...AND BEYOND

title: CORRECTION
description: In some copies of SportsMonday this week, the results of the Ramapo Kennel Club dog show at Mahwah, N.J., listed the third-place finisher in the toy group incorrectly. Third place went to Ch. Eric's Peter Munchkin, a 17-month-old smooth chihuahua owned by Annette Mellinger.

title: A NEW BOOK REBUTS CRIES OF 'TREASON'
description: Was P.G. Wodehouse, the popular novelist, musical comedy writer and humorist who created Bertie Wooster and Jeeves, the gentleman's gentleman, guilty of treason because of his wartime broadcasts from Berlin?

title: TRAINER IS CHARGED WITH HORSE NEGLECT
description: David Jacobson, a horse trainer based at Aqueduct, has been charged with failing to provide food and medical attention to a thoroughred that had to be destroyed last month.

title: Observer; PLAYING WITH FIRE
description: I see in the paper that conservatives with plenty of money are starting to finance collegiate newspapers in order to promote conservatism. I wish they had done it 30 years ago.

title: Boeing Lobbying For Awacs Sale
description: The Boeing Company is lobbying hard in support of the proposed sale of five Awacs radar planes to Saudi Arabia. Mailgrams from the company to its suppliers urge them to write to their Congressmen and say Boeing will stop producing Awacs craft if the sale does not go through.

title: UNITED STATES ANTIMONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KORCHNOI WINS, CUTTING KARPOV LEAD TO 2 POINTS
description: Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, resigned the sixth game of his title match with Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland this afternoon an hour before play was to resume.

title: EGYPT'S PRESIDENT IS SAID TO INITIATE A NEW CRACKDOWN
description: President Hosni Mubarak, moving swiftly to consolidate his rule, ordered a nationwide roundup of Moslem fundamentalists today, according to Egyptian sources.

title: OPERA: HOUSTON DIGS UP ROSSINI 'DONNA DEL LAGO'
description: Deeper, ever deeper we go into the boneyard of Italian operatic history. Most of the lesser works of Verdi and Donizetti having been brought to the surface in recent years, it is apparently the time now to excavate the ''serious'' works of Rossini. One of the leading centers of the Rossini revival, the Houston Grand Opera, dug up ''La Donna del Lago'' to open its 27th season last night, making use of a new critical edition of the score edited by H. Colin Slim and a production that was built in cooperation with the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden.

description: The winner of the first National Humanitarian Gold Medal of the National Conference of Christians and Jews is Leo Jaffe, chairman emeritus of Columbia Pictures Industries.

title: The Region; No Bail to Suspect In Stouffer's Fire
description: Justice Isaac Rubin of State Supreme Court denied bail for Luis Marin, who is accused of setting the fire that killed 26 persons last December at the Stouffer's Inn in Harrison, N.Y.

A Stitch in Time at Labor
description: Labor Secretary Donovan has begun to learn that nothing in Washington is ever as simple as it seems. He was not as wise in May, in his first clumsy attempt to resolve the case of the Vermont home knitters.

title: Patents; Thermal Storage Tanks For Daytime Cooling
description: A thermal storage system patented this week by Calvin D.MacCracken, president of Calmac Manufacturing Corporation, Englewood, N.J., is described as making it possible for the first time for ice to be frozen solid in a tank without damaging the tank.

title: PRINCTON U. OFFICIAL ACCUSED OF BILKING SCHOOL OF $59,000
description: The director of corporate relations for Princeton University has been dismissed and accused of misappropriating more than $59,000 in university funds, university officials said today.

description: Even though his father's distinctive voice, extolling quality tobaccos, was known to millions of American radio listeners, Mac Burnette grew up with every intention of steering clear of the tobacco business, he said in New York yesterday.

title: TOUR SHOWS HOW TRIMS WOULD HURT
description: Standing in a roomful of elderly persons yesterday during a visit by New York State legislators and socialservice advocates to the Woodstock Hotel, 79-year-old Leona Patterson succinctly summed up what she felt was the initial impact of Federal budget cuts on the aged and other groups.

description: A team of 148 police officers specially trained to combat street hoodlums conducted a series of predawn raids today, arresting 16 former convicts and suspected gang members.

description: Senate Republican leaders told White House officials today that Congress would reject most of the new round of budget cuts proposed by President Reagan for this fiscal year.

description: A Federal judge ruled against the LTV Corporation today in the second of two cases arising from the Texas conglomerate's $450 million bid to take control of the Grumman Corporation.

title: Wimbledon Switches To Sunday Men's Final
description: In a break with tradition, Wimbledon will hold the men's singles final of its tennis tournament on a Sunday next year, officials said today.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. Itzhak Perlman resides in the building on Riverside Drive where Babe Ruth once lived. 2. He is Sol M. Linowitz who, as President Carter's special envoy to the Middle East, a year ago proposed principles for Palestinian self-rule. Prime Minister Begin reportedly said he would announce Israel's acceptance of those principles next week.

title: The Whys and Wines of Spain
description: President Reagan chose the right moment and the right words to make plain America's support for Spain's troubled democracy. It was momentarily in doubt when Secretary Haig minimized the attempted coup in Madrid last February as an internal matter. Mr. Haig soon made amends, and any remaining doubts should finally be dispelled by Mr. Reagan's welcome to Juan Carlos, who risked his crown to defend Spain's reborn Parliament.

title: Nixon Is Expected to Present A Report on His Mideast Trip
description: White House officials said today that they expected former President Richard M. Nixon to send a written report on his tour of four Middle Eastern and North African nations.

title: Around the Nation; Bohemian Club Ordered To Begin Hiring Women
description: The all-male Bohemian Club, which counts President Reagan and many of the nation's elite among its members, discriminates illegally by employing only men at its rural retreat and must begin hiring women, a state commission has ruled.

title: Notes On People; Bella Abzug Barred From Speaking at Church Hall

title: WASHINGTON STATE REELING AS BOTH ITS TAX REVENUES AND FEDERAL AID DROP
description: The government of Washington State has suddenly begun to experience a severe revenue shortage. Gov. John Spellman, a moderate Republican, wants to raise taxes to meet the deficit but is opposed by conservative Republicans who control the Legislature and say they are determined to do for the state what President Reagan has been doing nationally: cut public services sharply.

title: SOFT SELL LURED ROGAN TO YALE
description: Carmen Cozza, Yale's head coach, began the wooing of John Rogan the night before Thanksgiving in 1977. Yale had ended its season the previous Saturday with a victory over Harvard to gain the Ivy League championship. Cozza was hoping to win over Rogan, the quarterback star of the Chaminade High School football team in Mineola, L.I., and a brother of Kevin Rogan, a quarterback for Cozza at Yale who graduated in 1974.

title: BUSINESS SAYS PRODUCT RECALL MAKES SENSE
description: Recalling a defective product may be embarrassing and costly for a company, but it has been found to make good business sense and to protect consumers from products that are potentially harmful.

title: KOPPERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bethlehem Steel
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it will shut down production at one of its two Burns Harbor steel plate mills on Monday, idling about 235 workers.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY TAXES TO RISE
description: The earnings limit for Social Security taxes, the point at which money is no longer taken out of the worker's paycheck for the retirement fund, will rise to $32,400 in 1982, the Social Security Administration said today.

title: FOR WODEHOUSE, A CENTENARY SOIREE
description: Greeting visitors from her chair in the marbled lobby of the Pierpont Morgan Library the other night, 96-year-old Lady Wodehouse might almost have been one of the nice rich aunts out of a novel by her late husband.

description: B-Including $169,000 income from sale of the company's protective packaging business

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1981
description: International Arrests of Moslem extremists in an extended Government crackdown was reported in Egypt. Egyptian sources said President Hosni Mubarak, in a move to consolidate his rule, ordered a nationwide roundup of fundamentalists. The Government would neither confirm nor deny reports that the police had arrested hundreds or even thousands of Moslem militants suspected of involvement in demonstrations and violence against the regime. (Page 1, Column 6.) Moshe Dayan died of a heart attack in Tel Aviv. The 66-year-old Israeli military leader and statesman was a former Chief of Staff, Defense Minister and Foreign Minister. He was a key architect of Israel's victories in the 1967 and 1973 wars as well as the Camp David accords that led to the peace treaty with Egypt. (1:4.)

title: HAYAKAWA'S DIVISIVE THOUGHTS ON EDUCATION

description: The economic and legal impact of the proposed $2.5 billion acquisition of the Santa Fe International Corporation by the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation will be explored by a Congressional committee next week.

title: NAPLES FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
Sawmill Unemployment
description: For the second consecutive week, more than half of the West's sawmill workers were unemployed or working short shifts last week, industry figures showed, while 39 more mills were closed down. The Western Wood Products Association reported yesterday that 52,175, or 51 percent, of the 102,000 sawmill employees in the Western lumber industry were out of work or on curtailed shifts during the week ending Oct. 10. During the previous week, 54,900, or 54 percent, were unemployed or on short hours.

title: A.M.C. NARROWS LOSSES
description: The American Motors Corporation today reported a $16.8 million net loss for the third quarter, a sharp reduction of the loss of $84.9 million a year earlier.

title: Briefing
description: S URPRISE! As the Republican Administration seeks an additional $2 billion reduction in defense spending, the majority of the cuts seem to be coming from - lo and behold - Democratic districts. According to a bipartisan internal report circulating in the Capitol, prepared by House military analysts and dealing specifically with the proposed cuts in research and development as well as procurement, it has worked out that the reductions are falling most heavily in the West, Middle West and Northeast. On Democrats.

title: SOUTHERN PACIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NETTLES, JACKSON REGRET SCUFFLING
description: Before the Yankees' chartered flight crossed the Rocky Mountains tonight on the way from Oakland, Calif., to Newark, Reggie Jackson and Graig Nettles were laughing together in the back row of the airplane and had put their scuffle behind them.

title: Around the World; Austrian Leader Cancels Trip to Talks in Mexico
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky has canceled plans to attend the conference of industrialized and developing nations at Cancun, Mexico, his private secretary announced tonight.

EDUARDO LE-RIVEREND
description: Eduardo Le-Riverend, a former Cuban Supreme Court Justice and law professor whose students included Fidel Castro, died Wednesday after a long illness.

title: 'Einstein and Polar Bear' Postponed to Oct. 29
description: The opening of ''Einstein and the Polar Bear'' by Tom Griffin at the Cort Theater has been postponed for one week, from next Thursday to Oct. 29. A search continues for a replacement for the leading lady, Barbara Hershey, who left the cast. Her understudy, Beth McDonald, who has been playing the role since the first preview Monday, will continue during the search.

title: Major Battle Reported In the Western Sahara
description: Fierce fighting was going on today between guerrillas and Moroccan forces in the Western Sahara some 650 miles southeast of Rabat, according to reports reaching here.

title: 3 AIRLINES RESCIND FARE CUTS
description: In a surprise reversal, United Airlines said yesterday that it would cancel most of the fare cuts that it had announced last week for its transcontinental routes - cuts that had intensified a fare war among domestic airlines.

title: No Headline

title: A SAMPLER OF COMMENTS BY DAYAN
description: On Battle ''When I go into battle, I am 100 percent sure I will win and come out safely. I believe, with my luck and skill, that I'll manage between the bullets and they will not get hold of me. You have to feel that way or you'll never come out of it.''

PARIBAS IS SAID TO AGREE TO HOLD ON TO ITS ASSETS
description: Finance Minister Jacques Delors said today that the directors of Compagnie Financiere de Paris et des Pays-Bas, the leading French investment bank scheduled for nationalization, had agreed to oppose a foreign bid for the bank's asset-rich Geneva subsidiary. The bid was intended to protect the bank from the nationalization.

title: BL Workers Vote Nov. 2 Walkout
description: Nearly 60,000 workers at BL Ltd., the former British Leyland, voted by a margin of 2 to 1 to walk off the job Nov. 2, defying threats by Sir Michael Edwardes, BL chairman, to close the ailing state-financed car company if the strike goes ahead.

title: About New York; AT BARNARD, TEDDY BEARS IN THE DEANERY; by Anna Quinlen
description: It may be that a little bit of social history was made yesterday at Barnard College, and Anne Victoria Shutkin made it. Anne Victoria is a baby, something less than a complete armful of black hair and embroidered cotton and diapers and pink body. Her mother is Ellen V. Futter, who is, at age 32, the youngest president of a major college in the United States.

title: A ROCKY START AT JERSEY ZINC
description: William E. Flaherty is a man who has to ignore omens. Two years ago the then executive vice president at Gulf and Western Industries decided to organize a management group to buy the conglomerate's New Jersey Zinc subsidiary.

title: MSI DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gain from discontinued operations of $130,000

title: SALVADORANS CALLED READY TO TALK
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, who made an unannounced trip to El Salvador this week, said today that he had been told by both sides in the Salvadoran conflict that they would be willing to begin an ''informal dialogue'' without preconditions.

title: UNITED TELEVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Yanks Showing Off in October
description: The Yankees are ready for the World Series, as ready as they have been for any World Series in the nine-year tenure of George Steinbrenner, whose moves as owner have restored them to the championship status they once held perennially.

title: Around the Nation; 3 Police Officers Charged In Rape Suspect's Death
description: Three police officers were arrested today on charges of homicide by reckless conduct in the death of Ernest R. Lacy, a young man who died in their custody.

title: Eugene Eisenmann,75, A Noted Ornithologist
description: Eugene Eisenmann, a leading ornithologist and a research associate in the department of ornithology at the American Museum of Natural History since 1957, was found dead of a heart attack yesterday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 75 years old.

title: Around the World; Dutch Cabinet Resigns Over Economic Policy
description: The coalition Government of the Netherlands resigned today after five weeks in office because its center and leftist ministers failed to reach agreement on economic policy, Prime Minister Andries van Agt said.

title: COLDWELL BANKER & CO reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
RATE FEARS SENDS DOW DOWN 4.57
description: Stock prices retreated moderately yesterday in slower trading, mainly because of investors' concern that the weekly money supply figures, which were announced by the Federal Reserve after the close, would show a huge increase.

title: Around the Nation
description: By United Press International More than 7 inches of driving rain forced about 500 Texans, including the residents of a nursing home in the city of Sherman, to evacuate their homes yesterday and swept two Oklahoma oilfield workers to their deaths.

title: SUDAN'S LEADER SAID TO OVERSTATE DANGER OF AN INVASION BY LIBYANS
description: Several European diplomats here say they believe that President Gaafar al-Nimeiry has been deliberately exaggerating the dangers of an invasion by Libyan forces. His purpose, they speculate, has been to win a commitment of accelerated weapons deliveries from the United States and to deflect attention from the economic crisis confronting his nation.

title: US HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GIMBEL GIFTS FROM BANK
description: In a new wrinkle to the practice among banks of gift-giving to attract deposits, Chemical Bank said yesterday that it would give Gimbels gift certificates to those who make large deposits.

title: The Region; Judge Orders Jail To Halt Crowding
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered the Westchester County Jail to stop housing two inmates in small single-occupancy cells, in which one prisoner must sleep on a mattress on the floor.

title: Sports People; Theo Bell Arrested
description: Theo Bell, wide receiver for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, was arrested and charged with reckless and impaired driving near Ocala, Fla.

title: Couples, on a 133, Leads By 1 in Pensacola Open
description: Fred Couples, a rookie, took the lead with a 133 total after the second round of the Pensacola Open today, and Tom Watson shot a 76 for a 140 total in his last chance to repeat as professional golf's Player of the Year and leading money winner.

title: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: * Bird & Son Inc., citing declining demand, said that it will permanently close its Perth Amboy, N.J., roofing plant Oct. 30.

title: FURTHER RETRENCHMENT IS SCHEDULED BY A.&P.
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company announced yesterday that it planned to close or sell unprofitable stores and manufacturing plants and would finance the ensuing write-off by drawing $200 million from an overfunded pension plan.

description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of City National Bank & Trust Co of Salem NJ on a pooling of interests basis

2 SEEK TO KEEP MX PLAN ALIVE
description: The chairmen of the Senate and House Armed Services Committees, both of whom have criticized President Reagan's decision to deploy new MX intercontinental missiles in hardened existing silos, have asked the Defense Department to complete environmental studies on a basing plan that the White House rejected.

title: S.E.C. Bars Jersey Broker
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged that the former manager of a brokerage house defrauded clients of almost $400,000.

title: RANGERS REACQUIRE HICKEY
description: In a move designed to invigorate a sluggish offense, the Rangers yesterday re-acquired Pat Hickey, a left wing who once scored 40 goals in a season for the club.

title: NORTHEAST OF EDEN: 11 TALES OF SERPENTS
description: 1. I don't know very much about snakes, just that I grew up far enough north in North America that there were no venomous or constricting snakes around, and that if you saw a snake there was no good reason to be afraid. Still, it can't be denied that to most people, snakes are startling -you see a stick but then you see it's a snake. It was startling in the Bible and it's startling on your lawn.

title: CORNELIUS SHIELDS, BANKER, 86, IS DEAD
description: Cornelius Shields, founder of an investment banking firm and a prominent yachtsman, died Thursday night at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. Mr. Shields, who lived in New Rochelle, had been ill with heart trouble for the last year. He was 86 years old.

title: Around the World; Turkey's Military Rulers Dissolve Political Parties
description: Turkey's military rulers today ordered the dissolution of all political parties and the confiscation of their property.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT OFF BY 0.8%
description: The nation's industrial production fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in September, another signal of the continued slowdown of the economy.

title: GEORGIA SOTHERN, 1940'S STRIPTEASER AND CABARET STAR
description: Georgia Sothern, a vivacious stripteaser and nightclub entertainer who was billed as ''The Dynamic Georgia Sothern'' in the 1940's, died of cancer at Memorial Hospital on Wednesday.

title: Hitachi Unit Is Bias Target
description: The State of California today accused a Japanese-controlled color television manufacturer situated in a predominantly black area of discriminating against non-Asians when it hires workers.

title: ARGUING AGAINST SOCIAL SECURITY CUTS
description: The vast majority of the 36 million Americans receiving Social Security checks have never heard of him, but Robert M. Ball is probably more responsible than any other individual for persuading Congress to ignore President Reagan and make only minor adjustments in the retirement system.

title: LANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Decision Goes To Escalera
description: Alfredo Escalera, fighting for the first time in two years, won a 10-round unanimous decision over Ruby Ortiz at Felt Forum last night. Escalera, the former World Boxing Council junior lightweight champion, dominated the bout.

title: Iona Routs St. Peter's
description: Rich Caprio threw an 84-yard touchdown pass to Marty Clancy and rushed 44 yards for another score to help Iona trounce St. Peter's, 41-15, tonight at Memorial Field.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Articles on Thursday and yesterday about the proposed sale of Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia erroneously re- ported the date of a law permitting a President to make a foreign military sale without Congressional approval if the sale is declared ''important to the security interests of the United States.'' The law was passed in 1980.

description: Wholesalers of Texaco gasoline filed suit to block the imposition of a proposed 3 percent surcharge on retail credit card sales of Texaco gasoline starting Nov. 1.

The Region; Forced Seminars For L.I. Vandals
description: Beginning next month, any youth convicted of criminal mischief and vandalism in Nassau County will have to attend a seminar about how their actions hurt the community, Police Commissioner Samuel Rozzi announced.

A Holding Pattern At Jets' Workout
description: As part of their preparation for Sunday's game against the Buffalo Bills, the Jets yanked on Abdul Salaam's face mask today.

description: WASHINGTON A NEW magnetic device, patented this week for the International Business Machines corporation, offers a substantial increase in the volume of information stored for use in a computer. A spokesman said the invention, already used in company products, provides a major improvement in performance.

GRAND PRIX RACING IN LAS VEGAS DEBUT
description: Las Vegas, which has enjoyed such distractions as championship prize fights and tennis matches, will have something new tomorrow to challenge the dice tables and slot machines for attention. It is a Grand Prix auto race, the final one of the season, the race that will determine the world championship of drivers.

title: Air Force Base to Close
description: Air Force support units at the Duluth International Airport will be phased out in 1982, the Air Force has announced. The base closing, combined with deactivation of an air defense computer operation, will result in the elimination of about 1,375 jobs, the Air Force said.

title: METHANE GAS KILLS 42 IN JAPAN MINE
description: Forty-two people were killed and 51 others were missing and feared dead after methane gas seeped into a coal mine yesterday near Sapporo, officials said today.

title: REAGAN, IN SHIFT, TO DELAY RISE ON PASSBOOK SAVINGS
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan announced today that he wanted Federal regulators to defer a scheduled increase in the maximum interest rate paid to 40 million Americans with passbook savings accounts. He acted under pressure from the nation's savings banks and savings and loan associations.

title: LOUIS FAIRCHILD, 80, PUBLISHING COMPANY HEAD
description: Louis W. Fairchild, a former chief operating officer of Fairchild Publications, died yesterday at Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N.H., after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

NORTHWEST NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANCOKLAHOMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Watt Allies Assail
description: Sierra Club

title: MERCANTILE BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
FRANKLIN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
ONE-MAN GRAND JURY NAMED IN NORWALK WATER-PANEL CASE
description: A one-man grand jury was appointed today to investigate Norwalk's Second District Water Commission. An inquiry into the South Norwalk Electric Works, the other half of Norwalk's Second Taxing District, has led to nine arrests and four convictions for misuse of funds.

title: No-Smoking Seat Rule For Airlines Revised
description: Starting today, airline passengers who arrive for their flights later than the normal check-in time could no longer be guaranteed a seat in the no-smoking section.

title: David C. Gordon, Headmaster Of a School in Garrison, N.Y.
description: David Cleaveland Gordon, headmaster emeritus of the Malcolm Gordon School in Garrison, N.Y., died Wednesday in his home at the school after a long illness.

title: HELPED WRITE AVIATION LAWS
description: Fred Dow Fagg Jr., a former president of the University of Southern California and director of the United States Bureau of Air Commerce, died Wednesday of cancer at the Willamette View Convalescent Center in Portland, Ore. He was 85 years old.

title: FOR HAITIAN CHILDREN, A BITTERSWEET NEW LIFE
description: Three months ago, Eugenie L. was pressed to the rail of a leaky sailboat in the Florida Straits, straining for her first sight of the United States after her boat's clandestine departure from Haiti and a month at sea.

title: Ali's Bout With Berbick Rescheduled for Dec. 11
description: The date for the 10-round bout against Trevor Berbick in which Muhammad Ali will make a comeback was changed yesterday from Saturday, Dec. 5 to Friday, Dec. 11. The change was made to take advantage of better closed-circuit television opportunities on the 11th.

title: U.S. RIGHTS PANEL ASKS CURB ON POLICE USE OF DEADLY FORCE
description: More restrictive state and municipal laws on the use of deadly force by police officers are necessary to protect the civil rights of citizens, especially members of minority groups, the United States Commission on Civil Rights said today.

title: FIRST ATLANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'82 Trade Parley Asked
description: Eighteen major trading nations today called on governments to hold a ministerial-level world conference in November 1982 to find ways to improve the flow of international commerce.

title: HERO OF WAR, ARCHITECT OF PEACE
description: Moshe Dayan, the Israeli soldier-statesman, died of a heart ailment today in Tel Aviv's Sheba Medical Center. He was 66 years old.

title: A LOOK AT THE OTHER SOUTH BRONX...
description: To the Editor:

title: IN GALICIA, A BIG TEST FOR SPAIN'S FRAGILE DEMOCRACY
description: A major electoral test for Spain's fragile democracy is about to take place in Galicia, whose wary people have expressed their sentiments about politics and politicians over the last few years by not voting.

title: Around the Nation; A.C.L.U. Seeking Curb On Data for Draft Rolls
description: A lawyer today asked a Federal appeals court to prohibit the Selective Service System from requiring draft registrants to disclose their Social Security numbers.

title: DANCE: KENNETH RINKER
description: Taking dances apart and putting them together is a favorite device of current experimental choreographers, and Kenneth Rinker shines brightly in this area - as just seen in two movement-filled 90-minute pieces.

title: Chicago Visa Cost
description: First National Bank of Chicago said it would raise its finance charge on Visa accounts to an annual rate of 19.8 percent, from 18 percent, or to 1.85 percent, from 1.5 percent, on a monthly basis. The bank noted that a bill lifting usury ceilings in Illinois was enacted last month and said the high cost of funds and increasing operating expenses had resulted in losses for most bank credit card programs. First National, which has about 1.8 million Visa accounts, said the increase would take effect Dec. 18 in 46 states and next March in Iowa, Texas, New Jersey and Wyoming.

title: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings and shrs outstndg for 1980 reflect a 3-for-2 split paid Sept 1980

title: NEW YORK MARATHON OFFERS PRIZE MONEY, TOP COACHES REPORT
description: Prize money again will be offered under the table to the leading finishers in this year's New York City Marathon, according to coaches of many of the top runners.

title: NEVADA NATIONAL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New York; WHY PUNISH THE KIDS?
description: This city's public school system, under Chancellor Frank Macchiarola, has directed fresh energy and resources at the critical problem of trying to hang onto dropout-prone children - to keep them from slipping out of their classrooms into an aimless and sometimes criminal existence on the streets. And yet, at this moment, that same system has taken the apparently contradictory step of shutting nearly 18,000 children out of their schools because they failed to comply with a new and stricter state health law on immunizations.

title: JANET MURROW FETED FOR DEVOTION TO ART
description: ''I haven't been to New York for about six months,'' Janet Brewster Murrow was saying the other day. ''My original plan when I moved to Massachusetts was to spend one week out of every month in New York. But it comes down to less and less.''

title: BEST-SELLING AUTHOR, 13, THANKS RUBIK'S CUBE
description: Patrick Bossert, who never needs more than 90 seconds to solve the Rubik's Cube puzzle, no matter how messed up it is, has become a best-selling author at the ripe old age of 13.

title: The City; City Tax Revenue Up 9.2 Percent
description: New York City's tax revenue from July to September - the first three months of fiscal 1982 - rose 9.2 percent compared with the same period last year, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday. The Koch administration had forecast a 5.8 percent increase In its financial plan for all of fiscal 1982.

title: MEDIA GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MIDLAND BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A LUNCHEON HONORS EAMES AND HIS WORK
description: Friends and colleagues of the late Charles Eames gathered at a luncheon at the Library of Congress today to reminisce about Charles Eames, the designer; Charles Eames, the photographer and cinematographer, and Charles Eames, the man.

title: SERIES TICKETS DRAW THRONG TO THE BRONX
description: The morning after their Yankees won the American League championship, thousands of fans nearly ringed Yankee Stadium seeking tickets for the World Series.

title: Required Reading
description: The New Wizards

title: ELIAS CANETTI'S U.S. PUBLISHERS JUBILANT OVER NOBEL PRIZE
description: When a friend told Helene Atwan Thursday morning that the 1981 Nobel Prize for Literature had been won ''by somebody nobody ever heard of,'' she asked the writer's name. Told it was Elias Canetti, a surprised Mrs. Atwan, publicity director of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, exclaimed, ''That's our author.''

title: LOMAS NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PENNSYLVANIANS HOPING TO BENEFIT IN LEGISLATOR'S SHIFT TO G.O.P.
description: Anger and pride, worry and hope simmered among the steelworkers as they poured out through the main gate of the sprawling Jones & Laughlin plant here, rushed past the Village Restaurant toward parking lots or clustered at a bus stop on a dusty corner under a highway overpass.

MASSMUTUAL CORPORATE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1981; The Economy
description: Deferral of a half-point increase in interest rates on passbook savings accounts was proposed by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. His announcement was viewed as certain to delay the increase in the maximum rate that had been scheduled to go into effect Nov.1. Mr. Regan did not say how long the delay would be. The Secretary, who had initially supported the higher rate, said his ''change of mind'' followed opposition from savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks. (Page 1.)

title: A PARTING SHOT
description: knew the ball was gone as soon as I hit it. My swing was easy and level; I could barely feel the collision of Hillerich and Bradsby ash and Clincher cowhide. Letting the bat drop noiselessly in the dust, I followed the ball's high arcing flight and smiled.

title: ZIONS UTAH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: the per shr figures reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug 14

title: The Region
description: A state trooper was injured when a bomb exploded as he started his cruiser at the state police substation in this Wayne County community, the police said.

title: Patents; A Radioactive Tracer For Probing Arteries
description: A cardiac probe with the trademark name The Nuclear Stethoscope was patented this week for Bios Inc., Valhalla, N.Y., which develops and manufactures medical equipment. Robert I. Gray, president, says he believes the invention is making a profound contribution to diagnosis of coronary artery disease, as demonstrated at various research centers.

title: FIRST AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Analysis
description: When Congress was considering President Reagan's proposed budget reductions, one New York State official after another declared that the state could not assume the cost of programs scaled down or eliminated by Federal actions.

title: EVANS PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $2.5 million gain from a change in account procedur

title: Sports People; Torre a Candidate
description: Ballard Smith, president of the San Diego Padres, said yesterday that Joe Torre, recently released as manager by the Mets, was among the candidates being considered to replace Frank Howard, whom the Padres dropped as manager this week. Others spoken to are Doug Rader, who managed the Padres' farm club in Hawaii the last two seasons; Dick Williams, dropped last month by Montreal, and Danny Ozark, former Philadelphia manager and now a coach with Los Angeles.

title: Consumer Saturday; DIAMOND PRICES: 2 PRICES
description: T HE diamond market may be in a slump, with prices of investmentquality stones down to about half what they were early last year, but that doesn't mean that the person shopping for an engagement ring or a pair of stud earrings is paying any less. That's because there are two markets in diamonds: one for investment (internally flawless stones weighing one carat or more) and one for jewelry (99 percent of the world volume).

title: Patents; Checking Cow Embryos, By an Analysis of Milk
description: A method by which dairymen can determine through its milk whether a cow is carrying a healthy embryo is disclosed in patent 4,294,922, obtained this week by Robert B. Heap of Cambridge, England, for the National Research Development Corporation, London.

title: WALTER, JIM, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
POLAND SAYS UNION SEEKS 'DICTATORSHIP'
description: The Government accused the Solidarity union tonight of trying to establish a ''totalitarian dictatorship'' and the Communist Party leader, Stanislaw Kania, proposed a suspension of strikes through the winter.

Quotation of the Day
description: ''Israel is a democracy, and anyone should be able to hear whatever he wants. Those who don't want to listen can leave the concert hall.'' - Zubin Mehta, on the music of Richard Wagner. (13:2.)

Sports of The Times; Dodgers' durable Quartet
description: THEY came from four sections of the country: a husky defensive back from Michigan State; a short outfielder from Rhode Island; a waddling third baseman from Washington and a quiet outfielder from Kansas.

title: HOSPITAL TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Paul Berthiaume Dies; Led Information Bank
description: Paul Berthiaume, president of the New York Times Information Bank, died of a heart attack yesterday in Marlboro (Mass.) Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: NORTHROP WINS STEALTH BOMBER CONTRACT
description: The Air Force has selected the Northrop Corporation as the prime contractor for initial development of the Stealth bomber, the company said today.

title: OREGON METALLURGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1980 shr earnings adjusted to reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid in Feb 1981

title: Top NATO Aide Tells Alliance Not to Delay on U.S. Missiles
description: The Secretary General of NATO, Joseph M.A.H. Luns, warned alliance nations today against being tempted to delay deployment of new American missiles in Europe until the outcome of scheduled United States-Soviet arms talks was known.

title: LED GENERAL FOODS
description: Arthur E. Larkin, a former president of the General Foods Corporation, died Wednesday at his home in Pauma Valley, Calif. He was 64 years old.

title: Montclair Streak at 6
description: Montclair State extended its undefeated streak to six games tonight with a 23-10 victory over William Paterson College. Bob Vannoy sparked Montclair with 170 yards in 32 carries, including touchdown runs of 19 and 2 yards.

title: PLAYING OF WAGNER IN ISRAEL PROVOKES DISTURBANCE
description: Disturbances broke out last night in the Mann Auditorium as Zubin Mehta resolutely led the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra in music by Richard Wagner, ending a four-decade boycott of the composer, whose works had been banned by the orchestra since 1939 because he was an anti-Semite and because the Nazis had glorified his music. Concertgoers argued heatedly, a security guard wrestled on the auditorium floor with a protester and three musicians left their places by prearrangement.

title: Ayako Kishikawa Gives Violin Recital
description: There were moments of strong feeling in Ayako Kishikawa's performance of Bach's Partita No. 2 in D minor in her debut Oct. 10 at Carnegie Recital Hall. But they were not woven into a dramatic whole.

title: Headliners; And Proud of It
description: If former President Richard M. Nixon ever hungers for praise, he need but call his niece, Lawrene Nixon Anfinson. ''Watergate aside, I think Uncle Dick did some wonderful things for the world,'' she said last week.

title: COPPOLA'S BATON GUIDING 'NAPOLEON'
description: AFTER its New York premiere at Radio City Music Hall in January, ''Napoleon'' was hailed by Vincent Canby, The New York Times critic, as ''the film event of the year.'' Last month's screenings in Rome turned into street spectacles: thousands of people were perched in trees and standing on hilltops alongside the Coliseum, where the film was shown. And next week, ''Napoleon'' will play at the San Francisco Opera House.

title: Criminals And Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: 400 ATTEND A CONFERENCE ON RUNNING A CO-OP
description: More than 400 residents of cooperative apartment buildings in New York City gathered yesterday to learn more about the complex problems they face as building managers.

title: HOW CBS IS CHANGING CHANNELS
description: SIXTEEN months ago, when a Pillsbury executive from Minneapolis named Thomas H. Wyman ac-cepted the job as president and chief executive of CBS Inc., he was throwing himself into the turbulence of at least two potential storms.

title: ALBERTO SALAZAR IS ALL BUSINESS
description: restraint, easing back on the throttle, is. ''I don't think you can attribute Al's talent to muscular gifts,'' Rich Phaigh, the masseur for the Athletics West track team, said, while administering a friction massage to Salazar in a training room at the club's headquarters. ''You can attribute it to the fact that he's the toughest runner on the face of the earth.''

title: Children's Books
description: THE STORY OF OLD MRS.BRUBECK And How She Looked for Trouble and Where She Found Him. By Lore Segal. Illustrated by Marcia Sewall. Unpaged. New York: Pantheon Books. $8.95. (Ages 4 to 7) By KARLA KUSKIN

title: Reagan Aide Says MX Plan Increases Likelihood of War
description: A military adviser to the Administration has charged that President Reagan's new nuclear defense program made atomic war more likely and conflicted with the Republican Party's campaign platform.

title: FINANCIAL GIANTISM
description: Circumstance, Congressional dawdling, and the strange ways in which capital flows these days have combined to change totally the United States financial system.

title: Around the Nation; Technicians Pump Fuel Into Space Shuttle Tanks
description: Moving gingerly to avoid a repetition of last month's spill, technicians at the Kennedy Space Center today began the six-day task of pumping rocket fuel into the on-board tanks of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: About Long Island
description: LIKE piano keys, each of the fingers that touch Long Island Sound from the North Shore strikes a somewhat different note. From the woodiness of Lloyd Neck to the manicured classiness of Kings Point, I enjoy riding up through various fingers from time to time, trying to discern what makes each different without destroying the underlying unity of character that distinguishes the North Shore from anywhere else.

title: THE BETTMANN BEHIND THE ARCHIVES
description: Helen Markel is a contributing editor of McCall's. By Helen Markel Within an hour after the 1978 birth of Baby Louise, the first testtube baby, an 1832 woodcut showing an alchemist brewing up a child in his chemical retort turned up on the desks of major newspaper editors. The next morning, the old print appeared in papers across the country with the familiar credit line ''The Bettmann Archive'' running chastely up the right-hand side.

title: Mailbox; Many Sports Fans Are Used to Cold
description: To the Sports Editor: I would like something explained to me. When baseball fields its playoffs and World Series on ''frigid'' October nights, the press lashes into the sport for being insensitive to the fans attending the games; pity the poor huddled masses yearning to be warm.

title: The Aloe Vera Mystique
description: Deborah Blumenthal's article, ''The Facts Behind the Aloe Mystique'' (Sept. 6), only scratched the surface of a fast-growing aloe vera industry in this country. As she mentioned, there are two types of aloe products, the drug and the gel.

title: The Nation; Planes' On-Time Performance Off
description: It's often taking a lot longer these days to get from here to there on an airliner. According to a Government tabulation released last week, significant delays in early October were five times higher than the rate recorded before the air traffic controllers strike.

title: The Careful Shopper; by Jeanne Clare Feron; Quick Service Offered At Eyeglass Center
description: Optical Insight at the White Plains Mall has an optometrist, an optician and a laboratory on the premises. The half-hour examination costs $12, including an eye health and glaucoma test. Glass lenses begin at $18 and plastic lenses start at $20, which are available the same day, although bifocals and trifocals take longer to prepare and cost more.

title: PAKISTANI LEADER DEFENDS MOVE TO BUY F-16'S
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq yesterday called upon ''a larger, more powerful India'' to show magnanimity in its attitude toward his country's efforts to acquire jet fighters from the United States.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BRUSSELS
description: PAUL LEWIS is a Paris-based correspondent of The New York Times. By PAUL LEWIS

title: Art; ENGAGING DIMENSIONS BEYOND THE VISUAL IN OPTICAL ART
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE ''Strata Construct Series'' of Shirley Lazarus Toran, on view through Oct. 30 at the Public Library here, can obviously be classified as Op Art, and yet this designation is an unfortunate one -unfortunate because, by calling it Op, one practically excludes it from consideration as art.

title: Nets Beat Bullets, 91-87
description: The New Jersey Nets defeated the Washington Bullets, 91-87, in an exhibition game tonight.

title: Volunteers' Response To Fire Alarms
description: The recent article on manpower problems in volunteer fire departments addressed valid concerns; however, reference made to a typical firefighter ''racing to the firehouse in his car at life-endangering speed'' is incorrect and fosters a negative stereotype.

title: OFF-THE-RACK POLICIES DON'T FIT IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Central America is like the proverbial doughnut. You can keep your eye on the substance or the hole, on the important differences which mark each country or the common problems and dangers.

title: Mrs. Gandhi to Meet Reagan
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India will meet with President Reagan Wednesday on the eve of the conference in Cancun, Mexico, a Government spokesman said today. Mrs. Gandhi, who leaves tomorrow for Rumania on her way to Mexico, will also meet separately with Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China and President Sergej Kraigher of Yugoslavia the same day, the spokesman said.

title: PUBLISHING AT NORTH CAROLINA
description: When Matthew Hodgson became director of the University of North Carolina Press in 1970, it had a distinguished history and a halfmillion dollar debt. It is said he was greeted by the faculty his first week on the job, and by bill collectors the second.

title: No Headline
description: The result of the game between Rutherford and Leonia was reported incorrectly last Sunday. Rutherford beat Leonia, 62-0, as Ray Frazier set a school record with six touchdowns.

title: ANCIENT JEWELRY, MODERN ARTISTRY
description: WILLIAM E. FARRELL is chief of The Times bureau in Cairo By WILLIAM E. FARRELL

title: LIBERATION OF JANE
description: LESSONS By Lee Zacharias. 342 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $12.95.

title: Lester L. Gavurin, 59, Is Dead; Professor at Brooklyn College
description: Dr. Lester L. Gavurin, a mathematics professor and chairman of the department of mathematics at Brooklyn College, died Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center after a long illness. He was 59 years old and a resident of Baldwin, L.I.

title: New Jersey Guide; by Martha G. Wilson; A TREAT FOR TEANECK
description: The world-renowned Juilliard Quartet, which celebrated its 35th anniversary in May, will give a concert at Benjamin Franklin Junior High School in Teaneck Tuesday night.

title: Architecture View; HOUSING VS. ART IN WEST BERLIN; WEST BERLIN
description: The wall, of course, is the immutable reality; its acceptance is a demonstration of how the surreal becomes ordinary if you live with it long enough, and after 20 years Berliners treat it as a fact of the local geography, like the forests and waterways that make the city such a special place. The line on the map that cuts the city apart at its heart, the Brandenburg Gate, and dismembers the axis of Unter den Linden, is a shocking act of urban amputation. As one stands looking east and west, at the two Berlins, the bland brutality of the division is as disturbing as the actual concrete barricade with its sinister baggage of alarms, mines and guards. No work of art can ever aspire to memorialize this presence and its meanings. The wall is its own best monument.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1981
description: International The pledge to Saudi Arabia not to permit the country to become another Iran was renewed by President Reagan. He said that Iran's Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi would not have fallen if the Carter Administration had given him unwavering support ''in whatever had to be done to curb the revolution.'' (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: THE SERIES GIVES MEMORY ITS TRIGGER TO THE PAST
description: IT is one of the special charms of baseball that it follows so closely the rhythm of the seasons. It begins with the sweet promise of spring, a time when all things seem possible, and it ends, with the whisper of lost chances, amid the bittersweet beauty of fall. April belongs to everyone; only winners walk the fields of autumn.

title: Sports of the Times; REGGIE JACKSON'S REVERBERATIONS
description: NOW that Vince's restaurant in Oakland has emerged as Copacabana West in Yankee lore, a plaque should be put up there on the wall that shook when Reggie Jackson scuffled with Graig Nettles during the Yankees' pennant party. That incident will not affect the upcoming World Series, but reverberations will be felt soon when George Steinbrenner has to decide if Reggie Jackson is worth the aggravation as well as several million dollars.

title: Maureen Johnson Wed to Christopher Burt Rich
description: Maureen Lillian Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold T. Johnson Jr., of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Burt Rich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Rich of Birmingham, Mich. The Rev. Steve Fink of the Riverside Church performed the ceremony at the American Yacht Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: Camera; SOME USEFUL NEW PHOTOGRAPHIC PRODUCTS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Manning is a photographer on the staff of this newpspaper.

title: HOW ARE WE POSSIBLE?
description: MAN, THE PROMISING PRIMATE The Conditions of Human Evolution. By Peter J. Wilson. 185 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $12.95. GENES, MIND, AND CULTURE The Coevolutionary Process. By Charles J. Lumsden and Edward O. Wilson. Illustrated. 428 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20.

title: MODERN ARMS MEET HISTORY AT YORKTOWN
description: A display of modern military might and the first ritual ceremony in a scheduled weekend of high diplomatic protocol drew thousands of people today to the Yorktown Bicentennial celebration.

title: THE ULTIMATE MOVEABLE FEAST
description: CRAIG CLAIBORNE is the food editor of The New York Times. By CRAIG CLAIBORNE

title: BRINGING UP MOTHER
description: BED REST By Rita Kashner. 266 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $10.95. RHINE MAIDENS By Carolyn See. 272 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $13.95.

title: Rocket Monument Dedicated
description: A 34-foot-tall rocket made of Indiana limestone has been dedicated here to Virgil I. Grissom, the astronaut who died in 1967 when fire swept his Apollo spacecraft. The monument is on the site of Grissom's elementary school.

title: Art; A PLETHORA OF PHOTOS
description: WITH no fewer than seven simultaneous shows, it's as if October were ''Photography Month'' in New Jersey. Unfortunately, limited traveling time and space allow for only three to be reviewed.

title: Reagan Signs Veterans' Bill
description: President Reagan signed a bill today providing cost-of-living benefit increases averaging 11.2 percent to 2.3 million service-disabled veterans and their survivors. Mr. Reagan objected to two provisions that he said ''represent unwarranted intrusions on executive branch management.'' One, he said, would require long delays in reorganizing the Veterans Administration to achieve a more economical operation, and the other would block the agency from conducting certain cost-comparision studies.

title: MAN AND CAPITAL
description: EQUALITY, THE THIRD WORLD, AND ECONOMIC DELUSION By P.T. Bauer. 293 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $17.50. INVESTING IN PEOPLE The Economics of Population Quality. By Theodore W. Schultz. 173 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $12.95.

title: Contract Ends 12-Day Strike By Cornell's Service Workers
description: A 12-day strike against Cornell University ended today when maintenance workers represented by the United Auto Workers union ratified their first contract with the Ivy League school.

title: U.S. CUTS BACK AND SHIFTS COURSE ON HOUSING AID
description: When Congress passed the Housing Act of 1968, it committed the nation to the goal of producing 2.6 million units of housing a year, including 600,000 annually for low-income families. Now, if the Reagan Administration has its way, the direct Federal subsidy programs enacted by Congress to help meet that goal will be drastically curtailed.

title: Crime
description: In recent years several South Africans have been writing mysteries that are more than orthodox detective novels, for they also shed light on the troubles of the continent. There has been John Wyllie and his Dr. Quarshie series. There has been James McClure, who started his series with ''The Steam Pig,'' a novel that attracted much attention in 1972. Two years ago, with ''A Lonely Place to Die,'' Wessel Ebersohn joined the crowd. Mr. Ebersohn's hero was Yudel Gordon, a Jewish police psychologist in Pretoria. He is back now in DIVIDE THE NIGHT (Pantheon, $10.95).

title: NEW YORK RANKS 2D IN SPENDING ON STUDENTS
description: New York State ranks second and New Jersey third behind Alaska in average spending for each public school child, according to a survey by a citizens' research group.

title: Rock 'Cowboy Mouth' Coming to Wonderhorse
description: ''Cowboy Mouth (In Concert)'' by Sam Shepard and Patti Smith will open Nov. 4 and run through Nov. 17 at the Wonderhorse Theater, at 83 East Fourth Street.

title: DR. RUSK WILL GET KAREN HORNEY AWARD
description: Dr. Howard A.
