Rusk, a world leader in modern rehabilitation medicine who founded the Institute of Medical Rehabilitation at New York University and served as its director for 33 years, will be honored for his work next month. Dr. Rusk, who is 80 years old, will receive the Karen Horney Clinic's annual Social Conscience Award at a dinner at the Pierre Hotel on Nov. 21.

title: DARTMOUTH TOPPLES HARVARD
description: Sean Maher, a halfback, scored two touchdowns and ran for 120 yards to lead Dartmouth to a 24-10 victory over Harvard today.

title: THE ART OF INNUENDO
description: JOE McCARTHY AND THE PRESS By Edwin R. Bayley. 270 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $16.50.

title: TV View; THE NETWORKS' CABLE DIVISIONS ARE BUSILY PURVEYING CULTURE
description: Commercial television is hurtling into another new season with its familiar baggage of weekly series, specials and overly ambitious made-for-television movies. Among the new situation comedies, for instance, CBS has ''Mr. Merlin,'' in which the gifted actor Barnard Hughes plays King Arthur's sorcerer in modern dress as the owner of a seedy garage. Excruciatingly juvenile in concept and execution, this one is strictly for the kiddies. Then, in the movie arena, this past week had ABC offering a reverential, not to mention dull, biography entitled ''Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy.'' That one was for the soap-opera and gossip-column crowd. Nothing much has changed, evidently, in the networks' unrelenting quest to woo the largest possible audiences for their products.

title: Schmidt and Pinnix, Violin and Piano Duo
description: The heart of the Carnegie Recital Hall program with which Rodney Schmidt, violinist, and David Pinnix, pianist, made their New York debut Friday night consisted of three violin sonatas written within 10 years of one another by Debussy, Bartok and Enesco. Bracketing them were a youthful essay for violin and piano by Brahms - the ''Sonatensatz'' of 1853 - and another youthful work, the Sonata in Eflat (Op. 18), by Richard Strauss.

title: College Changes Its Name
description: Claremont Men's College in Claremont, Calif., has changed its name to Claremont McKenna College, adopting the new name in honor of Donald C. McKenna, a founding trustee and major donor. The college, which has accepted women as well as men since 1976, appointed a committee in 1980 to consider the appropriateness of the old name. ''This is not a break with the past but a natural evolution,'' said Jack L. Stark, an alumnus who was chairman of the name committee.

title: THE GRAND PROJECTS
description: NEXT year Harvard University Press will publish Volume I of the Dictionary of American Regional English, edited by Frederic Cassidy of the University of Wisconsin. It has been in preparation for more than 30 years and may be one of the best-known unpublished books around, argued about, and even quoted from, far beyond academic circles. So it is startling to find that only now is publication beginning.

title: No Headline
description: MILWAUKEE POLICEMEN'S TRIAL MAY BE DELAYED

title: THE JOFFREY BALLET, AT 25, LOOKS TO THE FUTURE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- John Gruen is the host of ''The Sound of Dance'' on WNCN and the author of ''The World's Great Ballets,'' published recently by Harry N. Abrams. By JOHN GRUEN

title: Administration Resists Tax Aid for Adoptions
description: The Reagan Administration is opposing moves in Congress to give new income tax breaks to people who adopt children.

title: FLORIDA STATE ROUTED, 42-14
description: Privately, the Florida State Seminoles wondered how long their Oktoberfest could last. Enthusiastically, they said they could do here what they had done the last two weeks at Columbus, Ohio, and South Bend, Ind. - come home with another upset.

title: MICKEY ROSE'S 'STUDENT BODIES'
description: There are some funny things in ''Student Bodies'' but none of them is actually in the movie. There are, for example, the opening title cards, seen against a shot of a lonely house at night, which set the time for this horror-film parody. First: ''Halloween,'' then ''Friday the 13th,'' and then the topper, ''Jamie Leigh Curtis's Birthday.''

title: On Language
description: The Beauty Part

title: STONY BROOK POLITICAL theorists may draw dire analogies from insects that live off the labor of other insects, but Stefan Coven, a graduate student in ecology at the State University at Stony Brook, regards the rare parasitic ants he found living on Long Island as just another interesting part of the universe.
description: "You have to remain objective as an experimental scientist," said the 29-year-old Mr. Coven, "but it is tempting to see these ants as members of the leisure class. They are subtle parasites that sneak into a nest, then con the host ants into feeding them and raising their children."

title: Enough Already
description: To the Editor:

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE The streets will be filled with dancing this week. Well, metaphorically at least. Things get off to a start Sunday afternoon at 1 along West 55th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues when the Joffrey Ballet throws a free, five-hour birthday party for itself in honor of its upcoming 25th-anniversary season.

title: by Betsy Brown
description: SUGGESTING that landlords may report low profits when they request rent increases but then, when trying to sell a building as a cooperative, declare that it is economical to run, County Legislator Carl Calvi has asked the state to disclose rent-application figures.

title: Around the Nation; Lab Closed After Issuing Hepatitis-Positive Blood
description: An American Red Cross blood processing laboratory here was shut down after it dispensed two pints of hepatitis-contaminated blood. Dr. Eoline McGowan, medical director of blood services, said that the Red Cross would conduct a ''thorough review.''

title: Gallery View; NAPLES IN ITS GOLDEN AGE
description: DETROIT Naples until well into the 19th century was one of the most pleasant of all cities in which to spend time. If you had money, that is. Naples for the poor could be very unpleasant indeed. But for the moneyed visitor who had just one or two letters of introduction it was a metropolitan paradise. It had a spectacular site. It had just acquired a large number of strikingly inventive and imaginative new buildings. People had done up their houses in slam-bang style and were delighted to show them off.

title: Around the Nation; Retired Miner Is Held In Shooting Deaths of 5
description: A retired miner accused of fatally shooting five men and wounding three others in a rapid-fire attack in a store was hidden away today by the authorities, who said they were fearful of revenge.

title: J. B. Lloyd Weds Laura Knickerbocker
description: The marriage of Laura Patrick Knickerbocker, a writer, to James Bartlett Lloyd, an assistant vice president with the New York office of Banque de l'Indochine et de Suez, took place at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest yesterday. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: GUNMEN SHOOT OFFICIAL IN A TROUBLED INDIAN STATE
description: As Prime Minister Indira Gandhi conferred separately with Sikh and Hindu delegations from the troubled state of Punjab, gunmen wounded a state official yesterday and killed his brother in an ambush on the steps of the state capitol at Chandigarh.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: NORTHEAST UTILITIES' request for a rate increase, which is now before the Department of Public Utilities Control, has stirred protest and complaints, so the company has taken a new step to win over the public. In their bills this month, customers are finding notice of a ''rate case hot line,'' which they may call, toll-free, for Northeast's explanation of why it needs a $239 million rate increase. The hot line also gives the schedule for public hearings.

title: JAPAN BALKS AT U.S. FRUIT OVER TOXIN WORRIES
description: The first shipments of California citrus to Japan since mid-August are being held up at two ports here because of worries by harbor workers and the Japanese Government that the oranges and lemons may be contaminated with excessive amounts of a potentially cancer-causing toxin.

title: THRILLERS ON LOCATION
description: SAVAGE DAY By Thomas Wiseman. 438 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $14.95. THE LAST AMBASSADOR By Bernard Kalb and Marvin Kalb. 276 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $13.50. THE TWELFTH POWER OF EVIL By Jerrold Morgulas. 419 pp. New York: Seaview Books. $14.50.

title: U.S.C. DEFEATS STANFORD
description: John Mazur passed for 175 yards and one touchdown, Marcus Allen rushed for 153 yards and another score and Steve Jordan kicked three field goals to lift Southern California to 25-17 Pacific 10 Conference victory over Stanford today.

title: BERGEN-PASSAIC
description: Len Nelissant scored on a long run, and Jim Pescatore kicked a field goal for Passaic Valley yesterday to hand Clifton its first defeat, 10-0, at Montclair State College in Upper Montclair. It was only the second loss in two seasons for Clifton.

title: LIBRARIES BEGIN 5TH POETRY SERIES
description: THE poet, critic and literary historian Malcolm Cowley is to lead off the fifth season of the Poet's Voice with a reading at the Westport Library next Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Mr. Cowley, a longtime resident of Sherman, said he thought he would enjoy giving a reading for his ''fellow Nutmeggers.''

title: YALE WALLOPS COLUMBIA, 48-17
description: Undefeated Yale, which had fallen behind in each of its first four victories, never trailed against Columbia yesterday while registering a 48-17 triumph at Baker Field. The Eli led, 21-3, at halftime.

title: NEW PAPER STARTS IN SWEDISH CAPITAL
description: Stockholm has a new daily newspaper, a rare event in big-city life these days. It also has a rich and powerful morning newspaper that is offering its own kind of novelty: an acknowledgement that it went wrong in its approach to the news, and is making an attempt to change.

title: Barbara Bahlke Wed To Jeffrey M. Murphy
description: Barbara Alice Bahlke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Bahlke of Lighthouse Point, Fla., formerly of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Matthew Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Murphy of Cromwell, Conn. The Rev. James Adelmann performed the ceremony at the Garden City Community Church.

title: S.M.U. 38, Houston 22
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Southern Methodist safeties James Mobley and Wes Hopkins returned interceptions 65 and 66 yards for fourth-quarter touchdowns and the unbeaten Mustangs took advantage of nine Houston turnovers.

title: EQUITY CONVERSION PLANS GROW
description: Like many older homeowners, Robert and Alice Blersch paid off their mortgage long ago. Their house, in Buffalo, represents their most valuable asset.

title: CORPORATE PROFITS ARE COMING UP SHORT
description: Profits tumbled at many corporations in the third quarter, compared with results in the same period last year. The lackluster performance pushed stocks lower and raised fears of a worsening economic slump. I.B.M. was off 21.6 percent; International Paper, 23.6 percent; Reynolds Metals, 19.4 percent; Boise Cascade, 40.6 percent; CBS, 2.5 percent, Burroughs, 23.2 percent, NCR, 29.9 percent and Honeywell 30.8 percent.

title: Robert Hennessy Weds Anita Page
description: Anita Martha Page, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Page Jr., of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Manchester Center, Vt., was married yesterday to Robert E. Hennessy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Hennessy of Syracuse. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor.

title: CANCUN'S MEANING
description: The 22-country North-South meeting in Cancun, Mexico, affords an opportunity for Washington to make a strong commitment to global economic recovery. Instead, the Administration views the meeting, which begins Thursday, as a pulpit from which it can preach platitudes about self-reliance. This view ignores the significance of Cancun - history's first North-South summit conference - and imperils United States trade, jobs, and corporate profits.

title: ACCORD IS NEARING ON PROPERTY TAX
description: Legislative negotiators seeking to replace New York State's illegal property tax-assessment system have agreed on an approach they hope will lead to a new law by the end of the month.

title: CAIRO BANS FIREARMS AND VERIFIES REPORTS OF NEW CRACKDOWN
description: The new Government of President Hosni Mubarak issued a ban today on all use of firearms by civilians and confirmed that it was conducting a nationwide roundup of religious militants and political opponents.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Ghost Story

title: A QUESTION OF SEX BIAS AT HARVARD
description: Fran R. Schumer, a Harvard graduate, is a New York writer and teaches at City College. By Fran R. Schumer t 4 P.M. on Sept. 30, 1980, Theda R. Skocpol left her tiny office at Princeton's Institute for Advanced Studies, where she was on a oneyear fellowship away from Harvard. The sociology department at Harvard was scheduled to vote that afternoon on whether she would become its first tenured female professor. She walked down the lawn of the Princeton campus to the nearby complex of faculty housing in which she and her husband, William, a physicist also on leave from Harvard, were living and waited for the call. When it came, she was stunned. On a 5-to-5 vote with one abstention, the department had chosen not to recommend Theda Skocpol.

title: Ohio State 34, Illinois 27
description: Ohio State survived another big passing performance by Tony Eason, the Illinois quarterback.

title: Some History Portrayed in the Raw
description: MONTREAL BOWIE KUHN, probably wearing his historic thermal lingerie, but hatless and coatless with a sleeveless sweater under his jacket, watched the Montreal Expos win Canada's first pennant playoff game from a heated box upstairs Friday night. The baseball commissioner has said that he considers the playoffs a league matter, but in the World Series, where he is in command, he would be down front with the frosted customers.

title: BRAZIL'S PRESIDENT FLIES TO U.S. FOR HEART TESTS
description: President Joao Baptista Figueiredo, who had a heart attack last month, flew to the United States today for medical tests and possibly surgery.

title: STATE HEALTH AIDES FEARFUL OF CUTBACKS
description: TRENTON BUDGET cuts projected by the Reagan Administration have cast a dark cloud over the state's Department of Health. In fiscal 1981, Federal funds accounted for 64 percent of the department's budget, mostly through block grants. Current projections call for a $13.2 million decrease in Federal funds for fiscal 1982 - a 25 percent budget reduction - with the possibility of further cuts later in the fiscal year.

title: Major News; FOR REAGAN, THE ECONOMY MAKES 1982 LOOK NEAR
description: A reluctant Congress wasn't the only force menacing Ronald Reagan's economic revitalization program, or his party, last week. A decidedly unvital economy was too. The condition can be called sogginess, as the White House prefers, or recessionary. But the semantics were less relevant than the numbers, especially with the 1982 political campaign already under way.

title: TO GO OR NOT TO GO: HOW TO DECIDE
description: At first glance, some of the cruise ads seem enticing indeed: Six ports in seven days, eight ports in 14! But when you study the itinerary carefully and start calculating costs, you, the potential passenger, find yourself faced with a lot of ''should we's'' and ''shouldn't we's.'' Along with deciding what clothes to bring and how much extra cash to set aside for tipping, you must also choose how best to spend the time available to go ashore.

title: SENIOR U.S. JUDGES PREFER BENCH TO BENCHED
description: Judge Dudley B. Bonsal conducts many cases in Federal District Court in Manhattan, although he could be relaxing in retirement without losing any pay or financial benefits.

title: Newly Found March Of Mozart Set for Oct. 28
description: A newly discovered march that Mozart wrote in 1782 for ''The Abduction From the Seraglio'' will have its American premiere Oct. 28 in Alice Tully Hall. The concert will open the 25th-anniversary season of Clarion Concerts, under the direction of Newell Jenkins.

title: STAFFORD TO SEEK RE-ELECTION
description: Senator Robert T. Stafford, Republican of Vermont, has announced that he will run for re-election next year. Mr. Stafford, 68 years old, said he was in "a unique position to look out for Vermont's interests and rural America's interests." He is chairman of the Senate Committee on the Environment and Public Works and heads the Education subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources.

title: Connecticut 44 Holy Cross 24
description: Ken Sweitzer passed for 232 yards and three touchdowns for Connecticut (3-3). Holy Cross (3-3) took an early 17-0 lead, but Connecticut scored two touchdowns before halftime, then scored 30 points in the second half.

title: Aileen C. Ryan Is Married In Rye to Vincent R. Haas
description: Aileen C. Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Ryan of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection to Vincent R. Haas. He is the son of Mrs. Marilyn Danielle of Port Chester, N.Y., and Dr. Raymond Haas of Hartsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Gerard Rafferty performed the ceremony.

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; A Lot Less Oil On the Waters
description: The volume of oil accidentally spilled into the sea dropped sharply last year, the Center for Short-Lived Phenomena concluded in a report last week. Richard S. Golob, the center's executive director, quickly added that things going from worse to bad should not be cause for comfort.

title: 40 Food Spots Charged With Code Violations
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday cited 40 food establishments for violation of Health Code regulations. The department makes public in weekly reports the establishments that are fined, reopened or closed after inspection by health officials.

title: General Motors Recalls Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation has recalled 6,700 1981 mid-sized vehicles to find and replace about 300 improperly manufactured wheels that could crack at the hub. The action applies to certain Oldsmobile Cutlass, Buick Century and Regal, Chevrolet El Camino and G.M.C. Caballero models equipped with heavy-duty wheels.

title: A STABLE TRADE DEFICIT
description: While August's $5.6 billion trade deficit was the worst since February 1980, economists from Citibank and Manufacturers Hanover point out that speculation may be premature about a rapid deterioration of America's trade balance, which some analysts have been expecting. In spite of a 14 percent rise in the trade-weighted value of the dollar, the United States trade deficit has remained remarkably stable during the first eight months of the year.

title: IL PROGRESSO, 100, CHANGING FORMAT
description: Il Progresso, celebrating a century as a newspaper for Italian immigrants in the New York metropolitan area, is changing course under new publishers in an effort to attract later generations of readers interested in a Continental heritage.

title: Essay; THE REAGAN MEMOIRS
description: We are bracing ourselves for the memoirs of the Carter Administration, with Jimmy Carter hiring a ghost and Zbigniew Brzezinski putting rivets in his conceptual framework; meanwhile, Gerry Rafshoon and Hamilton Jordan are pressing ahead with plans for their television docudrama of the Iranian affair, mindful that Pierre Salinger's stunningly revealing book, ''America Held Hostage,'' will be published next month.

title: Miss Melton Wed To Thomas Stott
description: Michaelle Elizabeth Melton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Melton Jr. of Dorset, Vt., and Tequesta, Fla., was married yesterday to Thomas David Stott, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Tarsney Stott of North Palm Beach, Fla. The bride's uncles, Msgr.

title: MORRIS-SOMERSET
description: Chris Preston threw three touchdown passes - two to Rich Newman - to lift Somerville to a 21-0 defeat of Hillsborough yesterday in Hillsborough. Somerville (4-0) sent Hillsborough to its second loss in four games when Preston, a senior quarterback, hit Newman with scoring passes of 28 yards in the first quarter and 30 yards in the third.

title: Dining Out; FROM VAST MENU, GREEK IS CHOICE
description: TO enjoy a dinner at Aphrodite in White Plains, one would do well to be partial to Greek food and indifferent to conversation. The large dining areas of this restaurant are usually crowded with guests who come to take advantage of what the management calls ''diner prices'' and to dance, and sometimes sing, to the live music competing with the voices. Spirits soar as high as the noise level - a small party celebrating an anniversary at one table, bosses dining their secretaries at another, entire families at yet others. Amused by the dining room bustle, all take for granted the unstinting portions the kitchen doles. The distraction is welcome, however, for some of the food cannot bear close scrutiny.

title: Remsen Wins, 4 and 2
description: Richard Remsen of Locust Valley, L.I., defeated Neil Croonquist, 4 and 2, today and won the 30th annual North and South Senior Amateur golf tournament at the Pinehurst Country Club. Remsen, 61 years old, is a retired Wall Street stockbroker. Croonquist is a 64-year-old businessman from Edina, Minn.

title: Deborah von Hoffman Is Married to Dale Lanzone
description: Deborah Anne von Hoffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. von Hoffman of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday to Dale M. Lanzone of Arlington, Va., son of Mae L. Lanzone of Greencastle, Ind., and the late Charles P. Lanzone. The Rev. Frederick J. Warnecke Jr. performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: WOMEN WHO DID SOMETHING
description: ELIZABETH CADY STANTON SUSAN B.ANTHONY Correspondence, Writings, Speeches. Edited and With a Critical Commentary by Ellen Carol DuBois. Foreword by Gerda Lerner. 272 pp. New York: Schocken Books. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: RULING NEARS ON NOW SUIT
description: HARTFORD ASuperior Court judge said last week that he would decide within a month whether the rights of members of the National Organization for Women were violated when owners of the state's largest shopping mall prevented them from gathering signatures and soliciting funds on their property.

title: ROOMS AT THE TOP
description: By any name the concept is almost the same: Regency Club, Hilton Towers, Renaissance Club, Ambassador's Row, Concierge Level - they all promise the best in hotel luxury. Their message is that you do not have to be a president or member of royalty to be treated like one during an overnight stay or longer, provided you can afford the going rate. Surprisingly, however, the tariff is often not much more than you would pay at the same hotel for considerably fewer frills and less attention.

title: BROOKLYN UNION
description: To the Business Editor: As a staff attorney with the New York City department that enforces the Housing Maintenance Code, I read with much interest your Oct. 4 article about Brooklyn Union Gas, ''The Utility that Glows in Brooklyn.''

title: MEXICANS GO ALL OUT FOR TALKS IN CANCUN
description: Decorators are still sprucing up the Cancun airport and the hot lines to capitals as far apart as Abidjan and Peking have yet to be tested, but preparations for next week's conference of industrialized and developing nations are now virtually complete.

title: Bulls Defeat the Knicks By 120-98 in Exhibition
description: Reggie Theus scored 14 points and Jackie Robinson 13 to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 120-98 victory over the Knicks in an exhibition game.

title: Long Islanders; MATRIMONIAL TIES IN PEACE AND WAR
description: THE first time that Irene David's life intersected with that of Dwight D. Eisenhower was after the end of World War II. The former Irene Neer was working then for The Brooklyn Eagle, and the Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces in Europe was coming home to a hero's welcome.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; CLIVE CUSSLER
description: Four years after his ''Raise the Titanic!'' appeared on The New York Times fiction best-seller list, Clive Cussler is back on that list with ''Night Probe!'' He's also back into the watery depths with his suspense novel about a desperate hunt for a long-sunk and secret treaty between the United States and Great Britain.

title: Why Not Let the North Secede As Well?
description: It is understandable why the people of South Jersey want to secede.

title: CONTROVERSY MARKS RULES FOR LAND USE
description: ALTHOUGH new and more-restrictive land-use regulations in the last 11 years have partly reversed New Jersey's trend of cluttered development, many thousands of acres of farmland and open spaces continue to be developed annually both for residential and business use.

title: Alabama 38, Tennessee 19
description: Alabama bounced back from a tie last week with Southern Mississippi as four players scored touchdowns and Peter Kim kicked three field goals. Alabama led, 38-3, before allowing two late Tennessee touchdowns.

title: THE STRUGGLE OF ANDREW SILK
description: Andrew Silk, formerly a reporter for The Virginian-Pilot of Norfolk, Va., wrote ''A South African Shantytown: The Story of Modderdam,'' which was recently published in South Africa. By Andrew Silk ''Exhale, inhale, and hold your breath,'' a voice whispered over a microphone. The radiologist was taking a cross-section X-ray of my lung. I lay in the cradle of the computerized axial tomographer - the CAT scanner -with foam-rubber padding across my chest and a liquid sensitive to radiation dripping into a vein in my arm. In the control room, a technician pushed a button, and the cradle inched into a large metal tube. Like a salami in a delicatessen meat slicer, I passed slowly through the scanner.

title: 3,000 EVANGELICALS MEET IN JERUSALEM
description: Three thousand evangelical Christians from the United States, Western Europe and elsewhere gathered this week in Jerusalem to demonstrate their support for Israel.

title: RECYCLING: LESS GOLD IN GARBAGE
description: THE value of broken glass is up, waste paper is down, and the used aluminum can market is spongy, according to officials of the recycled-wastes industry. As a result, most organizations have canceled their paper drives as a means to raise money, and the Town of Islip, which operates the nation's largest recycling plant, is getting less for its aluminum and more for its glass and wondering what the future will bring.

title: WALDHEIM'S PREFERENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Penguins 5, North Stars 2
description: PITTSBURGH (UPI) - First-period goals by Rick Kehoe and Greg Malone helped give Pittsburgh a jump on Minnesota en route to the victory.

title: NEW SPECIALTY: EMERGENCIES
description: SUMMIT IT IS 4:27 P.M. in the emergency room at Overlook Hospital here, and half the cubicles are occupied by patients. A slim young physician moves from one curtained alcove to the next, talking reassuringly to the occupants, most of whom complain of problems familiar to most suburban emergency rooms: cuts, scrapes, sprains.

title: THEATER: 'UNCLE VANYA' STAGED AT THE YALE REP
description: Late-afternoon sunlight streams through the tall glass doors on Michael H. Yeargan's handsome set for ''Uncle Vanya'' at the Yale Repertory Theater. As the play begins, we feel the presence of a family and of a family estate as a symbol of what remains of unity, intimacy and tradition. The feeling is transmitted in the performance as well as the design of Lloyd Richards's Yale Repertory Theater production. Using Constance Garnett's translation, this is a carefully modulated, classically proportioned version of ''Uncle Vanya.''

title: J.P. STEVENS: ONE YEAR AFTER THE TRUCE
description: O N Oct. 19, 1980, J.P. Stevens signed an agreement with the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union approving the first collective bargaining contracts in the company's history. The agreement marked the end of one of the ugliest episodes in recent labor history: a 17-year war during which Stevens repeatedly harassed or fired union activists, and the union countered with a boycott of Stevens products and a campaign to isolate the company by pressuring companies that dealt with Stevens or had Stevens officers on their boards.

title: The Region; Hartford Speaks More Clearly On Second Try
description: As Mayor of Hartford, George A. Athanson frequently complained that the city council refused to follow his lead. Whether or not the council was behind him in the rerun of the city's Democratic mayoral primary last week, his career as Mayor was.

title: INNER CITY TROUPE HANGING ON
description: PATERSON THE hopes of several hundred urban youngsters are hinging on the outcome of a benefit dinner-dance to be held Saturday night at the Ottilio Pavilion here.

title: Nebraska 49 Kansas State 3
description: Turner Gill threw for two touchdowns and Mike Rozier ran 93 yards for another score for Nebraska. Gill hit the tight end Jamie Williams with scoring passes of 23 and 13 yards on Nebraska's first two possessions of the game and Rozier went 93 yards off right tackle on the Cornhuskers' first play of the second quarter for a 21-0 lead before the game was 20 minutes old.

title: ENGINEERS SIMULATE COLLAPSE OF HYATT'S 'SKYWALKS'
description: First, there was a sharp bang like a gunshot, then the sides of the steel ''box beam'' bulged outward, followed by two louder cracks, and, finally, a supporting rod pulled through.

title: RUTGERS DEFEATED BY TEMPLE, 24-12
description: With Tink Murphy playing superbly at quarterback and Harold Harmon effective as a runner and receiver, Temple proved too formidable for Rutgers today.

title: Editors' Choice
description: BACHELORHOOD, by Phillip Lopate. (Little, Brown & Company, $13.95.) Meditations on life and culture.

title: BAD LUCK AND VIOLET EYES
description: ELIZABETH TAYLOR The Last Star. By Kitty Kelley. Illustrated. 448 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: FRESH TALENT AND NEW BUYERS BRIGHTEN THE ART WORLD
description: The general image of art dealers is that they inhabit a glamorous world, taking off for Zurich or Beverly Hills to sell $2-million paintings to choice collectors, entertaining clients at three-star restaurants in Paris and New York, building big homes in East Hampton, owning boats with sails designed by, say, Dubuffet. And for some of the major dealers, the picture is not all that far from the truth.

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: Kunming To the Editor:

title: FEIJOADA, THE PRIDE OF THE BRAZILIANS
description: WARREN HOGE is chief of The New York Times bureau in Rio de Janeiro. By WARREN HOGE

title: U.S. WILL TEST PLAN TO HELP THE ELDERLY AT BROOKLYN CENTER
description: A Brooklyn nursing home has been selected for a federally assisted project that will seek to return some elderly patients to community settings and prevent others from ending up needlessly in nursing homes.

title: SEVENTH TITLE CHESS GAME DRAWN AFTER 31 MOVES
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world chess champion, and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, the challenger, drew the seventh game of their title match in 31 moves here in the Kurzentrum tonight.

title: ESSEX-HUDSON
description: Mike Volpe, a junior quarterback, scored on an 8-yard run in the first quarter to spark Passaic to a 70-0 victory over Belleville yesterday. A crowd of over 3,300 watched the game, which was played in Belleville.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Poised for a Fall

title: Claire Boyden Plays Romantic Piano Works
description: In her New York debut Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, Claire Boyden, a Canadian-born pianist, confined herself to a narrow but undeniably rich vein of the 19th-century literature, offering the Four Impromptus (Op. 90) of Schubert and other equally short and introspective pieces by Brahms and Chopin.

title: Theater in Review; MOLIERE'S 'INVALID': INFECTIOUS LAUGHTER
description: HUNTINGTON STATION WITH Moliere's ''The Imaginary Invalid,'' a reopened and renamed theater - the Harry Chapin Theater Center, formerly the PAF Playhouse - is off to a rollicking rebirth. John Reich's staging and adaptation of the French classic has flair and a sense of real class. Although the players are variable, the playhouse, battling bankruptcy, is on its way.

title: ARMS RACE QUICKENS; MUBARAK GETS TOUGH
description: THE chronic edginess of the Middle East, sharpened by the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat, has prompted a response that is by now familiar in the region - a rush to weaponry. As warnings rumbled out of Moscow and Washington last week, military forces were placed on heightened alert in Libya, Egypt, the Sudan and Chad. Asserting that it was trying to ''defuse the tensions through deterring possibile hostilities,'' the United States dispatched Awacs radar surveillance planes to Egypt, speeded up shipments of tanks, howitzers and F-5 trainers to the Sudan and took precautionary steps in case of an outbreak of fighting.

title: Future Events Galaxies, Girls, Galas
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated: Night for Light Oct. 20 - The first Woman of Vision and Man of Vision awards will presented tonight at the ''Night for Light'' gala of the Retina Foundation's Eye Research Institute to Georgette Klinger, a skincare specialist, and William Bernbach, advertising executive. The dinner-dance, to include Lena Horne, who will present Ella Fitzgerald with the Eye-Care award, will be in the grand ballroom of the Vista International Hotel at the World Trade Center. Partygoers, who will be bused downtown at 7 P.M. from the Regency Hotel, will be treated to cocktails at 7:30, dinner, and dancing music by Jerry Kravat's Orchestra until midnight. Tickets, at $150 a person, from 838-4996 or 838-5036.

title: NIXON ASSERTS WEST SHOULD BOYCOTT OIL PRODUCED BY LIBYA
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon said today that the West should consider an ''economic quarantine'' of Libya to cut off the oil income that supports the projects of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Mr. Nixon called the Libyan leader an ''international outlaw.''

title: GUIDRY MAY LEAVE
description: Ron Guidry will start the first game of the World Series for the Yankees Tuesday night, Manager Bob Lemon said yesterday, but only George Steinbrenner can say how many more games Guidry may start for the Yankees. And the team's principal owner is not prepared to say it yet.

title: SCIENTISTS TO SEEK ANIMAL OF LEGEND
description: American scientists plan to leave for Africa next Sunday on an expedition in search of a large jungle animal that the pygmies fear and explorers have heard described as ''half elephant, half dragon'' - which is to say that it bears a remarkable likeness to the dinosaurs.

title: LIBERALS, ON THE OUTSIDE, LEARN TO WORK INSIDE
description: When the Senate voted last week to restore the minimum Social Security benefit, it marked the first time this year that Congress had defied President Reagan on an important economic issue and reversed one of his budget trimming proposals. The unanimous vote was a testament to the power of the senior citizens' ''gray power'' lobby, and gave advocates of social welfare programs their strongest flicker of hope in many months.

title: Around the World; Diplomats in Zimbabwe Report Restrictions
description: Zimbabwe has ordered restrictions on the movement of diplomats and the size of the 60 embassies and consulates here, diplomats said today.

title: LEGISLATORS CHANGING PRIORITIES IN BUDGET
description: DESPITE the pleading of interest groups ranging from Vietnam veterans to lovers of the arts, Suffolk County's legislative leaders say that this year will not be one of ''pork barrel'' dealing as usual. Instead, they assert, some - but definitely not all - of the budget cuts and job reductions put forward in County Executive Peter F. Cohalan's proposed 1982 budget will have to be put into effect.

title: Alice Warne Married To Prof. Randall Stout
description: Alice Warne, a senior research associate at the College of Business Administration of Pennsylvania State University, was married yesterday to Randall Stout, professor emeritus of economics at the university.

title: Thieves Ransack the Rectory Of a Brooklyn Catholic Church
description: Theives ransacked the rectory of a Roman Catholic church in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was broken into yesterday taking $2,000, two television sets and religious objects including two crosses, the police reported. The burglary- the latest of several recent crimes directed against church property and the religious in the city- occured at Our Lady of Charity at 1669 Dean Street.

title: GILLIES'S TWO GOALS LEAD ISLANDERS OVER RANGERS, 5-4
description: Just when it seemed that every Islander-Ranger game would turn into penalty-filled, bench-clearing brawls with suspensions for the fighters, the New York rivals proved otherwise tonight.

title: CURB ON EVIDENCE IN LUGGAGE IN CAR UPHELD BY JERSEY COURT
description: A police officer who has permission to inspect the trunk of a car may not search closed luggage within it, a state appeals court ruled yesterday.

title: Westchester Housing; THE 'FRIENDLIER' NONEVICTION CO-OPS
description: WHILE apartment dwellers and landlords in half a dozen communities are locked in battle over plans to convert buildings into cooperatives, a minority of landlords are taking the slow but easy way: they ''co-op'' the building and do not evict any tenants.

title: A SWISS FILM BARES ANOTHER CHAPTER OF THE HOLOCAUST
description: ''The refugees don't like the fact that I'm criticizing the Swiss,'' said Markus Imhoof. ''They have to be thankful and careful, because their lives were saved. Those who hid refugees were decorated after the war: something must be wrong when you have to honor people for doing the right and normal thing.''

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; Toward Bearable Cancer Therapy
description: Where the treatment seems worse than the disease, cancer patients may well avoid the treatment. As many as half at Duke Medical Center, for example, miss appointments or otherwise delay prescribed chemotherapy because of severe nausea or vomiting, staff physicians say.

title: BARBARA WESTON ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Bruce Weston of Ardsley, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Weston, to Andrew Vincent Tung, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Tung of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Miss Weston is a design coordinator in the corporate buying office of R. H. Macy in New York. Her fiance is a landscape architect with P. G. Rolland & Associates in Rye, N.Y. A spring wedding is planned.

title: New Jersey Housing; 'ANGELS' IN THE HOME MARKET
description: IN THEATRICAL circles, they are called angels. In real-estate circles, they have a variety of names, such as ''home partners'' and ''owner-nonresident.''

title: B.Y.U. 27, San Diego State 7
description: SAN DIEGO (UPI) - Jim McMahon completed 27 of 42 passes for 348 yards and three touchdowns for Brigham Young in a Western Athletic Conference game.

title: LESS EXPENSIVE METHOD TO BAR RABIES IS FOUND
description: An inexpensive way to vaccinate people against rabies has been proposed to the Immunization Practices Advisory Committee, the panel that sets national immunization standards.

title: Topics; TRANSFORMATIONS; Planning for the Present
description: More than any agency of government, the City Planning Commission determines the future face of New York City. But it has not reflected the city's present face; until two years ago, all seven of its members were white.

title: ROLE OF MOSCOW IN TERROR DOUBTED
description: Early Reagan Administration charges that the Soviet Union was directly helping terrorists were essentially based on information provided a decade ago by a Czechoslavak defector, according to senior intelligence officials.

title: SUSPECT IS NAMED IN KILLING ON BUS
description: A 26-year-old Hicksville, L.I., man with tattooed hands and a record for robbery and weapons violations was identified by the police yesterday as ''the assailant'' who shot and killed a New York City bus driver in Brooklyn eight days ago in a dispute over a free transfer.

title: MERGERS' CONTRIBUTION TO HIGH INTEREST RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Powers Wed To Brian Swiggett
description: Laura Mathilde Powers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustin Jay Powers Jr. of Glen Head, L.I., was married in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday to Brian Edward Swiggett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lewis Swiggett of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: A BAGFUL OF MEMORIES
description: THIS year marked the end of the Danbury State Fair, and thus the end of an annual argument with myself. It went something like this: I will not go to the fair this year -it's become much too commercial. But the merchandise is really terrific: the squeegeehandled sponge mop, the magic miracle glass cleaner, the vibrating pillow - the kinds of things I could never find in retail stores.

title: 24 ON TAX-CUT PANEL TOOK CORPORATE GIFTS
description: Twenty-four members of the House Ways and Means Committee, who helped to write the largest business tax cut in history, received a total of $280,491 in campaign contributions from corporate interests in the first half of the year, a Ralph Nader organization reports.

title: Lieut. Comdr. Bryan Ingalls Marries Jane E. Ezzard
description: Jane Elizabeth Ezzard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Speer Ezzard of Marietta, Ohio, and Lieut. Comdr. Bryan William Ingalls, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Ingalls of Binghamton, N.Y., were married yesterday.

title: BEATING LONDON TRAFFIC ON A MOPED
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- EDMUND MORRIS, who received a Pulitzer Prize for ''The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt,'' is at work on a sequel, to be called ''Theodore Rex.'' He lives in New York City. By EDMUND MORRIS

title: Megan Follansbee Married
description: Megan Follansbee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Follansbee of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Peyton Randolph Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo J. Smith of Wilmington, N. C. The Rev. Max Smith performed the ceremony at St. Michael's of the Valley Episcopal Church in Ligonier, Pa.

title: POLLS SPLIT ON WHO WILL WIN GREEK ELECTION TODAY
description: More than six million Greeks vote tomorrow to decide whether they want continued rule by a conservative, pro-Western Government or the changes offered by the Socialist opposition.

title: ANOTHER SIDE OF RAUSCHENBERG
description: Andy Grundberg reviews photography for The New York Times and is picture editor of Modern Photography magazine. By Andy Grundberg

title: Dr. Kiki Palacios Wed to Ted Gilliam, Accountant
description: Dr. Quisqueya T. Palacios, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joaquin Palacios of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and Ted Wayne Gilliam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tom Gilliam of Centerville, Tenn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Nancy E. Muth performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N.J.

title: IS WILLIAM BAXTER ANTI-ANTITRUST?
description: T HE Reagan White House has a penchant for entrusting administration of our most important laws to those who believe they should not be enforced. Nowhere is this better illustrated than in the case of William F. Baxter, chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division.

title: Clean Air
description: To the Business Editor: Can our environment become too free from pollutants? One might reach such a conclusion from ''G.M. on Clean Air'' (Oct. 3). The carrot dangled before the public is that if only it will consent to a relaxation in atmospheric goals, it might save $300 on each car it buys.

title: Dance; SOARES GROUP TO DANCE IN CHAPPAQUA
description: ON a clear October afternoon, Janis Ansley, Francine Landes and Linda Roberts skittered about the light-filled dance studio at Barnard College in Manhattan, under the scrutiny of Janet Soares, the choreographer and director of the Janet Soares Company. Strains of a Benny Goodman recording of ''Blue Skies'' filtered through the space, as the group worked on a dance/theater piece, also titled ''Blue Skies,'' a collaboration between the choreographer and the writer Shirley Kaplan.

title: Jersey Seeking Increase In Budgets for Colleges
description: The state Board of Higher Education has requested a budget increase of 12 percent, and it has also approved a Philadelphia university's request to operate an extension campus in South Jersey.

title: WHY THE FUROR ON PERSKIE BILL?
description: THE arguments presented by Philip Nanzetta (Opinion Page, Sept. 13) raised the question of Governor Byrne's motives for opposing the lengthy and fairly complex bill introduced by State Senator Steven P. Perskie to amend the Pinelands Protection Act.

title: A NEW BASE FOR DANCE TROUPE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE Princeton Ballet rehearsed in new quarters here last week for its performance next Saturday night at North Brunswick High School. A recently acquired 5,000-square-foot studio on the second floor of 103 Church Street not only marks the ballet's expansion into New Brunswick, but also serves as a turning point for the group, which is directed by 71-year-old Audree Estey.

title: FISHERMEN ANGRY OVER BASS RULING
description: THE decision this month by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation to continue the five-year ban on commercial fishing for striped bass in the Hudson River has left fisherman in the area angry and frustrated. ''We're bitter about it,'' said Donald Hardy, president of the New York State Commercial Fishermens Association. The association represents 70 commercial fishermen who fish the Hudson River from the George Washington Bridge to New Hamburg, N.Y. About 40 percent of the fishermen live in the county, mostly along the river between Verplanck and Ossining.

title: SUDAN, EGYPT AND LIBYA: A TRIANGLE THAT'S A MAZE
description: Rumors of impending attacks, inflammatory statements by Muammar el-Qaddafi and Gaafar al-Nimeiry, warnings by the Reagan Administration and Soviet charges of American interference have raised tensions between Libya and its eastern neighbors, Egypt and the Sudan. But Western diplomats in Cairo detect no signs of imminent military conflict. Most of them believe that an always dangerous situation has been whipped up artificially since the slaying of Anwar el-Sadat. Egyptian officials, whose armed forces would have to bear the brunt of any war against Libya, have stayed calm and largely silent. Privately they discount the rumors.

title: Officer Weds Mary Duffy
description: Mary Margaret Duffy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sean Anthony Duffy of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, Conn., to Lieut. John Gerald Griffith 3d, U.S.A. He is a son of Betty Griffith of Daytona Beach, Fla., and Dr. Griffith Jr. of Watertown, Conn. Msgr. Francis X. McGuire performed the ceremony.

title: GOLD VIEWS, REFINED
description: I N the last two Sundays, articles have appeared on these pages by opponents of a gold standard -William Nordhaus, the Yale economist (''Gold in the Year of the Quack,'' Oct. 4) and James E. Sinclair, the metals market pundit (''Why We Ought to Go Slow,'' Oct. 11). Both are deficient in understanding the kind of system being proposed by the supply-side advocates of gold, so much so that supply siders can even agree with much of their critiques.

title: Around the Nation; Men Still Hold Top Jobs, Government Study Says
description: The number of women in athletics and customarily male courses has soared since the 1972 passage of Federal laws barring sex bias in education, but men still hold the top jobs and salaries, a Government report said today.

title: CHICAGO CUTTING TRANSIT SERVICE TO AVERT SHUTDOWN
description: For two years, operating costs and other expenditures have outstripped the Chicago Transit Authority's ability to pay for its system of buses and elevated trains, and the city has been forced to do what would have been unthinkable a few years ago: make widespread cuts in service.

title: WARDE TOPS STAMFORD
description: The three-way tie for the lead in the Eastern Division of the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference continued yesterday as Warde, Staples and Trumbull remained unbeaten after five weeks of play.

title: Hedberg Lost for Season
description: Anders Hedberg, one of the Rangers' top forwards, underwent surgery on his left knee yesterday and is not expected to play again during the regular season.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: Politics; KEAN SEEKS TO STRESS ISSUES, NOT IMAGE
description: IN POLITICS, how a candidate says something can matter nearly as much as what he says. Awareness of that fact is one of the unspoken concerns in the campaign of Thomas H. Kean, the Republican candidate for Governor.

title: O'NEILL'S DELICATE BALANCE
description: HARTFORD IN his first nine and one-half months as Governor, William A. O'Neill has gone out of his way to make business his business. His predecessor, the late Ella T. Grasso, actively recruited new businesses to bring jobs to Connecticut, but Mr. O'Neill has expanded the role.

title: Airman Sues Missile Maker
description: An Air Force sergeant injured in the explosion last year of a Titan 2 missile at Damascus, Ark., has filed suit against the missile's manufacturer. Jeffery K. Kennedy and his wife, Margaret, of Portland, Maine, filed the suit yesterday in Federal court against the Martin-Marietta Corporation, asserting negligence in the construction of the missile and silo.

title: OCEANSIDE HALTS MASSAPEQUA STREAK
description: Massapequa High School, defending Nassau County Rutgers Cup champion and winner of 15 straight games dating back to 1979, was upset by Oceanside, 20-13, yesterday. The loss dropped the Chiefs out of first place in Conference I-A with a 2-1 record. They are 3-1 over all. The victory was the first for Oceanside this season after three losses.

title: CAPITALISM ALIVE AND WELL AT A HAVANA MARKET
description: Every Saturday afternoon several thousand people converge on Havana's Cathedral Square to enjoy the bustle of one of the few examples of free enterprise in Cuba, a thriving handicraft market.

title: REDISTRICTING REFERENDUM ENMESHED IN CONFUSION
description: TWO weeks before the election, there has been no public debate on a Suffolk County legislative reapportionment referendum that will be on the ballot and, indeed, the wording of the referendum is still being challenged.

title: Purdue 35, Northwestern 0
description: Scott Campbell threw three touchdown passes and Jimmy Smith ran for two touchdowns for Purdue.

title: Kazis Yakutis, Bartione With Spontaneity
description: The communicative impulse runs deep enough in some singers to compensate for shortcomings in technique and stylistic fluency. In the singing Oct. 10 of Kazis Yakutis, baritone, at Carnegie Recital Hall, what struck the ear as labored and occasionally uncontrolled vocalizing often registered more sympathetically on the emotions, redeemed in this way by Mr. Yakutis's winning spontaneity.

title: Antiques; FIRST BIG SHOW AT BYRNE ARENA
description: EAST RUTHERFORD THE Brendan Byrne Arena, the latest addition to the Meadowlands Sports Complex, will be the scene of its first antiques show next weekend, the International Antiques Fair.

title: Don't Hold Prisons Hostage
description: Governor Carey, Mayor Koch and other New York officials are campaigning hard for a $500-million bond issue to build and renovate more prison cells. They are drawing heavy fire from the sponsors of reform who argue that improving the management of criminal justice overall is the sounder response to overcrowded prisons.

title: Richard Williams Weds Peggy Benziger
description: Marguerite Marie Benziger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Joseph Benziger of Bronxville, N.Y., and Richard Bruce Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Williams of Bay Head, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Joseph Reynolds performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville.

title: Heidi Swan Has Bridal
description: Harriet Stone Swan, an associate director of underwriting for KQED-TV in San Francisco, was married yesterday in New Canaan, Conn., to William Albert Helvestine, a lawyer in San Francisco. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: YOU THINK THERE'LL BE A GOLD STANDARD?
description: Y OU have a hunch that the Reagan Administration will return to the gold standard. You might be in a tiny minority, but as an investor, you know that big rewards, not to mention big losses, can go to those who put their money where their hunches are. So, allowing for your stout-hearted disposition and your belief that the nation will switch to gold, where should you put your money?

title: Washington 56 Oregon State 17
description: SEATTLE (UPI) - Steven Pelluer passed for four touchdowns and 159 yards to help Washington improve its Pacific-10 Conference record to 3-1. All of Pelluer's scoring passes came in the first half. Washington running backs scored four more touchdowns in the second half.

title: T. J. Santone Fiance Of Christine Mulligan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Mulligan of Havertown, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Christine Margaret Mulligan, to Thomas James Santone, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Santone of Pittsburgh. The wedding is planned for Nov. 14.

title: ZABAR'S EXPANSION MOVING FORWARD
description: The owners of Zabar's, the gourmet delicatessen, said last week they were moving ahead in a $300,000 renovation project of two floors atop their establishment on Broadway near 80th Street.

title: The World; Choose Sides, Kania Demands In Polish Crisis
description: Polish attempts to satisfy Moscow's clamor to defang Solidarity and restore political order look increasingly untenable.

title: Speaking Personally; ARROGANCE AND SYMPATHY ON THE HITCHHIKING TRAIL
description: HE'S AN old man, a perennial on Route 9 whose thumb is ignored as casually and unconsciously as the speed limit. Destination? Shop-Rite.

title: SCHOLARS MEET TO CELEBRATE BIRTHDAY OF BEN FRANKLIN'S LIBRARY
description: Scholars have been converging on Philadelphia to help celebrate the 250th year of a storehouse of cultural treasures that is now little known but is perhaps as important to the founding of a nation, if Benjamin Franklin is to be believed, as any of the great institutions here in the birthplace of the American republic.

title: SALVATION ARMY OFFICERS MEET TO ELECT LEADER
description: In a grand Georgian mansion on the banks of the Thames, the 44 ranking officers of the Salvation Army from all over the world are meeting behind closed doors to elect a new leader.

title: Around the Nation; Another Oklahoma Aide Indicted in Kickbacks
description: Another Oklahoma county commissioner was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in an investigation of kickbacks that has touched nearly half the counties in the state.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: CRUISES FOR 1981-82
description: Here is the 1981-82 Directory of Cruise Ship Sailings, covering most of the globe and giving a wide variety of ship choices ranging from 1,800-passenger luxury cruise vessels to four-passenger freighters.

title: The Nation; New Orleans Bows on Police
description: In part because of the Reagan budget vise, New Orleans last week chose a mode of affirmative action -quotas for hiring and promoting black policemen and officers - that has been going out of style, particularly in the Reagan Administration.

title: THE RISE AND FALL OF A POET
description: THE COMPLETE POEMS By Anne Sexton. With a Foreword by Maxine Kumin. 622 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $20.00.

title: Oklahoma 45, Kansas 7
description: A freshman halfback, Steve Sewell, scored one touchdown and made a 62-yard run to set up another for Oklahoma. Sewell, who rushed for 106 yards on 10 carries in the first half but saw little action in the third quarter, made a 17-yard touchdown run on Oklahoma's first possession.

title: Television Week
description: Nazi Hunt ''Filming the program was extremely dangerous, especially in Paraguay.'' Bill Bemister, a British-born filmmaker living in Australia, was talking about his ''The Hunter and the Hunted,'' a documentary concerning the search for Nazi war criminals, which will be broadcast for the first time Wednesday at 8 P.M. on Channel 13. Mr. Bemister could offer no solid proof that he was actually in danger, but one can be certain that war criminals in hiding don't surrender their identity voluntarily.

title: Woman Found Dead in an Auto Was Sodomized and Strangled
description: A 20-year-old woman, whose nude body was discovered in an auto in the Woodhaven section of Queens on Friday, had been sodomized and strangled, the police said yesterday.

title: Nordiques 6, Maple Leafs 4
description: QUEBEC (UPI) - Miroslav Frycer scored the first three goals of his National Hockey League career to lead Quebec.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: ARIEL SHARON: IRON MAN AND FRAGILE PEACE
description: Amos Perlmutter is professor of political science at the American University in Washington, and editor of The Journal of Strategic Studies. His most recent book is ''Modern Authoritarianism,'' published by Yale University Press. By Amos Perlmutter The day had been one of those warm, quiet, autumn Sabbaths in Jerusalem but Prime Minister Menachem Begin had neither rested nor relaxed. As usual, he had read the Israeli newspapers, starting with those on the left wing and working his way to the right. Today, however, he found little pleasure in the ritual. It was past 5 o'clock on the evening of Oct. 4, 1980, and as on every Sabbath, Begin had not shaved. Through the window of the Prime Minister's residence, he could see the light beginning to fade on Jerusualem's posh Rehavia section. Finally, he picked up the phone and dialed a familiar number. ''Mon General,'' he said to the answering voice. ''I need your advice on a most important matter. You must come right away.''

title: THE SURVIVAL OF THE SOVIET DISSIDENT MOVEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE HOUSE IS KEEPING AWACS ALIVE BY ALL MEANS
description: Last week the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly to disapprove President Reagan's proposed sale of Airborne Warning and Command System planes to Saudi Arabia, and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted for the same veto resolution by a one-vote margin.

title: Music; 4 BANDS TO FORM IN OSSINING UNIT
description: SIX trombones? It could happen today at the Ossining Festival of Bands. ''We're trying something new,'' explained Naomi Lasher, secretary of the Ossining Music Parents Association. ''We've invited four neighborhood high schools - Pleasantville, Croton-Harmon, Horace Greeley in Chappaqua and Sleepy Hollow in Tarrytown - to participate in a special showcase. Each marching band will offer the presentation of colors and its own individual performances, after which we'll have a massing of all the units. At that point, we should have a whole field full of students, marching in uniform and hopefully playing in unison.''

title: Dining Out; IF IT HAD KEPT TO GERMAN CUISINE...
description: WITH a name like the Jolly Swagman, there is no question that this restaurant in Hicksville is Australian. Less obviously, it is also German. A good measure of Continental cooking is also included. Of the cuisines it offers, the German is the most successful. In fact, if the kitchen concentrated on only German cooking, eliminating the Australian dishes (or substantially improving them), the restaurant would clearly deserve one star.

title: Film View; TRUFFAUT'S ART IS TO FIND THE TRUTH IN THE TRITE
description: Artists - including Francois Truffaut, whose ''The Woman Next Door'' (''La Femme d'a Cote'') was one of the few unqualified hits of the just concluded 19th New York Film Festival -seldom are helpful in describing their work, and that may be all to the good. If they knew exactly what they were up to, they probably wouldn't create anything. They'd hang around their lofts or condos or island seats, invite the press in from time to time to issue neatly packaged pronouncements and enjoy a standing, once-a-year invitation to appear on the Dick Cavett Show to bring us up to date on what they'd be doing if, indeed, they ever felt themselves sufficiently mystified by life to do something.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART In every great city, and in every generation, there is an artist who makes things happen. Most likely he teaches, and eager young people come to him from all over.

title: 'GIN GAME' PLAYS ITS CARDS JUST RIGHT
description: PLAINFIELD ONE reason for the success of the New Jersey Theater Forum's presentation of ''The Gin Game'' is is that it grasps a perfect way to portray the elderly. Here, they are occasionally depicted as though they were teen-agers.

title: SYRACUSE FALLS, 41-16; WARNER STARS
description: Curt Warner set a school single-game rushing record of 256 yards today, including a 69-yard touchdown run, as undefeated Penn State powered its way to an impressive 41-16 victory over Syracuse in the Carrier Dome.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Stage View; SURRENDERING TO 'NICHOLAS NICKLEBY'
description: During the weeks before ''Nicholas Nickleby's'' successful invasion of Broadway there was considerable speculation about the initially slow ticket sale. What was it that was holding you, the playgoer, back? The $100 tab or the eight-and-a-half hours you were being asked to spend in the theater seat? Or put it this way. Which were you less willing to part with, your money or your life?

title: PANEL TO CUT NOMINEES FOR CITY U. CHANCELLOR
description: The search for a new chancellor of the City University of New York will move into its second stage during the next two weeks as the committee handling the task winnows a list of almost 200 names down to about 25 or 30.

title: GRAVES NAMED TO DESIGN ADDITION ON THE WHITNEY
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art has named Michael Graves, one of the most widely discussed architects in the profession, to design an extension of its building on Madison Avenue at East 75th Street. The extension would take up the rest of the blockfront, south from the building designed by Marcel Breuer, to 74th Street, although no construction dates have been set. The extension will replace small buildings containing shops.

title: BASQUE REBELS, ENDING LULL, KILL A POLICEMAN
description: Terrorists from E.T.A., the Basque separatist organization, this morning ended a cease-fire of almost three months by assassinating a Civil Guard corporal in the northern town of Santurce.

title: Topics; TRANSFORMATIONS; Murderous Thought
description: In 1930 the Pallas Athena of detective fiction, Dorothy Sayers, wrote a mystery in which murder was by muscarine, a lethal component of certain toadstools. The solution involved a problem in organic chemistry so dazzlingly elucidated by her that ''The Documents in the Case'' was highly praised at a recent convention of the American Chemical Society.

title: Janet O'Donnell, Writer, Wed to Charles Klaveness
description: Janet Miller O'Donnell, widow of Prof. Charles R. O'Donnell, who was chairman of the English department at Hofstra University, was married yesterday to Charles Armistead Klaveness. Canon John W. Davis performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church in Hempstead, L.I.

title: EXERCISING THE LIMITS OF AGE
description: I AM 58 years old, but feel better now than when I was 30. I play tennis twice a week in winter and four times a week in summer. On nontennis days I jog up to six miles and twice reached eight miles. At least once a week I enjoy a workout in the exercise room of the recreation center built by the Town of North Hempstead in New Hyde Park. I follow the exercises with sessions in the sauna, steam room and indoor swimming pool.

title: RECITAL: TRIBUTE TO ENESCU
description: This year marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of Georges Enesco, to use the French variant of his name by which he is best known in the West; Rumanians, among whom he counts as the foremost native composer, prefer George Enescu. And it was Rumanians who presented an unusual, not entirely successful but always interesting tribute to Enescu and his influence Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Dance View; PAUL TAYLOR'S INTRIGUING AMBIGUITIES
description: Paul Taylor is ''the Bach of choreographers,'' another modern-dance choreographer was saying the other day. What he meant, he explained, is that while Bach may not have been ''ahead of his time,'' he was great. In other words, he was Bach.

title: SCHOLARS SIGN ON WITH SEMIOTICS
description: When Pioneer 10 was launched from Earth in 1972, it bore a plaque meant for extra-terrestrial beings. Scientists at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration wanted the imperishable goldcoated aluminum plate to be decipherable to any scientist, of any physiognomy, living anywhere in the universe.

title: A Correction
description: The Environews column (The New York Times, New Jersey Edition, Sept. 27, 1981) contained two errors. Dominick Presto has not been indicted or charged with dumping toxic liquids. The column also misidentified the seller of property to Mr. Presto. Mr. Presto and Leif R. Sigmond purchased property at 411-443 Wilson Avenue in Newark in 1975 from Luminall Paints Inc. of Los Angeles, Calif.

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; Final Push For E.R.A.
description: Three states short and only nine months left to pass the equal rights amendment, necessity has become the mother of political savvy at the National Organization for Women. At its annual conference last week, NOW unveiled all the essentials of single-issue politics, from spot television commercials and computerized contributor lists to action teams ''getting out the vote'' and the money in targeted Congressional districts.

title: Michigan State 33 Wisconsin 14
description: Bryan Clark passed for three touchdowns, two to Darryl Turner, as Michigan State upset Wisconsin.

title: Guilty Conscience Scores in Vosburgh
description: Three weeks ago, Sonny Hine was training a horse he thought had a good chance for an Eclipse Award. Hine was disappointed when that colt, Amber Pass, wrenched an ankle at a race in the Meadowlands, subsequently finished a sore 11th in the Jockey Club Gold Cup and was retired. Hine's dream of Amber Pass being named the best handicap runner for 1981 were over; but yesterday, another horse in his stable virtually clinched a different championship.

title: STATE FUNERAL IS SET FOR TODAY
description: Israelis paid tribute today to Moshe Dayan, a hero of war and an advocate of peace. A state funeral was set for tomorrow at the settlement where he grew up.

title: Ruth Finch Wed to Architect
description: Ruth Persis Finch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cornell Kip Finch of New Canaan, Conn., was married at St. Mark's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Scott Randolph Simons, son of Justice and Mrs. Richard D. Simons of Rome, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alfred H. Whisler, assisted by the Rev. Ian Montgomery.

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: Vacation Dilemma To the Editor: Upon returning home from a delightful summer vacation in Truro, Mass., and thinking about where we will be next summer I find myself remembering Tevye's remark in ''Fiddler on the Roof'' when he tries to argue his daughter out of an unsuitable mate: ''A bird may love a fish, but where will they build a home?'' If he had asked where will they build a vacation home he would have pictured the yearly dilemma my husband and I face.

title: Lebanon Frees Suspect In U.S. Envoy's Slaying
description: A young Lebanese detained for nearly three years as a suspect in the 1976 killing of the American Ambassador to Lebanon was freed today, judicial sources said.

title: FOCUS OF CURRENT DRAMA: THE HUMAN AND THE DIVINE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- The Rev. Robert E. Lauder is professor of philosophy at Cathedral College in Douglaston, N.Y. By THE REV. ROBERT E. LAUDER

title: LINA TSALDARIS
description: Lina Tsaldaris, the first woman to become a minister in the Greek Government, died here tonight of a heart ailment. She was 94 years old. Mrs. Tsaldaris was the widow of Panagis Tsaldaris, who served as Prime Minister in the 1930's. She was named Welfare Minister in 1952 and later served as Greece's delegate to the United Nations.

title: KING CENTER BEGINS CAMPAIGN
description: Founders of an institute established to pursue the goals of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. have announced a three-year, $5 million fund-raising campaign to create an endowment and finance the operations of the complex, which is scheduled to begin full operation here next year.

title: DU PONT DEFENDS GENETIC SCREENING
description: The corporate medical director of E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company, appearing before a Congressional subcommittee, has defended the company's program of screening prospective black employees for certain genetic characteristics.

title: Conspiracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Borg Is Upset By Panatta
description: Adriano Panatta upset Bjorn Borg, 6-4, 6-4, in the semifinals of the $390,000 City of Naples tennis tournament today.

title: NORTH CAROLINA WINS TO STAY UNDEFEATED
description: Undefeated North Carolina, held scoreless in the first half, got three touchdowns behind the power running of Tyrone Anthony and defeated North Carolina State, 21-10, in an Atlantic Coast Conference matchup today before a record crowd of 56,200 at Carter-Finley Stadium.

title: Drying the Streets
description: ''Ridiculous'' and ''nonsense'' were favorite public retorts the day Mayor Koch signed into law a paradox: While it was perfectly legal to be drunk on the streets of New York, it no longer was legal to drink there.

title: HOW REGAN SEES THE BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON I N 1956, Donald T. Regan, just retired as a lieutenant colonel in the Marine Corps, went to work for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Beane as an account trainee. Last January, he resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of Merrill Lynch & Company, the holding company for the Merill Lynch family of financial services, to join the Reagan Administration as Secretary of the Treasury - his first job in government.

title: L.S.U. 24, Kentucky 10
description: The running back Eric Martin grabbed a punt in the end zone and ran it back 100 yards to lift L.S.U. The Tigers broke the game open early with a 3-yard touchdown run by Jude Hernandez, a 30-yard field goal by David Johnston and a 1-yard quarterback sneak by Alan Risher.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Hussein Starts Gulf Tour
description: King Hussein of Jordan left here today to start a Persian Gulf tour that is expected to take him to seven Arab countries, Information Ministry officials said. They said he would go to Kuwait, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Oman and might also visit Saudi Arabia and Iraq.

title: MEDIA MAVENS MOLD IMAGES IN N.J. CONTEST
description: THE campaigns of the two major party candidates for Governor of New Jersey took a decidedly personal turn last week. Having attacked each other's positions since summer, the Democrat, Representative James J. Florio, and the Republican, Thomas H. Kean, attacked each other.

title: Mark Santiccioli passed for five touchdowns to lead Half Hollow Hills West to a 35-14 victory over Islip yesterday in a League IV game.
description: Santiccioli completed 13 of 23 passes for 217 yards. Two of his touchdown passes, for 21 and 41 yards, were to Brad McLam. The other touchdown recipients were Howie Wolcott on a 7-yarder, Chris Goodwin on a 16-yarder and Mark Warshaw on a 39-yarder.

title: Pate Gains 4-Shot Lead
description: Jerry Pate shot a seven-under-par 65 today and took a four-stroke lead after three rounds of the $200,000 Pensacola Open golf tournament.

title: Cornell 14, Brown 9
description: Derrick Harmon ran 56 yards for a touchdown and Mark DiNunzio returned a kickoff 94 yards for another score as Cornell beat Brown for the first time since 1972.

title: Gardening; THE ADVANTAGE OF DWARF APPLE TREE
description: CRISP apples and tangy cider are as much a part of autumn as turning leaves, golden pumpkins and frosty mornings. Although apples are available year-round from commercial sources, there is increased interest in growing them in backyard orchards. Whether it is feasible depends on several factors.

title: Theater Mailbag; GLORIA GRAHAME
description: To the Editor:

title: 86-Proof Lollipops
description: Seeking to improve on the apothegm ''Candy is dandy but liquor is quicker,'' Alvin Kreske Jr. patented a lollipop that eliminated the choice.

title: Nurses Issue Strike Warning At a Massachusetts Hospital
description: Registered nurses and licensed practical nurses at Fairview Hospital say they will leave their jobs Oct. 31 if their demands for a 50 percent raise are not met.

title: Reymond Berney Offers Difficult Piano Program
description: Though flamboyance came more easily to him than warmth, Reymond Berney had enough of both Wednesday night to make his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall an engaging one. Mr. Berney's program of works by Marescotti, Beethoven, Falla, Schumann and Liszt was not the sort behind which a pianist with flaws in his technique wants to hide; fortunately, from the moment he addressed Marescotti's ''Fantasque,'' it was clear he had no need to.

title: Around the World; Pope Meets Patriarch Of Ethiopian Church
description: Pope John Paul II and Patriarch Abuna Tekle Haimanot of the Ethiopian Orthodox Union Church met today. It was the first meeting between the leaders of the two churches in modern times.

title: IRAN ACCUSED OF STEPPED UP ATTACKS ON BAHAIS
description: Leaders of the Bahai faith in the United States charge that what they say is an Iranian Government campaign of persecution aimed at destroying their religion in Iran has become more intense and widespread in the last few months.

title: Navy 25, Boston College 10
description: Eddie Meyers rushed for 147 yards and two touchdowns and Steve Fehr tied a school record with four field goals to lead Navy.

title: YOUTH UNEMPLOYMENT IN CITY CONTINUES TO TOP RATE IN U.S.
description: The unemployment of young people in New York City is continuing at a rate substantially higher than the national rate, according to a new report issued by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The report reflects the difficulties encountered by job-seeking youths with limited skills and education.

title: Long Island Guide; ON THE FLY
description: Kite making, an ancient and inventive art, has long played an important role in societies - from the decorative days in early China to more scientific use today. As a tribute to artists who have always been fascinated by the potential of the kite as either a painting surface or a form of airborne sculpture, the Islip Town Art Center and Gallery has mounted ''Art on a String - Kites,'' an exhibition of kites made by painters and sculptors.

title: Painful Eye Infections Spread Outside Florida
description: A painful eye disease introduced into the United States earlier this year has spread from Florida to North Carolina, the national Centers for Disease Control reports.

title: October 18, 1981
description: NONFICTION THE DISTORTION OF AMERICA. By Oscar Handlin. 16 ELIZABETH CADY STANTON/SUSAN B. ANTHONY: Correspondence, Writing, Speeches. Edited by Ellen Carol DuBois. 9 ELIZABETH TAYLOR: The Last Star. By Kitty Kelley.9 EQUALITY, THE THIRD WORLD, AND ECONOMIC DELUSION. By P.T. Bauer. 13 THE FORGOTTEN MEN. By Jesus Torbado and Manuel Leguineche. 18 THE GATE OF HEAVENLY PEACE: The Chinese and Their Revolution, 1895-1980. By Jonathan D. Spence. 7 GENES, MIND, AND CULTURE: The Coevolutionary Process. By Charles J. Lumsden and Edward O. Wilson. 12 INVESTING IN PEOPLE: The Economics of Population Quality. By Theodore W. Schultz. 13 JOE McCARTHY AND THE PRESS. By Edwin R. Bayley. 11 MAN, THE PROMISING PRIMATE: The Conditions of Human Evolution. By Peter J. Wilson. 12 REFLECTIONS ON THE CIVIL WAR. By Bruce Catton. Edited by John Leekley. 16 YELLOW RAIN: A Journey Through the Terror of Chemical Warfare. By Sterling Seagrave. 11 FICTION AND POETRY BED REST. By Rita Kashner. 15 THE COMPLETE POEMS. By Anne Sexton. 3 DIVIDE THE NIGHT. By Wessel Ebersohn. 33 A FLAG FOR SUNRISE. By Robert Stone. 1 GO WEST, INSPECTOR GHOTE. By H.R.F. Keating. 33 THE LAST AMBASSADOR. By Bernard Kalb and Marvin Kalb. 14 LESSONS. By Lee Zacharias. 14 THE LONG DARK NIGHT OF BARON SAMEDI.

title: ARMY CRUSHES PRINCETON, 34-0
description: Gerald Walker, a 5-foot-11-inch halfback who never played high school football, led Army to a 34-0 victory today over Princeton.

title: Dining Out; HARD TO FIND, BUT WORTH THE EFFORT
description: IT'S a small adventure just finding the Pump House Inn on a back road in Pennsylvania's Poconos, but the scenic journey and the engaging ambiance of the place make it all seem worthwhile.

title: AFTER-SCHOOL CENTERS GAINIGN ADHERENTS
description: NEW CANAAN THE jaunty yellow school bus pulls up under the oak and maple trees that shade a quiet junction not far from the center of town. With a loud bang, the door swings open and out tumble seven small children, squealing, shouting, giggling as they run toward a young man and woman waiting by the curb.

title: BARGES IRK NORTH HEMPSTEAD
description: NORTH HEMPSTEAD NORTH Hempstead Town officials have long been trying to persuade the United States Army Corps of Engineers to remove 70 rotting wooden barges clustered around the west shoreline of Hempstead Harbor. A fire, which last week destroyed an estimated 10 to 12 of the barges, may serve to underscore the urgency of the request.

title: CANDY LOOKS SWEETER
description: With Halloween less than two weeks off, marketing campaigns by leading candy manufacturers are well under way for the $4.6 billion industry's second most important holiday. And, while sales through July have shown only a modest improvement from year-ago levels, candy manufacturers have reason to be hopeful.

title: COURAGE OF CANCER PATIENT, 17, INSPIRES YOUNG BLOOD DONORS
description: Just before he died of cancer in Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan last April at the age of 17, John Huneke succeeded in winning an Eagle Scout badge by persuading at least 100 people to donate blood in his name to the hospital.

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; Collective Pens Raise the Sword
description: Like Groucho Marx, writers often seek identification by the company they won't keep. But no more writers ''as solitary heroes,'' declared novelist Toni Morrison.

title: Energy Seers
description: To the Business Editor: Not all of the old predictions were wrong, as you claim in ''Winning the War on Energy'' (Oct. 11).
