Environmentalists, and generally not business or government, saw that the gross national product and energy use did not have to rise in lockstep, and that the country could have a growing G.N.P. with roughly constant energy use.

title: TWO VIEWS OF PRISON BOND ACT AN OPPONENT DOUBTS GAIN, CITES OPTIONS
description: ON Election Day, New York State voters will have an opportunity to approve or reject a $500 million bond issue for prison construction and improvement that is being offered as a panacea against crime in the street and overcrowding in the prisons. It will appear as Proposition 1 on the top of the ballot and is officially known as the Security Through Development of Correctional Facilities Bond Act of 1981.

title: Q&A
description: Question:My husband and I would like to sail to Europe on a freighter. Where can we get information on what is available? - C.R., Big Lake, Minn. Answer:Pearl Hoffman (Pearl's Freighter Tips, 175 Great Neck Road, Great Neck, N.Y. 11021, 212-895-7646 or 516-487-8351) is a specialist in the travel field who provides background information on freighters as well as making the bookings.

title: INDUSTRY TACKLING FOREIGN INROADS
description: ''We're trying to make a better product, and I think we're putting out a better product ...'' A Ford assembly-plant worker in a recent television commercial.

title: THE LONG REVOLUTION
description: THE GATE OF HEAVENLY PEACE The Chinese and Their Revolution, 1895-1980. By Jonathan D. Spence. Illustrated. 465 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $19.95.

title: Randi Loftsgaarden, Lawyer, Is Bride
description: Randi T. Loftsgaarden, a vice president and lawyer with the J. Walter Thompson Company, was married at the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday to James Hobson Season, who is a director and assistant treasurer of the De Lorean Motor Company and vice president-finance of the De Lorean Manufacturing Company. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: Price of Tin Increased At International Parley
description: The world's major tin producing and consuming nations agreed today on a price increase of nearly 7 percent after three days of bargaining, delegates at a meeting of the International Tin Council here said.

title: DelBello-Pisani Debates Open to Public
description: The following are debates, open to the public, between the candidates for county executive: the incumbent Democrat, Alfred B. DelBello, and his Republican challenger, State Senator Joseph R. Pisani. For further details, call @DelBello Headquarters at 997-9088 or Pisani Headquarters at 428-7041. Today 4 P.M. Town Hall tes forum Tomorrow 8 P.M. gh School n Bedford Tuesday 8:30 P.M. rs V.F.W. tes night Wednesday 1:30 P.M. te Plains idgeway; tes forum Wednesday 8 P.M. port Club Rochelle Thursday 7:30 P.M. uditorium an Ave., Yonkers Oct. 25 7 P.M. al Church cote Road Oct. 25 7 P.M. IP (1310) Oct. 26 8:30 P.M. ew Center bbs Ferry Oct. 27 0:30 A.M. y College e Theater Oct. 28 10 A.M. OX (1460) Oct. 29 9:45 P.M. Broadway sh Center Nov. 1 10 A.M. stchester us Ave., t. Vernon Nov. 2 9 P.M. AS (1230)

title: TELEVISION PORNOGRAPHY
description: Ours is a sight-oriented society, where television reigns. Television has made us - virtually all - voyeurs, of sorts. Is it any wonder, then, that we have ''The TV Pornography Boom''? JULIO C. NUNEZ

title: Photographer-Author Wins $10,000 Grant
description: A photographer for Magnum Photos has won the 1981 W. Eugene Smith grant for humanistic photography. The photographer, 37-year-old Eugene Richards of Dorchester, Mass., was awarded a $10,000 grant by the W. Eugene Smith Memorial Fund Inc. The fund honors Mr. Smith, a photographer acclaimed for his coverage of World War II.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS U.S. SHOULD NOT WAVER IN BACKING SAUDIS
description: President Reagan, elaborating on his pledge that the United States would not permit Saudi Arabia to become another Iran, says he will not repeat mistakes that he asserts the Carter Administration made in allowing Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi to fall in Iran.

title: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC Traveling shows that featured three or four popular blues singers crisscrossed the United States back in the 40's and 50's, stopping to play for black audiences in auditoriums, social halls, and large night clubs, in big cities and small towns. Those days are long gone, but the Savoy, 141 West 44th Street, is offering a blues show that could momentarily bring them back on Thursday evening, beginning at 9 P.M. The headliner is Muddy Waters, the most regal of blues singers and a powerful electric guitarist.

title: Sabres 4, Capitals 2
description: Yvon Lambert scored his first two goals of the season, both on power plays and led Buffalo. It was Washington's fourth straight loss.

title: HOW CLIFFORD ODETS SPENT HIS LAST, DESPERATE DAYS Sing'
description: Amajor voice in American theater in the 1930's was that of Clifford Odets, author of such plays as ''Waiting for Lefty,'' ''Awake and Sing!,'' ''Paradise Lost'' and ''Golden Boy.'' Odets died in Hollywood in 1963 after a long period of steadily declining creativity. This account of his final days is excerpted from the first volume of ''Clifford Odets: American Playwright,'' a biography by Margaret Brenman-Gibson, to be published next month by Atheneum. By MARGARET BRENMAN-GIBSON

title: WOMEN COMPLAIN OF BIAS ON JOBS AT THE U.N.
description: Mariana Scardino spoke three languages fluently and had the equivalent of a master's degree from her native Argentina. But when she went to work for the United Nations in 1970, she was placed in a clerical job.

title: Critics' Choices
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC It would be futile to claim that the Brooklyn Philharmonia is an outer-borough equivalent of the New York Philharmonic. Yet the orchestra, which opens its season Friday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with repeats Saturday and next Sunday, still has much to recommend it.

title: NAME A THREE-LETTER WORD THAT MEANS BE NICE TO ARAFAT
description: Touring the Far East last week, Yasir Arafat won impressive diplomatic gains for the Palestine Liberation Organization. Before visiting Japan, he was warmly received in Peking, Pyongyang and Hanoi. The New China News Agency called on the United States to press Israel to make concessions toward bringing the Palestinians into a peace settlement in the Middle East. ''Now it is up to Israel to make the next move,'' the Chinese Government agency said.

title: WHEN WASHINGTON PINCHES, DADE COUNTY QUICKLY FEELS PAIN
description: The Metropolitan-Dade County Commission is responsible for social programs within the Miami city limits as well as without. The nine-member board also is responsible to one of the more vocal constituencies in America - property tax payers who seem to find it galling to watch their money going to assist unwanted refugees from the Caribbean.

title: A TALK WITH ROBERT STONE
description: FOR the past 10 years Robert Stone has lived with his wife and two children in northern Massachusetts, where he moved after a stint of teaching at Harvard. Now that the children have grown up and are preparing to leave home, he and his wife are considering a move themselves. He leads a rigorously healthy life with disciplined work habits. He's out in the woods walking with his dog as soon as it gets light. After drinking a quantity of tea, he starts work and goes as long as he can. His wife is the first to read his work in manuscript, and he consults her if a decision of style is too close to call; except for his editor and his agent, she is his only reader of work in progress.

title: Woes at Triumph Endanger Models
description: MIKE COOK shook his head. ''It's something that just shouldn't have happened,'' he said. ''I think we have about 100 of them left, and there won't be any more after they're gone.''

title: Westchester Guide; by Eleanor Charles; MEETING ON ADOLESCENTS
description: A conference on ''The Dispirited Adolescent: Normal and Abnormal Bounds,'' will take place from 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Saturday under the aegis of the Westchester-Putnam-Rockland Personnel and Guidance Association, in conjunction with the Scarsdale Congregational Church, the Village of Scarsdale, Educage, the Cage Teen Center and the Scarsdale Clergy Club.

title: Antiques; A GIANT AUCTION OF DOLLS
description: Dolls. Big ones, small ones, fat and skinny. Dolls that smile, cry, pout, nod, sing, whistle and blink. Dolls that swim, shake a tambourine, open a flower basket, wash laundry and walk. Dolls in ballgowns, kimonas, sailor suits, knitted capes, pinafores, silks, laces, velvets, a wedding gown, plumed hat, fur muff, bonnets, bloomers and mufflers.

title: WHERE THE OLD WEST LIVES ON
description: WILLIAM K. STEVENS is Houston bureau chief of The New York Times. By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

title: Miss Keith Has Bridal
description: Jennifer Ann Keith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Russel Keith of Greenwich, Conn., and John's Island, Fla., was married yesterday to Maximilian Otto Urbahn 3d, son of Mr. Urbahn Jr. of Stonington, Conn., and Mrs. James L. Simmons of New York and Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich by the Rev. Edward A. M. Cobden Jr. and the Rev. Thomas P. Guinan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: SOO LINE RR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AN OPERA ERA ENDS IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Walter Frisch is a freelance writer living in the San Francisco area. By WALTER FRISCH SAN FRANCISCO

title: Ideas & Trends in summary
description: In awarding the Nobel Prize for Literature, the Swedish Academy has taught the world to expect the unexpected; but last week, the academy outdid itself. Elias Canetti, a Bulgarian-born son of Sephardic Jews who studied in Switzerland, lives in England and writes in German, has exercised a fascination over some critics and admirers as an intensely intellectual, isolate writer in the Central European tradition.

title: Long Island Journal
description: FOR those interested in viewing denizens of the deep, members of the New York Islanders and an eight-foot replica of the Stanley Cup at the same time, all of the above will be on display today in Long Island's first Pride Parade, starting at 1 P.M. at Heckscher State Park in East Islip. Sponsors hope that 6,000 marchers, 200 bands and professionally designed floats will help to make this the biggest parade ever held on Long Island.

title: Colgate 30, Lafayette 0
description: Tom McChesney ran for 117 yards and two touchdowns and Tom Rogers set a Colgate record for pass receptions in a career. Rogers caught six passes to give him 93 for his career.

title: MOSHE DAYAN AND THE QUEST FOR PEACE
description: The Middle East lost another champion of war and peace last week, Moshe Dayan. His death of a heart ailment at age 66 came at a time of uncertainty over whether the peace he helped forge with Egypt would survive.

title: Heidi Bloom Is Married
description: Heidi Bloom, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Bloom of Highland Park, N.J., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Randall Rene Knopp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Knopp of New New York.

title: BIG MACS FOR LEO BURNETT
description: The Leo Burnett Company of Chicago was the proud winner last week of the coveted $75 million McDonald's account for national advertising. The Chicago office of Needham, Harper & Steers, which held the account for over 11 years, and apparently had no inkling that anything was afoot, was shocked.

title: Around the World; Agriculture Secretary Has Talks in China
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block of the United States held talks with Chinese officials in Peking today on expanding trade in farm and forestry products, the New China News Agency reported.

title: Recordings; CONCERT OUTCASTS, SIBELIUS AND GRIEG ARE DISK FAVORITES
description: The New York City Opera's revival of ''Song of Norway'' may have suggested a renewed interest in Northern European late-Romantic nationalist composers. But the sad fact remains that the music of Edvard Grieg and Jean Sibelius, to name the two best known of such composers, is hardly central to the repertory these days. The concert repertory, that is; records of their music still pour forth, as attested by three recent digitally recorded symphonic releases.

title: REID CAPTURES 5,000 METERS
description: Bob Reid, a senior at Uniondale High School, clocked 15 minutes 49.5 seconds over the 5,000-meter course to win the first of two boys' varsity races in the Golden Apple Cross-Country Invitational yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

title: New York Times Magazine October 18, 1981
description: William Safire 16 On Language The Beauty Part Russell Baker 29 Sunday Observer Ghost Story Andrew Silk 33 The Struggle of Andrew Silk: A Young Man Confronts Cancer Amos Perlmutter 41 Ariel Sharon: Iron Man and Fragile Peace Andy Grundberg 42 Another Side of Rauschenberg John Egerton 56 Boom or Bust in the Hollows of Appalachia Big government failed to win its 20-year war on poverty in Kentucky's Martin County. Can big business under President Reagan do any better? Joe Goldberg 82 To Be Young and a Concert Pianist Fran R. Schumer 96 A Question of Sex Bias at Harvard Helen Markel 118 The Bettmann Behind the Archives Mary Russell 122 Fashion A Spring of Change in Paris Dona Guimaraes 128 Food To Market, to Market 132 Puzzles Answers, Page 141 142 Letters Cover:Photograph by Sara Krulwich/The New York Times Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: Headliners; Inquiry Benches Judge
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation told it to the judge last week, but not in court. Federal District Court Judge Alcee Hastings was informed by agents that William A. Borders Jr., a prominent Washington lawyer, had implicated him in a bribery scheme and that a grand jury would soon be called to weigh the evidence.

title: William E. Sauro New Cars for Hudson Line Commuters
description: Ten new commuter rail cars costing more than $1 million each entered service yesterday on Conrail's Hudson line.

title: Marketing The President
description: In his article ''Marketing the President'' (Sept. 13), Sidney Blumenthal cites an instance of deliberate manipulation of the news by the Reagan Administration. According to Mr. Blumenthal, President Reagan's political strategists, seeing a chance to enhance his popularity by playing on the national-security theme, started an intensive campaign of portraying the situation in El Salvador as a ''crucial confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union.''

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 5 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with the Berrys, an eccentric family that sets up house in unlikely hotels, here and abroad. 2 2 10 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 3 5 17 THE CARDINAL SINS, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Bernard Geis, $12.95.) The triumphs and tragedies of two Chicago boys as priests in the Catholic Church. 4 4 12 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Chief of Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York. 5 3 24 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 6 7 8 THE LAST DAYS OF AMERICA, by Paul Erdman. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) International intrigue and dirty financial wheeling-and-dealing in 1985. 7 6 28 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.)

title: Music; MUSIC COMING UP: QUALITY AND VARIETY
description: IF by chance you have not yet been convinced of the extraordinary vitality, quality and diversity of music on the Connecticut scene, take a look at some of the activities just ahead.

title: STUDY SUGGESTS ENDING TEEN-AGE DRIVER STUDY
description: A report by an insurance research group suggests that high school driver education programs be abolished and that teen-agers be allowed to drive only in the daytime as a means of saving lives.

title: The Region; Yes, Beggars Can Be Choosers
description: A Federal judge ruled last week that just because a community got Federal aid for sewers, roads and economic development did not mean it couldn't pull out of a program to provide housing for poor and moderate income families.

title: POLISH PARTY MEETING IS CRITICAL OF LEADERSHIP
description: Members of the Central Committee criticized Poland's Communist leadership today, many of them calling for stronger action to overcome the economic crisis and a tougher line against the Solidarity union.

title: About Westchester; by Lynne Ames
description: NEW ROCHELLE WITH its old-fashioned brick facade, ornate cornices and woodframed windows, the building at 14 Lawton Street here appears from the outside to be exactly what it is, a structure that dates from the 1890's. It is surprising, then, to step through a door and suddenly find the most contemporary kitchen - an airy, white-walled space equipped with high-tech ranges, grills and microwave ovens.

title: The World; Do Greeks Want A New Agenda?
description: A pivotal election today could take Greece out of NATO and the Common Market, but it will probably be decided on much more parochial grounds.

title: MUSIC AND DANCE: THE ANDES FESTIVAL
description: South America is not only a geographically big continent, it is also an artistically rich continent that remains all too little known by many North Americans. Therefore the South American and Andes Festival of music and dance that Philip Parkas and Erwin Frankel presented Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall was both welcome and frustrating: welcome because it did offer glimpses of South American folk culture, frustrating because it was little more than a collection of miscellaneous bits and pieces. Fortunately, however, some talented artists were on hand to provide samples of their work.

title: Piano-Cello Duo Mixes Standard and Modern
description: In their New York debut as a duo last Sunday night, Perfecto Garcia Chornet, pianist, and Mar,cal Cervera, cellist, chose to devote the first half of their Carnegie Recital Hall program to the standard repertory and the second to less conventional fare. The mix proved reasonably engaging, though it hardly changed one's perspective on the music of either half.

title: Ethiopians Out of Race
description: Ethiopia has withdrawn its runners from next Sunday's New York City Marathon to protest the recent appearance of the South African national rugby team, the Springboks, in the United States.

title: FLORIO RAISES ANTE IN THE BATTLE OF ADS
description: A dignified, gray-haired woman sits in a large wingbacked leather chair and speaks with careful articulation about the Republican Party. A viewer who does not look closely at this television commercial might mistake the woman for Representative Millicent Fenwick, the Republican from New Jersey. But the actress who looks and sounds so much like Representative Fenwick is urging New Jerseyans to vote Democratic this year because ''the Republicans fooled me once; nobody fools me twice.''

title: A THIRD OF NEW YORK BIRTHS IN '80 WERE TO THE UNMARRIED
description: More then one-third of the almost 100,000 infants born to New York City residents last year were born to unwed mothers, according to statistics released by the Department of Health.

title: Navy League Urges a Repeal Of Ban on Women in Combat
description: Congress should re-evaluate its ban on women in combat because the idea that they are incapabale is no longer valid, according to John Rau, president of the Navy League.

title: INCEST: SHOULD OFFENDERS BE JAILED?
description: ''WHEN I was old enough to realize that what was going on wasn't normal,'' said Cindy, who had been sexually abused by her alcoholic father from the age of 4, ''I felt like it was my fault. There wasn't anybody I could talk to about it. I tried running away, got into drugs, promiscuity, attempted suicide many times.''

title: Black Marble Road
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; It's Every Crop For Itself as Coalition Splits
description: The once-unbeatable farm-state coalition, a little wobbly in the Senate a few weeks ago, came completely unraveled last week in the House. By large margins, the representatives killed a sugar-price support program, rejecting producers' claims that they needed yet another break because they were about to go broke, and did away with 35-year-old restrictions on peanut planting and marketing.

title: I.R.A. BOMB WOUNDS A BRITISH GENERAL
description: The commandant of the Royal Marines, Lieut. Gen. Sir Steuart Pringle, was severely wounded today when a bomb went off in his car as he drove from his home in southeast London. The Irish Republican Army said later that it was responsible for the attack, the organization's second in a week here.

title: Ship Crashes Into a 2d At Port Elizabeth Pier
description: A docked cargo ship hit another vessel last night, causing an estimated $1 million damage. A port official said the accident had probably been caused by a crewman who mistakenly put the ship into gear.

title: STATEWIDE PRESECUTOR OF CORRUPTION IS SOUGHT
description: A special committee of the New York State Bar Association recommends the establishment of a prosecutor to investigate corruption in the state's criminal and civil justice systems.

title: Art; 3 CONNECTICUT ABSTRACTIONISTS WITH ROOTS IN THE 30'S
description: STAMFORD WORKS by Ceymour Fogel, Rhys Caparn and the late Louis Schanker comprise the show now running at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center under the title ''Three Connecticut Abstractionists'' (through Dec. 6). All achieved reputations early in their careers but fell back later on, except for Mr. Fogel, who had a solo in New York a year or so ago and who was included in the recent drawing show at the Aldrich Museum.

title: THE IRISH CATHOLIC CHURCH IS SORELY TRIED BY ULSTER
description: When the long hunger strike here finally collapsed, it was significant that Irish Republican Army prisoners blamed not Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher or the hated British Army, but the Roman Catholic Church - the dominant force in the lives of the people the I.R.A. says it is fighting for.

title: ART: THE NEW JAPANESE FASCINATION WITH GLASS
description: Japan is a nation prone to earthquakes. Every day there are minute tremblings in this archipelago. Every half-century or less, a mammoth earthquake rips into the nation with catastrophic force.

title: NEW LAW AFFECTS UTILITIES AND USERS
description: WHEN residential electrical bills were $28 a month, customers didn't complain, but now that they are $60 a month - and in some cases as much as $700 a month - an increasing number of customers are falling behind in their payments and are consulting consumer-affairs agencies for help in meeting them.

title: BOOM OR BUST IN THE HOLLOWS OF APPALACHIA
description: John Egerton is a journalist and author living in Nashville and is currently at work on ''Generations,'' a book about a Kentucky family. By John Egerton When President Lyndon B. Johnson flew into the mountains of Appalachia in the spring of 1964 to declare war on poverty in the United States, one of his stops was Martin County, Ky., where the typical citizen was said to be an unemployed white Republican. Martin County then vied with a handful of jurisdictions scattered across the country for the dubious distinction of being the poorest county in the richest nation on earth.

title: U.C.L.A. 17 Washington State 17
description: U.C.L.A. took advantage of a fourth-quarter fumble to score on a 6-yard run by Frank Cephous and held on for the tie in a Pacific-10 Conference game.

title: Crafts; by Patricia Malarcher
description: IN TAPESTRIES currently on view at the Newark Museum, Nancy Hoffman has translated personal impressions of nature into a traditional weaving idiom.

title: A 'Rent-a-Judge' Plan For Civil Suits Assailed
description: The ''rent-a-judge'' plan that allows litigants in California to hire retired judges to hear civil suits has been criticized by the state's Chief Justice, Rose Bird, as a ''judicial system for the wealthy.''

title: Paperback Talk
description: Looking good. What ''season'' are you? A ''summer,'' like Princess Grace and Candice Bergen? A ''winter,'' like Elizabeth Taylor and Jacqueline Onassis? An ''autumn'' like Katharine Hepburn or a ''spring'' like Zsa Zsa Gabor? Your season is determined by the coloring of your skin, hair and eyes and therefore is an invaluable key to the way you can dress most effectively.

title: Politics; RACE FOLLOWING FLORIO LINE
description: THERE are only two weeks left in the campaign for Governor and, judging by what has happened to date, it appears that the Democratic candidate, Representative James J. Florio, has been able to control the shape of the race - with some help from his Republican opponent, Thomas H. Kean.

title: DEMOCRATIC OFFICIALS ASSAIL KOCH ON TREATMENT OF MINORITIES
description: Led by Representative Charles B. Rangel, black officials at a Democratic Party conference here have bitterly attacked Mayor Koch, accusing him of abandoning minority groups in his attempt to recapture his co-called ''center of American politics.''

title: PHILLIPS ANDOVER PLAYS TIE
description: A budget crunch has forced Phillips Andover to end its long series with Lawrenceville, and the final game will long be remembered by those who were on hand yesterday at Andover's field. The teams, which started facing each other in 1895, played to an 18-18 tie when Lawrenceville scored a touchdown and the 2-point conversion with 21 seconds left in the game.

title: Anthony Bliss And the Met
description: Bernard Holland's article on Anthony Bliss might have mentioned his dedication to public education in New York City (''Anthony Bliss: Culture and Commerce at the Met,'' Sept. 20).

title: The Buffalo Chicken-Wing Run
description: Thank you, Craig Claiborne, for disclosing that delectable chicken-wing recipe (''Winging It in Buffalo,'' with Pierre Franey, Aug. 30). When I moved to Buffalo, I was introduced to this dish, which, needless to say, goes great with beer. After moving back to northern New York, I developed a chicken-wing craving, which was satisfied only by too infrequent (eight-hour) trips to Buffalo, on a pretense of visiting friends and relatives. Now, with this recipe, my grandmother will be seeing less of me! LUCIA DASHNAW, West Chazy, N.Y.

title: THERE'S ENERGY IN COAL
description: Although coal production was expected to rebound strongly after this year's 72-day strike by the United Mine Workers, the duration of the recovery has surprised some analysts.

title: Tatekawa Brothers Are Twin Assets In School Football
description: To figure the assets of the George Washington High School football team you have to start with the $1.5 million Astroturf field that was put down a few years ago, and then you have to move quickly to the Tatekawa brothers.

title: Fashion Preview; A SPRING OF CHANGE IN PARIS
description: Because of recent shifts in the French Government and economy, the general mood in Paris is one of uncertainty, and many industry observers have been convinced that this state of mind will begin to be reflected in Paris fashion with the spring 1982 ready-to-wear collections that will be unveiled this week.

title: Politics; HOUSE RACE ACTIVATES G.O.P.
description: HARTFORD THE Republican state chairman, Ralph E. Capecelatro, has been saying for some time that the party's improved health in Connecticut is demonstrated by the fact that it is finding it easier to attract candidates to run for major offices.

title: DELBELLO, PISANI FACE TO FACE ON THE ISSUES
description: THE political debate, a time-honored campaign device, seems to have come into its own this year in the race for county executive. Alfred B. DelBello, the two-term Democratic incumbent, and his Republican challenger, State Senator Joseph R. Pisani, have met nearly a dozen times so far and plan 20 more confrontations before Nov. 3.

title: NOVOTEL PLANS BROADWAY HOTEL ON OFFICES
description: Novotel, a Paris-based chain, plans to begin construction early next year of a 480-room hotel over an existing office building on the west side of Broadway between 51st and 52d Streets, according to the executive vice president of Novotel's American operation.

title: Sound; NEW ADVANCES IN CASSETTE RECORDERS
description: Apart from its technical aspects and practical uses, sound recording somehow seems touched by magic. In this it is unlike other forms of ''recording,'' such as still photography. Photography freezes the moment. Sound recording, by contrast, entails no arrest. It preserves breath and motion - the living line of melody - and thereby does its magic trick: transmuting the ephemeral event, singular and fleeting, into repeatable permanence.

title: WHAT'S NEW FOR SEAGOING TRAVELERS
description: VERNON KIDD is a New York actor and writer. By VERNON KIDD

title: TO BE YOUNG AND A CONCERT PIANIST
description: Joe Goldberg, a screenwriter and novelist, writes frequently on music. By Joe Goldberg here are too many pianists,'' says the French pianist Michel Beroff, who at the age of 31 has had ample opportunity to assess the competition. The general public, too, has become keenly aware of the increasing numbers of up-and-coming pianists as international competitions - and the publicity attending them -multiply. We are surrounded by more flying fingers than ever before, and today's younger pianist routinely operates on a general level of expertise that would have been unthinkable a generation ago. Virtuosity is what you need to get into the game, and a very tough game it is. Jacques Leiser, who has managed the careers of Sviatoslav Richter and Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli, and currently performs that service for Jean-Philippe Collard, said recently, and dismissively, of that week's young hotshot piano whiz, ''He has the fingers, but these days, who hasn't?''

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE shooting of Dr. Herman Tarnower, as described by Jean S. Harris during her three-month murder trial, was an ''accident,'' despite the fact that five shots were fired. It was a description that the jury did not accept, and she was convicted of intentionally killing him.

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: Winning the Revolution To the Editor: ''Yorktown: Where the Revolution Was Won'' (Travel Section, Sept. 6) is an inaccurate title. Actually, the Revolution was won a year earlier in the Carolinas.

title: Miss Black Is the Bride Of a Lawyer
description: Suzanne Black, director of corporate giving in the corporateaffairs department at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, was married at St. James Episcopal Church yesterday to John James O'Toole 3d, a lawyer with Manufacturers Hanover Trust. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Hays Rockwell, assisted by the Rev. Stanley Johnson, a chaplain at the University of Pennsylvania and minister of the Siasconset (Mass.) Chapel.

title: Heavy Rains Continue In Areas of Oklahoma
description: Thunderstorms brought 2 to 4 more inches of rain to eastern Oklahoma yesterday, pounding some areas with hail and high winds and threatening to flood areas already rain-soaked.

title: 9 MONTHS INTO TERM, REAGAN HAS AIR OF A LEADER AT EASE IN THE OVAL
description: OFFICE By SAUL PETT The Associated Press

title: SUFFOLK EXECUTIVE CUTS BUDGET BUT WILL THE BUDGET STAY CUT?
description: Experts may be divided on the effect of Federal spending cuts on the nation's economy, but there isn't much doubt about what they will do to local governments. The proposed 1982 budget for Suffolk County, which was unveiled only days before President Reagan's budget cuts began to take effect, is a case in point.

title: U.S. MERCHANT MARINERS LOSE TO WAGNER, 31-21
description: Sam Oncea threw for three touchdowns and set a school record by passing for 272 yards on 25 completions in 43 attempts yesterday, but his United States Merchant Marine Academy team lost, 31-21, to Wagner at Tomb Memorial Field, Kings Point, L.I. The Mariners have lost 18 games in a row, six this season, stretching back to 1979.

title: Vehicle to Honor Bradley
description: The Army's new infantry fighting vehicle will be named for the late General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, the Army has announced. The armored vehicle, which carries a nine-member squad, can shoot while in motion. General Bradley, a World War II leader in Europe and former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, died this year.

title: PLOTTING REVOLUTION, 1781
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON accepted the surrender of Lieut. Gen. Charles Cornwallis and his force of 7,247 men 200 years ago tomorrow, but the planning that led to that victory took place six months earlier, at Webb House in Wethersfield.

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: ''Pseudo-Gourmet'' To the Editor: This past summer we took a house in Vermont for a month with the specific goal of ''inn hunting.'' We ate lunch and dinner out every day, and were astounded at the proliferation of socalled ''gourmet'' restaurants, all within a radius of 25 miles of Londonderry.

title: A Special Insight Into English Schools
description: Reading ''Students Abroad: Experience as Vast as Globe'' (Oct. 4), I was reminded of an unforgettable and invaluable course that 14 women and I experienced in Dorking, England approximately eight years ago, sponsored by the College of New Rochelle. We were all teachers seeking master's credits.

title: Ormandy Is Recovering
description: Eugene Ormandy, the 82-year-old conductor laureate of the Philadelphia Orchestra, was reported in good condition today at Pennsylvania Hopsital. Tests showed the high fever that sent Mr. Ormandy to the hospital yesterday resulted from a pulmonary embolism, a blood clot in the lung, said Delores Ziff, a hospital spokesman. ''He is feeling infinitely better,'' she said, adding that the fever had subsided.

title: Reading and Writing
description: While quite a few books about the Bloomsbury writers have appeared in the past several years, there seems still to be a hunger for them. At the age of 80, Frances Partridge has just brought out another installment with ''Love in Bloomsbury.'' And we are reading it as if we too were just a little in love with this small group of English writers who have lived out an ideal for us, a dream of beauty combined with culture rather than with fashion.

title: NJ TRANSIT FACING NEW FISCAL WOES
description: SEVERAL recent developments in Washington have forced New Jersey transit officials to scuttle their plans once again and devise new methods for handling fiscal and operational uncertainties. The latest action in what has become a steady whittling-down of Federal operating subsidies to mass-transit systems around the country was the call by President Reagan for additional budget cuts of 12 percent across the board to offset a growing Federal deficit.

title: Time for a 'Mid-Course Correction'
description: It does not matter whether Pat Moynihan or his former baby sitter, David Stockman, invented the phrase. When the New York Senator and White House budget director agree on anything these days, attention should be paid. They agree that nine months after an impressive takeoff, the Reagan Administration needs a major ''mid-course correction.'' It certainly does.

title: Suzette Thebault Becomes a Bride
description: Suzette M. Thebault, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis P. Thebault of New Vernon, N.J., was there married yesterday to William Walter Negley, son of Nancy Brown Negley of San Antonio and the late Alfred Walter Negley.

title: ANTHONY BLISS AND THE MET
description: Bernard Holland's article contains an error I would like to correct.

title: TOUR BUSES FOR MYSTIC OPPOSED BY TOWNS
description: MYSTIC THIS seaport, which is the state's No. 1 tourist attraction, is resisting the idea of allowing sightseeing tour buses through its historic, narrow streets.

title: SCHOOL, TOWN SETTLE TAX ISSUE
description: SALISBURY THE Hotchkiss School's decision earlier this month to discontinue leasing part of its 480-acre campus for use as a summer tennis camp has prompted Salisbury officials to drop their effort to place the facilities on the town tax rolls.

title: Miss DeCarvalho, Ashbel Wall 2d, Lawyer, Married
description: Grace Episcopal Church in Providence, R.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Maria Elena DeCarvalho, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Alves DeCarvalho of Pawtucket, R.I. to Ashbel Tingley Wall 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Winthrop Wall of Providence. The Rev. Constance Chandler-Ward, chaplain of Wellesley College, performed the ceremony.

title: AT THE STROKE OF MIDNIGHT-POOF!- BACK TO REALITY
description: WHAT do Cinderella and a housewife with young children have in common? At first glance, the question almost seems absurd. Actually, I hadn't thought along these lines either until a few months ago, when I read the tale again for my daughters, aged 3 and 6. All of a sudden, I could see a remarkable resemblance - of course, with a couple of modifications.

title: A TALE OF FACADES
description: VOICES IN THE GARDEN By Dirk BOgarde. 340 pp. New York. Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: TIGHT GRIP ON A RICH EMPIRE
description: H E owns Crown Publishers, which has had such recent best-selling novels as ''Princess Daisy,'' ''Clan of the Cave Bear'' and ''The Spike.'' He owns Clarkson N. Potter, publisher of the current bestsellers ''101 Uses for a Dead Cat'' and ''How to Make Love to a Man.'' He owns the Outlet Book Company, the undisputed giant of the book remaindering industry. He owns Publishers Central Bureau, the big direct mail company, the Living Language record courses, a book club and some 40 or more imprints for handling remainders, reprint editions and special imported books.

title: Mailbox; Interference Rule Has Its Flaws
description: To the Sports Editor: A new rule has lately been seen in National Football League. I refer to a pass-interference situation, either by offense or defense, where the penalty is erased because officials decided that the passes were not catchable.

title: Eleanor Furlaud, Lawyer, Engaged To Laszlo Adam
description: The engagement of Eleanor Jay Furlaud, a New York lawyer, to Laszlo Adam, an investment banker, has been announced. The marriage is planned for December.

title: Major News; Laureate Tobin Straddles Gaps
description: Critics of prevailing economic practice took cheer in last week's award of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science to James Tobin, a self-described post-Keynesian who favors twinning a tough fiscal with an easy monetary policy.

title: WORLD BRIDGE PLAY COMING TO COUNTY
description: THE world bridge championships will be played in Westchester during the next two weeks, for the first and probably the last time, and they are already embroiled in controversy. Play begins Tuesday at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, with 12 teams, seven in the open series and five in the women's division, competing for 10 days.

title: Miss Chlumecky Bride of Lawyer
description: Darina Chlumecky, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leslie Chlumecky of Oak Brook, Ill., was married yesterday to Allan Douglas McKelvie, son of Dr. Allan M. McKelvie and Cynthia Helms of Washington. The ceremony was performed at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington by the Rev. Daniel Driscoll of Boston.

title: Dr. Denker Weds Margaret Borgers
description: Margaret Elizabeth Borgers, daughter of Richard William Borgers of Norris, Tenn., and the late Mrs. Borgers, was married yesterday in Alexandria, Va., to Dr. Joel Sibley Denker, son of Dr. and Mrs. David Denker of Somerset, N.J. The Rev. Beverly Bumbaugh performed the ceremony at the Mount Vernon Unitarian Church.

title: STAGE: ROMAN TROUPE USES PLAYLETS BY GRAIG
description: The Nuova Opera dei Burattini, an experimental marionette division of the Teatro di Roma, is in residence at New York University's University Theater through Monday with ''Gentlemen, the Marionette!'', a production in English of three playlets by Edward Gordon Craig. As one might expect from a show inspired by the work of this eminent designer and director, the scenery, lighting and marionettes are imaginatively synthesized in performance. The company, an Italian cousin to America's Bread and Puppet Theater, offers an evening of considerable visual virtuosity.

title: ELDERLY AND DISABLED GIVEN MOST OF MEDICAID
description: A state study shows that most of the Medicaid money spent in New York City goes to the elderly or disabled, according to the state's Social Services Commissioner.

title: PROBLEM FOR CITY PARENTS: PUBLIC OR PRIVATE SCHOOL?
description: It is a question that nags many middle-class parents, one that could influence what neighborhood they choose to live in, whether they need to take on an extra job, how to cut expenses by eliminating the weekly maid or even selling the family car.

title: ON A CARIBBEAN VACATION, BABY MAKES THREE
description: FRANK RICH is the chief drama critic of The New York Times. By FRANK RICH

title: PRICES AND MONEY, BY THE WINNER OF THE NOBEL
description: James Tobin, Sterling Professor of Economics at Yale University, won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science last week. Professor Tobin, who was a member of President John F. Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers, won the prize for his scholarly analysis of financial markets. Among his latest writings is a section on inflation for a new ''Encyclopedia of Economics,'' to be published next month by McGraw-Hill. Here is an excerpt: Measurement of Inflation

title: Major News; AN EASY CHOICE FOR PEACE PRIZE
description: Lech Walesa was an acknowledged early favorite, but the Norwegians on the Nobel Peace Prize committee may have realized that the Polish union leader has enough trouble, without adding an honor likely to give the Kremlin fits.

title: Bridge; ABNORMAL APPROACH
description: It was no great surprise to knowledgeable observers that Poland won the European Championship in Birmingham, England, this past July. The Poles have been becoming progressively stronger in recent years, as evidenced by their Rosenblum Cup victory in New Orleans in 1978. They are quite likely to start as favorites in the Bermuda Bowl competition that begins in Port Chester, N.Y., tomorrow.

title: PRESIDENT ANWAR EL-SADAT, IN PERSPECTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCKLAND
description: North Rockland, the last unbeated team in county P.S.A.L. play, won its fourth straight game yesterday, topping Clarkestown North, 17-6.

title: CAMBODIAN HELPS FELLOW REFUGEES ADJUST TO AMERICAN WAYS
description: Kim Huot Kiet sat with gentle dignity alongside two Cambodian refugees at a state employment office in Brooklyn, where he had accompanied them in their search for jobs.

title: A VICIOUS CIRCLE CONTINUES
description: WHEN Creedence Clearwater Revival sang the lyrics to ''Bad Moon Rising'' in 1969, they could not have realized its relevancy 12 years later. Those words describe perfectly the proposals to cut back certain day-care services from the welfare budget. These proposals will not only pull the rug out from under the people affected, but also make a tough job even tougher for those in the social work field.

title: ECONOMICS STUDIES THRIVE AT YALE
description: ONCE the champagne bottles have been tossed away and the congratulatory telegrams and phone calls trail off, James Tobin, the Yale Univeristy professor who last Tuesday was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, will go back to being a celebrated - though modest -member of a department that is already home to quite a few other celebrated economists.

title: HOW TO CHOOSE A REAL ESTATE AGENT
description: B ECAUSE persistently high interest rates have put a crimp in the housing market, a homeowner's choice of the right real estate agent can be crucial. But in a business where much depends on intangibles, and where word-of-mouth can be as important as a track record, selection is not easy.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: THE DISTORTION OF AMERICA By Oscar Handlin. 154 pp. Boston: Atlantic/Little, Brown. $10.95.

title: A Prospective Use For 'Brother-in-Law'
description: Shayna Alexander's ''Hang Tough When Dealing With Handymen'' (Sept. 27) sounds a rather jarring note in this so-called age of women's equality if, as a single woman, one must keep the specter of a ''male protector'' in the closet.

title: Food; WINE CELLAR GETS A TOAST
description: SAG HARBOR TED CONKLIN is highly selective about wine, and his attitude has resulted in a restaurant that has just won an award for its wine cellar - one of 13 restaurants in the United States to achieve the honor. Mr. Conklin is as careful about selling his wines as about buying them.

title: SAILORS GO DOWN TO THE POND AGAIN
description: GREENWICH NOW that October has come, many Greenwich sailors no longer go down to the Sound; they go instead to Binney Park Pond. Each year at this time they haul their children and their model sailboats, catamarans, trimarans and hydrofoils to a body of water 1,000 feet by 200 feet and cheer their vessels to the finish line in the annual Greenwich Model Sailboat Race. This year's race starts at 2 P.M. today, or next Sunday if it rains.

title: Effects of the 'Cure' For Child Abuse
description: The methods being used to cure child abuse (''Child-Abuse Study Challenges Beliefs,'' Sept. 20) may be worse than the ''disease'' itself. They may even help wreck the families involved, as has occurred within my own extended family.

title: WESTCHESTER
description: Harold Gayden scored four touchdowns and rushed for 190 yards as unbeaten Sleepy Hollow rolled to 34-18 victory yesterday over Ardsley.

title: Mailbox; GOLF BALL CAPER
description: To the Sports Editor: I can't hold back! After reading an item in The Times's Sports People column (Oct. 10), I was astonished that three men could be arrested for retrieving golf balls from water hazards.

title: Massachusetts Towns to Get Aid on Gypsy Moth Spraying
description: When gypsy moth caterpillars invade the state again in May, cities and towns that want to spray them will have some help from the state, according to an environmental official.

title: Whalers Beat Red Wings, 8-1
description: Rick Meagher scored three goals and Rick MacLeish two to help Hartford to an 8-1 victory tonight over the Detroit Red Wings. The victory was the Whalers' first of the season and the three-goal game was the first of Meagher's National Hockey League career.

title: Dining Out; EXPECTATIONS UNFULFILLED
description: OLD SAYBROOK DEVOTEES of the Goodspeed Opera productions at East Haddam are always pleased to know of a new or amenable restaurant in the vicinity. The Whitehouse, a year-old establishment in Old Saybrook, is conveniently located just off I-95 at Exit 66.

title: ARTISTS' STUDIOS AMID THE FACTORIES
description: MAMARONECK IN the former premises of a pickle factory surrounded by the rumbling sounds of tractor-trailers and garbage trucks, eight artists work in individual studios somewhat oblivious to any outside distractions.

title: RECITAL: MISS PARCELLS, SOPRANO
description: Elizabeth Parcells's soprano voice was not dark timbred or warmly sensuous in her recital at the Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night. But it was affecting and even exciting, most at home in its very highest octave, where its tones were pure, its trills precise, its shape capable of subtle variation.

title: Polish Prelate, in Rome, Asks For Unity to Overcome Crisis
description: Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Primate of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland, called on his countrymen today to unite to overcome ''the grave crisis striking the nation.''

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: century New England and moves geographically westward and chronologically up to the present, covering everything - their genesis, development, economy, architecture, religion, government, entertainment, crime and punishment - in fascinating detail. A monumental work of original scholarship.

title: WATER SUPPLY FEARS PERSIST
description: THE availability of water is again becoming a major concern of some communities in the state, but unlike the nature-created shortages of the past summer and spring, the new concern is over man's tampering with the water supplies.

title: Connecticut Housing; SWEEP'S ROLE GROWS
description: ADDING a new dimension to the more traditional sights and sounds of the New England fall these last few weeks has been an increasing presence of the chimney sweep. And while the logo on the outside of the truck may evoke quaint tales of a colorful past, the need for such a service should not be taken lightly.

title: SPORTS AND THE CURSE OF VIOLENCE
description: MY son is a 17-year-old who loves sports - basketball in particular. He could be described by that much abused cliche, ''typical teen-ager.'' Yet, I'm worried about this ''typical teenager'' because I see evidence that the overwhelming aura of violence associated with sports is beginning to leave a dark imprint on his basic beliefs regarding the purpose and proper spirit of athletic competition.

title: De La Rose, 1-5, Takes Feature at Woodbine
description: De La Rose, kept well off the pace by Eddie Maple, took the lead just before the stretch and went on to an easy victory in the $115,000 E.P. Taylor Stakes at Woodbine today.

title: N.F.L. INQUIRY OF RAIDERS WIDENS
description: Over the past decade, in clear violation of National Football League rules, bookmakers and gamblers have established close ties with the Oakland Raiders, according to information gathered by California and Federal law enforcement agencies.

title: A RECESSION COULD PUT REAGAN IN A BOX
description: W ITH the possibility of a recession seemingly on an increase, the President and his economic advisers need contingency plans. They may be faced with a situation in which nothing is growing in the economy except the deficit and the unemployment rate.

title: Goats in Surgery
description: ''Live goats are being shot and used as surgical patients in Green Beret medical training,'' the news report began. In explaining the program at Fort Bragg, N.C., the Army base said early this month that its aim was to teach medics ''surgical procedures which are essential to saving soldiers' lives in war.''

title: DATA ON CUTS IMPERILED BY CUTS IN DATA
description: The irony could not be starker. Before most major policy decisions, President Reagan sits down with Richard Beal, director of the White House Office of Planning and Evaluation. Armed with graphs, tables and maps, Mr. Beal outlines the latest statistical trends in crime, housing, health costs, employment, urban conditions. More detailed briefings are then given to 40 or 50 top White House Officials as part of the National Indicators System, developed by the Reagan Administration to be sure it has the best and latest social, economic and demographic data at hand before it makes a move.

title: 31% IN POLL SAY THEY ENGAGE IN VOLUNTEERISM
description: Thirty-one percent of America's adults are involved in organized, structured volunteerism on a regular basis, a new study by the Gallup Poll says.

title: FLORIDA SEEKS EXPLANATIONS AND CURES AS CRIME MOUNTS
description: When the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 1980 report on crime in the United States was published last month, crimeconscious Floridians were dismayed to find that six of the 10 most crime-ridden communities in the nation were in this state, including No. 1: Miami.

title: Washington; THE FORGOTTEN DEBATE
description: The decisive vote in the Senate on military weapons for Saudi Arabia has been postponed until near the end of the month. This delay has been arranged in accordance with the first principle of ''the greatest deliberative body in the world'': If you don't have the votes, don't vote - deliberate!

title: Politics; CANDIDATES DIFFER ON GOVERNOR'S ROLE
description: THE two major-party gubernatorial candidates disagree not only on what a Governor should do - to stimulate business, for instance - but also on what a Governor should be.

title: TELEVISION PORNOGRAPHY
description: It seems to me that the creators of the new TV pornography have two choices before them. Either they can go on manufacturing the same male-oriented, misogynist, exploitative material or they can create a new genre of sexual erotica that will not only be a turn-on, but will help to foster equal relations between the sexes. Let's hope for the latter. JESSICA SPORN

title: Dykes of the Jets Is His Own Best Critic
description: This is the lot of a cornerback on the New York Jets: Donald Dykes rummages inside his handsome briefcase which sits, incongruously, amid the underwear and socks and gear in his locker.

title: Around the World; Rumania Sets Limits On Bread Consumption
description: Rumania today introduced what amounted to bread rationing, setting annual consumption limits on wheat and corn products and making it a crime to buy them for animal fodder.

title: Food; TO MARKET, TO MARKET
description: I am a devotee of English market days, particularly those in rural towns and villages. Rain or shine, once a week there is a hustlebustle of vans and cars behind the market hall where boxes of vegetables, fruits, meats, clothing, dishes, blankets and notions are unloaded in the dawn. For the customers, market day is an opportunity to go to town, to stock the larder, meet friends, exchange news, complain about prices and generally catch up on things that have happened since the last market day.

title: UNION-MIDDLESEX
description: Sean Murphey scored on a long touchdown pass and stopped three drives with interceptions, and Mike Giacone gained 163 yards and scored a touchdown to lead Westfield to a 14-6 victory over Montclair yesterday before a crowd of 6,800 in Westfield.

title: Television Pornography
description: The growth of sexually explicit video, described by Tony Schwartz, raises a serious privacy issue (''The TV Pornography Boom,'' Sept. 13). While the videotape purchaser faces the minor embarrassment of the over-the-counter sale, the subscription television viewer has his sexual viewing habits chronicled in the computerized billing department of the cable-television operator.

title: DIGGERS FIND IMPERIAL CITY OF ASSYRIANS
description: It was in 1964 that a scholar at Yale, while cataloguing thousands of cuneiform tablets, came across a crucial clue: an itinerary of an ancient journey from the southern part of Mesopotamia up the Tigris River to northern Syria.

title: Algeria Agrees to Oil Parley
description: Algeria has agreed to a special meeting of the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to try to establish a common price structure, the official Algerian press agency said today. The next scheduled OPEC meeting is in Abu Dhabi on Dec. 9, but sources in several oil-producing nations have suggested that a meeting might be held earlier, possibly before the end of this month.

title: HE'S 'STILL' WHILE EVERYONE ELSE IS IN 'MOTION'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Louis Goldman is a lifelong still photographer who has spent the last 20 years working mainly in the entertainment field. By LOUIS GOLDMAN

title: FLYING, SKIING, ROUGHING IT; IRISH COTTAGE TO LET
description: It stands on the edge of a mill pond or a little town in Galway. Its roof may be thatched, its walls of stone. The furniture is a bit rough, perhaps, but there is a cozy fireplace for cool evenings. And looking out toward the town, or across the quiet Irish countryside, the only sounds are the buzzing of insects, the trickling of a lazy stream, the soft winds rustling shade trees and fields of long grass.

title: UNCHECKED URBANIZATION CLOGS LATIN AMERICAN
description: ''This corner is tops,'' said Alberto Vieira de Azevedo as he stood at the busy Copacabana intersection. He shouted the assertion, but his delivery had nothing to do with civic boosterism. He was simply trying to make himself heard on what statistically has become the noisiest street crossing in the world.

title: Clara E. Ruthrauff, Magazine Editor, Wed to Jeremiah Thomas 3d, Lawyer
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church yesterday, Clara Ewing Ruthrauff, who is china, glass and silver editor of House & Garden magazine, was married to Jeremiah Lindsay Thomas 3d, a partner in the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett. The Rev. Paul J. Walsh performed the ceremony.

title: SUDAN LEADER CONTENDS LIBYANS HAVE POSTPONED PLAN FOR INVASION
description: A senior Sudanese official said today that he believed Libya had postponed plans for an immediate invasion of the Sudan but still harbored designs to bring down President Gaafar al-Nimeiry by force.

title: 3 Iowa Field Goals Stop Michigan, 9-7
description: A freshman, Tom Nichol, kicked three field goals and Iowa's powerful defense made them stand up for a 9-7 victory over Michigan in a Big Ten game today.

title: MORE FATHERS SEEK CUSTODY OF CHILDREN
description: ENCOURAGED by support groups such as the Long Island League of Divorced Fathers, which has chapters in both Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and the Coalition of Free Men, a Manhasset men's-rights organization, many fathers are seeking full or partial custody of their children after a divorce.

title: Art View; A GLIMPSE OF BECKMANN'S ACHIEVEMENT
description: Three years hence, in 1984, we shall be observing the centenary of the birth of the German painter Max Beckmann. For that occasion the St. Louis Art Museum is preparing a major retrospective exhibition of his work. It was to St. Louis, to teach in the School of Fine Arts at Washington University, that Beckmann first came to the United States in 1947. He was then 63 years old, and had been living in exile, mainly in Amsterdam, since 1937 - the year that the Nazis organized the infamous ''Degenerate Art'' exhibition in which Beckmann was conspicuously represented. (He had been dismissed from his teaching position in Frankfurt in 1933 when Hitler first came to power.) When Beckmann died in New York in 1950, he was serving on the faculty of the Brooklyn Museum Art School.

title: SUSAN BELOFF IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey V. Sprung of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Sprung's daughter, Susan Lee Beloff, to Mark Allen Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Evans of Jackson, Miss. A November wedding is planned. The future bride, daughter also of Arthur Beloff of Woodbridge, Conn., graduated from Tufts University.

title: Headliners; Something He Said?
description: As a top Las Vegas entertainer, Wayne Newton has been known, in the jargon of his trade, to knock his audiences dead. Now, it seems, someone wants to knock him dead.

title: 2 MINOR PARTIES GIVE VIEWS ON THE RACE FOR MAYOR
description: ''Let's stop big government where it starts, New York City,'' says Judith Jones. ''Working people keep New York running, working people should run New York,'' says Wells Todd. Miss Jones and Mr. Todd are candidates for Mayor of New York City, having qualified for the Nov. 3 ballot by petition signatures. Miss Jones, representing the Free Libertarian Party, submitted 15,066 signatures and Mr. Todd, on the Socialist Workers Party line, turned in 17,537, according to the Board of Elections.

title: Soviet Says Mitterrand Errs on Foreign Policy
description: In the first detailed Soviet analysis of French policy under Francois Mitterrand, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda today expressed grave doubts over the course followed by the Socialist President in foreign affairs.

title: World Cup Soccer Still Wide Open
description: Qualifying matches for the 1982 World Cup finals in Spain started 18 months ago and there have been a number of surprising casualties along the way. Only nine countries so far have secured a place for the 24-team tournament in Spain, with the rest to be decided before the end of the year.

title: Iowa State 34, Missouri 13
description: Dwayne Crutchfield, the Big Eight's leading rusher, ran for 98 yards and scored three touchdowns for Iowa State.

title: FLORIO WINS SUPPORT IN SOUTH JERSEY POLL
description: Most of South Jersey's voters who have decided on a gubernatorial candidate would vote for the Democrat, Representative James J. Florio, according to a survey released yesterday.

title: SOUTH JERSEY SECESSION: TWO VIEWS OUTSIDER SEES A VALID COMPLAINT
description: AS A political scientist who came to New Jersey basically ignorant of its people and politics, who lived and worked there for two years and who now has departed, leaving no vested interest of any kind, I believe I can offer some useful comments about South Jersey's secessionist movement.

title: The Region; Housing Crunch Turns Literal
description: Two increasingly rare commodities - an apartment for rent in Manhattan and a subsidy from Washington to help pay for it - drew 2,000 prospective tenants to the Upper West Side last week. Most came away without so much as an application for one of the 126 units available.

title: D.B. Lyons Weds Margaret Olsan
description: Margaret A. Olsan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin S. Olsan of Rochester, was married in New York yesterday to David B. Lyons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Lyons of North Canton, Conn. State Supreme Court Justice Wilmer J. Patlow performed the ceremony at the Georgian Suite.

title: THE TWO WORLDS OF BERLIN
description: FLETCHER KNEBEL is the co-author of ''Seven Days in May.''' His most recent novel is ''Crossing in Berlin,'' published by Doubleday. By FLETCHER KNEBEL

title: SELECTING SHIPMATES
description: ENID NEMY, who watches bores from a safe distance, is a reporter for the Style section of The Times. By ENID NEMY

title: Leisure; SAFFRON, THE COSTLIEST SPICE IS PICKED FROM A HUMBLE FLOWER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Bertha P. Reppert is a writer and professional herbalist. By BERTHA P. REPPERT

title: IN WHITE PLAINS, CONTEST CENTERS ON MANAGEMENT
description: WHITE PLAINS TO its planners, White Plains is one of the biggest success stories around, a city bursting with vitality and promise in contrast to depressed conditions elsewhere. Mayor Alfred Del Vecchio says much of the credit belongs to him. But Carolyn L. Whittle, his challenger in the coming mayoral election, says the success came in spite of Mr. Del Vecchio. He has, in fact, harmed the city, she says, by fiscal mismanagement. Mr. Del Vecchio accuses Mrs. Whittle of making innaccurate charges against him.

title: SAUDIS, IN FIRM CONTROL, FACE LONG-TERM DANGERS
description: At his news conference on Oct. 1, President Reagan vowed that the United States would never permit Saudi Arabia ''to be an Iran.''

title: BRANDEIS STRIKE DRAGS ON
description: LAWRENCE THE longest and most bitter teachers' strike involving a Jewish parochial school on Long Island is entering its fifth week with no sign of a settlement.

title: WHEN 2 INCOMES BECOME HARD TO LIVE WITH
description: WHEN our youngest finally made it into high school, we became a two-income family. That's not unusual; working couples are becoming the national norm. My wife, Shirley, got a job. She was euphoric. With the older kids off to college or matrimony, she was liberated. No longer a household drudge but a fully certified psychiatric nurse, she could put the knowledge and skills earned in part-time college-going to use in exorcising the demons that haunt the emotionally troubled and make the world a better place.

title: No Headline
description: DEMAND IS GREAT FOR ROCK FEST TICKETS: Clerks process ticket applications for the Rolling Stones' concerts at the Meadowlands and Madison Square Garden, scheduled for Nov. 12 and 13. Boxes of mail line the wall behind them and much of two other rooms. The tickets will be dispensed on a lottery basis.

title: EVIDENCE OF 1980 MURDERS HIDDEN BY VOLCANO
description: A shroud of ash from the eruption of Mount St. Helens hid the bodies of two young women for a year and a half after they were murdered.

title: Lois Shaffer, Pianist, Offers 'Appassionata'
description: Just before the end of the first movement of Beethoven's ''Appassionata'' Sonata (Op. 57), after tumultuous arpeggiations, the motivic theme sounds quietly in the piano's bass. It is a dramatic moment, suggesting the futility of the music's straining passions.

title: MILSTEIN OPENS THROTTLE AS BUILDER
description: When Paul Milstein joined his father's floor contracting company at the end of World War II, he learned how risky the business could be. ''The interior of a building is the last element of construction,'' he said in an interview, ''and the contractors that normally would wind up a project would be paid last, if at all. So that if a builder got into trouble, he could always say to the last contractors, 'Well, wait till the next job.' ''

title: A NOVEL OF LOST AMERICANS
description: A FLAG FOR SUNRISE By Robert Stone. 439 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: AN EQUAL-TIME DISAGREEMENT ON F.C.C. RULES
description: THE Federal Communications Commission voted 4-2 last month to ask Congress to deregulate the broadcasting industry, repealing the ''fairness doctrine,'' which requires broadcasters to present opposing viewpoints; ''equal time'' rules, requiring time for political opponents when candidates appear in other than a news setting; and a requirement that individuals be allowed to reply to personal attacks on the air. Congress has yet to act on the F.C.C. proposal. Last week, New York Times reporter Ernest Holsendolph discussed these issues in separate interviews with Everett C. Parker, director of the United Church of Christ communications office and public access advocate, and Gene F. Jankowski, president of CBS Broadcasting. Excerpts follow. GENE F. JANKOWSKI

title: Anne Manning Is Wed To Steven Silverstein
description: Anne Manning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Manning of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married last evening to Steven Silverstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Silverstein of Bayside, Queens. Judge Lewis Rosenthal of the Kings County District Court performed the ceremony in the bride's Manhattan apartment.

title: Mary P. DeGroot Wed to a Lawyer
description: Mary Patricia DeGroot, daughter of Mrs. Herbert L. DeGroot of Morristown, N.J., and the late Mr. DeGroot, was married yesterday to Harry Cummings McPherson Jr., son of Mr. McPherson of Tyler, Tex., and the late Nan Hight McPherson. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Holmes in St. John's Episcopal Church in Lafayette Square in Washington.

title: Leisure; TINY BULBS TO GROW AT HOME
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joanna May Thach is a writer who gardens on Long Island. By JOANNA MAY THACH

title: Canadiens 10, Canucks 4
description: MONTREAL (AP) - Steve Shutt and Mario Tremblay each scored two goals in leading the Montreal rout of Vancouver. Keith Acton, Pierre Larouche, Guy Lafleur, Doug Jarvis, Doug Wickenheiser and Pierre Mondou scored single goals for the Canadiens, who have put in 31 goals in four games while posting a 3-0-1 record.

title: WHAT THE POOR WILL ASK OF THE RICH
description: PRESIDENTS Ronald Reagan, Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast, Abdus Sattar of Bangladesh and 19 other heads of state gather at the Mexican seaside resort of Cancun for two days of talk this week on how to improve the lot of the poor.

title: City Hall Notes
description: After months of having virtually nothing but kind things to say about President Reagan, Mayor Koch has begun to sound a few harsher notes.

title: Fumes From Glue Truck Fire Put 52 in Hospital in Germany
description: Fifty-two people were taken to a hospital after inhaling poisonous fumes from a burning truck loaded with glue, the police said today.

title: SOUTH JERSEY SECESSION: TWO VIEWS AN UNFUNNY POWER PLAY
description: THE tongue-in-cheek secession movement by the Committee to Free South Jersey does not leave most New Jerseyans laughing. Rather, this unfunny power play finds us with our jaws dropping in astonishment.

title: Deborah Ruth Laird a Bride
description: Deborah Ruth Laird, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Laird of Brookside, N.J., was married yesterday to David Gordon Ananson, son of Dr. Gordon Ananson of Summit, N.J., and Mrs. Robert J. Schenk of Morristown, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the Episcopal Chapel of St. John Baptist School in Mendham, N.J., by the Rev. Colley W. Bell, headmaster of the school.

title: HOLMDEL (4-0)44-14 WINNER
description: Jack Zawacki threw two touchdown passes, one to Jeff Todd, who also scored on an interception return, as unbeaten Holmdel beat Freehold Borough yesterday, 44-14, in Freehold.

title: DODGERS DEADLOCK PLAYOFF WITH 7-1 VICTORY
description: The Montreal Expos' dream of winning Canada's first pennant took a sharp setback today when the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated them, 7-1, and sent the National League playoff into its fifth and deciding game.

title: Tulane 31, Air Force 13
description: COLORADO SPRINGS (UPI) -Marvin Lewis, the Tulane tailback, scored three touchdowns and rushed for 143 yards in the second half. Tulane trailed, 13-3, at halftime but put together a rugged ground attack to dominate the last two quarters.

title: UNBEATEN LINCOLN SETS BACK SOUTH SHORE, 34-6
description: Abraham Lincoln High School won its fifth game without a defeat yesterday, trouncing South Shore, 34-6.

title: Antiques; DRINKING VESSELS OF THE COLONISTS
description: IT is cider-making time in Connecticut, as well as throughout other northern parts of the country, as it has been since the first crop of apples was harvested in 17th-century New England.

title: Ann B. Rhame and Susanne Madeira Fiancees of Peter and George Coffin 3d
description: Ann Buffington Rhame, a 1981 graduate of Hamilton College, and Peter Breckinridge Coffin, a senior at Hamilton, plan to be married Dec. 30. Mr. Coffin's older brother, George Jarvis Coffin 3d, and Susanne Claypoole Madeira, 1979 graduates of William Smith and Hobart Colleges, respectively, have set April 24 as their wedding date.

title: ARKANSAS, LED BY QUARTERBACK, UPSETS TEXAS, 42-11
description: Tom Jones, the quarterback, ran for two touchdowns and passed for a third, and Arkansas took advantage of mistakes to score a 42-11 upset over Texas.

title: TOP DEMOCRATS BID PARTY PANEL DEVELOP ISSUES
description: Democratic leaders urged their party today not to rest all its political hopes for 1982 on the immediate failure of the Reagan Administration, especially on the economy, but to develop alternatives, particularly a stress on maintaining vital functions of the Federal Government.

title: GREAT NECK AREA PAUSES TO RETHINK BUILDING
description: GREAT NECK ALONG Middle Neck Road, the main artery for entering and leaving most of the nine villages on the Great Neck peninsula, restaurants, gourmet food emporiums, boutiques, discount drug stores, pizza places and gift shops line the narrow sidewalks.

title: A NEW TWOSOME: ENGLAND'S NEW WAVE AND U.S. COUNTRY
description: English new wave rock and American country music may be strange bedfellows, but bedfellows is exactly what they are becoming. When the Clash, the most politically outspoken of the first wave of British punk bands, undertook their first extensive tour of America, they hired Joe Ely, a country and rock-and-roll singer from Lubbock, Tex., to open several of their concerts. Mr. Ely went over so well that in 1980 he found himself opening Clash shows in England, where he recorded his recently released live album ''Live Shots'' (MCA).

title: 70 Dead in Chinese Floods
description: Seventy people died and many thousands were made homeless in recent floods in the Zhanjiang district of Guangdong Province.

title: Stamps; COMMEMORATIVE PAIR FOR LAST BIG BATTLES OF 1781
description: There were actually two decisive battles that foreclosed the British hopes of crushing the rebellious Colonies in the closing years of the American Revolution: One was the famous land battle of Yorktown and the other was the little-known naval engagement of the Virginia Capes.

title: DIVORCE: A STANDARD FOR MEASURING LOSSES
description: SOME months ago a new book, written by a husband and wife, appeared on the market. The advertisement for it declared that ''divorced fathers comprise the most oppressed minority in the country - economically, socially, and emotionally'' and that ''in the stampede to help women, men are being trampled upon.''

title: Finite Resources
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Ready to Protect Blacks From Substandard Schooling
description: The Justice Department will move against school districts that provide inferior education in predominantly black schools, a Reagan Administration official says.

title: Indiana 17, Minnesota 16
description: Mike Greenstein kicked a 23-yard field goal to give Indiana a 17-14 lead and the Hoosiers held off a Minnesota rally in the last four minutes.

title: 18th-Century Bureau Sets Auction Record
description: A Queen Anne bureau-bookcase fetched more than $860,000, a record, in less than seven minutes today at Christie's auction house.

title: Auburn 31, Georgia Tech 7
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Joe Sullivan ran 24 yards for a touchdown on a fourth-down play as the Tigers handed the Engineers their fifth straight loss since an upset of Alabama.

title: The Moral Issue Of Drug Testing
description: John Kelly is right to worry that some subjects in controlled experiments might be denied useful and vitally needed drugs (''Bridging America's Drug Gap,'' Sept. 13). He notes that some doctors feel a moral problem when they are required to give patients an inactive pill, or placebo, rather than a drug which they ''know'' to work.

title: MOSCOW COUNTS ON WINNING A NUCLEAR WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess; BREAKING ROUTINE REQUIRES TIMING
description: You often hear it said after a lesser-ranked player loses to a grandmaster: ''Well, what can you expect against a player who is steeped in the routine?'' Nevertheless, this comment (usually intended to express sympathy) is just as often wrong. If there is any one quality that distinguishes the grandmaster, it is that he perceives when the moment is ripe to break the routine.

title: ENDURING THE MARATHON MARRIAGE
description: When Joan Paylo meets an attractive single man, her first question is always, ''What do you do to keep in shape?'' If he says, ''I run,'' she says, ''How often?'' If he says, ''Once around the reservoir twice a week,'' she smiles. He is not ''a real runner.''

title: PHILHARMONIC: GUESTS
description: The program for the New York Philharmonic this week at Avery Fisher Hall was presumably Andre Previn's, and it is a good one: the juxtaposition of two large-scale Russian orchestral works that in most ways couldn't be more different. First came Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3, which was composed in 1909 and first performed by the Symphony Society of New York (one ancestor of the Philharmonic) under Walter Damrosch and soon thereafter undertaken by Gustav Mahler and the Philharmonic (the other ancestor), both times with the composer as soloist. Then, after the intermission, there was Shostakovich's Symphony No. 10, from 1953.

title: Numismatics; THE VALUE OF SMART LONG-TERM INVESTMENTS
description: When New York lawyer Harold S. Bareford started buying coins four decades ago prices were laughably low by current standards. Of course, Mr. Bareford didn't have the benefit of this hindsight, but he did have the foresight to buy exceptional coins and his vision paid off handsomely for him and his heirs.

title: Topics; Transformations; Where the Buck Stops
description: So now they're shredding money. It used to be classified documents; but once shredded, the secret stuff was carefully disposed of.

title: Ibrahim to Perform Oct. 23-24 at the Public
description: Abdullah Ibrahim, a South African pianist, will perform Friday and Saturday at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater in the New Jazz at the Public series. He will perform in an octet with Carlos Ward, Andrei Strobert and Don Um Ramao.

title: Miss Dale, W.C. McNair Are Married
description: Kathleen Hamlin Dale and William Chaloner McNair were married yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Bryant Kirkland, the senior minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Steel Demand Drops; Plant to Lay Off 250
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it was laying off 250 workers at its 79-inch hot strip mill for a week because of a slump in orders.

title: AUTO SAFETY RULE REMAINS IN LIMBO
description: Within a week or two, the Reagan Administration plans to complete its re-evaluation of an automobile safety standard that for years has pitted the industry against a number of health, insurance and consumer groups.

title: Fly Fishing Center Started
description: NEW YORK STATE'S Catskill region - through which such glorious trout streams as the Beaverkill, the Willowemoc, the Neversink and the Esopus flow - is rightly regarded as the birthplace of American fly fishing, and a project aimed at formal recognition of that has been launched - the Catskill Fly Fishing Center.

title: Sylvia Reynolds, Pianist, Shows Intimate Manner
description: Sylvia Reynolds, an American pianist who has spent much of her young career in Norway, played with refreshing grace and simplicity Monday night at Alice Tully Hall. Miss Reynolds may lack the big sound and dramatic personality from which big careers are built, but her unassuming affection for line and texture in Haydn's B minor Sonata (Hob. 32) and the clarity and the sweetness of her phrasing in Schumann's difficult ''Humoreske'' was a soothing relief from New York's musical arena of giant egos.

title: Perkins Isn't Taking Seahawks Lightly
description: The Giants, who seem to be coming together as a team, and the Seattle Seahawks, a once-promising team that has almost collapsed, meet tomorrow at the Kingdome. The Seahawks are favored by a point, mainly because they are playing at home.

title: DESTINATION: NOWHERE
description: FRED FERRETTI is on the staff of The Times Style section. By FRED FERRETTI

title: SHARP DROP REPORTED IN FUNDS TO WILLIAMS
description: Contributions to help Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. pay his legal expenses in the Abscam case have fallen off sharply in recent months, a report filed with the Senate shows.

title: A CONDUCTOR'S TRIBULATIONS
description: LEONIA ''THERE is a certain element of risk-taking in this type of venture, but it's vitally important to keep a sense of the fun.'' Frederick Storfer was talking about some of the pleasurable - and pressure-filled - moments of starting one's own orchestra. The 54-year-old conductor has gained expertise in such matters, having founded the Garden State Chamber Orchestra.

title: Miss Egger Bride of Robert Taylor 3d
description: At St. Albans Episcopal Church in Washington yesterday, Antoinette Daue Egger was married to Robert E. Lee Taylor 3d by the Rev. Theodore Eastman.

title: The Nation; Who's Entitled To Know What?
