description: In the struggle by bureaucrats to keep secret the inner workings of Government, the Freedom of Information act unquestionably opened the window of vulnerability.

title: The Lively Arts; 'PIANO HANDS' SEEKING NEW CODA
description: SOUTHAMPTON ONCE a pianist, always a pianist. At least, that's what the composer Cy Coleman believes. And though he gave up the concert stage more than 30 years ago for popular music and, eventually, Broadway, the onetime child prodigy, who will appear with the Great Neck Symphony next Sunday, has discovered that when he resumes ''practicing again and working out my fingers,'' he can slip right back into his old world.

title: Cheryl Ann Abrams Is Wed
description: Cheryl Ann Abrams and Michael Krivoff Savit were married last evening at the Plaza Hotel by Rabbi Balfour Brickner.

title: Sea Law Aide to Be a Judge
description: President Reagan nominated Ronald P. Wertheim today to a 15-year term on the Superior Court for the District of Columbia. Mr. Wertheirm, of Washington, is a member of the Merit Systems Protection Board. He was adviser to the Secretary of Defense for the Law of the Sea Negotiations and an alternate representative at the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea.

title: CITY OPERA: 'TRAVIATA' WITH DIANA SOVIERO
description: When Beverly Sills assumed command of the New York City Opera, one of her high priorities was to put her young stars in jewel cases and show them off properly. Last night's new production of ''La Traviata'' performed that service for Diana Soviero, in particular. Zack Brown, in his company debut, designed sets that certainly can rank among the most fetching ever to occupy the State Theater stage, and Lou Galterio's direction was unerringly theatrical in the very best sense, giving Miss Soviero and her Alfredo, Barry McCauley, a framework in which they could make the most of their vocal and dramatic talents, not to forget those of Giuseppe Verdi.

title: MOSCOW COUNTS ON WINNING A NUCLEAR WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: REMARKS BY REAGAN TO EDITORS
description: Following are excerpts from a text provided by the White House of a luncheon meeting yesterday at which President Reagan was questioned by newspaper editors:

title: AMUSEMENT-GAME OPERATORS SEEK NEW RULES
description: AMONG the eight questions on the Nov. 3 ballot is one that would change the Amusement Games Licensing Law, a measure that game operators say is squeezing them out of business.

title: The Region; New Report From The Underground
description: The decline of the New York subway system may be readily apparent to the untrained eye, but that didn't stop two watchdog groups from focusing 60 pairs of them on it. Their findings, released last week, indicated that more than a third of all trains were late, about twice the rate in a similar study last year.

title: Mailbox; Lighten Pressure On Walt Michaels
description: To the Sports Editor: The ''heat'' must be removed from Walt Michaels, head coach of the New York Jets. It is unfair to punish this man any longer.

title: Wendover Wizard
description: The press called him the Wizard of Wendover, because since 1974 he had been doing esoteric research on nuclear fusion in a hangar at the abandoned Wendover Air Force Base in Utah. He was Robert K. Golka, a dropout from electrical engineering school, and his idea was to set off a fusion reaction by striking plasma with manmade lightning.

title: 40 Held in Buffalo Drug Raid
description: More than 40 people accused of selling drugs to undercover agents were rounded up by the police and sheriff's deputies early yesterday on the East Side here.

title: Connecticut Guide; by Eleanor Charles; A PUBLICK BEHEADING
description: Three years after celebrating the 100th birthday of its brontosaurus with a party attended by 1,700 people, the Peabody Museum of Yale University is inviting the public back to witness the beheading of the 80-foot-long 15-foot-high beast.

title: Index; International
description: Mexicans completing prepara- tions for Cancun talks 3 Head of Royal Marines is se- verely wounded by I.R.A. bomb 3 Around the World 5 Pakistani leader defends move to buy U.S. jets 6 Gunmen wound official in trou- bled Indian state 7 Basque rebels kill a Spanish po- liceman 8 Haig's charges on terrorism traced to a '68 Czech defector 9 Polish party session critical of leadership Japanese fascination with art of glass 69 South American and Andes danc- ers at Avery Fisher Hall< 70

title: Music View; VERDI VERSUS THE TYRANTS AND CENSORS
description: What might be called the Garret Theory of Art has probably never been especially popular with composers. The best use for attics, they may be excused for contending, is to provide a refuge for old clothes and bats. They can bring history to bear to refute the Romantic thesis that great art is only produced under the stress of bohemian poverty, mental anguish or political persecution. For every tubercular Chopin coughing his life away over a nocturne, there has been a Strauss or an Elgar, comfortably situated and idolized by his countrymen. Or a Verdi, who early in life suffered just enough to give his biographers something to chew over, but who was, before the age of 30, a national hero.

title: The Region; Life Is Hard On Parks, Too
description: Opened 108 years ago as a haven from the city's ills, Central Park has gradually become home to many of them. But last week, Gordon J. Davis, the New York City Parks Commissioner, announced a 10-year, $100-million effort to reverse the effects of aging and vandalism and restore the 830-acre expanse to glory.

title: Nippon Nine Wins
description: The Nippon Ham Fighters survived two late-inning rallies by the Yomiuri Giants today and won the first game of the Japan Series, 6-5.

title: GREEK CHURCH SAYS TALKS ON UNITY LAG
description: The Greek Orthodox Church has ended the first phase of unity talks with the Roman Catholic Church with a statement saying deep differences persist. But the Holy Synod, the Greek Orthodox governing body of 12 bishops, voted unanimously in favor of continuing the talks.

title: PIQUET CAPTURES WORLD DRIVING CROWN
description: Alan Jones, the 1980 world driving champion, leisurely cruised around for 165 miles this afternoon and scored an easy victory in the 16th and last Grand Prix race of the season.

title: BISHOPS DENOUNCE THE NEUTRON BOMB
description: Bishops in the New York metropolitan area used three forums over the last few days to denounce the development of the neutron bomb, calling the weapon ''immoral'' and ''ferocious.''

title: The World; For the Tories, None but 'Tina'
description: Margaret Thatcher rode out intraparty challenges to her economic policies last week, despite dissident warnings that she was taking the Conservative Party - and Britain - over a precipice.

title: THE KEAN STYLE GETS THE COMMON TOUCH
description: The chief image-maker in Thomas H. Kean's campaign for Governor is Mr. Kean himself - in part because so much of his style is deeply ingrained. Mr. Kean is a low-key member of an aristocratic family with a long history of government service in New Jersey, a Republican gentleman whose prep-school and Princeton education suffuses his speech.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: Each year, the state's Division of Taxation issues an inch-thick report that is a gold mine for statisticians interested in the distribution of wealth. The report, a compilation of data from the state income tax and the homestead rebate program, is entitled ''Owner Occupied Housing Statistics from Homestead Rebate and Income Tax Data Match.'' Among other things, it lists the average gross incomes for every community in the state and a breakdown, for each community, of the number of households in various income brackets (i.e., under $5,000, between $5,000 and $10,000, and so on). The latest report, published last summer, is for 1979. It lists four communities with average gross income in six figures: Far Hills (Somerset County), $127,880; Alpine (Bergen), $119,564; Essex Fells (Essex), $101,616, and Harding Township (Morris), $100,311. Also included is 1979's average gross income and average property tax by county. NEIGHBORLY good feelings on Ocean Drive West in Brigantine have been frayed by Dr. Joseph Chaikin's new windmill. It's not a rustic, wooden bit of rural Americana that the doctor has put up amid a cluster of affluent homes, but a 60-foot-high, $16,000 model that churns out about 40 percent of his home's electricity when the winds off the Atlantic hit 25 miles a hour. For his trouble in trying to conserve energy, Dr. Chaikin has been hauled into State Superior Court in Atlantic City. The windmill, his neighbors argue, is too noisy and disturbs their sleep, televisionwatching and privacy. A hearing is scheduled for Nov. 5 and a trial could follow. Until then, Judge L. Anthony Gibson has ordered, the windmill can be operated only two hours a day. Because of the pending court action, neither Dr. Chaikin nor his lawyer, Marvin Wallen, will comment. But the company that built the windmill - Enertech of Norwich, Vt. - is trying to sooth things. Edmund Coffin, Enertech's board chairman, says the problem is with the windmill's gear box. It is, Mr. Coffin notes, an early prototype with a noise level ''about 15 or 20 percent'' higher than the 50-decibel limit set by Brigantine's local windmill law. Meantime, a refined gear box is in production and will be installed. Kenneth Keslink, the salesman in the case, thinks both the 50-decibel level and the doctor's neighbors are unfair. ''They're all for energy conservation, but not in their neighborhood,'' Mr. Keslink said. ''The ocean, just about off their doorstep, makes more noise than this windmill is allowed to. The ocean is 50.7 decibels, and I tell them to turn it off.'' The mysteries of the sea never cease. One enigma is what caused at least 18 turtles to wash up dead last summer along a 40-mile stretch between Long Branch and Surf City on Long Beach Island. Perhaps 15 to 20 dead turtles wash ashore each summer, according to Robert Schoelkopf, director of the Marine Mammal Stranding Center, a nonprofit agency in Atlantic City that monitors cases of dead or beached whales, porpoises and turtles. In summers past, most were easily explicable, he said: Some died natural deaths, some were shot or harpooned, some struck by boat propellers, some drowned in fishermen's nets. ''A lot of this summer's deaths are an unknown -no apparent cause,'' he asserted. . The carcasses ranged from 20-pound loggerheads to 1,000-pound leatherbacks. Mr. Schoelkopf's staff did autopsies on 13 turtles; the five others, too decomposed, were buried. No causes of death was discernible in eight of the 13, he said. Of the five others, three died of propeller cuts, one of a digestive-tract blockage and two others -both big leatherbacks - because they had swallowed plastic bags. ''Leatherbacks' natural food source is jellyfish, and maybe they mistook the plastic bags for jellyfish,'' Mr. Schoelkopf said. The bags blocked their intestines. When the National Park Service announced in the spring of 1980 that it planned to shoot more than 500 wild burros in the Grand Canyon, Cleveland Amory, president of the New York-based Animal Protection Group, decided to do something about it. The Park Service said that the burros - descendants of those abandoned by prospectors 100 years ago - were damaging the vegetation and competing with native animals for food. Mr. Amory persuaded the service to give him a chance to save the burros. He hired a group of cowboys who, by last summer, managed to round up more than 500 of the animals. The burros were taken to the fund's Black Beauty Ranch in Texas, and 40 of them eventually were shipped to the R-D-R Farm in Kingwood Township, Hunterdon County. The farm is owned by Rolf and Dale Bauersachs. Now the burros are up for adoption. This requires $200 and strict adherence to the fund's adoption contract. Among its provisions are that the burros must never be used as beasts of burden and that a written health report be sent to the fund every six months. Why would anyone want a burro? Mr. Amory smiles and responds: ''Just for kicks.'' In Colonial days, the Saddle River Valley in northwestern Bergen County was home to the Minsi branch of the Lenni Lenape Indians. Perhaps the best depository of their lore and artifacts belongs to the Upper Saddle River Historical Society. It has about 500 pieces, primarily arrowheads, stone tools, ceremonial pendants and beads and shards of clay pottery. The collection was donated to the society in 1976 by Cornelius Berdan, a lifelong farmer in Upper Saddle River who died in 1979 at age 86. ''He collected the pieces over a lifetime, starting when he was about 10 years old,'' said Kay Yeomans, president of the society. Much of Mr. Berdan's Indian relics were stored in boxes until two Upper Saddle River Boy Scouts, Ted Hampton and Mike Passero, sorted and classified them, built wooden handles and shafts for the various arrowheads and stone tools and assembled exhibits. Both became Eagle Scouts as a result of their work. Portions of the exhibits are on permanent display in the town library and at Cavallini and Reynolds Schools in Upper Saddle River. From time to time, elements are assembled into a ''traveling exhibit.'' Until Nov. 10, such an exhibit will be on display at the Bergen County Wildlife Center in Wyckoff, together with a much larger exhibit on Indian life that belongs to the State Museum in Trenton.

title: Kieran M. Martin Is a Bride
description: Kieran Marie Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Martin of Cos Cob, Conn., was married yesterday in Riverside, Conn., to William Michael Parrilla, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Parrilla of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Joseph Amato performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Sienna Roman Catholic Church. The bride's father is a vice president, general counsel and secretary of Lone Star Industries Inc. Mr. Parrilla's father is systems development manager for the avionics division of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in Nutley, N.J.

title: Mississippi State 14 Miami (Fla.) 10
description: Lamar Windham scored on a 14-yard run and Dana Moore kicked two field goals to lead Mississippi State. Miami, led by its passing quarterback, Jim Kelly, staged a desperation drive in the closing seconds, but the comeback effort failed when an illegal motion penalty nullified an apparent scoring pass.

title: The Nation; Tax Charge for Rev. Moon
description: These days prophets, whether false or true, must pay taxes on personal income. And so (not for the first time) the Rev. Sun Myung Moon and the Government clashed last week.

title: Peggy Darrah, 28, Smashed Records in Distance Running
description: Peggy Neppel Darrah, a three-time world record-holder in distance running, died yesterday at the age of 28. She had been hospitalized for two weeks with cancer.

title: Georgia 53, Vanderbilt 21
description: Herschel Walker and Lindsey Scott scored two touchdowns each and set school career records for Georgia.

title: Kevin Foley Weds Elizabeth Sander
description: St. John's Episcopal Church in Georgetown, Washington, was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Deighton Sander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William McDonald Sander of Seattle, to Kevin Michael Foley, son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Xavier Foley of Fairfield, Conn. The bride's cousin, the Rev. Frederick Alexander McDonald, assisted by the Rev. Charles W. Stubbs, performed the ceremony.

title: REAGAN DECLARES HE NEEDS INCREASE IN BUDGET POWERS
description: President Reagan has called for a fundamental revision of the Federal budget process that would increase the President's power to control Government spending by giving him the authority to veto individual items in appropriations bills passed by Congress.

title: Florida 49, Mississippi 3
description: James Jones ran for three touchdowns and Wayne Peace ran and threw for two more for Florida in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: Penny Solution
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding, ''Currency: The Power of the Penny'' (Oct. 11), if you should do away with pennies and then require change of larger money, then do as other countries do: Give your change in postage stamps. That's how its done in Indonesia. EDMUND B. FREUND New York, N.Y., Oct. 11, 1981

title: Home Clinic; MODERN MATERIALS EASE FURNITURE-FINISHING TASK
description: MODERN furniture-finishing materials make it comparatively easy for any do-it-yourselfer to achieve a lustrous, long-lasting finish with much less time and effort than were required years ago. Even so, many finishing enthusiasts contend that nothing available today quite matches the beauty and practicality of classic French polishing.

title: CAPTURING CATTON'S 'THE BLUE AND THE GRAY' FOR THE TV SCREEN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Moseley is the editor of The Southwest Times Record in Fort Smith, Ark. By JACK MOSELEY PRAIRIE GROVE, Ark. Using Osark Mountain locations to depict events of the Civil War in six states, Columbia Pictures Television is attempting to recreate the passions that fueled that bitterest and bloodiest of all American conflicts.

title: Theater Mailbag; SALUTING A SHOW AND AN ACTRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: RUSSIAN CHEMISTRY
description: YELLOW RAIN A Journey Through the Terror of Chemical Warfare. By Sterling Seagrave. 316 pp. New York: M. Evans & Co. $11.95.

title: RACE ISSUE EMERGES IN ATLANTA MAYORAL CAMPAIGN
description: The issue of racism emerged publicly in the mayoral election campaign here this week, with the incumbent Mayor, Maynard Jackson, who is black, identifying the black supporters of the white candidate, State Representative Sidney Marcus, as ''Negroes'' who were ''shuffling and grinning around the camp of our opponent.''

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (NAL/

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''With his courage and wisdom, friends of Israel admired him. Enemies of Israel feared him.'' - Yitzhak Shamir, Foreign Minister of Israel, speaking of Moshe Dayan. (16:3.)

title: A LOSS OF $600 MILLION YEARLY LAID TO TAX VIOLATIONS IN CITY
description: New York City officials say they have uncovered widespread violations of the tax laws and estimate that individuals and businesses are holding back as much as $600 million a year in payments.

title: TWO VIEWS OF PRISON BOND ACT A SPONSOR SEES PASSAGE AS VITAL
description: ON Nov. 3, the voters of New York State will be asked to approve the Security Through Development of Correctional Facilities Bond Act of 1981, which would provide $500 million in state bonds to finance the construction of new correctional facilities and improvement of existing prisons and jails.

title: G.O.P. CRIES 'FOUL' ON NEW RELEASES
description: ''Rep. Snowe For and Against Military Waste.'' ''Congressman Fish Votes Against Vet Health Care, Elderly Housing.'' ''Roukema's Ax Hits Social Security, Student Programs.''

title: MUSIC: THE BOSTON SYMPHONY AT 100
description: When Maj. Henry Lee Higginson decided he wanted an orchestra in his hometown a century ago, he simply set one up. He hired a respectable German conductor, Georg Henschel. He paid for the $50,000 annual deficit in the $115,000 budget. And he arranged for light popular concerts to be offered for the larger public. That orchestra was the Boston Symphony Orchestra. This afternoon, 12 music directors later and after the establishment of the Boston Pops and the Tanglewood Festival and after becoming a major force in American musical life, the Boston Symphony celebrated its 100th birthday in its only slightly younger Symphony Hall.

title: MARY R. DUCAS
description: Mary R. Ducas, a former magazine editor, writer and researcher, died Saturday of pneumonia at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness.

title: Gunmen Get $700 At Bronx Rectory
description: Two gunmen entered the rectory of a Roman Catholic church in the Morrisania section of the Bronx yesterday afternoon and robbed a priest and two parishioners of $700 in Sunday collection money, the police said.

title: DYAN IS BURIED ON A HILLTOP IN GALILEE
description: Moshe Dayan was returned today to the land he loved. In the Galilee farming settlement where he spent his childhood, amid the rolling hills and fields and orchards that gave him solace, thousands came to mourn and honor him.

title: Chiefs 28, Broncos 14
description: Whitney Paul returned a fumble 47 yards for one Kansas City touchdown, and Joe Delaney ran 82 yards for another score.

title: Soccer to Germans
description: West Germany won the World Youth Soccer Championship today, 4-0, from Qatar during a steady rain before a crowd of 18,531.

title: St. Francis Still Unbeaten
description: St. Francis Prep of Queens ran its record to 4-0, including 3-0 in the City Division of the Catholic High Schools Football League, with a 33-16 victory over Iona Prep yesterday. Peter Murphy completed eight of 12 passes for 165 yards, including four touchdowns. John Dezago caught two of 33 and 5 yards, and the other two went for 60 yards to Mike DeLuca and 7 to Morgan Tierney.

title: MCENROE WINS FROM TANNER
description: Top-seeded John McEnroe defeated Roscoe Tanner, 6-4, 7-5, 6-2, today to win the $175,000 Australian Indoor tennis tournament.

title: Sport's New Dawn
description: A former teen-age trumpet player with the Lionel Hampton and Gene Krupa bands who gave up music almost 30 years ago to eventually become a professor of philosophy at New York University is currently engaged in investigating the phenomena of sports in America on the CBS network's Sunrise Semester.

title: MILBOURNE A HAPPY SURPRISE
description: On the night before the Yankees began their playoff drive against the Brewers, Larry Milbourne lay awake in his Milwaukee hotel room thinking about failure.

title: WALSH MCDERMOTT, MEDICAL RESEARCHER, DIES
description: Dr. Walsh McDermott, a medical educator and researcher who was professor of public health and medicine at the Cornell University Medical College, died of a heart attack Saturday at his vacation home in Pawling, N.Y. Dr. McDermott, who was also a resident of Manhattan, was 71 years old.

title: NEW PROJECT: A VICTORIAN STAGE SET; An Appraisal
description: The most talked-about new building in this city right now is not another museum, or government building, or embassy, or office block. It is a $93 million complex of stores and condominium apartments, and it is shoehorned tightly into a block just above the Potomac River in fashionable Georgetown.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 19, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: EGYPT ARRESTS 230 IN A 'TERRORIST RELIGIOUS GROUP'
description: The Government announced tonight that its security forces had arrested 230 members of a ''terrorist religious group'' who had planned assassinations and other acts of violence to undermine public security.

title: THE WONDER OF SPECIES
description: Charles Darwin was only 26 years old when he visited the Galapagos in 1835. His careful eye and his endless yet humble curiosity had already provided a great range of evidence on the extraordinary and subtle variety of life.

title: Washington Watch; Fed Vacancy Speculation
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT REAGAN may look no farther than the White House staff in filling the vacancy at the Federal Reserve Board that develops in January upon the resignation of its vice chairman, Frederick H. Schultz.

title: FOREIGN POLICY NEEDS
description: 4MEDFORD, Mass. - A great number of diverse regions and nations now play an important role in international affairs. The cultural universe in which American diplomacy has to operate and which American citizens need to understand is more varied and complex than ever before in our history. We do not move with assurance in that universe.

title: ALLIED'S NUCLEAR WRITE-OFF
description: The Allied Corporation has decided to take an $87 million write-off on a partially completed, nuclear-reprocessing plant in Barnwell, S.C. But the company may have to dismantle the plant to qualify for the applicable tax credit, industry sources here suggest.

title: Tank Overturns, Killing 2
description: An M-60 tank rolled over in hilly terrain while on a training maneuver yesterday, killing two soldiers who were pinned underneath and injuring a third, officials said today.

title: DESTRUCTION OF AN AILING HORSE CALLED A NECESSITY BY OWNER
description: Hugable Tom won the first time he raced, against maiden 2-year-olds at Aqueduct on Nov. 12, 1977. He won the last start of his career, as a 6-year-old gelding, running with a $35,000 claiming tag at Belmont last June 20. In all, he won 18 of 55 career starts, earning $271,804 and more than the usual affection from bettors, who considered him a particularly game and dependable investment.

title: PREMIER CONCEDES
description: Greece's Socialist opposition won a major victory in parliamentary elections today, bringing an end to 35 years of pro-Western conservative rule.

title: JETS TROUNCE BILLS BY 33-14, CAPITALIZING ON BREAKS
description: The Jets achieved one of the startling upsets of the season yesterday by trouncing the Buffalo Bills, 33-14, at Shea Stadium. ''There was a Remember Pearl Harbor syndrome around here,'' said Marvin Powell, the right tackle, alluding to the opening game of the season, when Buffalo embarrassed the Jets, 31-0.

title: REAGAN TO REDUCE BUDGET CUT PLANS
description: Bowing to Congressional opposition, White House officials agreed today to trim by more than half the $13 billion package of new budget cuts proposed for the 1982 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1. At the same time President Reagan said the nation's economy was in a ''slight'' recession.

title: Jersey Inspecting Grumman Buses
description: NEWARK (UPI) - Independent inspectors hired by NJ Transit are running final inspections on Grumman Flxible buses expected to be delivered to the state by next month.

title: TOMORROW'S MINORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Aires, a Sloop, Leads Regatta
description: Aires, a 46-foot sloop owned by Michael Swerdlow of New York, took the lead today in the big-boat division at the opening of the Manhasset Bay invitation fall regatta series.

title: BLACK BANK GRANTS MORTGAGE OF $500,000 TO AFRICAN GROUP
description: Freedom National Bank, the only black-owned bank in New York State, has granted a $500,000 mortgage loan to the Organization of African Unity for the purchase of a brownstone to house the group's office in New York City, according to the O.A.U.'s representative at the United Nations.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In a doubles match in tennis, a player on Team A puts up a deep lob. As a player on Team B goes back for the ball, he loses sight of it and, after he has stepped over the base line and no part of his body is within the lines, the ball hits him on the shoulder before hitting the ground. Whose point is it?

title: Italy in First Soviet Gas Deal
description: Italy's state-owned gas company has signed a preliminary agreement to buy about 300 billion cubic feet of natural gas a year from the Soviet Union starting in 1984, officials said. The announcement Friday of the Oct. 6 agreement was the first firm commitment by a West European country to purchase Siberian gas.

title: Block Closing Scheduled
description: Because of construction, 35th Street, between Park Avenue South and Lexington Avenue, was closed yesterday and will remain closed through Thursday, New York City's Department of Highways announced.

title: Japan Autos: Mixed Signals
description: Japan's domestic auto market is showing signs of recovery but exports remain sluggish, auto makers report.

title: People
description: * C.A. Wolfe has joined Needham, Harper & Steers Advertising as executive vice president and managing director of the Chicago office, a new position.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent shot and killed a man who tried to mug him in midtown Manhattan. The retired agent, John Danahy, 53 years old, of New City, was attacked at 51st Street and Madison Avenue. Mr. Danahy, who is licensed to carry a gun, shot the man during a scuffle on the sidewalk.

title: CHAMBER: SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER
description: VETERAN subscribers to the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center have learned over the years that dull spots in the programs are rare. Even the interludes when stagehands come on to rearrange the furniture are often worth paying attention to, for it is then that the society's artistic director, Charles Wadsworth, is likely to appear and dispense chatty patter about forthcoming concerts and tongue-in-cheek lessons in music history. At yesterday's Alice Tully Hall concert, which opened the Society's 13th regular season (the recent Haydn-Stravinsky celebration was an irregular prelude), Mr. Wadsworth bounced in to announce that the season was 91 per cent sold out by subscription, as was last season. He asked for a show of hands by new subscribers and could count only a few in the back rows, which plainly delighted him. Artistic directors are never happier than when the box office tells them they are doing something right.

title: FOREIGN POLICY SYSTEM CRITICIZED BY U.S. AIDES
description: Nine months ago President Reagan pledged to end the recent pattern of Administrations speaking with conflicting voices on foreign and military policy. But there are still mixed signals and there is still no disciplined system for making decisions in these areas, according to Administration officials, legislators and foreign diplomats interviewed over the last month.

title: A SUSPECT IN SLAYING OVER A BUS TRANSFER SURRENDERS TO POLICE
description: A 26-year-old Hicksville, L.I., man who was identified Saturday by the police as ''the assailant'' who shot and killed a Transit Authority bus driver in Brooklyn nine days ago in a dispute over a free transfer surrendered to Brooklyn detectives last night, the police said.

title: REAPPOINTING PLAN FOR COUNCIL IS CALLED BY ABRAMS
description: The New York State Attorney General yesterday called the proposed New York City Council reapportionment plan ''unlawful'' and urged the United States Justice Department to reject it.

title: FOR WEINBERGER, SWEDES STRESS ARMED MIGHT
description: In a small park in downtown Stockholm stands a statue of Charles XII, King of the Swedes in the early 18th century when they were the most powerful nation in Northern Europe. In his right hand, the King holds a sword while he points with his left toward Russia. The look on his face seems to say: ''There lies my enemy.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bank of New York has named Gerard P. Dougherty, Brian P. Reilly and Robert J. Wolf vice presidents.

title: Cosmos Tie Milan
description: The New York Cosmos played to a 1-1 draw against A.C. Milan, the former Italian soccer champion, in an exhibition match today.

title: Fire Silences Radio Station
description: A predawn fire destroyed the studios and transmitting facilities of radio station WIPS early today, causing damage estimated at more than $100,000.

title: U.S. CENSUS BUREAU SAYS DIVORCE AND UNMARRIED COUPLES INCREASED IN 70'S
description: More Americans are living together without marrying, more are marrying later in life and more are getting divorces, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Part of Viceroy Goes to Grey
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation has assigned its Viceroy brand of cigarettes to Grey Advertising, New York, for creative development.

title: IRAN-U.S. ARBITRATION OPENING
description: What is expected to be the largest and most complex arbitration process ever conducted gets under way this week as an international tribunal convenes to accept the claims of American corporations that did business with Iran before the fall of the Shah.

title: Girl and Man Die In Separate Fires
description: A young girl and an elderly man died yesterday in separate fires in Queens and Manhattan, the fire department said. The body of the girl, identified as Jeanette Nichol Dalton, 3 years old, was found at 12:16 P.M. in the kitchen of a two-story brick building at 146-40 South Road in Jamaica.

title: Cowboys Top Rams, 29-17
description: Tony Dorsett's 44-yard touchdown run and the longest touchdown pass play of Danny White's career helped the Dallas Cowboys score a 29-17 victory over the Los Angeles Rams tonight.

title: Rogue Elephants at Large
description: If the Central Intelligence Agency can punish former agents who break its rules against disclosing secrets learned on the job, why can't it do something about former spies who train foreign terrorists? The question becomes more compelling with each revelation about the exploits of Edwin Wilson and Frank Terpil. These former agents, currently fugitives from gun-running charges, have exploited their service-connected skills and credentials in the cause of terrorists like Idi Amin and Colonel Qaddafi.

title: Patriots 38, Oilers 10
description: Steve Grogan, who hadn't been in the starting lineup since the second game of the season, threw for two touchdowns to highlight a 17-point New England (2-5) third quarter.

title: Jordan's Chief Visits Bahrain
description: King Hussein of Jordan arrived from Kuwait today for talks with Bahrain's ruler, Sheik Isa bin Salman al-Khalifa. King Hussein visited Syria yesterday, and he is scheduled to go to Saudi Arabia, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and Muscat. The purpose of the tour, diplomatic sources said, is to obtain an Arab consensus on points of policy before King Hussein visits Washington in November.

title: Give Citycaid a Chance
description: Remember the uproar in Harlem last year over Mayor Koch's plan to close the troubled Sydenham and Metropolitan hospitals? He eventually bought some peace by persuading a campaigning Jimmy Carter to help save Metropolitan with Federal funds for an experimental health maintenance plan called Citycaid.

title: ENEMY PARKS STUDIED BY YANKEES
description: When the Yankees worked out at Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon, they did not know if they would be playing the Montreal Expos or the Los Angeles Dodgers in the World Series. Nor were they concerned that they didn't know.

title: CLIMBING, A HEIGHT OF EXPERIENCE
description: ''YOU'RE all insane!'' The shout rang out, directed at a group of rock climbers, from a car roaring along the road 50 yards below. Between climbers and those people who require flat earth under them, the feeling of incredulity is mutual. But climbers don't shout back because they're too busy ascending, and avoiding falls.

title: Browns 20, Saints 17
description: Mike Pruitt plunged 1 yard for a touchdown with 4:48 left in the game, capping a 78-yard drive, to give Cleveland (3-4) the victory.

title: INDEX
description: INTERNATIONAL Reporter's notebook: Ruining Zimbabwe's ruins A2 Cooking oil scandal hurts Spain abroad A3 Latin America economic gains are being eroded A6 Swedes stress armed strength to Weinberger A6 Around the World A9 Attitudes toward new Egyptian regime are divided A11 Reagan rejects Nixon's proposal for boycott of Libya A12 Soviet press reports briefly on Polish changes A14 U.S. voices concern over resolution adopted by Polish party A14 GOVERNMENT/POLITICS Layoffs and fiscal woes concern city's politicians and residents A16 Gotbaum, reflecting on primary, says Koch really lost B1 Partisan crowd cheers Florio as he debates Kean B2 Koch says recent remarks may harm relations with blacks B2 Abrams calls City Council reapportionment plan unlawful B3 WASHINGTON TALK Briefing A13 Georgetown Park project: a pleasant touch of Victoriana A18 Republicans yell "foul" over Democrats' news releases A18 The Calendar A18 RELIGION Rev. Sun Myung Moon stirs loyalty but remains distant B4 SPORTS MONDAY Baseball: Rain forces postponement of Expo-Dodgers game C8 Mets offer manager's job to Bamberger C8 Milbourne is happy surprise for Yankees C11 Columns: Red Smith on the winter game C8 Ira Berkow on Gene Michael C10 Features: Sports World Specials C2 Question Box C15 Football: Jets upset Bills 33-14, and stand .500 C1 Danelo kicks 6 field goals as Giants beat Seahawks 32-0 C1 Florida State makes comeback, takes on tough schedule C1 Davis accuses N.F.L. of attempt to "get me" C3 Golf: Pate wins Pensacola Open; Kite tops earnings list C13 Hockey: Johnstone scores twce as Rangers beat Blues C8 Outdoors: Rock climbing in the New York area C15 Statistics C14 GENERAL Vermont town competes with others in energy conservation A15 Around the Nation A16 Bob Hope and President Reagan attend dinner dance for U.S.O. A16 Hobbyists bring Texas longhorns back from near extinction A16 Boston judge accused of giving in to pressure in rape case A20 A ritual of autumn: homecoming weekend at Columbia B1 Joffrey Ballet celebrates 25th anniversary with street party B3 ARTS/ENTERTAINMENT David Henry Hwang's 'Family Devotions' is staged C17 Modernist art show in Moscow is four-month wonder C17 Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center gives recital C18 Boston Symphony marks its 100th anniversary C18 V.S. Naipaul's "Among the Believer's" is reviewed C21 Janacek's "Cunning Little Vixons" returns to City Opera C21 CBS-TV is showing an updated "Valley of the Dolls" C22 STYLE Relationships B10 Betty Friedan ushers in a second stage B10 Ungaro and Lagerfeld brighten Paris showings B10 OBITUARIES Dr. Walsh McDermott, researcher and Cornell professor D15 Virginia Lee, Chinese cook, teacher and author D15 FEATURES/NOTES Man in the News: Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's new leader A14 Man in the News: Stanislaw Kania, Poland's fallen leader A14 Notes on People C18 NEWS ANALYSIS John Darnton assesses Poland's new Communist Party leader A1 EDITORIALS/LETTERS Editorials A22 New harvest on farm policy Rogue elephants at large Give Citycaid a chance Letters A22 Anthony Lewis: Jimmy Carter and The Washington Post Flora Lewis: a visit to the Galapagos Islands A23 Robert L. Heilbroner: in Hoover's wake, helmsman Reagan A23 Jean Mayer: U.S. foreign-policy needs A23 Ross K. Bake: a former President's re-emergence A23

title: EVIDENCE IS FOUND OF WARMING TREND
description: New evidence that supports the theory that carbon dioxide pollution is causing a potentially dangerous warming of the earth's climate has been detected by scientists at Columbia University.

title: TAKEOVERS BY FRANCE RESISTED
description: Shareholders, both French and foreign, of the banks and industrial companies that President Francois Mitterrand is trying to nationalize are organizing resistance groups and fighting back.

title: Ormandy Recovering
description: A follow-up: Eugene Ormandy, the 81-year-old former conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra who was hospitalized with a fever on Friday, is recovering and is expected to be released from the hospital within a week.

title: Denver Marathon Is Won by French
description: Jim French, the prerace favorite, took the lead at the 23-mile mark and coasted to victory today in the ninth running of the Denver Marathon.

title: COOKING GAS LINKED TO CHILDREN'S MINOR BREATHING HABITS
description: Surveys in several cities, involving almost 29,000 children, have shown slightly higher rates of minor respiratory ailments in those living in homes where gas rather than electricity is used for cooking, it was reported at an international conference on indoor air pollution held last week at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst.

title: CONALLY'S OUTLOOK ON GOLD AND ARMS
description: Some of the more provocative views expressed during the current debate about putting the United States back on the gold standard are being heard from John B. Connally, the man who was Treasury Secretary when President Richard M. Nixon closed the gold window in 1971.

title: BIDS TO RAISE REVENUES EXPECTED IN CONGRESS
description: The Reagan Administration calls it ''revenue enhancement'' but the ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Barber B. Conable Jr. of upstate New York, calls it ''raising taxes'' and says he is against it - for the time being, anyway.

title: DANCE: TRISHA BROWN AND HER ARTIST FRIENDS
description: SOME pretty high-powered visual artists got involved in Trisha Brown's dance pieces in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's latest experimental dance series, conveniently titled ''The Next Wave.''

title: BETTY FRIEDAN USHERS IN A 'SECOND STAGE'
description: ''This uneasy sense of battles won, only to be fought over again, of battles that should have been won, according to all the rules, and yet are not, of battles that suddenly one does not really want to win, and the weariness of battle altogether - how many women feel it?'' - Betty Friedan in ''The Second Stage.'' By NAN ROBERTSON

title: DANCE: DIANA BYER'S LIGHT COMEDIES
description: THE Dance Ring, the chamber ballet company directed by Diana Byer, appeared Saturday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association in a program that emphasized light comedy. Although the dancers looked well-trained and the productions were pleasantly staged and costumed, these particular comedies were thin as well as light.

title: COOKING OIL SCANDAL HURTS SPAIN ABROAD
description: A scandal involving the illicit sale of toxic cooking oil, which has taken at least 160 lives and spread panic among Spanish consumers, has begun to concern nations that import Spanish canned goods and vegetable oils.

title: MITTERRAND AND REAGAN COVER SINAI AND ARMS
description: President Francois Mitterrand and President Reagan conferred here today in a series of diplomatic events and private meetings that are to lead up to ceremonies tomorrow marking the 200th anniversary of the British surrender on the nearby Yorktown battlefield.

title: CONCERN RISES IN BOSTON AFTER NEW SET OF LAYOFFS
description: Just before 2 A.M. yesterday, as the 38,000 residents of the island of East Boston slept, the only police station on the island was officially closed and an officer was posted as a security guard. The radio equipment, teletypes and typewriters had been removed from Station No. 7 Friday evening, when Police Commissioner Joseph M. Jordan ordered 146 more city police officers laid off and the East Boston, South Boston, Brighton and Mattapan substations closed.

title: White Lifts Giants
description: Roy White smashed a two-run home run in the top of the eighth inning, giving the Yomiuri Giants a 2-1 victory over the Nippon Ham Fighters in the second game of the four-of-seven-game Japan Series. The victory before 42,000 spectators at Tokyo's Korakuen Stadium enabled the Central League champions to tie the series at 1-1.

title: David Birch, Lawyer, Weds Beatrice Stern
description: Beatrice H. Stern, daughter Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Stern of Brooklyn, and David L. Birch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius L. Birch of Delray Beach, Fla., were married yesterday. Rabbi Lawrence W. Raphael, associate dean of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, performed the ceremony at the St. Moritz Hotel.

title: SOVIET PRESS REPORTS BRIEFLY ON THE CHANGES IN POLAND
description: The official Soviet press agency Tass reported briefly and without comment today the resignation of Stanislaw Kania as leader of Poland's Communist Party and his replacement by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski.

title: Lab's Plutonium Cleanup May Take Two Weeks
description: A chemistry metallurgy area where a plutonium leak occurred last week may not be decontaminated for two weeks, a spokesman for the Los Alamos National Laboratory said today.

title: Chargers 43, Colts 14
description: Dan Fouts completed 26 of 43 passes for 296 yards and threw for three touchdowns as San Diego (5-2) sent Baltimore to its sixth straight defeat after a season-opening victory. Fouts threw scoring passes of 7, 12 and 23 yards.

title: Digital's Market Move
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, the nation's leading manufacturer of minicomputers, is expected to announce today that it is entering the personal computer field.

title: CITY STUDY FINDS STREETS OF 2 BOROUGHS CLEANER
description: Streets are cleaner in Brooklyn and the Bronx than they were a year ago but dirtier on Manhattan's East Side, according to statistics released yesterday by Mayor Koch and the Sanitation Department.

title: B.B.D.O. and Tracey Get Borden Products
description: Borden Inc. has assigned about $5 million in milk, ice cream and related dairy product advertising to Tracey-Locke, Dallas, and Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, which is on the verge of acquiring the Texas agency.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption on a photograph accom- panying the television listings on Saturday misidentified the subject. The photograph was of Field Marshal Viscount Slim.

title: IN HOOVER'S WAKE, HELMSMAN REAGAN
description: .2,2If things continue, there is a fair chance that Ronald Reagan will be our second Herbert Hoover - elected in triumph, thrown out in ignominy. As someone from the other side of the political tracks, I do not find that possibility entirely displeasing. But the prospect requires that the American people take a battering like that experienced in the 1930's. I am not so eager to rub my hands as to wish for that.

title: TV: 'VALLEY OF THE DOLLS' GETS FACELIFT
description: LAST week, on ABC-TV, it was three hours of ''Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy.'' This week, on CBS, it's Jacqueline Susann's ''Valley of the Dolls,'' the novel that sold more than 20 million copies in addition to inspiring one of the classic trash movies of all time. With both of these Jacquelines, the consumer is in the booming pop arena of packaging, marketing and shrewd exploitation.

title: PARTY ON 55TH STREET MARKS JOFFREY BALLET'S 25TH YEAR
description: There was dancing in the street as promised, along with some unscheduled dancing and singing in the rain, as the Joffrey Ballet gave itself a blocklong birthday bash yesterday in front of its City Center headquarters on West 55th Street.

title: IN MOSCOW, 50-YEAR-OLD MODERN ART IS A 4-MONTH WONDER
description: After four months and more than 600,000 visitors, including the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, the largest exhibition of Russian and French modern art ever shown in the Soviet Union ended this month, leaving Russians exhilarated at the esthetic feast and occasionally bitter at its 50-year delay.

title: N.F.L., DAVIS SAYS IS TRYING TO 'GET ME'
description: Al Davis, the managing general partner of the Oakland Raiders, said yesterday that the National Football League was ''resurrecting old stories'' in its determination to ''get me'' - an apparent reference to the league's attempts to block Mr. Davis's efforts to move his team, winners of last year's Super Bowl, from Oakland to Los Angeles.

title: 'ALL SAVERS' BENEFIT TO THE GOVERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Dith Pran
description: Marathon Computer Gets a Road Test During a five-mile race yesterday in Central Park, volunteers checked the controls for the computer system that will be used to score the 16,000 runners who will compete in the New York City Marathon next Sunday. Another volunteer, left, checked a printout of the results. New systems were developed to provide official clockings for all the contestants.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1981
description: International The Polish Communist leader was dismissed and replace by his Prime Minister, the Central Committee reported. Stanislaw Kania, who gained power at the height of the labor unrest last year, resigned and Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski, was named his successor. General Jaruzelski is said to share Mr. Kania's moderate approach, so no abrupt attempt to reverse recent liberalizing changes in the country's political life was expected, but the leadership change came as Central Committee called for a tougher line against ''antisocialists.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) Greece's standing government fell as the opposition Panhellenic Socialists won a major victory in parliamentary elections. The victory of the Socialists, led by Andreas Papandreou, over the Government headed by Prime Minister George Rallis, brought to an end 35 years of pro-Western, conservative rule in Greece. The Socialist's success could mean radical changes in Greece's foreign policy since the party has opposed the country's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Common Market as well as the presence of American bases in Greece. (A1:4.)

title: Bozell & Jacobs Gains Norwegian Cruises
description: The Norwegian American Cruises account, handled by Homer & Durham Advertising for the last three years, has been assigned to Bozell & Jacobs.

title: Venezuelan Oil Output
description: Crude oil production in Venezuela for the week ending Oct. 7 averaged 1.9 million barrels a day, the Ministry of Mines and Energy reported, down 25,000 barrels from the previous week's average. Exports up to Oct. 7 of this year averaged 1.7 million barrels a day, down 153,000 barrels from the 1980 daily average, the Ministry said Friday.

title: Kramer of Vikings Sinks Eagles, 35-23
description: Tommy Kramer, the Minnesota quarterback who has been a superlative passer for the last month, gave another impressive performance today as the Vikings defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 35-23. The loss was the Eagles' first after six victories.

title: No Headline
description: REAGAN REJECTS LIBYA BOYCOTT

title: ATTITUDE OF ARABS DIVIDED ON EGYPT
description: After a brief, wary period, attitudes in the Arab world toward the new Egyptian regime have begun to take form, with the moderate nations seeking to cajole the Egyptians back into the Arab ranks and the hard-liners attacking President Hosni Mubarak for continuing to deal with Israel.

title: Sports World Specials; Fun Run
description: On the application form for this year's running of the New York Marathon, one entrant gave these answers to the following questions: College? ''Roads Scholar.'' Major? ''Road Running.'' Profession? ''Runner/Comedian.'' Why did you begin running? ''It's a feeling, and it felt good to run. So if it feels good, do it. I did.'' At the bottom of the entry sheet, he added: ''Can be awesome when in good shape. Sometimes, I like to set a hard pace and run from the front. I also do a good Elwood Blues imitation.''

title: 200 Are Feared Dead in Iran In Storm in Strait of Hormuz
description: At least 200 people were feared killed in a storm that swept through the Strait of Hormuz yesterday, the Teheran radio said tonight.

title: PROTESTS PLANNED OVER BUDGET CUTS
description: A coalition of more than 100 labor, social and political organizations, meeting over the weekend to devise a strategy for combating the Reagan Administration's slashes in social services, voted overwhelmingly to conduct a week of major demonstrations around the country beginning April 26.

title: CITY OPERA: 'VIXEN' RETURNS
description: JANACEK'S ''The Cunning Little Vixen,'' the centerpiece of last year's New York City Opera season, returned Saturday afternoon with its charm and mystery intact.

title: New Money Fund In Tax-Free Bonds
description: Some leading securities firms are planning to introduce a new taxexempt money market mutual fund next week, according to a spokesman for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the lead underwriter of the group involved.

title: HUGE U.S. PRESENCE IN CAIRO EVOKES MEMORIES OF TEHERAN
description: The process by which a visitor enters the United States Embassy here is a sobering reminder of how imposing the American presence in Egypt has become, and how precarious it may be.

title: CHINA SEES NO ADDED GRAIN NEED
description: With a good harvest in sight, China does not expect to buy any more American grain this year beyond the six million to nine million metric tons already agreed upon for the year, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt AMONG THE BELIEVERS. An Islamic Journey. By V.S. Naipaul. 430 pages. Knopf. $15.

title: VIRGINIA LEE, NOTED TEACHER AND CHINESE COOKING EXPERT
description: Virginia Lee, one of America's foremost Chinese cooks, died Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center after a long illness. She was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FALCONS ROLL UP CARDS
description: Jim Hart of the St. Louis Cardinals hit on 24 of 49 passes yesterday to move into third place on the career list for completions. But his achievement was overshadowed by Steve Bartkowski, who led the Atlanta Falcons to a 41-20 victory over the Cardinals at Atlanta.

title: GENE MICHAEL SITS ONE OUT
description: MONSEY, N.Y. ON Tuesday night in Yankee Stadium, amid the bright bunting and the sellout crowd of some 60,000 fans packed in for the first game of the World Series, Bob Lemon will be the first Yankee introduced in the pregame ceremony. It is customary that he get the first call since he is the home team's manager.

title: OPERA: 'DINORAH,' MEYERBEER RARITY
description: THE opera world's search for forgotten 19th-century minutiae continued Saturday night at the Lilly Blake School with the Apollo Opera's re-creation of ''Dinorah'' by Meyerbeer. ''Dinorah'' is a confused and bloated three-hour affair emanating from what the composer had originally - and rightly -conceived as a one-act opera.

title: Human Potential
description: Are there limits to human athletic performances? What is the fastest that man can run a mile or 100 meters? What is the highest or the furthest that a man can jump?

title: Guilford Lad Wins
description: Welcome Farm's Guilford Lad held on in the stretch and won the third running of the $82,800 Damon Runyon Stakes for New York-bred 2-year-olds yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Deer-Hunting Princess Bruises Some Feelings
description: She's named for the Roman goddess of the hunt, so it should come as no surprise that Diana, the Princess of Wales, has gone in for a bit of deer hunting during her stay at the royal estate of Balmoral in the Scottish highlands.

title: NEW YORK SEEKING TO DELAY EFFECT OF U.S. AID CUTBACK
description: New York State is attempting to delay the effects of an $800 million-a-year Federal aid cutback on social services by stretching its reduced allocation to prolong as many programs as possible. As a result, such services as day-care centers and programs for the elderly and infirm may not feel the full effect of the cutbacks until the middle of next year, according to Robert Morgado, Governor Carey's secretary.

title: Winning Edge
description: A 31-year-old assistant professor in civil engineering at Princeton University has an interesting hobby. When he is not using the university's I.B.M. 3033 computer to help design controls on automated transit systems, he employs it to predict upcoming National Football League games.

title: A Well-Researched Guide to Getting to College
description: He had no trouble getting into college, but Lawrence Graham, now a 19-year-old junior at Princeton, thought that many of the ''how to'' books he encountered along the way left a lot to be desired.

title: Anna D. Gorelick Bride of Paul Sterne
description: Anna Deborah Gorelick, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Gorelick of New York, was married yesterday to Paul Livingston Sterne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. L. Sterne of Lutherville, Md. Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Bridge: Appeals Hearing Put Off In Reese Credentials Case
description: The first order of business in the world team championship - a credentials appeal - had to be delayed here today. The tournament starts Tuesday.

title: MAKING DECISIONS FOR OTHERS
description: T HE word is ''paternalism,'' and it conjures up images of fathers telling children, ''Get that car home by 1 A.M.,'' lawyers saying to clients, ''You are now going to plead guilty'' and business managers intoning, ''We're going to move you to the Altoona office - you'll be so much happier there.''

title: THE INCOME TAX BY ANY OTHER NAME...
description: To the Editor:

title: RAINOUT POSTPONES PLAYOFF UNTIL TODAY
description: The fifth and final game of the playoff for the National League pennant was postponed by rain today, forcing the Montreal Expos and Los Angeles Dodgers to play it tomorrow, one day before the World Series.

title: Williamsburg Dinner Menu
description: This is the menu for tonight's state dinner for the President of France, Francois Mitterrand, at the Royal Governor's Palace in Colonial Williamsburg.

title: The Economy
description: The White House agreed to slim the budget cuts President Reagan had proposed for next year and to increase the amount of new revenues that would be sought. The President also acknowledged for the first time that the U.S. was in ''a slight recession.'' (Page A1.)

title: POLISH STATEMENT DISTURBS THE U.S.
description: The United States reacted with concern today to language in a resolution of the Polish Communist Party Central Committee that it interprets as allowing the Warsaw Government to use military force against striking Polish workers.

title: Raiders Edge Bucs, 18-16
description: The Oakland Raiders, who had been shut out for three straight games, defeated the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, 18-16, today on a 44-yard field goal by Chris Bahr with 2 minutes 21 seconds remaining.

title: TEXAS IS LATEST TO FALL FROM NO. 1 PERCH
description: There seems to be a jinx to the No.1 college football ranking. Texas, the fourth team to be rated on top in the wire-service polls this season, became the third of the four to be upset when it was trounced Saturday by Arkansas, 42-11.

title: DRIVING CHAMPION
description: DRIVING CHAMPION: Nelson Piquet of Brazil opening champagne Saturday in Las Vegas, Nev., after winning world driving title. Alan Jones won the Grand Prix race.

title: A New Harvest on Farm Policy
description: To win votes in Congress for his budget last spring, President Reagan promised conservative Southern Democrats, known as Boll Weevils, that he would stop opposing their effort to bolster price supports for peanut and sugar farmers.

title: BAMBERGER OFFERED METS MANAGER'S JOB
description: The New York Mets have offered the job of manager to George Bamberger, former manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, who indicated that he would make a decision perhaps as early as tomorrow.

title: GOTBAUM ASSERTS KOCH 'FAILED' IN THE PRIMARY
description: ''Here's a guy,'' Victor Gotbaum was saying, ''who spends a million skins and he comes up with 250,000 votes. How do you call that a victory? His support must be paper-thin. He failed.''

title: VIOLIN RECITAL: MISS JENSON
description: SOME debutantes are really new, but that could hardly be said for Dylana Jenson, the young American violinist who made her New York recital debut at Carnegie Hall Friday night before a good-sized and appreciative house. Miss Jenson is well known already, what with a concerto appearance here last season, a record album and a 1978 Silver Medal from the Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow.

title: JAZZ: A NEW ANTHONY DAVIS
description: WHEN he emerged on the New York jazz scene in 1977, Anthony Davis was known as a pianist. He still plays that instrument. But as indicated by his appearance Friday night with a group of musicians that he calls Episteme in the Public Theater' new-jazz series, he is really now more of a composer.

title: Susan Diane Schaler Married to Barry A. Weisfeld
description: Susan Diane Schaler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Gerald Schaler of New York, was married yesterday to Barry Andrew Weisfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Weisfeld of New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony in the Villard House of the Helmsley-Palace Hotel.

title: GRAND JURY TO GET CASE OF ATHLETE WHO DIED IN JAIL
description: The death in the Signal Hill jail of Ron Settles, a college football star, has led to an investigation into charges of police brutality in that oil town just south of Los Angeles.

title: 'BIG POTATOES MAN' THOUGHT TO BE HEAD OF LARGE DRUG RING
description: Donald Raulerson attracted police attention two and a half years ago when he reported the theft of $980,000 in cash. He said he had won the money gambling.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT BLUES, 5-3
description: The Rangers appeared to breaking out of their early-season slump last night as they defeated the St. Louis Blues, 5-3, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Islanders Sparked By Gillies
description: The Islanders were in agreement. The Rangers should never have disturbed Clark Gillies Saturday night. Let sleeping giants lie, so to speak.

title: Advertising; Publishers Take Look At Cable
description: There was a time when magazine publishers resented the appearance of television commercials at advertising industry conventions, so it was a bit surprising to have a session devoted to video at a publishers' meeting.

title: Montana to Permit Use Of Controversial Endrin
description: The Montana Department of Agriculture says it will permit use of endrin next year if necessary, although game birds were contaminated the pesticide this year.

title: DANELO'S SIX KICKS PACE GIANT VICTORY
description: The Giants, who won only four games last season, now have won four in less than half of this season. They routed the Seattle Seahawks, 32-0, today with a tight and opportunistic defense, a running game that wore down the opposition, crisp blocking and, every time you turned your back, Joe Danelo's field goals.

title: Hope Is Given Up for 61 Trapped in Mine in Japan
description: Relatives of 61 miners trapped and presumed dead in a Japanese coal mine gave permission today for the air supply to be cut off to prevent the fires caused by explosions from spreading.

title: 49ers 13, Packers 3
description: Johnny Davis ran 1 yard for a touchdown, and Ray Wersching kicked two field goals as San Francisco (5-2) won its fourth straight.

title: Commodities; Fertilizer As a Crop Indicator
description: STUDYING fertilizer usage as an indicator of future farm output and price trends has never been very popular with grain and soybean crop analysts. Most of the forecasters followed by farm commodity futures traders concentrate on weather patterns, output-per-acre statistics, foreign crop conditions, interest rates, political trends and other factors.

title: U.S. ISSUES HELP FUNDS GROW FAST
description: Money market funds that invest only in Treasury bills and other Government issues are now growing much faster than those that invest primarily in corporate securities, investment figures show.

title: SUN MYUNG MOON STILL AN ELUSIVE FIGURE
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, who was indicted with one of his aides last week for tax evasion, burst upon the American scene in 1974 with a coast-to-coast tour that mixed evangelism, patriotism and esoteric religion. Backing it all were high-powered public relations and Mr. Moon's own blend of charisma and mystery.

title: OPEN CALL SCORES ON TORONTO TURF
description: Jorge Velasquez rode Open Call through an opening on the rail in the final strides today to overtake a crowded field at Woodbine and capture the $300,000 Rothmans International Championship Stakes, the richest horse race ever held in Canada.

title: A GUATEMALAN REVOLUTION BACKED BY THE PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Smith; The Winter Pastime
description: WHEN Bowie Kuhn surrendered authority to schedule postseason baseball games to his television masters 11 years ago, he sowed the seeds that ripened yesterday in this popular ski resort.

title: HORS DE COMBAT
description: After nine months of rustication in Plains, Ga., Jimmy Carter surfaced in Washington last week and began to make noises like a Democratic Party spokesman. For a party with no recognized leader, his appearance might have been welcome but his statements on a broad range of issues from the propriety of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's attendance at the funeral of President Anwar el-Sadat to a broadside against President Reagan's economic program probably have harmed the disorganized Democrats more than they have helped.

title: Mark Nesoff, Lawyer, Marries Nancy Scheck
description: Nancy Lee Scheck, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Scheck of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Mark Nesoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Nesoff of the Bronx. Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony at Hisae's, a restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Graham's 70-280 Wins in France
description: LA-BRETECHE, France, Oct. 18 (UPI) - David Graham of Australia shot a two-under-par 70 today to win a $60,000 golf tournament.

title: London Police Call I.R.A. Bomb a Reprisal
description: A car bomb that critically injured the chief of the Royal Marines may have been in revenge for a marine action during the funeral of an Irish Republican Army hunger striker in Northern Ireland in July, the police said today.

title: Nobel Laureate Backs Effort To Make 'Reaganomics' Work
description: James Tobin, the Yale professor who last week won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, said today that ''Reaganomics'' was an incompatible blend of economic remedies.

title: Flyers 3, North Stars 2
description: Reggie Leach scored his seventh goal of the season as Philadelphia remained unbeaten. He put a 50-foot shot past Gilles Meloche 42 seconds into the third period for a 3-0 lead.

title: Accounts
description: * Converse, manufacturer of athletic footwear, to Ingalls Associates, Boston.

title: No Headline
description: Pate Wins by 3; Kite Tops Earnings List

title: RIOTING BY ALBANIAN NATIONISTS HAS LEFT SCARS IN YUGOSLAV REGION
description: Tension has eased in this capital and other parts of the troubled southern Yugoslav province of Kosovo, where Albanian nationalist riots left nine people dead and scores injured last spring.

title: U.S. HOPES TO RETURN SAFE-DEPOSIT TRIVIA FROM BYGONE BANKS
description: Thousands of safe-deposit boxes full of private treasures and such trivia as girlie magazines and false teeth may be returned to their rightful owners or heirs after half a century or more, the Government says.

title: Diana Marie Bass Wed to Joel Solkoff
description: Diana Marie Bass, an international economist at the Department of Labor in Washington, was married yesterday in Alexandria, Va., to Joel Solkoff, an author and freelance writer. Nicholas A. Colasanto, a court-appointed official of Alexandria performed the ceremony at Anchorage House.

title: KINNEY'S NEW PRESIDENT LOOKS CLOSELY AT METALS
description: Alan N. Cohen, former president and chief executive officer of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, has been elected president of the National Kinney Corporation, a diversified New York-based company.

title: Catherine Noone Wed to Philip Korsant
description: The marriage of Catherine Anne Noone to Philip Bowman Korsant took place yesterday at their home in Sherman, Conn. Probate Judge Barbara Ackerman of Sherman performed the ceremony.

title: CHAMBER: FIVE YOUNG ARTISTS
description: FIVE ardent young musicians opened the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Chamber Music series Friday with an evening of Prokoviev, Berg, Haydn and Dvorak. Half the program - Prokofiev's Sonata for Two Violins and the Berg Piano Sonata - seemed to bid a belated goodbye to the Romantic era.

title: MENTAL-HEALTH OFFICIALS' BURDEN IN THE PLIGHT OF THE HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Leona Nevler Leaves In Shake-Up at Fawcett
description: CBS, reportedly unhappy with the financial performance of its Fawcett Books unit, announced the formation of a three-member management committee with overall responsibility for Fawcett and its six paperback imprints.

title: Khomeini Assails Amnesty International
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran accused Amnesty International today of collaborating with ''all satanic superpowers'' to ''suffocate'' Iran.

title: U.S. Labor Leaders Rally For Philadelphia Strikers
description: The head of the American Federation of Teachers and about 100 other labor leaders from across the nation exhorted Philadelphia teachers today to continue their 41-day strike until their contract is honored.

title: KOCH SAYS REMARKS MAY HURT RELATIONS WITH BLACKS IN CITY
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that his remarks over the weekend criticizing racial quotas and busing might harm his relations with blacks in New York City.

title: How Far Is Fairness to Be Carried?
description: To the Editor:

title: AMID NOSTALGIA, U.S.O. IS HONORED
description: It was nostalgia time last night as Hollywood and Washington joined hands to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the United Service Organizations at a dinner dance at the Washington Hilton Hotel.

title: Profits Up 25% At First Boston
description: First Boston Inc., the investment bank holding company, reported sharply higher earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30. Its net income rose 25 percent, to $7.5 million from $6 million in the third quarter of 1980.

title: THE NEW LEADER
description: Last month, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's Prime Minister, ordered a tough army-police crackdown on lawlessness and anti-Soviet activity. In another breath, he asked the Solidarity labor union to join the Government in carrying out economic changes and to recognize the rationale of Polish alliance with the Soviet Union.

title: Residents' Donations Get Patrol Cars Back on Job
description: The Lawrence County Sheriff's Department, whose officers were ordered to respond only to life-anddeath emergencies after the office ran out of money to buy gasoline, is back in business.

title: POLISH PARTY GIVES HIS POST TO PREMIER
description: Stanislaw Kania, the Communist leader who gained power at the height of labor unrest nearly 14 months ago, was dismissed today and replaced by his Prime Minister, Wojciech Jaruzelski, a general.

title: Geers Gross To Put Sloane on TV
description: W&J Sloane, a major furniture chain, has assigned its account to Geers Gross Advertising. The account, worth about $2 million plus, had previously been handled in-house. The initial Geers campaign for the new client will represent the first time that Sloane has used television.

title: EX-CHAD OFFICIAL, IN SUDAN, REPORTED TO PLAN WAR
description: The former Defense Minister of Chad, whose insurgent forces were defeated with Libyan assistance last year by President Goukouni Oueddei, has begun to receive significant quantities of arms from Egypt, according to diplomats and Sudanese officials here. They say the arms are to be used in waging guerrilla warfare against the Chadian Government from the western Sudan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think there's a slight recession, and I hope a short recession.

title: AT YORKTOWN, CUISINE TAKES OVER FROM MUSKETRY
description: The smudgy ambience of campfires under pots of gruel at the 1,000-tent bivouac of the citizen ''army'' here for the mock battles of the Yorktown victory bicentennial was outsniffed today by the more exotic aromas of well-to-do 18th-century kitchens and contemporary French haute cuisine.

title: The Unplanned Brings the Unexpected
description: Dr. Aaron Klug is a freewheeling sort of scholar who says his research in molecular biology has been largely unplanned and that he never expected to win an award for it.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: EARLY JAPAN

title: BENGALS BEAT STEELERS BY 34-7
description: The Cincinnati Bengals took sole possession of first place in the American Conference Central Division yesterday by defeating the Pittsburgh Steelers, 34-7. Terry Bradshaw, the Steelers' quarterback, could not believe how easily the Bengals won.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: RUINING ZIMBABWE'S RUINS
description: This country takes its name from an African culture that flourished near here in the 14th and 15th centuries, leaving behind extensive foundations, walls and battlements of granite blocks to testify to its prosperity and sophistication.

title: THOSE LESS-THAN-TRUTHFUL LIE DETECTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Rival Cambodian Rebels Kill 20 at Thai Border
description: Rival groups of Cambodian guerrillas wielding grenade launchers and automatic rifles killed 20 people in a battle for control of a booming black market inside the Thai border, survivors of the clash said today.

title: Dolphins 13 Redskins 10
description: AT MIAMI - Uwe von Schamann kicked two field goals for Miami (5-1-1), including a 25-yarder with 9:34 left that gave the Dolphins the victory.

title: JUDGE ACCUSED OF YIELDING TO CRITICS IN RAPE CASE
description: A Massachusetts judge who gave suspended sentences to five men for a gang rape, then reversed his decision four days later has drawn a shower of criticism and charges that he let political pressure influence him.

title: SUPPORTERS CHEER FLORIO AS HE AND KEAN DEBATE
description: Debating in the Congressional District of Representative James J. Florio before a crowd that cheered Mr. Florio and booed Thomas H. Kean, the two major candidates for Governor of New Jersey differed today on how to deal with the elderly, transportation and economic development.

title: Police Raid Prison in Naples And Seize Arms and Drugs
description: Carabinieri policemen raided a topsecurity prison in Naples today and seized gas bombs, knives, heroin and large sums of cash, police sources said.

title: Couple Robbed At L.I. Home
description: Three men got away with $12,550 in cash and about $230,000 in jewelry and silver early yesterday when they robbed an Upper Brookville couple, holding them at gunpoint while ransacking their home, the police said.

title: THEATER: HWANG'S 'FAMILY DEVOTIONS'
description: IN his first two plays, ''FOB'' and ''The Dance and the Railroad,'' David Henry Hwang introduced us to Chinese immigrants who are still struggling up the lower rungs of America's economic ladder. That's why it's a jolt when the lights go up on this young writer's new, 70-minute-long play, ''Family Devotions,'' which opened at the Public last night. The setting is again California, but Mr. Hwang has moved far away from the scruffy Chinatown restaurant of ''FOB'' and the 19th-century labor camp of ''Railroad.'' What greets us instead - designed with Hockney-esque verve by David Gropman - is an airy, glass-and-blond-wood mansion in the ritzy Los Angeles enclave of Bel Air. This time Mr. Hwang's Chinese-Americans have made it big in the promised land.

title: THE 'BENEFITS' OF A RECESSION
description: An old rule of thumb on Wall Street is that an economic recession, painful as it may be for the unemployed or for corporate profits, is nevertheless good news for the credit markets. After all, past recessions have been accompanied by reduced credit demands that helped to lower interest rates and raise prices for notes and bonds.

title: BRIEFING
description: A FTER years of planning, controversy and replanning, sponsors of the proposed Tidal Basin memorial to Franklin Delano Roosevelt are hoping that the approaching 100th anniversary of his birth will galvanize agreement to finally start construction. A Senate Rules Committee hearing is scheduled next month on a measure authorizing construction of a memorial park with granite walls and fountains costing an estimated $23 million. Earlier plans that would have cost twice as much and included a more elaborate visitors' center were scaled back in the 37 years since the 32d President died. Thus far, no new round of objections is foreseen as the memorial plan is gingerly carried forward by two ranking Senate Republicans, Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, a member of the memorial commission, and Charles McC. Mathias Jr. of Maryland, the Rules Committee chairman. But proponents see the need for some clear resolve to proceed, and they hope the advent of the Roosevelt centenary Jan. 30 might be the spark.

title: Atlantic City Pier Destroyed by Fire
description: The second Boardwalk fire in less than a week destroyed the Garden Pier at the foot of New Jersey Avenue yesterday afternoon, and authorities called the blaze suspicious.

title: U.S. ISSUES FEATURED THIS WEEK
description: The United States Treasury is scheduled to sell $4.5 billion each of new three- and six-month bills at its regular auction today, followed on Wednesday by a $4.75 billion auction of new two-year notes. The minimum purchase is $10,000 for the bills and $5,000 for the notes.

title: HOBBYISTS REVIVING TEXAS LONGHORN
description: When Tom Chandler came back from a trip nine years ago with two longhorn cows and a longhorn calf purchased from a man who owned a trucking business, his friends were quick to take notice.

title: Publications Group Names New President
description: American Business Press Inc., the association of specialized business publications, has named Thomas H. King president. Mr. King, 48 years old, a group vice president at McGraw-Hill Publications, is succeeding Charles S. Mill, who retired from the post earlier this month. He will be taking over the salaried post on Nov. 2.

title: Primate Honored
description: More than 1,400 people, including Governor Carey and Mayor Koch, attended a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to honor Archbishop Iakovos, the Greek Orthodox Primate of North and South America on the occasion of his name day and the 22d anniversary of his enthronement.

title: LATIN AMERICA'S ECONOMICS LOSE STEAM
description: The economies of Latin America, emerging from a decade of substantial growth, are beginning to see their gains eroded by large trade deficits and mushrooming foreign debts, according to a regional bank report to be published tomorrow.

title: UNGARO AND LAGERFELD BRIGHTEN PARIS SHOWINGS
description: Emanuel Ungaro, with his clothes in magnificent silk prints, in colors of a luminous clarity, and Karl Lagerfeld's weightless airborne styles for Chloe opened the spring and summer ready-to-wear showings here in a glowing way. After that the descent was precipitous, and it was not simply the fault of the clothes.

title: FOR COLUMBIA ALUMNI, A TIME TO COME HOME
description: One of the rituals of autumn in the city - the annual Columbia homecoming for alumni - was played out in the picnic tents and ramshackle stands of Baker Field on the upper tip of Manhattan over the weekend.

title: POLISH PARTY GIVES HIS POST TO PREMIER; News Analysis
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's sudden installation as the new Communist leader of Poland was seen here as an attempt to stiffen the party's stand toward the Solidarity union. But it was not regarded as a signal that the policy of dialogue would be abandoned altogether.

title: 2D HOLDUP IN 48 HOURS
description: A 69-year-old taxi driver was found shot to death shortly before dawn yesteday on a deserted street in the Bronx. He was the second cabdriver slain in an apparent robbery in 48 hours and, according to taxi owners' organizations, the 17th to die violently this year.

title: Transoceanic Crossing
