description: Albert Ungar, who heads Century Opinion Polls in New York City, swears it happened just this way the other day when one of his employees, who happens to be an Englishman, tried to call a voter to get his views of Andrew J. Stein, the Manhattan Borough President.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Scores
description: Chris Evert Lloyd won 10 straight games in defeating an ailing Andrea Jaeger, 4-6, 6-3, 6-0, today in the final of the $125,000 Lynda Carter tennis tournament.

title: EMERSON PERSEVERES WITH HEART DEVICE
description: In September 1979, the Emerson Radio Corporation, a consumer electronics company based in Secaucus, N.J., stepped into unfamiliar terrain with the acquisition of 80 percent of a small company that had invented a first-aid device for heart attack victims.

title: Market Place; An Insurer's Real Estate
description: THE price tags on prime properties in most parts of the nation suggest that real estate offers few bargains today. But thoughtful investors sometimes find undervalued real estate on corporations' books.

title: Jill Cary Sandler Wed
description: Jill Cary Sandler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Sandler of White Plains, was married there yesterday to Charles Gulotta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gulotta of Nanuet, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center. Mrs. Gulotta is director of graphics at the Stamford (Conn.) Museum and Nature Center. Her husband is editor of the Tarrytown (N.Y.) Conference Center Newsletter.

title: Betty Friedan Ushers in a 'Second Stage'
description: Betty Friedan says the women's movement of the 1970's is at the ''second stage,'' consolidating hard-won gains and moving forward to new goals but certainly not ''over,'' as so many people say.

title: CITIES SAVE ENERGY WITH IMAGINATION
description: Stereo Village put solar-powered calculators on sale this week. The clothing stores have specials on sweaters and long underwear. And a kitchen equipment shop is demonstrating how to prepare Mexican food at a low energy cost.

title: MUSHROOM IMPORTS HURT U.S. FARMERS
description: The beam from the light on Gary Shroeder's cap cut through the dank darkness, gleaming on white plants mottling a bed of partly decayed organic matter, and the young man leaned over to pluck a plump mushroom and display it.

title: GOING GETS TOUGH FOR FLORIDA STATE
description: CLAY STAPLETON sits back on the farm these days, hundreds of miles away from Florida State University, where he was the athletic director for 16 months in the early 1970's, and just as far away from the fast pace of bigtime college athletics. After 20 years as a football coach and 10 more as an athletic director, he moved to Marshall, Mo., where there are no budgets to balance, no high school players to recruit and no alumni to satisfy.

title: New School's Writers Series Starts; Writers Series At the New School
description: Pietro Di Donato, 70 years old, and Sterling Brown, 80, are participating in the New School's ''Conversations With Writers'' series devoted to American literature, which began last week.

title: 'ONE LITTLE TATTLER'
description: Jimmy Carter's declared intention to sue The Washington Post for libel has piqued the public appetite for a Great Case. But few so far have realized what is likely to be the really interesting issue in such a case - and the tough one for The Post and the press generally. That is a demand by Mr. Carter to know the sources of the offending story.

title: ...AND THE OLD
description: As long ago as last spring, the common wisdom in Warsaw was that Stanislaw Kania was finished after only seven months as the leader of Poland's Communist Party. He had failed to halt the endless strikes and economic crises that had brought down his predecessor, Edward Gierek, and the death knell of his own leadership was being tolled in Moscow.

title: Auto Safety Unit Suing Over Emissions Decree
description: The Center for Auto Safety said today that it was filing suit to keep in effect major portions of a consent decree that prohibits auto makers from taking joint positions on emissions standards.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE DOUBTS GOOD FAITH OF AGENCIES IN DISCLOSURE DISPUTE
description: A Federal judge criticized the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday as he refused to dismiss a lawsuit seeking documents about a missing Soviet defector.

title: BURROUGHS H. PRINCE
description: Burroughs H. Prince, a retired editor for the National Broadcasting Comparny, died Thursday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 75 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: PRIVATE VIDEOTAPING OF COPYRIGHTED TV RULED INFRINGEMENT
description: Videotape recording of copyrighted television programs, even if done at home only for private use, is an infringement of the rights of those who own the programs, a Federal appellate court in San Francisco ruled yesterday.

title: AIR PRODUCTS & CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALPHA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BSD MEDICAL (CO) reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Burlington Northern Gain
description: Burlington Northern Inc., which operates the nation's longest rail line, said today that its third-quarter net income rose 59 percent compared with the similar period in 1980.

title: U. of Pennsylvania's First Inauguration in 86 Years
description: It has been 86 years since the University of Pennsylvania held formal inaugural ceremonies for a new chief executive, but on Friday the tradition will be resurrected for its new president, Sheldon Hackney.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TO CONTROL PARLEY ON AGED
description: To the Editor:

title: ARIZONA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Index; International

title: JUSTIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TEXT OF MAYOR KOCH'S ADDRESS TO DEMOCRATIC STRATEGY COUNCIL IN
description: BALTIMORE Following is the text of a statement by Mayor Koch, which stirred controversy over the weekend, before the Democratic National Strategy Council in Baltimore Friday:

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: W ITH the exception of Gianfranco Ferre, Karl Lagerfeld, Giorgio Armani and Emanuel Ungaro, no one on the Continent has so far served anything in a spring collection worth adding to the menu. But those four have given us the waist to think about again. In fact, while the long-skirt debate continues, the real story may lie higher up. Lagerfeld has reintroduced the corset, in a version unappealingly severe and not as playful as Perry Ellis's soft corset of last spring or as useful as Calvin Klein's wide belt of this fall. But the point is the same. Corsets, while cinching the waist, paradoxically draw the eye to what is above and below, and can lead to a lifting or lowering of the waistline, which seems to be happening.

title: Talking Business with Particelli of Booz-Allen; New Products Risky as Ever
description: Despite the increasing sophistication of marketing research methods, the management of new products remains as risky as ever. On average, the success rate of new products is no better than it was 20 years ago, according to Booz-Allen & Hamilton Inc., the management consulting group, which first tackled the subject in a major study in 1956.

title: French Jobless Down
description: French seasonally adjusted unemployment in September fell to 1.81 million from a revised 1.84 million in August but was up from 1.45 million in September 1980, the Labor Ministry said today. French adjusted unemployment hit a 1981 high of 1.85 million in July and has now fallen for the second consecutive month.

title: John Corrigan Plays A Sonata by Medtner
description: John Corrigan's piano recital at Alice Tully Hall last Tuesday evening centered on the ''Sonata Romantica'' of Nikolai Medtner. Medtner, a Russian composer who functioned during the first half of this century, enjoyed the praise of Scriabin and Rachmaninoff, and his musical style owes a great deal to both men.

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1981; The Economy
description: The recession is likely to push the jobless rate over 8 percent this winter, an Administration economist said. A recovery beginning in the first quarter of 1982 is hoped for. (Page A1.) President Reagan's surprise acknowledgement of a ''slight recession'' isn't likely to produce new policy initiatives, economists agree. (Page D27.)

title: Big Days Back for Barkum
description: There haven't been many days like yesterday for Jerome Barkum in recent years: a team-leading five receptions, one for a 19-yard score, in the Jets' 33-14 victory over the Buffalo Bills. But in recent weeks such days have become the norm.

title: Citicorp Plans A New Note
description: Citicorp, the parent of Citibank, announced yesterday that it would offer a new type of short-term, floating-rate debt instrument to institutional and corporate investors, beginning on Thursday. The holding company said its new notes would be issued in variable amounts.

title: A PEKING OFFER TAIFEI MUST REFUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. HAUPTMANN'S CAUSE
description: ''I have to go on,'' said Anna Hauptmann, explaining her extraordinary vigor at age 82, and slowly curling her frail fingers into a fist. ''This has to be done, and I'm going to do it!'' With that, she gave the table a good rap.

title: GIDDINGS & LEWIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to include operations of Snyder Corp acquired Mar 2, 1981

title: BANKS ARE REPORTED ENTHUSIASTIC ON INVESTMENT IN M.T.A. VEHICLES
description: Investors have responded enthusiastically to a plan by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to involve private corporations in the purchase of 632 railroad cars and buses, M.T.A. and banking officials said yesterday.

title: Ohio Gets Death Penalty
description: A new Ohio law that legalizes the death penalty for the third time in the state's history took effect today. Those who commit murder are now subject to the death penalty under certain conditions, including murdering while committing rape, robbery or burglary or while fleeing after committing one of those crimes.

title: ROLM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
MUBARAK BLAMES A 'LIMITED NET' OF 'FANATICS' FOR KILLING OF SADAT
description: President Hosni Mubarak said today that a ''limited net'' of ''fanatic'' plotters were involved in the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat 13 days ago and that a recent wave of arrests was rooting them out.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOME LIKE IT COOL

title: REOPEN PATCO TALKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Sperry Wasn't In the Dark, After All
description: Dr. Roger W. Sperry, one of the winners of the Nobel Prize in Medicine or Physiology announced on Oct. 9, returned home from a camping trip late Friday to be greeted by a week-old telegram announcing that he was a co-winner of the award.

title: No Headline
description: 22 Jailed Students in Algeria Said to Be on Hunger Strike

title: Ryder Unit Orders G.M. Vehicles
description: Ryder Truck Rental of Miami, a division of Ryder System Inc., has ordered 5,600 trucks costing about $75 million, the G.M.C. truck and coach division of the General Motors Corporation said.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When were the terms B.C. and A.D. first used and who introduced them? Why is B.C. in English and written after the number, while A.D. is in Latin and placed before the number?

title: SFM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings and shrs outstndg for the yr ago periods have been restated to reflect 5 percent stock divd paid Dec 29, 1980

title: STA-RITE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
QUOTRON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BROADWAY CELEBRATES EUGENE O'NEILL'S BIRTHDAY
description: Last night was Eugene O'Neill night on Broadway, as nearly 600 of the playwright's friends and admirers gathered at the Circle in the Square to pay tribute to his memory and to the theatrical legacy that has so enhanced their lives.

title: News Analysis
description: Mayor Koch and his observations on race relations provoked controversy again, this time over the weekend in Baltimore, where Democratic Party leaders gathered to search their souls as part of a newly formed National Strategy Council.

title: INTERMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTHWEST BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SWEARING-IN OF PAPANDREOU EXPECTED TO COME TOMORROW
description: Andreas Papandreou, whose Socialist party surprised even its most militant members with the extent of its election victory yesterday, is expected to be sworn in as Prime Minister on Wednesday.

title: WILDLIFE LAND IS IN DISPUTE BY 2 AGENCIES
description: Confusion among bureaucrats and conflict in Congress have slowed a decision on transferring wildlife refuge land on Matagorda Island to the State of Texas.

title: JOBLESS RATE RISE, TO ABOVE 8%, SEEN BY ADMINISTRATION
description: The recession that President Reagan has said is under way will likely drive unemployment to a rate of more than 8 percent this winter, an Administration economist predicted today.

title: WORCESTER BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $417,000 extraordinary tax credit

title: Addenda
description: * Science Digest magazine increasing both its circulation rate base, to 500,000 from 450,000, and advertising rates, by 11.1 percent, effective with the January issue.

title: Ground Broken in Pittsburgh For Subway to Open in 1984
description: Ground was broken today for a 1.1-mile downtown subway system scheduled to open in late 1984.

title: Retail Margins Rise
description: Retail companies' after-tax profits averaged 1.7 cents for each dollar of sales in this year's second quarter, up from 1.1 cents in the first quarter and 1.6 cents in the second quarter of 1980, the Federal Trade Commission staff reported today.

title: PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect 50 percent stock divd declared in Aug; Revs during the third qr and 9 mos were increased by 807,000 as a result of the Sept 1981 acquisition of the operations of Neotec and Belfab

title: Menotti Song Cycle to Be Performed Tomorrow
description: The last song cycle Gian Carlo Menotti wrote, in 1967, was for the soprano Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, but now the composer has written a new cycle of four songs, for a considerably lesser known singer, a New York tenor named Joseph Porrello.

title: Harold C. Havighurst, Authority on Contracts
description: Harold Canfield Havighurst, a professor and dean of the Northwestern University School of Law for 35 years until his retirement in 1966, and a recognized authority on the law of contracts, died last Tuesday in Alexandria, Va., where he resided. He was 83 years old.

title: Guard Dogs Cut Subway Graffiti
description: Guard dogs and fences at the Corona subway yard in Queens have dramatically reduced graffiti on subway cars in the last month, a Transit Authority official said yesterday, and use of the dogs will be extended to other yards.

title: BAKER DENIES 'FINAL' G.O.P. ACCORD ON TRIMMING BUDGET CUTS
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader, said today that there were ''no final arrangements'' concerning efforts between Senate Republican leaders and White House officials to trim by more than half the $13 billion package of new budget cuts proposed by President Reagan for the fiscal year 1982, which began Oct. 1.

title: MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes tax benefits of $523,000 for the qr and $584,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes tax benefits of $126,000

title: NORTHWEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After pretax charges of $34 million for a reserve in connection with discontinued operations

title: More Daylight Time Weighed in Congress
description: In hopes of saving lives, reducing street crime and conserving oil, there is a move in Congress to extend daylight saving time, which ends this year at 12:01 A.M. Sunday.

title: GRACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared Sept 25, 1981 in the form of a 50 percent stock divd

title: AFTER 11 YEARS, SEWERS ARE ARE OPERATING
description: While the trial on charges of corruption in the Southwest Sewer District goes on, the $932 million project in Suffolk County is beqinning to go into operation.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 4
description: Shr earnings adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split paid June 15, 198

title: Yachtsman Suspended
description: Burt Keenan of Lafayette, La., the owner of Acadia, one of the country's leading ocean-racing yachts, was suspended from racing yesterday for one year by the sport's governing body. Keenan was disqualified because of irregularities in Acadia's handicap rating certificate that were found to be ''substantial and without mitigating circumstances,'' according to the statement issued by the United States Yacht Racing Union.

title: UNITED BANKSHARES OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $260,000 in qr and $469,000 in the 9 mos...C-After loss from discontinue operations of $265,000 and a gain from sale of discontinued operations of $2.5 million

title: STATE AGENCY SEEKS HYDROELECTRIC-CREDIT CUT
description: The Power Authority of the State of New York yesterday called on Congress to eliminate many of the financial incentives that have spurred a nationwide boom in the development of small hydroelectric power plants.

title: EXPERT ON CLILDREN'S EYE DISEASE
description: Dr. Algernon B. Reese, an internationally known ophthalmologist who was a pioneer in the treatment of a serious eye disease in children, died yesterday at his home in Bedford Hills, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STAFF CHIEF QUITS INTELLIGENCE UNIT
description: John F. Blake, staff director of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, resigned today, partly because of what Congressional aides said he perceived as his lack of authority,

title: HASBRO INDUSTRIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $695,000 loss for the qr and $413,000 gain for the 9 mos from discontinued operations and $1.4 million nonrecurrin gain for the 9 mos on the sale of licensing rights

title: Ribicoff Case Trial Ordered
description: The man accused of murdering Sarai Ribicoff, the 23-year-old niece of former Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut, was ordered today to stand trial in Superior Court for the slaying last November. Frederick Jerome Thomas, 22, has been charged with murder, attempted murder and robbery in the case.

title: 2 Get 5 Years' Probation In Fixing of Lottery
description: Two brothers were sentenced today to five years probation for rigging the Pennsylvania lottery. They avoided jail by helping prosecutors convict a television announcer and a lottery official.

title: Stanley Clements, 55, Played Tough Kid in 'Going My Way'
description: Stanley Clements, who portrayed a tough street kid reformed by Bing Crosby as a determined young priest in ''Going My Way,'' died of emphysema at Pacoima Hospital on Friday. He was 55 years old.

title: UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIBBEY-OWENS-FORD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $33 million charge relating to the closing of a Toledo plant, $6 million charge from settlement of litigation and $1.3 million gain from the sale of real estate...C-Net inco D-Including $4.8 million gain on the sale of real estate and $700,000 charge relating to the closing of a plastics plant...E-After $10.2 million charge for closing of several plants

title: U.S. BEGINS QUOTAS ON USE OF AIRSPACE BY PRIVATE PILOTS
description: With delays for the nation's air travelers nearly twice what they were last month, the Federal Government imposed strict new regulations yesterday on private pilots seeking to use the strikedepleted air traffic control system.

title: SEDCO: GROWTH IN ADVERSITY
description: More than most companies in the business of drilling offshore oil wells around the globe, Sedco Inc. has found itself in the spotlight during the last few years - and not always in ways it would like.

title: Protestant Militant in Ulster Slain by Police at Roadblock
description: Policemen shot and killed one man in a stolen taxi that raced through a roadblock early today and arrested two others, a police spokesman said.

description: B-After $216,000 foreign exchange loss...C-After $14,000 foreign exchange loss

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Dale Electronics Inc., a subsidiary of the Lionel Corporation, amended its Securities and Exchange Commission registration on a proposed public offering by Lionel of 650,000 shares of Dale stock.

title: A Last Loud Roar And On to Series
description: MONTREAL DAVEY LOPES fielded a ground ball off Jerry White's bat, threw carefully to Steve Garvey, and Bob Welch was right there to fling his arms around the first baseman. In from their fielding positions and out from the bench poured the Dodgers to lay hands on Garvey, on Lopes, on Welch.

title: AN EATING DISORDER OF BINGES AND PURGES REPORTED
description: WIDESPREAD By JANE E. BRODY

title: Ruling in Drug Case
description: Dr. Patrick Mazza Jr., who admitted he improperly prescribed amphetamines to several members of the Phillies and the wives of some Philadelphia players, received a one-year stayed suspension of his medical license yesterday. The ruling was made by Frederic Antoun, the hearing officer for the State Board of Medical Education and Licensure. Dr. Mazza will have to submit quarterly reports of prescriptions he writes for certain controlled substances as a condition of the stayed suspension.

title: Moe Bandy, Texan, With the Rodeo Clowns
description: Moe Bandy, the Texan country singer who has been called ''The King of Honky Tonk,'' made a rare New York appearance Thursday at a new country-music club, Sundown, 56th Street between Second and Third Avenues. A well-appointed venue for country, Sundown is highceilinged and modern, with table seating, a dance floor, a balcony and excellent acoustics.

title: POGO PRODUCING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: 11 YOUNG DANCERS TAKING FIRST BIG STEP TO STARDOM
description: They have been the sugar plum fairies and the enchanted princes - the bright young stars of local ballet schools and small regional companies.

title: CHARLESTON MUSEUM BURNS
description: A fire yesterday destroyed the 82-yearold Charleston Museum. Three firefighters were injured and two dozen elderly residents of a nearby nursing home were evacuated when fire swept through the museum.

title: FIRST NATIONAL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

CREATING FARMLAND THROUGH SCIENCE
description: Contrary to general belief, farmland is not a ''natural'' r esource. It had to be created out of some form of wilderness, at s ome time in the past, and once created it has to be maintained in a f ertile condition. In many parts of the world, including the United S tates, large areas of good farmland are being lost, in part by beingu sed for nonagricultural purposes, in greater part as a result of u nwise agricultural practices. At the same time, however, new f armland is being created elsewhere, on a large scale, as I saw d uring a recent visit to Brazil.

title: MANUFACTURING NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: WORDS AREN'T RIGHTS
description: Nations and peoples have no moral obligation to deceive themselves. Yet in human rights matters today, self-deception is an awesome temptation. All of us would like to believe that there are ''internationally recognized human rights.'' In two important senses there are, but in others there are not.

title: The Smokeless Alternative
description: Those who find it difficult to give up cigarettes may at least be able to switch to a safer alternative. Instead of inhaling the noxious vapors into their lungs, they can satisfy their craving for nicotine by sniffing powdered tobacco.

title: MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Arafat in Moscow For Routine Talks
description: Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived in Moscow tonight at the head of a Palestinian delegation for routine talks with Soviet leaders.

title: LABOR DEPT. SETBACK FOR GRUMMAN
description: The Labor Department called today for the ouster of the three trustees of the Grumman Corporation's pension plan in a lawsuit that, if successful, would help the LTV Corporation in its $450 million bid to take over Grumman.

title: Two East Germans Defect
description: Two East Germans slipped across the fortified border between Czechoslovakia and West Germany last night and asked for asylum. The Bavarian Border Police said today that the men, 21 and 26 years old, told West German guards that they were dissatisfied with conditions in East Germany.

title: Holders Issue Nestle Letter
description: A group of Nestle shareholders demanded in an open letter today that only Swiss citizens be eligible to hold the two top posts in the $13 billion-a-year company.

title: U.P.S.'s Air Service May Shift to Grey Unit
description: There are reports that the United Parcel Service is assigning its Blue Label Air business to Grey, Conahay & Lyon, a subsidiary of Grey Advertising.

title: CITY WINS POINT ON PRODUCTIVITY DURING SUMMER
description: An arbitrator ruled yesterday that New York City could discontinue shortened summer hours for many of its employees and establish a uniform policy on lateness for work. As a result, the city expects to save $4.5 million a year.

title: WHEELABRATOR-FRYE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 results include the results of Pullman Inc acquired in Oct 1980

title: FRANCE WILLING TO CONTRIBUTE TROOPS TO SINAI FORCE
description: The new French Government would be willing to contribute troops to a peacekeeping force in Sinai, President Francois Mitterrand said today.

title: Gulf Canada Sets 2 Japanese Loans
description: Gulf Canada Ltd., an affiliate of the Gulf Oil Corporation, is expected to sign contracts here next month to raise two yen-denominated loans totaling $113 million, banking sources said. The loans will be raised from Japanese banking syndicates.

title: EVEN BRITISH CHEERY AT FETE OF YORKTOWN
description: What is it like to be British here at America's gala celebration of Britain's worst defeat of the Revolutionary War?

title: Arthur John Block, Journalist And a Theater Publicity Man
description: Arthur John Block, a journalist, playwright and theater publicity man, died of cardiac arrest Saturday at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 65 years old and lived in New York City.

title: KINARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vornado Store Closings Seen
description: Vornado Inc., the operator of the Two Guys discount store chain, plans to close a ''substantial number'' of its stores in New Jersey and Connecticut in the near future, according to reliable trade sources.

title: TOBACCO PROGRAM SCARES DEMOCRATS
description: Frightened by the prospect of political retribution in the South next year, Democratic leaders were working today to find House votes that would protect the tobacco program from an assault by liberal Frost Belt lawmakers.

title: LASERS, X-RAYS AND QUANTUM MECHANICS PROMINENT IN NOBELS
description: TWO Americans and a Swede were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics yesterday for their work in developing technologies with lasers and other devices that can seek out the innermost secrets of complex forms of matter.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HAWTHORNE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STAGE: 'GRACE,' THE WORK OF A NEW PLAYWRIGHT
description: WHILE it's noble of the American Place to present the work of new playwrights, the gesture is empty if this nonprofit institution isn't going to provide its fledgling writers with any strong guidance. Like most of the plays this theater staged last season, its first 1981-82 offering, ''Grace,'' seems many, many revisions away from anything resembling a finished script. By giving such an embryonic work a full-blown production, the American Place accomplishes little beyond embarrassing the playwright, Jane Stanton Hitchcock.

title: GIANTS NOW LOOK TO TOPPLE A CONTENDER
description: If the National Football League playoffs began tomorrow, four of the five National Conference teams would be the Philadelphia Eagles (with a 6-1 record), Minnesota Vikings (5-2), San Francisco 49ers (5-2) and Dallas Cowboys (5-2). The fifth would be the Atlanta Falcons, Los Angeles Rams, Tampa Bay Buccaneers or the Giants, each at 4-3.

title: BEVERAGE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-Including $669,000 gain from an accounting change

title: Y Chamber Symphony Gives Twist to the Past
description: The past moment can never be what it once was. But at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night, in the opening of the fifth season of the Y Chamber Symphony, the ensemble's director, Gerard Schwarz, put together a sparkling program that gave that fact a few twists.

title: One City, Fiscal '82 First article of a series appearing periodically on the impact of the Reagan budget on an economically troubled city, St. Louis.
description: When the budget cuts began in Washington, this city's effort to prevent lead poisoning in children was to have lost 25 percent of its Federal financing. By the time the money was allocated by the Missouri state government early this month, the Federal portion of financing for that program was calculated at no more than $37,000, or 7 percent of the $522,700 received in the last fiscal year.

title: BURNS, R L, CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $1,515,000 for the latest yr and $3.2 million for the previous yr

title: PETITIONS TO OUST WATT GO TO CONGRESS
description: Environmental groups today presented to Congress more than a million petition signatures urging the removal of James G. Watt as Secretary of the Interior and said they would conduct a grass roots political effort next year against Administration policies.

title: AVEMCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPY SATELLITE REPORTEDLY AIDED IN SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: ASECRET Air Force reconnaissance satellite was maneuvered into position to inspect the heat-protection tiles of the space shuttle during its first flight last April, according to a report in the magazine Aviation Week and Space Technology.

title: What Is Muscle Fatigue?
description: Everyone suffers from muscle fatigue from time to time and, of course, everyone knows what muscle fatigue is - or do they? An editorial in The Lancet, a medical journal published in England, says the definition is by no means as obvious as most people might think.

title: FOUR YEARS OF DONATIONS BUILT $120 MILLION HOSPITAL OF FAITH
description: A year ago Oral Roberts said he had a vision: A 900-foot figure of Jesus came to him as he prayed, assuring him that the City of Faith Hospital would be built.

description: B-After $766,999 loss from discontinued operations

title: Canteen Chief Aims At Leisure Market
description: James T. McGuire, who has spent his entire working life at the Canteen Corporation, has been named president and chief executive officer of the vending, food service and concessions company with headquarters in the Merchandise Mart in Chicago. He succeeds Howard C. Miller, 55 years old, who resigned from the concern, a subsidiary of the Trans World Corporation.

TWO PLAYS RECAST LEADING ROLES
description: TWO plays whose Broadway openings have been delayed by major cast changes have completed their search for replacements. Michael O'Keefe will take over Eric Roberts's role as the rebellious young seminary student in ''Mass Appeal,'' to open Nov. 11 at the Booth Theater. And Maureen Anderman will play opposite Peter Strauss when ''Einstein and the Polar Bear'' opens at the Cort Theater on Oct. 29. She will have the part once held by Barbara Hershey.

title: MIDLAND-ROSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RICHARD ROTH, 58, STATE SENATE AIDE
description: Richard J. Roth, who served for more than two decades as an adviser and chief spokesman for the State Senate's Republicans, died yesterday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany after a long illness. He was 58 years old and lived in Loudonville, N.Y.

title: TRITON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
6 Guards in Iowa Prison Taken Hostage, Freed
description: wielding Iowa State Penitentiary inmates, angry at being locked up since an uprising Sept. 2, took six guards hostage today, then released them two hours later when the authorities announced, ''We're coming in.''

title: Lawmakers From India Will Travel to Peking
description: An Indian Parliament delegation, which last week canceled a proposed visit to China in a controversy over disputed territory, will now travel to Peking under a mutually acceptable formula.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE HILL OF KRONOS. By Peter Levi. 222 pages. Dutton. $12.50. THE GREEKS AND THEIR HERITAGES. By Arnold Toynbee. 334 pages. Oxford. $19.95.

title: Autopsy Aide Describes 12 Drugs in Presley Body
description: Twelve drugs were found in blood and tissue samples from Elvis Presley's body, a biochemist testified today. Dr. Norman Weissman, a research associate at Bio Science Laboratories in Van Nuys, Calif., testified for the prosecution in the trial of Dr. George Nichopoulos, who is charged with prescribing excessive amounts of drugs for Mr. Presley and others.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: CAN leadership be culled from the grass roots? Can potential leaders be encouraged and trained to help improve life in local communities? Can a foundation identify such people and should it help them to acquire the knowledge and political influence they will need to overcome resistance from entrenched powers?

title: POLISH UNION REACTS MILDLY TO PARTY'S TOUGHER LINE
description: Stunned like the rest of the country by the sudden replacement of the Communist Party leader, the Solidarity union reacted mildly today to a new party program that laid down a sterner line in dealing with the union.

title: A HARD-DRIVING INVESTIGATOR'S POWER
description: Picture this familiar Washington scene: a Senate committee room jammed with reporters and cameramen. All eyes and cameras turn toward the chairman, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the powerful new Republican head of the Labor and Human Resources Committee, as he opens a hearing into charges of mismanagement at the National Cancer Institute.

title: SEPTEMBER PLANT USE OFF TO 78.5%
description: American manufacturers cut back on factory use again in September, as the national economy slowed in what President Reagan is now calling a recession, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Dwarf Star Found Hotter Than Sun
description: Astronomers have found a tiny, very dense star to be 20 times hotter than the sun, the National Science Foundation reported today.

title: REAGAN AND MITTERRAND OBSERVE 200TH ANNIVERSARY OF YORKTOWN
description: In speeches marking the bicentennial of the British surrender at Yorktown, President Reagan and President @Francois Mitterrand of France today hailed that Revolutionary War campaign as the event that established the tradition of free, representative government in the West.

title: Trudeau Says End of October Is Deadline for Charter Pact
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau set the end of October today as the deadline for reaching a compromise with provincial leaders who object to the changes he plans to make in Canada's century-old British constitution.

title: People
description: * Simone Hoffman named senior vice president, corporate product marketing at Max Factor & Company.

title: United Technologies, Apple, Natomas Gain
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that net income in the third quarter rose 14.8 percent on a sales increase of 11.6 percent.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 20, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NEW TITLE FOR PRESIDENT OF EQUITABLE BANCORP
description: H. Grant Hathaway, the 54-year-old president of the Equitable Bancorporation, a major bank holding company, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Owen Daly 2d, 57, who will continue as chairman until the end of the year, when he will become an adviser to the corporation.

title: MAGNUSON COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $421,000 for the qr and $1,121,000 for the 9 mos

title: NATOMAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Some Are Troubled By Lebow's Moves
description: Fred Lebow was sitting in his fourth-floor office of the Road Runners Club's new headquarters at 9 East 89th Street, a six-story gray building with 14,500 square feet that was purchased last year for $1.3 million. He was wearing a long-sleeve blue cotton sportshirt with thin red stripes, jeans, and as usual, running shoes. The date on the calendar behind his desk read ''Oct. 7,'' suggesting that time had stood still for more than a week.

title: METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $76,793 for the qr and $282,777 for the 9 mos and $3,155,000 gain on the sale of discontinued business for the 9 mos...C-Net loss after $139,842 loss from discontinued operations...D-After $91,588 loss from discontinued operations

title: The Art of Kicking the Poor
description: The holes in President Reagan's safety net for the poor keep getting larger. Now the White House wants to let the states set eligibility and benefit levels for food stamps. And as can be seen in New York, the local reserve nets are hardly secure; the victims of earlier Federal welfare cuts may soon be allowed to fall through the state's ''home relief'' program as well.

title: Air Products Net Up
description: The Air Products and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter increased 23.6 percent, to $28.8 million, or $1.01 a share, from $23.3 million, or 82 cents a share, in the corresponding period in 1980. Sales increased 9.1 percent, to $403 million, from $369.3 million.

title: PAPER BY HINCKLEY SEIZED BY GUARDS
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., who is charged with shooting President Reagan and three other persons on March 30, sat silently today through seven hours of courtroom testimony about a mysterious document taken from his cell in July.

title: Who Lost What in Greece
description: It may well be that local factors, notably a yearning for change, explain the election victory in Greece of a Socialist regime with a marked neutralist tinge. But there is more to it than that. Roughly half of Greece's voters chose a party advocating the closing of American bases and withdrawal from the military wing of NATO. That program evidently was no liability to Prime Minister-elect Andreas Papandreou. And defending military alignment with the West did not save Prime Minister George Rallis, whose New Democracy Party has ruled since 1974, when Athens rid itself of the ''colonels.''

title: 'WATCHER IN WOODS,' REVISED $1 MILLION WORTH, TRIES AGAIN
description: HOLLYWOOD WALT DISNEY'S ''The Watcher in the Woods'' opened in New York on April 17, 1980, and was clubbed to death by the critics. ''I challenge even the most indulgent fan to give a coherent translation of what passes for an explanation at the end,'' Vincent Canby, The New York Times critic, wrote of the ghost story-science fiction hybrid, which starred Bette Davis, Carroll Baker and Lynn-Holly Johnson. It seemed that Disney's desperate attempt to attract a new and older audience had ended in still another failure.

title: PAROLEE IS HELD
description: The body of a shy, intellectually gifted, 13-year-old boy who was abducted near his home in Shirley, L.I., on Saturday was found yesterday in a marshy area in Mastic Beach on Long Island's South Shore.

title: ADOPTING THROUGH THE CLASSIFIEDS
description: Stanley Michelman, a New York City lawyer, says he handled 12 adoptions of babies obtained through classified advertisements in South Carolina newspapers last year.

title: BREZHNEV PRAISES NEW POLISH LEADER
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev signaled satisfaction today with the selection of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski as the new leader of Poland's Communist party, lauding him as a consistent supporter of Soviet-Polish friendship and urging him to use his ''great prestige'' to rally Polish Communists against ''counterrevolution.''

AN ECONOMIC CATCH-22
description: James Tobin of Yale, the new Nobel Laureate in economics, came to New York University the other day and sternly criticized President Reagan's economic program - then gently ribbed it as a hybrid.

title: ARE OUR SCHOOLS REALLY DEMOCRATIC?
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOOTINGS OF CABDRIVERS SPUR NEW POLICE ACTION
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire, deploring the mounting violence against taxi drivers, announced yesterday stepped-up police protection for them, with 30 to 50 more officers being assigned to the department's 13- member taxi squad.

KUHLMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday incorrectly stated the magnitude of a cooling trend meas- ured in the Northern Hemisphere since the 1930's.

title: A BITTERSWEET TIME FOR MURCER
description: The wooden rocking chair in front of Bobby Murcer's Yankee Stadium locker has traveled with him across the country and back again since he bought it in 1973, and with each passing year its symbolism becomes more poignant.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per shr figures reflect a 5 percent stock divd paid in Aug 1981

title: LIBYA CALLS OIL COMPANIES TO DISCUSS OUTPUT AND PRICES
description: Libya has summoned representatives of Western oil companies to Tripoli to discuss oil pricing and production, several European and American companies reported yesterday.

title: Classic
description: The need for stocking caps and pin-striped blankets notwithstanding, we were half hoping that Montreal would win the National League championship yesterday. It would have moderated the chauvinism of the term ''World'' Series had there been one that was at least international.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge: Vu-graph and TV to Carry World Event Play-by-Play
description: The world team championships beginning at the Rye Town Hilton here tomorrow will offer a rare opportunity for local enthusiasts. They will not be able to breathe down the necks of the players, who will be in small rooms accompanied only by officials. Instead, they will watch a Vu-graph show, with commentary by Edgar Kaplan and Jean Besse, while seeing the players on splitscreen closed-circuit television.

title: Newmont Talks With Gold Fields
description: Court-ordered talks on a mutually agreeable level of purchases that Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd. would make in the Newmont Mining Company have resumed, Gold Fields said.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXCHANGE BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COAST GUARD SAYS AID TRIMS WOULD FORCE CUTS IN PATROLS
description: The Coast Guard's efforts to stop the illegal trade in drugs and aliens would be severely curtailed if the Reagan Administration's 12 percent across-the-board budget cut for Federal agencies was to go into effect immediately, Adm. John B. Hayes, the Coast Guard Comandant, said at a news conference here this morning.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chemical Bank has named John M. Eggemeyer 3d a senior vice president.

title: EXPERT VIEWS POLITICS' TIES TO PAINTINGS
description: It is, John Wilmerding was saying as he looked at Sanford Robinson Gifford's ''The Artist Sketching at Mount Desert,'' a quintessentially American painting.

title: PARIS: CLOTHES FOR REAL PEOPLE
description: Serenity prevailed at the fashion openings today as designers known originally for their couture collections presented their ready-to-wear styles for spring and summer. The clothes by Christian Dior, Chanel and Hubert de Givenchy reflected the style of their made-to-order collections and certainly approximated those people could wear. Unfortunately, they were not riveting. Still, the fashion theater of the absurd has receded for a spell and it is soothing to see clothes with some basis in the real world.

title: U.S. APPROVAL REPORTED ON A PLAN TO SAVE HOSPITAL ON STATEN ISLAND
description: The Reagan Administration has approved an agreement that averts the closing of the United States Public Health Hospital on Staten Island, and calls for spending $26 millio, the area's Representative in Congress said yesterday.

title: IN OLD JERUSALEM, PRAYER CAN BE AN INCENDIARY ACT
description: Shortly after noon last Thursday, a group of about 30 Jews walked briskly up a long, curved ramp to the Gate of the Mughrebins, which opens onto Jerusalem's Temple Mount.

title: BANK AMERICA EARNINGS DOWN 32.8%
description: In sharp contrast to the third-quarter results of most other major banking companies, the BankAmerica Corporation yesterday reported an earnings decline of 32.8 percent from the period a year earlier. The company is the corporate parent of the Bank of America, the nation's largest bank.

title: Press Notes
description: The Associated Press account of a thrilling 200-mile-an-hour ride down a California freeway was almost too good to be true, so The Los Angeles Times began checking and found out it wasn't true.

title: Bullets Get John Lucas
description: The Golden State Warriors, under the right of first refusual, matched the Utah Jazz offer for John Lucas, a free agent, yesterday, and traded the guard to the Washington Bullets for second-round draft choices in 1982 and 1984. Lucas, who averaged 8.4 points in 1980-81, was suspended by the Warriors late in the season after missing several practices and games.

title: SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $4.1 million writedown; yr-ago results restated to reflect an accounting change

title: TWO WOMEN KILLED AND ONE CRITICALLY HURT BY HIT-AND-RUN DRIVER
description: Two young women were killed and a third critically injured when they were struck on a rain-slicked Bronx street by a speeding automobile that did not stop, the police said yesterday. The force of the impact drove the three women more than 100 feet along the pavement.

title: STAUFFER CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DODGERS WIN PENNANT IN NINTH
description: In the final inning of the final game, the Los Angeles Dodgers won the National League pennant today when Rick Monday hit a two-out home run off Steve Rogers to beat the Montreal Expos, 2-1.

title: 2 Fire Marshals Hurt in Accident
description: Two city fire marshals were seriously injured when their automobile was struck by a van in Long Island City, Queens, the Fire Department said.

title: HOPE FOR CHESTNUT FOUND IN VIRUS THAT FIGHTS BLIGHT
description: handled basket from the crackling fireplace, shook out some roasted nuts and handed them to visitors gathered in the main lodge of the Chimney Corners resort here. ''This is a rare occasion now, '' he said, ''but 50 years ago it was commonplace. It's sad that that most people don't know what a real American chestnut tastes like anymore.''

title: Homelite Thins Agency Search
description: The Homelite division of Textron, which recently went through a mutually agreed upon split with Henderson Advertising, Greenville, S.C., has decided on the six agencies that are going to compete for its account, according to a reliable agency-world source.

title: SEALED POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $5.3 million gain on the sale of an interest in two Mexican subsidiaries

title: TV: 'BECOMING A MAN,' ON 2 YOUTHS MATURING
description: ''THE BODY HUMAN'' series began as explorations of the latest technical marvels in medicine, almost lyrical in their admiration for modern science and its practitioners. Now, with ''Becoming a Man,'' on CBS-TV this afternoon at 5 o'clock, it is moving in hazier, less illustratable directions. The subject is the process of maturing.

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JOLTED WHITE HOUSE IS HOPING TO AVOID CONFRONTATION WITH GREECE
description: Andreas Papandreou, whose Socialist party surprised even its most militant members with the extent of its election victory yesterday, is expected to be sworn in as Prime Minister on Wednesday.

title: DEATH PENALTY FOR ACCOMPLICE OF KILLER FACES COURT REVIEW
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the death penalty could be imposed on someone who participated in events that led to a murder but was not the actual killer.

title: Market Place; Teledyne Plan For Harvester
description: MANY in the Wall Street community are perplexed by Teledyne's persistent investments in International Harvester, the troubled Chicago farm equipment and truck manufacturer.

title: Agnew Papers Unsorted and Still Controversial
description: Although the University of Maryland has had the papers of Spiro T. Agnew for seven years, they remain stored in a secret place, unsorted and almost totally ignored, and the debate continues on what should be done with the material.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1981
description: International The American and French Presidents hailed the British surrender at Yorktown in 1781 as the event that established the tradition of free, representative government in the West. But in careful, polite language the two leaders also indicated their differences over how the ideals of the American Revolution applied to the present. President Francois Mitterrand suggested that Washington should provide more support for the third world, while President Reagan stressed his goals of a smaller Government and a stronger military. (Page A1, Columns 4-5.) The Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to Kenichi Fukui of Japan, whose work was neglected for decades, and to Roald Hoffmann of Cornell University, who developed a similar theory independently. Their work involves what is considered a major advance in applying the theories of quantum mechanics to predict the course of chemical reactions. (A1:2-4.)

title: ALASKA AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $1.5 million gain on the sale of aircraft; yr-ago shrs earnings have been restated to reflect a 5 percent stock divd in Dec 1980

title: TYMSHARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRITAIN PLANNING TO END ITS STATE GAS MONOPOLY
description: The British Government, announcing expanded plans to reduce the role of state-owned companies in the energy industry, said today that it would end the monopoly of the British Gas Corporation in supplying natural gas.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
MCGRAW-EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 Milan Policemen Slain in Shootout
description: Suspected urban guerrillas shot and killed two antiterrorist policemen, seriously wounded a third and slightly injured a passer-by today in a shootout on a busy Milan street.

title: ABC OUSTS 'MORNING' PRODUCER
description: In what it termed a long-standing disagreement over the ''concept and direction'' of ''Good Morning America,'' ABC-TV yesterday announced the resignation of George Merlis, who helped create the show in 1975 and has been its executive producer for the last two and a half years.

title: WHEAT, CHAFF AND PCB'S
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has told its regional offices to stop ordering cleanups of alleged hazardous-waste sites without prior approval from Washington. So far, approval has been denied for about half the requests. ''We see it as a method of separating the wheat from the chaff, cutting out the Mickey Mouse,'' said Douglas M. Macmillan, deputy assistant administrator for hazardous-waste enforcement. (The New York Times, June 21, 1981)

title: Anne deB. Young, 62, Curator At Cloisters and Medievalist
description: Anne deBonneville ''Bonnie'' Young, associate curator of the Cloisters, the medieval center of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, died of cancer here. She was 62 years old.

title: U.S. PLAYS DOWN INVOLVEMENT IN NIXON TRIP
description: The Reagan Administration, trying to smooth any political complications arising from former President Richard M. Nixon's visit to four Arab nations, sought today to dampen reports that his trip had caused frictions in the Administration and to play down the Government's involvement in the trip.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The aspirations of the peoples of the world today are just as legitimate as those of our forefathers.

title: White House to Oppose Voting Rights Provision
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would ask the Senate to delete from the House-passed extension of the Voting Rights Act a provision President Reagan has described as ''pretty extreme.''

title: Crocker Bank Sues Rockwell
description: Crocker National Bank has filed suit in Federal court here seeking $52.8 million in damages from the Rockwell International Corporation and two other defendants in a dispute over financing of data processing equipment.

title: JACKSON'S SERIES ROLE A PUZZLE
description: If the designated hitter were part of this year's World Series, Reggie Jackson would know before tonight whether he could play in the opener between the Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: No Headline
description: RAIDER BET CHARGE DISCOUNTED

title: BIG THREE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFING
description: A RAM Bakshian, a 37-year-old special assistant to President Reagan for the arts, is scheduled to step into the vacant job of chief White House speechwriter. Mr. Bakshian wrote speeches for Presidents Nixon and Ford and has written several books, including ''The Candidates - 1980,'' and ''The Memoirs of Robert Stolz,'' which is about the life of the last Viennese waltz king, who died in 1975. The job of chief speechwriter at the Reagan White House has been unfilled since Ken Khachigian left last spring to return to his consulting business in California.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: EVERYONE knows that drinking and driving is a dangerous mixture. But taking any of hundreds of prescribed drugs and driving may be equally dangerous, although that fact has gone largely unstudied and there have been few expressions of alarm.

title: APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 net income including a $9,493,000 gain on the sale of Geo Space Corp and $545,000 or $2.01 a shr income from discontinued operations

title: KARPOV DELAYS GAME 8 OF WORLD CHESS MATCH
description: Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, today postponed until Thursday the eighth game of his title match with Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland.

title: UNION METAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $133,364 for the qr and $283,774 for the 9 mos; yr ago results reflect the sale of Superior division; yr ago shr earnings restated to reflect stock divd paid Mar 19, 1981

title: Physician, 78, Is Found Dead In Office, Bound and Gagged
description: A 78-year-old physician was found dead - bound and gagged - in his office in Midtown yesterday evening, the police said.

title: NEW HOME BUILDING DOWN 1.7%
description: New housing construction fell 1.7 percent in September, to an annual rate of 918,000 units, the thirdlowest level on record, the Government reported today.

title: 3d Series for Harvey
description: Doug Harvey, the National League umpire, who worked in the 1968 and 1974 World Series, was among six umpires selected by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for this year's Series. Also selected were Nick Colosi and Dick Stello of the National League, and Larry Barnett, Terry Cooney and Rich Garcia of the American League. It will be the first Series for Cooney and Garcia.

title: IRAN PICKS U.S.-TRAINED DOCTOR TO BE PREMIER
description: Iran said today that a 36-year-old Islamic fundamentalist who received medical training in the United States had been chosen the new Prime Minister.

title: DUCOMMUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: Results have been restated on a pooling of interests basis to reflect the merger with Aerochem Inc on June 30

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Very Well, Tax Sin Some More
description: President Reagan, it appears, is ready to face some sobering realities. Responding to a reporter's question Sunday, he acknowledged that the economy had entered a ''slight recession.'' Moreover, White House aides now concede that Congress is in no mood to cut this year's budget even by an additional $6 billion, let alone the $13 billion the President wanted. If the Federal deficit is to be kept near $50 billion, new revenues will have to be found.

title: WAGNER DISRUPTED IN TEL AVIV
description: Zubin Mehta left the podium angrily last night when an outburst of protests erupted in the Mann Auditorium after the Israel Philharmonic had played two bars of the prelude to Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde.'' The reaction to the music of the 19th-century composer who had been a favorite of the Nazis left the future of Wagner performances in Israeli concert halls uncertain.

title: U.S. TO SEND AID TEAMS TO SCOUT THIRD WORLD
description: The Reagan Administration today outlined how it intended to give private enterprise a larger role in American foreign aid.

title: Pacific Holding's Dan River Stake
description: The Pacific Holding Corporation, which is controlled by David H. Murdock, a Los Angeles financier, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired a 5.76 percent interest in Dan River Inc., a major textile and apparel manufacturer.

title: Floods in South India Kill 110 After Irrigation Dam Bursts
description: An earthen irrigation dam burst in the southern Indian state of Karnataka today, killing at least 110 people, the United News of India reported.

title: TREASURY BILL RATES INCREASE
description: Interest rates turned upward at the weekly auctions of Treasury bills yesterday. The average rate on the three-month bills was 13.613 percent, up from 13.526 at the previous sale. The average rate on the companion six-month issue was 13.795 percent, up from 13.50.

title: Andrea Doria's Safe Belches Strange Gas
description: Another mystery from the Andrea Doria is bubbling to the surface in the New York Aquarium at Coney Island, and Peter Gimbel, who explored and filmed the sunken liner this summer, is worried.

title: HOMESTEAD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW SATELLITE MAY FINALLY DETERMINE WHETHER MAN IS DAMAGING OZONE LAYER
description: AN American satellite circling the earth from pole to pole has begun to return data that could resolve the issue of what impact manmade fluorocarbons have on the fragile upper-atmospheric layer of ozone that shields life from the sun's deadliest rays.

title: August Ad Revenues Are Put at $1.5 Billion
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau said that August ad revenues for daily newspapers rose 14.6 percent, to $1.5 billion, from the same month last year.

title: Lions Trounce Bears by 48-17
description: Eric Hipple, in his first start as a pro, passed for four touchdowns and ran for two other scores tonight to lead the Detroit Lions to a 48-17 victory over the Chicago Bears.

title: PIERCE, S S, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes $437,000 nonrecurring gain from the sale of the State Line potato chip subsidiary to a group of its employees

title: BAMBERGER TO BE MET MANAGER
description: George Bamberger, a native of Staten Island, is expected to be named the Mets' ninth manager today. Bamberger, 56 years old, who reportedly has signed a three-year contract at a salary of $200,000, would succeed Joe Torre, who was dismissed on the final day of the season.

title: FINANCE CHARGE CUT ON SOME G.M. CARS
description: Amid forecasts that the automobile industry's aggregate third-quarter loss could exceed $600 million, the General Motors Corporation said today that it had dropped by almost a full percentage point the interest rate it charged customers who borrow from its financing subsidiary to buy certain new G.M. cars.

title: KENNAMETAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tax Vote in Michigan To Close a 2d District
description: Voters in this Detroit suburb today defeated a tax rate increase, despite a warning that the district's 30 schools would close next month. The district is the second in Michigan to face a shutdown within a week.

title: ATLANTIC RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Basketball Fix Trial Put Off to Tomorrow
description: The Federal trial of Rick Kuhn, one of three former Boston College basketball players reportedly involved in point-shaving, was postponed yesterday to tomorrow.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Including $6.7 million extraordinary tax credit for the qr and 9mos and $1.2 million loss for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...D-After $3,850,000 loss from discontinued operations...E-Operating loss...F-Net loss after $18.7 million loss from discontinued operations

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for QTr to Sept 25
News Analysis
description: President Reagan's surprise remark that the nation's economy was in a ''slight recession'' may have startled his economic advisers, but it is not likely to send this Administration on the search for new policy initiatives.

title: EDUCATION
description: PROPOSALS for further cutbacks in Federal student aid programs suggest that a fundamental shift may be under way in the Government's commitment to promote wider access to higher education.

title: TRIAD SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
XIDEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
F-18 Order Set By Australia
description: The Australian Government is expected to announce today that it will place an order valued at between $2.5 billion and $3 billion for 75 McDonnell Douglas F-18 Hornet fighter aircraft, according to Australian sources.

title: 9 States in South Work On Atomic Dump Pact
description: Nine states near one of the nation's three radioactive waste landfills moved closer today to a plan that could close the site to the rest of the nation.

title: BUSINESS EXCHANGE INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
Advertising; Magazine Conference Reflections
description: AS with any event covered by the news media, there were a lot of nuggets of information to be found at the annual Magazine Conference last week in Palm Springs, Calif., that did not show up immediately in the pan.

title: ULSTER COURTS GET FEW COMPLAINTS
description: To the Editor:

title: UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes after tax foreign currency gain of $16 million... C-Includes after tax foreign currency loss of $900,000

title: Capital Occasions for Executive Spotlight
description: To the Editor:

title: A 60'S RADICAL COMES OF AGE
description: According to his American-born wife, Greece's Prime Minister-designate, Andreas Papandreou, ''is not anti-American but pro-Greek; he is against United States policies which are inconsistent with Greek national interests.''

title: CASE ACCEPTED ON EMPLOYER'S ROLE IN UNION BIAS
description: The Supreme Court, dealing with a case that has considerable importance for employers who rely on labor unions to screen and supply workers, agreed today to decide whether the employer can be held liable when the union hiring hall discriminates against blacks.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S REMARKS
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's remarks today at the bicentennial observance of the British surrender at Yorktown. The prepared text was made available by the White House.

title: Dow Drops 4.56; Volume Up
description: The stock market, beset by worries over the course of the economy and the outlook for interest rates, lost further ground yesterday after its fairly broad sell-off last week. Selected aerospace stocks, however, scored gains following the disclosure that the Air Force had selected the Northrop Corporation as prime contractor for initial development of the Stealth bomber.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TALK WITH EGYPT'S PRESIDENT
description: Following are excerpts from an interview today with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt:

title: SIMPSON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
6-Day Workweek Voted Out
description: General Tire Company workers voted 5 to 1 yesterday to change their schedule from a six-day, six-hour-aday workweek to a five-day, eight-hour-a-day workweek that will cost 60 to 70 jobs. The plant employs 1,500 people.

title: Recovering From March 30
description: It's business as usual for Timothy J. McCarthy, the 31-year-old Secret Service agent who was wounded in the liver last March 30 during the assassination attempt on President Reagan. He is back on the Presidential protective detail.

title: GREATER JERSEY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $63,897 for the qr and $184,034 for the 9 mos on the extinguishment of debt

title: 3 WIN IN PHYSICS
description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded yesterday to a Japanese whose work in explaining chemical reactions was neglected by the rest of the world for decades and to a younger American who independently developed similar theories.

title: Memorex and Tandy in Pact
description: The Tandy Corporation will buy or lease the consumer products division of the Memorex Corporation under a tentative agreement announced today by Memorex. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: BANC ONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPUTER DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PHIBRO NET OFF 28.1%
description: The Phibro Corporation, a leading international commodity trading concern, said yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter fell 28.1 percent, to $78.8 million, or $1.15 a share, from $109.6 million, or $1.61 a share, in the third quarter of 1980. Sales advanced 20 percent, to $6.6 billion, from $5.5 billion in the 1980 period.

title: F.D.A. Study Worries Makers of Drugs
description: The A.H. Robins Company sold $64 million worth of Robitussin cough preparations last year, but the Food and Drug Administration says that it is unclear that any of them helped consumers.

title: TENNANT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: * Air Florida Systems Inc. said it had increased its share in Western Airlines to 12.6 percent of the common stock outstanding.

title: MARVIN JOSEPHSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Controllers Snarl Traffic to Airport
description: Motor traffic entering La Guardia Airport was snarled for more than two hours yesterday as striking air traffic controllers staged another stall-in on airport roadways in an effort to call attention to their nationwide strike, which is in its 12th week.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SCIENTISTS SEEK TO CAPTURE CONDORS TO SAVE THEM
description: Many years ago, Indians snared birds on the scrub-carpeted slopes of the San Rafael Mountains here. It is a reasonable surmise that their aggregate effort did not approach current exertions aimed at capturing birds for their own good.

title: WHITEHALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RHODES RECALLS GLORY
description: It was around 11 o'clock on a recent morning, and in Ginger's Tavern, beside the docks on Staten Island, a baldish man with a widecreased face sat on a bar stool stirring his pick-me-up. Alongside him were a few of his fellow tugboat men.

title: PARTNER JOINS SAKS IN PLANS FOR A TOWER
description: Saks Fifth Avenue announced yesterday that it had entered a joint venture with Rockefeller Center to develop a 690,000-square-foot office tower at the rear of its flagship store on Fifth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets.

title: Moon in South Korea, Church Aide Asserts
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the head of the Unification Church, is in South Korea, a spokesman for the church said yesterday. The spokesman said she did not know whether Mr. Moon would return to the United States for his arraignment on charges of omitting more than $150,000 of his income in tax returns oover three years.

title: EGYPT DISMISSES 134 IN THE ARMY SUSPECTED OF 'EXTREMIST LEANINGS'
description: Thirty Egyptian officers and 104 enlisted men have been dismissed from the army and transferred to civilian jobs because of suspected ''extremist religious leanings,'' the army command announced today.

title: Suspect in Slaying On Bus Is Held
description: A 26-year-old man was arraigned in Criminal Court in Brooklyn and ordered held without bail on charges that he killed a city bus driver on Oct. 10.

title: Yankees; Pitchers (Throws, Won-Lost, ERA); Ron Guidry (L, 11-5, 2.76)
description: Eligible to be a free agent, so he could be making his last start or two for the Yankees. After a so-so first half, he rebounded with a 6-2 record, 1.74 e.r.a. in second half. However, he gained his last victory Sept. 13, failing to win in his last four starts of the regular season despite allowing three earned runs in 19 innings. Tommy John (L, 9-8, 2.63)

title: Strikers Dispute Injunction
description: Striking Philadelphia school teachers today asked Pennsylvania's Commonwealth Court to dismiss a back-towork injunction that was issued in an effort to end the walkout, now in its 42d day. James Binns, an attorney representing the 22,000-member Philadelphia Federation of Teachers, argued that the injunction had created chaos in negotiations to end the dispute.

title: Court Cites New Bar on Tax Data
description: The Internal Revenue Service's long-running legal battle with a Washington State couple over the disclosure of tax audit criteria came to an end in the Supreme Court today because of a provision in the new tax law.

title: Occidental Net Declines 13.5%
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, the country's 11th-largest oil company and the first of the major oil companies to report thirdquarter results, said yesterday that net earnings in the period fell 13.5 percent, to $115.7 million, or $1.15 a share, from $133.7 million, or $1.62 a share, in 1980.

title: TREASURY BACKS CHANGE IN SAVINGS BABK AID
description: In a major policy shift, the Treasury Department today supported a legislative change that would make it easier for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to assist financially troubled mutual savings banks.

title: Car Makers' Backlog Rises
description: Sluggish sales in September pushed inventories of new cars built in the United States to a 69-day supply on Oct. 1, up from a 64-day supply on Sept. 1, an industry journal reported today.

title: Uranium Released at Plant
description: Federal investigators were at the Nuclear Fuel Services plant here, where about 100 grams of radioactive uranium was accidentally released into the atmosphere Oct. 11, the authorities said today. A spokesman for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said that no workers were contaminated and nearby residents were not in danger. The plant processes uranium into fuel for the Navy's nuclear submarines.

title: MORTGAGE DEFAULTS INCREASE
description: Mortgage delinquency and foreclosure rates are reaching the worrisome proportions of the mid-1970's, putting the hard-pressed housing industry under still more pressure.

title: TRIAL ON SEWER PROJECT BRIBERY NEARING END
description: A Federal prosecutor summed up the evidence today against three persons charged with conducting a $900,000 bribery scheme involving four federally financed sewer projects in three states. Suffolk County's $932 million Southwest Sewer District is among them.

title: Pravda Denounces Cancun Conference
description: The Soviet party newspaper Pravda today condemned the coming conference between industrialized and developing nations in Cancun, Mexico, as an attempt by the West to divide third world countries and subjugate them to satisfy its own economic interests.

title: PACCAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Norwegian Cruise Line Appoints a President
description: Howard A. Fine, 39, has joined Norwegian American Cruises in the newly created position of president. The New York-based company is a subsidiary of Leif Hoegh & Company, A/S, a Norwegian corporation operating in the shipping, hotel and related industries.

title: Comissiona Conducts City Opera in 'Attila'
description: The animal vitality of Verdi's ''Attila'' at the New York City Opera Sunday afternoon derived from several sources. The first was Sergiu Comissiona's conducting, which from the opening chorus to the murderous finale, kept singers and players alive and alert.

title: SUDAN CALLS U.S. AID DEFICIENT
description: The Sudan asserted today that military aid offered by the United States was insufficient to meet its immediate defense needs.

title: Muncey, Hydro Racer, Killed in Acapulco Race
description: Bill Muncey, who had won more unlimited hydroplane races than any other driver, suffered fatal head injuries yesterday when he lost control and flipped in the $175,000 World Championship race.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Oklahoma Authorities Accept Suspected Kidnapper's Alibi
description: Kidnapping charges against Donald Michael Corey were dismissed today, 10 days after he was arrested in the disappearance of two 13-year-old girls from the State Fair of Oklahoma.

title: AMERICAN STERILIZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $457,000 for the qr and $910,000 for the 9 mos; yr ago shr earnings have been restated for an accounting change

title: UNITED CENTRAL BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV: TRAVELING COUPLE IN RURAL SOUTH
description: IN ''A Few Days in Weasel Creek,'' a country-and-western movie on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock this evening, the tone is set in the first few moments. There, stretched across the family sofa, is a sleeping dog. That is presumably meant to be cute. Then, up on the roof and obviously preparing to run away from home, a young man proceeds to fall through some rotted shingles with a clatter that wakes up the entire family. That's meant to be funny. ''A Few Days in Weasel Creek'' is indeed cute and funny and, quite unexpectedly, charming.

title: ARMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $31.5 million or 58 cents a shr for the qr and 9 mos from the sale of preferred stock of Rowan Cos and $17.7 million gain for the 9 mos from settlement of litigation

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SESQUICENTENNIAL

title: OPEC SCHEDULES TALKS AIMED AT PRICE UNITY
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said yesterday that it had called ''an extraordinary conference'' in Geneva on Oct. 29 in an effort to heal the bitter pricing dispute that has divided it for most of this year.

title: Final Trade Pact Reached
description: Twenty-two Western industrial nations reached a final agreement today to reduce government export subsidies by 20 to 25 percent, the Treasury Department announced.

title: Q&A
description: Q. While eating steamed mussels at a restaurant, I crunched into something and, on investigation, found a small, dead, crablike creature, seemingly living on or in the mussel's body. Do you know what it was and if it was edible? It was brown and had a carapace.

title: JACKSON AIMS TO RETURN FRIDAY
description: Reggie Jackson said after missing last night's World Series opener that he was ''almost positive'' he would be in right field for the Yankees in Friday night's third game at Los Angeles.

title: DATUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BREZHNEV BIDS REAGAN HELP BAN A NUCLEAR ATTACK
description: In a rebuttal to President Reagan's comments on American and Soviet nuclear strategy, Leonid I. Brezhnev today called on Mr. Reagan to join in ''rejecting the very idea of nuclear attack as criminal.''

title: TEXAS EATING: ETHNIC VARIETY WITH A FRONTIER SPIRIT
description: Linda West Eckhardt is the author of ''The Only Texas Cookbook,'' published this month by the Texas Monthly Press. By LINDA WEST ECKHARDT

title: STADIUM HOSTILE TO DODGERS
description: Three years later, the Los Angeles Dodgers still found Yankee Stadium a hostile place last night, from Graig Nettles to the umpires to the fan who threw a Coke bottle into left field past Dusty Baker's shoulder.

title: REAGAN STANCE ON PATCO CAUSES UNIONS ANXIETY
description: A number of labor experts say that the Reagan Administration's response to the air traffic controllers' strike may seriously injure public employee unions and perhaps other unions as well.

title: Using School to Fight Disease
description: New York State's tough immunization law makes adversaries of educators and epidemiologists. To contain contagious childhood diseases, health officials understandably focus on school-age children, a large captive population.

title: OPERA: 'I DUE FOSCARI'
description: REFINEMENT is not the first quality that comes to mind when you think of early Verdi, but his sixth opera, ''I Due Foscari,'' is a miracle of elegance compared to works that went before it, such as ''Nabucco'' and ''Ernani.'' Still, as last night's performance by Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York at Carnegie Hall made clear, ''I Due Foscari'' can be turned into a rip-snorting melodrama in which its highly reputed musical nuances are underplayed in favor of traditional Verdian energy and vocal thrust. Whether that is the best way is another question, but certainly Miss Queler's concert version churned up considerable foam, some of it around mouths in the enthusiastic audience. Old-fashioned bellow canto was the order of the evening.

title: UNEXPECTED VISITORS
description: When Robert Wayne Leath escaped from the Maine State Prison at Lewiston last August, he apparently saw no need to flee too far, nor to make any great effort at going into hiding.

title: ALCAN ALUMINIUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods include an $18.8 million or 23 cents a shr gain from release of a provision for British income taxes and a $6.2 million writeoff associated with development costs of an aluminum smelter in Australia

title: RECORD PACE FOR VEGETABLE GARDENS
description: A record number of Americans - 47 percent of households - planted vegetable gardens in 1981, as people tried to combat rising food prices and cultivate a hobby.

title: 'Kudzu' in Rehearsal
