description: ''Kudzu,'' a play by Jane Chambers, has begun rehearsals at the Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42d Street.

title: A VISIT FROM A THREE-STAR CHEF
description: ONE of the pleasures of working with professional chefs is that there will not be much wasted energy in their planning and executing almost any menu that comes to mind. When an old friend, Roger Verge, chef and owner of the three-star Moulin de Mougins (as well as the one-star Amandier) in the hills above Cannes, was last in New York, he agreed, on short notice, to cook a meal.

title: U.S. PLEDGES AID FOR 3 MILE ISLAND
description: The Reagan Administration, in what appeared to be a major breakthrough toward resolving the impasse over financing the cleanup of the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear reactor, has decided to ask Congress to appropriate $123 million for waste disposal and research costs.

title: Edward Alley Named Philharmonic Manager
description: Edward L. Alley, director of the Martha Baird Rockefeller Fund for Music, has been named orchestra manager of the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Alley will begin his job Nov. 2, supervising all orchestra operations, including concerts, tours, special events and recording, broadcast and television.

title: IS G.&W. A WISE INVESTOR?
description: One of the more successful mutual funds is not operating from Wall Street, but rather from the headquarters of Gulf and Western, a $5.3 billion conglomerate whose diverse subsidiaries bring forth auto parts, women's apparel, movie hits like ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' and raw sugar.

title: 3 Scholarships in Publishing Offered
description: In an effort to attract students to a career in publishing, the Gulf & Western Foundation and Simon & Schuster have announced a twoyear scholarship program for one student each year from Columbia, Stanford and Tufts Universities.

title: BUCYRUS-ERIE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revs figures represent shipments

title: DELUXE CHECK PRINTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST OKLAHOMA BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROBERT E. WHYTE
description: Robert E. Whyte, a partner in Deloitte Haskins & Sells, the public accounting firm, died of cancer Monday at his home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: KEAN VISITS FLORIO HOME BASE IN CAMDEN TOUR WITH KEMP
description: Campaigning in his opponent's Congressional district today, Thomas H. Kean, the Republican candidate for Governor, called Camden a city virtually without hope after years of expensive government soafter years of expensive government social programs. He said that private entrepreneurs should be lured back into poverty areas through tax breaks.

title: Brazilian President to Return Home Without Heart Surgery
description: President Joao Baptista Figueiredo will return to Brazil this week without heart surgery and will be able to carry out his duties within a month, officials at Cleveland Clinic said today.

title: NEW FEDERAL POLICIES ALTER FOOD PROGRAMS
description: THE Reagan Administration, through budget cuts and policy proposals, is changing the course of Federal food and nutrition programs. The changes, some already made, others expected shortly, affect everything from what consumers buy in the supermarket to what their children eat in school.

title: LONG-TERM BOND PRICES FALL
description: Long-term bond prices dropped sharply late yesterday and yields rose in thin trading that dealers said was typical of a nervous market.

title: IF THE FAIRNESS DOCTRINE IS TAKEN OFF THE AIR
description: To the Editor:

title: A FESTIVAL AT WHICH THE OYSTER REIGNED
description: LEONARDTOWN, Md. No one found a pearl at the St. Mary's County Oyster Festival in southern Maryland last weekend. And no one cared. The 30,000 people who attended were there to eat the ''orysters,'' as the local people call them, or oysters, as everyone else does. Carloads of them were consumed in just about every form: raw, stewed, fried and scalded.

title: Spare That Tree, Court Tells Builder
description: An endangered, five-story-high ailanthus tree in the Murray Hill section was ordered spared by a State Supreme Court justice.

title: Careers; Computer Jobs on The Farm
description: A FARMER in Indiana might know more about computers, and might use them more often to manage the business, than some executives in New York City who use computers to determine inventories, profits per unit of sales and many other things.

title: White Award Upheld
description: Thirteen years after Andre White, a former San Diego tight end, injured his knee in a professional football game, an appeals court has upheld a $250,000 damage award against two attorneys in a complicated case. The unanimous two and a half-page ruling was issued yesterday by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in California.

title: Character Study
description: Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democratic of Suffolk, Congressional Record, Oct. 14, 1981: One thing upon which we can all agree, Democrat and Republican, liberal and conservative, is that the Libyan Dictator Muammar Qaddafi is a blot on the slate of human history.

title: Text of the draft letter, page A12.
description: The White House has prepared a letter saying that if Saudi Arabia should adopt ''policies which are disruptive to prospects for stability'' in the Middle East President Reagan would cancel delivery of Awacs planes.

title: A MAKER OF MIRRORS FINDS A NEW PLANT IN BROOKLYN
description: It would not insult Seldon Barlow to be accused of achieving his success with mirrors. Quite the contrary. He and a partner founded Marsel Mirror & Glass Products with $1,900 in 1947. Now it is a $25 million-a-year business, making the decorative mirrors that K mart, Woolworth's, Sears and other chains and houseware stores sell for $5 to $20. Some bear legends such as ''Home Sweet Home'' or ''Drink Pepsi-Cola.'' Some show scenes of nature or cuddly puppies. Some are merely mirrors.

title: Trainer Denies Abuse; Says He's Victim of Plot
description: David Jacobson, the New York-based trainer who has been charged with failing to provide adequate food and medical attention for a thoroughbred in his stable, denied the accusation yesterday and said that the charges resulted from ''anonymous phone calls'' to the authorities from ''people who hold grudges against me.''

title: FOR FANS, HIGH JINKS, PRICES AND HOPES
description: Outside Yankee Stadium before the first game of the World Series yesterday evening, the Jerome Avenue elevated train rumbled overhead carrying and depositing fans, hot-dog and salt-pretzel vendors were hustling their wares with hiked-up prices, and the ticket scalpers were busy.

title: ARTS AGENCY GIVES $7 MILLION TO PUBLIC TV AND RADIO
description: The National Endowment for the Arts announced yesterday that it had awarded $7 million for programs in music, drama, architecture and art on public television and radio during the next year. Livingston L. Biddle Jr., the endowment chairman, said previous grants for the arts on public television and radio had never exceeded $2.5 million at one time.

title: Northrop Down
description: The Northrop Corporation, said that its profit in the third quarter plunged 89.9 percent to $2.5 million, or 17 cents a share, from $24.8 million, or $1.74, in the similar period last year. The company cited a four-fold increase in spending for production of its new F-5G tactical fighter aircraft. Sales rose 30.1 percent, to $524.2 million.

title: BAYUK CIGARS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-Including $288,000 tax credit, $245,000 from accounting adjustment and $625,000 net proceeds from the company's terminated pension plan; yr-ago qr and 9 mos net income do not include $414,000 of unrealized gain in marketable securitie

title: PROVIDENT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $600,000 loss for the qr and $9.1 million gain for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-Including gains from discontinued operations of $900,000 for the qr and $12.3 million for the 9 mos

title: GOODRICH, B F, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $8.7 million or 44 cents a shr for the qr and $13.1 million for the 9 mos from divestments and the sale of shrs in Yokohama Rubber Co and $18 million or 94 cents a shr gain for the 9 mos from the exchange of a series of convertible preferred stock for certain of the company's debentures in the first qr

title: Incidents of Sabotage Triple, Official of South Africa Says
description: Incidents of sabotage in South Africa tripled in the first half of this year compared with the last half of 1980, Defense Minister Magnus Malan said in a speech tonight.

title: Australians Will Buy 75 McDonnell F-18's
description: In the largest military deal in Australia's history, the Government announced today that its new tactical fighter will be the McDonnell Douglas F-18A Hornet.

title: New Leading Man in 'We Roll Along'
description: ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' a musical in previews at the Alvin Theater, has changed its leading man and postponed its opening from Nov. 1 to Nov. 9.

title: MRS. CODD VIEWS RACE ISSUES
description: Mary T. Codd, the Liberal Party candidate for Mayor, was asked by The New York Times for her views on major issues confronting New York City. Following are excerpts from her reply on race. The views of the other major party candidates were published during the primary campaign; those of Dr. Jeronimo Dominguez, the Right to Life Party candidate, will be published later.

title: VIDEO RECORDER SALES GO ON
description: Retailers of video cassette recorders said yesterday that they expected little immediate impact on sales from Monday's court ruling that taping television programs violated copyright laws.

title: U.S. TO PRESS 3 DESEGREGATION SUITS FILED BY THE CARTER ADMINISITRATION
description: The Justice Department announced today that it would continue to prosecute three school desegregation cases filed late in the Carter Administration.

title: KENTUCKY, INDIANA AND OHIO END RIVER BOUNDARY DISPUTE
description: Almost two centuries of dispute over who owns what part of the shifting Ohio River ended today when Kentucky agreed to new boundary lines, an action that is expected result in the transfer millions of dollars in revenue to Indiana and Ohio.

title: AMALGAMATED SUGAR REFINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In This Case, Winner of Series Bet Gets Wine
description: It is that time of the year again: When the World Series starts, boosters in prominent places make public bets on the outcome, and this time Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Senator S. I. Hayakawa are betting cases of wines from their respective states.

title: CHINESE ARE HOPING TO SIZE UP REAGAN AT CANCUN
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang left today for Mexico to represent China at the conference of 22 rich and poor nations, an event that will also give the Peking leadership its first opportunity to take personal measure of President Reagan.

title: HE WILL BE SWORN IN TODAY
description: The victorious Socialist party announced the list of the new Cabinet of Prime-Minister-designate Andreas Papandreou early today after he had received a mandate from President Constantine Caramanlis to form Greece's first Socialist government.

title: TO PREPARE A NATION FOR FLEXIBLE RETIREMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: A STONE GRAIN MILL
description: IN some parts of the country, the harvesting of wheat has only recently been completed and the conversion of the wheat seeds into white powder has begun. For most of us, it is difficult to think of flour as having any real origin in the soil.

title: CBS VETERAN SERIES DOMINATES RATINGS
description: With the new television season finally under way, CBS-TV easily won the prime-time audience-popularity ratings race last week. Its veteran series, led by ''Dallas,'' ''60 Minutes,'' ''The Jeffersons'' and ''The Dukes of Hazzard,'' dominated 8 of the top 10 slots.

title: ENERGY ISSUES LEAD DOW RISE
description: Stock prices moved higher on expanded trading volume yesterday after retreating in six of the seven previous sessions. Energy, technology, brokerage, airline and defense issues ranked among the leaders. The Dow Jones industrial average finished at 851.88, up 4.75 points. At 3 P.M., the indicator was ahead nearly 9 points.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: A curious point comes to mind when following the debate on the proposed Awacs sale to Saudi Arabia. One of the main arguments put forth is the risk that the Awacs may fall into ''unfriendly hands'' if they are given to Saudi Arabia.

title: Sports of The Times; Mantle at 50
description: GRATEFUL but still somewhat surprised, the most productive hitter in World Series history celebrated his 50th birthday last night with his family and friends in Dallas.

title: Sears Acquires Coldwell Stock
description: Sears, Roebuck and Company said that approximately 1.3 million shares of Coldwell, Banker & Company common stock had been tendered, as of noon yesterday, in response to its $42-a-share offer to acquire up to 1.5 million shares.

title: Braves Look to Torre
description: Joe Torre, dismissed Oct. 4 as manager of the New York Mets, has been offered the job of managing the Atlanta Braves, The Atlanta Journal reported yesterday.

title: JORGENSEN, EARLE M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MANY CHILDREN DECIDE NOT TO BUY MORE COSTLY SCHOOL LUNCHES
description: Students in many states are choosing not to buy school lunches at the increased prices made necessary by a reduction in Federal subsidies.

title: AMERICAN FLETCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GREEK SOCIALISTS TROUBLING SPAIN
description: The Spanish Government is studying whether the Socialist election victory in Greece could turn out to be an obstacle to Spain's plans to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: American Express Gains
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its third-quarter profit was up 12.4 percent over the previous year. American Express said that its earnings totaled $145 million, or $1.56 a share, in the July-August period, compared with a profit of $129 million, or $1.45 a share, in the comparable 1980 period.

title: FILM: 'THE BOAT IS FULL,' REFUGEES ON THE RUN
description: ''The Boat Is Full'' (''Das Boot Ist Voll'') was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times of April 25, 1981. The film opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, at Third Avenue.

title: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $917,000 net loss from discontinued operations... C-Net income after $1,223,000 net loss from discontinued operations...D-After $4,223,000 net loss from discontinued operations

title: MEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $156,000 gain from the sale of nonoperating assets for the qr and 9 mos and $553,000 gain on the sale of nonoperating assets for the 9 mos...C-Includes $700,000 of reduction in income tax reserve no longer required

title: Crew Cut
description: The crew chief for Cale Yarborough's racer on the Nascar circuit has been dismissed. M.C. Anderson, the owner of the car, said that David Ifft, the crew chief, would be replaced by David (Pete) Anderson for the rest of the Grand National season. ''Yarborough's car has never handled the way it should, especially in the second half of the season,'' said Anderson. He said that Yarborough should have won four or five races this season instead of two - the Atlanta 500 in March and the Firecracker 400 in July.

title: GENERAL PORTLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
India Seeking French Jets
description: A high-level Indian military mission arrived here today to continue negotiations with France on a possible purchase of 150 Mirage interceptor jet aircraft in a deal worth $2 billion. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi says her country needs the planes to counter a United States decision to supply Pakistan with 40 F-16 fighters.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Treasury Plans Borrowing Rise
description: Faced with a record anticipated cash need of $34 billion this quarter, the Treasury said yesterday that it was increasing its borrowing in all maturities, including at the regular three-month and six-month bill auctions.

title: China Denies That Submarine Exploded During Missile Test
description: The Chinese Foreign Ministry has denied that a submarine exploded during a missile firing test and called the report ''sheer fabrication,'' the English-language newspaper China Daily reported today.

title: LUKENS STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
David Guion, Wrote 'Home on the Range'
description: David Wendell Guion, composer of ''Home on the Range'' and many other popular songs, died Satuday in a Dallas hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: WINE TALK
description: EVERYTHING up until now has been amateur night. All the training, all the sweat were nothing but preparation for this moment. It's Randolph Scott climbing out of the back cockpit and saying: ''Take her up, kid. She's all yours.''

title: OPERA: 'RIGOLETTO' RETURNS TO MET WITH MANUGUERRA IN LEAD
description: THE Metropolitan Opera may not be the Italian bastion it was under Rudolf Bing. But the Italian warhorses are still given their regular outings at the Met, and Monday night, John Dexter's production of ''Rigoletto,'' which ran for three seasons after its first appearance four years ago and had a rest last season, returned to the course.

title: Passbook Rate Rise Postponed
description: Government financial regulators voted today to reverse themselves and indefinitely postpone a one-half percentage point increase for interest ceilings on passbook savings accounts.

title: A EUPHEMIST TAKES A BOW
description: The Reagan Administration's fiscal euphemist has been run to ground. He is Lawrence A. Kudlow, who says he coined ''revenue enhancement,'' the euphemism for tax increase used by the White House last month.

title: Oil Bids Total $1.28 Billion
description: Energy companies' bids reached $1.28 billion today at the Interior Department's auction of Gulf of Mexico drilling parcels, bringing offshore leases by the department's Bureau of Land Management this year to a record $6.31 billion.

title: CLEVELAND-CLIFFS IRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCHLESINGER JOINS CODD CAMPAIGN AND CRITICIZES KOCH ON MINORITIES
description: Arthur Schlesinger, the historian, accused Mayor Koch yesterday of turning his back on the Democratic Party and minorities. Referring to the Mayor's speech to Democratic Party leaders in Baltimore last Friday, Mr. Schlesinger said, ''He tried to convert the Democratic Party nationally to a set of Republican principles.'' Mr. Schlesinger's remarks came as he announced he would be chairman of an independent citizens' committee for City Councilwoman Mary Codd, the Liberal Party candidate for Mayor.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE word ''gridlock,'' which achieved urban eminence during the transit strike, won't go away. Metropolitan Diary readers report that it is being used to describe almost any overcrowded situation - as when, recently, a radio sports announcer wondered whether runners would create ''a gridlock condition'' on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge at the start of Sunday's New York Marathon. And, a few weeks back, concertgoers were heard muttering about ''human gridlock'' in Central Park during the Simon and Garfunkel concert.

title: FIRE IN DOWNTOWN SKYSCRAPER INJURES 5 AND ROUTS HUNDREDS
description: Five persons were injured yesterday afternoon, one of them critically, when a fire flashed through corridors on the 47th floor of a skyscraper in lower Manhattan, the Fire Department said.

title: IN MONTREAL, EXPOS' LOSS SETS OFF BILINGUAL GLOOM
description: There was neither joy nor joie in Montreal today as this much-divided city united in sadness at the defeat of its pennant hopes.

title: SHARK IS GAINING, AS BARGAIN AND TREAT
description: ''What beautiful fillets,'' the woman in the tweed suit remarked in the Central Fish Market, on Ninth Avenue near 39th Street. The big slices were moist and delicately pink and white, with dark flecks. ''And only $1.59 a pound,'' she said. ''What are they?''

title: BROTHERS ARRAIGNED IN ENSLAVEMENT OF MIGRANT WORKERS ON FARMS IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: Two members of an Orlando, Fla., family were arraigned today before a Federal magistrate on charges of conspiracy in the kidnapping and enslavement of at least eight migrant workers. The indictment charges that in one instance the conspiracy led to the death of a man.

title: Davidson Is Hospitalized
description: The Rangers, already beset by a large casualty list, lost one more player yesterday as John Davidson, formerly their No.1 goaltender, checked into Lenox Hill Hospital for treatment of what was believed to be a sciatic-nerve ailment. Dr. Norman Scott, an orthopedist who is the team physician, said Davidson's treatment would consist of a few days of traction and bed rest. The object, he said, is to relieve pressure on the big nerves that run down the backs of the legs and to get the muscles completely relaxed. Dr. Scott said he thought the goalie could be discharged by this weekend and play immediately thereafter if he responded to treatment.

title: CITY CONTROLLER EXPECTED TO UNSEAT MAYOR IN HOUSTON ELECTION
description: In one corner is Jim McConn, the Mayor of Houston for the last four years, a bluff, hearty, 53-year-old Notre Dame graduate who looks as if he could have played defensive tackle at his old school. In the other is Kathryn J. Whitmire, 35 years old, slender and precisely 5 feet tall. As City Controller, she is the second most powerful elected official in town, and she has often tilted with and never backed down from the Mayor over how city funds should be spent.

title: EECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $2.8 million for the qr and $2.9 million for the 9 mos

title: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including net income from discontinued operations of $1,000 for the qr and $72,000 for the 9 mos

title: Search Data Debated In Atlanta Murder Case
description: Investigators who searched the home and automobile of Wayne B. Williams in early June hoped to find evidence linking him to at least 10 of the 28 young blacks whose deaths terrorized the city for almost two years, a judge was told today.

title: CANADA TUNGSTEN MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXCERPTS FROM WALTER MONDALE'S SPEECH TO THE FOREIGN POLICY ASSOCIATION
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale's speech yesterday to the Foreign Policy Association in New York:

title: YANKEES DEFEAT DODGERS, 5-3, IN SERIES OPENER
description: In case the Los Angeles Dodgers thought this World Series would be different from their last one against the Yankees, Graig Nettles suggested otherwise last night.

title: Free-Tuition Benefits In Jersey Broadened
description: Governor Byrne signed a bill today extending free tuition at New Jersey public colleges to survivors of certain law enforcement officials killed in the line of duty.

title: ANDERSON MAY BE TOLD TO GIVE BACK U.S. AID
description: Federal Election Commission auditors recommended to the commission yesterday that John B. Anderson's Presidential campaign organization be ordered to repay nearly $640,000 in Government funds.

title: Studying for Bahr
description: Walter Bahr, the Penn State soccer coach, has been invited to Denver by the Broncos to tutor their soccer-style place-kicker, Fred Steinfort, and he admits that the situation is delicate. ''I don't want to get into the politics of Denver football,'' said Bahr.

title: PLAY: 'BIG APPLE MESSENGER' AT WPA
description: SHANNON KEITH KELLEY'S ''Big Apple Messenger,'' which chronicles a day at a New York messenger service, is an American play from the David Storey school of shared activity, but without the English playwright's gift for transforming a life experience into metaphor. As Morty (Merwin Goldsmith), the manager of a Big Apple branch office, says to his employees, ''What you see is what you get,'' and his philosophy could serve as an apt observation about Mr. Kelley's play.

title: INFORMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $582,000 for the qr and $1.3 million for the 9 mos

title: LA MAUR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a 6-for-5 stock split paid in June 1981

title: SAMUEL BARAF
description: Samuel Baraf, former president and chairman of the board of United Transformer Corporation, died yesterday at his summer home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 80 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Brazilian Iron Ore Deal
description: A Luxembourg-based steel producer, Arbed S.A., said today that it had signed a long-term contract with Companhia Vale do Rio Doce of Brazil for supplies of Brazilian iron ore. It gave no details of the value of the contract or of the quantities of iron ore involved.

title: TRIAL OF 2 CRIME FIGURES TOLD OF PLOT TO KILL KEY WITNESS
description: A plot to kill a key witness was described yesterday at the Manhattan trial of Russell A. Bufalino, who was portrayed by the prosecution as ''the boss of a Pennsylvania crime family.''

title: POOR LANDS' NEED FOR OIL SWELLING
description: For the rest of this century, experts predict, almost all the growth in demand for oil will come from poorer countries, while the amount of oil consumed by industrial nations continues to decline.

title: JOHANSSON FINDING A NEW CHALLENGE
description: For five days after he ran his first and only marathon last August, Ingemar Johansson said the pain was almost unbearable. ''I had not felt pain like that,'' the former heavyweight boxing champion said yesterday, pointing to his thickly muscular thighs. ''I pushed down on my legs with my fingers, just touching them a little bit, and it hurt. Upstairs, I could walk. But not down.''

title: Ex-Leader Defies Turkish Ban
description: Despite a ban on political comment by politicians, former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit criticized Turkey's military rulers today for having abolished the nation's political parties and confiscated their assets.

title: EX-C.I.A. AGENT BEGINS DRIVE FOR WEICKER'S SEAT
description: Predicting ''a wild and woolly year,'' John T. Downey, a former intelligence agent who spent 20 years in a Chinese prison, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in 1982.

title: CROCKER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dutch F-16 Crashes
description: A Dutch Air Force pilot ejected to safety today when his F-16 jet fighter crashed into the sea north of the island of Ameland, a Defense Ministry spokesman said. Engine problems were blamed.

title: Grand Circle Travel Goes to Frank Vos
description: The Frank Vos Company, an agency that specializes in direct marketing, has a new client: Grand Circle Travel, a wholesale travel agent that specializes in the over-50 market.

title: FABRI-TEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $27,000 for the qr and $850,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including extraordinary credits of $108,000 for the qr and $188,000 for the 6 mos

title: G.O.P. OFFICIAL SAYS PARTY PAID FOR A POLL ON ISSUES OF AGING
description: A recent survey of the delegates to next month's White House Conference on Aging, in which their views on President Reagan's policies and other issues were sought, was commissioned by the Republican National Committee and financed by political contributions.

title: Texaco to Halt Its Gasohol Sales
description: Texaco Inc., the nation's largest gasohol dealer, said it would stop selling gasohol at most of its service stations because of flagging motorist interest and high costs. Texaco has been the oil industry's most vocal advocate of the alcohol-and-gasoline mixture and has marketed it at 1,600 stations in 19 states.

title: CLOW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,000 for the qr and $644,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $185,000 for the qr and $567,000 for the 9 mos

title: ABC Unit's Chief Going To Reeves
description: Seth H. Baker, 52, is moving to a smaller pond in which he will be a bigger fish. Until now the president of the ABC Publishing division of the American Broadcasting Companies, he has been elected president of Reeves Communications Corporation.

title: CONSOLIDATED FREIGHTWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,934,000 for the qr and $9,402,000 for the 9 mos, $71,547,000 gain for the qr and 9 mos on the sale of discontinued operations and $14,235,000 extraordinary credit for the qr and 9 mos... C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $7,313, for the qr and $8,342,000 for the 9 mos and $32,102,000 extra- ordinary charge for the qr and 9 mos

title: HOUSE G.O.P. BALKS AT A TAX INCREASE TO CONTAIN DEFICIT
description: House Republican leaders balked today at raising taxes to hold down a growing deficit for this fiscal year, jeopardizing an informal agreement between White Hguse officials and Senate Republican leaders.

title: STRINGS ARE ATTACHED BY SENATORS TO AID GOING TO PAKISTANIS
description: The Senate voted today to require an annual report from President Reagan on nuclear activity in Pakistan as a condition for the renewal of military and economic aid.

title: 5 in Colorado Sue Army For Beer Party Arrests
description: Five claims, each seeking $100,000 in damages, have been filed against the Army over an incident last July 10 in which 23 armed soldiers were ordered into a neighborhood in Fountain, Colo., to break up a beer party.

title: E-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INDIAN ANGER AT THE U.S.
description: Not since the era of Dwight D. Eisenhower, when the United States looked upon India's neutralist leader Jawharlal Nehru as a stooge of Moscow, have relations between Washington and New Delhi reached as low a point as they have today.

title: Two Guys Chain To Drop 12 Units
description: Vornado Inc., operator of the Two Guys discount chain, said that it would soon shut 12 of its stores but declined to specify which of its 46 units would be affected.

title: Bridge: Americans in Close Match As World Tourney Begins
description: Both American teams were involved in close matches when the world team championships began here this afternoon. The open team, playing Pakistan, and the women's team, playing Brazil, both led by 2 international match points with 16 deals completed of a scheduled 32 in the first round of qualifying play.

title: 2 KILLED BY BOMB AT ANTWERP SYNAGOGUE
description: A car bomb exploded outside a synagogue in the predominantly Jewish diamond-trading district here today, killing 2 women and wounding 95 other people, 12 of them seriously.

title: ALLIED TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid in May 1981

title: FIDELITY UNION BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today; Oct. 21, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: A NEW ECONOMIC ORDER IS THE FOCUS AT CANCUN
description: Leaders of 22 nations are flying here for a meeting that its organizers hope will ultimately redesign the world economy to favor developing nations.

title: Oil and the 'Economic Pearl Harbor'
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 KILLED IN ARMORED CAR HOLDUP
description: Armed robbers waiting in ambush killed a Brink's guard in a blaze of gunfire at the Nanuet Mall in Rockland County yesterday and minutes later killed two police officers from Nyack, N.Y., in a shootout at a roadblock several miles away.

title: DMI FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 29
COMPOSER: MARGA RICHTER
description: IN small doses, the music of Marga Richter can be intriguing and enjoyable. Intriguing because it involves the listener in an experience in which he can gauge probabilities with a reasonable degree of accuracy.

title: G.O.P. TV CAMPAIGN EVOKES COMPLAINT
description: The Democratic Party, worried about the impact of millions of dollars in Republican national advertising, called on the television industry today either to stop running the advertisements or to give the Democrats time to make an opposing case.

title: BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAGIC CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-Includes gain equal to 10 cents a shr on the sale of certain company assets

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENERAL SHALE PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAYTAG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 results include the Hardwick Stove Co which became a wholly owned Maytag subsidiary the first of the yr

title: 30 DIRECTORS HONOR ORSON WELLES
description: HOLLYWOOD SOME 30 international movie directors, including Bernardo Bertolucci of Italy and Roger Vadim of France, honored Orson Welles, a director whom Hollywood has had little interest in for three decades, at a dinner given Sunday night by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association.

title: AMERICAN INCOME LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $350,000 for the qr and $1,100 for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $675,000 for the qr and $1,625,000 for the 9 mos

title: COOKING OIL RISK IN SPAIN
description: The Food and Drug Administration has warned American travelers to Spain that they risk serious illness or death if they consume adulterated cooking oil sold fraudulently as olive oil.

title: VITALY RUBIN, SOVIET EMIGRE, DIES IN AUTO ACCIDENT IN ISRAELI DESERT
description: Vitaly Rubin, a professor of Chinese history and a former leader of the Soviet Jewish emigration movement, was killed Sunday in an automobile accident south of Beersheba. He was 58 years old.

title: ADVISORY AND OVERSIGHT PANELS ON INTELLIGENCE NAMED
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it was reconstituting the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board in an effort to improve ''the quality and effectiveness of intelligence available to the United States.''

title: Economic Scene; A Recession?  Apparently So
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN beat his economic advisers to the punch in announcing that the economy is in a recession. But some economists, such as Michael Evans of Evans Econometrics, think he was premature. Was the President right?

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: GLEASON WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HERSHEY FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 4
CANCUN APT SITE FOR RICH-POOR PARLEY
description: In the last decade, $1.1 billion worth of investment has transformed this L-shaped island from a deserted strip of sand into an exclusive vacation resort, with 48 hotels, a convention center, a golf course, luxury villas and the inevitable bevy of discotheques.

title: CAMPBELL TAGGART INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Oct 6
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in Oct 1981

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1981
description: International The plan to sell Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia is being pressed in a White House letter prepared for the Senate. The letter pledges that if the Saudis should adopt policies ''disruptive to prospects for stability'' in the Middle East President Reagan would cancel delivery of the advanced radar craft. (Page A1, Column 6.) Participation in the Sinai peace force by several Western European countries is planned, according to State Department officials. They said they had been told that Britain and Italy were expected to join France in contributing troops to the force that is to monitor Egyptian-Israeli peace. (A11:3.)

title: WATSON GETS EVEN
description: When Bob Watson was a senior at Freemont High School in Los Angeles, dreaming of a professional baseball career with his hometown team, Tom Lasorda watched him play in the 1964 city championships and dashed his hopes.

title: General Electric Strike Ends
description: A strike by 300 General Electric white-collar workers ended today after the company agreed to negotiate a charge that it had used a manager to replace a union worker on vacation.

title: The Brass Medal
description: At an important moment in a game with Milwaukee last week Reggie Jackson batted the baseball over a distant wall for a home run. It was a good piece of workmanship under pressure and precisely the kind of work for which Mr. Jackson is paid a generous salary.

title: Stock Outlook in Technology
description: THE sun may or may not be setting on the bear market, but a few analysts are already looking for a brighter day in technology stocks. These stocks were particularly hard hit this year, partly because they had done unusually well in the prior bull market.

title: BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Iran Plans to Rebuff Amnesty International
description: Iran's revolutionary prosecutor said today that he would deny a request by Amnesty International to visit Iranian jails until the group also condemns the treatment of prisoners in Iraq, Israel, Egypt and the United States.

title: UPROOTED CAPE TOWN BLACKS DOOMED TO WANDER
description: The ordeal of the Cape Town squatters, 1,500 blacks who were expelled from their cramped lodgings here and then finally deported two months ago to their supposedly independent ''homeland,'' is not over yet. And it looks as if it never will be.

title: TOLEDO TRUSTCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including securities gains of $805 and $1,641 for the latest qr and 9 mos and $4,348 and $6,414 for the previous qr and 9 mos

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: EVEN without a cure, the major crippling forms of arthritis would disable far fewer people than they do now were it not for three obstacles:

title: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1981; Energy
description: OPEC has called an ''extraordinary meeting'' for Oct. 29 in Geneva to try to settle its bitter pricing dispute. All 13 members are expected to attend. (Page D1.)

title: KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COBB RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Net income; shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Feb 1981

title: WINE ENTHUSIASTS HOLD GATHERING
description: For hundreds of years, wine connoisseurs have sought one another's company, assembling at such times as the harvest to share the wine. Traditionally, these groups have been highly selective, embellishing their activities with ritual and costume. But recently, impelled by the growth of the wine market, a new kind of wine gathering seems to be gaining popularity. This involves a weekend of seminars, tastings, receptions and dinners, and, instead of nominations and initiations, one needs only an interesting wine and the price of admission to attend.

title: Police Get 50 Cabs
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire accepted an offer by the taxi industry of 50 cabs for use by the police in combating crimes against drivers.

title: Polaroid Net Off
description: The Polaroid Corporation said that its third-quarter earnings fell 69.4 percent from a year earlier.

title: NET RISES AT MONSANTO, DIGITAL
description: The Monsanto Company reported yesterday that the sale of part of its petrochemicals business caused earnings in the third quarter to more than quadruple, as sales increased 5.8 percent.
To the Editor:

title: KARPOV BID FOR A DELAY CALLED PLOY
description: After Anatoly Karpov postponed the eighth game of his world chess championship match with Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland yesterday, Miguel Najdorf, an Argentine grandmaster, hypothesized why the 30-year-old Soviet champion would take time out when he had the white pieces.

title: Advertising; No.3 Goes After No.1
description: THE Airborne Freight Corporation is getting into advertising, television advertising at that. With the help of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, it is employing an interesting advertising tactic: taking on No.1 so that all and sundry think it is No.2, instead of No.3, which it actually is.

title: CADO SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Sales figures represent sales; shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared Apr 29 Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition in Mar of Interactive Management Systems Inc accounted for as a pooling of interest

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the pleasures of cooking in my own or anyone else's kitchen is experimenting. Altering a traditional recipe, for example, either by changing the principal ingredient or by substituting flavors - tarragon for rosemary, basil for parsley and so on. I do this at times with classic French recipes and, once in a while, I ''borrow'' an international dish for my experiments.

title: MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: TEAMSTERS ACT TO NOMINATE A BOARD MEMBER AT PAN AM
description: A New York unit of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has named three persons, one of them a local union president, as possible nominees for a seat on the board of Pan American World Airways - a development that apparently surprised the company.

title: WEINBERGER SEEKS TO ASSURE ALLIES ON REAGAN REMARK ON ATOM WAR
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger sought today to reassure Europeans over a remark by President Reagan that appeared to accept the use of tactical nuclear weapons in the field.

title: HOW JERSEY POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Oct. 13 through Oct. 18 with 1,118 registered voters in New Jersey. To obtain this sample, the poll reached 1,570 adults.

title: BEST BUYS
description: FALL and winter produce is now coming in, bringing with it lower prices. The apple season is at its height, with a choice of generally good-quality Red and Golden Delicious, Greening and McIntosh apples selling at 49 cents a pound or less.

title: TEXT OF DRAFT LETTER BY THE PRESIDENT
description: Following is the text of a draft letter that President Reagan promised to give the Senate on the terms and conditions of the Awacs sale to Saudi Arabia:

title: SADAT'S DEATH: SOME IN CAIRO DO NOT CARE
description: Today is the 13th day of the 40-day mourning period for President Anwar el-Sadat, but as on the 12 previous days little public sorrow was being displayed.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Like Her Husband, Nancy Reagan Is Off Traveling
description: When her husband goes away on business, Nancy Reagan is not one to stay home and twiddle her thumbs. New York, after all, is just a short flight away, and that is just where she flew yesterday as President Reagan prepared to leave this morning for a conference in Mexico.

title: RECITAL: CHOPIN SOCIETE'S WINNING PIANISTS, AGES 13 TO 28
description: THE Chopin Societe, founded last February by Mr. and Mrs. Stewart E. Fason of Palm Beach, Fla., presented its first New York ''showcase'' for young pianists Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. As promised, the affair featured several young pianists playing music by Chopin and others.

title: SmithKline to Add Upjohn Subsidiary
description: The SmithKline Corporation said it would acquire Laboratory Procedures Inc., a nationwide network of clinical laboratories, from the Upjohn Company on undisclosed terms.

title: 5 Runners Suspended
description: The Athletics Congress, governing body for track and field in this country, has suspended five foreign runners for competing in races that offered prize money. John Halberstadt and Willie Farrell of South Africa; Antonio Villanueva of Mexico, and Gale Olinekoya and Wendy Roberston of Canada are no longer eligible to compete in events sanctioned by The Athletics Congress. The athletes must be cleared by the International Amateur Athletic Federation and their home associations before being reinstated for competition.

title: Consulting Engineers Blame Hyatt Fabricator
description: The consulting engineers of the Hyatt Regency Hotel, where two skywalks collapsed and killed 113 persons last July 17, filed court documents yesterday that said a critical design change made in the skywalks had been suggested by the steel fabricator.

title: Index; International
description: Uprooted Cape Town blacks doomed to wander A2 Greek Socialists list new Papan- dreou Cabinet A3 Spain sees possible threat to NATO entry in Greek's election A3 Egypt mourns, but many Egyp- tians do not A13 There is no joy in Montreal after the Expos are eliminated A14 Police fight 5,000 protesters in Polish city A15 Cancun is a surprisingly apt site for a conference on poverty A16 Around the World A17 Government/Politics Houston Mayor held unlikely to win re-election A18 Democrats complain about G.O.P. ad campaign on TV A29 Kean tours Florio's home base of Camden B2 Washington Talk Briefing A28 Required Reading A28 W. Averell Harriman offers ref- uge to the political ''outs ' A28 House Democrats quietly retreat in elevator skirmish A28 General Around the Nation A18 2 arraigned in migrants' enslave- ment in North Carolina A18 Three states reach accord on Ohio River boundary A20 Private charged in black slayings waives a jury trial B2 Plot to kill key witness described at trial of crime figure B3 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of the Jewish holiday of Simhath Torah, alternate-side regula- tions are suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect. Living Section Food Texas eating: Ethnic variety with a frontier spirit C1

title: King Publications Plans Holiday Inns Magazine
description: In January, King Publications, San Francisco, which already produces an in-room magazine for seven Hyatt Regency hotels, will begin publishing a similar magazine for Holiday Inns called Inn America.

title: HOSPITAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Mar 27, 1981

title: Running for a Cause
description: The marathoner Stan Cottrell was ''beat but happy'' after running 146 miles in 36 hours. A 38-year-old Kentucky native, Cottrell ran along U.S. 31W in his home state to promote the work of the American Lung Association.

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The third qr results included a gain of $7 million or 30 cents a shr from an exchange of newly issued common stock for $20 million of outstndg notes and debentures; the earnings in 1980's third qr included $3 million or 14 cents a shr from the redemption of notes and debentures

title: ADVANCE ROSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $364,000 loss from discontinued operations... C-Including $204,000 income from discontinued operations

title: BANCOHIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HIGH VOLTAGE ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $125,000 for the qr and $375,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $167,000 for the qr and $500,00 for the 9 mos

title: A GRAND SCHEME BY THE NIXONS' NEW MAYOR
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
MORE COUNTRIES SAID TO OFFER TROOPS FOR SINAI FORCE
description: State Department officials said today that several Western countries had told the United States that they intended to follow France's lead and agree to participate in the Sinai military force to monitor the peace between Israel and Egypt.

title: Geo Circulation Base And Ad Rates Cut 20%
description: Knapp Communications, according to an annoucement yesterday, thought that when it acquired the trouble-plagued, money-guzzling Geo magazine it would able to maintain the 250,000 circulation rate base.

title: Seven Tie Themselves To Fire Truck in Boston
description: Seven persons tied themselves to a fire truck today as 15 fellow demonstrators continued to occupy the East Boston firehouse to protest the disbanding of the neighborhood engine company.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beneficial Corp., Wilmington, Del., announced that George R. Evans, vice chairman, was retiring, and that David J. Farris had been named president and chief executive officer of the Beneficial Management Corp. subsidiary.

title: No Headline
description: Joe DiMaggio, no stranger to the World Series in Yankee Stadium, threw out the cermonial first ball. In his career, DiMaggio was on 10 Yankee teams in the World Series from 1936-51, three of which defeated Brooklyn Dodger teams - 1941, 1947 and 1949.

title: KEUFFEL & ESSER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A HARRIMAN SAMPLER
description: On President Reagan's economic policies: ''I don't think Reaganomics is going to work. But as an American, I wish the President well.

title: SANTA FE DATA CITED
description: The president of the Pacific Stock Exchange said today that his organization had no hard evidence - but much suspicion - that insider information was used in the trading of Santa Fe International Corporation stock options.

title: THE ECONOMY AND VOTER RESISTANCE TROUBLE MICHIGAN'S SCHOOL SYSTEMS
description: The effects of a two-year-old economic slump in Michigan have begun to grip the public schools, with districts fast running out of money and voters refusing to approve the school tax increases local officials say they need to stay open.

title: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credit of $9,960,000

title: Toll in Japan Mine Now 44
description: Mine company officials said rescue workers recovered another body today from a coal mine at Yubari in Hokkaido, bringing the number of known dead in the mine disaster to 44. Fortynine other miners and 10 rescue workers still are trapped and presumed dead, four days after methane gas seeped into the mine. Officials said there was ''practically no hope'' for them, and rescue workers abandoned their search for more bodies today.

title: POLISH POLICE BATTLE 5,000 PROTESTING ARRESTS
description: In the worst outbreak of street violence in 14 months of labor unrest, the police in Katowice today battled 5,000 protesters who had been angered by the arrest of three Solidarity activists for distributing leaflets.

title: HALL TAKES STEPS TO ACQUIRE JARTAN
description: Frank B. Hall & Company, in a move analysts said was designed to thwart the takeover attentions of Ryder System Inc., announced yesterday that its board had authorized its executive committee to ''execute a stock-purchase agreement'' to acquire Jartran Inc., a Miami-based truck leasing concern.

title: MONDALE SAYS REAGAN'S POLICY HURTS NATO
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale criticized the Reagan Administration yesterday for its approach to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, charging that it had sapped both the economic strength and the commitment to principle of the alliance by a ''goit-alone policy.''

title: KELLOGG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SECURITY ADVISER OUSTED FOR A TALK HINTING AT WAR
description: The chief military adviser to the National Security Council was dismissed today after saying in a speech that the Russians had achieved strategic superiority over the United States, were ''on the move'' and were ''going to strike.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cellu-Craft Inc. said its board had authorized the company to offer to purchase for cash from its shareholders up to 300,000 shares of its common stock at $6 a share, representing about 13 percent of the company's outstanding stock.

title: 'LIFT' BATTLE: HOUSE AIDES STAGE RETREAT
description: The battle of the Capitol Hill elevators has ended with House Democrats surrendering. Sort of. The skirmish started when the Republicans took over the Senate last January. As they looked around for opportunities to prove their devotion to fiscal austerity, they focused immediately on the elevators. After all, even the most ardent advocate of Big Government was hard pressed to defend a system in which fully automated lifts were manned by operators for several shifts a day.

title: Cagney to Toss First Ball
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn has invited James Cagney, the veteran actor, to throw out the first ball in tonight's second game of the World Series at Yankee Stadium.

title: ATHLONE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $1,767,000 extraordinary loss from debenture conversion

title: Bamberger Named; Will Rebuild Mets
description: The Mets introduced George Bamberger as the successor to Joe Torre yesterday, calling him ''the perfect man for the job.'' and the highest-paid manager in baseball.

title: HARRIMAN GIVES REFUGE TO THE 'OUTS'
description: It is not the sort of place you would expect to find many Democrats, considering the Oriental rugs, the Impressionist paintings and the other trappings of immense wealth that are so tastefully scattered about.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Sept 20
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a 4 percent stock divd in Jan 1981

title: BREZHNEV AND REAGAN ON ATOM WAR
description: Following are a question asked of President Reagan at a meeting with newspaper editors Friday in Washington and his answer as they appear in a White House transcript, and a question asked of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, by the newspaper Pravda yesterday and his answer, as translated by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,510,000 for the qr and $3,204,000 for the 9 mos and $54,527,000 gain for the 9 mos on the sale of proprietary medicine business... C-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,318,000 for the qr and $6,126,000 for the 9mos and income of $1.7 milli for the qr and $2.9 million for the 9 mos from sales by the company's real estate developments subsidiary of 70 percent of its interest in office buildings in Connecticut; yr-ago resu have been restated

title: HOUSE HOMELESS IN ARMORY, JUDGE ORDERS CITY AND STATE
description: A State Supreme Court justice ordered New York City and State yesterday to open an armory or other new facility for homeless men by 5 P.M. today because an overflow of at least 400 men have been overcrowding city shelters as the cold weather approaches.

title: MEXICO'S ALFA TIGHTENS BELT
description: Over the last four years, the Alfa Industrial Group not only has been Mexico's largest and fastestgrowing conglomerate but also it has become a symbol of the extraordinary economic boom that oil wealth has brought to this country.

title: CRUMP, E H, COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interests

title: BY JOANNE KAUFMAN
description: ON his 34th birthday Marc Malamed did what he had done on his birthday for the preceding 18 years: He watched a performance of ''The Fantasticks.'' During those years cast members have come and gone - and in some cases come back - during the almost 22 years that the play has been billeted at the Sullivan Street Playhouse. Mr. Malamed's finances have improved enough for him to advance from the $2.90 seats (as of 1963) in the rear of the theater to the $14 ones down front.

title: Zimbabwe Arrests Nurses and Teachers
description: Policemen in armored vehicles, breaking up demonstrations in central Salisbury, arrested about 750 striking nurses and teachers today, officials said.

title: INSTRUMENTATION LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jet Contract By Australia
description: The Australian Government announced today that it would award a $2.7 billion contract for new air force fighter planes to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which beat out the General Dynamics Corporation in a 10-year bidding war.

title: REGAN CITES 'PAINLESS' TAX RISES
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Administration was considering increases in the excise taxes on liquor and tobacco, adding another set of items to a growing list of revenue-producing proposals intended to help reduce the budget deficit.

title: DRAVO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Feb 1981

title: THE POP LIFE
description: MARIANNE FAITHFULL seemed the picture of youth and innocence when she made her American television debut on ''Shindig'' in 1964, singing her first record and first hit, the pretty, wistful ballad ''As Tears Go By.'' And appearances were not entirely deceiving. She had attended a convent school and was only 18 years old when Andrew Oldham, then the manager of the Rolling Stones, met her at a party. The Stones' Mick Jagger and Keith Richards had written ''As Tears Go By,'' but they had not recorded it; the song was too sweet to jibe with their bad-boy image. It was perfect for Miss Faithfull.

title: CITICORP'S EARNINGS DROP 11%
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that its third-quarter earnings declined by 11 percent from the comparable period last year, despite a nonrecurring, $36 million after-tax gain from the sale of property on Lexington Avenue.

title: AWACS, OIL AND THE VICE PRESIDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: BUREAUCRACY IS KEEPING OUR TEACHERS FROM TEACHING
description: To the Editor:

title: BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bryant Goes in Motion
description: North Carolina's star running back, Kelvin Bryant, is off his crutches and running, according to the team physican, Dr. Timothy Taft, who operated on the left knee Bryant injured against Georgia Tech Oct. 3. ''He is running, not sprinting,'' Dr. Taft said. ''He does not yet have full strength in his knee.''

title: INVESTING IN AMERICA
description: If you come across the country these days all you hear is a lot of grumbling about the economy. Auto sales are down 35 percent from last year; unemployment is edging up to around 8 percent, and even President Reagan is using that forbidden word ''recession.''

title: INCOME UP
description: Consumer spending, for months an island of strength in a weak economy, declined by one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the Government reported today.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DIAMOND CRYSTAL SALT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Last 'Private' M.A.C. Sale Set
description: New York City passed a milestone yesterday when its finance agency, the Municipal Assistance Corporation, authorized its final sale of bonds marketed with the ''private'' support of banks and city pension funds.

title: DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per shr amounts reflect a 5 percent stock divd payable Oct 30, 1981

title: GRANITEVILLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE MISMEASURE OF MAN. By Stephen Jay Gould. 352 pages. Illustrated. Nor- ton. $14.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When we in the United States back off arms control, and slacken our efforts to control the spread of nuclear weapons-grade material, and retreat from human rights, and ignore the plight of the people in the third world, and continue economic policies of high unemployment, and announce that social justice is no longer affordable -when we do these things, we surrender the most powerful weapon of the West, the arsenal of principles.'' - Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale. (A8:6.)

title: DENNY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
HELPING THE MENTALLY DISABLED THRIVE
description: Hartmut and Gerda von Jeetze have lived among and worked with the mentally handicapped most of their lives.

title: BADGER METER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EASTMET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Georgia-Pacific Antitrust Suit
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, the nation's largest producer of Southern plywood, said that a 1978 antitrust verdict against it, the Weyerhaeuser Company and Willamette Industries could have a material impact on the company's financial position.

title: TRANSITORY FEDERALISM
description: Ten months ago, the incoming Reagan Administration set a new agenda for the country's public-transportation systems. Under the banner of a ''new federalism'' - the return of funding and decisionmaking responsibility to local government - the Transportation Department proposed to end Conrail's responsibility for local commuter service, phase out subsidies for transit fares, and reduce Federal regulation that attends the expenditure of Federal capitalassistance funds. The Administration argued that keeping the Government out of local affairs would make management of local transit more effective and efficient.

title: IT'S A SERIES, IT'S WORLD, IT'S BRIDGE
description: ''I couldn't care less about the World Series,'' said James Thompson, taking a bite out of a ham-onrye sandwich as he watched a bridge match on closed-circuit television. ''This is my American pastime.''

title: 'Clear Insult' to Mothers
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: There is an implied but clear insult to women as mothers in the statement by DC Comics' president and publisher Jenette Kahn that ''most women don't begin their work lives until 40 because they've been busy raising children'' (''Foundation to Aid Women Over 40,'' Oct. 7).

title: JERSEY POLL INDICATES VOTERS' BACKGROUND OVERSHADOWS ISSUES
description: The election for Governor of New Jersey is being influenced more by the party affiliation, economic status, ethnic background and traditional policy concerns of voters than by reaction to the administrations of President Reagan and Governor Byrne, a survey of New Jersey voters indicates.

title: Renfro in Select Circle
description: The Dallas Cowboys announced that Mel Renfro, their former cornerback, would be inducted into their Ring of Honor next Sunday. Renfro thus will join Bob Lilly, Don Meredith, Don Perkins and Chuck Howley in having his name placed in large letters on the facade that encircles the field at the Cowboys' home, Texas Stadium .... Irv Pankey, Los Angeles' starting offensive tackle, will be lost for several weeks because of a knee strain suffered in the Rams' 29-17 loss to Dallas Sunday night.

title: Sphinx's Left Haunch Damaged by Erosion
description: The Sphinx has lost part of its left hindquarter because of erosion caused by backed up sewage from a village near the pyramids.

title: Nets' King Out Another Week
description: The start of Albert King's career with the Nets has been delayed at least another week, and doctors continued to disagree today whether he needed arthroscopic surgery to repair damaged cartilage in his right knee.

title: ALCAN, ARMCO DECLINE
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest steel producer, reported an earnings turnabout yesterday, saying that it had a $92.7 million profit in the third quarter, in contrast to a loss of $14.5 million for the comparable 1980 quarter.

title: FOREMOST CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Man, 25, Arrested In Hit-Run Deaths
description: A 25-year-old unemployed Bronx man was arrested yesterday on charges of having driven the car that killed two girls and critically injured a third in a hit-and-run accident in the Bronx on Sunday night.

title: Vatican Polishes New Code of Canon Law
description: After 18 years of study, the Roman Catholic Church took the final steps today to announce its new code of Canon Law.

title: INEXCO OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DONALDSON LUFKIN & JENRETTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFING
description: V ICE PRESIDENT BUSH'S Task Force on Regulatory Reform, now worming its way through the welter of Government regulations covering transportation, will issue its next wave of ''reg'' prunings next month. The task force staff says the job will necessarily consume years, but for a quick measure of progress, citizens should consult the Federal Register, the Government's publication detailing regulations and changes. In January the Register had 10,134 pages, but by August it had been more than halved to 4,392 pages, dropping, Mr. Bush's office happily contends, like a fever chart.

title: THE DOLPHINS HEAD SOUTH
description: It is a sure sign that cold weather is here to stay when the dolphins fly south for the winter. The staff at the New York Aquarium tests the waters in their outdoor pool and when it plunges into the 50's, the time is right to load Buie and Sasha into their custom travel slings, grease them up with plenty of lanolin and take them to Kennedy International Airport where, like hundreds of other New Yorkers, they will fly to Florida for a vacation, and the duration of the cold weather.

title: THE SURPRISES OF ITALIAN JEWISH FOOD
description: ''THE Classic Cuisine of the Italian Jews'' by Edda Servi Machlin (Everest House, $19.95) is a surprise. The food does not at all resemble the traditional Central and Eastern European dishes to which American Jews are accustomed. It is a combination of Italian, Spanish, Middle Eastern and North African cooking, with some recipes said to date back a thousand years.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRISTOL-MYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DISCOVERIES
description: 1. A Booted Compromise What do you do if you like the look of boots, but find them too warm indoors? Try spats. Barney's has come up with an idea that's both fashionable and practical - leather spats that button over any lowheeled shoes, with a strap to anchor them under the instep. They come in burgundy, luggage tan, gold and bronze and could also be worn to update a pair of last year's short boots. You'll find them in the Women's Duplex on Barney's seventh floor for $55. 2. Gold for Change The fad for metallic leathers goes on and on. Anyone who doesn't already have a gold bag might check out an amusing one stocked by Macy's. It looks like an oversize change purse with a snap closing and has a long, shoulder-strap handle. It's $27 in the Metal Deposits section of the main floor arcade, which also carries gold or silver leather bangles for $8 each. 3. Apples of Her Eye When Bonnie Sewell, a California artist, spent a year in Texas she discovered the local craft of apple-head dolls and decided to try her hand at them. They looked fine, but the apples got wormy. Undaunted, Mrs. Sewell began making the puckered faces from cloth instead of fruit. Her creations include a peddler woman holding a tray of her wares: tiny pots and pans, baskets and brooms and a string of dried, real peppers. There is also a gardener with her flowers and tools, and a baker with a tray full of pastries, rolling pins and other utensils.

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cubans Riot at Fort Chaffee
description: Twelve Cuban refugees confined in the stockade at the relocation center here rioted early today, ripping out light fixtures and tearing up beds, an official said. A spokesman said that the disturbance began about 11 P.M. yesterday after guards took three other refugees, who were suspects in an assault on guards earlier in the day, to a maximum security area. The property destruction ended about four hours later.

title: OAK RIDGE BOYS: 'SPILLOVER' TO POP
description: THE Oak Ridge Boys bounded up to the stage so many times to accept so many awards on last week's Country Music Awards telecast that one suspected they must have been following a rigid jogging regimen in preparation. Like most and possibly all music-industry awards shows, the Country Music Awards are more a confirmation of commercial success than a tribute to artistic excellence, and because the Oak Ridge Boys enjoyed the most spectacular country-to-pop crossover success of the year with their No. 1 hit, ''Elvira,'' the awards they received couldn't have come as much of a surprise.

title: Reinventing the Democrats
description: Ever since disaster struck last November, Democrats have been combing the debris looking for their compass. Now New York City's Mayor Koch has offered his advice, at a party strategy conference in Baltimore. Reject turning either right or left, he urges; reclaim the center that ideologues have forfeited and march straight down the middle.

title: Levi Strauss Names Operating Officer
description: Robert D. Haas, a 39-year-old great-great-grandnephew of the founder, has been named chief operating officer of Levi Strauss & Company, the country's biggest apparel manufacturer, effective at the start of its new fiscal year on Nov. 29. Mr. Haas, who will also become executive vice president, will succeed Robert T. Grohman, 57, who, as previously announced, will become president and chief executive officer.

title: CITICORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Board Votes Budget Cut For California Colleges
description: Trustees of the California State University and Colleges system voted yesterday to cut their operating budget by $20 million this year and said they were prepared to cut $50 million more next year.

title: VA. TECH TO CURB DISCIPLINARY DRILLS
description: The mother of a Virginia Tech football player who died after undergoing punishment drills has won as part of an out-of-court settlement a promise by the university to never again use the drills.

title: CALIFORNIA MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect 100 percent stock divd paid in 1981

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN BY KINGS, 9-6
description: The Islanders allowed 43 shots on goal and lost, 9-6, to the Los Angeles Kings tonight, their first defeat of the season after winning four and tying one.

title: PRIVATE WAIVES A JURY TRIAL IN SLAYINGS IN BUFFALO AREA
description: Disregarding the advice of his lawyers, an Army private waived his right to be tried by a jury as his trial on triple-murder charges opened here today.

title: MEMOREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $400,000 pretax profit income

title: Pentair Picks President
description: Pentair Inc., a diversified corporation that this week completed the acquisition of the portable electric power tool division of Rockwell International for $16 million in cash, has appointed Thomas J. Ryan, 51, as president. The subsidiary, whose headquarters will be moved from the Rockwell base in Pittsburgh to its plant in Jackson, Tenn., will be called the Porter-Cable Corporation.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Oct. 12, to Sunday, Oct. 18), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets. title: CHILDREN IN A CITY AUTUMN
description: ONE of the sure signs of fall is the return of children to the city's streets. They are everywhere, often with a parent in tow, going to and from school, on shopping expeditions, to the zoo, or just out for some favorite junk food.

title: Oklahoma Panel Lists Governmental Reforms
description: A study group on county government, spurred by disclosures of corruption, tentatively approved several major proposals yesterday that would strip county commissioners of much of their power.

title: HINCKLEY REPORTED TO DISCUSS 'CONSPIRACY' IN SEIZED PAPERS
description: A Justice Department source late tonight confirmed a report that John W. Hinckley Jr. had written in papers confiscated from his cell in July that he was part of a conspiracy when he shot President Reagan and three other men March 30.

title: Mattie Talmadge Dies at 100; Widow of a Georgia Governor
description: McRAE, Ga., Oct. 20 (AP) - Mattie Talmadge, whose husband was elected Governor of Georgia four times and whose son was a Governor and United States Senator, died today at the age of 100.

title: FIRST MISSISSIPPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Manager, Old Problem in Poland
description: Like a sports team in decline, Poland's Communists have fired the manager, naming the Prime Minister, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, to replace the party's First Secretary, Stanislaw Kania. As every front office knows, such a switch creates the illusion of change and eases the pressure for better results. But once the novelty wears off, the new manager must still field the same old players and hope that time and luck will improve their record.

title: MISSION OF P.L.O. IN MOSCOW IS RAISED TO DIPLOMATIC STATUS
description: Yasir Arafat today gained full diplomatic status for the Palestine Liberation Organization's permanent mission here. Although the gesture carried little practical benefit, he described it as a ''very important step'' that brought the Palestinians nearer to achieving their goal of an independent state.

title: BANK OF VIRGINIA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHESEBROUGH-POND'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CESSNA AIRCRAFT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHEN A SOCIETY DECIDES TO SURRENDER TO CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: BRUSH WELLMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENIUSES SPEAK
description: FOR the advancement of human knowledge and the benefit of guys with early deadlines, Bob Lemon and Tommy Lasorda, the licensed geniuses of the Yankees and Los Angeles Dodgers, and their pitchers-elect for the third game, Dave Righetti and Fernando Valenzuela, communed with the flower of American letters yesterday before the second match in the 78th tournament for the rounders championship of North America.

title: Dow Down 0.85; Volume Falls
description: The stock market, beset by increasing signs that the economy is softening, declined slightly yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range throughout the session, closed off 0.85 point, to 851.03. In the previous eight sessions, the blue-chip average had retreated seven times and has lost more than 20 points, mostly because of investors' concern over the economy and interest rates.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BARTOK EXTRAVAGANZA IN HUNGARY
description: BUDAPEST BELA BARTOK, the Hungarian composer, pianist and ethnomusicologist, has one street here named after him, one park, several cultural centers, one cinema and, most recently, his own house, transformed into a museum just opened to celebrate the 100th anniversary of his birth.

title: THE B-1'S ADVANTAGES OVER A 'STEALTH' PLANE
description: To the Editor:

title: Mitsui May Drop Venture With Iran
description: The Mitsui Industrial Group of Japan said it is prepared to withdraw soon from a troubled multibilliondollar petrochemical venture at the mouth of the Persian Gulf unless its Iranian partners put up more cash.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: KEKKONEN ILL, CANDIDATES MANEUVER
description: Questions of personalities and detail remain, but there is no question about the most important issue involving the successor to President Urho Kekkonen of Finland. Whoever replaces the ailing 81-year-old leader will not change Finland's foreign policy of neutrality and of avoiding antagonisms with the Soviet Union.

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Technology; It's Goodbye, Carburetors
description: DETROIT SOMETHING familiar is missing under the hood of 1982 General Motors cars equipped with the corporation's 2.5-liter, four-cylinder engine. It's the carburetor, that complex assembly of jets, floats, tubes and levers that has long been used to regulate the mixture of fuel and air delivered to the cylinders of a gasoline engines.

title: CARLISLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN CLARIFIES HIS STATEMENT ON NUCLEAR WAR
description: President Reagan sought to clarify American nuclear policy today by asserting that any suggestion that the United States was considering fighting a nuclear war with the Soviet Union at European expense was ''an outright deception.''

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pull Out of Cambodia, U.N. Tells Vietnam
description: For the third year in a row, the General Assembly today urged Vietnam to evacuate its forces from Cambodia and called for United Nations-supervised elections.

title: No Headline
description: Raider Trainer Weighs Truth Test on Gambling

title: CASCADE NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Three-Hour Metroliners Added to Washington Runs
description: The Metroliner, Amtrak's premier train between Washington and New York, will begin a new scheduled run of two hours and 59 minutes on Sunday, officials said yesterday.

AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SAMBO'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 11
Broker Loan Rate Up
description: The Chemical Bank said yesterday that it had raised its broker loan rate to 16 1/2 percent from 16 percent, effective immediately. The rate is 16 percent at most other banks, but is 16 1/4 percent at the Chase Manhattan Bank. The increase reflects the recent firmness in the Federal funds rate, analysts said.

title: REAGAN MEETS WITH CHINESE AND MEXICAN LEADERS
description: President Reagan arrived here today to attend a conference of developing and industrialized nations at which his views on international development appear certain to be challenged and criticized.
