description: Shr earnings adjusted for a 4-for-1 stock split in Oct 1981

title: ORROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BROADVIEW FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MERCHANTS OF DEATH
description: Few of us who are middle-aged or older have missed the grim experience of cancer striking a friend or relation. My sense, based on what has happened around me, is that incidence of the disease is sharply increasing. I find that others have the same feeling.

title: TIPS FOR THOSE WHO WILL TAKE THE PLUNGE
description: If you're determined to do your own contracting, here are some tips: Have a Master Plan - Hire an architect or designer who will provide you with a detailed set of plans and working drawings. Like general contractors, architects and designers may charge 15 to 20 percent of construction costs for design, working drawings and overseeing of construction. It may be possible to hire an architect or designer on a consulting basis for $35 to $75 an hour.

title: QUAKE UNDER L.I. SOUND
description: A minor earthquake centered in Long Island Sound shook parts of Connecticut and eastern Long Island today. There were no reports of injury or damage.

title: NORTHERN CALIFORNIA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
Penn Central Stock Surges
description: Shares of the Penn Central Corporation, buoyed by persistent rumors that the Esmark Corporation might attempt a takeover, closed up $2 yesterday, at $46, in heavy trading.

title: Charge Against Florio By G. O. P. Dismissed
description: The Election Law Enforcement Commission today dismissed a Republican State Committee complaint charging the campaign of the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, Representative James J. Florio, with violations of state election laws.

description: B-Including $2,458,000 or 11 cents a shr gain resulting from acquisition of $12 million principal amount of the 2 percent convertible subordinated debentures to meet re sinking requirements;yr-ago results have been restated

title: News of Music; U.S. PREMIERES FOR MOZART, SALIERI AND ANTHEIL
description: THE coming weeks will have some unusual offerings of unheard music - including the United States premiere of a Mozart work, the American premieres of three works by Salieri, the United States premiere of a 1920's jazz opera by George Antheil and the New York premiere of a new work by Elliott Carter.

title: SORG PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TUBES AND BULBS; Hope Operas
description: According to a University of Pennsylvania study, people who watch a lot of TV are more complacent about health than those who do not. That came as no surprise at all to a woman we know.

title: Notes on People; Weaponry Plays Major Role in New Film
description: To hear Barry Bostwick tell it, his new movie project, ''Megaforce,'' may turn out to be not so much an ''action-adventure'' film, as a trade show for the international weapons industry.

title: The City; Jacobson's Son Is Accused
description: David Jacobson, a horse trainer, was charged with a misdemeanor in the death last month of a thoroughbred race horse, Hugable Tom, the police said.

title: STAGE: HIRSHBEIN CENTENNIAL
description: THE all-but-forgotten country Jews of Eastern Europe, farmers and fishermen to whom even a shtetl was an urban center, were the inspiration for the Yiddish playwright and poet Peretz Hirshbein, whose 100th birthday is being joyously celebrated by a new Yiddish musical version of his comedy ''The Blacksmith's Daughters.''

title: PAPER POWER: ONE MAN'S STYLISH VISION
description: AT first glance, Jim McWilliams's small, lower Manhattan duplex with its bright palette and comfortably mismatched selection of chairs appears to be spontaneously designed: an almost haphazard combination of textures and patterns.

title: SPECTRO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
Insurers Oppose U.S. Writing Coverage for Nuclear Plants
description: A spokesman for the American Insurance Association says private insurers do not want the Federal Government to write insurance to cover accidents at nuclear power plants.

title: MID-AMERICA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLOR TILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: GANDHI REGIME ENDS COMMUNISTS' RULE OF A STATE
description: In a move underscoring the friction between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and India's Marxist parties, the central Government today suspended and took over from the Communistdominated legislature in the state of Kerala.

title: Hydro Speed Excessive
description: It was excessive speed and not a safety defect that caused the death of Bill Muncey in an Acapulco race on Sunday, in the opinion of the chairman of the Unlimited Hydroplane Racing Commission.

title: END OF LOAN-RATE LIMIT ON CONSUMERS REJECTED
description: A House banking subcommittee rejected today an Administration-supported bill that would abolish state interestrate ceilings on consumer loans, but backers of the measure are still pressing for its adoption by the Senate, where chances are rated more favorable.

title: 2 ANTIQUES SHOWS SET FOR NEW JERSEY
description: Two major antiques shows are being held over the next few days in New Jersey, starting today with the Morristown Antiques Fair. The International Antiques Fair opens tomorrow at the Meadlowlands sports complex.

title: 2 WOMEN IN BRINK'S CASE IDENTIFIED WITH WEATHERMEN FROM START IN '69
description: The lives of the two women arrested in the Brink's robbery in Nanuet, N.Y. -Katherine Boudin and Judith Alice Clark - had been entwined with the terrorist Weathermen movement since its inception in 1969. But they had apparently gone separate ways since the armed band of 40 or so radicals went underground in 1970.

title: ST REGIS PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOROCCAN JETS ENTER MAURITANIA AIRSPACE IN PURSUIT OF REBELS
description: For the first time since the Western Sahara conflict began six years ago, Morocco has exercised its right to ''hot pursuit'' by initiating aerial attacks against guerrillas across the frontier into Mauritania.

title: POLICE IN KATOWICE ANGRY OVER BRAWL
description: The streets of this tough-looking, tough-living city were quiet today, but knots of people still gathered on the sidewalks downtown under clouds of coal smoke to talk about what happened yesterday.

title: Critic's Notebook; DANCE SCORE STANDS ALONE
description: MANY dances these days are choreographed to pre-existing music. That is not surprising. A dancer may be inspired by something he or she likes, and if the composer is safely dead and gone, no royalties need be paid. Commissioned scores are rarer, yet some of the great musical masterpieces of the 20th century have come about through just such commissions.

title: Bronfman Reports Clevepak Holding
description: Edgar M. Bronfman, the chief executive officer of the Seagram Company Ltd., the Canadian distilling concern, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he holds a 15.5 percent stake in the Clevepak Corporation, a White Plains company that makes recycled paperboard, packaging and industrial products.

title: People
description: * Frederick W. Rhines has been elected a senior vice president of McCann-Erickson, New York.

title: SOUTHWEST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DOMENICI SAYS THAT G.O.P. GOAL TO BALANCE BUDGET IS IN JEOPARDY
description: Only last April, the Republican-controlled Senate Budget Committee worked day and night to come up with a threeyear plan that projected a balanced budget by 1984, a projection adopted last May by Congress.

title: TV: MOVIE OF MYSTERY AT HOSPITAL
description: ''KILLJOY'' is both a whodunit and a who-is-it, with a mystery plot revolving around a question of identity. Laury Medford (Kim Basinger) is extremely popular around a hospital community - because she's quite pretty and because her father is chairman of the hospital's board of governors. Because her father plans to make his son-in-law chief of staff, Laury has some ardent - and competitive - suitors.

title: SPANISH GOVERNING PARTY DEFEATED IN VOTE FOR A REGIONAL LEGISLATURE
description: A small right-wing party has inflicted a stunning defeat on both the Government party and the opposition Socialists in Spain's first elections since the attempted military coup of last February.

title: EQUINOX SOLAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NURSE CALLS OVERDOSES AN EFFORT TO EASE PAIN
description: A nurse accused of murdering a cancer victim with an overdose of morphine tearfully told the jury today that she loved her patient and was only trying to ease ''her agony and her suffering.''

title: FLAGSHIP BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Improving' Freedom of Information
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed ''Freedom of Information Improvements Act of 1981'' is an oddly titled bill. Its main purpose, quite contrary to current law, is to make it easier for Government to withhold information and harder for people to obtain it. Sponsored by an Administration that claims to be getting Washington off the people's back, the bill is a trophy for those who want to keep much of the public's business a hidden Government enterprise.

title: STORY PRIZE TO HONOR ALGREN
description: A $5,000 annual award has been established to honor the memory of Nelson Algren, the longtime Chicago resident who wrote ''The Man With the Golden Arm,'' ''Chicago: City on the Make'' and other works of fiction and Americana. The Nelson Algren Award will be for an unpublished short story of between 2,500 and 10,000 words by a writer living in the United States.

title: Notes on People; MISSING WALLET
description: If there is one thing Jem Jones is always running on about, it is what a wonderful city New York is. ''She thinks it's the greatest in the world,'' her husband, Elwyn, a British television writer, said yesterday.

title: DELTA AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Notes on People; Helen Hayes Honored in Washington
description: Although she has reluctantly accepted the economic inevitability of the destruction of the lovely small Times Square theater that bears her name, Helen Hayes says she is not at all certain that she will allow her name to be placed on it successor at the site, a 1,500-seat theater in the planned Portman Hotel.

title: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $34,000 tax credit...C-Includes $136,000 tax credit

title: SAN JOSE WATER WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SAINT LAURENT: NO TRICKS, JUST PRECISION AND STYLE
description: With clear, bold strokes Yves Saint Laurent swept away the debris that had been cluttering up the fashion field here this week. His lines are clean, his colors strong. ''Basic things from Yves Saint Laurent,'' the designer said with an unassuming smile right after his show and, as usual, showed that he knew what he was about.

title: CROSS, A T, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOR NATO MISSILES, A PUBLIC RELATIONS DRIVE
description: The Atlantic alliance, confronted by opposition to the deployment of new American medium-range missiles in Western Europe, plans a public relations campaign to dampen the protests.

title: NEW LARGE COMPUTER IS INTRODUCED BY I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced its most powerful computer, a machine that will be up to 40 percent faster than its current top model.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LOUIS BOSA
description: Louis Bosa, an artist and teacher whose paintings ranged from Manhattan street scenes to portraits of friends and family in his native Italy, died Monday. He was 76 years old.

title: CITY HEALTH DEPARTMENT AIMS TO REVERSE DECLINE
description: New York City's Department of Health, hard hit in recent years by budget cuts, is trying to regain its reputation as the finest municipal health department in the country, according to city officials.

title: MAYFLOWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 15 percent stock divd declared earlier this mo

title: MEDFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Trudeau Bids Premiers Meet Again on Charter
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, exasperated at the delay in bringing a debate over a new constitution to a conclusion, has asked the provincial premiers to meet ''one last time.''

title: Torre Talks to Braves
description: Joe Torre confirmed yesterday that he had been ''talking back and forth'' with the Atlanta Braves, and indicated that a decision would be reached in the next day or two on whether he would become their manager.

title: EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Summary; THURSDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1981
description: International American pilots are flying for Libya, according to associates of Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent. They said that dozens of American pilots and aircraft mechanics, including military veterans, were working for the Libyan Air Force in an operation organized by Mr. Wilson. The sources said that the recruits, along with pilots from Britain and Canada, were hired and paid by companies controlled by Mr. Wilson and have been flying and maintaining, at least since last year, a Libyan fleet of American-made cargo craft and helicopters. (Page A1, Column 6.) Opposition to the sale of Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia was expressed by Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, who said he would vote against President Reagan's proposal. The outcome of the Senate vote, set for next Wednesday, remained in doubt, but Senator Byrd's decision buoyed those opposing the sale of five radar planes and other equipment. (A1:4.)

title: M IS FOR THE MANY THINGS...
description: Never afraid to grasp the nettlesome issues of the day, the House of Representatives devoted the better part of a half-hour yesterday to considering whether the fourth Sunday in October should be designated National Mother-in-Law Day.

title: IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $1.5 million extraordinary gain from the exchange of nonmonetary assets

MURPHY MOTOR FREIGHT LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $1,904,000 tax credit...C-Net loss

title: Hollywood on Sideline
description: Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson, the veteran linebacker, once was expected to be back in the lineup Sunday for the Miami Dolphins' game against his old club, the Dallas Cowboys, at Texas Stadium. Instead, he will watch in street clothes from the sideline, his neck still in a brace.

title: WHAT DEREGULATION HAS DONE TO AIR TRAVEL
description: To the Editor:

title: James B. Beam Backing Horse Race in Kentucky
description: You can bet a bottle of your favorite booze that the James B. Beam Distilling Company is not at all pleased that its Jim Beam bourbon, the world's leading bourbon, is only No.3 in Kentucky, that grand bourbon state, the state where it comes to flower.

title: TRANS WORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $600,000 foreign exchange loss for the qr and $15.2 million foreign exchange gain for the 9 mos...C- Includes $49,446,000 extraordinary credit for the qr and 9 mos from debenture exchange, $400,000 foreign exchange gain for the qr nd $4.2 million foreign exchange loss for the 9 mos

title: Cagney Throws Out Ball
description: James Cagney, wearing a Yankee cap, threw out the ceremonial first ball last night before the start of the second World Series game. There had been some controversy over the assignment for the veteran actor, who was the Yankees' first choice to do the honors before the first game.

title: G.N.P. DROPS 0.6%, ACCENTING THE TREND TOWARD RECESSION
description: In another piece of evidence that the nation's economy appears to be in a recession, the Commerce Department reported today that the gross national product declined at an annual rate of six-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter and should continue falling in the present quarter.

title: American Fletcher
description: American Fletcher Mortgage Investors of Boston said it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by the United States Shelter Corporation in a series of exchanges of stock valued at $35 million. Under the agreement, about 15 limited partnerships affiliated with United States Shelter, an apartment management, development and construction concern, will be combined with the two companies.

title: Britain and Italy Undecided on Sinai Force
description: Spokesmen for the British and Italian Governments said today that neither had decided whether to take part in a proposed Sinai military force that would monitor the peace between Israel and Egypt.

title: Second Silver Auction Held
description: The United States Government's second auction of surplus silver from its strategic stockpile today drew fewer bids than last week's initial offering, but buyer interest still remained strong.

title: RENT STRIKE ON CITY LAND FACES DAY OF RECKONING
description: Harding Park, a surprising little community of bungalows, dirt lanes and tomato patches in the East Bronx, has long seemed a contented place.

title: MULTIBANK FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. and BRT Investments said they jointly own 6.2 percent of Amfac Inc. common stock.

title: NEWELL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Garfinckel Chief Reported Leaving
description: David R. Waters, chairman and chief executive officer of Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc., has decided to resign those posts only weeks before his company's stockholders are to vote on a proposed merger of the retail chain into the Allied Stores Corporation, sources close to Garfinckel indicated yesterday.

title: 86 Haitians in a Sailboat Land Near Miami Beach
description: A sailboat carrying 86 Haitians washed ashore behind a high-rise building near here today, marking the third time this month that refugees have made it to Florida since the Coast Guard was ordered to halt illegal aliens at sea.

title: THEATER: ONE-ACTERS BY DURANG
description: ANYONE can write an angry play - all it takes is an active spleen. But only a writer of real talent can write an angry play that remains funny and controlled even in its most savage moments. ''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You'' confirms that Christopher Durang is just such a writer. In this one-act comedy he goes after the Catholic Church with a vengeance that might well have shocked the likes of either Paul Krassner or Lenny Bruce, and yet he never lets his bitter emotions run away with his keen theatrical sense.

title: DATA ARCHITECTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

description: B-After foreign exchange losses of $761,000 for the qr and $1,666,000 for the 9 mos and $2,380,000 charge for the 9 mos from the settlement of litigation...C-Includes foreign exchange gains of $102,000 for the qr and $986,000 for the 9 mos

title: Melina Mercouri Takes Oath As Greece's Culture Minister
description: Melina Mercouri, the actress best known as the star of the 1960 movie ''Never on Sunday,'' was sworn in today as Minister of Culture and Sciences in Greece's first Socialist Government.

title: Vote Of Confidence
description: Jack Patera, coach of the Seattle Seahawks, got something of a vote of confidence from General Manager John Thompson despite the team's record of 15 losses in its last 16 games. ''His job is not in jeopardy at this time,'' Thompson said.

title: BETTER HOMES: SELLING DREAMS
description: The magazine was called Fruit, Garden and Home when it was spawned in 1922, the same year that Reader's Digest sprang into being and a year before something called Time hit the racks. The first issue had a story about the Delicious apple, and another article went into what you could do with $50 in your backyard. In 1924, the name was rewritten to what it has been ever since - Better Homes and Gardens.

title: A KORVETTES PLAN TO SELL 34TH ST. LEASE REPORTED
description: Korvettes Inc., the defunct retail chain that is now in bankruptcy proceedings, is preparing to sell the long-term lease on its Herald Square store to an unidentified Middle East company, sources close to the negotiations disclosed yesterday.

title: AMERICAN CAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $4.1 million net gain from the disposition of an investment in Franklin Mint Corp common stock and provisions for certain nonrecurring expenses

title: WOODSTREAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HERO SHUNS ROLE, HAILS FALLEN MEN
description: Michael Koch was being called a hero yesterday for capturing Katherine Boudin, a member of the Weather Underground, and he was not pleased.

title: Lockheed Net Up 25.6%
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that its third-quarter profit rose 25.6 percent, to $20.6 million, or $1.18 a share, from $16.4 million, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 8.1 percent, to $1.46 billion from $1.35 billion in 1980.

title: ELCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; yr-ago results have been restated

title: Going Out Guide
description: MORE MOZART

title: PESTICIDES ARE ENDANGERING WILDLIFE IN AN AFRICAN VALLEY
description: When David Livingstone and others passed this way a century ago, through the heat-seared valley of the Zambezi River, malaria-carrying mosquitoes infected them with often-fatal fevers and tsetse flies killed their animals.

title: Black United Fund Rebuffed On Exclusion From Campaign
description: The Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia yesterday reversed a lower court's ruling that a black charity's First Amendment rights were violated when it was excluded from a nationwide fund-raising drive for Federal workers.

title: HOMETOWN GREETS CARSON
description: Johnny Carson, host of NBC-TV's ''The Tonight Show,'' returned here this week to film ''Johnny Goes Home,'' a 90-minute special to be broadcast in January. Mr. Carson said he hoped to recapture the ''innocent era'' in which he grew up. Although he moved away from here 38 years ago, he has an abiding affection for the town in which he grew up.

title: WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Florio, the Democrat, against his Republican rival, former Assembly Speaker Thomas H. Kean.

Fire at Yankee Stadium
description: An electrical fire broke out in the basement of Yankee Stadium at about 1:30 this morning - two and a half hours after the finish of the second game of the World Series - filled corridors with smoke and forced the evacuation of about 100 people, mostly reporters and stadium personnel. There were no injuries immediately reported.

title: DE ROSE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: PROTECTED FEDERAL WITNESS IS SUSPECTED OF KILLING 4 IN 3 STATES
description: A man freed from a Federal prison two years ago and given a new identity under the Government's witness protection program is now suspected of killing four persons, officials said yesterday.

title: TUBES AND BULBS; Time Bombs
description: City cats, passive solar collectors, soak up fall sun in window boxes and on stoops. It's been warm - apple trees blossom on the East Side - but there are many signs of change.

title: PYGMIES LACK FACTOR REGULATING GROWTH, RESEARCH STUDY SAYS
description: A hormonal deficiency appears to be a major contributor to shortness among pygmies, according to research conducted by scientists from the University of Florida.

title: YANKS TOP DODGERS, 3-0, FOR 2-0 SERIES LEAD
description: In a game that saw Tommy John shut out his former teammates for seven innings, the Yankees defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-0, last night at Yankee Stadium and took a lead of two games to none in the World Series.

title: Notes on People; Glittering Attraction for Apartment Buyers
description: The sales office for his new Trump Tower has been open a full two weeks now, but so far, Donald J. Trump acknowledged yesterday, he has sold only $101 million of the $280 million worth of apartments in the 68-story building now going up on Fifth Avenue at 56th Street.

title: OREGON PORTLAND CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CALENDAR: GLASS ART AND A GHOSTLY TOUR
description: A Haystack Celebration, Cooper/ Lynn Gallery, 54 Seventh Avenue South; Aaron Faber Gallery, 666 Fifth Avenue (at 53d Street), and Heller Gallery, 965 Madison Avenue (at 75th Street).

title: DOW CORNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Dow Corning is 50 percent owned by Corning Glass Works and 50 percent owned by Dow Chemical Co

title: Alcan Smelters
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said that its Canadian smelting and chemicals subsidiary, Alcan Smelters and Chemicals Ltd., will close one-half of a smelting potline at its plant in Kitimat, British Columbia, on Nov. 1.

title: HOLLYWOOD HAILS LORENTZ, DOCUMENTARY PIONEER
description: HOLLYWOOD PARE LORENTZ never came to Hollywood except to scrounge some stock footage - of land rushes or cattle herds - for one of his movies. Those movies were the great Government-subsidized documentaries of the 30's -''The Plow That Broke the Plains,'' ''The River'' and ''The Fight for Life, all of which he wrote, produced, directed and edited.

title: The City; 3 Indicted in Plot In Chinatown
description: Three suspected members of a Chinatown gang were indicted on a charge that they conspired to kill the leader of a rival gang. The plan, according to the Manhattan District Attorney's office, was thwarted by a special task force set up eight months ago to investigate gang violence in Chinatown.

title: Student Protest Fails to End A Ban on Sharing Bathrooms
description: A sit-in at the University of Massachusetts ended last night as 70 students left an administration building. The four-and-one-half-hour effort to force a change in a rule against men and women sharing dormitory bathrooms was unsuccessful.

title: Nicaragua Arrests Critics of Regime
description: Four business leaders who accused the ruling junta of leading Nicaragua to Communism and ''preparing a new genocide'' have been arrested, Interior Minister Tomas Borge said today.

title: IN NYACK, TIME TO HANG BLACK CREPE
description: ''Is this a court?'' Judith Clark asked early this morning in Village Hall, standing before Robert P. Lewis, the Nyack Village judge. She was about to be arraigned, with two others, for the murder of two local police officers and a Brink's guard.

description: Grant F. Daniels, a former New York State Assemblyman and state official under three Governors, died Sunday in Memorial Hospital in Albany. He was 68 years old and lived in Loudonville, a suburb of Albany.

title: CORRECTION

description: A month after the strongest protests and demonstrations in this country since the Vietnam War, most New Zealanders believe that the invitation to the South African Springbok team to play rugby here was not worth it.

description: Following is a statement by President Reagan concerning United States nuclear strategy. The statement, which was distributed at the White House, was also read to reporters aboard Air Force One en route to Cancun, Mexico.

description: B-Including $560,000 gain from the termination of a lease

title: PAPANDREOU, AT SWEARING-IN, CALLS FOR CHANGE
description: Greece's first Socialist Government was sworn in today, and Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said that, having received ''a mandate for change'' in last Sunday's elections, it did not have the right to disappoint the people.

title: Ex-Soldier Gains in Lawsuit Against U.S. Over Radiation
description: Federal District Judge Norma Shapiro ruled yesterday that a soldier exposed to radiation while in the service can sue the Government over his children's birth defects.

title: AMERICAN PILOTS REPORTED FLYING IN LIBYAN FORCES
description: American pilots and aircraft mechanics, including military veterans, are flying and maintaining Libyan Air Force planes in an operation organized by Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent, according to associates of Mr. Wilson.

description: In a joint announcement, executives of Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd. of London and the Newmont Mining Corporation said that Consolidated Gold Fields would acquire one million shares of Newmont's stock at $72 a share under an agreement that limits the British concern to a 26 percent interest in Newmont. In addition, the officials said Newmont had agreed to drop its recently filed antitrust suit against Consolidated Gold Fields.

title: FURNITURE INDUSTRY TO SET STANDARDS
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission voted unanimously today to let the furniture industry continue to develop and promote voluntary standards to improve the flame resistance of upholstered furniture. The vote marked ''a new era of government and industry cooperation,'' according to its chairman, Nancy Harvey Steorts.

title: ENVIRONMENT AIDE'S INDUSTRY TALKS CRITICIZED
description: The chairman of the House Energy and Environment Subcommittee said today that the Environmental Protection Agency might have violated Federal law by holding closed meetings with chemical industry representatives to discuss two chemicals under the agency's regulation.

title: Addenda

title: E.E.C. Joblessness Up
description: Unemployment in the European Economic Community rose to a record 9.4 million people in September, or 8.3 percent of the work force, the Common Market statistics office said today. ''The figures show a worsening of the situation already observed in all community countries, without exception,'' the office said in a statement. The figure represents a seasonally adjusted 2.4 percent increase in unemployment from August, the office said.

description: Larry Milbourne has excelled as a starter for the Yankees since late August, but until last night he had not had the opportunity to stand behind a microphone in a crowded interview room and tell hundreds of strangers who he was and where he came from.

description: For Ronnie Lipkin and Marc Goldstein these golden fall days are long and the living is easy - too easy, both say.

title: CITY OPERA: 'ATTILA' RECAST
description: THE New York City Opera's production of Verdi's ''Attila'' is a handsome affair, and the introduction of three new principals into the cast Tuesday night did nothing to disturb that. This was partly because of their good qualities, but also because the success of the evening has much to do with Justino Diaz's commanding assumption of the title part, Sergiu Comissiona's hearty conducting and the decor of Ming Cho Lee and Hal George.

title: 'WEATHER' FUGITIVE IS SEIZED IN KILLINGS
description: Two members of the long-dormant Weather Underground terrorist group were identified yesterday as being among four captured suspects of a gang that killed an armored-car guard and two police officers in a robbery in Rockland County.

MUSIC: CAECILIAN ENSEMBLE 'HERODIADE'
description: THE best way to understand the effect of Hindemith's ''Herodiade,'' which was given an evocative performance at the Symphony Space Monday night by the Caecilian Ensemble, is to read its Mallarme text. Though Hindemith wrote the music in 1944, decades after the Symbolist poetry had its heyday, the score creates an interpretive gloss on the text, echoing its ingrown iciness and embittered passions.

description: Volkswagen of America said it would introduce three models for 1982, including a replacement for its Dasher sedan. The company said its Dasher model would be replaced by a slightly larger car, called the Quantum, that would be more fuel-efficient than the Dasher.

title: FOR DODGER, 'CRISIS MENTALITY '
description: ''The prophetic statement,'' Steve Garvey was saying, ''is that if you don't score, you don't win.'' The Los Angeles Dodgers didn't score last night in Yankee Stadium, and didn't win. They scored three runs the night before, and didn't win, either. And now they were down to the Yankees, two games to none, meaning that they had to win four of five games or lose the World Series.

Mr. Fogelberg bases his sound, which often features thick vocal harmonies and mixes acoustic and electric instrumentation, on Crosby, Stills and Nash and the Eagles, but throws in some light classical touches as well.

description: China experienced its first electronic rock concert tonight, leaving the audience rather bemused and the composer-performer Jean-Michel Jarre delighted to have played in Peking.

title: French Bank Head Out Over Nationalization
description: Pierre L. Moussa, 59, resigned yesterday as chairman of the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas, France's leading private bank, which is known as Paribas, after the French National Assembly voted to nationalize his company and the Compagnie Financiere Indosuez. The Assembly's approval of the nationalization, part of a Government bill for the nationalization of five major industrial companies and most French-owned private banks, came after one of its most acrimonious debates in recent years.

A week ago both men assisted in the delivery of a premature baby who died the next day.

title: OPERA ORCHESTRA: BERGONZI SINGS 'I DUE FOSCARI'
description: REFINEMENT is not the first quality that comes to mind when you think of early Verdi, but his sixth opera, ''I Due Foscari,'' is a miracle of elegance compared to works that went before it, such as ''Nabucco'' and ''Ernani.'' Still, as Tuesday night's performance by Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York at Carnegie Hall made clear, ''I Due Foscari'' can be turned into a rip-snorting melodrama in which its highly reputed musical nuances are underplayed in favor of traditional Verdian energy and vocal thrust. Whether that is the best way is another question, but certainly Miss Queler's concert version churned up considerable foam, some of it around mouths in the enthusiastic audience. Old-fashioned bellow canto was the order of the evening.

title: RESTAURANT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $47,000 pretax gain from purchase of debentures pretax gain of $36,000 from disposal of facilities and tax credit of $164,000...C-Includes $14,000 pretax gain from purchase of debentures and $116,000 tax credit...D-Includes pretax gain of $92,000 on repurchase of denbentures pretax gain of $1,135,000 from disposal of facilities and $609,000 tax credit...E-After pretax gain of $93,000 from purchase of debentures pretax loss of $27,000 from disposal of facilities and $212,000 tax credit

title: Briefing
description: A T the White House, the ''Quotations of Chairman Mel'' is being circulated from desk to desk in the unfolding little drama that has pitted conservatives against neoconservatives. ''Chairman Mel,'' who was given the title by disgruntled neoconservatives, is Prof. Melvin E. Bradford of Texas, a leading contender for the chairmanship of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: Compugraphic Hints at Merger
description: The Compugraphic Corporation, a leading manufacturer of photocomposition machines and supplies for the newspaper publishing industry, requested yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange halt trading in its stock amid widespread speculation that it would announce an acquisition proposal today.

title: AUTUMN'S GIFT OF A TUCKED-AWAY HOUR
description: FALL is indeed a comedown. The summer haze is gone from the towers; the final peaches are gone from the stores; the children are gone from the streets, having grown as leggy as begonias over the summer. There are no more twilights; fall doesn't allow such sentimentality. Nothing is allowed to linger, like suntan on the skin, like shadows on the sand. We house owners live with the white bones of garden furniture stacked in the garage, like a hall of dinosaur skeletons in the museum, leftovers from a leafier era.

description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on May 15, 1981; Yr-ago results have been restated

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1981; The Economy
description: The nation's gross national product fell at an annual rate of 0.6 percent in the third quarter and is expected to continue to decline in this quarter, the Commerce Department reported. It said prices, as measured by the G.N.P.'s broad price index, rose 9.2 percent annually. Analysts saw this as indicating the recent decline in inflation has not been as sharp as was believed. (Page A1.)

title: Finn Denies Reports Of Impending Merger
description: David Finn, a founder of Ruder & Finn, the nation's largest independent public realtions firm, yesterday denied a strong rumor that the company was merging with Harsh-Rotman & Druck, the secondlargest firm.

title: Virginia Execution Delayed
description: The Virginia Supreme Court today delayed the execution of Linwood Briley, who was scheduled to be electrocuted Friday for the murder of a disk jockey. A three-judge panel issued the order after a 15-minute hearing and five minutes of deliberation. Attorneys for both sides asked for the stay, although Deputy Attorney General James Kulp stressed that his request had been made reluctantly.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The parquet floor in my apartment has darkened over the years, apparently from too much waxing by previous occupants. Some spots are faded from exposure to the sun, and all of the floor lacks a sheen. I don't know what type of wood the floor is made of (the building is 20 years old), but can you tell me what I can do to restore the wood to its original color and luster? - J.M.F., New York City.

title: Bulletin Sued for Libel
description: The Bulletin was sued today for ''in excess of $12 million'' by Richard A. Sprague, the special prosecutor of the killers of Joseph A. Yablonski, a United Mine Workers dissident who was murdered in 1969.

title: REAGAN TO REQUEST NEW ALIEN CURBS
description: The Reagan Administration has sent Congress a package of proposals for immigration bills that would grant the President broad emergency powers to keep unwanted aliens out of the country.

title: Drama About Harlem To Benefit Playwrights
description: ''Tell Pharaoh,'' a concert drama by Loften Mitchell about Harlem from its beginning to the contemporary period, will be presented Saturday for the benefit of the Playwrights Program at the State University of New York at Binghamton. Mr. Mitchell, a teacher at Binghamton, wrote the book for ''Bubbling Brown Sugar'' and dramas including ''A Land Beyond the River.''

title: MODINE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: The company is traded on the Montreal Exchange

title: NIGERIA SAID TO CUT OIL PRICE
description: Nigeria yesterday offered to sell crude oil to its customers at $34.50 a barrel, according to Platt's Oilgram Price Report, or $1.50 below Nigeria's discount price.

title: The City;
description: A tapestry depicting the Resurrection and worth $30,000 has been stolen from the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, the police said. The tapestry, which is 14 feet wide and 6 feet 2 inches high, was discovered missing from its spot near the altar of the church, at 73d Street, Monday night. (AP)

title: Futures Exchange Names Top Officer
description: The New York Futures Exchange, a subsidiary of the New York Stock Exchange, known as N.Y.F.E. and pronounced ''knife,'' made the longawaited announcement yesterday that John F. Kelley, 37, who heads institutional financial futures trading at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, has been named president and chief executive officer, effective Nov. 2.

title: CLAIMANTS FILE WITH IRAN PANEL
description: Eleven American claimants, most of them major corporations, have filed documents seeking hundreds of millions of dollars that they argue they are owed in connection with the Iranian seizure of American hostages, according to an official at an international tribunal here.

title: GORMAN-RUPP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST LADY LOOKS TO PARENTS ON DRUGS
description: Asserting that the future of the nation depends upon its response to adolescent drug abuse, Nancy Reagan yesterday called upon American parents to take responsibility for their children and to become involved in drug-therapy efforts.

title: STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings are before giving effect to the pro rata 3-for-2 stock distribution payable Dec 1 on record Nov 1

title: ROBERT ALTMAN TO DIRECT CHER IN BROADWAY DEBUT
description: Cher, the singer and entertainer known especially for the Sonny & Cher comedy-variety series on CBS-TV in the 1970's, has been signed for ''Come Back to the the 5 & Dime, Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean,'' a play by Ed Graczyk that the film director Robert Altman plans to stage on Broadway early next year.

title: Helpful Hardware; FOLDAWAY ACCESSORIES
description: SMALLER kitchens are making built-in cabinet accessories a necessity rather than a luxury. And @Haefle America's Spacemagic line of European-made cabinet hardware is well suited to these demands for tight space.

title: Home Beat; PLANS FOR SUPERTOWER DESIGN OPEN HOUSE
description: THE designers were being sort of secretive, as they sometimes particularly like to be -especially when they haven't completely decided what they are going to do. In any case, at a luncheon last week, it was announced that R. Scott Bromley and Robin Jacobsen, Egon Von Furstenberg and W. Marc Janecki, as well as the firm Saporiti Italia, were all involved in the design of the model apartments for the St. James's Tower, American City Construction's slick luxury building going up on the East Side. Bravura was the order of the day, with 9-foot 3-inch ceilings described as a feature, and many slick accoutrements meant to appeal to an international, moneyed clientele. Mr. Jacobsen touted the use of the home computer systems in his scheme and Mr. Bromley tried to explain its more prosaic applications: ''Sensors are hidden under the carpeting to light the way to and back from the bathroom in the middle of the night.'' Mr. Von Furstenberg said that this would be ''his first big job in New York City'' and Mr. Janecki added: ''We want to show how space can be adapted to a variety of needs and are planning to stay away from an extreme style -O.K.?'' O.K., let's see in December. That's when the model apartments are supposed to be finished.

title: REFORMULATING ISLAM
description: If the Moslem world is at all to come to grips with the impact of the West, with radical new Islamic ideologies, and with severe indigenous social, economic, and demographic dislocations, it must do so through an Islam that must be reformulated by qualified religious thinkers and jurists.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 22, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PORTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Can Net Off
description: The American Can Company said today that weak demand for consumer goods pushed its third-quarter earnings down 19.3 percent from a year earlier, to $19.7 million, or 97 cents a share, from $24.4 million, or 97 cents a share, in the 1980 third quarter. The nation's leading producer of containers and packaging products said its revenues for the three months ended Sept. 30 were $1.24 billion, down slightly from last year's third-quarter revenues of $1.25 billion. ''The current recessionary environment, soft demand and margin pressure in certain of our businesses continue to impact overall results,'' said William S. Woodside, chairman and chief executive.

title: Design Notebook; 'TRANSFORMED HOUSES' OF THE WORKING CLASS
description: THERE are a lot of overlooked parts of the American landscape, but none, surely, is more consistently ignored than the wooden frame houses that fill working-class districts of older cities.

title: Amax Off; General Foods, G.&W. Up
description: Amax Inc. reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter of 1981 plunged 49 percent, as sales slipped 3.9 percent. The Greenwich, Conn., company, one of the world's leading producers of molybdenum, which has important interests in base metals, silver, coal, petroleum, aluminum and iron ore, said that net income dropped to $51 million, or 73 cents a share, from $100 million, or $1.53 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales were at $657 million, off from $684 million.

title: HANDGUNS NEED STRICTER NATIONAL CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: New Agency Opens With Predictable Flair
description: Phyllis Kish, 40 years old, and Ralph Casado, 45, have worked together for 20 years.

title: 22 LEADERS GATHER FOR TWO-DAY CANCUN MEETING
description: Leaders of 8 industrialized and 14 developing nations gathered here today for a meeting aimed at breaking the deadlock in years of protracted negotiations on problems of world poverty.

title: MEDALIST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXCERPTS FROM SENATOR BYRD'S SPEECH OPPOSING AWACS SALE TO SAUDIS
description: Following are excerpts from a Senate speech by Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the minority leader, outlining his position on the Administration proposal to sell Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia:

title: X-RAY TREATMENT FOR CANCER IS FOUND TO RELIEVE ARTHRITIS
description: An X-ray treatment for a form of cancer shows promise as an aid for thousands of people crippled by rheumatoid arthritis, two separate reports suggested today.

title: What's Possible at Cancun
description: The mass summit meeting at Cancun today and tomorrow will not narrow the development gap between the world's poor, mainly in the Southern Hemisphere, and the rich, chiefly in the North. But it can narrow the rhetorical gap. It can breathe humanity into dry discussions of dull statistics. And if it reaches for a few practical goals, the conference can stimulate a more effective attack on the poverty that scars and darkens too much of the globe.

title: TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Several Hurt in Collapse Of Church Hall's Floor
description: A concrete floor in a church hall collapsed today, plunging 200 people attending a turkey dinner into the basement below and critically injuring at least two of them.

title: Gardening; GARDENING HYDROPONICALLY, WITHOUT SOIL
description: WITH the last baskets of home-grown vegetables having been gathered, most backyard gardeners are looking rather wistfully toward the prospect of eating store-bought produce in the cold months ahead.

title: IN ARGENTINA, POLITICAL PARTIES COME TO LIFE AGAIN
description: After more than five years of dormancy, organized political activity has begun to grow here as demand builds for the military regime to step down.

title: HUBBELL, HARVEY, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The City; Council Unit Backs Prison Bond Plan
description: The City Council Committee on Public Safety voted, 8 to 0, to support the $500 million state prison bond issue, part of which would go toward replacement facilities for the Men's House of Detention on Rikers Island.

title: MORE AMERICANS LIVING ALONE, CENSUS REPORTS
description: The number of Americans living alone shot up much faster than the population during the 1970's, reflecting increased independence among young people and the rise in separation and divorce, the Census Bureau reported this week.

title: SERIES PROVOKES AN AMBIVALENT MOOD
description: Near the Pulitzer Fountain on Fifth Avenue, a small knot of people gathered round the shopping cart loaded with white and blue Yankee World Series banners and T-shirts that looked even whiter and bluer in the bright afternoon sunshine.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP 8.2 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose by 8.2 million shares, to 74.1 million, in the month ended Oct. 15.

title: ENSERCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $1.6 million reduction associated with the company's unsuccessful efforts to acquired Davy Corp Ltd; shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May 1981

title: Tokyo-E.E.C.  Surplus Off
description: The Japanese trade surplus is declining with the Common Market but increasing with the United States, the Economic Planning Agency, the ministry that monitors the country's business performance, said today.

title: Garcia Marquez of Colombia Wins Nobel Literature Prize
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 21

title: Andrew Oliver, Lawyer And a Historian, Dead
description: Andrew Oliver, an American historian and lawyer who had served as first vice president and an honorary trustee of the New York Historical Society, died Tuesday in Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. Mr. Oliver, who lived in Boston, was 75 years old.

title: Knight-Ridder Net Up
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. said today that its third-quarter profit rose 16 percent over the comparable period a year earlier, helped in part by strong national advertising revenues. The newspaper group said it earned $23.9 million, or 73 cents a share, compared with $20.6 million, or 64 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1980. Revenues rose 14.4 percent, to $300.9 million from $263 million.

title: Hers
description: YOU will recognize the kind of day it was: Out of milk the night before, all-night supermarket at 6:30 A.M., full day's work, week's grocery shopping on my lunch hour, a yogurt wolfed with a plastic spoon at 3 P.M., and there I was in my driveway at last, trying to figure out how I could get all those groceries into the house in less than four trips. My mother-in-law, as usual, was waiting for me at the front door. ''Faye,'' she said wistfully, as one of the overloaded bags slipped out of my arms, ''how come you don't bake apple pies no more?''

title: FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMSHARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $139,900 loss from discontinued operations

title: Soviet Boy Sues Parents To Avert Forced Return
description: A teenager who threatened to commit suicide rather than go back to the Soviet Union has filed suit against his parents.

title: WANG LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STAGE: 'COTTON PATCH GOSPEL'
description: ''COTTON Patch Gospel,'' a new musical with songs by the late Harry Chapin, is a down-home retelling of the New Testament, a kind of cracker-barrel turnabout of Alec McCowen's ''St. Mark's Gospel,'' or a ''Jesus Christ, Good Ol' Boy.'' The show, which moves the Gospels from Gethsemane to Georgia, opened last night at the Lambs Theater, a cozy bandbox of a stage in the former Lambs Club. Drawing its inspiration from Clarence Jordan's book ''The Cotton Patch Version of Matthew and John,'' the evening is as cute as calico and as sweet as sorghum. A little of it goes a very long way.

title: VICTORIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid in Feb 1981

title: Home Improvement; A GUIDE TO WINTERIZING THE HOUSE
description: TO keep the house as comfortable as possible during the coming cold season, and to save energy as well, the homeowner should act now. Most homeowners are aware of the need for adequate insulation in outside walls and attics to lower heating costs and increase comfort. Many still do not realize, however, that a lot of heat is often wasted in homes and apartments through the windows.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I do not believe this sale serves the best interests of the United States.

title: TWO GUARDS AT BERGEN JAIL ANNEX ARE SEIZED IN UPRISING BY INMATES
description: About 150 inmates seized two guards, set mattresses afire and rampaged through a wing of the Bergen County Jail Annex last night in a protest that continued early this morning.

title: Jessie C. Gneshin, 83, Headed Jewish War Veterans Auxiliary
description: Jessie C. Gneshin, a former president of the National Ladies Auxiliary of the Jewish War Veterans, died Tuesday in Doctors Hospital.

title: SAN-BAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split in July 1981

title: ON THE ADVANTAGES AND PITFALLS OF BEING YOUR OWN CONTRACTOR
description: IT can be as time-consuming as a full-time job. It is fraught with aggravation. And it is a test of patience. Still, the prospect of saving money makes being your own contractor very tempting to many cost-conscious New Yorkers, intent on changing their home environments but unwilling, or unable, to move.

title: FEDERAL CUTS FORCING STATES TO CURB DAY-CARE SERVICE FOR POOR
description: Federal budget cuts are forcing many day-care centers to increase their fees, close down or curtail their services to the children of poor families headed by working women.

title: Market Place; Little-Noticed Tax Shelter
description: NOTICED three-year-old tax shelter can protect more income for many investors than the brand new Individual Retirement Account sections of the Reagan tax law.

title: ALFRED BARR LAUDED AT TRIBUTE AT THE MODERN AS A 'TEACHER'
description: For the architect Philip Johnson, he was ''one of the few great men of our century - with awesome strength of character, torrential passion, a flaming and fierce loyalty.'' The art historian Meyer Schapiro saw him as ''a teacher and a guide'' remarkable for ''the purity and selflessness of his dedication to the support of contemporary art.'' William S. Paley, chairman of the Museum of Modern Art, said that he had ''profoundly affected and sharpened our understanding and perceptions of the age in which we live.''

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1980 earnings restated for a change in depreciation method and the adoption of LIFO inventory accounting for certain domestic inventories

title: U.S. SEEKS SCHLITZ MERGER BAN
description: In the Reagan Administration's first comment on a major corporate merger, the Justice Department announced today that it would oppose the $494 million acquisition of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company by the G. Heileman Brewing Company as a violation of antitrust law.

title: PLAN TO HALT PRICE SUPPORTS FOR TOBACCO LOSES IN HOUSE
description: After a tense struggle that produced some of the oddest political alliances of the year, the House of Representatives decided today to preserve the tobacco support program.

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO OFFER CONTINUING TALKS ON POVERTY
description: The United States is prepared to make a concession at the meeting of 22 countries here by backing continuing discussions to deal with the poverty of the developing nations, according to a ranking American official.

title: Advertising; Toothpaste Faces Gel Challenge
description: FIRST there was Close-Up, a gel toothpaste from Lever Brothers. It appealed to young members of the frequent-kisser set who were concerned about their breath and the whiteness of their teeth. There are a lot of those people.

title: Cox Profit Up 17%
description: The Cox Broadcasting Corporation said today that its cable television unit posted a 59 percent gain in thirdquarter revenues from a year earlier, helping the parent company's profit rise 17 percent on a 35 percent gain in revenues. Besides cable, Cox is involved in broadcasting, publishing and program production. Net income for the quarter ended Sept. 30 was $13.1 million, or 48 cents a share, compared with $11.2 million, or 42 cents a share, for the same quarter a year ago.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard NO PLACE OF GRACE. Antimodernism and the Transformation of American Culture 1880-1920. By Jackson Lears. 375 pages. Pantheon. $18.90.

title: YANKS STOP DODGERS, 3-0, AND LEAD SERIES, 2-0
description: Tommy John, let go by the Los Angeles Dodgers as a free agent in 1978 when they refused to give him the extra year he wanted in a contract, beat his former teammates, 3-0, last night for the Yankees' second straight victory in the World Series.

title: SYSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: Shr earnings reflect 3-for-1 stock split in Dec 1980

title: KNICKS BEATEN BY NETS
description: It seemed that each time one of them would touch the ball, the other would be there to meddle, harass, or intimidate him. The Knicks and the Nets were playing in the second game of a doubleheader at Madison Sqaure Garden last night and Marvin Webster, the Knicks' center, and his counterpart, Maurice Lucas, were going at it. The Nets won, 89-82, and both players fouled out.

title: BOOKS: HOW MISS DE MILLE FOUGHT BACK
description: REPRIEVE: A MEMOIR By Agnes de Mille. 288 pages. Doubleday. $14.95.

title: Quebec Separatist Is Guilty
description: A Quebec separatist, Marc Carbonneau, pleaded guilty in court today to the kidnapping of the British diplomat James Cross here in 1970. Mr. Carbonneau, who belonged to the now-defunct Quebec Liberation Front, returned to Canada last May from self-exile in France. He will be sentenced after the judge hears a probation officer's report on Dec. 11.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt LIFE ITSELF. Its Origins and Nature. By Francis Crick. 192 pages. Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: Dow Jones to Buy Cable Interest
description: Continental Cablevision Inc., the nation's 13th-largest cable operator in terms of subscribers, and Dow Jones & Company announced that Dow Jones would pay up to $80 million for a 24.5 percent interest in the cable television company.

title: U.S. Debt Past $1 Trillion
description: The national debt passed the $1 trillion mark today, Treasury Department officials confirmed, but the acknowledgement came with little fanfare. ''It's not an issue for celebration,'' a spokesman said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif., has named Joseph Graziano vice president of finance and chief financial officer. * Bank of New York has named W. Gilroy Davidson a vice president.

title: Hoover to Shut British Factory
description: The Hoover Company said that it would close one of its three factories in Britain and eliminate almost 2,000 jobs because of heavy losses.

title: ART: MARIN'S ROMANCE WITH NEW YORK CITY
description: THE American artists who came of age in the last years of the 19th century and the early years of the 20th often found themselves inhabiting two very different worlds. One was dominated by the life of small towns, rural landscapes and comfortable, middle-size cities that were only just awakening to the problems and promises of the industrial era, but were not yet overwhelmed by them. The other was the world of modern engineering and the kind of fast-paced technological change that was quickly altering the very look and rhythm of life in the main metropolitan centers.

title: JUDITH CLARK'S ESPOUSAL OF CAUSES TRACED TO '69
description: Judith A. Clark, who has been charged with second-degree murder in the killing Tuesday of a Brink's guard and two Nyack, N.Y., police officers, first became involved with radical causes in 1969. But for the last 10 years, she has been living in New York City and earlier this year gave birth to a daughter.

title: Business People; Diamond's Stores Chief May Go to Ward's Unit
description: Arthur F. Baumann, the 43-year old chairman and chief executive of Diamond's department stores of Phoenix and Las Vegas, is expected shortly to be named president and chief operating officer of the Jefferson Ward discount store division of Montgomery Ward, based in Miami.

title: TYPE UNIT SELLING 51% TO AGFA
description: Agfa-Gevaert, the photographic products subsidiary of the Bayer chemical group of West Germany, will acquire 51 percent of the Compugraphic Corporation, the leading maker of photocomposition equipment, for about $60 million, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Sohio to Close Part of a Refinery
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said that it would temporarily shut down a section of its Toledo refinery to adjust for lower demand for gasoline.

title: ROLE OF EVE ROSAHN IN PROTEST MOVEMENT SURPRISES NEIGHBORS
description: Neighbors in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, where Eve Rosahn had lived for at least the last 14 months, remember her quiet and almost diffident manner as she came and went in her olive drab fatigues and field jacket and carrying an old Army knapsack.

title: A 'DIFFERENT' BOSTON SYMPHONY MARKS A CENTURY
description: In the dark mornings between 4 and 5 A.M., on the winding wooded roads of a village 10 miles west of here, there is the soft sound of pad-pad-pad. Seiji Ozawa, the music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, is running off the tensions of the symphony's birthday celebration.

title: SPAIN SEIZES THREE LINKED TO BASQUES
description: Spain's antiterrorist policemen have opened a major new operation against the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. and have stunned political and intellectual circles here by detaining two prominent feminists and a leftist university professor.

title: Sports of The Times; 2 Relief Pitchers On Separate Paths
description: TERRY FORSTER remembers the summer of 1970, when he and Rich Gossage would cuff each other around for an extra pillow or the best bed in their apartment. They would compete for space, but there was no doubt about their roles on the farm team in Appleton, Wis.

title: SAN FRANCISCO TRANSIT STIRS DISCORD
description: It could have been any morning on one of the city bus lines. The bus arrived late, stopped four feet from the curb and passengers boarded the crowded vehicle. A few stops later, a passenger yelled at the driver that he had gone past his stop. The driver yelled back, pulled over at the next stop, got up from his seat and told the man, with an obscenity, to get off the bus or he would throw him off.

title: CAUGHT IN A DOCTRINE BOX
description: Ideological rigidity is beginning to catch the United States in an international box likely to be far more expensive than foreseen, and possibly dangerous.

title: 4 Killed in Kokomo Air Crash
description: Four Kokomo residents were killed when their single-engine airplane crashed and burned near the Kokomo Airport, the authorities said Thursday. The victims were identified as Terry Boyd, 37 years old; Walter Leo Duke, 41; Charlie Duke, 39, and Sharon Duke, 32. The police said the plane took off from the airport about midnight yesterday and apparently was returning when it crashed and burned in a soybean field about a mile southwest of the terminal.

title: THE DAY THE RUSSIANS HUNTED BLAIR HOUSE 'BUGS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People; Familiar Loss
description: A follow-up: Elwyn Jones, the visiting British television writer who had been looking for the caring New Yorker who mailed his lost wallet back to his Wales home, found his benefactor yesterday.

title: Torre Accepts 3-Year Braves Contract
description: Joe Torre said yesterday that he had agreed to a three-year contract to become manager of the Atlanta Braves, and that he hoped to hire three of his former coaches from the Mets.

title: Conferees Seek Swift Action To Block Reagan's MX Plans
description: A House-Senate conference committee voted today to call for action by both houses of Congress by Nov. 18 to block President Reagan's plans to deploy the MX missile and build the B-1 bomber, Congressional sources said.

title: Newmont Leader Achieves His Aim
description: Plato Malozemoff has long displayed a talent for locating common ground in big-stakes bargaining. That skill was in evidence again on Wednesday, when the Russianborn chairman and chief executive of the Newmont Mining Corporation cleared the way for Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd. of London to buy up to 26 percent of Newmont.

title: The Region; Guards Are Freed At Jail in Bergen
description: Thirty-one suspects awaiting trial will be released from the Bergen County Jail Annex here and 63 other inmates will be transferred after a nightlong uprising in which two guards were held hostage by about 150 inmates.

title: RECRUITER FOR PROJECT IN LIBYA SOUGHT PERSONNEL IN ALABAMA
description: Working under a contract to maintain Libyan aircraft and train pilots, Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent who is now a fugitive in Libya, sent a retired Army sergeant here this year to offer $60,000 to $72,000 a year to pilots, mechanics and other flight personnel if they would work for the Libyan Air Force.

title: MUSIC: KUBELIK GIVES ORCHESTRA LEEWAY
description: ANDRE PREVIN having dropped out of his engagement because of an onset of conductor's elbow, the duty and pleasure of leading the New York Philharmonic fell last night to Rafael Kubelik, an old friend of the orchestra. Whatever pain might come to the Czechoslovak conductor in this life, he is unlikely to feel it in the elbow. His baton work depends more on other parts of the anatomy, such as the shoulder and the lower back. He is not the most precise of technicians, but what he does seems to work for him. He pushes his left palm insistently at the musicians as if asking for a palm-reading, he appears to wave at a friend in the brass section, he holds his arms out imploring like St. Francis welcoming the birds, and he trembles in every bone and fiber.

title: DON'T SELL THE FX TO TAIPEI
description: The Administration is approaching a decision that, if mishandled, could produce a major setback in relations between the United States and China.

title: BIGOTRY CHARGE RAISED AT RALLY FOR REV. MOON
description: As more than 5,000 followers sang the ''Battle Hymn of the Republic,'' the Rev. Sun Myung Moon strode to a podium in Foley Square Park yesterday to declare that he was innocent of Federal tax fraud charges and that they resulted from religious and racial bigotry.

title: A RALLY OF LITERARY LIONS FOR PUBLIC LIBRARY
description: Those two marble lions guarding the entrance were not the only lions at the New York Public Library last night. They were joined by 24 prominent authors - dubbed ''literary lions'' for the evening - at a benefit dinner at which the real dessert was the surprise announcement that Enid A. Haupt had donated $1 million to the library.

title: Up From the Underground
description: A few months after the 1970 explosion in a Greenwich Village townhouse that killed three Weathermen, their leader, Bernardine Dohrn, said, ''We became aware that a group of outlaws who are isolated from the youth communities do not have a sense of what is going on.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.E. LePage Ltd., a Toronto-based real estate brokerage, said that it intended to maintain its position as a shareholder of Coldwell, Banker & Co., a United States real estate concern that has agreed to be acquired by Sears, Roebuck & Co. LePage holds an 18.8 percent interest in Coldwell.

title: MARY CHASE, 74, PLAYWRIGHT WHO WROTE 'HARVEY,' DEAD
description: Mary Chase, the imaginative playwright who became famous and wealthy by creating an invisible rabbit named Harvey that dwelled in the minds of theater and movie audiences all over the world, died Tuesday in Denver, where she was born 74 years ago.

title: G.O.P. Draws Fire for Polling Delegates to Forum on Aging
description: The Democrat who heads the House Select Committee on Aging accused the Republican national chairman today of trying to ''pervert and prostitute'' the forthcoming White House Conference on Aging by surveying the political views of about 900 delegates.

title: 25 Injured in Explosion At Aerosol Can Factory
description: A fiery explosion flashed through an aerosol can factory today, searing skin from the faces and bodies of some workers and blowing the clothes off others. At least 25 persons were injured.

title: 2 MORE ARE CHARGED IN KILLING OF LAWYER IN AN EAST SIDE PARK
description: Two men were arrested in their homes yesterday and charged with the stabbing murder last month of a 38-year-old lawyer who had been walking with a friend in a park on the Lower East Side.

title: CASTLEMAN LEADING A TOUR OF PAST VIOLIN STYLES
description: Followers of the violin, like opera fans, occupy a world of their own. It is the beauty of sound for its own sake -the subtle and mysterious variations of bow drawn across strings - that enchants this subspecies of audience. The music can often come second.

title: Curtiss Seeks More Of Western Union
description: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, whose chairman, T. Roland Berner, almost succeeded in taking over the Kennecott Corporation last year, said yesterday that it intended to acquire at least $15 million worth of Western Union Corporation stock.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bankamerica Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $200 million of adjustable-rate notes due Nov. 1, 1989, to be sold through a Blyth Eastman Paine Webber group.

title: DURABLES ORDERS SLUMP 2.9%
description: New orders for manufacturers' durable goods plunged 2.9 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ROBERT S. CLEMENT
description: Robert S. Clement, a former Mayor and the patriarch of a Tennessee political family, died yesterday at the age of 80.

title: House Adjournment Date
description: Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that he hoped the House could adjourn by Nov. 20 but feared Dec. 18 would be a more realistic date. The second session of Congress will probably begin Jan. 25, he said.

title: Money Funds' Assets Increase
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $2.39 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $166.04 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. It was the 21st consecutive weekly increase.

title: WHEN A WORLD SERIES GAME IS A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: Oh, everyone thinks of them as historic and important World Series games full of tension and triumph and that sort of thing, but they aren't only World Series games. They are also family occasions. ''A baseball game isn't just a baseball game when you're with your wife and children,'' said Senator Alphonse D'Amato from his seat at Yankee Stadium the other night. ''It becomes a family event.''

title: AUCTIONS
description: EUROPEAN paintings of the 19th and early 20th century by major artists will be offered at four galleries next week in sales that will be closely watched to see whether the lower prices and resistance in buying last spring continue. The causes for this softening of the market, including high interest rates and the effect of the stronger dollar on European buyers, have not changed.

title: UAL Inc. Net Down 53.8%
description: United Airlines, the nation's largest airline, said yesterday that it had a loss of $400,000 in the third quarter, although its parent company, UAL Inc., showed a profit of $7.2 million which came primarily from earnings of its hotel business.

title: No Headline
description: When the World Series resumes tonight in Los Angeles, both starting pitchers will be rookies for only the third time in 458 games in 78 years of Series history: Fernando Valenzuela of the Dodgers and Dave Righetti of the Yankees. Both are left-handers, both are strikeout pitchers with distinctive personalities. The only other times that rookies started a Series game was in 1950, when Whitey Ford of the Yankees faced Bob Miller of the Philadelphia Phillies in Game 4, and in 1967, when Gary Waslewski of the Boston Red Sox opposed Dick Hughes of the St. Louis Cardinals in Game 6.

title: KOCH IS MAIN TARGET AS HE AND 6 OPPONENTS DEBATE
description: Mayor Koch was the principal target yesterday in the first debate of the election campaign - an unusual confrontation involving all seven candidates for Mayor of the major and minor parties.

title: A NOSTALGIC TRIP TO THE GLORY DAYS OF THE BRONX
description: The twinkling stars on the ceiling of Loews Paradise Theater have dimmed, and the Fordham area of the Bronx has fallen on hard times. But the neighborhood still has many historical landmarks recalling its rich past, and they will be featured in a walking tour led by the Bronx County Historical Society on Sunday at 2 P.M.

title: DEY RATES Previous Year In Percent Yesterday Day ago
description: Prime Rate 18.00 18.00 14.00 Discount Rate* 14.00 14.00 13.00 Federal Funds 15.63 15.66 13.16 3-Mo.

title: BRIEFING
description: I T'S not the money, it's the principle of the thing: As if he were an ordinary taxpayer bereft of shelters and blind trusts, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan checked his paycheck stub the other day and discovered right there, in paycheck No. 1 of the New Beginning tax-cutting era - after all the minions of the Treasury Department had rushed to publish nationwide the new withholding tables for the Administration's tax cut - that the Treasury Secretary himself had been overlooked. The first year's 5 percent cut of the three-year, 25 percent-cut program that began Oct. 1 was not reflected in his withholding statement. The difference only amounts to about $9.44 a week less to be withheld from the check of a wage earner at Mr. Regan's salary ($69,630 a year). But the effect on the Secretary, according to one witness, was as if there had been a disastrous run on his political capital. The Treasury Secretary soon was in touch with the Treasury Department to have the oversight corrected in the name of all that's holy and supply-side in Washington.

title: About Real Estate; NEW TACK ON HOUSING AID FOR THE POOR
description: The Reagan Administration is starting to disclose its ideas on housing assistance for lower-income families amid fears that years of effort to make Federal subsidies work successfully against neighborhood blight may be unraveling.

title: GENERAL MOTORS DISCLOSES A LOSS OF $468 MILLION
description: The General Motors Corporation today reported a loss of $468 million for this year's third quarter - a first indication that the Big Three auto makers are plunging back into the red after reporting profits for the second quarter. G.M.'s loss was larger than expected.

title: Market Place; MCI's Future Vs. A.T.& T.
description: distance telephone network after American Telephone and Telegraph, wrote customers recently that a Senate bill could jeopardize its discount service.

title: VW Delays Start Of Plant Output
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. said that it was delaying for at least three months the start of production at its new assembly plant in suburban Sterling Heights.

title: HOUSE REPUBLICANS OPPOSE FURTHER CUTS FOR SCHOOL LUNCHES
description: Several Republican members of Congress broke with the Reagan Administration today and joined Democrats in saying that they would oppose further reductions in Federal funds for the national school lunch program.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1981
description: International The President stressed conciliation at the opening session of the conference of 14 developing and eight industrialized countries at the Mexican resort of Cancun. Mr. Reagan renewed a commitment to negotiations intended to narrow the gap between rich and poor nations, but he listed conditions for United States participation that suggested there was no significant change in Washington's basic approach to third-world issues. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Delegates reacted coolly to President Reagan's call for multiple forums to negotiate third-world development. Many of the 22 delegations at the conference of industrialized and developing countries seek a prompt start in global talks designed to put together a package for aid, trade and finance to benefit the poor nations. (A12:4-6.)

title: BIGOTRY'S MOLD
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People; Born Old
description: ''Timing,'' Parker Fennelly was saying yesterday, ''is very important for an actor - that's why I had my birthday fall between games of the World Series.''

title: SMITH SEES IMMIGRATION PLAN AS A MEANS TO AVERT BOATLIFTS
description: Attorney General William French Smith defended the Reagan Administration's new request for sweeping emergency immigration control powers today, calling them ''possibly the only way'' to prevent another influx like the 1980 Cuban boatlift.

title: U.S. OPEN TO LEASING OIL LAND TO KUWAIT
description: The Reagan Administration is ''favorably inclined'' to grant leasing privileges on mineral lands to the Government-owned Kuwait National Petroleum Company to help encourage foreign investment here, an Interior Department official told Congress today.

title: GELDING STAKES CLAIM TO FAME
description: On Nov. 5, 1979, Murray Garren and his trainer, Gil Puentes, watched the horses coming into the paddock for the third race at Aqueduct. They noticed that a 4-year-old gelding who had always raced with bandages on all four legs was without the wraps for the first time in his career. They took this as a sign that he was fit and they claimed him when he next ran, two weeks later, for $35,000.

title: Lemon Secure, Owner Says
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, said today that Bob Lemon could have the manager's job again next season if he wants it.

title: GREEK SOCIALISTS WELCOME CYPRIOT PRESIDENT
description: Greece's new Socialist Government today warmly welcomed President Spyros Kyprianou of Cyprus, its first foreign visitor since it was sworn in yesterday, and expressed full support for his cause.

title: BOARD APPROVES LEASES FOR SOUTH ST. SEAPORT PLAN
description: New York City's Board of Estimate gave its final approval yesterday to a planned complex of shops and malls designed to revitalize the South Street Seaport, one of the more ambitious projects taking advantage of the long-neglected waterfront.

title: Elia Joins Cub Staff
description: When Dallas Green became general manager of the Chicago Cubs last week, he denied that Lee Elia, his third-base coach during his recent tenure at Philadelphia, had already been chosen as the Cubs' new field manager. Yesterday Green appointed the manager, and, to the surprise of few, it turned out to be Elia, a 44-year-old former shortstop for the Cubs and the Chicago White Sox, who replaces Joe Amalfitano. Elia's first move after signing a three-year contract was to announce that he would retain Billy Williams from the previous coaching staff but would also be bringing in three new coaches: John Vukovich, a 34-year-old Philadelphia infielder who has spent most of his career in the minor leagues; Billy Connors, the pitching coach for the Kansas City Royals the last two years, and Gordon MacKenzie, the Royals' third-base coach this season.

title: COUNTRY MUSIC NOW A FIXTURE IN THE BIG CITY
description: COWBOY hats, western shirts and tooled-leather boots. Soft lights and hard country music. Boisterous beer drinkers dancing the Cotton Eyed Joe. Until recently, you didn't encounter this sort of thing in New York City. When the Lone Star Cafe opened at Fifth Avenue and 13th Street in February 1977, it was mostly a gathering place for transplanted Southerners. With the exception of several havens for bluegrass and other more traditional Southern music, it was the only club of its kind in the city, an island in a sea of discos.

title: DAVID J. GILBERT'S TRAIL: ACTIVIST AND A FUGITIVE
description: Like many members of the Weather Underground and other radical groups that seized public attention in the late 1960's, David Joseph Gilbert began his political activities in his college years with protests against the Vietnam War.

title: GAF Operating Loss
