description: The GAF Corporation yesterday reported a third-quarter loss from continuing operations of $5.1 million compared with continuing operations earnings of $4.2 million in the quarter last year. The company said that 1981 net income, including $19.3 million from discontinued segments, rose to $14.2 million, or 94 cents a share, from $4 million, or 23 cents a share, in the 1980 quarter, The chemical and building materials manufacturer said third-quarter sales were $177.5 million compared with $182.7 million last year.

title: Jersey Issues Second article of a series:; Education
description: While the two major-party candidates for Governor of New Jersey have barely addressed the education issue, the winner of the election on Nov. 3 will have to deal with the need to increase state school aid and with complaints by school officials that they are being inundated by unnecessary regulations and paperwork.

title: Sheet Music on Show At Historical Society
description: Examples of rare 18th-century sheet music and other memorabilia from the collection of the New-York Historical Society will be on view through Dec. 6 at the society, 170 Central Park West, at 76th Street. Among the pieces on display, many for the first time, is ''The Anacreontic Song'' by John Stafford Smith, a tavern ditty that developed into ''The Star-Spangled Banner.''

title: DOWN-HOME COOKING THAT GOES WITH THE MUSIC
description: AMONG the variety of regional cuisines recently added to the New York mix, count country-western, the down-home Texas cooking best suited to the down-home music usually dished up along with it. Like the Lone Star State itself, this cuisine lies somewhere between the Deep South and Mexico.

title: ROOKIE MATCHUP: RIGHETTI-VALENZUELA IN GAME 3
description: In the spring of 1980, Dave Righetti said, he thought he would win a job on the Yankees' pitching staff. He didn't.

title: ROCK: FOREIGNER AND BILL SQUIER
description: FOREIGNER and Billy Squier, the two ultra-popular rock acts that filled the Nassau Coliseum on Wednesday evening (the same show will be at Madison Square Garden next Friday) represent two distinct approaches to teen-oriented rock.

title: Braniff May Lease Its Headquarters
description: The Braniff International Corporation, which lost $128 million last year, is considering leasing all or part of its corporate headquarters at the Dallas-Fort Worth airport to help offset cash-flow problems, the company said.

title: Israeli Chief to Visit Egypt
description: President Yitzhak Navon of Israel will visit Egypt within the next month to pay his condolences on the death of President Anwar el-Sadat.

title: U.S. PANEL ORDERS CONTROLLER UNION STRIPPED OF ROLE
description: The Federal Labor Relations Authority today stripped the air traffic controllers' union of its status as legal representative of the controllers because of its action in calling the illegal nationwide strike that began Aug. 3. It was the first time that a union had ever lost its rights as the exclusive bargaining agent for Government employees.

title: AIR NEW ENGLAND WILL SHUT DOWN
description: Air New England, a regional airline, announced today it would shut down Oct. 31 because of the adverse affects of the air traffic controllers' strike and competition from other small airlines. It will become the third commuter carrier to shut down since the strike started on Aug. 3.

title: STRIKES SPREADING, SOLIDARITY MEETS
description: As strikes and strike threats multiplied throughout Poland today, the leadership of the Solidarity union assembled in Gdansk to come up with a response to what it contends is a campaign of harassment.

title: LANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Separate Bomb Threats Force Halt of Trading
description: Trading on the Chicago Board of Trade and the Phildelphia Stock Exchange was halted at midsession yesterday after anonymous callers said bombs had been placed in the buildings.

title: TELEGRAPH MEASURE ADVANCES IN HOUSE
description: A House panel passed a bill today to increase international and domestic competition in telegraph services, virtually assuring Congressional approval of some changes in the industry.

title: One State, Fiscal '82 First article of a series appearing periodically on the Reagan budget's impact on Pennsylvania
description: In Philadelphia, the Rev. Joseph Kakalek is closing down a job training program he started with high hopes more than a year ago, and the Philadelphia Corporation for the Aging is facing cuts in meals it serves the elderly. In Bucks County, a school district has doubled student charges for school lunches. To the west, Allegheny County, which includes Pittsburgh, is facing a loss of $25 million in Federal funds it had expected to receive to help provide services for its 1.5 million people.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1981; Companies
description: G.M. lost $468 million in the third quarter, more that expected. It was General Motors' first quarterly loss since the $567 million it lost in 1980's third quarter. The company blamed sluggish sales and rising costs. The figures raised the possibility that the world's largest auto maker might for the first time register losses in two consecutive years. (Page A1.)

title: CHAMBER: AMERICANA BY TARACK ENSEMBLE
description: THERE was a curious ad hoc flavor to the Tarack Chamber Ensemble's offering of American fare Wednesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. It was not so much that the program had a patched-together look: two works by Barber and one by Copland complemented each other well enough, and five rags by Scott Joplin from ''The Red Back Book'' made better bedfellows than one might have thought with six of Charles Ives's whimsical pieces for small instrumental combinations.

title: FOR KATHERINE BOUDIN, FURTIVE LIFE AS MOTHER
description: Katherine Boudin had been living in New York City for at least 21 months prior to her arrest, sharing an apartment with Rita Jensen, a reporter for The Stamford (Conn.) Advocate, according to an article yesterday in that newspaper.

title: DANCE: 'ENERGIES' IS REVIVED BY MAY O'DONNELL COMPANY
description: MAY O'DONNELL has long been interested in the dynamics of dance and what happens when different kinds and amounts of energy are balanced and contrasted. Her 1943 signature dance, ''Suspension,'' surprised a modern-dance world used to the literal expression of plots and emotions in dance. Miss O'Donnell's serene hand with building and diminishing tension was rare then, as was her sense of the juxtaposed planes of bodies moving and at rest. They still are, as a revival of ''Dance Energies,'' a full-company piece choreographed in 1959, proved on Wednesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, where the May O'Donnell Concert Dance Company is appearing through Sunday.

title: SUDAN DESCRIBES 25 LIBYAN AIR RAIDS
description: The Sudan today issued the first detailed account of a border conflict with Libya that has been depicted here as the forerunner of an invasion.

title: U.N. Refugee Chief Willing to Serve Again
description: Poul Hartling, a former Prime Minister of Denmark, said today that he would accept a renewal of his mandate as United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees next year if reelected by the General Assembly.

title: The Region; Health Aide Cites Outbreak of Lice
description: The city's Department of Health reported an outbreak of head lice among school-age children. Dr. Margaret T. Grossi, Acting Commissioner, said that the outbreak was not a ''health emergency,'' but that treatment was needed. (AP)

title: 'NIGHTMARE' OPENS
description: ''NIGHTMARE'' opens today at a number of theaters, which is perhaps the nicest thing that can be said for it. ''Nightmare'' is the perfunctory work of Romano Scavolini, a writer-director whose best idea here is to repeat the same gory flashback footage over and over again.

title: Crossing A Thin Line
description: Only a thin line exists between preparing to fight a nuclear war and preparing to prevent one; and when either superpower even appears to be preparing to fight such a war, the other superpower is bound to take alarm and react. This cycle may be the most dangerous threat to the efforts of either, or both, to prevent nuclear war.

title: U.S. TAX FRAUD CHARGE IS DENIED BY REV. MOON
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the leader of the Unification Church, pleaded not guilty to tax fraud charges yesterday in a crowded courtroom of the Federal courthouse in Manhattan.

title: SCHLITZ MERGER DOOMED BY JUSTICE DEPT. OPINION
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company's attempt to acquire the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company collapsed yesterday as Heileman bowed to Justice Department pressure and indicated that it would abandon the planned merger of the breweries.

title: Weekly Car Output Up
description: Production by domestic auto makers is expected to increase 8.7 percent, to 133,485 for the week ending Saturday, from 122,817 cars made last week, an industry journal said today.

title: Economic Scene; Ex-Advisers Advise Again
description: NEW HAVEN SEVEN former members of the Council of Economic Advisers, all of them present or former Yale economists, got together here Wednesday night to discuss the pleasures and pains of advising Presidents.

title: BROADWAY
description: PAUL ZINDEL has vivid recollections of a shipyard worker who lived in a bungalow near the high school where he used to teach on Staten Island: ''A lot of kids in my class would go over to his house after school, and there was always a lot of drinking and sex going on there. He was like a Minotaur devouring the youth of the community.''

title: Kicking the Economy When It's Down
description: President Reagan's acknowledgment that the nation has entered a recession raises two questions:

title: MISPLACED RESOLVE IN U.S. FOREIGN POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Panama Farm Loan
description: The Inter-American Development Bank today announced the approval of two loans for $29.5 million under a program to extend credit to farmers in Panama. It said the loans would help bring an additional 62,000 acres under cultivation, increasing farm production by about 42 percent for such major crops as rice, corn, sorghum and soybeans as well as for dairy and beef cattle.

title: BALLET: AN 'ALL STAR' GALA MARKS JOFFREY'S 25TH YEAR
description: This is ''Joffrey Ballet All-Star Week'' in New York, by Mayor Koch's official proclamation, and anyone familiar with the Joffrey Ballet knows that its no-star policy makes its every dancer a star.

title: COMPROMISE WILL BE SOUGHT FOR REVISING CLEAN AIR LAW
description: Vice President Bush and Anne M. Gorsuch, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, today agreed with key members of Congress to try to work out a compromise revision of the Clean Air Act that could be enacted this year.

title: BOLLING, TAKING UP PEN, PLANS OWN MONUMENT
description: Most monuments in Washington are made of granite and marble. Representative Richard Bolling's will be constructed of paper and ink.

title: HOUSE-SENATE REPUBLICANS REPORT TENTATIVE PLAN ON CUTS IN BUDGET
description: House and Senate Republican leaders announced today that they had reached a tentative agreement on President Reagan's proposed new round of budget cuts for the fiscal year 1982, but participants in a joint leadership conference later indicated that the agreement basically consisted of allowing each chamber to go its own way.

title: Topics; Man and Beast Cheap Therapy
description: As parents, some of us feel defensive about the growing nonhuman population in our urban homes. In one, a comfortable old dog no longer sufficed and has been joined by a purebred cat. Another now includes a cat, two parakeets, a hamster, a guinea pig and a fish. Wondering why we put up with all this, we were intrigued by a Wall Street Journal article about ''pet facilitated therapy.''

title: Diaper Search
description: President Reagan at a luncheon for out-of-town editors: Just one example on the exclusionary rule, because California had a classic case of this a few years ago. Two narcotics agents in San Bernardino, California, had enough evidence to get a warrant to search a home, a couple living there that they believed was peddling heroin.

title: Penn Central Suit Ended
description: A Federal judge today dismissed a suit filed by a group of Penn Central Corporation stockholders who sought to stop the company's proposed acquisition of Colt Industries.

title: MILITARY BUILDUP SEEN DRIVING UP SOME PRICES
description: Congress was told by two economists today that the Reagan Administration's military buildup might result in higher prices in some industries.

title: MONSTERS, RACE HORSES AND SUBURBIA
description: HALLOWEEN is a weekend away, but CBS begins trick-or-treating tonight at 8 with a documentary called, with strained cuteness, ''Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Monsters ... but Were Afraid!'' Charles Osgood, the CBS News correspondent, serves as host, operating out of a horror-movie film set, complete with squeaking doors, wisps of fog and flashes of lightning. He provides, with the help of photographs and film clips, a review of fictional and possibly real-life monsters.

title: NETTLES DOUBTFUL FOR 3D GAME, BUT JACKSON MAY PLAY
description: Graig Nettles, who has contributed so much to the Yankees' postseason success this year with his hitting and fielding, will probably miss the third World Series game here tomorrow night because of a seriously jammed thumb that he injured in last night's game in New York.

title: 2 MORE SENATORS DECLARE AWACS: 1 IS FOR, 1 AGAINST
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, said today that he was oppposed to the sale of Awacs radar planes to Saudi Arabia and Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, announced he would support the sale.

title: PUBLISHING: 'NICKLEBY' BOOK IS S.R.O.
description: WITH seats for the Broadway production of ''The Life & Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' going for $100 each, Penguin Books, which has published ''Nickleby'' and 16 other books by Charles Dickens, made up a sign for bookstores proclaiming, ''Save $95, buy the Penguin.''

title: ILL-CHOSEN DELEGATE TO SADAT'S FUNERAL
description: To the Editor:

title: STRAUSS FOR PRESIDENT? THERE HAS BEEN TALK
description: Robert S. Strauss settled into a corner booth at the Palm restaurant recently for what he called a light lunch on the occasion of his 63d birthday. First came the chopped steak, rare and thick, then a platter of two kinds of fried potatoes ''just to look at,'' and finally five young waiters bearing a single strawberry holding a candle.

title: Lasorda the Linguist
description: A sales clerk at the pharmacy in the New York Sheraton Hotel seemed vexed the other day when an Italian couple wanted to purchase something.

title: IRAN'S PARLIAMENT REJECTS PREMIER
description: The Iranian Parliament decided unexpectedly today to reject the nomination of a 36-year-old Islamic fundamentalist layman as Prime Minister.

title: SLOWING OF GROWTH IN PARTS OF SUN BELT IS FORESEEN
description: Growth in parts of the now booming Sun Belt will slow in the next decade and some previously stagnant areas in the North will experience new expansion, according to a major new study made public today by the Harvard-Massachusetts Institute of Technology Joint Center for Urban Studies.

title: ART: 50 ENIGMATIC YEARS OF DADA AMD SURREALISM
description: ''OBJECTS BY ARTISTS, 1915-65,'' an exhibition presented by Helen Serger and Timothy Baum at La Boetie Gallery, 9 East 82d Street, is, in effect, a survey of the Dada and Surrealist object. There are pioneer Dada works by people like the German artist Johannes Baader and the Belgian artist Paul Joostens. There are pieces by major international names - Marcel Duchamp, Man Ray, Joseph Cornell, Kurt Schwitters, Joseph Beuys. There are also pieces by gifted people like Andre Breton, Roland Penrose, Jean Cocteau and Laurence Vail, who were around at the time and saw no reason why they, too, should not make enigmatic and disquieting objects.

title: WHEN COMPUTERS DON'T WORK
description: Buddy Smith, an insurance agent in Warrenville, Ill., bought a computer in 1978 to automate his record-keeping and mailings. ''By 1980,'' he said, ''it ended up in my basement, with a year and a half of absolute hell in between.''

title: UNDERCUTTING YOUNG LIVES IN THE SOUTH
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: The dispute in Western Europe over President Reagan's comments about the possibility of a battlefield nuclear exchange reflects no basic differences over nuclear strategy but rather the acute state of political nervousness in the Atlantic alliance. The President's remarks did not signal any shift in either American policy or the doctrine of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Seahawks Empty Patera's Bag of Tricks
description: Coach Jack Patera has tried everything to wring a victory out of the Seattle Seahawks. He has concocted trick plays. He has hired a retired Army Ranger from Hawaii to teach players Oriental techniques of mind control. He looks over past performances to see where he went wrong in his player picks. He makes impassioned locker-room speeches.

title: The City; Dearie Announces Support for Goldin
description: Assemblyman John C. Dearie, who questioned Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin's integrity and competence during their bitter Democratic primary campaign, endorsed him for re-election.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: DURING the last several years, New York has seen the rise of the boutique restaurant, which offers a small, esoteric and stylized representation of a cuisine rather than a full range. For the most part, such restaurants have featured the French nouvelle cuisine, but a few also specialize in north Italian dishes. Pirandello, on Mercer Street and Washington Place, just east of Washington Square, is a perfect example of the Italian boutique restaurant. A dramatic modern cafe-dining room with its shadowy theatrical lighting, decorative pictures and hanging plants, Pirandello has become popular with Villagers as well as with Off Broadway theatergoers. It certainly has delivered on its earlier promise; when first reviewed nearly four years ago, it was given a one star rating with two stars predicted for the future.

title: Bridge: Poland and Britain Battle; U.S. Makes a Strong Move
description: Poland and Britain were locked in a close battle for the top position in the standings of the world team championship qualifying stage here this afternoon.

title: Beethoven at St. Bart's
description: A performance of Beethoven's Missa Solemnis with full orchestra Sunday at 4 P.M. will begin a series of Sunday afternoon concerts at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and 51st Street.

title: Darcy Leads Golf
description: David Graham, the United States Open champion, shot a four-over-par 77 in today's first round of the West Lakes Classic at Royal Adelaide. This left him nine strokes behind the leader, Eamonn Darcy, who posted six birdies while carding a 68.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: THERE are art collectors and there are art collectors. And then there are George Costakis and Baron Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza, who don't fool around. Mr. Costakis, a Greek citizen born in Moscow, has assembled what's regarded as the world's greatest collection of Russian avant-garde art, a hefty slice of which is now on view at the Guggenheim Museum. And the Baron, of the German steel family, inherited from his father - and built up substantially himself - a collection of Old Masters said to be the greatest private holding in the world next to that of the Queen of England. A large and beautiful selection of that is currently displayed at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: Long-Awaited Glory
description: Even if he fails to win a prize Sunday in the New York City Marathon - a distinct likelihood - Ingemar Johansson has something to look forward to. On Nov. 14, Johansson, the former heavyweight champion will take possession of a silver medal he won in the 1952 Olympics.
To the Editor:

title: POLICE RAID APARTMENTS TO GATHER EVIDENCE ON KILLINGS IN ROCKLAND
description: Federal agents and the police raided six apartments in New York City and Westchester County yesterday as new links emerged between radical activists, black terrorists and the gang that killed two police officers and a Brink's guard Tuesday in a $1.6 million armored-car holdup in Rockland County.

title: RODGERS WILL RUN
description: Bill Rodgers will run in Sunday's New York City Marathon, even though he admitted yesterday, ''It's pretty much a dead certainty that I can't win it.''

title: Friday; ANTIQUES AT THE MEADOWLANDS
description: A wide array of objects - from $3 postcards and $8 jewelry to $12,000 Meiji porcelain miniatures - will be offered at the first International Antiques Fair opening today in the Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. Among the items will be a hieroglyphic amulet once worn by an Egyptian priest and wrought by Cartier into a frame of gold, black onyx and diamonds, Shaker furniture, paperweights, 5,000-year-old pottery from Cambodia, an 1820 ivory chess set from India, Tiffany glass, Edison phonographs, a rocking horse and toys. Admission is $4, through Ticketron or at the box office. Travel and other information: (201) 935-8500. 53D STREET CHINESE SCREEN

title: SAMUEL BROWN: A PAST DEFINED BY POLICE FILES
description: A man who has been tentatively identified as 41-year-old Samuel Brown has an arrest record in New York City dating back to 1958. Charges against him, and a few convictions, include burglary, robbery and illegal possession of a 9-millimeter pistol. But apart from a police officer's recollection of Mr. Brown as ''very cool,'' little is known about him personally.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: A security guard was shot and critically wounded during a robbery attempt in the Prospect Park section of Brooklyn, the police said. Three men were taken into custody.

title: BEST SPOTS TO CHEER THE MARATHONERS ON
description: Network television coverage, the possibility of a world record and the expansion of spectator viewing areas are all sure to enhance Sunday's 12th running of the New York City Marathon, which will be held rain or shine.

title: Index; International
description: India trying to turn food-produc- tion gains to benefit the poor A2 Libyans launched 25 air raids, the Sudan says A3 Iranian Parliament rejects nomi- nation of Prime Minister A4 Around the World A5 Senate links arms aid to Chile to improved human rights A9 Bush defends Administration against attack by Mondale A13 Greece's new leaders welcome President of Cyprus A14 Spanish police open major drive against Basque guerrillas A15 Government/Politics Kean and Florio discuss issue of education B2 Koch's faces all six opponents in first of seven debates B3 Americans flying for Libya said to be not in U.S. interest B6 Attorney General defends immi- gration control proposals B6 Pennsylvania facing problems with budget cuts B10 House-Senate Republicans report budget agreement B10 House Republicans oppose fur- ther cuts in school lunch funds B11 Leaders to seek compromise revi- sion of Clean Air Act B11 Washington Talk Briefing A18 Strauss enjoying talk of a possible run for President A18 House Rules chairman plans own monument, in pen and ink A18 Comedian aims his sallies at the powerful A18 Style The Evening Hours B8 A rally of ''literary lions'' in aid of public library B8 When a ball game is a family af- fair B8 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Best spots for cheering on the Marathon C21 Walking tour of Bronx's Fordham area C32 Theater: Broadway C2

title: The City; City Giving Test For Park Workers
description: For the first time in more than 10 years, the city will give a Civil Service examination for the job of city park service worker. The Parks Department, which has done virtually no hiring at this level since before the city's fiscal crisis, plans to hire 1,000 people for cleaning and general park maintenance, gardening, building repairs and maintenance of equipment.

title: The Evening Hours
description: W HAT do you do if you get three invitations for the same night? Accept them all, of course, then send flowers to the hostesses you refuse at the last minute, with a little note attached saying it was all the fault of your date who had already accepted another invitation but what about lunch next week? That was the way some New Yorkers handled it this week as the social season went into overdrive.

title: Armco Steel Unit
description: Armco Inc. said that it had reached a definitive agreement to sell the assets of its Marion, Ohio, steelworks to Steel Bar Products Inc., a newly formed corporation in Columbus.

title: Notes on People; Decisions, Decisions
description: If Harry Rigby can figure out a way to start in the middle, his problem will be solved. Mr. Rigby, a Broadway producer, is putting together the Broadway segment of the benefit ''Broadway Salutes the New York City Opera'' at the New York State Theater next Monday night, and he has 19 eager performers in the wings - each perfectly willing to open or close the show.

title: Thousands in France Walk Off Jobs
description: Thousands of workers were on strike across France today in a variety of labor disputes, while thousands more planned walkouts.

title: MONDALE'S ATTACK SCORNED BY BUSH
description: Vice President Bush, condemning the economic and diplomatic conditions the Carter Administration left behind when it left office, defended the Reagan Administration today against criticism from former Vice President Walter F. Mondale.

title: COMIC JABS (AND DELIGHTS) THE MIGHTY
description: ''Do you get the idea that Richard Nixon is Secretary of State and they don't have the heart to tell us?'' The audience roars, and Mark Russell, the capital's chief admitted comic, is succeeding for another evening at what he describes as his main charitable work, cheering up whoever is out of power in Washington.

title: Ford Weighs Plant Closing
description: The Ford Motor Company has told workers at its aluminum-casting plant in Sheffield, Ala., that they must agree to pay and fringe-benefit cuts that total 50 percent or the plant will be closed.

title: TIMES NET AND REVENUE SET 3D-QUARTER RECORDS
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the third quarter rose 28 percent, to $10.2 million, or 82 cents a share. In the similar period a year earlier, the diversified communications concern had profits of $8 million, or 66 cents a share.

title: HIAS'S CHIEF CONCERN IN AIDING FALASHAS
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'RIGHT TO LIFE' UNACKNOWLEDGED BY NATURE
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHLUMBERGER AND COKE GAIN
description: Schlumberger Ltd. reported yesterday that big gains by its oilfield service operations caused earnings in the third quarter to increase by 35.7 percent, while sales grew by 14.2 percent.

title: FLIPPANT IN BINGHAMTON, CAREY OFFERS APOLOGIES
description: Governor Carey came here today to apologize, and he did so repeatedly as the day went on. In the process, he offered a candid analysis of his own political troubles, saying that his problems had been caused by his own ''flip statements.''

title: The Region; 3 Guilty of Aiding Mobsters at Casino
description: NEWARK (AP) - Three former partners in a Las Vegas, Nev., casino were found guilty yesterday of helping a New Jersey organized-crime ring secretly infiltrate the business.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't mind being unpopular because I am the victim sometimes of my own flip statements and incautious Irish humor.

title: 3 Critics Receive Promotions In General Services Shakeup
description: The chief of the General Services Administration carried out a campaign pledge by President Reagan today and gave top-level jobs to three outspoken critics of the agency.

title: Ecevit Threatened With a Prison Term
description: Turkey has started proceedings against Bulent Ecevit, the former Prime Minister, who is accused of violating the law by giving a speech in which he criticized the Government.

title: Challenge to Protein Theory Seen in Hunger Strike Deaths
description: The death of hunger strikers in the Irish Republican Army ran counter to usual theories on the process of starvation, a published report says.

title: ARTHUR M. BUECHE, 60, SERVED G.E. AS TOP TECHNICAL OFFICER
description: Dr. Arthur M. Bueche, senior vice president for corporate technology at the General Electric Company, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn., after a brief illness. He was 60 years old and lived in Bridgeport.

title: Heafner and Lott Teams Share Disney Golf Lead
description: Two pro golf tour sophomores, Vance Heafner and Mike Holland, shot a 12-under-par 60 today to tie with Lyn Lott and Barry Harwell for the first-round lead in the $400,000 Disney World national team championship.

title: Vintage Rock Tonight
description: The early days of rock-and-roll will be recreated tonight at 8 at the Richard Nader Rock-and-Roll Reunion, Volume I, at Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street.

title: 'Kinsmen' on Bowery
description: ''The Two Noble Kinsmen,'' a romantic comedy that many believe was written by William Shakespeare and John Fletcher, will be playing in repertory at the Cocteau Repertory Theater, 330 Bowery, tonight at 8, tomorrow night at 7:30 and Sunday at 3 P.M. The play, directed by Eve Adamson, stars J.D. Eich and David Fuller. Tickets are $7. For information and reservations, call 677-0060 between 1 and 5 P.M.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 23, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Political and Security Commitee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Military Analysis
description: An invasion of the Sudan by Libya would be a major operation demanding military resources far beyond those Libya now has. Military specialists in Washington, London and Tel Aviv believe that the Sudan would be in danger only if Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, invoked the alliance agreement signed Aug. 20 by Libya, Ethiopia and Southern Yemen.

title: VIDEO GAINING AS AN ART OF GARDE
description: NEXT April, the Whitney Museum will be the scene of a major retrospective by the video artist Nam June Paik. It was Mr. Paik who pioneered television as a vehicle for art in the late 1960's, after a period of making electronic music with Karlheinz Stockhausen and staging ''action concerts'' at which pianos were sometimes demolished, like the guitars in Jimi Hendrix's performances.

title: LABOR DEPT. IN 2D GRUMMAN INQUIRY
description: The Labor Department, which is seeking to oust the trustees of the Grumman Corporation's pension plan, is also conducting a separate investigation of possible Federal pension law violations by the company's employee investment plan, officials in Washington said yesterday.

title: MICHIGAN BRACES AGAIN AS BAD GOES TO WORSE
description: Unemployment in Michigan, after a short summer dip, is holding at more than 11 percent, tax revenues are dropping and, instead of an expected autumn turn for the better, the state is getting deeper and deeper into recession.

title: NATIONAL FOREST WEIGHING OIL AND GAS LEASES
description: The managers of the Los Padres National Forest are well along with studies that could result in the issuance of the first oil and gas exploration leases for national wilderness areas.

title: COMPUTER RANKING
description: College Top 20 Computer ranking based on games through Oct. 17 OPPONENTS' PERFORMANCES ast Avg. Marginvg. Margin RankTeamWeekRecord of Victory Rating *Record of Victory 1 Pittsburgh15-0 -022.01.00019-7-00.4 2 Penn State35-0-0 28.8.90313-10-11.2 3 North Carolina4*6-0-035.0 O.90216-14-19.2 4 Southern Methodist6 6-0-0 25.2.89016-14-11.5 5 Clemson8 6-0-021.0.85315-16-00.9 6 Arizona State95-1-020.3 O.83419-10-25.3 7 Georgia7 5-1-022.3.82817-15-04.2 8 Nebraska104-2-021.7.82618-11-02.3 9 Iowa11 HO5-1-014.2.80916-12-20.2 10 Missouri25-1-0 18.7.79719-11-10.7 11 Washington State135-0-1 12.2.73816-14-03.6 12 Texas4* 4-1-07.4.72613-9-11.2 13 Iowa State4-1-1 4.0.71223-6-11.2 14 Arkansas 5-1-014.7.70311-18-17.8 15 Mississippi State185-1-0 10.2.70214-17-11.3 16 Alabama205 -1-113.4.69916-21-06.8 17 So. California17+ 5-1-0 16.7.68912-16-16.6 18 Michigan144-2-08.8.66417-12-01.1 19 Florida145-2-0 13.1.65119-16-11.6 20 Miami, Fla.123-2-05.4 .64416-9-04.0 20 Southern Mississippi195-0-117.3.64413-20 -02.5 *Tied last week. +Tied with Florida State last week.

title: WHAT IS 'VOLUNTARY'?
description: The Justice Department has decided that it will not oppose in the Supreme Court a Washington state law that prevents local school districts from busing for purposes of desegregation. ''If the law is upheld,'' The New York Times reported, ''it would end an integration program that was voluntarily adopted by local school boards in Seattle and two other cities.'' At issue are the rights of communities to adopt integration plans independent of court orders, but even more at issue is the question of whether a local board can ''voluntarily'' adopt a plan that ''involuntarily'' requires children to attend schools outside their neighborhood in order to further racial integration.

title: DOLPHINS VS. COWBOYS A CLASSIC MATCHUP
description: The Miami Dolphins play the Cowboys at Dallas Sunday in a significant game between teams that have always done well in such interconference matches. The Dolphins, since 1970, have won 85 percent of their games against National Conference teams and that includes two Super Bowl victories.

title: 300 Florida Prisoners Riot in Racial Dispute
description: About 300 prisoners rioted for more than six hours at the Sumter Correctional Institution today in what the superintendent called a ''racial disturbance.''

title: Why Pay Now to Fly Later?
description: The Federal Aviation Administration now concedes that the traffic controllers' strike is beginning to pinch - as harassed travelers have known for weeks. Limiting the flights of private planes may give commercial passengers some relief. But bolder steps are needed to meet traffic demands without compromising safety.

title: Point-Shaving Trial Opens
description: The trial of five men accused of scheming to shave points in Boston College basketball games in 1978-79 opened yesterday, with the defense arguing for suppression of a statement that Rick Kuhn, one of the defendants, gave the Federal Bureau of Investigation in September 1980.

title: SEAR'S NET FALLS 4.7% IN QUARTER
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, said yesterday that its net income dropped 4.7 percent in the third quarter, to $125.2 million, or 40 cents a share, from $131.4 million, or 42 cents, in the period a year earlier.

title: Wall Collapses, Killing Boy
description: Classes were canceled here today to allow the authorities to investigate the collapse of a brick wall that crushed a 10-year-old boy to death and injured three of his classmates. Justin Thompson and some classmates were sheltered behind the eight-foot windbreak wall waiting to go inside the gymnasium this morning when the incident occurred, the officials said. Witnesses said boys standing nearby helped free the injured children but were unable to help Justin.

title: New Business Computer Line
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said that it would sell a new line of desk computers for small business, becoming the latest of several companies to enter a market estimated to contain 2.2 million individual businesses.

title: BRITISH DEBATE EXCHANGE CURB
description: Two years after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher dropped foreign-exchange controls, a flood of money out of the country has provoked a spate of calls for renewed strictures.

title: The Region; F.A.A. to Appeal Jobless Awards
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Connecticut's decision to grant unemployment compensation to discharged air traffic controllers is being appealed, officials of the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: NEW ALUMNUS, CLASS OF '45
description: It was, Mayor Koch noted, a one-time event. The time, however, was 36 years late. Yesterday, in a brief ceremony in his office, the Mayor received a Bachelor of Arts degree from City College, something he missed receiving as a student because of World War II.

title: 2 Reach Everest Summit
description: A member of an American medical expedition and his Sherpa guide reached the top of Mount Everest yesterday and carried out the first medical tests ever at the summit, the Ministry of Tourism said today. Christopher Kopcjynski, a 33-year-old contractor from Spokane, Wash., and his Nepalese guide, Sundere, 20, conducted heart and lung tests and took weather readings.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: VICKI FREDERICK was born in Atlanta, Georgia, trained as a dancer in New York, New York, and covered with mud in Youngstown, Ohio. It wasn't precisely what she'd had in mind when she'd dreamed of movie stardom, but having accepted a role as a wrestler, she wallowed right in.

title: Chrysler Furlough
description: The Chrysler Corporation said that it would furlough 3,500 hourly workers and close its assembly plant in Belvidere, Ill., for three weeks to refit the facility to produce new front-wheel-drive pickups. During the conversion, which begins Monday, equipment for building Dodge Rampage trucks will be added to a production line that already produces subcompact passenger cars, the company said.

title: Article 062639 -- No Title
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had ended discussions with a group of private investors who offered to pay $371.5 million for the company's 7.19 million outstanding shares.

title: MARILYN BUCK: A FUGITIVE AND LONG A RADICAL
description: Marilyn Jean Buck has been described as the only white member of the Black Liberation Army and was convicted of gunrunning for the organization eight years ago.

title: NEW CENTRIST ALLIANCE IN BRITIAN WINS BY-ELECTION
description: The new centrist alliance in British politics won a potentially historic victory yesterday over the two major parties in its first major electoral test.

title: NEW YORK BUS DRIVERS TO GET RADIOS TO FIGHT CRIME
description: Crime and mass-transit problems have led to a rise in lower-income taxi riders, a city study says. Page B3. By MICHAEL ORESKES

title: G.& W. to Buy Burlington Unit
description: Gulf and Western Industries has signed a letter of intent to buy Burlington Industries' hosiery and sock divisions for an undisclosed price, the companies said.

title: Lions' Hall Fined
description: Alvin Hall, cornerback for the Detroit Lions, has been fined $750 by the National Football League for what was deemed an unnecessarily rough hit on Ahmad Rashad, the Viking wide receiver, in a game at Bloomington, Minn., on Sept. 20. The fine was in keeping with the league's policy of cracking down on flagrant hits even if the play did not result in a penalty at the time.

title: Relaxing Retires
description: Relaxing, the 5-year-old mare who frequently defeated males and finished third in the Jockey Club Gold Cup Oct. 10, was retired yesterday for breeding purposes. She will be sent to Claiborne Farm in Lexington, Ky., and will be bred to Nijinsky next spring. Relaxing earned $590,030 in her career and won the Ruffian, Delaware, Campbell, Assault and Firenze handicaps this season.

title: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES MORE STABLE
description: After moving higher earlier this week, short-term and long-term rates stabilized yesterday, though dealers and investors agree that the outlook for rates remains uncertain.

title: Museum Mile Tour
description: Museum Mile, the section of Fifth Avenue from 82d to 104th Street that contains a wealth of museums, will be explored in a walking tour Sunday afternoon at 2.

title: STATE PLANNING WAYS TO HELP ITS AILING SAVINGS INSTITUTIONS
description: A four-point package of legislative proposals to help ailing savings institutions in New York, including tax relief, was announced yesterday by the State Superintendent of Banks, Muriel Siebert.

title: Ethel Rusk Dermady, 80, Dies; Official for Girls' Association
description: Ethel Rusk Dermady, a retired official of the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts, died Monday in her home in Marlboro, N.Y. She was 80 years old.

title: energywatch
description: OCT. 16, 1981 Crude oil stocks fell to 370.4 million barrels, a drawdown of 6 million, in an inventory adjustment.

title: STATE DEPT. AIDE IS CRITICAL OF U.S. PILOTS IN LIBYA
description: The State Department said today that it was not in the national interest for American pilots and mechanics to work for the Libyan Air Force.

title: KARPOV AND KORCHNOI ADJOURN 8TH GAME OF MATCH
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world chess champion, and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, the challenger, adjourned the eighth game of their title match tonight, with Karpov holding a slight positional superiority.

title: REAGAN SUPPORTS TALKS ON POVERTY IN CANCUN SPEECH
description: President Reagan today renewed a United States commitment to negotiations intended to narrow the gap between rich and poor nations.

title: Teamster Pension Fund Sues U.S. to Keep Plane
description: A pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has filed a suit against the United States Labor Department seeking to retain a corporate jet that the Government has ordered it to sell.

title: SENATE APPROVES '82 FOREIGN ASSISTANCE BILL, 40-33
description: The Senate tonight passed the 1982 Foreign Assistance Bill by a 40-33 vote. The final roll call on the $5.7 billion package came after a 13-hour day of debate during which the Senate voted to link the resumption of military aid to Chile to a Presidential report demonstrating that nation's progress on human rights.

title: STAGE: POICE STORY AT LONG WHARF
description: In graphic detail and with compulsive singlemindedness, John Hopkins's ''This Story of Yours'' charts the emotional collapse of a disintegrating personality. Detective Sergeant John Johnson, a 20-year veteran of the police force, has devoted his life to tracking murderers and rapists with an increasing sense of morbid fascination as well as revulsion for the horrible crimes he is investigating.

title: Advertising; Alexander's Takes Aim At Image
description: THE agency: Lois Pitts Gershon. The assignment: Make all of those sophisticated, chic, clandestine Alexander's shoppers not only come out of their closets, but also brag about it.

title: A World to Feed; 12th article in a series appearing periodically
description: With sharply increased food production having led to no significant improvement in the diet of the poorest half of India's population, agricultural planners are now turning toward a new rural development strategy based upon nutritional criteria. Basically, the lesson learned over the last two decades is that even though agricultural production has vastly increased, the proportion consumed by the poor has declined. Part of the explanation lies in steady population growth, but mostly the cause is market forces that channel grain into such things as tea biscuits that are eaten by the urban elite, depriving the landless laborer.

title: Pope Getting Back to Work
description: Pope John Paul II, returning to a full work schedule five months after an attempt on his life, presided today over a meeting of the Vatican commission that is completing 18 years' work on a new Roman Catholic code of canon law. The commission sessions, which began Tuesday, are being attended by 66 cardinals and bishops.

title: Stocks Edge Down On Profits Reports
description: Takeover situations and earnings reports dominated trading interest in the stock market yesterday as prices over all declined slightly. While individual issues responded to corporate developments, analysts said that high returns available in alternate investments continued to restrain enthusiasm for equities.

title: WASHINGTON POST APOLOGIZES TO CARTERS FOR PRINTING BUGGING RUMOR
description: The Washington Post, in tomorrow's issue, apologizes to former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, for a gossip column item reporting a rumor that Blair House was bugged while Ronald and Nancy Reagan stayed there on their preinaugural visits to the capital.

title: BARITONE AT CITY OPERA IS A MAN OF MANY PARTS
description: Chances are, no matter what weekend you go to the New York City Opera, you will encounter James Billings. Mr. Billings's bright presence illuminates any number of smaller roles there; this Sunday afternoon at 1, he can be found fulfilling the brief but amusing role of the Badger in the company's charming production of Janacek's ''The Cunning Little Vixen.''

title: HOUSE VOTES 4-YEAR FARM BILL
description: The House of Representatives tonight approved a huge farm bill that was denounced by its critics as a ''budgetbusting, deficit-ridden'' measure.

title: LOS ANGELES UNFAZED AS IT WELCOMES SERIES
description: It's not that Los Angeles isn't happy to welcome the Yankees to town for another World Series; it's just that it's somehow like being the understudy who's been bragging about how terrific he would be if only he had a chance to get on stage. Now he's got it and he's got to show what he can do.

title: CANCUN IS COOL TO REAGAN CALL FOR MULTIPLE TALKS
description: Developing nations and their industrial supporters today gave a tepid reception to President Reagan's plan for multiple forums to bargain over the problem of third world poverty.

title: No Headline
description: AUSTRALIAN OFFERING SINAI UNIT

title: Settlers in Sinai Block Dismantling of Homes
description: Israeli settlers in the Yamit area of Sinai today blocked trailer trucks sent by the Government to dismantle prefabricated homes on the Prigan cooperative farm.

title: U.S. Threat on A-Bomb Derided in India
description: A high ranking official in the Indian Foreign Ministry today scorned yesterday's decision by the United States Senate to cut off aid to Pakistan or India if either country detonated a nuclear device.

title: TAXI RIDERSHIP ON RISE AMONG THE LESS AFFLUENT
description: New York City's mass-transit and crime problems have led a growing number of ''lower-income riders'' to abandon subway trains and buses and use taxicabs, according to a mayoral committee created to study the taxi industry.

title: Gene-Splicing Success With Interferon Cited
description: A scientist with Genentech Inc., the biotechnology concern, yesterday reported success in using gene-splicing technology to make bacteria, yeast and animal cells each produce a scarce type of human interferon, the natural antivirus substance.

title: GULF UP
description: Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income fell by 7.3 percent. The Gulf Oil Corporation, No.6, reported that its earnings climbed by 29.5 percent.

title: WEINBERGER, IN LONDON, CAUTIONS AGAINST APPEASEMENT OF MOSCOW
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger questioned today whether the West had the will to meet a military challenge from the Soviet Union.

title: LOCTITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REGAL-BELOIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DYNAMICS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 5
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a stock divd

title: Sports of The Times; Scouts and Uncut Diamonds
description: WHEN each walked to the mound for the third game of the World Series last night, it was as if those two dazzling rookie lefthanders, 20-year-old Fernando Valenzuela of the Dodgers and 22-yearold Dave Righetti of the Yankees, had been destined to wear those uniforms. But their clubs' scouts, baseball's appraisers of uncut diamonds, had put them in those uniforms. The scouts always do. General managers make trades and dugout managers develop players, but the scouts discover or ignore the talent. And last night, before Fernando Valenzuela struggled to a 5-4 victory after two Yankee triumphs, each left-hander might have been in the other uniform if not for the scouts.

title: MAN CONVICTED OF A CONSPIRACY TO KILL WITNESS
description: Russell A. Bufalino, portrayed by the prosecutor as a leader of organized crime, was convicted in Federal District Court in Manhattan last night of conspiring to kill a witness.

title: TRUS JOIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BARGAIN TIME AT THE LIGHTHOUSE
description: The maintenance men at the Lighthouse no longer look surprised when they arrive at 6 A.M. and find several women already lined up outside 111 East 59th Street. It's that time of the year again, when the New York Association for the Blind holds its 10th annual ''posh'' sale, and experienced bargain hunters hope to get first crack at steals such as a sample Bill Blass red chiffon dinner dress (size 6) tagged at $95, a three-piece Chanel wool and chiffon outfit (size 14) at $180 or Lauren Bacall's Sonia Rykiel sweater for $22.

title: Going Out Guide
description: OFF THE WALL

title: RUDDICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Finn Is Elected Leader Of the Salvation Army
description: Jarl Wahlstrom, a 63-year-old native of Finland, was today elected to be international leader of the Salvation Army. Mr. Wahlstrom was chosen by the Salvationists' 44-member High Council, which has been meeting here for the last week. In the top position, which is called general, he will succeed Arnold Brown, a Canadian, who faces mandatory retirement on his 68th birthday in December.

title: AIDE SAYS TAX ROLE HAS BEEN SHIFTED TO STATES
description: A chief architect of the Administration's tax policy says that one of President Reagan's major federalism goals, the return of tax sources to states and localities, has ''substantially been accomplished'' through recent cuts in Federal taxes.

title: TENNECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Letter: On Illegal Immigrants; The Threat of Alien Entitlements
description: To the Editor:

title: BARBARA RHODES, 58, FORMER DRAMA CRITIC AND LITERARY AGENT
description: Barbara Lifflander Rhodes, a literary agent, died Thursday at Woman's Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 58 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Endangering the internal life of the country places the Government in the position of taking sharp and unpopular decisions. Such decisions include supressing street provocations and enforcing respect for the rule of law.'' -Jerzy Urban, a spokesman for the Polish Government. (1:6.)

title: MID-CONTINENT TELEPHONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN BUSINESS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALBANY LEADERS GAIN AN ACCORD ON PROPERTY TAX
description: The leaders of the Legislature have reached agreement on a proposal that they hope will end a six-year stalemate on the question of how New York should assess property.

title: FOREMOST-MCKESSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INDIANA FINANCIAL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest qr net loss includes extraordinary credits of $466,906 which reflects restructured debt and the qr also includes interest expense of $162,858 not payable until maturity of the loan or will be eliminated if certain requirements of debt restructuring are met

title: CARTER MAY DROP PLANS TO SUE PAPER FOR LIBEL
description: Former President Jimmy Carter is expected to announce tomorrow that he is dropping plans to sue The Washington Post for libel, in light of the newspaper's retraction today of a gossip column rumor that Blair House was bugged in his Administration, according to sources close to Mr. Carter.

Apple Jr. on the first vic- tory of Britain's alliance party 1 William Serrin on consequences of controllers' strike 7 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: Peat Moss Takes Kelso Again
description: Peat Moss, the long-winded 6-year-old gelding who was second to John Henry in the Jockey Club Gold Cup two weeks ago, won the 2-mile Kelso Handicap for the second year in a row at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: STEINBRENNER CITES 'MISTAKES'
description: Immediately after tonight's game, the Yankees' first loss in this World Series, George Steinbrenner, aided by two plainclothes security men, pushed his way through the crowd and entered the Yankee clubhouse. When the required five-minute waiting period was up and reporters were told they couldn't enter the clubhouse, another recent Steinbrenner episode was recalled - the night he talked to his club after the second loss to Milwaukee in the American League East playoff.

title: JOFFREY BALLET: KYLIAN
description: Jiri Kylian's ''Transfigured Night'' is a ballet of immense power and intensity, and its first performance by the Joffrey Ballet Thursday night at the City Center promises to put it on the must-see list in the current dance season.

title: SCHWAB SAFE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Analysis
description: The two-party dominance of British politics, which has endured since World War II, seems in serious jeopardy. If Labor and the Conservatives are to maintain their monopoly on power, both will have to regroup rapidly. To a political community already dazed by the most rambunctious round of party conferences in two decades, the startling result of a by-election yesterday in the obscure dormitory town of Croydon, south of London, administered a further shock. The election was won by William Pitt, a perennial loser, as the parliamentary candidate of the Liberal-Social Democratic alliance, which came into existence only in the last few months, in a constituency where third parties have never mounted any real threat.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
'Merrily We Roll' Gets A New Choreographer
description: Ron Field has been replaced by Larry Fuller as the choreographer of the new musical ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' currently in previews at the Alvin Theater. Mr. Field and the producers of the show said he left the production because of ''artistic differences.''

title: Sports People; Torre's Homecoming
description: ''It's like coming back home,'' Joe Torre said as he appeared at a news conference in Atlanta yesterday for the formal announcement that he was the new manager of the Braves. Torre, who played three seasons for the Braves in Atlanta after their move from Milwaukee, said that his four and a half years as manager of the Mets had given him ''more confidence,'' and he sounded an optimistic note for his new club's future.

title: BASS GROUP BUYS MARATHON OIL STAKE
description: Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. and Bass Equity Enterprises disclosed today that they had purchased a 4.5 percent interest, or 2.64 million shares, of the common stock of the Marathon Oil Company, the nation's 17th-largest oil concern, for $148.2 million.

title: Goodrich to Sell Plant to Polysar
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said that it had agreed to sell a synthetic rubber plant in Texas to Polysar Inc. of Akron for an undisclosed price. Goodrich said 1980 sales of products from the Orange, Tex., plant, which makes EPDM and cispolybutadiene, were about $90 million.

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $1,797,000 gain from the estimated tax benefits related to the Economic Recovery Act of 1981

title: POLICE FIND A HISTORY OF ARRESTS
description: In 1969, when Katherine Boudin, Judith A. Clark, David Joseph Gilbert and countless other college students across the country were clashing with the police in protests against the Vietnam War, Nathaniel Burns and a score of fellow Black Panther party members were charged with plotting to kill police officers and dynamite department stores.

title: AIDES QUIT AT PABST
description: The Pabst Brewing Company, the nation's third-largest brewer, announced yesterday the resignation of three officers as part of the corporate restructuring program begun by William F. Smith Jr., Pabst's new president and chief executive officer.

title: BULLETPROOFED 'GUERNICA' GOES ON DISPLAY IN SPAIN
description: Installed in a 17th-century palace behind sheets of bulletproof glass hinged with metal, Picasso's masterpiece ''Guernica'' was unveiled today to art critics and the press in its new, and presumably final, Spanish home.

title: IMMIGRATION REFORM
description: The Administration this week submitted to Congress a comprehensive package of legislation to reform our nation's immigration laws. Reform of some kind, all would agree, is long overdue. Earlier policies and practices were unrealistic, and have failed.

title: HAMILTON INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $96,000 or 4 cents a shr for the qr and $2,237,088 or $1.02 a shr for the 6 mos... C-Including extraordinary credits of $2,402,217 or $1.10 a shr for the qr and $2,877,952 or $1.32 a shr for the 6 mos

title: Abdul Qayyum Khan, Served As Pakistani Interior Minister
description: Abdul Qayyum Khan, who was active in Pakistan's independence movement and served as Interior Minister, died today.

title: PLATE TIED TO ARMORED-CAR GANG
description: A gunman was killed and a second was captured in a high-speed chase and shootout in Queens yesterday after the police linked their car's license plate to a gang that killed two policemen and an armored-car guard Tuesday.

title: Fred B. Manchee, an Author And Ex-Advertising Official
description: Fred B. Manchee, a former executive vice president and treasurer of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn Inc., died Wednesday of heart disease at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. He was 78 years old and maintained residences in Centerville, Mass., and Naples, Fla.

title: CINCINNATI GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENERAL STEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $119,000 for the qr and $1,275,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including $1.5 million tax credit; results for the latest qr and 9 mos include operations of Gruendler Crusher, acquired Aug 28 on a pooling of interests basis; shr earnings reflect a 20 percent stock divd paid in July

title: LOCTITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There was a net foreign exchange loss of $635,000 in the latest qr against $118,000 in 1980's first qr

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 FALL 27.6%
description: Despite a new round of rebates and other incentives, sales of new cars by the nation's Big Three auto manufacturers dropped 27.6 percent in mid-October, to their lowest level for this period in 23 years, the manufacturers reported today.

title: MOUNT VERNON MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $838,000 loss from closing of a plant...C-After $800,000 loss from closing of a plant

title: Around the World; Turkish Assembly Starts Drafting a Constitution
description: Turkey's ruling junta today opened the first meeting of a 160-member consultative assembly that will prepare a new constitution and laws relating to elections and political parties.

title: Your Money; Reagan Cuts In Student Aid
description: IF the budget cutters in the Reagan Administration have their way, Federal aid to low- and middle-income families putting children through college will be drastically curtailed next year.

title: VOLUNTEERS PUT MARATHON ON COURSE
description: When 16,000 runners step onto the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge at 10:30 tomorrow morning to start the 12th annual New York City Marathon, a small army of 4,300 volunteers will be standing by to get them safely through 26 miles and 385 yards of legwork.

title: COMBUSTION ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on the Boston Symphony incorrectly identified the husband of Susan Cabot, an organizer of the orchestra's centennial celebration.

title: Israel to Invite Bernstein to Lead Music by Wagner
description: The Israel Philharmonic orchestra will invite Leonard Bernstein to conduct music by Richard Wagner to try to overcome Israeli resistance to Nazi Germany's favorite composer.

title: DURIRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Mar 1981

title: Navy and Groton Yard Settle Disputes Over Trident Work
description: The Navy and the General Dynamics Electric Boat Division have announced that problems of workmanship, money claims and late deliveries have largely been resolved and that the company will get more orders for Trident missile submarines and attack submarines.

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1981; The Economy
description: The Consumer Price Index rose 1.2 percent in September. The rate, projected annually, was more than 14 percent, continuing a reversal of the slowing trend registered last spring. The chief impetus came from rising food, transportation, interest and medical costs. (Page 1.) The index in the New York area rose 1.5 percent. (30.)

title: McDonnell Douglas Up
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, builder of fighter aircraft, announced net income for the third quarter of $51.7 million, or $1.30 a share. The comparable figures for the third quarter last year, reduced by a write-off of $32 million related to the DC-9 program, were $11.7 million, or 30 cents a share. Sales advanced 20 percent, to $1.8 billion, from $1.5 billion.

title: TRANSAMERICA INCOME SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
6 Persons Charged With Bank Fraud
description: Six persons, including four employees of the Bankers Trust Company, were accused of stealing more than $300,000 from the bank in a credit-card scheme, according to the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: 8 Are Charged With Stealing By Tuning In Subscription TV
description: A Federal grand jury indicted eight persons for selling equipment to intercept signals of subscription television services.

title: SHOWBOAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reported on 2,755,305 shrs, the total shrs outstnd after adjustment for the 3-for-2 stock split on Oct 20

title: Belgian Blast Toll Rises to 3
description: A man died today from injuries suffered in Tuesday's bomb blast outside a synagogue in Antwerp's diamond district, bringing the death toll to three.

title: SERVISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANCORP HAWAII reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. A re-enactment of the Battle of Yorktown, the culminating Bicentennial event. 2. False. Senator Byrd says his opposition was based on the belief that secret military technology in the Awacs and other equipment might be compromised by the sale.

title: Moon, in Court, Confers on Trial
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon returned to court yesterday for a half-hour conference on plans for his trial on tax fraud charges. Judge Gerard L. Goettel, who will conduct the trial, called the conference in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: NORLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EASTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLAND DEPLOYING TROOPS FOR ACTION IN 'LOCAL DISPUTES'
description: The Polish Government announced today that it was sending teams of troops throughout the country to resolve unrest. The action came hours after Solidarity, the independent labor union, called a Excerpts from statement, page 5. one-hour national strike for Wednesday to protest food shortages and what it called harassment.

title: CONROCK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $1.9 million gain from the sale of land; yr- ago results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 22, 1981

title: No Headline
description: 114 TOXIC WASTE SITES LISTED AS NATION'S MOST DANGEROUS

title: Motion Is Denied in Fix Case
description: Rick Kuhn's defense suffered a setback yesterday when his lawyers lost a motion seeking to suppress a statement in which Mr. Kuhn acknowledged sharing payments in a point-shaving conspiracy involving six Boston College basketball games in the 1978-79 season.

title: MAN CLAIMING UNION THREAT FAILS IN BID TO TAKE OVER JET
description: A man from Puerto Rico who said he was fleeing fellow union members in fear of his life was foiled yesterday in an attempt to hijack an airliner bound from San Juan to New York and divert it to Quebec.

title: PRISON UNIT MUST REVEAL SPENDING ON BOND ISSUE
description: Justice Edward S. Conway of State Supreme Court today ordered the state's Department of Correctional Services to disclose what it had spent to help promote the $500 million prison bond issue that is on the November ballot. However, the judge declined to enjoin the department from further spending in promoting the bond proposal.

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: Results for the latest periods reflect foreign currency translation gains of 22 cents a shr for the qr and 90 cents a shr for the yr; yr-ago results reflect foreign currency translation losses of 32 cents a shr for the qr and 5 cents a shr for the yr

title: FARMER BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.M. Cancels Kansas Plant
description: One day after reporting a thirdquarter loss of $468 million, the General Motors Corporation said today that it was canceling plans to build a $500 million assembly plant in Kansas City, Kan., and that it would lay off indefinitely about 2,600 workers at an Oklahoma City assembly plant in a move to halve production.

UNITED MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MARK CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change covering vacation pay

title: DODGERS BEAT YANKEES, 5-4, AND TRAIL IN SERIES BY 2-1
description: It may have been the presence of Fernando Valenzuela, or the absence of Reggie Jackson and Graig Nettles. But, whatever it was, the Los Angeles Dodgers rallied tonight after two straight losses and defeated the New York Yankees, 5-4, in the third game of the World Series.

title: ROCHESTER GAS & ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOMESTAKE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books of The Times; CHILLED DELIRIUM
description: SIXTY STORIES. By Donald Barthelme. 457 pages. G.P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95.

title: CHRYSLER LOAN BID EXPECTED
description: Federal officials are expecting a request by the Chrysler Corporation for the $300 million in loan guarantees remaining in the $1.5 billion aid package approved by Congress in 1980.

title: WRIGHT, BARRY, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Mouse that Roared 'Trademark'
description: Mickey Colarusso and Mickey Visk, owners of a tavern called Mickey's Mousetrap in Colonie, N.Y., are bowing to Walt Disney Productions in a dispute over the Mickey Mouse trademark, which the company owns.

title: Colombian Guerrillas Kill 3
description: Three policemen were killed and an oil well was blown up in three separate attacks by leftist guerrillagroups, the Defense Ministry and the Government petroleum company said today.

title: PBA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: EXCERPTS FROM POLISH STATEMENT ON TROOPS

title: AMERICAN NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NURSE CLEARED IN DEATH LINKED TO DRUG INJECTIONS
description: Anne Capute, a nurse who said she had been following doctor's orders to keep a seriously ill cancer patient comfortable, was found not guilty today of killing the patient with large doses of morphine. She was also found not guilty of illegally dispensing the drug.

title: AMERICAN SEATING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $572,000 income from discontinued operations

title: SHOP & GO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1980 shr earnings adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid Oct 1

title: DR. ROBERT SPEIR, CANCER SPECIALIST
description: Dr. Robert Wade Speir, medical director-technology for the New York Telephone Company, was killed last Sunday when his car failed to make a curve in the Province Line Road in Lawrence Township near Trenton. A resident of Princeton, N.J., Dr. Speir would have been 53 years old next Wednesday.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Chilean Assails U.S. Plan To Resume Military Aid

title: PNB MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HIGH PRICES, FAT CONTENT SPUR A SHIFT
description: Out on the range, the cowboys are scratching their heads these days and wondering: What's happening to the red-blooded American beef eater?

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION TO WHAT END?
description: To the Editor:

title: Braniff Posts 3d-Period Loss
description: The Braniff International Corporation, holding company for Braniff Airways Inc., yesterday reported a loss of $20.3 million for the third quarter, contrasted with net income of $17 million, or 85 cents a share, in the third quarter of last year.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 15. 1. This man is getting a charge out of an historical re-enactment. In what is he taking part? 2. Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the minority leader, said he opposed the sale of five Awacs radar planes and other air defense equipment to Saudi Arabia because of the military danger to Israel. True or false?

title: SNAP-ON TOOLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LOWER FUND PROJECTION SNAGS PENSION MEASURE
description: The Social Security legislation that the Senate unanimously approved last week has run into serious difficulty in the House, reopening the question of how much immediate Congressional action is needed to keep the retirement system afloat.

title: VETERANS PROTEST PBS NOV.11 SPECIAL
description: One of the unfortunate byproducts of public broadcasting's marginal existence is that its most powerful promotional tool must often be controversy. In contrast to the commercial networks, PBS simply does not have the money to advertise widely and promote all its programs. But there is nothing quite like vocal opposition to a program to pique the interest of potential viewers.

title: BRANIFF INTERNATIONAL (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including $61.2 million gain from the sale of equipment

title: Frances Taussig Dead at 98; Leading Jewish Social Worker
description: Frances Taussig, executive director of the Jewish Family Service of New York for 30 years before her retirement in 1949, died Wednesday in Doctor's Hospital. She was 98 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: SCAN-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $151,000 for the qr and $377,000 for the 9 mos...C-Included $180,000 extraordinary credit

title: AMERADA HESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HILLER AVIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After $7,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: American Brands Net Off
description: American Brands Inc. reported yesterday that foreign-currency exchange translations at one of its major subsidiaries caused earnings in the third quarter to tumble 39.5 percent. Sales dropped 5.1 percent.

title: AIRBAG REGULATION ON CARS RESCINDED
description: A Federal agency today abandoned the longdisputed requirement that automobile manufacturers install automatic crash protection, such as airbags or ''passive'' safety belts.

title: MILTON ROY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $30,000 pretax equity in loss of joint venture for the qr and $38,000 pretax equity in income of affiliate for the 9 mos...C-Includes $176,000 gain from pretax equity in joint venture for the income of affiliate for the 9 mos

title: AMID PAGEANTRY AND PROTESTS, PENN INAUGURATES 20TH PRESIDENT
description: It was a time for fanfare, pomp and pageantry, a time for the University of Pennsylvania to celebrate itself.

title: GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Third article of a series: Jersey Issues; Crime
description: Both major-party candidates for Governor of New Jersey, responding to the public's concern about crime, have advocated programs designed to deal more forcefully with violent offenders, career criminals and juvenile lawbreakers. A poll of voter sentiment by The New York Times found that 10 percent believe crime was the state's most serious problem. Representative James J. Florio of Runnemede, the Democratic candidate, was heavily favored over the Republican, Thomas H. Kean of Livingston, a former Assembly Speaker, by those who said they were afraid to walk the streets near their homes.

title: COMMERCE CLEARING HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KAWASAKI GIVES A CITY ITS WORKERS
description: The concern traditionally shown by Japanese management about the fate of loyal workers has emerged in Nebraska.

title: MONEY SUPPLY DECLINES $1.5 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday afternoon that a key measure of the nation's money supply fell $1.5 billion in the week ended Oct. 14, a drop that was widely predicted by economists who expected a portion of the previous week's extraordinarily large $5.6 billion increase to be eliminated.

title: CASHMERE SWEATERS: A GUIDE TO BEST BUYS
description: Chinese emperors once wore cashmere robes. So did Himalayan princes and Roman senators. Down through the ages, cashmere was for the select few. It was too rare and too costly for the ordinary folk.

title: LODGE & SHIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STEPAN CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Briefing
description: I T'S probably the most exclusive dining spot in town - and getting more so. The White House Mess, two small rooms tucked away in the basement of the West Wing of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, has quietly barred reporters from dining on its steak-to-sandwich cuisine. (The mood picks up on Thursday's, however, when the Mexican special includes guacamole, meat tacos, meat enchiladas, refried beans and other fiery treats.) The Reagan Administration edict breaks the tradition of previous Administrations, which allowed reporters to dine in the clubby atmosphere so long as they were invited by staff members.

title: AYDIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Bonds Waived Again
description: Bobby Bonds, the 35-year-old slugger, found himself unemployed again yesterday when he was placed on waivers by the Cubs, the eighth major league team for which he had played. Filling Bonds's spot on the roster was Junior Kennedy, acquired earlier in the day from the Cincinnati Reds in exchange for a player to be named.

title: Car Output Off 7.9% in Japan
description: Reflecting sluggish car exports, Japan's output of passenger cars for September fell 7.9 percent from a year ago, to 579,654 units, according to industry figures released today.

title: KORCHNOI AND KARPOV DRAW 80-MOVE 8TH GAME OF MATCH
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland drew the eighth game of his world chess championship match with Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, but not without a grim struggle. It took 39 moves in the adjournment session before the champion acknowledged that he had been held at bay by offering him a draw.

title: AMARCO RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Margaret E. Sangster, A Writer and an Editor
description: Margaret E. Sangster, a former magazine editor and a prolific writer of verse, novels and radio scripts for more than half a century, died yesterday in the Barnwell Health Center, at Valatie, N.Y., after a long illness. She was believed to be about 90 years old.

title: TRANS-CANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto Stock exchang

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ATHENS DECIDES TO UPGRADE STATUS OF P.L.O. OFFICE
description: Greece's new Socialist Government announced today that it had decided to upgrade the diplomatic status of the Palestine Liberation Organization office in Athens but that its exact level would be determined later.

title: IRANIAN CLAIMS VICTORY OVER LEFTISTS
description: The Speaker of Iran's Parliament said today that the Islamic Government had succeeded in destroying most of the guerrilla forces opposing it and had cut the rest off from their leaders abroad.

title: READING & BATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Oct 7, 1981

title: MCQUAY-PERFEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Around the Nation; Michigan Judge Refuses Abortion for 11-Year-Old
description: A Kalamazoo County judge ruled today that it is not in the best interests of an 11-year-old girl who is nearly 24 weeks pregnant to undergo an abortion.

title: Joan Frances Gordon Wed To William Court Cohen
description: Joan Frances Gordon, a San Francisco real-estate broker, was married yesterday in Andover, Mass., to William Court Cohen, chairman of the board of Theater Now Inc., a New York theatrical-management and production company. Rabbi Harry Roth of Temple Emanuel in Andover performed the ceremony at the Andover Inn.

title: A Final West Side Compromise
description: The effort of two decades to rehabilitate a section of Manhattan's Upper West Side can now be triumphantly completed if the Federal Government will approve the last of many compromises governing the project.

title: FRENCH TAKEOVERS FACE CHALLENGE FROM ABROAD
description: France's new Socialist Government appears to be facing a major defeat in its sweeping nationalization program. A Geneva-based financial group announced today that it had acquired more than half the capital of Paribas (Suisse), the Geneva subsidiary of Compagnie Financiere de Paris et des Pays-Bas, the big French investment bank that is on the Government's nationalization list.

title: Consumer Saturday; PURSUING SMALL CLAIMS
description: In the summer of 1980, Robert M. Javeline, a salesman, found himself in a Long Island Rail Road car whose air conditioner was not working and whose windows were sealed shut.

title: CANCUN MEETING FAILS TO RESOLVE KEY DIFFERENCES
description: Leaders of 22 industrial and developing nations ended two days of closed-door talks tonight without a major breakthrough in their longstanding differences.

title: MARK PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $54,000 for the qr and $165,000 for the 9 mos

title: Bossy, Tonelli Spur Islanders' 4-2 Victory
description: Mike Bossy and John Tonelli scored two goals apiece tonight and led the New York Islanders to a 4-2 victory over the Washington Capitals, the team with the poorest record in the National Hockey League.

title: Coltrane's Widow Sues San Francisco Church
description: The widow of John Coltrane has filed a $7.5 million lawsuit against a San Francisco church that venerates the late jazz saxophonist as an ''anointed figure.''

title: FIRST NATIONAL BANK (ALLENTOWN, PA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCHULMAN, A, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd paid in Feb 1

title: AUTOMATED MARKETING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
