description: B-Net loss after $3.4 million loss from discontinued operations

title: INDEX ROSE 1.5 PERCENT IN THE CITY
description: An increase of 1.5 percent last month in the Consumer Price Index in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area lifted the inflation rate to 11.2 percent for the last 12 months.

title: DODGERS REVIVED BY CEY
description: While Graig Nettles watched from the Yankee bench with an injured thumb tonight, his Los Angeles counterpart, Ron Cey, sparked the Dodgers to their first victory in the World Series with a three-run home run and a defensive play worthy of the Yankees' third baseman.

title: POPE PUTS JESUITS UNDER CLOSER REIN
description: Pope John Paul II has appointed a conservative Italian theologian to take over direction of the Jesuit order as his personal ''delegate'' until the order elects a new leader.

title: Ejected Fan Not Held In Throwing of Bottle
description: The fan at Yankee Stadium believed to have been the person who threw a bottle at Dusty Baker in left field during the first game of the World Series was escorted out of the ball park by a member of the security detail, but was not arrested, according to Irv Kaze, a Yankee spokesman.

title: Around the Nation; Settlement Ends Trial On Disabled Children
description: Attorneys for the Bunker Hill Company and nine former Kellogg, Idaho, children settled out of court today in a $20 million lawsuit contending that the northern Idaho company's lead emissions had poisoned and permanently disabled the children.

title: DIETRICH RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DONNELLEY, R R, & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CLEVEPAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $426,000 or 12 cents a shr nonrecurring gain from a settlement with tax authorities to reduce retroactively property tax assessments for prior yrs at the company's Piermon NY facility

title: NATIONAL CAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New York State Seeking Lien On Carey Brother's Property
description: New York State has filed suit against Governor Carey's brother Martin seeking a lien against his property to insure payment in the event the state wins a damage suit against his corporation.

title: DANCE: FROM THE SIDEWALKS OF LOS ANGELES
description: During her Thursday night demonstration at the Kitchen, Toni Basil remarked, ''There's always dancing somewhere if you know where to look.'' These days, the Kitchen has been looking in city streets. Thus a few weeks ago it presented examples of ''breaking,'' a dance form born on the New York sidewalks. Aided by films, videotapes and live performers, Miss Basil, a rock choreographer who is also something of a historian of pop dance, presented a survey of Los Angeles street dancing.

title: Article 064092 -- No Title
description: The Seagram Company Ltd., the big Canadian distilling concern, has borrowed $300 million (in United States currency) from a consortium of Canadian banks to buy back as much as 14.25 percent of its common stock, the Bank of Montreal, one of five banks in the consortium, announced.

title: SCI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: Shr earnings reflect 50 percent stock divd paid in July

title: Around the Nation
description: Amtrak announced today that it will increase most train passenger fares and accommodation charges by an average of 6.5 percent, effective Sunday.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'I Live Here and You Don't'
description: We in the newspaper business are forever printing cute stories about cute letters from children. When they get angry, we consider them less charming and more often than not give them the silent treatment.

title: TESDATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income

title: Brittle Metal and Nuclear Safety
description: At times, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission makes the nuclear power business sound like the auto industry, issuing what amount to recall notices. The newest one concerns brittle steel in the pressure vessels at the center of every nuclear plant. The episode shows that the commission is on the job - but also how that job should be changed.

title: OPERA: JANICE YOES, SOPRANO
description: Janice Yoes, a soprano from Arkansas who has been ''covering'' the ''Siegfried'' Brunnhildes at the Metropolitan Opera, made an unscheduled debut in the part on Oct. 15, when Elisabeth Payer fell ill, and on Tuesday she went on again for the same reason, in the company's last performance of the opera this season.

title: CHOREOGRAPHER AND TEACHER
description: Edward Caton, a Russian-born American dancer, teacher and choreographer, died of cancer Thursday night in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: INSULTING VIETNAM VETS
description: Unless something unexpected happens, ground will soon be broken for the Vietnam veterans' memorial on the Mall here in Washington. Although I have long awaited this moment, as it now approaches I feel only pain.

title: Sports People; Norfolk State Inquiry
description: A committee was appointed by the Central Intercollegiate Athletic Association to investigate the basketball program at Norfolk State, where several players accused Coach Lucias Mitchell last month of ''demeaning and inhumane treatment.'' The committee, which is to report to Commissioner Bob Moorman next Friday, was formed one day after two Norfolk State players had quit the team and two others had said they were considering transferring to other schools.

title: GOMEZ AND GRAHAM SET TO TEST SALAZAR
description: Alberto Salazar remained on target for a world-record run in the New York City Marathon tomorrow, but Rodolfo Gomez and John Graham said yesterday they were equally prepared for the challenge.

title: INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a net gain of about $250,000 or 13 cents a shr from the sale of certain lease interests...C-Includes income of about $200,000 or 11 cents a shr from the sale of certain Black Strap molasses assets and operations, and net of expenses incurred in consolidating these and other operations...D-After a gain from discontinued operations of $48,000

title: HASTINGS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Leonard to Fight Finch
description: Sugar Ray Leonard has an oral agreement to make the first defense of his unified welterweight title against Bruce Finch in Reno on Feb. 15, according to Mike Trainer, Leonard's attorney.

title: IDLE WILD FOODS INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $1,279,886 pretax gain on the disposition of processing plant

title: HOWELL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STAMFORD PAPER CHECKS BOUDIN FRIEND'S VERACITY
description: The Advocate of Stamford, Conn., is reinvestigating assertions by one of its reporters, Rita Jensen, that she lived for 21 months on the West Side of Manhattan with the fugitive Katherine Boudin without knowing Miss Boudin's identity.

title: NOLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $61,523 gain for the qr from a class action lawsuit recovery and $206,540 gain from the sale of securities and class action suit...C-Includes $451,061 gain for the qr and 9 mos from class action recoveries and $62,726 gain for the 9 mos from the sale of land

title: FLOW GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHROMALLOY AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $11.2 million income from discontinued operations yr-ago results reflect a change in accounting for cost of vacation pay benefits and reflect the adoption of the LIFO method for most domestic inventories

title: THE U.N. APPROACH TO AIDING REFUGEES
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1981
description: International Soldiers were sent throughout Poland to deal with demonstrations. A Government announcement on television said the troops would be empowered to ''counteract problems on the spot'' and ''would attempt to ''solve problems and controversies. It followed soon after the union had called a one-hour national strike on Wednesday to protest food shortages and ''harassment.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) The Cancun talks ended without a major breakthrough in the longstanding differences between the leaders of the industrialized and developing nations, but they made a provisional agreement to pursue an antipoverty strategy at the United Nations. On the key issue of global negotiations it was apparent that President Reagan had stood firm in insisting on placing conditions on American involvement in the talks. (1:5.)

title: VW Executive Resigns
description: Volkswagen, West Germany's biggest auto maker, which has been plagued this year by diminishing earnings, today announced the resignation of its chief financial officer. Analysts suggested the move might be the first step in a major management reshuffling.

title: Retired Detective Dies After Seizing Suspect
description: A retired Transit Authority detective captured an intruder in his home last night but apparently died of a heart attack just as police officers arrived to make an arrest, the police said.

title: SUMMER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AUTUMN, O AUTUMN, THY NAME IS...UH,UH--AUTUMN
description: Every year at this time, I sit through the night at my typewriter, first drinking coffee and later Scotch, with the most profound intention of writing the definitive poem about Autumn. I've been at this off and on now for 10 years, and yet I'm not ready to announce the poem's completion.

title: AERONCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $343,000 for the qr and $376,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including $960,000 tax credit

title: TWO MORE SENATORS PLANNING TO OPPOSE AWACS SALE TO SAUDIS
description: Senator Dale Bumpers announced today that he would oppose the sale of Awacs radar planes and advanced air-to-air missiles to Saudi Arabia.

title: BURY THEM NOT IN POTTER'S FIELD
description: The man who was born in Hungary was the oldest. He had lived in a single-room-occupancy hotel and died in the hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: SOUTHERN INDIANA GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OWNER OF GETAWAY CAR FREED
description: A judge yesterday turned down an attempt by the Queens District Attorney to prevent the immediate release on $10,000 cash bail of Eve Rosahn, the owner of a car used in the robbery of an armored car and subsequent shootout in Rockland County on Tuesday.

title: LUCAS-WILLIAMS TRADE IS REPORTED NEAR
description: After weeks of speculation, the Knicks were very close yesterday to obtaining Maurice Lucas, a power forward of the caliber they have long needed, in return for Ray Williams, the free-agent shooting guard whom the Nets hope to convert to a playmaker.

title: Jackson to Play Today
description: Reggie Jackson will be the Yankees' cleanup hitter and right fielder in tomorrow's fourth World Series game, Manager Bob Lemon said after tonight's 5-4 loss to the Dodgers.

title: JOSEPH SOREFF
description: Joseph Soreff, a lawyer and former senior project engineer for the New York City Planning Board, died yesterday at his home in Miami Beach. Mr. Soreff, who was 79 years old, had moved to Florida after his retirement from the city agency in 1966.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Winding up a five-day visit to New York yesterday, Nancy Reagan listened to a song dedicated to her, wiped away a tear and pronounced the song ''just wonderful.''

title: BALDOR ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PARK CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONSUMER PRICES UP BY SHARP 1.2% DURING SEPTEMBER
description: The Consumer Price Index, pushed up by increases in food, transportation, interest rates and medical care costs, surged 1.2 percent in September. At an annual rate, this comes to more than 14 percent.

title: DINNER AT COLUMBIA HONORS ROBESON
description: Paul Robeson, who once declared that the Soviet Union had accorded him the ''complete human dignity'' he had been denied as a law student at Columbia University, was hailed at his alma mater Thursday night as a freedom fighter and humanitarian.

title: Bridge: U.S. Moves Into 2d Place In Play for Bermuda Bowl
description: The United States team moved into second position in the world team championship here this afternoon. The Americans won, 13 to 7, against Indonesia and overtook the Poles, who lost, 6 to 14, to Australia.

title: SPECTRADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 shr earnings reflect loss equal to 1 cent a shr for the acquisition of Spectradyne International in July; 1980 shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in July

title: Youth Exonerated In Lawyer's Death
description: Charges will be dropped against Luis Guzman, 16 years old, of 60 Avenue D, Manhattan, who had been incorrectly identified and indicted on charges of having killed a lawyer in an East Side park, according to the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau.

title: Around the Nation; Teacher's Ouster Barred Over Sexual Preference
description: A Federal court has ruled that sexual preference is not grounds for disciplining or dismissing a teacher as long as the preference does not affect school functions.

title: 10.28 Loss Puts Dow At 837.99; Poor Earnings Reports Cited
description: Stock prices retreated across a broad front yesterday in response to poor profit reports by several major corporations and renewed worries about inflation.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 24, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Executive Board of the United Na- tions Children's Fund - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Adm. Robert E. Dixon, Hero of a Naval Battle
description: Rear Adm. Robert E. Dixon, United States Navy, retired, who led an attack that sank the first Japanese aircraft carrier in World War II, died Wednesday.

title: FIRST BANKSHARES CORP OF SOUTH CAROLINA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: OCEAN DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $1,305,000 for the qr and $3,162,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: FOR THE P.L.O.'S MAN IN THE CAPITAL, THE DAYS BRING PAIN AND REWARDS
description: He looks and sounds like an urbane Washington lawyer. Dark pin-stripe suit. Graying mustache. Neatly cropped black hair. He argues points with cool eloquence, parrying questions he'd rather not answer, like the questions about why his leaders publicly applauded the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt.

title: Niece of U.S. Senate Leader Sentenced on a Theft Charge
description: A niece of Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, was sentenced to three years' probation today for embezzling more than $12,000 from the Senate post office, where she was chief clerk.

title: CONDATA NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Nov 1980

title: MUBARAK CALLS KILLING PART OF WIDER PLOT
description: President Hosni Mubarak said today that the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat was the first and key step in a plot to topple the Egyptian Government and install a fundamentalist Moslem regime modeled after that of Iran.

title: BARBATO ACQUITTED IN L.I. SEWER PROJECT CASE: 2 OTHERS FOUND GUILTY
description: The former Republican leader of Smithtown, Nicholas Barbato, was acquitted today of charges that he accepted bribes in return for promoting Suffolk County's $932 million Southwest Sewer District.

title: When in Doubt, Stamp It Out
description: All Presidents promise openness and operate secretively when they choose. But every President since Truman has made some progress in the rules for deciding what documents are classified confidential, secret, top secret and up.

title: Warner Cut More in Dorsett Mold Than Past Penn State Stars
description: Curt Warner is not like John Cappelletti, Penn State's powerful tailback who won the Heisman Trophy in 1973. Cappelletti was 6 feet 3 inches tall, weighed 220 pounds and played like a fullback.

title: Labor Official Promoted
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. today named John Perkins, coordinator of the Solidarity Day protest against the Reagan Administration on Sept. 19, as its new chief political official.

title: TRANSOHIO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including $800,000 gain on the sale of property

title: PARK-OHIO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOLT BERANEK & NEWMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings adjusted for a stock split

title: Four Oil Companies Cite Drop in Net
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, a major oil producer with large oil holdings in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea, reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings slumped 32.1 percent, although revenues increased 21.8 percent.

title: Golden West Seeks Fidelity Financial
description: The Golden West Financial Corporation confirmed earlier reports that it is engaged in preliminary talks aimed at acquiring the Fidelity Financial Corporation, parent of the Fidelity Savings and Loan Association.

title: RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. HEARD REPORT OF PILOTS IN CHAD
description: The State Department said today that it had received unconfirmed reports that Americans might have taken part in airlifts to supply Libyan troops in Chad.

title: A 'SLIVER' THE EAST SIDE CAN DO WITHOUT
description: To the Editor:

title: RICHMOND TANK CAR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALERT DETECTIVE'S USE OF CLUE LED POLICE TO THE 2 SUSPECTS
description: Daniel Kelly, a 53-year-old detective lieutenant with a sharp eye and a shining record, is credited by the police with uncovering the clue that led them to two gunmen suspected of taking part in Tuesday's robbery of a Brink's truck.

title: Patents; A System To Identify Callers
description: WASHINGTON WHEN a telephone rings, the caller is identified even before the receiver is lifted. The equipment, patented this week, is available throughout the Bell System, and is being offered especially to small companies with few telephones.

title: REPUBLIC AUTOMOTIVE PARTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $230,000 gain on the sale of real estate

title: Around the World; San Salvador Terrorists Set Off Five Bombs
description: Five bombs exploded in this capital city today, damaging a shopping center, two banks, a restaurant and a construction materials company, the authorities reported.

title: A CITY AGENCY INTENT ON RUNNING A CLEAN FOOD-STAMP PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOOTOUT IN QUEENS 'LIKE A WILD WEST MOVIE'
description: David Finsmith, a 27-year-old machinist in grimy jeans and sweatshirt, picked up a football after lunch and was heading out the door of his machine shop when it started to drizzle.

title: BUSINESSMAN TIED TO TERRORIST PLOT
description: A Federal indictment was made public today accusing a 38-year-old Virginian of shipping explosives to Libya and training terrorists there as part of a conspiracy headed by two former Central Intelligence agents.

title: PENNZOIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ACME ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock divd paid in Mar

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bethlehem Steel
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would temporarily lay off more than 1,500 employees in various divisions of its Baltimore operation because of declining orders. The plant manager, Russell R. Jones, said orders were down and the factory must adjust its level of operations. Mr. Jones said several major facilities are also scheduled for indefinite shutdown on Nov. 1, causing the layoff of another 650 workers.

title: Sports People; O'Koren Breaks Nose
description: Injuries continue to hamper the Nets, who open the regular season a week from today.

title: TWIN DISC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $1.3 million loss from liquidation of subsidiary

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said it had acquired 450,000 shares of Alexander Howden Group Ltd. at a price of $2.61 a share. Alexander & Alexander has announced an offer to acquire 100 percent of Alexander Howden pursuant to an exchange offer.

title: City Ballet Is Reviving 8 Tchaikovsky Ballets
description: Revivals of eight ballets from the Tchaikovsky Festival will highlight the New York City Ballet's winter season at the New York State Theater from Nov. 17 through Feb. 21.

title: News Analysis
description: One hot night in August, as he enjoyed a beer in Chicago, the president of a small, Southern-based union, which must grub hard not only to get contracts but just to stay alive, was asked what he thought of the air traffic controllers' strike.

title: Around the Nation; Haitian Refugee Deaths On a 2d Boat Reported
description: The Federal prosecutor who has charged two Haitian boatmen with starving 80 refugees and hacking, strangling or drowning up to 16 others said today that his office was investigating reports of a similar cruise.

title: HUNT, PHILIP A, CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $10,000 income for the qr and $113,000 loss for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $104,000 for the qr and $212,000 for the 9 mos; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect change to LIFO accounting and the effect of discon- tinued operations

title: MUELLER, PAUL, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JUDGE DENIES BAIL TO FOUR DEFENDANTS IN ROCKLAND COUNTY KILLINGS
description: The two men and two women accused of killing a Brink's guard and two local police officers on Tuesday were remanded without bail to the Rockland County jail today.

title: EVEN IN MEXICO, REAGAN TURNS HIS ATTENTION TO AWACS ISSUE
description: President Reagan met with Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia here today, but by prior agreement both men reportedly refrained from mentioning the sale of Awacs aircraft to the Saudis.

title: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW PROCESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
De Gustibus; LOWLY TEA BAG CONQUERS THE WORLD
description: Despite all that we hear these days about improved standards of cooking and the use of authentic and superior ingredients, the tea bag not just survives, but flourishes. This is the case even in the fanciest and most expensive restaurants where instant coffee never darkens the door and all cooking is done painstakingly from scratch.

title: Anticrime Plan For Cabs Detailed
description: Mayor Koch announced several new measures aimed at protecting cabdrivers from crimes. Under the plan, police officers will make random stops of drivers and the police will recommend specific thoroughfares in each borough where officers will be stationed at checkpoints.

title: Around the World; Crocker Sees U.S. Role In the Western Sahara
description: Chester A. Crocker, United States Assistant Secretary of State for African affairs, said today that the United States had ''a role to play'' in helping to bring about peace in the Western Sahara.

title: ACETO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOSPITAL'S TIE TO GERMAN OUTFIT STIRS CONCERN
description: A $50 million contract under which a West German drug company is supporting basic biological research at the Massachusetts General Hospital raises at least the possibility that the company could acquire control of inventions partly paid for with Federal money, in the view of the General Accounting Office.

title: NEW PACIFIC INDUSTRY: AIRLINES
description: Practically every Pacific island nation with a flag now has a national airline. Tiny Kiribati has Air Tungaru. The new nation of Vanuatu has Air Vanuatu. In Western Samoa, it is Polynesian Airlines, and in Papua New Guinea, Air Niugini. The Solomon Islands calls its national airline Solair. And Fiji has named its carrier Air Pacific.

title: Milton Weir, 82, Financier Who Put Seaplane Bases Here
description: Milton N. Weir, a financier who developed the West Side Airlines Terminal and established commuter seaplane bases on the East River, died last Saturday aboard a cruise ship in the Caribbean. Mr. Weir, who was a resident of Boca Raton, Fla., was 82 years old.

title: UNITED SERVICES LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gristle In The Wind
description: When I was 11 and briefly commanded the allegiance of four or five 8- and 9-year-olds, being of bureaucratic mentality I decided to organize them into a gang. I composed and issued membership cards and drew up rules specifying degrees of punishment for various derelictions such as losing your membership card and interrupting the leader when he was talking.

title: BUDGET CUTS THREATEN CULTURAL EXCHANGE PROJECTS
description: Budget cuts proposed under a revised State Department authorization bill would seriously curtail United States programs for scholars and other cultural exchanges, according to figures sent to Congress today.

title: BURMESE ABOUT TO SIGN AID ACCORD WITH U.S.
description: The Burmese Government is reported to be on the verge of signing an aid agreement with the United States providing $30 million in agricultural assistance spread over a period of three to five years.

title: COLLEGE CAMPUSES SINGING THE 'FRESHMAN BLUES' AGAIN
description: ''I HAD a wide range of problems. I didn't know the university, the culture - even what a credit was. It was all so new and big,'' said Debra Delagrenade of Trinidad, speaking about the difficulties she faced in her freshman year.

title: NUCLEAR FEARS STIR EUROPE AND STRAIN THE ALLIANCE
description: LONDON THREE comments from three European officials, all of them swimmers in the mainstream of politics and public opinion and none of them intemperate or demagogic, suggest the mounting anxiety in many parts of this continent over the prospect of nuclear cataclysm.

title: ONE OF THIS COUNTRY'S MOST POPULAR GATHERINGS, WITH A REGIONAL FLAVOR
description: When it comes to the country-food reminiscences of Edna Lewis, memory can make a person's mouth water. Memories, for instance, of warm springmorning breakfasts of river shad, fence-row asparagus and strawberries; of summer lunches of pan-fried barnyard chicken and cream gravy; of autumn picnics of field pheasant and wild-hickory-nut cookies; of winter suppers of Bay oyster stew and home-cured sausages.

title: Whales Ahoy!
description: The first glimpse is the spout, a thin fog-like spray rising from the sea. Then the dark thin line of its powerful back appears on the surface, rolling, glistening in the sunlight.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Peaceable Town
description: If Arlington, Kan., had as many murders as New York has in an average four months, Arlington would be wiped out. The town has but 505 people, and actually, as of April 1980, it had never had a single murder.

title: ACT I: THE PULITZER, ACT II: BROADWAY
description: How does the world look to a young playwright whose first fulllength work wins the Pulitzer Prize for drama? Beth Henley, who was awarded the prize last April for ''Crimes of the Heart'' without ever having had a play on Broadway, says it looks simultaneously ''wonderful'' and ''pretty terrifying.''

title: JAPAN'S 'EASTER PARADE'
description: R.V. DENENBERG writes frequently for Travel. By R.V.DENENBERG

title: CHRYSLER CONTINUING TO SQUEAK THROUGH
description: LIKE a coach at halftime seeking to inspire a battered team, Lee Iacocca was exhorting a group of New York State Chrysler dealers at their recent annual convention at Kiamesha Lake.

title: WEINBERGER DOES A TURN AS DIPLOMAT
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger began his toast in the ornate, formal banquet hall of the Swedish Foreign Ministry in Stockholm on a self-deprecating note, saying that on such occasions Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. sometimes quipped: ''Secretary Weinberger is about to commit foreign policy.''

title: Deborah Rhein, P.V. Fratello Jr.  Married on L. I.
description: Deborah Betz Rhein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H.W. Rhein 3d of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Peter Victor Fratello Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Victor Fratello of Sands Point, L.I. The ceremony was performed at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor by the bride's grandfather, the Rev. John H.W. Rhein of Saunderstown, R. I. He was assisted by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee, rector of St. John's.

title: The Nation in Summary; Unwelcome To the U.S.
description: The United States ''melting pot'' was put to a stern test last year, when more than 140,000 immigrants from Cuba and Haiti landed in southern Florida. Last week the Reagan Administration submitted legislation it described as ''possibly the only way'' to prevent it happening again.

title: ANTWERP GEM DEALERS TRY TO RECOVER FROM BLAST
description: ''It will be business as usual when we reopen next Monday, that's for sure,'' said Jaak Nutkewitz, president of the Diamond Bourse, the largest of the four diamond exchanges near the central station that make Antwerp the hub of the world's diamond trade.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA UPSETS NORTH CAROLINA
description: The quarterback Gordon Beckham passed for 195 yards and one touchdown and the tailback Johnnie Wright ran for 115 yards to lead South Carolina to a 31-13 upset over North Carolina today.

title: IRE RISES AS LEAVES COME DOWN
description: THERE is a small war going on on my street. It may explode into armed combat (I, with my one-woman powered hand rake and he, with his five-horse-powered leaf blower) if a certain gardener doesn't mend - or perhaps I should say, cultivate - his ways.

title: Television Week
description: Changing Charlie The 16th year of televised Peanuts cartoons will be celebrated with the broadcast of a new animated special, ''Someday, You'll Find Her, Charlie Brown,'' Friday evening beginning at 8 on CBS.

title: About Cars; TO LEARN TO RACE, A DRIVER NEEDS 3 FEET
description: MONT TREMBLANT, Quebec THERE they are, nose to tail, docile now but still with the look of something that bites. They are Formula Ford race cars and they are lined up like bright links in a rainbow sausage. Mine is blue, No. 6, and the instructor is standing next to it, saying he just doesn't know what to do with me.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption today in the Arts and Leisure section and a film listing in The GUide incorrectly identify the theater for the movie "Quartet." It opens today at the Beekman.

title: Hayman, Miss Bradley Capture Cycling Honors
description: Ron Hayman, a 27-year-old professional from Vancouver, British Columbia, and Jacque Bradley, 18, of Davenport, Iowa, won the men's and women's divisions of the $71,000 pro-am Great Mohawk bicycle race today. The purse, split evenly between the two divisions, made it the richest bicycle race ever.

title: by Leo H. Carney
description: TOMSRIVER AT A time when New Jersey is in a quandary over what to do with its abandoned hazardous-waste sites and how much more garbage can be stuffed into its landfills, Ocean County College is utilizing at least one old dump in an unusual way - as a teaching ground.

title: 'POLITICIAN' IS THE ONE TAG THAT STICKS TO THURMOND
description: When a group of feminists appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee earlier this year to express concern about clubs that excluded women, Senator Strom Thurmond told them that they were ''the prettiest witnesses we have had in a long time.'' He said he imagined the women were all married, but ''if not, you could be if you wanted to be.''

title: A DAY THAT RUNS ON AND ON
description: TODAY is a runner's dream. At the Verrazano Bridge, helicopters hover overhead. Network is there. Fireboats spout. A mass of human energy waits in a holding pattern. In a moments' notice, it surges forward, cascading like water through a broken dam, streaming forth endlessly into the streets of Bay Ridge.

title: Stamps; THE UNITED STATES UNVEILS ITS CHRISTMAS ISSUES
description: This year's Christmas stamps, being issued on Wednesday at two different locations, are costing a little more, like everything else. The stamps bear no denominations, but have a designated value of 20 cents, the new higher rate for first-class postage.

title: TAXPAYER LINE IN CORTLANDT WAVE OF FUTURE?
description: CORTLANDT voters will find something new on their town ballot this year. Not just another party, but a voting line that will let them send a personal message to the local politicians. A vote on this line will serve notice on them all to become more accountable to the public.

title: DELICIOUS FOOD IS A NEW ADDITION TO A NATIONAL INSTITUTION
description: The origin of the cocktail is still in dispute, but, according to one source, this peculiarly American way of entertaining began in New York City in the early part of this century with an elite group nicknamed Cafe Society. This crowd spent a great deal of time at parties where drink was taken in place of tea - or coffee, and out of this developed the social institution known as the cocktail party.

title: Comment; LAISSEZ-FAIRE IN OIL
description: A FTER eight years of dismal failure, the law authorizing the Federal Government to control oil prices and allocate supplies expired on Sept. 30. Congress is now considering renewal of those same price control and allocation authorities for use during oil supply disruptions.

title: HOUSING AND RECONSIDERED VALUES
description: SOME weeks ago on this page, United States Senator Christopher J. Dodd focused upon the need for a redefinition of our housing needs and how to fulfill them.

title: SHEPARDING NEWBORNS THROUGH CRITICAL FIRST DAYS
description: PATERSON LIKE proud first-time parents everywhere, David and Kathy Grunstra of Ringwood peered anxiously through the window of a special nursery at St. Joseph's Hospital here for a glimpse of their newborn daughter, Kim.

title: Around the World; Rebels Reported Routed In 2 Salvadoran Battles
description: Government forces reported victories today in two major operations against guerrillas.

title: REPUBLICANS FLEX PARTY MUSCLE IN PUSH TO WIN FALL ELECTIONS
description: The Republican Party and President Reagan are beginning their 1982 campaign with this fall's scattering of state and local elections, with serious efforts in Virginia and New Jersey and modest measures in Ohio, Kentucky and Oklahoma.

title: COOLIDGE'S TOWN
description: To the Editor:

title: Sue Barker Gains Final In Brighton Tennis
description: Sue Barker of Britain defeated Barbara Potter of the United States, 7-5, 4-6, 7-6, today to gain the final of the $125,000 Daihatsu Challenge women's tennis tournament at the Brighton Center.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Photo Freedom
description: When Governor Carey signed a law in July 1979 calling for individual photographs on the licenses of all nine million drivers in New York State, some legislators and libertarians protested with words like ''Big Brother,'' ''police state'' and ''1984.'' They noted that the state planned to keep its own central file in Albany of all the photos.

title: REJECTING THE 'CORPORATE GAMES WIVES HAVE TO PLAY'
description: LAST night I dreamt I died. I found myself knocking on the gates of heaven. ''Sorry, you can't come in,'' said the gatekeeper. ''You have failed at being a corporate wife. You'll simply have to go back and practice your golf game, your cocktail-party small talk and your passive attitude. Then, try again.'' I awoke teary-eyed and trembling.

title: Polish Tatras
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WELL-STOCKED BAR
description: The well-stocked bar in a sophisticated American household has undergone a transformation in recent years. Nowadays, there is much more emphasis on wine, for wine has increasingly been replacing whisky and other potables during the cocktail hour.

title: BAYSIDE, CANARSIE REMAIN UNBEATEN
description: Bayside, the defending Public Schools Athletic League champion, and Canarsie improved their records to 6-0 yesterday. Bayside's Commodores, winner of five out of the 10 titles since playoffs were formalized in 1971, clinched first place in the Bronx-Queens A division with a 30-6 triumph over Andrew Jackson.

title: BALLET: CRAGUN AND MISS HAYDEE IN CRANKO 'SHREW'
description: John Cranko's comedy ballet ''The Taming of the Shrew'' was one of the great hits of the Stuttgart Ballet's American debut in 1969, and it now promises to become just as popular with the Joffrey Ballet.

title: Australian Cardinal Attacked
description: A 42-year-old man was arrested today after he tried to stab the Roman Catholic Primate of Sydney with a knife hidden in a bunch of flowers. The police said the man, whose name was not immediately released, thrust the flowers at James Cardinal Freeman during mass in St. Mary's Cathedral. The man was seized by two priests, and Cardinal Freeman was unhurt.

title: Purdue 27 Michigan State 26
description: Scott Campbell passed for 237 yards and four touchdowns for Purdue, including a 32-yard scoring pass to Joe Linville with 11 minutes left to score the winning points for Purdue.

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'Supersisters'
description: In 1978 Lois Rich's 8-year-old daughter, Melissa, who collected baseball cards, asked her mother, ''Why aren't there any pictures of girls on the cards?''

title: BOOK ON RAID ON CHINESE ATOMIC LAB DENIED BY MARINE CORPS
description: The United States Marine Corps and a book publisher are at odds over a new book that describes a purported secret Marine mission into China in 1952 that the author said resulted in the destruction of an atomic laboratory complex. The publisher, E.P. Dutton, calls the book an ''incredible true account,'' but Marine Corps officials say that it is actually an imaginative work of fiction.

title: M. R. Long, Miss Hirson Are Married
description: Heather Ann Hirson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Miles W. Hirson of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael Raymond Long, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond F. Long of Columbia, S.C. The Rev. Gerard F. Rafferty performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: Virginia Marie Smith Wed To James Clerkin, Lawyer
description: Virginia Marie Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael W. Smith of New Hyde Park, L. I., was married there yesterday to James Clark Clerkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Clerkin of Sands Point, L.I. The Rev. Robert J. Clerkin Jr., brother of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: RENAISSANCE NEWARK, the business community's plan to construct about $150 million worth of high-rise buildings in the heart of the downtown business district, has been sharply criticized by representatives of community groups.

title: Giving Everyone A Chance to Work
description: I'm sure that most people who read the recent article ''Work and Play: Not Just Opposites'' (Opinion Page) must have found it interesting and enjoyable. However, it meant even more to me as the mother of a mentally retarded son.

title: THE THREE FACES OF SUE
description: DADDY'S GIRL By Beverly Lowry. 267 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: RICHARD MESSER FIANCE OF NORMA JEAN HONIG
description: Mrs. A. Milton Honig of Mount Vernon, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Norma Jean Honig, to Richard Messer of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. A late spring wedding is planned.

title: The Nation in Summary; It's Not Just Blowing Smoke
description: As expected, the House last week finally passed a four-year omnibus farm bill that cost less than the farm bloc would have liked, but more - by roughly $6 billion - than the Administration wants. Some funny things happened along the way.

title: Tufts 9, Williams 6
description: Mike Krueger scored the touchdown for Tufts on a 1-yard run in the third quarter.

title: Inhibiting Offspring
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: ''I THINK that I shall never see a poem lovely as a tree,'' wrote the poet Joyce Kilmer. These days, on the grounds of the State Capitol, it is tough to see some of the more notable trees. By dint of nature, vandals and bad luck, they are disappearing.

title: Maryland 24, Duke 21
description: Tim Quander scored on a 92-yard kickoff return and Charlie Wysocki's touchdown runs of 54 and 17 yards led Maryland.

title: PROSECUTION IN GOODY CASE DENIES MISCONDUCT
description: Justice Department prosecutors have denounced as "outrageous," "utterly absurd" and "gratuitous" a Federal Judge's ruling that a Government prosecutor engaged in serious misconduct in the recent trial of Sam Goody Inc. and a company official on counterfeit-tape charges. The judge, Thomas C. Platt of Federal District Court in Brooklyn, said in July that the asserted misconduct was one of the reasons he was dismissing a jury verdict that found the defendants guilty of knowingly dealing in counterfeit popular-music tapes. The misconduct, the judge said, involved the prosecutor's "attempted cover-up" of "false statements" given by a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent on the witness stand. The judge ordered a retrial for the Goody company - one of the oldest and largest chains of recorded-music stores in the country - and the Goody official, Samuel Stolon, a vice president. In a brief filed last week, two Justice Department officials used unusually harsh language as they pressed the Government's attempt to reverse Judge Platt and have the convictions reinstated by the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan. A review of the five-week trial last spring, the officials contended, "reveals how utterly absurd is the District Court's ruling on this issue, and how outrageous its epithets directed against a career Government prosecutor were." The officials attacking the Platt ruling were Edward R. Korman, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York; Thomas P. Puccio, head of the Justice Department's Organized Crime Strike Force in the district, and Lawrence H. Sharf, their special counsel. The Goody trial prosecutor, John H. Jacobs, is a member of Mr. Puccio's unit. In earlier court papers, Mr. Korman charged that the judge's decision setting aside the convictions reflected "an inexplicable animus toward the prosecution," while Mr. Puccio spoke of the judge's "apparent hostility toward the prosecutor." An aide to Judge Platt said the judge did not want to comment on these contentions because doing so "would be improper." Dismissal of Charges Sought But Martin R. Gold, a defense attorney in the case, said that "the charge of judicial bias in favor of the defendants is totally unsubstantiated by the record." Mr. Gold added: "During the course of the proceedings in this case, the defense made at least six separate major motions to dismiss the charges against the defendants. Each of these motions had a substantial basis and could well have been granted, though each was denied." Mr. Gold expressed these views recently in an affidavit he filed with Judge Platt asking again that the judge dismiss the charges altogether. As grounds this time, Mr. Gold cited "improper, misleading and prejudicial publicity about the case, which was, by all appearances, generated by the prosecution." In an affidavit of his own, Mr. Puccio denied the publicity-generating Charge and asked that Judge Platt remove himself from the case should there be a retrial. In accusing Mr. Jacobs of misconduct in prosecuting the original trial, Judge Platt referred to two appearances before the jury by the F.B.I. agent, Richard Ferri. In the first, Mr. Ferri testified that certain notes he had taken at meetings with Government informants had been destroyed. In his second appearance - which Judge Platt said he had, in effect, directed Mr. Ferri said that the relevant notes had not, in fact, been destroyed and that his original testimony had resulted from faulty recollection. Judge Platt described these events as Mr. Jacob's "attempted cover-up of the false statements" and called Mr. Ferri's testimony "unquestionably relevant and material." The brief by the Justice Department disputes that the Ferri testimony was false "or that it was material to any issue the jury was required to resolve."

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Brian Preston Performs Wide Piano Repertory
description: In his New York debut program Oct. 17 at Alice Tully Hall, Brian Preston proved to be a pianist comfortable with a varied repertory and with the technical and interpretive demands it placed on him.

title: FRIENDS OF ARTS EXPANDING
description: OYSTER BAY MAYBE it's coincidence, or maybe it's poetic justice. But when the Friends of the Arts, a leading presenter of concerts on Long Island, was founded nine years ago, the announced aim of ''stimulating cultural activities'' on the North Shore was, according to its director, Theodora Bookman, really just another way of saying ''help the school - Locust Valley High School - buy band uniforms.''

title: U.S. HOUSING PANEL CITES NEED FOR 'DECISIVE ACTION'
description: - Federal housing programs should be revamped to replace current subsidies for construction and rehabilitation of rental housing for low-income families with a system of grants to help needy households pay rent for existing apartments, the President's Commission on Housing has recommended.

title: Bernards Wins Cross-Country
description: Bernards of New Jersey claimed a piece of cross-country history yesterday in the Eastern States Championships at Van Cortlandt Park when it won the seeded A race with 68 points and had a five-man average of 12 minutes 58.7 seconds, the second fastest ever over the popular 2.5-mile course.

title: REAGAN STATEMENT ON CANCUN
description: For the last three days in Cancun I have participated in a unique and highly productive exchange of views with leaders of developed and developing nations. I hope that I speak for the many other world leaders there in saying that Cancun was a substantial success. The spirit of this conference, as the co-chairman described it, was extremely constructive and positive. The exchange was direct, frank, wide-ranging and free of recrimination. We dealt with hard issues and yet succeeded in finding many areas of shared priorities and of common ground. The fact that we could succeed demonstrates the possibility for a more fruitful dialogue conducted with candor and mutual respect.

title: SEVENTEEN YEARS IN KOLYMA
description: GRAPHITE By Varlam Shalamov. Translated by John Glad. 287 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $14.95.

title: SALAZAR GOES FOR RECORD
description: On the eve of the 12th New York City Marathon, Gary Fanelli donned his all-black Elwood Blues outfit and sunglasses, pulled out his harmonica and sang his rendition of what 16,000 other runners were thinking yesterday. I woke up this morning, What did I see; New York City, Staring at me. I said wait a minute, What am I doing here; Then I remembered, It's that time of year.

title: POLL FINDS IT'S STILL A KEAN-FLORIO TOSS-UP
description: NEW JERSEY residents see a difference between the problems at the national and state levels, and perceive differently the ability of the representatives of the two major political parties to handle those problems, according to a New York Times survey completed last week.

title: Representation For the People
description: The more things change, apparently, the more they remain the same. Ten years ago, an independent Democrat, Allard Lowenstein, lost his seat in Congress through the gerrymandering of his district by the Nassau Republican machine.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS MEETING IN CANCUN WAS CONSTRUCTIVE
description: President Reagan said today that the meeting of 22 leaders of industrialized and developing nations had been ''extremely constructive and positive.''

title: The World in Summary; Center-Right Loses in Galicia
description: Spanish Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo's center-right party wasn't right enough last week, at least in traditionally conservative Galicia. Electing their first home-rule parliament, voters in the poor northwestern region that produced Francisco Franco gave the Government party a shock.

title: EGYPT REPORTS ARRESTS OF 350 MOSLEM 'TERRORISTS'
description: Egyptian security units have arrested more than 350 Moslem ''terrorists'' belonging to the organzation that is believed responsible for the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat, the semi-official newspaper Al Ahram reported today.

title: WASHINGTON ON TWO WHEELS
description: FRANCIS X. CLINES is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. By FRANCIS X. CLINES

title: Frances Delinko Engaged
description: The engagement of Frances Amy Delinko to Charles Benjamin Ganz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Ganz of North Miami Beach, Fla., has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Delinko of Harrisburg, Pa. A May wedding is planned.

title: 2 SEIZED IN RAPE AND ROBBERY OF HARLEM NUN
description: Two men were arrested yesterday and charged with the rape, robbery and repeated slashing of an East Harlem nun earlier this month. A 22-year-old man was seized in Chicago early in the morning and a 23-year-old man was arrested in East Harlem 12 hours later, the police said.

title: COURT BACKS THE LEASING OF A STATE LAND TRACT TO MOHAWKS
description: New York State's highest court has upheld the legality of a lease of state land in the northern part of the state to a group of Mohawk Indians as part of an agreement that removed the Indians from nearby land they called their ancestral home.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Electric Phoenix, Quintet From England
description: A quintet of English musicians named Electric Phoenix stopped off Wednesday evening at the Symphony Space as part of a North American tour. Electric Phoenix's four singers divide into the traditional soprano, alto, tenor and bass; but John Whiting, as sound technician and electronic manipulator, is so busily creative at his board of switches and dials that he, too, becomes an active part of the music.

title: Georgetown's Gregorek Takes Cross-Country
description: John Gregorek of Georgetown outsprinted Geoff Smith of Providence, a British Olympian, and regained the Big East Conference cross-country title today at Franklin Park.

title: JACKSON HOMERS, MUFFS FLY
description: In a tumultuous three and one-half hours filled with 10 pitchers, 27 hits and 15 runs, the Los Angeles Dodgers rallied in the late innings today to defeat the New York Yankees, 8-7, and tie the World Series at two games apiece.

title: Janice Ellen Weiss a Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Weiss of River Edge, N.J. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janice Ellen Weiss, to Harvey Egna, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Egna of Bergenfield, N.J. Miss Weiss is a junior at Barnard College and Mr. Egna is completing studies for a master's degree in business administration at Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: Supply-Side
description: To the Business Editor: Carl Alan Batlin's analysis in ''Those Tax Cuts Could Miss the Target'' (Oct. 4), seems seriously flawed. He argues that since the reduction in the tax rates increases the after-tax rate of return for all securities, regardless of risk, ''safe securities are now relatively more attractive than risky ones, because investors can now earn the same expected return as before but without bearing as much risk.''

title: The World in Summary; Pursuing Peace In the Sinai
description: Dropping by last week to celebrate the 200th anniversary of Franco-American victory at Yorktown, French President Francois Mitterrand promised new French military assistance - numerically small but politically important. France agreed to send a contingent to the 2,500-member United States-sponsored military force that will patrol the Sinai next year after Israel pulls out.

title: LOSERS ADD TO MISTAKES
description: Rich Gossage candidly and succinctly summed up the Yankees' performance in the fourth game of the World Series today.

title: Iowa State 17, Colorado 10
description: Dwayne Crutchfield rushed for 168 yards and two touchdowns and broke his school record by carrying the ball 47 times. He scored on two 1-yard runs to increase his season touchdown total to 15, tying the Iowa State record. Alex Giffords added a 20-yard field goal for the Cyclones, who sent their record to 5-1-1 over all and 2-0-1 in the Big Eight.

title: NOTEBOOK: 3 CRITICISMS FOR EDITORS
description: Over the last three days, the editors in United States newspapers have been berated by, among others, Canadians, the New Right and critics of the news media.

title: JOHN CECIL HOLM, 76, ACTOR AND CO-AUTHOR OF RACE TRACK FARCE
description: John Cecil Holm, an actor and playwright best remembered as the co-author of the Broadway comedy hit, ''Three Men On a Horse,'' died yesterday at the Westerly Hospital in Rhode Island. He was 76 years old and lived in Westerly and Stonington, Conn.

title: Wyoming 33, B.Y.U. 20
description: Phil Davis, a senior quarterback, ran for three touchdowns and passed 81 yards to James Williams for another score as Wyoming upset Brigham Young in a Western Athletic Conference game played in a snowstorm.

title: A.C.L.U. MANUAL CITES POLICE OFFICER'S RIGHTS
description: The American Civil Liberties Union, sometimes criticized as too favorable to defendants and even as against the police, is publishing a handbook on ''The Rights of Police Officers.''

title: Future Events Books and Banks
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated: All for the Public Library Oct. 27 - Strollers may sip aquavit and nibble on Scandinavian cheeses and black caviar as they listen to a string ensemble playing Edvard Grieg selections, all while viewing, ''Edvard Munch: Paradox of Woman,'' an exhibition of 50 prints by the Norwegian artist at the Aldis Browne Fine Arts Gallery at 1018 Madison Avenue. A cocktail reception, to benefit the New York Public Library's Print Room, will begin at 5 P.M. Admission, $50, includes an open bar. The exhibition, mounted from the Epstein Collection, on view until Dec. 5. Tickets, $2. Call 593-3560.

title: 3 Leftist Guerrillas in Italy Get Life Terms in Police Deaths
description: Three leading members of the farleft guerrilla group Front Line were given life sentences today in the killing of two policemen after a bank robbery here last year, judicial officials said. A fourth guerrilla was sentenced to 13 years.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Helen Bowkun, Pianist, Plays Bach, Beethoven
description: Helen Bowkun, a Canadian pianist with a firm technique and promising musical instincts, played Bach, Beethoven, Chopin and Rachmaninoff on Thursday night at the Abraham Goodman House. Miss Bowkun made a real success of Bach's English Suite No. 3.

title: Photography View; THE INCREDIBLE COMMONPLACE
description: In Joel Sternfeld's provocative and frequently marvelous color photographs at Daniel Wolf Gallery (30 West 57th Street through Saturday), things seem to have gone awry in the relations between man and the rest of the natural world. In a picture called ''After a Flash Flood, Rancho Mirage, Ca.,'' an automobile lies belly-up in mud halfway down a freshly cut escarpment, while above it a nondescript bungalow teeters on the edge of destruction. In ''After a Tornado, Grand Island, Nebraska,'' a brick wall and an open refrigerator are all that remain of a house; next to them stands a tree devoid of limbs. Like insurance policies, these pictures suggest that the acts of God are not particularly friendly. ''McLean, Virginia,'' the most entertaining and unlikely picture of the exhibition, shows a fireman picking out a pumpkin at a farm market while behind him a house is in the process of being consumed by flames.

title: YOUTH KILLED AT MADISON AND 42D IN GUNMAN'S 15-MINUTE RAMPAGE
description: A gunman went on a 15-minute, two-block rampage down Madison Avenue yesterday morning for no apparent reason, shooting out windows of a passing automobile and killing a 17-year-old high school student from Westbury, L.I.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: GHOSTS and volunteer carpenters are stalking the Wildcliff Museum overlooking Long Island Sound in New Rochelle as Halloween approaches. The gray stone mansion, built in 1865 in the Hudson River Gothic style, is closed. On the padlocked gate, a white sign reading ''Reopens end of September'' swings in the October breeze.

title: SUCCESS STORY
description: THE KING OF FIFTH AVENUE The Fortunes of August Belmont.By David Black. Illustrated. 804 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $24.95.

title: Pregnant Women Cautioned On Use of the Pritiken Diet
description: The low-fat, high-fiber Pritikin diet may be unsuitable for pregnant women and others of child-bearing age because of evidence that it leads to reduced resistance to infection and poor healing of wounds, researchers say.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
description: The Atget Collection I had the privilege of knowing Julien Levy before his death this past year, and the story he told me about acquiring the Atget collection (''Atget,'' by John Russell, Sept. 13) is this: Mr. Levy had visited Eugene Atget's apartment-studio (the bathroom was the darkroom) several times in 1927, the last year of Atget's life. Atget was a virtual unknown then and sold his prints for roughly 40 cents each, of which Mr. Levy purchased many.

title: Stones of Many Uses, Colors and Prices
description: Stones of the nonrolling variety are the specialty at the Old Post Garden Center in Mount Kisco. The center's six-and-one-half acres contain top soil plus a series of pebble mounds, with flattened surrounding areas that simulate a patio or walk in each sort of stone.

title: Stage View; 'CANDIDA' AS A GAME, NOT A PLAY
description: It was apparent to me almost immediately that actor Ron Parady had decided to play - or had been instructed to play - the Reverend Morell in the Circle in the Square's production of ''Candida'' as though the Reverend Morell were a high-school athletic coach. Maybe junior high. There he was, backslapping everyone within reach, barking out go-get-'em jollities in the best peptalk tradition, planting one foot on the corner of a wicker chaise longue (quite treating his living-room as though it were a locker-room) as he gave man-to-man encouragement to his charges, including the women. I didn't honestly think, though, that he was really training the bunch of them to go for the pennant.

title: A NOUVELLE CUISINE WITH A CATALAN FLAIR
description: JAMES M. MARKHAM is chief of the Times bureau in Madrid. By JAMES M. MARKHAM

title: 'BLOOD WEDDING'
description: Of the three Spanish artists whose work is fused in ''Blood Wedding,'' Carlos Saura predominates. Mr. Saura, in filming Antonio Gades's dance interpretation of Federico Garcia Lorca's play, demonstrates an agility on a par with the dancers'. As his camera moves actively but unobtrusively, Mr. Saura captures both a sense of the dance as a performance and a feeling for its abstract properties. His film is beautifully made, and it carries the added excitement of Lorca's drama and Mr. Gades's magnetism.

title: Essay; LAST GASP OF THE 1960'S
description: Crime buffs up North are thrilled and horrified by the running gun battles of political terrorists, the early investigations of whom caused the decade-long harassment of F.B.I. officials. Times have changed: the lawmen are once again the good guys, and we give as much encouragement to enforcing the law as to upholding the law. It took until the early 1980's to bring the 1960's to an end.

title: BOSSY BREAKS TIE, ISLANDERS WIN, 6-4
description: The Islanders rallied from a 2-0 firstperiod deficit and completed a home-and-home sweep of the Washington Capitals with a 6-4 victory at the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Susan Svercek, Pianist, In Schumann 'Carnaval'
description: The most successful performance in Susan Svercek's debut piano recital in Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night was of Ginastera's Sonata. Considering that Miss Svercek also played Schumann's ''Carnaval,'' Beethoven's Opus 110 Sonata and Mozart's Sonata in Bflat (K. 281), that says something about her weaknesses as well as her strengths.

title: New Jersey Guide; by Martha G. Wilson; BIRGIT'S BACK AND ...
description: When Birgit Nilsson and Placido Domingo sang Puccini's ''Turandot'' with the New Jersey State Opera in 1974, it was an immediate sellout, and the great Swedish soprano reportedly agreed to a return engagement.

title: Around the Nation; Jewish Congress Assails The 'Evangelical Right'
description: The ''evangelical right,'' such as Moral Majority, is using religion as an instrument of political coercion and its methods are divisive and destructive, the American Jewish Congress charged today.

title: HOW THE U.S. STRUCK OUT IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO VIEWED against the huge trade deficit the United States is running with Japan, expected to reach as much as $15 billion this year, the market for aluminum baseball bats in Japan is puny - roughly $15 million a year.

title: PATCHOGUE PAUSES ON RIVER'S FUTURE
description: PATCHOGUE ON Patchogue River, a milelong waterway that joins the Great South Bay at its mouth, marinas and oil terminals coexist with apartment buildings, ferry companies and wholesale clam dealers, creating an ecletic mixture of uses for a river that was largely a commercial port at the turn of the century.

title: MAINLY, IT'S EXPENSIVE IMPORTS THAT SELL
description: LIKE those of their domestic counterparts, sales of foreign cars are down this year in the United States, a situation that most industry analysts attribute to restrictions on Japanese imports and a generally worrisome economic picture.

title: H.N. Day to Wed Martha J. Bonsal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard I. Bonsal of Upper Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Jean Bonsal, to Henry Neal Day, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Day of Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: WHOSE SIDE IS BUSINESS ON, ANYWAY?
description: Sidney Blumenthal is the author of ''The Permanent Campaign'' and is currently writing a book on the economic and intellectual roots of Reaganism. By Sidney Blumenthal

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: SELECTING A TRAVEL AGENT
description: W hen talking travel, few subjects evoke greater sensitivity and controversy than those dealing with travel agents and the services they perform.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART Alternative spaces, those lively non-profit arenas where emerging artists do their thing, are celebrated in ''Downtown/Uptown,'' a sampler show at the City Gallery, 2 Columbus Circle. The show, organized by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council and nicely installed in the gallery's elegant confines (through Nov. 6), comprises contributions from no less than 17 alternative spaces in the city, each presenting the work of individual artists or groups associated with them.

title: SUSPECT IN LIBYAN'S SHOOTING IS TRACED TO FARM IN ENGLAND
description: The man accused of attempting to assassinate a Libyan student in Colorado last year found sanctuary four months later at an isolated English farm owned by Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent who is now a fugitive in Libya, according to neighbors and local merchants in England.

title: Jennifer Knapp Fiancee of Singer
description: Prof. and Mrs. Charles L. Knapp of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Lynn Knapp, to Mark Christopher Beudert, son of Hubert J. Beudert of Birmingham, Mich., and the late Margery Beudert. A June wedding is planned.

title: IKE VS. ARMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Choice
description: BACHELORHOOD, by Philip Lopate. (Little, Brown & Company, $13.95.) Meditations on life and culture.

title: RIFTS MARK FRENCH SOCIALISTS' PARLEY
description: France's Socialist Party, which swept to undisputed power five months ago, is holding its national congress in an atmosphere of unexpected political challenge.

title: COMPOSTING LEAVES DOES A PILE OF GOOD
description: MANY of us remember when the most familiar fragrance of autumn was that of burning leaves. Even today, when that familiar odor is in the air, mental images of great piles of leaves burning on a cleared garden plot or in driveways come to mind.

title: Prospects
description: An Appetite for Debt

title: 4 Bombs Explode in Spain
description: Four bombs exploded outside public buildings in Barcelona and in the southeastern town of Alicante early today, causing some damage but no injuries, the police said. No one claimed responsibility for the blasts.

title: Speaking Personally; A TRULY SPECIAL AND BEWITCHING NIGHT
description: THAT first Halloween in suburbia took us by surprise. Oh, we had a basket of goodies ready by the front door. It was the last-minute offer of a neighbor to include our 3-year-old in her family's ''trick or treating'' that found us unprepared.

title: COMPUTERS STEER 'CUSTOM' CAR ASSEMBLY
description: year-old chemist from Paterson came in looking for the car of her dreams.

title: Harvard Ties Princeton
description: Bill McGlone and Jim Acheson scored fourth-quarter touchdowns, and Harvard, led by a 190-yard rushing effort by Jim Callinan, rallied to force a 17-17 tie with Princeton today.

title: Placing Personages In Their Proper Homes
description: The recent article about Bellport (''Idyllic Bellport 'Discovered' All Over Again'') stated erroneously that Bell House, on Bellport Lane, had been the home of Capt. Thomas Bell, founder of Bellport. He never lived there.

title: WESTCHESTER RACE BECOMES A FORM OF TRENCH WARFARE
description: When Alfred B. DelBello was narrowly elected Westchester's first Democratic County Executive in 1973, he took over what he acknowledged was the ''stable government'' of his Republican predecessor, Edwin G. Michaelian, who was retiring.

title: Music View; SNORKELING FOR OPERATIC TREASURES
description: At some point in their listening careers, most opera enthusiasts come across the startling fact that what they know of this 380-yearold art is comparable to what you could discover about the oceanic depths by examining whitecaps through a telescope. At that moment of revelation the fainthearted often decide to accept the fiction, promoted by our leading houses, that the viable repertory consists of about two dozen masterworks, mostly by Mozart, Wagner, Verdi and Puccini. An intrepid few choose to go snorkeling in search of sunken treasures, however, and they are never happier than when they can surface and report to their fellow adventurers that they have just found, perhaps in a church basement in Turtle Bay or a warehouse in Newark, a pickup performance of Adalbert Gyrowetz's ''Hans Sachs'' or Alexander Dargomyzhsky's ''Stone Guest.'' Don't bother notifying them that the former subject was later treated more successfully by Wagner or that the Don Juan legend was handled adequately by Mozart long before Dargomyzhsky was born. True opera maniacs not only know the best that the art has to offer; at times, they seem actually eager to know the worst.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: AMERICAN DREAMS: Lost and Found, by Studs Terkel. (Ballantine, $3.50.) During 20 years of travel around the country, Studs Terkel tape-recorded conversations he had with 100 Americans - as diverse as a Miss U.S.A., a folk singer and an elegant escapee from suburbia - about their personal aspirations and disappointments. Our reviewer Robert Sherrill found the ''scrappiness and sheer gall'' they revealed in this deftly edited collection most heartening.

title: EARL WILD'S 'DEFIANTLY KITSCH' CELEBRATION
description: Aweek from today Earl Wild will be observing the 50th anniversary of his Carnegie Hall debut with, of course, another Carnegie Hall recital. This recital that has a program of a type that might - just might -have been duplicated 80 years ago. It certainly could not have been given 20 years ago. Programs with dated examples of high salon Romanticism would have been hooted off the stage during those severe days before the Romantic Revival, when the approved kind of program had nothing but the last three Schubert sonatas, or the ''Hammerklavier'' and ''Diabelli,'' or the ''Goldberg'' Variations at slow tempos with all repeats.

title: Fiona Harris Wed to Geoffrey Lubbock
description: Fiona Constance Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Homer Eugene Harris of Beckley, W. Va., was married at the Congregational Church in Topsfield, Mass., yesterday to Geoffrey Orr Lubbock, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Miles Lubbock of Brechin, Scotland, and grandson of the late Lord Boyd Orr, the first director of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization and winner of the 1949 Nobel Peace Prize. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Leonard Kohlhofer and the Rev. Karl Phillippi.

title: AMERICA'S FISSURING ALLIANCE
description: Superficially, relations between the United States and its European allies are not at all bad. It is business-as-usual when ministers and generals meet. But below the surface, a drift continues that, if unchecked, will lead to a breakdown of the alliance and to a ''fortress America'' mentality.

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; It's One Way to Stop Inflation
description: The air has been going out of the airbag rule for a while. Last week came the final collapse. The regulation, which would have required installation of the air cushion or other automatic crash protections in cars next year, was revoked by the Reagan Administration on the grounds that it was both costly and ineffective.

title: Art; THE PRIVATE BERNINI GOES PUBLIC IN PRINCETON SHOW
description: PRINCETON GIANLORENZO BERNINI was one of the greatest artistic geniuses of all time. Whether the 17th-century Italian artist turned his vision to sculpture, architecture, artifacts like andirons or follies like fireworks, he created a consummate work of art.

title: Tricia Roth Sets Wedding in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jules Roth of Rye, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Suzanne Roth, to Nicholas Tetrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril E. Tetrick of Kokomo, Ind. The wedding has been planned for next May.

title: Major News in Summary; Reagan Goes Only So Far At Cancun
description: The economic hopes and fears of governments and their peoples on both sides of the world's Great Divide between rich and poor, were the main order of business last week as President Reagan met at Cancun, Mexico, with leaders of 14 developing countries and seven industrialized nations.

title: EVERY DODGER A HERO TO JUBLIANT LASORDA
description: Tommy Lasorda, an irrepressible cheerleader under the worst of circumstances, could barely contain himself after the Dodgers evened the World Series at two games apiece today.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I Remember Papa Patrick McDonnell

title: Boooklet Is Aided By Many Groups
description: We enjoyed Betsy Brown's story (''A Campaign to Keep Racial Balance,'' Oct. 4) describing efforts to keep racial balance in White Plains's integrated neighborhoods. The booklet she mentioned, ''White Plains, N.Y., a Great Place to Live,'' is a joint publication of the League of Women Voters of White Plains and the Housing Information Service.

title: Lafayette 28, Gettysburg 14
description: A sophomore fullback, Craig Wiliams scored four touchdowns, three in the second half, to lead Lafayette to a come-from-behind victory.

title: HOW CAMPAIGNS DIFFER
description: THE race for Governor is a good demonstration of the difference between a primary and general election in New Jersey. In the primary, the candidate's objective is to separate himself or herself from the pack. In the general election, the idea is to get as close to the middle of the road, and therefore to the opposition, as possible.

title: The New York Times Magazine; Part/2 Sunday October 25, 1981; HOME ENTERTAINING
description: EDITOR Edward Klein SENIOR EDITOR Carrie Donovan CONSULTANT Marilyn Kaytor ART DIRECTOR Michael Todd COPY EDITOR Alison MacFarlane REPORTER Melanie Fleischmann OPERATIONS Ann M. Schumacher MAKE UP Charles Conway 15 THE AMERICAN WAY OF ENTERTAINING By Mimi Sheraton. The freewheeling American spirit carries over to entertaining at home.

title: 4 CHALLENGERS TILT AT BROOKLYN PRESIDENT
description: A majority of Brooklyn voters are too young to remember when the office of Borough President was held by anyone other than a Democrat, but the other political parties' lack of success has not deterred them from placing four candidates on the Nov. 3 ballot in an effort to depose Howard Golden, the incumbent.

title: NEW ENGINES ARE MANY--BETTER ONES ARE FEW
description: A week ago yesterday, a convoy of 38 cars, trucks and other vehicular creations, some of them resembling science fiction dreams come true, set out from Los Angeles on a cross-country drive dubbed the Future Fuels Challenge Rally. The majority relied on ethanol or methanol, forms of alcohol that can be produced from coal and a variety of plants, in their quest for the $25,000 grand prize to be awarded to the most fuel efficient entrant. Others turned to wood, electricity, hydrogen and vegetable oils.

title: Isabel S. Pearce Is Engaged to Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Edward Pearce Jr. of Wilmington, Del., and Spring Lake, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Isabel Sexton Pearce, to Henry Alfred DePhillips 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. DePhillips Jr. of Wethersfield, Conn.

title: THE CLOUD OVER LAKER AIR
description: Atlantic flights. He is promoting his new ''Regency'' firstclass air fare for business travel, which costs a whopping $526 oneway, $322 more than the standby tourist fare that made his name a household word.

title: Children's Books
description: THE GATHERING ROOM By Colby Rodowsky. 186 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $9.95. (Ages 10 to 14) By JANE LANGTON

title: Paperback Best Sellers; October 25, 1981; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 COME POUR THE WINE, by Cynthia Freeman. (Bantam, $3.95.) A women'sl ong journey to self-discovery: fiction. 2 THE SIMPLE SOLUTION TO RUBIK'S CUBE, by James G, Nourse. (Bantam, $ 1.95.) Instructions for solving that puzzle. 3 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) Espionagei n Cairo in 1942: fiction. 4 THE SECOND LADY, by Irving Wallace. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) An A merican President's wife is kidnapped in Moscow: fiction. 5 THE RING, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.50.) German-American familys aga. 6 SOLO, by Jack Higgins. (Dell, $2.95.) Thriller about a famous c oncert pianist who secretly is an international hit man: fiction. 7 THE HIDDEN TARGET, by Helen MacInnes.

title: Musica Sacra to Open With Diamond 'Cantata'
description: Musica Sacra and its director, Richard Westenburg, will present David Diamond's ''A Secular Cantata'' in its season's opener Nov. 4 in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Mr. Koch and Other City Choices
description: The day when New York City elections are mostly decided by general election rather than Democratic primary is no nearer now that the Republicans don't even have a separate candidate for Mayor. But there are some choices in next week's balloting and these are our recommendations: MAYOR

title: MRS. CODD'S VIEWS ON CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: Mary T. Codd, the Liberal Party candidate for Mayor, was asked by The New York Times for her views on major issues confronting the city. Following are excerpts from her reply on education. The views of the other major mayoral candidates were published earlier.

title: Long Islanders; HER MUSIC AND CATS ARE A PERFECT MIX
description: ''I'M an oddball case,'' said Jeanne Singer of Manhasset. ''You never think of women as composers. And getting around the world breeding Siamese cats is something people think is crazy.''

title: KANSAS 17, KANSAS STATE 14
description: Elvis Patterson intercepted a pass by Darrell Dickey and returned 18 yards, setting up Bruce Kallmeyer's 28-yard field goal with 1 minute 33 seconds left that gave Kansas the victory.

title: Stamford, Conn.
description: Price Waterhouse & Company has leased 23,000 square feet in the 73,500-square-foot office building under construction at 707 Summer Street in Stamford.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: Dartmouth 42, Cornell 7
description: Scott Maher broke loose on two 44-yard scoring runs and Dartmouth converted two blocked punts into touchdowns to keep the Big Green (3-3) unbeaten against Ivy League opponents.

title: DEFEAT OF PEANUT ALLOTMENT IRKS GEORGIA FARMERS
description: J.R. Odom angrily dug the toe of his brogan into the sandy loam of south Georgia, muttered a few unkind words about ''ignorant'' Congressmen and vowed this would be the last year he took a loss growing peanuts.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: Reading and Writing; THE LITERATURE OF DEATH
description: In the 1960's, books told us how to rescue our identities from their crises, how to ''realize'' ourselves, how to ramify our sexual behavior. In the 70's and 80's, there has been a wave of books telling us how to die. Our anxiety has advanced from incidentals to ultimates; in our impatience we have run through life and arrived at death, which would seem to be our ''accelerated grimace.''

title: WOMEN'S HEALTH FOCUS OF STUDY
description: WHY do some women develop health problems that others do not? To find answers, Yale University's School of Medicine and the State Departmment of Health Services are interviewing women between the ages of 20 and 54 who have been recently hospitalized.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; William Blount Gives Clarinet Program
description: There were signs of something out of the ordinary at the 92d Street Y last Sunday evening even before the music began - first, a crowd of people much larger than the usual debut audience and, second, a high incidence of professional musicians among them.

title: Holy Cross 34, Brown 24
description: Mark Covington scored three times on short runs to lead Holy Cross. Brown, suffering its fifth loss in six starts, spotted the Crusaders a 20-0 lead in the first quarter on a 35-yard interception return by Doug O'Donnell and touchdown runs of 1 and 2 yards by Covington.

title: WITH WHICH WE SERVE
description: In most American households these days, the host or hostess, the cook, the butler and the scullery maid are all one and the same person. So, when it comes to entertaining at home, that one person invites the guests, buys the food and, on the evening of the dinner, plunges into the kitchen, fully intending to emerge with a meal before the guests arrive.

title: Veteran Looks Back and Ahead
