description: EACH year at the time of the New York City Marathon, a chronology will appear that starts with 1970 and the first New York race. It lists 126 starters and a lone female entrant. She did not finish.

title: Dining Out; A GREENING TAKES FORM IN PELHAM
description: ATRANSFORMATION has taken place on Wolfs Lane in Pelham. What used to be a long, dark catacomb of a place metamorphosed last August into Park Place, and its greening has resulted in a promising, though uneven, new restaurant. Although too long a barroom still serves as entranceway, it now opens into a cheery latticed dining room brightened by fresh flowers, large nature photographs and multiple shades of green on walls, ceiling and tables. If the same attention to detail that produced such a congenial dining space were invested in the functions of the kitchen, Park Place might emerge as a satisfying restaurant, indeed.

title: Dance View; NOTES ON POST-MODERNISM
description: If the 1960's dance avant-garde was marked by rule-breaking, the 1980's promise an era of rule-making. Or so one assumes after the back-to-back display of experimental works at the New Dance USA Festival just organized by the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis. Somewhere in the 1970's, as this survey indicated, a new series of closed systems managed to replace the free-wheeling, liberated probing of old dance definitions - to replace the undefined itself. Whereas nondancers or dancers pretending to be nondancers in their natural state were common currency 20 years ago, we now have the potential - and already the reality - of a highly systematized dance and the equally systematized dancer.

title: AMONG THE MING URNS
description: SPRING MOON By Bette Bao Lord. 464 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95

title: WARDE STOPS STAPLES BY 20-0
description: The questions concerning the validity of Warde's unbeaten record after five weeks of play were answered yesterday as the Fairfield school defeated previously undefeated Staples, 20-0, in Westport.

title: Vail Juhring Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Vail Bryant Juhring, daughter of Mrs. Brooks Juhring of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N. Y., and the late John C. Juhring to Peter Connor of East Grinstead, Sussex, England, has been announced by the future bride's mother. Mr. Connor is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Connor of Redditch, Worcestershire, England. The bride-to-be's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did Mr. Connor's.

title: Another World Below
description: There are flowers of rock, pearls of stone, sparkling waterfalls and rushing rivers. There are rainbows of dancing light, dripping forests of stalactites hanging from the roof and conical stalagmites that rise from the floor.

title: Florida State 38, L.S.U. 14
description: Rick Stockstill threw two touchdowns passes and Greg Allen, a freshman tailback, ran for a school-record 202 yards and one touchdown for Louisiana State.

title: BYRD PICKS UP THE TUNE IN A MINOR KEY
description: Some of his fellow Democrats were perplexed. Why, they asked Senator Robert C. Byrd a few days ago at a policy luncheon, shouldn't the proposed sale of five Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia be regarded as a party issue? Less than a handful of Senate Democrats supported the sale, they pointed out, and President Reagan's prestige and that of the Senate Republican leadership were at stake.

title: Augustyniak: Jets' Unlikely Fullback
description: Mike Augustyniak is the fullback and Bruce Harper is the halfback -the no-frills backfield of the National Football League. When they take the field against the Seattle Seahawks at Shea Stadium today at 4 P.M., they will form the only free-agent tandem of starting backs in the league. Yet the Jets have produced the American Conference's third-leading rushing attack.

title: Dining Out; A SLIGHT GAP ALONG THE DELAWARE
description: SAYRE'S, a restaurant overlooking the scenic Delaware Water Gap, is far removed from the cozy country inn that one might expect to find in such a spot. Our first erroneous impression was of a converted church. The solid-looking building is made of stone, and the oddly shaped dining room inside has a cathedral ceiling and alcoves. One of the alcoves resembles a gussied-up version of the small iron-gated private chapels in Paris's Notre Dame Cathedral.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Everybody knows the Joffrey Ballet but apparently not everyone knows that the company's current run at the City Center 55th Street Theater is its only season in the city. Unable to come back with the spring engagement season it could afford in the past, the Joffrey is to be treasured while we have it for the next four weeks.

title: Sports of The Times; The World Series' Other Owner
description: ONCE he was known as Walter O'Malley's son, but now Peter O'Malley has his own identity - the president of the Dodgers, the antithesis of George Steinbrenner.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Lawsuit Seeks to Oust Innis as CORE Leader
description: A lawsuit seeking to have Waverly Yates declared the chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality instead of Roy Innis, national chairman of the organization, has been filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN VIENNA
description: PAUL HOFMANN, a former Times correspondent, lives in Europe. By PAUL HOFMANN

title: Big Publisher
description: To the Business Editor: I would like to correct a statement about Nat Wartels in ''Tight Grip on a Rich Empire'' (Oct. 18). I was a Crown employee from September 1978 to August 1980, and during that time saw a lot of Nat and Crown.

title: AN OPERA THAT CAPTURES THE SOUL OF GERMANY
description: Carl Maria von Weber's ''Der Freischutz,'' which the New York City Opera will present in a new production this evening, may count as only a parochial national favorite. But the nation in question is Germany, which is not exactly on the periphery of the classical music mainstream. Furthermore, the opera once enjoyed an enormous international vogue, which makes its current obscurity on the international stage all the more puzzling. Even today, when it is occasionally revived outside of Germany, it pleases people.

title: Jane Gumley Married To Peter Lee Janiak
description: The marriage of Jane Ellen Gumley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Gumley of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Peter Lee Janiak, son of Theodore Janiak of Framingham, Mass., and the late Mrs. Janiak, took place yesterday at the Community Unitarian Church in White Plains.

title: Arizona State 62 Stanford 36
description: Mike Pagel passed for a Pacific-10 Conference record of seven touchdowns and set records for passing yardage and total offense to lead Arizona State.

title: Reagan Urged to Form A U.S. Peace Academy
description: A nine-member commission headed by Senator Spark M. Matsunaga, Democrat of Hawaii, has formally presented to President Reagan and Congress a proposal to establish a national peace academy to train Americans in ''conflict-resolution skills.''

title: TO STAY ABLOOM, FLOWER GROWERS LOOK OVERSEAS
description: CENTER MORICHES LONG ISLAND's flower growers are busy these days adopting the floriculture techniques that have revolutionized flower production in other areas of the nation and the world. They're using new insulation and heating methods - including coal-burning boilers - for glass greenhouses or converting to the use of portable, polyethylene greenhouses in an effort to remain competitive with domestic and international growers. One Long Island grower has even opened a nursery overseas.

title: MARGARET MCDAID BETROTHED
description: Mrs. Charles J. McDaid of Lynbrook, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Margaret Mary McDaid, to Lieut. (jg.) Harold Blaine Miller, U.S.N.R., son of Rear Adm. Harold Blaine Miller, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Miller of Manhasset, L.I.

title: North Stars 6, Kings 3
description: Bobby Smith and Steve Payne scored goals 17 seconds apart in the second period, and Neal Broten had two third-period goals to pace Minnesota.

title: Adirondacks
description: To the Editor:

title: About Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS ASHAFT of sunlight falls on the green felt of a craps table, reflects off a nearby marbelized wall mirror. Through the secondfloor window come the sounds of midday Mamaroneck Avenue traffic. A young man in a gray three-piece suit, an earnest expression on his face, picks up a craps stick. ''Seven on seven, nine's away, don't pay,'' he intones in a slightly insecure voice, like a carnival barker still learning his pitch. ''Last come, get some and point with nine.''

title: IN PAKISTAN, GRAVEL WORKS IMPERIL RELICS
description: Within a shard's throw of some of the oldest and best preserved archeological sites in South Asia, gravel-making machines are chewing up hillsides that provide relics going back 5,000 years.

title: Cindy Helfer to Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Allen R. Helfer of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagment of their daughter, Cindy Renee Helfer, to Bruce Evan Miller, son of Sylvia Zepnick of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Shephard S. Miller. A June wedding is planned in Stamford.

title: AFTER THE PARTY, AN OLD HOUSE HUMS TO A BYGONE TUNE
description: THE last party guests are leaving. Light laughter and embraces touch us like floating raiment. ''Good night! Good night!'' They meander past the garden lights up to the gate. Arms raised in farewell, they turn and melt wraithlike into the goblin gloom of the October night.

title: BUSINESS SAID TO GAIN BY SEEKING COMPLAINTS
description: Companies that encourage their customers to complain about poor service and faulty products make more profits in the long run, says a study released yesterday.

title: A WALLINGFORD INN'S WINE CELLAR GETS A TOAST
description: WALLINGFORD ''WE'RE an American restaurant,'' said Robert A. Meyer, the owner or, as he puts it, ''innkeeper'' of the Yankee Silversmith Inn here. ''It's the responsibility of an American restaurant to expose guests to what is available in the way of American wine.''

title: THE FONZIE OF LITERATURE
description: From time to time The Book Review has invited both new and established writers to comment on various aspects of their craft: their imaginative and autobiographical sources, their practices of composition, the origin of their sense of vocation. These essays are intended to provide a forum for writers to consider the rewards and perils of their craft.

title: TO A MOTHER, CHILD-REARING IS ABOUT CHOICE AND FREEDOM
description: The author of the following article, who lives on the South Shore, has asked to remain anonymous.

title: ADVICE ON SHOPPING
description: SUZANNE SLESIN is assistant editor of the Home Section of The Times. By SUZANNE SLESIN

title: MORE WOMEN SEEK DIVORCES IN EQUITABLE SETTLEMENT LAW
description: MORE Long Island women have been filing for divorce since the inception of the state's equitable distribution law in July 1980, according to lawyers interviewed on the Island who specialize in divorce cases.

title: HALLOWEEN DOINGS
description: A departure from the usual seasonal celebrations is the Artists and Doctors Ball, a Halloween costume party to be held at 8:30 P.M. next Sunday at Real Art Ways, 40 State Street, Hartford. The idea is that ''artists need patrons and doctors need patients'' and an avant-garde arts center is ''the place for them to mix drinks, metaphors and messages,'' according to R.A.W. publicity.

title: ANN V.R. HALSEY IS PLANNING BRIDAD
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Van R. Halsey of Locust, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Van Rensselaer Halsey, to Eric Templeton Davis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hamilton S. Davis of Davis, Calif. A wedding planned for Dec. 31 in Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: PEKING: NEITHER SHAKY NOR PRO-WASHINGTON
description: To the Editor:

title: IVORY'S 'QUARTET,' BASED ON RHYS NOVEL
description: The place is Paris in the pre-Depression 1920's, when World War II is scarcely a decade in the future and American and English expatriates, especially those with fixed incomes or even no incomes at all, live better and more flamboyantly in Paris, particularly in Montparnasse, than in the tediously genteel societies they have fled.

title: Texan Challenging Bentsen
description: Representative James M. Collins, Republican of Texas, announced today that he would seek to unseat Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic incumbent, in 1982. Mr. Collins, who has fought busing and campaigned to cut government spending, promised to give the state the ''strong conservative leadership it deserves.''

title: Critics' Choices
description: THEATER The Ensemble Studio Theater on West 52nd Street is beginning its tenth season on Tuesday with a reprise of four outstanding plays from last spring's one-act festival. The highlight of ''The Best of the Marathon'' is Shirley Lauro's ''Open Admissions,'' an explosive confrontation between a rule-bound teacher and a demanding black student.

title: LOVE AND DUTY
description: AN INDECENT OBSESSION By Colleen McCullough. 317 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.50.

title: C.R. Cooke Weds Lesley E. Graham
description: Lesley Ellen Graham, daughter of Lieut. Col. Jones R. Graham, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Graham of Florence, Ala., was married there yesterday to Christopher Robert Cooke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Cooke of Allenhurst, N.J., and New York.

title: Art View; THE RETURN OF THE REALISTS- AND A NEW BATTLE SHAPING UP; PHILADELPHIA
description: It looks as if 1981 is going to go down as the year of the Realist blitz. Not since the 1930's has Realist art - the kind of painting, drawing and sculpture that appears to give us an accurate and unembellished account of what we see in the world around us - enjoyed such widespread exposure and esteem. Long regarded in avantgarde circles as the exclusive terrain of academics and old fogeys, on the one hand, or of political and commercial hacks, on the other, Realism has lately acquired a new prestige and a new visibility on the international art scene. Young artists now flock to its swelling ranks, which are already well-populated with defectors from abstraction and other well-established modes of modernist art, and museums and galleries are hastening to adjust to what amounts to a major turnabout in the course of contemporary taste.

title: Temple 24, Cincinnati 13
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - Jim Brown rushed for 172 yards on 22 carries and scored three touchdowns, one on a 55-yard run, to lead Temple (5-2) to its third straight victory. The loss ended a three-game winning streak for Cincinnati (3-4).

title: Chicago's Fire Dept. Is Sued In Dispute Over Free Speech
description: The Chicago Fire Department was accused, in a lawsuit filed yesterday, of violating firemen's rights to free speech by ordering them not to talk to reporters without official approval.

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; Bob & Carol, Ted & Alice & So On
description: The Census Bureau released its annual ''Marital Status and Living Arrangement'' report last week and confirmed what many Americans already knew, namely that the family unit is enduring an unprecedented set of changes. But enduring none-the-less.

title: A MAN OF HIS WORDS
description: BORGES: A READER A Selection From the Writings of Jorge Luis Borges. Edited by Emir Rodriguez Monegal and Alastair Reid. 369 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. Cloth, $16.50. Paper, $10.

title: BAN ON FISHING FOR STRIPED BASS IS REAFFIRMED
description: A ban on commercial fishing for striped bass in the Hudson River has been reaffirmed by the State Department of Environmental Conservation because of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, in the fish.

title: Bombs Are Exploded in Rome At 2 Latin American Offices
description: Bombs exploded today in an Argentine Government commercial office and outside the Guatemalan mission to the Vatican, the police said.

title: Avenue of the Americas
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society has leased 20,000 square feet of office space on the 19th and 20th floors at 1350 Avenue of the Americas.

title: Miss Wehmann Bride Of Michael K. Magness
description: Carolyn Marie Wehmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmett F. Wehmann of Greenwood, S.C., was married yesterday in Grace Episcopal Church in Manhattan to Michael K. Magness, son of Carolyn Magness of Youngstown, Ohio, and Kenneth Magness of Vandergrift, Pa. The Rev. Paul F.M. Zahl performed the ceremony.

title: Recordings; 'LOS INDIOS' OPEN A NEW CHAPTER IN A FAMILY SAGA
description: ''Beautiful Sounds,'' a recently released RCA album by the guitar team Los Indios Tabajaras, lives up to its name, with renditions of such songs as ''Send in the Clowns,'' ''New York, New York'' and ''I'm Getting Sentimental Over You.'' If the songs themselves are conventional, the background of the artists is anything but.

title: Film View; THE PLEASURES OF 'BODY HEAT'
description: With ''Body Heat,'' the steamiest, most thoroughly satisfying melodrama about love, lust and greed to be seen since Billy Wilder's ''Double Indemnity'' and Tay Garnett's ''The Postman Always Rings Twice'' (forget about this year's lethargic remake), Lawrence Kasdan, heretofore known as a screenwriter (''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' ''Continental Divide''), suddenly emerges as a member of the American directing elite.

title: EX-HUSBAND OF MRS. JENSEN SAYS HE PAID FOR HER CO-OP
description: The Manhattan apartment that fugitive Katherine Boudin shared with a newspaper reporter was purchased about four years ago by the reporter's former husband, who said he visited the two women on several occasions.

title: Houston 20, Arkansas 17
description: The barefoot kicker Mike Clendenen booted a 17-yard fourth quarter field goal that capped a rally from a 10-point deficit and gave Houston its upset victory.

title: Yvor Winters
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR PLANTS WILL NOT MEET A DEADLINE ON SAFETY CHANGES
description: At least five of the 12 nuclear reactors in the New York area and many others around the country will miss a Federal deadline next summer for safety improvements to electrical equipment needed to keep the core cool in case of accident, according to the reactor operators.

title: October 25, 1981
description: This Week FICTION Last Week Weeks on t he List 1 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. 1 6 (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $25.50.) Life with the Berrys, an eccentric family that sets up house in unlikely hotels, here and abroad. 2 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) 2 11 Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 3 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Collen 2 1 McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 4 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delcorte, 5 25 $19.95.) British and Chines businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 5 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders, 4 13 (Putnam, $13.95.) Chief of Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York. 6 THE CARDINAL SINS, by Andrew M. 3 18 Greeley. (Warner/Bernard Geis, $12.95.) The triumphs and tragedies of two Chicago boys as priests in the Catholic Church. 7 THE LEGACY, by Howard Fast. (Houghton 3 3 Mifflin, $14.95.) The Lavette family of "The Immigrants" and "The Establishment" reaches the turbulent 60's. 8 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. 7 29 (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents.

title: B.C. BRUCKMANN TO WED JANICE M. ROGERS NOV. 21
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bart M. Rogers of Monmouth Beach, N.J., and Bal Harbour, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mr. Rogers's daughter, Janice Marie Rogers, to Bruce Cameron Bruckmann, son of Mrs. Bronson Lyon of Lake Forest, Ill., and the late William Arthur Bruckmann Jr. of Rumson, N.J.

title: ADULT ONLY ENCLAVES FIND WIDER MARKET
description: Else Sandom, who lives in Oronoque Village in Stratford, Conn., said she purchased a home in an age-restricted condominium because, at the age of 56, ''I didn't want to have skateboards to fall over any more.''

title: Nancy Leffler Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Leffler have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ellen Leffler, to Evan Neal Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Berman. Both families are of New York. A Jan. 9 wedding is planned.

title: PRETORIA RIGHTIST IS FIRM ON NAMIBIA
description: The leader of South Africa's extreme right, brushing aside an Afrikaner accusation that he is engaging in ''vulture politicking,'' has vowed to make it impossible for the National Party Government to reach an agreement on independence for South-West Africa.

title: Jean B. Douglass, Married in Jersey
description: Jean Bonner Douglass, daughter of Mrs. Edward Remington Nicholas Douglass of Lebanon, N.J., and the late Mr. Douglass, was married yesterday to Piers Michael MacDonald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. MacDonald of Bedford, N.Y.

title: 'EXHIBITION WATERCOLOR' AT CENTER FOR BRITISH ART
description: NEW HAVEN AN ancient medium, watercolor is swiftly used, its equipment easily transported. And, though the technique requires quick wits and a sure hand, its associations are with the fleeting impression rather than the heavily worked image - a legacy, perhaps, of its near monopoly by British landscapists of the early 19th century.

title: TRAILER HOMES WIN A STAY OF EVICTION
description: HACKENSACK TENANTS of a Fort Lee trailer park won an 18-month battle - at least temporarily -when a judge in Superior Court here granted them a stay of eviction Friday.

title: Business Conditions; SOFT SHOES
description: As more than 16,000 men and women start in today's 12th running of the New York City Marathon, analysts say the heady days of the late 1970's, when sales of jogging shoes mushroomed, are over. But they say the shoe manufacturers can now look to a period of steady growth.

title: No Headline
description: POLAND'S STRIKERS IGNORE ARMY PLAN AND UNION APPEAL

title: QUESTION IS, HOW TO HELP CARIBBEAN IF NOT IN CASH
description: On a modest scale, the effort by developed nations to help underdeveloped nations called for last week at the North-South Conference at Cancun has been under way in the Caribbean and Central America since the summer, with predictable delays, misunderstandings, frustrations, and contradictions.

title: TALENT ILLUSTRATED IN 11TH BOOK
description: THERE are toys in Eve Rice's workroom in her North Castle home - but it is not a frivolous touch, for the dolls, stuffed animals and blocks that she enjoys collecting appear in many of the illustrations for her books. Her 11th children's storybook was published this month.

title: U.C.L.A. 34, California 6
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Kevin Nelson scored touchdowns for U.C.L.A. on runs of 14 and 15 yards before being injured in the second quarter. Nelson gained 97 yards on 11 carries, and ran for his touchdowns following a pass interception and a fumble as the Bruins scored all their points in the first half. U.C.L.A. ran its overall record to 4-2-1 and Pacific-10 Conference mark to 2-1-1 to remain in contention for a Rose Bowl spot.

title: Food; AUTUMN YIELDS OPPORTUNITY FOR THE VERSATILE APPLE
description: APPLES are an easygoing and useful fruit, enjoyed at any time of day. Their flavor complements both delicate and rich meats. Cooked with butter and cream, apples add a fragrant touch to such meats as veal, chicken or pheasant. Pureed or sauteed, they are delicious with robust meats such as bacon, pork, goose, ham or sausages - especially boudin noir (black sausage). Apples can be mixed with prunes and stuffed into a pork loin, or combined with chestnuts and sausages for turkey. They also have the largest dessert repertory of any member of the fruit family.

title: POLY PREP STOPS LINCOLN BY 24-18
description: What Elroy Hill lacks in size he makes up for with speed. The Abraham Lincoln defense discovered this yesterday as Hill, the Poly Prep halfback, scored two touchdowns to lead the home team to a 24-18 victory over its Brooklyn neighbor. It was Lincoln's first loss in six games. Poly ran its three-year unbeaten streak to 24.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I believe all those who attended found our expectations fulfilled and even exceeded. Together we suceeded in creating a spirit of new hope which we want to translate into progress to revitalize the world economy and accelerate the growth of developing countries." - President Reagan discussing the economic conference in Cancun, Mexico. (12:1.)

title: WHEN A CHILD DECIDES NOT TO LIVE
description: VIVIENNE The Life and Suicide of an Adolescent Girl. By John E. Mack and Holly Hickler. 237 ppp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $13.95.

title: Delaware Trounces Rhode Island, 35-15
description: John Davies, who was making his first start at quarterback, completed 10 of 18 passes for 206 yards, including two touchdowns, to lead Delaware to a 35-15 victory over Rhode Island today.

title: Antiques; CERAMICS TRIBUTE AT STATE MUSEUM
description: TRENTON AN EXHIBIT at the State Museum here can add considerably to one's knowledge about the extent of ceramic wares produced in New Jersey, and Trenton in particular.

title: 9 Indonesians on Bus Killed
description: A bus en route here plunged into a river in the western Java village of Labuan, killing nine people and injuring five, the police said today.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Statue vs. Statute
description: For five years, a six-ton white marble representation of Jesus had stood in the Wichita Mountains Federal Wildlife Refuge in Oklahoma in an area called the ''Holy City,'' where an Easter sunrise service was held by permit every year. Critics charged that the statue and the Holy City, being on Federal land, violated the constitutional separation of church and state.

title: WHAT HATH A BRIDGE WROUGHT
description: FORT LEE THE George Washington Bridge celebrated its 50th birthday yesterday with a cavalcade of cars. In the procession that crossed into Upper Manhattan, paraded around Washington Heights and then returned to tour the streets here were models that Detroit produced in each year of the bridge's existence. Army jeeps represented the four years of World War II.

title: LIGHTING, SIGN OF WEALTH
description: EARLY to bed and early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise, so Benjamin Franklin advised 18th-century readers of ''Poor Richard's Almanack.'' Whether such a routine actually contributed to Colonial health or wisdom was, perhaps, debatable, but few would have argued that by saving light one saved money. Purchased candles were counted as luxuries even in well-to-do households. For those who had no hard cash to spend at the candlemaker's shop, dipping candles was at best a messy, time-consuming and repetitious job.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: A GLORIOUS WAY TO DIE The Kamikaze Mission of the Battleship Yamato, April 1945. By Russell Spurr. Illustrated. 341 pp. New York: Newmarket Press. $14.95.

title: A VEILED FEDERAL ASSAULT ON COLLECTIVE BARGAINING
description: To the Editor:

title: by Patricia Malarcher
description: NEW MILFORD THE key to survival, Alexandra Soteriou will tell you, is ''having enough alternatives under one roof.'' A commitment to making a living by ''humanizing work'' can take Miss Soteriou from restoring a collector's 500-year-old book to curating a master craftsman's retrospective for a Manhattan museum. Then, too, she might design a portfolio for an edition of an artist's prints, or work toward a forthcoming show of her own handmade paper collages.

title: A DEFENSE NEGLECTED BY THE ADMINISTRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: GREAT BLACK-BACKED GULL; Larus marinus
description: Size: To 31 inches. Color: White with black mantle. Yellow bill with red spot near tip of lower mandible.

title: Ernest A. Wente, 91, California Winemaker
description: Ernest A. Wente, a pioneer California winemaker, died Thursday at his home here. He was 91 years old.

title: Long Island Journal
description: What will the actress Patricia Neal, a non-Catholic, be doing in a Long Island Roman Catholic rectory next weekend? Miss Neal will be staying at St. Boniface Rectory in Elmont before her appearance Saturday evening at a fund-raiser for the handicapped at Cathedral College in Douglaston. The event is sponsored by the Alexander Roberts Memorial Fund, which is named after a Catholic seminarian who was active in work for the handicapped before his death in 1973. The seminarian's classmates at Cathedral, now priests, organized the fund and one, the Rev. James Lisante of St. Boniface, is chairman.

title: Numismatics; MEXICO TAKES AIM AT THE GOLD KRUGERRAND
description: The Mexican government has launched a new offensive in its battle to win the hearts, minds and dollars of American gold-coin buyers. At a press conference in New York, it declared war early this month by unveiling a series of three new "even-weight" coins. The new coins went on sale last Monday and contain precisely one ounce, one-half ounce and one-quarter ounce of gold.

title: On Language; Homogenized Etymology
description: Kimble Mead

title: PARIS FASHION: WEARER'S CHOICE
description: The ready-to-wear openings the past week of clothes for next spring and summer will not go down in the annals of fashion as the most memorable events. Still, three designers showed worthwhile and widely commended collections. Both Emanuel Ungaro and Karl Lagerfeld for Chloe emphasized beautiful prints in fabrics and styles so light they seemed airborne. The clothes of Yves Saint Laurent were a little more structured and defined, complementing the floaty styles of the two others.

title: KARPOV TURNS BACK KORCHNOI FOR A 4-1 LEAD IN WORLD CHESS
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world chess champion, won the ninth game of his title match with Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland in the Kurzentrum playing hall here tonight, extending his lead to 4 to 1. Four games ended in draws.

title: Grouse Plentiful, and Good
description: HURTLING on throbbing wings through the bare bones of fall-shorn trees, the ruffed grouse can make a competent wing shot look like a tyro.

title: Slevin Helps Top Jackson
description: Pat Slevin scored on two 1-yard runs to lift Toms River East to a 25-6 victory over Jackson today in Jackson. Slevin gave Toms River East (4-1) a 12-0 lead with his touchdown runs in the first and second quarters.

title: Chess; WHAT TO LOOK FOR WHEN SELECTING A SECOND
description: The first impression Yasser Seirawan made on Viktor Korchnoi was favorable, if one takes into account that Korchnoi was looking for a second to replace Raymond Keene, whom he had dismissed after his unsuccessful World Championship match against Anatoly Karpov in the Philippines in 1978. The 21-year-old Seattle grandmaster smashed Korchnoi with a brilliant mating attack in the Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands, in January 1980.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Ex-President of Uganda Is Expelled by Kenyans

title: DISCO YIELDS TO WESTERN SWING
description: IN towns where the disco scene is being replaced by the country bar scene, the phrase ''appropriate dress'' has taken on new meaning. Out are spike heels, white three-piece suits and heavy makeup. In are silver belt buckles, alligator boots and feathered cowboy hats.

title: Economic Affairs; WHY REAGAN SHOULD VETO THE BELL BILL
description: Once or twice each session, Congress passes a bill that has a surprising impact on the economy. This surprise is usually unintended, but it can still be quite unpleasant. Such an experience could be awaiting us in the later 1980's as a result of the 90-to-4 vote in the Senate last week to pass the Telecommunications Competition and Deregulation Act of 1981.

title: The Region in Summary; They're Lining Up Against Weicker
description: During two terms in the United States Senate, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. hasn't exactly lacked enemies. Nor, it seems, will there be any shortage of them when the Connecticut Republican seeks a third term next year.

title: WARNINGS SOUNDED ON PRIVATE MORTGAGE LOANS
description: WITH high interest rates preventing many potential home buyers from qualifying for conventional bank loans, a growing number of sellers have been offering some form of the financing themselves. Half of all home sales nationwide now involve personal mortgage loans, according to the National Association of Realtors.

title: EUROPE'S HIGH NOTES
description: HAROLD C. SCHONBERG is the cultural correspondent and former senior music critic of The New York Times. By HAROLD C. SCHONBERG

title: by Joseph Sullivan
description: WHEN Tal Farlow was a young apprentice sign-painter in Greensboro, N.C., before World War II, he liked to work nights so that he could turn on the radio and hear the remote broadcasts of swing and dance bands that were aired from all over the country.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: An established Seattle catalogue source for toasty and luxurious down and featherbedding in the European tradition has gradually expanded and moved east. It now has 49 franchised locations, including the Greenwich Scandia Down Shop, which opened in August. Tomorrow the prices there drop on the Feathery Down comforters: to $89 for a twin size; $119 for full; $159 for queen and $199 for king, These 25 percent reductions will be available through Nov. 6.

title: The Muncey Era Comes to a Sad End
description: ''Dangerous? This is defined as one of the cruel sports. We figure anything less than death is a minor accident.'' So said Bill Muncey of unlimited hydroplane racing two years ago. Then, at the age of 50, Muncey was preparing to embark on his 29th year on the circuit.

title: EASY AS PIE
description: As American as apple pie," we say. But, in fact, pies of all sorts make up this country's favorite dessert category. Only ice cream rivals pie in popularity, and a sure-fire red, white and blue treat combines these two choices in pie a la mode, a Frenchified name for a strictly American preference. Like so many other things we think of as being particularly American, pies are naturalized citizens, having originated in England and on the Continent in slightly different forms. Whatever the origins and resultant variations, pies provide a cook with elegant and sweetly satisfying desserts that can be made with a minimum of effort.

title: Perkins Gets His Big Game
description: For two and a half years as head coach of the Giants, Ray Perkins has been been saying that his team has not really faced a big game. Tomorrow, when the Giants face the Atlanta Falcons, one of the powers of the National Football League, Perkins says it will indeed be a big game.

title: STATE HOPEFUL ON WASTE PLANS
description: TRENTON STATE officials said last week that the cleanup of hazardous-waste dump sites could resume by January if voters approved the proposed $100 million Hazardous Discharge Bond Act on Nov. 3.

title: U.S. Begins Project to Assist Novice Farmers in 10 States
description: A pilot project aimed at helping parttime and beginning farmers upgrade their operations is being started in selected counties of 10 states, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block announced yesterday.

title: Personal Finance; WHAT TO DO WHEN THE HEADHUNTER CALLS
description: O NE of the headiest experiences an executive can have is to be courted by another company for an appealing job. There is a great temptation to jump at the offer, especially if it represents a big salary raise, but executive recruiters say that some restraint can pay off.

title: EMIGRATION BECOMES A PROBLEM IN ARGENTINA
description: In an alarming reversal of tradition, Argentian, once a haven for immigrants from depressed areas of Europe, is experiencing large-scale emigration.

title: DISCLOSURES ON PRESLEY DRUGS AT DOCTOR'S TRIAL SHAKE FANS
description: In this Mississippi River city, one that has groomed its share of noted singers and musicians, one need only mention the name Elvis to see faces light up and hear praise of Elvis Presley.

title: 'WOMEN WHO KILL'
description: ''Women Who Kill - and Why,'' the title of a book by Ann Jones, is also the subject to be discussed by the author at 8 P.M. Wednesday in Reisinger Auditorium at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville.

title: GROWING MARKET FOR VIOLIN MAKER
description: LEAVING an office at Lincoln Center, Brian Skarstad met a group of New York Philharmonic musicians heading for lunch. Observing the battered violin case Mr. Skarstad carried, a musician politely inquired, ''Do you play?''

title: HAVING CUT TAXES, MUST CONGRESS RAISE OTHERS?
description: It is unorthodox politics for an election year, it is unorthodox economics for a recession year. Nevertheless, the inescapable question before Congress in the next six months will be whether to raise taxes, one way or another.

title: A CAPITAL SABBATICAL
description: WASHINGTON I T started in the waning days of the Johnson years. Businessmen were railing against the bureaucrats, and the bureaucrats were railing against the businessmen. So each would don the other's shoes for a year, and from then on everybody would understand each other. Thus was born the President's Commission on Executive Exchange. Over a dozen years, 600 men and women switched jobs - but the railing goes on.

title: The Region in Summary; Staten Island Feels Healthier
description: The United States Public Health Hospital has provided vital medical services to merchant seamen and, more recently, to the ''medically indigent'' on Staten Island for 150 years. Last week, however, the nation's oldest and largest public hospital may have performed its most critical operation: It saved its own life.

title: LOOKING BACK ON A CAREER THAT ALMOST ENDED
description: LAST April the world had baseball and I didn't have any summer plans. By July, I found myself teaching a writing course at the State University of New York at Oneonta. Most people had no baseball but I had the New York-Pennyslvania League, with both the Oneonta Yankees and the Little Falls Mets. When I went to Little Falls to watch the Mets play, I saw a very familiar figure on the field.

title: Andrea M. Arena To Wed in Spring
description: The engagement of Andrea Mafalda Arena to Gregory Sean McDermott has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Angelo T. Arena of New City, N.Y. Mr. McDermott is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. McDermott of Westfield, N.J. A spring wedding is planned.

title: COLUMBIA PRIZE FOR TIMERMAN ANGERS EX-WINNERS
description: Another furor has erupted over Jacobo Timerman, the former Argentine newspaper publisher, as a result of information reaching here that he is to receive an award in New York on Tuesday for ''distinguished journalistic contributions to the advancement of inter-American understanding.''

title: Flames 7, Whalers 3
description: Jamie Hislop and Don Lever scored two goals each to give Calgary its first victory in five home games.

title: Dining Out; CHINESE FARE THAT'S MULTIREGIONAL
description: HUNAN PALACE is the latest tenant at a location in Huntington that has been occupied by a series of Chinese restaurants. The quality of a restaurant does not seem to be the major factor in determining changes in management or chefs. Such shifting around, accompanied by announcements of yet another ''grand opening,'' seems to be characteristic of the Chinese restaurant business. Hunan Palace is a decent restaurant, although less distinguished than some of its predecessors. The preparation is competent.

title: HUNTINGTON RACE FOCUSES ON DIVIDED-GOVERNMENT ISSUE
description: AS Huntington Supervisor Kenneth Butterfield sees it, he defeated Councilwoman Claire Kroft for supervisor two years ago but ''she became the supervisor'' as the veteran and most vocal member of a Republican-controlled Town Board.

title: Celebrating Halloween In a Cemetery
description: Masquerade costumes will be optional but mock terror will be all but inescapable on Baltimore-Rent-A-Tour's latest nocturnal outing in search of the bizarre, a Halloween Insomniacs Tour that will take participants trooping through a darkened cemetery to the gravesite of Edgar Allan Poe.

title: Nebraska 6, Missouri 0
description: Phil Bates, the Nebraska fullback, scored from 3 yards out with 23 seconds left for the only points.

title: PHILIP GLASS BREAKS THROUGH
description: Robert Coe is writing a book on dance in America for E.P. Dutton and WNET/13. By Robert Coe Five years ago, when it received its American premiere at the Metropolitan Opera, ''Einstein On the Beach,'' a controversial collaboration between the composer Philip Glass and the playwright-director Robert Wilson, exploded operatic conventions with amplified instruments played at rock-and-roll volume and a bizarre libretto of solfege syllables, counted numbers and stream-of-consciousness monologues. Hundreds in attendance at the two sold-out performances stalked out of the Met, handing their ticket stubs to hundreds of people waiting just as eagerly to get in.

title: LIBYA PLOT REPORTED
description: The United States Ambassador to Italy was hastily flown out of Milan on Wednesday, without even a change of clothes, after Italian authorities discovered a Libyan plot to assassinate him, State Department officials said today.

title: Environews; by Leo H. Carney
description: BEGINNING the first of the year, New Jersey municipalities will be able to earn credits from a state-sponsored program that will financially reward them for their recycling efforts.

title: Thompson, Brown Star
description: Brandon Brown and Joe Thompson scored two touchdowns each, and the defense earned its fourth shutout to help Clifford Scott to a 44-0 victory over Paterson Catholic yesterday in East Orange.

title: Texas A & M 51, Rice 26
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Gary Kubiak threw six touchdown passes to set a Southwest Conference record.

title: Southern Cal Beats Irish, 14-7
description: Todd Spencer's 26-yard touchdown with four minutes 52 seconds left in the game lifted Southern California to a 14-7 victory over Notre Dame today.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; DOROTHY UHNAK
description: Dorothy Uhnak believes that if she had not served for more than 14 years on the New York transit patrol, she could not have written ''False Witness,'' recently on the fiction best-seller list, or the five novels that preceded it. All of them are heavily peopled by cops, con men and criminals, because - as she puts it - ''I learned early on to write what I know.''

title: THE KINGSLAND POINT BEACON WILL LIGHT THE DARK AGAIN
description: TARRYTOWN KINGSLAND POINT lighthouse, which has helped skippers of sailing vessels, freighters, tug-pushed barges and Hudson River excursion boats find their way through many a murky night, is to be illuminated again.

title: Prof. Susan Muhler Married to Dr. Jeffrey Graves
description: At the Presbyteran Church of Chestnut Hill in Philadelphia yesterday, Susan Ann Muhler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Muhler of River Vale, N.J., was married to Dr. Jeffrey Mershon Graves, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Graves of Spartanburg, S.C. The Rev. Douglas W. Stevens Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: TV View; 'TODAY'S F.B.I.'- OFF TO AN IMPRESSIVE START
description: Tonight at 8, a new weekly series entitled ''Today's F.B.I.'' is being given a special two-hour premiere as the ''ABC Sunday Night Movie.'' Considered strictly within the context of a standard copsand-robbers concoction, it's good - so good that it makes me wary. The problem is that the first installment of any new weekly series can be notoriously misleading. Season after season, the networks bombard reviewers with elaborate press kits promising all sorts of programming wonders. And season after season, the reviewers watch the widely publicized debuts and venture forth with carefully considered opinions. More often than not, a program's time slot can be as crucial as its content. Any new show going up against ''Dallas,'' for instance, starts out with a whopping liability.

title: Headliners; Asking for Punishment
description: In the category of beating your critics to the punch, and with a vengeance: Sister Jane Scully, president of Carlow College, a Catholic women's school in Pittsburgh, last week administered her own lumps for canceling a speaking engagement by a lawyer who has advocated abortion rights for women. The lawyer, Sarah R. Weddington, argued the pro-choice case that led to the 1973 United States Supreme Court decision upholding a woman's right to seek an abortion, and later was President Carter's adviser on women's issues.

title: COLGATE BEATS COLUMBIA, 41-3
description: Stacy Hall, a freshman tailback who started the season with the junior varsity, scored five touchdowns to spark Colgate to a 41-3 rout of Columbia at Baker Field yesterday.

title: Mailbox; The Yankees Need No Pity
description: To the Sports Editor: Although I consider myself to be a dedicated Yankee fan, I still cannot feel sorry for my team as Julian Auerbach suggested (The New York Times, Oct. 4) with his 50 Yankee failures (actually 49, as Thurman Munson's death should not be called a Yankee failure).

title: Earthquake Hits Mexico City; Power Outages Widespread
description: A strong earthquake lasting about three minutes shook Mexico City tonight, causing buildings to shake and knocking out power in a widespread area of the capital.

title: VENICE IN FALL AND WINTER
description: Muriel Spark, the British novelist and poet, was born in Edinburgh but has lived in Italy for 14 years. She is the author of more than 20 books, among them ''The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie,'' ''Territorial Rights,'' which was set in Venice, and, most recently, ''Loitering With Intent.''

title: CUTS IMPERIL COAST GUARD PROJECTS
description: GROTON IN the early days of oil-spills, finding the responsible party was almost impossible because there was no way to identify the source of the oil. Now, a system developed by the United States Coast Guard Research and Development Center here can be used to ''fingerprint'' the oil in the water, making it possible for the parties who spilled it to be found and billed for the cleanup.

title: PARLEY ON AGED WARNED ON ABUSE
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK ''ABUSE of the elderly - parent abuse - is today where child abuse and the issue of the battered spouse were 10 years ago,'' Dr. Sylvia Herz told more than 400 people gathered at the Holiday Inn here last week. ''It is now finally beginning to be talked about and recognized as a real problem.''

title: Major News in Summary; A Bloody Holdup And a Secret Life
description: From time to time and without much fuss, surviving members of the Weather Underground have turned themselves in, tired of living secret lives, perhaps, or wondering which way the wind was blowing. Last week Katherine Boudin, perhaps the group's most prominent fugitive, was also taken into custody, but only after a brutal, bungled bank holdup that left three dead and enough clues for police to race to hide-outs used by radicals in the New York region.

title: A SALUTE TO JAPAN'S LAST NETSUKE ARTIST
description: TOKYO Japan is a nation of craftsmen and artisans, people good with their hands. Any visitor to Japan senses that. The green tea bushes of Shizuoka Prefecture - visible from the ''bullet'' train on its way from Tokyo to Osaka - are arranged to fit every last inch of the mountains that face south there. The Japanese plainly have an extraordinary instinct for using limited space, down to the last tiny tea-leaf-sized pocket of air.

title: CONVIVIAL COFFEE
description: Americans now drink two-thirds of the world's coffee-and it is no longer restricted to a weak brew packaged in a Styrofoam cup. The demitasse, served with after-dinner mints, brandy or liqueur, has become an integral part of American entertaining. Shops specializing in nothing but fresh roasted beans have been burgeoning across the country. Many of them roast their beans daily and offer a variety of blends that can be baffling. The names are as enticing as those in the 19th-century travel book: Celebes Kalossi, Jamaican Blue Mountain, Samatra Mandheling, Kenya AA. Yet with all this, the promise of a delicious homebrewed cup is not always fulfilled.

title: Dutch Wind Ensemble To Be Profiled on PBS
description: A half-hour documentary profiling the Netherlands Wind Ensemble will be shown on WNET-TV and other PBS stations tomorrow at 9:30 P.M. The group, formed in the late 50's, is composed of members of the country's 16 symphony orchestras. The documentary, narrated by David Frost, presents the group in classical music, jazz and a work by Frank Zappa, the rock star. Mr. Zappa will appear in the film, as will the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra conducted by Bernard Haitink.

title: SAUDIS COULD BAR AWACS MONITORING
description: Military experts say that American personnel could be prevented by electronic means from monitoring all information gathered by Saudi Arabian Awacs aircraft. However, the officers say, the Americans would know that they were being denied the information.

title: Miss Warner Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. James Drake Macneil of Pasadena, Calif., and Dr. Silas Llewellyn Warner of Gladwyne, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Carol Ridgely Warner, to Edward Strong Cooke Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cooke of Madison, Conn., and Blue Hill, Me. The wedding is planned for next May.

title: Georgia 21, Kentucky 0
description: Herschel Walker and Buck Belue each scored on short touchdown runs and Kevin Butler kicked two field goals as the Bulldogs capitalized on mistakes for their fourth Southeastern Conference victory.

title: THE LITERARY SHOTGUN
description: Having exercised romantic license with Japanese culture in ''Shogun,'' James Clavell then does the same with American politics when he declares, ''We are in a sweep away from the left-wing attitudes that have been creeping in against our Constitution.

title: THE TRUE HOMELAND OF ELIAS CANETTI
description: To the Editor:

title: INGRID BERGMAN PLAYS A PRIME MINISTER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jane Friedman regularly reports on cultural affairs in Israel. By JANE FRIEDMAN TEL AVIV It was May 1981. After several years in retirement and a bout with breast cancer, Ingrid Bergman girded herself for a screen test, her first confrontation with the movie camera in almost four years. Experts were called in to build up her nose, to costume her and to arrange the wisps of coarse gray hair that would transform the grand dame of Hollywood into the late grand dame of Israel, Golda Meir, who served as Prime Minister from February 1969 until her resignation in June 1974 and who died in December 1978. A few minutes before the film began to roll, Miss Bergman admitted she was nervous. ''But,'' she smiled, looking at the camera, ''I see a friend over there.''

title: PARLEY IN CANCUN: NEXT STEP BY WORLD'S LEADERS IN DOUBT
description: Most government leaders at the meeting of industrialized and developing nations that concluded here last night agree that they have given a strong impetus to the proposed global negotiations designed to aid poor nations.

title: Chaminade Prevails, 15-7
description: Chris Pujols completed 11 of 19 passes for 141 yards and two touchdowns to lead Chaminade of Mineola to a 15-7 Catholic High Schools Football League victory over Holy Trinity of Hicksville yesterday.

title: Practical Philosophy
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Afghan Rebels Report Capturing Soviet Adviser
description: An Afghan guerrilla group said today that it had captured a senior Soviet adviser in Afghanistan and was prepared to exchange him for 50 guerrillas held by the Afghan authorities.

title: UNBEATEN HARRISON TOPS OSSINING, 34-12
description: Chris Straube, a senior fullback, scored two touchdowns to lead unbeaten Harrison to a 34-12 victory over Ossining yesterday. Coach Mike Belmont has led the Huskies to a 5-0 record in his first season.

title: The Region in Summary; At the End of The Pipeline
description: Suffolk County's Southwest Sewer District was beginning to function last week, just as some of those who built it were being put out of operation by a Federal jury.

title: Business Forum; A MESSAGE FOR THE MEDIUM
description: N OW that the fuss stirred by the Rev. Donald Wildmon and the Coalition for Better Television has died down, a curiously familiar and somewhat frightening phenomenon is taking place in the business community. The predominant feeling among advertising executives, marketing managers, public affairs officers and even chief executive officers seems to be that the coalition cannot carry out a boycott and that the affair is over.

title: S.M.U.  Falls, 9-7, To Texas
description: Kenneth Sims, a 6-foot-5-inch, 270-pound defensive tackle for Texas described by his coach, Fred Akers, as ''the finest lineman in the U.S.A.,'' slammed Lance McIlhenny, the dangerous Southern Methodist quarterback, to the Astroturf at appropriate times today in Texas Stadium and the Longhorns defeated the Mustangs, 9-7, in an important Southwest Conference game.

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; Quantum Theory Is Mother Tongue Of Nobel Winners
description: Science has become so complex that researchers in allied fields may not speak the same language. Last week, however, Nobel Prizes were awarded to chemists and physicists who speak the same dialect - quantum theory, which describes the behavior of atoms and subatomic particles and is central to understanding the structure of matter and the interplay of forces.

title: Gypsy-Cab Driver Shot While Fleeing 2 Riders
description: A gypsy-cab driver, fleeing from his taxi on a Brooklyn street, was shot in the back of the head by one of two passengers last night, the police said.

title: HOW ROBERT DUVALL MASTERS HIS MANY FILM FACES
description: Last month, Robert Duvall drove 680 miles across eastern Texas looking for someone with just the right accent to read his next script into a tape recorder.

title: Swarthmore 32, Upsala 0
description: Steve Massi passed for 262 yards and three touchdowns for Swarthmore.

title: THE SUBTLE CONTROL OF A VAST FORTUNE
description: PHILADELPHIA S IX years before his death in 1971 at age 93, J. Howard Pew, chairman of the Sun Oil Company and patriarch of the Pew family, whose fortune controlled the company, would call his 29-year-old greatnephew into his office. There, in a ritual that occurred every other day for about a month and lasted exactly one hour, R. Anderson Pew would be grilled about religion, his life goals and politics.

title: Headliners; Earache
description: There are ways to make news and ways to report it. Recently, The Washington Post has managed to do both, to its discomfort.

title: THE PRESIDENT CALLS A RECESSION
description: IT looks like a duck, it flies like a duck, it quacks like a duck. And last week, President Reagan conceded that the creature might indeed be what it seems. ''I think there's a slight recession,'' he said, ''and I hope a short recession.''

title: Coolidge's Town
description: To the Editor:

title: HALLOWEEN SPIRITS STALK THE COUNTY
description: BABE RUTH bars and corn candy are disappearing from area supermarkets just as fast as managers can stock the shelves. Halloween, Allhallows Eve or the Eve of Sam Hain, as the pre-Christian Celts called it, is coming in just six days.

title: Molly Hoagland, Clarence King 3d To Wed in Winter
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hoagland of Wellesley, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Molly Hoagland of Greenwich, Conn., to Clarence Hopkins King 3d of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. King Jr., of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

title: CALIFORNIA PRISON GANG LINKED TO DEATH PLOT
description: An investigation of mail thefts has led California officials to a group of former convicts described as members of the Black Guerrilla Family, a prison gang, and to evidence that a plot existed to kill certain state officials.

title: FACTORY BUILDINGS AS VISUAL FASCINATION
description: SPARKILL ASHOW that is well worth checking out this week is ''Factories: Miniature Cities,'' at Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in Sparkill (Route 340 in Rockland County through Nov. 1). Also, the many admirers of Will Barnet should know that a small display of his prints is on view at the River Gallery in Irvington-on-Hudson (49 Main Street, through Oct. 31).

title: Critics' Choices
description: MUSIC Seeing the Czech-born conductor Rafael Kubelik on the podium is a little like stepping into an earlier age. He looks the stereotype of the distinguished, long-haired European maestro, and his style and ideas seem to be drawn from the wellspring of 19th- and early 20thcentury Romanticism.

title: DUTCH ARE SPENDING BILLIONS ON A PROJECT TO KEEP SEA AT BAY
description: A few miles north of here, the Dutch are fighting what they hope will be the final battle of their centuries-old struggle against the encroaching sea.

title: The Region in Summary; The Wire Gets Closer in the N.J. Campaign
description: When the New Jersey gubernatorial campaign began last spring, state Democrats predicted a solid if not overwhelming victory for Representative James J. Florio over Republican Thomas H. Kean. But as the campaign enters its final week, Mr. Florio and his suppporters find themselves clinging to a fragile lead and hoping for a last-week boost over the top.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Passionate Pilgrims The American Traveler in Great Britain, 1800-1914 By Allison Lockwood. 551 pages. Cornwall/Fairleigh Dickinson University Press. $30.

title: Moscow Youngsters Find Ticket Scalping A Lucrative Business
description: Ticket scalping for seats in the Bolshoi and other leading Moscow theaters has become such a lucrative business that gangs are going to war against one another to corner the market, a Soviet newspaper has reported.

title: About Long Island
description: THE office is in the middle of a bustling mid-Island shopping area, on a north-south road. Its waiting room is dark-paneled. Piped-in music issues softly from the ceiling. Those who come here regularly step from a bright busy world of honking horns and hurrying shoppers into a subdued, darkened atmosphere, silent except for the unobtrusive music; two rows of chairs, facing each other, the men, women and children occupying them reading the dog-eared magazines available in a pile at the far end.

title: TAKE YOUR PICK OF THE PUMPKINS
description: JACK-O-LANTERNS decorating household, school and shop windows are reminders that Halloween is approaching. Many farms on Long Island grow the pumpkins in great profusion and several open their fields to those who want to pick their own.

title: The Nation in Summary; Prosecuting Bias Is Different Now
description: The Administration announced last week that the Justice Department was going forward with three desegregation actions filed late in the Carter days - but in its own Reaganesque way. The differences made plain how the civil rights division under William Bradford Reynolds has shifted from the civil rights division under Drew S. Days 3d.

title: VIDEO GAMES STAR WAR
description: Aaron Latham is a freelance writer and novelist. By Aaron Latham Michael Blanchet stared through the window of his tank at a futuristic landscape bristling with dangers. An enemy tank came straight at him. As the two tanks bore down on each other across what looked like the surface of another planet, pyramids and cubes and other geometric shapes rumbled past. Mike fired. There was a hypergalactic blast. Mike was afraid he was dead.

title: The Fonzie of Literature
description: In the beginning there was the word: WRITER, like ATHLETE or GENIUS or MOST HANDSOMEST GUY or TOUGHEST, signifying that pre-adolescent scrambling for Ace-hood, for a specialty, so at least you're breaking even while you're breaking out.

title: Deirdre K. Guernsey Wed
description: Deirdre Kent Guernsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter E. Guernsey of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Kent Harbor, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., was married yesterday to Timothy Corbin Woodhull, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Woodhull 2d of Richmond, Mass., and Martha's Vineyard. The Rev. Bruce A. Rodgers performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley,

title: Paperback Talk
description: Fun and games. As the days grow shorter, many publishers are releasing paperbacks in unusual formats to help readers brighten their winter evenings. Herewith notes on a few of this season's novelties.

title: Gallery View; UP AND DOWN THE AVENUE
description: People sometimes say that words like ''uptown'' and ''downtown'' are going out of style. And it's certainly true that among the art galleries niched high above 57th Street some are ''downtown'' in all but their location. Their image, that is to say, is that of an operation that starts small, travels light and will give new young people a chance. It is also true that there are downtown galleries, downtown restaurants and downtown shops that are ''uptown'' in their scope, their pretensions and their prices. There is a certain elasticity, that is to say, about these two concepts.

title: FRENCH CUISINE COOKED TO ORDER
description: RIDGEFIELD ENTREZ VOUS is a tiny restaurant in a wood-frame shopping complex on a side street in Ridgefield. At first glance, the interior looks like a modest soup-and-quiche eatery. There are tables for 22 in the small dining area, and tables for 18 more on the glassed-in porch. In the rear of the dining area are refrigerated display cases, where some of the day's offerings are visible.

title: A Filly Captures Turf Classic
description: April Run, an oversized 3-year-old filly who was a fast-closing third in the Arc de Triomphe in Paris three weeks ago, shot to the lead at the top of the stretch yesterday and withstood the late rush of Galaxy Libra to win the $300,000 Turf Classic on the grass at Aqueduct.

title: THE MARGIOTTA CASE: HOW BIG A FACTOR IN NASSAU'S ELECTION?
description: Mineola, L.I. - Although Francis T. Purcell has talked many times about the idea of retiring, he finds himself running again at age 63 for re-election as Nassau County Executive.

title: Record Child Support Paid
description: The Government collected $430 million, a record, in child support payments from delinquent parents in April, May and June because of stepped-up efforts, including interception of some state income tax refunds, the Office of Child Support Enforcement said yesterday.

title: Reagan Asks Senate To Support the Sale Of Awacs to Saudis
description: President Reagan issued a new plea to the Senate today for his proposal to sell radar surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia.

title: THOSE INGENIOUS AMERICANS
description: There's nothing wrong with sitting down to a perfectly appointed table and having the butler pour the wine and white-gloved waiteres offer silver platters of underdone vegetables. In fact, it's delightful.

title: The World in Summary; The Message From Croydon Echoes Loudly
description: Last week's by-election in an obscure London suburb risks being overrated as a harbinger of national events, but that didn't alter the jubilation of Liberals and Social Democrats at the first victory of their electoral alliance - or the jitters of Conservatives and Laborites at the growing threat to their long dominance of British politics. Said William Pitt, the centrist elected to Parliament from a district that had been Conservative for more than 30 years, the ''whole mood of the country has changed.''

title: Clare C. Dixon Is Bride Of Kenneth Alan Klee
description: Clare Catherine Dixon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold V. Dixon of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday to Kenneth Alan Klee, son of Dr. Gerald D. Klee and Elizabeth Grace Klee, both of Baltimore. The Rev. Edward Kiernan performed the ceremony in St. Andrew the Apostle Roman Catholic Church.

title: Flyers 6, Blues 3
description: ST. LOUIS (AP) - Bobby Clarke contributed four assists and Tim Kerr had a pair of power-play goals to lead Philadelphia.

title: Canadiens 7, Bruins 0
description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Guy Lafleur scored once and assisted on two other goals and Denis Herron stopped 25 shots to gain the shutout for unbeaten Montreal.

title: Navy 27, William & Mary 0
description: Eddie Meyers, a halfback, ran 70 yards for a touchdown early in the second quarter. Meyers broke through right tackle from the Navy 30-yard line, cut to the sideline and outran several defenders to the goal line.

title: NEW ERRORS FOUND AT NUCLEAR PLANT
description: A new series of errors related to earthquake safety, which the Government says are ''potentially more significant'' than those identified earlier, have been discovered at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant.

title: TOP-RATED PENN STATE BEATS WEST VIRGINIA, 30-7, WARNER OUT
description: The No. 1 ranking in the nation has been a prelude to defeat in the first half of the college football season, but not for unbeaten Penn State today. The Lions played a strong second half and trounced West Virginia, 30-7, for their sixth victory of the year.

title: REGIONAL COOKING-AN AMERICAN SAMPLER
description: When it comes to the kitchen, it sometimes seems that cooks of this country make up a nation of strangers.

title: JOHN CAGE'S NIGHT OF UPROAR
description: The 1913 premiere of Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring'' at the Theatre des Champs Elysees in Paris is firmly enshrined in the mythology of modern music - it was the opening salvo in the 20th century's continuing brushfire war between concertgoers who prefer well-trodden paths and composers who insist on plunging off into the thickets. But a concert that took place at New York's Town Hall on May 15, 1958, presented a more varied and more provocative program for musical revolution than the ''Rite of Spring'' performance, and, according to an observer who was present on both occasions, the 1958 concert caused ''more of a disturbance (in the audience) than anything that happened at the Champs Elysees.''

title: REDUCING WINDOW HEAT LOSSES
description: ALTHOUGH much has been said about the need for insulating walls and attics in the average house, recent studies have indicated that not enough attention has been paid to heat wasted through windows during cold weather.

title: NORTH ROCKLAND VICTORIOUS
description: The unbeaten North Rockland Raiders conquered Ramapo, 14-6, yesterday for their their fifth straight victory in the county P.S.A.L. Bob Brisolari passed 33 yards to Mike Settchie early in the first quarter to put North Rockland on the scoreboard.

title: Nuke Shutdowns
description: To the Business Editor: ''Nuclear Power's New Dilemma'' (Oct. 4) of chronic reactor shutdowns is actually one of the nuclear industry's oldest problems. Numerous studies since the mid-70's have shown that United States nuclear power plants produce an average of only 60 percent of their design output, versus industry projections of 75 to 80 percent; that the second generation of larger plants (in excess of 800 megawatts capacity) produces only 55 percent, and that reactor output increases only slightly with operating experience.

title: NABOKOV'S RUSSIANS
description: LECTURES ON RUSSIAN LITERATURE By Vladimir Nabokov. Edited, With an Introduction, by Fredson Bowers. Illustrated. 324 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95

title: PONY CLUB TRIALS HONE SKILLS
description: THE initial experience for entering national and international riding events is often gained at the local and regional level at such events as the horse show the Glastonbury Pony Club is sponsoring on Saturday.

title: MUMPHREY UNHAPPY ON BENCH
description: The strange disappearance of Jerry Mumphrey as the Yankees center fielder injected an intriguing controversy into the fourth World Series game today.

title: Josephine Prevost Wed to Reporter
description: Josephine Evelyn Prevost, managing director of Chemical Asia Ltd., the Chemical Bank's merchant banking subsidiary in Hong Kong, was married yesterday to Earl Staten Browning 3d, banking correspondent for The Asian Wall Street Journal in Hong Kong. The Rev. Claude Peters performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn.

title: GREETINGS TO ALL!
description: There are artists in every medium whose proper audience, one feels, is God. Their message is that man suffers beyond his deserts.

title: 5-0 Bergen Catholic Rolls, 23-6
description: Bergen Catholic remained undefeated in five games with a 23-6 victory over Hackensack yesterday in Hackensack. Bergen Catholic, the defending state champion in the Parochial A Division, took a 6-0 lead when Darren Pellegrino recovered a blocked punt in the end zone in the first quarter. In the second, Bob Murray hit Chris Lester with an 8-yard scoring pass. Bergen Catholic made the score 21-0 in the third period when Tom Azelby recovered a fumble on the Hackensack 7-yard line to set up Steve Zigman's 4-yard touchdown burst two plays later.

title: OIL RUSH OF THE EIGHTIES
description: Well beyond the colorful pictures of hard-hatted roughnecks and Denver skyscrapers, Mr. Lohr raises the key question: Aren't there more effective, less risky and less harmful methods of addressing our oil-import dependence?

title: RANGERS AND WEEKS SET BACK LEAFS, 5-3
description: Steve Weeks, the rookie goalie who has a university degree in conservation, kept the environs of the Ranger net relatively free of pucks tonight and won his first game in the National Hockey League, a 5-3 decision over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: BRITISH SIDE LOSES, BUT RETAINS LEAD
description: Britain held on to its lead in the world bridge team championships this afternoon despite a loss to Indonesia in the eighth round. The Indonesians won, 12 to 8.

title: OLSZOWSKI'S TOUCH IS APPARENT IN POLISH PARTY'S HARDER LINE
description: About eight months ago, Jadwiga Nowakowska, a worker from Lodz who is also a Central Committee member, summed up the psychological trauma of Communist Party leaders this way: ''A lot of the activists at the higher level got so used to hearing applause in their honor that now, when there's no more applause, they think there's no more party.''

title: GAINS IN CONSENSUS ON JAIL ISSUES CITED
description: ENFORCEMENT officials and criminal-justice advocates - who often disagreed over how best to reduce overcrowding at the Westchester County Jail in Valhalla - recently concurred that alternatives to confinement have had an important part in reducing the jail's population.

title: IRE RISES AS THE LEAVES COME DOWN
description: THERE is a small war going on on my street. It may explode into armed combat (I, with my one-woman powered hand rake and he, with his five-horse-powered leaf blower) if a certain gardener doesn't mend - or perhaps I should say, cultivate - his ways.

title: FOR SWEDEN, A NEW KIND OF POLITICIAN
description: Sweden has a major new political figure. By his admirers' accounts, he embodies all that is direct, courageous, warm and innovative. For his detractors, the more characteristic phrases are erratic, impulsive, short on facts and transparently long on ambition.

title: Advice to Purchasers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation in Summary; Anxiety Time For Republican Congressmen
description: ''Without the tax cuts,'' Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan insisted last week in defense of the Administration's supplyside program, ''you don't get the economic recovery; you shoot yourself in the foot.''

title: Washington; A VIEW FROM TOKYO
description: Any remark by the President of the United States, no matter how casual, about the possibility of nuclear war, sends a shudder down the spine of Japan. People here have memories.

title: Crafts; by Patricia Malarcher
description: REACHING across the glass-and-chrome counter, the trim-looking salesman handed a woman her credit card and package. Adjusting his tie, he approached the next customer.

title: Suns' Davis Undergoes Surgery on Left Elbow
description: Walter Davis, the Phoenix Suns' guard, underwent surgery today for a fractured left elbow he suffered in a 109-106 exhibition victory over the San Diego Clippers last night.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Could you explain why it is not possible to make a reservation at a major hotel in Boston on a Saturday morning? I called the hotel and was told to call back on Monday morning. Similarly, when I called a hotel in Charleston, S.C. one evening, I was told the reservations desk was closed, to call back ''tomorrow morning.'' And when I called a resort on Virgin Gorda I was told the reservations desk closes at 5 P.M. - S.M., Manhattan. Answer:Hotels have become bigger; frequently they are units in a chain and their operation has become more cost-conscious, hence the decrease in such services as reservations being taken at almost any time of the day or night. According to the manager of a metropolitanarea hotel, a guest should, however, be able to make a reservation during normal business hours, between 9 A.M. and 5 P.M. Monday through Saturday.

title: 900 Seized in the Sudan
description: The police have arrested 900 illegal immigrants and vagrants here since a crackdown began Sept. 12 to secure the capital and avert Libyan subversion, the police said. More than 17,000 people were reportedly arrested in the intitial stages of the crackdown, but most were later released.

title: Rams to Be a Test For Revived 49ers
description: In a night game at Yankee Stadium 17 years ago the Giants lined up for their first offensive play against Washington and their center, Greg Larson, was unsure what Sam Huff had in mind. Right over there at middle linebacker for the ragtag Redskins team stood Huff, publicly angry after having been traded away a few months before by his beloved Giants, traded summarily by Coach Allie Sherman in Huff's view. How angry and avenging would Huff be?

title: CAN PRO BASKETBALL SURVIVE ITS OWN MONEY WAR?
description: OTIS BIRDSONG is a rich New Jersey Net, Mitch Kupchak is a wealthy Los Angeles Laker and James Edwards, Scott Wedman and Bobby Wilkerson are affluent Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Rita Ungar and Nathan Moser to Wed March 27
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Ungar of Great Neck, L.I., and Longboat Key, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Rita Louise Ungar, to Nathan Frederick Moser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander S. Moser of New York and Loon Lake, N.Y.

title: Investing; STOCKBROKERS AND THE NEW TEMPTATIONS
description: T HE traditional broker - the ''stock jockey'' who lives and dies on the ups and downs of various equities - is rapidly going the way of the stock ticker.

title: MCINTEE PACES EAST ISLIP VICTORY
description: East Islip and West Islip continued to build up to their confrontation next Saturday as they scored impressive League II victories yesterday. They are each 5-0 over all and have 4-0 records in league competition. Last season they played to a scoreless tie.

title: ADS REFLECT ROUGH TONE OF STEIN-DINKINS CONTEST
description: Andrew J. Stein is depicted in a television commercial as granting favors to landlords who give him campaign contributions. An announcer says, ''Well, Andy Stein's finally found a way to get somebody else to pay for his campaigns.''

title: Other Business; HUMAN EVENTS: THE WHITE HOUSE GETS 24 COPIES
description: For most of its 37 years, the magazine Human Events was everything you'd expect of a small right-wing Washington tabloid. It lost money. It was vilified by liberals. It never made much of an impact.

title: by Richard Meislin
description: ALTHOUGH naming the new indoor arena in the Meadowlands Sports Complex for Governor Byrne was not viewed as a major problem facing the state, it did raise the ire of a good number of those interviewed by The New York Times.

title: THE CLEARWATER IS BRINGING SONG TO THE SHORES
description: WHEN the frost is on the pumpkin, the pumpkins are on the Clearwater, the celebrated river sloop that plies the Hudson, bringing ballads to residents of towns on both banks, along with twin tidings of environmental warning and hope.

title: Major News in Summary; More Power To Jaruzelski
description: Five years ago, when he was only Defense Minister, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski refused to send soldiers against rioting workers, vowing that ''Polish troops will never be used to fire upon Polish workers.'' Last week, as the general became Poland's supreme leader, the continued unraveling of the country's economic and social order cast doubt over how much longer he could keep that pledge.

title: Morris Hills (5-0) Wins, 27-7
description: Chris Kehoe, a senior fullback, rushed 24 times for 167 yards and two touchdowns to give undefeated Morris Hills a 27-7 victory over West Morris yesterday in Rockaway.

title: THE FUNNY BUSINESS WITH LIBYA, CONTINUED
description: There is something about the relationship between the United States and Libya that seems to produce breakdowns in the normal practices of American government. The latest occurred last week when Justice Department officials said they had known for months that American pilots and mechanics were being recruited by a former American intelligence agent, Edwin P. Wilson, to fly and maintain Libyan Air Force planes. The same day, senior American military and intelligence officials said they knew nothing about the American involvement.

title: Around the Nation; 3d Inmate Who Testified In Texas Prison Suit Dies
description: A prison spokesman denied today that the slaying last Sunday of an inmate who had testified in a Federal lawsuit against the corrections system had anything to do with his court appearance.

title: COPYRIGHT V. 'REPROGRAPHY' REVOLUTION
description: In San Francisco last week, a Federal appellate court ruled that the three million Americans who own home videotape recorders are little more than modern-day pirates. While recorder owners need not walk the magnetic-tape plank, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit declared, they can no longer use the machines for recording - pirating - copyrighted television programs.

title: CARTER DECIDES AGAINST SUING PAPER FOR LIBEL
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that he had decided against filing a libel suit against The Washington Post.

title: PIANIST: MARK WESTCOTT AT Y
description: The New York debut of Mark Westcott on Thursday night at the 92d Street Y confirmed the impression made on this listener three years ago, of a pianist who possesses not only an overwhelming talent but extraordinary musical sensitivity as well. At every point in every selection on his program, Mr. Westcott kept this rare combination of virtuosity and profundity in balance, so that when his performance was over one didn't know whether to be more awed by his command of the keyboard or moved by his interpretive vision.

title: Fires at Subway Construction Disrupt Section on East Side
description: Billowing smoke from underground fires disrupted activities around 63d Street and Third Avenue in Manhattan for several hours last night, the police said.

title: U.S. Grants Asylum to Three Who Left Polish Ship in June
description: Three Polish seamen who jumped ship at Astoria last June have been granted political asylum by the United States and say they will celebrate by buying an American automobile.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
