description: The Literary Shogun Although the academics have been provided with years of grist by James Clavell's ''Shogun,'' to those who must teach about 16thcentury Japan in the public schools, he has done a great service (''Making of a Literary Shogun,'' by Paul Bernstein, Sept. 13). Historical abstractions aside, an important era in Japanese culture has been brought to life in the minds of young and old. As history, ''Shogun'' provides a vehicle for discovery, just as ''Gone With the Wind'' did for generations of Americans. JAMES B. BARRY East Hampton, L.I.

title: By Mitchell A. Martin
description: WHO'S BEING LAID OFF

title: Sports of the Times; MR. OCTOBER
description: LOS ANGELES L ET it be recorded for posterity that Mr. October joined the cast in baseball's gaudy road show for the fourth match of the tournament for the rounders championship of North America. Without Mr. October, alias Reginald Martinez Jackson, the Yankees might not be here playing the Los Angeles Dodgers, for the big bat he habitually swings in autumn was instrumental in achieving two of their three necessary victories in the Eastern Division playoff against Milwaukee.

title: Shaw's Music Criticism
description: George Bernard Shaw began writing musical criticism in 1876 and continued almost until his death in 1950. On Nov. 16, Dodd, Mead will publish ''Shaw's Music: The Complete Musical Criticism in Three Volumes,'' including more than 125,000 words of material never published in book form.

title: TEACHER STRIKE REFLECTS STRAIN
description: THE recent strike by the Lay Faculty Association against the four diocesan Roman Catholic high schools in Nassau and Suffolk counties pointed up the discontent and dissatisfaction that has existed between the diocese and the teachers, a situation that has been simmering since the union held its first walkout four years ago.

title: MIANUS RIVER GORGE YIELDS A WEALTH OF VARIETY
description: ON a Saturday morning, Gily Bard tied a small botanical 20-power lens loosely around her neck and drove from her home in Tuckahoe to a lush meadow near the Bedford Village Green. It was there that the plant succession committee of the Mianus River Gorge Wildlife Refuge and Botanical Preserve was conducting its fourth annual survey of plants growing in the abandoned field.

title: HODGEPODGE OF HOPEFULS
description: At 10:30 A.M. today, some 16,000 runners will cross the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and begin the annual five-borough journey through the streets -the New York City Marathon.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Radoslav Kvapil Plays Czech Piano Works
description: Radoslav Kvapil, a 47-year-old native of Czechoslovakia, brought some of his regional piano music with him when he made his debut Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y. Interestingly enough, the works by Dvorak and Martinu were written when the composers were also in the United States.

title: ONE YEAR IN MOSCOW
description: RUSSIAN JOURNAL By Andrea Lee. 239 pp. New York: Random House. $13.50.

title: WHAT TEACHERS COULD LEARN BY AT-HOME PUPIL OBSERVATION
description: IHAVE just reached a parental milestone - I have gone to my 25th Back-to-School Night. That's not 25 nights to learn something about one magnificently underachieving child. No. That's 25 nights divided, through the years, among three more or less scholastically successful children. Still, as I fidgeted through a microcosmic re-enactment of a typical day in the school life of Joshua Chervokas, the thought struck me that the entire concept of Back-to-School Night is wrong. It's pointless. It's backward.

title: Rutgers Defeated By Alabama, 31-7
description: On the opening kickoff today, Alabama fumbled and Rutgers, a 19 1/2-point underdog, recovered. But the Scarlet Knights failed to capitalize on the opportunity, and Alabama - bigger, stronger, faster, quicker and deeper -battered its way to a 31-7 victory.

title: SHADOWING SAM SPADE
description: JOHN JUSTICE is a freelance writer in Chapel Hill, N.C. By JOHN JUSTICE

title: Park Avenue South
description: The Marvel Entertainment Group, a subsidiary of Cadence Industries Corporation, publishers of MarvelComics, has leased about 35,000 square feet of office space at 387 Park Avenue South.

title: Long Island City
description: Burnham Products Corporation, a division of Scripto Inc., has subleased from Executone Inc. 45,000 square feet of manufacturing, warehouse and office space on the seventh floor of the Executone Building at 29-10 Thompson Avenue in Long Island City. The 17-year sublease has an aggregate rent of about $2 million.

title: Long Island Housing; VOLUNTEERISM RESTORES FORECLOSED HOMES TO THE MARKET
description: BAY SHORE ATHOUGH President Reagan's recent appeal to the spirit of volunteerism may seem like wishful thinking to some, millions of Americans - estimates are one in three - already volunteer their time to help others.

title: Art; REAPPRAISING ALEXANDER BROOK
description: SOUTHAMPTON AS one of the most highly regarded artists of his generation, Alexander Brook had numerous exhibitions, awards, honors and works in important collections to his credit. As Grace Glueck wrote in The New York Times at the time of his death last year, he may have had ''more one-man shows at American museums than any other American painter of his day.''

title: Europe's Fear of Frying
description: Ideas drive policy, but emotions drive ideas. And the cascading emotion in democratic Europe is rage against national impotence - the dependence on Arab oil and American interest rates and the fear of frying in a nuclear war.

title: BOARD VOTING COULD TURN ON RACE IN WHITE
description: PLAINS By JAMES FERON

title: THE AMERICAN WAY OF ENTERTAINING
description: THE FREEWHEELING SPIRIT ASSOCIATED WITH MANY THINGS AMERICAN IS ALSO EVIDENT IN THIS COUNTRY'S APPROACHE TO ENTERTAINING AT HOME

title: NEW WATER FILTRATION PLANT OPENED
description: WANAQUE THE Wanaque Reservoir is the largest facility of its kind in North Jersey and the backbone of the water-supply system for the cities and suburbs of the state's most densely populated area. But until a new $28 million filtration plant went into service earlier this month, treatment of the Wanaque's drinking water lagged behind that of other supply systems.

title: NEW KIND OF LAW FIRM KEEPING LABOR AT BAY
description: A new type of law firm specializing exclusively in the practice of labor and employment law on behalf of management has emerged in recent years, to the distress of union labor.

title: 150,000 IN LONDON RALLY AGAINST BOMB
description: About 150,000 people marched through the heart of London today in a peaceful demonstration demanding nuclear disarmament.

title: PLAN TO DEVELOP OLD ARMY TERMINAL SET BACK
description: Plans to turn the abandoned Brooklyn Army Terminal into an industrial site have been set back by the cancellation of lease negotiations between the Koch administration and a developer.

title: AN ALL-AMERICAN WINE FEAST
description: Orchestrating an all-American wine feast can be a rewarding experience, for the quality and variety of fine American table wines have grown vastly in the last decade.

title: INDEX
description: INTERNATIONAL Award for Timerman protested by previous Argentine winners 4 Argentine emigration now exceeds immigration 5 Around the World 6 Saudis could prevent the U.S. from monitoring Awacs planes 8 Sadat-Nimeiry parallels are drawn 9 Egypt reports arresting 350 for plotting assassination and coup 10 South African rightist vows to stop any accord on Namibia 11 Burma signs U.S. farm aid accord 13 Chinese peasants' profits create unfilled consumer demand 15 Gravel-making machines competing with archaeologists 17 New conservative party leader in Sweden faces tough road 20 Dutch spending $2 billion for equivalent of finger in the dike 22 Antwerp's Jewish diamond dealers clean up after blast 23 GOVERNMENT/POLITICS Gallup Poll finds 64% favor expanding President's veto power 29 Trade expansion attracts U.S. law firm to China 30 Presidential hopefuls are already scouting New Hampshire 32 Prosecutors denounce ruling of misconduct in Goody trial 43 Ads reflect rough tone of Stein-Dinkins contest 50 Four challengers tilt at Brooklyn Borough President 51 Mrs. Codd's views on city schools 51 Support is sought for state job Development Authority 54 Koch aide, retiring, reflects on record 55 U.S. Pine Barrens bill urged to protect L.I. water supply 56 Court backs leasing of state land tract to Mohawks 57 State's wetlands given another legal shelter 57 GENERAL Around the Nation 24 Drug disclosures shake Presley fans at trial 28 11 years after deaths on Kent campus, R.O.T.C. is thriving 34 Six apartment-referral companies accused of fraud 44 11 die in a Hoboken fire believed set by arsonist 45 INDUSTRY/LABOR New kind of law firm keeping labor at bay 53 RELIGION Mormons offer example of a self-help welfare system 37 ARTS/ENTERTAINMENT Karpov defeats Korchnoi to take 4-1 lead in chess championship 36 "Quartet," movie based on Rhys novel 62 Book's on raid on Chinese atomic laboratory denied by Marines 64 Joffrey premiere of Cranko's "Shrew" 64 OBITUARIES Adm. Walter Anderson, served 43 years in Navy 44

title: Elise G. Smith Is Wed to Cole Heyniger
description: Elise Griswold Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Huntington Smith of South Dartmouth, Mass., was married there yesterday to Cole Heyniger, son of Mrs. Brendan Griswold of Buffalo and South Dartmouth and the late Frank Kingsbury Heyniger of Lawrenceville, N.J. The bridegroom's stepfather, Canon Griswold of St. Paul's Episcopal Cathedral in Buffalo, performed the ceremony at the Smith home. He was assisted by the Rev. Benjamin Lentz of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in South Dartmouth.

title: Headliners; Sifting Stories
description: To listen to the opening statements of defense and prosecuting lawyers last week, there are two Marian W. Zacharski's - the dedicated young businessman determined to obtain ''harmless'' information for his company, a Polish Government-owned firm with offices in Illinois and California; and a Polish spy who paid cash and almost carried out a plot against the United States. For the moment, jurors at Mr. Zacharski's trial can be sure only that he is a Polish citizen accused of paying a former Hughes Aircraft engineer $110,000 in cash and gold coins over a year and a half in exchange for documents on some of the company's latest weapons and radar systems. The engineer, William Holden Bell, has pleaded guilty to one count of espionage and is cooperating with the Government.

title: TRAY CHIC SUPPER
description: Every once in a while, a dining habit gets started and overtakes us before we realize that it is going on. Something like that has happened to the TV dinner.

title: CHINESE FARMER FINDS HIS PROFIT IS A PROBLEM
description: Yang Xiaoyun, an industrious young peasant in Hubei Province, turned a sizable profit last summer by selling more than five tons of grain to the state. But when he set out to treat himself to a new bicycle, he could not find one.

title: STATE'S WETLANDS GIVEN ANOTHER LEGAL SHELTER
description: An unusual legal controversy that pitted one state environmental agency against another has led the state's highest court to broaden the powers of the Environmental Conservation Commissioner to protect the state's wetlands.

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; Simple Question, Complex Answer
description: Discovering that African pygmies don't grow because they lack the proper hormones may prompt the question, So what else is new? The answer is that thanks to pygmies and their particular chemical deficiency, scientists may have pinpointed the principal substance responsible for human growth.

title: Dana Murphy, Law Student, Fiancee Of James Knowles Ketcham, Banker
description: Nina L. Murphy of Bronxville, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dana Nina Murphy, to James Knowles Ketcham, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Ketcham of Ottawa Hills, Ohio.

title: Camera; HIKING AND BACKPACKING GUIDE; Jack Neubart
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Neubart is a freelance writer and photographer specializing in nature photography.

title: AN INSIDER'S GUIDE
description: PETER LAURITZEN, an American writer and historian, has lived in Venice since 1967. He is the author of ''Venice: A Thousand Years of Culture and Civilization'' and several other Venetian studies. By PETER LAURITZEN

title: Vanderbilt 27, Mississippi 23
description: Van Heflin raced 49 and 13 yards for fourthquarter touchdowns to help the Commodores break a losing streak that covered 33 Southeastern Conference games.

title: Modell Fined For Outburst
description: Art Modell, the Cleveland Browns' owner, has been fined $5,000 for criticizing the officiating in his team's 13-7 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers on Oct. 11.

title: STATE GROUP AIDING PRINCIPAL'S FIGHT FOR REINSTATEMENT
description: WESTBROOK THE dismissal last month a junior high school principal here has prompted a statewide organization of secondary school principals to help a local group of parents and teachers raise money for the ousted principal's effort to win reinstatement.

title: Bridge; SOME ENGLISH EXOTICA
description: Aslight disappointment for the spectators at the world team championships now in progress in Port Chester has been the failure of the Polish team to bring any of its players who use a ''strong pass'' system. Since such methods force the players to open the bidding with all weak and medium hands, the Poles may find themselves suffering heavy penalties. Against that, they create totally unfamiliar situations for the opponents, who will seldom have a free run when they have strong hands.

title: LAST OF RADICAL LEADERS ELUDED POLICE 11 YEARS
description: Jeffrey Carl Jones, arrested Friday night in his Bronx apartment as he watched the World Series with his wife and 4-year-old son, was the last identified leader of the Weather Underground to escape capture or surrender in the 11-year search by the authorities to round up members of the terrorist group.

title: Correction
description: A chart accompanying ''How CBS Is Changing Channels'' last Sunday incorrectly identified the partners in NBC's Entertainment Channel. They are RCA and Rockefeller Center Inc.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
description: Kurt Waldheim And the U.N. Jane Rosen's article ''The U.N.'s Man in the Middle'' (Sept. 13) contends that Kurt Waldheim has no power because he cannot force the Security Council or the General Assembly to act. In the same vein, it could be argued that Ronald Reagan has no legislative power because he cannot force the Senate or the House of Representatives to act.

title: The New York Times; BOOK REVIEW; October 25, 1981
description: NONFICTION THE AMERICAN THEATHER. By Ethan Mordden. 18 AMONG THE BELIEVERS: An Islamic Journey. By V.S. Naipaul. 7 BORGES: A Reader.

title: EARLY LINEUP FOR '82 PROMISES LIVELY CONTESTS
description: AFTER months of exploration, indecision and sometimes conflicting signals by potential candidates, the state's political picture for 1982 is rapidly coming into sharp focus.

title: 7 Young Escapees at Large
description: Seven of nine juveniles who escaped from the Youth Development Center remained at large tonight, and the police called on the state attorney general's office to investigate security at the institution, from which there has been 124 escapes this year.

title: GRUMMAN MAY LOSE SKIRMISHES BUT WIN THE WAR
description: IN three days the LTV Corporation will take its case for its proposed $450 million takeover of the Grumman Corporation to the second level of the Federal judicial system, the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan. Officials of the Texas-based conglomerate have already said that unless they win this appeal of a ruling handed down 10 days ago by Judge Jacob Mishler the takeover would be ''doomed.''

title: KENT STATE R.O.T.C. THRIVES AMID MEMORY FO 1970 KILLINGS
description: The Army's Reserve Officer Training Corps is thriving at Kent State University, where 11 years ago antiwar demonstrators burned the corps building, setting off a chain of events that ended with the killing of four students by the Ohio National Guard.

title: ROCKEFELLER TRACT TO BE A PARK
description: The Rockefeller family plans to donate 1,500 acres of its 3,500-acre estate in Pocantico Hills in Westchester County for public use as a state park, Laurance S. Rockefeller announced today.

title: A 27-YEAR OLD AND HIS HALF BILLION DOLLAR DEAL
description: Rory Taggart is a 27-year-old Englishman whose faith in capitalism would warm the cockles of Milton Friedman's heart. Mr. Taggart's faith in the ability of an entrepreneur to flourish is based on experience. In his first brokerage deal, he brought Grand Metropolitan Ltd., the London-based conglomerate, together with Pan American World Airways in the sale of Pan Am's Intercontinental Hotel Corporation for $500 million. The sale, which Pan Am announced Aug. 21, earned Douglas Elliman Knight Frank, Inc., Mr. Taggart's employer, ''a seven figure'' commission, according to Earl Reiss, president of the firm.

title: Amherst 6, Wesleyan 3
description: Brian Curran hit Dave Silliman with a 6-yard scoring pass in the third quarter for Amherst's touchdown.

title: A WOMAN REPORTER IN YANKEE COUNTRY
description: Jane Gross is a reporter on the sports staff of The Times. By Jane Gross t is a perfect May afternoon -months before the World Series that began a few days ago - the Yankees have been summoned to center field at Yankee Stadium for their team picture.

title: Children's Books
description: THE PATCHWORK CAT By William Mayne. Illustrated by Nicola Bayley. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $8.95. (Ages 4 to 6) By ELAINE EDELMAN

title: Leisure; UNUSUAL 'FLOWERING STONES'FASCINATE INDOOR GROWERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joanna May Thach is a writer who gardens on Long Island. By JOANNA MAY THACH

title: GLEN COVE CONTEST HAS FAMILIAR RING
description: GLEN COVE ONCE again, the downtown redevelopment project that has remolded the core of this North Shore community dominates the race for mayor, which appears to be a rerun of the 1979 election.

title: Ohio State 29, Indiana 10
description: Bob Atha kicked a school-record five field goals and Jimmy Gayle rushed for a career-high 186 yards for Ohio State, which is 3-1 in the Big Ten and 5-2 in all games.

title: Around the Nation; Woman Slain in Hospital After Shooting at Home
description: A 24-year-old woman injured in a shooting was killed today when a gunman burst into a hospital emergency room and fired several bullets at her as she lay on an examining table, the police said.

title: A BOMBER'S CONFESSIONS
description: GROWING UP UNDERGROUND By Jane Alpert. 372 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $13.95.

title: Bridges and Yesalonia Help Iselin Edge Edison
description: Jack Bridges passed for two long touchdowns to Bob Yesalonia in the first half, and the defense twice stopped 2-point conversion attempts in the second half to lift Iselin to a 13-12 victory over Edison yesterday in Iselin.

title: Joseph Finn Jr. Weds Mary L. Reilly on L.I.
description: Mary Louise Reilly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Reilly of Greenlawn, L.I., was married there yesterday at St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church to Joseph Finn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Finn of Laurel Hollow, L.I. The Rev. Joseph Keys performed the ceremony.

title: Michigan 38 Northwestern 0
description: A sophomore quarterback, Steve Smith, passed to Anthony Carter and Norm Betts for touchdowns and ran for one himself to lead Michigan.

title: St. John's Defeats Hofstra, 17-3
description: Todd Jamison of St. John's, a transfer from Hofstra, beat his former teammates yesterday by passing for one touchdown and running for another as the Redmen defeated the Flying Dutchmen, 17-3, at Jamaica, Queens.

title: LAW FIRMS CAPITALIZE ON CHINA TRADE BOOM
description: In keeping with the rapid expansion of United States trade with China in the last few years, five American law firms have now established what amount to permanent offices in Peking.

title: WRITER FINDS VALUE IN VAGABOND TRAVEL
description: SALISBURY ''IT'S a little game with me to sleep in unusual spots,'' said Richard Curtis, author of ''Taking Off: A Guide for the Uncommon Traveler.'' Sitting on a dock beside Lake Washinee in Salisbury recently, he recalled the rainy night he spent sheltered in an alcove in one of the exterior walls of the State Capitol in Hartford. And then there was the wet-weather evening at a construction site near Middletown when he found accommodations inside the cab of a bulldozer and slept ''sitting up at the control levers - which wasn't the most comfortable night's sleep I've ever had, but I was dry.''

title: PEOPLE, FOOD AND THE SPIRIT OF THOMAS MALTHUS
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXT OF CARTER STATEMENT ON PAPER'S APOLOGY
description: Following is the text of a statement issued today by former President Jimmy Carter concerning his decision not to sue The Washington Post:

title: POLISH TATRAS
description: To the Editor:

title: Senior Volunteers Are Not Paid
description: Maxine Frankenfelder, in a letter to The Times (''Money Can Be of Help to the Elderly,'' Sept. 27,), implies that R.S.V.P. (Retired Senior Volunteer Program) volunteers are paid. They receive no pay, although they are reimbursed for travel and meal expenses if they need this support in order to be involved in volunteer service.

title: Mailbox; The Split Season Caused Problems
description: To the Sports Editor: I totally agree with Red Smith's column about the split season (''Baseball's Dishonest Season, The New York Times, Oct. 7). Attendance was diluted this year because competition was diluted.

title: The Region in Summary; Summer Blues: A Full Day's Work
description: Come summer, the living won't be quite so easy for many New York City employees. Ruling on several issues unresolved in last year's contract, an arbitrator last week gave the city permission to eliminate that traditional warm weather perk - shorter seasonal hours.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
description: Oil Rush of The Eighties There is a concerned effort being made by the oil companies, Secretary of the Interior James Watt and the friends of the energy industry in Congress to open the wilderness system to oil and gas exploration and development (''The Great Oil Rush of the Eighties,'' by Steve Lohr, Aug. 30).

title: Lehigh 18, Bucknell 0
description: Terry Heffner of Lehigh, the holder on a field goal attempt, fumbled the snap but eluded a tackler and threw a 31-yard touchdown pass to Tom Nikles.

title: Coast Guard 6, Bowdoin 0
description: Chris Hall of Coast Guard (3-3) kicked two second-half field goals for the only points.

title: HALLOWEEN TO SEE A RETURN OF ZORRO
description: WITCHES, ghosts and goblins are passe. So are Star Wars and punk outfits, last year's fads. This year French maids and Zorros are keeping costumers in Connecticut scurrying to fill their racks.

title: Nordiques 8, Red Wings 3
description: QUEBEC (AP) - Real Cloutier of Quebec scored three goals in the first period and assisted on two later. Cloutier has scored seven goals this season, all in his last four games. Peter Stastny scored two goals for Quebec, and Stastny's brother, Marian, Michel Goulet and Jacques Richard scored a goal each.

title: A PLACE THE ROCKEFELLERS CALL HOME
description: With its massive stone walls and iron gates; its Georgian mansion set on a 250-acre park within the 3,500-acre estate; its exquisite statues and dramatic landscaping, Pocantico Hills is the American equivalent of the great English aristocratic preserves of the 17th and 18th centuries.

title: The Week in Business; CONSUMER PRICES TAKE AN UNEXPECTED LEAP
description: Consumer prices soared across the board in September, the Government reported. The Consumer Price Index climbed 1.2 percent, or at an annual rate of 14.4 percent, with increases in food, housing, transportation and medical costs.

title: OPERA'S TRIUMPHAL MARCH INTO HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD IS it possible to stage an opera at an indoor sports arena, using a company of 1,000, two elephants, three camels, 22 horses, 10 pythons and a monkey, all on a set that has to be struck each night to make way for professional hockey games? Between 30,000 and 40,000 people have paid good money to find out.

title: Theater in Review; A PYRRHIC VICTORY FOR 'WHOSE LIFE IS IT?'
description: EAST FARMINGDALE IN ''Whose Life Is It Anyway?'' a hopelessly paralyzed patient wins the ultimate pyrrhic victory: the right to end his life. At the end of the Arena Players Repertory Theater production, just before the final fadeout frames his face, one is overcome by a sudden swelling of emotion. As a woman doctor - the gender designation is crucial in this context - Pam Pugliese sends forth subtle signals that betray her detachment. How unfair, how brutally unfair, is what she is silently saying.

title: Business Conditions; THE SUTRO FORECAST
description: While the six-tenths of a percent drop in the third-quarter gross national product caught some analysts by surprise, economists who have been tracking a little-known indicator that has correctly forecast the last four recessions were not surprised.

title: GOLDMAN ON PRESLEY
description: ELVIS By Albert Goldman. Illustrated. 598 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Co. $14.95.

title: The World in Summary; Targets of Opportunity
description: They could hardly disagree more about what's wrong, but Maj. Gen. Robert L. Schweitzer, a White House aide who was dismissed for speaking out of turn, and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale both concluded last week that United States foreign policy was in deep trouble.

title: Nancy A. Cenek, David Brigstocke To Wed on Jan. 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Henry Cenek of Syracuse have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ann Cenek, to David Hugh Charles Brigstocke, son of Heather Renwick Brigstocke of London, and the late Geoffrey Reginald William Brigstocke.

title: HEMPSTEAD TAKES FIFTH IN ROW, 19-0
description: Hempstead, enjoying its most successful season since 1967, when the Tigers had an 8-0 record, defeated Great Neck South, 19-0, yesterday, for its fifth straight victory and third in Conference III-A. Hempstead remains tied for the III-A lead with Lynbrook, which routed Carey, 50-15, as Larry Galizia scored four touchdowns to lead the Owls to their fifth triumph in a row. Hempstead face Lynbrook next Saturday.

title: 11 DIE IN A HOBOKEN FIRE BELIEVED SET BY ARSONIST
description: Eleven persons died today in an early morning fire in a tenement in downtown Hoboken that investigators said they believed might have been started by an arsonist.

title: Elizabeth Sean Kennedy Married to Paul Console
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Sean Kennedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Kennedy of New Canaan, Conn., to Paul Dominick Console, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominick J. Console of Wethersfield, Conn., took place yesterday. Msgr. Francis X. McGuire performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan.

title: Sound; OPEN-REEL VERSUS CASSETTE
description: Mark Twain, as is widely known, didn't believe everything he read in the papers. For example, he regarded published reports of his death as exaggerated. Public requiems over the supposed demise of open-reel tape recording are similarly overstated. Despite the predominance of cassettes, the open-reel format refuses to become extinct. In fact, open-reel is currently having something of a renaissance among tape hobbyists, and it almost seems that the challenge of cassettes has invigorated the older recording medium.

title: THE SECOND GREEN REVOLUTION
description: The industrial section of San Carlos, Calif., does not look like the birthplace of an agricultural revolution. It is one of those instant commercial complexes whose poured concrete walls seem to have been raised and stitched together overnight. The air is filled with the roar of traffic and the smells of gasoline, roofing tar and bay mud. The International Plant Research Institute (I.P.R.I.), a pioneering agricultural firm, is next door to a water-bed showroom. In the parking lot, two men are trying to push-start a stalled car. No fields of sighing wheat here. Just the 20th century, with all its overloaded circuitry.

title: REPRESENTING THE BUYER
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPPORT IS SOUGHT FOR JOB-LOAN UNIT
description: With tours of a plastic company in the Bronx and a news conference at City Hall, state and city officials have been trying to drum up support for a constitutional amendment on the Nov. 3 ballot to increase the bonding limit of the state Job Development Authority.

title: LIBRARIES GETTING LISTINGS FOR WOMEN
description: TRENTON THE state's Division on Women has put together a 35-page guide entitled ''Women's Library Resources.'' The guide, a compilation of bibliographies, basic information and publications pertaining to women's interests, is the first of its kind in New Jersey, according to the eight-member committee that developed it.

title: 1984 ASPIRANTS ALREADY SCOUTING NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: It has been only nine months since Ronald Reagan moved into the White House, but already a lengthening line of Democrats is scouting New Hampshire with an eye on its 1984 Presidential primary, the earliest in the nation.

title: NEW TOUCHES ADD AN INNOVATIVE TWIST TO A TRADITIONAL HOLIDAY FEAST
description: The way things are and the way things were blend no more beautifully than in an updated holiday meal attended by three generations of family and friends.

title: Why Small Colleges Are Holding Their Own
description: It was reassuring to learn from the recent article ''Smallness Paying Off for Small Colleges'' that Long Island's small liberal arts colleges are holding their own despite strong competition from the State University establishments in Nassau and Suffolk. To borrow a phrase from Elliot Janeway, these private institutions make their money the old-fashioned way - they earn it.

title: FLUTIE AND BROWN LEAD BOSTON COLLEGE TO A 41-6 ROUT OF ARMY
description: His name does not appear in the program because he is still a freshman, but Doug Flutie led Boston College to a 41-6 rout of Army today. Flutie threw for three touchdowns, completing 15 of 21 passes for 244 yards.

title: Illinois 23, Wisconsin 21
description: Tony Eason, the Illinois quarterback, threw three touchdown passes. Eason, who tied a conference record by passing for more than 300 yards in five games, found Darrell Smith for two scores, and hit Oliver Williams for the third. The Illinois victory gave both teams Big Ten records of 3-2.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; The Trio Live Oak Offers Early Works
description: While there was a delightful spontaneity to the performance Monday night by the Trio Live Oak at Carnegie Recital Hall, there were also occasional examples of what, for lack of a better word, one might call stylistic trespass. It was not that the group, which specializes in early music, specifically that of Moorish and Christian Spain, mistook the aims of the music it programmed or the spirit in which the selections might have been presented.

title: LANDMARK STATION REPAIRED
description: ROSLYN THE renovation of the old Long Island Rail Road station here has received both good and bad reviews but has evoked a large measure of nostalgia. Everyone seems to approve of the changes in the building itself, agreeing with Dr. Roger Gerry, Roslyn Village trustee and president of the Roslyn Landmark Society.

title: The World in Summary; Antwerp Bomb Aimed at Jews
description: Shortly after shops opened in the predominately Jewish diamond trading district of Antwerp, Belgium, on Tuesday, a parked van that had been booby-trapped exploded in front of the Antwerp Diamond Club. Two women were killed and 95 other persons were injured.

title: U.S. PINE BARRENS BILL URGED TO PROTECT L.I. WATER SUPPLY
description: The Federal preservation of 86,000 acres of coastal pine barrens in Suffolk County was endorsed today by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan as one way of protecting the deep reservoirs of pure water that lie beneath the forests there.

title: SUSPECTS' LAWYERS DIFFER IN TACTICS
description: Two legal and political philosophies will emerge in the defense of the four suspects who were jailed in last Tuesday's Rockland County shootout, according to lawyers close to the defense.

title: Democracy on the Run
description: Today's running of the New York City Marathon marks a crucial point in the history of the event. For the second year in a row, this once ragtag race has attracted 16,000 entrants, including the world's leading runners, and for the first time, it will be nationally televised, with every manufacturer of running shoes straining to be in the picture.

title: WOMEN OF ORT WILL DISCUSS ANTI-SEMITISM
description: The challenge of education to keep up with technology will be among the principal topics of discussion at the national convention of Women's American ORT, which convenes tomorrow in Manhattan.

title: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1981
description: INTERNATIONAL THE CANCUN TALKS WERE "extremely constructive and positive," President Reagan said upon his return from the conference of 22 industrialized and developing nations in Mexico. Before leaving, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. sharply criticized the Soviet Union's absence from the meeting. (Page 1, Column 6). PROTESTS OVER POLAND'S FOOD SHORTAGES in the form of wildcat walkouts continued in 36 of the 49 provinces, the official press agency P.A.P. said. The strikes were held despite the Government's announcement on Friday that it was sending troops to deal with the local problems. (1:4.)

title: BROOKHAVEN RACE APPEARS ONE-SIDED
description: BROOKHAVEN A 35-year-old lawyer and a 60-year-old town clerk are vying for Supervisor of the largest town in Suffolk County in a campaign that seems to be dominated by voter apathy, a lack of serious debate and difficulty by both parties in raising funds.

title: HOUSTON EMERGING AS A MAJOR CENTER OF AIR TRAVEL
description: In 1969, when the first flights touched down at brand-new Houston Intercontinental Airport, the futuristic sparkle of its two terminal buildings seemed to express the brave-new-world outlook with which Houston faced the future. Nowhere in the South or Southwest was there anything to match the spaciousness and scale of the new airport carved out of 8,000 acres of piney woods 22 miles north of downtown.

title: Westchester Housing; IN SEARCH OF HISTORIC HOUSES
description: ''WE always knew the houses on our street were old, and our history teacher mentioned something about them,'' said Rebecca Adams, a 20-year-old nurse's aide who lives on Hamilton Avenue in Ossining. ''But I didn't know this place was historic.'' Miss Adams is among hundreds of Westchester residents whose homes, in the older and sometimes shabby sections of the county, have attracted the attention of history experts.

title: Music; COLONIAL SYMPHONY WASHINGTON-BOUND
description: IN ALL its 31 years, the Madison-based Colonial Symphony has never ventured beyond Morris County. However, things are looking up - or, to be geographically precise, down - because the 46-member ensemble is going to Washington in March for an appearance at the Kennedy Center.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
description: Steve Lohr writes, ''The Colorado School of Mines, outside Denver, ... is the Harvard of geological education.'' Harvard considers itself ''the Harvard of geological education.'' JAMES FRED HAYS Chairman Department of Geological Sciences Harvard University Cambridge, Mass.

title: KOCH AIDE, RETIRING, REFLECTS ON RECORD
description: Having made major administrative changes in a law office once regarded as moribund, Allen G. Schwartz will be leaving his post as the City Corporation Counsel at the end of the year.

title: DEFECTORS: A PROFILE
description: Every five years or so, the K.G.B. issues alphabetical lists of ''enemies of the Soviet state,'' which are distributed among operatives in the Soviet Union and abroad. They contain basic data on each ''enemy'' and are stamped ''absolutely secret.'' One such list, in effect a K.G.B. ''wanted'' list on defectors, was stolen from a K.G.B. office and found its way into the hands of the National Labor Union of Russian Solidarists, an emigre organization headquartered in Frankfurt, West Germany. After examining my own entry on that list, I concluded that the document was completely authentic.

title: Major News in Summary; Awacs: 3 Days And Counting
description: There's a chance the Reagan Administration might not suffer a stunning foreign policy embarrassment on Wednesday, when the Senate is due to vote at last on the proposed Awacs sale. But by week's end, the odds had tilted in favor of those who oppose the $8.5 billion shipment of five Airborne Warning and Control System planes and other military hardware to the Royal Saudi Air Force.

title: PITT RALLY DOWNS STUBBORN SYRACUSE
description: In a season of shocks, the University of Pittsburgh, the No. 2 team in the country, learned an inexpensive lesson today. ''We've got to understand,'' said Sal Sunseri, a senior linebacker. ''People are coming after us, and they're swinging. And when they come swinging, you've got to be careful.''

title: MINNESOTA DEFEATS IOWA ON A 4TH-QUARTER FIELD GOAL
description: Jim Gallery kicked four field goals, including a 27-yarder with 2 minutes 22 seconds left, to lead Minnesota to a 12-10 upset of Iowa in a Big Ten game today.

title: Antiques; MEDIEVAL MANUSCRIPTS
description: The passionate pursuit of illuminated manuscripts was at its peak a half century ago when the titans of industry, banking and finance competed at auction and with rare book dealers for the most outstanding prizes, pushing prices to what were then viewed as astronomical levels. On July 29, 1929 J. P. Morgan paid 33,000 ($160,380) for the manuscript of ''The Bedford Hours,'' establishing a record at auction for any illuminated manuscript that was not eclipsed for 30 years.

title: THE ATGET COLLECTION
description: John Russell gave a fine description of Eugene Aget's character and some insight into what he was after in his relentless picture making. However, I was disturbed by Mr. Russell's dismissal of certain painters of the time.

title: Laura Jane Barker a Bride
description: The marriage of Laura Jane Barker to Kenneth Paul Morse took place yesterday in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. William B. Heuss performed the ceremony.

title: POLL FINDS 64% FAVOR EXPANDED VETO POWER
description: The Gallup Poll reported yesterday that a solid majority of Americans favored giving the President stronger power over Government spending by permitting him to veto specific items in Congressional appropriation bills rather than being forced to approve or reject them in their entirety.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
description: Helping the Mushroom Growers

title: PITFALLS IN PUBLIC FUNDING
description: N ATIONAL MEDICAL CARE INC. made its fortune in outpatient centers for treating kidney failure with machines that artificially purify the blood. The secret of its success was that the Government picked up much of the tab for these expensive treatments through Medicare. The company's revenues swelled, from $30 million in 1973 to $245.5 million in 1980, and its 140 outpatient clinics make it the nation's largest company offering hemodialysis treatments.

title: Charles Bresinger Weds Miss Stephens
description: Diana Patricia Stephens, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold W. Stephens of Memphis, was married there yesterday to Charles Bresinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Bresinger of Suffern, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. James M. Barr performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of the River.

title: Ann Barkley Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Ann Elyse Marie Barkley to David Patrick Hickey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Hickey of Boca Raton, Fla., formerly of Hartsdale, N.Y., has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Barkley of Yonkers. The wedding is planned for January.

title: PLANKS IN A PLATFORM
description: THE ROAD FROM HERE Liberalism and Realities in the 1980s. By Paul Tsongas 280 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: Business Conditions; HOW COLLEGE PAYS
description: In order to get a job in today's market, it helps to hit the books. According to a recent survey by the Labor Department, the American worker is better educated than ever before.

title: THOUSANDS ATTEND VICTIMS' FUNERAL
description: The two Nyack police officers who died in the aftermath of the holdup of a Brink's armored car Tuesday were buried here today, honored by thousands of police officers as well as the residents of this small Hudson River village.

title: WHY DIM SUM IS 'HEART'S DELIGHT'
description: FEI LO teaches regional Chinese cooking and nutrition at the China Institute in America in New York. She is the author of ''The Dim Sum Book: Art of the Chinese Teahouse'' to be published in the spring. By EILEEN YIN-FEI LO

title: AUTUMN YIELDS OPPORTUNITY FOR THE VERSATILE APPLE
description: APPLES are an easygoing and useful fruit, enjoyed at any time of day. Their flavor complements both delicate and rich meats. Cooked with butter and cream, apples add a fragrant touch to such meats as veal, chicken or pheasant. Pureed or sauteed, they are delicious with robust meats such as bacon, pork, goose, ham or sausages - especially boudin noir (black sausage). Apples can be mixed with prunes and stuffed into a pork loin, or combined with chestnuts and sausages for turkey. They also have the largest dessert repertory of any member of the fruit family.

title: Action Is Needed On Executive Power
description: The numerous articles about the Del Bello/Delaney controversy that have appeared in The Westchester Weekly section over the past few months illustrate the need for prompt legislative action that will prevent a similar situation from occurring in the future.

title: COOLIDGE'S TOWN
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Polisario Says It Downed A Moroccan Copter
description: Guerrillas fighting for independence for Moroccan-ruled Western Sahara today reported shooting down another Moroccan aircraft, killing the crew of three.

title: YALE SUBDUES PENN BY 24-3
description: When asked to evaluate his team's performance after today's 24-3 victory over Penn, its weakest opponent so far, Coach Carman Cozza of Yale said:

title: IN SEARCH OF ISLAM
description: AMONG THE BELIEVERS An Islamic Journey. By V.S. Naipaul. 430 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.

title: New Jersey Housing; FOR SALE: 'LITTLE HOME' OF 13 ROOMS
description: MAPLEWOOD HELENE KESSLER thinks of it as ''a little home,'' a warm, comfortable and liveable place where her three children grew up. However, a visitor might think otherwise on first seeing Shizuka na Uchi, the name of an 8,000-square-foot, four-level, 13-room contemporary home that occupies two acres in this suburban Essex County community. (The name means ''The Calm or Peaceful Home.'')

title: Rachel Feldman Is Betrothed to Glenn Kesselhaut
description: The engagement of Rachel Ann Feldman to Glenn David Kesselhaut has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Feldman of Philadelphia. Mr. Kesselhaut is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kesselhaut of New Vernon, N.J., and Sunapee, N.H. The wedding is planned for next August.

title: UPSTAIRS IN THE FAMILY DINING ROOM, PRIVATE PARTIES ARE FORMAL YET RELAXED
description: There are two ways to dine with the First Family. One is at the State Dinner, with its attendant pomp and ceremony. But perhaps even more special is the other - a private gathering in the family residence. When the President and Mrs. Reagan entertain in the family quarters on the second floor of the White House, they greet their guests in the reception hall, which serves as an entrance to the 14-room residential area.

title: MORMONS PROVIDE WELFARE EXAMPLE
description: In 1936, one of the gloomiest of Depression years here, the Mormon Church established a welfare services plan for its members.

title: Long Island Guide; ART SHOW AT SYNAGOGUE
description: He's called the ''Jewish Norman Rockwell'' and although the artist Emanuel Schary is flattered - ''I respect Rockwell as a tremendous artist,'' he said - he does cringe when the comparison is made. ''I take myself too seriously as my own person,'' he said, ''and I don't like being shoved like a square peg into a round hole.''

title: The Lively Arts; HUNTINGTON CINEMA UNREELS ALTERNATIVES
description: HUNTINGTON ''WE'VE mixed art and commerce,'' Victor Skolnick said of the New Community Cinema, of which he is co-director. ''Not only are we careful with our programming, but we also keep a good set of books.''

title: LOWER MANHATTAN LURING OFFICE DEVELOPERS
description: Lower Manhattan appears to be on the verge of historic change, according to many real estate experts, change similar to that experienced with the construction of the Chase Manhattan Plaza tower at the start of the 1960's and with the World Trade Center at the start of the 1970's.

title: Washington 14, Tex. Tech 7
description: Chuck Nelson's record-tying four field goals and a safety late in the game forced by Chris O'Conner led Washington.

title: The New York Times Magazine; October 25, 1981
description: William Safire 16 On Langauge Homogenized Etymology Russell Baker 25 Sunday Observer I Remember Papa Sidney Blumenthal 29 Whose Side is Business on, Anyway? Jane Gross 32 A Woman Reporter in Yankee Country Looking back on her first year with the Yankees, the writer discovers that baseball is a warm and enveloping society of men who greatly enjoy playing the game and, most of all, relish the company of their teammates. Peter Steinhart 46 The Second Green Revolution Robert Coe 68 Philip Glass Breaks Through Carrie Donovan 82 Fashion Manhattan's Medley for Spring Aaron Latham l00 Video Games Star War 114 Puzzles Answers, Page 121 123 Letters Cover: Illustrations by Robert Grossman

title: CENTRAL ASIAN DANCE TAKES ROOT ON THE EAST SIDE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Alan Jones edits articles on dance and theater for the ''Great Soviet Encyclopedia'' published by Macmillan. By ALAN JONES

title: PAPANDREOU'S TARGETS ARE ALL ABOUT, BUT HARD TO HIT
description: Andreas Papandreou, who won an overwhelming victory for his Socialist Party with the one-word slogan, ''Change,'' exhorted his new Cabinet last week to ''lay the foundations of change for a new Greece.''

title: Wake Forest 24, Virginia 21
description: Gary Schofield passed for 373 yards and three touchdowns and Wake Forest held off a fourth-quarter Virginia rally.

title: CAREER OF NIMEIRY PARALLELS SADAT'S
description: Just as Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was once compared to the Shah of Iran, with the implicit prediction of parallel destinies, similarities are now being noted between Mr. Sadat and Gen. Gaafar al-Nimeiry, the Sudanese leader.

title: KLAN'S CRITICS SPLIT ON EDUCATIONAL RESPONSE
description: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and the National Education Association, each of which say they are fiercely opposed to the activities of the Ku Klux Klan, are sharply divided over what young people should be taught about the genesis of the Klan.

title: U.S. CENTRALISM, YES
description: The block-grants program, which will put wide discretionary powers, and fewer dollars, into states' hands, is trumpeted by the Administration as a revival of the federalist system, in which power is broadly shared. In fact, the Administration's approach may produce an anachronistic mess, in which power is dissipated harmfully.

title: Robert Francis Hartsook Marries Elizabeth M. Drill
description: Elizabeth Mary Drill daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Thomas Drill of Leawood, Kan., was married yesterday to Robert Francis Hartsook, son of Mrs. Herbert Hartsook of Emporia, Kan., and the late Mr. Hartsook.

title: 24 Food Establishments Cited For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 24 food establishments it said had violated the health code. The department also released the names of two establishments that reopened after correcting earlier violations.

title: Sallie Grant Is Married
description: The marriage of Sallie Elizabeth Grant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Randolph Grant of Greenwich, Conn., to Anthony Phillip Russo took place yesterday in Greenwich. The Rev. Jon Freeberg, a Presbyterian minister of Bridgehampton, L.I., performed the ceremony at St. Bede's Chapel.

title: IN ERA OF SMALLER CARS, DETROIT TURNING TO EXOTICS
description: DETROIT DESPITE the slumping sales and red ink of the past two years, these are exciting times for the people who make and sell automobiles: The domestic industry is about halfway through a headlong rush to completely redesign its products so they can squeeze more miles from a gallon on gasoline, and the major automakers are about to start introducing relatively exotic models such as sports cars and convertibles.

title: TRILLING ON HARRIS
description: MRS.HARRIS The Death of the Scarsdale Diet Doctor. By Diana Trilling. 341 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: WALTER ANDERSON, EX-ADMIRAL, DIES
description: Vice Adm. Walter S. Anderson of the Navy, retired, a former chief of naval intelligence and the oldest living graduate of the United States Naval Academy, died today at the Georgetown University Hospital of cardiac arrest. He was 100 years old.

title: MANHATTAN'S MEDLEY FOR SPRING
description: Don't waste time worrying about the Americans. True, when New York designers start to show their spring 1982 collections tomorrow, they will be bringing up the rear, the big guns of Milan, Paris and London having already shown theirs and been accorded the usual worldwide ballyhoo and publicity. And, sure as shooting, should any top American designer show any idea similar to one already spotted in another fashion capital, he or she stands to be labeled a silhouette snatcher. No one, it seems, considers that good designers are mysteriously and invariably on the same wavelength. Or that the best designers everywhere get the bulk of their fabrics from Italy's fabled factories and that these fabrics suggest, sometimes even dictate, the shape of the clothes. So it is the special talent of each designer that gives a finished piece of clothing its special twist, its personal stamp. And there are so many good design talents in New York, with points of view that range from blue-sky fantasy to good old down-to-earth, wearable practicality. So never mind that New York is the last one in the fashion-show parade. It is the marketplace offering the most to the largest number of vastly varied customers.

title: Knicks and Nets Lose; Bullets Sign Haywood
description: Jim Chones hit a 12-foot jumper with 35 seconds left and the Washington Bullets held on and posted a 104-102 victory over the New York Knicks in a National Basketball Association exhibition game tonight.

title: LIFE WITHOUT TELEVISION IS A PRESSING ISSUE
description: Children here play European sports and electronic games, learn karate from Asian movies and eat Indian curry and tropical fruits. They listen to rock music on imported cassettes and wear T-shirts from Hawaii. All that the children of prosperous Fijian families don't have is television.

title: BRINK'S HOLDUP SPURS U.S. INQUIRY ON LINKS AMONG TERRORIST GROUPS
description: A Federal official said yesterday that the investigation of the $1.6 million Brink's robbery that left three persons dead in Rockland County last week had grown into a major inquiry of radical organizations dedicated to the overthrow of the Government.

title: Other Business; WINNING AND LOSING ON MADISON AVENUE
description: Needham, Harper & Steers held the the McDonald's Corporation advertising account for a decade, and two weeks ago, the No. 1 hamburger chain shocked Madison Avenue in switching its account to Leo Burnett, the big Chicago agency. It might have been a time for tears and dismissing vice presidents, but Paul C. Harper Jr., Needham's chairman and chief executive, chose instead to cheer. Here are excerpts from a memo he wrote the staff:

title: HOW TO PARRY THE THRUST OF THE INEVITABLE QUESTION
description: AS night follows day, as storm follows lull, as heartburn follows raw onion, so does ''What do you do?'' follow ''How do you do?'' It is the question of our times, pervading and preceding all human contact, and it strikes a double chord of guilt and terror in my heart. I don't do anything.

title: MALA MALA: POSH IN THE WILD
description: JOSEPH LELYVELD is chief of the Times bureau in Johannesburg. By JOSEPH LELYVELD

title: Other Business; THE HERTZ OF TV SETS
description: For Americans, a television has always been something to own, but in Britain, 65 percent of all sets are rented. A British company hopes it can persuade Americans to rent their sets as well.

title: SIMON IS CHAIRMAN OF A NEW VENTURE
description: William E. Simon never ceases to amaze his associates. They wonder how many different hats he can wear at the same time. Quite a few, apparently, and the former Secretary of the Treasury says they all fit just fine.

title: ISRAELIS ASSESS ROLE OF RELIGION
description: One recent afternoon, shortly before sunset, long whistle blasts sounded across Israel to mark the beginning of the most solemn day in the Jewish calendar - Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement. For twenty-five hours, no car moved. Television and radio stations went off the air. Whole cities fell silent.

title: Bears 20, Chargers 17
description: John Riveto's 26-yard field goal with 5:30 left in sudden-death overtime lifted Chicago to victory and snapped a fourgame losing streak.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1981
description: International

title: Female Officers in Knoxville Are Ordered to Cut Their Hair
description: Knoxville's police chief has ordered female officers to cut their hair, saying ''This is a tough job.

title: Driver Killed and 10 Hurt
description: The driver of a car was killed and 10 others injured yesterday in a bus-car collision on Route 6 near the New York State border, the police reported. A Bonanza Bus Lines Inc. bus traveling from New York City to Pittsfield, Mass., collided with the car at about 6:08 P.M., the police said. The name of the driver was not released pending notification of his family.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In a National League Football game, a punt receiver calls for a fair catch, but the gun goes off ending the game while the ball is still in the air. Does the receiving team get a chance to attempt a field goal, since a free kick is permitted after a fair catch?

title: DODGERS DEFEAT YANKEES, 2-1, AND TAKE 3-2 LEAD IN SERIES
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers continued their remarkable revival today when they defeated the New York Yankees, 2-1, for their third straight victory of the 78th World Series.

title: 49ers Defeat Rams by20-17
description: Since 1977, both of the games for the California bragging rights have belonged to the Los Angeles Rams, but the surprising San Francisco 49ers rose up yesterday and won the first meeting of the season between the two teams and their fifth straight of the season, beating their intrastate tormentors, 20-17, and opening up a two-game lead in the National Football Conference Western Division.

title: DANCE: GALA OPENS JACOB'S PILLOW GOLDEN JUBILEE
description: FIFTY years ago Ted Shawn, one of America's early modern-dance pioneers, bought a farm in Becket, Mass., and settled down to teach and choreograph. It was there that Mr. Shawn formed his Men Dancers company to prove dance needn't rob men of their virility. As the classes and his company grew, people turned up to watch. And from those impromptu performances came the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival.

title: TRIAL OF UKRAINIAN IMMIGRANT REVIVES BITTERNESS ON 2 SIDES
description: All last week, Jews sat on one side of a Federal courtroom here and Ukrainian-Americans sat on the other as the second denaturalization trial in a year involving charges of collaboration with Nazis revived ancient bitterness.

title: Colt Merger Appeal Filed
description: Lawyers for holders of Penn Central Corporation preferred stock, who tried to block Penn Central's purchase of Colt Industries, have appealed a Federal judge's decision to dismiss their suit.

title: Lisa Wanderman Married
description: Lisa Philippa Wanderman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney E. Wanderman of New York, was married yesterday at the Plaza Hotel to E. David Harrison, son of Mrs. Pearl W. Harrison of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late H. Joseph Harrison.

title: AGONY AND ECSTASY OF THE LAST FINISHERS
description: ''You start out fast because you're caught up in all the excitement,'' said a runner, now walking with a slight limp, as he and a companion left Central Park, where thousands of runners were finishing the marathon. ''Then you poke along, just to survive, but the distance gets amplified. You feel like you're out there forever.''

title: Retarded Patient Dies In Abortion After Rape
description: A 19-year-old retarded patient in a mental hospital who went into shock during a court-approved abortion was removed from life-sustaining machines after she was declared dead, hospital officials said today.

title: SOARING UNEMPLOYMENT RATES ALARM EUROPE
description: Thousands of Brussels residents line up daily at a grimy building just off the city's fashionable shopping avenues, mount a curved stone staircase and answer a few questions. The purpose is to preserve their unemployment benefits.

title: Drs. Marcia Bergtraum and Daniel Williams Wed
description: The marriage of Dr. Marcia Phyllis Bergtraum to Dr. Daniel Turk Williams took place yesterday at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue. Rabbis Samuel Turk and I. Usher Kirshblum performed the ceremony.

title: In the Cards
description: Baseball cards, which for decades have been a vital accessory in the lives of young baseball fans, play an important part in the ''Baseball Figures'' show that is curerently on display at the Spectrum Fine Art Gallery on West 57th Street. Painted reproductions of such former stars as Robin Roberts, Yogi Berra, Bob Feller, Don Newcombe, Gil Hodges and Roy Campanella hang on the walls and may be purchased for $850 and up.

title: CITY OPERA: A NEW PRODUCTION OF 'DER FREISCHUTZ'
description: THE theater has its problem plays, works of obvious significance that somehow are difficult to perform convincingly. Shakespeare's ''Measure for Measure,'' for instance, is usually placed in that category. The opera literature also has its problem works, one of the more important of which is ''Der Freischutz.'' In Germany, Weber's score is regarded as a sacred spring from which all of the Romantic repertory flowed; in this country, in spite of a staging here and there, it has resisted being imported.

title: Turkish Official Shot in Rome
description: An unidentified gunman fired three pistol shots at a Turkish diplomat in Rome today, wounding him in both arms, the police reported. The diplomat, Gokberk Ergenekon, 28 years old, was said to have returned fire and probably wounded the fleeing attacker.

title: Holy Cross 21-13 Winner
description: Holy Cross of Flushing maintained its lead in the Long Island Division of the Catholic High Schools Football League with a 21-13 victory over St. Anthony's of Smithtown yesterday at Flushing Memorial Field. The victory gave the Knights a 4-0 league record. They are followed by St. John the Baptist of West Islip, which routed Maria Regina of Uniondale, 34-0, in an interdivisional game, for its fifth victory against one loss. St. John has a 3-1 league mark and meets Holy Cross next Sunday.

title: Landfill in Jersey Petitions State
description: Owners of the Edgeboro landfill have filed a petition seeking to force the state to alter its demands for environmental improvements at the dump.

title: 100,000 Spanish Basques Protest Autonomy Issue
description: Basque nationalist leaders led as many as 100,000 silent marchers through central Bilbao today to protest what they said were moves by the Government to reduce their autonomy.

title: CITY AND U.S. OFFICIALS TO SEEK FOREIGN TIES TO BRINK'S HOLDUP
description: The chief spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that there would be a ''major coordinated effort'' between Federal and local authorities to investigate ties between a wide range of domestic and foreign terrorist groups in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery in Rockland County last week.

title: SUPREME COURT; OF THE MANY, FEW CASES ARE CHOSEN
description: A new Supreme Court term brings back to town a special kind of lottery, a high-stakes game of chance in which the lucky number comes up no more than one time in 30. The winners are guaranteed nothing but an opportunity: The Court will hear their case. The legal system will give them one more chance.

title: MUSIC: A BEAUX ARTS NIGHT
description: A WET and windblown crowd struggled in off the street Friday night, filled the Metropolitan Museum's concert hall to overflowing and then warmed itself with a comfortable evening of music by the Beaux Arts Trio. There was nothing particularly new or challenging for the listener, although the Tchaikovsky A minor Trio is something of a rarity.

title: Lions 31, Packers 27
description: Detroit's Eric Hipple, outstanding for the second straight game, ran 5 yards on a quarterback draw for the winning score with 1:54 remaining. Hipple scored twice and passed for a touchdown in leading the Lions back to the .500 mark at 4-4; Green Bay slipped to 2-6.

title: Pope Urges That Work Codes Include Rights of the Family
description: Pope John Paul II said today that family rights should be written into work codes so that labor does not break up the home and turn it into a ''transitory hotel used only for meals and rest.''

title: Commodities; Gold Fever Takes Hold In Japan
description: GOLD fever seems to be sweeping Japan, where investors are resisting the recent weakening of bullion prices that has cooled such fervor in most other countries. Indeed, Japanese of all classes and in record numbers have been buying gold bars, bullion coins and small wafers.

title: Eagles 20, Bucs 10
description: Tony Franklin's 32-yard field goal with 4:18 left broke a 10-10 tie. It came nearly three minutes after the Bucs' Bill Capece had kicked a 29-yarder.

title: PROPOSED ROCKEFELLER PARK TO BE LEFT MOSTLY WILD
description: New York State would leave largely wild, at least temporarily, the 1,500 acres of the Pocantico Hill estate that the Rockefeller family intends to donate for use as a park, the State Parks Commissioner said yesterday.

title: Lucas-Williams Trade Set
description: The on again, off again trade of Maurice Lucas for Ray Williams finally became a reality last night after a weekend of negotiations. Under the right of first refusal, the Knicks matched the New Jersey Nets' three-year, $1.5 million offer sheet to Williams and traded him to the Nets for Lucas.

title: Euphrosyne First On Aqueduct Turf
description: When Steve DiMauro entered The Very One in Saturday's Turf Classic against males instead of yesterday's Long Island Handicap against fillies and mares, many wondered why the trainer had passed up the easier spot. But The Very One finished a close third in the rich Turf Classic and yesterday DiMauro disclosed his reason for keeping The Very One out of the Long Island.

title: LIFE FROM SPACE
description: Where did life start? Could it be true that biological life and even higher civilization developed first on another planet and that the simple organisms regarded as one of the earliest forms of life on earth were sent here as ''seeds'' by the sophisticated creatures of that other world?

title: COWBOYS OVERTAKE DOLPHINS, 28-27
description: Four touchdowns were scored in the final quarter of the stirring game between Dallas and Miami here today and the Cowboys made the last two to beat the Dolphins, 28-27. The 1-point difference was set early in the game when Uwe von Schamann, the Miami kicker, missed his conversion kick after the first Dolphin touchdown. The ball hit the goalpost and fell away.

title: TREASURY TO SELL BILLS OF 3 MATURITIES THIS WEEK
description: This week's Treasury financing is confined to the bill sector, with $4.7 billion each of three-month and six-month bills to be auctioned today, followed by $5 billion of one-year bills on Thursday.

title: News Analysis
description: In the 11 days that he has been Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak has spent a good deal of time trying to dispel fears that the peace treaty with Israel that was signed by the late Anwar el-Sadat is in jeopardy.

title: DRIVE FOR TUITION TAX CREDIT SHIFTS TO WASHINGTON
description: After failing in California, supporters of tax credits for tuition payments made to private schools have brought their campaign to Washington in hopes of reviving the issue here.

title: RATES HAMPER BANK'S RESULTS
description: High interest rates during the third quarter continued to depress earnings of a number of the nation's 15 largest bank holding companies, although several showed relatively strong results.

title: WITHOUT GUILT OR SHAME
description: For delegates who wanted rosy headlines, the Cancun summit conference on development was a great success because the U.S. accepted a distant pledge of ''global negotiations.'' For others, it was a disappointment because no specific approach and no deadline was set.

title: WAS A ROBERT MOSES ENGINEER
description: Michael John Madigan, president of Madigan-Hyland, the consulting engineering concern that had been associated with Robert Moses during the construction and design of major bridges, highways and other building projects over a period of four decades, died Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. Mr. Madigan, who lived in Hinsdale, N.H., and had residences in Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla., was 86 years old.

title: FIRST CHICAGO SLIPS IN BANK RANKING
description: The First Chicago Corporation, the parent holding company of the First National Bank of Chicago, has dropped off the list of the nation's 10 largest banking companies, which could make it more costly for the bank to raise money.

title: BAKER SEES NO CHANGE IN AWACS TERMS
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader of the Senate, said today that he did not envision any important change in the terms and conditions of the proposed sale of Awacs radar aircraft to Saudi Arabia.

title: Giants Take Series
description: The Central League champion Yomiuri Giants beat the Pacific League champion Nippon Ham Fighters today, 6-3, and won the Japanese baseball World Series, four games to two. It was the Giants' first championship in eight years and their 16th since 1950. Takashi Nishimoto, the Giant pitcher, was named the most valuable player for his two victories against no defeats.

title: 3 MORE SUSPECTS IDENTIFIED IN HOLDUP OF BRINK'S TRUCK
description: Investigators have tentatively identified three new suspects wanted in connection with the $1.6 million Brink's robbery last Tuesday that resulted in the deaths of two police officers and an armored-car guard in Rockland County.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day Friday incorrectly attributed a position to the Interior De- partment on the question of reci- procity in the granting of mineral rights to Kuwait. Before granting leas- ing privileges on Federal lands, In- terior by statute must determine whether ''similar or like'' privileges are granted to Americans in Kuwait. The department has not yet issued its finding on the matter.

title: No Headline
description: WARSAW DEMANDS SOLIDARITY CANCEL GENERAL WALKOUT

title: YOUNG MAN OF AMERICA
description: LOS ANGELES STEVEN PATRICK GARVEY is a comely and courteous young man who was taught as a boy in Tampa, Fla., to stand when his mother entered the room. His manners, his patience with fans, his friendly relations with the press sometimes impress his playmates as phony and they jeer, but the fact is the first baseman of the Los Angeles Dodgers is a gentleman. He is also a very good ballplayer.

title: STEINBRENNER IS CRITICAL OF STRATEGY IN 5TH-GAME LOSS
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner and principal igniter of Yankee winning streaks, says he has addressed his team for the last time this year.

title: TV: 'SPLENDOR IN GRASS' RDONE 20 YEARS LATER
description: ''SPLENDOR IN THE GRASS'' is back in a new television version that can be seen tonight at 9 on NBC. The William Inge screenplay was first produced in 1961 as a film directed by Elia Kazan and starring Warren Beatty and Natalie Wood. At the time, it was considered rather steamy stuff, its story of adolescent sexual longings drenched in standard Freudian imagery, most notably the passion-and-purifcation symbol of rushing water.

title: Bus Rider Seized in Driver Assault
description: A mounted police officer yesterday arrested a man who was beating a bus driver in the Bronx in an apparent dispute over a fare or transfer, the police said.

title: Account Activity Here and There
description: Four bits of unrelated account activity took place last week. Tracy-Locke in Dallas may have had to resign the Shasta beverage business because of its impending acquisition by BBDO International, which has Pepsi-Cola, but there are rewards, too.

title: Fedele C. Tordella, 57, Dead; Head of a Financial Concern
description: Fedele C. Tordella, president of Manfra, Tordella & Brookes Inc. of New York City, died Saturday at his home in Allendale, N.J. He was 57 years old.

title: Soviet Says U.S. Wants Alignment With Sweden
description: The Soviet Union has accused the United States of seeking to undermine Sweden's neutrality and make that nation an active military partner against Moscow.

title: America, Nonaligned
description: President Reagan last week recalled something many Americans forget -that foreign intervention made it possible for America to gain its independence without mortgaging national honor. There's a useful lesson in that for his own Administration as it attempts to deal with today's chaotic and confusing revolutions.

title: Jersey Issues Fourth article of a series:; The Elderly
description: When the two major party gubernatorial candidates in New Jersey address elderly people, the most frequent question they are asked concerns the use of tax revenues from casino gambling for programs to aid them. The intense interest by the elderly in casino tax revenues was aroused in July when the Byrne administration announced that to balance the budget $80 million had been transferred from the Casino Revenue Fund to pay for Homestead Rebates, a property tax rebate program.

title: GREECE'S LEADER EASES HIS STAND ON U.S. BASES
description: Greece's new Socialist Prime Minister said today that despite his party platform his Government would not move on its own to end Greece's participation in NATO or close American military bases in Greece.

title: CHINESE WIDENING ROLE AT THE U.N.
description: Ten years ago today, the Communists in Peking were given the seat in the United Nations that had been held by the Nationalists in Taipei.

title: COUGARS EYEING ROSE BOWL
description: The last time Washington State went to the Rose Bowl was on New Year's Day of 1931, and the Cougars lost to Alabama, 24-0. That was long before there was a Pac-10 Conference and before the Big Ten champion was the automatic opponent. Now the Cougars have football fans talking about another appearance in the Rose Bowl next January.

title: Soccer to Egypt
description: Hisham Saleh's goal in the 70th minute gave Egypt a 1-0 victory over the United States and the championship of the Great Wall Youth Cup soccer tournament tonight.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Saudi To Visit Germany For Talks With Schmidt

title: CALIFORNIA FACING A NEW REALITY IN PLANT CLOSINGS
description: California, which set a national standard for industrial expansion in most of the past 35 years, is experiencing an unexpected shock: Industrial plants in many communities are closing, eliminating jobs and causing serious economic dislocations for some cities.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Looking It Up, Simplified and Updated The problem with dictionaries, David Fisher discovered, is that they are great at telling you what you already know, but no good at all when you need a word you've never heard of, such as the name of the grating that can be lowered at a castle's gateway.

title: NEW HURDLES MAY SLOW ATLANTA'S RAPID GROWTH
description: A generation ago, this city began bucking the South's deeply entrenched segregationist policies and propelled itself into the national limelight as a model for social and economic progress for people of all races. Its success has been shown by the steady expansion of its economic base, reflecting its image as a good place to live and work, the cultivation of racial rapport and gains by blacks in political and, to a lesser extent, economic power.

title: TRAFALGAR SHIFTS POSTS
description: Trafalgar Industries realigned some top management posts over the weekend with the election of Peter W. May, its leading financial executive, as president and chief operating officer. As president, Mr. May assumes a post formerly held by Nelson Peltz, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

title: AD EXECUTIVE LEAVING
description: Wayne J. Fickinger, 55-year-old president and chief operating officer of the J. Walter Thompson Company, a subsidiary of the JWT Group, has decided to depart Jan. 1. As he put it, ''I have a whole new set of goals that cannot be fulfilled at the company.''

title: Notre Dame's Talent Search That Ended at Home
description: After almost 30 years as president of the University of Notre Dame, the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh thought it was time to assume the new title of Chancellor and turn over day-to-day executive responsibilities to a new president.

title: A RACE FOR THE COMMON MAN
description: The fanfare that New York gave the marathon runners yesterday was for the common man - a cheer for a determined horde of 14,496, among whom it seemed that those leaning on the blue police barricades could find faces like theirs to urge on.

title: LOBBYING INTENSIFIES OVER BANKRUPTCY LAWS
description: Alarmed by the swelling tide of consumer bankruptcies, the credit industry is lobbying heavily for Congress to repeal most of the liberalized bankruptcy laws passed three years ago.

title: TREASURY'S DEBT PLANS AWAITED
description: The Treasury's heavy borrowing needs have been a key ingredient in the behavior of the credit markets all year and may have even a larger impact after Wednesday, when the Government announces its financing plans for the rest of the year.

title: Cardinals 30, Vikings 17
description: Jim Hart threw two scoring passes, Wayne Morris ran 13 yards for a touchdown and Neil O'Donoghue kicked three field goals as St. Louis (3-5) snapped Minnesota's five-game winning streak. Hart's second scoring pass, an 8-yarder to Mel Gray late in the game, marked his 200th career touchdown toss.

title: THE CALENDER
description: Monday

title: INCENTIVES CREATE DISARRAY IN CAR PRICING
description: The American automobile industry used to play follow-the-leader: General Motors would establish prices for its new cars, and Chrysler and Ford would fall into ragged line. But in the past four weeks, the game has come to look like a free-for-all, as members of the Big Three announced one price incentive after another in an effort to attract customers.

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: I T is over, and he, or she, will never be in your life again. What do you do now that the relationship has ended? Three psychologists with wide experience on the subject of loving and the end of love have something to say about this. They are Drs. Elaine Hatfield, chairman of the psychology department of the University of Hawaii and the author of ''A New Look at Love,'' written with G. William Walster; Lee Salk, professor of psychology in the psychiatry department of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, and Hanna Kapit, a psychologist and psychoanalyst on the staff of the Albert Einstein School of Medicine, who is also consultant to the professional board of Parents Without Partners.

title: 500 ATTEND FUNERAL FOR BOY 17, KILLED BY MADISON AVE. GUNMAN
description: A 17-year-old honor student from Westbury, L.I., who was shot to death yesterday in Manhattan by a gunman who apparently selected his victim at random, was buried today after funeral services attended by more than 500 relatives and friends.

title: Some Former Law Clerks Recall a 'Great Judge'
description: Paul M. Bator teaches law at Harvard, Richard Hiegel is a partner of a major New York law firm and Norman Dorsen is president of the American Civil Liberties Union. That puts them at the top of the legal profession, but what brought them and two dozen other leading legal figures to the Century Association in lower Manhattan Saturday night was a bond forged at the bottom.

title: BARBARO AND UNITY: A GRASS-ROOTS TEAM
description: To the Editor:

title: A SHIN INJURY FORCES MRS. WAITZ TO QUIT
description: Jack Waitz, the husband of the winner of the women's section of the New York Marathon the last three years, waited at the west end of the Queensboro Bridge yesterday for his wife to appear as the leading female runners made the U-turn off the bridge and headed up First Avenue.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Wednesday on intelligence oversight incorrectly described the activity of H. Ross Perot, chairman of Electronic Data Systems, regarding hostages in Iran. In February 1979 Mr. Perot said he had financed an assault by Iranians on a Teheran prison that led to the freeing of two of his company's employees.

title: S.E.C. CHIEF PLANS INSIDER TRADE CURB
description: Instances of insider trading appear to be on the rise, a problem that has not escaped the attention of John S.R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Restraining such abuses, he says, will be a top priority during his term in office.

title: FAMILY COURT UNIT ASSAILED BY STUDY AS 'NOT EFFICIENT'
description: The city's Family Court system, which handles youthful offenders from teen-age muggers to truant schoolchildren, dismisses the vast majority of its cases because of disorganization and inefficiency, according to a study by the Community Service Society.

title: Bridge: Argentina Beats Australia; U.S. Wins From Indonesia
description: Play in the world team championship here this afternoon strongly indicated the shape of things to come. The four qualifiers for the semifinal playoffs Wednesday are likely to be Britain, Argentina, Poland and the United States.

title: DISARMAMENT PANEL WORRIES ABOUT REAGAN POLICY
description: An international panel on disarmament agreed this weekend that the increased military spending that President Reagan is advocating to match Soviet spending risked making the world's economy worse rather than better.

title: Delay Assailed On Transit Funds
