description: City Council President Carol Bellamy, saying that $8 million was being lost for each month of delay, urged a state panel to act quickly to approve the $7.9 billion capital improvement plan for mass transit.

title: SEAHAWKS CONTINUE MASTERY OVER JETS
description: The Jets relived an old, recurring nightmare yesterday: the annual encounter with the Seattle Seahawks. Suddenly the ''new'' Jets disappeared, along with a four-game unbeaten streak that had lifted them to .500, as the Seahawks dominated the game with a 19-3 victory at Shea Stadium.

title: WHY AMBULANCES HAVE FIRST TO SCREAM
description: To the Editor:

title: The Choice in the Region
description: Close Call in New Jersey

title: Patricia A. Tinto Bride Of Alton Jay Landsman
description: Patricia Ann Tinto, director of communications for the minority members of the New York State Senate Finance Committee, was married yesterday to Alton Jay Landsman, a New York lawyer. The ceremony was performed at the Swan Club in Glenwood Landing, L.I., by Cantor David Benedict of Lawrence, L.I. He was assisted by the Rev. Peter Brennan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Browns 42, Colts 28
description: CLEVELAND (UPI) - Brian Sipe completed 30 of 41 passes for four touchdowns and a team-record 444 yards to lead the Cleveland attack.

title: FINANCIAL SOUNDNESS OF TEAMSTER PENSION FUND QUESTIONED BY U.S.
description: The General Accounting Office has expressed doubts about the financial soundness of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' Central States Pension Fund, one of the nation's largest private pension plans.

title: SONG: PORRELLO OFERS 4 NEW MENOTTIS
description: JOSEPH PORRELLO gave the world premieres of four new songs by Gian Carlo Menotti on Wednesday night in a Merkin Hall concert, and - given the composer's reputation - one assumed they would add zest to the evening. Unfortunately, they ended up counting for little.

title: STAGE: 'THREADS' BY JONATHAN BOLT AT CIRCLE REP
description: AS long as there is an American theater, there will always be plays about the prodigal son who returns home to make final peace with his gruff, distant father and overadoring mother. And apparently, such plays will always offer the same litany of events. Late in Act I, an old family trauma, repressed since the hero's childhood, will be dredged up tearfully by one and all. Late at night - and late in Act II -Dad and Son will make one last attempt to express their mutual love. Once they succeed, the two men will finally face the fact that both their lives are empty shams. At which point one parent will die - forcing the son to leave the womb, sadder but wiser, forever.

title: Reaching The China Market
description: IN Peking and probably in all of China, Angela Newsome, 27 years old, is Madison Avenue. For about a month, Miss Newsome, who speaks fluent Mandarin Chinese, has been the representative in China of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, ''the only international agency,'' she said, ''registered and accredited and working in China.''

title: Homestake Net Drops
description: The Homestake Mining Company, the nation's largest gold miner, said Friday that a strike and lower precious metals prices helped push its third-quarter earnings down by 95.6 percent from the period a year earlier.

title: IN NOMINEES' DEBATE, KOCH STICKS TO RACIAL-QUOTA OPPOSITION
description: In the second debate among all seven mayoral candidates, Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would try ''very hard'' to get across his ''substantive record'' on helping blacks and Hispanic people but that he would continue to oppose racial quotas.

title: 'Thank God For Helmets'
description: OUT there on the mound in the Dodgers Stadium shadows, Rich (Goose) Gossage went into his flailing windup and flung his fastball. ''I was just aiming it down the middle of the plate,'' the Yankee righthander would say later. ''But the ball got away from me.''

title: 2 WORLD RECORDS SET AS 13,360 FINISH MARATHON
description: The 12th New York City Marathon became the biggest and best yesterday, from world records by Alberto Salazar and Allison Roe to a record field of 14,496 starters, 13,360 finishers and perhaps as many 2.5 million spectators.

title: Chiefs 28, Raiders 17
description: A Kansas City rookie, Billy Jackson, rushed for three late touchdowns and Gary Spani, a linebacker, offset a final Oakland rally by streaking 91 yards to score with a recovered fumble as the Chiefs surged to victory.

title: BIRDSONG IS PLAYING DOWN HIS MILLION-DOLLAR SALARY
description: AT 25 years old, Otis Birdsong, the son of a Southern minister, has joined the New Jersey Nets as basketball's first $1 million guard.

title: Big Little Man
description: When James Bettis, a 160-pound running back, went out for the University of Cincinnati football team in the fall of 1978, he was cut after one practice.

title: 50,000 MARCH IN PARIS TO PROTEST WEAPONS BUILD UP
description: Fifty thousand chanting men and women, some wearing gas masks and others in skeleton costumes, marched through chill, rainy Paris streets today demanding an end to the East-West armament buildup and to the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: KEAN: G.O.P. CANDIDATE WITH LIBERAL TENDENCY
description: Second of two profiles of candidates for Governor of New Jersey. By RICHARD J. MEISLIN

title: 80,000 Pack Tel Aviv Square At a Concert Honoring Sadat
description: About 80,000 people packed Tel Aviv's main square and held lighted candles last night at a concert to honor President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, who was assassinated Oct. 6.

title: Quake in Mexico Kills 3; Affects Power in 2 Areas
description: Repair crews in Mexico City and in the western coastal state of Michoacan worked today to restore electric power and telephone service knocked out by a powerful earthquake that officials said killed 3 people and injured 28.

title: Ex-Congressman Cited For Contempt of Court
description: Former Representative John E. Moss has been cited for contempt of court for refusing to answer questions in a libel suit against a Seattle newspaper.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif., named Joseph Graziano vice president of finance and chief financial officer. * Bank of New York named W. Gilroy Davidson a vice president.

title: GERULAITIS IS RULED LOSER BY UMPIRE
description: Umpire David Bierwirth declared Peter McNamara of Australia the winner over Vitas Gerulaitis in the final of the $142,000 Miracle indoor tennis tournament today after Gerulaitis argued with officials over a disputed line call.

title: 17 Suspects in 22 Months Die in Chicago Lockups
description: Seventeen men, most of them young firsttime offenders, have apparently committed suicide by hanging in the city's police district lockups in 22 months, police records show.

title: The Economy
description: The Treasury will give details this week of its financing plans for the rest of 1981. Heavy Government borrowing throughout the year has been a key ingredient in the behavior of the credit markets, and further debt sales could have an even larger impact. (Page D1.)

title: SOVIET REJECTS CRITICISM OF ITS SHUNNING OF CANCUN
description: The Soviet Union today rejected criticism of its absence from the meeting of leaders of industrialized and developing nations in Cancun, Mexico, and summed up the conference as a confrontation between ''plunderers and the plundered peoples.''

title: REPORT ON ROME ENVOY DISPUTED BY U.S. AIDES BUT ALSO CONFIRMED
description: American officials in Washington and Rome today disputed a report in the Sunday issue of The New York Times that the American Ambassador to Rome had been hastily evacuated from Italy to protect him from an assassination plot by Libya.

title: Argentine Wheat Crop
description: Widespread drought has hit Argentina's wheat-growing areas and traders said Friday that they had reduced estimates of the next harvest to 7 million metric tons, about 1.5 million less than estimated a week ago and well below the 10 million forecast when the wheat was sown. The drought could affect grain exports from Argentina, which became the biggest supplier to the Soviet Union when Washington curtailed supplies after the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan.

title: YALE BRONTOSAURUS GETS HEAD ON RIGHT AT LAST
description: In what may be the world's most ancient case of mistaken identity, the huge brontosaurus on display at Yale's Peabody Museum of Natural History lost its head this weekend to scientists with new ideas of how the dinosaur really looked.

title: Warren Green, Lawyer, Weds Marsha Salamoff
description: Marsha Anne Salamoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Salamoff of Newton, Mass., was married there yesterday at Temple Shalom to Warren I. Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Green of North Miami Beach, Fla. Rabbi Murray I. Rothman performed the ceremony.

title: DIVING DEEP IN NEW YORK
description: THE dark green ocean rolls by, tugging gently as I hang on to the anchor line of the Sea Hunter, a 42-foot charter dive boat. My buddy jumps in, swims to the line and submerges to follow it to the bottom 100 feet below. I follow, the big bright silver air bubbles from his regulator swirling around me. Then the world becomes apple green and the only sounds are the hiss and click of my regulator as I breathe in and the bubbling as I exhale.

title: BILLS WIN WITH FIELD GOALS
description: The Denver Broncos went into their game against the Buffalo Bills at Orchard Park, N.Y., yesterday with the best defensive record and the top passer in the National Football League. The Broncos had allowed an average of only 257 yards a game to opponents and Craig Morton, rated No.1 in the league, was fresh from completing 25 of 38 passes for 342 yards and two touchdowns against Kansas City.

title: BOBBY MAURICE
description: Bobby Maurice, an entertainer and broadcaster, died in Roosevelt Hospital on Oct. 17 after suffering a heart attack in his Manhattan home.

title: Military Analysis
description: The controversy over the proposed sale of five Awacs aircraft to the Saudis has raised questions that go beyond the elementary issue of what the weapons will mean initially to Saudi Arabia and Israel.

title: No Headline
description: LIBYA REPORTEDLY USED 20 FLORIDA PILOTS IN CHAD

title: Fireman Arrested For Arson on L.I.
description: A volunteer fireman was arrested on charges of setting a fire that ripped through two hangars at Mitchel Field. The hangars were used to store Nassau County records and as a repair center for police vehicles.

title: Egyptian Office in New York Damaged by Fire Bomb Members of the Police Department's bomb squad inspecting the Egyptian Government's tourist office yesterday morning in Rockefeller Center after a fire bomb was hurled through its front window. No injuries were reported, but the office was heavily damaged. A caller identifying himself as a member of the Jewish Defense
description: League claimed responsibility for the bombing, saying it was a protest against the Camp David peace agreement.

title: Joined Twins, of Triplets, Die
description: Siamese twin girls died a month after they were born, medical officials say. The girls, Jeanette and Jillian, were born Sept. 24 as part of a set of triplets to Bertha Barcena, 28 years old, and her husband, Armando, 31, of El Paso. The third daughter, Jacklyn, is at home and in good health.

title: HOW AN AMIABLE YOUTH BECAME A STAR AT 20
description: business veteran, age 20, gets out of the elevator with an attractive young woman on his arm. He is wearing sunglasses, a baseball cap and designer jeans, and he is carrying an elegant soft leather briefcase the same shade of burgundy as his soft-leather shoes. The briefcase contains the two items he could not fit into his wallet - monthly car-payment bills for his Camaro and Trans Am.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a caption in Business Day Friday, Charles F. Butler was incorrectly identified as president of Air New England. Mr. Butler resigned in October 1980 and was succeeded by Robert J. Norris, who continues to serve in that position.

title: Tracy Ecclesine, W.G. Ivie 3d Wed
description: Tracy Ann Ecclesine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Ecclesine of San Diego, was married yesterday at the Norwood (N.J.) Presbyterian Church to William George Ivie 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivie Jr. of Harrington Park, N.J. The Rev. William Doster performed the ceremony.

title: Sawdon Named Agency For La Yogurt
description: Sawdon & Bess, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, is going to be the ad agency for La Yogurt French Style Yogurt, a product of Johanna Farms in Flemington, N.J.

title: ROBERT G. HOYE
description: Robert G. Hoye of Wellesley, Mass., retired president and board chairman of Jordan Marsh Company, has died at the Lahey Clinic here.

title: NOT IRON BARS OR BOND ISSUES CURB VIOLENT CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. BENJAMIN W. CAREY
description: Dr. Benjamin W. Carey, retired medical director of the Lederle Laboratories Division of the American Cyanamid Company, died Friday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. Dr. Carey, who was a resident of Westwood, was 74 years old.

title: Market Place; Storer's Plans Questioned
description: STORER BROADCASTING, like others in the burgeoning field of cable television, is spending heavily to develop its own systems, and in some quarters this is proving worrisome. The rising cost of winning new franchises and buying existing ones has alarmed skeptics, who say they believe cable's potential may not justify the expense.

title: Sports World
description: Marathon Woman

title: LACK OF FOOD MAKES STRIKERS OF 12,000 POLISH WOMEN
description: ''I worked in this factory for 20 years,'' said one of the strikers. ''I won two awards for high productivity. I was rarely sick. And what do I have? My sight is failing, I'm old and I can't even feed my family.''

title: BOTANICAL GARDENS GETS SECOND $5 MILLION GIFT
description: Enid A. Haupt, the philanthropist and former publisher of Seventeen magazine, has given $5 million to the New York Botanical Garden to endow its soaring glass-domed Conservatory. Three years ago, Mrs. Haupt donated $5 million to the Botanical Garden, which is in the Bronx, for a complete restoration of the Italian Renaissance-style structure.

title: A.M. Aikin, Longest Tenured In Texas Legislature, Is Dead
description: A.@M. Aikin Jr., dean emeritus of the Texas Senate, died last night at a Paris hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: Wild car chases, blazing shootouts, police officers slain, raids on radicals' bomb factories and hideouts - the stunning events of recent days have burst upon the New York metropolitan area with a fury unseen since the heyday of political terrorists in the 1960's.

title: MUMPHREY SIGNS
description: Speculation continued today that Jerry Mumphrey has been removed from the Yankees' starting World Series lineup as a ploy by George Steinbrenner in the owner's contract negotiations with the center fielder. But that can't be so because it was learned that Mumphrey signed a new Yankee contract last Tuesday in New York.

title: ASTOR PLACE CELEBRATES ITS NEW LEASE ON LIFE
description: Despite cloudy skies, there was a bright rainbow over Astor Place in lower Manhattan yesterday - a symbol of the growing cultural, commercial and residential life in the area.

title: Texas Instrument Net
description: Texas Instruments Inc. reported that net income in the third quarter declined 48.8 percent, to $27.1 million, or $1.15 a share, from $52.9 million, or $2.30, during the corresponding period in 1980.

title: Soviet Fuel Production
description: The Soviet Union's output of oil and natural gas climbed in the first nine months of this year, compared with last year's levels, but coal production declined, according to official industrial statistics published Friday.

title: AT 30, THE PARIS BALL IS PROPLERLY ELEGANT
description: The April in Paris Ball, which took place Friday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, is one of the grande dames of the charity circuit.

title: Washington Watch; Foreign Ties Of Companies
description: WASHINGTON OFFICIAL Government policy is still to encourage foreign investment, but Congress and some departments, especially the Defense Department, are starting to worry about the implications of the ownership of some high-technology American enterprises by foreign government-controlled companies.

title: HASHISH IN SUNKEN SHIP FOUND OFF JERSEY SHORE
description: The puzzle began with several 130-pound bales of hashish that washed up on beaches in Ocean County, N.J., and the solution began to be pieced together with the chance discovery last week of a sunken ship.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 26, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Tornado Causes Injuries On Florida Panhandle
description: A tornado touched down in this Florida Panhandle town today, injuring at least 10 people and causing extensive property damage, officials said.

title: Yeager Is Proving To Be Right Man
description: Manager Tommy Lasorda of the Dodgers watched Dusty Baker strike out swinging mightily in the seventh inning today with the Yankees ahead, 1-0, and Rich Gossage waiting in the bullpen and decided his next hitters needed some advice.

title: ADVERTISING LURES HOSPITAL PATIENTS
description: Steak and champagne dinners, guarantees of 60-second service, promises that nobody does it better: all are being used to lure more patients into the nation's hospitals.

title: Index; International
description: Israelis debate the role of religion in daily lives A1 Report on Rome envoy disputed by aides but also confirmed A4 Around the World A5 China gradually extending its in- fluence in the U.N. A9 Lack of food turns 12,000 Polish women into strikers A10 Margaret Papandreou, an Ameri- can-born feminist in Greece A12 International panel cites ''eco- nomic case for disarmament'' A14 Soaring unemployment alarms Europe A15 Government/Politics Thomas H. Haupt donates $5 million to aid Conservatory B6 News Analysis William E. McFadden examines terrorist groups' resurfacing B8 SportsMonday Baseball: Reuss stops Yankees, 2-1; Dodgers lead, 3-2 C1

title: 5 Railroads Enter Pleas
description: Five railroad companies have entered pleas in the first major antitrust court case begun by the Reagan Administration.

title: News Analysis
description: The Legislature is returning tomorrow, and that in itself says a great deal about the changes that have taken place in New York State government over the last decade.

title: Saints 17, Bengals 7
description: George Rogers broke open a scoreless tie with a 19-yard touchdown run in the third quarter, and New Orleans went on to an upset.

title: Suspect in Nun's Rape Is Held Without Bail
description: A judge ordered yesterday that one of two men charged with the rape and mutilation of a 31-year-old nun be held without bail and be placed under a suicide watch.

title: Arizona Plans Medicaid With Competitive Bids
description: Arizona, the only state without a Medicaid program, has reached agreement with the Federal Government to split costs of a project to provide health care for the poor based on competitive bidding.

title: SOMALI LEADER MARKS ANNIVERSARY
description: President Mohammed Siad Barre watching parade in Mogadishu that commemorated the 12th year of his takeover. Soviet SAM-3 antiaircraft missiles, above, were on display, although Somalia has abandoned Soviet support and is now a pro-Western nation. Somalia's foe now is Ethiopia, which claims the disputed Ogaden region.

title: CITY AID FOR CITY U. SENIOR COLLEGES NEARING END
description: The adoption of the proposed 1982-83 budget by the trustees of the City University of New York, expected tonight, will complete the phasing out of the city's contribution to the operations of the university's nine senior colleges.

title: LOCAL EROSION
description: To the Editor:

title: A FEDERAL LAW THAT PUTS PRODUCT LIABILITY INSURANCE AT RISK
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR MARGARET PAPANDREOU, A 'QUIET RAGE' OF FEMINISM
description: Margaret Papandreou believes her husband's new Socialist Government will mean a breakthrough for Greek women, who she says ''have been largely suppressed through our capitalist system and our patriarchal mentality.''

title: Ex-Wife of Furniture Mogul Found Dead in Burned Home
description: Margaret (Bibi) Levitz, the ex-wife of Leon Levitz, founder of a chain of furniture stores, was found dead today in the ruins of her home, which had been set on fire, the police said.

title: ORDERS DIP BY 49.8% FOR TOOLS
description: Machine tool orders, which have been depressed for the past year, fell a sharp 49.8 percent in September from the similar period in 1980, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.

title: Harold L. Renfield, 77; An Importer of Spirits
description: Harold L. Renfield, a founder of Renfield Importers Ltd., a leading importer of wine and liquors, died Friday at his home on the Upper East Side after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In this court, the defendant is very, very, very innocent until proven guilty.'' - Michael Fabricant, associate professor at Hunter College School of Social Work, on study critical of New York City's Family Court. (A1:1.)

title: DOGS THAT DO NOT BARK
description: The ineptitude of the Reagan Administration in foreign policy - the fumbles, the discords, the embarrassing corrections -has become an open scandal. But it is an amazingly quiet scandal in the one place where vigorous criticism might be expected: Washington. The Washington critics who savaged Jimmy Carter for ''incompetence'' are acting less like tigers now than tabby cats.

title: MARATHONERS A DIVERSE GROUP
description: On a gray day on the gray Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, a shimmering, brightly clad throng of 14,496 men and women streamed across as the New York Marathon began yesterday morning. Among them were some highly unusual entrants, including people who might never be expected to run 26 miles - or to run a single step.

title: COALITION OF BLACK WOMEN GOES NATIONAL
description: Repeatedly, before small groups and large ones, in a soft voice and an impassioned one, Jewell Jackson McCabe said, ''We always hear that behind every great man is a woman. I say that in this world behind every great effort is a black woman going unrecognized.''

title: Gilbert Leaves Ads For Cable Business
description: Richard L. Gilbert, a young-looking 60, has decided after being president of two ad agencies that he really needs a change of pace after 30 years in the same business. So, having read all there is to read on the subject and talking to as many experts as possible, he is becoming a consultant on cable television programming.

title: Man Injured in Explosion
description: An explosion ripped through part of a three-story apartment building in this Chicago suburb today, slightly injuring one man, the police said. The man, who was not immediately identified, was treated at Lutheran General Hospital in Park Ridge and released. A disaster alert at local hospitals was called off when all of the building's approximately 100 tenants were accounted for.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOMER ON VIEW

title: PONDERING REACTIONS TO PHONIC INSULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surchages on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Redskins 24, Patriots 22
description: Joe Theismann passed for one touchdown and ran for another to lead Washington over the Patriots, who missed a 53-yard field-goal attempt with 51 seconds to play.

title: Waste Plant Gains In Connecticut
description: After three years of study, the University of Connecticut is about to build a $600,000 treatment and disposal system for hazardous wastes produced during research and teaching.

title: QUEEN COMPLETES A TIRING STATE VISIT
description: It was goodbye to Sri Lanka for Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip yesterday as the royal couple ended a five-day state visit to the island nation.

title: INJURIES MOUNTING FOR RANGERS
description: The Rangers were giving away pucks on the ice at Madison Square Garden last night, so the Montreal Canadiens took four of them and put them in the New York net for a 4-2 victory that extended their undefeated streak to eight games.

title: WALDHEIM, HIS OFFICE, AND ITS FUTURE
description: Kurt Waldheim's candidacy for a third five-year term raises questions not only about his performance but also about the office of Secretary-General itself. The system needs reform.

title: FORMER REAGAN INSIDER PERCEIVES SIGNS OF DRIFT
description: John P. Sears, who twice managed Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaigns, never gets invited to the White House.

title: GIANTS WIN, 27-24, ON OVERTIME KICK
description: The Giants are for real. In a game filled with opportunities made and opportunities lost, they seized enough chances at the right time today and upset the Atlanta Falcons, 27-24.

title: Jewel Dealer Robbed at Waldorf
description: A Manhattan jewel dealer was lured to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and robbed of more than $200,000 worth of assorted jewelry, the police said.

title: U.S. COURT REJECTS ROTTED-CASH CASE
description: A man who hid cash in his mother's basement, where it was damaged by a flood, now says he is out nearly $73,000 in rotted bills that the Treasury Department will not redeem.

title: DID CASTRO DOUBLE-CROSS OSCAR LEWIS?
description: THE anthropologist Oscar Lewis died of a heart attack at 55 in December 1970 while he was in New York doing research on poor Puerto Ricans and Cubans. Mr. Lewis, who wrote ''The Children of Sanchez'' and other well-known studies of slum families, had been ill with heart trouble earlier that year. But a recent book by an American professor in Canada, Maurice Halperin, contends that the government of Fidel Castro contributed to Mr. Lewis's death when it ''doublecrossed'' him by closing Project Cuba, his research into the transformation of Cuban society under a revolutionary government, and confiscating the project's files in June 1970.

title: ARGENTINA'S INSTABILITY SLOWS INFLOW OF FOREIGN INVESTMENT
description: Foreign investors, who have been showing increased interest in Argentina in the past few years, are apparently adopting a more cautious approach because of the country's political and economic instability.

title: A MODERN MAJOR GENERAL
description: HE was William the Conqueror catching the south wind into England. He was Hannibal crossing the Alps with a cortege of elephants. He was George Washington crossing the Delaware in a rowboat.

title: Jose Ferrer Bows Out Of Golda Meir TV Film
description: Jose Ferrer withdrew last week from the cast of a television movie about Golda Meir, Prime Minister of Israel from 1969 to 1974. Mr. Ferrer was to portray President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt in ''A Woman Called Golda,'' which is being filmed in Israel. After Mr. Sadat's assassination, Mr. Ferrer, according to reports, feared the Middle East was unstable.

title: AFTER FIRE: PERPLEXITY IN HOBOKEN
description: Ministers from many of this city's churches gathered for a prayer service tonight amid fire hoses and rubble in front of the tenement where fire took the lives of 11 persons early yesterday.

title: Lori Jane Wische Married To Donald T. Stone, Artist
description: The marriage of Lori Jane Wische to Donald Todd Stone took place yesterday at the couple's home in Manhattan.

title: TOWN BUILT OF LEGENDS KEEPS WILD WEST ALIVE
description: Around here, some folks still talk about Wyatt and Doc as if they were acquaintances you might meet any time at the big mahogany bar in the Crystal Palace Saloon. You can almost believe it - if you can ignore the Hondas, Kawasakis and Suzukis parked at the hitching rail nearby, and block out Reggie Jackson chasing a fly ball on the saloon's television set.

title: BUILDING TO BE HALTED ON COAST NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: Directors of the Washington Public Power Supply System have approved a $150 million plan to suspend construction of two nuclear power plants for which $2.25 billion has already been raised.

title: Deborah Ann Walsh Wed To Robert Davis Rathbun
description: Deborah Ann Walsh and Robert Davis Rathbun were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Sharon, Conn. The Rev. Thomas A. Roan, associate minister of the First Congregational Church in Naugatuck, Conn., the bridegroom's brother-in-law, performed the ceremony.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard LECTURES ON RUSSIAN LITERATURE. By Vladimir Nabokov. Edited, with in- troduction by Fredson Bowers. Illus- trated. 324 pages. Harcourt Brace Jova- novich. $19.95.

title: 6 STUDENTS AT BROWN CHARGED FOR DISRUPTING CASEY SPEECH
description: At least six and possibly as many as 25 Brown University students could be dismissed as a result of a protest at a speech on Oct. 15 by William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Deere Unit Rating Cut
description: The Standard and Poor's Corporation said that it had downgraded the Deere & Company credit subsidiary's senior debt ratings to AA from AA and subordinated debt rating to A+ from AA. It noted that the ratings applied to almost $400 miliion of securities. S.& P. said the changes reflected the credit subsidiary's growing use of short-term, variable-rate debt to finance its fixed-rate receivables portfolio. This imbalance has resulted in falling earnings, necessitating income-support payments from the parent to maintain fixed-charge coverage, it added.

title: Mr. Reagan's Immigration Music
description: Give the Reagan Administration, and especially Attorney General Smith, credit: they have now devised and sent to Congress a detailed program for modernizing the creaky immigration laws. It took a long time; we disagree with some parts; and there are even parts we detest. But it is a careful and coherent program - one which, however modified, can finally put the country back in charge of its own borders. That is more than any President has offered since Lyndon Johnson, and even if it does no more than focus national debate, the Reagan package can provide the basis for new laws that can and should be enforced.

title: REVIVAL AT DYING G.M. PALNT
description: The shock waves struck early this year: The General Motors Corporation, operator of the Hyatt bearing plant here since 1938, planned to close the factory. G.M. said it would buy less costly parts elsewhere, including Japan, where wages and benefits run about half of the more than $20 an hour that workers here cost.

title: BRIEFING
description: ONE clear message at the Cancun economic conference was Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s primacy over Richard V. Allen, the President's national security adviser, in stating, and coloring, the Reagan Administration's position each day at news briefings.

title: Schwarz Expanding Toy Store
description: F.A.O. Schwarz, the nation's largest toy chain, is carrying out the first major expansion of its flagship store in Manhattan in half a century.

title: Coast Guard Intercepts Boat With 57 Haitians
description: The Coast Guard intercepted its first boatload of refugees tonight after two weeks of patrolling Haitian waters in an effort to turn back illegal aliens, a spokesman said.

title: NEW BILL RATES DOWN A BIT
description: Interest rates declined slightly at yesterday's auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills, but that provided little comfort to the bond market, where long-term yields rose sharply.

title: Steamers Select Hayes In Indoor Soccer Draft
description: The St. Louis Steamers selected John Hayes, a forward from St. Louis University, with its first pick in the Major Indoor Soccer League's annual draft today. The Steamers, the league runner-up last season to the New York Arrows, acquired the first selection in the draft in a late deal with the New Jersey Rockets for future considerations.

title: Gold Contract Margins Cut
description: New York's Commodity Exchange, the major metals futures market, said yesterday that it would reduce margin requirements for traders in gold and silver contracts, effective tomorrow.

title: JWT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign currency translation losses of $677,000 for the qr and $4.4 million for the 9 mos...C-After foreign currency translation losses of $359,000 for the qr and $850,000 for the 9 mos

FIRST CITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After tax credits of $278,708 for the qr and $386,590 for the yr...C-Net income; no yr-ago shr earnings figures are available since the association was converted to a stock company on Mar 2 1981

title: BEGIN SAYS ISRAEL AND EGYPT SEEK A 'BREAKTHROUGH' ON PALESTINIANS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Israel and Egypt would try for a breakthrough in the stalled talks on Palestinian self-administration by concentrating negotiations on the elections, strucutures and powers of Palestinian councils to be established in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank.

title: News Analysis
description: Throughout the last two years, and again last Tuesday, New York City has been prodded by court orders into providing decent shelter for its tens of thousands of homeless men - action the city insists it always intends to take, but not on the court's timetable.

title: KANSAS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INVESTMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After capital gains of $321...C-After income of $77,000 from discontinued operations and capital gains of $3,872... D-After a capital loss of $204,968...E-After income of $70,000 from discontinued operations and capital losses of $302,128

title: BALLET: MISSES RODRIGUEZ AND JACKSON AS SHREWS
description: JOHN CRANKO'S ''The Taming of the Shrew'' may not be the most subtle of comic ballets. Fortunately, however, weekend cast changes at the Joffrey Ballet showed that it provides opportunities for robust characterizations and vivid displays of dancing.

title: PLAY: VIOLENT 60'S RELIVED IN 'BLACK PEOPLE'S PARTY'
description: AS tragic coincidence would have it, the time seems terribly right for a play like Earl Anthony's ''Black People's Party,'' now at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater. Like last week's reallife events in Nyack, this drama jolts us back to the revolutionary violence of the 60's. Mr. Anthony's subject, only thinly disguised, is the Black Panther Party, and it's a subject he can presumably speak about with authority and understanding. For a few months in 1968 - until he departed in an ideological dispute - Mr. Anthony served as the party's deputy minister of information in Los Angeles. He later wrote a controversial memoir of his experiences, ''Picking Up the Gun: A Report on the Black Panthers.''

title: EATON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After credits from insurance settlement of $10.5 million for the qr and $24.4 million for the 9 mos...C-After $43.6 million charge from the phaseing out of plants

title: BEAR CREEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERNATIONAL SHIPHOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $3,422,000 or 65 cents a shr for the qr and $4,622,000 or $1.07 a shr for the 9 mos...C-Net loss after $2,953,000 gain from the sale of vessels; yr-ago revs have been restated to exclude a gain on the sale of vessels and barges

title: TEXAS GAS TRANSMISSION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $8.5 million tax credit.

title: A VERY SMALL MISSION, A VERY GREAT SURPRISE
description: On any given day Ernest Corea might have to serve as economist, negotiator, writer, speaker, public relations expert and policy analyst. In Washington barely six months, he has already been auctioned off as a dinner partner and cross-examined by curious citizens in a supermarket.

title: Jury Selection Begins In Point-Shaving Trial
description: Thirty-three prospective jurors were chosen yesterday for the trial of five men charged in a point-shaving conspiracy involving six Boston College basketball games during the 1978-1979 season.

title: THE GREAT (PIECEMEAL) EMANCIPATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Option Trade Plan Delayed
description: A Federal appeals court has blocked the opening of trading in options on interest-bearing securities on the Chicago Board Options Exchange.

title: LOUISIANA LAND OFFSHORE EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
POP: 3 ARTISTS IN MIXED MEDIA
description: based performance artist who recently signed a major contract with Warner Bros. Records, appeared in concert at the Ritz on Sunday with the poet John Giorno and the author William Burroughs.

title: RUTH LEONARD HARRISON
description: Ruth Leonard Harrison, the mother of William A. Leonard, president of CBS News, died Sunday in a Connecticut nursing home at the age of 93. A longtime resident of East Haddam and Westport, Conn., she was the widow of Richard C. Harrison, former president of the White Rock Mineral Springs Company.

title: A FRENCH SOCIALIST PUZZLE: AFTER WINNING, WHAT?
description: ''It would be a paradox if we should see in our success our own extinction,'' Paul Quiles, a Socialist leader, told his party's congress on Friday.

title: Korchnoi Postponement Delays World Chess
description: The 10th game of the world chess championship match between Anatoly Karpov, the titleholder, and Viktor Korchnoi has been postponed until Thursday at the challenger's request.

title: LTV-Grumman
description: The LTV Corporation said that a United States District Court will hear arguments on Thursday on its charges that the Grumman Corporation made material omissions and misrepresentations in public statements on LTV's tender offer for Grumman stock. It said the court in Dallas will also hear its charges that recent purchases of Grumman stock by the company and its pension plan violated securities laws.

COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO CONSOLIDATED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: B-Includes currency translation losses of $1,700,000 for the qr and $11,500,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes currency translat loss of $570,000 for the qr and a currency translation gain of $400,000 or 1 cent a shr for 9 mos

CRUTCHER RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of companies acquired in 1981 on a pooling of interests basis

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $75 million extraordinary charge for removal of Rely tampons fromthe market.

title: 'BLANKET PROTEST' FADING AT ULSTER JAIL
description: The Irish nationalists' so-called ''blanket protest'' staged over the last five years by prisoners at Maze Prison near Belfast, Northern Ireland, seems to be coming to an end.

title: HERITAGE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1980 shr earnings adjusted for 50 percent and 10 percent stock divds paid in Jan and Sept, respectively

title: PINE POINT MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THRIFTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
EDUCATION
description: TWO Chicago researchers have confirmed what high school and college students have known for years: Many English teachers are more impressed by purple prose than by the clear, concise language that they profess to teach.

title: Moody's Lowers Woolworth Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc., a major bond rating service, said it had lowered its rating on the F.W. Woolworth Company's senior debt to Baa from A. Moody's ratings range from AAA, considered the highest quality, to C, considered the highest risk. Baa is at the low end of what is considered investment grade.

title: Trial Date Scheduled For Super Giant Slalom
description: The super giant slalom, which could become the fourth speciality in the World Cup of Alpine skiing, will be tried on an experimental basis for the first time in Madonna di Campigli Dec. 10, ski officials said today.

title: DODGERS SEEK TO CLINCH SERIES AS HOOTON FACES JOHN
description: Before the Yankees' lost weekend in Los Angeles, their believers had felt certain that when the team returned home, George Steinbrenner would have a World Series trophy instead of a possibly broken hand.

title: KROGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOPRANO: IRENE GUBRUD IN RECITAL AT TULLY HALL
description: IN a time of general prosperity for the performing arts, the song recital remains a pocket of poverty. It is only in audiences that we are poor, however, not in talented singers. For that reason, the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation's vocal awards have become an invaluable way to encourage both artists and audiences to keep the song recital tradition alive in a time of shrinkage. In 1980, the Naumburg Award went to four sopranos, all of them well-recognized young professionals: Irene Gubrud, Lucy Shelton, Jan Opalach and Faith Esham.

title: IN ALBANY, LAWMAKERS RECTIFY OWN OVERSIGHTS
description: The New York State Legislature, facing a wide range of difficult issues here this week, will have to spend part of its time correcting mistakes - more commonly referred to by legislators as ''slight errors.''

title: By Mary Cantwell
description: The Editorial Notebook Imperfect Parents

title: MOSELEY HALLGARTEN & ESTABROOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Money Is Found From '57 Robbery
description: Receipts found in a rotting burlap bag filled with thousands of dollars confirm that the money had been taken in an armed robbery in 1957, Police Chief Maxie Patterson said.

title: NEW CHIEF IS NAMED AT LYKES STEAMSHIP
description: The LTV Corporation has named a new chief executive officer of its Lykes Bros. Steamship Company unit. W. James Amoss Jr., the 57-yearold president of Lykes, will succeed Joseph T. Lykes Jr., the 63-year-old chairman, as chief executive on Jan. 1, 1982. Mr. Lykes is retiring but will become a consultant to the company.

title: License Renewed For Caesars World
description: The Casino Control Commission unconditionally renewed a permanent gaming license to Caesars World for its Atlantic City Boardwalk Regency hotel-casino.

title: BOOK OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt WALDO EMERSON. A Biography. By Gay Wilson Allen. 751 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $25.

title: A LOOK BACK AT THE FIRST VOYAGE
description: THE second mission of the Columbia has a hard act to follow. After nearly a decade of development, at a cost of some $10 billion, the first mission began what would prove to be a dramatically successful maiden test flight at 6:50 A.M. April 12 from launching pad 39-A at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. It had been nearly six years since Americans had flown in space. The mission would end with the shuttle entering the earth's atmosphere as a glistening speck in the sky and then settling down for the smoothest of landings. Here is a reprise: The Crew John W. Young and Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy. Objectives Test the ability of the world's first re-usable spaceship to lift off under rocket power, cruise through orbit like a spacecraft, reenter the atmosphere and glide to a runway landing. Problems

title: Sale of Celebrities' Castoffs Benefits Blind
description: It was raining, but that did not keep more than 200 people from lining up outside the Lighthouse for the Blind auditorium on 59th Street yesterday to buy castoff clothes from the wardrobes of such celebrities as Ethel Merman, Lauren Bacall and Betty Furness.

title: Stocks Weaken Amid Concern on Rates
description: Stock prices dropped moderately yesterday, reflecting investor apprehension over high interest rates and inflation as well as the sluggish state of the nation's economy.

title: Auction of Artists' Masks
description: A silent auction of 100 artists' masks will take place at a gala dinner and masked ball tomorrow at 7 P.M. at the Metropolitan Club, 1 East 60th Street. The sale will benefit the New Museum, a modern-art museum at 65 Fifth Avenue. Tickets to the event, which will disperse masks by, among others, William Copley, Nancy Graves and Susan Rothenberg, are $150 each.

title: Airline Credit Fears Voiced
description: A senior official of Pan American World Airways warned today that the borrowing practices of the world's ailing air transportation industry could be selfdestructive.

title: LEGISLATORS WEIGH WELFARE CUTS' IMPACT
description: As members of the Legislature returned here for a session designed to handle unfinished business, the leaders of the Democratic-led Assembly were pushing to expand Governor Carey's proposal to have the state pick up the costs for some groups who have been cut from the welfare rolls by Federal budget reductions.

title: Johnson, Bucks Apart
description: Here it is only three days before their season opener, and the Milwaukee Bucks appear as far as ever from a contract agreement with Marques Johnson, one of the best small forwards in the National Basketball Association, who is a holdout. ''I just don't know what is going to happen,'' says Don Nelson, Milwaukee's coach and general manager.

title: STUDY ON INFANT FORMULA USE
description: Despite the natural childbirth and nursing movement that has led many women back to breast-feeding, 68 percent of the mothers who gave birth in all types of hospitals in New York City last year planned to use infant formula, according to a study by the New York City Department of Health.

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign currency translation losses of $9,990,000 for the qr and $23,611,000 for the 9 mos...C-After foreign currency translation losses of $246,000 for the qr and $2,051,0 for the 9 mos

title: REAGAN AIDES FAIL TO MOLLIFY WORRIED SCIENTISTS
description: In an atmosphere of deep crisis, a delegation of nearly 100 leaders of American science met here today with top Reagan Administration officials to discuss the fate of science in anticipation of further cuts in Federal support for research.

title: SUBCOMMITTEE MOVES TO CENTER STAGE
description: When Representative Norman D. Dicks walked into his office today, he was handed a note that Bill Burlison wanted to see him. The Washington Democrat was not exactly surprised.

title: THREAT OF STEEL IMPORTS IS CHALLENGED
description: When the import figures for August showed that steel imports accounted for 25 percent of the market, U.S. Steel, National Steel and Bethlehem Steel began threatening to file dumping suits against foreign steel producers.

title: ROLLINS BURDICK HUNTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenues for the 9 months include investment income of $7,498,000 in 1982 and $5,325,000 for the 1980 period.

title: Heavy Turnout Expected In Atlanta Mayoral Vote
description: A heavy voter turnout was forecast for tomorrow's Atlanta mayoral runoff pitting Andrew Young, the former chief delegate to United Nations, against a state Representative, Sidney Marcus.

PHILADELPHIA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN ASSERTS U.S. IS COMMITTED TO SECURITY OF SOME IN MIDDLE EAST
description: The Reagan Administration says in a report to Congress that although the United States has no formal security obligations toward Middle East nations, it has ''a general policy commitment to the security and integrity'' of Israel and other ''friendly states in the area.''

title: VETERANS' ART: REFLECTIONS ON VIETNAM
description: Camouflage fabric has been stapled over the picture windows of NAME, the city's oldest alternative gallery, renowned for exhibiting experimental and controversial art.

title: Bowler Battles Pain
description: There was 33-year-old Bong Coo, one of the world's outstanding female amateur bowlers, preparing to take a practice shot for the 1981 Bowling World Cup at Madison Square Garden the other day when she felt a twinge in her lower back. ''It almost put me in a state of shock,'' she said.

title: News Analysis
description: The farm-state coalition, which has long dictated agricultural policy on Capitol Hill, is cracking under budget pressures and political rivalries.

title: RISE OF MILITANCY BY MOSLEMS THREATENS STABILITY IN EGYPT
description: Tallal, a 26-year-old who is in prison, is known to the authorities here as a ''muta'assib,'' a Moslem fanatic. His life story is the story of the rise in Egypt of Islamic militancy - the political force that not only assassinated Anwar el-Sadat but also continues to pose a serious threat to the stability of this nation of 43 million.

title: N.& W. Profit Up by 112.6%
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway Company reported today a profit of $92.7 million, or $2.85 a share, in the third quarter ended Sept. 30, up 112.6 percent from $43.6 million, or $1.38, in the same period last year.

description: The Eaton Corporation, which makes automobile, truck and off-highway vehicle components as well as industrial electrical and electronic devices, reported today that third-quarter earnings rose 43.2 percent, to $22.2 million, or 81 cents a share, from $15.5 million, or 58 cents a share, in the 1980 third quarter.

It's On With the Dance
description: When he took over the Roseland ballroom last month, there was immediate speculation that Albert Ginsberg planned to raze the landmark to make way for a skyscraper.

title: Bridge: U.S., Poles and Argentines Lose, Tightening the Race
description: At the world team championships here this afternoon, two surprises left a tense situation in which all seven teams still have a chance to qualify for the semifinal playoffs due Wednesday.

title: N.A.I.A. Sets Meet
description: The National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics will hold its track and field championship meet at Laidley Field here next spring, officials said today.

title: MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Papandreou Opens Drive To Settle Cyprus Issue
description: Greece's new Socialist Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, said today that he was calling on all foreign governments to declare whether they recognize that northern Cyprus is under Turkish military occupation.

title: Alexander's Head Gets $80,000 Raise
description: When the Farkas family, founders of Alexander's Inc., split over what was thought to be a demand that the retailer make better use of its real estate, there was talk that Alexander Farkas would resign as president and chief executive officer when his employment contract expired on July 31, 1981. But, according to the New York retail chain's proxy statement, issued last week, Mr. Farkas, 51 years old, signed a new contract effective Aug. 1 with an $80,000-a-year salary increase.

title: Lion Coach Says Player Faces a Certain Fine
description: Monte Clark, the Detroit Lions coach, said today he thought William Gay, a Lions defensive tackle, faces a certain fine and possible suspension by the National Football League for a late hit he made on Lynn Dickey of Green Bay.

title: ASARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago 9 mos results have been restated to include earnings of $20,866,000 or 71 cents a shr for the cumulative effect on prior yrs of changes in accounting policy made in the fourth qr of 1980

title: Unofficial Soviet Art On View in Jersey City
description: The 25th anniversary of nonconformist art in the Soviet Union is being observed by the Museum of Soviet Unofficial Art in Jersey City with an exhibition of 200 works by 70 artists.

title: Backer & Spielvogel Adds V-8 Juice Account
description: Backer & Spielvogel, which became the national ad agency for Campbell Soup's condensed soups last May, has now picked up the V-8 line of vegetable juices.

title: PRENTICE-HALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
After Cancun
description: The Cancun 22 did not parley in vain. It was assuredly useful for President Reagan to try taking pie in the sky off the agenda of North-South conversation. No doubt the arguments will continue in the vague ''global negotiations'' agreed upon in Mexico. But at least one point is now clearer. Poorer nations demand more control over international assistance agencies - and America rightly says no. There are other ways it can sensibly say yes.

title: P.L.O.'S KEY ROLE IN A MIDEAST PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: EDITH HEAD, FASHION DESIGNER FOR THE MOVIES, DIES
description: Edith Head, the doyenne of motion-picture costume design who received a record eight Academy Awards for her work on films, died at Good Samaritan Hospital in Hollywood on Saturday. Death was attributed to myelobibrosis myeloid, a rare disease of the bone marrow.

title: People
description: * Richard H. Thomas and Thomas Mabley, senior vice presidents at Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein Inc., have been named creative directors.

title: DOLE URGES '82 TAX RISE TO AVERT HUGE DEFICITS
description: Senator Bob Dole, splitting openly with his Republican colleagues in the House, declared today that ''Congress must act in 1982'' to raise more revenues to avert huge budget deficits in the future.

title: 33 HAITIANS DROWN AS BOAT CAPSIZES OFF FLORIDA
description: Thirty-three Haitians drowned this morning in choppy waters just north of here after their jerry-built 30-foot boat capsized less than a mile from shore. Thirty-four others from the overloaded vessel swam to shore and were taken, many of them in tears, to a Federal detention facility for illegal aliens.

title: GROLIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After pretax foreign exchange losses of 2,677,000... C-After pretax foreign exchange gains of $450,000... D-After pretax foreign exchange losses of $3,518,000 and a pretax provision of $6 million for liquidation of Japanese operations...E-Net income after a pretax foreign exchange gain of $2,235,000

title: BIRMINGHAM ELECTIONS MIRROR CITY'S VOLATILE RACIAL DIVISION
description: Next week's runoff for five seats on the nine-member Birmingham City Council offers a polarized electorate a choice between white and black candidates.

title: P.& G., SMITHKLINE, PITTSTON, SINGER UP
description: The Procter & Gamble Company announced yesterday that earnings in the first fiscal quarter of 1982 ended Sept.30 increased 12.9 percent, on a 3.4 percent sales increase. The company attributed the gains to higher unit sales but said results were lower than expected because of changes in foreign currency exchange rates.

title: CONSULTANT TO U.S.
description: Dr. Jane Perry Clark Carey, a political scientist and consultant to the Federal Government on displaced persons and refugees, died Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan and Weston, Conn.

title: Private to Undergo Psychiatric Tests
description: BUFFALO (AP) - Joseph Christopher, a white Army private charged with killing four black men in the Buffalo area, will undergo psychiatric examination to see if he knew what he was doing when he waived a trial by jury, a judge ruled.

Though hardly a new phenomenon, attacks on books, films and other teaching materials, have greatly increased in recent years as newly resurgent conservative groups try to cleanse the schools, and the children's minds, of words and ideas they find objectionable.

description: Three physicians from Rochester, N.Y., have reported what they believe is the first case of toxic shock syndrome in a woman who had just given birth after a normal pregnancy.

description: The Broadway opening of the musical ''Merrily We Roll Along'' has been postponed from Nov. 9 to Nov. 16.

description: It was an unlikely sight at Lincoln Center. A glittering Broadway chorus line trailed by Mickey Rooney in drag descended a grand staircase at the New York State Theater last night in an extravaganza that brought together two different worlds of the stage.

title: Transactions;

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1981; The Economy
description: The Government will revise the housing part of the Consumer Price Index. Administration officials said the aim was to eliminate the distorting impact of mortgage interest rates on the key inflation measure. They said this would eventually reduce cost-of-living increases for people whose benefits are tied to the index. (Page A1.)

description: Glenn Anders, the leading man of many Broadway plays in the 1920's and 30's, most notably Eugene O'Neill's ''Strange Interlude,'' died yesterday in Englewood, N.J. He was 92 years old and had lived in recent years at the Actors Fund Home there.

title: Home Sales Lowest Since 1974 Level
description: Sales of existing single-family homes continued to slide in September, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.1 million, the lowest level since 1974, the National Association of Realtors reported today.

title: STEELERS DEFEAT OILERS, 26 TO 13
description: The Steelers' swarming defense tonight stopped Earl Campbell, the Oilers' halfback, and a key interception of a Ken Stabler pass set up a final score with two minutes remaining as Pittsburgh defeated Houston, 26-13.

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1981
description: International Polish military units were deployed across the country to help the local authorities resolve shortages of food and fuel. As hundreds of the small units arrived in towns, there was no report of major reaction or any incidents. A one-hour national strike scheduled by the Solidarity union for tomorrow was denounced by officials as ''a threat to security.'' (Page A1, Column 1.) Washington asked Moscow to ''review'' its actions and policies around the world. In making the request, Arthur A. Hartman, the new Ambassador, cited the Reagan Administration's main criticisms of the Soviet Union, but pledged to pursue diplomatic negotiations. He is a career Foreign Service officer. (A6:3-6.)

description: Two propositions on next Tuesday's ballot in New York would give state agencies the money they need to meet urgent public needs. We urge support for both.

description: Gnome's Gold, the 122-pound highweight, closed strongly in the stretch yesterday and won the $84,300 Pilgrim Stakes on a soggy turf course at Aqueduct.

title: NEW U.S. ENVOY BIDS SOVIET 'REVIEW' ITS POLICIES AND ACTIONS
description: Arthur A. Hartman presented his credentials today as the 17th United States Ambassador to Moscow and in a statement prepared for the occasion urged the Soviet Union to ''review'' its actions and policies in Afghanistan, Africa, Southeast Asia and elsewhere.

title: PROFITS ON SANTA FE TRADING FROZEN
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused a Kuwaiti businessman and several others of profiting from advance knowledge that the state-owned Kuwait Petroleum Corporation planned to buy the Santa Fe International Corporation, an American oil drilling company, for $2.5 billion.

title: BROCKWAY GLASS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bally Acquisition
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, the world's leading manufacturer of coin-operated amusement games, said it had reached an agreement to acquire the Scientific Games Development Corporation, a major designer, producer and supplier of instant and weekly lottery games. Bally operates a casino-hotel in Atlantic City and a national chain of family amusement centers. It had 1980 sales of $690 million.

title: Secrets of the Mastodon
description: The discovery of mastodon bones on a high plateau in Utah indicates that these ancient giant mammals ranged more widely across North America and at higher elevations than was previously thought, according to scientists from Brigham Young University.

title: CITY OPERA: 'FREISCHUTZ' IN NEW ENGLISH VERSION
description: THE theater has its problem plays, works of obvious significance that somehow are difficult to perform convincingly. Shakespeare's ''Measure for Measure,'' for instance, is usually placed in that category. The opera literature also has its problem works, one of the more important of which is ''Der Freischutz.'' In Germany, Weber's score is regarded as a sacred spring from which all of the Romantic repertory flowed; in this country, in spite of a staging here and there, it has resisted being imported.

title: U.S. Asks Lifting of Stay On Patco Decertification
description: The Government filed a motion today opposing a Federal court's temporary stay of a decision to strip the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization of its right to represent air controllers.

EGYPT PUBLISHES A REPORT ON POLICE BATTLES WITH 'MOSLEM TERRORISTS'

description: ''We're into a juggling act,'' said District Attorney Kenneth Gribetz of Rockland County. ''My schedule has been impossible - 14 or 15 hours a day or more. Last night, we were with the Medical Examiner until midnight going over testimony.''

Byrne Arena, to pick up his personal belongings and say his goodbyes. At noon he joined his new Knick teammates in a shooting practice before last night's final exhibition game against the Chicago Bulls at Madison Square Garden.

description: Western nations seeking to end the impasse over independence for South-West Africa formally presented a set of constitutional principles today that are designed to insure that whites and other minorities will have an opportunity to influence the shape of a new system of government there.

title: A Suspect in the Rape Of Nun Is Extradited
description: A 22-year-old man wearing a paper bag over his head was whisked from a Chicago courtroom to O'Hare International Airport today and returned to New York City to face charges of raping and mutilating a 31-year-old nun.

title: EASING POLAND'S CRISIS
description: Brumberg WASHINGTON - The Polish Government's deployment of 2,000 troops across the country to put down ''street provocations'' and to safeguard food distribution and transportation is another indication that Poland is in the grip of the most serious crisis since the summer of 1980 when strikes broke out and Solidarity was formed. Who is responsible for this crisis?

LANGUAGE PATTERNS REVEAL PROBLEMS IN PERSONALITY
description: IT was Richard Nixon on the Watergate tapes, saying nothing terribly incriminating: ''The report was not frankly accurate,'' he was saying. ''Well it was accurate but it was not full. And he tells me the reason it wasn't full, was that he didn't know. Whether that is true or not, I don't know. Although it wasn't I'm told. But I'm satisfied with it.''

title: Michigan School District Reject Higher Tax Levy
description: Harper Creek School District voters today rejected, by 152 votes, a tax increase that would have prevented the closing of the district's schools.

title: New Endeavors
description: A few months ago Stephen C. Joseph and Eugene N. Babb were worrying about how they were going to pay their bills. They were jobless. It was last May when the two senior officials of the Agency for International Development quit their $50,000-a-year jobs in protest over the Reagan Administration's refusal to support a voluntary international code to curtail the marketing of infant formulas in developing countries.

BRIEFING
description: E DWIN P. WILSON, a former intelligence agent indicted last year on charges of illegally shipping explosives to Libya to help train terrorists, has been attempting through a well-known member of the Washington social scene to obtain a lawyer with Republican credentials to represent him, according to the lawyer, Donald E. Santarelli.

title: A BAND-AID FOR CRIME
description: The crime rate in New York is rising and prisons are overcrowded to the point of dangerous tension. The solution offered by our leading elected officials and the criminal justice community? Throw some big money at the problem and build more state and local prisons.

title: ANIMALS IN THE LAB: PROTESTS ACCELERATE, BUT USE IS DROPPING
description: IN England, animal lovers have ''liberated'' animals from the laboratory and daubed paint on the houses of offending scientists. In this country, they recently instigated a well-publicized police raid on a Maryland research laboratory that they charged was mistreating monkeys.

title: Football Footnotes
description: Donald F. Wade, the former National Football League player accused of fraud for claiming the league's total-disability benefits while working as a sheriff's deputy, serving in the military and playing semipro football, went on trial in a Federal District Court in Baltimore. As the trial began, Wade sat stiffly in the uniform of an Army private first class to answer an 11-count indictment charging that he had been receiving as much as $2,100 a month in undue benefits. .. Don Cockroft, one of the leading scorers in National League Football history, announced he was retiring.

title: FIRST MARATHON PROVES FATAL
description: A 26-year-old runner who collapsed two blocks from the finish line of the Richmond Marathon on Sunday died as a result of a heart attack caused by a coronary artery disease, the Virginia state medical examiner's office said yesterday.

description: Shr earnings reflect a 4-for-1 stock split effective in January 1981

description: AM International, the troubled information processing and graphics equipment company, disclosed yesterday that it was not in compliance with some requirements of a $106 million revolving credit agreement with 19 banks.

title: A.T.&T. TO BUY REST OF PACIFIC UNIT
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would acquire the minority-held shares of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, its financially troubled California subsidiary, in a stock swap valued at nearly $400 million.

title: U.S. SEAMEN'S HOSPITALS STILL OPEN IN MANY CITIES
description: Since 1798, the United States has operated a system of public health hospitals in major port cities to provide care for merchant seamen. And since Dwight D. Eisenhower, Presidents have been trying to shut them down as obsolete.

title: BRENTON BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Columbia U. to Pay $153,000 To the Parents of Dead Girl
description: Henry and Sylvia Gold of Brooklyn, the parents of a Barnard College freshman who was killed when a piece of masonry from an apartment building fell on her, reached a $153,000 settlement yesterday with Columbia University, the building's owner.

title: JAPAN'S BIG ENERGY SETBACK
description: Beyond the personal tragedy, a coal mine disaster about 500 miles north of here has dealt a big blow to Japan's coal industry and the Government's recent efforts to increase domestic production.

title: Teen-Age Girls Found Reluctant to Get Sex Advice
description: Ambivalence, procrastination, fear of the pelvic examination, the need to keep sexual activity a secret from their parents and the hope of developing a closer relationship with their sexual partners are some of the factors that keep adolescent girls from visiting a family planning clinic for more than a year after they become sexually active, according to a study by researchers at Johns Hopkins University.

title: MONTANA (NOBODY CAN SAY WHY) FINDS NORTH DAKOTA HILARIOUS
description: ''Do you know what the official tree of North Dakota is?'' a man asked recently, sidling up to an unsuspecting visitor in a local tavern. ''No? It's a telephone pole.''

title: FARMERS TEND TO BLAME 18% INTEREST FOR TROUBLES
description: President Reagan's admission that the country is in a slight recession was not news to farmers in this part of west central Kansas or to the small town merchants who depend on them as customers.

description: Mayor Randy Tyree said today that he would work to soften an order requiring policewomen to wear their hair the same length as men, saying the rule was ''too restrictive.''

title: ATTENDENCE FALLS AT KENNEDY LIBRARY
description: Two years after it opened in October 1979 on a grassy promontory in Boston Harbor, the gleaming white John F. Kennedy Library is facing declining attendance.

title: VENEZUELA SET TO CUT ITS OIL PRICES
description: Venezuela is prepared to take the politically distasteful step of lowering its official oil price by $2, to $34 a barrel, officials of its Government said yesterday. This position, which hinges on Saudi Arabia increasing its prices by $2 a barrel, may pave the way to price unification at a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries set for Thursday in Geneva.

description: BEAR markets are insensitive to value. Good stocks slide, along with the not-so-good. Dramatic casualties are often found among secondary companies, and even the shares of quality companies that are temporarily off stride are frequently hard hit.

title: A SUCCESSOR TO SHAD CHOSEN AT E.F. HUTTON
description: W. James Lopp 2d, 42, is stepping into the shoes, if not the title, of John S.R. Shad at the securities firm of E.F. Hutton & Company. Mr. Shad, who earlier this year became chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was head of Hutton's corporate finance department and vice chairman of the firm. Mr. Lopp, who was instrumental in the concern's public finance efforts, will take over the corporate finance function, but will retain his title of executive vice president.

title: THE AUTOMATED RESEARCH LAB
description: To a visitor peering through the plate-glass window into the climate-controlled room filled with rack after rack of white rats, the animal being plopped onto the scale by Jose Torres seems identical to its roommates.

title: Texas Air Cutback
description: Texas International Airlines, which has been seeking to acquire Continental Airlines, said yesterday it would cut the salaries of about 600 management employees by between 5 percent and 15 percent starting Nov. 15 and increase their workweek to a minimum of 48 hours. Texas International also said it would try to increase management productivity by allowing managers of one department to work in other areas. The airline, which said these and other efficiency measures were aimed at offsetting effects of the air controllers' strike, said the cuts would be effective through March 31.

title: Historic Fort Gets a Modern Marker
description: Fort Ontario in Oswego, N.Y., has figured in a lot of history over the years, including the French and Indian War and the American Revolution.

title: SOCAL NET OFF 15.5% SHELL GAINS
description: The Standard Oil Company of California yesterday reported a 15.5 percent decline in its third quarter earnings, to $527 million, or $1.54 a share, from $624 million, or $1.82 a share.

title: PYONGYANG LACKS NOT FOR POTENT ALLIES
description: To the Editor:

title: POOR PAY BY THE U.S.
description: Back in 18th-century England, Tories argued that Members of Parliament should not be paid so that the nation could be sure that wealthy men would always fill the position and, hence, there would be no danger of corruption. Until now, no one has seriously argued that we should deliberately underpay higher executives in our Government in order to be sure that only the independently wealthy should be attracted. But the recent refusal by Congress to restore some equity to the Federal pay system for executives shows that it must be beginning to think that way.

title: Hoffman-Koos Account To Albert J. Rosenthal
description: Huffman-Koos, the 14-outlet furniture store chain, has assigned its broadcast advertising account to Albert J. Rosenthal & Company.

title: STEINBRENNER CHEERFUL DESPITE WOUNDS
description: George Steinbrenner's lip was still swollen and his injured left hand throbbed inside its plaster cast this morning when the Yankees began their trip home, but the owner was in a chipper mood after what he described as a fight with two young men in a hotel elevator last night.

title: NEW CHAIRMAN OF TRADE PANEL ASKS RULE SHIFT
description: James C. Miller 3d, the new chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today that the commission should no longer protect consumers from defective products and unsubstantiated advertising claims.

title: Israeli Musicians Back Mehta
description: Members of the Israel Philharmonic closed ranks today around their music director, Zubin Mehta, after he was told to ''go home'' by a deputy minister incensed over Mr. Mehta's breach of an Israeli ban on Richard Wagner's music.

title: South African Gold Uses
description: South Africa, worried by balanceof-payments problems, may use its gold as collateral in the next few months for currency loans and to bolster its foreign exchange reserves, banking sources said today.

title: Mets Drop Marshall
description: Mike Marshall, whom the Mets signed as bullpen insurance when it appeared they might be able to join the split-season pennant race, has been placed on waivers. Marshall, who won the Cy Young Award while with Los Angeles in 1974, is now 38 years old and perhaps at the end of his career.

title: MINNETONKA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adorance Co. has appointed Martin Aronson vice president of sales.

title: Pitney to End Copier Research
description: Pitney Bowes Inc. said it was dropping most of its copier research and development and that it had no plans to develop new copier products for manufacture.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Brock Hotel Group said that it plans to offer 900,000 shares after registering with the Securities and Exchange Commission in early November.

title: CHICAGO MILWAUKEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $949,000 for the qr and $2,210,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $655,000 for the qr and $1,442,000 for the 9 mos

title: Mexicans Hunt Victims In Rubble of Quake
description: Rescue workers tried today to a dig out trapped victims of an earthquake that flattened houses and injured dozens of people, most of them in remote Indian villages, the authorities said.

title: IN A REPLAY OF PRIMARY, GOLDIN'S INTEGRITY IS AGAIN A KEY ISSUE IN
description: CAMPAIGN FOR COMPTROLLER By FRANK LYNN

title: BOMBINGS WIDENED IN BEIRUT
description: A car bomb exploded in Christian east Beirut this morning, killing one person, wounding about 10 others and setting off a large fire.

title: Wrong 30 Million Times, but Consistent
description: There is nothing especially wrong with the name McDonaly. It just does not happen to be Gregory Mcdonald's name, and to Mr. Mcdonald's way of thinking, that is an important distinction.

title: NORSUL OIL & MINING LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NOTES ON FASHION
description: K ENNETH JAY LANE, who has simulated almost every form of reality, is most successful when he concentrates on costume jewelry. His skill at transforming the lowliest of materials into almost the real thing is awesome. As dressy costume pieces are being worn more and more, his work is increasingly important.

title: ARKANSAS LOUISIANA GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE COLUMBIA, CONT'D... NOW FOR THE REAL WORK
description: EARLY on their second morning in space, as they meet the dawn over the eastern United States, the two astronauts should be peering out the rear windows of the Columbia's flight deck. One of them will grip the hand controller jutting from the control console and, after checking all systems, apply pressure. Reacting to that pulse of human energy, translated through a maze of electronic circuitry, a long, slender metal arm will rise out of its cradle in the cargo bay with a slow, robotic salute.

title: Advertising; New Link In Public Relations
description: RUDER & FINN and Harshe-Rotman & Druck announced yesterday that they will merge on Jan. 1. The resulting firm, with fee income of about $15 million and 400 employes, will be called Ruder Finn & Rotman.

title: EX-EMPLOYEES OF CETA TRY TO MAKE DO
description: Nicholas Foye is in a training program that he believes may lead nowhere. Glennis Cherry has obtained a permanent job with the city and is in line for a promotion. Manuel Rosa is living off his limited savings and looking for a job. Harold Rivera is receiving unemployment payments and says the next step for him may be welfare.

title: 4 Hurt, 7 Seized in Fight After Bills' Triumph
description: Authorities said today that a ''near riot'' occurred at Rich Stadium in a brawl yesterday following the Buffalo Bills' 9-7 victory over the Denver Broncos.

title: UNION ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fire Disrupts Boston Transit
description: Commuters in Medford, Mass., waiting yesterday for a train to Boston. The fire in a Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority building in Boston destroyed communications and power facilities, disrupting service for 300,000 commuters. Gov. Edward J. King said a $10,000 reward would be paid for information leading to the conviction of anyone responsible for the fire, which investigators said was deliberately set.

title: WHEN PRESIDENTS MAKE PROMISES
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILADELPHIA UNIONS SET MASS STRIKE TOMORROW
description: The city's labor leaders pledged 100 percent support for a general work stoppage Wednesday that they said they hoped would bring about an equitable settlement of a 49-day teachers' strike that has kept more than 200,000 children out of public school.

title: GRANTS TOTALING $15 MILLION GO TO 25 SCHOOLS
description: Although the late John D. MacArthur, a self-made billionaire, never completed high school, academic chairs in his memory have been endowed at nine research universities under a $15.6 million grant from the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation of Chicago.

title: The Final Folly of Awacs
description: President Reagan is down to a single argument for selling the Awacs. Foolish or not, he contends, the deal has to be honored to enhance his influence abroad. To which the only reply is that rewarding folly with political triumph improves neither reputation abroad nor policy-making at home.

title: MENTAL CASES ARE CROWDING CITY HOSPITALS
description: The New York State Office of Mental Health has charged that seven municipal hospitals in New York City are overcrowded with psychiatric patients.

title: Jet Loss Is Traced To a Turnover Diet
description: It didn't make much sense to the Jets either. While their fans tried to sort out reasons for the lackluster performance in bowing to Seattle yesterday - and determine whether it means a return to the old, losing ways - the players grudgingly accepted it.

title: WHEN PRESIDENTS MAKE PROMISES
description: To the Editor:

title: Morocco Assails Soviet Over Missiles in Sahara
description: Morocco protested to the Soviet Union today that ''non-Africans'' appeared to be manning Soviet missiles in the guerrilla war against Moroccan rule in Western Sahara.

title: Jersey Issues; Last article of a series:; Taxes
description: No issue in the campaign for Governor of New Jersey has attracted more attention, provided clearer distinctions between the candidates or raised more questions than the competing Democratic and Republican proposals to cut taxes and balance the state budget. The issue is likely to play a major role in the outcome of the campaign: Taxes and state and local budget problems were cited as the state's most important problem by 20 percent of the registered voters interviewed in a recent New York Times survey - more than any other problem.
