title: Energy Pact Set in Canada
description: The federal and Saskatchewan governments signed a $15 billion energy revenue-sharing agreement today that Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau and Premier Allan Blakeney described as an important step in the goal of energy self-sufficency.

title: MISS NILSSON THE OBJECT OF OPERA GUILD AFFECTION
description: The Metropolitan Opera Guild honored Birgit Nilsson at its 47th membership luncheon yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom. Count Wilhelm Wachtmeister, Sweden's Ambassador to the United States, presented to the Swedish soprano a gift ''very carefully chosen as a token of what New Yorkers feel for you.''

title: MARY CODD GIVES VIEWS ON BUDGETS
description: Mary T. Codd, the Liberal Party candidate for Mayor, was asked by The New York Times for her views on major issues confronting New York City. Following are excerpts from her reply on fiscal policy. The views of the other mayoral candidates were published earlier.

title: HUNTING FOR DOOHICKEYS
description: Into the suburban hardware store strode the few hundred - complaining of faucets dripping, drains clogging, toilets running, plaster falling, mowers stalling.

title: AMERICAN NATURAL RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from the company's Michigan Consolidated Gas Co unit of $6,280,000 for the qr and $17,867,000 for the 9 mos extraordinary net writeoff of trucking operating rights of $2,383,000 for the qr and 9 mos and $4,749,000 income for the 9 mos from the cumulative effect in yrs prior to 1981 of a change in accounting for depletion...C-Net loss after loss fr the Michigan Consolidated unit of $9,069,000 for the qr... D-Including income from the Michigan Consolidated unit of $163,

title: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: B-Includes $570,000 extraordinary credit.

title: 7TH AVE. SPRING FASHIONS
description: Big tops and skinny bottoms. Flirty full skirts that bare the knees - and that turn out to be full shorts. Calf-length pants that are loose at the top and snug at the bottom - or are almost as wide as skirts. Supple suedes and shiny leathers.

title: Samples of Writing in Study
description: In their study, two Chicago researchers asked English teachers to rate essays that said the same things and contained the same errors but differed in writing style. The teachers tended to prefer verbosity to clear writing. The following are examples of the essays used in the study. Direct Style

title: Dome Trading Volume Heavy
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. led the most active list on the Toronto Stock Exchange today amid intense investor speculation that it would report significant Beaufort Sea exploration results later this week. The company's stock has been depressed lately by uncertainty over Dome's ability to finance its Beaufort exploration program,

title: 2 SIDES ON AWACS EACH GAIN A VOTE
description: Senator William L. Armstrong, Republican of Colorado, announced today that he would vote in favor of selling Awacs planes and other equipment to Saudi Arabia, and Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, told the Senate he would oppose the $8.5 billion sale.

title: U.S. TO REVISE HOUSING COMPONENT OF PRICE INDEX
description: The Government plans to announce tomorrow that it will revise the much-criticized housing component of the Consumer Price Index, a move that could eventually mean smaller increases in this best-known of inflation indexes.

title: Ariel Durant, Author Of 'Civilization' Series
description: Historian Ariel Durant, the historian who collaborated with her husband Will in writing the 11-volume ''Story of Civilization,'' died last night at her home following a long illness. She was 83.

title: Hotel Sale Helps Net At Pan Am
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. yesterday reported net earnings of $281.5 million, or $3.95 a share, for the third quarter, attributable to a $358.8 million pretax gain from the sale of its subsidiary, the Intercontinental Hotels Corporation. The company's airline had a pretax loss of $80.2 million for the quarter.

title: Salazar Prefers Under-Table Payments
description: Alberto Salazar, New York's marathon king, said yesterday he preferred under-the-table payments to having his prize money left in trust with The Athletics Congress, America's governing body for track and field.

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COAST DOCTORS REBUFF PENTAGON ON PLAN FOR WAR
description: A group of doctors in the San Francisco Bay area have rejected a request from the Pentagon to allocate hospital beds for casualties of an overseas war on the ground that the allocation amounts to preparation for a nuclear war.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ago International said it was filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its offer to purchase up to 1.5 million shares of common stock of Life Investors Inc. for $34 a share.

title: U.S. Merger Policy Stated
description: The Reagan Administration will adopt a hands-off policy on corporate mergers unless they significantly reduce competition, the head of the Justice Department's antitrust division said today.

title: MAN KILLED IN SHOOTOUT TIED TO HOLDUP OF BRINK'S TRUCK
description: An additional link between a shootout in Queens Friday and last Tuesday's holdup of an armored car in Rockland County was announced yesterday by the Rockland County District Attorney.

title: PRUDENTIAL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WARSAW DEPLOYS SMALL ARMY UNITS ACROSS THE NATION
description: Hundreds of small military units were deployed across Poland today under a new program to use the army to bolster local authority and attempt to sort out food and fuel supply problems.

title: 1,000 Officials Slain In 4 Months, Iran Says
description: Iran's official press agency, Pars, reported today that more than 1,000 Government officials had been killed since the dismissal of former President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr four months ago.

title: Ghanaian Threatens More With Blacklist
description: Every English county cricket player and every member of the European professional golf tour could be on the United Nations anti-apartheid blacklist in the next year because they played with individual South Africans in other countries, James Beho, Ghana's Ambassador to Britain, said today.

title: Talking Business with Innocenti of Alfa Romeo; Alfa Romeo And Nissan
description: Alfa Romeo, Italy's troubled, Government-owned auto maker, signed a joint production agreement last year with Nissan of Japan. Under the agreement, which was the first of its kind between a Western and a Japanese auto company, a factory to be built in southern Italy is to produce 60,000 cars a year, half to be sold in Italy and the rest elsewhere in Europe. The agreement, made over the objections of Fiat, Alfa Romeo's privately held rival, was soon emulated by other auto makers on the Continent and in the United States.

title: HINCKLEY VIEWED AS RATIONAL SOON AFTER REAGAN SHOOTING
description: A Secret Service agent, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent and a police officer testified today that John W. Hinckley Jr. responded clearly and rationally when they questioned him a few hours after President Reagan and three other men were shot last March 30.

title: MARY PELTZ, EDITOR OF OPERA NEWS
description: Mary Ellis Peltz, founder and former editor of The Opera News and archivist for the Metropolitan Opera, died Saturday at her New York home. She was 85 years old.

title: Rangers Are Losing Games and Players
description: The Rangers were beaten Sunday night for the sixth time in their nine games this season, but what hurt them more than another loss was news of another severe injury to one of their regulars.

title: 70-Year-Old Floridian Accused of War Crimes
description: The Government began proceedings today to strip a 70-year-old artist of his American citizenship, charging that Jurgis Juodis collaborated with the Nazis and killed Jews in World War II.

title: Bossy Signs 6-Year Pact
description: Mike Bossy, the Islanders' leader in career goals, signed a six-year contract today. Though no figures were mentioned, it was believed that Bossy had agreed to a yearly salary of about $500,000.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citibank said an average rate of 15.23 percent was set yesterday at its weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp commercial paper; last week the rate was 15.13 percent.

title: SUSPECTS, OR THOSE TIED TO THEM, IN ARMORED-TRUCK HOLDUP
description: The following have been identified by authorities as suspects, or individuals linked to suspects, in the Rockland County armored-car robbery in which two police officers and a guard were killed Oct. 20:

title: Court Upholds Penn Central
description: A three-judge Federal appeals panel denied a request by two Penn Central Corporation stockholders to delay the company's Thursday meeting at which shareholders are to vote on its proposed merger with Colt Industries.

title: AH, JACKIE, YOGI, ROY
description: LelchukCANAAN, N.H. -Is it fair to say that each age deserves its World Series in the same way that we deserve our political leaders? Does the current Series with its display of shoddy baseball and inflated media hype about personalities, reflect our time aptly? I've had these thoughts while watching the current Series, and remembering the old classics between these same teams during the late 40's, 50's, and early 60's. For no one seeing the current imitation would dream of offering up this stuff as baseball at its best.

title: Brooklyn Philharmonia And Foss Open Season
description: When it comes to programming, Lukas Foss has never been one to travel down the center of the pike. Though his season-opening concert with the Brooklyn Philharmonia at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last Friday night certainly ended near the middle of the road, with Beethoven's Symphony No. 7, it began somewhere along the lessfrequently traveled byways of American music, with a triptych honoring Charles Ives's birthday that included two New York premieres.

title: Eli Lilly to Build A $60 Million Lab
description: Eli Lilly & Company said that it plans to build a $60 million biomedical laboratory for research ranging from cancer to the common cold.

title: AMERICAN HERITAGE LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAMSON & SESSIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,828,000 for the qr and $4,555,000 for the 9 mos; 1980 sales excluded sales from discontinued operations of $14,595,000 for the qr and $52,356,000 for the 9 mos

title: STORING WINE AND SERVING IT AT ITS BEST
description: Confronted with a wine list of limited appeal, we ordered Beaujolais, invariably a safe and palatable choice guaranteed not to devastate the pocketbook. The waiter crossed the dining room and plucked a bottle from its berth in a series of racks that doubled as a divider between restaurant and bar. We examined the bottle, tasted and accepted the wine and ordered a bucket of ice.

title: Dow Reaches 838.38, Up 7.42
description: Stock prices rebounded yesterday after recent weakness that reflected continuing fears of high interest rates and a softening economy. Adverse earnings reports for the September quarter also had depressed the market.

title: BORDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Real Estate; Houston, First, Then On to Rye
description: RYE, N.Y. JONATHAN MORSE tells this tale: An office construction site came on the market outside Houston in 1974 and nobody would touch it. It seems that the location was a bit off the beaten track, or perhaps beyond it.

title: Britain to Get New Weekly Newspaper
description: A new national weekly newspaper, The Mail on Sunday, will be started next May, Lord Rothermere, head of The Associated Newspapers group, said today.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Elvis Presley received addictive drugs from sources other than his doctor, who attempted to replace the drugs with harmless substances, a jury was told today.

title: Letter: On World Population Some Ominous Trends for Hunger
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Reagan Unbruised, Amused by Cutout Book
description: One of the Great American Pastimes seems to be kidding the President and his family. The latest example is ''The First Family Paper Doll and Cutout Book,'' and Nancy Reagan likes the ribbing she and the President get, even though it shows the Reagans in red, white and blue underwear.

title: SYBRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign currency losses of $3,927,000 for the qr and $7,723,000 for the 9 mos and $700,000 credit from tax changes for the qr ...C-Includes $182,000 foreign currency gain for the qr and $1,239,000 foreign currency loss for the 9 mos

title: 2-Stage Revision Set for Price Index
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics said today that it would revamp the controversial housing component of the Consumer Price Index in two stages, the first in January 1983 and the second in January 1985.

title: Backer & Spielvogel Wins Lestoil Account
description: Again? Yes, Backer & Spielvogel has landed another account. This time its for the Lestoil products from the Noxell Corporation, which had been at Foote, Cone & Belding for seven years.

title: SPECIALITY FOOD EXPLOSION: WHERE WILL IT END?
description: ONCE upon a time, when a gallon of gasoline cost 20 cents and mortgage rates were at 5 1/2 percent, mustard came in two flavors - French's and Gulden's. There was still only one kind of kind of bagel - hard. It was a time when we had just learned to distinguish between Emmenthaler and Gruyere and been introduced to red wine vinegar to use in place of white distilled. Food purchasing was simple, if uninspired. Today it is simply bewildering.

title: Michigan School District Warned of Program Cuts
description: Harper Creek school officials, stung by voter rejection of a tax increase proposal, warned today of extensive program cuts to avoid school closings.

title: BLACK HOLDS AN EDGE IN CHESS MATCH
description: Black's normal inferiority in the opening is nowhere to be seen in the world championship chess match here between Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the titleholder, and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland. In the five decisive outcomes so far, Black has won three times and White twice.

title: Brenda Roberts Sings Dyer's Wife in 'Frau'
description: Filling Birgit Nilsson's shoes and vocal cords in a cast change of Strauss's ''Die Frau ohne Schatten'' cannot be an easy task. And comparison would be unfair to Brenda Roberts who made her Metropolitan Opera debut on Monday night in just such a position; it is as the Dyer's Wife that she really had to be judged.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: Groups representing more than five million supporters of the proposed equal rights amendment announced today a $1 million radio campaign to push for ratification of the constitutional amendment.

title: HANDMADE NOODLES THE CHINESE WAY
description: KIN JING MARK swung a long rope in the air like a lasso and with extraordinary sleight of hand twirled it into a noose. He was not practicing for a rodeo. He was making noodles, and the rope was a long strip of dough -made with flour, water and a quarter of a teaspoon of baking powder.

title: Drugs Cited In Pentathlon
description: A report compiled by the Army Inspector General's Office indicates that a team doctor and two coaches on the United States' modern pentathlon Olympic team often dispensed drugs to athletes to enhance their scores, according to an article in The San Antonio Light.

title: MONEY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BARDEN GETS NEW CHIEF
description: Stanley Noss, a 56-year-old engineer, management consultant and corporate executive at high-technology companies, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Barden Corporation, a manufacturer of bearings based in Danbury, Conn., effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Emil J. Karkut, who will retire at age 65 from the company founded by Carl Norden - inventor of the Norden bomb sight, used during World War II.

title: OAK INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago results are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Mar 1981

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Banister Continental, Edmonton, Alberta, has appointed Ray MacTavish vice president of finance.

title: BE IT EVER SO HUMBLE
description: By day, it is a busy House office building. At night, the sole occupants are two Republican Congressmen and a few scurrying mice.

title: WINE TALK
description: PARIS THE grapes are in all over France and the people who turn them into wine are saying that it has been a so-so year: quality from fair to good, quantity off by half to two-thirds of normal. Whether one is a Keynesian or a monetarist, it is not difficult to figure this one out: higher and higher prices for French wine.

title: SUN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GULFSTREAM BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Union Rejects Renegotiation
description: The United Auto Workers union will not renegotiate its current contract with the Allis-Chalmers Corporation despite the company's claim that it needs wage and benefit concessions, U.A.W. officials said.

title: TEXT OF LETTER EXPLAINING U.S. OBJECTIONS TO CITY COUNCIL REDISTRICTING PLAN
description: Following is the text of the letter in which New York City was notified that the United States Attorney General was interposing an objection to the City Council redistricting plan involving Bronx, Kings and New York Counties: Fabian Palomino, Esq. Counsel, New York City Council Redistricting Commission City Hall New York, New York 10007 Dear Mr. Palomino: This is in reference to your submission to the Attorney General, pursuant to Section 5 of the voting Rights Act of 1965, 42 U.S.C. - 1973c, of Local Law 47 (1981) of the City of New York providing for the increase in the number of single-member councilmanic districts, and the redistricting of the 35 single-member districts and related election district changes occasioned by the local law. Additional information was received on Sept. 21, 1981. Since that date, the city has supplemented the submission with further information. The submission was completed on the date of the receipt of the last supplement on Oct. 19, 1981.

title: GUIDE THROUGH MAZE OF PSYCHOTHERAPIES
description: MORE and more people with personal problems are coming out of the closet and seeking the help of psychotherapists. Prompted by the stresses of family and social upheavals, the narcissism of the ''me'' generation, publicity about new approaches to treatment and a plethora of popular books prescribing do-it-yourself emotional inventories, they are trying to unravel the intricacies of their psyches and improve their potential for happiness.

title: AUTOPSIES CALLED 'HARD EVIDENCE' THAT SMUGGLERS ASSISTED HAITIANS
description: A medical examiner said today that the bodies of 33 drowning victims amounted to ''good, hard evidence'' that many of the thousands of illegal Haitian immigrants who have made it to these shores have been helped by smugglers.

title: Greek Publisher Is Freed From Prison
description: A Greek newspaper publisher, sentenced to two years in prison for accusing former Prime Minister George Rallis of involvement in financial corruption, was released today pending his appeal before the Supreme Court.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $134.3 million net charge relating to the restructuring and planned sale of certain operations...C-Net income including a loss of 4 cents a shr for the qr and 4 cents a shr gain for the 9 mos from the restructuring and planned sale of certain operations

title: AMERICAN CAN SET TO ACQUIRE INSURER
description: The American Can Company said that it has agreed to acquire Associated Madison Companies Inc., an insurance concern, for $140 million in a tax-free exchange of cash and stock.

title: MONTGOMERY STREET INCOME SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ABOUT NEW YORK
description: In the midafternoon drizzle, there were people giving out leftist literature at the arching gates that lead to College Walk on the Columbia University campus. It sometimes seems that there have always been people at these gates giving out literature - through rain and snow, gloom of night, the heat of the Vietnam War and the lukewarm early 1960's and 1980's.

title: AIRLINE TRAFFIC DISRUPTED BY FOG
description: Dense fog and rain that reduced visibility and safety conditions to ''marginal'' levels seriously disrupted airline traffic in the New York metropolitan area yesterday.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped 60 cents to $105.O8 during the two-week period that ended last Friday. Shoppers paid $5.30 less during the same period last year. Lower average prices for fresh fruits and vegetables and less expensive beef cuts helped reduce the total.

title: BIRD & SON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2.1 million for the qr and $2.7 million for the 9 mos

title: PERRY ELLIS, UPSTAGING WITH SIMPLICITY
description: PERRY ELLIS presented a smashing collection yesterday. It showed thought and it looked contemporary. Though there were some echoes from the past, they were completely reworked for today's woman, who is not nearly as concerned with gimmickry and costumes as many designers seem to feel she is. Like a beautiful woman in a simple black dress at a party where all others are dressed to the nines, the designer has upstaged everyone else.

title: Charles Krutch, Tennessean; Photographed T.V.A. Growth
description: Charles Krutch, a photographer who documented the Tennessee Valley Authority's first 20 years, died yesterday at his home. He was 94 years old.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S a beautiful, sentimental moment, and as the rock, or pebble, is slid onto the third finger of the left hand, most women are sure that a lifetime of togetherness is ahead. Then custom stales, and boredom sets in. Someone younger, richer, more intelligent comes along. She nags, he's a chauvinist, they don't agree on how toothpaste should be squeezed - it's over. The marriage that was supposed to have been made in heaven ends in a divorce court.

title: TAFT BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Engineering and Construction Co., the energy division of Boeing, has been awarded a $46.8 million contract to design and build a large facility in New England to convert municipal waste into energy, said Energy Refuse Fuels Inc. of Massachusetts.

title: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $658,000 gain for the qr from discontinued operations and $35,000 less for the 9 mos from discontinued operations

title: TEXTRON DOWN 6.6%
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday that foreign-exchange translations caused it to lose nearly $35 million in the third quarter, the biggest adverse impact from such translations in the company's history. Revenues, excluding insurance and finance operations, dropped 9.3 percent.

title: Osian Ellis, Harpist, Plays at Met Museum
description: Within the world of the conventional classical-music instrumental recital, Osian Ellis is an oddity. But he is a serious musician, even a great one -the kind for whom technical skill, while demonstrable, takes a back seat to expressiveness.

title: CON ED'S PROFIT UP BY 51.9%
description: The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday that its earnings for the third quarter rose by 51.9 percent, to $202.9 million, or $3.05 a share, from $133.6 million, or $1.96 a share, for the similar quarter last year. It attributed the gain primarily to the 15.5 percent rate increase that the New York State Public Service Commission approved last March 12.

title: LLEWELYN-DAVIES, CITY PLANNER, 68
description: Lord Llewelyn-Davies, a city planner and architect whose work ranged from the design of influential new towns in England and Iran to research in the social sciences, died Monday evening in London. He was 68 years old.

title: A FORMER CITY POLICE OFFICER HELD IN STRANGLING OF WOMAN
description: A former New York City police officer was arrested and charged with strangling a 27-year-old securities analyst whose nude body was found in her Brooklyn apartment last June.

title: COMMON SIGNALS OF NEED FOR HELP
description: It is estimated that 34 million Americans are receiving professional psychotherapy or counseling and millions more are believed to be in need of it. Part of the problem in obtaining care for those who could benefit from it is the difficulty many people have in recognizing and acknowledging the existence of emotional problems.

title: JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income for 1981 9 mos includes investments loss of $16,000 or 1 cent a shr; net income in 1980 includes investments losses of $16,000 or 1 cent for the qr and $32,000 or 2 cents for the 9 mos

title: PHILADELPHIA SCHOOL STRIKE TO END
description: The city teachers' union said tonight that its 22,000 members would return to work tomorrow, obeying a judge's order to end their 50-day-old strike immediately. The order also directed the school district to rehire 3,500 employees whose layoffs had been partly responsible for the strike.

title: Taylor Dropped By Jets
description: Billy Taylor, the running back released by the Giants 21 days ago and picked up by the Jets the following day, was released again yesterday. The Jets placed him on waivers to make room for a defensive lineman.

title: Tube Thieves
description: It never occurred to us that taping a crucial episode of ''Dallas'' for more convenient viewing at another hour might be a violation of the copyright law. After all, the recorders and the tape are openly sold. And the program's sponsors should welcome our watching when we can. Yet the United States Court of Appeals finds a problem of piracy, even in the privacy of the home. Broadly stated, it is that the producers of the better broadcasts may lose some of their benefits of resale, by tape or disk, if too many of us capture the show the first time around.

title: Bonn Is Acting On Budget Gap
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt met today with Helmut Kohl, the opposition leader, for the first time in more than six months to seek support enabling his Government to pass legislation needed for its 1982 budget.

title: CARTER'S PUZZLING SECOND THOUGHTS ON JORDAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Beneficial Closings
description: The Beneficial Finance Company said that it plans to close 16 offices throughout New York state in a consolidation move.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VENETIAN FINDS

title: Actor Guilty in Brawl
description: The British actor Oliver Reed, arrested last month in a barroom brawling incident in Stowe, Vt., pleaded no contest yesterday to two charges of simple assault and was fined $1,200.

title: G.E. CREDIT: FINANCIAL HYBRID
description: Back in 1932, in the depths of the Depression, the General Electric Company found it tough to sell refrigerators. Consumers, hard pressed to buy even food to fill a refrigerator, were hardly interested in purchasing new appliances.

title: INCOMES POLICY TO THE ECONOMY'S RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Including $1,354,000 or 8 cents a shr, income from discontinued operations...C-Including $1,771,000 or 10 cents a shr, income from discontinued operations

title: Kodak Introduces New Movie Film
description: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced three professional motion picture films, in 35 millimeter and 70 millimeter sizes.

title: KOCH DEBATES MRS. CODD AS 2 OTHERS IN RACE PROTEST THEIR EXCLUSION
description: As two other mayoral candidates protested and their supporters picketed, Mayor Koch and City Councilwoman Mary T. Codd of Staten Island engaged in a debate yesterday.

title: AMERICAN BROADCASTING COS INC (ABC) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Operating Net Up at El Paso
description: The El Paso Company, a diversified energy concern, said today that its third-quarter operating profits soared 53.7 percent on a 20.7 percent rise in revenues.

title: Indonesian Oil Exports
description: Indonesia's oil exports in July rose to $1.26 billion from June's $1.12 billion, the Bank of Indonesia said today. Exports of natural gas increased to $212 million from $205 million.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Warning sirens wailed repeatedly over Venice today as high tides flooded most of the lagoon city for a second day.

title: BEHIND THE SCENES IS FINE, HE SAYS
description: George Bush was posing for pictures with the March of Dimes poster child the other day when he offered the boy a ballpoint pen.

title: U.S. WILL SEND $29 MILLION FOOD AID TO POLAND
description: The United States said today that it would supply Poland with $29 million in surplus dairy products to help resolve its ''pressing difficulties peacefully and without foreign interference.''

title: Cey Apprehensive, Unsure of Playing
description: ''Somebody must be testing me this year,'' Ron Cey said. ''I don't know why. I don't go around blaming God for the things that happen to me. But somewhere in the great design for this year, I'm being tested.''

title: ALL-BACH RECITAL: THE TURECK PLAYERS
description: THE Tureck Bach Players, led by Rosalyn Tureck, the pianist, presented the first program of an all-Bach series devoted to the keyboard concertos Monday night at Carnegie Hall. Among the offerings was Miss Tureck's reconstruction of a concerto in D minor with oboe obbligato, based on Cantata No. 35, ''Geist un Seele wird verwirret,'' for which there is but a nine-measure fragment in Bach's hand.

title: THOMAS & BETTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
America Surrenders
description: The United States is about to launch a policy of unilateral disarmament in the worldwide contest of ideas. The Administration proposes cuts in the revised State Department authorization bill that would devastate educational and cultural exchange.

title: STUFFED SEAFOOD: ADDING NEW TASTES AND TEXTURES
description: AS we noted recently, the appeal of stuffed foods is universal. Every nation in the civilized world has a word for them. In Germany it is ''fullung,'' in Italy it is ''ripieno'' or ''farcito'' and in France it is ''farce.''

title: BALLY MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $3.6 million or 10 cents a shr net gain from the sale of property

title: FIRST FILM AND PRESS FESTIVAL OPENS IN STRASBOURG
description: Against a backdrop of some 30 feature and documentary films dealing with the news and with journalists, film makers and newsmen are meeting here for a week to explore the relationship between their two crafts.

title: Spanish Regime Wins A Round on NATO Issue
description: The Government defeated a Socialist attempt today to derail debate in Parliament on Spain's entry into NATO, moving the governing centrist party a step closer to victory on the issue.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on lonas to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: REAGAN IS URGED TO BLOCK SPYING BY C.I.A. IN U.S.
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence recommended today that the Reagan Administration abandon its plan to permit the Central Intelligence Agency to infiltrate and influence domestic groups.

title: Advertising; Old Name Attempts Comeback
description: GUENTHER LAW, one of the oldest advertising agencies in the world, has gotten its name back. And the two men who are running the place and plan to buy it hope they can return some of its old luster as well.

title: Lease Fee Rises Asked
description: Fees to participate in the Government's popular oil and gas leasing lotteries would triple under a proposal announced today by Interior Secretary James G. Watt. Mr. Watt proposed raising the filing fee from $25 to $75 and increasing rental fees in the second half of the 10-year leases from $1 an acre to $3 an acre. The changes are needed to eliminate ''casual speculative filing'' and encourage those who are interested in developing energy resources, Mr. Watt said.

title: WILLIAM R. MEAGHER
description: William R. Meagher, former senior partner with the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, died yesterday in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

title: ECONOMY OR EGGS, U.S. ADVISORS DIFFER
description: When the top economic policymakers in the Reagan Administration sit down to a breakfast meeting once a week in the Treasury Secretary's private dining room, they often order eggs but they rarely agree on how they should be cooked.

title: USLIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $19,000 realized gains on investments for the qr and $189,000 realized loss on investments for the 9 mos and $5,801,000 loss on disposal of subsidiary for the 9 mos... C-Includes $113,000 realized gains on investments for the qr and $1,482,000 realized gains on investments for the 9 mos and $234,000 loss from operations prior to disposition for the 9 mos and $10,594,000 loss on disposal of subsidiary for the 9

title: FRENCH COOL TO COMPENSATION DEMANDS
description: France's new Socialist Government today apparently turned down a joint demand by American and other foreign banks for a substantial improvement in the compensation being offered for their shareholdings in French industrial companies and banks scheduled for nationalization.

title: FOR DIANA, WELSH TRIP IS TRIUMPH
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales, in their first important ceremonial appearance together since their marriage last July, made a triumphant tour of this corner of Wales today and got a thunderous welcome at every stop.

title: PLAYING CHARADES AT CANCUN
description: The artificial elegance that shields the Cancun Sheraton from Mexico's population pressures, joblessness, and desperate poverty was an appropriate setting for the North-South talks. In splendid isolation, statesmen from both sides of the Equator said what they did not mean, embraced positions they knew to be absurd, and rescheduled as ''global negotiations'' the same pointless double-talk that has passed for a ''North-South dialogue.''

title: UGI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss; yr ago results have been restated to reflect a merger on a pooling of interest basis and for an accounting change

title: Steel Output Declines 5%
description: Steel production fell to 1.97 million tons in the week ended Oct. 24, down 5 percent from the previous week's 2.07 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: EAST-WEST CONFERENCE IN MADRID RECONVENES
description: Almost one year old, the 35-nation East-West conference on detente and human rights resumed here today after a summer break with expressions of gloom about the outcome.

title: Market Place; A 'New' Face In CAD/CAM
description: SUDDENLY and without fanfare, the International Business Machines Corporation has become the No. 2 factor in CAD/CAM, after the Computervision Corporation. Partly as a result of this, the spectacular growth of smaller participants in the industry has slowed.

title: OMAN'S FRIEND
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Private Debt: Hidden Pitfall
description: THE national debt has hit $1 trillion, and a string of budget deficits looming for the next three years could swell the debt by one-third before the 1984 election.

title: KEAN GIVES FT. DIX PLAN
description: Representative James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, called yesterday for the resignation of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency Administrator, Anne M. Gorsuch, saying that she had failed to enforce the law.

title: FOR CAMPBELL, IT IS NOT A GOOD SEASON
description: On the sideline last night during a dreary game between Pittsburgh and Houston, Earl Campbell was disgusted. He said it was the worst game he had ever played.

title: Scripture Lesson
description: Senator Howell Heflin, Democrat of Alabama, to reporters after a discussion with President Reagan: We got off into the Bible a little bit. We were talking about the fact that the Middle East, according to the Bible, would be the place where Armageddon would start.

title: ENVOY'S SON IS TARGET IN SALVADOR
description: An unknown assailant with a large-caliber pistol tried to kill the son of El Salvador's Ambassador to the United States yesterday as he was driving to his office in San Salvador.

title: Lack of Consent Ruled No Bar to Alcohol Test
description: The state's highest court ruled today that even if a driver is too drunk or too badly injured to refuse a bloodalcohol test, it may still be given and the results used in court.

title: U.N. SECURITY COUNCIL FAILS TO AGREE ON WALDHEIM
description: The Security Council, after four secret ballots, failed to agree today on a new Secretary General. The trend of the voting, however, according to those who took part, indicated that Kurt Waldheim of Austria was in a strong position to capture an unprecedented third five-year term.

title: M.T.A. FACING ALBANY QUESTIONS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will be asked in Albany today to answer 183 prepared questions about its $7.9 billion plan for rebuilding the region's subway, bus and rail systems.

title: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1981; Companies
description: The F.T.C. will go to court to keep LTV from buying out Grumman. The agency said it would file a complaint today charging that the acquisition would diminish competition in the aerospace industry. LTV said it would fight the lawsuit. The Administration's antimerger action was its second in a week. (Page D1.)

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: UNIQUE may be a strong word to use in describing a specific food, but to my mind scallops qualify on several counts. They have a certain texture and flavor that are basically incomparable, whether they are eaten raw in a plate of seviche, deep-fried and served with a mayonnaise sauce, sauteed with any of countless flavors and seasonings, simply broiled or turned into soup.

title: POLAND'S UNION ASKS FULL TURNOUT IN STRIKE TODAY
description: The Solidarity union called on its members today to honor a one-hour national strike tomorrow. The Polish Government continued its publicity against the job action.

title: INDIANA FINANCIAL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After an accounting gain related to the company's debt restructuring of $466,906

title: GAETA STAYS OPTIMISTIC IN S.I. PRESIDENT'S RACE
description: When Anthony R. Gaeta was asked recently if he would win reelection by a bigger margin than four years ago, when he handily won the Staten Island Borough President's post, his answer was a confident ''Oh, yes.''

title: No Headline
description: FINLAND'S PRESIDENT, 81, RESIGNS BECAUSE OF HEALTH

title: FROM ALAN KING, TALES OF A HAPPY EATER AT LARGE
description: TO Alan King's reputation as a producer, actor, stand-up comic, master of ceremonies, philanthropist and tennis player, add that he is a passionate eater, a cook and a restaurant buff.

title: Connecticut Gets Transport Chief
description: J. William Burns, the second-ranking official in Connecticut's state budget office, was appointed Commissioner of Transportation, succeeding Arthur B. Powers, who resigned Monday.

title: School Bus Falls Into Ravine
description: A school bus flipped over and fell into a 330-foot ravine today, killing 3 children and injuring 17 others. The police said the accident took place near the town of Algodonales, 75 miles west of Cadiz.

title: Steinbrenner: No Break
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, spent about two hours having his fight-connected injuries checked yesterday. He also spent time reading telegrams he received in the aftermath of his fight with two Dodger fans in a hotel elevator in Los Angeles.

title: Careers; Home Repair for Women
description: These are among the topics in a course on Small Building Superintendency given especially for low-income women at the New York City Technical College, which is part of the City University of New York.

title: Bugner Reappears
description: Joe Bugner, the former European heavyweight champion, said in Las Vegas, Nev., that he had signed to fight Gerry Cooney there on Dec. 5. That is the date on which the undefeated Cooney, tuning up for his title bout against Larry Holmes next March, was to have fought Eddie Lopez, who recently withdrew. ... Billy Walker and Kenny Haynes have joined two other Norfolk State players who left the basketball team in a controversy over Coach Lucias Mitchell. Louis Thomas, last year's captain, and Tim Allen had quit earlier over what they said was the coach's mistreatment of players. ... Teams throughout the National Basketball Association are trimming their rosters to meet tomorrow's deadline for the 12-player limit. The most prominent casualty yesterday was Scott May, the onetime all-American at Indiana, who was waived by the Chicago Bulls. May, a forward, has been slowed by illness and injury throughout his five-year pro career. ... John Kinsella, winner of two Olympic swimming medals, has been charged with failure to file Federal income tax returns in 1975, 1976 and 1977. He won a siver medal in the 1,500-meter freestyle in 1968 and was a member of the 800 freestyle team that won a gold medal in 1972. ... Sam Boardman, who had said he was wrongfully deprived of a lucrative contract to manage the heavyweight boxer Ron Lyle, was awarded $10,180 by a judge in Denver. Boardman had charged that William Lyle, the boxer's brother, had failed to honor an agreement. ... A truck driver was convicted in England of careless driving in the crash that killed a former motorcyle champion, Mike Ailwood, and his 9-year-old daughter.

title: YONKERS, FACING DEFICIT, SUDDENLY FINDS A SURPLUS
description: After projecting a budget deficit of $4 million last June, Yonkers announced today that a surplus of $1,065,293 had been discovered in a final audit by outside accountants.

title: BAKER, MICHAEL, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STATE SEEKS LEGISLATION TO HELP SAVINGS BANKS
description: As the already serious financial condition of many of the state's savings banks worsens, legal technicalities are making it difficult for the New York State Banking Department to avert some failures - leading the department to seek urgent changes in state law.

title: SENATOR'S CHANGE OF HEART: POWER OF THE PRESIDENCY
description: Senator Roger W. Jepsen has long been a strong supporter of Israel and a leading opponent of the proposed sale of Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia.

title: Incident at Meadowlands
description: About 300 fans started a disturbance and caused damage reported at several thousand dollars at the Meadowlands last night after one part of the heavily favored entry in the fifth race was scratched at the starting gate. The disturbance ended when the Meadowlands ordered the refund of $84,482 in win, place, show and exacta bets.

title: LTV BID OPPOSED BY F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it would ask the Federal courts to prohibit the LTV Corporation from buying the Grumman Corporation on the ground that the acquisition would diminish competition in the aerospace industry.

title: RISK ANALYSIS BIG BUSINESS FOR EX-AIDES
description: At the end of a long shadowy corridor in a nondescript office building three blocks from the White House, the sign by the locked door reads International Business Government Counsellors Inc.

title: RENT STRIKERS, CITY OFFICIALS STRIKE A DEAL
description: The families living on city-owned land in the Harding Park neighborhood of the Bronx have ended their rent strike, dropped a lawsuit against the city and agreed in principle to an offer to sell them the land for $700,000.

title: ANDERSON GREENWOOD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect yr-end adjustments

title: EASTERN, REPUBLIC HAVE LOSS
description: Eastern Airlines reported a loss of $38.7 million for the third quarter, compared with a loss of $22.3 million for the third quarter last year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle yesterday on the trial of Elvis Pres- ley's doctor incorrectly identified Bruce Jenner, the husband of a possi- ble defense witness in the case. Mr. Jenner won the decathlon in the 1976 Olympic Games. An article yesterday on a Chicago art exhibition by Vietnam veterans in- completely identified the site for a similar show opening on Nov. 10. It is the Parks Department gallery at the Arsenal, in Central Park at Fifth Ave- nue and 64th Street.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: TV: 'LOVE, SIDNEY'
description: THE first episode of ''Love, Sidney'' begins with a tearful reunion and ends with another tearful reunion, but it's possible that all this sentimentality is just a way of getting the show on the road. The situation for this comedy series, which is billed as ''warmhearted,'' takes a good deal of setting up (even though the fulllength television movie ''Sidney Schorr'' helped launch the series several weeks ago). ''Love, Sidney,'' which hits its stride only in the latter half of this promising and well-played premiere episode, will be shown tonight at 9:30 P.M. on NBC-TV.

title: Fargo Fraud Trial Opens
description: Harold R. Smith, the boxing promoter, went on trial today charged with plotting to defraud the Wells Fargo Bank of $21.3 million that vanished from a bank branch early this year. Questioning of 100 prospective jurors began in the courtroom of Federal District Judge Consuelo B. Marshall.

title: RIGHTS FOUNDATION HONORS 2
description: The Appeal of Conscience Foundation gave its annual Man of Conscience awards yesterday to Robert O. Anderson, chairman of the board of Atlantic Richfield, and Brooke Astor, president of the Vincent Astor Foundation.

title: AMPCO-PITTSBURGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bill Approved to Lease Stadium to U.S.T.A.
description: The Assembly today approved a bill that would allow New York City to lease the Louis Armstrong Tennis Stadium to the United States Tennis Association.

title: BERKLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
PERINI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $1.4 million gain on the sale of investment; yr-ago results have been restated

title: UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $72,000 for the qr and $206,000 for the 9 mos; shr earnings reflect 10 percent stock divd paid in 1981

title: MANY IN SENATE WORRY ABOUT ANTI-SEMITISM
description: Several Democratic and Republican senators said today that latent anti-Semitism was being stirred by the disputes surrounding the proposed sale of Awacs radar planes to Saudi Arabia.

title: FRANCE IS SENDING ARMS TO BOLSTER CHAD'S PRESIDENT AGAINST LIBYANS
description: France has begun to provide military assistance to the Government of Chad - installed with Libyan help last year - to counter a feared Libyan attempt to destabilize or overthrow it.

title: MALLINCKRODT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed May 26, 1981

title: PENNZOIL ECONOMIST WINS AS FORECASTER
description: James L. Pate, the 46-year-old vice president and treasurer of the Pennzoil Company, may be the hottest economic forecaster of all. At least he will get an award and $5,000 today for his forecasts of the gross national product and inflation rate from 1978 through 1980.

title: TEXTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $5.4 million for the qr and $5.9 million for the 9 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.3 million for the qr and $4.1 million for the 9 mos

title: U.S. COURT EXTENDS EDITORIAL RIGHTS TO PUBLIC TV
description: A Federal appeals court in Birmingham, Ala., has ruled that public-television stations have the same freedom as private stations to decide what shows to broadcast.

title: Jersey Bond Yields at Records
description: A new issue of New Jersey bonds, rated triple-A, was offered yesterday with record yields peaking at 12.7 percent for bonds due in 2000-01.

title: FILM: ANTHROPOLOGISTS FOCUS ON TRIBAL PATRIARCH IN KENYA
description: A DOZEN Ugandan tribesmen are hunkered down in the shade, taking a break from their labors, and what do you suppose they're talking about? Cars! One of them has been for a ride in a car, and he insists that he saw it drive right up to another car and pass it! Just like one gazelle passing another gazelle! Just like that!

title: Salman Rushdie Wins Booker Prize for Novel
description: Salman Rushdie, author of ''Midnight's Children,'' about India, has received the 1981 Booker Prize for the best novel of the year.

title: BARBARALEE DIAMONSTEIN, A WRITER, WED
description: Barbaralee Diamonstein, a television writer, interviewer and producer, and Carl Spielvogel, chairman and chief executive officer of Backer & Spielvogel Inc., a New York advertising agency, were married yesterday in the Beth El Chapel of Temple Emanu-El. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Ronald Sobel.

title: ABC Up 14.8% In 3d Quarter
description: American Broadcasting Companies Inc. said yesterday that its thirdquarter profit was 14.8 percent higher than a year earlier but added that its earnings were moderated by development costs related to its video enterprises and motion pictures divisions.

title: YUGOSLAVS' HOME CURE: NEW DOSE OF DEMOCRACY
description: Despite economic hardships, troubles with the country's large Albanian minority and the uncertainties of the international situation, the Yugoslav leadership is planning to proceed with further democratization and decentralization of power.

title: UNIROYAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $1 million gain for the qr on the purchase of the company's own bonds, foreign exchange losses of $1 million for the qr and $6.7 million for the 9 mos and $5 million tax credit for the 9 mos...C-Includes $8 million gain for the qr on the restructuring of Uniroyal's Texas-U.S. chemical joint venture and foreign currency gains of $1.4 million for the qr and $2.9 million for the 9 mos...D-Net loss

title: No Headline
description: UNBEATEN MONTREAL CRUSHES FLYERS, 11-2

title: New-Venture Aid Defended
description: The Government gets back more in taxes than it pays out for a small-business program, so it should be spared the Reagan Administration's budget ax, an industry group asserted today.

title: High Bail Set In Shipboard Case
description: NEWARK (UPI) - Bail of $1 million each was set for five men arrested on a small fishing trawler loaded with 12 tons of marijuana.

title: Bodies on the Beach
description: There is a lesson in the grim sight of those 33 dead Haitians on a Florida beach. Frank Jean, a weak and bleary-eyed survivor, spelled it out yesterday: ''Deaths will not discourage others. They will take the chance.''

title: Charges Against Peter Fonda Dropped
description: A follow-up: When Peter Fonda saw a sign that said ''Feed Jane Fonda to the Whales'' in a Denver airport last July 24, he had an angry brotherly reaction - he ripped down the offending message.

title: DISPUTE CENTERS TO GET STATE AID IN NEW PROGRAM
description: A new program to siphon off minor criminal matters from the courts and channel them to neighborhood centers where the disputes can be resolved through mediation was announced yesterday by New York State's Chief Judge.

title: EUROPEANS, U.S. AGREE ON TAXES
description: The United States and Europe's Common Market have reached tentative agreement on a major tax conflict that has affected Atlantic economic relations for the last decade, Deputy United States Trade Representative David R. Macdonald reported today.

title: BETZ LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HITLER VICTIMS MEET LIBERATORS AGAIN
description: They met for just a moment more than three decades ago, after the liberation of the Nazi concentration camps in Europe, and today prisoners and liberators met again.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: B-Net income after a $20,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: COURT DECERTIFIES AIR CONTROL UNION
description: A Federal appeals court refused yesterday to grant further delay of a labor agency's ruling that the air traffic controllers' union should be stripped of its status because of the illegal strike that began Aug. 3.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: IN 1948 my wife and I bought our first KitchenAid mixer. I recently acquired a new one, but not because the old one had failed. It had been moved to our summer house, where we now leave it. It is working fine, thank you, and I have a suspicion that it will be bequeathed to the next generation.

title: YOUNG IS ELECTED MAYOR OF ATLANTA
description: Andrew Young, a former United States Representative and chief delegate to the United Nations in the Carter Administration, was elected Mayor tonight, solidly defeating State Representative Sidney Marcus.

title: McEnroe Ousts Sadri
description: Top-seeded John McEnroe beat a fellow American, John Sadri, 6-2, 6-2, today and advanced to the second round of the $300,000 Seiko tournament. McEnroe, who took 55 minutes to win, scored five aces in the first set and six in the second. He will meet Tsuyoshi Fukui, Japan's No. 1 singles player, in the second round Thursday.

title: George H. Chase, 83, Ex-Reserve Board Aide
description: George Howland Chase, former assistant general counsel of the Federal Reserve Board, died Saturday at a nursing home in Bar Harbor, Me., at the age of 83. He lived in Washington and in Prospect Harbor, Me.

title: OLGA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WALDBAUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
THE HIGH COST OF ATTEMPTING TO RID AMERICA OF MEASLES
description: To the Editor:

title: BBDO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign currency translation losses of $211,000 for the qr and $586,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including $13,000 gain for the qr and $39,000 loss for the 9 mos from foreign currency translations; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interests with Duremus & Co which was acquired in 1980

title: Woe Unto the Rams
description: The Los Angeles Rams, who have been struggling with severe injuries to key players all season long, were dealt another blow when they learned that the starting offensive tackle Doug France tore a rotator cuff in Sunday's loss to San Francisco and would be out the rest of the season. France's backup, Irv Pankey, has been suffering from a knee injury and is still unable to play.

title: Maria Moors Cabot Prizes Presented
description: The Maria Moors Cabot Prizes for distinguished contributions to the advancement of inter-American understanding were presented yesterday at a convocation in Low Memorial Library of Columbia University.

title: BREZHNEV, REVIVING MIDEAST PLAN, SUGGESTS A BROADER PARLEY
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, today renewed a proposal for a conference on the Middle East and suggested that it be expanded to include Western Europe, North Africa and South Asia.

title: REAGAN GOES TO VIRGINIA TO AID G.O.P. CANDIDATE
description: President Reagan campaigned in Virginia tonight for the faltering candidacy of state Attorney General Marshall Coleman, the first Republican gubernatorial candidate here to find himself trailing a Democrat in pre-election polls since 1969.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HE new Senate Subcommittee on Security and Terrorism, which drew criticism last spring in airing broad charges that the Soviet Union was responsible for most international terrorism, has taken a noticeably more subdued approach thus far to the violent episode in New York last week when underground radicals were arrested on charges of murder after an armored car robbery.

title: TELEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Helmsley Is Sued In Test on Elderly
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The state filed suit yesterday against one of the metropolitan New York region's largest real estate firms for failing to give eviction protection to elderly and disabled tenants whose apartments are being converted to condominiums.

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Including 1,032,000 net gain from the sale of operating and nonoperating assets...D-Including $225,000 net gain from the repurchase of debentures and $1,984,000 net gain from the sale of nonoperating assets

title: 1. Funny Caps
description: Melissa and Reed Evins, who call their company Two City Kids, design hats. Not serious, hatty hats, but amusing knitted or crocheted caps that are cheery to wear on a cold day. The brother and sister, who are also shoe designers, use hand-spun and hand-dyed yarns for their caps, which are, of course, handmade. They do solid colors or rainbow mixes and then add whatever strikes their fancy: fur tails, tassels, feathers, bells or streamers of leather made like kite tails. The hats are priced from $70 to $162 on the main floor at Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: AN ALBATROSS NAMED UNIVERSAL YOUTH SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED STATES STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes the sale of coal to Standard Oil of Ohio

title: LLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $437,000 extraordinary tax credit...C-Including $343,000 extraordinary credit

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mets Get the Ax
description: Shortly after dropping Mike Mar-shall, the Mets cut their winter roster to 39, one below the limit, in moves that sent another member of the bullpen packing. Dyar Miller, who had a 1-0 record and a 3.29 earned run average this season, was released. Two other pitchers, Dan Boitano and Tom Thurberg, and an outfielder, Sergio Beltre, were sent to the Tidewater farm club. ... Don Robinson, the Pirate pitcher, underwent surgery for removal of a bone fragment in his right shoulder.

title: News Analysis
description: The most significant change that has been evolving in social welfare programs this year is not simply the reduction in Federal financing, but a basic shift in purpose and philosophy, separating the poorest people from the ''working poor'' and middle-income families.

title: Ford Closing Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company's Dutch subsidiary said it will close its Amsterdam truck plant by Nov. 24, laying off 1,200 assembly line workers. The action follows reversal of an injunction granted to Dutch labor unions preventing management from closing the plant as planned on Sept. 30 until a court-ordered investigation of other options was completed. Earlier this year, Ford's Dutch work force had occupied the premises in a two-week protest against management's plans.

title: Witness Describes Point-Shaving Plot
description: Henry Hill, the Government informant who is a key prosecution witness in the case involving charges of point-shaving in Boston College basketball games, testified yesterday about a conspiracy he said was hatched in the summer of 1978 in Pittsburgh.

title: TV: LEE MAJORS PLAYS A STUNT MAN
description: TV weekly series, ''The Fall Guy,'' is being launched tonight at 9 o'clock as a two-hour movie. The hero is Colt Seavers, a veteran Hollywood stunt man, played by Lee Majors, the actor who once made a good deal of money for the same network as ''The Six Million Dollar Man.'' In addition to being co-producer of the series, Mr. Majors gets to sing the ''Unknown Stuntman'' theme. Television is not always ungrateful to its stars.

title: JERRICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago figures were restated for an accounting change

title: ANATOMY OF SPORT
description: Midway through the 37 years of baseball played on television this last month I slipped into deep narcosis and encountered the late Judge Learned Hand. He was not wearing his judicial robes but a baseball uniform, and he was carrying a bat.

title: RENT VOUCHER USE BY POOR FORESEEN
description: The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development said today that the Reagan Administration intended to begin giving rent vouchers to the poor instead of subsidizing more low-income housing.

title: HOUSING SLUMP: THE IMPACT SPREADS
description: The slump in the American home-building industry, the longest since World War II, is cutting deeply across a broad spectrum of the nation's economy, according to housing specialists.

title: NORTHERN TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $16 million gain from sale of investment

title: A SURROGATE MOTHER PROPOSAL
description: A state legislator introduced yesterday what was described as the nation's first proposed law on surrogate parents. It would empower Michigan Probate Courts to handle surrogate adoptions much as they process standard adoptions.

title: WEATHER DELAY ALLOWS NETTLES, CEY EXTRA DAY
description: The weather has given the Yankees something they could not guarantee giving themselves last night - at least a one-day reprieve in the World Series with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Index; International
description: Yugoslavia's home remedy: a new dose of democracy A2 East-West parley in Madrid is reconvened A3 Egypt tries to reassure Israel on the Camp David peace process A7 Son of envoy to U.S. is gunman's target in Salvador A9 Anatomy of one senator's switch in voting on the Awacs sale A12 Security Council fails to agree on a new Secretary General A14 Diana captures Welsh hearts on first tour A14 Government/Politics Consumer activists assail plan to end advertising rule A18 Outside accountants find $1 mil- lion surplus in Yonkers B3 Assembly approves $79.9 million in aid to localities B3 Washington Talk Briefing A20 Two Congressmen live in building that offices are taking over A20 Working profile of Vice President Bush A20 Political risk analysis is burgeon- ing industry A20 General Around the Nation A16 Soggy week in Boston: transpor- tation problems, political feuds A16 After 36 years, Holocaust survi- vors and liberators meet again A24 Hinckley's lawyers urge judge to bar use of some evidence A25 High bail set for 2 Weather Under- ground members B6 News Analysis Hedrick Smith examines effects of Awacs vote A12 Robert Pear examines major shift in social welfare A22 Edward B. Fiske on ruling on New York school financing B3 Living Section Food Specialty food explosion: Where will it end? C1

title: Bridge: U.S. Is Virtually Assured Of Gaining Semifinal Spot
description: The United States was virtually certain to qualify for the semifinals of the world team championships, which went into the final qualifying round tonight. The Americans lead in the Bermuda Bowl event thanks to its big victory over Britain last night.

title: SUNCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1981
description: International More support for the sale of Awacs was annnounced. Eight Senators who previously took no position said they would approve President Reagan's plan to sell the advanced radar craft to Saudi Arabia, and one strong opponent, Senator Roger W. Jepsen, Republican of Iowa, switched to Mr. Reagan's side. The statements raised the strong possibility that the President might win when the Senate votes this afternoon. (Page A1, Column 1.) Latent anti-Semitism is being stirred by the debate surrounding the proposed sale of Awacs radar planes to the Saudis, according to several Senators on both sides of the issue. Some cited a marked increase in anti-Semitic mail and also anti-Semitic remarks they said they heard in recent visits to their states. (A13:1-3.)

title: Grand Trunk Merger Talks
description: The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad Company - the Milwaukee Road -said that is has begun talks with the Grand Trunk Corporation concerning its possible ''integration'' into Grand Trunk's system of railroads.

title: BENJAMIN SCHLEIFER
description: Benjamin Schleifer, a developer who founded Youngtown, the nation's first retirement community, died Sunday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Phoenix.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT OILERS
description: The Islanders overcame a 3-1 deficit tonight to post a 4-3 victory over the Edmonton Oilers at Nassau Coliseum. Wayne Merrick scored the tying and winning goals in the final period.

title: U.S. SCIENCE AID STUDY ASKED
description: A convocation of nearly 100 leaders of American science called on the Reagan Administration today to review the Government's role in supporting research in an effort to prevent further budget cuts from undermining American scientific and technological prowess.

title: Haywood Confident He'll Help Bullets
description: At the age of 19 years, Spencer Haywood was the youngest player on the 1968 United States Olympic basketball team. At 20, he was the youngest player in professional basketball. By the time he was 21, Haywood said, at times, ''I felt like 51.''

title: ACTION ON EL PUT OFF
description: Amid spirited debate over how New York City should protect its architectural heritage, the Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday tentatively rejected plans for a 15-story apartment tower on East 71st Street.

title: SUSPECT IN QUEENS SHOOTOUT SAYS THAT OFFICERS BEAT HIM
description: Nathaniel Burns, a suspect in a shootout in Queens last Friday, charged yesterday that the police repeatedly beat him after his arrest. The police denied his accusation.

title: ZALE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $2.2 million foreign exchange gain for the qr and $1.9 million gain for the qr and 6 mos from a nonrecurring real estate gain...C-Includes $742,000 gain for the qr from discontinued operations and $6.2 million after-tax gain for the 6 mos from the sale of the Light of Peace diamond

title: News Analysis
description: For President Reagan, the crucial Senate vote tomorrow on his proposed arms sale to Saudi Arabia offers an opportunity to revive his leadership image during a difficult time when he has lost the momentum of his Administration's early months.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WILL Patrol Car, as a game, displace Dungeons and Dragons, backgammon and three-card monte in the affections of New Yorkers? The person to thank for the game of Patrol Car is Margaret Loftus Ranald. She is a professor of English at Queens College and a literary historian. A few years ago, being of curious mind, she noted that the license-plate numbers of New York City police cars could be read as historical years. But let her tell it:

title: VERNITRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign currency losses of $395,000 for the qr and $59,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes foreign currency gains of $21,000 for the qr and $5,000 for the 9 mos

title: 9 MORE SENATORS SUPPORT PRESIDENT ON SALE OF AWACS
description: Eight Senators who previously took no position on the sale of Awacs planes and other air combat equipment to Saudi Arabia said today that they would support the sale. Another Senator, an opponent, switched to Mr. Reagan's side.

title: Report Ties the C.I.A.  To Libyan Recruiting
description: ABC News said on its World News Tonight program last night that one potential American recruit for assignment in Libya wrote another possible recruit four years ago that if he was interested in such work, he should send a job resume to a Washington post office box that proved to be rented by the Central Intelligence Agency's Office of Personnel.

title: ASSEMBLY APPROVES AID FOR LOCALITIES
description: Continuing to clean up matters left over from last July's regular session, the Assembly today approved $79.9 million in local aid.

title: PAPERCRAFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3 percent stock divd paid in Mar 1981

title: The Talk of Boston
description: This week got off to a delayed and soggy start in Boston, but it wasn't dull. Hampered for the last few days by a union slowdown, the result of a dispute over work rules, the subway and trolley system failed to work at all yesterday as the morning flow of 260,000 riders was about to start.

title: Sun Earnings Up 7.7%
description: Sun Company Inc., the 12th-largest United States oil company, said today that its third-quarter profits rose 7.7 percent from a year earlier.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WROTE 'THE STORY OF CIVILIZATION'
description: Ariel Durant, who collaborated with her husband Will Durant in the 11-volume series ''The Story of Civilization,'' which included the 1968 Pulitzer Prize-winner for general nonfiction, ''Rousseau and Revolution,'' died Sunday night at her home in Hollywood Hills, Calif. Mrs. Durant had suffered a stroke some time ago. She was 83 years old.

title: The Wounded Come Back Home
description: THE burning question remains: Was either of those miscreants who so foully attacked George M. Steinbrenner III a marshmallow salesman? George III's Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers were back in New York yesterday, with the Dodgers hungering for the one victory they needed to win the baseball championship of North America, but New York weather gave the Yankees a stay of execution. Rain was forecast for last night, the field at Yankee Stadium was soggy, and conditions too miserable for even Bowie Kuhn brought postponement of the sixth World Series game until tonight.

title: Burden Given 6 to 18 Years
description: Luther (Ticky) Burden, who played guard for the Knicks in the 1976-77 season, was sentenced to six to 18 years for masterminding an $18,000 bank robbery in Hempstead, L.I., in July 1980. He had been convicted in August.

title: LEMON STAYS CALM AMID TURBULENCE
description: On the Yankees, the most turbulent team in baseball, one man can be depended upon to crack a timely joke and sail quietly over the most troubled waters. He is the manager, Bob Lemon, and yesterday, after rain forced a postponement of the sixth game of the World Series, he anticipated a question about how he manages to stay so calm.

title: MIDWESTERN DISTRIBUTION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $1,180,000 extraordinary tax benefit from writeoff...C-Net loss

title: A Cooling in the Pits
description: Bobby Unser, the championship-car driver who had to wait five months before being declared the winner of the Indianapolis 500, will drive for Roger Penske from now on only in what Penske called selected races. Unser will be in a Penske car in next year's Indy, and perhaps a few other races, but otherwise will be devoting full time to handling the young Mexican driver Josele Garza.

title: STATE SAYS ITS WORKERS LEAD COUNTRY IN SICK LEAVE TAKEN
description: New York State employees take more sick leave a year than public employees anywhere else in the nation, according to statistics issued today. The state says this makes for ''a lot of three-day weekends,'' and it plans to combat the problem.

title: OAKITE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Analysis
description: The decision this week by an appellate court that the New York State system of financing public education was ''constitutionally defective'' came seven years after the case was originally brought by the town fathers of Levittown, L.I.

title: LORAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERNATIONAL TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
description: B-Net income; results reflect a loss from foreign currency loss equal to $1.41 a shr for the latest third qr and a gain equal to 21 cents a shr from foreign currency translations for the yr-ago third qr

title: NETS EXPECT TO SIGN ALBERT KING TODAY
description: Albert King, the second of the New Jersey Nets' 1980 draft choices, is expected to sign a contract today with the Nets, according to his lawyer, Bill Pollack, and the team's general manager, Bob MacKinnon.

title: HIGH BAIL SET FOR COUPLE ON JERSEY BOMB CHARGE
description: Jeffrey C. Jones and Eleanor Stein Raskin, two fugitive members of the Weather Underground, were ordered held in $150,000 and $100,000 bail today. They were charged with possessing a bomb and other explosive materials in their apartment in Hoboken in August 1979.

title: BASIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $58,000 or 1 cent a shr for the qr and $135,000 or 2 cents a shr for the 9 mos and also $535,00 or 7 cents a shr income for the qr and 9 mos representing administration and interest costs of prior yrs expensed as incurred pending the recent acknowledgement of proper classi- fication as recoverable preproduction costs under the company's oil and gas license agreement in Greece and now recoverable fro production revs

title: Ysaye's Last 6 Sonatas Played by Castleman
description: Eugene Ysaye had a shaky bow arm toward the end of his life, but Charles Castleman, who played the great violinist's six solo sonatas Sunday night in Alice Tully Hall, had no similar problems. He made it seem as if these virtuosic works were elegant instrumental explorations, requiring hardly more effort than a page turn.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard BOSWELL. The Applause of the Jury, 1782- 1785. Edited by Irma S. Lustig and Frederick A. Pottle. Illustrated. 419 pages. McGraw-Hill. $22.95.

title: A Singer's Memory Aid for Lyrics to 1,500 Songs
description: Anyone who has caught Susannah McCorkle off in the corner of a restaurant rifling through her 4- by 6-inch cards might get the idea that the singer has trouble remembering lyrics.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 28, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 3 P.M.

title: OTTER TAIL POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Texaco in Venture
description: Texaco Financial Services Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Texaco Inc., has joined in the formation of a new company that will specialize in brokering time-deposit money market instruments and foreign currencies between corporations and world financial markets. In a joint announcement with its new partner in the venture, Charles Fulton Holdings Ltd., of London, Texaco Financial said that the new company would be named Ful-Tex Euro Services Inc.

title: Q&A
description: I recently dined with friends at Le Cirque and the fish course was served in a light butter sauce that contained among its garnishes a small amount of tiny green, slightly crunchy slivers that I could not analyze, never having tasted them before.

title: PRIVATE CONCERN WILL BUY BUSES FOR M.T.A. USE
description: A private corporation has agreed to purchase buses and rail cars from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and lease them back to the authority for a fee.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think there's a latent anti-Semitism in this country, and my mail has shown a definite increase.

title: Text of U.S. letter, page B5.
description: The reapportionment of New York City Council districts was rejected yesterday by the United States Justice Department on the ground that it ''does not fairly reflect minority voting strength.''

title: Veterans Day Proclaimed
description: President Reagan, in a proclamation issued today, set aside Nov. 11 as Veterans Day in memory of the men and women ''who served to protect our freedom.''

title: EGYPT ATTEMPTING TO REASSURE ISRAEL
description: In a series of minor agreements and major expressions of good will, Egypt has made recent efforts to reassure Israel on the continuation of the Camp David peace process.

title: TIMMS MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED STATES GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. STEEL OPERATING NET SOARS
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, reported yesterday that operating profits for the third quarter more than quadrupled, compared with the period last year.

title: Red Norvo Will Play At Highlights in Jazz
description: Red Norvo, the vibraharpist, and Tal Farlow the guitarist, will be the featured performers in a Highlights in Jazz concert at the New York University Loeb Student Center on Nov. 12.

title: KNUDSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After income from gain on real estate sales of $862,000 or 32 cents a shr for the latest 9 mos and $887,000 or 33 cents a shr for the yr-ago 9 mos

title: 2 NEW BRINK'S SUSPECTS HELD IN MISSISSIPPI AND MANHATTAN
description: In raids on a rural Mississippi farmhouse and a Manhattan apartment yesterday, Federal agents and the police arrested two new suspects linked to last week's $1.6 million Brink's robbery in Rockland County.

title: KEY PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The shr earnings for the 1980 periods adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split paid June 1981

title: PEOPLE
description: * John P. McLaughlin has joined Richardson, Myers, Donofrio Inc., Baltimore, as executive vice president, marketing services.

title: ANGOLA SAYS TROOPS OF SOUTH AFRICA TRY TO CAPTURE A TOWN
description: The Angolan Defense Ministry tonight accused South Africa of launching a new military attack against southern Angola to coincide with the presence of a five-nation Western negotiating team in the Angolan capital.

title: RAQUEL WELCH ON BROADWAY
description: Raquel Welch has been signed as Lauren Bacall's vacation replacement in ''Woman of the Year'' at the Palace Theater. Miss Welch, who will be making her Broadway debut, will star in the musical Dec. 1-13, for 16 performances.

title: Ooops! Wrong Move
description: The Toronto Argonauts, one of the Canadian Football League's most fumble-prone teams, may have fumbled away their starting quarterback, Condredge Holloway. The team's president, Ralph Sazio, said that, through a typing error, his office had mistakenly placed Holloway on the injury list instead of the reserve list.

title: POP LIFE
description: THE history of rock-and-roll is essentially a rags-to-riches story. The music of poor whites and poor blacks merged in the mid-50's to become the most popular music in America. Performers from poor or middle-class backgrounds have risen to undreamed-of pinnacles of stardom and earned substantial fortunes through rock-and-roll, from Elvis Presley, who was living with his parents in Federally subsidized housing in Memphis when he made his first record, to Rod Stewart, who grew up in working-class North London, the son of a Scottish-born construction worker. Mr. Stewart, who is now 36 years old, supported himself as a street singer and gravedigger before becoming one of the most popular and distinctive rock singers of the 70's.
