He now lives as a tax exile from Britain in the exclusive Holmby Hills area of Los Angeles, where his neighbors have included Gregory Peck and Burt Reynolds.

title: POWER AND INSECURITY: THE JAPANESE PARADOX
description: RestonTOKYO - It's not too hard to get a tip here on why Japan is getting on in the economic world. All you have to do is watch somebody fix a car or mop a floor. They pay attention to every detail, as if they were surgeons.

title: HINCKLEY LAWYERS SEEK TO BAR DATA
description: Attorneys for John W. Hinckley Jr., who is accused of shooting President Reagan and three other men last March 30, urged Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker today to bar use of evidence obtained through what they said were violations of Mr. Hinckley's constitutional rights.

title: SENATE VOTES INTERIOR DEPT. BILL EXCEEDING NEW REAGAN BUDGET GOAL
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The Senate today approved a $7.6 billion spending bill for the Department of the Interior and related agencies that exceeds President Reagan's latest round of budget cuts.

title: SOVIET BACKING GAVE KEKKONEN ROOM TO FINESSE
description: The announcement that 81-year-old President Urho Kekkonen of Finland has resigned for reasons of health brings to an end a presidency that has lasted more than 25 of the nation's 64 years of independence.

title: Southern Railway Net
description: The Southern Railway Company reported record earnings today for both the third quarter and the first nine months of the year.

title: AMSTED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WARNER BROS. MAKING CHANGES AT THE TOP
description: Frank Wells, the last of the senior management triumvirate that ran Warner Bros. Inc., the motion picture unit of Warner Communications Inc., for about a decade, will take a much less active role at the company on Jan. 1. At that time, the two men at the top of Warner Bros., which is based in Burbank, Calif., will be Robert Daly, 43, chairman and chief executive officer, and Terry Semel, 38, president and chief operating officer.

title: IN IRAN, A NEW CHOICE FOR PREMIER
description: Iran's Foreign Minister was nominated today as the President's second choice for Prime Minister. Parliament, which rejected the President's first choice last week, was asked to endorse Hojatolislam Hossein Musavi for the position. Neither Mr. Musavi nor the President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, was present in Parliament today when the letter asking for approval of the latest nominee was read to the legislators, a Government spokesman said in a telephone interview.

title: Barbara Cadranel Plays Scarlatti on Harpsichord
description: If anyone wanted to know whether Domenico Scarlatti's harpsichord sonatas have, by themselves, the variety and substance to hold our interest for an hour and a half, Barbara Cadranel's recital at the Abraham Goodman House Monday evening seemed to answer yes. Scarlatti's imagination was absolutely fearless, and his wild-eyed dissonances, startling shifts of mood and his Italianate reenactments of Spanish street scenes - with their beating drums, blaring horns and acerbic guitars - all reflect a musical raconteur whose constant companionship rarely bores.

title: Salvadoran Commandos Raid Rebel Region
description: Salvadoran commandos trained by United States Special Forces advisers swept into eastern El Salvador today in what the Government said was the year's largest army drive against leftist rebels.

title: Harvester Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc., said that it was reducing its rating on International Harvester Company debt to Caa from B. Moody's said that it was lowering Harvester's rating because of extreme weakness in the company's major markets.

title: Earnings Rise At Top Brewer
description: Anheuser-Busch Companies, the nation's largest brewer, reported today that earnings for the third quarter jumped 26.9 percent, to a record $71.8 million, or $1.57 a share, from $56.6 million, or $1.25, a year earlier.

title: SO YOU'RE CLOSING THE SUMMER HOUSE?
description: IT is, as the poet said, the season of mists and mellow fruitfulness, but that's not all. Autumn is also the season of the first sniffle, of checking last winter's coat for buttons and of that melancholy process known as closing the summer house for the winter.

title: ISRAELI SAYS U.S. IS SECRETLY SUPPLYING ARMS TO IRAQ
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon accused the United States today of secretly supplying heavy weapons to Iraq. He said shipments of artillery pieces and ammunition had been sent to the Iraqis ''for months and months now'' through Jordan and Saudi Arabia.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our house is built on a concrete slab and has vinyl tiles cemented directly to the concrete. During the summer months the tile ''sweats'' so much that actual puddles of water accumulate on the floor. We would like to cover the tile with carpeting, but don't know what to do to prevent the moisture from damaging the new carpet. Can you suggest anything? - A.F.H., Sherman, Conn.

title: STANDEX INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIELDCREST MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1980 9 mos results increased by $1,967,000 or 52 cents a shr as a result of an accounting change

title: Dutch to Grant Independence To Caribbean Island of Aruba
description: The Dutch Government and the colonial administration of the Netherlands Antilles have reached provisional agreement on independence for Aruba, Prime Minister Andries van Agt said today.

title: Winifred Wolfe, Wrote About Career Women
description: Winifred Wolfe, author of ''Ask Any Girl,'' ''If a Man Answers'' and other novels about career women in New York, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. Miss Wolfe, who was 53 years old, had been under treatment for stomach cancer since February.

title: CENTRAL PARK WILL GET FEWER BUT BRIGHTER LIGHTS
description: Central Park is getting new lights -more than 1,000 metal halide ones -that will be placed atop existing cast-iron lampposts. These posts were designed in 1910 by Henry Bacon, the architect of the Lincoln Memorial, and have been reproduced in parks all over the country.

title: BLAIR, JOHN, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OFFSHORE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FREEDOM SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (TAMPA, FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
description: B-Net income...No per share figure for the year-ago 9 months net income was provided since Freedom Savings & Loan only converted to a public stock association in May 1980. Results reflect early withdrawal penalties of $1,789,927 and $2,640,722 for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively and $118,252 and $2,250,870 for the year-ago quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Advertising; Lessons In Keeping It Simple T- ODAY'S advertising lesson is this: When your product's consumer benefit can be displayed with a simple demonstration, use a simple demonstration.
description: Here is a classic case in point: the Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn spot for Du Pont's Zerex self-sealing antifreeze that took so many advertising awards back in 1970.

title: EARLY OPEC PRICE ACCORD PREDICTED
description: After months of dissension, oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gathered at a tightly guarded hotel here today and predicted they will quickly agree on a unified pricing structure.

title: LTV Extends Tender Offer
description: The LTV Corporation said yesterday that it would extend its $450 million tender offer for the Grumman Corporation until the United States Court of Appeals ruled on its appeal of a preliminary injunction that has blocked the proposed takeover of the Long Island military equipment manufacturer.

title: AIRBORNE FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $2,647,000 net gain on the sale of Assets... C-After $120,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: TIMKEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A STUDY OF CUTS IS BUDGET-CUT VICTIM
description: Winning lucrative Federal contracts and grants for project research, consultation and program management has become a growth industry in this town in recent years.

title: AM Announces Sale of Infortext
description: AM International Inc. said that it had sold its Infortext operation to Infortext Systems Inc., a new company consisting of current Infortext managers and the MorAmerica Capital Corporation, a venture capital company.

title: PARIS BARS UNITS' SALE ABROAD
description: The Government today forbade French companies and residents to sell shares in the foreign subsidaries of the banks and industrial groups that it plans to nationalize.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press published yesterday erroneously de- scribed a bill passed by the House of Representatives on funds for sewage plants. The bill authorizes $2.4 billion for one year. It also bans sewage dis- charges into the ocean for one year.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PRIZE OF $50,000 OFFERED FOR AN ORCHID HYBRID
description: The American Orchid Society will award a $50,000 cash prize to the first individual or team of plant scientists who creates an artificial orchid hybrid.

title: PHILADELPHIANS HAIL TEACHERS' RETURN
description: Tired but surprised Philadelphians breathed a collective sigh of relief today as the city's 50-day school strike ended.

title: TECHNICOLOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
HOME BEAT
description: THE creme de la creme of the New York design scene came to what they knew was their homecoming party last week, at Knoll International's showroom. They came to celebrate the publication of ''Knoll Design,'' written by Eric Larrabee and designed by Massimo Vignelli (Harry N. Abrams, $65), and to see Florence Knoll Bassett, above, known as Shu, who founded the company with her late husband, Hans Knoll.

title: CETEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $197,000 income from discontinued operations

title: FARR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: The 1980 shr earnings adjusted for a 20 percent stock divd in Sept 1980

title: KERR-MCGEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BLOCK OUTLINES PLANS TO SHIFT SOIL PROTECTION ROLE TO STATES
description: Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block today disclosed an outline for a new soil conservation plan that would shift more responsibility for protecting crop land to the states and would provide modest Federal block grants to assist them.

title: BRADFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $2,933,000 or 73 cents a shr nonrecurring gain for the qr and 9 mos from the sale of realty option and $2,488,000 charge for the 9 mos for equipment lease obligations

title: KORCHNOI SHUNNING PREGAME STRATEGY IN MATCH
description: The most difficult facet of the world championship chess match to fathom is the failure of the challenger, Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, to play the moves that he and his seconds had agreed on beforehand.

title: TEXAS EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOEING NET OFF 33.8% IN QUARTER
description: The Boeing Company reported yesterday a 33.8 percent decline in third-quarter profits, to $92.5 million, or 96 cents a share, from $139.8 million, or $1.45, in the third quarter of 1980. Sales for the quarter were $2.2 million, the same as last year.

title: The City; Courier Shot At Queens Bank
description: An armed courier making a bank pickup was shot three times and critically wounded in Queens, the police said. The courier, George Overmeyer, 38 years old, of Ozone Park, was shot outside the Chase Manhattan Bank branch at 97th Street and 101st Avenue in Ozone Park at 4:05 P.M. yesterday.

title: DICOMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $103,000 for the qr and $173,000 for the 9 mos

title: CONTROLLERS OFFER TO RETURN IF U.S. ENDS 'LOCKOUT'
description: The air traffic controllers' union, seeking to improve its case for a reversal of last week's ruling stripping it of its status, said yesterday that it stood ready to end its strike when the Government ''ends its lockout.''

title: BELL CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics Animal; Vegetable; Insulated Duck
description: What's a duck worth? The ones in the supermarket freezer run $7 or $8, ready to roast. On the wing, they can be very pricey indeed.

title: DI GIORGIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $3.1 million gain from the sale of a mobile home park

title: MAURICE S. WORTH
description: Maurice S. Worth, retired vice president of Sandler & Worth Inc., a carpet store chain in New Jersey, died Tuesday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital.

title: BOLT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EDWARD CUMBERBATCH
description: Edward A. Cumberbatch, a journalist who worked for The New York Post, Newsweek magazine and CBS-TV, died on Saturday in Los Angeles as a result of a bullet wound. He was 43 years old.

title: Partial Close At BL Nearer
description: BL Ltd., Britain's ailing state-owned auto maker, came closer to a partial shutdown when its board decided not to submit next year's production program to the Government for approval and additional aid because of a threatened strike.

title: PARKING LOT SETS SCENE OF SKIRMISH
description: Sometimes even Washington, a city with a long history of pampering the powerful, does not have enough privileges and perquisites to go around.

title: Libyan Force Reported On the Move in Chad
description: A French Foreign Ministry source reported that there had been Libyan tank and troop movements in Ndjamena, Chad's capital, today. Government officials here said French soldiers in the neighboring Central African Republic had been placed on alert.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Net loss...The 1981 net includes income from continuing operations of $28 million and a loss from discontinued operations of $1.7 million. The 1980 net includes income from continuing operations of $22.5 million and income from discontinued operations of $370,766 and income from an accounting change of $1.6 million...The 1980 sales are restated for discontinued operations which reduced sales by $8.5 million and the 1980 share earnings have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split.

title: WESTCOAST TRANSMISSION CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Briton Is Acquitted Of Murder in Uganda
description: Robert Astles, a British-born former aide to Idi Amin, was acquitted by Uganda's High Court today of charges that he murdered a 16-year-old fisherman in 1977, but he was sent back to jail to face other possible murder charges.

title: WILLIAMHOUSE-REGENCY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
DREYER'S GRAND ICE CREAM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DELMARVA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LOUISVILLE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Public Questions for New Jersey
description: New Jersey's voters will be asked next week to pass on three bond issues, three constitutional amendments and two referendums. The print is fine, but all merit attention.

title: Lights Go Out For 9 Minutes
description: A power dip that lasted one-tenth of one second knocked out a bank of lights at Yankee Stadium, halting World Series play for nine minutes last night.

title: BETHLEHEM POSTS GAIN IN QUARTER
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel producer, yesterday reported a profit of $76.3 million, or $1.75 a share, in the third quarter, in contrast to a loss of $32.3 million during the comparable period a year earlier. Sales rose 25 percent, to $1.85 billion from $1.48 billion.

title: CHINA CONTINUES TO BAR WALDHEIM RENOMINATION
description: The Security Council failed again today to choose a new Secretary General as China continued to veto Kurt Waldheim's candidacy for a third five-year term.

title: MIDLAND CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Assets represent net assets

title: ASHLAND SURGES
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation, with overseas earnings depressed by the strength of the dollar and by reduced inventory profits, yesterday reported net income of $506 million in the third quarter, a 29.8 percent decline from the $721 million reported in the period last year.

title: G.M. Sets Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation said it was planning to lay off 4,000 of the 4,500 employees at its plant in North Tarrytown and shut down production for one week next month. A plant spokesman said that the Nov.9-Nov.15 shutdown was being called to reduce inventories, the first such shutdown at G.M.'s North Tarrytown plant since 1979.

title: THE RENAISSANCE OF HOME MUSICALES
description: WHEN Judy and Marcus Mello decided a few weeks ago to give a musicale in their home, they didn't know that they would be facing stiff competition from the World Series. Nevertheless, it was standing room only in the living room of the Mellos' West 73d Street duplex apartment late Sunday afternoon, as 50 of their friends came to listen to the Riverside String Quartet.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SALAZAR IS WRONG, TRACK GROUP SAYS
description: The Athletics Congress, sanctioning organization for amateur track and road running in the United States, called Alberto Salazar's criticism of the organization ''unwarranted'' today.

title: ROCK: DYLAN, IN JERSEY, REVISES OLD STANDBYS
description: BOB DYLAN belongs to a select group of artists, including Frank Sinatra, Hank Williams, Ray Charles and Elvis Presley, who have changed our ideas about what it means to be a male pop singer. And at the Brendan T. Byrne Sports Arena on Tuesday, where he performed more than two dozen songs with a six-piece band, Mr. Dylan showed that neither age (he's now 40) nor his much-publicized conversion to bornagain Christianity has altered his essentially iconoclastic temperament. In a program that mixed several of his more recent gospel compositions with many of his best-known songs from the 60's and 70's, Mr. Dylan was alternately thrilling, exasperating and impenetrable, as he delivered drastically revised vocal and instrumental arrangements of some of the most familiar songs of modern times.

title: Sugar Company Allowed To Import West Indians
description: The Labor Department gave the U.S. Sugar Corporation final approval today to import 2,400 West Indians to harvest this season's sugar cane crop, negating the effects of a walkout by Haitian workers who were demanding higher pay.

title: BIG STORES ADD ART TO SHOPPER WARES
description: SOME people may think it very daring for Saks Fifth Avenue to open an art gallery where its bed linen shop used to be, but not Arnold H. Aronson, the store's chairman.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: DRUG CLINIC BUGGING CAUSES SUIT
description: A jury is expected to begin hearing testimony tomorrow in the Federal court trial of a civil suit against two employees of the University of Alabama involved in the bugging of a university-run drug-treatment center.

title: BRIEFING
description: W ITHIN the Reagan Administration, one of the most angry behind-thescenes conflicts, with a heavy ideological overlay, has emerged in the offices of Action, the umbrella agency that oversees Federal volunteer programs.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES B-1 FUNDS BUT TURNS DOWN MX
description: A House subcommittee, in the first test in Congress of President Reagan's major new weapons proposals, today approved money for 100 B-1 bombers but refused any funds for the MX missile.

title: LEPAGE LOATH TO SELL COLDWELL STAKE
description: When Sears, Roebuck & Company takes control of Coldwell Banker & Company, the American retailer is likely to find a big Canadian real estate firm at its side.

title: Old Home Week for Supreme Court Justices
description: It was old home week at the Justice Department yesterday as three United States Supreme Court Justices swore in five new department officials.

title: House Backs Thrift Aid
description: The House today overwhelmingly passed a compromise bill that sets guidelines for mergers and acquisitions to rescue financially troubled thrift institutions. The bill, approved by a vote of 371 to 46, now goes to the Senate, where its future is in doubt.

title: HOUSE REFUSES TO LIFT OUTSIDE INCOME LIMITS
description: The House, forced into a recorded vote, today rejected a proposal that would have eased restrictions on its members' outside earned income.

title: Bert Lance in Texas Chili Business
description: Ruby's Original Beans With Meat and Ruby's Texas Chili are the first products of a new Georgia company in which Bert Lance, the former White House Budget Director, is principal investor, board chairman and best customer.

title: MOBIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign exchange losses of $20 million for the qr and $103 million for the 9 mos, $100 million benefit from LIFO inventory drawdown for the qr...C-Includes $459 million gain in the first qr from the sale of Mobil's interest in Beiridge Oil Co; shr earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split

title: Index; International
description: Soviet reporters in U.S. have problems, too A2 Mrs. Thatcher back to rising criti- cism A3 U.S. to give Burma $30 million in aid A4 Jaruzelski pledges Polish alle- giance in message to Brezhnev A7 Vatican body approves new rules on annulment A8 Waldheim again fails to win re- nomination A9 Namibian parties near accord on independence A11 Saudis bid Arabs stop attacks on Egypt A12 The U.S. is withdrawing the two Awacs planes sent to Egypt A13 Government/Politics G.O.P. expects to raise record funds for 1982 elections A21 Kean and Florio are scrambling for crowds B2 Democratic plan wins in Connect- icut redistricting B2 Albany votes new property-tax assessment system B4 Report recommends changes in juvenile justice system B7 Mary T. title: MONTANA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Roll-Call Vote
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate rejected the resolution of disapproval of the sale of radar surveillance planes and other military equipment to Saudi Arabia. A no vote was a vote in favor of the sale.

title: U.S. PULLING OUT AWACS SENT TO EGYPT 2 WEEKS AGO
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that because of an easing of tensions the United States was withdrawing the two Awacs radar surveillance planes that it sent to Egypt two weeks ago.

title: Yield Cut Seen For 'All Savers'
description: Yields on the one-year tax-exempt savings deposits known as ''All Savers'' certificates are almost certain to decline after today's auction of one-year Treasury bills.

title: Disco Party to Aid Asian Women United
description: Sumi Tonooka, a Japanese-American jazz pianist and composer, and Alex Chin and His Amerasia rock band will perform tomorrow in ''Mellow Yellow Madness,'' a concert and party at New York, New York, a disco at 33 West 52d Street, for the benefit of Asian Women United.

title: Texas Murder Suspect Waives Jury Trial Rights
description: Vickie Daniel waived her rights to a jury trial today, leaving a district judge to decide whether she murdered her husband, Price Daniel Jr., former Speaker of the Texas House of Representatives.

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1981; Companies
description: The Greenwich Savings Bank is in danger of failing, and the F.D.I.C. is trying to match it with a merger partner, banking sources said. Greenwich, the nation's seventh-largest savings bank, holds about 25,000 mortgages and 320,000 deposit accounts. The F.D.I.C. would reimburse deposits of $100,000 or less, both principal and interest, and at least the principal over $100,000. (Page A1.)

title: Wisconsin Club Gets a New Lease on Lies
description: Two years ago, Otis C. Hulett, the founder of the 50-year-old Liars Club of Burlington, Wis., unilaterally shut it down, leaving about 200,000 members around the world nowhere to turn to tell their tall tales.

title: U.S. Imports Of Oil Down
description: The United States imported only 3.3 million barrels of crude a day last week - the smallest amount of foreign oil reaching United States shores since 1975, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: G.&W. AND S.E.C. SIGN AGREEMENT SETTLING SUIT
description: Gulf and Western Industries and the Securities and Exchange Commission today settled the agency's highly publicized lawsuit that had charged the company and two of its top officers with wide-ranging ''fraudulent courses of conduct.''

title: Auto Exports By Japan Fall
description: Despite gains in shipments to the United States, Japan's overall exports of autos in September fell 6.4 percent, to 484,148 vehicles, from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. The figures included exports of passengers cars, trucks and buses.

title: CAPITOL AIRWAYS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. SET TO RAISE $8.75 BILLION
description: The Treasury announced yesterday plans to raise $3.75 billion of new cash next week when it auctions $8.75 billion of new notes and bonds divided into 3- , 10- and 30-year maturities.

title: DATA CARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-After $1,093,000 foreign currency translation loss... C-Including $382,000 foreign currency translation gain

title: ROBINSON NUGENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW MEXICO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe it will change the military balance somewhat, but I think the Israelis can cope with that.

title: New Vicks Assignment
description: Jordan, Case & McGrath, which already works for the Vicks Health Care division of Richardson-Vicks Inc., has now gotten two unnamed new product assignments from the Vicks Toiletry Products Division.

title: Soviet Woman Retains Her World Chess Title
description: Maya Chiburdanidze, 20 years old, has retained her world women's chess title, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.

title: U.S. TESTS SHOW DRUG BLOCKS SECOND HEART ATTACK
description: The National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute is expected to announce tomorrow that a drug has proved so useful in preventing deaths of heart patients in a nationwide experiment that clinical tests are being cut short.

title: MAPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VICTORY AND ITS BURDEN
description: Winning beats losing, as they say. President Reagan is entitled to exhilaration at his dramatic last-minute victory in the Awacs battle on Capitol Hill. It was a masterpiece of Presidential lobbying.

title: MRS. THATCHER BACK, TO RISING CRITICISM
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has returned to Britain from the conference of rich and poor nations in Mexico to find the dissatisfaction with her economic program stronger than ever.

title: Interpublic Group Has 1.6% Drop in Net
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies released yesterday their thirdquarter financial results, showing a 1.6 percent decline in net income, to $2.19 million, or 47 cents a share, from $2.2 million, or 50 cents, last year.

title: FIRE SETS BACK 'DRESSER'
description: A FIRE broke out in the backstage area of the Brooks Atkinson Theater on West 47th Street yesterday morning. Performances of Ronald Harwood's London hit, ''The Dresser,'' were suspended for one to two weeks. The play, starring Tom Courtenay and Paul Rogers, had begun previews Oct. 15 and was to open Nov. 5. No new dates were announced.

title: Chinese to See Reagan
description: Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China will meet with President Reagan on Friday for talks expected to include the subject of arms sales to Peking, the State Department said today.

title: INDIANAPOLIS WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split to be paid in Nov; yr-ago results have been restated to include operations of Memodyne Corp acquired Sept 30, 1981 on a pooling of interests basis

title: SAUDIS BID ARABS HALT ATTACK ON EGYPT OVER ITS ISRAEL TIES
description: Saudi Arabia, in an apparent appeal for Arab reconciliation with Egypt, has urged Arab countries to refrain from pressing the new Egyptian President to abrogate the peace treaty with Israel.

title: HUDSON'S BAY OIL & GAS CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NAPCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $9,791,000 gain on sale of operations

title: MILLIONS OF POLES STRIKE FOR AN HOUR IN A PROTEST
description: Millions of Polish workers staged a one-hour general strike today. A spokesman for the Solidarity union in Gdansk, where reports of the effectiveness of the work stoppage were still coming in, pronounced himself ''satisfied'' with the scope of the protest.

title: EX-ADVISOR TO CARTER ASSAILS REAGAN PLAN FOR DOMESTIC SPYING
description: The former Intelligence adviser to the Attorney General in the Carter Administration said today that a proposal for domestic spying by the Central Intelligence Agency was unprecedented in the agency's 35-year history and raised the potential for "a scandal bigger than Watergate."

title: FROM THE ESTATES OF NOBILITY
description: Viscount De L'Isle eyed the reproduction of the Chippendale china cabinet that usually resides at his ancestral estate, Penshurst Place, in Tonbridge, England. ''It's much better than the original,'' he said finally.

title: LEASEWAY TRANSPORTATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CAMPAIGN NOTES: ON JERSEY HUSTINGS, CANDIDATES SCRAMBLING FOR COVERAGE
description: New Jersey, says Thomas H. Kean, the Republican candidate for Governor, is ''in many ways a state the communications revolution has bypassed.''

title: MUSIC: PIANIST IN 23-HOUR 'VEXATIONS'
description: AS part of the ambitious ''Soundings'' exhibition of aural art at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at Purchase, Richard Cameron, a pianist on the university's dance faculty, undertook a complete solo performance of Satie's ''Vexations.'' The performance lasted 23 hours, from Tuesday at 2 P.M. to yesterday at 1 P.M., and it proved a bit more vexing than even Satie might have anticipated.

title: STATE LEGISLATURE APPROVES A NEW PROPERTY-TAX ASSESSMENT SYSTEM
description: The State Legislature tonight approved a new system of property tax assessment for New York State, ending six years of debate.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abraham & Straus has appointed Wilmer Weiss vice president-merchandise presentation.

title: LOUIS P. SILL
description: Louis P. Sill, head of Sill Realties Inc. of Manhattan, died Saturday at New York University Medical Center from injuries suffered in a fall.

title: GRETZKY SCORES TWO GOALS AS OILERS DEFEAT THE RANGERS, 5-3
description: Wayne Gretzky, playing with a severely bruised left leg, couldn't do much to help the Edmonton Oilers or hurt the Rangers for the first 39 minutes at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: The City; Murder Charge In Burglary Death
description: A 25-year-old man was indicted on a charge of second-degree murder in the death of a retired Transit Authority detective who died of a heart attack while thwarting a burglary at his own Bronx home.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT SHRINKS
description: The nation's foreign trade deficit narrowed to $2.6 billion in September from $5.6 billion in August as the lagging United States economy depressed demand for imported goods, Commerce Department officials reported today.

title: WESPERCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONRAIL HAS SECOND GAIN IN NET
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation yesterday reported a thirdquarter profit of $64.9 million, or $2.56 a share, only the second quarter of profitability since Conrail was formed in 1976 by combining six bankrupt railroads.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOME TO MAMA

title: Rare Greek Art in Show At the Boston Museum
description: Greek art from the fourth and third centuries B.C., some of which has never been seen outside Greece, will be on view at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston through Jan. 10. The exhibition will travel to San Francisco, New Orleans and New York, where it will be at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Suspect in Slaying Says He Killed Three Others
description: Within hours after leading lawenforcement officers to the body of a savings and loan association employee he reportedly abducted more than a month ago, Marion A. Pruett, who had been given a new identity under the Federal witness protection program, told reporters today that he killed three other persons and wanted to die for his crimes.

title: CONTINENTAL MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Run, Shoot and Go
description: Darrel Davis, the assistant coach who was the architect of the University of California's much-publicized ''run-and-shoot'' offense, just couldn't make it work, so he has resigned.

title: Brooklyn Union Gas
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company, which serves an estimated 4 million customers in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, reported yesterday that it lost $6.5 million in the fourth quarter of 1981, compared with a loss of $3.2 million in the last quarter of the previous year.

title: MAN GUILTY IN SOVIET EXPORT CASE
description: A 61-year-old man has been found guilty in a plot to ship sophisticated electronic and computer equipment to the Soviet Union.

title: HOLIDAY INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED STATES FIDELITY & GUARANTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALASKA INTERSTATE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $7 million net minority interest charge for the cash flow increase in the account of Virginia International Co special stock

title: Silver Auction Bids Decline
description: Buying interest eased today at the third in a series of auctions offering 1.25 million ounces a week of surplus silver from the country's stockpile.

title: MORAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gains from the sale of capital assets of $118,000 for the qr and $1.1 million for the 9 mos; yr-ago shr earnings restated for 2-for-1 stock split paid Nov 1980

title: LEHIGH PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline

title: South African Court Acquits White in Killing of 14 Blacks
description: Lieut. Johan Verster, a white 29-year-old paratrooper was acquitted today of having murdered 14 blacks, but was found guilty of lesser charges stemming from his involvement in fighting between Zulu clans.

title: TO VOTE 'NO' ON AWACS
description: To the Editor:

title: ASHLAND OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $6.7 million loss from the redeployment of assets... C-Including $8.6 million gain from the redeployment of assets

title: HEAVY LOBBYING TIPS KEY VOTES
description: The Senate voted 52 to 48 today to permit the sale of Awacs planes and other air combat equipment to Saudi Arabia. The action gave President Reagan an important legislative victory when only days ago he seemed to be facing defeat.

title: DODGERS BEAT YANKS, 9-2, TO WIN THE WORLD SERIES
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers, frustrated by the Yankees in 1977 and 1978, achieved their first World Series championship since 1965 by soundly defeating New York, 9-2, last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AT FURNITURE FAIR, PRESENCE OF THE PAST
description: The newest designs being shown at the fall Southern Furniture Market here are easily 200 years old. As home furnishings buyers gathered for the fall market, which ends Friday, the mood was conservative. ''Tried and true'' seemed to be the philosophy, reflected by a raft of reproduction furniture.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Borg-Warner Corp. said that it sold its Kemron Division to Industrial Hygienics Inc., a privately held company that provides laboratory environmental health services. Terms were not disclosed

title: Borg and Gerulaitis Extended in Victories
description: Bjorn Borg, seeded second behind John McEnroe, was extended in beating Ramesh Krishnan of India today, 6-3, 4-6, 6-2, in the first round of the $300,000 Seiko tennis tournament.

title: AMERICAN INDEMNITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Driving Figures Cleared
description: The manslaughter trial involving the death of the Swedish driver Ronnie Peterson at the 1978 Italian Grand Prix ended in Milan yesterday with both defendants found not guilty. The defendants were Riccardo Patrese, the first driver ever tried in Italy for a racing accident, and Giovanni Restelli, racing director for the 1978 event.

title: CITIES SERVICE COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Patriarca Too Ill to Be Tried
description: Raymond L.@S. Patriarca, 73 years old, is too ill to stand trial now on charges of ordering a killing in 1965, Judge Francis M. Kiely of Superior Court ruled today. Mr. Patriarca is accused by law enforcement agencies of being a leader of organized crime. In this case, he is charged with ordering the death of Raymond Curcio, a drug addict who reportedly burglarized the home of a Patriarca brother.

title: President Suffers Cold; Physical Set Tomorrow
description: President Reagan is suffering from a cold, but it will not prevent him from receiving an annual physical examination at Bethesda Naval Medical Center Friday, his doctor said today.

title: MACMILLAN BLOEDEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $30 million gain on the sale of MacMillan Rosthesy Ltd for both periods...C-Net income

title: CALVIN KLEIN: SPRING SUEDES AND CHOICE OF HEMLINES
description: ''YOU have long skirts and short skirts in your collection,'' a spectator said to Calvin Klein after his capsule showing of clothes for spring and summer yesterday. ''How do you explain this?''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Empire Airlines said it filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a public offering of 500,000 shares of its common stock. The shares will be sold by a group of underwriters led by L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: W.B.A. Season in Peril, A Club Owner Warns
description: Only a new major sponsor can save the Women's Basketball League from multimillion-dollar losses that threaten to eliminate plans for a 1981-1982 season, says the principal owner of the New Orleans Pride.

title: U.S. ASSERTS CITY IS IGNORING FOOD STAMP PROGRAM ABUSE
description: A Federal official charged today that there were ''serious failures of management'' in New York City's food stamp program.

title: STELCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...The company is listed on the Montreal and Toront stock exchanges.

title: FORD MOTOR CO OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Danelo, Giants' Calm Kicker
description: When the Giants upset the Atlanta Falcons, 27-24, last Sunday on Joe Danelo's 40-yard field goal in overtime, the 10 other Giants on the field raised their fists in triumph and surrounded their hero. The Giants on the bench rushed out to join the celebration.

title: HOMELESS CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $840,000... C-After a loss of $136,000 from discontinued operations... D-After a loss from discontinued operations of $7.2 million... E-After a gain from discontinued operations of $2.7 million

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
The City; A Premature Baby Saved From Closet
description: An infant girl, born two months prematurely, was found yesterday morning by the police under a pile of clothes in a closet in a Brooklyn apartment, authorities said.

title: CONSERVATORY CREATES A HOUSE FOR MORE
description: SEASONS By SUZANNE SLESIN

title: SULLAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOUTHLAND CORP
CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated for a 3-for-1 stock spli effective June 3

title: Help-Wanted Index Declines
description: A measure of the volume of help-wanted advertisements in large newspapers fell in September to its lowest level since May 1980, when the nation was in a steep but brief recession, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: RCA Video Cuts
description: The RCA Corporation said that it would lay off about 400 of the 4,100 workers at its videodisk and color television manufacturing plant here on Nov.6 because of slumping product demand. RCA said that about 300 employees from videodisk manufacturing and about 100 from color television manufacturing would be furloughed.

title: Jailed West Bank Arab Dies
description: Fayez Tarairah, a 22-year-old West Bank Arab, died last Friday of ''brain hemorrhages and lacerated blood vessels in the heart'' after being detained about three months, according to Palestinian sources. His family said that he had been injured during interrogation. Itzhak Agasi, spokesman for the Interior Ministry, which administers prisons, dismissed the charges as ''nonsense.''

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's startling catch-up victory in the Senate on the arms package for Saudi Arabia will bolster his credibility and influence with the moderate Arab countries and with European governments, though it sharpens his differences at least temporarily with Israel.

title: Pan Am Chief To Sell Stock
description: C. Edward Acker, the newly appointed chairman and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways, told Air Florida that he was planning to sell 350,000 of its common shares in a block transaction. Mr. Acker was Air Florida's chairman before joining Pan Am.

title: Tanzanians Facing Famine
description: Tanzania faces famine by 1982 unless it gets immediate food aid, diplomats and Government officials said today.

title: News Analysis
description: In an unusually candid assessment, David A. Stockman said the other evening that the Administration's drive to balance the Federal budget by 1984 ''is now seriously behind schedule for a hundred little reasons - and no one's particular fault.''

title: U.S. FIGHTS FOREIGN SUBSIDY
description: The United States Government, stepping up its campaign against exports subsidized by its trading partners, today announced an action that could lead to a skirmish over chickens with the European Common Market.

title: STUCK ON ROCHAMBEAU
description: To the Editor:

title: SADAT'S DEATH TURNS SPOTLIGHT TO A SUDANESE WAR OF SORTS
description: There is a war going on in this land where the hot, pale desert peopled by nomads provides an inhospitable and improbable theater of confrontation between East and West.

title: The Tenement Palm
description: An ailanthus tree of 70 years and five stories, at 245 East 36th Street, has been spared death-by-developer, at the order of State Supreme Court Justice Alfred Ascione. That may underwhelm a lot of people, who think of the ailanthus as a weed and nuisance.

title: EDWIN A. TENNANT JR.
description: Edwin A. Tennant Jr., counsel to the New York law firm of Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg & Casey, died Sunday in White Plains Hospital.

title: HANDGUNS PROVIDE LINK IN BRINK'S INVESTIGATION
description: Several of the automatic pistols recovered after last week's Rockland County armored-car robbery and slayings were purchased from gun dealers in Texas, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: The City; Delay in Hiring Firemen Ordered
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered the city to postpone the hiring of 300 new firemen for at least 10 days because of charges that the hiring test discriminated against women. The city said it would appeal the order.

title: UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUNSINGWEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: EXCERPTS FROM TALK BY ROHATYN ON RAISING TAXES TO OFFSET U.S.  CUTBACKS
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, to the Fifth Avenue Association:

title: SOME IDEAL INDOOR BULBS FOR THE WINTER
description: ALTHOUGH practical-minded gardeners are scurrying around now to finish bulb planting before the ground freezes, this may be the year to relax and try something different.

title: FORD POSTS BIG DEFICIT IN QUARTER
description: The Ford Motor Company reported today a loss of $334.5 million for the third quarter of 1981. The loss was slightly larger than analysts had expected but far below its thirdquarter 1980 deficit of $595 million.

title: NAMIBIAN PARTIES APPROACH ACCORD
description: West Africa, Oct. 28 - With South Africa's ostensible blessing, nearly all the political parties in South-West Africa appear ready to subscribe to a Western-sponsored set of ''constitutional principles'' leading to an independence settlement.

title: TV: 2 NBC COMEDIES HAVE PREMIERES
description: TWO new situation comedies are making their debuts on NBC-TV tonight: ''Lewis & Clark'' at 8:30 and ''Gimme a Break'' at 9:30. Gabe Kaplan has had a measure of sitcom success in ''Welcome Back, Kotter,'' playing the high-school teacher overshadowed each week by a group of students that included John Travolta. Now he has ''created'' a series about a Long Island man who buys a saloon in Luckenbach, Tex. Stewart Lewis, played by Mr. Kaplan, discovers that he has to cope with, among other things, a folksy manager named Roscoe Clark, played by an actor named Guich Koock. Thus are titles like ''Lewis & Clark'' concocted.

title: MARY CODD'S VIEWS ON CRIME
description: Mary T. Codd, the Liberal Party candidate for Mayor, was asked by The New York Times for her views on major issues confronting the city. Following is her reply on crime. The views of the other mayoral candidates were published earlier.

title: Bridge: United States Leads Poles In Semifinal Competition
description: After a dramatic conclusion to the qualifying stage of the world championships, in which Britain was eliminated on the last deal last night, semifinal play for the Bermuda Bowl began this afternoon.

title: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EUROPE'S NEW ISOLATION
description: A wave of isolationism is sweeping across Europe. From the rejuvenation of the better-Red-than-dead set in massive parades to the foolish demand by European defense ministers in its stead that the U.S. should offer a ''zero-option'' proposal to remove all long-range theater nuclear missiles before disarmament talks begin, the notion is taking hold that Europe can go it alone.

title: Tranasactions; BASEBALL MONTREAL (NL) - Signed Bill Sattler and Jeff Taylor, minor league pitchers, and sent Chris Smith, infielder, and An- thony Johnson, outfielder, to Wichita of the American Association.; BASKETBALL
description: Named Brian McIntyre as pub- l ic relations director. NETS (NBA) - Signed Albert King, for- w ard, to four-year contract for $1 million.

title: FINE ARTS MUSEUM: A WING GROWS IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON It takes no time to find the architecture in the brand-new $22-million West Wing of the Museum of Fine Arts here - it hits you with a wallop in the form of a high, glass-enclosed galleria that is just beyond the front door. But it takes a bit longer to find the art - as at the East Building of the National Gallery in Washington, the pictures themselves are somewhere off to the side, not quite hidden away but somehow less than conspicuous. It is hard not to think that something else besides merely the display of art was the real purpose behind the design of this museum building.

description: B-Including $62,400 tax credit...C-Including $440,000 credit from a reduction of trust allowance for possible losses and $321,800 tax credit

N.H.L. LOOKING INTO SMITH'S SLASHING OF GRETZKY
description: The National Hockey League said yesterday that it would investigate the slashing of Wayne Gretzky, the virtuoso scorer of the Edmonton Oilers, by Billy Smith, the Islander goalie, in a game at the Nassau Coliseum Tuesday night.

title: FORD MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Senate Unit Approves Koop
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee voted 11 to 5 today to recommend that the Senate confirm President Reagan's nomination of Dr. C. Everett Koop, a pediatric surgeon who is an opponent of abortion, as surgeon general.

title: A MAGIC BLACK BOX ADDS WONERMENT TO MOVIES
description: HOLLYWOOD MOVIEMAKING has always been part magic. It was no accident that George Melies, who had made more than 200 one-minute-long mystical trick films by 1900, was a professional magician.

title: T-BAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Greece Lets Communists Join Patriotic Parades
description: Greece's Socialist Government today allowed Communist-led former World War II resistance groups to take part in commemorative military parades here and around the country. The Government said it took the step to help further its goal of ''uniting the people and the armed forces.''

title: ARVIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DOES THE MOVIE VERSION HELP-OR HURT-A BOOK?
description: WHAT can be getting into these novelists anyway? A month or so ago, in the Sunday Magazine section of this newspaper, John Fowles was worrying out loud about the possible effect that the film version of his novel ''The French Lieutenant's Woman'' would have on the novel itself. He wasn't fretting, you understand, about the fate of the film as a film; he was concerned that the film, whether it turned out well or badly, would somehow and forever overshadow the book he'd written, supersede it, damage it, deface it, or perhaps just take its place in the public mind.

title: G.O.P. FUND GOALS SET FOR '82 RACES
description: National Republican campaign committees expect to raise about $90 million for the 1982 elections, most of it to be aimed at gaining control of the House of Representatives and holding a majority in the Senate, a top national party leader said today.

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DILLON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
BORN-AGAIN DOORKNOBS
description: WHEN replacing vintage doorknobs there are numerous sources to turn to. If you are not a stickler for age, a wide variety of reproductions are available, both copies of old styles and castings from actual old molds. Generally dealers in antique house parts will have old knobs.

title: Ozark Posts a Profit
description: Ozark Air Lines, which lost $623,000 in last year's third quarter, said today that it earned $1.19 million, or 13 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1981. Edward J. Crane, Ozark's president, said the profit was achieved despite a declining economy and scheduling restrictions caused by the air traffic controllers' strike. Operating revenues for the third quarter rose 14.9 percent, to $88 million from $76.6 million.

title: 'BANNED' DONALD WOODS RELISHES APARTHIED FIGHT
description: and so he did by speaking and writing against the racial policies of the Pretoria Government. Several years ago, under the eyes of the security police, he escaped his native land disguised as a priest, with his wife at the wheel of the getaway car, leaving a life and a home behind him.

description: Everett E. Elting, vice president for the Caribbean region of the International Executive Service Corps in Manhattan, died Tuesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

INTERDICTION POLICY DEFENDED
description: An officials of the Reagan Administration today defended its policy of intercepting would-be Haitian immigrants at sea and returning them to Haiti without any administrative or judicial review.

title: RAILROAD STOCKS UP
description: Railroad stocks, after performing indifferently most of this year, posted the best gains of any market group yesterday. Meanwhile, both General Motors and International Business Machines traded at their lowest prices since 1975.

title: POLITICAL RUMORS DANCE AROUND MRS. THURMOND
description: Item: A good share of the Washington establishment, including half the Cabinet, other top Administration officials and several dozen ambassadorial and Congressional couples, turned out tonight to help Nancy Moore Thurmond celebrate her 35th birthday at a surprise party at the home of Douglas and Mary Jo Campbell.

title: Albany Fellowship a Memorial to Roth
description: Few press secretaries have been as highly regarded as Richard J. Roth, who died last week after more than two decades as an adviser and chief spokesman for the Republicans in the New York State Senate.

title: CHILTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TASTE OF THE LAW CLOUDS WINE AUCTION
description: Like sediment in a vintage bottle, legal issues continued yesterday to cloud the question of where and whether rare wines can be auctioned.

title: DAISY WHEEL PRINTER: RACE FOR SALES
description: Each morning, as he enters the circular drive of the Qume Corporation headquarters here, David Lee, the company's president, is reminded of one of the major obstacles to his company's growth: Japanese competition.

title: Msgr. J. J. Przezdziecki Dies; A Pastor in Bloomfield, N.J.
description: Msgr. Joseph J. Przezdziecki, pastor of St. Valentine's Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, N.J., died Oct. 14 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Montclair.

title: Cessna Aircraft
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company said that it had acquired, for an undisclosed price, the United Hydraulics Corporation in order to expand the product line of its Fluid Power Division, company officials said. Cessna's chairman, Russ Meyer, said that United Hydraulics, a unit of the Amerace Corporation, based in Hampton, Iowa, would become a wholly owned subsidiary of Cessna. United Hydraulics has about 200 workers and builds large hydraulic cylinders used in strip mining equipment and by heavy industries.

title: POLAND'S NEW LEADER PLEDGES LOYALTY TO BREZHNEV
description: The Soviet press gave front-page display today to assurances from the new Polish party leader that Poles considered the defense of Communism and of the Soviet alliance their ''highest duty.''

title: PRESIDENT PRAISES SENATE'S ACTION AS STATESMANLIKE AND COURAGEOUS
description: President Reagan said today that he made no political deals to achieve Senate approval of the Awacs sale, which he said would enhance world confidence in the United States as a military ally.

title: WASHINGTON GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dry Dock Savings Elects New Chief
description: Robert H. Steele, the 42-year-old president and chief executive officer of the Norwich Savings Society in Norwich, Conn., and a former United States Congressman, has been elected chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Dry Dock Savings Bank in New York, effective Dec.1.

title: PINKERTON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GULF ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VATICAN PANEL GIVES APPROVAL TO NEW RULES ON ANNULMENTS
description: A Vatican commission approved a new code of universal church law today that substantially adopts the grounds for marriage annulment used in the United States for the last 11 years, according to church officials.

title: DART & KRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INFORMANT TELLS COURT OF POINT-SHAVING
description: Henry Hill, a Government informant, testified yesterday that as a member of a betting syndicate he had warned Rick Kuhn, a reserve player with the Boston College basketball team during the 1978-79 season, that ''you can't play basketball with broken arms.''

title: HERS
description: THE new carriage was woven of wicker; rich brown strands twisted and plaited into rococo curlicues like sea waves. Inside my infant brother lay, a prince, amid satin cushions and hand-crocheted coverlets, each tiny feature softened by the gauze mosquito net covering the buggy. My mother's pride was contagious. As we strolled along the sidewalk together, one of her hands steering the buggy, the other clasped firmly in mine, the tips of my earlobes bloomed with self-conscious pleasure.

title: Sports of the Times; WHY DID LEMON TAKE OUT TOMMY JOHN?
description: IN the shambles of the Yankees' 9-2 loss that enabled the Dodgers to win the World Series last night, the question was asked over and over and over, as it will be asked over and over and over for the next several days, the next several weeks, possibly the next several years - why did the Yankee manager, Bob Lemon, remove Tommy John for a pinch-hitter, Bobby Murcer, with the score at 1-1 and runners on second and first in the fourth inning?

title: TACKLING THE U.S. JARGON JUGGERNAUT
description: In a quiet brick office building overlooking the Georgetown waterfront, one of the boldest challenges to hallowed tradition in the history of this tradition-conscious city is being painstakingly planned and executed.

title: ABC's 'Superadio'
description: ABC Radio Enterprises is promising a multi-million dollar advertising budget to promote its Superadio, a 24-hour-a-day, stereo programming service that will be delivered to stations by satellite. It has named the Marschalk Company, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to do that advertising.

title: AUGUSTA, GA., GETS BLACK MAYOR
description: Ed McIntyre today was elected the first black mayor of this eastern Georgia city. The 49-year-old Mr. McIntyre, a former county commissioner, captured 53.7 percent of all votes, defeating a white businessman, Joe Taylor, 60, by a vote of 7,642 to 6,567.

title: 3 HAPPY DODGERS FORGET THEIR PROBLEMS
description: The dizzy spells that had convinced Ron Cey to take himself out of the game did not seem to be such a problem anymore. The New York cold, which had bothered Pedro Guerrero, disappeared last night. And Steve Yeager's season on the Los Angeles Dodger bench, a year of bitterness, was sweet at the finish.

title: Syrian Fighters Intercept French Jumbo Jetliner
description: Syrian Air Force fighters intercepted an Air France jumbo jetliner today after it strayed off course over Lebanon's Bekaa Valley, where Syrian antiaircraft missile batteries are stationed, an official source said.

title: SOUNDESIGN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign currency losses of $505,000 for the quarter and $875,000 for the 9 months...C-Net loss.

title: YOUNG INHERITING A TROUBLED ATLANTA
description: Andrew Young, the former Congressman and delegate to the United Nations, who has weathered civil rights conflict and international controversy, now faces the challenge of running the government of a major city in a time of financial shortfalls and expanding problems.

title: Technology; Innovations in Photography
description: SOME technology developments help companies find market niches that allow them, in a sense, to expand through the walls that competitors have erected around them. Other, more innovative developments allow companies to simply crumble those walls. Competitors are then forced to rebuild them elsewhere, in essence recognizing that the basic nature of the market has been transformed.

title: Through the Windshield
description: ''It's all over,'' Ralph Nader remarked the other day on learning that the Reagan Administration had abandoned an automatic seat belt requirement for new cars. He was referring to a proposal that would save thousands of lives each year in auto accidents, and he's probably right. Federal officials insist they are exploring alternatives. But such ''nonregulatory'' approaches offer little hope of keeping people from smashing into dashboards and windshields.

title: STAGE: 'BRONTOSAURUS,' GAS AND SPARK PLUGS
description: IN Schuyler Bishop's ''Brontosaurus Rex,'' Angelo Settembrini runs his small-town service station in traditional fashion. The customer is always right; profits are less important than good will. However, business is dwindling. Enter a vice president for the parent oil company, vowing foreclosure. Although the man is boyish, we recognize him immediately. He is Simon Legree in a business suit.

title: VESTRY BACKS SKYSCRAPER AT ST. BARTHOLOMEW
description: The leaders of St. Bartholomew's Church have tentatively accepted a plan to build a 59-story office tower finished with glass or highly polished stone next to - and partly above - the landmark Episcopal church on Park Avenue, according to officials familiar with the project.

title: No Headline
description: Harold R. Smith, a former boxing promoter charged with conspiring to embezzle $21.3 million from the Wells Fargo Bank, awaited completion of a jury today. His co-defendant is Sammie Marshall, a former bank loan officer.

title: PENNSYLVANIA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Shape of New York's Shame
description: What's five miles long, half a mile wide and helps white candidates? It's a racial gerrymander that takes the shape of the 24th New York City Council District in Brooklyn - and it is forbidden by the

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 29, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Decolonizaiton Committee - 10:30 A.M.

title: A SPLIT SOVIET IMAGE ON NUCLEAR WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: THE U.S. AND QADDAFI
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, sitting in his book-lined office, thoughtfully sniffs a sprig of mint, then emphatically reiterates several points. He and the Libyan people are ready to fight against the United States, he says, because they believe that it is preparing war against Libya. He denies that he is the aggressor, as Washington claims, and calls the many accusations made against him lies. He emphasizes that he would like to open a dialogue with American leaders, to establish normal, peaceful relations.

title: EXHIBITIONS OF GLASS ABOUND IN NEW YORK
description: Manhattan will offer a feast of stain and blown glass, starting tomorrow and continuing through Nov. 30. Through the efforts of Lili Lihn of the Glassmasters Guild and Sally Helfman and Philip Girard of the Donnell Library, Mayor Koch has declared November Glass Month again.

title: A JOYOUS LASORDA SALUTES HIS TEAM
description: Tommy Lasorda, dripping champagne and emotion, paaked the dozens mf telegrams into a cardboard box, tucked the picture of St. Jude into his pocket, shook hands with George Steinbrenner, hugged Burt Hooton of his Dodeers and Lou Piniella of the Yankees, kissed his bpother Harry and his cousin Vince, and shmuted himself hoarse in Yankee Stadium last night.

title: EMONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Improper Payments Tied To Black Lung Program
description: Up to $18 million in improper payments for black lung disease have been sent for an average of nearly seven years to dead or divorced wives of disabled coal miners, Social Security Commissioner John A. Svahn said today.

title: INTERTHERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Pan Am to Increase Service to Florida
description: Pan American World Airways, the carrier that sparked a price war on the lucrative South Florida to New York route, said today that it would triple its service between Florida and the Northeast in time for the winter tourist season.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Eddie Johnson, the guard whose psychiatric problems kept him out of the Atlanta Hawks' preseason practice, said he was prepared for the possibility that he would be dropped from the squad today, the deadline for pro basketball teams to reach the 12-player limit. Coach Kevin Loughery says Johnson has not been able to work himself into condition to play. ... Bill Walton has been ordered to answer questions about his alleged use of cocaine or else face dismissal of his $5.6 million suit against doctors who treated his broken foot when Walton was with the Portland Trail Blazers ... F. Eugene Dixon, former owner of the Philadelphia 76ers, has joined a group of investors whose purchase of the Philadelphia Phillies from Ruly Carpenter is expected to be announced this week. The group is headed by Bill Giles, the Phillies' executive vice president.

title: L.I. Jury Votes No Bill In Fatal Sinking of Boat
description: A Suffolk County grand jury that investigated the sinking of a 36-foot cabin cruiser in Long Island Sound last Aug. 9 did not indict the owner of the pleasure boat or the crew of the tugboat that is suspected of having collided with her. Five persons died in the accident.

title: COUNCIL WILL REDRAW LINES IN RESPONSE TO U.S. RULING
description: The City Council decided yesterday to redraw its proposed redistricting lines instead of challenging a Justice Department ruling that called the proposed lines unfair to minority groups.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN LETTER TO BAKER ON AWACS
description: Following are excerpts from a letter sent today by President Reagan to Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader. A copy of the letter was circulated among members of Congress.

title: U.S. DIPLOMATS IN CUBA DISSENT ON RADIO PLAN
description: The United States diplomatic mission in Havana has objected to a Reagan Administration plan to set up a radio service modeled on Radio Free Europe to beam broadcasts to Cuba.

title: WEAK SAFEGUARDS IN NORTHERN IRELAND'S TRIAL WITHOUT JURY
description: To the Editor:

title: PENN CENTRAL, COLT VOTE TODAY
description: Stockholders of the Penn Central Corporation convene in Tarrytown, N.Y., today to vote on management's proposed agreement to purchase Colt Industries for $1.2 billion.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DECLINE IN STEEL IMPORTS LEAVES 1981 TOTAL HIGH
description: Foreign steel imports declined 21.5 percent last month from August's record level, but still were too high, a trade group reported today.

title: GULF INTERSTATE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $71,000 or 2 cents a share, gain on the disposition of certain aspects...C-Including $1,626,000, or 70 cents a shar gain of the disposition of certain stock held for investment.

title: House Passes Daylight Bill
description: The House voted, 243 to 165, today to extend daylight-saving time by two months. The ''fast'' time would be in effect from the first Sunday in March to the last Sunday in October. The bill was sent to the Senate.

title: EX-GIMBELS MANAGER AND BREEDER OF DOGS
description: Charles H. Werber Jr., retired general manager of Gimbel Brothers Inc. and a noted Long Island dog breeder, died Tuesday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Mr. Werber, who was 81 years old, lived in Manhattan and Great Neck, L.I.

title: SPECIAL CASE AT THE F.T.C.
description: The news from the Federal Trade Commission, which normally deals with weighty issues like antitrust law, involves a company called Cooga Mooga Inc., a skin lotion named Acne Statin, up to 13,000 dissatisfied customers and the prayer life of the singer Pat Boone.

title: CITY OPERA: CLAUDETTE PETERSON'S VIXEN
description: SINGERS who grow up thinking of opera as ''Aida,'' ''Faust'' and ''La Boheme'' must get a jolt when assigned to Janacek's ''The Cunning Little Vixen,'' in which the main character is a fox, and in which a dog, a badger and a frog also figure among the singing principals.

title: Michaels Muzzles Aides
description: Coach Walt Michaels, who recently cut down the time reporters could interview Jet players, has now barred his assistants from being interviewed.

title: QUEENS DISTRICT AGAIN LEADS IN READING
description: A Queens school district where students are perennially the highest achievers in the city once again leads New York City's public school system in reading, according to school ratings released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: Loan for Libya
description: The Libyan Government's new Libyan Arab Foreign Investment Company is raising $200 million through a sevenyear international loan, banking sources said here today. Most of the underwriting banks are Arab. The interest rate will be one-half percentage point above the London interbank rate.

title: NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shrs earnings reflect 20 percent stock divd

title: BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONRAIL (CONSOLIDATED RAIL CORP) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEMOCRATS' DISTRICTING PLAN VOTED FOR CONNECTICUT SEATS IN CONGRESS
description: A reapportionment plan for the next decade that makes subtle changes in Connecticut's six Congressional districts was approved tonight by a 5-to-4 vote of a nine-member special commission.

HEAVY
description: SOVIET SHIP AGROUND IN SWEDEN: A diesel-powered submarine resting in shallow waters 300 miles south of Stockholm, near a secret Swedish naval base. The vessel's captain blamed ''faulty radar and bad weather'' for his plight but the Swedish Government dismissed that explanation as ''unacceptable.'' Just getting that far into Swedish waters called for expert navigation, officials pointed out, demanding an explanation.

title: New Top Officers at Helm Of Two Sugar Companies
description: John B. Bunker, 54 years old, resigned yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the Holly Sugar Corporation in Colorado Springs to become president and chief executive officer of the California and Hawaiian Sugar Company of San Francisco, effective Nov. 2. He was succeeded at Holly by Ben H. Slothower, 55, who recently resigned from the Kennecott Corporation as an evaluation engineer.

description: Directors of the Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company and industrial concern, yesterday declared a cash dividend of 75 cents a share for the fourth quarter, unchanged from the amount paid in the third quarter.

title: Emery Buys Jets
description: Emery Air Freight, an overnight air freight service, said it had purchased five Boeing 727-100 series planes at an undisclosed price as part of a program to expand its lift capacity.

title: THE STAGE: 'ROUTE 1 & 9'
description: WHAT do Thornton Wilder and Pigmeat Markham have in common? Absolutely nothing, except to the members of the Wooster Group, the resident experimental company at the Performing Garage. The Wooster Group's latest performance piece, ''Route 1 & 9 (The Last Act),'' directed by Elizabeth LeCompte, is designed as a commentary on the play ''Our Town.'' However, it stops in the middle for a raucous and unfunny ''reconstruction'' of a Pigmeat Markham comedy routine, which in context - or rather, out of context with the rest of the evening - is as pointless as it is predictable.

title: REPUBLICANS SEIZE INITIATIVE IN OKLAHOMA SCANDELS
description: The Republican National Committee is trying to turn a kickback scandal affecting most of Oklahoma's 77 counties into a ''golden opportunity'' for party growth, by putting $100,000 into an effort to elect more Republicans to the once-obscure posts of county commissioner.

title: STEIN-DINKINS QUARREL ON BIAS ERUPTS ON A RADIO TALK SHOW
description: A testy argument over accusations of racism and anti-Semitism broke out between two candidates for Manhattan Borough President in a radio studio yesterday.

title: COAL-LOADING CHANGES END SHIPPING JAM
description: Thomas Rappold, manager of the Norfolk & Western Railway Company's coal pier, stood on the deck of the Mineral Alegria and watched with satisfaction as wide conveyor belts dumped 49,604 tons of coal into the ship's cavernous holds.

title: HARRY HOCH
description: Harry Hoch, a pitcher with the Philadelphia Phillies in 1908 and the St.Louis Browns in 1914 and 1915, died yesterday at the Convalescent Center after a long illness. He was 94 years old. Hoch, who won two games and lost seven in the majors, is survived by two sons, four brothers and two grandchildren.

title: NEW COMEX STRUCTURE
description: The Commodity Exchange Inc., the largest commodity exchange in New York, yesterday adopted the two-man, salaried top executive structure that is now common on most of the nation's securities exchanges.

description: The problem with starting at the top of the ladder is that you miss some exciting rungs along the way. That, at least, seems to be the message of Michael Laughlin, a longtime movie producer who has just made his debut as a director and screenwriter.

description: The midweek assault against the officiating in the National Football League is on again. Coach Ed Biles of the Houston Oilers has filed a grievance with the league over a penalty in last Monday's game, which the Oilers lost to the Pittsburgh Steelers.

description: After he twice failed the Nets' physical because of his injured right knee, and after more than five weeks of often-pointed accusations from both sides in the negotiations, Albert King today was signed to a four-year, $1 million contract.

title: U.S. GIVING BURMA $30 MILLION, THE FIRST SUCH AID SINCE 1966
description: The United States Government announced today that it had signed a $30 million economic assistance agreement with Burma.

title: STAGE: YIDDISH 'ROUMANIAN WEDDING'
description: THERE are weddings and there are weddings but if you really like a wedding, you'll want to invite yourself to ''The Roumanian Wedding,'' the completely refurbished Yiddish revival now carousing at Town Hall. Mary Soreanu,its star, is a beautiful bride, and there's a score that will keep you humming along all through the ceremonies and the attendant ancient but amusing plot.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO SEEK BANK MERGER TO SAVE GREENWICH SAVINGS
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is seeking a merger partner for the Greenwich Savings Bank, which is in danger of failing because of persistent losses, according to banking sources.

title: Market Place; Fund Manages Without Stock
description: JUDGING from performance records, money managers have been heavily committed to stocks during the current bear market. The average equity fund followed by Arthur Lipper & Company, which monitors mutual fund performance, fell 4.24 percent between Jan.1 and Oct.22 this year - with all distributions presumed reinvested.

title: LAST SCENE OF THE DRAMA: A FOREGONE CONCLUSION
description: Lobbyists milled nervously outside the Senate floor, aides waited anxiously in the corridors. But there was a sense of calm in the Senate itself today.

title: VOTE NO ON PRISONS
description: Common sense, historical experience, and fiscal reality all argue for the defeat of Proposition 1, the $500 million prison-construction bond issue that New York voters are asked to authorize next Tuesday.

title: CAPITAL'S NEW DESIGN CENTER
description: WASHINGTON IT was not exactly a ground-breaking ceremony, for there was no shovel. It was more a ''design breakthrough'' ceremony Tuesday as Mayor Marion Barry Jr. of the District of Columbia and Thomas V. King, general manager of Chicago's Merchandise Mart, symbolically christened the site of the $35 million Design Center in downtown Washington by bisecting an enormous tissue-paper T-square.

title: GREECE, CYPRUS, AMERICA
description: There was a time when Greece seemed friendly to the Sixth Fleet and when Andreas Papandreou appeared to be a noisy economics professor. But that time is definitively over. What is disappointing is that many observers continue to apply old criteria to a wholly different setting.

title: COURT ACTION HALTED IN ALABAMA U. SUIT ON BUGGING OF CLINIC
description: Court proceedings were abruptly halted this morning shortly after two University of Alabama employees went on trial in a civil suit in which they are accused of installing electronic eavesdropping devices in the campus drug clinic.

title: LEADING INDICATORS DECLINE 2.7%, GIVING NEW EVIDENCE OF RECESSION
description: The Government index that is intended to forecast upturns and downturns in the economy fell 2.7 percent in September, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Retiree Is Appointed President of Wurlitzer
description: At the end of last month, George B. Howell took mandatory retirement from the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation at the age of 62. Now he is back in business, as president and chief operating officer of the Wurlitzer Company, an organ and piano manufacturer based in Dekalb, Ill.

description: The Bank of America said today it would act as agent for eight banks, including four in Japan, that will lend $135 million to Chile's electric utility, Empresa Nacional de Electricidad.
