title: Warren L. Smith, 75, Ex-Head Of Refinery-Building Concern
description: Warren Lister Smith, retired president of an international refinery planning and construction company, died Wednesday at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 75 years old and a resident of Philadelphia after having previously maintained homes in New York City and Camden, S.C.

title: MAIN WESTCHESTER ELECTIONS EXPECTED TO BE CLOSE RACE
description: This year's election contests in Westchester County have rarely been closer or more important, in the view of many political observers.

title: PETITION-SIGNERS IN MINNEAPOLIS GET RENT CONTROL ONTO BALLOT
description: Hard hit by rising prices and rents, a group of citizens organized and collected a petition to put a proposal for rent control before voters in the city elections to be held here next Tuesday.

title: AGM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Alleghany to Close Trucking Unit
description: The Alleghany Corporation, a diversified services company with interests in transportation, insurance, mortgage banking and pension management, said that it would shut its General Commodities trucking unit because of an unfavorable union ruling.

title: NIELSEN, A C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
O'NEILL SAID TO BAR PENSIONS HEARING
description: Two Congressmen accused Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. today of refusing to allow a House subcommittee to hold a hearing that could have increased pressure for more extensive Congressional action on the financing of Social Security.

title: GANG IN HOLDUP IN NANUET TIED TO BRONX THEFT
description: Law enforcement officials said last night that evidence had been uncovered supporting earlier suspicions that the gang of Black Liberation Army and Weather Underground members accused of the Brink's armored-car robbery in Rockland County last week was also responsible for an earlier Brink's robbery and slaying in the Bronx.

title: PRESIDENT ASSURES ISRAEL OF SUPPORT AFTER AWACS VOTE
description: President Reagan followed up his victory on the sale of Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia by telling Israel that the United States is ''fully committed'' to helping Israel retain ''its military and technological edge'' over the Arabs.

title: HEAD OF NASSAU COLLEGE AMONG 5 INDICTED ON CHARGES OF CORRUPTION
description: The president and the executive vice president of the Nassau County Community College were arrested today on indictments charging them with grand larceny, conspiracy and official misconduct.

title: Knicks Open Against Nets
description: The Knicks and Nets, who split two exhibition meetings, open the season tonight at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. With an advance sale of more than 15,000 for the first of the three games there between the cross-river rivals, the Byrne arena could reach its seating capacity of 20,149.

title: VOLCKER URGES EMERGENCY BANK POWERS
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that Congress should act urgently to provide emergency merger and capital infusion powers to Federal bank regulators to help them deal with problems of the distressed thrift industry.

title: Source of Geothermal Steam Found in an Oregon Volcano
description: An extremely hot source of geothermal steam discovered beneath Oregon's Newberry volcano holds promise for generating electricity, the United States Geological Survey says.

title: Costa Rican Plants
description: The United States Alcohol Corporation will build two fuel alcohol distilleries in Costa Rica, the company's president, William Tragert, said here. He said the project was valued at $36 million and will have an annual capacity of 13.2 million gallons.

title: 'HALOWEEN II' FOR FRIGHT FANS
description: ALL those long, dark corridors. And all those empty - or are they empty? - rooms. Not to mention all those wicked-looking medical instruments. ''Halloween II'' is set in a hospital at night, on the precise night when the original ''Halloween'' left off. The bodies are being counted. The killer is still at large. And the heroine, Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis), has been whisked off for medical treatment at the local hospital, where she is given a sedative and put to bed. And left in her room. All alone.

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE Modern Jazz Quartet and the composer-pianist Thelonious Monk have profoundly affected modern jazz, and while their approaches are very different, the quartet and Mr. Monk have also been interestingly and inextricably linked. As luck would have it, the Modern Jazz Quartet, disbanded in 1974, but reunited recently for a concert tour, is performing at Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 8, while on Sunday at 3 and 7:30 P.M., there will be two concerts featuring some of the most devoted and knowledgeable interpreters of Thelonious Monk's music. The Monk concerts, two entirely different programs, take place at Columbia University's Wollman Auditorium.

description: Consumer prices in the European Economic Community rose by an annual rate of 12.4 percent in September, the community's statistics office reported today. The figure compared with an annual inflation rate of 12.2 percent in August and 12 percent in July.

When the plane carrying the 1981 World Series champions touched earth shortly after 6 A.M. today, he dipped into his picnic basket, pulled out a Budweiser, shook it and sprayed a geyser of suds six feet high.

title: CHICAGO BANK PRIME CUT TO 17 1/2%
description: The prime lending rate was lowered one-half percentage point, to 17 1/2 percent, yesterday by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the nation's seventh-largest commercial bank, but no other major bank followed its lead.

title: United Air Names A New President
description: James J. Hartigan, 57 years old, has been elected president of United Airlines, the nation's largest airline. He succeeds Percy A. Wood, 61, who was named vice chairman of the Chicago-based carrier, a post he will hold until his retirement next April. Richard J. Ferris, 45, continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the airline, as well as president and chief executive of its parent company, UAL Inc.

title: Ford Credit Co. Gains
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, said that its third-quarter net income rose to $48.1 million from $47.9 million in the comparable period in 1980. The unit said that the latest results included a profit maintenance payment of $13.3 million from its parent. Automotive retail contract purchases in the quarter rose by 14.3 percent, to 251,200, the company said.

title: KEAN ASSAILS FLORIO FOR STATEMENT ON USE OF JERSEY CASINO REVENUE
description: The Republican candidate for Governor, Thomas H. Kean, assailed his Democratic opponent today for trying to back off from a statement that implied he might continue to use casino tax revenues to balance the state budget.

title: SRURNING EUROPE
description: That 52-48 Senate victory in the Awacs fight was another demonstration of Ronald Reagan's clout in Congressional politics, but it didn't give him a coherent foreign policy. For example: when hundreds of thousands of anti-nuclear protesters have just marched in five major European capitals, what sense does it make for the Reagan Administration to insist that these demonstrations will have ''no impact'' on plans to deploy 572 more nuclear missiles in Europe?

title: MUSIC: MOZART CONCERTO IN D MINOR BY PERAHIA
description: EVEN when he is writing his piano concertos - in fact, especially when he is writing his piano concertos - Mozart is a dramatist, an opera composer, an impresario completely at ease in the theater. Last night's performance of his Concerto in D minor (K. 466) by Murray Perahia, with Rafael Kubelik leading the New York Philharmonic, made that facet of Mozart stand out with brilliant clarity. Mr. Perahia and Mr. Kubelik, a deeply sympathetic pair despite their disparity in age and their superficial differences in musical manner, joined in a performance of this most familiar of the late concertos that brought a remarkable freshness and dramatic tension to each phrase and period.

description: The Marschalk Company has been named agency for You panties, a new product introduced a year ago by Formfit Rogers, specialist in undergarments that is owned by Grupo Pliana of Mexico City.

title: Allied Sets Store Plans
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, which now owns more than 92 percent of Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc., will accelerate expansion of Brooks Brothers but suspend expansion of Miller & Rhoads, Thomas M. Macioce, president and chief executive officer, said yesterday.

title: FLORIDA'S PEPPER SUPPORTS FLORIO IN VISIT TO JERSEY
description: The Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, Representative James J. Florio, was helped in his campaigning among the elderly today by 81-year-old Representative Claude Pepper of Florida.

title: ART: HARRY JACKSON RIDES IN WITH HIS BRONCO BUSTERS
description: NEW YORK CITY is going ''country.'' A popular song has been saying so for more than a year and it's no secret that the flaunters of boots and Stetsons around town are as likely to come from Brooklyn as from Texas. But this is not just fallout from the movie ''Urban Cowboy,'' for wranglers and Indians have been at the gates of the Eastern art scene for a long time now. There are months when art journal advertisements feature little but Western work, most of it from dealers in New Mexico, but some of it visible in New York, too.

title: Sports People; Surgery for Wilcox
description: Milt Wilcox, who with Jack Morris and Dan Petry has helped form the nucleus of the Detroit Tiger pitching staff, underwent surgery after injuring his pitching hand during a charity basketball game. Wilcox's right index finger will be in a cast for several weeks, and the Tigers said they did not know whether the injury - a ligament sprain and dislocation of the middle joint - would affect his ability to throw. ... The crowded hall at Baruch College was hushed as Isaac Bashevis Singer, this year's Morton Globus Distinguished Lecturer, spoke about literature and freedom Wednesday night.

title: HEALTH-CHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a tax credit of $25,000 for the qr and $50,000 for the 9 mos

title: TERROR IN FICTION AND FACT
description: ''KILLING AT HELL'S GATE,'' the CBS Saturday Night Movie at 9 tomorrow, begins at a Washington cocktail party where the nation's wheelers and dealers are viewed with surprisingly cynical eyes. When Charles Duke (Robert Urich), a Justice Department lawyer, begins sweet-talking an attractive woman, an aging Senator runs over to whisk her away, snarling, ''Find your own toy, sonny.'' Minutes later, another attractive woman is confessing to Duke, ''I have this attraction for bright young lawyers from the Justice Department that borders on the obsessive.''

title: BALDWIN-UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Price of Five Airplanes
description: How can I convince foreign leaders that I am in command if I cannot sell five airplanes?

title: CHRYSLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ohio Ballet Performing In East Hampton
description: Works choreographed by Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor, Robert Joffrey and Heinz Poll will be performed by the Ohio Ballet, under the direction of Mr. Poll, this weekend at the Guild Hall, 158 Main Street, in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Saving the 'Thrifts'
description: The Greenwich Savings Bank, ninth largest in the country, will be merged out of business in a matter of days. Squeezed by high interest rates, other savings banks and savings and loan associations in New York and elsewhere in the country are almost sure to follow.

title: 'THE DEVIL'S PLAYGROUND'
description: ''YOUNG MEN,'' say the ads for Fred Schepisi's ''The Devil's Playground,'' which opens today at the D.W. Griffith Theater, ''torn between physical desire and religious discipline.''

title: MUSE AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-The company had no revs last yr...C-Net income

title: Around the Nation; 10 at a Carolina College Arrested in Dinner Riot
description: The Mayor lifted a state of emergency today that was imposed when a food fight at a college cafeteria expanded into a riot when students threw furniture.

title: EMOTIONS FLARE IN POINT-SHAVING TRIAL
description: The Federal trial involving charges of point-shaving in Boston College basketball games was enlivened yesterday when a defense attorney requested a mistrial and engaged in a heated exchange with the judge before the request was denied.

title: Piedmont Orders 11 Boeing 737's
description: Piedmont Airlines has ordered 11 Boeing Twinjet 737-200 airliners valued at $155 million, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company said.

title: MCCORMICK OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $2 million gain from retroactive adjustment to the price of gas produced from certian wells; 1980 9 mos covers only a 5 mos period

title: Sports People; McGinnis Plays On
description: George McGinnis, formerly a star with those powerful Philadelphia teams, has decided to pass up the Indiana Pacers' suggestion that he retire but has accepted, he says, his role as a Pacer reserve.

title: Around the World; Jamaica Breaks Relations With Cuban Government
description: Jamaica broke diplomatic relations with Cuba today and ordered the Cuban Embassy here closed within 48 hours.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: TRIALS FOR COUNCIL
description: Partly because of the nature of their work, members of the New York City Council often seem to have about them an air of it's-us-againstthe-world.

title: RAILROADS IN AMERICA ARE NOT DISAPPEARING
description: To the Editor:

title: EL PASO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TELESCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GOLDMAN, SACHS BUYS BIG COMMODITY DEALER
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, one of the world's leading investment banking houses, said yesterday that it had acquired J. Aron & Company, the nation's biggest supplier of green coffee beans to roasters and a major factor in the international precious and base metals trade.

title: MONARCH MACHINE TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $2.4 million tax credit for the qr and 9 mos and $1.5 million gain from the liquidation of a French subsidiary

title: Penn Central Vote Delayed
description: The Penn Central Corporation, faced with counting the votes in a close proxy fight, adjourned until Monday a stockholders' meeting on the company's proposal to acquire Colt Industries for $1.2 billion. Richard Dicker, chairman, said election judges were so far unable to announce the final tally.

title: Italian Paper is Struck
description: Corriere della Sera, a daily owned by the Rizzoli publishing group, did not appear today because of a strike by journalists and printers. The unions are protesting plans by the publishing group to close or sell Corriere d'Informazione, a Milan afternoon paper; the national tabloid L'Occhio, and Il Lavoro of Genoa, as well as a magazine for children, Corriere dei Piccoli.

title: Former Player Is Guilty In Disability Fraud Case
description: Donald F. Wade, a former National Football League player, was convicted of fraud today by a Federal Court jury for claiming pension benefits for ''total disability'' while he was working. Wade, who suffered a broken neck during a practice with the New England Patriots before the 1971 season, had been receiving as much as $2,100 a month in benefits from the league, according to testimony in the four-day trial.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After net foreign currency translation losses of $5.6 million for the qr and $1.1 million for the 9 mos... C-Including net foreign currency translation gain of $1.9 million or 7 cents a shr for the qr and $3.5 million or 12 cents a shr for the 9 mos

title: ANWAR EL-SADAT: A WOULD BE PEACEMAKER'S FATAL MISTAKES
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: RESEARCHERS SAY HEART DRUG MAY SAVE 6,500 LIVES A YEAR

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE SECOND STAGE. By Betty Friedan. 344 pages. Summit. $14.95

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The groundswell of conservatism evidenced by the 1980 election makes this an especially appropriate time to urge upon the courts more principled bases that would diminish judicial activism.'' - Attorney General William French Smith. (A1:1.)

title: NO BUYER FOUND IN SOUTHLAND TALKS
description: The Southland Royalty Company, an oil and gas concern that analysts say is worth nearly $2 billion, said yesterday that recent merger discussions with a number of companies failed to produce an acceptable offer for the company.

title: COST OF TOWER NEAR ST. BART'S WILL BE HIGHER BY $33 MILLION
description: The office tower proposed for a site next to St. Bartholomew's Church would cost at least $33 million more than originally planned because of special efforts to blend it into the site, the building's architect said yesterday.

title: NORTHERN STATES POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BROADWAY
description: REVIVALS are no longer the Broadway staple they were a few seasons ago, but they are still pretty hearty fare. Witness ''My Fair Lady'' at the Uris Theater, where audiences are flocking to see the still debonair Rex Harrison. And ''Camelot,'' which did exceptional business on the road with Richard Harris as King Arthur, is headed for a Nov. 15 opening at the Winter Garden. Now comes word of a revival of ''Oliver,'' the musical based on Dickens's ''Oliver Twist,'' which will go into rehearsal on Dec. 7, begin a crosscountry tour in Boston on Jan. 7, and open on Broadway in the fall of 1982.

title: OPEC MEMBERS UNITE TO FREEZE OIL PRICE AT $34
description: The 13 members of OPEC agreed today on a unified price for crude oil that is expected to push up the retail cost of gasoline and heating oil in the United States by 3 cents or more a gallon.

title: VIOLIN: ONE HOUR WITH RONY ROGOFF
description: The tradition of the two-hour recital has become inviolate in recent years, but Rony Rogoff in Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night offered just under an hour of unaccompanied violin works. And, at least in Bach's Sonata No. 3 in C (BWV 1005), the shorter program seemed to make for more intense concentration.

title: 10TH CHESS GAME DRAWN
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland drew the 10th game of their world championship chess match here tonight with a 32-move antiperformance in the Kurzentrum playing hall.

title: Around the Nation; F.B.I. Says Violent Crime Is Up 5% Over '80 Period
description: The number of violent crimes, including murder, forcible rape and aggravated assault, reported to law enforcement authorities increased 5 percent in the first half of this year over the same period last year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: HEWLETT EXPANDS OFFICE SYSTEMS LINE
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company yesterday made its full entry into the office automation market, announcing a series of new products that it said were aimed at putting a computer terminal on the desk of every office worker.

title: No Headline
description: Text of OPEC Communique

title: RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $7,432,000 extraordinary charge

title: PHILLIES ARE SOLD FOR $30 MILLION
description: The Philadelphia Phillies, purchased 38 years ago for $500,000, were sold yesterday for the record price of $30.175 million, seven months after the owners had claimed disenchantment with the rising costs of baseball's new economics and put the team on the market.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Paris on Monday in- correctly listed speakers who ad- dressed a rally opposing arms in- creases.

title: MONUMENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COALITION IN NAMIBIA APPEARS TO ACCEPT WEST'S GUIDELINES
description: West Africa, Oct. 29 - The multiracial coalition that nominally governs here appeared today to go along with Westernsponsored constitutional guidelines but demanded guarantees that they would be respected both before and after independence.

title: ART: WHITNEY MUSEUM FINALLY SHOWS ITS BEST
description: THE good news at the Whitney Museum of American Art is that the permanent collection is back, and back - apparently - to stay. Not the whole collection, of course. That is reported to number more than 6,000 objects now, and it is probably a mercy that we almost never get to see most of them. But in what is said to be a new ''permanent'' installation in the museum's third-floor galleries - we shall presently explain what is meant by ''permanent'' in this case - we are being shown an important and sizable chunk of the collection. More than 80 of the outstanding paintings and sculptures for which the Whitney Museum is best known are included in this installation - which, by the way, is very likely the best installation the collection has ever been given.

title: No Headline
description: SPAIN PREPARES TO JOIN NATO: King Juan Carlos, left, with his son, Prince Felipe, arriving at a military practice zone near the Mediterranean. Yesterday, the Con-gress of Deputies, the lower house of Parliament, approved a plan to join the Atlantic alliance. The Senate is expected to approve the proposal next month. Page A11.

title: BODIES OF DROWNED HAITIANS TO GO BACK TO ISLAND
description: The local Haitian community wants the 33 immigrants who drowned off Florida's shore to be buried here, but the State Department and the Government of Haiti have decided to bury them on the island they were trying to escape. The decision has deeply upset the Haitians in Miami, and a coroner caught in the middle is beside himself with rage.

title: WESTERN GEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $472,000 for the qr and $980,000 for the 9 mos...C-After $193,000 loss from disposal of discontinued operations

title: OHIO CASUALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXCERPTS FROM ATTORNEY GENERAL'S REMARKS ON PLANS OF JUSTICE DEPARTMENT
description: Following are excerpts from the remarks of Attorney General William French Smith to the Federal Legal Council in Reston, Va., today:

title: PUBLISHING: PAULE MARSHALL'S SUCCESS
description: When Paule Marshall's novel "The Chosen Place, The Timeless People" (Harcourt Brace) was published in 1969, a reviewer in The New York Times called it the best novel to be written by an American black woman and one of the four or five most impressive novels ever written by a black American.

title: Around the World; Protesters in Poland Swell to 400,000
description: Brief strikes took place today in the Baltic port of Szczecin and a number of universities, swelling the ranks of protesters to about 400,000 across Poland.

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $3.7 million extraordinary credit for the qr and 9 mos and $9,197,000 tax credit for the qr

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1981
description: International President Reagan assured Israel in a message to Prime Minister Menachem Begin that the United States was ''fully committed'' to helping Israel retain ''its military and technological edge'' over the Arab countries. After his Senate victory Wednesday on the sale of Awacs radar planes to Saudi Arabia, Mr. Reagan also sent a message to King Khalid urging ''close cooperation'' in seeking ''peace, security and prosperity'' in the Middle East. (Page A1, Column 6.) The ''deep gratitude'' of Saudis was expressed by the Defense Minister of Saudi Arabia. He said ''the Saudi people will undoubtedly never forget'' the approval of the Awacs sale, and he asserted that the planes would help stabilize the Persian Gulf. (A10:2-4.)

title: JOFFREY BALLET: 'TRINITY' GOES ON DESPITE AN INJURY
description: THE Joffrey Ballet's mixed bill on Wednesday night at the City Center began delightfully and ended in an unexpected dramatic manner. The first three ballets, ''Les Patineurs,'' ''Return to the Strange Land'' and ''Pas de Six'' from ''La Vivandiere,'' are among the best anybody would want to see in the company and they were danced without incident.

title: Frenchwoman next door talks of love.
description: SOMETIMES, during the course of a press conference following a movie at the New York Film Festival, a person can develop a cold. Or at least a headache. Listening, for instance, to the woman who attacked Francois Truffaut for ''The Woman Next Door'' on the ground that it wasn't relevant to the 1980's. She said maybe the picture would have been relevant in the 60's.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-Includes $2,524,220 gain on the sale of discontinued operations

title: Stocks Decline; Dow at 832.95
description: Stock prices dropped yesterday after the Commerce Department said that its index of leading economic indicators fell 2.7 percent in September. It was the largest decline of the indicators in 17 months, and it eroded hopes of an imminent rebound in business activity.

title: 'LOOKER,' A SINISTER-COMPUTER THRILLER
description: MICHAEL CRICHTON'S ''Looker,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, is a slick-looking, paranoid nightmare about our society's increasing dependency on computers and the awful things that might happen to us if the people who make computers join forces with the people who decide what we'll see on television. It is Mr. Crichton's promising premise that this evil if cordial entente will soon be ruling the world by sending out subliminal messages hidden in television commercials for everything from hair-sprays to political candidates.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Nicaraguans Hijack Costa Rican Plane

title: Attack by Baron Guy
description: Faced with the imminent nationalization of much of his financial empire, Baron Guy de Rothschild today publicly relinquished his role as a banker and industrialist in a bitter personal statement.

title: Unauthorized TV Broadcasts Are Barred in North Carolina
description: The Federal Communications Commission has shut down a low-power television station in Southern Pines, N.C., that was broadcasting ''adult'' programs from a satellite without a license.

title: LEGISLATURE APPEARS TO REACH COMPROMISE ON WELFARE CUTS
description: Federal fund cuts caught up with the Legislature as it grappled with the Reagan Administration's program of reduced block grants into the early morning today and the Legislature appeared to reach a compromise on how to deal with people dropped from Federal welfare rolls.

title: FALCONBRIDGE NICKEL MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $37.7 million gain on the sale of Canadian Superior Oil shrs; the company is also listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: Money Funds Up $2.5 Billion
description: Assets held by the nation's money market mutual funds increased $2.5 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $169.4 billion, the 22d consecutive weekly increase, the Investment Company Insitute reported yesterday.

title: Pitt, Penn St.  Tied for No.1
description: For the first time since The New York Times began publishing a weekly computer ranking of college football's top teams two seasons ago, there is a tie for first place.

title: A FREE LUNCH? YES, INDEED
description: ''THERE'S no free lunch,'' James C. Miller 3d, the new chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, declared in Washington this week. Mr. Miller was not merely voicing a cliche. He was explaining his strongly held view that the commission should stop trying to protect consumers from defective products and unsubstantiated advertising claims. Such protective efforts, he said, saddle business with costs that are then passed on to consumers.

title: No Headline
description: RED WINGS TROUNCE FLAMES BY 12-4

title: PRICE FRAUD LAID TO TULSA OILMAN
description: In one of the biggest fraud cases ever brought by the United States Government, a Federal grand jury today indicted a Tulsa, Okla., businessman on charges that he had violated price controls on oil that brought him hundreds of millions of dollars and resulted in consumer overcharges estimated at $2 billion to $4 billion.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 30, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Top-Dollar Gretzky
description: The money is really symbolic of appreciation, Wayne Gretzky said, and that's the most important thing. With that statement of principle, Gretzky, the 20-year-old center for the Edmonton Oilers, accepted a new pact - actually renegotiation of the 21-year contract he had signed previously - that everyone agrees makes him the highest-paid player in hockey.

Liberian Ex-Aide Arrested
description: The Former Liberian Justice Minister, Chea Cheapoo, has been arrested near the Ivory Coast border while trying to flee the country and has been charged with theft, Justice Ministry sources reported today. The Justice Ministry ordered his arrest two days ago after he failed to appear for investigation into what was said to be his illegal seizure of equipment of the Liberia Overseas Venture Corporation.

title: OLD MUSIC IS ENJOYING NEW POPULARITY
description: MUSICAL instruments have evolved along paths that would have warmed Charles Darwin's heart. Like living organisms transforming themselves from one page of natural history to the next, man-made musical devices stretch, shrink and wriggle their way from epoch to epoch, either dying from a wrong turn or a false move, or else adapting and moving on.

title: 'DRESSER' PREVIEWS RESUME WEDNESDAY
description: Previews of Ronald Harwood's London hit ''The Dresser,'' which were suspended after a fire broke out backstage Wednesday morning at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, will resume Wednesday evening. The show's opening, previously scheduled for next Thursday, is now set for Nov. 9.

title: VIDEO MISJUDGMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: CINCINNATI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Leivick's 'Shop' Revived
description: Many of the Jewish immigrants who left the shtetls of Eastern Europe at the turn of the century, found themselves working as operators or cutters, pressers or finishers in garment sweatshops on the Lower East Side. ''Shop,'' the 1926 Yiddish play by H. Leivick, about the struggles of these workers, will be revived at the Folksbiene Playhouse, 123 East 55th Street, tomorrow.

title: Around the World; War Uncontainable, According to Study
description: The United States and the Soviet Union would not be able to contain a limited nuclear war in Europe or anywhere else, the International Institute for Strategic Studies reported today.

title: Pamela Mason Ousted From Wool Concern
description: Pamela Mason, the actress and heiress to a wool-manufacturing fortune, and her son, Morgan Mason, a White House aide, have been ousted from the board of Illingworth Morris Company, Britain's largest manufacturer of wool textiles.

title: WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FUND'S CHIEF DEFENDS TIES TO TEAMSTER HEAD
description: The new executive director of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' Central States Pension Fund testified today that his friendship with the union's president, Roy L. Williams, had nothing to do with his selection as head of one of the nation's largest employee benefit plans.

title: Outdoor Fence Art
description: Good fences might have made good neighbors to Robert Frost, but to the sculptor Susannah Hardaway, fences of screen, barbed wire and feather constitute an art exhibition called ''Fences and Gates.'' It will be on view starting Sunday at 10 A.M. on eight outdoor display cases on Eighth Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets.

title: SUDAN BIDS OTHERS TO CUT TIES TO LIBYA
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan renewed a diplomatic campaign today against his archenemy, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya.

title: Briefing
description: W ITH time waning and the equal rights amendment still three states short of final approval, the National Organization for Women is borrowing a tactical page from conservative political fund-raising groups and preaching to the converted. NOW has begun showing television commercials designed for states that have already strongly approved of the measure, aiming to raise $15 million to finance an intensive lobbying campaign directed at six state legislatures before the Federal deadline for passage of the proposed amendment to the Constitution, June 30.

title: TAMPAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes interest income equal to 40 cents a shr and foreign currency loss equal to 40 cents a shr...C-After minority interest of $644,000 and foreign currency gain equal to 8 cents a shr

title: THE NEW CONDOMINIUMS RESEMBLE EARLIER RENTALS
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J. AROUND the country, younger people finding shelter for the first time have traditionally been a leading sales target for the nation's housing producers. These buyers have been among the chief victims of prevailing 17 percent to 18 percent interest rates. Production has accordingly subsided drastically.

title: OGDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STEINBRENNER CALLS FOR NEW DEDICATION
description: Fourteen hours after the Yankees failed in their latest quest for baseball's championship, George Steinbrenner sounded the rallying cry for the next quest: dedication and discipline.

title: SWEDES BAR SOVIET FROM RESCUING SUB
description: Sweden today blocked Soviet efforts to rescue a Soviet submarine that ran aground near a Swedish naval base on Tuesday. The Swedes said Moscow then agreed to let them do the salvaging.

BELCO PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including net income from discontinued operations of $2,312,000 for the qr and $7,496,000 for the 9 mos... C-Including $1,619,000 net income from discontinued operations and $8,793,000 gain on the sale of discontinued operations; shr earnings reflect a 4 percent stock divd to be paid Nov 18, 1981; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect as discon- tinued the company's Israel operations which were sold in 1981 and have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Feb 1981

title: Two new links in a Szechuan empire.
description: TO understand what is going on here, it is necessary to have a few names clearly fixed in mind. Empire Szechuan Gourmet, the grandaddy of this Empire restaurant group, is at 2574 Broadway, at 97th Street on the Upper West Side. Two years ago, it received a one-star rating. A few months ago, Empire Szechuan Columbus opened at 193 Columbus Avenue, between 68th and 69th Street. Shortly after, came the Empire Szechuan Balcony at 381 Third Avenue (between 27th and 28th Street). The chain grows again in a few weeks when the same management opens Empire Szechuan Bleecker in Greenwich Village. Before the paint is dry on the walls of the two newest restaurants, their windows were displaying the review of the original Empire Szechuan Gourmet, sometimes with the date and address, other times without, and a huge blow-up was mounted in the window of the Bleecker Street newcomer at least two months ago, even before construction began.

title: MARSH & MCLENNAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes the activities of C.T. Bowring

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1981; The Economy
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell 2.7 percent in September, providing more evidence that the economy is in a recession, the Commerce Department reported. The decline was the largest since last year's recession. The department's chief economist commented that it is now ''hard to believe one can have rapid growth over the next year.'' (Page A1.)

title: No Headline
description: BACK TO SCHOOL: A University City High School class in Philadelphia yesterday as classes resumed after a 50-day strike by teachers. Officials are now considering cutting the year to 170 days and eliminating all but five holidays. A fourth grader, Juan Lara, said, ''I missed math and gym, but most of all I missed my friends.''

title: Around the Nation; Small Quakes Increasing At Mount St. Helens
description: The frequency of small earthquakes has increased at Mount St. Helens, where scientists predict a nonviolent eruption within nine days, officials said today.

title: MUELLER, PAUL, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CLOSED HEARINGS ORDERED IN RAPE OF NUN
description: News reporters and the public have been barred from preliminary hearings in the cases of two men who have been charged with raping and assaulting a nun in an East Harlem convent.

title: TIDEWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Image of Koch in Shirtsleeves Preserved on Canvas
description: Last spring Mayor Koch was going around telling people he had ''fallen in love'' with a self-portrait of Alice Neel, the 82-yearold painter who got around to acting as her own model only last October.

title: TROUBLED TIMES AT GREENWICH
description: For more than a century, the Greenwich Savings Bank did not care whether its name was pronounced ''green,'' as in the color, or ''gren,'' as in Greenwich Village, where the bank first opened its doors in 1833.

title: Data Access Consent Pact
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Data Access Systems, a New Jersey computer-systems company, with improper accounting procedures and violations of Federal securities law.

title: Ward Losses Up in Quarter To $63 Million
description: Montgomery Ward & Company lost $63 million in the third quarter - its worst period since the Mobil Corporation bought it in 1976 - and one industry analyst said losses would grow during the Christmas selling season.

title: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1980 figures were restated to reflect change in accounting for book returns; 1980 shr earnings adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock divd in May

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Andrea Leand, who upset Andrea Jaeger in the United States Open tennis tournament, plans to turn pro. Miss Leand, a 17-year-old Princeton freshman, said she would complete her college-tournament commitments before making the move next year. ... Don King, the boxing promoter, said Aaron Pryor had signed to defend the World Boxing Association's junior welterweight championship against Dujuan Johnson of Detroit in Cleveland on Nov. 14. ... A spokesman for Joe Frazier said that the former heavyweight champion would fight in his comeback bout against Jumbo Cummings on Dec. 3 in Chicago, Cummings's hometown. Frazier, who hasn't fought in five and a half years, was to have met Monte Masters, but Masters withdrew.

title: THEATER: 'EINSTEIN AND THE POLAR BEAR' AT THE CORT
description: FORGET about Einstein. Forget about the polar bear. Forget, too, about Silas Marner, Vladimir and Estragon, Alexander Pope, D. H. Lawrence, Cervantes, Aeschylus and all the other weighty baggage that's been shoveled on top of the play that opened at the Cort last night. Stripped of its unstoppable name-dropping and other pretensions, Tom Griffin's ''Einstein and the Polar Bear'' is nothing more - and sometimes less - than a typically contrived romantic comedy about two lonely strangers who meet and go bump in the night. By wrapping a frivolous play in so much pseudo-literary gauze, Mr. Griffin reminds one of a high-school student who slips a ''War and Peace'' dust jacket over the trashy novel he's reading in study hall.

title: FOR COLLEGIATE CHORALE'S OPENING NIGHT, A CHORUS WITHIN A CHORUS
description: Departing from its tradition of concerts in Carnegie Hall, the Collegiate Chorale will open its 1981-82 season at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street on Sunday night at 7. Billed as ''a concert of contrasts,'' the program will also introduce an innovation by featuring a chamber chorus drawn from the ranks of the full group.

title: Real-Life Role
description: It has been two days since a robber struck Barbara Stanwyck on the head in her bedroom and fled with $5,000 worth of jewelry. Miss Stanwyck, according to the police account, has apparently played too many tough roles to be trifled with by an intruder.

title: Advertising; Creative Service to Ad Agency
description: AFTER four years of handling ads for clients on a project basis, Jim Durfee/Martin Solow Creative Service has taken the big step up to ad agency and thus the name change to Durfee & Solow Advertising.

title: New Signal From Michaels
description: Coach Walt Michaels of the Jets called an audible today, changing his mind about yesterday's ruling that prohibited assistant coaches from talking to reporters.

title: OXOCO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $192,803 for the qr and $871,346 for the 9 mos...C-Includes extraordinary credits of $206,452 for the qr and $488,122 for the 9 mos

title: BETWEEN THE HOCKEY GAMES 'AIDA' PACKS HARTFORD ARENA
description: A terrified squirrel ran through the opera company backstage at the opening of ''The Largest Indoor Staging of 'Aida' Ever Mounted in the Western Hemisphere.''

title: GREENWICH MERGER SAID TO BE NEAR
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is close to concluding an agreement under which the troubled Greenwich Savings Bank will be acquired by another institution, according to an agency official.

title: A SKELETON KEY TO HALLOWEEN TRICKS AND TREATS
description: WITH a whole weekend to celebrate Halloween this year, the city will be taken over, it seems, by goblins, magicians and a host of mysterious incorporeal phenomena. There will be a parade through Greenwich Village and in Queens a wand-breaking ceremony over the grave of Harry Houdini, master magician and escape artist. The avantgarde will take over the World in Wax Musee at Coney Island for an eight-hour performance tomorrow. Children will have their pick of pumpkin festivals and adults a choice of costume parties. The most ambitious event of all, however, will probably be ''The Ghosts of New York,'' a seven-hour tour sponsored by the 92d Y.

title: COMMONWEALTH TELEPHONE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kissinger in Singapore
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight for a four-day private visit in which he will talk informally with leaders from the five-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

title: LACLEDE STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Current qr and 9 mos includes a net charge of $625,000 for settlement of an anti-trust suit...B-Net loss

title: WHAT UNESCO WANTS TO DO FOR JOURNALISM
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. TO NAME HUMAN RIGHTS AIDE
description: The Administration is planning to announce tomorrow the nomination of an Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, according to State Department officials. The nominee is reported to be Elliott Abrams, a Washington lawyer who is now Assistant Secretary for International Organization Affairs.

title: Atlantic Airline Talks
description: The International Air Transport Association will hold a meeting in Geneva on Dec. 2 to discuss fares on the North Atlantic routes, the association's director general, Knut Hammarskjold, said here today. An association executive said that members had lost more than $650 million this year on the routes. The announcement was made at the end of the association's annual meeting here.

title: ALBERT J. ZACK, EX-PUBLICITY CHIEF FOR MEANY AND THE A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: Albert J. Zack, the public spokesman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the late George Meany for 23 years, died last night at his home in Florida after suffering a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

title: Bridge: Two U.S. Teams Lagging In World Championships
description: Two world team championship finals were in progress here this afternoon, and the United States was trailing in both.

title: JETS HAVE A NOSTALGIC VISITOR
description: He no longer lives in New York and 12 years have passed since he coined the ''braggin' rights to New York'' slogan, but Weeb Ewbank was passing through today and he paid a visit to the Jets, his former team.

title: SPAIN'S PLAN TO ENTER NATO GAINS IN PARLIAMENT
description: After three days of occasionally angry debate, the lower house of the Spanish Parliament tonight approved by a solid majority the Government's proposal to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: A WEB OF MUSIC AND DANCE AS SPUN BY LAURA DEANE
description: Although Laura Dean is certainly a choreographer with an individual style, Miss Dean herself maintains, ''I didn't consciously decide to create a Dean style. But I do happen to be Dean and this is what developed.''

title: I.M.F. PUTS PRESSURE ON BANGLADESH
description: The International Monetary Fund, which has recently come under pressure from the Reagan Administration to tighten its lending policies, has cracked down on one of the poorest countries in the world - Bangladesh.

title: Choices for Prosecutors and Judges
description: New York City voters on Tuesday will decide contests for district attorneys in three boroughs and for judgeships in all five. Some of the races offer compelling choices. Our recommendations to New Yorkers are as follows: DISTRICT ATTORNEY

title: RECESSION HITS BUSY NEBRASKA TOWN
description: This normally prosperous town of 13,000, depending for its well-being on a cluster of small industries and the skilled farmers in this southeastern corner of Nebraska, is already feeling the dual pressures of Federal budget cuts and a recession that began here three months ago.

title: People
description: * Frances Kennedy has been named executive vice president and chairman of the creative review board at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc.

title: Shield Soap Gets J.W.T. Support
description: A full-page ad from J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. faced this column yesterday, and in the memory of Thompson people it was a new ploy for the agency. It congratulated the people at Lever Brothers (the longest J.W.T. client, starting with Lifebuoy in 1902) on the completion of the national rollout of Shield, its new deodorant soap.

title: DOCUTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $39,000 or 1 cent a shr for the qr and $946,000 or 28 cents a shr for the 9 mos

title: Bucks Give An Offer to Dandridge
description: Bobby Dandridge, a forward who played on championship teams with the 1971 Milwaukee Bucks and 1978 Washington Bullets, signed a twoyear offer sheet yesterday to return to the Bucks.

description: B-Includes tax credits of $39,600 for the qr and $53,800 for the 9 mos and extraordinary credits of $3,400 for the qr and $10,200 for the 9 mos...C-Includes tax credits of $83,100 for the qr and $69,000 for the 9 mos and extraordinary gains of $3,700 for the qr and $10,300 for the 9 mos

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AMERICAN DESIGNERS: THE MOOD IS PLAYFUL
description: In a storybook collection filled with pristine white cotton skirts swirling over petticoats, Ralph Lauren brought a sense of long ago and far away to the spring fashion openings. Adri countered with easy, modern separates that hardly touched the body. Halston started off with short knitted dresses with long cardigans to toss over the shoulders and ended with lacy evening clothes that either glimmered with beads or draped snugly around the body. Caroline Simonelli made cheerful styles for the Mollie Parnis Studio - ''simple, not minimal,'' she said -the kind she likes to wear herself.

title: RACE FOR CAROL BELLAMY A PREPARATION FOR FUTURE
description: For Carol Bellamy, next week's election is not so much a contest as a preparation. The 39-year-old New York City Council President has won considerable power in a job so governmentally innocuous that even its title is misleading. Now, as she campaigns for re-election, her support is sought eagerly - and her future political intentions watched warily - by others in the business.

title: REVLON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp. said it would suspend vehicle production at two United States plants for one week next week to balance inventories with slow sales, temporarily idling 6,000 workers at its Kenosha, Wis., and Toledo, Ohio plants.

title: Article 072247 -- No Title
description: Pleasant Colony, the 3-year-old colt who won the Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Woodward this year before a leg injury forced his retirement, has been syndicated for $12 million for breeding purposes.

title: EAGLES-COWBOYS WILL BE TELEVISED HERE
description: Rivalries in the National Football League warm and cool according to the success of the teams involved, and the most fiery confrontation currently is the one between the Dallas Cowboys and the Philadelphia Eagles. It will be renewed in Philadelphia Sunday in a game that will be televised in the New York area (Channel 2, 4 P.M.).

title: PUBLISHER OF BLACK WEEKLY
description: William Otis Walker, publisher for nearly 50 years of The Cleveland Call and Post, a black weekly newspaper, and an influential figure in Ohio politics, died yesterday after suffering a heart attack outside his office in Cleveland. He was 85 years old.

title: Friday; TOWN HALL IRISH NIGHT
description: Tomorrow is the eve of Samhain, the Celtic New Year, and two Irishmusic groups are in town to celebrate a day early. Appearing tonight at 8 at Town Hall will be De Danann, the acclaimed band that combines traditional music with music of its own, and three young performers who specialize in Irish dance music, and airs and traditional songs of Ireland, England and Scotland. They are Dolores Keane, John Faulkner and Eamonn Curran. Tickets are $9.95 and can be purchased at the box office, 123 West 43d Street. Information: 840-2824. COLUMBIA DREAM HOUSES

title: REAGAN AWACS PLEDGES APPEAR TO BE SOFTENING
description: The White House was not as specific today about the pledges given to win acceptance of the Awacs sale to Saudi Arabia as some senators had seemed to believe yesterday.

title: STAGE: SPURLING'S 'MACRUNE'S GUEVARA' AT OFF CENTER
description: IN John Spurling's ''MacRune's Guevara,'' an eccentric Scottish artist, ''the Michelangelo of Primrose Hill,'' covers the walls of his apartment with pictures of his hero, Che Guevara. When MacRune dies, a man named Edward Hotel moves into his quarters and assumes his obsession. Hotel creates a play about ''MacRune's Guevara,'' a deviously prismatic work that views the subject from at least three angles -that of the fictitious author, the artist who was a dedicated Marxist and the historical figure himself.

title: AT YANKEE CLUBHOUSE, PLANS AND PAINS
description: Dave Winfield, carrying an attache case as any fashionable young businessman might, walked into the clubhouse at Yankee Stadium yesterday, his 6-foot-6-inch body tall and straight.

title: Interest Rates in Sharp Drop; 1-Year Bills Yield 13.159%
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday as fears of rising rates and heavy Federal borrowings subsided following Wednesday's announcement of Treasury borrowing plans.

title: TRANSCO COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Judge Refuses to Block Execution of Louisiana Killer
description: Federal District Judge John V. Parker today rejected a plea by the mother of Colin Clark and refused to block the convicted murderer's execution in the electric chair next week.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NORTH CAROLINA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Such Costly Errors
description: Robert Jackson, the Cleveland Browns' linebacker, has a problem. He said that, when he is on the field, ''I don't let anyone mess with me.''

title: PRODUCTIVITY DOWN AT 1.9% YEARLY RATE
description: American business productivity declined at an annual rate of 1.9 percent in the quarter ended Sept. 30, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. It was the worst showing since the first quarter of 1978, when a 2.3 percent annual rate of decline was registered.

title: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LORAL CORP reports earnings for 6 mos to Sept 30
Massey-Ferguson Layoffs Are Set
description: Massey-Ferguson Industries Ltd. announced that because of depressed conditions in the farm machinery industry, it will cut one shift at its Brantford, Ontario, combine plant on Nov. 6, a move that will result in the layoff of about 600 of the plant's 2,800 employes.

title: India in TriBeCa
description: The music of the Bauls of Bengal, a blend of religious and folk idioms, will be performed by Purna Das and his ensemble tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Alternative Museum, at 17 White Street in the TriBeCa section. Mr. Das, a well-known folk singer in India, will also play the khamak and ektara, percussion instruments.

title: 4,000 WOMEN TALK BUSINESS
description: Marie Unsworth Agurcia flew in from Honduras, Bettye Baldwin drove up from King of Prussia, Pa., Susan B. Engel came from the Upper East Side on a No. 3 bus. The three women joined 4,000 other participants, all of whom gathered this week for breakfasts, luncheon meetings and informal evening events, in addition to the more than 70 workshops and seminars that were the heart of a five-day conference held by the Women Business Owners of New York. The event wound up at the Sheraton Centre Hotel last night.

description: B-Adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in Sept 1980

title: Excerpts from speech, page A22.
description: Attorney General William French Smith accused the Federal courts today of ''constitutionally dubious and unwise intrusions upon the legislative domain'' and vowed to oppose such ''subjective judicial policy-making.''

TALKS TO FREE 38 DRAG ON IN PRISON
description: Correction officials and a psychiatrist tried early this morning to negotiate the release of 38 hostages held by four state prisoners, including one who killed two prison officials in 1975.

title: Baseball, Such as It Is
description: THE 1981 baseball championship of North America, such as it is, belongs to the Los Angeles Dodgers. They won it in an untidy World Series following a double round of playoffs following a lacerated season with its heart cut out.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: ENERGY WATCH
description: CRUDE OIL INVENTORIES Crude oil stocks dropped to 362.9 million barrels, down 7 million.

title: Italy-Occidental Joint Venture
description: Italy's state energy group, Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said they have signed a definitive agreement to form a $1 billion joint venture in coal and chemicals.

title: ATHENS BUREAUCRACY CHANGING HANDS
description: Greece's new Socialist Government has moved swiftly to wrest control of the state machinery from what it calls the sympathizers and political clients of the former conservative administration.

title: THE AWACS IMAGE
description: The gap between what other people think about the U.S. and what we seem to think they think has widened substantially in recent months.

CHRYSLER POSTS LOSS IN QUARTER
description: The Chrysler Corporation today reported a loss of $149.3 million for the third quarter -more than the company had predicted earlier this year, but generally in line with present industry expectations.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD PLUNGES
description: Nabisco Brands Inc. reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter increased 14.1 percent, as sales increased 3.6 percent. Nabisco Brands, formed on July 6 by the merger of Nabisco Inc. and Standard Brands Inc., said that net income in the latest three months increased to $71 million, or $1.12 a share, from $62.2 million, or 99 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales rose to $1.45 billion, from $1.4 billion.

title: TRIANGLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW PREMIER OF IRAN IS CONFIRMED
description: Iran announced today that Parliament had confirmed a 39-year-old Islamic fundamentalist layman as the new Prime Minister.

description: B-After $646,000 extraordinary credit...C-Net income

title: UNITED KENO MILL MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EARLY MUSIC: POMERIUM ENSEMBLE
description: If anyone is curious about early music but confused as to which of the many local groups to sample, Pomerium Musices would be a good bet. Not the only bet, to be sure. But for consistent quality, this 10-member vocal ensemble led by Alexander Blachly would be difficult to surpass, both for seriousness of intent and for simple pleasure.

THEATER FRIENDS RECALL LIFE AND WORKS OF ODETS

title: TRI-CHEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place; Chinese Bonds: Is Payoff Near?
description: IN a surprise decision last week, a Federal court in Alabama ruled that China was in default on payments of a bond issue sold in this country and in Europe in 1911.

title: NUCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHALERS AND ISLANDERS TIE, 6-6
description: The trend was set early tonight at the Civic Center: The Islanders scored in the first 24 seconds, and the Hartford Whalers came back with a goal at the 46-second mark.

title: THE WORLDLY WISE WORLD OF KAREN AKERS
description: CAN a 36-year-old woman married to a Washington lawyer and the mother of two young boys also have a successful career as a cabaret singer in New York? That isn't the tag line to a soap opera but the question facing Karen Akers, the critically acclaimed chanteuse who is appearing at Mickey's, 44 West 54th Street, through Nov. 21.

title: FELMONT OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 figures include a $1,978,934 gain from the sale of 50 percent interest in certain offshore leases

title: EGYPT HAILS VOTE, CALLING IT A 'TURNING POINT'
description: Egypt today hailed the vote in the United States Senate to permit the sale of radar planes to Saudi Arabia and described it as a ''turning point'' in American policy.

title: DREYFUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $27,000 for the qr and $334,000 for the 9 mos; shr earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in Feb

title: Magazine Publishing Award Selection
description: The 1981 edition of the Henry Johnson Fisher Award, the most prestigious honor in the magazine publishing business, will be going to Robert A. Burnett, 54, who worked his way up from ad salesman on Better Homes & Gardens to president and chief executive of the Meredith Corporation.

title: PENN VIRGINIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split

title: SOCIALISTS LOOSEN THE KNOTS THAT BIND FRENCH TV
description: The advent of the Socialist Government of Francois Mitterrand has nowhere produced a larger political and psychological displacement than in the tightly held and troubled domain of French radio and television.

title: WATT DROPS A POWER PROJECT THREATENING COLORADO RIVER
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt gave conservationists a victory today by dropping plans for a hydroelectric project that would have affected the flow of the Colorado River through the Grand Canyon.

title: Fieldcrest Executive Is Joining J.P. Stevens
description: After 33 years with Fieldcrest Mills, David M. Tracy, 57, has resigned to join J.P. Stevens & Company next Monday as its senior marketing executive, with the expectation of becoming vice chairman after a board meeting in two weeks.

title: HALL, FRANK B, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1980 figures restated for pooling of interests

title: ART: SPIRITS OF 1700'S HAUNT A SOHO GALLERY
description: WHEN the Swiss painter Angelica Kauffmann was alive - her dates were 1740-1807 - she cut a wide swathe through the distinguished men of the day. No one could resist her. She was quite a good painter, too, and a founding member of the Royal Academy of Arts in London. But charm of the kind that she had in such abundance is not easily communicated to posterity, and even in an age that has upgraded virtually everything that was ever committed to canvas, there are no signs of a Kauffmann revival.

title: A WOMAN TRANSFORMED BY A CAUSE
description: She was, once, a Niagara Falls housewife. She was 25 years old and sometimes she wore a flower in her hair. Her kitchen was always spotless, the baked goods always fresh. She picked up her spending money by baby-sitting for the children in the neighborhood, a modest subdivision that was known locally as Love Canal.

title: OPERA: HARTFORD STAGES 'AIDA'
description: ''Aida'' has been associated since its birth with vast undertakings and vast spaces, not all of them theatrical in the accepted sense. Commissioned by the Khedive of Egypt to celebrate the opening of the Suez Canal and the building of a new opera house in 1869, it has seen performance everywhere, from Cairo to the Baths of Caracalla. As Verdi's most successful transformation of Meyerbeerian grand opera and its scenic formulas into the eloquent, powerful, and thoroughly sympathetic musical language he forged over years of effort, it invites treatment on a lavish scale and is a surefire vehicle to open an opera season.

title: Big art sales next week
description: THE auction season moves into high gear next week with sales of modern and Impressionist art at New York's two top auction galleries. The first sale of the week begins Tuesday at 7 P.M. at Christie's, Park Avenue and 59th Avenue, with 12 paintings from the collection of Charles Tobatschnik, a Toronto builder, whom Christie's lists as ''anonymous private collector.'' The most important of these works are Kees van Dongen's 1908 ''Portrait of Madame Malpel'' and Georges Braque's 1906 ''The Harbor at Antwerp, the Mast,'' each expected to sell for as much as $300,000. Notable, too, are van Dongen's 1905 ''Nude Against Black Background'' (up to $250,000) and Albert Marquet's 1905 ''The Blue Pavilion at St.-Cloud'' (up to $200,000).

title: MARY CODD GIVES HER VIEWS ON MASS TRANSIT
description: Mary T. Codd, the Liberal Party candidate for Mayor, was asked by The New York Times for her views on major issues confronting the city. Following is her reply on transportation. The views of the other mayoral candidates were published earlier.

RUSSIANS LAUNCH MISSION TO VENUS
description: The Soviet Union today launched an unmanned spaceship that is expected to reach Venus in March and apparently attempt a soft landing.

title: RACIAL RELATIONS IN CITY MUCH BETTER, KOCH SAYS
description: Racial tensions in New York City have dissipated, not worsened, in recent years, Mayor Koch said yesterday. Race relations was one of the assigned topics addressed by five of the seven mayoral candidates at a forum sponsored by the City Club, a civic group that focuses on municipal government and politics.

title: WHY IS JOHNNY NOT ALLOWED TO GO TO SCHOOL?
description: To the Editor:

TI-CARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Patents; Parking Meter Alarm
description: WASHINGTON THE inventor of a vandal alarm for parking meters hopes it will save money for municipalities. A radio signal will notify the authorities if a thief opens the coin box, breaks the housing or bends the support pipe.

No Headline
description: Books of The Times Fathers and Sons By ALJEAN HARMETZ MOVING PICTURES. Memories of a Holly- wood Prince. By Budd Schulberg. Illus- trated. 494 pages. Stein & Day. $16.95.

title: Leslie Fay Pact On Takeover Set
description: Leslie Fay Inc., a leading manufacturer of women's dresses and sportswear, announced it had reached an agreement in principle with a group of private investors headed by John J. Pomerantz, Leslie Fay president, and Harold Geneen, the former chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, and certain other members of Fay's management, to acquire the company at a price of $15.50 a share, or $55 million.

title: JOHN COGGESHALL
description: John Coggeshall, a stockbroker and an authority on domestic and foreign gold investments, died Thursday at his farm in Dover Plains, N.Y. He was 70 years old.

title: Saudek Retiring as the Head Of Museum of Broadcasting
description: Robert Saudek, president of the Museum of Broadcasting since its organization in 1975, has announced he will retire from the museum and return to the production of cultural television programs.

title: No Headline
description: A news item in Weekend yesterday incorrectly listed the day for an open rehearsal by Musica Sacra at Central Presbyterian Church. It is today at 9:30 A.M. The actual performance is Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: TEAMSTER LEADER IN DELAWARE GUILTY OF LABOR RACKETEERING
description: The president of the Wilmington teamsters' local, Francis J. Sheeran, was found guilty here today of 11 charges of labor racketeering.

title: NELSON, L B, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including $157,000 credits to income resulting from a change in accounting estimates

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Carlos Reutemann, runner-up for this year's world drivers' championship, has retired from Formula One auto racing after nearly a decade on the circuit. He never won the drivers' title, finishing behind Nelson Piquet of Brazil this year. ... The Dec. 11 boxing card in the Bahamas that will feature Muhammad Ali against Trevor Berbick will include Thomas Hearns fighting as a middleweight in a 10-round bout against Marcos Geraldo.

title: I LOVE MANHATTAN. BUT.
description: I used to be able to afford to live in Manhattan, but now I no longer can. And I have paid a price to live here, given up this and that, compromised, traded off.

title: DOW JUMPS ON HOPE OF RATE DROP
description: Stock prices swept sharply higher yesterday in response to forecasts of easing interest rates by a prominent Wall Street economist and a revival of takeover fever in oil issues.

Brinkley's ABC-TV Program To Begin Morning of Nov. 15
description: David Brinkley, the former NBC newscaster who joined ABC News last September, will appear on ABC-TV Sundays from 11:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. starting Nov. 15 in ''This Week With David Brinkley,'' an interview and analysis program.

title: DAY OF RECKONING FOR TWO YANKEE FANS
description: Declaring that ''not since the Battleship Missouri sailed into Tokyo Bay has there been such a reversal of fortune,'' Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan paid up today on his losing bet on the World Series.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefing
description: T WO of the nation's most conservative Senators, Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, are locked in an unusual conflict over the abortion issue that has irritated the staffs of both Republicans. The Shocking Apology

Seven years I have lived in New York, and nobody has ever apologized for anything. In New York, taxicabs try to run you down while you are crossing the street, and do they apologize? Not in New York, pal. They raise the cab fare.

Fairness Is the Issue
description: Fairness was the only issue. And the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, to its credit, made its decision on that issue. It ruled on Tuesday that the City Council's plan for redrawing its election district lines from 1980 census data ''does not fairly reflect minority voting strength as it currently exists.'' Put simply, the Justice Department was saying that 8 minority seats on a 45-seat Council bears no resemblance to the city's makeup, which is 44 percent black and Hispanic.

title: SAFETY PANEL EASES RULES FOR POWER LAWN MOWERS
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission, following Congressional orders, today voted unanimously, 5 to 0, to accept weakening of its standards governing safety features of power lawn mowers sold after June 1982.

A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MOSCOW'S CHANGING FACE
description: A visit to Moscow after 20 years yields impressions of both progress and stagnation in Soviet life. The line of Russians winding across Red Square, waiting to pass through the Lenin mausoleum at the foot of the Kremlin wall, is familiar. They stand patiently in a cold rain, fur-hatted tourists from Siberia, peasants in black rubber boots, children wearing red Pioneer kerchiefs, some curious, others wanting to render homage to the Soviet messiah.

They included a proposal to assist the state's ailing savings banks, which Governor Carey signed early in the evening. Also approved were changes in taxes passed earlier this year to assist mass transit and a bill authorizing the expenditure of $7.8 billion in Federal funds.

About New York; BELIEF IN GHOST HAUNTS A HISTORIC MANSION
description: Like a Great Dane or a terrace garden, a ghost is hard to maintain in New York. In the suburbs, apparently, neighbors will leave a person alone with his own little piece of psychic manifestation or table-rapping ectoplasm, but in the city it is nothing but a hassle. The bars close, and people with nothing better to do come over, stand outside and throw rocks to try to bring the ghost out. Mediums want to sleep on the sofa bed. Publicity follows, and crowds.

title: EGYPT REPORTS PLOT TO KILL AIDES AT SADAT'S FUNERAL

title: Sports People; Nanne Re-Signed

Nanne, 40, has been general manager since February 1978 when he retired as a player to take over the club's management.

title: News Analysis
description: West Africa, Oct. 30 - Although it remains easy to come up with reasons for pessimism about a settlement in South-West Africa, the excruciatingly slow and wayward diplomatic effort to bring this vast territory to independence looked less moribund this week than at any other time in the last two and a half years. It was even possible to speak of a climate of faint hope. The Western diplomatic mission left Windhoek this afternoon in its American Air Force jet without a definite response from South Africa or the political parties here to the constitutional guidelines it presented this week. But it seemed unlikely that any of the key parties to the dispute over South Africa's continued occupation of a territory it once held on a League of Nations mandate is prepared to see negotiations break down over constitutional questions.

title: TWO-MONTH-OLD SAUDI PEACE PLAN IS GAINING NEW ATTENTION IN U.S.

title: THEATER: 2 LA MAMA REVIVALS
description: ''Clara's Ole Man,'' in revival at La Mama as part of Ellen Stewart's 20th anniversary season, reminds us of Ed Bullins's ebullient humor and his gift for creating vivid, larger-than-life characters. In this case, the character is Big Girl, a bold, brassy, overweight young woman with the presence of a longshoreperson. In common with ''The Fabulous Miss Marie'' and other assertive women who have appeared on Mr. Bullins's stages, Big Girl runs the show. She is ''ole man'' to her petite friend Clara, as is clear to everyone except Jack, Clara's uptight, Ivy Leaguish visitor.
